English: I have half a mind to hit you before you speak again .
Shakespearean: I have a mind to strike thee ere thou speak'st .

English: But if Antony is alive , healthy , friendly with Caesar , and not Caesar's prisoner , I'll shower you with gold and pearls .
Shakespearean: Yet if thou say Antony lives , is well , Or friends with Caesar , or not captive to him , I'll set thee in a shower of gold and hail Rich pearls upon thee .

English: Madam , he's well .
Shakespearean: Madam , he's well .

English: That's well spoken .
Shakespearean: Well said .

English: And he's friendly with Caesar .
Shakespearean: And friends with Caesar .

English: You are an honest man .
Shakespearean: Th' art an honest man .

English: Caesar and he are better friends than ever .
Shakespearean: Caesar and he are greater friends than ever .

English: I'm going to make you a rich man .
Shakespearean: Make thee a fortune from me .

English: But yet , madam , I don't like the sound of "but yet." It reverses all the good that came before it .
Shakespearean: But yet , madam , I do not like "But yet." It does allay The good precedence .

English: Damn those words , "but yet ! " "But yet" is like a jailer about to bring out some horrible criminal .
Shakespearean: Fie upon "But yet." "But yet" is as a jailer to bring forth Some monstrous malefactor .

English: Please , my friend , give me all the news , both good and bad , at the same time .
Shakespearean: Prithee , friend , Pour out the pack of matter to mine ear , The good and bad together .

English: You say he's friendly with Caesar , healthy , and free .
Shakespearean: He's friends with Caesar , In state of health , thou say'st , and , thou say'st , free .

English: I didn't say free , madam .
Shakespearean: Free , madam , no .

English: No , I didn't say that .
Shakespearean: I made no such report .

English: He's bound to Octavia .
Shakespearean: He's bound unto Octavia .

English: For what favor ?
Shakespearean: For what good turn ?

English: For the favor of sleeping in her bed .
Shakespearean: For the best turn i' th' bed .

English: I'm sick , Charmian .
Shakespearean: I am pale , Charmian .

English: He's married to Octavia , madam .
Shakespearean: Madam , he's married to Octavia .

English: May you die of the worst disease !
Shakespearean: The most infectious pestilence upon thee !

English: Good madam , be patient .
Shakespearean: Good madam , patience .

English: What did you say to me ?
Shakespearean: What say you ?

English: Get out , you horrible bastard , or I'll gouge out your eyes .
Shakespearean: Hence , horrible villain , or I'll spurn thine eyes Like balls before me !

English: I'll scalp you .
Shakespearean: I'll unhair thy head !

English: I'll have you whipped with wire and soaked in brine like a pickle , making your pain linger .
Shakespearean: Thou shalt be whipped with wire and stewed in brine , Smarting in ling'ring pickle !

English: If you say it isn't true , I'll give you a province and make you rich .
Shakespearean: Say 'tis not so , a province I will give thee And make thy fortunes proud .

English: The blows I gave you already will make up for your upsetting me .
Shakespearean: The blow thou hadst Shall make thy peace for moving me to rage , And I will boot thee with what gift beside Thy modesty can beg .

English: He's married , madam .
Shakespearean: He's married , madam .

English: Rogue , you've lived too long !
Shakespearean: Rogue , thou hast lived too long .

English: No way , then , I'll run .
Shakespearean: Nay then , I'll run .

English: What's the matter with you , madam ?
Shakespearean: What mean you , madam ?

English: I haven't done anything to you .
Shakespearean: I have made no fault .

English: Good madam , restrain yourself .
Shakespearean: Good madam , keep yourself within yourself .

English: The man hasn't done anything wrong .
Shakespearean: The man is innocent .

English: Even innocents can not always escape disaster .
Shakespearean: Some innocents 'scape not the thunderbolt .

English: May Egypt drown in the Nile and all good creatures turn into poisonous snakes .
Shakespearean: Melt Egypt into Nile , and kindly creatures Turn all to serpents .

English: Call that servant back .
Shakespearean: Call the slave again .

English: Even though I'm mad , I won't bite him .
Shakespearean: Though I am mad , I will not bite him .

English: Call him !
Shakespearean: Call !

English: He's afraid to come in .
Shakespearean: He is afeard to come .

English: I won't hurt him .
Shakespearean: I will not hurt him .

English: My hands are tainted if they hit an inferior , especially since I myself am the cause of my own distress .
Shakespearean: These hands do lack nobility that they strike A meaner than myself , since I myself Have given myself the cause .

English: Come here , sir .
Shakespearean: Come hither , sir .

English: It may be honest , but it's never wise to bring bad news .
Shakespearean: Though it be honest , it is never good To bring bad news .

English: You can give good news in many ways , but let bad news interpret itself as you tell it .
Shakespearean: Give to a gracious message An host of tongues , but let ill tidings tell Themselves when they be felt .

English: I've only done my duty .
Shakespearean: I have done my duty .

English: Is he married ?
Shakespearean: Is he married ?

English: May the gods destroy you !
Shakespearean: The gods confound thee !

English: Do you maintain the same story ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou hold there still ?

English: Do you want me to lie , madam ?
Shakespearean: Should I lie , madam ?

English: Go , get out !
Shakespearean: Go , get thee hence .

English: Even if you were as handsome as I beg your highness' pardon .
Shakespearean: I crave your highness' pardon .

English: Is he really married ?
Shakespearean: He is married ?

English: Please don't be offended that I don't want to offend you any more .
Shakespearean: Take no offense that I would not offend you .

English: It's not fair to punish me for something you make me do .
Shakespearean: To punish me for what you make me do Seems much unequal .

English: He's married to Octavia .
Shakespearean: He's married to Octavia .

English: It's too bad that Antony's fault should make you look like a jerk .
Shakespearean: Oh , that his fault should make a knave of thee , That art not what th' art sure of !

English: Go away .
Shakespearean: Get thee hence .

English: The merchandise you bring from Rome is too expensive for me .
Shakespearean: The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome Are all too dear for me .

English: Let it stay in your inventory until it bankrupts you .
Shakespearean: Lie they upon thy hand And be undone by 'em !

English: Be patient , your highness .
Shakespearean: Good your highness , patience .

English: When I have praised Antony , I've disparaged Caesar .
Shakespearean: In praising Antony , I have dispraised Caesar .

English: Many times , madam .
Shakespearean: Many times , madam .

English: I'm being repaid for that now .
Shakespearean: I am paid for 't now .

English: Help me out of here .
Shakespearean: Lead me from hence .

English: Oh , Iras , Charmian !
Shakespearean: O Iras , Charmian !

English: It doesn't matter .
Shakespearean: Tis no matter. , Go to the fellow , good Alexas .

English: How old is she ?
Shakespearean: Bid him Report the feature of Octavia : her years , Her inclination .

English: Don't let him leave out the color of her hair .
Shakespearean: Let him not leave out The color of her hair .

English: Bring me his answers quickly .
Shakespearean: Bring me word how tall she is .

English: Even though half of him is like a
Shakespearean: Lead me to my chamber .

English: Lord Alexas , sweet Alexas , most anything Alexas , almost the most consummate Alexas , where's the fortuneteller you recommended so highly to the Queen ?
Shakespearean: Lord Alexas , sweet Alexas , most anything Alexas , almost most absolute Alexas , where's the soothsayer that you praised so to th' Queen ?

English: Oh , I only wish I knew the name of that husband you said he predicted will have a cheating wife !
Shakespearean: Oh that I knew this husband , which , you say , must charge his horns with garlands !

English: I don't make fortunes ; I only see them .
Shakespearean: I make not , but foresee .

English: Then see a good one for me .
Shakespearean: Pray , then , foresee me one .

English: No , he means you'll use makeup when you're old .
Shakespearean: No , you shall paint when you are old .

English: May my wrinkles forbid that !
Shakespearean: Wrinkles forbid !

English: Don't joke about his predictions .
Shakespearean: Vex not his prescience .

English: Pay attention .
Shakespearean: Be attentive .

English: Quiet !
Shakespearean: Hush !

English: You will love more than you are loved .
Shakespearean: You shall be more beloving than beloved .

English: It's proper that we speak first , which is why we sent our proposals ahead of us for your consideration .
Shakespearean: Most meet That first we come to words , and therefore have we Our written purposes before us sent , Which , if thou hast considered , let us know If 'twill tie up thy discontented sword And carry back to Sicily much tall youth That else must perish here .

English: Why did Cassius conspire against Caesar ?
Shakespearean: What was 't That moved pale Cassius to conspire ?

English: Take your time .
Shakespearean: Take your time .

English: Pompey , you can not frighten us with your navy .
Shakespearean: Thou canst not fear us , Pompey , with thy sails .

English: We'll meet you at sea .
Shakespearean: We'll speak with thee at sea .

English: Yes , on land you do outnumber me .
Shakespearean: At land , thou know'st How much we do o'ercount thee .

English: Even more since you annexed my father's house and lands .
Shakespearean: At land indeed Thou dost o'ercount me of my father's house , But since the cuckoo builds not for himself , Remain in 't as thou mayst .

English: But since , To get back to the matter at hand , what do you think of our proposal ?
Shakespearean: Be pleased to tell us , For this is from the present , how you take The offers we have sent you .

English: That's the point .
Shakespearean: There's the point .

English: Don't let us talk you into anything , but consider carefully the value of our offers .
Shakespearean: Which do not be entreated to , but weigh What it is worth embraced .

English: You have offered me the lands of Sicily and Sardinia .
Shakespearean: You have made me offer Of Sicily , Sardinia .

English: In return , I must clear the sea of pirates and send tributes of wheat to Rome .
Shakespearean: And I must Rid all the sea of pirates , then , to send Measures of wheat to Rome .

English: If I agree to this , we may leave unharmed , with our shields undented .
Shakespearean: This 'greed upon To part with unhacked edges and bear back Our targes undinted .

English: That's our offer .
Shakespearean: That's our offer .

English: You should know that when I came here I was prepared to accept your offer .
Shakespearean: Know then I came before you here a man prepared To take this offer , but Mark Antony Put me to some impatience .

English: Let me shake your hand .
Shakespearean: Let me have your hand .

English: I didn't think I would see you here .
Shakespearean: I did not think , sir , to have met you here .

English: The East is very seductive .
Shakespearean: The beds i' th' East are soft , and thanks to you , That called me timelier than my purpose hither , For I have gained by 't .

English: Well , I can not tell how my difficult life has weathered my face , but I will never let those difficulties subdue my courage .
Shakespearean: Well , I know not What counts harsh Fortune casts upon my face , But in my bosom shall she never come To make my heart her vassal .

English: It's good we had this meeting .
Shakespearean: Well met here .

English: I hope it works out for the best , Lepidus .
Shakespearean: I hope so , Lepidus .

English: So we are in agreement .
Shakespearean: Thus we are agreed .

English: That's the next thing on the agenda .
Shakespearean: That's the next to do .

English: We'll have celebration feasts for each other before we go our separate ways .
Shakespearean: We'll feast each other ere we part , and let's Draw lots who shall begin .

English: I'll give the first one , Pompey .
Shakespearean: That will I , Pompey .

English: No , Antony .
Shakespearean: No , Antony , take the lot .

English: Whether your banquet is first or last , your Egyptian cooking will make it the best .
Shakespearean: But , first or last , Your fine Egyptian cookery shall have The fame .

English: I heard that Julius Caesar got fat from all the feasting there .
Shakespearean: I have heard that Julius Caesar Grew fat with feasting there .

English: You've heard a lot .
Shakespearean: You have heard much .

English: I mean well , sir .
Shakespearean: I have fair meanings , sir .

English: I'm sure you do .
Shakespearean: And fair words to them .

English: I've heard a lot more .
Shakespearean: Then so much have I heard .

English: I heard that Apollodorus carried , What did he carry , please ?
Shakespearean: And I have heard Apollodorus carried , What , I pray you ?

English: How are you , soldier ?
Shakespearean: How far'st thou , soldier ?

English: I'm well , and probably will be for a while , as I hear that four feasts are being prepared .
Shakespearean: Well , And well am like to do , for I perceive , Four feasts are toward .

English: Let me shake your hand .
Shakespearean: Let me shake thy hand .

English: I've never been your enemy .
Shakespearean: I never hated thee .

English: I've seen you fight and envied your skill .
Shakespearean: I have seen thee fight When I have envied thy behavior .

English: Sir , I wouldn't say I was your friend , but I've praised you when you deserved ten times more praise than I gave .
Shakespearean: Sir , I never loved you much , but I ha' praised ye When you have well deserved ten times as much As I have said you did .

English: Enjoy your frankness ; it suits you .
Shakespearean: Enjoy thy plainness .

English: I invite you all aboard my ship .
Shakespearean: It nothing ill becomes thee. , Aboard my galley I invite you all .

English: After you , my lords ?
Shakespearean: Will you lead , lords ?

English: Show us the way , sir .
Shakespearean: Show 's the way , sir .

English: Come with me .
Shakespearean: Come .

English: I think it was at sea .
Shakespearean: At sea , I think .

English: That it was , sir .
Shakespearean: We have , sir .

English: You've done well at sea .
Shakespearean: You have done well by water .

English: And you've done well on land .
Shakespearean: And you by land .

English: I'll flatter anyone who flatters me , though what I've accomplished on land can not be denied .
Shakespearean: I will praise any man that will praise me , though it can not be denied what I have done by land .

English: Neither can my accomplishments at sea .
Shakespearean: Nor what I have done by water .

English: Yes , for your own safety , you should deny one thing : you have been a great thief at sea .
Shakespearean: Yes , something you can deny for your own safety : you have been a great thief by sea .

English: As you were on land .
Shakespearean: And you by land .

English: That's the one part of my service on land I do deny .
Shakespearean: There I deny my land service .

English: But let's shake hands , Menas .
Shakespearean: But give me your hand , Menas .

English: If our eyes were policemen , they might capture two thieves at once while we're embracing .
Shakespearean: If our eyes had authority , here they might take two thieves kissing .

English: Men's faces are truthful , whatever their hands do .
Shakespearean: All men's faces are true , whatsome'er their hands are .

English: But no beautiful woman has an honest face .
Shakespearean: But there is never a fair woman has a true face .

English: That's no lie .
Shakespearean: No slander .

English: They steal hearts .
Shakespearean: They steal hearts .

English: We came here to fight against you .
Shakespearean: We came hither to fight with you .

English: For my part , I'm sorry this battle turned into a drinking match .
Shakespearean: For my part , I am sorry it is turned to a drinking .

English: Today Pompey laughs away his fortune .
Shakespearean: Pompey doth this day laugh away his fortune .

English: If that's true , he won't get it back by crying .
Shakespearean: If he do , sure he can not weep 't back again .

English: That's the truth , sir .
Shakespearean: You've said , sir .

English: We didn't expect Mark Antony to be here .
Shakespearean: We looked not for Mark Antony here .

English: Is he married to Cleopatra ?
Shakespearean: Pray you , is he married to Cleopatra ?

English: Caesar's sister is named Octavia .
Shakespearean: Caesar's sister is called Octavia .

English: That's true , sir .
Shakespearean: True , sir .

English: She was previously Caius Marcellus' wife .
Shakespearean: She was the wife of Caius Marcellus .

English: But she is now Mark Antony's wife .
Shakespearean: But she is now the wife of Marcus Antonius .

English: Excuse me , sir ?
Shakespearean: Pray ye , sir ?

English: It's true .
Shakespearean: Tis true .

English: Then Caesar and he will always be united .
Shakespearean: Then is Caesar and he forever knit together .

English: If I were to make a prediction regarding this union , I wouldn't say that .
Shakespearean: If I were bound to divine of this unity , I would not prophesy so .

English: I think the marriage was made more for political reasons than for love .
Shakespearean: I think the policy of that purpose made more in the marriage than the love of the parties .

English: I think so too .
Shakespearean: I think so too .

English: But you'll see that the very thing that joins them will be the thing that separates them .
Shakespearean: But you shall find the band that seems to tie their friendship together will be the very strangler of their amity .

English: Octavia has a pious , chaste , meek disposition .
Shakespearean: Octavia is of a holy , cold , and still conversation .

English: Doesn't everyone want a wife like that ?
Shakespearean: Who would not have his wife so ?

English: Not someone who doesn't share that disposition , meaning Mark Antony .
Shakespearean: Not he that himself is not so , which is Mark Antony .

English: He'll go back to his Egyptian dish .
Shakespearean: He will to his Egyptian dish again .

English: Then Octavia's complaints will rouse Caesar , and as I said before , the thing that brought them together will part them .
Shakespearean: Then shall the sighs of Octavia blow the fire up in Caesar , and , as I said before , that which is the strength of their amity shall prove the immediate author of their variance .

English: Antony will go where his passion is .
Shakespearean: Antony will use his affection where it is .

English: He only married out of political necessity .
Shakespearean: He married but his occasion here .

English: Then that's the way it may turn out .
Shakespearean: And thus it may be .

English: Come on , sir , will you come aboard ?
Shakespearean: Come , sir , will you aboard ?

English: I want to drink your health .
Shakespearean: I have a health for you .

English: I'll join you , sir .
Shakespearean: I shall take it , sir .

English: We did a lot of drinking in Egypt .
Shakespearean: We have used our throats in Egypt .

English: Let's go .
Shakespearean: Come , let's away .

English: Here's where they'll end up , on the floor .
Shakespearean: Here they'll be , man .

English: Some of them are leaning already .
Shakespearean: Some o' their plants are ill-rooted already .

English: Lepidus is red in the face .
Shakespearean: Lepidus is high-colored .

English: They made him drink the leftover wine usually given to the poor .
Shakespearean: They have made him drink alms-drink .

English: I'd rather carry a reed that obviously can't protect me than a sword I can not lift .
Shakespearean: I had as lief have a reed that will do me no service as a partisan I could not heave .

English: This is how they do it , sir : they measure the depth of the Nile , according to certain marks made on the walls of the Pyramid .
Shakespearean: Thus do they , sir : they take the flow o' th' Nile By certain scales i' th' Pyramid .

English: They know by those measurements if there will be famine or plenty .
Shakespearean: They know By th' height , the lowness , or the mean , if dearth Or foison follow .

English: The higher the Nile flows , the better the harvest .
Shakespearean: The higher Nilus swells The more it promises .

English: The harvest comes shortly after that .
Shakespearean: As it ebbs , the seedsman Upon the slime and ooze scatters his grain , And shortly comes to harvest .

English: Do you have unusual snakes there ?
Shakespearean: You've strange serpents there ?

English: Yes , Lepidus .
Shakespearean: Ay , Lepidus .

English: The Egyptian snake is born when the sun shines on the Nile mud , just like the crocodile .
Shakespearean: Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the operation of your sun .

English: I don't feel so well , but I won't stop .
Shakespearean: I am not so well as I should be , but I'll ne'er out .

English: Not until you pass out .
Shakespearean: Not till you have slept .

English: I'm afraid you'll keep going until then .
Shakespearean: I fear me you'll be in till then .

English: I've heard that the pyramids build by the Ptolemies are splendid .
Shakespearean: Nay , certainly , I have heard the Ptolemies' pyramises are very goodly things .

English: Without doubt I've heard that .
Shakespearean: Without contradiction I have heard that .

English: What does a crocodile look like ?
Shakespearean: What manner o' thing is your crocodile ?

English: Sir , it's shaped like itself and is as wide as it has width .
Shakespearean: It is shaped , sir , like itself , and it is as broad as it hath breadth .

English: It is only as high as it is and moves with its own legs .
Shakespearean: It is just so high as it is , and moves with its own organs .

English: Its own color .
Shakespearean: Of it own color too .

English: It's a strange snake .
Shakespearean: Tis a strange serpent .

English: It is that .
Shakespearean: Tis so .

English: And its tears are wet .
Shakespearean: And the tears of it are wet .

English: What is it ?
Shakespearean: The matter ?

English: I've always had great respect for your destiny .
Shakespearean: I have ever held my cap off to thy fortunes .

English: You've served me faithfully .
Shakespearean: Thou hast served me with much faith .

English: What else can I say ?
Shakespearean: What's else to say ? , These quicksands , Lepidus , Keep off them , for you sink .

English: What are you saying ?
Shakespearean: What sayst thou ?

English: Would you like to be king of the entire world ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou be lord of the whole world ?

English: Now I've said it twice .
Shakespearean: That's twice .

English: How could that happen ?
Shakespearean: How should that be ?

English: Just listen to him .
Shakespearean: Nay , hear him .

English: Be kind now and tell me some excellent fortune .
Shakespearean: Good now , some excellent fortune !

English: Tell me that I'll marry three kings before noon and be widowed by all of them .
Shakespearean: Let me be married to three kings in a forenoon and widow them all .

English: Oh , excellent !
Shakespearean: Oh , excellent !

English: Then my children will probably be illegitimate .
Shakespearean: Then belike my children shall have no names .

English: Tell me , please : how many boys and girls will I have ?
Shakespearean: Prithee , how many boys and wenches must I have ?

English: If every time you wished for a child you could have had one , you would have a million children .
Shakespearean: If every of your wishes had a womb , And fertile every wish , a million .

English: You seem to think no one outside of your bedroom knows what you wish .
Shakespearean: You think none but your sheets are privy to your wishes .

English: We'll all want our fortune told .
Shakespearean: We'll know all our fortunes .

English: My fortune , like that of many of us tonight , is to go drunk to bed .
Shakespearean: Mine , and most of our fortunes tonight , shall be , drunk to bed .

English: Are you drunk ?
Shakespearean: Hast thou drunk well ?

English: No , Pompey , I haven't had anything to drink .
Shakespearean: No , Pompey , I have kept me from the cup .

English: Tell me how .
Shakespearean: Show me which way .

English: The three who share the known world are aboard your boat .
Shakespearean: These three world-sharers , these competitors , Are in thy vessel .

English: Everything that belongs to them is yours .
Shakespearean: All there is thine .

English: Oh , you should have done it without telling me !
Shakespearean: Ah , this thou shouldst have done And not have spoke on 't !

English: For you to do it would be good service .
Shakespearean: In me 'tis villainy , In thee 't had been good service .

English: You should know that to me , profit isn't more important than honor , but the other way around .
Shakespearean: Thou must know , 'Tis not my profit that does lead mine honor ; Mine honor , it .

English: Regret that your mouth betrayed your actions .
Shakespearean: Repent that e'er thy tongue Hath so betrayed thine act .

English: But now I must condemn it .
Shakespearean: Being done unknown , I should have found it afterwards well done , But must condemn it now .

English: Give it up and go drink .
Shakespearean: Desist , and drink .

English: This toast is for Lepidus !
Shakespearean: This health to Lepidus !

English: Here's to you , Menas .
Shakespearean: Here's to thee , Menas !

English: I accept with thanks , Enobarbus .
Shakespearean: Enobarbus , welcome .

English: There goes a strong fellow , Menas .
Shakespearean: There's a strong fellow , Menas .

English: Why do you say that ?
Shakespearean: Why ?

English: He carries a third of the world .
Shakespearean: He bears The third part of the world , man .

English: Can't you see that ?
Shakespearean: Seest not ?

English: Then a third of the world is drunk .
Shakespearean: The third part , then , is drunk .

English: Drink up .
Shakespearean: Drink thou .

English: All right , then .
Shakespearean: Come .

English: This hasn't reached the level of an Egyptian feast yet .
Shakespearean: This is not yet an Alexandrian feast .

English: It's getting there .
Shakespearean: It ripens towards it .

English: Clink your cups together in a toast !
Shakespearean: Strike the vessels , ho !

English: Here's to Caesar .
Shakespearean: Here's to Caesar .

English: I could do without another toast .
Shakespearean: I could well forbear 't .

English: Live in the moment .
Shakespearean: Be a child o' th' time .

English: But I would rather abstain from everything for four days than drink so much in one .
Shakespearean: But I had rather fast from all four days Than drink so much in one .

English: Let's have one , good soldier .
Shakespearean: Let's ha 't , good soldier .

English: Come , let's join our hands until the overpowering wine makes us soft and forgetful .
Shakespearean: Come , let's all take hands Till that the conquering wine hath steeped our sense In soft and delicate Lethe .

English: Everyone join hands .
Shakespearean: All take hands .

English: How can you top that ?
Shakespearean: What needs more words ?

English: Good night , Pompey .
Shakespearean: Good night .

English: Yes , we will .
Shakespearean: And shall , sir .

English: Let's shake on it .
Shakespearean: Give 's your hand .

English: We're friends !
Shakespearean: We are friends .

English: Come , this way to the rowboat .
Shakespearean: Come , down into the boat .

English: Be careful not to fall in .
Shakespearean: Take heed you fall not .

English: Menas , I'm not going back on shore .
Shakespearean: Menas , I'll not on shore .

English: No , come to my cabin .
Shakespearean: No , to my cabin .

English: What do you say ?
Shakespearean: What !

English: There's my hat !
Shakespearean: There's my cap .

English: Hooray !
Shakespearean: Hoo !

English: Come on , noble captain .
Shakespearean: Noble captain , come .

English: Now I've paid you back , Parthia , and gotten revenge for Marcus Crassus' death .
Shakespearean: Now , darting Parthia , art thou struck , and now Pleased fortune does of Marcus Crassus' death Make me revenger .

English: You must understand , Silius , that it's better to leave something undone than achieve too much fame in your superior's absence .
Shakespearean: For learn this , Silius : Better to leave undone than by our deed Acquire too high a fame when him we serve's away .

English: Caesar and Antony have always achieved more by delegating authority to their officers than by leading their troops in person .
Shakespearean: Caesar and Antony have ever won More in their officer than person .

English: A man who achieves more in war than his captain does becomes his captain's rival .
Shakespearean: Who does i' th' wars more than his captain can Becomes his captain's captain ; and ambition , The soldier's virtue , rather makes choice of loss Than gain which darkens him .

English: I could do more to help Antony , but to do so would insult him .
Shakespearean: I could do more to do Antonius good , But 'twould offend him , and in his offense Should my performance perish .

English: A soldier is just a tool , like his sword , unless he has your qualities , Ventidius .
Shakespearean: Thou hast , Ventidius , that Without the which a soldier and his sword Grants scarce distinction .

English: Are you going to write Antony about this ?
Shakespearean: Thou wilt write to Antony ?

English: I'll write how , under his flag and with his well-paid troops , we have beaten the formerly unvanquished Parthia .
Shakespearean: I'll humbly signify what in his name , That magical word of war , we have effected : How with his banners and his well-paid ranks The ne'er-yet-beaten horse of Parthia We have jaded out o' th' field .

English: Where's Antony now ?
Shakespearean: Where is he now ?

English: Did the brothers-in-law leave ?
Shakespearean: What , are the brothers parted ?

English: They finished their business with Pompey , and Pompey has left .
Shakespearean: They have dispatched with Pompey ; he is gone .

English: Octavia weeps at the thought of leaving Rome .
Shakespearean: Octavia weeps To part from Rome .

English: Caesar is in a sober mood .
Shakespearean: Caesar is sad , and Lepidus , Since Pompey's feast , as Menas says , is troubled With the greensickness .

English: He's a stylish man .
Shakespearean: A very fine one .

English: And how he loves Caesar !
Shakespearean: Oh , how he loves Caesar !

English: Yes , but how he adores Mark Antony !
Shakespearean: Nay , but how dearly he adores Mark Antony !

English: Caesar ?
Shakespearean: Caesar ?

English: Then what's Antony ?
Shakespearean: What's Antony ?

English: A god of a god ?
Shakespearean: The god of Jupiter .

English: Are you talking about Caesar ?
Shakespearean: Spake you of Caesar ?

English: He's without equal !
Shakespearean: How , the nonpareil !

English: Oh , Antony !
Shakespearean: O Antony , O thou Arabian bird !

English: Oh , you If you want to praise Caesar , just say his name , that's all the praise that's necessary .
Shakespearean: Would you praise Caesar , say "Caesar." Go no further .

English: He certainly flattered them both with extravagant compliments .
Shakespearean: Indeed , he plied them both with excellent praises .

English: He loves Caesar best , but he also loves Antony .
Shakespearean: But he loves Caesar best ; yet he loves Antony .

English: Oh !
Shakespearean: Hoo !

English: Hearts can not think it , tongues can not speak it , meas-urements can not calculate it , scribes can not write it , bards can not sing it , and poets can not make verses about it .
Shakespearean: Hearts , tongues , figures , scribes , bards , poets , can not Think , speak , cast , write , sing , number , hoo ! , His love to Antony .

English: He loves them both .
Shakespearean: Both he loves .

English: They are his dung , and he their beetle .
Shakespearean: They are his shards , and he

English: So , there's the signal to ride .
Shakespearean: So , This is to horse .

English: Good-bye , noble Agrippa .
Shakespearean: Adieu , noble Agrippa .

English: Good luck , worthy soldier , and good-bye .
Shakespearean: Good fortune , worthy soldier , and farewell .

English: You can't go any further with us , sir .
Shakespearean: No further , sir .

English: If you and I don't value her equally , it would be better for us to work out our differences without her .
Shakespearean: For better might we Have loved without this mean , if on both parts This be not cherished .

English: Don't insult me with your distrust .
Shakespearean: Make me not offended In your distrust .

English: I mean what I say .
Shakespearean: I have said .

English: You won't find any cause for anxiety , even if you look for one .
Shakespearean: You shall not find , Though you be therein curious , the least cause For what you seem to fear .

English: So , may the gods protect you and change the hearts of the Romans so that they turn and give you their support .
Shakespearean: So the gods keep you And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends .

English: We'll leave you here .
Shakespearean: We will here part .

English: Good-bye , my dearest sister , good-bye .
Shakespearean: Farewell , my dearest sister , fare thee well .

English: I hope you have good weather to set your mind at ease .
Shakespearean: The elements be kind to thee and make Thy spirits all of comfort !

English: Farewell .
Shakespearean: Fare thee well .

English: My noble brother !
Shakespearean: My noble brother !

English: Her eyes are like April : full of showers .
Shakespearean: The April's in her eyes ; it is love's spring , And these the showers to bring it on .

English: What is it , Octavia ?
Shakespearean: What , Octavia ?

English: I'll tell you privately .
Shakespearean: I'll tell you in your ear .

English: See , now I have you .
Shakespearean: Look , here I have you .

English: And thus I let you go and give you to the gods .
Shakespearean: Thus I let you go And give you to the gods .

English: Good-bye .
Shakespearean: Adieu .

English: Be happy .
Shakespearean: Be happy .

English: Farewell , farewell .
Shakespearean: Farewell , farewell .

English: Farewell .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: Like the Oh stop it , you lusty bed-hopper .
Shakespearean: E'en as the o'erflowing Nilus presageth famine .

English: You can't see the future .
Shakespearean: Go , you wild bedfellow , you can not soothsay .

English: Well , if a moist palm isn't a clear sign of promiscuity , then I can't scratch my own ear .
Shakespearean: Nay , if an oily palm be not a fruitful prognostication , I can not scratch mine ear. , Prithee , tell her but a workaday fortune .

English: Your fortunes are the same .
Shakespearean: Your fortunes are alike .

English: But how ?
Shakespearean: But how , but how ?

English: Give me details .
Shakespearean: Give me particulars .

English: I've said what I have to say .
Shakespearean: I have said .

English: Isn't my fortune just a little better than hers ?
Shakespearean: Am I not an inch of fortune better than she ?

English: Well , if you could have just an inch of better fortune than me , where would you like the improvement ?
Shakespearean: Well , if you were but an inch of fortune better than I , where would you choose it ?

English: Not in my husband's nose .
Shakespearean: Not in my husband's nose .

English: May heaven save us from indecent thoughts !
Shakespearean: Our worser thoughts heavens mend .

English: Alexas !
Shakespearean: Alexas !

English: If it's sad to see a handsome man with a cheating wife , it's a tragedy to see an ugly thug with a wife who's faithful .
Shakespearean: For , as it is a heartbreaking to see a handsome man loose-wived , so it is a deadly sorrow to behold a foul knave uncuckolded .

English: Therefore , dear Isis , do the right thing and give him the fortune he deserves .
Shakespearean: Therefore , dear Isis , keep decorum , and fortune him accordingly .

English: Where is that messenger ?
Shakespearean: Where is the fellow ?

English: He's afraid to come in .
Shakespearean: Half afeard to come .

English: Oh , come on. , Come here , sir .
Shakespearean: Go to , go to. , Come hither , sir .

English: Gracious Queen , even Herod of Judea wouldn't dare look at you unless you were in a good mood .
Shakespearean: Good majesty , Herod of Jewry dare not look upon you But when you are well pleased .

English: I'll have Herod's head chopped off !
Shakespearean: That Herod's head I'll have !

English: Most formidable Queen !
Shakespearean: Most gracious majesty !

English: Did you see Octavia ?
Shakespearean: Didst thou behold Octavia ?

English: Yes , revered Queen .
Shakespearean: Ay , dread Queen .

English: Where ?
Shakespearean: Where ?

English: In Rome , Madam .
Shakespearean: Madam , in Rome .

English: I saw her face as she walked with her brother and Mark Antony .
Shakespearean: I looked her in the face , and saw her led Between her brother and Mark Antony .

English: Is she as tall as I am ?
Shakespearean: Is she as tall as me ?

English: She is not , madam .
Shakespearean: She is not , madam .

English: Did you hear her speak ?
Shakespearean: Didst hear her speak ?

English: Is her voice pitched high or low ?
Shakespearean: Is she shrill-tongued or low ?

English: Madam , I heard her speak .
Shakespearean: Madam , I heard her speak .

English: She has a low-pitched voice .
Shakespearean: She is low-voiced .

English: That's not in her favor .
Shakespearean: That's not so good .

English: He can't like her very long .
Shakespearean: He can not like her long .

English: Like her ?
Shakespearean: Like her ?

English: Oh , Isis , that's impossible .
Shakespearean: O Isis , 'tis impossible .

English: You're right , Charmian .
Shakespearean: I think so , Charmian .

English: She creeps along .
Shakespearean: She creeps .

English: She has a body , not a life .
Shakespearean: She shows a body rather than a life , A statue than a breather .

English: Is this true ?
Shakespearean: Is this certain ?

English: If not , then I have no powers of observation .
Shakespearean: Or I have no observance .

English: There aren't three people in all of Egypt who could do better .
Shakespearean: Three in Egypt Can not make better note .

English: She doesn't have anything going for her so far .
Shakespearean: There's nothing in her yet .

English: This messenger is wise .
Shakespearean: The fellow has good judgment .

English: Very wise .
Shakespearean: Excellent .

English: Do you hear that , Charmian ?
Shakespearean: Charmian , hark .

English: And I think she's at least thirty .
Shakespearean: And I do think she's thirty .

English: Do you remember her face ?
Shakespearean: Bear'st thou her face in mind ?

English: Was it long or round ?
Shakespearean: Is 't long or round ?

English: Round enough to be unattractive .
Shakespearean: Round , even to faultiness .

English: Usually that means a person is foolish .
Shakespearean: For the most part , too , they are foolish that are so .

English: What color is her hair ?
Shakespearean: Her hair , what color ?

English: Brown , madam , and she wouldn't want her forehead to be any lower .
Shakespearean: Brown , madam , and her forehead As low as she would wish it .

English: You mustn't hold my earlier outburst against me .
Shakespearean: Thou must not take my former sharpness ill .

English: I'll hire you again to go back to Rome .
Shakespearean: I will employ thee back again ; I find thee Most fit for business .

English: My letters are ready to go .
Shakespearean: Go make thee ready ; Our letters are prepared .

English: He's an admirable man .
Shakespearean: A proper man .

English: He certainly is .
Shakespearean: Indeed , he is so .

English: I'm very sorry I was so hard on him .
Shakespearean: I repent me much That so I harried him .

English: Not a bit , madam .
Shakespearean: Nothing , madam .

English: Everything may still be all right .
Shakespearean: All may be well enough .

English: I assure you it is , madam .
Shakespearean: I warrant you , madam .

English: Oh , dear husband , don't believe everything you hear , or if you must believe it , don't let it all make you angry .
Shakespearean: O my good lord , Believe not all , or , if you must believe , Stomach not all .

English: No lady could be more miserable than I if you two disagree .
Shakespearean: A more unhappy lady , If this division chance , ne'er stood between , Praying for both parts .

English: Gentle Octavia , support the one that supports you .
Shakespearean: Gentle Octavia , Let your best love draw to that point which seeks Best to preserve it .

English: In the meantime , I'll raise an army that will surpass his .
Shakespearean: The meantime , lady , I'll raise the preparation of a war Shall stain your brother .

English: May the god of power make me , the weakest of the weak , your mediator .
Shakespearean: The Jove of power make me most weak , most weak , Your reconciler !

English: When you find out who started this disagreement , turn your anger upon them .
Shakespearean: When it appears to you where this begins , Turn your displeasure that way , for our faults Can never be so equal that your love Can equally move with them .

English: Order supplies for your trip and choose your traveling companions .
Shakespearean: Provide your going ; Choose your own company and command what cost Your heart has mind to .

English: How goes it , friend Eros ?
Shakespearean: How now , friend Eros !

English: Some startling news has just arrived , sir .
Shakespearean: There's strange news come , sir .

English: What news , man ?
Shakespearean: What , man ?

English: Caesar and Lepidus declared war against Pompey .
Shakespearean: Caesar and Lepidus have made wars upon Pompey .

English: That's old news .
Shakespearean: This is old .

English: Who's winning ?
Shakespearean: What is the success ?

English: So the weak third of the triumvirate is imprisoned until death frees him .
Shakespearean: So the poor third is up , till death enlarge his confine .

English: And even if you throw everything you possess to the two of them , they'll battle each other to the death to have it all .
Shakespearean: Then , world , thou hast a pair of chaps , no more , And throw between them all the food thou hast , They'll grind the one the other .

English: Where's Antony ?
Shakespearean: Where's Antony ?

English: Another thing , Domitius : Antony wants to see you now .
Shakespearean: More , Domitius : My lord desires you presently .

English: I should have waited to tell you my news .
Shakespearean: My news I might have told hereafter .

English: But never mind .
Shakespearean: Twill be naught , But let it be .

English: Take me to Antony .
Shakespearean: Bring me to Antony .

English: Come with me , sir .
Shakespearean: Come , sir .

English: In Alexandria he condemned Rome , and that's not all .
Shakespearean: Contemning Rome , he has done all this and more In Alexandria .

English: This is what happened : he and Cleopatra sat on chairs of gold on a silver-covered stage in the marketplace .
Shakespearean: Here's the manner of 't : I' th' marketplace , on a tribunal silvered , Cleopatra and himself in chairs of gold Were publicly enthroned .

English: He did this in public ?
Shakespearean: This in the public eye ?

English: He gave Syria , Cilicia , and Phoenicia to Ptolemy .
Shakespearean: She In th' habiliments of the goddess Isis That day appeared , and oft before gave audience , As 'tis reported , so .

English: Let's send this news to Rome .
Shakespearean: Let Rome be thus informed .

English: The Roman people are fed up with his arrogance already .
Shakespearean: Who , queasy with his insolence already , Will their good thoughts call from him .

English: The people have heard it already , and they've been told of his accusations .
Shakespearean: The people knows it , and have now received His accusations .

English: Who does he accuse ?
Shakespearean: Who does he accuse ?

English: He accuses me of withholding his share of Sextus Pompeius' possessions , which we seized in Sicily .
Shakespearean: Caesar , and that , having in Sicily Sextus Pompeius spoiled , we had not rated him His part o' th' isle .

English: Then he says I didn't return some ships he loaned me .
Shakespearean: Then does he say he lent me Some shipping , unrestored .

English: Sir , these accusations should be answered .
Shakespearean: Sir , this should be answered .

English: It has been done already , and the messenger is on his way .
Shakespearean: Tis done already , and the messenger gone .

English: I answered that Lepidus had become too brutal and abused his position .
Shakespearean: I have told him , Lepidus was grown too cruel , That he his high authority abused And did deserve his change .

English: He'll never agree to that .
Shakespearean: He'll never yield to that .

English: Then we won't agree to his demands .
Shakespearean: Nor must not then be yielded to in this .

English: Greetings , Caesar , my lord !
Shakespearean: Hail , Caesar , and my lord !

English: Greetings , dearest Caesar !
Shakespearean: Hail , most dear Caesar !

English: Oh , to think you've been rejected !
Shakespearean: That ever I should call thee castaway !

English: You've never thought of me like that , and you have no reason to .
Shakespearean: You have not called me so , nor have you cause .

English: Then why did you travel so quietly ?
Shakespearean: Why have you stol'n upon us thus ?

English: You didn't arrive like Caesar's sister .
Shakespearean: You come not Like Caesar's sister .

English: Antony's wife should have an army to escort her , with neighing horses to announce her arrival long before she appears .
Shakespearean: The wife of Antony Should have an army for an usher and The neighs of horse to tell of her approach Long ere she did appear .

English: The dust from your attending troops should have risen to heaven .
Shakespearean: Nay , the dust Should have ascended to the roof of heaven , Raised by your populous troops .

English: I would have met you by sea and again by land .
Shakespearean: We should have met you By sea and land , supplying every stage With an augmented greeting .

English: Mark Antony heard that you were preparing to wage war on him .
Shakespearean: My lord , Mark Antony , Hearing that you prepared for war , acquainted My grieved ear withal , whereon I begged His pardon for return .

English: Which he quickly allowed , given that you're an obstacle to his lust .
Shakespearean: Which soon he granted , Being an obstruct 'tween his lust and him .

English: Amen .
Shakespearean: Amen .

English: Quiet !
Shakespearean: Hush !

English: Here comes Antony .
Shakespearean: Here comes Antony .

English: Have you seen my lord ?
Shakespearean: Saw you my lord ?

English: No , lady .
Shakespearean: No , lady .

English: Wasn't he here ?
Shakespearean: Was he not here ?

English: No , madam .
Shakespearean: No , madam .

English: He was in a good mood , and then suddenly he started thinking of Rome .
Shakespearean: He was disposed to mirth , but on the sudden A Roman thought hath struck him. , Enobarbus !

English: Madam ?
Shakespearean: Madam ?

English: Here , at your service .
Shakespearean: Here at your service .

English: Here comes my lord .
Shakespearean: My lord approaches .

English: Your wife , Fulvia , mustered her army first .
Shakespearean: Fulvia thy wife first came into the field .

English: Against my brother Lucius ?
Shakespearean: Against my brother Lucius ?

English: Yes .
Shakespearean: Ay .

English: Don't say that , my lord .
Shakespearean: Do not say so , my lord .

English: Where do you think he is now ?
Shakespearean: Where is he now ?

English: He's in Athens , my lord .
Shakespearean: My lord , in Athens .

English: No , he's not .
Shakespearean: No , my most wronged sister .

English: Cleopatra summoned him .
Shakespearean: Cleopatra Hath nodded him to her .

English: He's given his empire to a whore , and now they're gathering kings to wage a war .
Shakespearean: He hath given his empire Up to a whore ; who now are levying The kings o' th' earth for war .

English: He's recruited Bocchus , the King of Libya ; Archelaus of Cappadocia ; Philadelphos , King of Paphlagonia ; the Thracian king , Adallas ; King Manchus of Arabia ; the King of Pont ; Herod , of Judea ; Mithridates , King of Comagen ; Polemon and Amyntas , the kings of Mede and Lycaonia , and many more .
Shakespearean: He hath assembled Bocchus , the King of Libya ; Archelaus , Of Cappadocia ; Philadelphos , King Of Paphlagonia ; the Thracian king , Adallas ; King Manchus of Arabia ; King of Pont ; Herod of Jewry ; Mithridates , King Of Comagen ; Polemon and Amyntas , The Kings of Mede and Lycaonia , With a more larger list of scepters .

English: I'm divided between two friends who are determined to kill each other .
Shakespearean: Ay me , most wretched , That have my heart parted betwixt two friends That does afflict each other !

English: You're welcome here .
Shakespearean: Welcome hither .

English: I didn't write about breaking the alliance with Antony until I saw you were being misled and realized how dangerous it would be to keep postponing preparations .
Shakespearean: Your letters did withhold our breaking forth Till we perceived both how you were wrong led And we in negligent danger .

English: Cheer yourself .
Shakespearean: Cheer your heart .

English: You will always be welcome to me .
Shakespearean: Best of comfort , And ever welcome to us .

English: Welcome , lady .
Shakespearean: Welcome , lady .

English: Welcome , dear madam .
Shakespearean: Welcome , dear madam .

English: Every heart in Rome loves and pities you .
Shakespearean: Each heart in Rome does love and pity you .

English: Only the adulterous and abominable Antony abandons you , giving his power to a whore who turns that power against us .
Shakespearean: Only th' adulterous Antony , most large In his abominations , turns you off And gives his potent regiment to a trull That noises it against us .

English: It's undeniable .
Shakespearean: Most certain .

English: You are welcome here , sister .
Shakespearean: Sister , welcome .

English: I beg you to continue to be patient .
Shakespearean: Pray you Be ever known to patience .

English: My dearest sister !
Shakespearean: My dear'st sister !

English: But why , why , why ?
Shakespearean: But why , why , why ?

English: You opposed my taking part in the war .
Shakespearean: Thou hast forspoke my being in these wars And sayst it is not fit .

English: Isn't this war against me ?
Shakespearean: Is 't not denounced against us ?

English: Why shouldn't I be there in person ?
Shakespearean: Why should not we Be there in person ?

English: What do you mean ?
Shakespearean: What is 't you say ?

English: Let Rome fall !
Shakespearean: Sink Rome !

English: May the tongues of our critics rot !
Shakespearean: And their tongues rot That speak against us !

English: I have responsibilities in this war , and as the absolute ruler of my kingdom I will carry out my duties as if I were a man .
Shakespearean: A charge we bear i' th' war , And as the president of my kingdom will Appear there for a man .

English: Don't argue against it .
Shakespearean: Speak not against it .

English: I won't stay behind .
Shakespearean: I will not stay behind .

English: No , I've had my say .
Shakespearean: Nay , I have done .

English: Here comes the Emperor .
Shakespearean: Here comes the Emperor .

English: Isn't it strange , Canidius , that he could cross the Ionian Sea so quickly from Tarentum and Brundusium and take Toryne ? , Have you heard about this , sweet ?
Shakespearean: Is it not strange , Canidius , That from Tarentum and Brundusium He could so quickly cut the Ionian sea And take in Toryne ? , You have heard on 't , sweet ?

English: No one admires speed more than the lazy .
Shakespearean: Celerity is never more admired Than by the negligent .

English: What else ?
Shakespearean: By sea , what else ?

English: Why do you want to do that , my lord ?
Shakespearean: Why will My lord do so ?

English: Because he's daring us to do it .
Shakespearean: For that he dares us to 't .

English: So you've dared him to single combat .
Shakespearean: So hath my lord dared him to single fight .

English: Yes , and you dared Caesar to fight the battle at Pharsalia , where he fought against Pompey .
Shakespearean: Ay , and to wage this battle at Pharsalia , Where Caesar fought with Pompey .

English: But Caesar ignores offers that don't give him an advantage , and so should you .
Shakespearean: But these offers , Which serve not for his vantage , he shakes off , And so should you .

English: His ships are maneuverable .
Shakespearean: In Caesar's fleet Are those that often have 'gainst Pompey fought .

English: Yours are slow and awkward .
Shakespearean: Their ships are yare , yours , heavy .

English: Refusing to fight him at sea won't disgrace you .
Shakespearean: No disgrace Shall fall you for refusing him at sea , Being prepared for land .

English: I'll fight at sea .
Shakespearean: I'll fight at sea .

English: Even if we fail at that , we can still fight him on land .
Shakespearean: But if we fail , We then can do 't at land .

English: What's your business ?
Shakespearean: Thy business ?

English: The news is true , my lord .
Shakespearean: The news is true , my lord .

English: He has captured Toryne .
Shakespearean: He is descried .

English: Canidius , take our nineteen
Shakespearean: Canidius , Our nineteen legions thou shalt hold by land , And our twelve thousand horse .

English: What's the news , brave soldier ?
Shakespearean: How now , worthy soldier ?

English: Oh , don't fight by sea , noble Emperor !
Shakespearean: O noble Emperor , do not fight by sea !

English: Don't trust rotten planks .
Shakespearean: Trust not to rotten planks .

English: Don't you trust my sword and these wounds ?
Shakespearean: Do you misdoubt This sword and these my wounds ?

English: Let the Egyptians and Phoenicians go swimming .
Shakespearean: Let th' Egyptians And the Phoenicians go a-ducking .

English: We are used to winning by standing on the earth and fighting toe to toe .
Shakespearean: We Have used to conquer standing on the earth And fighting foot to foot .

English: Well , well , let's go .
Shakespearean: Well , well , away .

English: By Hercules , I think I'm right .
Shakespearean: By Hercules , I think I am i' th' right .

English: Soldier , you are .
Shakespearean: Soldier , thou art ; but his whole action grows Not in the power on 't .

English: Our leader is being led .
Shakespearean: So our leader's led , And we are women's men .

English: On land you keep the legions and cavalry together , don't you ?
Shakespearean: You keep by land The legions and the horse whole , do you not ?

English: Marcus Octavius , Marcus Justeius , Publicola , and Caelius will go by sea , but we'll keep the bulk on land .
Shakespearean: Marcus Octavius , Marcus Justeius , Publicola , and Caelius , are for sea ; But we keep whole by land .

English: Caesar's speed defies belief .
Shakespearean: This speed of Caesar's Carries beyond belief .

English: While he was still in Rome , he deployed his forces in so many different disguises that all our spies were fooled .
Shakespearean: While he was yet in Rome His power went out in such distractions as Beguiled all spies .

English: Who's his lieutenant , do you know ?
Shakespearean: Who's his lieutenant , hear you ?

English: A man named Taurus , they say .
Shakespearean: They say , one Taurus .

English: I know the man well .
Shakespearean: Well I know the man .

English: The Emperor is calling for Canidius .
Shakespearean: The Emperor calls Canidius .

English: The present time is like a woman in labor , each minute giving birth to some piece of news .
Shakespearean: With news the time's with labor , and throws forth Each minute some .

English: Taurus !
Shakespearean: Taurus !

English: My lord ?
Shakespearean: My lord ?

English: Don't attack by land .
Shakespearean: Strike not by land ; keep whole .

English: Don't provoke them to battle until we have finished at sea .
Shakespearean: Provoke not battle Till we have done at sea .

English: Our fate depends on this chance .
Shakespearean: Our fortune lies Upon this jump .

English: Assemble our squadrons on the other side of the hill , in sight of Caesar's navy .
Shakespearean: Set we our squadrons on yond side o' th' hill , In eye of Caesar's battle , from which place We may the number of the ships behold And so proceed accordingly .

English: I can't watch any more .
Shakespearean: I can behold no longer .

English: The Egyptian flagship , the Gods and goddesses , the whole congregation of them !
Shakespearean: Gods and goddesses , All the whole synod of them !

English: What's wrong with you ?
Shakespearean: What's thy passion ?

English: We have lost a major portion of the world through utter foolishness .
Shakespearean: The greater cantle of the world is lost With very ignorance .

English: We have kissed away entire kingdoms and provinces .
Shakespearean: We have kissed away Kingdoms and provinces .

English: How goes the battle ?
Shakespearean: How appears the fight ?

English: Right in the middle of the fight , just when the battle could have gone either way , actually we had a slight advantage , that immoral Egyptian nag , May she die of leprosy ! , suddenly became frightened , and turned her ships around and fled .
Shakespearean: Yon ribaudred nag of Egypt , Whom leprosy o'ertake ! , i' th' midst o' th' fight , When vantage like a pair of twins appeared Both as the same , or rather ours the elder , The breeze upon her , like a cow in June , Hoists sails and flies .

English: I saw that .
Shakespearean: That I beheld .

English: The sight made me so sick I couldn't watch any more .
Shakespearean: Mine eyes did sicken at the sight and could not Endure a further view .

English: Well , give me the worst news .
Shakespearean: Well , what worst ?

English: The bearer of bad news is often blamed for it .
Shakespearean: The nature of bad news infects the teller .

English: Only if the hearer is a fool or a coward .
Shakespearean: When it concerns the fool or coward .

English: Go on .
Shakespearean: On .

English: As far as I'm concerned , what's past is done .
Shakespearean: Things that are past are done , with me .

English: It's like this : as long as a person tells me the truth , even though it means my death , I will listen as though he praised me .
Shakespearean: Tis thus : Who tells me true , though in his tale lie death , I hear him as he flattered .

English: Oh , my lord !
Shakespearean: O my lord !

English: Speak plainly .
Shakespearean: Speak to me home .

English: Call Cleopatra what the Romans call her .
Shakespearean: Name Cleopatra as she is called in Rome .

English: It's easy to err when left to our own devices , but criticism helps us to see our faults and correct them .
Shakespearean: Oh , then we bring forth weeds When our quick minds lie still , and our ills told us Is as our earing .

English: Good-bye for a while .
Shakespearean: Fare thee well awhile .

English: I never saw such a shameful act .
Shakespearean: I never saw an action of such shame .

English: Terrible .
Shakespearean: Experience , manhood , honor , ne'er before Did violate so itself .

English: Terrible .
Shakespearean: Alack , alack !

English: The battle on the sea is almost lost .
Shakespearean: Our fortune on the sea is out of breath And sinks most lamentably .

English: If our general had been his old self , we would have won .
Shakespearean: Had our general Been what he knew himself , it had gone well .

English: Oh , with his sordid desertion , he sets the example for our own .
Shakespearean: Oh , he has given example for our flight Most grossly by his own !

English: Are you considering desertion , as well ?
Shakespearean: Ay , are you thereabouts ?

English: Then everything must really be finished .
Shakespearean: Why then , good night indeed .

English: They fled toward Peloponnesus .
Shakespearean: Toward Peloponnesus are they fled .

English: I'll yield my legions and cavalry to Caesar .
Shakespearean: To Caesar will I render My legions and my horse .

English: Listen .
Shakespearean: Hark .

English: Friends , come here .
Shakespearean: Friends , come hither .

English: I'm completely lost .
Shakespearean: I am so lated in the world that I Have lost my way forever .

English: I have a ship full of treasure .
Shakespearean: I have a ship Laden with gold .

English: Escape and make peace with Caesar .
Shakespearean: Fly And make your peace with Caesar .

English: Flee ?
Shakespearean: Fly ?

English: Not us .
Shakespearean: Not we .

English: I've told cowards to turn their backs on me and run .
Shakespearean: I have fled myself , and have instructed cowards To run and show their shoulders .

English: Friends , go .
Shakespearean: Friends , begone .

English: I've decided on a plan that doesn't require your assistance .
Shakespearean: I have myself resolved upon a course Which has no need of you .

English: Leave .
Shakespearean: Begone .

English: Oh , I followed something I'm ashamed to look at now !
Shakespearean: Oh , I followed that I blush to look upon !

English: Even my hair revolts .
Shakespearean: My very hairs do mutiny , for the white Reprove the brown for rashness , and they them For fear and doting .

English: Friends , go .
Shakespearean: Friends , begone .

English: I'll give you letters of introduction to some friends of mine who will help you .
Shakespearean: You shall Have letters from me to some friends that will Sweep your way for you .

English: Please , don't be sad , and don't tell me how reluctant you are .
Shakespearean: Pray you , look not sad , Nor make replies of loathness .

English: Take your cues from my own despair .
Shakespearean: Take the hint Which my despair proclaims .

English: Abandon the person that has abandoned himself .
Shakespearean: Let that be left Which leaves itself .

English: Go to the harbor immediately !
Shakespearean: To the seaside straightway !

English: I'll give you the title to that ship and its treasure .
Shakespearean: I will possess you of that ship and treasure .

English: Just give me a moment , please , only a moment .
Shakespearean: Leave me , I pray , a little .

English: I've relinquished my authority , so please , I'll see you all before long .
Shakespearean: Pray you now , Nay , do so , for indeed I have lost command .

English: What else ?
Shakespearean: Why , what else ?

English: Let me sit down .
Shakespearean: Let me sit down .

English: Oh , damn , damn , damn !
Shakespearean: Oh , fie , fie , fie !

English: Madam !
Shakespearean: Madam !

English: Madam , oh , good Empress !
Shakespearean: Madam , O good Empress !

English: The Queen is here , my lord .
Shakespearean: The Queen , my lord , the Queen .

English: Go to him , madam , speak to him .
Shakespearean: Go to him , madam , speak to him .

English: He's not himself because he feels so ashamed .
Shakespearean: He is unqualitied with very shame .

English: Well , then , help me .
Shakespearean: Well then , sustain me .

English: Most noble sir , stand up .
Shakespearean: Most noble sir , arise .

English: The Queen is coming .
Shakespearean: The Queen approaches .

English: She's weak and will die unless you comfort her .
Shakespearean: Her head's declined , and death will seize her but Your comfort makes the rescue .

English: I've destroyed my reputation , a most shameful error .
Shakespearean: I have offended reputation , A most unnoble swerving .

English: Sir , here's the Queen .
Shakespearean: Sir , the Queen .

English: Oh , where have you led me , Egypt ?
Shakespearean: Oh , whither hast thou led me , Egypt ?

English: Oh , my lord , my lord , forgive my panic !
Shakespearean: O my lord , my lord , Forgive my fearful sails !

English: I didn't think you would follow me .
Shakespearean: I little thought You would have followed .

English: Queen , you knew very well that my heart was tied to your ship and that you would pull me along with you .
Shakespearean: Egypt , thou knew'st too well My heart was to thy rudder tied by th' strings , And thou shouldst tow me after .

English: You knew that my spirit was completely under your control and that I would ignore the gods' orders in favor of yours .
Shakespearean: O'er my spirit Thy full supremacy thou knew'st , and that Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods Command me .

English: Oh , forgive me !
Shakespearean: Oh , my pardon !

English: Now I will have to send my humble proposal of peace to that young man .
Shakespearean: Now I must To the young man send humble treaties , dodge And palter in the shifts of lowness , who With half the bulk o' th' world played as I pleased , Making and marring fortunes .

English: You knew that my sword , weakened by my love for you , would obey that love no matter what .
Shakespearean: You did know How much you were my conqueror , and that My sword , made weak by my affection , would Obey it on all cause .

English: Don't shed even one tear .
Shakespearean: Fall not a tear , I say .

English: One of your tears is worth everything that was won and lost .
Shakespearean: One of them rates All that is won and lost .

English: Give me a kiss .
Shakespearean: Give me a kiss .

English: This repays me .
Shakespearean: Even this repays me. , We sent our schoolmaster .

English: Let the envoy from Antony come in .
Shakespearean: Let him appear that's come from Antony .

English: Do you know him ?
Shakespearean: Know you him ?

English: Come forward and speak .
Shakespearean: Approach and speak .

English: Humble as I am , I represent Antony .
Shakespearean: Such as I am , I come from Antony .

English: Until recently , I was as unimportant to his affairs as the morning dew is to the wide ocean .
Shakespearean: I was of late as petty to his ends As is the morn-dew on the myrtle leaf To his grand sea .

English: So be it .
Shakespearean: Be 't so .

English: Say what you're here for .
Shakespearean: Declare thine office .

English: If that is not granted , he reduces his requests and asks only that he be allowed to live as a private man in Athens .
Shakespearean: Lord of his fortunes he salutes thee , and Requires to live in Egypt ; which not granted , He lessens his requests , and to thee sues To let him breathe between the heavens and earth A private man in Athens .

English: That's all he asks for himself .
Shakespearean: This for him .

English: Cleopatra recognizes your greatness and accepts your authority .
Shakespearean: Next , Cleopatra does confess thy greatness , Submits her to thy might , and of thee craves The circle of the Ptolemies for her heirs , Now hazarded to thy grace .

English: As for Antony , I'm not interested in his requests .
Shakespearean: For Antony , I have no ears to his request .

English: I'll give the Queen a hearing and grant her requests if she either throws her dishonored friend out of Egypt or kills him .
Shakespearean: The Queen Of audience nor desire shall fail , so she From Egypt drive her all-disgraced friend Or take his life there .

English: Then I'll listen to her .
Shakespearean: This if she perform , She shall not sue unheard .

English: Give my answer to them both .
Shakespearean: So to them both .

English: May good luck follow you !
Shakespearean: Fortune pursue thee !

English: Take him safely through the lines .
Shakespearean: Bring him through the bands .

English: I go , Caesar .
Shakespearean: Caesar , I go .

English: Observe how Antony takes his defeat and how his attitude influences his actions .
Shakespearean: Observe how Antony becomes his flaw , And what thou think'st his very action speaks In every power that moves .

English: I will , Caesar .
Shakespearean: Caesar , I shall .

English: What are we going to do , Enobarbus ?
Shakespearean: What shall we do , Enobarbus ?

English: Think about our situation , then die .
Shakespearean: Think and die .

English: Who is to blame for this : Antony or I ?
Shakespearean: Is Antony or we in fault for this ?

English: Only Antony was at fault .
Shakespearean: Antony only , that would make his will Lord of his reason .

English: Why should he have followed you ?
Shakespearean: Why should he follow ?

English: With half the world opposing the other half , it wasn't the time for Antony , the pivotal player , to let love distract him .
Shakespearean: The itch of his affection should not then Have nicked his captainship at such a point When half to half the world opposed , he being The mered question .

English: To race after your departing ships , leaving his navy to watch , was a shame as great as the resulting loss .
Shakespearean: Twas a shame no less Than was his loss , to course your flying flags And leave his navy gazing .

English: Please , let's not talk about it .
Shakespearean: Prithee , peace .

English: Is that his answer ?
Shakespearean: Is that his answer ?

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my lord .

English: The Queen will be treated fairly if she gives me up ?
Shakespearean: The Queen shall then have courtesy , so she Will yield us up ?

English: That's what he says .
Shakespearean: He says so .

English: Tell her .
Shakespearean: Let her know 't. , And he will fill thy wishes to the brim With principalities .

English: Your head , my lord ?
Shakespearean: That head , my lord ?

English: A messenger has arrived from Caesar .
Shakespearean: A messenger from Caesar .

English: With no more ceremony than that ?
Shakespearean: What , no more ceremony ?

English: See , ladies , how they scorn me now .
Shakespearean: See , my women , Against the blown rose may they stop their nose , That kneeled unto the buds. , Admit him , sir .

English: I'll be at your service .
Shakespearean: At your noble pleasure .

English: He's waiting outside .
Shakespearean: He stays upon your will .

English: What's your message ?
Shakespearean: What are you ?

English: Your wife , Fulvia , is dead .
Shakespearean: Fulvia thy wife is dead .

English: Where did she die ?
Shakespearean: Where died she ?

English: In Sicyon .
Shakespearean: In Sicyon .

English: In this letter you'll find details of her illness and other , more serious matters that concern you .
Shakespearean: Her length of sickness , with what else more serious Importeth thee to know , this bears .

English: Leave me .
Shakespearean: Forbear me .

English: What does Caesar want ?
Shakespearean: Caesar's will ?

English: It is for your ears only .
Shakespearean: Hear it apart .

English: There are only friends here .
Shakespearean: None but friends .

English: Speak confidently .
Shakespearean: Say boldly .

English: So they are possibly Antony's friends .
Shakespearean: So haply are they friends to Antony .

English: Sir , he should have as many as Caesar has .
Shakespearean: He needs as many , sir , as Caesar has , Or needs not us .

English: If Caesar chose , Antony would jump at the chance to be his friend .
Shakespearean: If Caesar please , our master Will leap to be his friend .

English: As for us , you know we are Antony's , and he is Caesar's .
Shakespearean: For us , you know Whose he is we are , and that is Caesar's .

English: Just remember that he is Caesar .
Shakespearean: So. , Thus then , thou most renowned : Caesar entreats Not to consider in what case thou stand'st , Further than he is Caesar .

English: He knows that you didn't embrace Antony because you loved him , but because you feared him .
Shakespearean: He knows that you embrace not Antony As you did love , but as you feared him .

English: Oh !
Shakespearean: Oh !

English: He is like a god and knows the truth .
Shakespearean: He is a god and knows What is most right .

English: My honor wasn't given ; it was only dominated .
Shakespearean: Mine honor was not yielded , But conquered merely .

English: Shall I tell Caesar what you request from him ?
Shakespearean: Shall I say to Caesar What you require of him ?

English: He almost begs for the opportunity to help you .
Shakespearean: For he partly begs To be desired to give .

English: It would please him very much if you would rely on his wealth and success to support you .
Shakespearean: It much would please him That of his fortunes you should make a staff To lean upon .

English: But he would feel even better if I could tell him that you had left Antony and put yourself under his protection .
Shakespearean: But it would warm his spirits To hear from me you had left Antony And put yourself under his shroud , The universal landlord .

English: What's your name ?
Shakespearean: What's your name ?

English: My name is Thidias .
Shakespearean: My name is Thidias .

English: Most kind messenger , tell great Caesar that through his deputy I kiss his conquering hand .
Shakespearean: Most kind messenger , Say to great Caesar this in deputation : I kiss his conqu'ring hand .

English: Tell him I am ready to lay my crown at his feet and kneel before him .
Shakespearean: Tell him I am prompt To lay my crown at 's feet , and there to kneel .

English: Promising favors ?
Shakespearean: Favors ?

English: By Jove that thunders !
Shakespearean: By Jove that thunders !

English: Who are you , slave ?
Shakespearean: What art thou , fellow ?

English: You will be whipped .
Shakespearean: You will be whipped .

English: Take away this lout and whip him .
Shakespearean: Take hence this jack and whip him .

English: By the moon and stars !
Shakespearean: Moon and stars !

English: Whip him !
Shakespearean: Whip him .

English: If I saw twenty of the greatest powers that pay tribute to Caesar taking such liberties with her hand , what's her name now ?
Shakespearean: Were 't twenty of the greatest tributaries That do acknowledge Caesar , should I find them So saucy with the hand of she here , what's her name Since she was Cleopatra ?

English: Whip him , fellows , until he screws up his face like a baby and cries aloud for mercy !
Shakespearean: Whip him , fellows , Till like a boy , you see him cringe his face And whine aloud for mercy .

English: Take him away .
Shakespearean: Take him hence .

English: Caesar's knave will bring him a message for us .
Shakespearean: This jack of Caesar's shall Bear us an errand to him .

English: My good lord , You've always been a liar .
Shakespearean: Good my lord , You have been a boggler ever .

English: But when our vices become habits , Oh , the sadness of it ! , the wise gods blind us , shade our better judgment , make us love our mistakes , and laugh as we strut to our ruin .
Shakespearean: But when we in our viciousness grow hard , Oh , misery on 't ! , the wise gods seel our eyes , In our own filth drop our clear judgments , make us Adore our errors , laugh at 's while we strut To our confusion .

English: Oh , has it come to this ?
Shakespearean: Oh , is 't come to this ?

English: You were a cold crumb on dead Julius Caesar's plate when I met you .
Shakespearean: I found you as a morsel cold upon Dead Caesar's trencher .

English: No , you were one of Gneius Pompey's leftovers , not to mention your other , more depraved affairs , which have somehow managed to avoid becoming the subject of vulgar gossip .
Shakespearean: Nay , you were a fragment Of Gneius Pompey's , besides what hotter hours , Unregistered in vulgar fame , you have Luxuriously picked out .

English: For I'm sure that although you may know what temperance is , you've never experienced it firsthand .
Shakespearean: For I am sure , Though you can guess what temperance should be , You know not what it is .

English: Why are you doing this ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore is this ?

English: Soundly , my lord .
Shakespearean: Soundly , my lord .

English: Did he cry ?
Shakespearean: Cried he ?

English: Did he beg my pardon ?
Shakespearean: And begged he pardon ?

English: He did ask for mercy .
Shakespearean: He did ask favor .

English: Are you done yet ?
Shakespearean: Have you done yet ?

English: You , my earthly moon , are now eclipsed , and that alone foretells my ruin .
Shakespearean: Alack , our terrene moon is now eclipsed , And it portends alone the fall of Antony .

English: In order to flatter Caesar , would you flirt with the servant who laces up his pants ?
Shakespearean: To flatter Caesar , would you mingle eyes With one that ties his points ?

English: Don't you know me still ?
Shakespearean: Not know me yet ?

English: Has your heart cooled toward me ?
Shakespearean: Coldhearted toward me ?

English: Ah , dear , if that is true , let heaven make poisonous hail grow from my heart , and let the first hailstone drop down my throat .
Shakespearean: Ah , dear , if I be so , From my cold heart let heaven engender hail , And poison it in the source , and the first stone Drop in my neck .

English: As it dissolves , so shall my life .
Shakespearean: As it determines , so Dissolve my life !

English: The next hailstone should hit Caesarion , until one by one all my children , and every one of my brave Egyptians , are killed by the dissolving of this pellet storm and lie unburied , covered by gnats and flies .
Shakespearean: The next Caesarion smite , Till by degrees the memory of my womb , Together with my brave Egyptians all , By the discandying of this pelleted storm Lie graveless till the flies and gnats of Nile Have buried them for prey !

English: I am satisfied .
Shakespearean: I am satisfied .

English: I will fight him there .
Shakespearean: Caesar sits down in Alexandria , where I will oppose his fate .

English: Our land forces have bravely stood firm .
Shakespearean: Our force by land Hath nobly held .

English: Our tattered navy has reassembled and set sail , as formidable as the sea itself .
Shakespearean: Our severed navy too Have knit again , and fleet , threat'ning most sealike .

English: Where have you been , my bravery ?
Shakespearean: Where hast thou been , my heart ?

English: Do you hear what I say , lady ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou hear , lady ?

English: If I come back from the battlefield again to kiss those lips , I'll be covered in blood .
Shakespearean: If from the field I shall return once more To kiss these lips , I will appear in blood .

English: My sword and I will earn our place in history .
Shakespearean: I and my sword will earn our chronicle .

English: We still have hope .
Shakespearean: There's hope in 't yet .

English: That's my brave lord !
Shakespearean: That's my brave lord !

English: I'll fight brutally .
Shakespearean: I will be treble-sinewed , -hearted , -breathed , And fight maliciously .

English: But now I'll grit my teeth and kill anyone who tries to stop me .
Shakespearean: For when mine hours Were nice and lucky , men did ransom lives Of me for jests ; but now I'll set my teeth And send to darkness all that stop me .

English: Come , let's have one more extravagant night .
Shakespearean: Come , Let's have one other gaudy night .

English: Invite all my sad captains .
Shakespearean: Call to me All my sad captains .

English: Let's drink through midnight .
Shakespearean: Let's mock the midnight bell .

English: It's my birthday .
Shakespearean: It is my birthday .
