English: I had planned to celebrate it quietly , but since my lord is once more himself , I will be Cleopatra again .
Shakespearean: I had thought t' have held it poor ; but since my lord Is Antony again , I will be Cleopatra .

English: We'll win yet .
Shakespearean: We will yet do well .

English: Do so .
Shakespearean: Do so .

English: I'll speak to them , and then tonight I'll get them all so drunk that the wine seeps out of their old war wounds .
Shakespearean: We'll speak to them , and tonight I'll force The wine peep through their scars. , Come on , my Queen , There's sap in 't yet .

English: Now he'll work himself up to a fury .
Shakespearean: Now he'll outstare the lightning .

English: When courage consumes reason , it destroys its only weapon .
Shakespearean: When valor preys on reason , It eats the sword it fights with .

English: I'll look for some way to leave his service .
Shakespearean: I will seek Some way to leave him .

English: He calls me "boy" and scolds me as if he had the power to whip me out of Egypt .
Shakespearean: He calls me "boy" and chides as he had power To beat me out of Egypt .

English: Let the old ruffian discover that I have many other ways to die , and in the meantime , we'll laugh at his challenge .
Shakespearean: Let the old ruffian know I have many other ways to die , meantime Laugh at his challenge .

English: Don't give him time to catch his breath .
Shakespearean: Give him no breath , but now Make boot of his distraction .

English: Anger does not protect the angry well .
Shakespearean: Never anger Made good guard for itself .

English: Tell our top commanders that I want tomorrow's battle to be the last we fight .
Shakespearean: Let our best heads Know that tomorrow the last of many battles We mean to fight .

English: Our army has recently acquired many of Mark Antony's former soldiers , enough to capture him .
Shakespearean: Within our files there are , Of those that served Mark Antony but late , Enough to fetch him in .

English: See that it is done , and prepare a feast for the soldiers .
Shakespearean: See it done And feast the army .

English: We have enough supplies for it , and they've earned it .
Shakespearean: We have store to do 't , And they have earned the waste .

English: Poor Antony !
Shakespearean: Poor Antony !

English: What would you like , sir ?
Shakespearean: What's your pleasure , sir ?

English: I have to leave right away .
Shakespearean: I must with haste from hence .

English: That will kill our lovers .
Shakespearean: Why , then , we kill all our women .

English: We know how much they suffer if we are unkind to them .
Shakespearean: We see how mortal an unkindness is to them .

English: If we leave , it will feel like nothing less than death to them .
Shakespearean: If they suffer our departure , death's the word .

English: I must be gone .
Shakespearean: I must be gone .

English: If it's that important , then let the women die .
Shakespearean: Under a compelling occasion , let women die .

English: It would be a pity to throw them away for nothing , but if it's a matter of choosing between them and a great cause , then they're worthless .
Shakespearean: It were pity to cast them away for nothing , though between them and a great cause they should be esteemed nothing .

English: If Cleopatra hears even a breath of this , she'll die immediately .
Shakespearean: Cleopatra , catching but the least noise of this , dies instantly .

English: I've seen her claim to be dying twenty times before , and for far less reason .
Shakespearean: I have seen her die twenty times upon far poorer moment .

English: I think there must be something invigorating about death , since she dies with such enthusiasm .
Shakespearean: I do think there is mettle in death , which commits some loving act upon her , she hath such a celerity in dying .

English: She's more cunning than anyone can imagine .
Shakespearean: She is cunning past man's thought .

English: Her sighs and tears are like great winds and floods .
Shakespearean: We can not call her winds and waters sighs and tears .

English: He won't fight with me , Domitius ?
Shakespearean: He will not fight with me , Domitius ?

English: No .
Shakespearean: No .

English: Why won't he ?
Shakespearean: Why should he not ?

English: He thinks that since his fortune is twenty times better than yours , it would be like pitting twenty men against one .
Shakespearean: He thinks , being twenty times of better fortune , He is twenty men to one .

English: Tomorrow , soldier , I'll fight by sea and land .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow , soldier , By sea and land I'll fight .

English: By the end I will either live , or else I'll restore my honor by shedding my blood .
Shakespearean: Or I will live Or bathe my dying honor in the blood Shall make it live again .

English: Will you fight well ?
Shakespearean: Woo't thou fight well ?

English: When I strike , I'll cry , "All or nothing ! " Well put .
Shakespearean: I'll strike and cry , "Take all." Well said .

English: Come on .
Shakespearean: Come on !

English: Call out my household servants .
Shakespearean: Call forth my household servants .

English: Tonight let's have plenty to eat .
Shakespearean: Let's tonight Be bounteous at our meal .

English: You have all served me well , and kings are your peers .
Shakespearean: You have served me well , And kings have been your fellows .

English: The gods forbid !
Shakespearean: The gods forbid !

English: Well , my good fellows , wait on me tonight .
Shakespearean: Well , my good fellows , wait on me tonight .

English: Keep my cups full and treat me as you did when my empire was one of your fellow servants , obeying my commands .
Shakespearean: Scant not my cups , and make as much of me As when mine empire was your fellow too , And suffered my command .

English: Look , they're crying .
Shakespearean: Look , they weep , And I , an ass , am onion-eyed .

English: Ha , ha , ha !
Shakespearean: Ho , ho , ho !

English: May the evil one take me if I meant it like that !
Shakespearean: Now the witch take me if I meant it thus !

English: Those tears will bring blessings to you .
Shakespearean: Grace grow where those drops fall !

English: You interpret my words in a melancholy sense , my hearty friends .
Shakespearean: My hearty friends , You take me in too dolorous a sense , For I spake to you for your comfort , did desire you To burn this night with torches .

English: You should know , my friends , that I have good hopes for tomorrow , and that I will lead you as if I expect victory rather than an honorable death .
Shakespearean: Know , my hearts , I hope well of tomorrow , and will lead you Where rather I'll expect victorious life Than death and honor .

English: Good night , brother .
Shakespearean: Brother , good night .

English: Tomorrow is the day .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow is the day .

English: Have you heard about anything unusual happening in the city ?
Shakespearean: Heard you of nothing strange about the streets ?

English: No .
Shakespearean: Nothing .

English: What was it ?
Shakespearean: What news ?

English: It was probably just a rumor .
Shakespearean: Belike 'tis but a rumor .

English: Good night .
Shakespearean: Good night to you .

English: Well sir , good night .
Shakespearean: Well , sir , good night .

English: Soldiers , watch carefully .
Shakespearean: Soldiers , have careful watch .

English: You too .
Shakespearean: And you .

English: This is our station .
Shakespearean: Here we .

English: And if our navy wins tomorrow , no doubt our army will do their part .
Shakespearean: And if tomorrow Our navy thrive , I have an absolute hope Our landmen will stand up .

English: It's an outstanding army and highly motivated .
Shakespearean: Tis a brave army , and full of purpose .

English: Quiet !
Shakespearean: Peace !

English: What's that sound ?
Shakespearean: What noise ?

English: Listen !
Shakespearean: Hark !

English: There's music coming out of thin air .
Shakespearean: Music i' th' air .

English: From under the earth .
Shakespearean: Under the earth .

English: It's a lucky sign , isn't it ?
Shakespearean: It signs well , does it not ?

English: No .
Shakespearean: No .

English: Quiet , I say .
Shakespearean: Peace , I say !

English: What does this mean ?
Shakespearean: What should this mean ?

English: Hello there , good sirs .
Shakespearean: How now , masters ?

English: Yes .
Shakespearean: Ay .

English: Isn't it strange ?
Shakespearean: Is 't not strange ?

English: Do you hear that , men ?
Shakespearean: Do you hear , masters ?

English: Do you ?
Shakespearean: Do you hear ?

English: Let's follow the music as far as we can without leaving our station and see if it stops .
Shakespearean: Follow the noise so far as we have quarter ; Let's see how it will give off .

English: Good idea .
Shakespearean: Content .

English: It's very strange .
Shakespearean: Tis strange .

English: Get a little sleep .
Shakespearean: Sleep a little .

English: Come on , good fellow , help me into that armor you're carrying .
Shakespearean: Come , good fellow , put thine iron on .

English: If luck deserts us today , it's because we defy it .
Shakespearean: If fortune be not ours today , it is Because we brave her .

English: Come on .
Shakespearean: Come .

English: No , I'll help too .
Shakespearean: Nay , I'll help too .

English: What's this part for ?
Shakespearean: What's this for ?

English: Ah , leave it alone .
Shakespearean: Ah , let be , let be !

English: You armor my heart .
Shakespearean: Thou art The armorer of my heart .

English: No !
Shakespearean: False , false .

English: No !
Shakespearean: This , this .

English: Really , I'll help .
Shakespearean: Sooth , la , I'll help .

English: It must go like this .
Shakespearean: Thus it must be .

English: We've got it now. , Do you see this , my good fellow ?
Shakespearean: Well , well , We shall thrive now. , Seest thou , my good fellow ?

English: Go and put on your own armor .
Shakespearean: Go put on thy defenses .

English: In a minute , sir .
Shakespearean: Briefly , sir .

English: Didn't I buckle this well ?
Shakespearean: Is not this buckled well ?

English: Excellently , excellently .
Shakespearean: Rarely , rarely .

English: Hurry. , Oh , love , if you could only watch the battle today and see how expert I am at my craft .
Shakespearean: Dispatch. , O love , That thou couldst see my wars today , and knew'st The royal occupation !

English: Good morning to you .
Shakespearean: Good morrow to thee .

English: Welcome .
Shakespearean: Welcome .

English: You look like a person who knows the business of war .
Shakespearean: Thou look'st like him that knows a warlike charge .

English: When we love our job we get up early and go to it joyfully .
Shakespearean: To business that we love we rise betimes And go to 't with delight .

English: Even though it's early , there are already a thousand armored soldiers waiting for you at the harbor .
Shakespearean: A thousand , sir , Early though 't be , have on their riveted trim And at the port expect you .

English: The weather is fair .
Shakespearean: The morn is fair .

English: Good morning , General .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , General .

English: Good morning , General .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , General .

English: That was a fine fanfare , boys .
Shakespearean: Tis well blown , lads .

English: Like a young man who wants to amount to something , this morning begins early .
Shakespearean: This morning , like the spirit of a youth That means to be of note , begins betimes .

English: Farewell , lady .
Shakespearean: Fare thee well , dame .

English: Whatever happens to me , this is a soldier's kiss .
Shakespearean: Whate'er becomes of me , This is a soldier's kiss .

English: I'll leave you without revealing any emotion , like a man of steel .
Shakespearean: I'll leave thee Now like a man of steel .

English: Lead the way .
Shakespearean: Lead me .

English: He goes forth to war bravely .
Shakespearean: He goes forth gallantly .

English: May the gods bless Antony today !
Shakespearean: The gods make this a happy day to Antony !

English: I wish you and your scarred self had convinced me to wage our last battle on land .
Shakespearean: Would thou and those thy scars had once prevailed To make me fight at land !

English: If you had , the kings that have revolted and the soldier that deserted this morning would still be behind you .
Shakespearean: Hadst thou done so , The kings that have revolted , and the soldier That has this morning left thee , would have still Followed thy heels .

English: Who deserted this morning ?
Shakespearean: Who's gone this morning ?

English: You don't know ?
Shakespearean: Who ?

English: Someone who was always near you .
Shakespearean: One ever near thee .

English: Sir , he's with Caesar .
Shakespearean: Sir , He is with Caesar .

English: Sir , he left his belongings and treasure .
Shakespearean: Sir , his chests and treasure He has not with him .

English: He's gone ?
Shakespearean: Is he gone ?

English: It's certain .
Shakespearean: Most certain .

English: Eros , send his treasure to him .
Shakespearean: Go , Eros , send his treasure after .

English: Do it now .
Shakespearean: Do it .

English: Don't keep anything back , I insist .
Shakespearean: Detain no jot , I charge thee .

English: Write to him from me , I'll sign it , sending greetings and gentle good-byes .
Shakespearean: Write to him , I will subscribe , gentle adieus and greetings .

English: Say that I hope he never has cause to look for a new master .
Shakespearean: Say that I wish he never find more cause To change a master .

English: Oh , my bad luck has forced honest men to become traitors .
Shakespearean: Oh , my fortunes have Corrupted honest men !

English: Hurry .
Shakespearean: Dispatch. , Enobarbus !

English: Fulvia is dead .
Shakespearean: Fulvia is dead .

English: Pardon me ?
Shakespearean: Sir ?

English: Fulvia is dead .
Shakespearean: Fulvia is dead .

English: Fulvia ?
Shakespearean: Fulvia ?

English: Dead .
Shakespearean: Dead .

English: Then you should offer the gods a sacrifice to show your thanks .
Shakespearean: Why , sir , give the gods a thankful sacrifice .

English: If Fulvia were the last woman on earth , there would be a reason to grieve .
Shakespearean: If there were no more women but Fulvia , then had you indeed a cut , and the case to be lamented .

English: But in this way , grief and comfort appear together .
Shakespearean: This grief is crowned with consolation .

English: The only kind of tears you should shed in this case are the kind you might get from holding an onion to your nose .
Shakespearean: Your old smock brings forth a new petticoat , and indeed the tears live in an onion that should water this sorrow .

English: I must go and continue the business Fulvia started .
Shakespearean: The business she hath broached in the state Can not endure my absence .

English: The business you began here needs you as well , especially the business with Cleopatra , which only you can attend to .
Shakespearean: And the business you have broached here can not be without you , especially that of Cleopatra's , which wholly depends on your abode .

English: Enough of this frivolous talk .
Shakespearean: No more light answers .

English: Give our officers notice of our intentions .
Shakespearean: Let our officers Have notice what we purpose .

English: I'll tell the Queen the reason for our quick departure and get her permission to leave .
Shakespearean: I shall break The cause of our expedience to the Queen And get her leave to part .

English: Fulvia's death and the pressing concerns related to it are not the only reasons I am eager to go ; friends in Rome have also sent many letters advising my return .
Shakespearean: For not alone The death of Fulvia , with more urgent touches , Do strongly speak to us , but the letters too Of many our contriving friends in Rome Petition us at home .

English: The empire may be in danger if he's not restrained before he reaches his full potential .
Shakespearean: Much is breeding Which , like the courser's hair , hath yet but life , And not a serpent's poison .

English: There are many troubles brewing now that have yet to become full-fledged threats .
Shakespearean: Say our pleasure , To such whose place is under us , requires Our quick remove from hence .

English: Agrippa , go start the battle .
Shakespearean: Go forth , Agrippa , and begin the fight .

English: We want Antony taken alive .
Shakespearean: Our will is Antony be took alive .

English: Make sure everyone knows that .
Shakespearean: Make it so known .

English: I will , Caesar .
Shakespearean: Caesar , I shall .

English: An era of universal peace is about to start .
Shakespearean: The time of universal peace is near .

English: That way Antony will feel like he's fighting his own men .
Shakespearean: Go charge Agrippa Plant those that have revolted in the vant , That Antony may seem to spend his fury Upon himself .

English: Caesar hanged him for this service .
Shakespearean: For this pains Caesar hath hanged him .

English: Canidius and the others that left Antony are given hospitality here but no positions of trust .
Shakespearean: Canidius and the rest That fell away have entertainment but No honorable trust .

English: I've done a bad thing , for which I will blame myself so much that I'll never be happy again .
Shakespearean: I have done ill , Of which I do accuse myself so sorely That I will joy no more .

English: Enobarbus , Antony has sent you all your treasure , with generous gifts besides .
Shakespearean: Enobarbus , Antony Hath after thee sent all thy treasure , with His bounty overplus .

English: The messenger arrived on my watch and is unloading his mules at your tent .
Shakespearean: The messenger Came on my guard , and at thy tent is now Unloading of his mules .

English: It's yours .
Shakespearean: I give it you .

English: Don't joke about this , Enobarbus .
Shakespearean: Mock not , Enobarbus .

English: I'm telling you the truth .
Shakespearean: I tell you true .

English: You'd better bring the messenger safely through the lines so he can return .
Shakespearean: Best you safed the bringer Out of the host .

English: I'd do it myself , but I can't leave my post .
Shakespearean: I must attend mine office , Or would have done 't myself .

English: Your Emperor is still a king among gods .
Shakespearean: Your Emperor Continues still a Jove .

English: I am the worst person alive , and I know it the best .
Shakespearean: I am alone the villain of the earth , And feel I am so most .

English: Oh , Antony , you extravagantly generous man , how would you have rewarded me for serving you faithfully when you reward my badness with all of this gold !
Shakespearean: O Antony , Thou mine of bounty , how wouldst thou have paid My better service , when my turpitude Thou dost so crown with gold !

English: My heart feels like it's about to explode .
Shakespearean: This blows my heart .

English: If grief doesn't kill me , I'll find a quicker way to kill myself , even though I think grief will do the job just as well .
Shakespearean: If swift thought break it not , a swifter mean Shall outstrike thought , but thought will do 't , I feel .

English: I , fight against you , Antony ?
Shakespearean: I fight against thee ?

English: No , I'll go find some ditch to die in .
Shakespearean: No , I will go seek Some ditch wherein to die .

English: The foulest fate would be most appropriate for me now in this latest phase of my life .
Shakespearean: The foul'st best fits My latter part of life .

English: Retreat !
Shakespearean: Retire !

English: We've advanced too far .
Shakespearean: We have engaged ourselves too far .

English: Caesar himself is in trouble and there are more adversaries than we expected .
Shakespearean: Caesar himself has work , and our oppression Exceeds what we expected .

English: Oh , my brave Emperor , this is what I call a fight !
Shakespearean: O my brave Emperor , this is fought indeed !

English: If we'd fought like this before , we'd have driven them home with bandaged heads .
Shakespearean: Had we done so at first , we had droven them home With clouts about their heads .

English: You're bleeding a lot .
Shakespearean: Thou bleed'st apace .

English: I had a scar here that looked like a "T" ; now it's an "H." They're retreating .
Shakespearean: I had a wound here that was like a "T , " But now 'tis made an "H." They do retire .

English: We'll chase 'em into their latrines .
Shakespearean: We'll beat 'em into bench-holes .

English: I still have room for six more wounds .
Shakespearean: I have yet Room for six scotches more .

English: They're retreating , sir , and our superiority indicates a clear victory .
Shakespearean: They are beaten , sir , and our advantage serves For a fair victory .

English: Let's slash their backs and grab 'em like we do rabbits , from behind .
Shakespearean: Let us score their backs And snatch 'em up , as we take hares , behind !

English: It's fair game to mark a coward .
Shakespearean: Tis sport to maul a runner .

English: I'll reward you once for your cheerfulness and ten times for your courage .
Shakespearean: I will reward thee Once for thy sprightly comfort and tenfold For thy good valor .

English: Come on .
Shakespearean: Come thee on .

English: I'll limp after you .
Shakespearean: I'll halt after .

English: We've driven him all the way back to his camp .
Shakespearean: We have beat him to his camp .

English: One of you run to the Queen with the news .
Shakespearean: Run one before And let the Queen know of our gests .

English: Before sunrise tomorrow , we'll kill anyone who escaped today .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow , Before the sun shall see 's , we'll spill the blood That has today escaped .

English: You are all Lord of lords !
Shakespearean: Lord of lords !

English: Have you returned smiling from the great battle for the world ?
Shakespearean: O infinite virtue , com'st thou smiling from The world's great snare uncaught ?

English: My songbird , we have beaten them to their beds .
Shakespearean: Mine nightingale , We have beat them to their beds .

English: What do you think , girl !
Shakespearean: What , girl , though gray Do something mingle with our younger brown , yet ha' we A brain that nourishes our nerves and can Get goal for goal of youth .

English: Look at this man .
Shakespearean: Behold this man .

English: Today he fought as though he were a god who hated mankind .
Shakespearean: He hath fought today As if a god , in hate of mankind , had Destroyed in such a shape .

English: He deserves it , even if it were covered with jewels like holy
Shakespearean: He has deserved it , were it carbuncled Like holy Phoebus' car .

English: If we aren't relieved in an hour , we have to return to our barracks .
Shakespearean: If we be not relieved within this hour , We must return to th' court of guard .

English: Oh , listen to me , night , Who is this ?
Shakespearean: O bear me witness , night , What man is this ?

English: Stay hidden and listen .
Shakespearean: Stand close and list him .

English: Be my witness , oh you blessed moon .
Shakespearean: Be witness to me , O thou blessed moon , When men revolted shall upon record Bear hateful memory , poor Enobarbus did Before thy face repent .

English: That's Enobarbus ?
Shakespearean: Enobarbus ?

English: Quiet !
Shakespearean: Peace !

English: Keep listening .
Shakespearean: Hark further .

English: My heart , which dried out with grief , will surely break apart into a powder , and that will be the end of my disgusting mind .
Shakespearean: Throw my heart Against the flint and hardness of my fault , Which , being dried with grief , will break to powder And finish all foul thoughts .

English: Oh , Antony !
Shakespearean: O Antony !

English: Let's speak to him .
Shakespearean: Let's speak to him .

English: Let's listen to him .
Shakespearean: Let's hear him , for the things he speaks may concern Caesar .

English: Good idea .
Shakespearean: Let's do so .

English: But he's sleeping .
Shakespearean: But he sleeps .

English: No one ever gave a prayer like that before going to sleep .
Shakespearean: Swoons rather , for so bad a prayer as his Was never yet for sleep .

English: Let's go to him .
Shakespearean: Go we to him .

English: Wake up , sir , wake up .
Shakespearean: Awake , sir , awake .

English: Speak to us .
Shakespearean: Speak to us .

English: Do you hear us , sir ?
Shakespearean: Hear you , sir ?

English: The hand of death has taken him .
Shakespearean: The hand of death hath raught him .

English: Let's carry him to the barracks .
Shakespearean: Let us bear him To th' court of guard .

English: He's an important person .
Shakespearean: He is of note .

English: Our hour is up .
Shakespearean: Our hour Is fully out .

English: Come on , then .
Shakespearean: Come on , then .

English: He may recover yet .
Shakespearean: He may recover yet .

English: I will .
Shakespearean: I shall do 't .

English: They've switched their operation to the sea today .
Shakespearean: Their preparation is today by sea .

English: We didn't please them on land .
Shakespearean: We please them not by land .

English: We're ready for both , my lord .
Shakespearean: For both , my lord .

English: I wish they'd fight in fire or in the air .
Shakespearean: I would they'd fight i' th' fire or i' th' air , We'd fight there too .

English: But here's the plan : our army will stay with us on the hills by the city .
Shakespearean: But this it is : our foot Upon the hills adjoining to the city Shall stay with us .

English: Let's take up the best positions we can in the valleys .
Shakespearean: To the vales , And hold our best advantage .

English: They still haven't joined the battle .
Shakespearean: Yet they are not joined .

English: I'll be able to see better from that pine tree over there .
Shakespearean: Where yond pine does stand I shall discover all .

English: I'll let you know right away how it's going .
Shakespearean: I'll bring thee word Straight how 'tis like to go .

English: Swallows have built nests in Cleopatra's sails .
Shakespearean: Swallows have built In Cleopatra's sails their nests .

English: All is lost !
Shakespearean: All is lost !

English: This treacherous Egyptian has betrayed me .
Shakespearean: This foul Egyptian hath betrayed me .

English: Three-time traitor and whore !
Shakespearean: Triple-turned whore !

English: Tell the army to flee .
Shakespearean: Bid them all fly , For when I am revenged upon my charm , I have done all .

English: Order them to escape .
Shakespearean: Bid them all fly .

English: Go !
Shakespearean: Begone !

English: Oh , sun , I will never see another one of your sunrises .
Shakespearean: O sun , thy uprise shall I see no more .

English: Luck and Antony separate here and now .
Shakespearean: Fortune and Antony part here .

English: Here we'll shake hands good-bye .
Shakespearean: Even here Do we shake hands .

English: Is it all come to this ?
Shakespearean: All come to this ?

English: I've been stripped of everything , betrayed .
Shakespearean: Betrayed I am .

English: Oh , that devious Egyptian spirit !
Shakespearean: Oh , this false soul of Egypt !

English: Ah , you sorceress !
Shakespearean: Ah , thou spell !

English: Be gone !
Shakespearean: Avaunt !

English: Why is my lord enraged against his love ?
Shakespearean: Why is my lord enraged against his love ?

English: Get out of my sight , or I'll give you what you deserve and spoil Caesar's victory .
Shakespearean: Vanish , or I shall give thee thy deserving , And blemish Caesar's triumph .

English: Let him hoist you up in front of the shouting crowds !
Shakespearean: Let him take thee And hoist thee up to the shouting plebeians !

English: Follow his chariot , like the greatest disgrace to your whole gender .
Shakespearean: Follow his chariot , like the greatest spot Of all thy sex .

English: Then let Octavia dig up your face with her nails .
Shakespearean: Most monsterlike be shown For poor'st diminutives , for dolts , and let Patient Octavia plow thy visage up With her prepared nails !

English: She'll die for it. , Eros , ho !
Shakespearean: She dies for 't. , Eros , ho !

English: Help me , ladies !
Shakespearean: Help me , my women !

English: Go to your tomb !
Shakespearean: To th' monument !

English: Lock yourself in and send him word that you're dead .
Shakespearean: There lock yourself and send him word you are dead .

English: When a great person departs , it causes more pain than when the soul leaves the body .
Shakespearean: The soul and body rive not more in parting Than greatness going off .

English: Say the last word I spoke was "Antony , " and please word it pathetically .
Shakespearean: Say that the last I spoke was "Antony , " And word it , prithee , piteously .

English: Go , Mardian , and let me know how he reacts to my death .
Shakespearean: Hence , Mardian , And bring me how he takes my death .

English: Eros , can you still see me ?
Shakespearean: Eros , thou yet behold'st me ?

English: Yes , noble lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , noble lord .

English: You've seen these illusions .
Shakespearean: Thou hast seen these signs .

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my lord .

English: What looks like a horse is quick as thought disfigured by the wind , made as difficult to distinguish as water poured into water .
Shakespearean: That which is now a horse , even with a thought The rack dislimns and makes it indistinct As water is in water .

English: That's true , my lord .
Shakespearean: It does , my lord .

English: Eros , my young friend , your captain is now just like that cloud .
Shakespearean: My good knave Eros , now thy captain is Even such a body .

English: Here and now I seem like Antony , but I can't keep myself in this form , my boy .
Shakespearean: Here I am Antony , Yet can not hold this visible shape , my knave .

English: No , don't cry , kind Eros .
Shakespearean: Nay , weep not , gentle Eros .

English: Oh , your contemptible lady !
Shakespearean: Oh , thy vile lady !

English: She has disarmed me .
Shakespearean: She has robbed me of my sword .

English: Get out , insolent eunuch !
Shakespearean: Hence , saucy eunuch !

English: Silence !
Shakespearean: Peace !

English: She has betrayed me and shall die .
Shakespearean: She hath betrayed me and shall die the death .

English: A person can only pay with their life once , and she has paid in full .
Shakespearean: Death of one person can be paid but once , And that she has discharged .

English: What you wanted is yours .
Shakespearean: What thou wouldst do Is done unto thy hand .

English: Most noble Antony ! " Then , as she was speaking your name , a strangled groan split her words .
Shakespearean: The last she spake Was "Antony , most noble Antony ! " Then in the midst a tearing groan did break The name of Antony .

English: Antony" was divided between her heart and lips .
Shakespearean: It was divided Between her heart and lips .

English: She gave up her life with your name still within her .
Shakespearean: She rendered life , Thy name so buried in her .

English: Is she dead , then ?
Shakespearean: Dead , then ?

English: Dead .
Shakespearean: Dead .

English: Remove your armor , Eros .
Shakespearean: Unarm , Eros .

English: Off !
Shakespearean: Go .

English: Take off my armor .
Shakespearean: Off , pluck off !

English: Oh , chest , obey me !
Shakespearean: O , cleave , my sides !

English: Heart , for once be stronger than all the rest of the body combined .
Shakespearean: Heart , once be stronger than thy continent .

English: Faster , Eros , faster .
Shakespearean: Crack thy frail case ! , Apace , Eros , apace .

English: I won't be a soldier anymore .
Shakespearean: No more a soldier .

English: Battered armor , be off .
Shakespearean: Bruised pieces , go .

English: You were worn with honor .
Shakespearean: You have been nobly borne .

English: I will catch up with you , Cleopatra , and weep for your forgiveness .
Shakespearean: I will o'ertake thee , Cleopatra , and Weep for my pardon .

English: Since the light of my life has gone out , I'll stop here .
Shakespearean: Since the torch is out , Lie down and stray no farther .

English: Now any effort ruins what it attempts .
Shakespearean: Now all labor Mars what it does .

English: Yes , even power gets in its own way .
Shakespearean: Yea , very force entangles Itself with strength .

English: End it , then , and everything is over. , Eros ! , I'm coming , my Queen ! , Eros ! , Wait for me .
Shakespearean: Seal then , and all is done. , Eros ! , I come , my Queen. , Eros ! , Stay for me .

English: In the place where souls recline on beds of flowers we'll walk hand in hand and amaze the other ghosts with our spirited demeanor .
Shakespearean: Where souls do couch on flowers , we'll hand in hand , And with our sprightly port make the ghosts gaze .

English: Eros !
Shakespearean: Dido and her Aeneas shall want troops , And all the haunt be ours. , Come , Eros , Eros !

English: What can I do for my lord ?
Shakespearean: What would my lord ?

English: Since Cleopatra died , I have lived in such dishonor that the gods despise my disgrace .
Shakespearean: Since Cleopatra died I have lived in such dishonor that the gods Detest my baseness .

English: Do it .
Shakespearean: Do 't .

English: This is that time .
Shakespearean: The time is come .

English: You won't be striking me down , but defeating Caesar .
Shakespearean: Thou strik'st not me , 'tis Caesar thou defeat'st .

English: Call up your courage .
Shakespearean: Put color in thy cheek .

English: The gods forbid !
Shakespearean: The gods withhold me !

English: Can I do what all the Parthian arrows , though shot by enemies , could not ?
Shakespearean: Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts , Though enemy , lost aim and could not ?

English: Eros , would you like to look through a window in Rome and watch your master marching in Caesar's victory parade , his arms crossed and tied , his head bowed in submission , his face red from shame , while the chariot of triumphant Caesar precedes him , putting the final stamp to his humiliation ?
Shakespearean: Eros , Wouldst thou be windowed in great Rome and see Thy master thus with pleached arms , bending down His corrigible neck , his face subdued To penetrative shame , whilst the wheeled seat Of fortunate Caesar , drawn before him , branded His baseness that ensued ?

English: I would not .
Shakespearean: I would not see 't .

English: Draw your trustworthy sword , which you have used in such service to your country .
Shakespearean: Draw that thy honest sword , which thou hast worn Most useful for thy country .

English: Oh , sir , pardon me !
Shakespearean: O sir , pardon me !

English: When I freed you from slavery , didn't you swear to do this when I asked you ?
Shakespearean: When I did make thee free , swor'st thou not then To do this when I bade thee ?

English: Do it immediately , or all your previous services to me were accidental , without purpose .
Shakespearean: Do it at once , Or thy precedent services are all But accidents unpurposed .

English: Take out your sword and come on .
Shakespearean: Draw and come .

English: Then turn your noble face away from me , that face that the whole world adores .
Shakespearean: Turn from me then that noble countenance Wherein the worship of the whole world lies .

English: Look !
Shakespearean: Lo thee !

English: Where is he ?
Shakespearean: Where is he ?

English: I haven't seen him recently .
Shakespearean: I did not see him since .

English: What should I do that I'm not doing ?
Shakespearean: What should I do I do not ?

English: Always give him his way .
Shakespearean: In each thing give him way .

English: Never contradict him .
Shakespearean: Cross him in nothing .

English: Don't push him too far .
Shakespearean: Tempt him not so too far .

English: I wish you'd be patient .
Shakespearean: I wish , forbear .

English: We come to hate that which controls us .
Shakespearean: In time we hate that which we often fear .

English: But here comes Antony .
Shakespearean: But here comes Antony .

English: I am sick and sullen .
Shakespearean: I am sick and sullen .

English: I'm sorry to have to say this , Help me away from here , dear Charmian !
Shakespearean: I am sorry to give breathing to my purpose , Help me away , dear Charmian !

English: I shall faint .
Shakespearean: I shall fall .

English: I have drawn my sword .
Shakespearean: My sword is drawn .

English: My dear master , my captain , my sovereign , let me say before I strike this fatal blow : farewell .
Shakespearean: My dear master , My captain , and my emperor , let me say , Before I strike this bloody stroke , farewell .

English: You've said it , friend , and farewell to you .
Shakespearean: Tis said , man , and farewell .

English: Good-bye , great commander .
Shakespearean: Farewell , great chief .

English: Should I do it now ?
Shakespearean: Shall I strike now ?

English: Now , Eros .
Shakespearean: Now , Eros .

English: Well , then , there !
Shakespearean: Why , there then !

English: With this I avoid the grief of Antony's death .
Shakespearean: Thus I do escape the sorrow Of Antony's death .

English: My Queen and Eros have by their brave examples beaten me to the history books .
Shakespearean: My Queen and Eros Have by their brave instruction got upon me A nobleness in record .

English: I learned to do this from you .
Shakespearean: To do thus I learned of thee .

English: What !
Shakespearean: How !

English: I'm not dead ?
Shakespearean: Not dead ?

English: Oh , kill me !
Shakespearean: Oh , dispatch me !

English: What's the trouble ?
Shakespearean: What's the noise ?

English: I've botched the job , friends .
Shakespearean: I have done my work ill , friends .

English: Oh , finish what I've begun .
Shakespearean: Oh , make an end Of what I have begun !

English: Our guiding light is out .
Shakespearean: The star is fall'n .

English: And time itself is ended .
Shakespearean: And time is at his period .

English: Sadness and despair !
Shakespearean: Alas , and woe !

English: Whoever's a real friend should strike me dead .
Shakespearean: Let him that loves me strike me dead .

English: Not me .
Shakespearean: Not I .

English: Me neither .
Shakespearean: Nor I .

English: None of us .
Shakespearean: Nor anyone .

English: Your death and destiny advise your followers to escape .
Shakespearean: Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly .

English: I only need to show your sword to Caesar and tell him about your death to get into his good favor .
Shakespearean: This sword but shown to Caesar , with this tidings , Shall enter me with him .

English: Where's Antony ?
Shakespearean: Where's Antony ?

English: There , Diomedes , there .
Shakespearean: There , Diomed , there .

English: Is he still alive ?
Shakespearean: Lives he ?

English: Why don't you answer me , man ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou not answer , man ?

English: Is that you , Diomedes ?
Shakespearean: Art thou there , Diomed ?

English: Draw your sword and give me enough blows to kill me .
Shakespearean: Draw thy sword and give me Sufficing strokes for death .

English: Most powerful lord , my mistress Cleopatra sent me to you .
Shakespearean: Most absolute lord , My mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee .

English: When did she send you ?
Shakespearean: When did she send thee ?

English: Just now , my lord .
Shakespearean: Now , my lord .

English: Where is she ?
Shakespearean: Where is she ?

English: Locked in her tomb .
Shakespearean: Locked in her monument .

English: She had a premonition of what has actually happened .
Shakespearean: She had a prophesying fear Of what hath come to pass .

English: Afraid that your anger would not subside , she sent you word she was dead .
Shakespearean: For when she saw , Which never shall be found , you did suspect She had disposed with Caesar , and that your rage Would not be purged , she sent you word she was dead .

English: Too late , good Diomedes .
Shakespearean: Too late , good Diomed .

English: Call my guard , please .
Shakespearean: Call my guard , I prithee .

English: Hey out there !
Shakespearean: What ho , the Emperor's guard !

English: Carry me , good friends , to where Cleopatra is .
Shakespearean: Bear me , good friends , where Cleopatra bides .

English: It's the last command I shall ever give you .
Shakespearean: Tis the last service that I shall command you .

English: We're very sorry , sir , that you may not live to wear us out with your commands .
Shakespearean: Woe , woe are we , sir , you may not live to wear All your true followers out .

English: It's a very sad day .
Shakespearean: Most heavy day !

English: No , my friends , don't please fate by giving it your sorrow as well .
Shakespearean: Nay , good my fellows , do not please sharp fate To grace it with your sorrows .

English: If we welcome our punishment , we punish it right back by seeming to take it lightly .
Shakespearean: Bid that welcome Which comes to punish us , and we punish it , Seeming to bear it lightly .

English: Pick me up .
Shakespearean: Take me up .

English: I have often led you , now you must carry me , my good friends , and take my thanks for everything .
Shakespearean: I have led you oft ; carry me now , good friends , And have my thanks for all .

English: Oh , Charmian , I will never leave this tomb !
Shakespearean: O Charmian , I will never go from hence .

English: Be calm , dear lady .
Shakespearean: Be comforted , dear madam .

English: No , I won't .
Shakespearean: No , I will not .

English: Strange and terrible events are all welcome , but I despise comforts .
Shakespearean: All strange and terrible events are welcome , But comforts we despise .

English: The size of my sorrow must be as great as its source .
Shakespearean: Our size of sorrow , Proportioned to our cause , must be as great As that which makes it .

English: What's the news !
Shakespearean: How now ?

English: Is he dead ?
Shakespearean: Is he dead ?

English: He is close to death , but not dead yet .
Shakespearean: His death's upon him , but not dead .

English: Oh , Antony , Antony , Antony !
Shakespearean: O Antony , Antony , Antony !

English: Help , Charmian , help , Iras , help !
Shakespearean: Help , Charmian , help , Iras , help !

English: Be calm !
Shakespearean: Peace !

English: It was not Caesar's bravery that conquered Antony but Antony's that has triumphed over himself .
Shakespearean: Not Caesar's valor hath o'erthrown Antony , But Antony's hath triumphed on itself .

English: That's the way it should be , only Antony should conquer Antony .
Shakespearean: So it should be , that none but Antony Should conquer Antony , but woe 'tis so !

English: No , our general's infatuation is out of control .
Shakespearean: Nay , but this dotage of our general's O'erflows the measure .

English: His eyes used to glow with pride when he reviewed his troops .
Shakespearean: Those his goodly eyes , That o'er the files and musters of the war Have glowed like plated Mars , now bend , now turn The office and devotion of their view Upon a tawny front .

English: His heart used to burst the buckles on his breastplate in great fights , but now he's lost all temperance and dedicates his heart to satisfying the lust of an Egyptian whore .
Shakespearean: His captain's heart , Which in the scuffles of great fights hath burst The buckles on his breast , reneges all temper And is become the bellows and the fan To cool a gypsy's lust .

English: Look at them .
Shakespearean: Look where they come .

English: Take a good look , and you'll see that one of the three men who rule the world has turned into a whore's jester .
Shakespearean: Take but good note , and you shall see in him The triple pillar of the world transformed Into a strumpet's fool .

English: Look and see .
Shakespearean: Behold and see .

English: If what you feel is really love , tell me how much .
Shakespearean: If it be love indeed , tell me how much .

English: It would be a pretty stingy love if it could be counted and calculated .
Shakespearean: There's beggary in the love that can be reckoned .

English: I want to measure the extent of your love , to see how far it stretches .
Shakespearean: I'll set a bourn how far to be beloved .

English: Then you would have to go beyond heaven , beyond earth .
Shakespearean: Then must thou needs find out new heaven , new earth .

English: I have news from Rome , my good lord .
Shakespearean: News , my good lord , from Rome .

English: I am dying , Cleopatra , dying .
Shakespearean: I am dying , Egypt , dying .

English: I just beg death to wait awhile , until I place the last of our many thousands of kisses on your lips .
Shakespearean: Only I here importune death awhile , until Of many thousand kisses the poor last I lay upon thy lips .

English: I don't dare come down , forgive me , my lord , I don't dare , for fear of capture .
Shakespearean: I dare not , dear , Dear my lord , pardon , I dare not , Lest I be taken .

English: I will never be exhibited as lucky Caesar's prize .
Shakespearean: Not th' imperious show Of the full-fortuned Caesar ever shall Be brooched with me .

English: If knives , poison , or snakes have edge , effect , or venom , I am safe from that fate .
Shakespearean: If knife , drugs , serpents , have Edge , sting , or operation , I am safe .

English: Your wife Octavia , with her self-effacing eyes and self-righteous assumptions , won't get any praise from patronizing me .
Shakespearean: Your wife Octavia , with her modest eyes And still conclusion , shall acquire no honor Demuring upon me .

English: Help us , good friends .
Shakespearean: Assist , good friends .

English: Oh , quick , before I'm gone .
Shakespearean: Oh , quick , or I am gone .

English: Such exercise !
Shakespearean: Here's sport indeed !

English: My lord is so heavy !
Shakespearean: How heavy weighs my lord !

English: If I had the goddess Juno's power , I would make the strong-winged messenger , Mercury , pick you up and seat you beside Jove .
Shakespearean: Had I great Juno's power , The strong-winged Mercury should fetch thee up And set thee by Jove's side .

English: And welcome , welcome !
Shakespearean: And welcome , welcome !

English: Die where you have lived , in my arms .
Shakespearean: Die when thou hast lived .

English: If my lips had the power to give life , I would wear them out like this .
Shakespearean: Had my lips that power , Thus would I wear them out .

English: What a sad sight !
Shakespearean: A heavy sight !

English: I am dying , Cleopatra , dying .
Shakespearean: I am dying , Egypt , dying .

English: Give me some wine and let me say a few words .
Shakespearean: Give me some wine and let me speak a little .

English: I'll trust my determination and my hands , but none of Caesar's men .
Shakespearean: My resolution and my hands I'll trust , None about Caesar .

English: Now I feel my soul leaving .
Shakespearean: Now my spirit is going .

English: I can't speak any more .
Shakespearean: I can no more .

English: Most noble man , will you die ?
Shakespearean: Noblest of men , woo't die ?

English: Don't you care about me ?
Shakespearean: Hast thou no care of me ?

English: Shall I stay in this dreary world , which is no better than a pigsty without you ?
Shakespearean: Shall I abide In this dull world , which in thy absence is No better than a sty ?

English: My lord !
Shakespearean: My lord !

English: Oh , the glory of war has faded .
Shakespearean: Oh , withered is the garland of the war .

English: The flags have fallen .
Shakespearean: The soldier's pole is fall'n !

English: Young boys and girls are equal to men .
Shakespearean: Young boys and girls Are level now with men .

English: There is nothing distinctive , nothing remarkable left in the world .
Shakespearean: The odds is gone , And there is nothing left remarkable Beneath the visiting moon .

English: Our Queen is dead too .
Shakespearean: She's dead too , our sovereign .

English: Lady !
Shakespearean: Lady !

English: Madam !
Shakespearean: Madam !

English: Oh , madam , madam , madam !
Shakespearean: O madam , madam , madam !

English: Royal Egypt , Empress !
Shakespearean: Royal Egypt , Empress !

English: Quiet , quiet , Iras .
Shakespearean: Peace , peace , Iras .

English: Now I am no more than a woman , ruled by the same lowly passion as the maid who milks and does the humblest chores .
Shakespearean: No more but e'en a woman , and commanded By such poor passion as the maid that milks And does the meanest chares .

English: Now all is for nothing .
Shakespearean: All's but naught .

English: How are you , my ladies ?
Shakespearean: How do you , women ?

English: Cheer up !
Shakespearean: What , what , good cheer !

English: How are you , Charmian ?
Shakespearean: Why , how now , Charmian ?

English: My gallant girls !
Shakespearean: My noble girls !

English: Good noble ladies , be brave .
Shakespearean: Good sirs , take heart .

English: We'll bury him , and then we'll commit acts as brave and fine as any Romans , and make death proud to take us .
Shakespearean: We'll bury him , and then , what's brave , what's noble , Let's do 't after the high Roman fashion And make death proud to take us .

English: Come on , you can go .
Shakespearean: Come , away .

English: The container of that great soul is now cold .
Shakespearean: This case of that huge spirit now is cold .

English: Ah , ladies , ladies !
Shakespearean: Ah , women , women !

English: Let's go .
Shakespearean: Come .

English: We have no friends but determination and the quickest death .
Shakespearean: We have no friend But resolution , and the briefest end .

English: Tell him to surrender .
Shakespearean: Go to him , Dolabella , bid him yield .

English: His position is hopeless .
Shakespearean: Being so frustrate , tell him , he mocks The pauses that he makes .

English: Right away , Caesar .
Shakespearean: Caesar , I shall .

English: What are you doing with a sword ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore is that ?

English: Who do you think you are coming in here armed ?
Shakespearean: And what art thou that dar'st Appear thus to us ?

English: My name is Decretus .
Shakespearean: I am called Dercetus .

English: I served Mark Antony , who was the commander most worthy of my services .
Shakespearean: Mark Antony I served , who best was worthy Best to be served .

English: While he was alive , I lived only to serve him and oppose his enemies .
Shakespearean: Whilst he stood up and spoke , He was my master , and I wore my life To spend upon his haters .

English: If not , you can kill me .
Shakespearean: If thou pleasest not , I yield thee up my life .

English: What are you saying ?
Shakespearean: What is 't thou say'st ?

English: Caesar , I'm telling you that Antony is dead .
Shakespearean: I say , O Caesar , Antony is dead .

English: When such a great man dies there should be a thunderclap .
Shakespearean: The breaking of so great a thing should make A greater crack .

English: The fractured world , in its confusion , should send lions into the city streets and humans into the wilderness to live in lions' dens .
Shakespearean: The round world Should have shook lions into civil streets And citizens to their dens .

English: This isn't the death of one man .
Shakespearean: The death of Antony Is not a single doom .

English: It's the death of half the world .
Shakespearean: In the name lay A moiety of the world .

English: Now , my dearest Queen , Please , stand farther away from me .
Shakespearean: Now , my dearest Queen , Pray you , stand farther from me .

English: What's the matter ?
Shakespearean: What's the matter ?

English: I can see in your eyes there's been some good news .
Shakespearean: I know by that same eye there's some good news .

English: What , does your wife say you can come home ?
Shakespearean: What , says the married woman you may go ?

English: I wish she'd never let you come .
Shakespearean: Would she had never given you leave to come !

English: Don't let her say I kept you .
Shakespearean: Let her not say 'tis I that keep you here .

English: I have no power over you .
Shakespearean: I have no power upon you .

English: You belong to her .
Shakespearean: Hers you are .

English: The gods know , Oh , never has a queen been so betrayed as I have been .
Shakespearean: The gods best know , Oh never was there queen So mightily betrayed !

English: I knew from the first it would be this way .
Shakespearean: Yet at the first I saw the treasons planted .

English: Cleopatra , How could I have ever thought that you would be faithful and true , even though your vows of love shook the heavens themselves , you , who were unfaithful to Fulvia ?
Shakespearean: Cleopatra , Why should I think you can be mine , and true , Though you in swearing shake the throned gods , Who have been false to Fulvia ?

English: It was wild insanity to believe promises made by the mouth and not the heart .
Shakespearean: Riotous madness , To be entangled with those mouth-made vows Which break themselves in swearing !

English: When you begged to stay , that was the time for words .
Shakespearean: When you sued staying , Then was the time for words .

English: You didn't want to go then !
Shakespearean: No going then !

English: You saw eternity in my lips and eyes , and happiness in the arch of my eyebrows .
Shakespearean: Eternity was in our lips and eyes , Bliss in our brows' bent , none our parts so poor But was a race of heaven .

English: My features are still that beautiful , or else you , the greatest soldier in the world , have become the greatest liar by overpraising them .
Shakespearean: They are so still , Or thou , the greatest soldier of the world , Art turned the greatest liar .

English: This is his sword .
Shakespearean: This is his sword .

English: I pulled it from his wound .
Shakespearean: I robbed his wound of it .

English: Look , his noble blood is still on it .
Shakespearean: Behold it stained With his most noble blood .

English: Listen , sad friends , though the gods may rebuke me , this news would make kings cry .
Shakespearean: Look you , sad friends , The gods rebuke me , but it is tidings To wash the eyes of kings .

English: His faults were equally matched by his virtues .
Shakespearean: His taints and honors Waged equal with him .

English: But gods , you give us faults so we'll be human .
Shakespearean: A rarer spirit never Did steer humanity , but you gods will give us Some faults to make us men .

English: Caesar is upset .
Shakespearean: Caesar is touched .

English: Either I had to ruin you , or you would have ruined me .
Shakespearean: I must perforce Have shown to thee such a declining day , Or look on thine .

English: Let me tell you , friends ,
Shakespearean: Hear me , good friends ,

English: I'll tell you at a better time .
Shakespearean: But I will tell you at some meeter season .

English: This man looks like his business is urgent .
Shakespearean: The business of this man looks out of him .

English: Let's hear what he has to say .
Shakespearean: We'll hear him what he says .

English: Tell her to put her mind at rest .
Shakespearean: Bid her have good heart .

English: She'll find out soon enough by one of our messengers how respectfully and kindly we plan to treat her .
Shakespearean: She soon shall know of us , by some of ours , How honorable and how kindly we Determine for her , for Caesar can not live To be ungentle .

English: May the gods bless you .
Shakespearean: So the gods preserve thee !

English: Come here , Proculeius .
Shakespearean: Come hither , Proculeius .

English: Tell her we mean her no disrespect .
Shakespearean: Go and say We purpose her no shame .

English: Go , and hurry back to bring us her reply and news of her state of mind .
Shakespearean: Go , And with your speediest bring us what she says And how you find of her .

English: I will , Caesar .
Shakespearean: Caesar , I shall .

English: Gallus , you go with him .
Shakespearean: Gallus , go you along .

English: Where's Dolabella ?
Shakespearean: Where's Dolabella , To second Proculeius ?

English: Dolabella !
Shakespearean: Dolabella !

English: I remember he's already occupied .
Shakespearean: Let him alone , for I remember now How he's employed .

English: He'll be done in time .
Shakespearean: He shall in time be ready .

English: Come and see the proof .
Shakespearean: Go with me and see What I can show in this .

English: It's pathetic to be Caesar .
Shakespearean: Tis paltry to be Caesar .

English: He can't be Fortune ; he's only Fortune's errand boy .
Shakespearean: Not being Fortune , he's but Fortune's knave , A minister of her will .

English: Caesar greets the Queen of Egypt and asks that you consider what you will ask from him .
Shakespearean: Caesar sends greeting to the Queen of Egypt , And bids thee study on what fair demands Thou mean'st to have him grant thee .

English: What's your name ?
Shakespearean: What's thy name ?

English: My name is Proculeius .
Shakespearean: My name is Proculeius .

English: But I don't worry about being deceived because I don't need to trust .
Shakespearean: Antony Did tell me of you , bade me trust you , but I do not greatly care to be deceived , That have no use for trusting .

English: If your master wants a queen to beg from him , you should tell him that a queen will beg for no less than a kingdom .
Shakespearean: If your master Would have a queen his beggar , you must tell him , That majesty , to keep decorum , must No less beg than a kingdom .

English: If he will grant me conquered Egypt , so that I may give it to my son , I will kneel to him with thanks .
Shakespearean: If he please To give me conquered Egypt for my son , He gives me so much of mine own as I Will kneel to him with thanks .

English: Be content .
Shakespearean: Be of good cheer .

English: You're in the charge of an honorable man .
Shakespearean: You're fall'n into a princely hand .

English: Don't be afraid .
Shakespearean: Fear nothing .

English: If I can tell him that you have submitted to him sweetly , he'll request your assistance in finding ways in which he can support you .
Shakespearean: Let me report to him Your sweet dependency , and you shall find A conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness Where he for grace is kneeled to .

English: Please tell him I have surrendered to his fortune .
Shakespearean: Pray you , tell him I am his fortune's vassal , and I send him The greatness he has got .

English: I'm learning every hour how to be subservient .
Shakespearean: I hourly learn A doctrine of obedience , and would gladly Look him i' th' face .

English: I'll tell him all of this , dear lady .
Shakespearean: This I'll report , dear lady .

English: Be at ease .
Shakespearean: You see how easily she may be surprised .

English: Your majesty !
Shakespearean: Royal Queen !

English: Oh , Cleopatra !
Shakespearean: O Cleopatra !

English: Stop , brave lady , stop !
Shakespearean: Hold , worthy lady , hold !

English: We have not betrayed you .
Shakespearean: Do not yourself such wrong , who are in this Relieved but not betrayed .

English: What , am I being denied death , as well ?
Shakespearean: What , of death too , That rids our dogs of languish ?

English: Don't insult my master's generosity by killing yourself .
Shakespearean: Cleopatra , Do not abuse my master's bounty by Th' undoing of yourself .

English: Your death would prevent that .
Shakespearean: Let the world see His nobleness well acted , which your death Will never let come forth .

English: Where are you , Death ?
Shakespearean: Where art thou , Death ?

English: Come here .
Shakespearean: Come hither , come !

English: Come , and you can have a queen .
Shakespearean: Come , come and take a queen Worth many babes and beggars !

English: Oh , control yourself , lady !
Shakespearean: Oh , temperance , lady !

English: Let Caesar do whatever he wants .
Shakespearean: This mortal house I'll ruin , Do Caesar what he can .

English: You'd better understand that I won't wait till I'm chained up in your master's court , and I won't let myself be scolded even once by dull Octavia .
Shakespearean: Know , sir , that I Will not wait pinioned at your master's court , Nor once be chastised with the sober eye Of dull Octavia .

English: Shall I let them exhibit me to the shouting mobs of Rome ?
Shakespearean: Shall they hoist me up And show me to the shouting varletry Of censuring Rome ?

English: I'd rather die in a ditch in Egypt , and make it my gentle grave .
Shakespearean: Rather a ditch in Egypt Be gentle grave unto me .

English: I'd rather lie in the Nile mud with flies laying their eggs in me , making me disgusting .
Shakespearean: Rather on Nilus' mud Lay me stark naked and let the waterflies Blow me into abhorring .

English: I'd rather be hung in chains from one of our pyramids !
Shakespearean: Rather make My country's high pyramides my gibbet And hang me up in chains !

English: You'll see that Caesar is giving you no reason to do so .
Shakespearean: You do extend These thoughts of horror further than you shall Find cause in Caesar .

English: Proculeius , Caesar has heard about what you've done here and has sent for you .
Shakespearean: Proculeius , What thou hast done thy master Caesar knows , And he hath sent for thee .

English: I'll take the Queen into my custody .
Shakespearean: For the Queen , I'll take her to my guard .

English: So be it , Dolabella .
Shakespearean: So , Dolabella , It shall content me best .

English: Be kind to her .
Shakespearean: Be gentle to her .

English: Have you heard of me , most noble Empress ?
Shakespearean: Most noble Empress , you have heard of me ?

English: I don't remember .
Shakespearean: I can not tell .

English: You must be the one who laughs when boys or women tell you their dreams .
Shakespearean: You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams .

English: Isn't that your habit ?
Shakespearean: Is 't not your trick ?

English: I don't know what you mean , madam .
Shakespearean: I understand not , madam .

English: I dreamed about an emperor called Antony .
Shakespearean: I dreamt there was an emperor Antony .

English: Oh , I wish I could sleep again , so I could have another dream like that !
Shakespearean: Oh , such another sleep , that I might see But such another man !

English: When he raised his arm in command , the world trembled .
Shakespearean: His reared arm Crested the world .

English: There was no end to his generosity .
Shakespearean: For his bounty , There was no winter in 't , an autumn 'twas That grew the more by reaping .

English: Kings and noblemen served him .
Shakespearean: In his livery Walked crowns and crownets .

English: Kingdoms and provinces dropped from his pockets like loose change .
Shakespearean: Realms and islands were As plates dropped from his pocket .

English: Cleopatra , Do you think there ever was , or could there ever be , a man such as the one I dreamed about ?
Shakespearean: Cleopatra , Think you there was or might be such a man As this I dreamt of ?

English: No , gentle madam .
Shakespearean: Gentle madam , no .

English: The gods can hear you lying !
Shakespearean: You lie up to the hearing of the gods .

English: Antony would easily outshine all imaginary beings .
Shakespearean: Nature wants stuff To vie strange forms with fancy , yet t' imagine An Antony were nature's piece 'gainst fancy , Condemning shadows quite .

English: Listen to me , madam .
Shakespearean: Hear me , good madam .

English: You are a remarkable person and your loss is equally remarkable .
Shakespearean: Your loss is as yourself , great , and you bear it As answering to the weight .

English: I hope I never achieve success if I don't feel some of your heartbroken grief right now .
Shakespearean: Would I might never O'ertake pursued success , but I do feel , By the rebound of yours , a grief that smites My very heart at root .

English: Thank you , sir .
Shakespearean: I thank you , sir .

English: Do you know what Caesar intends to do with me ?
Shakespearean: Know you what Caesar means to do with me ?

English: I'm reluctant to tell you what I wish you knew .
Shakespearean: I am loath to tell you what I would you knew .

English: You need not kneel to me .
Shakespearean: Arise , you shall not kneel .

English: Please rise , Queen .
Shakespearean: I pray you , rise .

English: The gods have ordained it to be like this , sir .
Shakespearean: Sir , the gods Will have it thus .

English: Don't think I blame you .
Shakespearean: Take to you no hard thoughts .

English: I'll leave you now .
Shakespearean: I'll take my leave .

English: You may do whatever you want in the world .
Shakespearean: And may , through all the world !

English: It's yours , and you may hang us , your trophies of war , anywhere you like .
Shakespearean: Tis yours , and we , Your scutcheons and your signs of conquest , shall Hang in what place you please .

English: Here , my good lord .
Shakespearean: Here , my good lord .

English: What do you mean , lady ?
Shakespearean: How now , lady ?

English: I wish I were as big and strong as you .
Shakespearean: I would I had thy inches .

English: Listen to me , Queen .
Shakespearean: Thou shouldst know There were a heart in Egypt .

English: There is an emergency I must take care of , but my whole heart will remain here with you .
Shakespearean: Hear me , Queen : The strong necessity of time commands Our services awhile , but my full heart Remains in use with you .

English: My Italy is full of civil war .
Shakespearean: Our Italy Shines o'er with civil swords .

English: Sextus Pompeius is sailing toward the port of Rome .
Shakespearean: Sextus Pompeius Makes his approaches to the port of Rome .

English: But my personal motivation , and that which should move you most to sanction my departure , is that Fulvia is dead .
Shakespearean: My more particular , And that which most with you should safe my going , Is Fulvia's death .

English: Is it possible Fulvia is dead ?
Shakespearean: Can Fulvia die ?

English: She's dead , my Queen .
Shakespearean: She's dead , my Queen .

English: You shall advise me in everything having to do with Cleopatra .
Shakespearean: You shall advise me in all for Cleopatra .

English: This is the inventory of the money , silverware , dishes , and jewels that are still in my possession .
Shakespearean: This is the brief of money , plate , and jewels I am possessed of .

English: Not even trivial things were left out .
Shakespearean: Tis exactly valued , Not petty things admitted .

English: Where's Seleucus ?
Shakespearean: Where's Seleucus ?

English: Here , madam .
Shakespearean: Here , madam .

English: This is my treasurer .
Shakespearean: This is my treasurer .

English: My lord , he will swear on his life that I haven't kept a thing. , Tell the truth , Seleucus .
Shakespearean: Let him speak , my lord , Upon his peril , that I have reserved To myself nothing .

English: Madam , I'd rather sew my lips shut than tell a lie when my life depends upon it .
Shakespearean: Madam , I had rather seal my lips Than to my peril speak that which is not .

English: What did I keep for myself ?
Shakespearean: What have I kept back ?

English: Enough to buy everything you have declared .
Shakespearean: Enough to purchase what you have made known .

English: No , don't be ashamed , Cleopatra .
Shakespearean: Nay , blush not , Cleopatra .

English: Look around you , Caesar .
Shakespearean: See , Caesar !

English: Oh , just see what happens after the pageantry is over !
Shakespearean: Oh , behold How pomp is followed !

English: Seleucus' ingratitude makes me wild .
Shakespearean: The ingratitude of this Seleucus does Even make me wild .

English: I'll give you a good reason to cringe , I promise you .
Shakespearean: Thou shalt Go back , I warrant thee !

English: I'll scratch out your eyes , even if they could fly .
Shakespearean: But I'll catch thine eyes , Though they had wings .

English: Oh , that was unbelievably low !
Shakespearean: Oh , rarely base !

English: Cleopatra , our conquest won't include either the things you kept back or the ones you listed .
Shakespearean: Cleopatra , Not what you have reserved nor what acknowledged Put we i' th' roll of conquest .

English: It's all still yours .
Shakespearean: Still be 't yours .

English: Do whatever you like with it .
Shakespearean: Bestow it at your pleasure , and believe Caesar's no merchant , to make prize with you Of things that merchants sold .

English: So cheer up .
Shakespearean: Therefore be cheered .

English: No , dear Queen .
Shakespearean: No , dear Queen , For we intend so to dispose you as Yourself shall give us counsel .

English: Eat and sleep .
Shakespearean: Feed and sleep .

English: I have so much care and pity for you that you could call me friend .
Shakespearean: Our care and pity is so much upon you That we remain your friend .

English: And so , good-bye .
Shakespearean: And so , adieu .

English: My master and my lord !
Shakespearean: My master , and my lord !

English: Not true .
Shakespearean: Not so .

English: Good-bye .
Shakespearean: Adieu .

English: But listen , Charmian .
Shakespearean: But , hark thee , Charmian .

English: It's time to end it , good lady .
Shakespearean: Finish , good lady .

English: I will , madam .
Shakespearean: Madam , I will .

English: Where's the Queen ?
Shakespearean: Where's the Queen ?

English: Look , sir .
Shakespearean: Behold , sir .

English: Dolabella .
Shakespearean: Dolabella !

English: Make the best use of this information you can .
Shakespearean: Make your best use of this .

English: I have done your bidding and fulfilled my promise .
Shakespearean: I have performed Your pleasure and my promise .

English: Dolabella , I will always be in debt to you .
Shakespearean: Dolabella , I shall remain your debtor .

English: And I your servant .
Shakespearean: I your servant .

English: Good-bye , good Queen .
Shakespearean: Adieu , good Queen .

English: I must go attend Caesar .
Shakespearean: I must attend on Caesar .

English: Farewell , and thanks .
Shakespearean: Farewell , and thanks .

English: Now , Iras , what do you think ?
Shakespearean: Now , Iras , what think'st thou ?

English: You will be exhibited in Rome along with me , like Egyptian puppets .
Shakespearean: Thou an Egyptian puppet shalt be shown In Rome , as well as I .

English: Crude slaves with greasy aprons , rulers , and hammers shall lift us up so everyone can see .
Shakespearean: Mechanic slaves With greasy aprons , rules , and hammers shall Uplift us to the view .

English: The gods forbid !
Shakespearean: The gods forbid !

English: No , it's certain , Iras .
Shakespearean: Nay , 'tis most certain , Iras .

English: Insolent Oh , the good gods !
Shakespearean: Oh , the good gods !

English: No , that's the truth .
Shakespearean: Nay , that's certain .

English: I'll never see it .
Shakespearean: I'll never see 't !

English: I know my nails are stronger than my eyes ; I'll scratch them out .
Shakespearean: For I am sure mine nails Are stronger than mine eyes .

English: Why , that's just the way to frustrate their plans and defeat their absurd intentions .
Shakespearean: Why , that's the way To fool their preparation and to conquer Their most absurd intents .

English: Now , Charmian !
Shakespearean: Now , Charmian !

English: Women , dress me like a queen .
Shakespearean: Show me , my women , like a queen .

English: Go get my best clothes .
Shakespearean: Go fetch My best attires .

English: What's that noise ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore's this noise ?

English: There's a farmer here who won't leave without seeing your Highness .
Shakespearean: Here is a rural fellow That will not be denied your Highness' presence .

English: He has brought you figs .
Shakespearean: He brings you figs .

English: Let him come in .
Shakespearean: Let him come in .

English: What a poor instrument , that can do such a noble deed !
Shakespearean: What poor an instrument May do a noble deed !

English: He brings me freedom .
Shakespearean: He brings me liberty .

English: There's nothing of the weak woman left in me .
Shakespearean: My resolution's placed , and I have nothing Of woman in me .

English: Now from head to foot I'm as firm as marble .
Shakespearean: Now from head to foot I am marble-constant .

English: Now the inconstant moon has nothing to do with me .
Shakespearean: Now the fleeting moon No planet is of mine .

English: This is the man .
Shakespearean: This is the man .

English: Leave us .
Shakespearean: Avoid , and leave him .

English: Do you have in there the pretty snake of the Nile that kills without pain ?
Shakespearean: Hast thou the pretty worm of Nilus there , That kills and pains not ?

English: I certainly do have him , but I wouldn't advise you to touch him .
Shakespearean: Truly , I have him , but I would not be the party that should desire you to touch him , for his biting is immortal .

English: People who die of it seldom or never recover .
Shakespearean: Those that do die of it do seldom or never recover .

English: Do you remember anyone who died of it ?
Shakespearean: Remember'st thou any that have died on 't ?

English: Many people , men and women alike .
Shakespearean: Very many , men and women too .

English: Indeed , she gives a very good testimony of the snake's power .
Shakespearean: Truly , she makes a very good report o' th' worm .

English: But if you believe everything they say , you won't be saved by half of what they do .
Shakespearean: But he that will believe all that they say shall never be saved by half that they do .

English: But this is a sure thing : the snake's an odd snake .
Shakespearean: But this is most falliable , the worm's an odd worm .

English: I hope you are pleased with the snake .
Shakespearean: I wish you all joy of the worm .

English: Farewell .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: You must know that the snake will act according to his nature .
Shakespearean: You must think this , look you , that the worm will do his kind .

English: Yes , yes .
Shakespearean: Ay , ay .

English: Farewell .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: There isn't any kindness in the snake .
Shakespearean: Look you , the worm is not to be trusted but in the keeping of wise people , for indeed there is no goodness in the worm .

English: Good .
Shakespearean: Very good .

English: Will it eat me ?
Shakespearean: Will it eat me ?

English: Don't think I'm so dumb that I don't know that the devil himself won't eat a woman .
Shakespearean: You must not think I am so simple but I know the devil himself will not eat a woman .

English: Well , you can go now .
Shakespearean: Well , get thee gone .

English: Farewell .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: Give me my robe .
Shakespearean: Give me my robe .

English: Put on my crown .
Shakespearean: Put on my crown .

English: I long to be immortal .
Shakespearean: I have Immortal longings in me .

English: Quickly , quickly , good Iras , quickly .
Shakespearean: Yare , yare , good Iras , quick .

English: I think I hear Antony call me .
Shakespearean: Methinks I hear Antony call .

English: I see him revive himself to praise my noble act .
Shakespearean: I see him rouse himself To praise my noble act .

English: I hear him mock Caesar's luck , which the gods give to men in order to balance out their subsequent wrath .
Shakespearean: I hear him mock The luck of Caesar , which the gods give men To excuse their after wrath. , Husband , I come !

English: Now let my courage prove my title as wife .
Shakespearean: Now to that name my courage prove my title !

English: So , are you done ?
Shakespearean: I am fire and air , my other elements I give to baser life. , So , have you done ?

English: Come then , kiss me and take the last bit of warmth from my lips .
Shakespearean: Come then and take the last warmth of my lips .

English: Good-bye , kind Charmian .
Shakespearean: Farewell , kind Charmian .

English: Iras , I won't see you again for a long time .
Shakespearean: Iras , long farewell .

English: Do I have the asp's poison on my lips ?
Shakespearean: Have I the aspic in my lips ?

English: Did you fall ?
Shakespearean: Dost fall ?

English: If you can leave your body so easily , then the touch of death is like a lover's pinch , which hurts but is desired .
Shakespearean: If thou and nature can so gently part , The stroke of death is as a lover's pinch , Which hurts , and is desired .

English: Do you lie still ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou lie still ?

English: If you leave like that , you tell the world that it's not worthy of a good-bye .
Shakespearean: If thus thou vanishest , thou tell'st the world It is not worth leave-taking .

English: Clouds , dissolve into rain , so that I could say the gods themselves are weeping !
Shakespearean: Dissolve , thick cloud , and rain , that I may say The gods themselves do weep !

English: Separate me from life with your sharp teeth .
Shakespearean: Come , thou mortal wretch , With thy sharp teeth this knot intrinsicate Of life at once untie .

English: Poor poisonous fool , be angry and bite .
Shakespearean: Poor venomous fool Be angry and dispatch .

English: Oh , if you could speak , I might hear you call Caesar an ass who's been outsmarted !
Shakespearean: Oh , couldst thou speak , That I might hear thee call great Caesar ass Unpolicied !

English: Oh , eastern star !
Shakespearean: O eastern star !

English: Quiet , quiet !
Shakespearean: Peace , peace !

English: Don't you see my baby suckling at my breast so that its nurse will fall asleep ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou not see my baby at my breast , That sucks the nurse asleep ?

English: The poison is as sweet as balm , as soft as air , as gentle , Oh , Antony ! , No , I'll take you too .
Shakespearean: As sweet as balm , as soft as air , as gentle , O Antony ! , Nay , I will take thee too .

English: Why should I stay , In this vile world ?
Shakespearean: What should I stay , In this wild world ?

English: So , good-bye .
Shakespearean: So , fare thee well .

English: Now , Death , you can boast that you have an incomparable girl in your possession .
Shakespearean: Now boast thee , Death , in thy possession lies A lass unparalleled .

English: Close , soft eyes .
Shakespearean: Downy windows , close ,

English: The sun will never be seen by such royal eyes again .
Shakespearean: And golden Phoebus never be beheld Of eyes again so royal !

English: Your crown is crooked .
Shakespearean: Your crown's awry .

English: I'll straighten it , then play , Where's the Queen ?
Shakespearean: I'll mend it and then play , Where's the Queen ?

English: Speak softly .
Shakespearean: Speak softly .

English: Don't wake her .
Shakespearean: Wake her not .

English: Caesar has sent , Too slow a messenger .
Shakespearean: Caesar hath sent , Too slow a messenger .

English: Oh , come quickly !
Shakespearean: Oh , come apace , dispatch !

English: I almost feel you .
Shakespearean: I partly feel thee .

English: There's Dolabella , who was sent from Caesar .
Shakespearean: There's Dolabella sent from Caesar .

English: Call him .
Shakespearean: Call him .

English: What kind of work is this , Charmian ?
Shakespearean: What work is here , Charmian ?

English: Is this well done ?
Shakespearean: Is this well done ?

English: It is well done , and appropriate for a princess who has descended from so many royal kings .
Shakespearean: It is well done and fitting for a princess Descended of so many royal kings .
