English: Ah , soldier !
Shakespearean: Ah , soldier !

English: What's going on in here ?
Shakespearean: How goes it here ?

English: They're all dead .
Shakespearean: All dead .

English: Caesar , you thought this would happen .
Shakespearean: Caesar , thy thoughts Touch their effects in this .

English: You're coming here yourself to see the dreaded act you had tried to stop .
Shakespearean: Thyself art coming To see performed the dreaded act which thou So sought'st to hinder .

English: Oh , unfaithful lover !
Shakespearean: O most false love !

English: Stop arguing and listen to my plans .
Shakespearean: Where be the sacred vials thou shouldst fill With sorrowful water ?

English: Whether I go ahead with them or not is completely up to you .
Shakespearean: Now I see , I see , In Fulvia's death how mine received shall be .

English: I swear by the sun that when I leave here , it will be as your faithful servant .
Shakespearean: By the fire That quickens Nilus' slime , I go from hence Thy soldier , servant , making peace or war As thou affects .

English: Cut my corset laces , Charmian , so I can breathe .
Shakespearean: Cut my lace , Charmian , come !

English: Hurry !
Shakespearean: But let it be .

English: Just as Antony loves .
Shakespearean: I am quickly ill , and well , So Antony loves .

English: Control yourself , my precious Queen , and concede that my love is true .
Shakespearean: My precious Queen , forbear , And give true evidence to his love which stands An honorable trial .

English: That's what Fulvia told me .
Shakespearean: So Fulvia told me .

English: I beg you , turn away and cry for her .
Shakespearean: I prithee , turn aside and weep for her .

English: Then say good-bye to me and tell me those tears were for my benefit .
Shakespearean: Then bid adieu to me , and say the tears Belong to Egypt .

English: Oh , sir , you are too good at predicting the future .
Shakespearean: O sir , you are too sure an augurer .

English: What you were afraid of has happened .
Shakespearean: That you did fear is done .

English: How did they die ?
Shakespearean: The manner of their deaths ?

English: I don't see any blood .
Shakespearean: I do not see them bleed .

English: Who was with them last ?
Shakespearean: Who was last with them ?

English: A simple country farmer who brought her figs .
Shakespearean: A simple countryman that brought her figs .

English: This was the basket .
Shakespearean: This was his basket .

English: They were poisoned , then .
Shakespearean: Poisoned , then .

English: Oh , Caesar , this Charmian lived until a moment ago .
Shakespearean: Oh , Caesar , This Charmian lived but now .

English: She stood and spoke .
Shakespearean: She stood and spake .

English: I found her adjusting the crown on her dead mistress .
Shakespearean: I found her trimming up the diadem On her dead mistress .

English: She stood trembling , then suddenly dropped dead .
Shakespearean: Tremblingly she stood And on the sudden dropped .

English: Oh , noble weakness !
Shakespearean: Oh , noble weakness !

English: Here on her breast there's a little bloody mark .
Shakespearean: Here on her breast There is a vent of blood , and something blown .

English: There's a similar mark on her arm .
Shakespearean: The like is on her arm .

English: This is an asp's trail , and these fig leaves have slime on them , just like the kind that asps deposit on the caves by the Nile .
Shakespearean: This is an aspic's trail , and these fig leaves Have slime upon them , such as th' aspic leaves Upon the caves of Nile .

English: Pick up her bed and carry her ladies out of the tomb .
Shakespearean: Take up her bed And bear her women from the monument .

English: She shall be buried next to her Antony .
Shakespearean: She shall be buried by her Antony .

English: No other grave on earth shall hold a pair this famous .
Shakespearean: No grave upon the earth shall clip in it A pair so famous .

English: Our army shall somberly attend this funeral and then depart for Rome .
Shakespearean: Our army shall In solemn show attend this funeral , And then to Rome .

English: Come , Dolabella .
Shakespearean: Come , Dolabella , see High order in this great solemnity .

English: You'll make me angry .
Shakespearean: You'll heat my blood .

English: No more of this .
Shakespearean: No more .

English: I know you can do better than that , but it'll do for now .
Shakespearean: You can do better yet , but this is meetly .

English: I swear by my sword , Swear by your shield , too !
Shakespearean: Now , by my sword , And target .

English: I'll leave you , lady .
Shakespearean: I'll leave you , lady .

English: Polite sir , let me say one thing .
Shakespearean: Courteous lord , one word .

English: Sir , you and I must part company , no , that's not it .
Shakespearean: Sir , you and I must part , but that's not it .

English: It's difficult to have such immaturity so close to my heart , but bear with me .
Shakespearean: Tis sweating labor To bear such idleness so near the heart As Cleopatra this .

English: Even the traits that become me most kill me when you don't approve of them .
Shakespearean: But , sir , forgive me , Since my becomings kill me when they do not Eye well to you .

English: Your honor is the reason you are leaving .
Shakespearean: Your honor calls you hence .

English: May the gods be with you .
Shakespearean: Therefore be deaf to my unpitied folly , And all the gods go with you !

English: May your sword be victorious and everything you do succeed .
Shakespearean: Upon your sword Sit laurel victory , and smooth success Be strewed before your feet .

English: Let's go .
Shakespearean: Let us go .

English: Come with me .
Shakespearean: Come .

English: Our imminent separation so occupies our thoughts that even though you stay here , you come with me , and even though I leave here , I stay with you .
Shakespearean: Our separation so abides and flies That thou , residing here , goes yet with me , And I , hence fleeting , here remain with thee .

English: You're too forgiving .
Shakespearean: You are too indulgent .

English: Even if we said that this behavior suits him , though only a man with a perfect character could avoid being disgraced by such antics , there's no excuse for the extra work we've had to take on while he's been off amusing himself .
Shakespearean: Say this becomes him , As his composure must be rare indeed Whom these things can not blemish , yet must Antony No way excuse his foils when we do bear So great weight in his lightness .

English: If he's been spending his leisure time in lustful pursuits , then he'll be punished with venereal diseases , and that's his business .
Shakespearean: If he filled His vacancy with his voluptuousness , Full surfeits and the dryness of his bones Call on him for 't .

English: Here's more news .
Shakespearean: Here's more news .

English: Pompey has a strong navy .
Shakespearean: Pompey is strong at sea , And it appears he is beloved of those That only have feared Caesar .

English: I should have known it .
Shakespearean: I should have known no less .

English: It's been this way ever since the first government was organized .
Shakespearean: It hath been taught us from the primal state That he which is was wished until he were , And the ebbed man , ne'er loved till ne'er worth love , Comes deared by being lacked .

English: Caesar , I have news about Menecrates and Menas , notorious pirates who prowl the sea in a variety of ships .
Shakespearean: Caesar , I bring thee word Menecrates and Menas , famous pirates , Make the sea serve them , which they ear and wound With keels of every kind .

English: They've made many raids upon Italy , and the naval patrols go pale at even the thought of resisting them .
Shakespearean: Many hot inroads They make in Italy , the borders maritime Lack blood to think on 't , and flush youth revolt .

English: Antony , it's time to stop your wild hedonism .
Shakespearean: Antony , Leave thy lascivious wassails .

English: And even though you were brought up as a gentleman , you patiently tolerated more hardships than savages could withstand .
Shakespearean: When thou once Wast beaten from Modena , where thou slew'st Hirtius and Pansa , consuls , at thy heel Did famine follow , whom thou fought'st against , Though daintily brought up , with patience more Than savages could suffer .

English: You drank horses' urine and water from scum-covered puddles that even animals would refuse .
Shakespearean: Thou didst drink The stale of horses and the gilded puddle Which beasts would cough at .

English: It's too bad .
Shakespearean: Tis pity of him .

English: Let's hope his sense of shame will send him back to Rome quickly .
Shakespearean: Let his shames quickly Drive him to Rome .

English: It's time that we brought our armies into the field .
Shakespearean: Tis time we twain Did show ourselves i' th' field , and to that end Assemble we immediate council .

English: Pompey is making the most of our absence .
Shakespearean: Pompey Thrives in our idleness .

English: Tomorrow , Caesar , I'll be able to tell you what land and sea forces I can raise for this war .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow , Caesar , I shall be furnished to inform you rightly Both what by sea and land I can be able To front this present time .

English: I'll be getting my own figures together in the meantime .
Shakespearean: Till which encounter It is my business too .

English: Good-bye .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: Good-bye , my lord .
Shakespearean: Farewell , my lord .

English: Charmian !
Shakespearean: Charmian !

English: Madam ?
Shakespearean: Madam ?

English: So I can sleep away the time while my Antony is gone .
Shakespearean: That I might sleep out this great gap of time My Antony is away .

English: You think about him too much .
Shakespearean: You think of him too much .

English: That's treason !
Shakespearean: Oh , 'tis treason !

English: I hope not , Madam .
Shakespearean: Madam , I trust , not so .

English: What can I do for your highness ?
Shakespearean: What's your highness' pleasure ?

English: I don't want to hear you sing .
Shakespearean: Not now to hear thee sing .

English: I'm not interested in anything a eunuch can do .
Shakespearean: I take no pleasure In aught an eunuch has .

English: It's a good thing for you that , being castrated , you can better concentrate on my needs .
Shakespearean: Tis well for thee That , being unseminared , thy freer thoughts May not fly forth of Egypt .

English: Do you have desires ?
Shakespearean: Hast thou affections ?

English: Yes , dear madam .
Shakespearean: Yes , gracious madam .

English: Indeed ?
Shakespearean: Indeed ?

English: Well , not in deed , madam , since I can't do anything unchaste .
Shakespearean: Not in deed , madam , for I can do nothing But what indeed is honest to be done .

English: Is he standing or sitting ?
Shakespearean: Stands he or sits he ?

English: Or is he walking ?
Shakespearean: Or does he walk ?

English: Or is he on his horse ?
Shakespearean: Or is he on his horse ?

English: Oh , how fortunate that horse is to have Antony on him .
Shakespearean: O happy horse , to bear the weight of Antony !

English: He's speaking now , or perhaps he's whispering , "Where's my serpent of the Nile ? " For that's his pet name for me .
Shakespearean: He's speaking now , Or murmuring "Where's my serpent of old Nile ? " For so he calls me .

English: I'm killing myself with this provocative speculation.. .
Shakespearean: Now I feed myself With most delicious poison .

English: Are you thinking about me ?
Shakespearean: Think on me , That am with Phoebus' amorous pinches black And wrinkled deep in time .

English: No , listen to it , Antony .
Shakespearean: Nay , hear them , Antony .

English: Perhaps What , my love ?
Shakespearean: Perform 't , or else we damn thee." How , my love ?

English: Maybe ?
Shakespearean: Perchance ?

English: No , most likely .
Shakespearean: Nay , and most like .

English: You can't stay here any longer .
Shakespearean: You must not stay here longer .

English: Call in the messengers and we'll find out .
Shakespearean: Call in the messengers .

English: As surely as I am the queen of Egypt , Antony , you're blushing , which means you're Caesar's servant .
Shakespearean: As I am Egypt's queen , Thou blushest , Antony , and that blood of thine Is Caesar's homager .

English: Call the messengers !
Shakespearean: The messengers !

English: Queen of Egypt , greetings !
Shakespearean: Sovereign of Egypt , hail !

English: You are nothing like Mark Antony !
Shakespearean: How much unlike art thou Mark Antony !

English: But since you come from him , you're saturated with his healing spirit .
Shakespearean: Yet , coming from him , that great med'cine hath With his tinct gilded thee .

English: How does it go with my magnificent Mark Antony ?
Shakespearean: How goes it with my brave Mark Antony ?

English: The last thing he did before sending me off , dear Queen , was to kiss , the last of many such kisses , this Indian pearl for you .
Shakespearean: Last thing he did , dear Queen , He kissed , the last of many doubled kisses , This orient pearl .

English: My ear must pull it out .
Shakespearean: Mine ear must pluck it thence .

English: Good friend , " he said , "say that the faithful Roman sends an oyster's treasure to the great Queen of Egypt , and that he plans to enhance this meager gift by adding new kingdoms to her empire .
Shakespearean: Good friend , " quoth he , "Say the firm Roman to great Egypt sends This treasure of an oyster , at whose foot , To mend the petty present , I will piece Her opulent throne with kingdoms .

English: Tell her that the entire East shall call her Queen." Then he nodded and solemnly mounted an armored warhorse , which neighed so loudly it effectively silenced anything I might have said in reply .
Shakespearean: All the East , Say thou , shall call her mistress." So he nodded , And soberly did mount an arm-gaunt steed , Who neighed so high that what I would have spoke Was beastly dumbed by him .

English: Was he sad or happy ?
Shakespearean: What was he , sad or merry ?

English: He was like that time of year halfway between the extremes of hot and cold : he was neither sad nor happy .
Shakespearean: Like to the time o' th' year between the extremes Of hot and cold , he was nor sad nor merry .

English: Just notice .
Shakespearean: Note him , Note him , good Charmian , 'tis the man , but note him .

English: He wasn't sad , because he knows that his disposition affects others .
Shakespearean: He was not sad , for he would shine on those That make their looks by his .

English: He was somewhere in the middle , between them.. .
Shakespearean: He was not merry , Which seemed to tell them his remembrance lay In Egypt with his joy , but between both .

English: Oh , heavenly mixture !
Shakespearean: O heavenly mingle !

English: Whether you are sad or merry , the intensity of either suits you like no one else.. .
Shakespearean: Be'st thou sad or merry , The violence of either thee becomes , So does it no man else. , Mett'st thou my posts ?

English: Yes , madam , twenty different messengers .
Shakespearean: Ay , madam , twenty several messengers .

English: Why did you send so many ?
Shakespearean: Why do you send so thick ?

English: Whoever is born on a day I forget to send a message to Antony will die a beggar .
Shakespearean: Who's born that day When I forget to send to Antony Shall die a beggar .

English: Bring ink and paper , Charmian .
Shakespearean: Ink and paper , Charmian .

English: Welcome , my good Alexas .
Shakespearean: Welcome , my good Alexas .

English: Charmian , did I ever love Caesar as much as this ?
Shakespearean: Did I , Charmian , Ever love Caesar so ?

English: Oh , that splendid Caesar !
Shakespearean: Oh , that brave Caesar !

English: May you choke on any other sentiments like that !
Shakespearean: Be choked with such another emphasis !

English: Say , "That splendid Antony." The courageous Caesar !
Shakespearean: Say , "the brave Antony." The valiant Caesar !

English: By Isis , I'll give you bloody teeth if you ever compare Caesar with Antony , my best man among men .
Shakespearean: By Isis , I will give thee bloody teeth If thou with Caesar paragon again My man of men .

English: Pardon me , but I'm just repeating what you yourself have said .
Shakespearean: By your most gracious pardon , I sing but after you .

English: That was when I was young and inexperienced and didn't know what passion was .
Shakespearean: My salad days , When I was green in judgment , cold in blood , To say as I said then .

English: In that case , the wise gods deny our prayers for our own good .
Shakespearean: We , ignorant of ourselves , Beg often our own harms , which the wise powers Deny us for our good , so find we profit By losing of our prayers .

English: I'll do well .
Shakespearean: I shall do well .

English: The people are on my side , and I'm in charge of the sea .
Shakespearean: The people love me , and the sea is mine .

English: My forces are growing , and everything I know tells me it's all coming together .
Shakespearean: My powers are crescent , and my auguring hope Says it will come to th' full .

English: Mark Antony is at dinner in Egypt and won't be going outside to make war .
Shakespearean: Mark Antony In Egypt sits at dinner , and will make No wars without doors .

English: Caesar loses supporters wherever he raises money .
Shakespearean: Caesar gets money where He loses hearts .

English: Lepidus flatters both of them , as they flatter him , but he doesn't love them , and they don't love him .
Shakespearean: Lepidus flatters both , Of both is flattered , but he neither loves , Nor either cares for him .

English: Caesar and Lepidus are organizing their military operation .
Shakespearean: Caesar and Lepidus Are in the field .

English: They have a massive army .
Shakespearean: A mighty strength they carry .

English: Where did you hear this ?
Shakespearean: Where have you this ?

English: It's not true .
Shakespearean: Tis false .

English: From Silvius , sir .
Shakespearean: From Silvius , sir .

English: He's dreaming .
Shakespearean: He dreams .

English: I know they're in Rome together , hoping for Antony to return .
Shakespearean: I know they are in Rome together Looking for Antony .

English: Lecherous Cleopatra , may all the charms of love soften those withered lips !
Shakespearean: But all the charms of love , Salt Cleopatra , soften thy wanned lip !

English: Join your witchcraft with your beauty , and let Antony's lust combine with both .
Shakespearean: Let witchcraft join with beauty , lust with both .

English: Keep this libertine occupied with endless debauchery .
Shakespearean: Tie up the libertine in a field of feasts , Keep his brain fuming .

English: This news is absolutely true : Mark Antony is expected to arrive in Rome at any hour now .
Shakespearean: This is most certain that I shall deliver : Mark Antony is every hour in Rome Expected .

English: In the time since he left Egypt , he could have traveled an even longer distance .
Shakespearean: Since he went from Egypt 'tis A space for farther travel .

English: His military ability is double that of the other two .
Shakespearean: His soldiership Is twice the other twain .

English: We must form a better opinion of ourselves if our uprising can pull the insatiable Antony's attention away from that Egyptian widow .
Shakespearean: But let us rear The higher our opinion , that our stirring Can from the lap of Egypt's widow pluck The ne'er lust-wearied Antony .

English: I don't expect Caesar and Antony will have a very friendly reunion .
Shakespearean: I can not hope Caesar and Antony shall well greet together .

English: Menas , I don't understand how minor quarrels can be superseded by greater ones .
Shakespearean: I know not , Menas , How lesser enmities may give way to greater .

English: It will be as the gods see fit .
Shakespearean: Be 't as our gods will have 't .

English: In any case , our survival depends on putting together the strongest force possible .
Shakespearean: It only stands Our lives upon to use our strongest hands .

English: Let's go , Menas .
Shakespearean: Come , Menas .

English: Good Enobarbus , you would be doing a very good thing if you advised your captain to speak calmly and quietly .
Shakespearean: Good Enobarbus , 'tis a worthy deed , And shall become you well , to entreat your captain To soft and gentle speech .

English: I will advise him to speak as he usually does .
Shakespearean: I shall entreat him To answer like himself .

English: By Jupiter , if I were Antony , I wouldn't shave my beard today .
Shakespearean: By Jupiter , Were I the wearer of Antonio's beard , I would not shave 't today .

English: This is not the time for dwelling on personal grievances .
Shakespearean: Tis not a time for private stomaching .

English: But major issues must come before minor ones .
Shakespearean: But small to greater matters must give way .

English: Not if the minor ones come up first .
Shakespearean: Not if the small come first .

English: Here comes the noble Antony .
Shakespearean: Here comes the noble Antony .

English: And there comes Caesar .
Shakespearean: And yonder , Caesar .

English: You're right .
Shakespearean: Tis spoken well .

English: If we were in front of our armies , about to fight , I would do this .
Shakespearean: Were we before our armies , and to fight , I should do thus .

English: Welcome to Rome .
Shakespearean: Welcome to Rome .

English: Thank you .
Shakespearean: Thank you .

English: Have a seat .
Shakespearean: Sit .

English: After you .
Shakespearean: Sit , sir .

English: No , after you .
Shakespearean: Nay , then .

English: I should be ridiculed if I were offended so easily , and laughed at even more for speaking of you disrespectfully , when I had no reason to speak of you at all .
Shakespearean: I must be laughed at If or for nothing or a little , I Should say myself offended , and with you Chiefly i' th' world ; more laughed at , that I should Once name you derogately , when to sound your name It not concerned me .

English: Caesar , what did my stay in Egypt have to do with you ?
Shakespearean: My being in Egypt , Caesar , what was 't to you ?

English: No more than my staying here in Rome might mean to you in Egypt .
Shakespearean: No more than my residing here at Rome Might be to you in Egypt .

English: But if you conspired against my position while you were there , I might be interested in the reason for your stay in Egypt .
Shakespearean: Yet if you there Did practice on my state , your being in Egypt Might be my question .

English: How do you mean , "conspired" ?
Shakespearean: How intend you , "practiced" ?

English: You can judge for yourself what I mean .
Shakespearean: You may be pleased to catch at mine intent By what did here befall me .

English: Your wife and brother led troops against me , claiming to be fighting in your name .
Shakespearean: Your wife and brother Made wars upon me , and their contestation Was theme for you .

English: They said they were acting for you .
Shakespearean: You were the word of war .

English: You're mistaken .
Shakespearean: You do mistake your business .

English: My brother didn't use my name to justify his rebellion .
Shakespearean: My brother never Did urge me in his act .

English: He rejected my authority as much as yours .
Shakespearean: Did he not rather Discredit my authority with yours , And make the wars alike against my stomach , Having alike your cause ?

English: I've already sent the proof in my letters .
Shakespearean: Of this my letters Before did satisfy you .

English: If you want to pick a fight , you'll have to find a more substantial excuse .
Shakespearean: If you'll patch a quarrel , As matter whole you have to make it with , It must not be with this .

English: You defend yourself by blaming my judgment , but you're just making up feeble excuses .
Shakespearean: You praise yourself By laying defects of judgment to me , but You patched up your excuses .

English: Not true , not true .
Shakespearean: Not so , not so .

English: You know I would never approve a war against my own cause .
Shakespearean: I know you could not lack , I am certain on 't , Very necessity of this thought , that I , Your partner in the cause 'gainst which he fought , Could not with graceful eyes attend those wars Which fronted mine own peace .

English: As for my wife , if only you had such a wife .
Shakespearean: As for my wife , I would you had her spirit in such another .

English: It's easier to rule a third of the world than a wife like that .
Shakespearean: The third o' th' world is yours , which with a snaffle You may pace easy , but not such a wife .

English: But you can't blame me for her offenses .
Shakespearean: For that you must But say I could not help it .

English: I sent you a letter while you were carousing in Alexandria .
Shakespearean: I wrote to you When rioting in Alexandria .

English: I was not myself , as a result of the wine .
Shakespearean: Three kings I had newly feasted , and did want Of what I was i' th' morning .

English: The next day I explained all this to him , which was as good as begging his pardon .
Shakespearean: But next day I told him of myself , which was as much As to have asked him pardon .

English: Let's not fight over this fellow .
Shakespearean: Let this fellow Be nothing of our strife .

English: Meet with the ambassadors .
Shakespearean: Hear the ambassadors .

English: Tonight we'll wander through the streets and observe the people .
Shakespearean: No messenger but thine , and all alone Tonight we'll wander through the streets and note The qualities of people .

English: You will never be able to say the same about me .
Shakespearean: You have broken The article of your oath , which you shall never Have tongue to charge me with .

English: Go on , Caesar .
Shakespearean: Soft , Caesar .

English: What part of the agreement did I break ?
Shakespearean: No , Lepidus , let him speak .

English: You agreed to send me troops and weapons when I needed them .
Shakespearean: The honor is sacred which he talks on now , Supposing that I lacked it. , But , on , Caesar .

English: You refused me both .
Shakespearean: The article of my oath ?

English: I overlooked your request , but I did not deny it .
Shakespearean: To lend me arms and aid when I required them , The which you both denied .

English: Your request came at a time when the poisonous effects of reveling caused me to be unaware of my own actions .
Shakespearean: Neglected , rather , And then when poisoned hours had bound me up From mine own knowledge .

English: Spoken like a gentleman .
Shakespearean: Tis noble spoken .

English: If it's okay with you , you should not press your grievances any further , but realize that the current situation should be enough to reconcile you .
Shakespearean: If it might please you to enforce no further The griefs between ye , to forget them quite Were to remember that the present need Speaks to atone you .

English: Well put , Maecenas .
Shakespearean: Worthily spoken , Maecenas .

English: Or you can pretend to settle your differences until this matter with Pompey is finished .
Shakespearean: Or , if you borrow one another's love for the instant , you may , when you hear no more words of Pompey , return it again .

English: You can argue as much as you like when there's nothing else to do .
Shakespearean: You shall have time to wrangle in when you have nothing else to do .

English: You are only a soldier .
Shakespearean: Thou art a soldier only .

English: Don't speak any further .
Shakespearean: Therefore speak no more .

English: As you please .
Shakespearean: Go to , then .

English: May I speak , Caesar .
Shakespearean: Give me leave , Caesar .

English: What is it , Agrippa ?
Shakespearean: Speak , Agrippa .

English: You have a beautiful half-sister , Octavia .
Shakespearean: Thou hast a sister by the mother's side , Admired Octavia .

English: Great Mark Antony is a widower now .
Shakespearean: Great Mark Antony Is now a widower .

English: You'd better not make that suggestion , Agrippa .
Shakespearean: Say not so , Agrippa .

English: If Cleopatra heard you , you would be well punished for your audacity .
Shakespearean: If Cleopatra heard you , your reproof Were well deserved of rashness .

English: It's true I'm not married , Caesar .
Shakespearean: I am not married , Caesar .

English: Let me hear what Agrippa has to say .
Shakespearean: Let me hear Agrippa further speak .

English: With this marriage , all the petty jealousies that now seem huge , and all the great fears that are dangerous in themselves , would disappear .
Shakespearean: By this marriage , All little jealousies , which now seem great , And all great fears , which now import their dangers , Would then be nothing .

English: Since she would love both of you , you two would be joined in that love .
Shakespearean: Her love to both Would each to other and all loves to both Draw after her .

English: What do you say , Caesar ?
Shakespearean: Will Caesar speak ?

English: He has both my power and my influence over Octavia .
Shakespearean: The power of Caesar , and His power unto Octavia .

English: I wouldn't dream of opposing such an obviously promising idea .
Shakespearean: May I never To this good purpose , that so fairly shows , Dream of impediment !

English: Here's my hand .
Shakespearean: There's my hand .

English: I give you a sister whom I love more than a brother ever loved any sister .
Shakespearean: A sister I bequeath you whom no brother Did ever love so dearly .

English: She will be the bond that joins our kingdoms and our hearts .
Shakespearean: Let her live To join our kingdoms and our hearts , and never Fly off our loves again !

English: I'm happy to say "amen" to that !
Shakespearean: Happily , amen !

English: I didn't think I would ever fight Pompey .
Shakespearean: I did not think to draw my sword 'gainst Pompey , For he hath laid strange courtesies and great Of late upon me .

English: There isn't much time .
Shakespearean: Time calls upon 's .

English: Either we go after Pompey or he'll come after us .
Shakespearean: Of us must Pompey presently be sought , Or else he seeks out us .

English: Where is he now ?
Shakespearean: Where lies he ?

English: Near How large is his land army ?
Shakespearean: What is his strength by land ?

English: Large and increasing .
Shakespearean: Great and increasing .

English: But his navy rules the sea .
Shakespearean: But by sea he is an absolute master .

English: That's what I hear .
Shakespearean: So is the fame .

English: Come with us , Lepidus .
Shakespearean: Let us , Lepidus , not lack your company .

English: Noble Antony , even illness couldn't keep me away .
Shakespearean: Noble Antony , not sickness should detain me .

English: Good Enobarbus !
Shakespearean: Good Enobarbus !

English: We can be happy that things have been resolved so agreeably .
Shakespearean: We have cause to be glad that matters are so well digested .

English: And I see you survived your time in Egypt .
Shakespearean: You stayed well by 't in Egypt .

English: We heard that once you were served eight wild boars roasted whole for breakfast , for only twelve people !
Shakespearean: Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast , and but twelve persons there !

English: Is that true ?
Shakespearean: Is this true ?

English: That was nothing .
Shakespearean: This was but as a fly by an eagle .

English: There were many even more memorable feasts .
Shakespearean: We had much more monstrous matter of feast , which worthily deserved noting .

English: She's a remarkable lady , if the rumors are to be believed .
Shakespearean: She's a most triumphant lady , if report be square to her .

English: I'll tell you .
Shakespearean: I will tell you .

English: The sails were dyed purple , and they were perfumed so heavily that they made the air seem dizzy with love .
Shakespearean: The poop was beaten gold , Purple the sails , and so perfumed that The winds were lovesick with them .

English: The oars were made of silver , and the oarsmen rowed in time to flute music .
Shakespearean: The oars were silver , Which to the tune of flutes kept stroke , and made The water which they beat to follow faster , As amorous of their strokes .

English: Pretty , Cupid-like boys stood on either side of her , smiling and cooling her with multicolored fans , which seemed to fan the flames in her cheeks even as they cooled them , undoing what they did .
Shakespearean: On each side her Stood pretty dimpled boys , like smiling Cupids , With divers-colored fans , whose wind did seem To glow the delicate cheeks which they did cool , And what they undid did .

English: How excellent for Antony !
Shakespearean: Oh , rare for Antony !

English: When she landed at the port , Antony sent an invitation for her to come to supper .
Shakespearean: Upon her landing , Antony sent to her , Invited her to supper .

English: She replied by saying that it would be better for him to be her guest instead .
Shakespearean: She replied It should be better he became her guest , Which she entreated .

English: Royal seductress !
Shakespearean: Royal wench !

English: Now Antony has to leave her completely .
Shakespearean: Now Antony must leave her utterly .

English: Age won't wither her , and her charms are so varied that she never grows boring .
Shakespearean: Age can not wither her , nor custom stale Her infinite variety .

English: Even her worst faults are charming , and holy priests bless her even when she acts the slut .
Shakespearean: Other women cloy The appetites they feed , but she makes hungry Where most she satisfies , for vilest things Become themselves in her , that the holy priests Bless her when she is riggish .

English: Let's go .
Shakespearean: Let us go .

English: Good Enobarbus , consider yourself my guest as long as you're here .
Shakespearean: Good Enobarbus , make yourself my guest Whilst you abide here .

English: I humbly thank you .
Shakespearean: Humbly , sir , I thank you .

English: And I will spend our time apart on my knees , praying for you .
Shakespearean: All which time Before the gods my knee shall bow my prayers To them for you .

English: Good night .
Shakespearean: Good night .

English: Tell me why , if you can .
Shakespearean: If you can , your reason ?

English: But you had better get back to Egypt again .
Shakespearean: But yet hie you to Egypt again .

English: Tell me who shall have the better luck , Caesar or me ?
Shakespearean: Say to me whose fortunes shall rise higher , Caesar's or mine ?

English: Caesar .
Shakespearean: Caesar's .

English: So you'd better not stay with him , Antony .
Shakespearean: Therefore , O Antony , stay not by his side .

English: Your guardian angel is noble , courageous , significant , and unmatched when Caesar's not around .
Shakespearean: Thy daemon , that thy spirit which keeps thee , is Noble , courageous , high , unmatchable Where Caesar's is not .

English: But when you are with him , your angel is weakened and easily frightened .
Shakespearean: But near him thy angel Becomes afeard , as being o'erpowered .

English: That's why there must be space between you .
Shakespearean: Therefore Make space enough between you .

English: Have a good night !
Shakespearean: Rest you happy !

English: Don't speak of this again .
Shakespearean: Speak this no more .

English: To none but you , only to you .
Shakespearean: To none but thee , no more but when to thee .

English: With his natural luck , he will beat you even against the odds .
Shakespearean: If thou dost play with him at any game , Thou art sure to lose , and of that natural luck He beats thee 'gainst the odds .

English: Your light dulls when he is near .
Shakespearean: Thy luster thickens When he shines by .

English: Leave now .
Shakespearean: I will to Egypt .

English: Tell Ventidius I want to speak with him .
Shakespearean: And though I make this marriage for my peace , I' th' East my pleasure lies .

English: Come here , Ventidius .
Shakespearean: O come , Ventidius .

English: You must go to Parthia .
Shakespearean: You must to Parthia .

English: Your authorization is ready .
Shakespearean: Your commission's ready .

English: Come with me and I'll get it for you .
Shakespearean: Follow me and receive 't .

English: Don't spend any more time here .
Shakespearean: Trouble yourselves no further .

English: Go tell your generals to hurry their preparations .
Shakespearean: Pray you , hasten Your generals after .

English: Sir , we'll follow as soon as Mark Antony kisses Octavia good-bye .
Shakespearean: Sir , Mark Antony Will e'en but kiss Octavia , and we'll follow .

English: Good-bye then , until the time I see you dressed in your battle gear , which will suit you both very well .
Shakespearean: Till I shall see you in your soldiers' dress , Which will become you both , farewell .

English: You're taking a shorter route .
Shakespearean: Your way is shorter .

English: My plans take me a roundabout way .
Shakespearean: My purposes do draw me much about .

English: You'll get there two days before me .
Shakespearean: You'll win two days upon me .

English: Good luck , sir .
Shakespearean: Sir , good success .

English: Farewell .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: Play me some music .
Shakespearean: Give me some music .

English: Music feeds the melancholy moods of us lovers .
Shakespearean: Music , moody food Of us that trade in love .

English: Musicians , come in !
Shakespearean: The music , ho !

English: Never mind .
Shakespearean: Let it alone .

English: Let's play billiards .
Shakespearean: Let's to billiards .

English: Play with me , Charmian .
Shakespearean: Come , Charmian .

English: My arm is sore .
Shakespearean: My arm is sore .

English: I'll do my best , madam .
Shakespearean: As well as I can , madam .

English: I don't want to play now .
Shakespearean: I'll none now .

English: Give me my fishing rod .
Shakespearean: Give me mine angle .

English: We'll go to the river .
Shakespearean: We'll to th' river .

English: With my music playing in the background , I'll lure fish .
Shakespearean: There , My music playing far off , I will betray Tawny-finned fishes .

English: Cram your good news into my ears .
Shakespearean: Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears , That long time have been barren .

English: Madam , madam , Antony's dead !
Shakespearean: Madam , madam , Antonio's dead !

English: If you say that , you bastard , you'll kill your Queen .
Shakespearean: If thou say so , villain , Thou kill'st thy mistress .

English: Kings have trembled to kiss this hand .
Shakespearean: But well and free , If thou so yield him , there is gold , and here My bluest veins to kiss , a hand that kings Have lipped , and trembled kissing .

English: Let me say first , madam , that he is well .
Shakespearean: First , madam , he is well .

English: Well then , here's more money for you .
Shakespearean: Why , there's more gold .

English: But you know , sirrah , we customarily say that the dead are well .
Shakespearean: But , sirrah , mark , we use To say the dead are well .

English: If that's what you mean , I'll melt this gold and pour it down your throat that speaks these hateful words .
Shakespearean: Bring it to that , The gold I give thee will I melt and pour Down thy ill-uttering throat .

English: Good madam , let me speak .
Shakespearean: Good madam , hear me .

English: All right , I will .
Shakespearean: Well , go to , I will .

English: But you don't look as if you bring good news .
Shakespearean: But there's no goodness in thy face , if Antony Be free and healthful , so tart a favor To trumpet such good tidings !

English: If you really are Sir Rowland's son , as you've just whispered to me , and I can absolutely see the likeness in your face , you are truly welcome here .
Shakespearean: If that you were the good Sir Rowland's son , As you have whispered faithfully you were , And as mine eye doth his effigies witness Most truly limned and living in your face , Be truly welcome hither .

English: I am the duke who loved your father .
Shakespearean: I am the duke That loved your father .

English: Come to my cave and tell me the rest of your story. , Good old man , you are as welcome here as your master is .
Shakespearean: The residue of your fortune Go to my cave and tell me. , Good old man , Thou art right welcome as thy master is .

English: Give him your arm .
Shakespearean: Support him by the arm .

English: Give me your hand , and explain your situation to me .
Shakespearean: Give me your hand , And let me all your fortunes understand .

English: You haven't seen him since ?
Shakespearean: Not see him since ?

English: Sir , sir , that can't be true .
Shakespearean: Sir , sir , that can not be .

English: If I weren't a merciful man , I'd forget about your missing brother and punish you in his place .
Shakespearean: But were I not the better part made mercy , I should not seek an absent argument Of my revenge , thou present .

English: But do this : find your brother , wherever he is .
Shakespearean: But look to it : Find out thy brother , wheresoe'er he is .

English: Bring him here dead or alive within the next year , or get out off my land .
Shakespearean: Bring him , dead or living , Within this twelvemonth or turn thou no more To seek a living in our territory .

English: I'm seizing your lands and all that you possess until your brother gives testimony that absolves you of any guilt .
Shakespearean: Thy lands and all things that thou dost call thine Worth seizure , do we seize into our hands Till thou canst quit thee by thy brother's mouth Of what we think against thee .

English: I wish your Highness knew my true feelings in this matter : I have never in my life loved my brother .
Shakespearean: Oh , that your Highness knew my heart in this : I never loved my brother in my life .

English: That makes you an even bigger villain. , Well , throw him out , and have my officers seize his house and lands .
Shakespearean: More villain thou. , Well , push him out of doors And let my officers of such a nature Make an extent upon his house and lands .

English: Do this immediately , and send him packing .
Shakespearean: Do this expediently , and turn him going .

English: Hang there on this tree , you lines of poetry , and bear witness to my love .
Shakespearean: Hang there , my verse , in witness of my love .

English: And you , And how are you liking the shepherd's life , Master Touchstone ?
Shakespearean: And how like you this shepherd's life , Master Touchstone ?

English: Well , in and of itself , it is a good life , but given that it's a shepherd's life , it's worthless .
Shakespearean: Truly , shepherd , in respect of itself , it is a good life ; but in respect that it is a shepherd's life , it is naught .

English: In the fact that it's solitary , I enjoy it very much ; but in the sense that it's private , it's terrible .
Shakespearean: In respect that it is solitary , I like it very well ; but in respect that it is private , it is a very vile life .

English: Now , I'm very pleased with it being outdoors , but in its not being at the court , it is boring .
Shakespearean: Now in respect it is in the fields , it pleaseth me well ; but in respect it is not in the court , it is tedious .

English: Are you any kind of philosopher yourself , shepherd ?
Shakespearean: Hast any philosophy in thee , shepherd ?

English: You're a natural-born philosopher !
Shakespearean: Such a one is a natural philosopher .

English: Were you ever at court , shepherd ?
Shakespearean: Wast ever in court , shepherd ?

English: Honestly , no .
Shakespearean: No , truly .

English: Then you are damned .
Shakespearean: Then thou art damned .

English: I hope not .
Shakespearean: Nay , I hope .

English: Explain .
Shakespearean: Your reason .

English: Well , if you were never at court , you were never exposed to good manners ; if you never witnessed good manners , your manners must be wicked ; wickedness is a sin , and committing sins leads to damnation .
Shakespearean: Why , if thou never wast at court , thou never saw'st good manners ; if thou never saw'st good manners , then thy manners must be wicked , and wickedness is sin , and sin is damnation .

English: You are in a perilous state , shepherd .
Shakespearean: Thou art in a parlous state , shepherd .

English: Not at all , Touchstone .
Shakespearean: Not a whit , Touchstone .

English: The good manners of the court look as silly in the country as country behavior is laughable at the court .
Shakespearean: Those that are good manners at the court are as ridiculous in the country as the behavior of the country is most mockable at the court .

English: You told me that you don't salute at the court but kiss hands .
Shakespearean: You told me you salute not at the court but you kiss your hands .

English: Now , if courtiers were shepherds , that kind of courtesy would be unclean .
Shakespearean: That courtesy would be uncleanly if courtiers were shepherds .

English: Give a quick example .
Shakespearean: Instance , briefly .

English: Come , explain .
Shakespearean: Come , instance .

English: Why , because we're always handling our ewes , and their fleece , as you know , is greasy .
Shakespearean: Why , we are still handling our ewes , and their fells , you know , are greasy .

English: What , don't courtiers ' hands sweat ?
Shakespearean: Why , do not your courtier's hands sweat ?

English: And isn't a sheep's grease as wholesome as a man's sweat ?
Shakespearean: And is not the grease of a mutton as wholesome as the sweat of a man ?

English: That's a poor example .
Shakespearean: A better instance , I say .

English: A better example , come on .
Shakespearean: Come .

English: Besides , our hands are hard and calloused .
Shakespearean: Besides , our hands are hard .

English: Then your lips will feel them more quickly .
Shakespearean: Your lips will feel them the sooner .

English: Come on .
Shakespearean: Come .

English: You worthless man !
Shakespearean: Most shallow man .

English: You are about as much of a thinker as worm's meat is a nice steak .
Shakespearean: Thou worms ' meat in respect of a good piece of flesh , indeed .

English: Learn from the wise , and comprehend : the courtier's perfume is made from cat discharge , much more disgusting than tar .
Shakespearean: Learn of the wise and perpend : civet is of a baser birth than tar , the very uncleanly flux of a cat .

English: Fix your example , shepherd .
Shakespearean: Mend the instance , shepherd .

English: Your wit is too courtly for me .
Shakespearean: You have too courtly a wit for me .

English: I'll rest now .
Shakespearean: I'll rest .

English: Good morning , sir .
Shakespearean: Good morrow to your Worship .

English: Can you tell me whether Rosalind , Duke Senior's daughter , has also been banished ?
Shakespearean: Can you tell if Rosalind , the duke's daughter , be banished with her father ?

English: Where will the old duke live ?
Shakespearean: Where will the old duke live ?

English: You're going to rest while you're still damned ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou rest damned ?

English: God help you , foolish man .
Shakespearean: God help thee , shallow man .

English: Pray God does some surgery on you : you need to be fixed .
Shakespearean: God make incision in thee ; thou art raw .

English: That's another sin arising from your ignorance : you bring ewes and rams together and make your living by their copulation .
Shakespearean: That is another simple sin in you , to bring the ewes and the rams together and to offer to get your living by the copulation of cattle ; to be bawd to a bellwether and to betray a she-lamb of a twelvemonth to a crooked-pated old cuckoldly ram , out of all reasonable match .

English: Here comes young Mr. Ganymede , my new mistress's brother .
Shakespearean: Here comes young Master Ganymede , my new mistress's brother .

English: There is no jewel like Rosalind .
Shakespearean: No jewel is like Rosalind .

English: Her worth is carried on the wind And it blows throughout the world , carrying the name of Rosalind .
Shakespearean: Her worth being mounted on the wind , Through all the world bears Rosalind .

English: All the most beautiful paintings Are black when compared to Rosalind .
Shakespearean: All the pictures fairest lined Are but black to Rosalind .

English: Don't think of any beauty But the beauty of Rosalind .
Shakespearean: Let no fair be kept in mind But the fair of Rosalind .

English: I could rhyme like that for eight years in a row , excepting meal times and sleeping hours .
Shakespearean: I'll rhyme you so eight years together , dinners and suppers and sleeping hours excepted .

English: That awful , plodding rhyme sounded like a row of dairy women stomping off to market .
Shakespearean: It is the right butter-women's rank to market .

English: Oh , stop , fool .
Shakespearean: Out , fool .

English: Let me try : If there's a buck who needs a doe Tell him Rosalind will do .
Shakespearean: For a taste : If a hart do lack a hind , Let him seek out Rosalind .

English: A cat in heat will look for a mate , And Rosalind certainly will too .
Shakespearean: If the cat will after kind , So , be sure , will Rosalind .

English: Winter garments need to be filled with something , And so does skinny Rosalind .
Shakespearean: Winter garments must be lined , So must slender Rosalind .

English: After you harvest , you have to sheaf and bind So throw ripe Rosalind on the harvest cart .
Shakespearean: They that reap must sheaf and bind , Then to cart with Rosalind .

English: The sweetest nut has the sourest rind And Rosalind is that kind of nut .
Shakespearean: Sweetest nut hath sourest rind ; Such a nut is Rosalind .

English: The man who finds the sweetest rose Will be pricked by it , and by Rosalind .
Shakespearean: He that sweetest rose will find Must find love's prick , and Rosalind .

English: This is exactly the false way that verses gallop along .
Shakespearean: This is the very false gallop of verses .

English: Why bother with them ?
Shakespearean: Why do you infect yourself with them ?

English: Quiet , you stupid fool .
Shakespearean: Peace , you dull fool .

English: I found them on a tree .
Shakespearean: I found them on a tree .

English: Well , the tree bears rotten fruit .
Shakespearean: Truly , the tree yields bad fruit .

English: All right , you've had your say , but we'll let the forest judge whether or not you spoke wisely .
Shakespearean: You have said , but whether wisely or no , let the forest judge .

English: Quiet !
Shakespearean: Peace .

English: But on the prettiest branches Or at the end of every sentence I'll write "Rosalinda , " Teaching everyone who can read that the essence of every spirit Is contained in this one woman .
Shakespearean: But upon the fairest boughs , Or at every sentence end , Will I "Rosalinda" write , Teaching all that read to know The quintessence of every sprite Heaven would in little show .

English: Heaven commanded Nature To fill her one body With all the graces that women contain .
Shakespearean: Therefore heaven nature charged That one body should be filled With all graces wide-enlarged .

English: Nature took Helen's Cleopatra's majesty , The best of Atalanta , And unhappy Lucretia's modesty .
Shakespearean: Nature presently distilled Helen's cheek , but not her heart , Cleopatra's majesty , Atalanta's better part , Sad Lucretia's modesty .

English: So , by heaven's decree , Rosalind Was composed Of different faces , eyes , and hearts , so that she might have the most prized touches of all .
Shakespearean: Thus Rosalind of many parts By heavenly synod was devised , Of many faces , eyes , and hearts To have the touches dearest prized .

English: Heaven wanted Rosalind to have these gifts And me to live and die as her slave .
Shakespearean: Heaven would that she these gifts should have And I to live and die her slave .

English: Were you listening to these verses ?
Shakespearean: Didst thou hear these verses ?

English: Oh yes , I heard them all , and more , too .
Shakespearean: Oh , yes , I heard them all , and more too , for some of them had in them more feet than the verses would bear .

English: Some of those lines had more feet than the That's not a problem : the feet can bear Sure , but these feet were
Shakespearean: Ay , but the feet were lame and could not bear themselves without the verse , and therefore stood lamely in the verse .

English: But did you listen to all that poetry without even wondering about what your name is doing on all these trees ?
Shakespearean: But didst thou hear without wondering how thy name should be hanged and carved upon these trees ?

English: Was it a man ?
Shakespearean: Is it a man ?

English: And he had a chain that once belonged to you hanging around his neck .
Shakespearean: And a chain , that you once wore , about his neck .

English: Are you blushing ?
Shakespearean: Change you color ?

English: Please , who ?
Shakespearean: I prithee , who ?

English: It's difficult to bring two friends together , but even mountains can be moved together by earthquakes .
Shakespearean: O Lord , Lord , it is a hard matter for friends to meet , but mountains may be removed with earthquakes and so encounter .

English: No , who are you talking about ?
Shakespearean: Nay , but who is it ?

English: Is it possible ?
Shakespearean: Is it possible ?

English: No , I'm begging you now , tell me who it is .
Shakespearean: Nay , I prithee now , with most petitionary vehemence , tell me who it is .

English: Oh , this is wonderful , wonderful , just wonderful wonderful !
Shakespearean: O wonderful , wonderful , and most wonderful wonderful , and yet again wonderful , and after that , out of all whooping !

English: Good grief , do you think that just because I'm dressed like a man , I have a man's patience ?
Shakespearean: Good my complexion , dost thou think though I am caparisoned like a man , I have a doublet and hose in my disposition ?

English: Every second you delay is as long and dull as a journey to South Seas .
Shakespearean: One inch of delay more is a South Sea of discovery .

English: I'm begging you , tell me who it is quickly , and speak fast .
Shakespearean: I prithee , tell me who is it quickly , and speak apace .

English: I wish you could just stammer this hidden man out of your mouth like wine out of a narrow-necked bottle : either too much at once or none at all .
Shakespearean: I would thou couldst stammer , that thou might'st pour this concealed man out of thy mouth as wine comes out of a narrow-mouthed bottle , either too much at once , or none at all .

English: I'm begging you , take the cork out of your mouth so I can drink the news .
Shakespearean: I prithee take the cork out of thy mouth , that I may drink thy tidings .

English: So you want to put a man in your belly .
Shakespearean: So you may put a man in your belly .

English: Did God make him ?
Shakespearean: Is he of God's making ?

English: I mean , what sort of man is he ?
Shakespearean: What manner of man ?

English: Is he enough of a man to wear a hat and grow a beard ?
Shakespearean: Is his head worth a hat or his chin worth a beard ?

English: No , he has only a little beard .
Shakespearean: Nay , he hath but a little beard .

English: Well , eventually God will send him some more hair , if he thanks Him .
Shakespearean: Why , God will send more , if the man will be thankful .

English: I'll wait till his beard grows in , if you'll just hurry up and tell me what chin that beard is on .
Shakespearean: Let me stay the growth of his beard , if thou delay me not the knowledge of his chin .

English: It's Orlando , who triumphed over both the wrestler and you in the same instant .
Shakespearean: It is young Orlando , that tripped up the wrestler's heels and your heart both in an instant .

English: Damn you for mocking me .
Shakespearean: Nay , but the devil take mocking .

English: Really , cousin , it's him .
Shakespearean: I ' faith , coz , 'tis he .

English: Orlando ?
Shakespearean: Orlando ?

English: Orlando .
Shakespearean: Orlando .

English: What did he do when you saw him ?
Shakespearean: What did he when thou saw'st him ?

English: What did he say ?
Shakespearean: What said he ?

English: How did he look ?
Shakespearean: How looked he ?

English: Where did he go ?
Shakespearean: Wherein went he ?

English: What brings him here ?
Shakespearean: What makes him here ?

English: Did he ask about me ?
Shakespearean: Did he ask for me ?

English: Where is he staying ?
Shakespearean: Where remains he ?

English: How did he say good-bye ?
Shakespearean: How parted he with thee ?

English: And when will you see him again ?
Shakespearean: And when shalt thou see him again ?

English: Answer me in a word .
Shakespearean: Answer me in one word .

English: You'd better get me But does he know that I'm here in the forest and dressed in men's clothing ?
Shakespearean: But doth he know that I am in this forest and in man's apparel ?

English: Does he look as bright and handsome as the day we saw him wrestling ?
Shakespearean: Looks he as freshly as he did the day he wrestled ?

English: But taste my story , and relish it by paying attention .
Shakespearean: But take a taste of my finding him , and relish it with good observance .

English: I found Orlando under a tree , like a dropped acorn .
Shakespearean: I found him under a tree like a dropped acorn .

English: That tree could be called God's tree , since it drops such wonderful fruit .
Shakespearean: It may well be called Jove's tree when it drops forth such fruit .

English: Let me talk , good lady .
Shakespearean: Give me audience , good madam .

English: Go on .
Shakespearean: Proceed .

English: He lay there , stretched out like a wounded knight .
Shakespearean: There lay he , stretched along like a wounded knight .

English: Though that must have been a pitiful sight , the ground looked beautiful .
Shakespearean: Though it be pity to see such a sight , it well becomes the ground .

English: Cry , "whoa ! " to your tongue , please .
Shakespearean: Cry "holla" to thy tongue , I prithee .

English: It's leaping about like a frisky horse .
Shakespearean: It curvets unseasonably .

English: He was dressed like a hunter .
Shakespearean: He was furnished like a hunter .

English: Oh , that's ominous !
Shakespearean: Oh , ominous !

English: He has come to kill my heart .
Shakespearean: He comes to kill my heart .

English: I'd like to sing my song solo .
Shakespearean: I would sing my song without a burden .

English: You're making me go off-key .
Shakespearean: Thou bring'st me out of tune .

English: Don't you know that I'm a woman ?
Shakespearean: Do you not know I am a woman ?

English: Whatever I think , I have to say .
Shakespearean: When I think , I must speak .

English: Sweetheart , go on .
Shakespearean: Sweet , say on .

English: Quiet !
Shakespearean: You bring me out .

English: Isn't that him heading this way ?
Shakespearean: Soft , comes he not here ?

English: That's him .
Shakespearean: Tis he .

English: Thanks for your company but , really , I would have preferred being alone .
Shakespearean: I thank you for your company , but , good faith , I had as lief have been myself alone .

English: Me too , but still , for the sake of good manners , I'll say thanks for your company .
Shakespearean: And so had I , but yet , for fashion sake , I thank you too for your society .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: God be wi ' you .

English: Let's meet as little as we can .
Shakespearean: Let's meet as little as we can .

English: I also hope that we can be better strangers .
Shakespearean: I do desire we may be better strangers .

English: Please don't ruin any more trees by carving love poems on their barks .
Shakespearean: I pray you mar no more trees with writing love songs in their barks .

English: Please don't ruin any more of my poems by reading them so badly .
Shakespearean: I pray you mar no more of my verses with reading them ill- favoredly .

English: Your love's name is Rosalind ?
Shakespearean: Rosalind is your love's name ?

English: Yes , that's it .
Shakespearean: Yes , just .

English: I don't like her name .
Shakespearean: I do not like her name .

English: How tall is she ?
Shakespearean: What stature is she of ?

English: Just as tall as my heart .
Shakespearean: Just as high as my heart .

English: You're sure full of smooth answers .
Shakespearean: You are full of pretty answers .

English: Your worst fault is being in love .
Shakespearean: The worst fault you have is to be in love .

English: Well , it's a fault I wouldn't trade for your best virtue .
Shakespearean: Tis a fault I will not change for your best virtue .

English: I'm tired of you .
Shakespearean: I am weary of you .

English: There I'll see only myself .
Shakespearean: There I shall see mine own figure .

English: Which is either a fool or a nothing .
Shakespearean: Which I take to be either a fool or a cipher .

English: I'm not going to waste any more time with you .
Shakespearean: I'll tarry no longer with you .

English: Goodbye , good Mr. Love .
Shakespearean: Farewell , good Signior Love .

English: I'm glad to see you go .
Shakespearean: I am glad of your departure .

English: Adieu , good Mr. Depression .
Shakespearean: Adieu , good Monsieur Melancholy .

English: Very well .
Shakespearean: Very well .

English: What do you want ?
Shakespearean: What would you ?

English: You should ask me what time of day it is , instead .
Shakespearean: You should ask me what time o ' day .

English: There's no clock here in the forest .
Shakespearean: There's no clock in the forest .

English: Then there must be no lovers in the forest , either , because they're as good as a clock , marking the lazy foot of time with a sigh every minute and a groan every hour .
Shakespearean: Then there is no true lover in the forest , else sighing every minute and groaning every hour would detect the lazy foot of time as well as a clock .

English: Indeed I do , sir , and I've come to let you in on a certain problem .
Shakespearean: Marry , do I , sir , and I came to acquaint you with a matter .

English: I've been informed by certain sources I can't disclose that your younger brother Orlando plans to fight me in disguise .
Shakespearean: I am given , sir , secretly to understand that your younger brother Orlando hath a disposition to come in disguised against me to try a fall .

English: Tomorrow , sir , I'm fighting for my reputation , and any man who gets away without a broken bone or two is an exceptional wrestler indeed .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow , sir , I wrestle for my credit , and he that escapes me without some broken limb shall acquit him well .

English: Your brother is young and inexperienced , and because of my affection for you , I'd hate to crush him , though I'd have to , if he challenged me .
Shakespearean: Your brother is but young and tender , and , for your love I would be loath to foil him , as I must for my own honor if he come in .

English: I'm telling you all this out of affection for you , so you can either keep him from carrying out his plans or prepare to accept his disgrace , which will be his own fault , not mine .
Shakespearean: Therefore , out of my love to you , I came hither to acquaint you withal , that either you might stay him from his intendment or brook such disgrace well as he shall run into , in that it is a thing of his own search and altogether against my will .

English: Charles , I thank you for your loyalty to me , and you'll see that I'll reward you .
Shakespearean: Charles , I thank thee for thy love to me , which thou shalt find I will most kindly requite .

English: I'd heard about my brother's plan and have been subtly trying to change his mind , but he's determined .
Shakespearean: I had myself notice of my brother's purpose herein and have by underhand means labored to dissuade him from it ; but he is resolute .

English: I tell you , Charles , he's the stubbornest young fellow in France : overly ambitious , jealous of other people's good qualities , and a traitor against me , his own blood brother .
Shakespearean: I'll tell thee , Charles : it is the stubbornest young fellow of France , full of ambition , an envious emulator of every man's good parts , a secret and villainous contriver against me his natural brother .

English: So use your discretion .
Shakespearean: Therefore use thy discretion .

English: I'd be just as happy if you broke his neck as his finger .
Shakespearean: I had as lief thou didst break his neck as his finger .

English: But if I really laid him bare , I'd have to weep and hang my head , and you would not believe me , his behavior is so shocking .
Shakespearean: I speak but brotherly of him , but should I anatomize him to thee as he is , I must blush and weep , and thou must look pale and wonder .

English: Why didn't you say "the swift steps" of time instead of the "lazy foot" ?
Shakespearean: And why not the swift foot of time ?

English: Wouldn't that have been just as appropriate ?
Shakespearean: Had not that been as proper ?

English: No , not at all , sir .
Shakespearean: By no means , sir .

English: Time travels at different speeds for different people .
Shakespearean: Time travels in diverse paces with diverse persons .

English: I can tell you who time strolls for , who it trots for , who it gallops for , and who it stops cold for .
Shakespearean: I'll tell you who time ambles withal , who time trots withal , who time gallops withal , and who he stands still withal .

English: Okay , who does it trot for ?
Shakespearean: I prithee , who doth he trot withal ?

English: Who does time amble for ?
Shakespearean: Who ambles time withal ?

English: Time ambles for both men .
Shakespearean: These time ambles withal .

English: Who does it gallop for ?
Shakespearean: Who doth he gallop withal ?

English: Who does it stand still for ?
Shakespearean: Who stays it still withal ?

English: For lawyers on vacation , because they sleep their holidays away , with no sense of how time moves .
Shakespearean: With lawyers in the vacation , for they sleep between term and term , and then they perceive not how time moves .

English: Where do you live , pretty young man ?
Shakespearean: Where dwell you , pretty youth ?

English: Were you born here ?
Shakespearean: Are you native of this place ?

English: Just like the rabbit , who lives where she is born .
Shakespearean: As the cony that you see dwell where she is kindled .

English: Your speech is more refined than I would expect in such a remote place as this .
Shakespearean: Your accent is something finer than you could purchase in so removed a dwelling .

English: Many people have told me so .
Shakespearean: I have been told so of many .

English: Actually , an old religious uncle of mine taught me how to speak , and he was brought up in the city .
Shakespearean: But indeed an old religious uncle of mine taught me to speak , who was in his youth an inland man , one that knew courtship too well , for there he fell in love .

English: Thank God I'm not a woman and afflicted with all the giddiness that troubles that entire sex .
Shakespearean: I have heard him read many lectures against it , and I thank God I am not a woman , to be touched with so many giddy offenses as he hath generally taxed their whole sex withal .

English: What were the primary evils he claimed women were guilty of ?
Shakespearean: Can you remember any of the principal evils that he laid to the charge of women ?

English: There were no primary ones .
Shakespearean: There were none principal .

English: Please , tell me some of them .
Shakespearean: I prithee , recount some of them .

English: No , I won't give my medicine away to anyone but the sick .
Shakespearean: No , I will not cast away my physic but on those that are sick .

English: There's a man haunting this forest who abuses the trees by carving "Rosalind" on their barks .
Shakespearean: There is a man haunts the forest that abuses our young plants with carving "Rosalind" on their barks , hangs odes upon hawthorns and elegies on brambles , all , forsooth , deifying the name of Rosalind .

English: Well , I'm the man you're speaking of .
Shakespearean: I am he that is so love-shaked .

English: Please , tell me your cure .
Shakespearean: I pray you tell me your remedy .

English: But you don't have any of the symptoms my uncle told me about .
Shakespearean: There is none of my uncle's marks upon you .

English: He taught me how to recognize a man in love , and you're not a prisoner of love , I'm sure .
Shakespearean: He taught me how to know a man in love , in which cage of rushes I am sure you are not prisoner .

English: What did he say the symptoms were ?
Shakespearean: What were his marks ?

English: A thin face , which you don't have ; a sleepless , sunken eye , which you don't have ; an irritable temper , which you don't have ; a neglected beard , which you don't have , but that might not be so telling , since you don't have much beard anyway .
Shakespearean: A lean cheek , which you have not ; a blue eye and sunken , which you have not ; an unquestionable spirit , which you have not ; a beard neglected , which you have not , but I pardon you for that , for simply your having in beard is a younger brother's revenue .

English: Your stockings should be falling down around your ankles , your hat flying off your head , your sleeves unbuttoned , your shoes untied , and everything about you demonstrating carelessness and misery .
Shakespearean: Then your hose should be ungartered , your bonnet unbanded , your sleeve unbuttoned , your shoe untied , and everything about you demonstrating a careless desolation .

English: But you're no such man .
Shakespearean: But you are no such man .

English: You're so neat and well put-together that you look like you love yourself more than anyone else .
Shakespearean: You are rather point-device in your accouterments , as loving yourself than seeming the lover of any other .

English: Young boy , I wish I could make you believe that I'm in love .
Shakespearean: Fair youth , I would I could make thee believe I love .

English: Make me believe it ?
Shakespearean: Me believe it ?

English: But really , are you the one who's been hanging on the trees those poems that speak so admiringly of Rosalind ?
Shakespearean: But , in good sooth , are you he that hangs the verses on the trees wherein Rosalind is so admired ?

English: I swear to you by Rosalind's own pretty hand that I am that unfortunate man .
Shakespearean: I swear to thee , youth , by the white hand of Rosalind , I am that he , that unfortunate he .

English: Are you really as in love as your poems declare ?
Shakespearean: But are you so much in love as your rhymes speak ?

English: Neither rhyme nor reason can express how much I love her .
Shakespearean: Neither rhyme nor reason can express how much .

English: The only reason they don't get punished and cured is that the disease is so commonplace that the nuthouse nurses are usually suffering from it , too .
Shakespearean: Love is merely a madness and , I tell you , deserves as well a dark house and a whip as madmen do , and the reason why they are not so punished and cured is that the lunacy is so ordinary that the whippers are in love , too .

English: But I promise it can be cured with some guidance .
Shakespearean: Yet I profess curing it by counsel .

English: Have you ever cured anyone this way before ?
Shakespearean: Did you ever cure any so ?

English: Yes , one , and this is how I did it .
Shakespearean: Yes , one , and in this manner .

English: I don't want to be cured , boy .
Shakespearean: I would not be cured , youth .

English: I could cure you , if you just called me Rosalind and came by my cottage every day to woo me .
Shakespearean: I would cure you if you would but call me Rosalind and come every day to my cote and woo me .

English: By my faith in love , I will , then .
Shakespearean: Now , by the faith of my love , I will .

English: Tell me where you live .
Shakespearean: Tell me where it is .

English: Come with me , I'll show you , and along the way , you can tell me where you live .
Shakespearean: Go with me to it , and I'll show it you ; and by the way you shall tell me where in the forest you live .

English: Will you come ?
Shakespearean: Will you go ?

English: Wholeheartedly , good young man .
Shakespearean: With all my heart , good youth .

English: No , you have to call me Rosalind. , Sister , you're coming ?
Shakespearean: Nay , you must call me Rosalind. , Come , sister , will you go ?

English: Come on , sweet Audrey .
Shakespearean: Come apace , good Audrey .

English: I'll get your goats , Audrey .
Shakespearean: I will fetch up your goats , Audrey .

English: Do my simple features please you ?
Shakespearean: Doth my simple feature content you ?

English: Your features , God help us !
Shakespearean: Your features , Lord warrant us !

English: What features ?
Shakespearean: What features ?

English: Really , Audrey , I wish you were more poetical .
Shakespearean: Truly , I would the gods had made thee poetical .

English: I don't know what "poetical" means .
Shakespearean: I do not know what "poetical" is .

English: Is it "chaste in word and action" ?
Shakespearean: Is it honest in deed and word ?

English: Does it mean being truthful ?
Shakespearean: Is it a true thing ?

English: Not really , for the truest poetry is often the most artificial .
Shakespearean: No , truly , for the truest poetry is the most feigning , and lovers are given to poetry , and what they swear in poetry may be said as lovers they do feign .

English: But you still wish the gods had made me poetical ?
Shakespearean: Do you wish then that the gods had made me poetical ?

English: I do , in fact .
Shakespearean: I do , truly , for thou swear'st to me thou art honest .

English: Right now you swear to me that you are a virgin ; if you were a poet , I might have some hope you were lying .
Shakespearean: Now , if thou wert a poet , I might have some hope thou didst feign .

English: What , you don't want me to be chaste ?
Shakespearean: Would you not have me honest ?

English: Not really , unless you were ugly .
Shakespearean: No , truly , unless thou wert hard-favored , for honesty coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to sugar .

English: Well , I'm not beautiful , so I hope that I can at least be chaste .
Shakespearean: Well , I am not fair , and therefore I pray the gods make me honest .

English: I'm not a slut , I keep myself clean , but I thank God I am ugly .
Shakespearean: I am not a slut , though I thank the gods I am foul .

English: Well , praise the Lord you're ugly .
Shakespearean: Well , praised be the gods for thy foulness ; sluttishness may come hereafter .

English: Well , God bless this marriage !
Shakespearean: But what though ?

English: Amen .
Shakespearean: Courage .

English: Well , that's what the wife brings to the marriage .
Shakespearean: Well , that is the dowry of his wife ; 'tis none of his own getting .

English: Horns ?
Shakespearean: Horns ?

English: Well , there they are .
Shakespearean: Even so .

English: Only for poor men ?
Shakespearean: Poor men alone ?

English: No , no .
Shakespearean: No , no .

English: The nobleman's are as huge as the underfed villager's .
Shakespearean: The noblest deer hath them as huge as the rascal .

English: Is the single man lucky , then ?
Shakespearean: Is the single man therefore blessed ?

English: No .
Shakespearean: No .

English: Just as a town protected by a wall around it is worth more than a low-lying village , a married man's horned forehead is more honorable than a bachelor's bare forehead .
Shakespearean: As a walled town is more worthier than a village , so is the forehead of a married man more honorable than the bare brow of a bachelor .

English: Here comes Sir Oliver .
Shakespearean: Here comes Sir Oliver. , Sir Oliver Martext , you are well met .

English: Will you marry us here , under this tree , or should we follow you to your chapel ?
Shakespearean: Will you dispatch us here under this tree , or shall we go with you to your chapel ?

English: Is there anyone to give the bride away ?
Shakespearean: Is there none here to give the woman ?

English: I don't want to take another man's second-hand goods .
Shakespearean: I will not take her on gift of any man .

English: No , someone has to give her away or the marriage isn't legal .
Shakespearean: Truly , she must be given , or the marriage is not lawful .

English: How are you , sir ?
Shakespearean: How do you , sir ?

English: We're glad to see you .
Shakespearean: You are very well met .

English: God bless you for being here .
Shakespearean: God 'ild you for your last company .

English: I'm very glad to see you .
Shakespearean: I am very glad to see you .

English: This is just a trifling matter here , sir .
Shakespearean: Even a toy in hand here , sir .

English: No , no , put your hat back on .
Shakespearean: Nay , pray be covered .

English: Do you want to get married , fool ?
Shakespearean: Will you be married , motley ?

English: Just as the ox has his yoke , the horse its bridle , the falcon a tether , a man has his desires , to keep in check .
Shakespearean: As the ox hath his bow , sir , the horse his curb , and the falcon her bells , so man hath his desires ; and as pigeons bill , so wedlock would be nibbling .

English: And , being a man of your breeding , you're going to be married under some shrubs like a beggar ?
Shakespearean: And will you , being a man of your breeding , be married under a bush like a beggar ?

English: Get yourself to a church and have a proper priest , who can tell you what marriage is all about , marry you .
Shakespearean: Get you to church , and have a good priest that can tell you what marriage is .

English: Then one of you will warp and pull away , and there goes your marriage .
Shakespearean: Then one of you will prove a shrunk panel and , like green timber , warp , warp .

English: Come with me and let me advise you .
Shakespearean: Go thou with me , and let me counsel thee .

English: Come , sweet Audrey .
Shakespearean: Come , sweet Audrey .

English: We have to be married properly .
Shakespearean: We must be married , or we must live in bawdry. , Farewell , good Master Oliver , not 'T is no matter .

English: None of these deranged rascals can shake me from my profession .
Shakespearean: Ne'er a fantastical knave of them all shall flout me out of my calling .

English: Don't talk to me .
Shakespearean: Never talk to me .

English: I'm going to cry .
Shakespearean: I will weep .

English: Go ahead if you want , but remember that crying doesn't suit a man .
Shakespearean: Do , I prithee , but yet have the grace to consider that tears do not become a man .

English: But don't I have good reason to cry ?
Shakespearean: But have I not cause to weep ?

English: As good a reason as any .
Shakespearean: As good cause as one would desire .

English: So go ahead and cry .
Shakespearean: Therefore weep .

English: His kiss is as holy as bread blessed by a priest .
Shakespearean: And his kissing is as full of sanctity as the touch of holy bread .

English: I'm very glad I came to see you .
Shakespearean: I am heartily glad I came hither to you .

English: If he shows up tomorrow , I'll give him what's coming to him .
