Shakespearean: If he come tomorrow , I'll give him his payment .

English: If he can manage to walk after our fight , I'll never wrestle for money again .
Shakespearean: If ever he go alone again , I'll never wrestle for prize more .

English: Farewell , my lord .
Shakespearean: Farewell , good Charles .

English: But not for long ; Charles will take care of everything .
Shakespearean: But it shall not be so long ; this wrestler shall clear all .

English: But you heard him swear up and down that he was .
Shakespearean: You have heard him swear downright he was .

English: He's staying in the forest with your father now .
Shakespearean: He attends here in the forest on the duke your father .

English: I met my father in the woods yesterday and had a long conversation with him .
Shakespearean: I met the duke yesterday and had much question with him .

English: He laughed at that and let me go .
Shakespearean: So he laughed and let me go .

English: He writes brave poems , speaks brave words , makes brave promises , and then breaks them just as bravely .
Shakespearean: But what talk we of fathers when there is such a man as Orlando ?

English: He's like a cowardly
Shakespearean: Oh , that's a brave man .

English: Who's coming here ?
Shakespearean: Who comes here ?

English: Mistress and master , you've often asked about that lovelorn shepherd you once saw me sitting with , the one who complained about the disdainful shepherdess he was in love with .
Shakespearean: Mistress and master , you have oft inquired After the shepherd that complained of love , Who you saw sitting by me on the turf , Praising the proud disdainful shepherdess That was his mistress .

English: Yes , what about him ?
Shakespearean: The sight of lovers feedeth those in love .

English: Sweet Phoebe , do not scorn me .
Shakespearean: Sweet Phoebe , do not scorn me .

English: Do not , Phoebe .
Shakespearean: Do not , Phoebe .

English: Go ahead and say you don't love me , but not so bitterly .
Shakespearean: Say that you love me not , but say not so In bitterness .

English: Faint , fall down , if you don't , then you're lying about my eyes being murderers .
Shakespearean: Now counterfeit to swoon , why , now fall down ; Or if thou canst not , Oh , for shame , for shame , Lie not , to say mine eyes are murderers .

English: Come on , show me the wound that my eyes have caused .
Shakespearean: Now show the wound mine eye hath made in thee .

English: But my eyes , which I've darted at you , haven't even left a mark .
Shakespearean: But now mine eyes , Which I have darted at thee , hurt thee not .

English: Now I am sure that eyes can't hurt a person .
Shakespearean: Nor , I am sure , there is no force in eyes That can do hurt .

English: Oh , darling Phoebe , if you ever fall in love with some fresh face , then you'll know about the invisible wounds that love's sharp arrows can make .
Shakespearean: O dear Phoebe , If ever , as that ever may be near , You meet in some fresh cheek the power of fancy , Then shall you know the wounds invisible That love's keen arrows make .

English: Well , until that time , don't come near me .
Shakespearean: But till that time Come not thou near me .

English: And when that time comes , then you can mock me , but please don't pity me , because I won't pity you .
Shakespearean: And when that time comes , Afflict me with thy mocks , pity me not , As till that time I shall not pity thee .

English: But mistress , know yourself .
Shakespearean: But , mistress , know yourself .

English: Get down on your knees and thank heaven for sending you such a good man .
Shakespearean: Down on your knees And thank heaven , fasting , for a good man's love , For I must tell you friendly in your ear , Sell when you can ; you are not for all markets .

English: Ask this man's forgiveness , love him , and accept his offer .
Shakespearean: Cry the man mercy , love him , take his offer .

English: So take her , shepherd , and God bless you .
Shakespearean: So take her to thee , shepherd .

English: Besides , I don't like you .
Shakespearean: Besides , I like you not .

English: Come on , sister .
Shakespearean: Will you go , sister ? , Shepherd , ply her hard .

English: And don't be proud .
Shakespearean: Come , sister. , Shepherdess , look on him better , And be not proud .

English: The whole world could look at you , and no one would be as blind as he is , thinking you're beautiful .
Shakespearean: Though all the world could see , None could be so abused in sight as he .

English: Sweet Phoebe , have pity on me .
Shakespearean: Sweet Phoebe , pity me .

English: Well , I'm sorry for you , gentle Silvius .
Shakespearean: Why , I am sorry for thee , gentle Silvius .

English: Then both my grief and your sorrow will be cured .
Shakespearean: If you do sorrow at my grief in love , By giving love your sorrow and my grief Were both extermined .

English: You have my friendship .
Shakespearean: Thou hast my love .

English: Isn't that enough ?
Shakespearean: Is not that neighborly ?

English: I want you .
Shakespearean: I would have you .

English: Well , that's just greedy .
Shakespearean: Why , that were covetousness .

English: But don't expect any more than that .
Shakespearean: But do not look for further recompense Than thine own gladness that thou art employed .

English: Do you know the boy who was just speaking to me ?
Shakespearean: Know'st thou the youth that spoke to me erewhile ?

English: Not very well , but I've met him several times .
Shakespearean: Not very well , but I have met him oft , And he hath bought the cottage and the bounds That the old carlot once was master of .

English: Don't think I'm in love with him just because I'm asking about him .
Shakespearean: Think not I love him , though I ask for him .

English: But what do I care about words ?
Shakespearean: Tis but a peevish boy , yet he talks well , But what care I for words ?

English: And yet , words are a good thing when the man speaking them is pleasant to listen to .
Shakespearean: Yet words do well When he that speaks them pleases those that hear .

English: He's awfully proud , but his pride suits him .
Shakespearean: It is a pretty youth , not very pretty , But sure he's proud , and yet his pride becomes him .

English: He'll grow up to be a proper man .
Shakespearean: He'll make a proper man .

English: He's not very tall , but he's tall enough for his age .
Shakespearean: He is not very tall , yet for his years he's tall .

English: His legs aren't great , but they're alright .
Shakespearean: His leg is but so-so , and yet 'tis well .

English: His lips were nice and red , a little more lively and passionate than the red that was in his cheeks , one was pure red and the other more pink .
Shakespearean: There was a pretty redness in his lip , A little riper and more lusty red Than that mixed in his cheek : 'twas just the difference Betwixt the constant red and mingled damask .

English: What right did he have to scold me like that ?
Shakespearean: For what had he to do to chide at me ?

English: He said my eyes and my hair were black and , now that I think of it , he scorned me .
Shakespearean: He said mine eyes were black and my hair black And , now I am remembered , scorned at me .

English: I'm surprised I didn't bite back .
Shakespearean: I marvel why I answered not again .

English: But no matter , I'll get back at him soon enough .
Shakespearean: But that's all one : omittance is no quittance .

English: I'll write him a taunting letter , and you can deliver it .
Shakespearean: I'll write to him a very taunting letter , And thou shalt bear it .

English: Will you do that for me , Silvius ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou , Silvius ?

English: With all my heart , Phoebe .
Shakespearean: Phoebe , with all my heart .

English: I'll be bitter toward him , and curt .
Shakespearean: I will be bitter with him and passing short .

English: Come with me , Silvius .
Shakespearean: Go with me , Silvius .

English: Please , pretty young man , I'd like to get to know you better .
Shakespearean: I prithee , pretty youth , let me be better acquainted with thee .

English: They say you are a melancholy fellow .
Shakespearean: They say you are a melancholy fellow .

English: I am .
Shakespearean: I am so .

English: I like it better than laughing .
Shakespearean: I do love it better than laughing .

English: People who are either too serious or too silly are awful .
Shakespearean: Those that are in extremity of either are abominable fellows and betray themselves to every modern censure worse than drunkards .

English: Well , I think it's good to be serious and keep quiet .
Shakespearean: Why , 'tis good to be sad and say nothing .

English: In that case it's good to be a post .
Shakespearean: Why then , 'tis good to be a post .

English: I don't have the proud melancholy of a courtier or the ambitious melancholy of a soldier or the calculated melancholy of a lawyer .
Shakespearean: I have neither the scholar's melancholy , which is emulation ; nor the musician's , which is fantastical ; nor the courtier's , which is proud ; nor the soldier's , which is ambitious ; nor the lawyer's , which is politic ; nor the lady's , which is nice ; nor the lover's , which is all these , but it is a melancholy of mine own , compounded of many simples , extracted from many objects , and indeed the sundry contemplation of my travels , in which my often rumination wraps me in a most humorous sadness .

English: You're a traveler .
Shakespearean: A traveler .

English: Well then , you have good reason to be sad .
Shakespearean: By my faith , you have great reason to be sad .

English: I'm afraid you've sold your own land to see other men's .
Shakespearean: I fear you have sold your own lands to see other men's .

English: To have seen much but own nothing is to have rich eyes and poor hands .
Shakespearean: Then to have seen much and to have nothing is to have rich eyes and poor hands .

English: Not true .
Shakespearean: Yes , I have gained my experience .

English: And your experience makes you sad .
Shakespearean: And your experience makes you sad .

English: I'd rather have a jester to make me happy than experience to make me sad , and to travel for all that trouble , no less !
Shakespearean: I had rather have a fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad , and to travel for it , too .

English: Good day and happiness to you , darling Rosalind .
Shakespearean: Good day and happiness , dear Rosalind .

English: My beautiful Rosalind , I'm only an hour late .
Shakespearean: My fair Rosalind , I come within an hour of my promise .

English: Please , Rosalind , my sweet cousin , be happy .
Shakespearean: I pray thee , Rosalind , sweet my coz , be merry .

English: Dear Celia , I already look much happier than I feel , but you want me to look even happier ?
Shakespearean: Dear Celia , I show more mirth than I am mistress of , and would you yet I were merrier ?

English: Unless you can also teach me how to forget my banished father , you shouldn't try to teach me how to be happy .
Shakespearean: Unless you could teach me to forget a banished father , you must not learn me how to remember any extraordinary pleasure .

English: Well , by this I can see that you don't love me as much as I love you .
Shakespearean: Herein I see thou lov'st me not with the full weight that I love thee .

English: If Well , I'll just forget the difficulties of my situation , in order to focus on the happiness of yours .
Shakespearean: Well , I will forget the condition of my estate to rejoice in yours .

English: I swear I will , and if I ever break my promise let me turn into a monster .
Shakespearean: By mine honor I will , and when I break that oath , let me turn monster .

English: So please , my sweet Rose , my dear Rose , be happy .
Shakespearean: Therefore , my sweet Rose , my dear Rose , be merry .

English: From now on I will , cousin , and I'll think of all kinds of games for us .
Shakespearean: From henceforth I will , coz , and devise sports .

English: Let me see , what do you think about falling in love ?
Shakespearean: Let me see , what think you of falling in love ?

English: You'd break a date with your beloved by a whole hour ?
Shakespearean: Break an hour's promise in love ?

English: Forgive me , darling Rosalind .
Shakespearean: Pardon me , dear Rosalind .

English: No , if you're ever late like this again , I'll refuse to see you .
Shakespearean: Nay , an you be so tardy , come no more in my sight .

English: I'd rather be wooed by a snail .
Shakespearean: I had as lief be wooed of a snail .

English: A snail ?
Shakespearean: Of a snail ?

English: Besides , he brings his fate with him .
Shakespearean: Besides , he brings his destiny with him .

English: What fate is that ?
Shakespearean: What's that ?

English: Why , his cuckold's horns , of course , the kind you men are always blaming on your wives .
Shakespearean: Why , horns , which such as you are fain to be beholding to your wives for .

English: See , the snail already has its horns , which prevents nasty rumors from spreading about his wife's infidelity .
Shakespearean: But he comes armed in his fortune and prevents the slander of his wife .

English: A virtuous woman won't give her husband horns , and my Rosalind is definitely virtuous .
Shakespearean: Virtue is no hornmaker , and my Rosalind is virtuous .

English: And I am your Rosalind .
Shakespearean: And I am your Rosalind .

English: Come on , woo me , woo me .
Shakespearean: Rosalind of a better leer than you .

English: I'm in a good mood now and likely to give you what you want .
Shakespearean: Come , woo me , woo me , for now I am in a holiday humor , and like enough to consent .

English: What would you say to me now if I really were your precious little Rosalind ?
Shakespearean: What would you say to me now , an I were your very , very Rosalind ?

English: I'd kiss you before I spoke .
Shakespearean: I would kiss before I spoke .

English: No , it would be better to speak first and kiss only after you've run out of things to say .
Shakespearean: Nay , you were better speak first , and when you were graveled for lack of matter , you might take occasion to kiss .

English: When good orators finish talking , they spit ; when lovers do ( God help us if they ever do ) , they kiss .
Shakespearean: Very good orators , when they are out , they will spit ; and for lovers lacking , God warn us , matter , the cleanliest shift is to kiss .

English: What if she won't kiss me ?
Shakespearean: How if the kiss be denied ?

English: Who could be out of things to say if he were with the girl he loves ?
Shakespearean: Who could be out , being before his beloved mistress ?

English: Indeed , you would be out if I were your mistress , if my chastity is worth as much as my wit .
Shakespearean: Marry , that should you if I were your mistress , or I should think my honesty ranker than my wit .

English: Aren't I your Rosalind ?
Shakespearean: Am not I your Rosalind ?

English: I like to pretend you are , because then it's almost like actually talking to her .
Shakespearean: I take some joy to say you are because I would be talking of her .

English: No , you won't die yourself , but only by proxy .
Shakespearean: No , faith , die by attorney .

English: This world is almost six thousand years old , and in all this time not one man has ever actually died from love .
Shakespearean: The poor world is almost six thousand years old , and in all this time there was not any man died in his own person , videlicet , in a love cause .

English: Then love me , Rosalind .
Shakespearean: Then love me , Rosalind .

English: Okay , I will , on Fridays and Saturdays , and the rest .
Shakespearean: Yes , faith , will I , Fridays and Saturdays and all .

English: And will you have me ?
Shakespearean: And wilt thou have me ?

English: Sure , and twenty others just like you .
Shakespearean: Ay , and twenty such .

English: What's that ?
Shakespearean: What sayest thou ?

English: Well , aren't you a good man ?
Shakespearean: Are you not good ?

English: I hope so .
Shakespearean: I hope so .

English: And can a person ever have too much of a good thing ? , Come on , sister , you can be the priest and marry us. , Give me your hand , Orlando. , What do you say , sister ?
Shakespearean: Why then , can one desire too much of a good thing ? , Come , sister , you shall be the priest and marry us. , Give me your hand , Orlando. , What do you say , sister ?

English: Please , marry us .
Shakespearean: Pray thee , marry us .

English: I do .
Shakespearean: I will .

English: Okay , but when ?
Shakespearean: Ay , but when ?

English: Right now ; as fast as she can say the vows .
Shakespearean: Why , now , as fast as she can marry us .

English: Then you have to say , "I take you , Rosalind , to be my lawfully wedded wife." I take you , Rosalind , to be my lawfully wedded wife .
Shakespearean: Then you must say "I take thee , Rosalind , for wife." I take thee , Rosalind , for wife .

English: Maybe I should ask you what right you have to take me , but I'll take you , Orlando , to be my husband .
Shakespearean: I might ask you for your commission , but I do take thee , Orlando , for my husband .

English: So do all thoughts .
Shakespearean: So do all thoughts .

English: They have wings .
Shakespearean: They are winged .

English: Now tell me how long you intend to keep her .
Shakespearean: Now tell me how long you would have her after you have possessed her .

English: Forever and a day .
Shakespearean: Forever and a day .

English: No , Orlando , men are like April when they're wooing a girl , young , and passionate , but like December once they're married and their passions have cooled .
Shakespearean: Say "a day" without the "ever." No , no , Orlando , men are April when they woo , December when they wed. Maids are May when they are maids , but the sky changes when they are wives .

English: I'll be more jealous of you than a wild rooster over his hen ; more noisy than a parrot chattering about the rain ; more fond of new things than an ape ; more giddy about getting what I want than a monkey .
Shakespearean: I will be more jealous of thee than a Barbary cock- pigeon over his hen , more clamorous than a parrot against rain , more newfangled than an ape , more giddy in my desires than a monkey .

English: I'll cry at nothing , and I'll always do it when you're in a good mood .
Shakespearean: I will weep for nothing , like Diana in the fountain , and I will do that when you are disposed to be merry .

English: And when you want to go to sleep , I'll be up laughing like a hyena .
Shakespearean: I will laugh like a hyena , and that when thou art inclined to sleep .

English: But will my Rosalind do this , too ?
Shakespearean: But will my Rosalind do so ?

English: But she is wise .
Shakespearean: Oh , but she is wise .

English: Right .
Shakespearean: Or else she could not have the wit to do this .

English: The wiser the woman , the wilder .
Shakespearean: The wiser , the waywarder .

English: If you close the doors on a woman's wit , it'll fly out the window .
Shakespearean: Make the doors upon a woman's wit , and it will out at the casement .

English: If you shut the windows , it will pour out the keyhole .
Shakespearean: Shut that , and 'twill out at the keyhole .

English: If you stop up the keyhole , it will escape from the chimney along with the smoke .
Shakespearean: Stop that , 'twill fly with the smoke out at the chimney .

English: A man with a wife like that might ask , "Hey , wandering wit , where are you off to ? " Nah , better save the questions for when you find her in your neighbor's bed .
Shakespearean: A man that had a wife with such a wit , he might say "Wit , whither wilt ? " Nay , you might keep that check for it , till you met your wife's wit going to your neighbor's bed .

English: You'll never find her without an answer unless you find her without a tongue .
Shakespearean: You shall never take her without her answer unless you take her without her tongue .

English: A woman who doesn't know how to make her own indiscretions look like her husband's fault is hardly a woman .
Shakespearean: Oh , that woman that can not make her fault her husband's occasion , let her never nurse her child herself , for she will breed it like a fool .

English: Rosalind , I have to leave you for two hours .
Shakespearean: For these two hours , Rosalind , I will leave thee .

English: I must join the duke for lunch .
Shakespearean: I must attend the duke at dinner .

English: I'll be back here with you by two o'clock .
Shakespearean: By two o'clock I will be with thee again .

English: Oh , go , leave me .
Shakespearean: Ay , go your ways , go your ways .

English: I knew you'd turn out this way .
Shakespearean: I knew what you would prove .

English: My friends told me as much , and I knew it , too .
Shakespearean: My friends told me as much , and I thought no less .

English: So , take me , death !
Shakespearean: Tis but one cast away , and so , come , death .

English: You'll be back at two o'clock ?
Shakespearean: Two o'clock is your hour ?

English: Yes , sweet Rosalind .
Shakespearean: Ay , sweet Rosalind .

English: So beware of my contempt , and keep your promise .
Shakespearean: Therefore beware my censure , and keep your promise .

English: I'll keep my promise just as if you really were Rosalind .
Shakespearean: With no less religion than if thou wert indeed my Rosalind .

English: So , goodbye .
Shakespearean: So , adieu .

English: Well , time is the old judge that tries your kind of criminal .
Shakespearean: Well , time is the old justice that examines all such offenders , and let time try .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Adieu .

English: You have absolutely abused our sex in this love talk of yours .
Shakespearean: You have simply misused our sex in your love-prate .

English: We should rip off your man's clothing and show the world the woman who has represented her own kind so badly .
Shakespearean: We must have your doublet and hose plucked over your head and show the world what the bird hath done to her own nest .

English: Oh cousin , cousin , cousin , my sweet little cousin , I wish you knew how deep in love I am .
Shakespearean: O coz , coz , coz , my pretty little coz , that thou didst know how many fathom deep I am in love .

English: Or it's bottomless , at least : pour affection in one end , and it runs out the other .
Shakespearean: Or rather bottomless , that as fast as you pour affection in , it runs out .

English: Cupid , that blind bastard son of Venus , conceived from a thought and anger , born from insanity , that blind , naughty boy who makes everyone else go blind just because he can't see himself , let Cupid judge how deep my love runs .
Shakespearean: No , that same wicked bastard of Venus that was begot of thought , conceived of spleen , and born of madness , that blind rascally boy that abuses everyone's eyes because his own are out , let him be judge how deep I am in love .

English: I'm telling you , Aliena , I can't stand being apart from Orlando .
Shakespearean: I'll tell thee , Aliena , I can not be out of the sight of Orlando .

English: I'm going to find some shade and sigh until he returns .
Shakespearean: I'll go find a shadow and sigh till he come .

English: And I'm going to sleep .
Shakespearean: And I'll sleep .

English: Which one of you killed the deer ?
Shakespearean: Which is he that killed the deer ?

English: Yes , sir .
Shakespearean: Yes , sir .

English: Then sing it .
Shakespearean: Sing it .

English: It doesn't matter if it's in tune so long as it's loud enough .
Shakespearean: Tis no matter how it be in tune , so it make noise enough .

English: What do you say now ?
Shakespearean: How say you now ?

English: Isn't it past two o'clock ?
Shakespearean: Is it not past two o'clock ?

English: And I see a lot of Orlando here .
Shakespearean: And here much Orlando .

English: Look who's coming .
Shakespearean: Look who comes here .

English: No , I swear , I don't even know what's in it .
Shakespearean: No , I protest , I know not the contents .

English: Phoebe wrote it .
Shakespearean: Phoebe did write it .

English: Well , then , what should we do for fun instead ?
Shakespearean: What shall be our sport , then ?

English: Let's go find that hussy , Fortune , and and mock her till she starts distributing her gifts more equally .
Shakespearean: Let us sit and mock the good housewife Fortune from her wheel , that her gifts may henceforth be bestowed equally .

English: Oh , really ?
Shakespearean: No ?

English: Well , when Nature makes a person beautiful , can't Fortune make her fall into a fire , thereby making her ugly after all ?
Shakespearean: When Nature hath made a fair creature , may she not by Fortune fall into the fire ?

English: And even though Nature has given us the wit to have this argument , hasn't Fortune sent this fool here to stop us ?
Shakespearean: Though Nature hath given us wit to flout at Fortune , hath not Fortune sent in this fool to cut off the argument ?

English: Come on , you're a fool , and driven to extreme measures by love .
Shakespearean: Come , come , you are a fool , And turned into the extremity of love .

English: The point is that she didn't write this letter .
Shakespearean: I say she never did invent this letter .

English: These are a man's words , and his handwriting .
Shakespearean: This is a man's invention , and his hand .

English: I'm telling you , it's hers .
Shakespearean: Sure it is hers .

English: Why , she challenges me like a Muslim would challenge a Christian .
Shakespearean: Why , she defies me Like Turk to Christian .

English: No , a woman's gentle brain could never have come up with such crude expressions and even harsher meanings .
Shakespearean: Women's gentle brain Could not drop forth such giant-rude invention , Such Ethiop words , blacker in their effect Than in their countenance .

English: Do you want to hear what she says ?
Shakespearean: Will you hear the letter ?

English: If you want to read it , as I haven't heard it yet , though I've heard too much of Phoebe's cruelty .
Shakespearean: So please you , for I never heard it yet , Yet heard too much of Phoebe's cruelty .

English: She's Phoebe-ing me .
Shakespearean: She Phoebes me .

English: Listen to what the tyrant says .
Shakespearean: Mark how the tyrant writes .

English: You call that ranting ?
Shakespearean: That a maiden's heart hath burned ?

English: You call this sneering ?
Shakespearean: Call you this railing ?

English: Why do you pity him ?
Shakespearean: Why , thy godhead laid apart , Warr'st thou with a woman's heart ?

English: Follow them straight to the cottage .
Shakespearean: Not to be endured .

English: Since you asked , I suppose it's not bragging to say that we are .
Shakespearean: It is no boast , being asked , to say we are .

English: Orlando sends his regards to you both , and he sends this bloody handkerchief to the boy he calls "his Rosalind." Is that you ?
Shakespearean: Orlando doth commend him to you both , And to that youth he calls his Rosalind He sends this bloody napkin .

English: It is .
Shakespearean: Are you he ?

English: It's about who I am , and how , why , and where this handkerchief was stained .
Shakespearean: Some of my shame , if you will know of me What man I am , and how , and why , and where This handkercher was stained .

English: Please , tell us .
Shakespearean: I pray you , tell it .

English: He looked to the side , and pay attention to what he saw then : under an oak tree , whose lower branches were mossy with age and top branches ancient and brittle , he saw a wretched beggar , with overgrown hair and beard , asleep on his back .
Shakespearean: He threw his eye aside , And mark what object did present itself : Under an old oak , whose boughs were mossed with age And high top bald with dry antiquity , A wretched , ragged man , o'ergrown with hair , Lay sleeping on his back .

English: He discovered that the man was his older brother .
Shakespearean: This seen , Orlando did approach the man And found it was his brother , his elder brother .

English: Oh , I've heard him talk about that brother , and he described him as the most inhumane man alive .
Shakespearean: Oh , I have heard him speak of that same brother , And he did render him the most unnatural That lived amongst men .

English: He turned away twice and almost left him there .
Shakespearean: But to Orlando : did he leave him there , Food to the sucked and hungry lioness ?

English: But his kindness was nobler than even his desire for revenge , his natural goodness was stronger than his need to give his brother what he deserved .
Shakespearean: Twice did he turn his back and purposed so , But kindness , nobler ever than revenge , And nature , stronger than his just occasion , Made him give battle to the lioness , Who quickly fell before him ; in which hurtling , From miserable slumber I awaked .

English: Are you his brother ?
Shakespearean: Are you his brother ?

English: Was it you that he rescued ?
Shakespearean: Was 't you he rescued ?

English: Was it you that was always plotting to kill him ?
Shakespearean: Was 't you that did so oft contrive to kill him ?

English: That was me , but it's not me , I'm not ashamed to tell you what I once was , since I'm so happy to have since converted .
Shakespearean: Twas I , but 'tis not I. I do not shame To tell you what I was , since my conversion So sweetly tastes , being the thing I am .

English: But what about the bloody handkerchief ?
Shakespearean: But for the bloody napkin ?

English: I'll get there .
Shakespearean: By and by .

English: After a brief time , as he is a strong , brave man ,
Shakespearean: Brief , I recovered him , bound up his wound , And after some small space , being strong at heart ,

English: Many people faint when they see blood .
Shakespearean: Many will swoon when they do look on blood .

English: There's more to it than that. , Ganymede !
Shakespearean: There is more in it. , Cousin Ganymede .

English: Look , he's recovering .
Shakespearean: Look , he recovers .

English: I want to go home .
Shakespearean: I would I were at home .

English: We'll take you there .
Shakespearean: We'll lead you thither .

English: Please , will you take his arm ?
Shakespearean: I pray you , will you take him by the arm ?

English: Buck up , boy !
Shakespearean: Be of good cheer , youth .

English: You're a man ?
Shakespearean: You a man ?

English: You don't have a man's courage .
Shakespearean: You lack a man's heart .

English: It's true , I confess .
Shakespearean: I do so , I confess it .

English: Oh , sir , someone would think I was a good fake .
Shakespearean: Ah , sirrah , a body would think this was well-counterfeited .

English: Please tell your brother what a convincing show I put on .
Shakespearean: I pray you tell your brother how well I counterfeited .

English: Whoo-hoo !
Shakespearean: Heigh-ho .

English: That was no show .
Shakespearean: This was not counterfeit .

English: Your cheeks are too flushed for me to believe that was a fake faint .
Shakespearean: There is too great testimony in your complexion that it was a passion of earnest .

English: Fake , I'm telling you .
Shakespearean: Counterfeit , I assure you .

English: Well , then , be brave and pretend to be a man .
Shakespearean: Well then , take a good heart and counterfeit to be a man .

English: That's what I'm doing .
Shakespearean: So I do .

English: But honestly , I should have been a woman .
Shakespearean: But i ' faith , I should have been a woman by right .

English: Come on , you keep getting paler .
Shakespearean: Come , you look paler and paler .

English: I'll do that , because I have to tell my brother how you forgave him , Rosalind .
Shakespearean: That will I , for I must bear answer back How you excuse my brother , Rosalind .

English: I'll think of something .
Shakespearean: I shall devise something .

English: But please , tell him how well I faked a faint .
Shakespearean: But I pray you commend my counterfeiting to him .

English: Will you come with us ?
Shakespearean: Will you go ?

English: We'll get married at some point , Audrey .
Shakespearean: We shall find a time , Audrey .

English: Be patient .
Shakespearean: Patience , gentle Audrey .

English: Really , the priest was good enough , no matter what that old guy said .
Shakespearean: Faith , the priest was good enough , for all the old gentleman's saying .

English: No , he was wicked and vile .
Shakespearean: A most wicked Sir Oliver , Audrey , a most vile Martext .

English: But Audrey , there's a boy in the forest who claims you're his girl .
Shakespearean: But , Audrey , there is a youth here in the forest lays claim to you .

English: Here comes the man himself .
Shakespearean: Here comes the man you mean .

English: It warms my heart to encounter such a country bumpkin .
Shakespearean: It is meat and drink to me to see a clown .

English: How old are you , friend ?
Shakespearean: How old are you , friend ?

English: Twenty-five , sir .
Shakespearean: Five-and-twenty , sir .

English: A mature age .
Shakespearean: A ripe age .

English: Is your name William ?
Shakespearean: Is thy name William ?

English: Yes , it's William , sir .
Shakespearean: William , sir .

English: A good name .
Shakespearean: A fair name .

English: Were you born here in the forest ?
Shakespearean: Wast born i ' th ' forest here ?

English: Yes sir , thank God .
Shakespearean: Ay , sir , I thank God .

English: Thank God" , that's a good answer .
Shakespearean: Thank God." A good answer .

English: Are you rich ?
Shakespearean: Art rich ?

English: Well , so-so .
Shakespearean: Faith , sir , so-so .

English: So-so" is good , very good , an excellent answer .
Shakespearean: So-so" is good , very good , very excellent good .

English: And then again , it's not so good , but only so-so .
Shakespearean: And yet it is not : it is but so-so .

English: Are you wise ?
Shakespearean: Art thou wise ?

English: Yes sir , I'm fairly witty .
Shakespearean: Ay , sir , I have a pretty wit .

English: Well , that's a fine answer .
Shakespearean: Why , thou sayst well .

English: Give me your hand .
Shakespearean: Give me your hand .

English: Are you educated ?
Shakespearean: Art thou learned ?

English: No , sir .
Shakespearean: No , sir .

English: Then learn this from me : if you have something , you have it .
Shakespearean: Then learn this of me : to have is to have .

English: Everyone knows that when you pour a drink out of a cup and into a glass , the cup becomes empty .
Shakespearean: For it is a figure in rhetoric that drink , being poured out of a cup into a glass , by filling the one doth empty the other .

English: Why , the he that will marry this woman .
Shakespearean: He , sir , that must marry this woman .

English: Or , rather , I'll kill you , or I'll do away with you , or I'll turn your life into death and your freedom into captivity .
Shakespearean: Therefore , you clown , abandon , which is , in the vulgar , "leave" , the society , which in the boorish is "company" , of this female , which in the common is "woman" ; which together is , abandon the society of this female , or , clown , thou perishest ; or , to thy better understanding , diest ; or , to wit , I kill thee , make thee away , translate thy life into death , thy liberty into bondage .

English: I'll poison you , or beat you with a club , or stab you with a sword .
Shakespearean: I will deal in poison with thee , or in bastinado , or in steel .

English: I'll bandy you about and overwhelm you with my cleverness .
Shakespearean: I will bandy with thee in faction .

English: I will , in other words , kill you in three hundred and fifty ways .
Shakespearean: I will kill thee a hundred and fifty ways .

English: Therefore , tremble with fear and leave .
Shakespearean: Therefore tremble and depart .

English: Do what he says , William .
Shakespearean: Do , good William .

English: Farewell , sir .
Shakespearean: God rest you merry , sir .

English: Our master and mistress are looking for you .
Shakespearean: Our master and mistress seeks you .

English: Let's go .
Shakespearean: Come away , away .

English: Hurry up , Audrey , hurry. , I'm coming , I'm coming .
Shakespearean: Trip , Audrey , trip , Audrey. , I attend , I attend .

English: Mistress , you have to go see your father .
Shakespearean: Mistress , you must come away to your father .

English: Did they make you the messenger ?
Shakespearean: Were you made the messenger ?

English: From a certain knight who swore on his honor that the pancakes he was eating were good , and that the mustard on top of them , he swore on his honor , was bad .
Shakespearean: Of a certain knight that swore by his honor they were good pancakes , and swore by his honor the mustard was naught .

English: Now , I'll swear to the opposite , that the pancakes were rotten , and the mustard was fine , but even so , the knight wasn't lying .
Shakespearean: Now , I'll stand to it , the pancakes were naught and the mustard was good , and yet was not the knight forsworn .

English: And how , out of your great heap of knowledge , will you manage to prove that ?
Shakespearean: How prove you that in the great heap of your knowledge ?

English: Yes , please ; unleash your wisdom .
Shakespearean: Ay , marry , now unmuzzle your wisdom .

English: Watch me : stroke your chins and swear by your beards that I am a knave .
Shakespearean: Stand you both forth now : stroke your chins and swear by your beards that I am a knave .

English: By our beards ( if we had them ) , you are a knave .
Shakespearean: By our beards ( if we had them ) , thou art .

English: And I swear by my wickedness ( if I had any ) that I am a knave .
Shakespearean: By my knavery ( if I had it ) , then I were .

English: Is it really possible that you could like her right after meeting her ?
Shakespearean: Is 't possible that on so little acquaintance you should like her ?

English: It will be to your advantage , because I'll leave our father's house and all his property to you , while I live and die a shepherd here in the forest .
Shakespearean: It shall be to your good , for my father's house and all the revenue that was old Sir Rowland's will I estate upon you , and here live and die a shepherd .

English: You have my consent .
Shakespearean: You have my consent .

English: You can be married tomorrow if you want .
Shakespearean: Let your wedding be tomorrow .

English: I'll invite the duke and all of his followers .
Shakespearean: Thither will I invite the duke and all's contented followers .

English: Go get Aliena ready , because , look , here comes my Rosalind .
Shakespearean: Go you and prepare Aliena , for look you , here comes my Rosalind .

English: And hello to you , fair sister .
Shakespearean: And you , fair sister .

English: Oh , darling Orlando , it's so hard to see you wearing your heart in a sling .
Shakespearean: O my dear Orlando , how it grieves me to see thee wear thy heart in a scarf .

English: Actually , it's my arm .
Shakespearean: It is my arm .

English: I thought your heart had been wounded by a lion's claws .
Shakespearean: I thought thy heart had been wounded with the claws of a lion .

English: They're in the heat of passion ; they simply have to be together .
Shakespearean: They are in the very wrath of love , and they will together .

English: You couldn't beat the two of them apart .
Shakespearean: Clubs can not part them .

English: They'll be married tomorrow , and I'll invite the duke to the ceremony .
Shakespearean: They shall be married tomorrow , and I will bid the duke to the nuptial .

English: But , oh , it makes me bitter to look at happiness through another man's eyes .
Shakespearean: But Oh , how bitter a thing it is to look into happiness through another man's eyes .

English: Tomorrow I'll be at the depths of my misery thinking about the happiness my brother has achieved , in having what he wished for .
Shakespearean: By so much the more shall I tomorrow be at the height of heart-heaviness , by how much I shall think my brother happy in having what he wishes for .

English: Well then , can't I act as Rosalind for you tomorrow ?
Shakespearean: Why , then , tomorrow I can not serve your turn for Rosalind ?

English: I can't live by pretending anymore .
Shakespearean: I can live no longer by thinking .

English: I won't exhaust you anymore with idle chitchat .
Shakespearean: I will weary you then no longer with idle talking .

English: You should know that I think you're a smart man .
Shakespearean: I speak not this that you should bear a good opinion of my knowledge , insomuch I say I know you are .

English: Believe me , then , that I have special powers .
Shakespearean: Believe then , if you please , that I can do strange things .

English: Since I was three years old , I've been in contact with a powerful but virtuous magician , no black magic here .
Shakespearean: I have , since I was three year old , conversed with a magician , most profound in his art and yet not damnable .

English: If you love Rosalind as much as you say you do , you will marry her when your brother marries Aliena .
Shakespearean: If you do love Rosalind so near the heart as your gesture cries it out , when your brother marries Aliena shall you marry her .

English: I know where she is and , if you don't mind , I will set her before you tomorrow , whole and unharmed .
Shakespearean: I know into what straits of fortune she is driven , and it is not impossible to me , if it appear not inconvenient to you , to set her before your eyes tomorrow , human as she is , and without any danger .

English: Are you serious ?
Shakespearean: Speak'st thou in sober meanings ?

English: I swear on my life , which I take pretty seriously , even if I am a magician .
Shakespearean: By my life I do , which I tender dearly , though I say I am a magician .

English: Look , here comes someone who loves me , along with someone who loves her .
Shakespearean: Look , here comes a lover of mine and a lover of hers .

English: I don't care .
Shakespearean: I care not if I have .

English: A faithful shepherd worships you .
Shakespearean: You are there followed by a faithful shepherd .

English: Silvius , tell this youth what it means to be in love .
Shakespearean: Good shepherd , tell this youth what 'tis to love .

English: It means being full of sighs and tears , like I am for Phoebe .
Shakespearean: It is to be all made of sighs and tears , And so am I for Phoebe .

English: And like I am for Ganymede .
Shakespearean: And I for Ganymede .

English: And like I am for Rosalind .
Shakespearean: And I for Rosalind .

English: And like I am for no woman .
Shakespearean: And I for no woman .

English: It means being faithful and ready to serve , just like I am for Phoebe .
Shakespearean: It is to be all made of faith and service , And so am I for Phoebe .

English: And like I am for Ganymede .
Shakespearean: And I for Ganymede .

English: And like I am for Rosalind .
Shakespearean: And I for Rosalind .

English: And like I am for no woman .
Shakespearean: And I for no woman .

English: It means being filled with fantasy ; with passion and wishes ; with adoration , loyalty , and devotion .
Shakespearean: It is to be all made of fantasy , All made of passion and all made of wishes , All adoration , duty , and observance , All humbleness , all patience and impatience , All purity , all trial , all observance , And so am I for Phoebe .

English: And I for Rosalind .
Shakespearean: And so am I for Rosalind .

English: And I for no woman .
Shakespearean: And so am I for no woman .

English: Since you know all this is true , why do you blame me for loving you ?
Shakespearean: If this be so , why blame you me to love you ?

English: And why do you blame me for loving you ?
Shakespearean: If this be so , why blame you me to love you ?

English: And why do you blame me for loving you ?
Shakespearean: If this be so , why blame you me to love you ?

English: Who are you talking to ?
Shakespearean: Why do you speak , too , "Why blame you me to love you ? " ?

English: I'm saying it to the girl who isn't here and doesn't hear me .
Shakespearean: To her that is not here , nor doth not hear .

English: All right , stop this .
Shakespearean: Pray you , no more of this .

English: You sound like a pack of wolves howling at the moon .
Shakespearean: Tis like the howling of Irish wolves against the moon .

English: As long as I'm alive , I'll be here .
Shakespearean: I'll not fail , if I live .

English: Me too .
Shakespearean: Nor I .

English: Me too .
Shakespearean: Nor I .

English: Tomorrow is the happy day , Audrey .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow is the joyful day , Audrey .

English: We'll be married tomorrow .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow will we be married .

English: I hope it doesn't make me unchaste that I really want to be a married woman .
Shakespearean: I do desire it with all my heart , and I hope it is no dishonest desire to desire to be a woman of the world .

English: Here come two of Duke Senior's pages .
Shakespearean: Here comes two of the banished duke's pages .

English: Good afternoon , good gentleman .
Shakespearean: Well met , honest gentleman .

English: It really is good to see you .
Shakespearean: By my troth , well met .

English: Come , sit , sit , and sing me a song .
Shakespearean: Come , sit , sit , and a song .

English: Sounds good to us .
Shakespearean: We are for you .

English: Sit between us .
Shakespearean: Sit i ' th ' middle .

English: Should we just get down to it ?
Shakespearean: Shall we clap into 't roundly , without hawking or spitting or saying we are hoarse , which are the only prologues to a bad voice ?

English: Yes , yes , and let's sing in unison , like two gypsies riding on a single horse .
Shakespearean: I ' faith , i ' faith , and both in a tune like two gypsies on a horse .

English: Really , young men , though it wasn't a very hard song to get right , the music was still all out of tune .
Shakespearean: Truly , young gentlemen , though there was no great matter in the ditty , yet the note was very untunable .

English: Orlando , do you really believe that this boy can do everything he's promised ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou believe , Orlando , that the boy Can do all this that he hath promised ?

English: Yes , even if I had whole kingdoms to give along with her .
Shakespearean: That would I , had I kingdoms to give with her .

English: I will , even if I were king of all kingdoms .
Shakespearean: That would I , were I of all kingdoms king .

English: Yes , even if I die an hour later .
Shakespearean: That will I , should I die the hour after .

English: But if you decide not to marry me , you'll marry this faithful shepherd instead ?
Shakespearean: But if you do refuse to marry me , You'll give yourself to this most faithful shepherd ?

English: That's the deal .
Shakespearean: So is the bargain .

English: Even if marrying her meant I died .
Shakespearean: Though to have her and death were both one thing .

English: I've promised to make everything right .
Shakespearean: I have promised to make all this matter even .

English: Phoebe , keep your promise to marry me , and to marry this shepherd if you choose to refuse me .
Shakespearean: Keep your word , Phoebe , that you'll marry me Or else , refusing me , to wed this shepherd .

English: Silvius , keep your promise to marry Phoebe if she refuses me .
Shakespearean: Keep your word , Silvius , that you'll marry her If she refuse me .

English: I'll leave now , to set all these things right .
Shakespearean: And from hence I go To make these doubts all even .

English: This shepherd boy reminds me quite vividly of my daughter .
Shakespearean: I do remember in this shepherd boy Some lively touches of my daughter's favor .

English: My lord , when I first saw him I thought he was your daughter's brother .
Shakespearean: My lord , the first time that I ever saw him Methought he was a brother to your daughter .

English: But , my lord , this boy was born in the forest and has been schooled not in the usual subjects but only in magic .
Shakespearean: But , my good lord , this boy is forest-born And hath been tutored in the rudiments Of many desperate studies by his uncle , Whom he reports to be a great magician Obscured in the circle of this forest .

English: My lord , welcome this man .
Shakespearean: Good my lord , bid him welcome .

English: This is the jester I have met so many times in the forest .
Shakespearean: This is the motley-minded gentleman that I have so often met in the forest .

English: He swears he used to be a courtier .
Shakespearean: He hath been a courtier , he swears .

English: If anyone doubts this , let him put me on trial .
Shakespearean: If any man doubt that , let him put me to my purgation .

English: I have bankrupted three tailors .
Shakespearean: I have undone three tailors .

English: I have quarreled four times , and almost got in a fight .
Shakespearean: I have had four quarrels , and like to have fought one .

English: And how was that one settled ?
Shakespearean: And how was that ta'en up ?

English: Well , we almost fought and then realized that we had reached the seventh cause .
Shakespearean: Faith , we met and found the quarrel was upon the seventh cause .

English: What do you mean , the seventh cause ?
Shakespearean: How "seventh cause" ? , Good my lord , like this fellow .

English: I like him very well .
Shakespearean: I like him very well .

English: Tell me , who is this knight ?
Shakespearean: Prithee , who is 't that thou mean'st ?

English: A man old Frederick , your father , loves .
Shakespearean: One that old Frederick , your father , loves .

English: If he has my father's love , then that's enough honor for me .
Shakespearean: My father's love is enough to honor him .

English: Enough of this .
Shakespearean: Enough .

English: No more talk about my father ; you'll be whipped for slander one of these days .
Shakespearean: Speak no more of him ; you'll be whipped for taxation one of these days .

English: It's a pity that fools aren't allowed to speak wisely about the foolish things that wise men do .
Shakespearean: The more pity that fools may not speak wisely what wise men do foolishly .

English: Honestly , you're speaking the truth , ever since the fools were With his mouth full of news .
Shakespearean: With his mouth full of news .

English: Which he'll shove down our throats the way pigeons feed their young .
Shakespearean: Which he will put on us as pigeons feed their young .

English: Then we'll be stuffed with news .
Shakespearean: Then shall we be news-crammed .

English: Well that's good .
Shakespearean: All the better .

English: If we're Hello , Monsieur Le Beau .
Shakespearean: We shall be the more marketable. , Bonjour , Monsieur Le Beau .

English: What's the news ?
Shakespearean: What's the news ?

English: Fair princess , you've missed some good sport .
Shakespearean: Fair princess , you have lost much good sport .

English: Sport ?
Shakespearean: Sport ?

English: Of what
Shakespearean: Of what color ?

English: God bless you , sir .
Shakespearean: God 'ild you , sir .

English: This poor virgin isn't much to look at , sir , but she's mine .
Shakespearean: A poor virgin , sir , an ill-favored thing , sir , but mine own .

English: Really , he's very witty , and full of wise sayings .
Shakespearean: By my faith , he is very swift and sententious .

English: But back to that argument you mentioned .
Shakespearean: But for the seventh cause .

English: What's the "seventh cause" ?
Shakespearean: How did you find the quarrel on the seventh cause ?

English: I didn't like the way a particular courtier had cut his beard .
Shakespearean: Upon a lie seven times removed. , Bear your body more seeming , Audrey. , As thus , sir : I did dislike the cut of a certain courtier's beard .

English: He sent me word that , whether I liked it or not , he liked it fine .
Shakespearean: He sent me word if I said his beard was not cut well , he was in the mind it was .

English: They call this "the argumentative countercheck." And so on through "the circumstantial lie" and "the direct lie." And how many times did you say his beard wasn't cut well ?
Shakespearean: This is called "the countercheck quarrelsome , " and so to "the lie circumstantial" and "the lie direct." And how oft did you say his beard was not well cut ?

English: He's as smart as they come , but just a jester .
Shakespearean: He's as good at anything and yet a fool .

English: He uses his clownishness to disguise his deadly wit .
Shakespearean: He uses his folly like a stalking-horse , and under the presentation of that he shoots his wit .

English: There is laughter in heaven When earthly affairs are put right And people unite .
Shakespearean: Then is there mirth in heaven When earthly things , made even , Atone together .

English: Good duke , come receive your daughter .
Shakespearean: Good duke , receive thy daughter .

English: Hymen brought her from heaven Yes , brought her here .
Shakespearean: Hymen from heaven brought her , Yea , brought her hither , That thou mightst join her hand with his Whose heart within his bosom is .

English: If my eyes don't deceive me , you are my daughter .
Shakespearean: If there be truth in sight , you are my daughter .

English: If my eyes don't deceive me , you are my Rosalind .
Shakespearean: If there be truth in sight , you are my Rosalind .

English: If my eyes aren't deceiving me , goodbye , love .
Shakespearean: If sight and shape be true , Why then , my love adieu .

English: Quiet !
Shakespearean: Peace , ho !

English: My niece , you are welcome here as if you were my own daughter .
Shakespearean: O my dear niece , welcome thou art to me , Even daughter , welcome in no less degree .

English: Let me have your attention for a moment .
Shakespearean: Let me have audience for a word or two .

English: I'm Sir Rowland's middle son , and I bring you news .
Shakespearean: I am the second son of old Sir Rowland , That bring these tidings to this fair assembly .

English: When Duke Frederick heard that great , worthy men were coming to this forest every day , he raised a large army to invade this land and fight his brother .
Shakespearean: Duke Frederick , hearing how that every day Men of great worth resorted to this forest , Addressed a mighty power , which were on foot In his own conduct , purposely to take His brother here and put him to the sword .

English: I swear on my life that I'm speaking the truth .
Shakespearean: This to be true I do engage my life .

English: Do you mean to say that the duke has abandoned the glamorous court to live as a monk ?
Shakespearean: Sir , by your patience : if I heard you rightly , The duke hath put on a religious life And thrown into neglect the pompous court .

English: Yes , he has .
Shakespearean: He hath .

English: I will go find him .
Shakespearean: To him will I .

English: There is much to be learned from these converts .
Shakespearean: Out of these convertites There is much matter to be heard and learned .

English: Stay , Jaques , stay here for a bit .
Shakespearean: Stay , Jaques , stay .

English: No , this fun is not for me .
Shakespearean: To see no pastime I .

English: I'll wait for you in your cave , where you can tell me what you need from me .
Shakespearean: What you would have I'll stay to know at your abandoned cave .

English: Let's proceed .
Shakespearean: Proceed , proceed .

English: We'll begin the ceremony the way we hope it will end , with delight .
Shakespearean: We'll so begin these rites As we do trust they'll end , in true delights .

English: If it's true that you don't need
Shakespearean: If it be true that good wine needs no bush , 'tis true that a good play needs no epilogue .

English: What color , madam ?
Shakespearean: What color , madam ?

English: I don't understand , how should I answer that ?
Shakespearean: How shall I answer you ?

English: However your wit and luck allow .
Shakespearean: As wit and fortune will .

English: Tell us about this wrestling .
Shakespearean: You tell us the manner of the wrestling .

English: Well , we've missed the beginning ; it's dead and buried .
Shakespearean: Well , the beginning that is dead and buried .

English: There comes an old man with his three sons , It sounds like the beginning of an old folktale .
Shakespearean: There comes an old man and his three sons , I could match this beginning with an old tale .

English: Three proper young men , all good looking and with great presence ,
Shakespearean: Three proper young men of excellent growth and presence .

English: Right , and they wore proclamations around their necks , saying , "Be it known to all men by these The eldest of the three brothers wrestled with Charles , the duke's wrestler .
Shakespearean: With bills on their necks : "Be it known unto all men by these presents." The eldest of the three wrestled with Charles , the duke's wrestler , which Charles in a moment threw him and broke three of his ribs , that there is little hope of life in him .

English: Charles did the same to the second brother , and the third .
Shakespearean: So he served the second , and so the third .

English: They're lying over there , and the poor old man , their father , weeps so piteously over them that the whole audience has joined him in grieving .
Shakespearean: Yonder they lie , the poor old man their father making such pitiful dole over them that all the beholders take his part with weeping .

English: Oh , dear !
Shakespearean: Alas !

English: But tell me , monsieur , what sport are the ladies missing ?
Shakespearean: But what is the sport , monsieur , that the ladies have lost ?

English: Why , the one I just told you about .
Shakespearean: Why , this that I speak of .

English: Me too , I swear .
Shakespearean: Or I , I promise thee .

English: Doesn't anyone else want to see this , and hear breath wheezing out from broken ribs ?
Shakespearean: But is there any else longs to see this broken music in his sides ?

English: Shall we go watch this wrestling , cousin ?
Shakespearean: Shall we see this wrestling , cousin ?

English: Yes , I see them coming .
Shakespearean: Yonder sure they are coming .

English: Let's stay and watch .
Shakespearean: Let us now stay and see it .

English: Come on .
Shakespearean: Come on .

English: Since the youth won't be reasoned with , he'll have to suffer for his stubbornness .
Shakespearean: Since the youth will not be entreated , his own peril on his forwardness .

English: Is that the man ?
Shakespearean: Is yonder the man ?

English: That's him , madam .
Shakespearean: Even he , madam .

English: Alas , he is too young .
Shakespearean: Alas , he is too young .

English: Yet he seems capable .
Shakespearean: Yet he looks successfully .

English: What's up , daughter and niece ?
Shakespearean: How now , daughter and cousin ?

English: Have you snuck over here to watch the wrestling ?
Shakespearean: Are you crept hither to see the wrestling ?

English: Yes , my lord , if you give us permission .
Shakespearean: Ay , my liege , so please you give us leave .

English: You won't enjoy it much , I can tell you , the odds are so against this young man .
Shakespearean: You will take little delight in it , I can tell you , there is such odds in the man .

English: Because he's so young , I've tried to discourage him , but he won't listen .
Shakespearean: In pity of the challenger's youth , I would fain dissuade him , but he will not be entreated .

English: Call him over here , good Monsieur Le Beau .
Shakespearean: Call him hither , good Monsieur Le Beau .

English: I remember , Adam , that's Here comes my master , your brother .
Shakespearean: Yonder comes my master , your brother .

English: Go hide , Adam , and you'll hear how he abuses me .
Shakespearean: Go apart , Adam , and thou shalt hear how he will shake me up .

English: Mister Challenger , the princess wants to speak to you .
Shakespearean: Monsieur the challenger , the Princess calls for you .

English: I'll wait on them with all respect and duty .
Shakespearean: I attend them with all respect and duty .

English: Young man , have you challenged Charles the Wrestler ?
Shakespearean: Young man , have you challenged Charles the wrestler ?

English: No , lovely princess .
Shakespearean: No , fair princess .

English: He is the general challenger .
Shakespearean: He is the general challenger .

English: I have only come in , like the others have , to try to fight him with the strength of my youth .
Shakespearean: I come but in as others do , to try with him the strength of my youth .

English: Young gentleman , you are too bold for your age .
Shakespearean: Young gentleman , your spirits are too bold for your years .

English: You have seen the cruel proof of this man's strength .
Shakespearean: You have seen cruel proof of this man's strength .

English: If you took a good look at yourself , or if you thought about this more carefully , your fear would teach you to act more cautiously .
Shakespearean: If you saw yourself with your eyes or knew yourself with your judgment , the fear of your adventure would counsel you to a more equal enterprise .

English: We beg you , for your own sake , to respect your safety and give up .
Shakespearean: We pray you for your own sake to embrace your own safety and give over this attempt .

English: Please , young sir .
Shakespearean: Do , young sir .

English: If I'm killed , it will only be the death of a man who was willing to be dead .
Shakespearean: But let your fair eyes and gentle wishes go with me to my trial , wherein , if I be foiled , there is but one shamed that was never gracious ; if killed , but one dead that was willing to be so .

English: I won't wrong any of my friends , because I don't have any to mourn for me , and I won't have wronged the world , because I don't have anything in the world .
Shakespearean: I shall do my friends no wrong , for I have none to lament me ; the world no injury , for in it I have nothing .

English: In this world , I'm only taking up space .
Shakespearean: Only in the world I fill up a place which may be better supplied when I have made it empty .

English: I wish I could give you the little strength that I have .
Shakespearean: The little strength that I have , I would it were with you .

English: Mine too , to join hers .
Shakespearean: And mine , to eke out hers .

English: Good luck .
Shakespearean: Fare you well .

English: I hope to God I'm wrong about your chances .
Shakespearean: Pray heaven I be deceived in you .

English: I hope you get what you desire !
Shakespearean: Your heart's desires be with you .

English: You get only one round .
Shakespearean: You shall try but one fall .

English: No , I'm sure your Grace won't be able to persuade him to try a second round , even though you couldn't dissuade him from trying the first .
Shakespearean: No , I warrant your Grace you shall not entreat him to a second , that have so mightily persuaded him from a first .

English: You should mock me I wish I were invisible , so I could grab that strong fellow by the leg .
Shakespearean: I would I were invisible , to catch the strong fellow by the leg .

English: Oh , what an excellent young man !
Shakespearean: O excellent young man !

English: If I could shoot lightning bolts from my eyes , I can tell you who'd be on the ground .
Shakespearean: If I had a thunderbolt in mine eye , I can tell who should down .

English: No more , no more .
Shakespearean: No more , no more .

English: How are you doing , Charles ?
Shakespearean: How dost thou , Charles ?

English: He can't speak , my lord .
Shakespearean: He can not speak , my lord .

English: Carry him away .
Shakespearean: Bear him away .

English: What is your name , young man ?
Shakespearean: What is thy name , young man ?

English: Orlando , my lord , the youngest son of Sir Rowland de Boys .
Shakespearean: Orlando , my liege , the youngest son of Sir Rowland de Boys .

English: I wish you were someone else's son .
Shakespearean: I would thou hadst been son to some man else .

English: The whole world thought your father was an honorable man , but he was always my enemy .
Shakespearean: The world esteemed thy father honorable , But I did find him still mine enemy .

English: I wish you had told me you had a different father .
Shakespearean: I would thou hadst told me of another father .

English: If I were my father , cousin , would I do this ?
Shakespearean: Were I my father , coz , would I do this ?

English: I'm proud to be Sir Rowland's son , his youngest son , and I would never change that , not even to be Frederick's adopted heir .
Shakespearean: I am more proud to be Sir Rowland's son , His youngest son , and would not change that calling To be adopted heir to Frederick .

English: My father loved Sir Rowland as much as he loved his own soul , and the rest of the world shared my father's opinion .
Shakespearean: My father loved Sir Rowland as his soul , And all the world was of my father's mind .

English: If I had known this young man was his son , I would have tried harder to convince him not to fight .
Shakespearean: Had I before known this young man his son , I should have given him tears unto entreaties Ere he should thus have ventured .

English: Gentle cousin , let's go thank him and encourage him .
Shakespearean: Gentle cousin , Let us go thank him and encourage him .

English: Yes .
Shakespearean: Shall we go , coz ?

English: Good luck , fair gentleman .
Shakespearean: Ay. , Fare you well , fair gentleman .

English: He's calling us back .
Shakespearean: He calls us back .

English: My Will you come on , cousin ?
Shakespearean: Will you go , coz ?

English: I'm coming .
Shakespearean: Have with you .

English: Farewell .
Shakespearean: Fare you well .

English: What is this passion that ties up my tongue ?
Shakespearean: What passion hangs these weights upon my tongue ?

English: I can't speak to her , even though she asked me to .
Shakespearean: I can not speak to her , yet she urged conference .

English: Either Charles or some prettier thing has mastered you .
Shakespearean: Or Charles or something weaker masters thee .

English: Good sir , as a friend , I advise you to leave this place .
Shakespearean: Good sir , I do in friendship counsel you To leave this place .

English: Although you deserve praise , applause , and love , right now the duke misconstrues everything you've done .
Shakespearean: Albeit you have deserved High commendation , true applause , and love , Yet such is now the duke's condition That he misconsters all that you have done .

English: The duke is temperamental .
Shakespearean: The duke is humorous .

English: But I will tell you that lately the duke has been displeased with his niece , and for no other reason than that people praise her virtues and pity her for her father's sake .
Shakespearean: But I can tell you that of late this duke Hath ta'en displeasure 'gainst his gentle niece , Grounded upon no other argument But that the people praise her for her virtues And pity her for her good father's sake ; And , on my life , his malice 'gainst the lady Will suddenly break forth .

English: Goodbye , sir .
Shakespearean: Sir , fare you well .

English: Later , in a better world than this , I'd love to get to know you .
Shakespearean: Hereafter , in a better world than this , I shall desire more love and knowledge of you .

English: I'm indebted to you .
Shakespearean: I rest much bounden to you .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Fare you well .

English: Out of the frying pan and into the fire , from a tyrant duke to a tyrant brother !
Shakespearean: Thus must I from the smoke into the smother , From tyrant duke unto a tyrant brother .

English: But , oh , heavenly Rosalind !
Shakespearean: But heavenly Rosalind !

English: What's going on , Rosalind ?
Shakespearean: Why , Rosalind !

English: I don't even have one to throw at a dog .
Shakespearean: Not one to throw at a dog .

English: No , your words are too precious to be wasted on dogs .
Shakespearean: No , thy words are too precious to be cast away upon curs .

English: Throw some of your words at me .
Shakespearean: Throw some of them at me .

English: Then there would be two cousins lying sick in bed : one hurt by reasons and the other gone crazy without any .
Shakespearean: Then there were two cousins laid up , when the one should be lamed with reasons and the other mad without any .

English: Is all of this about your father ?
Shakespearean: But is all this for your father ?

English: No , some of it is about my child's father .
Shakespearean: No , some of it is for my child's father .

English: If we walk on the well-worn paths , they won't get caught in our petticoats .
Shakespearean: If we walk not in the trodden paths our very petticoats will catch them .

English: Cough them up .
Shakespearean: Hem them away .

English: I'd try it , if I could cry "hem" and have him .
Shakespearean: I would try , if I could cry "hem" and have him .

English: Come on , take control of your feelings .
Shakespearean: Come , come , wrestle with thy affections .

English: But they're siding with a better wrestler than myself .
Shakespearean: Oh , they take the part of a better wrestler than myself .

English: Oh , that's a good wish !
Shakespearean: Oh , a good wish upon you .

English: You'll fight with him eventually , and The duke , my father , loved his father very much .
Shakespearean: The duke my father loved his father dearly .

English: Does that necessarily mean you should love his son ?
Shakespearean: Doth it therefore ensue that you should love his son dearly ?

English: By that kind of logic , I should hate Orlando , since my father hates his father .
Shakespearean: By this kind of chase I should hate him , for my father hated his father dearly .

English: But I don't hate Orlando .
Shakespearean: Yet I hate not Orlando .

English: No , please don't hate him , for my sake .
Shakespearean: No , faith , hate him not , for my sake .

English: Why shouldn't I ?
Shakespearean: Why should I not ?

English: Doesn't he deserve it ?
Shakespearean: Doth he not deserve well ?

English: Let me love him because he deserves it , and you can love him because I do .
Shakespearean: Let me love him for that , and do you love him because I do .

English: Look , here comes the duke .
Shakespearean: Look , here comes the duke .

English: He looks angry .
Shakespearean: With his eyes full of anger .

English: Madam , hurry as fast as you can get out of my court .
Shakespearean: Mistress , dispatch you with your safest haste , And get you from our court .

English: Me , uncle ?
Shakespearean: Me , uncle ?

English: You , niece .
Shakespearean: You , cousin .

English: In ten days time , if you're found within twenty miles of the court , you'll die for it .
Shakespearean: Within these ten days if that thou beest found So near our public court as twenty miles , Thou diest for it .

English: Please , your Grace , tell me what crime I have committed .
Shakespearean: I do beseech your Grace , Let me the knowledge of my fault bear with me .

English: If I know my own thoughts and desires , and I'm not dreaming or crazy , which I'm sure I'm not , then , dear uncle , I've never had so much as a half-formed thought that would have offended you .
Shakespearean: If with myself I hold intelligence Or have acquaintance with mine own desires , If that I do not dream or be not frantic , As I do trust I am not , then , dear uncle , Never so much as in a thought unborn Did I offend your Highness .

English: All traitors protest like this .
Shakespearean: Thus do all traitors .

English: If they could purge their guilt simply by saying that they were innocent , they'd all be as innocent as God Himself .
Shakespearean: If their purgation did consist in words , They are as innocent as grace itself .

English: I don't trust you .
Shakespearean: Let it suffice thee that I trust thee not .

English: You are your father's daughter .
Shakespearean: Thou art thy father's daughter .

English: That's enough .
Shakespearean: There's enough .

English: I was his daughter when your Highness took my father's dukedom .
Shakespearean: So was I when your Highness took his dukedom .

English: I was his daughter when you banished him .
Shakespearean: So was I when your Highness banished him .

English: My father wasn't a traitor .
Shakespearean: My father was no traitor .

English: So , please , my lord , don't assume that I'm treacherous just because I'm poor , with no titles to my name .
Shakespearean: Then , good my liege , mistake me not so much To think my poverty is treacherous .

English: Dear master , listen to me .
Shakespearean: Dear sovereign , hear me speak .

English: Yes , Celia , we kept her here for your sake .
Shakespearean: Ay , Celia , we stayed her for your sake .

English: I was too young at the time to appreciate her value , but now I know her .
Shakespearean: I was too young that time to value her , But now I know her .

English: If she's a traitor , why then , so am I .
Shakespearean: If she be a traitor , Why so am I .

English: You're a fool .
Shakespearean: Thou art a fool .

English: You will seem even brighter and more virtuous when she's out of the picture .
Shakespearean: She robs thee of thy name , And thou wilt show more bright and seem more virtuous When she is gone .

English: So be quiet .
Shakespearean: Then open not thy lips .

English: The sentence I've passed down on her is firm and unshakeable .
Shakespearean: Firm and irrevocable is my doom Which I have passed upon her .

English: She is banished .
Shakespearean: She is banished .

English: Then lay that sentence on me too , my lord .
Shakespearean: Pronounce that sentence then on me , my liege .

English: I can not live without her .
Shakespearean: I can not live out of her company .

English: You are a fool. , You , niece , prepare to leave .
Shakespearean: You are a fool. , You , niece , provide yourself .

English: On my honor and by my word , if you outstay the ten days , you will die .
Shakespearean: If you outstay the time , upon mine honor And in the greatness of my word , you die .

English: Oh , my poor Rosalind , where will you go ?
Shakespearean: O my poor Rosalind , whither wilt thou go ?

English: Do you want to exchange fathers ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou change fathers ?

English: I'll give you mine .
Shakespearean: I will give thee mine .

English: I insist , don't be more distressed than I am .
Shakespearean: I charge thee , be not thou more grieved than I am .

English: I have more reason to be distressed .
Shakespearean: I have more cause .

English: Hey , you !
Shakespearean: Now , sir , what make you here ?

English: What are you Nothing .
Shakespearean: Nothing .

English: I've never been taught how to make anything .
Shakespearean: I am not taught to make anything .

English: Well , then , what are you messing up ?
Shakespearean: What mar you then , sir ?

English: I'm helping Indeed , sir , find something better to do and get lost for a while .
Shakespearean: Marry , sir , be better employed , and be naught awhile .

English: Should I tend your pigs and eat husks with them ?
Shakespearean: Shall I keep your hogs and eat husks with them ?

English: When did I Do you know where you are , sir ?
Shakespearean: Know you where you are , sir ?

English: Yes , sir , very well , I'm here in your orchard .
Shakespearean: O sir , very well : here in your orchard .

English: Do you know whom you're talking to ?
Shakespearean: Know you before whom , sir ?

English: Yes , better than you know me .
Shakespearean: Ay , better than him I am before knows me .

English: I know you're my oldest brother , and deserve more respect .
Shakespearean: I know you are my eldest brother , and in the gentle condition of blood you should so know me .

English: I have as much of our father in me as you do , though I admit you're closer to him and matter more because you're older .
Shakespearean: I have as much of my father in me as you , albeit , I confess , your coming before me is nearer to his reverence .

English: No you haven't , cousin .
Shakespearean: Thou hast not , cousin .

English: Please , be cheerful .
Shakespearean: Prithee , be cheerful .

English: Don't you realize the duke has also banished me , his daughter ?
Shakespearean: Know'st thou not the duke Hath banished me , his daughter ?

English: No , he hasn't .
Shakespearean: That he hath not .

English: Oh , he hasn't ?
Shakespearean: No , hath not ?

English: Well , then , you don't have the affection that would teach you that you and I are one .
Shakespearean: Rosalind lacks then the love Which teacheth thee that thou and I am one .

English: Will we be separated ?
Shakespearean: Shall we be sundered ?

English: Should we part , sweet girl ?
Shakespearean: Shall we part , sweet girl ?

English: I swear by the heavens , which have grown pale in sympathy with us , I'm going with you , whatever you say .
Shakespearean: For , by this heaven , now at our sorrows pale , Say what thou canst , I'll go along with thee .

English: But where will we go ?
Shakespearean: Why , whither shall we go ?

English: To the Forest of Arden , to find your father .
Shakespearean: To seek my uncle in the Forest of Arden .

English: But what danger we'll put ourselves in , two young , innocent women traveling so far !
Shakespearean: Alas , what danger will it be to us , Maids as we are , to travel forth so far ?

English: Fresh beauty attracts thugs and thieves even more than money .
Shakespearean: Beauty provoketh thieves sooner than gold .

English: I'll put on some poor and ragged clothes and smudge my face with dirt .
Shakespearean: I'll put myself in poor and mean attire And with a kind of umber smirch my face .

English: Wouldn't it be better , since I'm unusually tall for a woman , to dress myself like a man ?
Shakespearean: Were it not better , Because that I am more than common tall , That I did suit me all points like a man ?

English: I'll wear a big sword in my belt , carry a boar-spear in my hand , and hide all my womanish fear in my heart .
Shakespearean: A gallant curtal-axe upon my thigh , A boar-spear in my hand , and in my heart Lie there what hidden woman's fear there will , We'll have a swashing and a martial outside , As many other mannish cowards have That do outface it with their semblances .

English: What should I call you when you're a man ?
Shakespearean: What shall I call thee when thou art a man ?

English: I'll take no lesser name than that of Something that refers to my current state .
Shakespearean: I'll have no worse a name than Jove's own page , And therefore look you call me Ganymede .

English: Instead of Celia , call me Aliena .
Shakespearean: But what will you be called ?

English: Wouldn't he be a comfort to us in our travels ?
Shakespearean: Would he not be a comfort to our travel ?

English: Let's go gather our jewels and money .
Shakespearean: Leave me alone to woo him .

English: We'll figure out the best time and safest route to avoid being found out by my father's guards , whom he'll send out as soon as he discovers I've gone .
Shakespearean: Let's away And get our jewels and our wealth together , Devise the fittest time and safest way To hide us from pursuit that will be made After my flight .

English: Now , we go contentedly to freedom , not banishment .
