Shakespearean: Now go we in content To liberty , and not to banishment .

English: Now , my companions and brothers in exile , hasn't experience made this simple life sweeter than a life of glittery pomp and circumstance ?
Shakespearean: Now , my co-mates and brothers in exile , Hath not old custom made this life more sweet Than that of painted pomp ?

English: Aren't these woods less perilous than the court , with all its jealousies and intrigues ?
Shakespearean: Are not these woods More free from peril than the envious court ?

English: I smile and think , "Thank goodness the wind doesn't flatter me : it's like a councilor who makes me feel what I'm really made of." Adversity can have its benefits , like the ugly , poisonous I wouldn't change my situation for anything .
Shakespearean: These are counselors That feelingly persuade me what I am." Sweet are the uses of adversity , Which , like the toad , ugly and venomous , Wears yet a precious jewel in his head .

English: You're lucky , my lord , to be able to see the peace and sweetness even in what bad luck has brought you .
Shakespearean: And this our life , exempt from public haunt , Finds tongues in trees , books in the running brooks , Sermons in stones , and good in everything .

English: Come , shall we hunt some deer for dinner ?
Shakespearean: I would not change it .

English: It bothers me , though , that these poor spotted innocents , who , after all , are this deserted city's native citizens , should be gouged with arrows .
Shakespearean: Happy is your Grace , That can translate the stubbornness of fortune Into so quiet and so sweet a style .

English: Indeed , my lord , the gloomy Jaques grieves over these deaths .
Shakespearean: Come , shall we go and kill us venison ?

English: Big , round tears ran piteously down the animal's innocent nose .
Shakespearean: And indeed , my lord , The wretched animal heaved forth such groans That their discharge did stretch his leathern coat Almost to bursting , and the big round tears Coursed one another down his innocent nose In piteous chase .

English: And did you leave him like this ?
Shakespearean: And did you leave him in this contemplation ?

English: We did , my lord , weeping and carrying on about the sobbing deer .
Shakespearean: We did , my lord , weeping and commenting Upon the sobbing deer .

English: Take me to him .
Shakespearean: Show me the place .

English: I love to argue with him when he's having one of these fits , because then he always has a lot to say .
Shakespearean: I love to cope him in these sullen fits , For then he's full of matter .

English: I'll bring you to him right away .
Shakespearean: I'll bring you to him straight .

English: Can it be possible that no one saw them leave ?
Shakespearean: Can it be possible that no man saw them ?

English: It can not be .
Shakespearean: It can not be .

English: Some villains in my court must have known about this and let it happen .
Shakespearean: Some villains of my court Are of consent and sufferance in this .

English: I can't find anyone who saw her leave .
Shakespearean: I can not hear of any that did see her .

English: Her ladies-in-waiting saw her go to bed , and early this morning the bed was empty .
Shakespearean: The ladies , her attendants of her chamber Saw her abed , and in the morning early They found the bed untreasured of their mistress .

English: My lord , that dirty clown whom you laughed at so often is also missing .
Shakespearean: My lord , the roinish clown , at whom so oft Your Grace was wont to laugh , is also missing .

English: Send a message to his brother .
Shakespearean: Send to his brother .

English: Bring that swinger Orlando here .
Shakespearean: Fetch that gallant hither .

English: If he's not around , bring his brother Oliver to me .
Shakespearean: If he be absent , bring his brother to me .

English: I'll make Oliver find him .
Shakespearean: I'll make him find him .

English: Do this immediately , and don't stop searching and interrogating until you've brought home these foolish runaways .
Shakespearean: Do this suddenly , And let not search and inquisition quail To bring again these foolish runaways .

English: Who's there ?
Shakespearean: Who's there ?

English: What are you doing here ?
Shakespearean: Why , what make you here ?

English: Why are you so strong and good ?
Shakespearean: Why are you virtuous ?

English: Why do people love you ?
Shakespearean: Why do people love you ?

English: And why are you noble , strong , and brave ?
Shakespearean: And wherefore are you gentle , strong , and valiant ?

English: Why would you be so foolish as to beat the moody duke's favorite champion ?
Shakespearean: Why would you be so fond to overcome The bonny prizer of the humorous duke ?

English: Your praise has beaten you home .
Shakespearean: Your praise is come too swiftly home before you .

English: Don't you know , master , that some men's best qualities do them in ?
Shakespearean: Know you not , master , to some kind of men Their graces serve them but as enemies ?

English: Oh , what a world this is , when even what is beautiful in a man poisons him !
Shakespearean: Oh , what a world is this when what is comely Envenoms him that bears it !

English: Why , what's the matter ?
Shakespearean: Why , what's the matter ?

English: In this house lives a man who despises all that is good in you .
Shakespearean: Within this roof The enemy of all your graces lives .

English: Oliver , your brother , no , not your brother ; and yet he's the son , but no , I won't call him the son , of that great man I was about to call his father , has heard about how well you did in the wrestling match , and tonight he's planning on burning your house down , with you in it .
Shakespearean: Your brother , no , no brother , yet the son , Yet not the son , I will not call him son , Of him I was about to call his father Hath heard your praises , and this night he means To burn the lodging where you use to lie , And you within it .

English: And if he fails at that , he will find other ways to kill you .
Shakespearean: If he fail of that , He will have other means to cut you off .

English: I overheard him and his plans .
Shakespearean: I overheard him and his practices .

English: This is no place for you ; this home is now a slaughterhouse .
Shakespearean: This is no place , this house is but a butchery .

English: Hate it , fear it , do not come inside .
Shakespearean: Abhor it , fear it , do not enter it .

English: Then where would you have me go , Adam ?
Shakespearean: Why , whither , Adam , wouldst thou have me go ?

English: It doesn't matter where , so long as it's not here .
Shakespearean: No matter whither , so you come not here .

English: What , would you have me beg for my food ?
Shakespearean: What , wouldst thou have me go and beg my food , Or with a base and boist'rous sword enforce A thievish living on the common road ?

English: This is all that's left for me to do , but I won't do it .
Shakespearean: Yet this I will not do , do how I can .

English: I'd rather give myself up to the hatred of a violent brother who refuses to recognize that we are brothers .
Shakespearean: I rather will subject me to the malice Of a diverted blood and bloody brother .

English: But don't do that .
Shakespearean: But do not so .

English: Let me be your servant .
Shakespearean: Let me be your servant .

English: I know I may be old , but I'm strong and healthy , because in my youth I never drank nor lived recklessly .
Shakespearean: Though I look old , yet I am strong and lusty , For in my youth I never did apply Hot and rebellious liquors in my blood Nor did not with unbashful forehead woo The means of weakness and debility .

English: Therefore , my old age is like a blustery winter : cold , but kindly .
Shakespearean: Therefore my age is as a lusty winter , Frosty but kindly .

English: Let me go with you .
Shakespearean: Let me go with you .

English: I'll do everything a younger man could do for you .
Shakespearean: I'll do the service of a younger man In all your business and necessities .

English: Oh , good old man , you're a great example of that old work ethic , where people worked because it was their duty , not just for the money .
Shakespearean: O good old man , how well in thee appears The constant service of the antique world , When service sweat for duty , not for meed .

English: Come along , though .
Shakespearean: But come thy ways .

English: We'll go together , and before we've spent all the savings of your youth , we'll find a way to make a living .
Shakespearean: We'll go along together , And ere we have thy youthful wages spent , We'll light upon some settled low content .

English: Go on , master , and I will follow you , with truth and loyalty to my last breath .
Shakespearean: Master , go on , and I will follow thee To the last gasp , with truth and loyalty .

English: From the time I was seventeen , over sixty years ago , I have lived in this house , but now I will live here no more .
Shakespearean: From seventeen years till now almost fourscore Here lived I , but now live here no more .

English: Many men seek their fortune at seventeen ; at eighty , it's a bit late .
Shakespearean: At seventeen years , many their fortunes seek , But at fourscore , it is too late a week .

English: But fortune could not reward me better than to let me die well , without owing my master anything .
Shakespearean: Yet fortune can not recompense me better Than to die well , and not my master's debtor .

English: Oh Lord , my spirits are tired !
Shakespearean: O Jupiter , how weary are my spirits !

English: I wouldn't care about my spirits , if my legs weren't tired .
Shakespearean: I care not for my spirits , if my legs were not weary .

English: I can't go any further .
Shakespearean: I can not go no further .

English: I'd rather bear with you than Well , this is the Forest of Arden .
Shakespearean: For my part , I had rather bear with you than bear you .

English: Yes , now I'm in Arden , and that makes me the bigger fool .
Shakespearean: Ay , now am I in Arden , the more fool I .

English: Yes , be content , good Touchstone .
Shakespearean: Ay , be so , good Touchstone .

English: Look who's coming : a young man and an old man , having a serious talk .
Shakespearean: Look you who comes here , a young man and an old in solemn talk .

English: What , you dare put your hands on me , villain ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou lay hands on me , villain ?

English: I'm no villain .
Shakespearean: I am no villain .

English: If you weren't my brother , I'd leave this hand of mine on your neck until I'd pulled out your tongue for talking like this .
Shakespearean: Wert thou not my brother , I would not take this hand from thy throat till this other had pulled out thy tongue for saying so .

English: You've only insulted yourself .
Shakespearean: Thou hast railed on thyself .

English: Gentlemen , calm down .
Shakespearean: Sweet masters , be patient .

English: For the sake of your father's memory , make peace .
Shakespearean: For your father's remembrance , be at accord .

English: Let me go , I say .
Shakespearean: Let me go , I say .

English: I won't until I'm ready .
Shakespearean: I will not till I please .

English: You will listen to me .
Shakespearean: You shall hear me .

English: My father instructed you in his will to give me a good education .
Shakespearean: My father charged you in his will to give me good education .

English: But you've raised me as a peasant , hiding from me what I needed to become a gentleman .
Shakespearean: You have trained me like a peasant , obscuring and hiding from me all gentlemanlike qualities .

English: My father's spirit is growing in me , and I won't take this any longer .
Shakespearean: The spirit of my father grows strong in me , and I will no longer endure it .

English: And what are you going to do after you've spent your money ?
Shakespearean: And what wilt thou do , beg when that is spent ?

English: Well , sir , go inside .
Shakespearean: Well , sir , get you in .

English: I'm not going to be bothered by you for long .
Shakespearean: I will not long be troubled with you .

English: You'll get some of what you want .
Shakespearean: You shall have some part of your will .

English: Now please leave me alone .
Shakespearean: I pray you leave me .

English: What you're doing is the way to make her scorn you continually .
Shakespearean: That is the way to make her scorn you still .

English: Oh , Corin , I wish you could understand how much I love her !
Shakespearean: O Corin , that thou knew'st how I do love her !

English: I'm sure I can guess .
Shakespearean: I partly guess , for I have loved ere now .

English: No Corin , since you're old , you can not guess , even if you were as dedicated a lover in your youth as there ever was , sighing and mooning all night long .
Shakespearean: No , Corin , being old , thou canst not guess , Though in thy youth thou wast as true a lover As ever sighed upon a midnight pillow .

English: If your love was anything like mine , and I'm sure that no man has loved as I love now , exactly how many ridiculous actions did your fantasizing lead you to ?
Shakespearean: But if thy love were ever like to mine , As sure I think did never man love so , How many actions most ridiculous Hast thou been drawn to by thy fantasy ?

English: Oh , a thousand of them , all of which I've forgotten .
Shakespearean: Into a thousand that I have forgotten .

English: Oh , then you never loved as wholeheartedly as me .
Shakespearean: Oh , thou didst then ne'er love so heartily .

English: If you can't remember the stupidest little thing love made you do , you haven't loved .
Shakespearean: If thou rememb'rest not the slightest folly That ever love did make thee run into , Thou hast not loved .

English: Or if you haven't sat as I do now , boring your listener with all your lover's virtues , then you haven't loved .
Shakespearean: Or if thou hast not sat as I do now , Wearying thy hearer in thy mistress's praise , Thou hast not loved .

English: Or if you haven't broken away from human company , as my feelings now lead me to do , you haven't loved .
Shakespearean: Or if thou hast not broke from company Abruptly , as my passion now makes me , Thou hast not loved .

English: O Phoebe , Phoebe , Phoebe !
Shakespearean: O Phoebe , Phoebe , Phoebe !

English: Oh , poor shepherd !
Shakespearean: Alas , poor shepherd , searching of thy wound , I have by hard adventure found mine own .

English: Me too .
Shakespearean: And I mine .

English: I remember when I was in love , I broke my sword on a stone , and told him to take that for coming at night to see Jane Smile .
Shakespearean: I remember when I was in love I broke my sword upon a stone and bid him take that for coming a- night to Jane Smile .

English: I remember kissing her washing stick and the cow's udders that her pretty , chapped hands had milked .
Shakespearean: And I remember the kissing of her batler , and the cow's dugs that her pretty chopped hands had milked .

English: I remember wooing a pea plant in her name , and then taking two pea pods and begging her to wear them "for my sake." Those of us who are really in love will do the strangest things .
Shakespearean: And I remember the wooing of a peascod instead of her , from whom I took two cods and , giving her them again , said with weeping tears , "Wear these for my sake." We that are true lovers run into strange capers .

English: But everything that lives is mortal , including the foolishness of love .
Shakespearean: But as all is mortal in nature , so is all nature in love mortal in folly .

English: You speak more wisely than you know .
Shakespearean: Thou speak'st wiser than thou art ware of .

English: Nah , I'll never be aware of my own wit , until I break my shins on it .
Shakespearean: Nay , I shall ne'er be ware of mine own wit till I break my shins against it .

English: By God !
Shakespearean: Jove , Jove , this shepherd's passion Is much upon my fashion .

English: And like mine , but I'm getting a little tired of it .
Shakespearean: And mine , but it grows something stale with me .

English: Please , one of you go ask that man over there if we can buy some food off him .
Shakespearean: I pray you , one of you question yond man , if he for gold will give us any food .

English: Shut up , fool .
Shakespearean: Peace , fool .

English: He's not your relative .
Shakespearean: He's not thy kinsman .

English: Who's calling ?
Shakespearean: Who calls ?

English: Your superiors .
Shakespearean: Your betters , sir .

English: Please sir , if love or money can buy anything in this empty place , tell us where we can rest and feed ourselves .
Shakespearean: I prithee , shepherd , if that love or gold Can in this desert place buy entertainment , Bring us where we may rest ourselves and feed .

English: Dear sir , I pity the lady and wish , more for her sake than my own , that I was more able to help her .
Shakespearean: Fair sir , I pity her And wish , for her sake more than for mine own , My fortunes were more able to relieve her .

English: But I'm a hired hand : I don't profit from the flocks I tend .
Shakespearean: But I am shepherd to another man And do not shear the fleeces that I graze .

English: Besides , his cottage , his flocks , and his grazing rights are on sale now , and since he's not there , there's nothing to eat at our house .
Shakespearean: Besides , his cote , his flocks , and bounds of feed Are now on sale , and at our sheepcote now , By reason of his absence , there is nothing That you will feed on .

English: Who wants to buy the flock and the pasture ?
Shakespearean: What is he that shall buy his flock and pasture ?

English: That young man who was just here .
Shakespearean: That young swain that you saw here but erewhile , That little cares for buying anything .

English: Please , if you can do it without taking advantage of the young man , buy the cottage , pasture , and flock for us , and we'll pay you for it .
Shakespearean: I pray thee , if it stand with honesty , Buy thou the cottage , pasture , and the flock , And thou shalt have to pay for it of us .

English: And we will raise your wages .
Shakespearean: And we will mend thy wages .

English: The thing is definitely going to be sold .
Shakespearean: Assuredly the thing is to be sold .

English: Come with me .
Shakespearean: Go with me .

English: If you like what you see of the land , the profit that's possible , and this rustic life , I'll be your faithful servant , and buy the place with your gold right away .
Shakespearean: If you like upon report The soil , the profit , and this kind of life , I will your very faithful feeder be And buy it with your gold right suddenly .

English: More , more , please , more .
Shakespearean: More , more , I prithee , more .

English: It's only going to make you sad , Monsieur Jaques .
Shakespearean: It will make you melancholy , Monsieur Jaques .

English: I'm glad about that .
Shakespearean: I thank it .

English: More , please , more .
Shakespearean: More , I prithee , more .

English: I can suck sadness out of a song the way a weasel sucks eggs .
Shakespearean: I can suck melancholy out of a song as a weasel sucks eggs .

English: More , please , more .
Shakespearean: More , I prithee , more .

English: My voice is ragged .
Shakespearean: My voice is ragged .

English: I know I won't please you .
Shakespearean: I know I can not please you .

English: Come on , another stanza , is that what you call 'em , "stanzas" ?
Shakespearean: Come , more , another stanzo .

English: Nah , I don't care what their
Shakespearean: Nay , I care not for their names .

English: Well then , if I've ever thanked a man , I'll thank you now .
Shakespearean: Well then , if ever I thank any man , I'll thank you .

English: But two men complimenting each other is like two baboons getting together .
Shakespearean: But that they call "compliment" is like th ' encounter of two dog- apes .

English: The duke will drink under this tree. , He's been looking for you all day , you know .
Shakespearean: Well , I'll end the song. , Sirs , cover the while ; the duke will drink under this tree. , He hath been all this day to look you .

English: And I've been avoiding him all day .
Shakespearean: And I have been all this day to avoid him .

English: He's too argumentative for me .
Shakespearean: He is too disputable for my company .

English: I think of as many things as he does , but I just thank heaven and don't show off about it .
Shakespearean: I think of as many matters as he , but I give heaven thanks and make no boast of them .

English: Come , warble for me .
Shakespearean: Come , warble , come .

English: I wrote a verse to this tune , though it's not very imaginative .
Shakespearean: I'll give you a verse to this note that I made yesterday in despite of my invention .

English: Dear master , I can't go any farther .
Shakespearean: Dear master , I can go no further .

English: Oh , I'm dying of hunger .
Shakespearean: Oh , I die for food .

English: I'll lie down here and measure out my grave .
Shakespearean: Here lie I down and measure out my grave .

English: Farewell , kind master .
Shakespearean: Farewell , kind master .

English: Hey , what's this , Adam ?
Shakespearean: Why , how now , Adam ?

English: No braver than this ?
Shakespearean: No greater heart in thee ?

English: Live a little , be comforted a little , cheer up a little .
Shakespearean: Live a little , comfort a little , cheer thyself a little .

English: If I can find any animal in this wild forest , I'll either be food for it or bring it as food for you .
Shakespearean: If this uncouth forest yield anything savage , I will either be food for it or bring it for food to thee .

English: You're not as close to death as you think you are .
Shakespearean: Thy conceit is nearer death than thy powers .

English: I'll be back soon , and if I haven't brought you anything to eat , I will give you permission to die .
Shakespearean: I will here be with thee presently , and if I bring thee not something to eat , I will give thee leave to die .

English: But if you die before I return , you'll have made a mockery of my efforts .
Shakespearean: But if thou diest before I come , thou art a mocker of my labor .

English: There we go !
Shakespearean: Well said .

English: You look happier already , and I'll be back quickly .
Shakespearean: Thou look'st cheerly , and I'll be with thee quickly .

English: But you're lying out in the cold .
Shakespearean: Yet thou liest in the bleak air .

English: Cheer up , good Adam .
Shakespearean: Cheerly , good Adam .

English: I think he must have turned into an animal , because I can't find him anywhere looking like a man .
Shakespearean: I think he be transformed into a beast , For I can nowhere find him like a man .

English: My lord , he just left here .
Shakespearean: My lord , he is but even now gone hence .

English: He was happy here , listening to a song .
Shakespearean: Here was he merry , hearing of a song .

English: If that man , who's made up of conflicts , becomes musical , then there must be something wrong with the universe .
Shakespearean: If he , compact of jars , grow musical , We shall have shortly discord in the spheres .

English: Go find him .
Shakespearean: Go seek him .

English: Tell him I want to speak with him .
Shakespearean: Tell him I would speak with him .

English: He saved me the trouble : here he comes .
Shakespearean: He saves my labor by his own approach .

English: Well , what's going on , mister ?
Shakespearean: Why , how now , monsieur ?

English: What kind of life do you lead that your poor friends must beg for your company ?
Shakespearean: What a life is this That your poor friends must woo your company ?

English: What , you look amused .
Shakespearean: What , you look merrily .

English: Then he pulled a watch from his bag and , looking at it solemnly , said , "It's ten o'clock .
Shakespearean: And then he drew a dial from his poke And , looking on it with lackluster eye , Says very wisely , "It is ten o'clock .

English: This way , we can see how the world moves .
Shakespearean: Thus we may see , " quoth he , "how the world wags .

English: Only an hour ago it was nine , and in another hour it will be eleven .
Shakespearean: Tis but an hour ago since it was nine , And after one hour more 'twill be eleven .

English: Oh , noble fool !
Shakespearean: O noble fool !

English: A worthy fool !
Shakespearean: A worthy fool !

English: Motley is the only thing to wear .
Shakespearean: Motley's the only wear .

English: Who is this fool ?
Shakespearean: What fool is this ?

English: A worthy fool !
Shakespearean: Oh , that I were a fool !

English: God bless my old master .
Shakespearean: God be with my old master .

English: He would never have spoken to me like this .
Shakespearean: He would not have spoke such a word .

English: Is that how it's going to be ?
Shakespearean: Is it even so ?

English: Are you starting to challenge me ?
Shakespearean: Begin you to grow upon me ?

English: I'll cure you of your insolence , and I'm not going to give you a thousand crowns , either ! , Hey , Dennis !
Shakespearean: I will physic your rankness and yet give no thousand crowns neither. , Holla , Dennis !

English: Did you call for me , your Worship ?
Shakespearean: Calls your Worship ?

English: Wasn't Charles , the duke's wrestler , here to speak with me ?
Shakespearean: Was not Charles , the duke's wrestler , here to speak with me ?

English: Yes , sir , he's here at the door right now and asks to see you .
Shakespearean: So please you , he is here at the door and importunes access to you .

English: Call him in .
Shakespearean: Call him in .

English: I have a good plan .
Shakespearean: Twill be a good way , and tomorrow the wrestling is .

English: Like the wind , I must have the freedom to blast anyone I please , as fools do .
Shakespearean: I must have liberty Withal , as large a charter as the wind , To blow on whom I please , for so fools have .

English: And whoever is most irritated by my foolishness has to laugh the hardest .
Shakespearean: And they that are most galled with my folly , They most must laugh .

English: Why , sir , must he ?
Shakespearean: And why , sir , must they so ?

English: Well , it's as plain as the beaten path to a parish church .
Shakespearean: The "why" is plain as way to parish church : He that a fool doth very wisely hit Doth very foolishly , although he smart , Not to seem senseless of the bob .

English: Dress me up in motley .
Shakespearean: Invest me in my motley .

English: Let me speak my mind , and I'll rid the world of its sickness , if it will only tolerate my medicine .
Shakespearean: Give me leave To speak my mind , and I will through and through Cleanse the foul body of th ' infected world , If they will patiently receive my medicine .

English: To hell with you !
Shakespearean: Fie on thee !

English: I know what you'd do .
Shakespearean: I can tell what thou wouldst do .

English: What would I do besides good ?
Shakespearean: What , for a counter , would I do but good ?

English: You would be committing a wicked sin by chiding other people for sinning , because you yourself have been a terrible sinner , as carnal in your appetites as lust itself , and all the swollen pustules of sin that you acquired in your freedom you now want to burst and shoot back into the world at large .
Shakespearean: Most mischievous foul sin in chiding sin , For thou thyself hast been a libertine , As sensual as the brutish sting itself , And all th ' embossed sores and headed evils That thou with license of free foot hast caught Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world .

English: Who can say I mean just her when all her neighbors are exactly like her ?
Shakespearean: Who can come in and say that I mean her , When such a one as she such is her neighbor ?

English: And when some lowlife protests that Stop , and eat no more .
Shakespearean: Forbear , and eat no more .

English: But I haven't eaten anything yet .
Shakespearean: Why , I have eat none yet .

English: And you won't until the needy eat .
Shakespearean: Nor shalt not till necessity be served .

English: What kind of fighting cock is this ?
Shakespearean: Of what kind should this cock come of ?

English: Are you acting so boldly from hardship or because you despise good manners ?
Shakespearean: Art thou thus boldened , man , by thy distress Or else a rude despiser of good manners , That in civility thou seem'st so empty ?

English: You were right the first time .
Shakespearean: You touched my vein at first .

English: But stop , I say .
Shakespearean: But forbear , I say .

English: If you won't listen to reason , I'll have to die .
Shakespearean: An you will not be answered with reason , I must die .

English: What would you like ?
Shakespearean: What would you have ?

English: Gentlemanly manners have more sway around here than force does .
Shakespearean: Your gentleness shall force More than your force move us to gentleness .

English: I'm dying for food , so let me have some .
Shakespearean: I almost die for food , and let me have it .

English: Sit down and eat , and welcome to our table .
Shakespearean: Sit down and feed , and welcome to our table .

English: Do you really speak like such a gentleman ?
Shakespearean: Speak you so gently ?

English: I beg your pardon .
Shakespearean: Pardon me , I pray you .

English: I thought everything out here was wild , which is why I acted so stern and commanding .
Shakespearean: I thought that all things had been savage here , And therefore put I on the countenance Of stern commandment .

English: We have in fact seen better days and been summoned to church by the ringing of the holy bell and sat at good men's feasts and cried tears of pity , therefore , sit down and take whatever will satisfy your needs .
Shakespearean: True is it that we have seen better days And have with holy bell been knolled to church , And sat at good men's feasts and wiped our eyes Of drops that sacred pity hath engendered .

English: Then please , put off your eating for a little while I , like a mother doe , find my fawn and bring it food .
Shakespearean: Then but forbear your food a little while Whiles , like a doe , I go to find my fawn And give it food .

English: There is a poor old man who , purely out of love , has limped after me for miles .
Shakespearean: There is an old poor man Who after me hath many a weary step Limped in pure love .

English: Thank you , and God bless you for your hospitality .
Shakespearean: I thank you ; and be blessed for your good comfort .

English: You see , we're not alone in our unhappiness .
Shakespearean: Thou seest we are not all alone unhappy .

English: The whole world is a stage , and all the men and women merely actors .
Shakespearean: All the world's a stage , And all the men and women merely players .

English: They have their exits and their entrances , and in his lifetime a man will play many parts , his life separated into seven acts .
Shakespearean: They have their exits and their entrances , And one man in his time plays many parts , His acts being seven ages .

English: In the first act he is an infant , whimpering and puking in his nurse's arms .
Shakespearean: At first the infant , Mewling and puking in the nurse's arms .

English: Then he's the whining schoolboy , with a book bag and a bright , young face , creeping like a snail unwillingly to school .
Shakespearean: Then the whining schoolboy with his satchel And shining morning face , creeping like snail Unwillingly to school .

English: He's full of wise sayings and up-to-the-minute anecdotes : that's the way he plays his part .
Shakespearean: And then the justice , In fair round belly with good capon lined , With eyes severe and beard of formal cut , Full of wise saws and modern instances ; And so he plays his part .

English: Welcome .
Shakespearean: Welcome .

English: Set the honorable old man down and let him eat .
Shakespearean: Set down your venerable burden , And let him feed .

English: I thank you very much on his behalf .
Shakespearean: I thank you most for him .

English: Welcome .
Shakespearean: Welcome .

English: Eat .
Shakespearean: Fall to .

English: I won't trouble you yet with questions about your situation. , Some music , please , and , good friend , sing .
Shakespearean: I will not trouble you As yet to question you about your fortunes. , Give us some music , and , good cousin , sing .

English: Time's not the one in debt .
Shakespearean: As if time were in debt .

English: Your logic is so foolish .
Shakespearean: How fondly dost thou reason !

English: Take it to your master and bring him home immediately .
Shakespearean: Bear it straight , And bring thy master home immediately .

English: Every person I meet greets me like an old friend , and every one of them knows my name .
Shakespearean: There's not a man I meet but doth salute me As if I were their well-acquainted friend , And every one doth call me by my name .

English: Some of them give me money , some invite me places , some thank me for the kind things I've done for them , some try to sell me things .
Shakespearean: Some tender money to me ; some invite me ; Some other give me thanks for kindnesses ; Some offer me commodities to buy .

English: Just now a tailor showed me fabrics he bought especially for me and then started to take my measurements .
Shakespearean: Even now a tailor called me in his shop And showed me silks that he had bought for me , And therewithal took measure of my body .

English: These are tricks of the imagination , and this place is filled with magicians .
Shakespearean: Sure , these are but imaginary wiles , And lapland sorcerers inhabit here .

English: Here's the money you wanted , master .
Shakespearean: Master , here's The gold you sent me for .

English: Who's this Adam you speak of ?
Shakespearean: What Adam dost thou mean ?

English: Not the Adam from the garden of Eden , but the Adam from the jailhouse .
Shakespearean: Not that Adam that kept the Paradise , but that Adam that keeps the prison ; he that goes in the calf's skin that was killed for the Prodigal ; he that came behind you , sir , like an evil angel , and bid you forsake your liberty .

English: I don't know what you're talking about .
Shakespearean: I understand thee not .

English: No ?
Shakespearean: No ?

English: You mean an officer ?
Shakespearean: What , thou meanest an officer ?

English: Yes , the leader of the team ; the one that gets you if you can't pay a debt ; the one who assumes people are always going to bed and says to them , "Have arrest." Well , sir , stop your joking there .
Shakespearean: Ay , sir , the sergeant of the band ; he that brings any man to answer it that breaks his band ; one that thinks a man always going to bed and says "God give you good rest." Well , sir , there rest in your foolery .

English: Are any ships leaving tonight ?
Shakespearean: Is there any ships put forth tonight ?

English: Can we go ?
Shakespearean: May we be gone ?

English: Please , somebody , get us out of here !
Shakespearean: Some blessed power deliver us from hence !

English: Good to see you , Master Antipholus .
Shakespearean: Well met , well met , Master Antipholus .

English: I see you've met with the jeweler .
Shakespearean: I see , sir , you have found the goldsmith now .

English: Is that chain you're wearing the one you promised to give to me ?
Shakespearean: Is that the chain you promised me today ?

English: Get away from me , Satan !
Shakespearean: Satan , avoid !

English: Don't try to tempt me !
Shakespearean: I charge thee , tempt me not .

English: Master , is this Satan's mistress ?
Shakespearean: Master , is this Mistress Satan ?

English: She's the devil .
Shakespearean: It is the devil .

English: No , she's worse : she's the devil's mother , and she comes to us disguised as an easy wench .
Shakespearean: Nay , she is worse ; she is the devil's dam , and here she comes in the habit of a light wench .

English: But fire also gives off light , and fire will burn you .
Shakespearean: Light is an effect of fire , and fire will burn : ergo , light wenches will burn .

English: You and your servant are very funny , sir .
Shakespearean: Your man and you are marvelous merry , sir .

English: Will you come with me ?
Shakespearean: Will you go with me ?

English: Can we finish our lunch ?
Shakespearean: We'll mend our dinner here .

English: Master , if you eat with her , bring really long silverware .
Shakespearean: Master , if you do , expect spoon meat ; or bespeak a long spoon .

English: Why , Dromio ?
Shakespearean: Why , Dromio ?

English: Some Now listen , either give me my ring or give me the necklace .
Shakespearean: I pray you , sir , my ring or else the chain .

English: I hope you're not trying to cheat me .
Shakespearean: I hope you do not mean to cheat me so .

English: Come , Dromio , let's go .
Shakespearean: Avaunt , thou witch ! , Come , Dromio , let us go .

English: Mistress , you know about that .
Shakespearean: Mistress , that you know .

English: Antipholus has gone insane , no question about it .
Shakespearean: Now , out of doubt Antipholus is mad ; Else would he never so demean himself .

English: He has a ring of mine , worth forty ducats , and he promised to give me a necklace in exchange for it .
Shakespearean: A ring he hath of mine worth forty ducats , And for the same he promised me a chain .

English: Now he won't give me either .
Shakespearean: Both one and other he denies me now .

English: The reason I think he's insane , besides the way he just acted , is that he told a senseless story over lunch about being locked out of his own house .
Shakespearean: The reason that I gather he is mad , Besides this present instance of his rage , Is a mad tale he told today at dinner Of his own doors being shut against his entrance .

English: His wife probably did it on purpose because she knows what kind of fits he's having .
Shakespearean: Belike his wife , acquainted with his fits , On purpose shut the doors against his way .

English: I must go to his house and tell his wife that he came bursting into my place like a lunatic and stole my ring .
Shakespearean: My way is now to hie home to his house And tell his wife that , being lunatic , He rushed into my house and took perforce My ring away .

English: It's my best option : I can't afford to lose forty ducats .
Shakespearean: This course I fittest choose , For forty ducats is too much to lose .

English: I've spent five years in the remotest parts of Greece and roaming all over Asia .
Shakespearean: Five summers have I spent in farthest Greece , Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia , And , coasting homeward , came to Ephesus , Hopeless to find , yet loath to leave unsought Or that or any place that harbors men .

English: However , I'll do what I can for you .
Shakespearean: But though thou art adjudged to the death , And passed sentence may not be recalled But to our honour's great disparagement , Yet will I favor thee in what I can .

English: I will allow you one day to look for help in Ephesus .
Shakespearean: Therefore , merchant , I'll limit thee this day To seek thy life by beneficial help .

English: I will .
Shakespearean: I will , my lord .

English: Don't worry , man , I won't try to escape .
Shakespearean: Fear me not , man .

English: I tell you , this will make her angry when she hears about it .
Shakespearean: I tell you , 'twill sound harshly in her ears .

English: Here's my servant .
Shakespearean: Here comes my man .

English: I think he's got the money .
Shakespearean: I think he brings the money .

English: Hello there , sir !
Shakespearean: How now , sir ?

English: Do you have what I told you to get ?
Shakespearean: Have you that I sent you for ?

English: Yes .
Shakespearean: Here's that , I warrant you , will pay them all .

English: But where's the money ?
Shakespearean: But where's the money ?

English: Why , sir , I spent it on this rope .
Shakespearean: Why , sir , I gave the money for the rope .

English: I can get you five hundred ropes for that price .
Shakespearean: I'll serve you , sir , five hundred at the rate .

English: Why did I just send you home ?
Shakespearean: To what end did I bid thee hie thee home ?

English: And here I am , with that piece .
Shakespearean: To a rope's end , sir , and to that end am I returned .

English: And I'll use that piece of rope to welcome you with .
Shakespearean: And to that end , sir , I will welcome you .

English: Good sir , calm down .
Shakespearean: Good sir , be patient .

English: Hold your tongue .
Shakespearean: Good now , hold thy tongue .

English: No , you should tell him to hold his hands !
Shakespearean: Nay , rather persuade him to hold his hands .

English: I wish I were senseless , sir , so that I wouldn't feel your punches !
Shakespearean: I would I were senseless , sir , that I might not feel your blows .

English: The only thing you can sense are punches , just like an ass .
Shakespearean: Thou art sensible in nothing but blows , and so is an ass .

English: I am an ass , indeed : you can tell by my long ears .
Shakespearean: I am an ass , indeed ; you may prove it by my long ears. , I have served him from the hour of my nativity to this instant , and have nothing at his hands for my service but blows .

English: I figure that once he's crippled me , I'll beg by showing off my beatings .
Shakespearean: Nay , I bear it on my shoulders as a beggar wont her brat , and I think when he hath lamed me , I shall beg with it from door to door .

English: That's enough .
Shakespearean: Come , go along .

English: My wife's coming .
Shakespearean: My wife is coming yonder .

English: Mistress , think about your end , beware of your death !
Shakespearean: Mistress , Wilt thou still talk ?

English: EPHESUS Now what do you think ?
Shakespearean: How say you now ?

English: Your husband's mad , isn't he ?
Shakespearean: Is not your husband mad ?

English: He's trembling in his fit !
Shakespearean: Mark how he trembles in his ecstasy .

English: I demand this in the name of all the saints in heaven .
Shakespearean: I conjure thee by all the saints in heaven .

English: Shut up , you doddering old wizard !
Shakespearean: Peace , doting wizard , peace .

English: I'm not possessed !
Shakespearean: I am not mad .

English: Oh , I wish you weren't , you poor , frightened soul .
Shakespearean: O , that thou wert not , poor distressed soul !

English: Listen , hussy , is this man one of your customers ?
Shakespearean: You minion , you , are these your customers ?

English: Did this fool with the yellow face feast and celebrate in my house today while the guilty doors shut in my face and locked me out of my own house ?
Shakespearean: Did this companion with the saffron face Revel and feast it at my house today Whilst upon me the guilty doors were shut And I denied to enter in my house ?

English: Ate at home ?
Shakespearean: Dined at home" ?

English: You there , rogue , what do you have to say about that ?
Shakespearean: Thou villain , what sayest thou ?

English: I swear , sir , you did not eat at home .
Shakespearean: Sir , sooth to say , you did not dine at home .

English: My doors were locked and I was shut out , right ?
Shakespearean: Were not my doors locked up and I shut out ?

English: By God , your doors were locked and you were shut out .
Shakespearean: Perdie , your doors were locked , and you shut out .

English: And she screamed at me , right ?
Shakespearean: And did not she herself revile me there ?

English: No lie , she screamed at you .
Shakespearean: Sans fable , she herself reviled you there .

English: And her cook yelled , mocked , and teased me , right ?
Shakespearean: Did not her kitchen maid rail , taunt , and scorn me ?

English: And I departed in a rage , right ?
Shakespearean: And did not I in rage depart from thence ?

English: You truly did .
Shakespearean: In verity you did. , My bones bear witness , That since have felt the vigour of his rage .

English: Good idea .
Shakespearean: It is no shame .

English: I gave it to Dromio , who rushed in for it .
Shakespearean: Alas , I sent you money to redeem you By Dromio here , who came in haste for it .

English: You gave money to me ?
Shakespearean: Money by me !

English: Didn't you go to her for a purse full of ducats ?
Shakespearean: Went'st not thou to her for a purse of ducats ?

English: He did , and I gave it to him .
Shakespearean: He came to me , and I delivered it .

English: And I saw her do it .
Shakespearean: And I am witness with her that she did .

English: I was sent for a rope !
Shakespearean: God and the rope-maker bear me witness That I was sent for nothing but a rope .

English: Mistress , both the man and his master are possessed .
Shakespearean: Mistress , both man and master is possessed .

English: I can tell by how pale and deathlike they look .
Shakespearean: I know it by their pale and deadly looks .

English: We must tie them up and leave them in some dark room .
Shakespearean: They must be bound and laid in some dark room .

English: My sweet husband , I did not lock you out .
Shakespearean: I did not , gentle husband , lock thee forth .

English: And my sweet master , I received no gold .
Shakespearean: And , gentle master , I received no gold .

English: But I agree , sir , that we were locked out .
Shakespearean: But I confess , sir , that we were locked out .

English: Keep him away from me !
Shakespearean: Let him not come near me .

English: We need more help !
Shakespearean: More company !

English: The devil in him is strong !
Shakespearean: The fiend is strong within him .

English: jailer , i'm your prisoner .
Shakespearean: What , will you murder me ? , Thou jailer , thou , I am thy prisoner .

English: are you going to let them break me out of jail ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou suffer them To make a rescue ?

English: Gentlemen , let go of him .
Shakespearean: Masters , let him go .

English: He's my prisoner and you can't have him .
Shakespearean: He is my prisoner , and you shall not have him .

English: Tie up the servant , for he is mad as well .
Shakespearean: Go , bind this man , for he is frantic too .

English: He's my prisoner .
Shakespearean: He is my prisoner .

English: If I let him go , I'll have to pay his bail fees myself .
Shakespearean: If I let him go , The debt he owes will be required of me .

English: I'll pay you .
Shakespearean: I will discharge thee ere I go from thee .

English: Take me to the man my husband is in debt to .
Shakespearean: Bear me forthwith unto his creditor , And , knowing how the debt grows , I will pay it. , Good Master Doctor , see him safe conveyed Home to my house .

English: What a horrible day !
Shakespearean: O most unhappy day !

English: What a horrible slut !
Shakespearean: O most unhappy strumpet !

English: Master , I'm all tied up for you .
Shakespearean: Master , I am here entered in bond for you .

English: The poor souls , how strangely they talk !
Shakespearean: How idly do they talk !

English: Angelo , the jeweler .
Shakespearean: One Angelo , a goldsmith .

English: Do you know him ?
Shakespearean: Do you know him ?

English: I know him .
Shakespearean: I know the man .

English: Two hundred ducats .
Shakespearean: Two hundred ducats .

English: For what ?
Shakespearean: Say , how grows it due ?

English: For a necklace your husband had him make .
Shakespearean: Due for a chain your husband had of him .

English: He said he was going to buy me a necklace , but I never saw it .
Shakespearean: He did bespeak a chain for me but had it not .

English: I need to hear the truth about all this .
Shakespearean: I long to know the truth hereof at large .

English: God have mercy on us !
Shakespearean: God for Thy mercy , they are loose again !

English: And they've got their swords unsheathed !
Shakespearean: And come with naked swords .

English: Let's call for help and get them tied up again !
Shakespearean: Let's call more help To have them bound again .

English: Let's get out of here !
Shakespearean: Away !

English: They'll kill us !
Shakespearean: They'll kill us .

English: It looks like these witches are scared of swords .
Shakespearean: I see these witches are afraid of swords .

English: The one who claims to be your wife just ran away from you .
Shakespearean: She that would be your wife now ran from you .

English: I wish we were safely on board our ship already .
Shakespearean: I long that we were safe and sound aboard .

English: Look , let's stay here tonight .
Shakespearean: Faith , stay here this night .

English: Nobody will hurt us .
Shakespearean: They will surely do us no harm .

English: You see how kind everyone is to us , how they just hand us gold .
Shakespearean: You saw they speak us fair , give us gold .

English: I think this country is so kind that if it weren't for
Shakespearean: Methinks they are such a gentle nation that , but for the mountain of mad flesh

English: that mountain of insanity that wants to marry me , I could find it in my heart to stay here and become a witch myself .
Shakespearean: that claims marriage of me , i could find in my heart to stay here still , and turn witch .

English: I wouldn't stay here tonight for the entire town .
Shakespearean: I will not stay tonight for all the town .

English: Go and get our stuff onto the ship .
Shakespearean: Therefore away , to get our stuff aboard .

English: What's this man's reputation like here in the city ?
Shakespearean: How is the man esteemed here in the city ?

English: I'd trust him with everything I own .
Shakespearean: His word might bear my wealth at any time .

English: You're right .
Shakespearean: Speak softly .

English: And that necklace around his neck is the very one he swore he didn't have !
Shakespearean: Tis so ; and that self chain about his neck Which he forswore most monstrously to have .

English: Good sir , stay close to me .
Shakespearean: Good sir , draw near to me .

English: So , tell people that you're from Epidamnum-otherwise all your goods will be confiscated .
Shakespearean: Therefore give out you are of Epidamnum , Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate .

English: Here's the money you asked me to hold .
Shakespearean: There is your money that I had to keep .

English: Dromio , bring this money to the Centaur Inn , where we're lodging , and wait there until I come .
Shakespearean: Go bear it to the Centaur , where we host , And stay there , Dromio , till I come to thee .

English: It'll be lunchtime within an hour .
Shakespearean: Within this hour it will be dinnertime .

English: Until then , I'll walk around town , peruse the markets , and gaze upon the buildings , and then I'll return and sleep at the inn .
Shakespearean: Till that , I'll view the manners of the town , Peruse the traders , gaze upon the buildings , And then return and sleep within mine inn , For with long travel I am stiff and weary .

English: Get going now .
Shakespearean: Get thee away .

English: Many men would take you literally and take off with all this money .
Shakespearean: Many a man would take you at your word And go indeed , having so good a mean .

English: Often , when I'm dulled by worry and melancholy , he lightens my mood with his merry pranks .
Shakespearean: A trusty villain , sir , that very oft , When I am dull with care and melancholy , Lightens my humor with his merry jests .

English: Listen , will you walk with me around the town and then dine with me at the inn ?
Shakespearean: What , will you walk with me about the town And then go to my inn and dine with me ?

English: But if
Shakespearean: I think I had .

English: I got it from you , I never said I didn't .
Shakespearean: I never did deny it .

English: Yes , you did , sir .
Shakespearean: Yes , that you did , sir , and forswore it too .

English: Who heard me do that ?
Shakespearean: Who heard me to deny it or forswear it ?

English: My own ears heard it , and you know it .
Shakespearean: These ears of mine , thou know'st did hear thee .

English: To hell with you !
Shakespearean: Fie on thee , wretch .

English: It's a shame that you walk the streets with all the honest men .
Shakespearean: Tis pity that thou liv'st To walk where any honest men resort .

English: You're a villain to say this about me .
Shakespearean: Thou art a villain to impeach me thus .

English: I'll prove that I'm an honest man and a man of honor if you dare defend yourself .
Shakespearean: I'll prove mine honor and mine honesty Against thee presently if thou dar'st stand .

English: I do dare , and I say that you are the villain .
Shakespearean: I dare , and do defy thee for a villain .

English: Run , master , run .
Shakespearean: Run , master , run .

English: For God's sake , find a house to duck into .
Shakespearean: For God's sake , take a house .

English: This looks like an abbey .
Shakespearean: This is some priory .

English: Go in , or we're done for .
Shakespearean: In , or we are spoiled .

English: Be quiet , people !
Shakespearean: Be quiet , people .

English: Why have you come here in such a mob ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore throng you hither ?

English: To get my poor , mad husband out from inside there .
Shakespearean: To fetch my poor distracted husband hence .

English: Let us in so we can tie him up tight and bring him home to recover .
Shakespearean: Let us come in , that we may bind him fast And bear him home for his recovery .

English: How long has he been possessed like this ?
Shakespearean: How long hath this possession held the man ?

English: This week he was sad , moody , and depressed and very different from his usual self .
Shakespearean: This week he hath been heavy , sour , sad , And much different from the man he was .

English: But it wasn't until this afternoon that he broke out into violence .
Shakespearean: But till this afternoon his passion Ne'er brake into extremity of rage .

English: That's a sin young men often commit because they allow their eyes to wander .
Shakespearean: Hath not else his eye Stray'd his affection in unlawful love , A sin prevailing much in youthful men Who give their eyes the liberty of gazing ?

English: Which of these bad things happened to him ?
Shakespearean: Which of these sorrows is he subject to ?

English: You should have reprimanded him for that .
Shakespearean: You should for that have reprehended him .

English: I did .
Shakespearean: Why , so I did .

English: Fine , but you weren't harsh enough .
Shakespearean: Ay , but not rough enough .

English: You scolded him in private ?
Shakespearean: Haply in private .

English: And in public too .
Shakespearean: And in assemblies too .

English: Fine , but not enough .
Shakespearean: Ay , but not enough .

English: He couldn't eat without me talking about it .
Shakespearean: Alone , it was the subject of my theme ; In company I often glanced it .

English: All I ever did was tell him how hurtful and bad it was .
Shakespearean: Still did I tell him it was vile and bad .

English: And that's why he went crazy .
Shakespearean: And thereof came it that the man was mad .

English: A jealous woman's poisonous ranting is worse than the bite of a rabid dog .
Shakespearean: The venom clamors of a jealous woman Poisons more deadly than a mad dog's tooth .

English: You seasoned his food with screams .
Shakespearean: Thou sayst his meat was sauced with thy upbraidings .

English: Fever , as we know , is a kind of madness .
Shakespearean: Thou sayest his sports were hinderd by thy brawls .

English: Ruining his meals , his enjoyment , and his sleep would drive any man or beast mad .
Shakespearean: In food , in sport , and life-preserving rest To be disturbed , would mad or man or beast .

English: What I'm saying is , your jealousy has pushed your husband away from his sanity .
Shakespearean: The consequence is , then , thy jealous fits Have scared thy husband from the use of wits .

English: Gentlemen , go in there and grab him .
Shakespearean: Good people , enter and lay hold on him .

English: Then have your servants bring him out .
Shakespearean: Then let your servants bring my husband forth .

English: Healing is part and parcel of my religious vows ; it is a charitable duty my order performs .
Shakespearean: It is a branch and parcel of mine oath , A charitable duty of my order .

English: Therefore , depart , and leave him here with me .
Shakespearean: Therefore depart and leave him here with me .

English: Be quiet and depart .
Shakespearean: Be quiet and depart .

English: You're not going to take him .
Shakespearean: Thou shalt not have him .

English: Go lodge a complaint about this with the duke .
Shakespearean: Complain unto the Duke of this indignity .

English: Come with me .
Shakespearean: Come , go .

English: I'll fall at his feet and lie there until my pleading and crying convinces the duke to come here and force my husband to leave this abbey .
Shakespearean: I will fall prostrate at his feet And never rise until my tears and prayers Have won his grace to come in person hither And take perforce my husband from the Abbess .

English: It's almost five o'clock .
Shakespearean: By this , I think , the dial points at five .

English: To see an elderly , unlucky merchant from Syracuse publicly beheaded for breaking the law and coming here to Ephesus .
Shakespearean: To see a reverend Syracusian merchant , Who put unluckily into this bay Against the laws and statutes of this town , Beheaded publicly for his offense .

English: Here they come .
Shakespearean: See where they come .

English: We will watch the execution .
Shakespearean: We will behold his death .

English: Kneel down to the duke before he passes by the abbey .
Shakespearean: Kneel to the duke before he pass the abbey .

English: One more time , we proclaim this publicly : If anyone will pay this man's bail , he will not be put to death .
Shakespearean: Yet once again proclaim it publicly , If any friend will pay the sum for him , He shall not die ; so much we tender him .

English: Duke , the abbess has wronged me and I seek justice .
Shakespearean: Justice , most sacred duke , against the Abbess .

English: She's a virtuous and holy lady .
Shakespearean: She is a virtuous and a reverend lady .

English: She can't possibly have done you any wrong .
Shakespearean: It can not be that she hath done thee wrong .

English: So please , most gracious duke , order her to bring him out so we can get him some help .
Shakespearean: Therefore , most gracious duke , with thy command Let him be brought forth and borne hence for help .

English: And when you married him and made him the master of your bed , I gave you my word that I would do everything I possibly could for him .
Shakespearean: Long since thy husband served me in my wars , And I to thee engaged a prince's word , When thou didst make him master of thy bed , To do him all the grace and good I could .

English: Shut up , fool !
Shakespearean: Peace , fool .

English: Your master and his servant are here .
Shakespearean: Thy master and his man are here , And that is false thou dost report to us .

English: Mistress , I swear on my life that it's true .
Shakespearean: Mistress , upon my life I tell you true .

English: It was just moments ago .
Shakespearean: I have not breathed almost since I did see it .

English: He's crying out for you and swears he'll burn your face and disfigure you if he can get ahold of you .
Shakespearean: He cries for you , and vows , if he can take you , To scorch your face and to disfigure you .

English: Oh , my , it's my husband .
Shakespearean: Ay me , it is my husband .

English: Look , he can become invisible .
Shakespearean: Witness you That he is borne about invisible .

English: Just now we put him in the abbey over here , and now he's over there .
Shakespearean: Even now we housed him in the abbey here , And now he's there , past thought of human reason .

English: In exchange for the blood I shed for you then , I ask you for justice now .
Shakespearean: Even for the blood That then I lost for thee , now grant me justice .

English: The things she has shamelessly hurled on me are beyond imagination .
Shakespearean: Beyond imagination is the wrong That she this day hath shameless thrown on me .

English: Today , great duke , she locked me out of my house and feasted there with whores .
Shakespearean: This day , great duke , she shut the doors upon me While she with harlots feasted in my house .

English: That's terrible !
Shakespearean: A grievous fault. , Say , woman , didst thou so ?

English: No , my good lord .
Shakespearean: No , my good lord .

English: I ate with him and my sister .
Shakespearean: Myself , he , and my sister Today did dine together .

English: Damn my soul if these accusations are true !
Shakespearean: So befall my soul As this is false he burdens me withal .

English: If she's lying , I pray that I never sleep again at night or wake up during the day .
Shakespearean: Ne'er may I look on day , nor sleep on night But she tells to your Highness simple truth .

English: Oh , lying woman !
Shakespearean: O perjured woman !

English: My lord , I know what I'm saying .
Shakespearean: My liege , I am advised what I say , Neither disturbed with the effect of wine , Nor heady-rash , provoked with raging ire , Albeit my wrongs might make one wiser mad .

English: He left to fetch a necklace and he promised to bring it to the Porcupine , where I was dining with Balthasar .
Shakespearean: That goldsmith there , were he not packed with her , Could witness it , for he was with me then , Who parted with me to go fetch a chain , Promising to bring it to the Porpentine , Where Balthasar and I did dine together .

English: He hadn't arrived by the time we finished eating , so I went out looking for him .
Shakespearean: Our dinner done and he not coming thither , I went to seek him .

English: I met him in the street , he was there with that man .
Shakespearean: In the street I met him , And in his company that gentleman .

English: On the way , we came across my wife , her sister , and their gang of vile associates .
Shakespearean: By th ' way we met My wife , her sister , and a rabble more Of vile confederates .

English: One of them was a man named Pinch : a hungry , narrow-faced villain ; a skeleton ; a fraud ; a raggedy magician and fortune-teller ; a needy , hollow-eyed , emaciated wretch ; a walking corpse .
Shakespearean: Along with them They brought one Pinch , a hungry , lean-faced villain , A mere anatomy , a mountebank , A threadbare juggler , and a fortune-teller , A needy , hollow-eyed , sharp-looking wretch , A living dead man .

English: He pretended to be some kind of sorcerer , and he gazed in my eyes and took my pulse .
Shakespearean: This pernicious slave , Forsooth , took on him as a conjurer , And , gazing in mine eyes , feeling my pulse ,

English: They left me and my servant there , tied together .
Shakespearean: But had he such a chain of thee or no ?

English: He did , my lord .
Shakespearean: He had , my lord , and when he ran in here , These people saw the chain about his neck .

English: I never saw the necklace , so help me heaven !
Shakespearean: I never saw the chain , so help me heaven , And this is false you burden me withal .

English: Why , what a complicated case this is !
Shakespearean: Why , what an intricate impeach is this !

English: it pleases you , I'll meet you in the marketplace at five and will keep you company until bedtime .
Shakespearean: Soon at five o'clock , Please you , I'll meet with you upon the mart And afterward consort you till bedtime .

English: Right now , my pressing business calls me away .
Shakespearean: My present business calls me from you now .

English: Farewell till then .
Shakespearean: Farewell till then .

English: I will go lose myself , wandering up and down throughout the city .
Shakespearean: I will go lose myself And wander up and down to view the city .

English: Sir , I leave you to your own contentment .
Shakespearean: Sir , I commend you to your own content .

English: He leaves me to my own contentment , but that's the one thing I can not find .
Shakespearean: He that commends me to mine own content Commends me to the thing I can not get .

English: Out in the world , I'm like a drop of water , trying to find a drop that matches in the whole wide ocean .
Shakespearean: I to the world am like a drop of water That in the ocean seeks another drop , Who , falling there to find his fellow forth , Unseen , inquisitive , confounds himself .

English: In order to find a mother and a brother , I too have lost myself , unhappily .
Shakespearean: So I , to find a mother and a brother , In quest of them , unhappy , lose myself .

English: How is it that you've come back so soon ?
Shakespearean: How chance thou art returned so soon ?

English: Back so soon ?
Shakespearean: Returned so soon ?

English: Too late is more like it .
Shakespearean: Rather approach'd too late !

English: The chicken is burning , the pig is overcooked , the clock has already struck twelve , and my mistress has clocked me one on the cheek .
Shakespearean: The capon burns ; the pig falls from the spit ; The clock hath strucken twelve upon the bell ; My mistress made it one upon my cheek .

English: ate at home , but the jeweler says he didn't .
Shakespearean: You say he dined at home ; the goldsmith here Denies that saying .

English: Sir , he ate with this woman at the Porcupine .
Shakespearean: Sir , he dined with her there , at the Porpentine .

English: He did , and he snatched my ring right off my finger .
Shakespearean: He did , and from my finger snatched that ring .

English: That's true , my lord : I did get this ring from her .
Shakespearean: Tis true , my liege ; this ring I had of her .

English: Did you see him enter this abbey ?
Shakespearean: Saw'st thou him enter at the abbey here ?

English: As clearly as I see you , my lord .
Shakespearean: As sure , my liege , as I do see your Grace .

English: I think you're all either bewildered or stark raving mad .
Shakespearean: I think you are all mated or stark mad .

English: Mighty duke , please allow me to say something .
Shakespearean: Most mighty duke , vouchsafe me speak a word .

English: I think I see a friend who will pay my bail and save my life .
Shakespearean: Haply I see a friend will save my life And pay the sum that may deliver me .

English: I was bound to him an hour ago , sir , but thankfully he chewed through our ropes .
Shakespearean: Within this hour I was his bondman sir , But he , I thank him , gnawed in two my cords .

English: Now I'm Dromio and no longer attached to him .
Shakespearean: Now am I Dromio , and his man , unbound .

English: I'm sure you both remember me .
Shakespearean: I am sure you both of you remember me .

English: You're not one of Pinch's patients , are you , sir ?
Shakespearean: You are not Pinch's patient , are you , sir ?

English: Why are you looking at me so strangely ?
Shakespearean: Why look you strange on me ?

English: You know me well .
Shakespearean: you know me well .

English: I never saw you before in my life .
Shakespearean: I never saw you in my life till now .

English: Oh , grief has transformed me since the last time you saw me .
Shakespearean: O , grief hath changed me since you saw me last , And careful hours with time's deformed hand Have written strange defeatures in my face .

English: But tell me this : don't you know my voice ?
Shakespearean: But tell me yet , dost thou not know my voice ?

English: No .
Shakespearean: Neither .

English: Don't you , Dromio ?
Shakespearean: Dromio , nor thou ?

English: No sir , trust me , I do not .
Shakespearean: No , trust me , sir , nor I. I am sure thou dost .

English: You don't know my voice ?
Shakespearean: Not know my voice !

English: Have you mangled my tongue so badly in these seven short years that my only son can no longer recognize my weak , sorrow-ravaged voice ?
Shakespearean: O time's extremity , Hast thou so crack'd and splitted my poor tongue In seven short years that here my only son Knows not my feeble key of untuned cares ?

English: But I still have a little memory left , and there's still some fire in my eyes ; my dull , deaf ears can still hear a little .
Shakespearean: Though now this grained face of mine be hid In sap-consuming winter's drizzled snow , And all the conduits of my blood froze up , Yet hath my night of life some memory , My wasting lamps some fading glimmer left , My dull deaf ears a little use to hear .

English: All these aging faculties tell me , and I can not be wrong , that you are my son , Antipholus .
Shakespearean: All these old witnesses , I can not err , Tell me thou art my son Antipholus .

English: I never saw my father in my life .
Shakespearean: I never saw my father in my life .

English: You know that we parted only seven years ago , in Syracuse .
Shakespearean: But seven years since , in Syracusa , boy , Thou know'st we parted .

English: Your old age and the prospect of death are making you imagine things .
Shakespearean: I see thy age and dangers make thee dote .

English: Mighty duke , look here and see a man who's been treated most terribly !
Shakespearean: Most mighty duke , behold a man much wronged .

English: Either my eyes deceive me , or I see two husbands .
Shakespearean: I see two husbands , or mine eyes deceive me .

English: I , sir , am Dromio .
Shakespearean: I , sir , am Dromio .

English: Command this man to leave .
Shakespearean: Command him away .

English: I , sir , am Dromio .
Shakespearean: I , sir , am Dromio .

English: Pray , let me stay .
Shakespearean: Please , let me stay .

English: Oh , my old master ! , Who tied him up ?
Shakespearean: O , my old master. , Who hath bound him here ?

English: Tell us , old Egeon : are you the man who once had a wife named Emilia , who gave birth to two fair sons ?
Shakespearean: Whoever bound him , I will loose his bonds And gain a husband by his liberty. , Speak , old Egeon , if thou be'st the man That hadst a wife once called Emilia , That bore thee at a burden two fair sons .

English: Oh , if you are the same Egeon , speak now , and speak to that same Emilia !
Shakespearean: O , if thou be'st the same Egeon , speak , And speak unto the same Emilia .

English: These two Antipholuses , who look so alike , and these two Dromios , who seem to have the same face , and her story of being shipwrecked , why , these two are the parents of these children and have been reunited by accident .
Shakespearean: Why , here begins his morning story right ; These two Antipholuses , these two so like , And these two Dromios , one in semblance , Besides her urging of her wreck at sea , These are the parents to these children , Which accidentally are met together .

English: If I'm not dreaming , you are Emilia .
Shakespearean: If I dream not , thou art Emilia .

English: If it's really you , tell me what happened to our son , who floated away with you on that deadly raft .
Shakespearean: If thou art she , tell me where is that son That floated with thee on the fatal raft ?

English: Antipholus , aren't you originally from Corinth ?
Shakespearean: Corinth first .

English: Wait , don't stand next to each other .
Shakespearean: Stay , stand apart .

English: I can't tell who's who .
Shakespearean: I know not which is which .

English: I came from Corinth , Your Highness .
Shakespearean: I came from Corinth , my most gracious lord .

English: And I came with him .
Shakespearean: And I with him .

English: Your renowned uncle , Duke Menaphon , the famous soldier , brought me here .
Shakespearean: Brought to this town by that most famous warrior Duke Menaphon , your most renowned uncle .

English: Which of you two ate lunch with me today ?
Shakespearean: Which of you two did dine with me today ?

English: I did , kind lady .
Shakespearean: I , gentle mistress .

English: And you're my husband , right ?
Shakespearean: And are not you my husband ?

English: That's the necklace I gave you , sir .
Shakespearean: That is the chain , sir , which you had of me .

English: I think it is , sir .
Shakespearean: I think it be , sir .

English: I don't deny it .
Shakespearean: I deny it not .

English: And you , sir , had me arrested over that necklace .
Shakespearean: And you , sir , for this chain arrested me .

English: I think I did , sir .
Shakespearean: I think I did , sir .

English: I don't deny it .
Shakespearean: I deny it not .

English: I sent Dromio to you with money for bail , but I don't think he brought it to you .
Shakespearean: I sent you money , sir , to be your bail By Dromio , but I think he brought it not .

English: No , he didn't get any by me .
Shakespearean: No , none by me .

English: I got this purse full of money from you , and my Dromio brought it to me .
Shakespearean: This purse of ducats I received from you , And Dromio my man did bring them me .

English: I want to use this money to set my father free .
Shakespearean: These ducats pawn I for my father here .

English: That's not necessary .
Shakespearean: It shall not need .

English: I'm going to let him live .
Shakespearean: Thy father hath his life .

English: Sir , I must get that diamond ring back from you .
Shakespearean: Sir , I must have that diamond from you .

English: There , take it , and thanks for taking such good care of me .
Shakespearean: There , take it ; and much thanks for my good cheer .

English: Renowned duke , please join us in the abbey , where we will discuss at length all that has happened to us .
Shakespearean: Renowned duke , vouchsafe to take the pains To go with us into the abbey here And hear at large discoursed all our fortunes , And all that are assembled in this place That by this sympathized one day's error Have suffered wrong .

English: Duke Solinus , my husband , and both my children , and you two Dromios , who marked the day of my sons ' births with your own , come into the abbey with me for a new christening .
Shakespearean: Go , keep us company , And we shall make full satisfaction. , Thirty-three years have I but gone in travail Of you , my sons , and till this present hour My heavy burden ne'er delivered. , The Duke , my husband , and my children both , And you , the calendars of their nativity , Go to a gossips ' feast , and go with me .

English: After such a long period of grief , we will have such a celebration !
Shakespearean: After so long grief , such nativity !

English: With all my heart , I'll join you .
Shakespearean: With all my heart I'll gossip at this feast .

English: Dromio , what stuff of mine did you put on a ship ?
Shakespearean: Dromio , what stuff of mine hast thou embarked ?

English: The stuff you had at the Centaur , sir .
Shakespearean: Your goods that lay at host , sir , in the Centaur .

English: I'm your master , Dromio .
Shakespearean: He speaks to me. , I am your master , Dromio .

English: You have a fat friend at your master's house : she took care of me in the kitchen today , thinking I was you .
Shakespearean: There is a fat friend at your master's house That kitchened me for you today at dinner .

English: I guess now she's going to be my sister-in-law and not my wife .
Shakespearean: She now shall be my sister , not my wife .

English: I think you're my mirror , not my brother .
Shakespearean: Methinks you are my glass , and not my brother : I see by you I am a sweet-faced youth .

English: Do you want to go in and join the party ?
Shakespearean: Will you walk in to see their gossiping ?

English: After you , sir .
Shakespearean: Not I , sir .

English: You're older than me .
Shakespearean: You are my elder .

English: That's a good point .
Shakespearean: That's a question .

English: How can we tell which of us is the oldest ?
Shakespearean: How shall we try it ?

English: We'll draw straws .
Shakespearean: We'll draw cuts for the signior .

English: Meanwhile , after you .
Shakespearean: Till then , lead thou first .

English: We came into the world as brother and brother , so now let's enter hand in hand , not one before the other .
Shakespearean: Nay , then , thus : We came into the world like brother and brother , And now let's go hand in hand , not one before another .

English: Hold on a second .
Shakespearean: Stop in your wind , sir .

English: Answer me this , please : where's the money I gave you ?
Shakespearean: Tell me this , I pray : Where have you left the money that I gave you ?

English: Oh , the sixpence you gave me last Wednesday to buy leather goods for my mistress ?
Shakespearean: O , sixpence , that I had o ' Wednesday last To pay the saddler for my mistress ' crupper ?

English: The saddle maker has it , sir , I didn't keep it .
Shakespearean: The saddler had it , sir ; I kept it not .

English: I'm not in a joking mood .
Shakespearean: I am not in a sportive humor now .

English: Tell me right now and stop fooling : where's the money ?
Shakespearean: Tell me , and dally not : where is the money ?

English: We're strangers here .
Shakespearean: We being strangers here , how dar'st thou trust So great a charge from thine own custody ?

English: Please , sir ; crack jokes over lunch .
Shakespearean: I pray you , jest , sir , as you sit at dinner .

English: I should think that your appetite would act like a clock ( as mine does ) and bring you home on its own , without the need for a messenger .
Shakespearean: Methinks your maw , like mine , should be your clock , And strike you home without a messenger .

English: That's enough , Dromio , please .
Shakespearean: Come , Dromio , come , these jests are out of season .

English: This isn't a good moment for jokes , save them till a happier time .
Shakespearean: Reserve them till a merrier hour than this .

English: Where's the gold I gave you ?
Shakespearean: Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee ?

English: Gave me , sir ?
Shakespearean: To me , sir ?

English: You didn't give me any gold .
Shakespearean: Why , you gave no gold to me !

English: Tell me what you've done with the money I entrusted to you .
Shakespearean: Come on , sir knave , have done your foolishness , And tell me how thou hast disposed thy charge .

English: The only thing that I've been entrusted with was getting you from the market and bringing you to your house , the Phoenix , for lunch .
Shakespearean: My charge was but to fetch you from the mart Home to your house , the Phoenix , sir , to dinner .

English: My mistress and her sister are waiting for you .
Shakespearean: My mistress and her sister stays for you .

English: Tell me where you've stowed away my money , or I swear I'll break that comical head of yours for goofing when I'm not in the mood .
Shakespearean: Now , as I am a Christian , answer me In what safe place you have bestowed my money , Or I shall break that merry sconce of yours That stands on tricks when I am undisposed .

English: Where are the thousand
Shakespearean: Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me ?

English: Your mistress's marks ?
Shakespearean: Thy mistress ' marks ?

English: What mistress do you have ?
Shakespearean: what mistress , slave , hast thou ?

English: What , are you going to mock me to my face when I told you not to ?
Shakespearean: What , wilt thou flout me thus unto my face , Being forbid ?

English: There , take that , you scoundrel !
Shakespearean: There , take you that , sir knave .

English: What are you doing ?
Shakespearean: What mean you , sir ?
