English: Stop , for God's sake !
Shakespearean: For God's sake , hold your hands .

English: Well , if you don't , then I'm out of here .
Shakespearean: Nay , an you will not , sir , I'll take my heels .

English: I swear , somehow the fool has been cheated out of all my money .
Shakespearean: Upon my life , by some device or other The villain is o'erraught of all my money .

English: They say that this town is full of deception , illusionists that can fool the eye , dark sorcerers who can bewitch your mind , soul-killing witches who can disfigure your body , disguised swindlers , fast-talking fakers , and all kinds of other unchecked sins .
Shakespearean: They say this town is full of cozenage , As nimble jugglers that deceive the eye , Dark-working sorcerers that change the mind , Soul-killing witches that deform the body , Disguised cheaters , prating mountebanks , And many suchlike liberties of sin .

English: Neither my husband nor the slave has returned , even though I sent the slave off running .
Shakespearean: Neither my husband nor the slave returned That in such haste I sent to seek his master ?

English: Surely , Luciana , it's already two o'clock .
Shakespearean: Sure , Luciana , it is two o'clock .

English: Maybe some merchant at the marketplace invited him home for lunch .
Shakespearean: Perhaps some merchant hath invited him , And from the mart he's somewhere gone to dinner .

English: Sister , let's eat and stop worrying .
Shakespearean: Good sister , let us dine and never fret .

English: A man is master of his own freedom : time is his only master , and when the right moment comes along , he'll come or go as he pleases .
Shakespearean: A man is master of his liberty ; Time is their master , and when they see time They'll go or come .

English: If this is so , be patient , sister .
Shakespearean: If so , be patient , sister .

English: Why should men be more free than women ?
Shakespearean: Why should their liberty than ours be more ?

English: Because their business lies outside the home .
Shakespearean: Because their business still lies out o ' door .

English: Why , too much freedom leads to woe .
Shakespearean: Why , headstrong liberty is lashed with woe .

English: Therefore , you should obey their wishes .
Shakespearean: Then let your will attend on their accords .

English: It's this servantlike mentality that's keeping you unmarried .
Shakespearean: This servitude makes you to keep unwed .

English: No , that's not it , it's because of what happens in the marriage bed .
Shakespearean: Not this , but troubles of the marriage bed .

English: But if you were married , you'd wield some influence .
Shakespearean: But , were you wedded , you would bear some sway .

English: Before I learn how to love , I'll learn how to follow orders .
Shakespearean: Ere I learn love , I'll practice to obey .

English: What if your husband strays elsewhere ?
Shakespearean: How if your husband start some otherwhere ?

English: I'd endure it until he came home again .
Shakespearean: Till he come home again , I would forbear .

English: Now that's patience !
Shakespearean: Patience unmoved !

English: No wonder she's waiting to get married .
Shakespearean: No marvel though she pause ; They can be meek that have no other cause .

English: When we're faced with a wretched person , bruised and crying with hardship , we try to get them to shush up .
Shakespearean: A wretched soul , bruised with adversity We bid be quiet when we hear it cry , But were we burdened with like weight of pain , As much or more we should ourselves complain .

English: But if you live to see yourself similarly denied your rights , this foolish patience will abandon you .
Shakespearean: So thou , that hast no unkind mate to grieve thee , With urging helpless patience would relieve me ; But , if thou live to see like right bereft , This fool-begged patience in thee will be left .

English: Well , I'll get married one day , just to see .
Shakespearean: Well , I will marry one day , but to try .

English: Tell me , is your tardy master close at hand ?
Shakespearean: Say , is your tardy master now at hand ?

English: Do you know his plans ?
Shakespearean: Know'st thou his mind ?

English: But please , tell me : is he coming home ?
Shakespearean: But say , I prithee , is he coming home ?

English: It seems he has taken great care to please his wife .
Shakespearean: It seems he hath great care to please his wife .

English: Why , mistress , my master is as angry as a bull with horns .
Shakespearean: Why , mistress , sure my master is horn mad .

English: You bastard !
Shakespearean: Horn mad , thou villain !

English: I don't mean he's
Shakespearean: I mean not cuckold mad , But sure he is stark mad .

English: My mistress , " I said .
Shakespearean: My mistress , sir , " quoth I .

English: Damn your mistress !
Shakespearean: Hang up thy mistress !

English: My master said it .
Shakespearean: Quoth my master .

English: I don't know , " he said , "any house , wife , or mistress." My message , which was supposed to be delivered with my mouth , ended up being carried back home by my shoulders .
Shakespearean: I know , " quoth he , "no house , no wife , no mistress." So that my errand , due unto my tongue , I thank him , I bare home upon my shoulders , For , in conclusion , he did beat me there .

English: Go back again , slave , and bring him home .
Shakespearean: Go back again , thou slave , and fetch him home .

English: Go back again , to be beaten home again ?
Shakespearean: Go back again and be new beaten home ?

English: For God's sake , send somebody else .
Shakespearean: For God's sake , send some other messenger .

English: Go back , slave , or I'll knock you one across the head .
Shakespearean: Back , slave , or I will break thy pate across .

English: Get out of here , you blathering peasant !
Shakespearean: Hence , prating peasant !

English: Bring your master home .
Shakespearean: Fetch thy master home .

English: You kick me out , he kicks me back .
Shakespearean: You spurn me hence , and he will spurn me hither .

English: Look at you !
Shakespearean: If I last in this service , you must case me in leather .

English: You have impatience all over your face .
Shakespearean: Fie , how impatience loureth in your face .

English: He feels the need to grace all his other tramps with his presence while I sit at home starving for a smile from him .
Shakespearean: His company must do his minions grace , Whilst I at home starve for a merry look .

English: Has homely old age taken the alluring beauty from my poor cheeks ?
Shakespearean: Hath homely age th ' alluring beauty took From my poor cheek ?

English: Have I lost my wit ?
Shakespearean: Barren my wit ?

English: One smile from him would repair my decayed beauty .
Shakespearean: My decayed fair A sunny look of his would soon repair .

English: But like an unruly deer , he's always trespassing past the park borders and straying away from home to feed in new pastures .
Shakespearean: But , too unruly deer , he breaks the pale And feeds from home .

English: I am nothing but a poor , used fool .
Shakespearean: Poor I am but his stale .

English: Drive it out of you .
Shakespearean: Self-harming jealousy , fie , beat it hence .

English: I know his eyes are worshiping some other woman , or why wouldn't he be here ?
Shakespearean: I know his eye doth homage otherwhere , Or else what lets it but he would be here ?

English: Sister , you know he promised to give me a necklace .
Shakespearean: Sister , you know he promised me a chain .

English: I would gladly do without that if he would only stay faithful to me .
Shakespearean: Would that alone o ' love he would detain , So he would keep fair quarter with his bed .

English: Even the best jewel can be tarnished .
Shakespearean: I see the jewel best enameled Will lose his beauty .

English: And no man with a reputation will tarnish that name with lies and bad behavior .
Shakespearean: Yet the gold bides still That others touch , and often touching will Wear gold ; yet no man that hath a name By falsehood and corruption doth it shame .

English: Since my beauty no longer pleases my husband , I'll weep away what's left and then die with weeping .
Shakespearean: Since that my beauty can not please his eye , I'll weep what's left away , and weeping die .

English: How many infatuated people go mad with jealousy !
Shakespearean: How many fond fools serve mad jealousy !

English: Give me the death sentence and end all my troubles .
Shakespearean: Proceed , Solinus , to procure my fall , And by the doom of death end woes and all .

English: Ever since these deadly conflicts erupted between your violent countrymen and ours , both you Syracusians and we Ephesians have held serious councils and decided not to permit any travel between our two hostile towns .
Shakespearean: For , since the mortal and intestine jars 'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us , It hath in solemn synods been decreed Both by the Syracusians and ourselves , To admit no traffic to our adverse towns .

English: No-the law goes further : if anyone born in Ephesus is seen in Syracuse's marketplaces or if anyone born in Syracuse comes to Ephesus , that man dies , and his possessions will be confiscated by the Duke , unless he can raise a thousand marks to pay the penalty and ransom himself .
Shakespearean: Nay , more , if any born at Ephesus Be seen at any Syracusian marts and fairs ; Again , if any Syracusian born Come to the bay of Ephesus , he dies , His goods confiscate to the Duke's dispose , Unless a thousand marks be levied To quit the penalty and to ransom him .

English: Therefore , by law , you are condemned to die .
Shakespearean: Thy substance , valued at the highest rate , Can not amount unto a hundred marks ; Therefore by law thou art condemned to die .

English: The gold I gave Dromio is safe and sound at the Centaur , and the inn host says that Dromio has left and is looking for me .
Shakespearean: The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up Safe at the Centaur , and the heedful slave Is wandered forth , in care to seek me out .

English: I haven't spoken to him since I sent him away from the marketplace earlier .
Shakespearean: By computation and mine host's report , I could not speak with Dromio since at first I sent him from the mart .

English: Here he comes .
Shakespearean: See , here he comes .

English: So , sir .
Shakespearean: How now , sir ?

English: Are you over your ridiculous mood ?
Shakespearean: is your merry humor altered ?

English: You never heard of the Centaur ?
Shakespearean: You know no Centaur ?

English: You weren't given any gold ?
Shakespearean: You received no gold ?

English: Your mistress sent for me to come to dinner ?
Shakespearean: Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner ?

English: The Phoenix is my house ?
Shakespearean: My house was at the Phoenix ?

English: Were you mad when you spoke to me so madly ?
Shakespearean: Wast thou mad , That thus so madly thou didst answer me ?

English: Said what , sir ?
Shakespearean: What answer , sir ?

English: When did I say all that ?
Shakespearean: When spake I such a word ?

English: I haven't seen you since you sent me to the Centaur with the gold you gave me .
Shakespearean: I did not see you since you sent me hence , Home to the Centaur with the gold you gave me .

English: And I hope you realized I wasn't very happy about it .
Shakespearean: Villain , thou didst deny the gold's receipt And told'st me of a mistress and a dinner , For which , I hope , thou felt'st I was displeased .

English: I'm glad to see you in such a merry mood .
Shakespearean: I am glad to see you in this merry vein .

English: But what's the joke ?
Shakespearean: What means this jest ?

English: Please , master , tell me .
Shakespearean: I pray you , master , tell me ?

English: What , are you mocking me to my face ?
Shakespearean: Yea , dost thou jeer and flout me in the teeth ?

English: Here .
Shakespearean: Think'st thou I jest ?

English: Take that , and that !
Shakespearean: Hold , take thou that and that .

English: Stop , sir , for God's sake !
Shakespearean: Hold , sir , for God's sake !

English: Now this joke has turned serious .
Shakespearean: Now your jest is earnest .

English: Why are you doing this ?
Shakespearean: Upon what bargain do you give it me ?

English: Just because I act familiar with you sometimes and let you fool around and joke with me , you try to take advantage of my affection .
Shakespearean: Because that I familiarly sometimes Do use you for my fool and chat with you , Your sauciness will jest upon my love And make a common of my serious hours .

English: You call it my " Don't you know ?
Shakespearean: Sconce" call you it ?

English: Should I tell you why ?
Shakespearean: Shall I tell you why ?

English: Well , thank you .
Shakespearean: Well , sir , I thank you .

English: Because you gave me something for nothing .
Shakespearean: Marry , sir , for this something that you gave me for nothing .

English: Next time I'll give you nothing for something .
Shakespearean: I'll make you amends next , to give you nothing for something .

English: Is it lunchtime ?
Shakespearean: But say , sir , is it dinnertime ?

English: What would that be ?
Shakespearean: In good time , sir , what's that ?

English: A basting .
Shakespearean: Basting .

English: Well , then it will be dry .
Shakespearean: Well , sir , then 'twill be dry .

English: If it is , I suggest you don't eat it .
Shakespearean: If it be , sir , I pray you , eat none of it .

English: Why not ?
Shakespearean: Your reason ?

English: Because it will make you angry , and that will get me another beating .
Shakespearean: Lest it make you choleric and purchase me another dry basting .

English: Well , learn to make jokes at the appropriate time .
Shakespearean: Well , sir , learn to jest in good time .

English: There's a time for all things .
Shakespearean: There's a time for all things .

English: Before you got so angry , I never would have thought that .
Shakespearean: I durst have denied that before you were so choleric .

English: Why not ?
Shakespearean: By what rule , sir ?

English: I'll tell you : it's because of a law as plain as Father Time's bald head .
Shakespearean: Marry , sir , by a rule as plain as the plain bald pate of Father Time himself .

English: Let's hear it .
Shakespearean: Let's hear it .

English: There may be a time for everything , but no man who has gone bald naturally can get his hair back .
Shakespearean: There's no time for a man to recover his hair that grows bald by nature .

English: Why is Time so cheap about giving out hair ?
Shakespearean: Why is Time such a niggard of hair , being , as it is , so plentiful an excrement ?

English: But a lot of men have more hair than intelligence .
Shakespearean: Why , but there's many a man hath more hair than wit .

English: So then , you must think that hairy men are honest and simpleminded .
Shakespearean: Why , thou didst conclude hairy men plain dealers without wit .

English: Two reasons .
Shakespearean: For what reason ?

English: And good ones , too .
Shakespearean: For two , and sound ones too .

English: Not good ones , please .
Shakespearean: Nay , not sound , I pray you .

English: Then sure ones .
Shakespearean: Sure ones , then .

English: No , not sure ones when we're talking about something unsure .
Shakespearean: Nay , not sure , in a thing falsing .

English: Then certain ones .
Shakespearean: Certain ones , then .

English: Name them .
Shakespearean: Name them .

English: One , so they can save the money they spent on hairstyling , and two , so that when their hair falls out it doesn't land in their dinner .
Shakespearean: The one , to save the money that he spends in tiring ; the other , that at dinner they should not drop in his porridge .

English: You were supposed to be proving that there isn't time for everything .
Shakespearean: You would all this time have proved there is no time for all things .

English: Then I'll change it to this : Father Time himself is bald , so for all time there will be bald men .
Shakespearean: Thus I mend it : Time himself is bald and therefore , to the world's end , will have bald followers .

English: There was a time when you'd freely tell me that words were never music to your ear unless I said them , that objects never pleased your eye unless I showed them to you , that touches never pleased your hands unless they were my touches , and that food never tasted sweet to you unless I had prepared it .
Shakespearean: The time was once when thou unurged wouldst vow That never words were music to thine ear , That never object pleasing in thine eye , That never touch well welcome to thy hand , That never meat sweet-savored in thy taste , Unless I spake , or looked , or touched , or carved to thee .

English: How is it , my husband , oh , how is it , that you have become a stranger to yourself ?
Shakespearean: How comes it now , my husband , O , how comes it That thou art thus estranged from thyself ?

English: Ah , don't tear yourself away from me !
Shakespearean: Ah , do not tear away thyself from me !

English: I don't know you .
Shakespearean: I know you not .

English: Why are you treating my sister like this ?
Shakespearean: When were you wont to use my sister thus ?

English: She sent Dromio to bring you home for lunch .
Shakespearean: She sent for you by Dromio home to dinner .

English: Dromio ?
Shakespearean: By Dromio ?

English: And this is what you told me he said : that he beat you and pretended his house wasn't his and I wasn't his wife .
Shakespearean: By thee ; and this thou didst return from him : That he did buffet thee and , in his blows , Denied my house for his , me for his wife .

English: Did you talk with this woman ?
Shakespearean: Did you converse , sir , with this gentlewoman ?

English: What kind of scheme do you have going together ?
Shakespearean: What is the course and drift of your compact ?

English: Me , sir ?
Shakespearean: I , sir ?

English: I never saw her till now .
Shakespearean: I never saw her till this time .

English: You said those exact things to me back in the marketplace .
Shakespearean: Villain , thou liest ; for even her very words Didst thou deliver to me on the mart .

English: I never talked with her in my life .
Shakespearean: I never spake with her in all my life .

English: What , was I married to her in a dream ?
Shakespearean: What , was I married to her in my dream ?

English: Or am I asleep now and imagining all this ?
Shakespearean: Or sleep I now and think I hear all this ?

English: What is making our eyes and ears act so strangely ?
Shakespearean: What error drives our eyes and ears amiss ?

English: Until I know for sure , I'll humor her .
Shakespearean: Until I know this sure uncertainty I'll entertain the offered fallacy .

English: Dromio , tell the servants to prepare for lunch .
Shakespearean: Dromio , go bid the servants spread for dinner .

English: Oh , I wish I had my rosary !
Shakespearean: O , for my beads !

English: I'll cross myself .
Shakespearean: I cross me for a sinner .

English: This must be some kind of fairyland .
Shakespearean: This is the fairy land .

English: Oh , spite of spites !
Shakespearean: O spite of spites !

English: If we don't obey them , they'll suck the life out of us or pinch us black and blue .
Shakespearean: We talk with goblins , owls , and sprites : If we obey them not , this will ensue : They'll suck our breath , or pinch us black and blue .

English: Why are you mumbling to yourself instead of answering the order I gave you ?
Shakespearean: Why prat'st thou to thyself and answer'st not ?

English: Dromio , you drone , you snail , you slug , you idiot !
Shakespearean: Dromio , thou , Dromio , thou snail , thou slug , thou sot .

English: I've been transformed somehow , haven't I , master ?
Shakespearean: I am transformed , master , am I not ?

English: No , master , I've been changed in both mind and body .
Shakespearean: I think thou art in mind , and so am I. Nay , master , both in mind and in my shape .

English: That's true .
Shakespearean: Tis true .

English: I must be as stupid as an ass , that's why I don't know her , but she knows me .
Shakespearean: I am an ass ; else it could never be But I should know her as well as she knows me .

English: I won't play the fool anymore and just cry while my husband and his man laugh at me .
Shakespearean: Come , come , no longer will I be a fool , To put the finger in the eye and weep Whilst man and master laugh my woes to scorn .

English: Come , husband , let's go to lunch .
Shakespearean: Come , sir , to dinner. , Dromio , keep the gate .

English: Husband , I'll eat with you in private today and hear your confession about all the pranks you've pulled .
Shakespearean: Husband , I'll dine above with you today , And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks .

English: Am I on earth , in heaven , or in hell ?
Shakespearean: Am I in earth , in heaven , or in hell ?

English: know myself !
Shakespearean: Known unto these , and to myself disguised !

English: Master , should I watch the door ?
Shakespearean: Master , shall I be porter at the gate ?

English: Yes , and don't let anyone come in , or else I'll break your head .
Shakespearean: Ay ; and let none enter , lest I break your pate .

English: Well , Syracusian , tell us-briefly-why you left your hometown and came to Ephesus .
Shakespearean: Well , Syracusian , say in brief the cause Why thou dep-artedst from thy native home And for what cause thou camest to Ephesus .

English: And yet I would have made her happy had our luck not been so bad .
Shakespearean: In Syracusa was I born , and wed Unto a woman happy but for me , And by me , had not our hap been bad .

English: In the same hour , and in the same inn , a poor woman also delivered identical twin boys .
Shakespearean: That very hour , and in the selfsame inn , A meaner woman was delivered Of such a burden , male twins , both alike .

English: Reluctantly , I agreed-alas !
Shakespearean: Unwilling , I agreed .

English: Too quickly , we boarded a ship .
Shakespearean: Alas , too soon We came aboard .

English: Signior Angelo , please excuse us .
Shakespearean: Good Signior Angelo , you must excuse us all ; My wife is shrewish when I keep not hours .

English: Here's the story we'll tell her : that I was with you at your shop , watching you make her necklace , and that you're going to deliver it tomorrow .
Shakespearean: Say that I lingered with you at your shop To see the making of her carcanet , And that tomorrow you will bring it home .

English: But here comes a scoundrel who says he saw me at the marketplace and that I beat on him , told him I'd given him a thousand marks in gold , and then lied about my wife and my house .
Shakespearean: But here's a villain that would face me down He met me on the mart , and that I beat him And charged him with a thousand marks in gold , And that I did deny my wife and house. , Thou drunkard , thou , what didst thou mean by this ?

English: Say what you want , but I know what I know .
Shakespearean: Say what you will , sir , but I know what I know .

English: I think you're an ass .
Shakespearean: I think thou art an ass .

English: Signior Balthasar , you look upset .
Shakespearean: You're sad , Signior Balthasar .

English: Your delicacies aren't worth as much to me as your welcome is .
Shakespearean: I hold your dainties cheap , sir , and your welcome dear .

English: Good food's not a big deal , everyone can afford that .
Shakespearean: Good meat , sir , is common ; that every churl affords .

English: And everyone can say "welcome , " which is just a word .
Shakespearean: And welcome more common , for that's nothing but words .

English: A little food and a huge welcome makes a joyous feast .
Shakespearean: Small cheer and great welcome makes a merry feast .

English: Sure , to a cheap host and an even cheaper guest .
Shakespearean: Ay , to a niggardly host and more sparing guest .

English: But look , even if my dishes are poor , eat them with my best wishes .
Shakespearean: But though my cates be mean , take them in good part .

English: You may come across better food , but not a warmer welcome .
Shakespearean: Better cheer may you have , but not with better heart .

English: What's this ?
Shakespearean: But soft !

English: My door is locked .
Shakespearean: My door is lock'd .

English: Maud , Bridget , Marian , Ciceley , Gillian , Ginn !
Shakespearean: Maud , Bridget , Marian , Ciceley , Gillian , Ginn !

English: My master is standing out in the street !
Shakespearean: My master stays in the street .

English: Who's in there ?
Shakespearean: Who talks within there ?

English: Hey , open the door !
Shakespearean: Ho , open the door .

English: A reason ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore ?

English: So I can eat lunch .
Shakespearean: For my dinner .

English: I haven't eaten today .
Shakespearean: I have not dined today .

English: Who do you think you are , keeping me out of my own house ?
Shakespearean: What art thou that keep'st me out from the house I owe ?

English: You've stolen both my job and my name !
Shakespearean: O villain , thou hast stolen both mine office and my name !

English: Oh , Lord , this makes me laugh !
Shakespearean: O Lord , I must laugh .

English: I'll come at you with the old proverb : "Should I make myself at home ? "
Shakespearean: Have at you with a proverb : shall I set in my staff ?

English: Listen up , you slave .
Shakespearean: Do you hear , you minion ?

English: Are you going to let us in ?
Shakespearean: You'll let us in , I hope ?

English: Come , help me bang on the door , master .
Shakespearean: So , come , help .

English: Well done !
Shakespearean: Well struck !

English: We answered them , blow for blow .
Shakespearean: There was blow for blow .

English: You good-for-nothing , let me in .
Shakespearean: Thou baggage , let me in .

English: Master , knock hard upon the door .
Shakespearean: Master , knock the door hard .

English: If I break the door down , slave , you'll be sorry for this .
Shakespearean: You'll cry for this , minion , if I beat the door down .

English: Is that you , wife ?
Shakespearean: Are you there , wife ?

English: You could have come sooner .
Shakespearean: You might have come before .

English: If she punishes you , master , she's sure to punish me .
Shakespearean: If you went in pain , master , this knave would go sore .

English: We argued about which was best , and now we won't get either one .
Shakespearean: In debating which was best , we shall part with neither .

English: And if your clothes were as thin as mine , you'd really feel the air .
Shakespearean: You would say so , master , if your garments were thin .

English: The food inside is warm , but you're out here freezing .
Shakespearean: Your cake there is warm within ; you stand here in the cold .

English: It would make any man as mad as a bull to be betrayed like this .
Shakespearean: It would make a man mad as a buck to be so bought and sold .

English: Go get me something I can use to break down the door .
Shakespearean: Go , fetch me something : I'll break ope the gate .

English: I've had enough of this "off with you ! " Come on , let me in !
Shakespearean: Here's too much "out upon thee ! " I pray thee , let me in .

English: Well , I'm going to break in .
Shakespearean: Well , I'll break in .

English: Go get me a crow .
Shakespearean: Go , borrow me a crow .

English: A crow without feathers ?
Shakespearean: A crow without feather ?

English: Master , do you really mean that ?
Shakespearean: Master , mean you so ?

English: I meant a crowbar .
Shakespearean: For a fish without a fin , there's a fowl without a feather. , Go , get thee gone .

English: Get going already .
Shakespearean: Fetch me an iron crow .

English: Be patient , sir !
Shakespearean: Have patience , sir .

English: Don't do this !
Shakespearean: O , let it not be so .

English: All this suggests that she has a good reason for doing this to you .
Shakespearean: And doubt not , sir , but she will well excuse Why at this time the doors are made against you .

English: Let's assume that she has a reason , which you don't know yet : have faith that she'll eventually explain why she shut the doors on you today .
Shakespearean: Be ruled by me ; depart in patience , And let us to the Tiger all to dinner , And about evening come yourself alone To know the reason of this strange restraint .

English: You're right , I'll go quietly .
Shakespearean: You have prevailed .

English: And even though I'm in a distasteful mood , I'll work on being happy .
Shakespearean: I will depart in quiet And , in despite of mirth , mean to be merry .

English: I know a terrific wench .
Shakespearean: I know a wench of excellent discourse , Pretty and witty , wild and yet , too , gentle .

English: We'll eat at her place .
Shakespearean: There will we dine .

English: I swear to her that I haven't , but it doesn't change anything .
Shakespearean: That chain will I bestow , Be it for nothing but to spite my wife , Upon mine hostess there .

English: I'll meet you there in an hour .
Shakespearean: I'll meet you at that place some hour hence .

English: Do that .
Shakespearean: Do so .

English: This little prank of hers is going to cost me .
Shakespearean: This jest shall cost me some expense .

English: Is the building of your love already in ruins ?
Shakespearean: Shall , Antipholus , Even in the spring of love thy love-springs rot ?

English: If you married my sister for her wealth , then for her wealth's sake , treat her with more kindness .
Shakespearean: If you did wed my sister for her wealth , Then for her wealth's sake use her with more kindness .

English: What foolish thief brags about his crimes ?
Shakespearean: What simple thief brags of his own attaint ?

English: It's doubly wrong to cheat on your wife and then let her see the offense in your eyes .
Shakespearean: Tis double wrong to truant with your bed And let her read it in thy looks at board .

English: We follow in your orbit , and you have the power to move us .
Shakespearean: Though others have the arm , show us the sleeve ; We in your motion turn , and you may move us .

English: So , my sweet brother-in-law , go inside .
Shakespearean: Then , gentle brother , get you in again .

English: Sweet mistress , I don't know what other name to give you , or how you've figured out mine , you seem as
Shakespearean: Sweet mistress , what your name is else I know not , Nor by what wonder you do hit of mine , ,

English: wise and graceful as the earth is wonderful and divine .
Shakespearean: Less in your knowledge and your grace you show not Than our earth's wonder , more than earth divine .

English: Teach me how I should think and speak .
Shakespearean: Teach me , dear creature , how to think and speak .

English: Why would you have me betray the truth of my emotions and make my love wander in some other direction ?
Shakespearean: Against my soul's pure truth why labour you To make it wander in an unknown field ?

English: Are you a god ?
Shakespearean: Are you a god ?

English: Are you trying to remake me ?
Shakespearean: would you create me new ?

English: Go ahead , I'll yield to your power .
Shakespearean: Transform me , then , and to your power I'll yield .

English: But if I am myself , then I know for sure that your weeping sister is not my wife .
Shakespearean: But if that I am I , then well I know Your weeping sister is no wife of mine , Nor to her bed no homage do I owe .

English: I don't owe her any duty , it's you that I submit to .
Shakespearean: Far more , far more , to you do I decline .

English: Oh , sweet mermaid , don't command me to drown myself in the flood of your sister's tears .
Shakespearean: O , train me not , sweet mermaid , with thy note To drown me in thy sister's flood of tears .

English: Are you insane , talking like this ?
Shakespearean: What , are you mad that you do reason so ?

English: Your eyes are playing tricks on you .
Shakespearean: It is a fault that springeth from your eye .

English: That's because you are near me , and you're as dazzling as the sun .
Shakespearean: For gazing on your beams , fair sun , being by .

English: Why are you calling me "love" ?
Shakespearean: Why call you me "love" ?

English: Call my sister that .
Shakespearean: Call my sister so .

English: Your sister's sister .
Shakespearean: Thy sister's sister .

English: That's my sister .
Shakespearean: That's my sister .

English: My food , my fortune , my sweetest hope , my heaven on earth , and my entrance to heaven .
Shakespearean: No , It is thyself , mine own self's better part , Mine eye's clear eye , my dear heart's dearer heart , My food , my fortune , and my sweet hope's aim , My sole earth's heaven , and my heaven's claim .

English: My sister is all those things , or else she should be .
Shakespearean: All this my sister is , or else should be .

English: Call yourself your own sister , because I want you .
Shakespearean: Call thyself "sister , " sweet , for I am thee .

English: Give me your hand .
Shakespearean: Give me thy hand .

English: Oh , wait , sir .
Shakespearean: O soft , sir !

English: Stay here .
Shakespearean: Hold you still .

English: I'll go get my sister and see what she thinks .
Shakespearean: I'll fetch my sister to get her goodwill .

English: What's going on , Dromio ?
Shakespearean: Why , how now , Dromio .

English: Where are you running so fast ?
Shakespearean: Where runn'st thou so fast ?

English: Do you know me ?
Shakespearean: Do you know me , sir ?

English: Am I Dromio ?
Shakespearean: Am I Dromio ?

English: Am I your servant ?
Shakespearean: Am I your man ?

English: Am I myself ?
Shakespearean: Am I myself ?

English: It carried us toward Corinth-or so we thought .
Shakespearean: The children thus disposed , my wife and I , Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fixed , Fastened ourselves at either end the mast And , floating straight , obedient to the stream , Was carried towards Corinth , as we thought .

English: But before they reached us-let me say no more !
Shakespearean: But ere they came , -O , let me say no more !

English: You are Dromio , you are my servant , and you are yourself .
Shakespearean: Thou art Dromio , thou art my man , thou art thyself .

English: I'm an ass , I'm a woman's servant , and I'm beside myself .
Shakespearean: I am an ass , I am a woman's man , and besides myself .

English: What woman's servant ?
Shakespearean: What woman's man ?

English: What do you mean , beside yourself ?
Shakespearean: And how besides thyself ?

English: How does she claim to own you ?
Shakespearean: What claim lays she to thee ?

English: I don't mean that she wants me because What's she like ?
Shakespearean: What is she ?

English: The only thing I could do with her is to use all that oil as fuel in a lamp and then use that light to run away by .
Shakespearean: Marry , sir , she's the kitchen wench , and all grease , and I know not what use to put her to but to make a lamp of her and run from her by her own light .

English: Her
Shakespearean: I warrant her rags and the

English: Even if she lives till the end of the world , she'd keep burning an additional week .
Shakespearean: If she lives till doomsday , she'll burn a week longer than the whole world .

English: What's her skin like ?
Shakespearean: What complexion is she of ?

English: It's dark , like my shoe .
Shakespearean: Swart like my shoe , but her face nothing like so clean kept .

English: Some water will fix that .
Shakespearean: That's a fault that water will mend .

English: No , it's permanent .
Shakespearean: No , sir , 'tis in grain ; Noah's flood could not do it .

English: What's her name ?
Shakespearean: What's her name ?

English: Nell .
Shakespearean: Then she bears some breadth ?

English: She's round , like a globe .
Shakespearean: She is spherical , like a globe .

English: What part of her body is Ireland ?
Shakespearean: In what part of her body stands Ireland ?

English: Her bottom .
Shakespearean: Marry , sir , in her buttocks .

English: Honestly , I didn't see it , but I felt it in her hot breath .
Shakespearean: Faith , I saw it not , but I felt it hot in her breath .

English: Where's America and the West Indies ?
Shakespearean: Where America , the Indies ?

English: Oh , sir , on her nose , which is covered with pimples , sores , and red welts .
Shakespearean: O , sir , upon her nose , all o'er-embellished with rubies , carbuncles , sapphires , declining their rich aspect to the hot breath of Spain , who sent whole armadas of caracks to be ballast at her nose .

English: And I think that if I hadn't been brave and strong , she would have turned me into a dog and made me her slave .
Shakespearean: And , I think , if my breast had not been made of faith , and my heart of steel , She had transformed me to a curtal dog and made me turn i ' th ' wheel .

English: If there's enough wind for a ship to sail out tonight , I won't spend tonight in this town .
Shakespearean: An if the wind blow any way from shore , I will not harbor in this town tonight .

English: If a ship's leaving , come to the marketplace .
Shakespearean: If any bark put forth , come to the mart , Where I will walk till thou return to me .

English: If everyone here knows us but we don't know anybody , it's time , I think , for us to pack our bags and take off .
Shakespearean: If every one knows us , and we know none , 'T is time , I think , to trudge , pack , and be gone .

English: I'll run from this woman who claims to be my wife as fast as I'd run from a bear .
Shakespearean: As from a bear a man would run for life , So fly I from her that would be my wife .

English: That means it's high time for me to go .
Shakespearean: There's none but witches do inhabit here , And therefore 'tis high time that I were hence .

English: That woman who claims I am her husband , I loathe her in my soul .
Shakespearean: She that doth call me husband , even my soul Doth for a wife abhor .

English: I'd better stop up my ears against this siren's song .
Shakespearean: But lest myself be guilty to self wrong , I'll stop mine ears against the mermaid's song .

English: I know that , sir .
Shakespearean: I know it well , sir .

English: Look , here's the necklace .
Shakespearean: Lo , here's the chain .

English: What do you want me to do with this ?
Shakespearean: What is your will that I shall do with this ?

English: Whatever you want , I made it for you .
Shakespearean: I have made it for you .

English: Made it for me ?
Shakespearean: Made it for me , sir ?

English: I didn't order it .
Shakespearean: I bespoke it not .

English: You did , not just once or twice , but twenty times .
Shakespearean: Not once , nor twice , but twenty times you have .

English: You're a funny man , sir .
Shakespearean: You are a merry man , sir .

English: Take care .
Shakespearean: Fare you well .

English: I don't know what to think about this .
Shakespearean: What I should think of this I can not tell , But this I think : there's no man is so vain That would refuse so fair an offered chain .

English: I'll go wait for Dromio at the marketplace .
Shakespearean: I'll to the mart , and there for Dromio stay .

English: If any ships are sailing , I'll get right on one .
Shakespearean: If any ship put out , then straight away .

English: Antipholus owes me the exact amount that I owe you .
Shakespearean: Even just the sum that I do owe to you Is growing to me by Antipholus .

English: At five o'clock he's going to pay me for it .
Shakespearean: At five o'clock I shall receive the money for the same .

English: Please , come to his house with me .
Shakespearean: Pleaseth you walk with me down to his house , I will discharge my bond and thank you too .

English: The total due is about three ducats more than I owe this gentleman .
Shakespearean: Saving your merry humor , here's the note How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat , The fineness of the gold , and chargeful fashion , Which doth amount to three-odd ducats more Than I stand debted to this gentleman .

English: Please , pay him immediately .
Shakespearean: I pray you , see him presently discharged , For he is bound to sea , and stays but for it .

English: I don't have the cash right now .
Shakespearean: I am not furnished with the present money .

English: Besides , I have some business to take care of in town .
Shakespearean: Besides , I have some business in the town .

English: So you'll bring the necklace to her yourself ?
Shakespearean: Then you will bring the chain to her yourself .

English: All right , sir , I will .
Shakespearean: Well , sir , I will .

English: Do you have it with you ?
Shakespearean: Have you the chain about you ?

English: Listen , please , give me the necklace .
Shakespearean: Nay , come , I pray you , sir , give me the chain .

English: The wind is right and it's high tide , and I've delayed him a long time already .
Shakespearean: Both wind and tide stays for this gentleman , And I , to blame , have held him here too long .

English: Good Lord !
Shakespearean: Good Lord !

English: You're using this as an excuse for not showing up at the Porcupine like you promised .
Shakespearean: You use this dalliance to excuse Your breach of promise to the Porpentine .

English: I should have reprimanded you then for not bringing it , but you started fighting with me first .
Shakespearean: I should have chid you for not bringing it , But , like a shrew , you first begin to brawl .

English: It's getting late .
Shakespearean: The hour steals on .

English: Please , sir , hurry up .
Shakespearean: I pray you , sir , dispatch .

English: Antipholus , you hear how the man pleads with me .
Shakespearean: You hear how he importunes me .

English: Give me the necklace !
Shakespearean: The chain !

English: Give it to my wife , and get your money .
Shakespearean: Why , give it to my wife , and fetch your money .

English: Come , come .
Shakespearean: Come , come .

English: You know I gave it to you just now .
Shakespearean: You know I gave it you even now .

English: Send the necklace to her , or send me with a token that will authorize her to pay me .
Shakespearean: Either send the chain , or send me by some token .

English: Damn it , this isn't funny .
Shakespearean: Fie , now you run this humor out of breath .

English: Where's the necklace ?
Shakespearean: Come , where's the chain ?

English: Let me see it .
Shakespearean: I pray you , let me see it .

English: Pay you ?
Shakespearean: I answer you ?

English: What should I pay you ?
Shakespearean: What should I answer you ?

English: The money you owe me for the necklace .
Shakespearean: The money that you owe me for the chain .

English: I owe you nothing until I receive the necklace .
Shakespearean: I owe you none till I receive the chain .

English: You know that I gave it to you a half hour ago .
Shakespearean: You know I gave it you half an hour since .

English: You wrong me even more , sir , by denying it .
Shakespearean: You wrong me more , sir , in denying it .

English: Consider how poorly this reflects on me .
Shakespearean: Consider how it stands upon my credit .

English: I will .
Shakespearean: Well , officer , arrest him at my suit .

English: This harms my reputation .
Shakespearean: I do , This touches me in reputation .

English: Pay for something I never got ?
Shakespearean: Consent to pay thee that I never had ? , Arrest me , foolish fellow , if thou dar'st .

English: Go ahead , you fool .
Shakespearean: Here is thy fee .

English: Arrest me if you dare .
Shakespearean: Arrest him , officer .

English: I would have my own brother arrested if he treated me so terribly .
Shakespearean: I would not spare my brother in this case If he should scorn me so apparently .

English: You're under arrest , sir .

English: You hear the charges .
Shakespearean: You hear the suit .

Shakespearean: I do obey thee till I give thee bail .

Shakespearean: But , sirrah , you shall buy this sport as dear As all the metal in your shop will answer .

Shakespearean: Sir , sir , I will have law in Ephesus , To your notorious shame , I doubt it not .

English: No , keep going , old man ; don't stop like that .
Shakespearean: Nay , forward , old man .

Shakespearean: Do not break off so , For we may pity though not pardon thee .

Shakespearean: O , had the gods done so , I had not now Worthily termed them merciless to us .

English: It's been my bad luck to remain alive long enough to be able to tell the sad stories of my own misfortunes .
Shakespearean: Thus have you heard me severed from my bliss ; That by misfortunes was my life prolonged To tell sad stories of my own mishaps .

English: And for the sake of those you grieve for , do me a favor : tell me the full story of what has happened to you and them , up to this point .
Shakespearean: And for the sake of them thou sorrowest for , Do me the favour to dilate at full What hath befall'n of them and thee till now .

English: I've left our luggage on the ship , and I bought the oil , balm , and liquor you wanted .
Shakespearean: Our fraughtage , sir , I have conveyed aboard , and I have bought The oil , the balsamum and aqua vitae .

Shakespearean: Why , thou peevish sheep , What ship of Epidamnum stays for me ?

English: A ship you sent me to find , to book passage out of here .
Shakespearean: A ship you sent me to , to hire waftage .

Shakespearean: Thou drunken slave , I sent thee for a rope And told thee to what purpose and what end .

English: Yeah , right , you sent me to get whipped .
Shakespearean: You sent me for a rope's end as soon .

English: You sent me to the port to find a ship .
Shakespearean: You sent me to the bay , sir , for a bark .

English: I'll debate this with you later , and then I'll teach you to listen more carefully .
Shakespearean: I will debate this matter at more leisure And teach your ears to list me with more heed .

Shakespearean: To Adriana , villain , hie thee straight .

Shakespearean: Give her this key , and tell her in the desk That's cover'd o'er with Turkish tapestry There is a purse of ducats .

Shakespearean: Let her send it .

Shakespearean: Tell her I am arrested in the street , And that shall bail me .

Shakespearean: Hie thee , slave .

Shakespearean: Begone. , On , officer , to prison till it come .

Shakespearean: To Adriana .

Shakespearean: That is where we dined , Where Dowsabel did claim me for her husband .

Shakespearean: She is too big , I hope , for me to compass .

Shakespearean: Thither I must , although against my will , For servants must their masters ' minds fulfill .

English: Oh , Luciana , did he tempt you like that ?
Shakespearean: Ah , Luciana , did he tempt thee so ?

English: Sad or happy ?
Shakespearean: Looked he or red or pale , or sad or merrily ?

English: First , he said you had no right to him .
Shakespearean: First he denied you had in him no right .

Shakespearean: He meant he did me none ; the more my spite .

Shakespearean: Then swore he that he was a stranger here .

English: And that's true , he Then I pleaded for you .
Shakespearean: Then pleaded I for you .

Shakespearean: And what said he ?

Shakespearean: That love i begged for you he begged of me .

Shakespearean: With what persuasion did he tempt thy love ?

Shakespearean: Have patience , I beseech .

Shakespearean: No evil lost is wailed when it is gone .

Shakespearean: Ah , but I think him better than I say , And yet would herein others ' eyes were worse .

Shakespearean: My heart prays for him , though my tongue do curse .

Shakespearean: By running fast .

Shakespearean: Why , man , what is the matter ?

Shakespearean: I know not at whose suit he is arrested well , But he's in a suit of buff which 'rested him ; that can I tell .

Shakespearean: For if the sun breed maggots in a dead dog , being a good kissing carrion , Have you a daughter ?

Shakespearean: I have , my lord .

Shakespearean: Let her not walk i ' th ' sun .

English: Denmark's a prison .

English: Then I guess the whole world is one .

English: Yes , quite a large one , with many cells and dungeons , Denmark being one of the worst .

English: We don't think so , my lord .
Shakespearean: We think not so , my lord .

English: Well , then it isn't one to you , since nothing is really good or bad in itself , it's all what a person thinks about it .

Shakespearean: To me it is a prison .

English: That must be because you're so ambitious .

English: It's too small for your large mind .

English: But a dream itself is just a shadow .

English: Then I guess beggars are the ones with bodies , while ambitious kings and heroes are just the shadows of beggars .
Shakespearean: Then are our beggars bodies , and our monarchs and outstretched heroes the beggars ' shadows .

English: Should we go inside ?
Shakespearean: Shall we to th ' court ?

English: Or was it just your whim , on your own initiative ?
Shakespearean: Is it your own inclining ?

English: What should we say , my lord ?

English: You were sent for .
Shakespearean: You were sent for , and there is a kind of confession in your looks which your modesties have not craft enough to color .

Shakespearean: I know the good king and queen have sent for you .

English: Why would they do that , my lord ?

English: That's what I want you to tell me .

Shakespearean: My lord , we were sent for .

Shakespearean: Who is 't that can inform me ?

English: Or at least I can describe the rumors .

Shakespearean: The adventurous knight shall use his foil and target , the lover shall not sigh gratis , the humorous man shall end his part in peace , the clown shall make those laugh whose lungs are tickle o ' th ' sear , and the lady shall say her mind freely , or the blank verse shall halt for 't .

Shakespearean: What players are they ?

English: The tragic actors from the city , the ones you used to enjoy so much .

Shakespearean: How chances it they travel ?

English: They made more money and got more attention in the city .

English: But things have changed there , and it's easier for them on the road now .

Shakespearean: Do they hold the same estimation they did when I was in the city ?

English: Do they attract big audiences ?

English: Why ?

English: Are they getting rusty ?

English: The problem is that they have to compete with a group of children who yell out their lines and receive outrageous applause for it .
Shakespearean: But there is , sir , an eyrie of children , little eyases , that cry out on the top of question and are most tyrannically clapped for 't .

English: These child actors are now in fashion , and they've so overtaken the public theaters that society types hardly come at all , they're so afraid of being mocked by the playwrights who write for the boys .
Shakespearean: These are now the fashion , and so berattle the common stages , so they call them , that many wearing rapiers are afraid of goose quills and dare scarce come thither .

English: What , you mean kid actors ?
Shakespearean: What , are they children ?

English: Who takes care of them ?
Shakespearean: Who maintains 'em ?

English: Who pays their way ?
Shakespearean: How are they escoted ?

English: Will they stop working when their voices mature ?
Shakespearean: Will they pursue the quality no longer than they can sing ?

English: Aren't the playwrights hurting them by making them upstage adult actors , which they are going to grow up and become ?
Shakespearean: Will they not say afterwards , if they should grow themselves to common players ( as it is most like if their means are no better ) , their writers do them wrong to make them exclaim against their own succession ?

English: There's been a whole debate on the topic .
Shakespearean: Faith , there has been much to do on both sides , and the nation holds it no sin to tar them to controversy .

English: For a while , no play was sold to the theaters without a big fight between the children's playwright and the actors playing adult roles .
Shakespearean: There was , for a while , no money bid for argument unless the poet and the player went to cuffs in the question .

English: Are you kidding ?
Shakespearean: Is 't possible ?

English: Oh , there's been a lot of quarreling .
Shakespearean: Oh , there has been much throwing about of brains .

English: And the boys are winning so far ?
Shakespearean: Do the boys carry it away ?

English: Actually , it's not so unusual when you think about it .
Shakespearean: It is not very strange .

English: My uncle is king of Denmark , and the same people who made fun of him while my father was still alive are now rushing to pay twenty , forty , fifty , a hundred ducats apiece for miniature portraits of him .
Shakespearean: For my uncle is King of Denmark , and those that would make mouths at him while my father lived give twenty , forty , fifty , a hundred ducats apiece for his picture in little .

English: There's something downright unnatural about it , if a philosopher stopped to think about it .
Shakespearean: Sblood , there is something in this more than natural , if philosophy could find it out .

English: The actors are here .
Shakespearean: There are the players .

English: Gentlemen , welcome to Elsinore .
Shakespearean: Gentlemen , you are welcome to Elsinore .

Shakespearean: Your hands , come then .

English: And if we don't shake hands , when I act all nice to the players it will seem like I'm happier to see them than you .
Shakespearean: Let me comply with you in this garb , lest my extent to the players , which , I tell you , must show fairly outwards , should more appear like entertainment than yours .

English: You are very welcome here .
Shakespearean: You are welcome .

English: But still , my uncle-father and aunt-mother have got the wrong idea .
Shakespearean: But my uncle-father and aunt-mother are deceived .

Shakespearean: In what , my dear lord ?

Shakespearean: I am but mad north-north-west .

Shakespearean: Well be with you , gentlemen .

Shakespearean: Hark you , Guildenstern , and you too , at each ear a hearer .

Shakespearean: Happily he's the second time come to them , for they say an old man is twice a child .

Shakespearean: My lord , I have news to tell you .

English: My lord , I have news for you .
Shakespearean: My lord , I have news to tell you .

English: When Roscius was an actor in ancient Rome , The actors have arrived , my lord .
Shakespearean: When Roscius was an actor in Rome , The actors are come hither , my lord .

English: I swear , , each actor arrived on his ass .
Shakespearean: Upon my honor , Then came each actor on his ass ,

English: Well , Aren't I right , Jephthah , old man ?
Shakespearean: Why , Am I not i ' th ' right , old Jephthah ?

English: If you're calling me Jephthah , my lord , I do have a daughter I love more than anything , yes .
Shakespearean: If you call me Jephthah , my lord , I have a daughter that I love passing well .

Shakespearean: What follows , then , my lord ?

English: Why ,
Shakespearean: Why ,

English: Welcome , welcome to all of you .
Shakespearean: You are welcome , masters , welcome , all ! , I am glad to see thee well. , Welcome , good friends. , O old friend ?

Shakespearean: What speech , my good lord ?

English: But the critics and I found it to be an excellent play , with well-ordered scenes that were clever but not fancy .
Shakespearean: But it was , as I received it , and others , whose judgments in such matters cried in the top of mine , an excellent play , well digested in the scenes , set down with as much modesty as cunning .

English: I loved one speech in particular .
Shakespearean: One speech in it I chiefly loved .

English: This speech is going on too long .
Shakespearean: This is too long .

Shakespearean: It shall to the barber's , with your beard. , Prithee , say on .

Shakespearean: The mobled queen" ?

English: That's good .
Shakespearean: That's good .

English: The muffled queen" is good .

English: Look how flushed the actor is , with tears in his eyes .
Shakespearean: Look whe'e he has not turned his color and has tears in 's eyes. , Prithee , no more .

Shakespearean: My lord , I will use them according to their desert .

English: Good heavens , man , give them more than that !

Shakespearean: Use them after your own honor and dignity .

Shakespearean: We'll hear a play tomorrow .

Shakespearean: Ay , my lord .

English: Then we'll see that tomorrow night .
Shakespearean: We'll ha 't tomorrow night .

Shakespearean: You could , for a need , study a speech of some dozen or sixteen lines which I would set down and insert in 't , could you not ?

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my lord .

English: Very well .
Shakespearean: Very well .

Shakespearean: Follow that lord , and look you mock him not .

Shakespearean: My good friends , I'll leave you till night .

English: Welcome to Elsinore .
Shakespearean: You are welcome to Elsinore .

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Good my lord .

English: Oh , what a mean low-life I am !

Shakespearean: And all for nothing , For Hecuba !

English: The ghost is definitely something to worry about .
Shakespearean: And terms compulsatory , those foresaid lands So by his father lost .

English: In the high and mighty Roman Empire , just before the emperor Julius Caesar was assassinated , corpses rose out of their graves and ran through the streets of Rome speaking gibberish .
Shakespearean: In the most high and palmy state of Rome , A little ere the mightiest Julius fell , The graves stood tenantless and the sheeted dead Did squeak and gibber in the Roman streets As stars with trains of fire and dews of blood , Disasters in the sun , and the moist star Upon whose influence Neptune's empire stands Was sick almost to doomsday with eclipse .

English: Wait , look !
Shakespearean: But soft , behold !

English: It has come again .

Shakespearean: Am I a coward ?

Shakespearean: Plucks off my beard and blows it in my face ?

English: Remorseless , treacherous , sex-obsessed , unnatural villain !

English: Ah , revenge !

Shakespearean: I'll have grounds More relative than this .

Shakespearean: The play's the thing Wherein I'll catch the conscience of the king .

Shakespearean: And can you by no drift of conference Get from him why he puts on this confusion , Grating so harshly all his days of quiet With turbulent and dangerous lunacy ?

Shakespearean: Did he receive you well ?

English: Yes , in a very gentlemanly way .
Shakespearean: Most like a gentleman .

Shakespearean: Niggard of question , but of our demands Most free in his reply .
