Shakespearean: Madam , it so fell out , that certain players We o'erraught on the way .

English: They are here at court now , and I believe they've been told to give a performance for him tonight .
Shakespearean: They are about the court , And , as I think , they have already order This night to play before him .

English: It's true , and he asked me to beg you both to attend .
Shakespearean: Tis most true , And he beseeched me to entreat your Majesties To hear and see the matter .

English: It makes me very happy to hear he's so interested .
Shakespearean: With all my heart , and it doth much content me To hear him so inclined .

English: Gentlemen , please try to sharpen his interest even more , and let this play do him some good .
Shakespearean: Good gentlemen , give him a further edge , And drive his purpose on to these delights .

English: We will , my lord .
Shakespearean: We shall , my lord .

English: Yes , I'll go .
Shakespearean: I shall obey you .

English: I hope so too , Madam .
Shakespearean: Madam , I wish it may .

English: Ophelia , come here. , I hear him coming .
Shakespearean: Ophelia , walk you here .

English: Quick , let's hide , my lord .
Shakespearean: Let's withdraw , my lord .

English: Dying , sleeping , that's all dying is , a sleep that ends all the heartache and shocks that life on earth gives us , that's an achievement to wish for .
Shakespearean: To die , to sleep , No more , and by a sleep to say we end The heartache and the thousand natural shocks That flesh is heir to , 'tis a consummation Devoutly to be wished !

English: To die , to sleep , to sleep , maybe to dream .
Shakespearean: To die , to sleep .

English: That's the consideration that makes us stretch out our sufferings so long .
Shakespearean: There's the respect That makes calamity of so long life .

English: After all , who would put up with all life's humiliations , the abuse from superiors , the insults of arrogant men , the pangs of unrequited love , the inefficiency of the legal system , the rudeness of people in office , and the mistreatment good people have to take from bad , when you could simply take out your knife and call it quits ?
Shakespearean: For who would bear the whips and scorns of time , Th ' oppressor's wrong , the proud man's contumely , The pangs of despised love , the law's delay , The insolence of office , and the spurns That patient merit of th ' unworthy takes , When he himself might his quietus make With a bare bodkin ?

English: Who would choose to grunt and sweat through an exhausting life , unless they were afraid of something dreadful after death , the undiscovered country from which no visitor returns , which we wonder about without getting any answers from and which makes us stick to the evils we know rather than rush off to seek the ones we don't ?
Shakespearean: Who would fardels bear , To grunt and sweat under a weary life , But that the dread of something after death , The undiscovered country from whose bourn No traveler returns , puzzles the will And makes us rather bear those ills we have Than fly to others that we know not of ?

English: But Hello , my lord , how have you been doing lately ?
Shakespearean: Good my lord , How does your honor for this many a day ?

English: Very well , thank you .
Shakespearean: I humbly thank you .

English: Well , well , well .
Shakespearean: Well , well , well .

English: My lord , I have some mementos of yours that I've been meaning to give back to you for a long time now .
Shakespearean: My lord , I have remembrances of yours That I have longed long to redeliver .

English: Please take them .
Shakespearean: I pray you now receive them .

English: There , my lord .
Shakespearean: There , my lord .

English: Ha ha , are you good ?
Shakespearean: Ha , ha , are you honest ?

English: Excuse me ?
Shakespearean: My lord ?

English: Are you beautiful ?
Shakespearean: Are you fair ?

English: My lord , what are you talking about ?
Shakespearean: What means your lordship ?

English: I'm just saying that if you're good and beautiful , your goodness should have nothing to do with your beauty .
Shakespearean: That if you be honest and fair , your honesty should admit no discourse to your beauty .

English: But could beauty be related to anything better than goodness ?
Shakespearean: Could beauty , my lord , have better commerce than with honesty ?

English: Sure , since beauty's power can more easily change a good girl into a whore than the power of goodness can change a beautiful girl into a virgin .
Shakespearean: Ay , truly , for the power of beauty will sooner transform honesty from what it is to a bawd than the force of honesty can translate beauty into his likeness .

English: This used to be a great puzzle , but now I've solved it .
Shakespearean: This was sometime a paradox , but now the time gives it proof .

English: I used to love you .
Shakespearean: I did love you once .

English: You certainly made me believe you did , my lord .
Shakespearean: Indeed , my lord , you made me believe so .

English: I didn't love you .
Shakespearean: I loved you not .

English: Then I guess I was misled .
Shakespearean: I was the more deceived .

English: Get yourself to a
Shakespearean: Get thee to a nunnery .

English: I am arrogant , vengeful , ambitious , with more ill will in me than I can fit into my thoughts , and more than I have time to carry it out in .
Shakespearean: I am very proud , revengeful , ambitious , with more offences at my beck than I have thoughts to put them in , imagination to give them shape , or time to act them in .

English: Why should people like me be crawling around between earth and heaven ?
Shakespearean: What should such fellows as I do crawling between earth and heaven ?

English: Every one of us is a criminal .
Shakespearean: We are arrant knaves , all .

English: Don't believe any of us .
Shakespearean: Believe none of us .

English: Hurry to a convent .
Shakespearean: Go thy ways to a nunnery .

English: Where's your father ?
Shakespearean: Where's your father ?

English: He's at home , my lord .
Shakespearean: At home , my lord .

English: Lock him in , so he can play the fool in his own home only .
Shakespearean: Let the doors be shut upon him , that he may play the fool no where but in 's own house .

English: Good-bye .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: Oh , dear God , please help him !
Shakespearean: O , help him , you sweet heavens !

English: Get yourself to a convent , at once .
Shakespearean: Get thee to a nunnery , go .

English: Good-bye .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: Good-bye .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: Dear God , please make him normal again !
Shakespearean: Heavenly powers , restore him !

English: I've heard all about you women and your cosmetics too .
Shakespearean: I have heard of your paintings too , well enough .

English: God gives you one face , but you paint another on top of it .
Shakespearean: God has given you one face and you make yourselves another .

English: You dance and prance and lisp ; you call God's creations by pet names , and you excuse your sexpot ploys by pleading ignorance .
Shakespearean: You jig and amble , and you lisp , you nickname God's creatures and make your wantonness your ignorance .

English: Come on , I won't stand for it anymore .
Shakespearean: Go to , I'll no more on 't .

English: It's driven me crazy .
Shakespearean: It hath made me mad .

English: I hereby declare we will have no more marriage .
Shakespearean: I say , we will have no more marriages .

English: Whoever is already married ( except one person I know ) will stay married , all but one person .
Shakespearean: Those that are married already , all but one , shall live .

English: Everyone else will have to stay single .
Shakespearean: The rest shall keep as they are .

English: Get yourself to a convent , fast .
Shakespearean: To a nunnery , go .

English: Love ?
Shakespearean: Love ?

English: His feelings don't move in that direction .
Shakespearean: His affections do not that way tend .

English: With any luck , the sea and new countries will push out these thoughts that have somehow taken root in his mind .
Shakespearean: Haply the seas and countries different With variable objects shall expel This something-settled matter in his heart , Whereon his brains still beating puts him thus From fashion of himself .

English: What do you think of this plan ?
Shakespearean: What think you on 't ?

English: It should work .
Shakespearean: It shall do well .

English: But I still believe that his madness was caused by unrequited love. , Hello , Ophelia .
Shakespearean: But yet do I believe The origin and commencement of his grief Sprung from neglected love. , How now , Ophelia ?

English: You don't have to tell us what Lord Hamlet said .
Shakespearean: You need not tell us what Lord Hamlet said .

English: I'll hide and listen in .
Shakespearean: Let her be round with him , And I'll be placed , so please you , in the ear Of all their conference .

English: If she can't find out what his secret is , then send him off to England or wherever you think best .
Shakespearean: If she find him not , To England send him or confine him where Your wisdom best shall think .

English: That's how we'll do it , then .
Shakespearean: It shall be so .

English: If there's any good deed I can do that will bring you peace and me honor , speak to me .
Shakespearean: If there be any good thing to be done That may to thee do ease and grace to me , Speak to me .

English: Or if you've got some buried treasure somewhere , which they say often makes ghosts restless , then tell us about it .
Shakespearean: Or if thou hast uphoarded in thy life Extorted treasure in the womb of earth , For which , they say , you spirits oft walk in death , Speak of it .

English: Stay and speak !
Shakespearean: Stay and speak !

English: Keep it from leaving , Marcellus .
Shakespearean: Stop it , Marcellus .

English: Should I strike it with my spear ?
Shakespearean: Shall I strike at it with my partisan ?

English: Yes , if it doesn't stand still .
Shakespearean: Do , if it will not stand .

English: It's over here .
Shakespearean: Tis here .

English: There it is .
Shakespearean: Tis here .

English: It's gone .
Shakespearean: Tis gone .

English: It was about to say something when the rooster crowed .
Shakespearean: It was about to speak when the cock crew .

English: Perform the speech just as I taught you , musically and smoothly .
Shakespearean: Speak the speech , I pray you , as I pronounced it to you , trippingly on the tongue .

English: I hate it when I hear a blustery actor in a wig tear a passion to shreds , bursting everyone's eardrums so as to impress the audience on the lower levels of the playhouse , who for the most part can only appreciate loud noises and pantomime shows .
Shakespearean: Oh , it offends me to the soul to hear a robustious periwig-pated fellow tear a passion to tatters , to very rags , to split the ears of the groundlings , who for the most part are capable of nothing but inexplicable dumb-shows and noise .

English: I would whip a guy for making a tyrant sound too tyrannical .
Shakespearean: I would have such a fellow whipped for o'erdoing Termagant .

English: Please avoid doing that .
Shakespearean: Pray you , avoid it .

English: I will , sir .
Shakespearean: I warrant your honor .

English: But don't be too tame , either , let your good sense guide you .
Shakespearean: Be not too tame neither , but let your own discretion be your tutor .

English: I hope we've corrected that fault pretty well in our company , sir .
Shakespearean: I hope we have reformed that indifferently with us , sir .

English: Oh , correct it completely .
Shakespearean: O , reform it altogether !

English: Make sure that the clowns do not ad-lib , since some of them will make certain dumb audience members laugh mindlessly at them , while an important issue in the play needs to be addressed .
Shakespearean: And let those that play your clowns speak no more than is set down for them , for there be of them that will themselves laugh to set on some quantity of barren spectators to laugh too , though in the meantime some necessary question of the play be then to be considered .

English: Yes , he will , and the queen as well .
Shakespearean: And the queen too , and that presently .

English: Tell the actors to hurry .
Shakespearean: Bid the players make haste .

English: Will you two help them get ready ?
Shakespearean: Will you two help to hasten them ?

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my lord .

English: Well , hello there , Horatio !
Shakespearean: What ho , Horatio !

English: Here I am at your service , my dear lord .
Shakespearean: Here , sweet lord , at your service .

English: Horatio , you're the best man I've ever known .
Shakespearean: Horatio , thou art e'en as just a man As e'er my conversation coped withal .

English: Oh , sir , Don't think I'm flattering you .
Shakespearean: O my dear lord , Nay , do not think I flatter .

English: What could I hope to get from you , who've got nothing but your charm to support you in life ?
Shakespearean: For what advancement may I hope from thee That no revenue hast but thy good spirits , To feed and clothe thee ?

English: Why would anyone flatter a poor person ?
Shakespearean: Why should the poor be flattered ?

English: No , keep flattery for kissing the hands of those who can pay well .
Shakespearean: No , let the candied tongue lick absurd pomp , And crook the pregnant hinges of the knee Where thrift may follow fawning .

English: You understand ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou hear ?

English: Ever since I've been a free agent in my choice of friends , I've chosen you because you take everything life hands you with calm acceptance , grateful for both good and bad .
Shakespearean: Since my dear soul was mistress of her choice And could of men distinguish , her election Hath sealed thee for herself , for thou hast been , As one in suffering all that suffers nothing , A man that Fortune's buffets and rewards Hast ta'en with equal thanks .

English: Watch him closely .
Shakespearean: Give him heedful note .

English: They're coming .
Shakespearean: They are coming to the play .

English: I can't talk now .
Shakespearean: I must be idle .

English: Take your seat .
Shakespearean: Get you a place .

English: So how's my nephew Hamlet doing ?
Shakespearean: How fares our cousin Hamlet ?

English: Wonderful !
Shakespearean: Excellent , i ' faith , of the chameleon's dish .

English: I eat the air , like chameleons do .
Shakespearean: I eat the air , promise-crammed .

English: I'm positively stuffed with air , I eat so much of it .
Shakespearean: You can not feed capons so .

English: I have no idea what you're talking about , Hamlet .
Shakespearean: I have nothing with this answer , Hamlet .

English: You're not answering my question .
Shakespearean: These words are not mine .

English: Mine , neither .
Shakespearean: No , nor mine now .

English: Indeed I did , my lord .
Shakespearean: That did I , my lord , and was accounted a good actor .

English: What role did you play ?
Shakespearean: What did you enact ?

English: I played Julius Caesar .
Shakespearean: I did enact Julius Caesar .

English: I was killed in the Capitol .
Shakespearean: I was killed i ' th ' Capitol .

English: Brutus killed me .
Shakespearean: Brutus killed me .

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my lord .

English: They're ready whenever you are .
Shakespearean: They stay upon your patience .

English: No thanks , my good mother .
Shakespearean: No , good mother .

English: There's a nicer piece of work right here .
Shakespearean: Here's metal more attractive .

English: My lady , should I lie in your lap ?
Shakespearean: Lady , shall I lie in your lap ?

English: No , my lord .
Shakespearean: No , my lord .

English: I mean , with my head in your lap ?
Shakespearean: I mean , my head upon your lap ?

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my lord .

English: Did you think I was talking about sex ?
Shakespearean: Do you think I meant country matters ?

English: What is , my lord ?
Shakespearean: What is , my lord ?

English: Nothing .
Shakespearean: Nothing .

English: You're in a good mood tonight , my lord .
Shakespearean: You are merry , my lord .

English: Who , me ?
Shakespearean: Who , I ?

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my lord .

English: Oh God , who is , by the way , the best comic of them all .
Shakespearean: O God , your only jig-maker .

English: What can you do but be happy ?
Shakespearean: What should a man do but be merry ?

English: Look how cheerful my mother is , only two hours after my father died .
Shakespearean: For , look you , how cheerfully my mother looks , and my father died within these two hours .

English: No , my lord , it's been four months .
Shakespearean: Nay , 'tis twice two months , my lord .

English: As long as that ?
Shakespearean: So long ?

English: I'll get myself a fur-trimmed suit .
Shakespearean: Nay then , let the devil wear black , for I'll have a suit of sables .

English: In that case , there's reason to hope a man's memory may outlive him by six months .
Shakespearean: Then there's hope a great man's memory may outlive his life half a year .

English: But he's got to build churches for that to happen , my lady , or else he'll have to put up with being forgotten , like the hobby-horse in the popular song that goes , "Heigh-ho , heigh-ho , the hobby-horse is forgotten." What does this mean , my lord ?
Shakespearean: But , by 'r Lady , he must build churches then , or else shall he suffer not thinking on , with the hobby-horse , whose epitaph is "For , oh , for , oh , the hobby-horse is forgot." What means this , my lord ?

English: This means we're having some mischievous fun .
Shakespearean: Marry , this is miching

English: This pantomime was probably a summary of the play .
Shakespearean: Belike this show imports the argument of the play .

English: This guy will tell us everything .
Shakespearean: We shall know by this fellow .

English: Actors can't keep a secret .
Shakespearean: The players can not keep counsel .

English: They'll tell all .
Shakespearean: They'll tell all .

English: Will he tell us what that pantomime meant ?
Shakespearean: Will he tell us what this show meant ?

English: Sure , or anything else you show him .
Shakespearean: Ay , or any show that you will show him .

English: As long as you aren't ashamed to show it , he won't be ashamed to tell you what it means .
Shakespearean: Be not you ashamed to show , he'll not shame to tell you what it means .

English: You're naughty .
Shakespearean: You are naught , you are naught .

English: I'm watching the play .
Shakespearean: I'll mark the play .

English: Was that the prologue or the inscription on some wedding ring ?
Shakespearean: Is this a prologue or the posy of a ring ?

English: It was a bit short , my lord .
Shakespearean: Tis brief , my lord .

English: Yes , as short as a woman's love .
Shakespearean: As woman's love .

English: Madam , how are you liking this play ?
Shakespearean: Madam , how like you this play ?

English: The lady's overdoing it , I think .
Shakespearean: The lady protests too much , methinks .

English: Oh , but she'll keep her word .
Shakespearean: Oh , but she'll keep her word .

English: Is there anything offensive in it ?
Shakespearean: Is there no offense in 't ?

English: Not offensive at all .
Shakespearean: No offense i ' th ' world .

English: What's the play called ?
Shakespearean: What do you call the play ?

English: Yes , it faded away when the rooster crowed .
Shakespearean: It faded on the crowing of the cock .

English: Don't you agree that we owe it to him to tell him about this , out of duty and love ?
Shakespearean: Do you consent we shall acquaint him with it , As needful in our loves , fitting our duty ?

English: I could even supply the dialogue between you and your lover if you did your little puppet show of love for me .
Shakespearean: I could interpret between you and your love , if I could see the puppets dallying .

English: We're all waiting for the revenge !
Shakespearean: Come , "The croaking raven doth bellow for revenge , "

English: The original story was written in the finest Italian .
Shakespearean: The story is extant , and writ in choice Italian .

English: You'll see shortly how the murderer wins the love of Gonzago's wife .
Shakespearean: You shall see anon how the murderer gets the love of Gonzago's wife .

English: The king is getting up .
Shakespearean: The king rises .

English: What , is he scared of a gun that only fired a blank ?
Shakespearean: What , frighted with false fire ?

English: My lord , how are you feeling ?
Shakespearean: How fares my lord ?

English: Get me out of here !
Shakespearean: Give me some light , away !

English: Lights , lights , get us some lights !
Shakespearean: Lights , lights , lights !

English: No , a whole share for me .
Shakespearean: A whole one , I .

English: Did you notice ?
Shakespearean: Didst perceive ?

English: Yes , I did , my lord .
Shakespearean: Very well , my lord .

English: When the actors were talking about poison ?
Shakespearean: Upon the talk of the poisoning ?

English: I watched him very closely .
Shakespearean: I did very well note him .

English: Ah ha !
Shakespearean: Ah ha !

English: Hey , let's have some music here !
Shakespearean: Come , some music !

English: Play your flutes !
Shakespearean: Come , the recorders !

English: Come on , music !
Shakespearean: Come , some music !

English: My lord , could I have a word with you ?
Shakespearean: Good my lord , vouchsafe me a word with you .

English: You can have a whole story , not just a word .
Shakespearean: Sir , a whole history .

English: Sir , the king , Yes , what about him ?
Shakespearean: The king , sir , Ay , sir , what of him ?

English: He's in his chambers now , and he's extremely upset .
Shakespearean: Is in his retirement marvelous distempered .

English: I'll be good , sir .
Shakespearean: I am tame , sir .

English: Go ahead .
Shakespearean: Pronounce .

English: The queen your mother is upset , and sent me to see you .
Shakespearean: The queen your mother , in most great affliction of spirit , hath sent me to you .

English: It's lovely to see you .
Shakespearean: You are welcome .

English: No , my lord , your polite words are not to the point .
Shakespearean: Nay , good my lord , this courtesy is not of the right breed .

English: If you could please stop fooling around , I'll tell you what your mother wants .
Shakespearean: If it shall please you to make me a wholesome answer , I will do your mother's commandment .

English: If not , I'll leave you alone and that'll be the end of my business .
Shakespearean: If not , your pardon and my return shall be the end of my business .

English: Sir , I can't .
Shakespearean: Sir , I can not .

English: Can't what , my lord ?
Shakespearean: What , my lord ?

English: Stop fooling around .
Shakespearean: Make you a wholesome answer .

English: My mind is confused .
Shakespearean: My wit's diseased .

English: Okay , to the point .
Shakespearean: Therefore no more but to the matter .

English: Oh , what a wonderful son , I can impress my mother !
Shakespearean: O wonderful son that can so 'stonish a mother !

English: But what's the upshot of her admiration ?
Shakespearean: But is there no sequel at the heels of this mother's admiration ?

English: Do tell .
Shakespearean: Impart .

English: She wants to have a word with you in her bedroom before you go to bed .
Shakespearean: She desires to speak with you in her closet ere you go to bed .

English: I'd obey even if she were my mother ten times over .
Shakespearean: We shall obey , were she ten times our mother .

English: Is there anything else I can do for you ?
Shakespearean: Have you any further trade with us ?

English: My lord , you used to like me .
Shakespearean: My lord , you once did love me .

English: And still do , I swear by my hands .
Shakespearean: And do still , by these pickers and stealers .

English: My lord , what's wrong with you ?
Shakespearean: Good my lord , what is your cause of distemper ?

English: Sir , I have no future ahead of me .
Shakespearean: Sir , I lack advancement .

English: But how can you say that , when the king himself says you're the heir to the Danish throne ?
Shakespearean: How can that be , when you have the voice of the king himself for your succession in Denmark ?

English: I don't really understand what you mean .
Shakespearean: I do not well understand that .

English: Will you play this recorder ?
Shakespearean: Will you play upon this pipe ?

English: I can't , my lord .
Shakespearean: My lord , I can not .

English: Please .
Shakespearean: I pray you .

English: I'm serious , I can't .
Shakespearean: Believe me , I can not .

English: I'm begging you .
Shakespearean: I do beseech you .

English: I have no idea how .
Shakespearean: I know no touch of it , my lord .

English: Oh , it's as easy as lying .
Shakespearean: It is as easy as lying .

English: But I can't play a melody .
Shakespearean: But these can not I command to any utterance of harmony .

English: I don't know how .
Shakespearean: You would seem to know my stops .

English: My God , do you think I'm easier to manipulate than a pipe ?
Shakespearean: Sblood , do you think I am easier to be played on than a pipe ?

English: You can push my buttons , but you can't play me for a fool .
Shakespearean: Call me what instrument you will , though you can fret me , yet you can not play upon me .

English: Hello and God bless you , sir .
Shakespearean: God bless you , sir .

English: My lord , the queen wants to speak with you right away .
Shakespearean: My lord , the queen would speak with you , and presently .

English: Do you see that cloud up there that looks like a camel ?
Shakespearean: Do you see yonder cloud that's almost in shape of a camel ?

English: By God , it does look like a camel .
Shakespearean: By th ' mass , and 'tis like a camel indeed .

English: To me it looks like a weasel .
Shakespearean: Methinks it is like a weasel .

English: It does have a back like a weasel's .
Shakespearean: It is backed like a weasel .

English: Or like a whale .
Shakespearean: Or like a whale .

English: Yes , very much like a whale .
Shakespearean: Very like a whale .

English: I'll go see my mother soon .
Shakespearean: Then I will come to my mother by and by .

English: I'll tell her .
Shakespearean: I will say so .

English: This is the time of night when witches come out , when graveyards yawn open and the stench of hell seeps out .
Shakespearean: Tis now the very witching time of night , When churchyards yawn and hell itself breathes out Contagion to this world .

English: I could drink hot blood and do such terrible deeds that people would tremble even in the daylight .
Shakespearean: Now could I drink hot blood And do such bitter business as the bitter day Would quake to look on .

English: I'll speak as sharp as a dagger to her , but I won't use one on her .
Shakespearean: I will speak daggers to her but use none .

English: And so , my words and thoughts will be at odds .
Shakespearean: My tongue and soul in this be hypocrites .

English: I don't like the way he's acting , and it's not safe for me to let his insanity get out of control .
Shakespearean: I like him not , nor stands it safe with us To let his madness range .

English: So get prepared .
Shakespearean: Therefore prepare you .

English: I'm sending you to England on diplomatic business , and Hamlet will go with you .
Shakespearean: I your commission will forthwith dispatch , And he to England shall along with you .

English: As king , I can not risk the danger he represents as he grows crazier by the hour .
Shakespearean: The terms of our estate may not endure Hazard so dangerous as doth hourly grow Out of his lunacies .

English: We'll take care of it .
Shakespearean: We will ourselves provide .

English: When a great leader dies he doesn't die alone but , like a whirlpool , draws others with him .
Shakespearean: The cease of majesty Dies not alone , but , like a gulf , doth draw What's near it with it .

English: He's like a huge wheel on the top of the highest mountain whose spokes touch the rim of ten thousand smaller things , when it falls down the mountain , every little object goes down with it .
Shakespearean: It is a massy wheel Fixed on the summit of the highest mount , To whose huge spokes ten thousand lesser things Are mortised and adjoined , which , when it falls , Each small annexment , petty consequence , Attends the boisterous ruin .

English: Whenever a king sighs , everyone groans .
Shakespearean: Never alone Did the king sigh , but with a general groan .

English: Prepare yourself , please , for this trip .
Shakespearean: Arm you , I pray you , to this speedy voyage .

English: We'll put a leash on this danger that's now running wild .
Shakespearean: For we will fetters put upon this fear , Which now goes too free-footed .

English: We'll hurry .
Shakespearean: We will haste us .

English: My lord , Hamlet's going to his mother's room .
Shakespearean: My lord , he's going to his mother's closet .

English: Very humid , I can't tell you how humid it is .
Shakespearean: It is very sultry , as 'twere , I can not tell how .

English: My lord , His Majesty wanted me to tell you that he's placed a large bet on you .
Shakespearean: My lord , his majesty bade me signify to you that he has laid a great wager on your head .

English: This is what it's all about , Please , I beg you , No , my lord , I'm comfortable like this , thank you .
Shakespearean: Sir , this is the matter , I beseech you , remember , Nay , good my lord , for mine ease , in good faith .

English: Sir , your description of him doesn't detract from his good qualities , though I know that trying to list them all would make your head spin , and even so you wouldn't be able to keep up with him .
Shakespearean: Sir , his definement suffers no perdition in you , though I know to divide him inventorially would dizzy th ' arithmetic of memory , and yet but yaw neither , in respect of his quick sail .

English: I felt like skipping school , sir .
Shakespearean: A truant disposition , good my lord .

English: I wouldn't allow your enemies to say that , and I won't believe it from you .
Shakespearean: I would not hear your enemy say so , Nor shall you do mine ear that violence , To make it truster of your own report Against yourself .

English: I know you'd never skip school .
Shakespearean: I know you are no truant .

English: What are you doing here in Elsinore ?
Shakespearean: But what is your affair in Elsinore ?

English: I'll teach you to drink hard by the time you leave .
Shakespearean: We'll teach you to drink deep ere you depart .

English: Sir , we came to see your father's funeral .
Shakespearean: My lord , I came to see your father's funeral .

English: Please , don't make fun of me .
Shakespearean: I pray thee , do not mock me , fellow student .

English: I think you came to see my mother's wedding instead .
Shakespearean: I think it was to see my mother's wedding .

English: Well , sir , it's true it came soon after .
Shakespearean: Indeed , my lord , it followed hard upon .

English: The leftovers from the funeral dinner made a convenient wedding banquet .
Shakespearean: The funeral baked meats Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables .

English: Oh , I'd rather have met my fiercest enemy in heaven , Horatio , than have lived through that terrible day !
Shakespearean: Would I had met my dearest foe in heaven Or ever I had seen that day , Horatio .

English: My father , I think I see my father .
Shakespearean: My father , methinks I see my father .

English: Where , sir ?
Shakespearean: Where , my lord ?

English: In my imagination , Horatio .
Shakespearean: In my mind's eye , Horatio .

English: I saw him once .
Shakespearean: I saw him once .

English: He was an admirable king .
Shakespearean: He was a goodly king .

English: He was a great human being .
Shakespearean: He was a man .

English: He was perfect in everything .
Shakespearean: Take him for all in all .

English: I'll never see the likes of him again .
Shakespearean: I shall not look upon his like again .

English: You speak absolutely correctly , sir .
Shakespearean: Your lordship speaks most infallibly of him .

English: And what's the point , sir ?
Shakespearean: The concernancy , sir ?

English: Why are we talking about him like this ?
Shakespearean: Why do we wrap the gentleman in our more rawer breath ?

English: Sorry , sir ?
Shakespearean: Sir ?

English: I know you know something , Thanks for the compliment , I'm happy you know that .
Shakespearean: I know you are not ignorant , I would you did , sir .

English: But in fact it doesn't say much .
Shakespearean: Yet in faith , if you did , it would not much approve me .

English: I'm sorry , you were saying ?
Shakespearean: Well , sir ?

English: I know you know something about how excellent Laertes is ,
Shakespearean: You are not ignorant of what excellence Laertes is ,

English: I can't admit that , since you'd have to compare his excellence to mine .
Shakespearean: I dare not confess that lest I should compare with him in excellence , but to know a man well were to know himself .

English: Excellent in fencing , I mean , sir .
Shakespearean: I mean , sir , for his weapon .

English: The rapier and the dagger .
Shakespearean: Rapier and dagger .

English: Those are only two of his weapons .
Shakespearean: That's two of his weapons .

English: But , go on .
Shakespearean: But well .

English: The king has bet six Barbary horses , and he has prepared six French rapiers and daggers with all their accessories .
Shakespearean: The king , sir , hath wagered with him six Barbary horses , against the which he has impawned , as I take it , six French rapiers and poniards with their assigns , as girdle , hangers , and so .

English: Three of the carriages are very imaginatively designed , and they match the fencing accessories .
Shakespearean: Three of the carriages , in faith , are very dear to fancy , very responsive to the hilts , most delicate carriages , and of very liberal conceit .

English: What do you mean by "carriages" ?
Shakespearean: What call you the carriages ?

English: The carriages , sir , are the hangers , where the swords hang .
Shakespearean: The carriages , sir , are the hangers .

English: Carriage" makes it sound like it's pulling around a cannon .
Shakespearean: The phrase would be more germane to the matter if we could carry cannon by our sides .

English: I prefer to call it a "hanger." But anyway .
Shakespearean: I would it might be hangers till then .

English: Six Barbary horses , six French swords with accessories , and three imaginatively designed carriages , sounds like a French bet against the Danish .
Shakespearean: But , on : six Barbary horses against six French swords , their assigns , and three liberal-conceited carriages , that's the French bet against the Danish .

English: Why has all this been put on the table ?
Shakespearean: Why is this "impawned , " as you call it ?

English: The king , sir , has bet that in a dozen rounds between you and Laertes , he won't beat you by more than three hits .
Shakespearean: The king , sir , hath laid that in a dozen passes between yourself and him , he shall not exceed you three hits .

English: But what if my answer's no ?
Shakespearean: How if I answer "No" ?

English: It's my exercise time .
Shakespearean: If it please His Majesty , 'tis the breathing time of day with me .

English: My services are at your command .
Shakespearean: I commend my duty to your lordship .

English: Thank you .
Shakespearean: Yours , yours .

English: It's a good thing he's here to recommend himself .
Shakespearean: He does well to commend it himself .

English: No one else would .
Shakespearean: There are no tongues else for 's turn .

English: He used to praise his mother's nipple before he sucked it .
Shakespearean: He did comply , sir , with his dug before he sucked it .

English: The king wishes to know if you want to play against him right away , or wait awhile .
Shakespearean: He sends to know if your pleasure hold to play with Laertes , or that you will take longer time .

English: I'll do whatever the king wants .
Shakespearean: I am constant to my purpose .

English: If he's ready now , so am I .
Shakespearean: They follow the king's pleasure .

English: Otherwise , I'll do it anytime , as long as I'm able .
Shakespearean: If his fitness speaks , mine is ready , now or whensoever , provided I be so able as now .

English: The king and queen are coming down with everyone else .
Shakespearean: The king and queen and all are coming down .

English: Right on cue .
Shakespearean: In happy time .

English: The queen wants you to chat with Laertes , politely , before you begin your match .
Shakespearean: The queen desires you to use some gentle entertainment to Laertes before you fall to play .

English: She's full of good advice .
Shakespearean: She well instructs me .

English: You're going to lose this bet , my lord .
Shakespearean: You will lose this wager , my lord .

English: I don't think so .
Shakespearean: I do not think so .

English: I've been practicing fencing constantly since he went off to France .
Shakespearean: Since he went into France , I have been in continual practice .

English: With the handicap they've given me , I think I'll win .
Shakespearean: I shall win at the odds .

English: But I have a sinking feeling anyway .
Shakespearean: But thou wouldst not think how ill all's here about my heart .

English: Oh well .
Shakespearean: But it is no matter .

English: I'll say you're not feeling well .
Shakespearean: I will forestall their repair hither and say you are not fit .

English: You'll do no such thing .
Shakespearean: Not a whit .

English: I thumb my nose at superstitions .
Shakespearean: We defy augury .

English: What's important is to be prepared .
Shakespearean: If it be not to come , it will be now .

English: Since nobody knows anything about what he leaves behind , then what does it mean to leave early ?
Shakespearean: Since no man of aught he leaves knows , what is 't to leave betimes ?

English: Let it be .
Shakespearean: Let be .

English: Come shake hands with Laertes , Hamlet .
Shakespearean: Come , Hamlet , come , and take this hand from me .

English: I will accept no apology until experts in matters of honor show me how to make peace with you without staining my own reputation in doing so .
Shakespearean: But in my terms of honor I stand aloof , and will no reconcilement Till by some elder masters , of known honor , I have a voice and precedent of peace To keep my name ungored .

English: Yes , hand me one too .
Shakespearean: Come , one for me .

English: I'm going to make you look sharp , Laertes .
Shakespearean: I'll be your foil , Laertes .

English: You're making fun of me .
Shakespearean: You mock me , sir .

English: No , I swear I'm not .
Shakespearean: No , by this hand .

English: Yes , my lord , quite well .
Shakespearean: Very well , my lord .

English: You've bet on the weaker fencer .
Shakespearean: Your grace hath laid the odds o ' th ' weaker side .

English: I've seen both of you fence .
Shakespearean: I have seen you both .

English: But since Laertes is better , we've given him a handicap .
Shakespearean: But since he is better we have therefore odds .

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my good lord .

English: Put the goblets of wine on that table .
Shakespearean: Set me the stoups of wine upon that table .

English: If Hamlet makes the first or second hit , or gets back at Laertes by making the third hit , then let my soldiers give him a military salute .
Shakespearean: If Hamlet give the first or second hit Or quit in answer of the third exchange , Let all the battlements their ordnance fire !

English: I'll drink to Hamlet's health , and into his goblet I'll drop a pearl even more costly than those in the crowns of the last four Danish kings .
Shakespearean: The king shall drink to Hamlet's better breath , And in the cup an union shall he throw Richer than that which four successive kings In Denmark's crown have worn .

English: Give me the goblets .
Shakespearean: Give me the cups .

English: Come on , sir .
Shakespearean: Come on , sir .

English: Come on , my lord .
Shakespearean: Come , my lord .

English: That was one hit .
Shakespearean: One .

English: No , it wasn't .
Shakespearean: No .

English: Referee !
Shakespearean: Judgment ?

English: It was obviously a hit .
Shakespearean: A hit , a very palpable hit .

English: Well , let's go on .
Shakespearean: Well , again .

English: Give me a goblet. , Hamlet , this pearl's yours .
Shakespearean: Stay , give me drink. , Hamlet , this pearl is thine .

English: Here's to your health .
Shakespearean: Here's to thy health .

English: Give him the goblet .
Shakespearean: Give him the cup .

English: Set it down awhile .
Shakespearean: Set it by a while .

English: Let's play .
Shakespearean: Come .

English: Another hit .
Shakespearean: Another hit .

English: What do you say ?
Shakespearean: What say you ?

English: You got me , I admit it .
Shakespearean: A touch , a touch , I do confess 't .

English: My son will win .
Shakespearean: Our son shall win .

English: He's flabby and out of breath. , Here , Hamlet , take my handkerchief and wipe your forehead .
Shakespearean: He's fat , and scant of breath. , Here , Hamlet , take my napkin , rub thy brows .

English: The queen drinks to your good luck and happiness , Hamlet .
Shakespearean: The queen carouses to thy fortune , Hamlet .

English: Thank you , madam .
Shakespearean: Good madam .

English: Gertrude , don't drink that .
Shakespearean: Gertrude , do not drink .

English: Excuse me .
Shakespearean: I will , my lord .

English: I'll drink it if I like .
Shakespearean: I pray you , pardon me .

English: I'd better not drink now .
Shakespearean: I dare not drink yet , madam .

English: I'll drink later .
Shakespearean: By and by .

English: Come on , let me wipe your face .
Shakespearean: Come , let me wipe thy face .

English: I doubt it .
Shakespearean: I do not think 't .

English: Get ready for the third hit , Laertes .
Shakespearean: Come , for the third , Laertes .

English: You're just playing around .
Shakespearean: You do but dally .

English: Come on , give me your best shot .
Shakespearean: I pray you , pass with your best violence .

English: I sense you're treating me like a child .
Shakespearean: I am afeard you make a wanton of me .

English: You think so ?
Shakespearean: Say you so ?

English: Come on .
Shakespearean: Come on .

English: Take this !
Shakespearean: Have at you now !

English: Separate them .
Shakespearean: Part them !

English: They're overdoing it .
Shakespearean: They are incensed .

English: No , come on , one more time .
Shakespearean: Nay , come , again .

English: Take care of the queen !
Shakespearean: Look to the queen there , ho !

English: Both fencers are bleeding , how do you feel , my lord ?
Shakespearean: They bleed on both sides. , How is it , my lord ?

English: How do you feel , Laertes ?
Shakespearean: How is 't , Laertes ?

English: Like a mouse caught in my own trap , Osric .
Shakespearean: Why , as a woodcock to mine own springe , Osric .

English: How's the queen ?
Shakespearean: How does the queen ?

English: She fainted at the sight of them bleeding .
Shakespearean: She swoons to see them bleed .

English: The drink , the drink !
Shakespearean: The drink , the drink !

English: I've been poisoned .
Shakespearean: I am poisoned .

English: Oh , what evil !
Shakespearean: O villainy !

English: Lock the door .
Shakespearean: Ho , let the door be locked .

English: We've been betrayed !
Shakespearean: Treachery !

English: Find out who did it !
Shakespearean: Seek it out .

English: I'm the one , Hamlet .
Shakespearean: It is here , Hamlet .

English: Hamlet , you're dead .
Shakespearean: Hamlet , thou art slain .

English: No medicine in the world can cure you .
Shakespearean: No medicine in the world can do thee good .

English: You don't have more than half an hour to live .
Shakespearean: In thee there is not half an hour of life .

English: The treacherous weapon is right in your hand , sharp and dipped in poison .
Shakespearean: The treacherous instrument is in thy hand , Unbated and envenomed .

English: The foul plan backfired on me .
Shakespearean: The foul practice Hath turned itself on me .

English: Here I lie and will never get up again .
Shakespearean: Lo , here I lie , Never to rise again .

English: Your mother's been poisoned .
Shakespearean: Thy mother's poisoned .

English: I can't speak anymore .
Shakespearean: I can no more .

English: The king , the king's to blame .
Shakespearean: The king , the king's to blame .

English: Then get to work , poison !
Shakespearean: The point envenomed too ! , Then , venom , to thy work .

English: Sir , I think I saw him last night .
Shakespearean: My lord , I think I saw him yesternight .

English: Saw who ?
Shakespearean: Saw who ?

English: The king my father ? !
Shakespearean: The king my father ? !

English: Just listen carefully while I tell you the amazing thing I saw , with these gentlemen as witnesses .
Shakespearean: Season your admiration for a while With an attent ear , till I may deliver , Upon the witness of these gentlemen , This marvel to you .

English: For God's sake , let me hear it .
Shakespearean: For God's love , let me hear .

English: After midnight , for two nights running , these two guards , Marcellus and Barnardo , saw a figure that looked very much like your father , in full armor from head to toe .
Shakespearean: Two nights together had these gentlemen , Marcellus and Barnardo , on their watch , In the dead waste and middle of the night , Been thus encountered : a figure like your father , Armed at point exactly , cap-a-pie , Appears before them and with solemn march Goes slow and stately by them .

English: It just appeared before them and marched past them with slow dignity three times , a staff's distance from their amazed eyes , while they turned , quaking with fear and too shocked to speak .
Shakespearean: Thrice he walked By their oppressed and fear-surprised eyes Within his truncheon's length , whilst they , distilled Almost to jelly with the act of fear , Stand dumb and speak not to him .

English: I knew your father .
Shakespearean: I knew your father .

English: But where did this happen ?
Shakespearean: But where was this ?

English: Treason !
Shakespearean: Treason !

English: Treason !
Shakespearean: Treason !

English: Protect me , my friends .
Shakespearean: O , yet defend me , friends .

English: I've only been hurt , not killed .
Shakespearean: I am but hurt .

English: Here , you goddamn incest-breeding Danish murderer , drink this .
Shakespearean: Here , thou incestuous , murderous , damned Dane , Drink off this potion .

English: Is your little pearl in there ?
Shakespearean: Is thy union here ?

English: Follow my mother .
Shakespearean: Follow my mother .

English: He got what he deserved .
Shakespearean: He is justly served .

English: He mixed that poison himself .
Shakespearean: It is a poison tempered by himself .

English: Please forgive me as I forgive you , Hamlet .
Shakespearean: Exchange forgiveness with me , noble Hamlet .

English: You're not responsible for my death and my father's , and I'm not responsible for yours .
Shakespearean: Mine and my father's death come not upon thee , Nor thine on me .

English: God will free you from blame .
Shakespearean: Heaven make thee free of it .

English: You're alive .
Shakespearean: Thou livest .

English: Not for a second .
Shakespearean: Never believe it .

English: I'm more like an ancient Roman than a corrupt modern Dane .
Shakespearean: I am more an antique Roman than a Dane .

English: Some of this liquor's still left in the goblet .
Shakespearean: Here's yet some liquor left .

English: Please , give me that goblet , if you love me .
Shakespearean: As thou'rt a man , Give me the cup .

English: Let go of it !
Shakespearean: Let go !

English: I'll get it from you , I swear .
Shakespearean: By heaven , I'll have 't .

English: Oh God , Horatio , what a damaged reputation I'm leaving behind me , as no one knows the truth .
Shakespearean: O God , Horatio , what a wounded name , Things standing thus unknown , shall live behind me !

English: If you ever loved me , then please postpone the sweet relief of death awhile , and stay in this harsh world long enough to tell my story .
Shakespearean: If thou didst ever hold me in thy heart Absent thee from felicity a while , And in this harsh world draw thy breath in pain To tell my story .

English: What are these warlike noises ?
Shakespearean: What warlike noise is this ?

English: Young Fortinbras , returning in triumph from Poland , is firing his guns to greet the English ambassadors .
Shakespearean: Young Fortinbras , with conquest come from Poland , To th ' ambassadors of England gives This warlike volley .

English: Oh , I'm dying , Horatio !
Shakespearean: O , I die , Horatio .

English: This strong poison's overpowering me .
Shakespearean: The potent poison quite o'ercrows my spirit .

English: I will not live to hear the news from England .
Shakespearean: I can not live to hear the news from England .

English: But I bet Fortinbras will win the election to the Danish crown .
Shakespearean: But I do prophesy the election lights On Fortinbras .

English: He's got my vote as I die .
Shakespearean: He has my dying voice .

English: Oh , oh , oh , oh .
Shakespearean: O , O , O , O .

English: What do I see here ?
Shakespearean: Where is this sight ?

English: What would you like to see ?
Shakespearean: What is it ye would see ?

English: These corpses suggest mayhem .
Shakespearean: This quarry cries on havoc .

English: Oh , proud Death , what banquet are you preparing that you've needed to knock off so many princes at one stroke ?
Shakespearean: O proud death , What feast is toward in thine eternal cell , That thou so many princes at a shot So bloodily hast struck ?

English: This is a horrible sight .
Shakespearean: The sight is dismal , And our affairs from England come too late .

English: We meant to tell the king that his orders have been carried out , and Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead .
Shakespearean: The ears are senseless that should give us hearing , To tell him his commandment is fulfilled , That Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead .

English: Who will thank us now ?
Shakespearean: Had it th ' ability of life to thank you .

English: As for me , I welcome my good luck with sadness .
Shakespearean: For me , with sorrow I embrace my fortune .

English: Let four captains carry Hamlet like a soldier onto the stage .
Shakespearean: Let four captains Bear Hamlet like a soldier to the stage , For he was likely , had he been put on , To have proved most royally .

English: Military music and military rites will speak for his heroic qualities .
Shakespearean: And , for his passage , The soldiers ' music and the rites of war Speak loudly for him .

English: Pick up the corpses .
Shakespearean: Take up the bodies .

English: On the platform where we stand guard , sir .
Shakespearean: My lord , upon the platform where we watch .

English: Didn't you talk to it ?
Shakespearean: Did you not speak to it ?

English: I did , sir , but it didn't answer me .
Shakespearean: My lord , I did , But answer made it none .

English: That's very strange .
Shakespearean: Tis very strange .

English: I swear to God it's true , sir .
Shakespearean: As I do live , my honored lord , 'tis true .

English: We thought you ought to know about it .
Shakespearean: And we did think it writ down in our duty To let you know of it .

English: Yes , I should know , but it disturbs me .
Shakespearean: Indeed , indeed , sirs , but this troubles me .

English: Are you on duty again tonight ?
Shakespearean: Hold you the watch tonight ?

English: Yes , sir .
Shakespearean: We do , my lord .

English: It was armed , you say ?
Shakespearean: Armed , say you ?

English: Armed , sir .
Shakespearean: Armed , my lord .

English: From head to toe ?
Shakespearean: From top to toe ?

English: Yes , from top to bottom , sir .
Shakespearean: My lord , from head to foot .

English: So you couldn't see his face , then ?
Shakespearean: Then saw you not his face ?

English: Oh , yes , we could , sir .
Shakespearean: Oh yes , my lord .

English: He had his helmet visor up .
Shakespearean: He wore his beaver up .

English: Was he pale or flushed and red-faced ?
Shakespearean: Pale or red ?

English: Very pale , sir .
Shakespearean: Nay , very pale .

English: Did he stare at you ?
Shakespearean: And fixed his eyes upon you ?

English: The whole time .
Shakespearean: Most constantly .

English: I wish I'd been there .
Shakespearean: I would I had been there .

English: Did it stay a long time ?
Shakespearean: Stayed it long ?

English: About as long as it would take someone to count slowly to a hundred .
Shakespearean: While one with moderate haste might tell a hundred .

English: No , longer than that .
Shakespearean: Longer , longer .

English: Not the time I saw it .
Shakespearean: Not when I saw 't .

English: His beard was gray , right ?
Shakespearean: His beard was grizzled , no ?

English: It was just like in real life , dark brown with silver whiskers in it .
Shakespearean: It was , as I have seen it in his life , A sable silvered .

English: I'll stand guard with you tonight .
Shakespearean: I will watch tonight .

English: Maybe it'll come again .
Shakespearean: Perchance 'Twill walk again .

English: I bet it will .
Shakespearean: I warrant it will .

English: If it looks like my good father , I'll speak to it , even if Hell itself opens up and tells me to be quiet .
Shakespearean: If it assume my noble father's person , I'll speak to it , though Hell itself should gape And bid me hold my peace .

English: I ask you , if you've kept this a secret , keep doing so .
Shakespearean: I pray you all , If you have hitherto concealed this sight , Let it be tenable in your silence still .

English: Whatever happens tonight , don't talk about it .
Shakespearean: And whatsoever else shall hap tonight , Give it an understanding , but no tongue .

English: I'll return the favor .
Shakespearean: I will requite your loves .

English: So good-bye for now .
Shakespearean: So fare you well .

English: I'll see you on the guards ' platform between eleven and twelve tonight .
Shakespearean: Upon the platform , 'twixt eleven and twelve , I'll visit you .

English: We'll do our duty to you , sir .
Shakespearean: Our duty to your honor .

English: Give me your love instead , as I give you mine .
Shakespearean: Your loves , as mine to you .

English: Good-bye .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: My father's ghost , armed !
Shakespearean: My father's spirit in arms .

English: Something's wrong .
Shakespearean: All is not well .

English: I suspect some foul play .
Shakespearean: I doubt some foul play .

English: I wish the night were here already !
Shakespearean: Would the night were come !

English: Until then , I have to remain calm .
Shakespearean: Till then sit still , my soul .

English: Bad deeds will be revealed , no matter how people try to hide them .
Shakespearean: Foul deeds will rise , Though all the earth o'erwhelm them , to men's eyes .

English: My belongings are on the ship already .
Shakespearean: My necessaries are embarked .

English: Good-bye .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: And , my dear sister , as long as the winds are blowing and ships are sailing , let me hear from you , write .
Shakespearean: And , sister , as the winds give benefit And convey is assistant , do not sleep , But let me hear from you .

English: Do you doubt I'll write ?
Shakespearean: Do you doubt that ?

English: As for Hamlet and his attentions to you , just consider it a big flirtation , the temporary phase of a hot-blooded youth .
Shakespearean: For Hamlet and the trifling of his favor , Hold it a fashion and a toy in blood , A violet in the youth of primy nature , Forward , not permanent , sweet , not lasting , The perfume and suppliance of a minute .

English: It won't last .
Shakespearean: No more .

English: Not a second more .
Shakespearean: No more but so ?

English: No more than a minute ?
Shakespearean: Think it no more .

English: Then think about how shameful it would be for you to give in to his seductive talk and surrender your treasure chest to his greedy hands .
Shakespearean: Then weigh what loss your honor may sustain If with too credent ear you list his songs , Or lose your heart , or your chaste treasure open To his unmastered importunity .

English: Watch out , Ophelia .
Shakespearean: Fear it , Ophelia .

English: Just keep your love under control , and don't let yourself become a target of his lust .
Shakespearean: Fear it , my dear sister , And keep you in the rear of your affection , Out of the shot and danger of desire .

English: Baby blooms are most susceptible to disease .
Shakespearean: And in the morn and liquid dew of youth , Contagious blastments are most imminent .

English: So be careful .
Shakespearean: Be wary , then .

English: Fear will keep you safe .
Shakespearean: Best safety lies in fear .

English: Young people often lose their self-control even without any help from others .
Shakespearean: Youth to itself rebels , though none else near .

English: I'll keep your words of wisdom close to my heart .
Shakespearean: I shall the effect of this good lesson keep As watchman to my heart .

English: Don't worry , I won't .
Shakespearean: O , fear me not .

English: I've been here too long .
Shakespearean: I stay too long .

English: And here comes father .
Shakespearean: But here my father comes .

English: You're still here ?

Shakespearean: Let me not burst in ignorance , but tell Why thy canonized bones , hearsed in death , Have burst their cerements ; why the sepulcher ,

Shakespearean: But that I am forbid To tell the secrets of my prison house , I could a tale unfold whose lightest word Would harrow up thy soul , freeze thy young blood ,

Shakespearean: I am sorry that with better heed and judgment I had not quoted him .

English: I thought he was just toying with you and meant to ruin your reputation .
Shakespearean: I feared he did but trifle And meant to wreck thee .

English: Damn my suspicious thoughts !
Shakespearean: But beshrew my jealousy !

English: It's as common for us old people to assume we know more than we do as for young people to be too wild and crazy .
Shakespearean: By heaven , it is as proper to our age To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions As it is common for the younger sort To lack discretion .

English: Come on , let's go see the king .
Shakespearean: Come , go we to the king .

English: Welcome , dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern .
Shakespearean: Welcome , dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern .

English: I've wanted to see you for a long time now , but I sent for you so hastily because I need your help right away .
Shakespearean: Moreover that we much did long to see you , The need we have to use you did provoke Our hasty sending .

English: You've probably heard about the "change" that's come over Hamlet , that's the only word for it , since inside and out he's different from what he was before .
Shakespearean: Something have you heard Of Hamlet's "transformation" , so call it Since nor th ' exterior nor the inward man Resembles that it was .

English: I can't imagine what's made him so unlike himself , other than his father's death .
Shakespearean: What it should be , More than his father's death , that thus hath put him So much from th ' understanding of himself , I can not dream of .

English: Both you and the king might have ordered us to execute your command , instead of asking us so politely .
Shakespearean: Both your majesties Might , by the sovereign power you have of us , Put your dread pleasures more into command Than to entreaty .

English: But we'll obey .
Shakespearean: But we both obey And here give up ourselves , in the full bent , To lay our service freely at your feet To be commanded .

English: Thanks , Rosencrantz and worthy Guildenstern .
Shakespearean: Thanks , Rosencrantz and gentle Guildenstern .

English: Thanks , Guildenstern and worthy Rosencrantz .
Shakespearean: Thanks , Guildenstern and gentle Rosencrantz .

English: I beg you to pay a visit right away to my son , who's changed too much .
Shakespearean: And I beseech you instantly to visit My too much changed son .

English: Servants , take these gentlemen to see Hamlet .
Shakespearean: Go , some of you , And bring these gentlemen where Hamlet is .

English: I hope to God we can make him happy and do him some good !
Shakespearean: Heavens make our presence and our practices Pleasant and helpful to him !

English: Amen to that !
Shakespearean: Ay , amen !

English: The ambassadors are back from Norway , sir .
Shakespearean: Th ' ambassadors from Norway , my good lord , Are joyfully returned .

English: Once again you bring good news .
Shakespearean: Thou still hast been the father of good news .

English: Do I , sir ?
Shakespearean: Have I , my lord ?

English: I assure your majesty I'm only doing my duty both to my God and my good king .
Shakespearean: I assure my good liege , I hold my duty as I hold my soul , Both to my God and to my gracious king .

English: It looks like you've offended it .
Shakespearean: It is offended .

English: Look , it's going away .
Shakespearean: See , it stalks away .

English: Stay !
Shakespearean: Stay !

English: I order you , speak !
Shakespearean: I charge thee , speak !

English: What's going on , Horatio ?
Shakespearean: How now , Horatio ?

English: You're pale and trembling .
Shakespearean: You tremble and look pale .

English: You agree now that we're not imagining this , don't you ?
Shakespearean: Is not this something more than fantasy ?

English: What do you think about it ?
Shakespearean: What think you on 't ?

English: I swear to God , if I hadn't seen this with my own eyes I'd never believe it .
Shakespearean: Before my God , I might not this believe Without the sensible and true avouch Of mine own eyes .

English: Doesn't it look like the king ?
Shakespearean: Is it not like the king ?

English: Yes , as much as you look like yourself .
Shakespearean: As thou art to thyself .

English: The king was wearing exactly this armor when he fought the king of Norway .
Shakespearean: Such was the very armour he had on When he the ambitious Norway combated .

English: And the ghost frowned just like the king did once when he attacked the Poles , traveling on the ice in sleds .
Shakespearean: So frowned he once when , in an angry parle , He smote the sledded Polacks on the ice .

English: It's weird .
Shakespearean: Tis strange .

English: And I believe , unless this brain of mine is not so politically cunning as it used to be , that I've found out why Hamlet's gone crazy .
Shakespearean: And I do think , or else this brain of mine Hunts not the trail of policy so sure As it hath used to do , that I have found The very cause of Hamlet's lunacy .

English: Tell me !
Shakespearean: Oh , speak of that .

English: I want very much to find out .
Shakespearean: That do I long to hear .

English: All right , but first let the ambassadors speak .
Shakespearean: Give first admittance to th ' ambassadors .

English: Then you can hear my news , as dessert .
Shakespearean: My news shall be the fruit to that great feast .

English: Then be so kind as to show them in .
Shakespearean: Thyself do grace to them , and bring them in .

English: Gertrude , he says he's found out the reason for your son's insanity .
Shakespearean: He tells me , my dear Gertrude , he hath found The head and source of all your son's distemper .

English: I doubt it's anything but the obvious reason : his father's dying and our quick marriage .
Shakespearean: I doubt it is no other but the main : His father's death and our o'erhasty marriage .

English: Welcome , my good friends .
Shakespearean: Well , we shall sift him. , Welcome , my good friends !

English: Tell me , Voltemand , what's the news from the king of Norway ?
Shakespearean: Say , Voltemand , what from our brother Norway ?

English: He was very upset that Fortinbras had taken advantage of his being old and sick to deceive him , and he ordered Fortinbras's arrest .
Shakespearean: Whereat grieved , That so his sickness , age , and impotence Was falsely borne in hand , sends out arrests On Fortinbras , which he , in brief , obeys , Receives rebuke from Norway , and in fine Makes vow before his uncle never more To give th ' assay of arms against your majesty .

English: Fortinbras swore never to threaten Denmark again .
Shakespearean: Whereon old Norway , overcome with joy ,

English: The old king was so overjoyed by this promise that he gave young Fortinbras an annual income of three thousand I like this news , and when I have time I'll read this and think about how to reply .
Shakespearean: Gives him three thousand crowns in annual fee And his commission to employ those soldiers , So levied as before , against the Polack , With an entreaty , herein further shown , That it might please you to give quiet pass Through your dominions for this enterprise , On such regards of safety and allowance As therein are set down .

English: Meanwhile , thank you for your efforts .
Shakespearean: Meantime we thank you for your well-took labor .

English: Go relax now .
Shakespearean: Go to your rest .

English: Tonight we'll have dinner .
Shakespearean: At night we'll feast together .

English: Welcome back !
Shakespearean: Most welcome home !

English: Well , that turned out well in the end .
Shakespearean: This business is well ended .

English: Sir and madam , to make grand speeches about what majesty is , what service is , or why day is day , night is night , and time is time is just a waste of a lot of day , night , and time .
Shakespearean: My liege and madam , to expostulate What majesty should be , what duty is , Why day is day , night night , and time is time , Were nothing but to waste night , day , and time .

English: Your son is crazy .
Shakespearean: Therefore , since brevity is the soul of wit And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes , I will be brief : your noble son is mad .

English: Crazy" I'm calling it , since how can you say what craziness is except to say that it's craziness ?
Shakespearean: Mad call I it , for , to define true madness , What is 't but to be nothing else but mad ?

English: But that's another story .
Shakespearean: But let that go .

English: Think about it .
Shakespearean: Thus it remains , and the remainder thus .

English: I have a daughter ( I have her until she gets married ) who's given me this letter , considering it her duty .
Shakespearean: I have a daughter , have while she is mine , Who in her duty and obedience , mark , Hath given me this .

English: Madam , please be patient .
Shakespearean: Good madam , stay a while .

English: I'll read it to you .
Shakespearean: I will be faithful .

English: Oh , Ophelia , I'm bad at poetry .
Shakespearean: O dear Ophelia , I am ill at these numbers .

English: I can't put my feelings into verse , but please believe I love you best , oh , best of all .
Shakespearean: I have not art to reckon my groans , but that I love thee best , oh , most best , believe it .

English: Believe it .
Shakespearean: Adieu .

English: Hamlet." Dutifully and obediently my daughter showed me this letter , and more like it .
Shakespearean: Hamlet." This in obedience hath my daughter shown me , And more above , hath his solicitings , As they fell out by time , by means , and place , All given to mine ear .

English: And how did she react to all this ?
Shakespearean: But how hath she received his love ?

English: Sir , what is your opinion of me ?
Shakespearean: What do you think of me ?

English: I know you are loyal and honorable .
Shakespearean: As of a man faithful and honorable .

English: I would like to prove to you that I am .
Shakespearean: I would fain prove so .

English: No , I had to do something .
Shakespearean: What might you think ?

English: And so I said to my daughter : "Lord Hamlet is a prince , he's out of your league .
Shakespearean: No , I went round to work , And my young mistress thus I did bespeak : "Lord Hamlet is a prince out of thy star .

English: It may be , it certainly may be .
Shakespearean: It may be , very like .

English: Has there ever been a time , I'd really like to know , when I've definitely said something was true , and it turned out not to be true ?
Shakespearean: Hath there been such a time , I would fain know that , That I have positively said , "'Tis so , " When it proved otherwise ?

English: Not that I know of .
Shakespearean: Not that I know .

English: What can we do to find out if it's true ?
Shakespearean: How may we try it further ?

English: Well , you know he sometimes walks here in the lobby for four hours at a time .
Shakespearean: You know sometimes he walks four hours together Here in the lobby .

English: Yes , he does .
Shakespearean: So he does indeed .

English: When he's there next time , I'll send my daughter to see him .
Shakespearean: At such a time I'll loose my daughter to him .

English: Please go away , both of you .
Shakespearean: Away , I do beseech you , both away .

English: I'll speak to him now .
Shakespearean: I'll board him presently .

English: Oh , please let me .
Shakespearean: O , give me leave .

English: How are you , Hamlet ?
Shakespearean: How does my good Lord Hamlet ?

English: Fine , thank you .
Shakespearean: Well , God-'a'-mercy .

English: Do you know who I am ?
Shakespearean: Do you know me , my lord ?

English: The town is besieged , and the trumpet calls us to the gap , and we talk and do nothing , by Christ .
Shakespearean: The town is beseeched , and the trumpet call us to the breach , and we talk and , be Chrish , do nothing , 'tis shame for us all .

English: It's a disgrace to us all .
Shakespearean: So God sa ' me , 'tis shame to stand still .

English: I swear by the mass , before I close my eyes to go to sleep , I'll put in some good fighting , or I'll lie in the ground dead .
Shakespearean: By the mess , ere theise eyes of mine take themselves to slomber , ay'll de gud service , or I'll lig i ' th ' grund for it , ay , or go to death .

English: Captain Macmorris , I think , see , correct me if I'm wrong , there are not many of your nation , My nation ?
Shakespearean: Captain Macmorris , I think , look you , under your correction , there is not many of your nation , Of my nation ?

English: What is my nation ?
Shakespearean: What ish my nation ?

English: It's a villain and a bastard and a coward and a rascal .
Shakespearean: Ish a villain and a basterd and a knave and a rascal .

English: What is my nation ?
Shakespearean: What ish my nation ?

English: Who talks of my nation ?
Shakespearean: Who talks of my nation ?

English: Captain Macmorris , if you take my words in some way other than how they were meant , see , I'll have to think you're not treating me with the good will you ought to , see , since I am as good a man as yourself , both in the practice of war and in my country of origin and in other respects .
Shakespearean: Look you , if you take the matter otherwise than is meant , Captain Macmorris , peradventure I shall think you do not use me with that affability as , in discretion , you ought to use me , look you , being as good a man as yourself , both in the disciplines of war and in the derivation of my birth and in other particularities .

English: I do not know that you are as good a man as myself .
Shakespearean: I do not know you so good a man as myself .

English: So , by Christ , I'll cut off your head .
Shakespearean: So Chrish save me , I will cut off your head .

English: Now , now , both of you gentlemen !
Shakespearean: Gentlemen both , you will mistake each other .

English: Yes , and that's a serious failing .
Shakespearean: Ah , that's a foul fault .

English: The town is asking for a pause in the fighting for negotiation .
Shakespearean: The town sounds a parley .

English: Captain Macmorris , when we have more leisure , see , I will be so bold as to show you I know about the practice of warfare , and that's that .
Shakespearean: Captain Macmorris , when there is more better opportunity to be required , look you , I will be so bold as to tell you I know the disciplines of war , and there is an end .

English: What has the governor of the town decided ?
Shakespearean: How yet resolves the governor of the town ?

English: This is the final discussion I will grant .
Shakespearean: This is the latest parle we will admit .

English: So submit to my mercy or , like men who revel in their own destruction , challenge me to do my worst .
Shakespearean: Therefore to our best mercy give yourselves Or , like to men proud of destruction , Defy us to our worst .

English: For , as I am a soldier , the name I think suits me best , once I begin my attack on Harfleur again , I will not leave the half-conquered town until she lies buried in her own ashes .
Shakespearean: For , as I am a soldier , A name that in my thoughts becomes me best , If I begin the batt'ry once again , I will not leave the half-achieved Harfleur Till in her ashes she lie buried .

English: The gates of mercy will be closed by then , and harsh and hard-hearted soldiers , who have tasted blood , will have free reign to commit whatever violence they want , mowing down your lovely young virgins and budding infants .
Shakespearean: The gates of mercy shall be all shut up , And the fleshed soldier , rough and hard of heart , In liberty of bloody hand , shall range With conscience wide as hell , mowing like grass Your fresh fair virgins and your flow'ring infants .

English: What power can rein in promiscuous evil once it's gotten rolling ?
Shakespearean: What rein can hold licentious wickedness When down the hill he holds his fierce career ?

English: We might as well send orders to the whale to come ashore as try to restore order in soldiers carried away with their looting .
Shakespearean: We may as bootless spend our vain command Upon th ' enraged soldiers in their spoil As send precepts to the Leviathan To come ashore .

English: What do you say ?
Shakespearean: What say you ?

English: Will you surrender and avoid all this or be called to account for the destruction of this town ?
Shakespearean: Will you yield and this avoid Or , guilty in defense , be thus destroyed ?

English: Today our hopes are at an end .
Shakespearean: Our expectation hath this day an end .

English: The Dauphin , whom we asked for reinforcements , sends back the answer that he's not yet in a position to raise so great an army .
Shakespearean: The Dauphin , whom of succors we entreated , Returns us that his powers are yet not ready To raise so great a siege .

English: Therefore , great king , we surrender our town and lives to your kind mercy .
Shakespearean: Therefore , great King , We yield our town and lives to thy soft mercy .

English: Open your gates .
Shakespearean: Open your gates .

English: Come , uncle Exeter , enter Harfleur .
Shakespearean: Come , uncle Exeter , Go you and enter Harfleur .

English: Stay there and fortify it well against the French .
Shakespearean: There remain And fortify it strongly 'gainst the French .

English: Tonight in Harfleur we will be your guest ; tomorrow we'll march on .
Shakespearean: Tonight in Harfleur will we be your guest ; Tomorrow for the march are we addressed .

English: No , I'll recite it for you right now : "de hand , de fangres , de nails , " "De nails , " madame .
Shakespearean: It must be so , for miracles are ceased , And therefore we must needs admit the means How things are perfected .

English: Ugh !
Shakespearean: Doth his Majesty Incline to it or no ?

English: That's enough for one lesson .
Shakespearean: D'elbow." "D'elbow , " "De nick , " "De nick." "De chin." "De sin."

English: He's certainly crossed the river Somme .
Shakespearean: Tis certain he hath passed the river Somme .

English: And if he advances unopposed , my lord , let us abandon France .
Shakespearean: An if he be not fought withal , my lord , Let us not live in France .

English: Let us leave everything and give our vineyards to the barbarous nation .
Shakespearean: Let us quit all And give our vineyards to a barbarous people .

English: God alive !
Shakespearean: Normans , but bastard Normans , Norman bastards !

English: If they march along unopposed , I will sell my dukedom for a sodden , filthy farm in that craggy isle of Albion .
Shakespearean: Unfought withal , but I will sell my dukedom To buy a slobb'ry and a dirty farm In that nook-shotten isle of Albion .

English: Doesn't the sun shine palely down on them , as though in contempt , killing their fruit with frowns ?
Shakespearean: Is not their climate foggy , raw , and dull , On whom , as in despite , the sun looks pale , Killing their fruit with frowns ?

English: And shall our lively blood , quickened by wine , be so frosty ?
Shakespearean: And shall our quick blood , spirited with wine , Seem frosty ?

English: Where is Montjoy , the herald ?
Shakespearean: Where is Montjoy the herald ?

English: Send him on his way quickly .
Shakespearean: Speed him hence .

English: Tell him to greet the king of England with our sharp defiance .
Shakespearean: Let him greet England with our sharp defiance .

English: Rise , princes , and , with a spirit of honor more sharply edged than your swords , rush to the battlefield : Charles Delabreth , High Constable of France ; you dukes of Orleans , Bourbon , Berri , Alencon , Brabant , Bar , and Burgundy ; Jaques Chatillon , Rambures , Vaudemont , Beaumont , Grandpre , Roussi , and Fauconberg , Foix , Lestrale , Bouciqualt , and Charolois .
Shakespearean: Up , princes , and , with spirit of honor edged More sharper than your swords , hie to the field : Charles Delabreth , High Constable of France ; You dukes of Orleans , Bourbon , and of Berri , Alencon , Brabant , Bar , and Burgundy ; Jacques Chatillon , Rambures , Vaudemont , Beaumont , Grandpre , Roussi , and Faulconbridge , Foix , Lestrale , Bouciqualt , and Charolois ; High dukes , great princes , barons , lords , and knights , For your great seats now quit you of great shames .

English: Stop Harry of England , who is now sweeping through our land with banners drenched in the French blood he spilled at Harfleur .
Shakespearean: Bar Harry England , that sweeps through our land With pennons painted in the blood of Harfleur .

English: Have Montjoy hurry , then , Lord Constable , and have him ask the king of England what he is willing to pay us to get out of the war .
Shakespearean: Therefore , Lord Constable , haste on Montjoy And let him say to England that we send To know what willing ransom he will give .

English: Prince Dauphin , you'll stay with me in Rouen .
Shakespearean: Prince Dauphin , you shall stay with us in Rouen .

English: No , please , I beg your Majesty .
Shakespearean: Not so , I do beseech your Majesty .

English: Be patient , because you're staying with me .
Shakespearean: Be patient , for you shall remain with us .
