English: Go now , Lord Constable and all you princes , and quickly bring us news of England's defeat .
Shakespearean: Now forth , Lord Constable and princes all , And quickly bring us word of England's fall .

English: Is the duke of Exeter safe ?
Shakespearean: Is the duke of Exeter safe ?

English: He is called Ensign Pistol .
Shakespearean: He is called Aunchient Pistol .

English: I don't know him .
Shakespearean: I know him not .

English: Here he is .
Shakespearean: Here is the man .

English: Captain , I have a favor to beg of you .
Shakespearean: Captain , I thee beseech to do me favors .

English: You're on very good terms with the duke of Exeter .
Shakespearean: The duke of Exeter doth love thee well .

English: Yes , God be praised , I have managed to earn his favor .
Shakespearean: Ay , I praise God , and I have merited some love at his hands .

English: She provides an excellent moral .
Shakespearean: Fortune is an excellent moral .

English: I'm glad to hear it .
Shakespearean: A damned death !

English: Discipline must be kept .
Shakespearean: Aunchient Pistol , I do partly understand your meaning .

English: Then die and be damned !
Shakespearean: Die and be damned , and It is well .

English: Why , that man is a total fraud and rascal .
Shakespearean: Why , this is an arrant counterfeit rascal .

English: What he just said to me , it's alright .
Shakespearean: I'll assure you , he uttered as prave words at the pridge as you shall see in a summer's day .

English: And what a beard trimmed like the general's or a rough uniform will do among foaming mugs and brains washed with ale , you wouldn't believe .
Shakespearean: trick up with new-tuned oaths ; and what a beard of the general's cut and a horrid suit of the camp will do among foaming bottles and ale-washed wits is wonderful to be thought on .

English: But you must learn to recognize such liars , or you will be greatly taken advantage of .
Shakespearean: But you must learn to know such slanders of the age , or else you may be marvelously mistook .

English: If I find an opportunity , I will give him a piece of my mind .
Shakespearean: If I find a hole in his coat , I will tell him my mind .

English: Tell me , Fluellen : did you just come from the bridge ?
Shakespearean: How now , Fluellen , cam'st thou from the bridge ?

English: Yes , your Majesty .
Shakespearean: Ay , so please your Majesty .

English: The duke of Exeter has held the bridge very gallantly .
Shakespearean: The duke of Exeter has very gallantly maintained the pridge .

English: The French have retreated , see , and there were great acts of courage .
Shakespearean: The French is gone off , look you , and there is gallant and most prave passages .

English: Indeed , the enemy nearly took the bridge , but he was forced to retreat , and the duke of Exeter holds the bridge .
Shakespearean: Marry , th ' athversary was have possession of the pridge , but he is enforced to retire , and the duke of Exeter is master of the pridge .

English: I can tell your Majesty , the duke is a brave man .
Shakespearean: I can tell your Majesty , the duke is a prave man .

English: What men have you lost , Fluellen ?
Shakespearean: What men have you lost , Fluellen ?

English: The enemy's losses have been very great , pretty substantial .
Shakespearean: The perdition of th ' athversary hath been very great , reasonable great .

English: To tell the truth , though , I think the duke hasn't lost a single man , except for one who will probably be executed for robbing a church , one Bardolph , I don't know if your Majesty knows the man .
Shakespearean: Marry , for my part , I think the duke hath lost never a man , but one that is like to be executed for robbing a church , one Bardolph , if your Majesty know the man .

English: I want all such offenders to be dealt with that way , and I give precise orders that in our progress through the country there shall be nothing seized from the villages , nothing taken that is not paid for , none of the French harassed or abused in disrespectful language .
Shakespearean: We would have all such offenders so cut off , and we give express charge that in our marches through the country there be nothing compelled from the villages , nothing taken but paid for , none of the French upbraided or abused in disdainful language ; for when lenity and cruelty play for a kingdom , the gentler gamester is the soonest winner .

English: You know from my clothing who I am .
Shakespearean: You know me by my habit .

English: Well then , I know who you are .
Shakespearean: Well then , I know thee .

English: What do you have to tell me ?
Shakespearean: What shall I know of thee ?

English: My master's decision .
Shakespearean: My master's mind .

English: Go ahead .
Shakespearean: Unfold it .

English: My king says this : "Tell Harry of England : though we appeared dead , we were only asleep .
Shakespearean: Thus says my king : "Say thou to Harry of England , though we seemed dead , we did but sleep .

English: Strategy makes a better soldier than haste .
Shakespearean: Advantage is a better soldier than rashness .

English: Tell him we could have driven him back at Harfleur but thought it unwise to burst a pustule before it had fully ripened .
Shakespearean: Tell him we could have rebuked him at Harfleur , but that we thought not good to bruise an injury till it were full ripe .

English: Now the time is right for us to speak , and we do so with imperial authority .
Shakespearean: Now we speak upon our cue , and our voice is imperial .

English: Favorably , except that there wasn't enough time for his Grace to hear , as I sensed he would have liked to , the details about how he is rightfully entitled to certain dukedoms in France , and to the throne of France in general , through clear lines of descent originating with his great-grandfather , Edward III .
Shakespearean: With good acceptance of his Majesty , Save that there was not time enough to hear , As I perceived his Grace would fain have done , The severals and unhidden passages Of his true titles to some certain dukedoms , And generally to the crown and seat of France , Derived from Edward , his great-grandfather .

English: What kept you from telling him this ?
Shakespearean: What was th ' impediment that broke this off ?

English: The French ambassador arrived at that moment and asked to see the king .
Shakespearean: The French ambassador upon that instant Craved audience .

English: And , in fact , I think they're meeting together right now .
Shakespearean: And the hour , I think , is come To give him hearing .

English: Is it four o'clock ?
Shakespearean: Is it four o'clock ?

English: It is .
Shakespearean: It is .

English: Then let's go in and hear what he has to say , though I think I can guess before the Frenchman has uttered a word .
Shakespearean: Then go we in to know his embassy , Which I could with a ready guess declare Before the Frenchman speak a word of it .

English: have lost , and the indignity we have endured , for which he is too insignificant to sufficiently pay us back .
Shakespearean: Bid him therefore consider of his ransom , which must proportion the losses we have borne , the subjects we have lost , the disgrace we have digested , which , in weight to reanswer , his pettiness would bow under .

English: His coffers are too poor to atone for our losses , his entire kingdom too small to account for the amount of blood we've shed , and the sight of him kneeling at our feet an empty satisfaction compared to the indignity we have put up with .
Shakespearean: For our losses , his exchequer is too poor ; for th ' effusion of our blood , the muster of his kingdom too faint a number ; and for our disgrace , his own person , kneeling at our feet but a weak and worthless satisfaction .

English: Add defiance to all this and , by way of conclusion , tell him that he has betrayed the men who follow him , whose death sentence has been pronounced." My king and master's message delivered , my task is done .
Shakespearean: To this , add defiance , and tell him , for conclusion , he hath betrayed his followers , whose condemnation is pronounced." So far my king and master ; so much my office .

English: What is your name ?
Shakespearean: What is thy name ?

English: I know your position .
Shakespearean: I know thy quality .

English: Montjoy .
Shakespearean: Montjoy .

English: You do your job well .
Shakespearean: Thou dost thy office fairly .

English: Go back and tell your king I do not seek an encounter with him now but would be willing to march on to Calais without interference , for , to be honest , though it's probably unwise to confess this to a powerful enemy who has the advantage , my men are considerably weakened by illness , my numbers reduced , and those few men I have almost no better than so many Frenchmen , though when they were in good form , I tell you , herald , I thought three Frenchmen walked on every pair of English legs .
Shakespearean: Turn thee back , And tell thy king I do not seek him now But could be willing to march on to Calais Without impeachment , for , to say the sooth , Though 'tis no wisdom to confess so much Unto an enemy of craft and vantage , My people are with sickness much enfeebled , My numbers lessened , and those few I have Almost no better than so many French , Who when they were in health , I tell thee , herald , I thought upon one pair of English legs Did march three Frenchmen .

English: But God forgive me for bragging .
Shakespearean: Yet , forgive me , God , That I do brag thus .

English: Anyway , go tell your master I am here .
Shakespearean: Go therefore , tell thy master : here I am .

English: I'll deliver the message .
Shakespearean: I shall deliver so .

English: I thank your Highness .
Shakespearean: Thanks to your Highness .

English: I hope they don't attack us now .
Shakespearean: I hope they will not come upon us now .

English: We're in God's hands , brother , not in theirs .
Shakespearean: We are in God's hand , brother , not in theirs .

English: March to the bridge .
Shakespearean: March to the bridge .

English: Night is approaching .
Shakespearean: It now draws toward night .

English: I have the best armor in the world .
Shakespearean: Tut , I have the best armor of the world .

English: I wish it were day !
Shakespearean: Would it were day !

English: You have wonderful armor , but give my horse his due .
Shakespearean: You have an excellent armor , but let my horse have his due .

English: It is the best horse in Europe .
Shakespearean: It is the best horse of Europe .

English: Will it never be morning ?
Shakespearean: Will it never be morning ?

English: My lord of Orleans , and my lord high Constable , are you talking about horses and armor ?
Shakespearean: My lord of Orleans , and my Lord High Constable , you talk of horse and armor ?

English: You are as well provided in both respects as any prince in the world .
Shakespearean: You are as well provided of both as any prince in the world .

English: What a long night this is !
Shakespearean: What a long night is this !

English: I will not trade my horse for any that walks on four legs .
Shakespearean: I will not change my horse with any that treads but on four pasterns .

English: He leaps from the ground as if his insides were light as hairs .
Shakespearean: He bounds from the earth , as if his entrails were hairs , le cheval volant , the Pegasus , qui a les narines de feu .

English: The earth sings when he touches it .
Shakespearean: The earth sings when he touches it .

English: The lowest part of his hoof is more musical than Pan's pipe .
Shakespearean: The basest horn of his hoof is more musical than the pipe of Hermes .

English: He's the color of nutmeg .
Shakespearean: He's of the color of the nutmeg .

English: And hot as ginger .
Shakespearean: And of the heat of the ginger .

English: He is an animal worthy of Perseus .
Shakespearean: It is a beast for Perseus .

English: He is indeed worthy of the name "horse , " and you can call all the rest beasts .
Shakespearean: He is indeed a horse , and all other jades you may call beasts .

English: Indeed , my lord , he is a perfectly wonderful horse .
Shakespearean: Indeed , my lord , it is a most absolute and excellent horse .

English: He is the prince of horses .
Shakespearean: It is the prince of palfreys .

English: His neigh is like a monarch's command .
Shakespearean: His neigh is like the bidding of a monarch , and his countenance enforces homage .

English: Enough , cousin .
Shakespearean: No more , cousin .

English: No , the man who can not extol the virtues of my horse from dawn to dusk is not particularly clever .
Shakespearean: Nay , the man hath no wit that can not , from the rising of the lark to the lodging of the lamb , vary deserved praise on my palfrey .

English: It's a subject as worthy of endless discussion as the changing sea .
Shakespearean: It is a theme as fluent as the sea .

English: If each grain of sand had a tongue to eulogize , my horse would be a topic for them all .
Shakespearean: Turn the sands into eloquent tongues , and my horse is argument for them all .

English: He is a subject for a king to contemplate , and for a king's king to ride on , and for the world at large , both friend and stranger , to stop whatever they are doing and marvel at .
Shakespearean: Tis a subject for a sovereign to reason on , and for a sovereign's sovereign to ride on , and for the world , familiar to us and unknown , to lay apart their particular functions and wonder at him .

English: I once wrote a sonnet in his praise which began , "Wonder of nature , " I have heard a sonnet to one's mistress that began like that .
Shakespearean: I once writ a sonnet in his praise and began thus : "Wonder of nature , " I have heard a sonnet begin so to one's mistress .

English: Then the writer imitated the one I composed to my steed , for my horse is my mistress .
Shakespearean: Then did they imitate that which I composed to my courser , for my horse is my mistress .

English: Your mistress is a good mount .
Shakespearean: Your mistress bears well .

English: So , perhaps , did yours .
Shakespearean: So perhaps did yours .

English: Mine wasn't wearing a bridle .
Shakespearean: Mine was not bridled .

English: Oh , then I guess she was old and gentle , and you rode barelegged , like an Irish yokel .
Shakespearean: Oh , then belike she was old and gentle , and you rode , like a kern of Ireland , your French hose off and in your straight strossers .

English: You're a good judge of horsemanship .
Shakespearean: You have good judgment in horsemanship .

English: Take a tip from me , then .
Shakespearean: Be warned by me , then : they that ride so , and ride not warily , fall into foul bogs .

English: I'd rather have my horse than a mistress .
Shakespearean: I had rather have my horse to my mistress .

English: I'd prefer to keep my mistress rather than some lame horse .
Shakespearean: I had as lief have my mistress a jade .

English: I'll tell you this , Constable , my mistress has his own hair .
Shakespearean: I tell thee , Constable , my mistress wears his own hair .

English: I could make the same boast even if I had a pig as my mistress .
Shakespearean: I could make as true a boast as that if I had a sow to my mistress .

English: The dog returns to its own vomit , and the newly washed sow to its mud puddle." You'd take anything for a mistress .
Shakespearean: Le chien est retourne a son propre vomissement , et la truie lavee au bourbier." Thou mak'st use of anything .

English: At least I don't have a horse for my mistress , or a saying so beside the point .
Shakespearean: Yet do I not use my horse for my mistress , or any such proverb so little kin to the purpose .

English: My Lord Constable , are those stars or suns I saw on the armor in your tent tonight ?
Shakespearean: My Lord Constable , the armor that I saw in your tent tonight , are those stars or suns upon it ?

English: Stars , my lord .
Shakespearean: Stars , my lord .

English: I hope some will fall off tomorrow .
Shakespearean: Some of them will fall tomorrow , I hope .

English: And yet I'll still have plenty .
Shakespearean: And yet my sky shall not want .

English: No doubt , for you wear too many in the first place , and it might be more seemly to make do with fewer .
Shakespearean: That may be , for you bear a many superfluously , and 'twere more honor some were away .

English: Yes , like your horse , who , staggering under your boasts , would trot more easily if some of them dismounted .
Shakespearean: Ev'n as your horse bears your praises , who would trot as well were some of your brags dismounted .

English: I only wish I could load him up with all the praise he deserves !
Shakespearean: Would I were able to load him with his desert !

English: Oh , will it never be day ?
Shakespearean: Will it never be day ?

English: I'd say the same thing , but I'm afraid I'd be faced out of my way .
Shakespearean: I will not say so , for fear I should be faced out of my way .

English: It's midnight .
Shakespearean: Tis midnight .

English: I'll go put my armor on .
Shakespearean: I'll go arm myself .

English: The Dauphin really wants it to be morning .
Shakespearean: The Dauphin longs for morning .

English: He wants to eat the English .
Shakespearean: He longs to eat the English .

English: Swear by her foot , so she can stamp out the oath .
Shakespearean: Swear by her foot , that she may tread out the oath .

English: He's definitely the most active gentleman of France .
Shakespearean: He is simply the most active gentleman of France .

English: Performing is activity , and he is always doing that .
Shakespearean: Doing is activity , and he will still be doing .

English: He never did harm that I heard of .
Shakespearean: He never did harm that I heard of .

English: And he's not going to do any tomorrow .
Shakespearean: Nor will do none tomorrow .

English: That part of his reputation will stand .
Shakespearean: He will keep that good name still .

English: I know him to be valiant .
Shakespearean: I know him to be valiant .

English: I was told that by one who knows him better than you .
Shakespearean: I was told that by one that knows him better than you .

English: Who was that ?
Shakespearean: What's he ?

English: Why , he told me so himself , and he said he didn't care who knew it .
Shakespearean: Marry , he told me so himself ; and he said he cared not who knew it .

English: He doesn't have to care .
Shakespearean: He needs not .

English: His virtue is not hidden .
Shakespearean: It is no hidden virtue in him .

English: His courage is hidden , and when it is revealed , it will shrink .
Shakespearean: Tis a hooded valor , and when it appears , it will bate .

English: Ill will never prompted anything well said .
Shakespearean: Ill will never said well .

English: I'll go straight for that proverb with "To hell with the devil." You are better at proverbs than I am by as much as "A fool shoots quickly and overshoots his mark." You have overshot .
Shakespearean: Have at the very eye of that proverb with "A pox of the devil." You are the better at proverbs , by how much "A fool's bolt is soon shot." You have shot over .

English: I've outshot you , and not for the first time .
Shakespearean: Tis not the first time you were overshot .

English: My Lord High Constable , the English lie within fifteen hundred paces of your tents .
Shakespearean: My Lord High Constable , the English lie within fifteen hundred paces of your tents .

English: Who measured the ground ?
Shakespearean: Who hath measured the ground ?

English: The Lord Grandpre .
Shakespearean: The Lord Grandpre .

English: Poor Harry of England !
Shakespearean: Alas , poor Harry of England !

English: He doesn't long for the dawn as we do .
Shakespearean: He longs not for the dawning as we do .

English: What a miserable and obstinate fellow this king of England is , to blunder with his fat-headed followers so far beyond his capacity .
Shakespearean: What a wretched and peevish fellow is this king of England to mope with his fat-brained followers so far out of his knowledge .

English: If the English had any sense , they would run away .
Shakespearean: If the English had any apprehension , they would run away .

English: If there were anything inside their heads , they could never wear such heavy helmets .
Shakespearean: That they lack , for if their heads had any intellectual armor , they could never wear such heavy head-pieces .

English: That island of England breeds very valiant creatures .
Shakespearean: That island of England breeds very valiant creatures .

English: Their hounds are unequaled in courage .
Shakespearean: Their mastiffs are of unmatchable courage .

English: Foolish dogs , blindly running straight toward a Russian bear only to have their heads crushed like rotten apples .
Shakespearean: Foolish curs , that run winking into the mouth of a Russian bear and have their heads crushed like rotten apples .

English: You might just as well say , "That's a valiant flea that dares to eat its breakfast on the lip of a lion." Yes , exactly .
Shakespearean: You may as well say , that's a valiant flea that dare eat his breakfast on the lip of a lion .

English: And the men resemble their English hounds in their loud , showy ferocity , too , leaving their brains behind with their wives .
Shakespearean: Just , just ; and the men do sympathize with the mastiffs in robustious and rough coming on , leaving their wits with their wives .

English: Give them hefty meals of beef and iron and steel , and they will eat like wolves and fight like devils .
Shakespearean: And then give them great meals of beef and iron and steel , they will eat like wolves and fight like devils .

English: Yes , but these English are seriously short of beef .
Shakespearean: Ay , but these English are shrewdly out of beef .

English: Then tomorrow we'll find that they feel only like eating , not like fighting .
Shakespearean: Then shall we find tomorrow they have only stomachs to eat and none to fight .

English: It's time to put our armor on .
Shakespearean: Now is it time to arm .

English: Shall we get started ?
Shakespearean: Come , shall we about it ?

English: It's two o'clock now .
Shakespearean: It is now two o'clock .

English: But let me see , by ten we shall each have captured a hundred Englishmen .
Shakespearean: But , let me see , by ten We shall have each a hundred Englishmen .

English: Now summon up the image of stealthy murmurs and engulfing darkness filling the wide vessel of the universe .
Shakespearean: Now entertain conjecture of a time When creeping murmur and the poring dark Fills the wide vessel of the universe .

English: He bids them good morning with a modest smile and calls
Shakespearean: Oh , now , who will behold The royal captain of this ruined band

English: Where is my gracious lord of Canterbury ?
Shakespearean: Where is my gracious lord of Canterbury ?

English: He's not here .
Shakespearean: Not here in presence .

English: Send for him , dear uncle .
Shakespearean: Send for him , good uncle .

English: Shall we call in the ambassador , my liege ?
Shakespearean: Shall we call in th ' ambassador , my liege ?

English: Not yet , cousin .
Shakespearean: Not yet , my cousin .

English: Before I hear him , I want to decide some important issues that are on my mind concerning my throne and France .
Shakespearean: We would be resolved , Before we hear him , of some things of weight That task our thoughts concerning us and France .

English: May God and his angels guard your sacred throne and grant that you dignify it for a long time .
Shakespearean: God and his angels guard your sacred throne And make you long become it .

English: Thank you , I'm sure .
Shakespearean: Sure we thank you .

English: My learned lord , kindly explain to us the legal and religious grounds for why this French Salic law either should or shouldn't bar me in my claim .
Shakespearean: My learned lord , we pray you to proceed And justly and religiously unfold Why the law Salic that they have in France Or should or should not bar us in our claim .

English: For God knows how many healthy men will shed their blood in support of whatever you persuade me to do .
Shakespearean: And God forbid , my dear and faithful lord , That you should fashion , wrest , or bow your reading , Or nicely charge your understanding soul With opening titles miscreate , whose right Suits not in native colors with the truth ; For God doth know how many now in health Shall drop their blood in approbation

English: them brothers , friends , and countrymen .
Shakespearean: Let him cry , "Praise and glory on his head ! " For forth he goes and visits all his host , Bids them good morrow with a modest smile , And calls them brothers , friends , and countrymen .

English: There is no indication of the mighty army that surrounds them in his expression , nor has the long , sleepless night robbed his face of an ounce of color .
Shakespearean: Upon his royal face there is no note How dread an army hath enrounded him , Nor doth he dedicate one jot of color Unto the weary and all-watched night , But freshly looks and overbears attaint With cheerful semblance and sweet majesty , That every wretch , pining and pale before , Beholding him , plucks comfort from his looks .

English: Gloucester , it's true that we are in great danger .
Shakespearean: Gloucester , 'tis true that we are in great danger .

English: But our courage should only be the greater for that .
Shakespearean: The greater therefore should our courage be .

English: Good morning , brother Bedford .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , brother Bedford .

English: God Almighty , there must be some essential goodness even in evil , if men would only look for it .
Shakespearean: God almighty , There is some soul of goodness in things evil , Would men observingly distill it out .

English: In our case , our bad neighbors over their make us early risers , a healthy and sensible thing to be .
Shakespearean: For our bad neighbor makes us early stirrers , Which is both healthful and good husbandry .

English: Besides , they act as outward consciences and preachers to us all , a visible reminder that we should prepare ourselves for death .
Shakespearean: Besides , they are our outward consciences And preachers to us all , admonishing That we should dress us fairly for our end .

English: Think like that , and you'll manage to get honey out of a common weed and find a moral lesson in the devil himself .
Shakespearean: Thus may we gather honey from the weed And make a moral of the devil himself .

English: Good morning , old Sir Thomas Erpingham !
Shakespearean: Good morrow , old Sir Thomas Erpingham .

English: A nice , soft pillow would be a more suitable place to lay that good white head than France's hard , cold ground .
Shakespearean: A good soft pillow for that good white head Were better than a churlish turf of France .

English: It eases the spirit .
Shakespearean: So the spirit is eased .

English: And when the mind is engaged , the rest of the body , dead and dull before , wakes up and comes to life with a new nimbleness and sensitivity , like a snake shedding its dead skin .
Shakespearean: And when the mind is quickened , out of doubt , The organs , though defunct and dead before , Break up their drowsy grave and newly move , With casted slough and fresh legerity .

English: Lend me your cloak , Sir Thomas .
Shakespearean: Lend me thy cloak , Sir Thomas .

English: We shall , my liege .
Shakespearean: We shall , my liege .

English: Shall I accompany your Grace ?
Shakespearean: Shall I attend your Grace ?

English: No , my good knight .
Shakespearean: No , my good knight .

English: Go with my brothers to my English peers .
Shakespearean: Go with my brothers to my lords of England .

English: I need to be alone with my thoughts for a while and don't want any company .
Shakespearean: I and my bosom must debate awhile , And then I would no other company .

English: The Lord in heaven bless you , noble Harry !
Shakespearean: The Lord in heaven bless thee , noble Harry !

English: A friend .
Shakespearean: A friend .

English: Or are you low , vulgar , and of the common people ?
Shakespearean: Discuss unto me : art thou officer or art thou base , common , and popular ?

English: I am a gentleman of a company .
Shakespearean: I am a gentleman of a company .

English: Do you carry a pike ?
Shakespearean: Trail'st thou the puissant pike ?

English: Exactly .
Shakespearean: Even so .

English: What about you ?
Shakespearean: What are you ?

English: I'm as good a gentleman as the emperor .
Shakespearean: As good a gentleman as the emperor .

English: Then you're a better man than the king .
Shakespearean: Then you are a better than the king .

English: The king's a dear boy with a heart of gold , he's a lively lad , a wag , born of fine parents , good with his fists .
Shakespearean: The king's a bawcock , and a heart of gold , A lad of life , an imp of fame , Of parents good , of fist most valiant .

English: I kiss his dirty shoe , and from the bottom of my heart I love the lovely boy .
Shakespearean: I kiss his dirty shoe , and from heartstring I love the lovely bully .

English: What is your name ?
Shakespearean: What is thy name ?

English: Harry le Roy .
Shakespearean: Harry le Roy .

English: Le Roy ?
Shakespearean: Le Roy ?

English: That's a Cornish name .
Shakespearean: A Cornish name .

English: Are you with a Cornish company ?
Shakespearean: Art thou of Cornish crew ?

English: No , I am a Welshman .
Shakespearean: No , I am a Welshman .

English: Do you know Fluellen ?
Shakespearean: Know'st thou Fluellen ?

English: Yes .
Shakespearean: Yes .

English: Tell him I'll take the leek out of his hat on Saint Davy's Day and slap his head with it .
Shakespearean: Tell him I'll knock his leek about his pate Upon Saint Davy's day .

English: You'd better not wear your dagger in your cap that day , or he might slap your head with it .
Shakespearean: Do not you wear your dagger in your cap that day , lest he knock that about yours .

English: Are you his friend ?
Shakespearean: Art thou his friend ?

English: Yes , and his relative , too .
Shakespearean: And his kinsman too .

English: Thank you .
Shakespearean: The I thank you .

English: God be with you .
Shakespearean: God be with you .

English: My name is Pistol .
Shakespearean: My name is Pistol called .

English: The name suits your fierceness .
Shakespearean: It sorts well with your fierceness .

English: Captain Fluellen !
Shakespearean: Captain Fluellen .

English: It never ceases to amaze me the way people ignore the correct , traditional principles and rules of war .
Shakespearean: It is the greatest admiration in the universal world when the true and aunchient prerogatifes and laws of the wars is not kept .

English: If you would take the trouble to study the tactics of Pompey the Great , I can tell you that you would find no tittle-tattle or pibble-pabble in Pompey's camp .
Shakespearean: If you would take the pains but to examine the wars of Pompey the Great , you shall find , I warrant you , that there is no tiddle toddle nor pibble babble in Pompey's camp .

English: I tell you , you would find the rituals of war and , I promise you , its ceremonies and its solicitudes and its forms and its gravity and its discipline all to be quite counter to all this noise .
Shakespearean: I warrant you , you shall find the ceremonies of the wars and the cares of it and the forms of it and the sobriety of it and the modesty of it to be otherwise .

English: But the enemy is loud .
Shakespearean: Why , the enemy is loud .

English: You can hear them all night long .
Shakespearean: You hear him all night .

English: And if the enemy is an ass and a fool and a prating idiot , does that mean , you think , that we should also be an ass and a fool and a prating idiot ?
Shakespearean: If the enemy is an ass and a fool and a prating coxcomb , is it meet , think you , that we should also , look you , be an ass and a fool and a prating coxcomb , in your own conscience , now ?

English: Think about it .
Shakespearean: I will speak lower .

English: I will lower my voice .
Shakespearean: I pray you and beseech you that you will .

English: Though he seems a little old-fashioned , there is much care and courage in this Welshman .
Shakespearean: Though it appear a little out of fashion , There is much care and valor in this Welshman .

English: Brother John Bates , isn't that dawn breaking over there ?
Shakespearean: Brother John Bates , is not that the morning which breaks yonder ?

English: That's the beginning of the day we see , but I don't think we'll see the end of it. , Who goes there ?
Shakespearean: We see yonder the beginning of the day , but I think we shall never see the end of it. , Who goes there ?

English: A friend .
Shakespearean: A friend .

English: What captain do you serve ?
Shakespearean: Under what captain serve you ?

English: Sir Thomas Erpingham .
Shakespearean: Under Sir Thomas Erpingham .

English: A veteran commander and a very kind gentleman .
Shakespearean: A good old commander and a most kind gentleman .

English: Tell me , what does he think of our situation ?
Shakespearean: I pray you , what thinks he of our estate ?

English: We're men beached on the sand , hoping to be washed out by the next tide .
Shakespearean: Even as men wracked upon a sand , that look to be washed off the next tide .

English: He hasn't told this to the king , has he ?
Shakespearean: He hath not told his thought to the king ?

English: The violet smells to him the same as it does to me .
Shakespearean: The violet smells to him as it doth to me .

English: And though his feelings may be pitched higher than ours , when they plummet , they plummet that much farther .
Shakespearean: His ceremonies laid by , in his nakedness he appears but a man , and though his affections are higher mounted than ours , yet when they stoop , they stoop with the like wing .

English: Therefore , when he has reason to fear , as we do , his fears are without question of the same order .
Shakespearean: Therefore , when he sees reason of fears as we do , his fears , out of doubt , be of the same relish as ours are .

English: Still , it stands to reason that he mustn't betray his fear , as it might dishearten his army .
Shakespearean: Yet , in reason , no man should possess him with any appearance of fear , lest he , by showing it , should dishearten his army .

English: He can act as brave as he wants , but I believe on a cold night like this he wishes he were neck-deep in the Thames , and I wish he were , too , and I with him , whatever the danger , so long as we were far away from here .
Shakespearean: He may show what outward courage he will , but I believe , as cold a night as 'tis , he could wish himself in Thames up to the neck ; and so I would he were , and I by him , at all adventures , so we were quit here .

English: I'll tell you truly what I think about the king in my heart .
Shakespearean: By my troth , I will speak my conscience of the king .

English: I don't think he wants to be anywhere but where he is .
Shakespearean: I think he would not wish himself anywhere but where he is .

English: Oh , I'm sure you don't dislike him so much as to wish he were here alone , even though you say this to find out how the rest of us feel .
Shakespearean: I dare say you love him not so ill to wish him here alone , howsoever you speak this to feel other men's minds .

English: I don't think there's anywhere I'd rather die than in the king's company , as his cause is just and honorable .
Shakespearean: Methinks I could not die anywhere so contented as in the king's company , his cause being just and his quarrel honorable .

English: That's more than we know .
Shakespearean: That's more than we know .

English: If his cause is wrong , our obedience to the king clears us of responsibility for it .
Shakespearean: If his cause be wrong , our obedience to the king wipes the crime of it out of us .

English: But if the cause is not just , the king himself will have a lot to answer for , when all those legs and arms and heads chopped off in battle shall join together on Judgment Day crying , "We died at such and such a place." Some will be swearing , some crying for a surgeon , some for the wives that are destitute without them , some about the debts they owed , some for their children left unprovided for .
Shakespearean: But if the cause be not good , the king himself hath a heavy reckoning to make , when all those legs and arms and heads , chopped off in a battle , shall join together at the latter day , and cry all , "We died at such a place , " some swearing , some crying for a surgeon , some upon their wives left poor behind them , some upon the debts they owe , some upon their children rawly left .

English: I think few die well who die in battle .
Shakespearean: I am afeard there are few die well that die in a battle , for how can they charitably dispose of anything , when blood is their argument ?

English: The father and the master and the king didn't order their subordinates ' deaths when they ordered their services .
Shakespearean: The king is not bound to answer the particular endings of his soldiers , the father of his son , nor the master of his servant , for they purpose not their death , when they purpose their services .

English: Besides , there's no king , however pure his cause , who , if it comes to a trial by combat , can rely on using completely blameless soldiers .
Shakespearean: Besides , there is no king , be his cause never so spotless , if it come to the arbitrament of swords , can try it out with all unspotted soldiers .

English: Even if these men have escaped the law and punishment at home , they can not escape God .
Shakespearean: Now , if these men have defeated the law and outrun native punishment , though they can outstrip men , they have no wings to fly from God .

English: When they feared death , they escaped with their lives ; and now where they imagine they're safe , they perish .
Shakespearean: Where they feared the death , they have borne life away ; and where they would be safe , they perish .

English: So , if they die unprepared , the king is no more guilty of their damnation than he was guilty of the earlier crimes they're finally being punished for .
Shakespearean: Then , if they die unprovided , no more is the king guilty of their damnation than he was before guilty of those impieties for the which they are now visited .

English: Every subject's duty is the king's , but every subject's soul is his own .
Shakespearean: Every subject's duty is the king's , but every subject's soul is his own .

English: Therefore , every soldier should do as any man who is sick in his bed would do : clear his conscience of any stain .
Shakespearean: Therefore should every soldier in the wars do as every sick man in his bed : wash every mote out of his conscience .

English: Then if he dies , his death serves him .
Shakespearean: And , dying so , death is to him advantage ; or not dying , the time was blessedly lost wherein such preparation was gained .

English: It's clear , every man must take responsibility for the manner of his own death .
Shakespearean: Tis certain , every man that dies ill , the ill upon his own head .

English: The king is not responsible for it .
Shakespearean: The king is not to answer it .

English: I don't expect him to answer for me , and yet I'm determined to fight vigorously for him .
Shakespearean: I do not desire he should answer for me , and yet I determine to fight lustily for him .

English: I myself heard the king say he would not be ransomed .
Shakespearean: I myself heard the king say he would not be ransomed .

English: If I live to see it , I'll never trust his word again .
Shakespearean: If I live to see it , I will never trust his word after .

English: Yeah , right , go get him .
Shakespearean: You pay him then .

English: That's a lame threat from a toy gun , a poor individual's private displeasure with a monarch .
Shakespearean: That's a perilous shot out of an elder gun , that a poor and private displeasure can do against a monarch .

English: You may as well try to turn the sun to ice by fanning its face with a peacock feather .
Shakespearean: You may as well go about to turn the sun to ice with fanning in his face with a peacock's feather .

English: You'll "never trust his word again." Come on , that was a stupid thing to say .
Shakespearean: You'll "never trust his word after." Come , 'tis a foolish saying .

English: Your scolding is somewhat overblown .
Shakespearean: Your reproof is something too round .

English: I'd be angry with you if the occasion allowed .
Shakespearean: I should be angry with you if the time were convenient .

English: Let it be a quarrel between us , if you live .
Shakespearean: Let it be a quarrel between us , if you live .

English: I'm game .
Shakespearean: I embrace it .

English: How will I recognize you in the future ?
Shakespearean: How shall I know thee again ?

English: Give me some trinket of yours , and I will wear it in my hat .
Shakespearean: Give me any gage of thine , and I will wear it in my bonnet .

English: Then , if you dare to acknowledge it , I'll take up my quarrel with you .
Shakespearean: Then , if ever thou dar'st acknowledge it , I will make it my quarrel .

English: Here .
Shakespearean: There .

English: I'll also wear this in my cap .
Shakespearean: This will I also wear in my cap .

English: If you come to me after tomorrow and say , "That's my glove , " I swear by this hand , I will take it and give you a box on the ear .
Shakespearean: If ever thou come to me and say , after tomorrow , "This is my glove , " by this hand I will take thee a box on the ear .

English: If I ever see it , I will challenge you .
Shakespearean: If ever I live to see it , I will challenge it .

English: You may as well undertake to be hanged .
Shakespearean: Thou dar'st as well be hanged .

English: I'll do it even if I find you in the company of the king himself .
Shakespearean: Well , I will do it , though I take thee in the king's company .

English: Keep your word .
Shakespearean: Keep thy word .

English: Farewell .
Shakespearean: Fare thee well .

English: Indeed , the French can bet twenty French crowns to one that they'll beat us , they have such an army .
Shakespearean: Indeed , the French may lay twenty French crowns to one they will beat us , for they bear them on their shoulders .

English: But it's no treason for an Englishman to cut off a French crown , a head , I mean , and tomorrow the king himself will do some snipping .
Shakespearean: But it is no English treason to cut French crowns , and tomorrow the king himself will be a clipper .

English: to wage war .
Shakespearean: Of what your reverence shall incite us to .

English: I charge you , in the name of God , be careful what you say .
Shakespearean: Therefore take heed how you impawn our person , How you awake our sleeping sword of war .

English: With this in mind , speak , my lord .
Shakespearean: Under this conjuration , speak , my lord , For we will hear , note , and believe in heart That what you speak is in your conscience washed As pure as sin with baptism .

English: Then hear me , gracious sovereign , and all you peers who owe your lives and duty to this imperial throne .
Shakespearean: Then hear me , gracious sovereign , and you peers That owe yourselves , your lives , and services To this imperial throne .

English: Upon the king !
Shakespearean: Upon the king !

English: Let's lay everything upon the king : our lives , our souls , our debts , our anxious wives , our children , and our sins." I must bear responsibility for all of it .
Shakespearean: Let us our lives , our souls , our debts , our careful wives , our children , and our sins lay on the king !

English: What a painful condition responsibility is .
Shakespearean: We must bear all .

English: It goes along with being born to greatness , but it makes you get badmouthed by every fool who only has his own suffering to care about .
Shakespearean: O hard condition , Twin-born with greatness , subject to the breath Of every fool , whose sense no more can feel But his own wringing .

English: What infinite peace do king's give up that private men enjoy ?
Shakespearean: What infinite heart's ease Must kings neglect that private men enjoy ?

English: What do kings have that private men do not , besides the pomp of their position ?
Shakespearean: And what have kings that privates have not too , Save ceremony , save general ceremony ?

English: And what is this useless ceremony of kings ?
Shakespearean: And what art thou , thou idol ceremony ?

English: What kind of god is ceremony , which suffers more than its worshippers do ?
Shakespearean: What kind of god art thou , that suffer'st more Of mortal griefs than do thy worshippers ?

English: What income , what profit does it bring in ?
Shakespearean: What are thy comings in ?

English: Oh , ceremony , only show me your value !
Shakespearean: O ceremony , show me but thy worth !

English: Why are you adored ?
Shakespearean: What is thy soul of adoration ?

English: You're less happy , being feared , than they are in fearing you .
Shakespearean: Art thou aught else but place , degree , and form , Creating awe and fear in other men , Wherein thou art less happy , being feared , Than they in fearing ?

English: What do you get to drink , instead of sweet obedience , but poisonous flattery ?
Shakespearean: What drink'st thou oft , instead of homage sweet , But poisoned flattery ?

English: Try being sick , great greatness , and see if ceremony can cure you !
Shakespearean: Oh , be sick , great greatness , And bid thy ceremony give thee cure !

English: Do you think fiery fever can be put out by the windy puff of titles ?
Shakespearean: Think'st thou the fiery fever will go out With titles blown from adulation ?

English: Will it be chased away by bowing and scraping ?
Shakespearean: Will it give place to flexure and low bending ?

English: You can command a beggar to bow on bended knee , but can you take possession of his health ?
Shakespearean: Canst thou , when thou command'st the beggar's knee , Command the health of it ?

English: No , vain illusion , so intricately bound up with a king's rest .
Shakespearean: No , thou proud dream , That play'st so subtly with a king's repose .

English: dusk and all night long sleeps in peace .
Shakespearean: And , but for ceremony , such a wretch , Winding up days with toil and nights with sleep , Had the forehand and vantage of a king .

English: My lord , your noble subjects are looking for you all over the camp .
Shakespearean: My lord , your nobles , jealous of your absence , Seek through your camp to find you .

English: Good old knight , gather them all together at my tent .
Shakespearean: Good old knight , Collect them all together at my tent .

English: I'll meet you there .
Shakespearean: I'll be before thee .

English: Consider it done , my lord .
Shakespearean: I shall do't , my lord .

English: Oh God of battles , bolster my soldiers ' courage .
Shakespearean: O God of battles , steel my soldiers ' hearts .

English: Don't let them know fear .
Shakespearean: Possess them not with fear .

English: Rob them of the ability to count before the numbers against them overwhelm their courage .
Shakespearean: Take from them now The sense of reck'ning ere th ' opposed numbers Pluck their hearts from them .

English: And just for today , Oh , Lord , just today don't think of the crime my father committed in seizing the crown !
Shakespearean: Not today , O Lord , Oh , not today , think not upon the fault My father made in compassing the crown .

English: I've transferred Richard's body to a new grave and on it poured more tears of remorse than it has shed drops of blood .
Shakespearean: I Richard's body have interred anew , And on it have bestowed more contrite tears Than from it issued forced drops of blood .

English: I've hired five hundred almsmen to hold up their withered hands to heaven , praying for my pardon twice a day throughout the year .
Shakespearean: Five hundred poor I have in yearly pay , Who twice a day their withered hands hold up Toward heaven to pardon blood .

English: And I've built two chapels where solemn priests sing continually for Richard's soul .
Shakespearean: And I have built Two chantries where the sad and solemn priests Sing still for Richard's soul .

English: I will do more , though nothing I can do is any good since this remorse comes after the crime , asking for pardon .
Shakespearean: More will I do , Though all that I can do is nothing worth , Since that my penitence comes after all , Imploring pardon .

English: My liege .
Shakespearean: My liege .

English: My brother Gloucester's voice ?
Shakespearean: My brother Gloucester's voice. , Ay , I know thy errand .

English: I'll go with you .
Shakespearean: I will go with thee .

English: The day , my friends , and everything await me .
Shakespearean: The day , my friends , and all things stay for me .

English: The sun glints off our armor .
Shakespearean: The sun doth gild our armor .

English: Awake , my lords !
Shakespearean: Up , my lords .

English: Is it time , my Lord Constable ?
Shakespearean: Now , my Lord Constable ?

English: Listen to our horses neighing , longing to be working .
Shakespearean: Hark how our steeds for present service neigh .

English: Ha !
Shakespearean: Ha !

English: What , you want them to weep our horses ' blood ?
Shakespearean: What , will you have them weep our horses ' blood ?

English: Then how will we see their own natural tears ?
Shakespearean: How shall we then behold their natural tears ?

English: The English are in the field , French lords .
Shakespearean: The English are embattled , you French peers .

English: To our horses , you gallant princes .
Shakespearean: To horse , you gallant princes , straight to horse .

English: What's there to say ?
Shakespearean: What's to say ?

English: Our advance will so dazzle the enemy that England will cower in fear and surrender .
Shakespearean: Then let the trumpets sound The tucket sonance and the note to mount , For our approach shall so much dare the field That England shall couch down in fear and yield .

English: What are you waiting for , lords of France ?
Shakespearean: Why do you stay so long , my lords of France ?

English: Those island-bred skeletons , terrified for their bones , are an offensive sight on the morning field .
Shakespearean: Yond island carrions , desperate of their bones , Ill-favoredly become the morning field .

English: The horsemen stand frozen like candlesticks , torches in their hands .
Shakespearean: Big Mars seems bankrupt in their beggared host And faintly through a rusty beaver peeps .

English: Meanwhile , their They've said their prayers , and now they wait for death .
Shakespearean: They have said their prayers , and they stay for death .

English: Shall we go send them food and fresh clothing and feed their starving horses before we fight them ?
Shakespearean: Shall we go send them dinners and fresh suits , And give their fasting horses provender , And after fight with them ?

English: To the field !
Shakespearean: On , to the field !

English: I'll take the banner from a trumpeter and use that .
Shakespearean: I will the banner from a trumpet take And use it for my haste .

English: Come , let's be off !
Shakespearean: Come , come away .

English: The sun is up and we're wasting the day !
Shakespearean: The sun is high , and we outwear the day .

English: Where is the king ?
Shakespearean: Where is the king ?

English: The king rode out alone to view their troops .
Shakespearean: The king himself is rode to view their battle .

English: They have fully sixty thousand fighting men .
Shakespearean: Of fighting men they have full threescore thousand .

English: That's five to one .
Shakespearean: There's five to one .

English: Besides , they're fresh .
Shakespearean: Besides , they all are fresh .

English: May God's arm strike on our side !
Shakespearean: God's arm strike with us !

English: These are frightening odds .
Shakespearean: Tis a fearful odds .

English: God be with all of you , princes .
Shakespearean: God be wi ' you , princes all .

English: I'll go and join my men .
Shakespearean: I'll to my charge .

English: Farewell , good Salisbury ; and may good luck go with you .
Shakespearean: Farewell , good Salisbury , and good luck go with thee .

English: Farewell , kind lord .
Shakespearean: Farewell , kind lord .

English: Fight valiantly today .
Shakespearean: Fight valiantly today .

English: But then I do you wrong to say as much , since you are the very embodiment of bravery .
Shakespearean: And yet I do thee wrong to mind thee of it , For thou art framed of the firm truth of valor .

English: He is as full of courage as of kindness , princely in both .
Shakespearean: He is as full of valor as of kindness , Princely in both .

English: Oh , if only we had with us here ten thousand of those men back home in England who aren't working today .
Shakespearean: Oh , that we now had here But one ten thousand of those men in England That do no work today .

English: Who wishes that ?
Shakespearean: What's he that wishes so ?

English: My cousin Westmoreland ?
Shakespearean: My cousin Westmoreland ?

English: No , my dear cousin .
Shakespearean: No , my fair cousin .

English: If we are slated to die , the fewer , the better for our country , and if we're slated to live , the fewer men , the greater the share of honor for each of us .
Shakespearean: If we are marked to die , we are enough To do our country loss ; and if to live , The fewer men , the greater share of honor .

English: In God's name , I beg you not to wish for one more man .
Shakespearean: God's will , I pray thee wish not one man more .

English: By God , I am not selfish when it comes to money : I don't care who eats at my expense .
Shakespearean: By Jove , I am not covetous for gold Nor care I who doth feed upon my cost ; It yearns me not if men my garments wear ; Such outward things dwell not in my desires .

English: But if it is a sin to be selfish about honor , I am the most guilty soul alive .
Shakespearean: But if it be a sin to covet honor , I am the most offending soul alive .

English: No , my cousin , don't wish that even one man who is now in England were here instead .
Shakespearean: No , faith , my coz , wish not a man from England .

English: By God , I wouldn't lose as much honor as a single man more would cost me , I think , not even if it meant giving up my best hope for victory .
Shakespearean: God's peace , I would not lose so great an honor As one man more , methinks , would share from me , For the best hope I have .

English: Oh , do not wish one more !
Shakespearean: Oh , do not wish one more !

English: He will be given safe conduct and money for his passage home .
Shakespearean: His passport shall be made , And crowns for convoy put into his purse .

English: We would not want to die in the company of a man who fears to die with us .
Shakespearean: We would not die in that man's company That fears his fellowship to die with us .

English: He who survives this day and lives to see old age shall yearly entertain his neighbors on the eve , saying , "Tomorrow is
Shakespearean: He that shall see this day , and live old age , Will yearly on the vigil feast his neighbors And say , "Tomorrow is Saint Crispian." Then will he strip his sleeve and show his scars , And say , "These wounds I had on Crispin's day."

English: We're ready if our minds are ready .
Shakespearean: All things are ready if our minds be so .

English: Let any man perish who isn't ready now !
Shakespearean: Perish the man whose mind is backward now !

English: You don't wish we had more help from England anymore , cousin ?
Shakespearean: Thou dost not wish more help from England , coz ?

English: God be with you all .
Shakespearean: God be with you all .

English: Once more I come to ask you , King Harry , if you're ready to negotiate your ransom before your certain defeat .
Shakespearean: Tucket Once more I come to know of thee , King Harry , If for thy ransom thou wilt now compound , Before thy most assured overthrow .

English: For assuredly , you are so near the abyss that you're bound to be swallowed up .
Shakespearean: For certainly thou art so near the gulf Thou needs must be englutted .

English: Moreover , out of mercy , the Constable urges you to remind your men to make their peace with God and repent , so that their souls may depart sweetly and peacefully from these fields where , poor wretches , their bodies will likely fall and fester .
Shakespearean: Besides , in mercy , The constable desires thee thou wilt mind Thy followers of repentance , that their souls May make a peaceful and a sweet retire From off these fields where , wretches , their poor bodies Must lie and fester .

English: Who sent you this time ?
Shakespearean: Who hath sent thee now ?

English: The Constable of France .
Shakespearean: The constable of France .

English: Be good enough to take back the same answer I gave before .
Shakespearean: I pray thee , bear my former answer back .

English: Tell them to capture me , then sell my bones .
Shakespearean: Bid them achieve me and then sell my bones .

English: The man that once sold the skin of a lion while the beast still lived died hunting him .
Shakespearean: The man that once did sell the lion's skin While the beast lived was killed with hunting him .

English: And on their graves , I trust , the story of this day's work will be written in brass .
Shakespearean: A many of our bodies shall no doubt Find native graves , upon the which , I trust , Shall witness live in brass of this day's work .

English: And those who leave their valiant bones in France , dying like men though buried in your dunghills , they'll be remembered , too .
Shakespearean: And those that leave their valiant bones in France , Dying like men though buried in your dunghills , They shall be famed ; for there the sun shall greet them And draw their honors reeking up to heaven , Leaving their earthly parts to choke your clime ,

English: Besides , according to the French historians , King Pepin , who deposed Childeric , based his own claim to the crown of France on his descent from Blithild , the daughter of King Clothair .
Shakespearean: Besides , their writers say , King Pepin , which deposed Childeric , Did , as heir general , being descended Of Blithild , which was daughter to King Clothair , Make claim and title to the crown of France .

English: Another case : Hugh Capet , who usurped the crown from Charles the duke of Lorraine , sole male heir in a direct line from Charles the Great , passed himself off as heir to Lady Lingare , daughter of Charlemagne , who was the son of Lewis the Emperor ( who was the son of Charles the Great ) , in order to give his claim to the throne more validity ( though , in fact , the claim was completely false and worthless ) .
Shakespearean: Hugh Capet also , who usurped the crown Of Charles the duke of Lorraine , sole heir male Of the true line and stock of Charles the Great , To find his title with some shows of truth , Though in pure truth it was corrupt and naught , Conveyed himself as th ' heir to th ' Lady Lingare , Daughter to Charlemagne , who was the son To Lewis the Emperor , and Lewis the son Of Charles the Great .

English: Another case : King Lewis the Tenth , who was sole heir to the usurper Capet , could not rest easy as king until he was assured that Queen Isabel , his grandmother , was a direct descendent of the Lady Ermengare , daughter of the aforementioned Charles duke of Lorraine , by which marriage the line of Charles the Great was reunited with the throne of France .
Shakespearean: Also King Lewis the Tenth , Who was sole heir to the usurper Capet , Could not keep quiet in his conscience , Wearing the crown of France , till satisfied That fair Queen Isabel , his grandmother , Was lineal of the Lady Ermengare , Daughter to Charles the foresaid duke of Lorraine , By the which marriage the line of Charles the Great Was reunited to the crown of France .

English: Thus , it should be clear as day that King Pepin's title , Hugh Capet's claim , and the resolution of King Lewis's doubts all plainly derive from the female .
Shakespearean: So that , as clear as is the summer's sun , King Pepin's title and Hugh Capet's claim , King Lewis his satisfaction , all appear To hold in right and title of the female .

English: Let me speak proudly : tell the Constable we're only workaday soldiers .
Shakespearean: Let me speak proudly : tell the constable We are but warriors for the working day ; Our gayness and our gilt are all besmirched With rainy marching in the painful field .

English: There's not a strand of feather left in our whole army , a good sign , I hope , that we won't fly away like birds , and time on the field has made us slovenly .
Shakespearean: There's not a piece of feather in our host , Good argument , I hope , we will not fly , And time hath worn us into slovenry .

English: If they do this , as they will , God willing , my ransom will soon be raised .
Shakespearean: If they do this , As , if God please , they shall , my ransom then Will soon be levied .

English: Herald , spare yourself .
Shakespearean: Herald , save thou thy labor .

English: Don't come again to ask for my ransom , good messenger .
Shakespearean: Come thou no more for ransom , gentle herald .

English: I swear the only ransom will be these bones of mine .
Shakespearean: They shall have none , I swear , but these my joints , Which , if they have , as I will leave 'em them , Shall yield them little .

English: Tell the constable that .
Shakespearean: Tell the constable .

English: I shall , King Harry .
Shakespearean: I shall , King Harry .

English: And so farewell .
Shakespearean: And so fare thee well .

English: You'll never hear from the herald again .
Shakespearean: Thou never shalt hear herald anymore .

English: I'm afraid you'll come to me again for ransom .
Shakespearean: I fear thou wilt once more come again for a ransom .

English: My lord , most humbly on bended knee I beg you to grant me the leading of the vanguard .
Shakespearean: My lord , most humbly on my knee I beg The leading of the vaward .

English: Take it , brave York .
Shakespearean: Take it , brave York .

English: Now , soldiers , advance .
Shakespearean: Now , soldiers , march away , And how Thou pleasest , God , dispose the day .

English: Surrender , dog !
Shakespearean: Yield , cur .

English: Is that a lot of He says his name is Master Fer .
Shakespearean: He says his name is Master Fer .

English: Master Fer !
Shakespearean: Master Fer .

English: What does he say ?
Shakespearean: What are his words ?

English: He begs you to spare his life .
Shakespearean: He prays you to save his life .

English: He is a gentleman of a good family , and for his ransom , he will give you two hundred crowns .
Shakespearean: He is a gentleman of a good house , and for his ransom he will give you two hundred crowns .

English: Tell him my fury will abate , and I'll take the crowns .
Shakespearean: Tell him my fury shall abate , and I the crowns will take .

English: Explain , boy .
Shakespearean: Expound unto me , boy .

English: He thanks you on his knees many times and considers himself fortunate to have fallen into the hands of one , as he thinks , who is the bravest , most valorous , and thrice-worthy gentleman of England .
Shakespearean: He gives you upon his knees a thousand thanks , and he esteems himself happy that he hath fall'n into the hands of one , as he thinks , the most brave , valorous , and thrice- worthy seigneur of England .

English: As I get to leech him , I will show some mercy .
Shakespearean: As I suck blood , I will some mercy show .

English: Follow me .
Shakespearean: Follow me .

English: I never heard so loud a voice issue from such an empty heart .
Shakespearean: I did never know so full a voice issue from so empty a heart .

English: I have to stay with the servants , who are with our camp's luggage .
Shakespearean: I must stay with the lackeys with the luggage of our camp .

English: We're sitting ducks for the French , if they only knew it , for there is no one guarding it but boys .
Shakespearean: The French might have a good prey of us if he knew of it , for there is none to guard it but boys .

English: Regret and everlasting shame sit on our helmets , mocking us .
Shakespearean: Reproach and everlasting shame Sits mocking in our plumes .

English: Do not run away .
Shakespearean: Do not run away .

English: Our men have all broken ranks .
Shakespearean: Why , all our ranks are broke .

English: O , everlasting shame !
Shakespearean: O perdurable shame !

English: Let's fall on our swords .
Shakespearean: Let's stab ourselves .

English: Are these the wretches that we threw dice for ?
Shakespearean: Be these the wretches that we played at dice for ?

English: Is this the king we offered to ransom ?
Shakespearean: Is this the king we sent to for his ransom ?

English: Shame , eternal shame , and nothing but shame !
Shakespearean: Shame , and eternal shame , nothing but shame !

English: Let us die honorably .
Shakespearean: Let us die .

English: He who will not follow me now , let him depart and stand in the doorway like a pimp , cap in hand , while some slave , no nobler than my dog , violates his daughter .
Shakespearean: And he that will not follow Bourbon now , Let him go hence , and with his cap in hand Like a base pander hold the chamber door , Whilst by a slave , no gentler than my dog , His fairest daughter is contaminate .

English: Maybe we can benefit from the same chaos that has defeated us .
Shakespearean: Disorder , that hath spoiled us , friend us now .

English: Let's go offer up our lives
Shakespearean: Let us on heaps go offer up our lives .

English: There are enough of us still alive in the field to overcome the English with our numbers if we could just restore some kind of order .
Shakespearean: We are enough yet living in the field To smother up the English in our throngs , If any order might be thought upon .

English: The hell with order !
Shakespearean: The devil take order now !

English: I'm going back into battle .
Shakespearean: I'll to the throng .

English: Let life be short so that shame won't last too long .
Shakespearean: Let life be short , else shame will be too long .

English: The French are still fighting .
Shakespearean: Yet keep the French the field .

English: The duke of York sends your Majesty his respects .
Shakespearean: The duke of York commends him to your Majesty .

English: Is he still alive , good uncle ?
Shakespearean: Lives he , good uncle ?

English: Three times in an hour I saw him down , and three times up again and fighting .
Shakespearean: Thrice within this hour I saw him down , thrice up again and fighting .

English: He was covered with blood from his helmet to his spurs .
Shakespearean: From helmet to the spur , all blood he was .

English: By his side lies the noble earl of Suffolk , York's comrade and equal in brave wounds .
Shakespearean: In which array , brave soldier , doth he lie , Larding the plain , and by his bloody side , Yoke-fellow to his honor-owing wounds , The noble earl of Suffolk also lies .

English: Suffolk died first , and York , cut to pieces , came to him where he lay in his blood and took him by the face , kissing his gashes .
Shakespearean: Suffolk first died , and York , all haggled over , Comes to him where in gore he lay insteeped And takes him by the beard , kisses the gashes That bloodily did yawn upon his face .

English: He cried out , "Wait for me , dear cousin .
Shakespearean: And cries aloud , "Tarry , my cousin Suffolk .

English: My soul will keep yours company on the way to heaven .
Shakespearean: My soul shall thine keep company to heaven .

English: Wait for mine , sweet soul .
Shakespearean: Tarry , sweet soul , for mine ; then fly abreast , As in this glorious and well-foughten field We kept together in our chivalry." Upon these words I came and cheered him up .

English: The French have reinforced their scattered men .
Shakespearean: The French have reinforced their scattered men .

English: Then every soldier must kill his prisoners .
Shakespearean: Then every soldier kill his prisoners .

English: Spread the word .
Shakespearean: Give the word through .

English: To this day , the kings of France follow this unspoken rule , even though they point to this Salic law to bar your Highness from inheriting it through the female line .
Shakespearean: So do the kings of France unto this day , Howbeit they would hold up this Salic law To bar your Highness claiming from the female And rather choose to hide them in a net Than amply to imbar their crooked titles Usurped from you and your progenitors .

English: Can I justifiably and in good conscience make this claim ?
Shakespearean: May I with right and conscience make this claim ?

English: For it is written in the book of Numbers : "When the man dies , let the inheritance descend unto the daughter." Gracious lord , claim what is yours .
Shakespearean: The sin upon my head , dread sovereign , For in the Book of Numbers is it writ : "When the man dies , let the inheritance Descend unto the daughter." Gracious lord , Stand for your own , unwind your bloody flag , Look back into your mighty ancestors .

English: Go to the tomb of your great-grandfather , from whom your own title to the crown derives .
Shakespearean: Go , my dread lord , to your great-grandsire's tomb , From whom you claim .

English: Invoke his warlike spirit and that of Edward the Black Prince , your great-uncle , who fought a tragic battle on French soil , routing the French army in full force while his mighty father stood by on a hilltop , smiling to see his son steeped in the blood of French noblemen .
Shakespearean: Invoke his warlike spirit And your great-uncle's , Edward the Black Prince , Who on the French ground played a tragedy , Making defeat on the full power of France Whiles his most mighty father on a hill Stood smiling to behold his lion's whelp Forage in blood of French nobility .

English: O noble English , who could take on the entire French army with only half their forces , leaving the other half to stand by , idle and laughing .
Shakespearean: O noble English , that could entertain With half their forces the full pride of France And let another half stand laughing by , All out of work and cold for action !

English: Awaken the memory of those valiant ancestors and with your own powerful arm make their deeds live again .
Shakespearean: Awake remembrance of these valiant dead And with your puissant arm renew their feats .

English: You are their heir and sit on their throne , and the blood and courage that glorified them run in your veins .
Shakespearean: You are their heir , you sit upon their throne , The blood and courage that renowned them Runs in your veins ; and my thrice-puissant liege Is in the very May-morn of his youth , Ripe for exploits and mighty enterprises .

English: To kill the boys with the luggage !
Shakespearean: Kill the poys and the luggage !

English: It's expressly against the rules of combat .
Shakespearean: Tis expressly against the law of arms .

English: It's as complete a work of villainy as any that could be thought up .
Shakespearean: Tis as arrant a piece of knavery , mark you now , as can be offert , in your conscience now , is it not ?

English: There's certainly not a boy left alive , and it was done by the cowardly rascals who were running from the battle .
Shakespearean: Tis certain there's not a boy left alive , and the cowardly rascals that ran from the battle ha ' done this slaughter .

English: On top of this , they've either burned or carried away everything that was in the king's tent .
Shakespearean: Besides , they have burned and carried away all that was in the king's tent , wherefore the king , most worthily , hath caused every soldier to cut his prisoner's throat .

English: Oh , he's a gallant king !
Shakespearean: Oh , 'tis a gallant king !

English: Yes , he was born at Monmouth , Captain Gower .
Shakespearean: Ay , he was porn at Monmouth , Captain Gower .

English: And is "pig" not the same as "great , " may I ask ?
Shakespearean: Why , I pray you , is not "pig" great ?

English: The pig or the mighty or the huge or the magnanimous , they all mean the same thing , with some variation .
Shakespearean: The pig , or the great , or the mighty , or the huge , or the magnanimous are all one reckonings , save the phrase is a little variations .

English: I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon .
Shakespearean: I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon .

English: His father was Philip of Macedon , as I remember .
Shakespearean: His father was called Philip of Macedon , as I take it .

English: I think that Macedon is indeed where Alexander was born .
Shakespearean: I think it is in Macedon where Alexander is porn .

English: I tell you , Captain , if you look at a map of the world , I'll bet you will find , comparing Macedon and Monmouth , that the situations , see , are very similar .
Shakespearean: I tell you , Captain , if you look in the maps of the 'orld , I warrant you shall find , in the comparisons between Macedon and Monmouth , that the situations , look you , is both alike .

English: There is a river in Macedon , and there is likewise a river in Monmouth .
Shakespearean: There is a river in Macedon , and there is also , moreover , a river at Monmouth .

English: The river in Monmouth is called Wye , but the name of the other river has gone out of my head .
Shakespearean: It is called Wye at Monmouth , but it is out of my prains what is the name of the other river .

English: Nevertheless , it's all one , the two rivers are as alike as my fingers are to my fingers , and there are salmon in both .
Shakespearean: But 'tis all one ; 'tis alike as my fingers is to my fingers , and there is salmons in both .

English: If you look closely at Alexander's life , Harry of Monmouth's stands up fairly well by comparison , for there are analogies in everything .
Shakespearean: If you mark Alexander's life well , Harry of Monmouth's life is come after it indifferent well , for there is figures in all things .

English: Alexander , God knows and you know , in his rages and his furies and his wraths and his angers and his moods and his displeasures and his indignations , and also being a little the worse for drink , killed his best friend Cleitus in a drunken rage , see .
Shakespearean: Alexander , God knows and you know , in his rages and his furies and his wraths and his cholers and his moods and his displeasures and his indignations , and also being a little intoxicates in his prains , did , in his ales and his angers , look you , kill his best friend , Cleitus .

English: It is not courteous , you know , to assume you know my meaning before I've finished talking .
Shakespearean: It is not well done , mark you now , to take the tales out of my mouth ere it is made and finished .

English: I'm speaking purely in analogies and comparisons .
Shakespearean: I speak but in the figures and comparisons of it .

English: Sir John Falstaff .
Shakespearean: Sir John Falstaff .

English: That's the one .
Shakespearean: That is he .

English: I tell you , there are good men born at Monmouth .
Shakespearean: I'll tell you , there is good men porn at Monmouth .

English: Here comes his Majesty .
Shakespearean: Here comes his Majesty .

English: I was not angry since I came to France until this instant .
Shakespearean: I was not angry since I came to France Until this instant .

English: Take a trumpet , herald .
Shakespearean: Take a trumpet , herald .

English: Ride out to the horsemen on that hill .
Shakespearean: Ride thou unto the horsemen on yond hill .

English: If they seek battle with us , have them come down or else clear the field .
Shakespearean: If they will fight with us , bid them come down , Or void the field .

English: The sight of them is offensive .
Shakespearean: They do offend our sight .

English: If they'll do neither , we'll come to them and make them fly like stones shot from powerful slings .
Shakespearean: If they'll do neither , we will come to them And make them skirr away as swift as stones Enforced from the old Assyrian slings .

English: Go and tell them this .
Shakespearean: Go and tell them so .

English: Here comes the herald of the French , my liege .
Shakespearean: Here comes the herald of the French , my liege .

English: He looks humbler than he used to .
Shakespearean: His eyes are humbler than they used to be .

English: Don't you know that I have offered these bones of mine for ransom ?
Shakespearean: Know'st thou not That I have fined these bones of mine for ransom ?

English: Are you coming again for ransom ?
Shakespearean: Com'st thou again for ransom ?

English: No , great king .
Shakespearean: No , great king .

English: I come to ask you out of charity to let us wander over this bloody field to record the numbers of our dead and bury them , separating our nobles from the common men , for many of our princes , alas ! , lie drowned and soaked in the blood of mercenary soldiers .
Shakespearean: I come to thee for charitable license , That we may wander o'er this bloody field To book our dead and then to bury them ; To sort our nobles from our common men , For many of our princes , woe the while ! , Lie drowned and soaked in mercenary blood .

English: Likewise , our common men lie drenched in the blood of princes , and their wounded steeds , ankle-deep in gore , struggle and , raging wildly , stamp on their dead masters with their hooves , killing them a second time .
Shakespearean: So do our vulgar drench their peasant limbs In blood of princes , and the wounded steeds Fret fetlock deep in gore , and with wild rage Yerk out their armed heels at their dead masters , Killing them twice .

English: Oh , give us permission , great king , to search the field in safety and dispose of our dead bodies .
Shakespearean: Oh , give us leave , great king , To view the field in safety and dispose Of their dead bodies .

English: You won it .
Shakespearean: The day is yours .

English: God , not our strength , be praised !
Shakespearean: Praised be God , and not our strength , for it !

English: What is the name of the castle that stands over there ?
Shakespearean: What is this castle called that stands hard by ?

English: Agincourt .
Shakespearean: They call it Agincourt .

English: Then we'll call this the Battle of Agincourt , fought on the day of Crispin Crispianus .
Shakespearean: Then call we this the field of Agincourt , Fought on the day of Crispin Crispianus .

English: If I may say so , your Majesty , your famous grandfather and your great-uncle Edward , the Black Prince of Wales , or so I've read in the history books , fought a very brave battle here in France .
Shakespearean: Your grandfather of famous memory , an't please your Majesty , and your great-uncle Edward the Plack Prince of Wales , as I have read in the chronicles , fought a most prave pattle here in France .

English: They did , Fluellen .
Shakespearean: They did , Fluellen .

English: Your Majesty is quite right .
