Shakespearean: Your Majesty says very true .

English: If your Majesties recall it , the Welsh fought very valiantly in a garden where there were leeks growing , wearing leeks in their Monmouth caps which , your Majesty knows , is to this day a badge of honorable military service .
Shakespearean: If your Majesties is remembered of it , the Welshmen did good service in a garden where leeks did grow , wearing leeks in their Monmouth caps , which , your Majesty know , to this hour is an honorable badge of the service .

English: I do believe your Majesty takes no shame in wearing the leek on Saint Davy's Day .
Shakespearean: And I do believe your Majesty takes no scorn to wear the leek upon Saint Tavy's day .

English: I wear it with pride , for I am Welsh you know , good countryman .
Shakespearean: I wear it for a memorable honor , For I am Welsh , you know , good countryman .

English: Thanks , my good countryman .
Shakespearean: Thanks , good my countryman .

English: By Jesus , I am your Majesty's countryman , and I don't care who knows it .
Shakespearean: By Jeshu , I am your Majesty's countryman , I care not who know it .

English: I will confess it to all the world .
Shakespearean: I will confess it to all the 'orld .

English: I needn't be ashamed of your Majesty , God be praised , so long as your Majesty is an honest man .
Shakespearean: I need not to be ashamed of your Majesty , praised be God , so long as your Majesty is an honest man .

English: God keep me so. , Heralds , go with him .
Shakespearean: God keep me so. , Our heralds go with him .

English: Bring me an exact report of the number of dead on both sides .
Shakespearean: Bring me just notice of the numbers dead On both our parts .

English: Soldier , you must come to the king .
Shakespearean: Soldier , you must come to the king .

English: Soldier , why are you wearing that glove in your cap ?
Shakespearean: Soldier , why wear'st thou that glove in thy cap ?

English: If it pleases your Majesty , it is the token of a man I must fight with , if he's still alive .
Shakespearean: An't please your Majesty , 'tis the gage of one that I should fight withal , if he be alive .

English: An Englishman ?
Shakespearean: An Englishman ?

English: If I may say so , your Majesty , as I see it he would be a coward and a villain not to .
Shakespearean: He is a craven and a villain else , an 't please your Majesty , in my conscience .

English: It may be that his antagonist is a gentleman of very high degree , quite outside of his own sphere .
Shakespearean: It may be his enemy is a gentleman of great sort , quite from the answer of his degree .

English: Even if he were as important a man as the devil , as Lucifer or Beelzebub himself , he's required , see , your Grace , to keep his vow .
Shakespearean: Though he be as good a gentleman as the devil is , as Lucifer and Beelzebub himself , it is necessary , look your Grace , that he keep his vow and his oath .

English: If he backs down , he'll become as notorious a villain and as saucy a Jack as ever walked on God's earth , in my opinion .
Shakespearean: If he be perjured , see you now , his reputation is as arrant a villain and a Jack Sauce as ever his black shoe trod upon God's ground and His earth , in my conscience , la .

English: Then keep your vow , fellow , when you meet the man .
Shakespearean: Then keep thy vow , sirrah , when thou meet'st the fellow .

English: So I will , my liege .
Shakespearean: So I will , my liege , as I live .

English: Whom do you serve under ?
Shakespearean: Who serv'st thou under ?

English: Under Captain Gower , my liege .
Shakespearean: Under Captain Gower , my liege .

English: Gower is a good captain , and is well versed and well read in the wars .
Shakespearean: Gower is a good captain , and is good knowledge and literatured in the wars .

English: Have him come to me here , soldier .
Shakespearean: Call him hither to me , soldier .

English: I will , my liege .
Shakespearean: I will , my liege .

English: Here , Fluellen , stick this in your cap .
Shakespearean: Here , Fluellen , wear thou this favor for me and stick it in thy cap .

English: Your Grace does me as great an honor as could be wished by any of his subjects .
Shakespearean: Your Grace does me as great honors as can be desired in the hearts of his subjects .

English: Do you know Captain Gower ?
Shakespearean: Know'st thou Gower ?

English: He is my dear friend , your Majesty .
Shakespearean: He is my dear friend , an please you .

English: Go find him , please , and bring him to my tent .
Shakespearean: Pray thee , go seek him , and bring him to my tent .

English: I'll fetch him .
Shakespearean: I will fetch him .

English: My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester , follow Fluellen at a close distance .
Shakespearean: My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester , Follow Fluellen closely at the heels .

English: The glove which I have given him to wear may possibly win him a box on the ear .
Shakespearean: The glove which I have given him for a favor May haply purchase him a box o ' th ' ear .

English: According to an agreement , I should wear it myself .
Shakespearean: I by bargain should Wear it myself .

English: Follow and see to it that nothing serious happens between them .
Shakespearean: Follow , and see there be no harm between them .

English: You come with me , uncle of Exeter .
Shakespearean: Go you with me , uncle of Exeter .

English: I'm sure it is to knight you , Captain .
Shakespearean: I warrant it is to knight you , Captain .

English: As it is God's will and pleasure , Captain , I entreat you to come quickly to the king .
Shakespearean: God's will and His pleasure , Captain , I beseech you now , come apace to the king .

English: Sir , do you recognize this glove ?
Shakespearean: Sir , know you this glove ?

English: Know the glove !
Shakespearean: Know the glove !

English: I know the glove is a glove .
Shakespearean: I know the glove is a glove .

English: Well , I recognize this one Good God !
Shakespearean: I know this , and thus I challenge it .

English: As absolute a traitor as any in the whole entire world , or even France or England !
Shakespearean: Sblood , an arrant traitor as any 's in the universal world , or in France , or in England !

English: Do you think I'd break my oath ?
Shakespearean: Do you think I'll be forsworn ?

English: Stand aside , Captain Gower .
Shakespearean: Stand away , Captain Gower .

English: I'll reward treason with blows , I promise you .
Shakespearean: I will give treason his payment into plows , I warrant you .

English: I'm not a traitor .
Shakespearean: I am no traitor .

English: Arrest him : he's a friend of the duke of Alencon's .
Shakespearean: He's a friend of the Duke Alencon's .

English: My Lord of Warwick , a most corrupt treason , God be praised for it ! , has been discovered , as plain as any you'd hope to see on a summer's day .
Shakespearean: My Lord of Warwick , here is , praised be God for it , a most contagious treason come to light , look you , as you shall desire in a summer's day .

English: Here is his Majesty .
Shakespearean: Here is his Majesty .

English: My liege , this man is a villain and a traitor , who , see , your Grace , has struck the glove which your Majesty took from Alencon's helmet .
Shakespearean: My liege , here is a villain and a traitor , that , look your Grace , has struck the glove which your Majesty is take out of the helmet of Alencon .

English: My liege , this was my glove .
Shakespearean: My liege , this was my glove ; here is the fellow of it .

English: I met this man with my glove in his cap , and I have been as good as my word .
Shakespearean: I met this man with my glove in his cap , and I have been as good as my word .

English: Your Majesty , see here , if it won't offend your Grace , what a complete , rascally , beggarly , lousy rat this is .
Shakespearean: Your Majesty , hear now , saving your Majesty's manhood , what an arrant , rascally , beggarly , lousy knave it is .

English: I hope your Majesty will , in all good conscience , bear me out and vouch for the fact that this is the glove of Alencon and that your Majesty gave it to me .
Shakespearean: I hope your Majesty is pear me testimony and witness , and will avouchment that this is the glove of Alencon that your Majesty is give me , in your conscience now .

English: It was I , in fact , whom you promised to strike .
Shakespearean: Twas I indeed thou promised'st to strike , And thou hast given me most bitter terms .

English: And so you do .
Shakespearean: They know your Grace hath cause and means and might ; So hath your Highness .

English: Their bodies may remain here in England , but their hearts are encamped on the fields of France already .
Shakespearean: Never king of England Had nobles richer , and more loyal subjects , Whose hearts have left their bodies here in England And lie pavilioned in the fields of France .

English: Oh , let their bodies follow , my dear king , to win back what's rightfully yours with blood and sword and fire .
Shakespearean: Oh , let their bodies follow , my dear liege , With blood and sword and fire to win your right , In aid whereof we of the spiritualty Will raise your Highness such a mighty sum As never did the clergy at one time Bring in to any of your ancestors .

English: What we have to worry about is a full-scale invasion from Scotland , always an unreliable neighbor .
Shakespearean: We do not mean the coursing snatchers only , But fear the main intendment of the Scot , Who hath been still a giddy neighbor to us .

English: If it pleases your Majesty , let his neck pay the price , if there is any martial law in the world .
Shakespearean: An please your Majesty , let his neck answer for it , if there is any martial law in the world .

English: How can you square things with me ?
Shakespearean: How canst thou make me satisfaction ?

English: You abused me to my face .
Shakespearean: It was ourself thou didst abuse .

English: Your Majesty didn't present yourself as the king .
Shakespearean: Your Majesty came not like yourself .

English: You represented yourself as just a common man .
Shakespearean: You appeared to me but as a common man .

English: Anything your Highness suffered in that disguise , I beg you to see it as your own fault and not mine , because if you'd been what I took you for , there would have been no offense .
Shakespearean: And what your Highness suffered under that shape , I beseech you take it for your own fault and not mine , for , had you been as I took you for , I made no offense .

English: Therefore , I beg your Highness , pardon me .
Shakespearean: Therefore , I beseech your Highness pardon me .

English: I'll have none of your money .
Shakespearean: I will none of your money .

English: It's meant in good will .
Shakespearean: It is with a good will .

English: I tell you , you can use it to get your shoes fixed .
Shakespearean: I can tell you it will serve you to mend your shoes .

English: Come , why be so hesitant ?
Shakespearean: Come , wherefore should you be so pashful ?

English: Your shoes are in pretty bad shape .
Shakespearean: Your shoes is not so good .

English: It's a good shilling , I promise you .
Shakespearean: Tis a good silling , I warrant you , or I will change it .

English: Now , herald , have the dead been counted ?
Shakespearean: Now , herald , are the dead numbered ?

English: Here is the count of the slaughtered French .
Shakespearean: Here is the number of the slaughtered French .

English: What prisoners of rank have been taken , uncle ?
Shakespearean: What prisoners of good sort are taken , uncle ?

English: This paper tells me of ten thousand Frenchmen who lie dead on the battlefield .
Shakespearean: This note doth tell me of ten thousand French That in the field lie slain .

English: Among them are one hundred twenty-six princes and standard-bearing nobles .
Shakespearean: Of princes in this number And nobles bearing banners , there lie dead One hundred twenty-six .

English: Add to these eight thousand four hundred knights , squires , and brave gentlemen , five hundred of whom were given the title of knight only yesterday .
Shakespearean: Added to these , Of knights , esquires , and gallant gentlemen , Eight thousand and four hundred , of the which , Five hundred were but yesterday dubbed knights .

English: Among the ten thousand the French have lost only sixteen hundred are mercenaries .
Shakespearean: So that in these ten thousand they have lost , There are but sixteen hundred mercenaries .

English: The rest of the dead are princes , barons , lords , knights , squires , and gentlemen of birth and rank .
Shakespearean: The rest are princes , barons , lords , knights , squires , And gentlemen of blood and quality .

English: Of brave earls , Grandpre and Roussi , Fauconberg and Foix , Beaumont and Marle , Vaudemont and Lestrale .
Shakespearean: Of lusty earls : Grandpre and Roussi , Faulconbridge and Foix , Beaumont and Marle , Vaudemont and Lestrale .

English: Where is the number of our English dead ?
Shakespearean: Where is the number of our English dead ?

English: When was there ever before so great a loss on one side and so little on the other , in the ordinary and equal clash of battle ?
Shakespearean: When , without stratagem , But in plain shock and even play of battle , Was ever known so great and little loss On one part and on th ' other ?

English: Take credit , God , for it is no one's doing but yours .
Shakespearean: Take it , God , For it is none but thine .

English: It's unbelievable .
Shakespearean: Tis wonderful .

English: Yes , Captain , but with this acknowledgement , that God fought for us .
Shakespearean: Yes , Captain , but with this acknowledgement : That God fought for us .

English: Yes , I truly think He did great good .
Shakespearean: Yes , my conscience , He did us great good .

English: We'll perform all the holy rites .
Shakespearean: Do we all holy rites .

English: As for those who have , I beg you to excuse the gaps in time , and the many people and things that can not be represented here in all their magnitude and proper form .
Shakespearean: Vouchsafe to those that have not read the story That I may prompt them ; and of such as have , I humbly pray them to admit th ' excuse Of time , of numbers , and due course of things , Which can not in their huge and proper life Be here presented .

English: Let's have him land and solemnly proceed to London .
Shakespearean: So let him land , And solemnly see him set on to London .

English: Thoughts work so quickly that even now you can imagine him on Blackheath , where his lords suggest that he should carry his battle-scarred sword and helmet on a procession through the city .
Shakespearean: So swift a pace hath thought that even now You may imagine him upon Blackheath , Where that his lords desire him to have borne His bruised helmet and his bended sword Before him through the city .

English: He refuses , as he is free of vanity and self-serving pride and ascribes all the glory and responsibility for victory to God .
Shakespearean: He forbids it , Being free from vainness and self-glorious pride , Giving full trophy , signal , and ostent Quite from himself , to God .

English: Now in the factory of thought , create the image of all London pouring forth into the streets .
Shakespearean: But now behold , In the quick forge and workinghouse of thought , How London doth pour out her citizens .

English: Picture the mayor and all his brother citizens dressed in their best as they go forth like senators of ancient Rome to welcome home their conquering Caesar .
Shakespearean: The Mayor and all his brethren in best sort , Like to the senators of th ' antique Rome , With the plebeians swarming at their heels , Go forth and fetch their conquering Caesar in , As , by a lower but loving likelihood ,

English: Skip over all the particularities between then and Harry's return to France .
Shakespearean: Then brook abridgment , and your eyes advance After your thoughts , straight back again to France .

English: Saint Davy's Day has passed .
Shakespearean: Saint Davy's day is past .

English: There are reasons and causes why and how in everything .
Shakespearean: There is occasions and causes why and wherefore in all things .

English: We were somewhere where I couldn't pick a fight with him , but I've decided to wear it in my cap until I see him again , whereupon I'll give him a little piece of my mind .
Shakespearean: It was in place where I could not breed no contention with him , but I will be so bold as to wear it in my cap till I see him once again , and then I will tell him a little piece of my desires .

English: And here he comes , puffing himself up like a turkey .
Shakespearean: Why , here he comes , swelling like a turkey-cock .

English: Are you mad ?
Shakespearean: Ha , art thou bedlam ?

English: Away !
Shakespearean: Hence .

English: The smell of leek turns my stomach .
Shakespearean: I am qualmish at the smell of leek .

English: I wonder if you'd be so good , you lousy , rotten villain , to grant my wish and my request and gratify me , see , by eating this leek .
Shakespearean: I peseech you heartily , scurvy , lousy knave , at my desires , and my requests , and my petitions , to eat , look you , this leek .

English: I'd like you to , see , because you don't like it , and because it isn't to your taste , and because it doesn't agree with you .
Shakespearean: Because , look you , you do not love it , nor your affections and your appetites and your digestions does not agree with it , I would desire you to eat it .

English: Not for Cadwallader and all his goats .
Shakespearean: Not for Cadwallader and all his goats .

English: Here's a goat for you .
Shakespearean: There is one goat for you .

English: Dissolute lowlife , you shall die .
Shakespearean: Base Trojan , thou shalt die .

English: That's very true , mangy rascal , when it pleases God .
Shakespearean: You say very true , scald knave , when God's will is .

English: Meanwhile , I'd be gratified if you'd live and eat your food .
Shakespearean: I will desire you to live in the meantime and eat your victuals .

English: Come , here's some sauce to go with it .
Shakespearean: Come , there is sauce for it .

English: Enough , Captain .
Shakespearean: Enough , Captain .

English: You've stunned him .
Shakespearean: You have astonished him .

English: I tell you , I'll either make him eat some part of this leek or give him a four-day head-bashing. , Go on , bite .
Shakespearean: I say I will make him eat some part of my leek , or I will peat his pate four days. , Bite , I pray you .

English: It's good for your fresh wound and your bloody noggin .
Shakespearean: It is good for your green wound and your ploody coxcomb .

English: Must I bite ?
Shakespearean: Must I bite ?

English: Yes , absolutely , no question or ambiguity about it .
Shakespearean: Yes , certainly , and out of doubt and out of question , too , and ambiguities .

English: By this leek , I swear I'll make you pay for this .
Shakespearean: By this leek , I will most horribly revenge .

English: Would you like some more sauce to go with it ?
Shakespearean: Will you have some more sauce to your leek ?

English: There isn't enough leek left for you to swear on .
Shakespearean: There is not enough leek to swear by .

English: Lay off , already !
Shakespearean: Quiet thy cudgel .

English: Can't you see I'm eating ?
Shakespearean: Thou dost see I eat .

English: I sincerely hope it does you good , mangy rascal .
Shakespearean: Much good do you , scald knave , heartily .

English: No , don't throw any of it away .
Shakespearean: Nay , pray you throw none away .

English: The skin is good for your cracked head .
Shakespearean: The skin is good for your broken coxcomb .

English: When you see leeks in the future , I hope you keep mocking them .
Shakespearean: When you take occasions to see leeks hereafter , I pray you , mock at 'em , that is all .

English: Good .
Shakespearean: Good .

English: Yes , leeks are good .
Shakespearean: Ay , leeks is good .

English: Wait , here's a penny to heal your head .
Shakespearean: Hold you , there is a groat to heal your pate .

English: Me , a penny ?
Shakespearean: Me , a groat ?

English: If I owe you anything , I'll pay you in clubbings .
Shakespearean: If I owe you anything , I will pay you in cudgels .

English: You'll become a wood salesman and buy nothing but clubs from me .
Shakespearean: You shall be a woodmonger and buy nothing of me but cudgels .

English: God be with you and keep you , and may he heal your head .
Shakespearean: God be wi ' you and keep you and heal your pate .

English: There'll be hell to pay for this .
Shakespearean: All hell shall stir for this .

English: Go on , get out of here .
Shakespearean: Go , go .

English: You're a lying , cowardly wretch .
Shakespearean: You are a counterfeit cowardly knave .

English: You mock an ancient tradition , born of reverence and worn in honor of brave men who have died , and then have the gall not to stand by your words .
Shakespearean: Will you mock at an ancient tradition begun upon an honorable respect and worn as a memorable trophy of predeceased valor , and dare not avouch in your deeds any of your words ?

English: I've seen you bait and mock this man more than once .
Shakespearean: I have seen you gleeking and galling at this gentleman twice or thrice .

English: You thought because he didn't speak English like a native he couldn't handle an English club .
Shakespearean: You thought because he could not speak English in the native garb , he could not therefore handle an English cudgel .

English: Farewell .
Shakespearean: Fare you well .

English: Has Fortune turned on me , like the whore she is ?
Shakespearean: Doth Fortune play the huswife with me now ?

English: I've had news that my Nell died of the pox in a hospice .
Shakespearean: News have I that my Nell is dead i ' th ' spital Of a malady of France , And there my rendezvous is quite cut off .

English: I grow old , and all dignity has been thrashed out of me .
Shakespearean: Old I do wax , and from my weary limbs Honor is cudgeled .

English: Well , I'll turn pimp and do some occasional pickpocketing .
Shakespearean: Well , bawd I'll turn , And something lean to cutpurse of quick hand .

English: I'll steal away to England , and I'll steal some more when I get there .
Shakespearean: To England will I steal , and there I'll steal .

English: I'll bandage up these wounds and swear I got them in the French wars .
Shakespearean: And patches will I get unto these cudgeled scars , And swear I got them in the Gallia wars .

English: But here's an old , true saying : "If you want to win France , start with Scotland." For when the eagle England leaves her nest to seek prey , the weasel Scot always comes sneaking around to suck dry her princely eggs and , like the mouse when the cat's away , destroy more than she can actually eat .
Shakespearean: But there's a saying very old and true : "If that you will France win , Then with Scotland first begin." For once the eagle England being in prey , To her unguarded nest the weasel Scot Comes sneaking and so sucks her princely eggs , Playing the mouse in absence of the cat , To 'tame and havoc more than she can eat .

English: It would follow from this that the cat should stay home .
Shakespearean: It follows , then , the cat must stay at home .

English: But that is a false conclusion , since we have locks to keep our valuables safe and clever traps to catch little thieves .
Shakespearean: Yet that is but a crushed necessity , Since we have locks to safeguard necessaries And pretty traps to catch the petty thieves .

English: While the armed hand fights in foreign lands , the wise head defends itself at home .
Shakespearean: While that the armed hand doth fight abroad , Th ' advised head defends itself at home .

English: We rejoice to see you , most worthy brother of England .
Shakespearean: Right joyous are we to behold your face , Most worthy brother England .

English: You are welcome here , as are all of you English princes .
Shakespearean: So are you , princes English , every one .

English: We hope your poison has worn off and this day shall transform all grievances and quarrels into friendship .
Shakespearean: The venom of such looks , we fairly hope , Have lost their quality , and that this day Shall change all griefs and quarrels into love .

English: We're here to say "amen" to that .
Shakespearean: To cry "Amen" to that , thus we appear .

English: All you English princes , I salute you .
Shakespearean: You English princes all , I do salute you .

English: Great kings of France and England , I owe you both equal service and loyalty .
Shakespearean: My duty to you both , on equal love , Great kings of France and England .

English: Your Highnesses can both attest to the fact that I've strived mightily , with all my wits and energy , to bring about this royal meeting between you two imperial Majesties .
Shakespearean: That I have labored With all my wits , my pains , and strong endeavors , To bring your most imperial Majesties Unto this bar and royal interview , Your mightiness on both parts best can witness .

English: Alas , she has been too long exiled from France , whose crops all lie in heaps , rotting with ripeness .
Shakespearean: Alas , she hath from France too long been chased , And all her husbandry doth lie on heaps , Corrupting in its own fertility .

English: Her grapes , which make the wine that cheers our hearts , die unpruned on the vines .
Shakespearean: Her vine , the merry cheerer of the heart , Unpruned , dies .

English: Her once-trimmed hedges , like prisoners with wild , untended hair , put forth unruly twigs .
Shakespearean: Her hedges , even-pleached , Like prisoners wildly overgrown with hair , Put forth disordered twigs .

English: Her fallow fields are overgrown with weeds , while the blade that should uproot such wilderness lies rusting .
Shakespearean: Her fallow leas The darnel , hemlock , and rank fumitory Doth root upon , while that the coulter rusts That should deracinate such savagery .

English: The level meadow , where the freckled cowslip , burnet , and green clover once grew , has become useless : unmowed , it grows to seed , so that nothing springs up but weeds , rough thistles , barren plants , and burs .
Shakespearean: The even mead , that erst brought sweetly forth The freckled cowslip , burnet , and green clover , Wanting the scythe , withal uncorrected , rank , Conceives by idleness , and nothing teems But hateful docks , rough thistles , kecksies , burrs , Losing both beauty and utility .

English: children have lost , or no longer have time to learn , skills that should be a credit to our country .
Shakespearean: And as our vineyards , fallows , meads , and hedges , Defective in their natures , grow to wildness , Even so our houses and ourselves and children Have lost , or do not learn for want of time , The sciences that should become our country , But grow like savages , as soldiers will

English: They grow like savages , like soldiers who meditate on nothing but blood , surrounded by swearing and stern looks , ragged clothing and everything unnatural .
Shakespearean: That nothing do but meditate on blood , To swearing and stern looks , diffused attire , And everything that seems unnatural .

English: Duke of Burgundy , if you want peace , the lack of which creates these misfortunes you describe , you must purchase it buy agreeing across-the-board to all our very just demands .
Shakespearean: If , Duke of Burgundy , you would the peace , Whose want gives growth to th ' imperfections Which you have cited , you must buy that peace With full accord to all our just demands , Whose tenors and particular effects You have , enscheduled briefly , in your hands .

English: The king has heard them , but as yet has made no answer .
Shakespearean: The king hath heard them , to the which as yet There is no answer made .

English: Well , the peace you pleaded for so eloquently just now lies in his answer .
Shakespearean: Well then , the peace which you before so urged Lies in his answer .

English: I've only given the articles a cursory glance .
Shakespearean: I have but with a cursitory eye O'erglanced the articles .

English: If your Grace would kindly appoint some members of your council to sit with me once more and go over them more carefully , I will give my answer and acceptance right away .
Shakespearean: Pleaseth your Grace To appoint some of your council presently To sit with us once more with better heed To resurvey them , we will suddenly Pass our accept and peremptory answer .

English: Fair sister , will you go with the princes or stay here with me ?
Shakespearean: And we'll consign thereto. , Will you , fair sister , Go with the princes or stay here with us ?

English: Gracious brother , I will go with them .
Shakespearean: Our gracious brother , I will go with them .

English: Perhaps a woman's voice may do some good when some small detail proves to be holding things up .
Shakespearean: Haply a woman's voice may do some good , When articles too nicely urged be stood on .

English: In that case , leave our cousin Katherine here with us .
Shakespearean: Yet leave our cousin Katherine here with us .

English: She is our principal demand , one of the first points of the treaty .
Shakespearean: She is our capital demand , comprised Within the forerank of our articles .

English: She is welcome to stay .
Shakespearean: She hath good leave .

English: Lovely , most lovely Katherine , will you agree to teach a soldier the words that would recommend his love-suit to a gentle heart like yours ?
Shakespearean: Fair Katherine , and most fair , Will you vouchsafe to teach a soldier terms Such as will enter at a lady's ear And plead his love suit to her gentle heart ?

English: Your Majesty shall mock at me .
Shakespearean: Your Majesty shall mock at me .

English: I can not speak your England .
Shakespearean: I can not speak your England .

English: Lovely Katherine , if you will love me well with your French heart , I'm happy to hear you confess it in broken English .
Shakespearean: O fair Katherine , if you will love me soundly with your French heart , I will be glad to hear you confess it brokenly with your English tongue .

English: Do you like me , Kate ?
Shakespearean: Do you like me , Kate ?

English: Pardon me but I do not know what is "like me." An angel is like you , Kate , and you are like an angel .
Shakespearean: An angel is like you , Kate , and you are like an angel .

English: I said so , dear Katherine , and I'm not ashamed to repeat it .
Shakespearean: I said so , dear Katherine ; and I must not blush to affirm it .

English: Kate , my wooing is fit for your understanding : I am glad your English isn't better .
Shakespearean: The princess is the better Englishwoman. , I ' faith , Kate , my wooing is fit for thy understanding .

English: If it were , you would find me such an ordinary king that you would think I'd sold my farm to buy my crown .
Shakespearean: I am glad thou canst speak no better English , for if thou couldst , thou wouldst find me such a plain king that thou wouldst think I had sold my farm to buy my crown .

English: I don't know any fancy ways of talking about love , only to say right out , "I love you." If you press me any further than with the question , "Do you really ? " my love scene is over .
Shakespearean: I know no ways to mince it in love , but directly to say , "I love you." Then if you urge me farther than to say , "Do you , in faith ? " I wear out my suit .

English: So give me your answer , and we'll shake on it .
Shakespearean: Give me your answer , i ' faith , do ; and so clap hands and a bargain .

English: Deal ?
Shakespearean: How say you , lady ?

English: I have no gift for the one and no strength for the other , though I have the gift of strength .
Shakespearean: For the one , I have neither words nor measure ; and for the other , I have no strength in measure , yet a reasonable measure in strength .

English: If I could win a lady by playing leapfrog or vaulting into my saddle with my armor on my back , though you may accuse me of boasting , I could easily get myself a wife .
Shakespearean: If I could win a lady at leapfrog or by vaulting into my saddle with my armor on my back , under the correction of bragging be it spoken , I should quickly leap into a wife .

English: If you can love a man of this temperament , Kate , whose face a sunburn wouldn't make any worse and who never looks in the mirror to admire himself , let your eye improve me .
Shakespearean: If thou canst love a fellow of this temper , Kate , whose face is not worth sunburning , that never looks in his glass for love of anything he sees there , let thine eye be thy cook .

English: I speak to you as a plain soldier .
Shakespearean: I speak to thee plain soldier .

English: If you can love me for this , take me .
Shakespearean: If thou canst love me for this , take me .

English: If not , to tell you I will die is true , but not for love , by God .
Shakespearean: If not , to say to thee that I shall die is true , but for thy love , by the Lord , no .

English: And yet I do love you .
Shakespearean: Yet I love thee too .

English: So take for life a fellow of pure and plain faithfulness .
Shakespearean: And while thou liv'st , dear Kate , take a fellow of plain and uncoined constancy , for he perforce must do thee right because he hath not the gift to woo in other places .

English: These chatty fellows who can rhyme their way into a lady's good graces always reason themselves out again .
Shakespearean: For these fellows of infinite tongue , that can rhyme themselves into ladies ' favors , they do always reason themselves out again .

English: If you would have such a man , take me .
Shakespearean: If thou would have such a one , take me .

English: So what do you say to my suit ?
Shakespearean: And what say'st thou then to my love ?

English: Speak , my fair one , and speak fairly , I beg you .
Shakespearean: Speak , my fair , and fairly , I pray thee .

English: Is it possible dat I sould love de enemy of France ?
Shakespearean: Is it possible dat I sould love de enemy of France ?

English: No , it is not possible you should love the enemy of France , Kate .
Shakespearean: No , it is not possible you should love the enemy of France , Kate .

English: But in loving me , you would love the friend of France , for I love France so much that I will not part with a single village of it .
Shakespearean: But , in loving me , you should love the friend of France , for I love France so well that I will not part with a village of it .

English: I will have it all mine .
Shakespearean: I will have it all mine .

English: And , Kate , when France is mine and I am yours , then France is yours and you are mine .
Shakespearean: And , Kate , when France is mine and I am yours , then yours is France and you are mine .

English: I don't understand all dat .
Shakespearean: I can not tell wat is dat .

English: No , Kate ?
Shakespearean: No , Kate ?

English: Can any of your neighbors tell , Kate ?
Shakespearean: Can any of your neighbors tell , Kate ?

English: I'll ask them .
Shakespearean: I'll ask them .

English: But mock me gently , dear Kate , because I love you terribly .
Shakespearean: But , good Kate , mock me mercifully , the rather , gentle princess , because I love thee cruelly .

English: Shall we not ?
Shakespearean: Shall we not ?

English: What do you say , my fair I do not know dat .
Shakespearean: What say'st thou , my fair flower de luce ?

English: No , of course you don't .
Shakespearean: I do not know dat .

English: Now there can only be the promise .
Shakespearean: No , 'tis hereafter to know , but now to promise .

English: Do promise , Kate , that you'll do your French part to bring forth such a boy ; and for my English half , take the word of a king and a bachelor .
Shakespearean: Do but now promise , Kate , you will endeavor for your French part of such a boy ; and for my English moiety take the word of a king and a bachelor .

English: I tell you truly , in true English : I love you , Kate .
Shakespearean: By mine honor , in true English , I love thee , Kate .

English: And though I wouldn't dare to swear that you love me , still my blood begins to flatter me that you do , despite the ill effects of my face .
Shakespearean: By which honor I dare not swear thou lovest me , yet my blood begins to flatter me that thou dost , notwithstanding the poor and untempering effect of my visage .

English: Curse my father's ambition !
Shakespearean: Now , beshrew my father's ambition !

English: But I promise you , Kate : the older I grow the better I'll look .
Shakespearean: But , in faith , Kate , the elder I wax , the better I shall appear .

English: My comfort is that old age , that poor preserver of beauty , can't make my face any worse than it already is .
Shakespearean: My comfort is that old age , that ill layer-up of beauty , can do no more spoil upon my face .

English: If you have me , you have me now at my worst ; and if you have me , you'll appreciate me better and better .
Shakespearean: Thou hast me , if thou hast me , at the worst , and thou shalt wear me , if thou wear me , better and better .

English: Therefore tell me , fairest Katherine , will you have me ?
Shakespearean: And therefore tell me , most fair Katherine , will you have me ?

English: Take me by the hand and say , "Harry of England , I am yours." No sooner shall I hear that word than I will tell you straight out , "England is yours , Ireland is yours , France is yours , and Harry Plantagenet
Shakespearean: Put off your maiden blushes , avouch the thoughts of your heart with the looks of an empress , take me by the hand , and say "Harry of England , I am thine , " which word thou shalt no sooner bless mine ear withal , but I will tell

English: is yours." And , though I say so in his presence , if he's not a friend of the best kings , you'll find him king of the best friends .
Shakespearean: thee aloud "England is thine , Ireland is thine , France is thine , and Harry Plantagenet is thine , " who , though I speak it before his face , if he be not fellow with the best king , thou shalt find the best king of good fellows .

English: Come on , tell me in broken music , for your voice is music and your English broken .
Shakespearean: Come , your answer in broken music , for thy voice is music and thy English broken .

English: Come , Katherine Queen of All , reveal your heart to me in broken English .
Shakespearean: Therefore , queen of all , Katherine , break thy mind to me in broken English .

English: Will you have me ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou have me ?

English: Den it shall also content me .
Shakespearean: Den it sall also content me .

English: With that I kiss your hand and call you my queen .
Shakespearean: Upon that I kiss your hand , and I call you my queen .

English: Then I will kiss your lips , Kate .
Shakespearean: Then I will kiss your lips , Kate .

English: What does she say , madam interpreter ?
Shakespearean: Madam my interpreter , what says she ?

English: Dat it not be de custom pour les ladies of France , I can not tell vat is To kiss .
Shakespearean: Dat it is not be de fashion pour les ladies of France , I can not tell wat is To kiss .

English: It is not the custom for the maids in France to kiss before they are married , is that what she says ?
Shakespearean: Your It is not a fashion for the maids in France to kiss before they are married , would she say ?

English: Oh , Kate , prudish customs bow before great kings .
Shakespearean: O Kate , nice customs curtsy to great kings .

English: You and I can not be held within the confines of a country's arbitrary customs , dear Kate .
Shakespearean: Dear Kate , you and I can not be confined within the weak list of a country's fashion .

English: You and I , Kate , we are the makers of custom , and the freedom that goes with our position silences all who would criticize , as I will silence you for upholding the prudish custom of your country in refusing me a kiss .
Shakespearean: We are the makers of manners , Kate , and the liberty that follows our places stops the mouth of all find- faults , as I will do yours for upholding the nice fashion of your country in denying me a kiss .

English: Therefore , willingly and yielding .
Shakespearean: Therefore , patiently and yielding .

English: God save your Majesty .
Shakespearean: God save your Majesty .

English: My royal kinsman , are you teaching our princess English ?
Shakespearean: My royal cousin , teach you our princess English ?

English: I wanted to teach her how perfectly I love her , kinsman , and that's good English .
Shakespearean: I would have her learn , my fair cousin , how perfectly I love her , and that is good English .

English: She picks it up quick , doesn't she ?
Shakespearean: Is she not apt ?

English: So , possessing neither a voice nor a heart for flattery , I can't awaken the spirit of love in her so as to make him appear in his true likeness .
Shakespearean: Our tongue is rough , coz , and my condition is not smooth , so that , having neither the voice nor the heart of flattery about me , I can not so conjure up the spirit of love in her that he will appear in his true likeness .

English: From this , I conclude that many different elements can work toward one common end , just as many arrows , shot from different points , converge on a single target ; just as many roads meet in a single town ; just as many fresh streams empty into only one salt sea ; just as the many radiuses of a
Shakespearean: I this infer : That many things , having full reference To one consent , may work contrariously , As many arrows loosed several ways Come to one mark , as many ways meet in one town , As many fresh streams meet in one salt sea , As many lines close in the dial's center , So may a thousand actions , once afoot , End in one purpose , and be all well borne Without defeat .

English: Forgive my boldness if I take you up on your words about making magic .
Shakespearean: Pardon the frankness of my mirth if I answer you for that .

English: For love to appear in his true likeness , he would have to be as Cupid is : naked and blind .
Shakespearean: If you would conjure in her , you must make a circle ; if conjure up Love in her in his true likeness , he must appear naked and blind .

English: How can you blame her , a tender young maiden still given to virgin blushes , for objecting to having a blind , naked boy appear before her ?
Shakespearean: Can you blame her then , being a maid yet rosed over with the virgin crimson of modesty , if she deny the appearance of a naked blind boy in her naked seeing self ?

English: It's a lot to ask of a maiden .
Shakespearean: It were , my lord , a hard condition for a maid to consign to .

English: They're forgiven , then , if they don't see what they're doing .
Shakespearean: They are then excused , my lord , when they see not what they do .

English: Then teach your cousin to also be willing to close her eyes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Then , good my lord , teach your cousin to consent winking .

English: So you're telling me to give it time and wait for summer .
Shakespearean: This moral ties me over to time and a hot summer .

English: And even then , in order for me to catch the fly your cousin , she must be blind ?
Shakespearean: And so I shall catch the fly , your cousin , in the latter end and she must be blind too .

English: Like love , my lord , before it learns to love .
Shakespearean: As love is , my lord , before it loves .

English: Fair enough .
Shakespearean: It is so .

English: Shall Kate be my wife ?
Shakespearean: Shall Kate be my wife ?

English: If you wish .
Shakespearean: So please you .

English: I am satisfied , as long as the maiden cities you talk of come with her .
Shakespearean: I am content , so the maiden cities you talk of may wait on her .

English: That way , the maiden that stood between me and them shall be the means of my achieving my desire .
Shakespearean: So the maid that stood in the way for my wish shall show me the way to my will .

English: We have consented to all reasonable terms .
Shakespearean: We have consented to all terms of reason .

English: Is that true , my lords of England ?
Shakespearean: Is 't so , my lords of England ?

English: The king has agreed to every point : first his daughter , then everything else , as you strictly proposed .
Shakespearean: The king hath granted every article , His daughter first , and , in sequel , all , According to their firm proposed natures .

English: Except that he has not yet agreed to address you in this form and with this title , in French , And even this I'm willing to grant if you request it .
Shakespearean: Only he hath not yet subscribed this : Where your Majesty demands that the king of France , having any occasion to write for matter of grant , shall name your Highness in this form and with this addition , in French : Nor this I have not , brother , so denied But your request shall make me let it pass .

English: In that case , I ask that for the sake of friendship and alliance you let that one item stand with the rest , and bestow your daughter on me .
Shakespearean: I pray you , then , in love and dear alliance , Let that one article rank with the rest , And thereupon give me your daughter .

English: Amen .
Shakespearean: Amen .

English: Now , welcome , Kate. , And let everyone bear witness that here I kiss her as my sovereign queen .
Shakespearean: Now welcome , Kate , and bear me witness all That here I kiss her as my sovereign queen .

English: May God , who is the best matchmaker , join your hearts and realms in one .
Shakespearean: God , the best maker of all marriages , Combine your hearts in one , your realms in one .

English: God say , "Amen" !
Shakespearean: God speak this "amen" !

English: Amen !
Shakespearean: Amen .

English: Let us prepare for our wedding. , On that day , I'll take your oath of loyalty , my Lord of Burgundy and all my peers , to guarantee my treaty .
Shakespearean: Prepare we for our marriage ; on which day , My Lord of Burgundy , we'll take your oath , And all the peers ' , for surety of our leagues .

English: Then I will swear to Kate and you to me , and may our oaths be faithfully kept and prove fortunate .
Shakespearean: Then shall I swear to Kate , and you to me , And may our oaths well kept and prosp'rous be .

English: Thus far has our straining author pursued the story with his crude , inadequate writing , keeping important people penned up in this little room while he mangled history's full glory with his uneven telling .
Shakespearean: Thus far with rough and all-unable pen Our bending author hath pursued the story , In little room confining mighty men , Mangling by starts the full course of their glory .

English: Henry the Sixth , crowned king of France and England while still in his infancy , succeeded him .
Shakespearean: Henry the Sixth , in infant bands crowned king Of France and England , did this king succeed , Whose state so many had the managing That they lost France and made his England bleed , Which oft our stage hath shown .

English: With those plays in mind , we hope you'll receive this one kindly .
Shakespearean: And for their sake , In your fair minds let this acceptance take .

English: If we can not defend our country with three times such a power left at home , then we deserve to be harassed by an invader and lose our reputation as a powerful and politically savvy nation .
Shakespearean: If we , with thrice such powers left at home , Can not defend our own doors from the dog , Let us be worried , and our nation lose The name of hardiness and policy .

English: Call in the messengers sent from the Dauphin .
Shakespearean: Call in the messengers sent from the Dauphin .

English: I'm ready now to hear what my good cousin the Dauphin has to say , for I hear that the greeting you bear is from him , not the king .
Shakespearean: Now are we well prepared to know the pleasure Of our fair cousin Dauphin , for we hear Your greeting is from him , not from the king .

English: Will your Majesty grant us permission to freely express the message we've been asked to convey ?
Shakespearean: May 't please your Majesty to give us leave Freely to render what we have in charge , Or shall we sparingly show you far off The Dauphin's meaning and our embassy ?

English: Let your thoughts make up for our imperfections .
Shakespearean: Piece out our imperfections with your thoughts .

English: Divide each man into a thousand , and there you will have an imaginary army .
Shakespearean: Into a thousand parts divide one man , And make imaginary puissance .

English: Imagine , when we talk of horses , that you see them planting their proud hooves in the soft earth .
Shakespearean: Think , when we talk of horses , that you see them Printing their proud hoofs i ' th ' receiving earth , For 'tis your thoughts that now must deck our kings , Carry them here and there , jumping o'er times ,

English: I am no tyrant but a Christian king , whose emotions are as tightly controlled as the wretches who languish in our prisons .
Shakespearean: We are no tyrant , but a Christian king , Unto whose grace our passion is as subject As is our wretches fettered in our prisons .

English: Therefore tell me the Dauphin's mind frankly and without constraint .
Shakespearean: Therefore with frank and with uncurbed plainness Tell us the Dauphin's mind .

English: You can't party your way into dukedoms there .
Shakespearean: You can not revel into dukedoms there .

English: And in return for this gift , he wishes you to drop your claim to the dukedoms .
Shakespearean: He therefore sends you , meeter for your spirit , This tun of treasure , and , in lieu of this , Desires you let the dukedoms that you claim Hear no more of you .

English: This is the Dauphin's message .
Shakespearean: This the Dauphin speaks .

English: What's the treasure , uncle ?
Shakespearean: What treasure , uncle ?

English: Tennis balls , my liege .
Shakespearean: Tennis balls , my liege .

English: I'm happy the Dauphin has such a good sense of humor .
Shakespearean: We are glad the Dauphin is so pleasant with us .

English: Thank you for his present and your trouble .
Shakespearean: His present and your pains we thank you for .

English: Once I've put my rackets to these balls , I'll play a set in France , God willing , that will knock his father's crown right out of the court .
Shakespearean: When we have matched our rackets to these balls , We will in France , by God's grace , play a set Shall strike his father's crown into the hazard .

English: And I understand perfectly his sneering reference to my wilder days .
Shakespearean: And we understand him well , How he comes o'er us with our wilder days , Not measuring what use we made of them .

English: Men tend to be at their most irresponsible when they're away from home .
Shakespearean: We never valued this poor seat of England And therefore , living hence , did give ourself To barbarous license , as 'tis ever common That men are merriest when they are from home .

English: So go in peace .
Shakespearean: So get you hence in peace .

English: And tell the Dauphin his joke will look pretty stupid when thousands more weep than ever laughed at it .
Shakespearean: And tell the Dauphin His jest will savor but of shallow wit When thousands weep more than did laugh at it .

English: That was a humorous message .
Shakespearean: This was a merry message .

English: I hope to make the sender blush for it .
Shakespearean: We hope to make the sender blush at it .

English: Now , lords , don't let slip any opportunity that might be advantageous for our expedition .
Shakespearean: Therefore , my lords , omit no happy hour That may give furth'rance to our expedition ; For we have now no thought in us but France , Save those to God , that run before our business .

English: Therefore , let every man give some thought to how this noble expedition may be undertaken .
Shakespearean: Therefore let every man now task his thought , That this fair action may on foot be brought .

English: Now all the young men of England are inspired and have stored their party clothes in the closet .
Shakespearean: Now all the youth of England are on fire , And silken dalliance in the wardrobe lies .

English: shifts , friends , to Southampton .
Shakespearean: Ere he take ship for France , and in Southampton .

English: From there we'll safely carry you to France and back , calming the waters of the Channel to provide you with a smooth voyage .
Shakespearean: There is the playhouse now , there must you sit , And thence to France shall we convey you safe And bring you back , charming the narrow seas To give you gentle pass ; for , if we may , We'll not offend one stomach with our play .

English: But we won't shift the scene to Southampton until Henry reappears .
Shakespearean: But , till the king come forth , and not till then , Unto Southampton do we shift our scene .

English: Good to see you , Corporal Nym .
Shakespearean: Well met , Corporal Nym .

English: Good day , Lieutenant Bardolph .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , Lieutenant Bardolph .

English: Tell me , are you and Ensign Pistol friends again yet ?
Shakespearean: What , are Ancient Pistol and you friends yet ?

English: For my part , I really don't care .
Shakespearean: For my part , I care not .

English: Then we can all three be comrades on our way to France .
Shakespearean: I will bestow a breakfast to make you friends ; and we'll be all three sworn brothers to France .

English: How about it , Corporal Nym ?
Shakespearean: Let 't be so , good Corporal Nym .

English: That's it .
Shakespearean: That is my rest ; that is the rendezvous of it .

English: It's not for me to say .
Shakespearean: I can not tell .

English: Things are what they are .
Shakespearean: Things must be as they may .

English: Men may sleep , and when they do they may have their throats with them , and some people say knives have blades .
Shakespearean: Men may sleep , and they may have their throats about them at that time , and some say knives have edges .

English: There must be some resolution .
Shakespearean: There must be conclusions .

English: Well , it's not for me to say .
Shakespearean: Well , I can not tell .

English: Here comes Ensign Pistol and his wife .
Shakespearean: Here comes Ancient Pistol and his wife .

English: I swear , I scorn the word .
Shakespearean: Now , by this hand , I swear , I scorn the term , Nor shall my Nell keep lodgers .

English: Oh , dear .
Shakespearean: Oh , well-a-day , Lady !

English: Pish !
Shakespearean: Pish !

English: Pish to you , you mangy dog , you pointy-eared Icelandic mutt .
Shakespearean: Pish for thee , Iceland dog , Thou prick-eared cur of Iceland !

English: Corporal Nym , be a man and put away your sword .
Shakespearean: Good Corporal Nym , show thy valor and put up your sword .

English: Get lost , will you ?
Shakespearean: Will you shog off ?

English: I am not some fiend of hell : you can't get rid of me with spells .
Shakespearean: I am not Barbason ; you can not conjure me .

English: I'm in a mood to beat you up pretty good .
Shakespearean: I have an humor to knock you indifferently well .

English: If you get nasty with me , Pistol , I'll stab you with my sword , in fair play .
Shakespearean: If you grow foul with me , Pistol , I will scour you with my rapier , as I may , in fair terms .

English: Your grave is gaping open , and your death is near .
Shakespearean: O braggart vile and damned furious wight , The grave doth gape , and doting death is near .

English: So take your last breath .
Shakespearean: Therefore exhale .

English: Listen , listen to what I say : whoever strikes first , I'll run him through with my sword , as sure as I'm a soldier .
Shakespearean: Hear me , hear me what I say : he that strikes the first stroke , I'll run him up to the hilts , as I am a soldier .

English: That's an oath of great power , and our fury must subside .
Shakespearean: An oath of mickle might , and fury shall abate .

English: That's enough .
Shakespearean: Thy spirits are most tall .

English: I swear , he'll be food for the crows soon .
Shakespearean: By my troth , he'll yield the crow a pudding one of these days .

English: The king has broken his heart .
Shakespearean: The king has killed his heart .

English: Good husband , come home soon .
Shakespearean: Good husband , come home presently .

English: Come on , can I get you two to make up ?
Shakespearean: Come , shall I make you two friends ?

English: Let rivers flood and fiends howl for food !
Shakespearean: Let floods o'erswell and fiends for food howl on !

English: Are you going to pay the eight shillings I won from you in a bet ?
Shakespearean: You'll pay me the eight shillings I won of you at betting ?

English: Paying debts is for peasants .
Shakespearean: Base is the slave that pays .

English: I'm going to take it from you now .
Shakespearean: That now I will have , that's the humor of it .

English: We'll see , won't we ?
Shakespearean: As manhood shall compound .

English: Do your best .
Shakespearean: Push home .

English: By this sword , I'll kill whichever one of you makes the first thrust .
Shakespearean: By this sword , he that makes the first thrust , I'll kill him .

English: By this sword , I will .
Shakespearean: By this sword , I will .

English: By this sword" is an oath , and oaths must be kept .
Shakespearean: Sword" is an oath , and oaths must have their course .

English: Come on , put it away .
Shakespearean: Prithee , put up .

English: In cash .
Shakespearean: In cash , most justly paid .

English: Well , then , that's how it is .
Shakespearean: Well , then , that's the humor of 't .

English: If you ever had a mother , come in quickly to Sir John .
Shakespearean: As ever you come of women , come in quickly to Sir John .

English: The poor thing , he is so shaken with a fever that it's terrible to see .
Shakespearean: Ah , poor heart , he is so shaked of a burning quotidian tertian that it is most lamentable to behold .

English: Sweet men , come to him .
Shakespearean: Sweet men , come to him .

English: And , as the speaker of any prologue should , I ask you to hear our play courteously and to judge it kindly .
Shakespearean: Turning th ' accomplishment of many years Into an hour-glass ; for the which supply , Admit me chorus to this history ; Who , prologue-like , your humble patience pray Gently to hear , kindly to judge our play .

English: Nym , what you say is true .
Shakespearean: Nym , thou hast spoke the right .

English: He has his moods and his ways .
Shakespearean: He passes some humors and careers .

English: How smooth and cool they seem !
Shakespearean: They shall be apprehended by and by .

English: Just as if they were perfectly loyal and faithful .
Shakespearean: How smooth and even they do bear themselves , As if allegiance in their bosoms sat Crowned with faith and constant loyalty .

English: The king has been informed of all their plans , but they have no idea .
Shakespearean: The king hath note of all that they intend , By interception which they dream not of .

English: Now that the wind is favorable , let's board the ship .
Shakespearean: Now sits the wind fair , and we will aboard .

English: My Lord of Cambridge and my good Lord of Masham and you , my noble knight , what do you think ?
Shakespearean: My Lord of Cambridge , and my kind Lord of Masham , And you , my gentle knight , give me your thoughts .

English: Will our army cut a swath through the fighting force of France , achieving and accomplishing everything I've assembled them to do ?
Shakespearean: Think you not that the powers we bear with us Will cut their passage through the force of France , Doing the execution and the act For which we have in head assembled them ?

English: No doubt it will , my liege , if each man does his best .
Shakespearean: No doubt , my liege , if each man do his best .

English: I have no doubt about that , since I know there isn't a man among us who isn't with me wholeheartedly , or a soul left behind who doesn't wish us success and conquest .
Shakespearean: I doubt not that , since we are well-persuaded We carry not a heart with us from hence That grows not in a fair consent with ours , Nor leave not one behind that doth not wish Success and conquest to attend on us .

English: There never was a monarch better feared and loved than yourself , your Majesty .
Shakespearean: Never was monarch better feared and loved Than is your Majesty .

English: I don't think there's a single unhappy subject living under the protection of your government .
Shakespearean: There's not , I think , a subject That sits in heart-grief and uneasiness Under the sweet shade of your government .

English: True .
Shakespearean: True .

English: Those who were bitter enemies of your father in his time have turned their bitterness to sweetness , serving you loyally and wholeheartedly .
Shakespearean: Those that were your father's enemies Have steeped their galls in honey , and do serve you With hearts create of duty and of zeal .

English: Yes , I have great cause to be thankful .
Shakespearean: We therefore have great cause of thankfulness And shall forget the office of our hand Sooner than quittance of desert and merit According to the weight and worthiness .

English: Uncle of Exeter , release the man who was arrested yesterday for railing against me .
Shakespearean: We judge no less. , Uncle of Exeter , Enlarge the man committed yesterday That railed against our person .

English: That's merciful but a bit careless .
Shakespearean: That's mercy , but too much security .

English: Oh , let us be merciful anyway .
Shakespearean: Oh , let us yet be merciful .

English: And now , let's turn to our business with the French .
Shakespearean: And now to our French causes .

English: Who are the new commissioners ?
Shakespearean: Who are the late commissioners ?

English: I am one , my lord .
Shakespearean: I one , my lord .

English: Your Highness told me to ask for my commission today .
Shakespearean: Your Highness bade me ask for it today .

English: You told me to do the same , my liege .
Shakespearean: So did you me , my liege .

English: And me , too , my royal sovereign .
Shakespearean: And I , my royal sovereign .

English: I confess my crime and throw myself on your Highness's mercy .
Shakespearean: I do confess my fault , And do submit me to Your Highness ' mercy .

English: To which we all appeal .
Shakespearean: To which we all appeal .

English: The mercy that was alive in me a moment ago was smothered and killed by your own advice .
Shakespearean: The mercy that was quick in us but late By your own counsel is suppressed and killed .

English: Though the truth of your treachery is as plain as black on white , I can scarcely believe it , it's so past understanding .
Shakespearean: Tis so strange That , though the truth of it stands off as gross As black and white , my eye will scarcely see it .

English: All other devils who tempt people to treason patch together some motive , put together from shreds
Shakespearean: Treason and murder ever kept together As two yoke-devils sworn to either's purpose , Working so grossly in a natural cause That admiration did not whoop at them .

English: and patches of righteousness .
Shakespearean: All other devils that suggest by treasons Do botch and bungle up damnation With patches , colors , and with forms being fetched From glist'ring semblances of piety .

English: But the devil that tempted you gave you no reason why you should commit treason other than to win the name of traitor .
Shakespearean: But he that tempered thee bade thee stand up , Gave thee no instance why thou shouldst do treason , Unless to dub thee with the name of traitor .

English: The demon who seduced you could stride the world over with the proud gait of a lion , could return to hell and tell the devil's legions , "I will never win another soul as easily as I won that Englishman's." How you have poisoned my faith in people !
Shakespearean: If that same demon that hath gulled thee thus Should with his lion gait walk the whole world , He might return to vasty Tartar back And tell the legions "I can never win A soul so easy as that Englishman's." Oh , how hast thou with jealousy infected The sweetness of affiance !

English: Why , so did you .
Shakespearean: Why , so didst thou .

English: Why , so did you .
Shakespearean: Why , so didst thou .

English: Do they come from good families ?
Shakespearean: Come they of noble family ?

English: Why , so did you .
Shakespearean: Why , so didst thou .

English: Do they seem religious ?
Shakespearean: Seem they religious ?

English: Why , so did you .
Shakespearean: Why , so didst thou .

English: That's how sound a man you appeared .
Shakespearean: Such and so finely bolted didst thou seem .

English: Your fall has left a blot that opens even the best and brightest to suspicion .
Shakespearean: And thus thy fall hath left a kind of blot To mark the full-fraught man and best endued With some suspicion .

English: This treachery of yours is like the second
Shakespearean: I will weep for thee , For this revolt of thine methinks is like Another fall of man. , Their faults are open .

English: Richard Earl of Cambridge , I arrest you for high treason .
Shakespearean: I arrest thee of high treason , by the name of Richard , Earl of Cambridge .

English: Henry Lord Scroop of Masham , I arrest you for high treason .
Shakespearean: I arrest thee of high treason , by the name of Henry , Lord Scroop of Masham .

English: Thomas Grey , knight , of Northumberland , I arrest you for high treason .
Shakespearean: I arrest thee of high treason , by the name of Thomas Grey , knight , of Northumberland .

English: I regret my crime more than my death , and I beg your Highness to forgive me , while punishing my body with death .
Shakespearean: Our purposes God justly hath discovered , And I repent my fault more than my death , Which I beseech Your Highness to forgive , Although my body pay the price of it .

English: But I thank God that I failed in my scheme , and I rejoice in paying the penalty , as I beg God and you to pardon me .
Shakespearean: For me , the gold of France did not seduce , Although I did admit it as a motive The sooner to effect what I intended ; But God be thanked for prevention , Which I in sufferance heartily will rejoice , Beseeching God and you to pardon me .

English: No faithful subject ever rejoiced more at the discovery of most dangerous treason than I now rejoice that I was thwarted in a damnable undertaking .
Shakespearean: Never did faithful subject more rejoice At the discovery of most dangerous treason Than I do at this hour joy o'er myself , Prevented from a damned enterprise .

English: Pardon my crime , sovereign , but not my person .
Shakespearean: My fault , but not my body , pardon , sovereign .

English: May God in His mercy forgive you .
Shakespearean: God quit you in His mercy .

English: I seek no revenge for myself , but so dearly do I hold the safety of my kingdom , which you sought to destroy , that you must be punished according to her laws .
Shakespearean: Touching our person , seek we no revenge , But we our kingdom's safety must so tender , Whose ruin you have sought , that to her laws We do deliver you .

English: So go to your deaths , poor miserable wretches , the pain of which may merciful God give you the strength to endure .
Shakespearean: Get you therefore hence , Poor miserable wretches , to your death , The taste whereof God of His mercy give You patience to endure , and true repentance Of all your dear offences. , Bear them hence .

English: I have no doubt that it will be a swift and successful war , since God so graciously exposed this dangerous plot .
Shakespearean: We doubt not of a fair and lucky war , Since God so graciously hath brought to light This dangerous treason lurking in our way To hinder our beginnings .

English: I'm now sure that every bump in the road has been removed .
Shakespearean: We doubt not now But every rub is smoothed on our way .

English: Let's go forth , dear countrymen .
Shakespearean: Then forth , dear countrymen .

English: I'll be no king of England if I'm not also king of France .
Shakespearean: No king of England if not king of France .

English: No , because my manly heart is grieving .
Shakespearean: For Falstaff , he is dead , and we must earn therefore .

English: Bardolph , be happy. , Nym , rouse your bragging spirits. , Boy , be brave .
Shakespearean: He's in Arthur's bosom , if ever man went to Arthur's bosom .

English: Oh , no , he's surely not in hell .
Shakespearean: I hoped there was no need to trouble himself with any such thoughts yet .

English: He's in They say he cried out against sherry .
Shakespearean: They say he cried out of sack .

English: Yes , he did .
Shakespearean: Ay , that he did .

English: And women .
Shakespearean: And of women .

English: No , he did not .
Shakespearean: Nay , that he did not .

English: He could never bear carnation .
Shakespearean: A could never abide carnation .

English: It was a color he never did like .
Shakespearean: Twas a color he never liked .

English: He once said the devil would get him because of women .
Shakespearean: He said once the devil would have him about women .

English: He did touch on women a bit , but his body was aching with fever and he talked about the Whore of Babylon .
Shakespearean: He did in some sort , indeed , handle women , but then he was rheumatic , and talked of the Whore of Babylon .

English: Don't you remember how he saw a flea land on Bardolph's nose and said it was a black soul burning in hell ?
Shakespearean: Do you not remember he saw a flea stick upon Bardolph's nose , and he said it was a black soul burning in hell ?

English: Well , the Shall we get moving ?
Shakespearean: Shall we shog ?

English: The king will already have left Southampton .
Shakespearean: The King will be gone from Southampton .

English: Look after my goods and possessions .
Shakespearean: Look to my chattels and my movables .

English: My lord , this bill that's being proposed is the same one that was proposed in the eleventh year of old King Henry's reign .
Shakespearean: Therefore , Go , clear thy crystals. , Yoke-fellows in arms , Let us to France , like horse-leeches , my boys , To suck , to suck , the very blood to suck .

English: Everyone thought it would pass then , and it probably would have had it not been for the great civil unrest and uncertainty of the time , which required the matter to be put off .
Shakespearean: My lord , I'll tell you that self bill is urged Which in th ' eleventh year of the last king's reign Was like , and had indeed against us passed But that the scambling and unquiet time Did push it out of farther question .

English: But how will we keep it from being passed now , my lord ?
Shakespearean: But how , my lord , shall we resist it now ?

English: We have to think about that .
Shakespearean: It must be thought on .

English: If it does pass , the Church will lose more than half of what it possesses , because the bill would strip us of enough real estate left to the church by wealthy , pious men in their wills to support fifteen earls and fifteen hundred knights , six thousand two hundred squires , and a hundred well-supplied almshouses for the relief of lepers , old-age pensioners , the poor , and those too weak or sick to work .
Shakespearean: If it pass against us , We lose the better half of our possession , For all the temporal lands which men devout By testament have given to the Church Would they strip from us , being valued thus : "As much as would maintain , to the King's honor , Full fifteen earls and fifteen hundred knights , Six thousand and two hundred good esquires ; And , to relief of lazars and weak age Of indigent faint souls past corporal toil , A hundred almshouses right well supplied ; And to the coffers of the King besides , A thousand pounds by th ' year." Thus runs the bill .

English: That's what the bill says .
Shakespearean: This would drink deep .

English: But what can be done to prevent it ?
Shakespearean: But what prevention ?

English: The king is virtuous and kind .
Shakespearean: The king is full of grace and fair regard .

English: And a true lover of the holy Church .
Shakespearean: And a true lover of the holy Church .

English: I've heard that's not the most nourishing food .
Shakespearean: And that's but unwholesome food , they say .

English: Kiss her soft mouth , and we'll be off .
Shakespearean: Touch her soft mouth , and march .

English: Farewell , hostess .
Shakespearean: Farewell , hostess .

English: Be thrifty .
Shakespearean: Let housewifery appear .

English: And keep yourself hidden , I command you .
Shakespearean: Keep close , I thee command .

English: Farewell .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: Adieu .
Shakespearean: Adieu .

English: Therefore the dukes of Berri , Bretagne , Brabant , and Orleans shall advance , and you , Prince Dauphin , will swiftly entrench and fortify our fortress towns with men of courage and the means to defend themselves .
Shakespearean: Therefore the Dukes of Berri and of Brittany , Of Brabant and of Orleans , shall make forth , And you , Prince Dauphin , with all swift dispatch , To line and new-repair our towns of war With men of courage and with means defendant .

English: The king of England's approach is as forceful as a whirlpool .
Shakespearean: For England his approaches makes as fierce As waters to the sucking of a gulf .

English: Let's do it with no show of anxiety , no , with no more fear than if we'd heard that the English were busying themselves with folk dancing .
Shakespearean: And let us do it with no show of fear , No , with no more than if we heard that England Were busied with a Whitsun morris-dance .

English: Because , my good king , England is so poorly led , her scepter so foolishly borne by a vain , silly , shallow , impulsive youth , that she's hardly a threat .
Shakespearean: For , my good liege , she is so idly kinged , Her scepter so fantastically borne By a vain , giddy , shallow , humorous youth , That fear attends her not .

English: Oh , please , Prince Dauphin !
Shakespearean: Oh peace , Prince Dauphin !

English: You are completely wrong about this king .
Shakespearean: You are too much mistaken in this king .

English: Talk to the ambassadors who've just come back : ask them how majestically he responded to their message , how well supplied he was with good advisors , how restrained in expressing his displeasure , and , moreover , how terrifyingly firm he was in his resolve .
Shakespearean: Question your Grace the late ambassadors With what great state he heard their embassy , How well supplied with noble counselors , How modest in exception , and withal How terrible in constant resolution , And you shall find his vanities forespent Were but the outside of the Roman Brutus , Covering discretion with a coat of folly , As gardeners do with ordure hide those roots That shall first spring and be most delicate .

English: You'll discover that his youthful follies were like the persona that Well , you're wrong , my Lord High Constable .
Shakespearean: Well , 'tis not so , my Lord High Constable .

English: But even if I thought you were right , it doesn't matter .
Shakespearean: But though we think it so , it is no matter .

English: When it comes to defense , it's best to assume that the enemy is more powerful than he seems .
Shakespearean: In cases of defense 'tis best to weigh The enemy more mighty than he seems .

English: crowned by the golden sun , observed his heroic son and smiled to see him mangle the work of nature , French youth whose fathers and God had nurtured for twenty years , since they were babies .
Shakespearean: Up in the air , crowned with the golden sun , Saw his heroical seed and smiled to see him Mangle the work of nature and deface The patterns that by God and by French fathers Had twenty years been made .

English: This king is a branch of that same victorious stock .
Shakespearean: This is a stem Of that victorious stock , and let us fear The native mightiness and fate of him .

English: Ambassadors of Harry , king of England , request a hearing with your Majesty .
Shakespearean: Ambassadors from Harry King of England Do crave admittance to your Majesty .

English: We'll see them immediately .
Shakespearean: We'll give them present audience .

English: Bring them right in .
Shakespearean: Go , and bring them .

English: My good King , surprise the English and let them know what kind of kingdom you rule over .
Shakespearean: Good my sovereign , Take up the English short , and let them know Of what a monarchy you are the head .

English: Self-love , my liege , is not so great a sin as self-neglect .
Shakespearean: Self-love , my liege , is not so vile a sin As self-neglecting .

English: From our brother monarch , the king of England ?
Shakespearean: From our brother England ?

English: And what will happen if I don't ?
Shakespearean: Or else what follows ?

English: Bloodshed will force you to .
Shakespearean: Bloody constraint , for if you hide the crown Even in your hearts , there will he rake for it .

English: I'll think it over .
Shakespearean: For us , we will consider of this further .

English: Tomorrow , I'll let you know what I've decided and what answer you should deliver to the king of England .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow shall you bear our full intent Back to our brother England .

English: Regarding the Dauphin , you can speak to me .
Shakespearean: For the Dauphin , I stand here for him .

English: What's the message from the English king ?
Shakespearean: What to him from England ?

English: Scorn and defiance , indifference , contempt , and any insult that wouldn't disgrace the mighty sender , that's the value he puts on you .
Shakespearean: Scorn and defiance , slight regard , contempt , And anything that may not misbecome The mighty sender , doth he prize you at .

English: And my king goes on : if your royal father does not sweeten the bitter insult you sent my king and grant all our demands , Henry's artillery will give you so resounding an answer that the very caves and vaulted cathedrals of France shall echo your mocking of him back in your face .
Shakespearean: Thus says my king : an if your father's Highness Do not , in grant of all demands at large , Sweeten the bitter mock you sent his Majesty , He'll call you to so hot an answer of it That caves and womby vaultages of France Shall chide your trespass and return your mock In second accent of his ordinance .

English: To that end , I presented him with the tennis balls , the perfect expression of his inexperience and frivolity .
Shakespearean: To that end , As matching to his youth and vanity , I did present him with the Paris balls .

English: He'll make your palace tremble for this insult , even if it were the mightiest in all of Europe .
Shakespearean: He'll make your Paris Louvre shake for it , Were it the mistress court of mighty Europe .

English: And , make no mistake , you'll find , as we his subjects have , an amazing difference between the king as a young man and the way he is now .
