Shakespearean: And be assured you'll find a difference , As we his subjects have in wonder found , Between the promise of his greener days And these he masters now .

English: We'll give you an answer tomorrow .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow shall you know our mind at full .

English: Don't take too long , unless you want our king to come after me to ask what's holding things up , because he's already landed here .
Shakespearean: Dispatch us with all speed , lest that our king Come here himself to question our delay , For he is footed in this land already .

English: You'll have your answer soon .
Shakespearean: You shall be soon dispatched with fair conditions .

English: A night isn't much time for addressing matters of this importance .
Shakespearean: A night is but small breath and little pause To answer matters of this consequence .

English: And so , on the wings of imagination and at the speed of thought , our scene flies swiftly on .
Shakespearean: Thus with imagined wing our swift scene flies In motion of no less celerity Than that of thought .

English: Picture the cabin boys climbing around the rigging .
Shakespearean: Play with your fancies and in them behold , Upon the hempen tackle , shipboys climbing .

English: Hear the shrill whistle that brings order to the hubbub .
Shakespearean: Hear the shrill whistle , which doth order give To sounds confused .

English: Picture the linen sails driven by the invisible and subtle wind as they pull the vast hulls through the wrinkled sea , breasting the high waves .
Shakespearean: Behold the threaden sails , Borne with th ' invisible and creeping wind , Draw the huge bottoms through the furrowed sea , Breasting the lofty surge .

English: Pretend that you're standing on the shore , watching a city dance on the shifting waves , and you'll have an idea of the look of this majestic fleet as it holds a straight course for Harfleur .
Shakespearean: Oh , do but think You stand upon the rivage and behold A city on th ' inconstant billows dancing , For so appears this fleet majestical Holding due course to Harfleur .

English: Follow it , follow it !
Shakespearean: Follow , follow !

English: Once there , make your thoughts work harder , and witness a siege .
Shakespearean: Work , work your thoughts , and therein see a siege .

English: Take in the wheeled canons with their deadly gaping mouths trained on the walled city of Harfleur .
Shakespearean: Behold the ordnance on their carriages , With fatal mouths gaping on girded Harfleur .

English: Imagine the French ambassador returning to inform Harry that the king offers him
Shakespearean: Suppose th ' Ambassador from the French comes back , Tells Harry that the king doth offer him

English: his daughter , Katherine , with some insignificant , unprofitable dukedoms as her dowry .
Shakespearean: Katherine his daughter and with her , to dowry , Some petty and unprofitable dukedoms .

English: Indulge us further and supplement our performance with your own imaginings .
Shakespearean: Still be kind And eke out our performance with your mind .

English: Attack the breach in the city wall once more , dear friends , attack it once more , or else let's close it up with English corpses .
Shakespearean: Once more unto the breach , dear friends , once more , Or close the wall up with our English dead !

English: Now grit your teeth and let your nostrils flare .
Shakespearean: Now set the teeth and stretch the nostril wide , Hold hard the breath and bend up every spirit To his full height .

English: On , on , you noblest Englishmen , descended as you are from battle-tested fathers , fathers who , like so many Alexander the Greats , have fought in these regions from morning until night , sheathing their swords only when there was no one left to fight .
Shakespearean: On , on , you noblest English , Whose blood is fet from fathers of war-proof , Fathers that , like so many Alexanders , Have in these parts from morn till even fought And sheathed their swords for lack of argument .

English: Don't dishonor your mothers !
Shakespearean: Dishonor not your mothers .

English: Prove that the men you call your fathers did truly conceive you .
Shakespearean: Now attest That those whom you called fathers did beget you .

English: And you , good farmers , whose limbs were made in England , show us here the vigor of your upbringing .
Shakespearean: And you , good yeoman , Whose limbs were made in England , show us here The mettle of your pasture .

English: Prove you are worthy of your birth , which I do not doubt for a moment .
Shakespearean: Let us swear That you are worth your breeding , which I doubt not ,

English: We are fortunate in the change .
Shakespearean: We are blessed in the change .

English: Listen to him talk about war , and you'll hear elegant and thrilling accounts of the battles .
Shakespearean: List his discourse of war , and you shall hear A fearful battle rendered you in music .

English: Follow your spirit , and as you charge cry , "God for Harry , England , and Saint George ! "
Shakespearean: Follow your spirit , and upon this charge Cry "God for Harry , England , and Saint George ! "

English: On , on , on , on , on !
Shakespearean: On , on , on , on , on !

English: To the breach , to the breach !
Shakespearean: To the breach , to the breach !

English: Please , corporal , stop !
Shakespearean: Pray thee , corporal , stay .

English: You can see how it is all around .
Shakespearean: The plainsong" is most just , for humors do abound .

English: I wish I were in an alehouse in London !
Shakespearean: Would I were in an alehouse in London !

English: I would give all my glory for a mug of ale and safety .
Shakespearean: I would give all my fame for a pot of ale , and safety .

English: Me too .
Shakespearean: And I .

English: Up to the breach , you dogs !
Shakespearean: Up to the breach , you dogs !

English: Go !
Shakespearean: Avaunt , you cullions !

English: Great Duke , be merciful to mortal men .
Shakespearean: Be merciful , great duke , to men of mold .

English: Dear man , calm your rage .
Shakespearean: Good bawcock , 'bate thy rage .

English: Be lenient , dearest !
Shakespearean: Use lenity , sweet chuck .

English: This is healthy talk .
Shakespearean: These be good humors .

English: Your Honor's is unhealthy talk .
Shakespearean: Your Honor wins bad humors .

English: Young though I am , I've been observing these three blowhards closely .
Shakespearean: As young as I am , I have observed these three swashers .

English: Yet not one among them , if all three were to wait on me , could be my "man , " because three such fakes don't amount to a man .
Shakespearean: I am boy to them all three , but all they three , though they would serve me , could not be man to me .

English: They will steal anything and call it spoils .
Shakespearean: They will steal anything and call it purchase .

English: They would like me to be as familiar with men's pockets as their gloves and handkerchiefs , which goes against my manhood , because to take something from another's pocket and put it into my own is plain stealing .
Shakespearean: They would have me as familiar with men's pockets as their gloves or their handkerchers , which makes much against my manhood , if I should take from another's pocket to put into mine , for it is plain pocketing up of wrongs .

English: I must leave them and seek some better employment .
Shakespearean: I must leave them and seek some better service .

English: Their villainy nauseates me , and I must therefore vomit it up .
Shakespearean: Their villainy goes against my weak stomach , and therefore I must cast it up .

English: The tunnels !
Shakespearean: To the mines ?

English: For the enemy , see , and you can explain this to the duke , see , has dug its own tunnels four yards below ours .
Shakespearean: The concavities of it is not sufficient , for , look you , th ' athversary , you may discuss unto the duke , look you , is digt himself four yard under the countermines .

English: By Jesus , I think they will blow up everything if we don't improve our tactics .
Shakespearean: By Cheshu , I think he will plow up all if there is not better directions .

English: The duke of Gloucester , who has command over the siege , is in consultation with an Irishman , a very valiant gentleman indeed .
Shakespearean: The duke of Gloucester , to whom the order of the siege is given , is altogether directed by an Irishman , a very valiant gentleman , i ' faith .

English: It's Captain Macmorris , right ?
Shakespearean: It is Captain Macmorris , is it not ?

English: I think so .
Shakespearean: I think it be .

English: Jesus , he's an ass if there ever was one !
Shakespearean: By Cheshu , he is an ass , as in the world .

English: I will say as much to his face .
Shakespearean: I will verify as much in his beard .

English: He knows no more about the proper practice of war , see , the ancient practices , than a puppy .
Shakespearean: He has no more directions in the true disciplines of the wars , look you , of the Roman disciplines , than is a puppy dog .

English: Here he comes with Captain Jamy , the Scots captain .
Shakespearean: Here he comes , and the Scots captain , Captain Jamy , with him .

English: Captain Jamy is a wonderfully valorous gentleman , that's certain , one with great learning and knowledge concerning ancient warfare , I happen to know from his maneuvers .
Shakespearean: Captain Jamy is a marvelous falorous gentleman , that is certain , and of great expedition and knowledge in th ' aunchient wars , upon my particular knowledge of his directions .

English: By Jesus , he will defend his position on the practices of the ancient Roman wars as well as any military man in the world .
Shakespearean: By Cheshu , he will maintain his argument as well as any military man in the world in the disciplines of the pristine wars of the Romans .

English: Good day to you , Captain Fluellen .
Shakespearean: I say gudday , Captain Fluellen .

English: Good evening to your Worship , good Captain James .
Shakespearean: Godden to your Worship , good Captain James .

English: Tell me , Captain Macmorris , have you left the tunnels ?
Shakespearean: How now , Captain Macmorris , have you quit the mines ?

English: Have the excavators stopped work ?
Shakespearean: Have the pioneers given o'er ?

English: Christ , it's a disaster .
Shakespearean: By Chrish , la , 'tish ill done .

English: I swear by this hand and my father's soul , the whole thing is a disaster .
Shakespearean: By my hand I swear , and my father's soul , the work ish ill done .

English: It's all stopped .
Shakespearean: It ish give over .

English: I could have blown up the town in an hour .
Shakespearean: I would have blowed up the town , so Chrish save me , la , in an hour .

English: Oh , it's a disaster , a disaster , by this hand , it's a disaster .
Shakespearean: Oh , 'tish ill done , 'tish ill done , by my hand , 'tish ill done .

English: Captain Macmorris , I beg your pardon , but would you grant me a discussion or two with you , see , partly touching on or concerning the practice of war , the Roman wars , for the sake of argument , see , and friendly conversation ?
Shakespearean: Captain Macmorris , I beseech you now , will you voutsafe me , look you , a few disputations with you as partly touching or concerning the disciplines of the war , the Roman wars ?

English: Partly to confirm my opinion and partly for the satisfaction , see , of my mind , with respect to the demands of proper military practice , that's the point ?
Shakespearean: In the way of argument , look you , and friendly communication , partly to satisfy my opinion , and partly for the satisfaction , look you , of my mind , as touching the direction of the military discipline , that is the point .

English: What endeavor , Popillius ?
Shakespearean: What enterprise , Popillius ?

English: Good luck .
Shakespearean: Fare you well .

English: Look , he's approaching Caesar .
Shakespearean: Look how he makes to Caesar .

English: Keep an eye on him .
Shakespearean: Mark him .

English: Brutus , what will we do ?
Shakespearean: Casca , be sudden , for we fear prevention , Brutus , what shall be done ?

English: If our secret's known , either Caesar or I will die , for I'll kill myself .
Shakespearean: If this be known , Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back , For I will slay myself .

English: Cassius , stand firm .
Shakespearean: Cassius , be constant .

English: Trebonius knows his cue .
Shakespearean: Trebonius knows his time .

English: Where's Metellus Cimber ?
Shakespearean: Where is Metellus Cimber ?

English: He should go up and offer his petition to Caesar now .
Shakespearean: Let him go And presently prefer his suit to Caesar .

English: They're speaking to him .
Shakespearean: He is addressed .

English: Go up there and second his petition .
Shakespearean: Press near and second him .

English: Casca , you'll be the first to raise your hand .
Shakespearean: Casca , you are the first that rears your hand .

English: Are we all ready ?
Shakespearean: Are we all ready ?

English: I have to stop you , Cimber .
Shakespearean: Most high , most mighty , and most puissant Caesar , Metellus Cimber throws before thy seat An humble heart , I must prevent thee , Cimber .

English: These kneelings and humble courtesies might excite ordinary men , flattering them into turning Roman law into children's games .
Shakespearean: These couchings and these lowly courtesies Might fire the blood of ordinary men And turn preordinance and first decree Into the law of children .

English: What , even you , Brutus ?
Shakespearean: What , Brutus ?

English: I could be convinced if I were like you .
Shakespearean: I could be well moved if I were as you .

English: If I could beg others to change their minds , begging would convince me , too .
Shakespearean: If I could pray to move , prayers would move me .

English: But I'm as immovable as the northern star , whose stable and stationary quality has no equal in the sky .
Shakespearean: But I am constant as the northern star , Of whose true-fixed and resting quality There is no fellow in the firmament .

English: The sky shows countless stars .
Shakespearean: The skies are painted with unnumbered sparks .

English: So it is on earth .
Shakespearean: So in the world .

English: To show you that that's me , let me prove it a little even in this case .
Shakespearean: And that I am he Let me a little show it even in this : That I was constant Cimber should be banished , And constant do remain to keep him so .

English: Enough !
Shakespearean: Hence !

English: Would you try to lift Mount Olympus ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou lift up Olympus ?

English: Haven't I resisted even Brutus , begging from his knees ?
Shakespearean: Doth not Brutus bootless kneel ?

English: Hands , speak for me !
Shakespearean: Speak , hands , for me !

English: Liberty !
Shakespearean: Liberty !

English: Freedom !
Shakespearean: Freedom !

English: Tyranny is dead !
Shakespearean: Tyranny is dead !

English: Run and proclaim it in the streets .
Shakespearean: Run hence , proclaim , cry it about the streets .

English: Some should go to the public platforms and cry out , "Liberty , freedom , and democracy ! " People and senators , don't be afraid .
Shakespearean: Some to the common pulpits , and cry out , "Liberty , freedom , and enfranchisement ! " People and senators , be not affrighted .

English: Don't run away , stay where you are .
Shakespearean: Fly not .

English: Go to the platform , Brutus .
Shakespearean: Go to the pulpit , Brutus .

English: And Cassius too .
Shakespearean: And Cassius too .

English: Where's Publius ?
Shakespearean: Where's Publius ?

English: Stand close together , in case someone loyal to Caesar tries to , Don't talk about standing together. , Publius , cheer up .
Shakespearean: Stand fast together , lest some friend of Caesar's Should chance , Talk not of standing. , Publius , good cheer .

English: We don't intend any harm to you , nor to anyone else .
Shakespearean: There is no harm intended to your person , Nor to no Roman else .

English: Tell them this , Publius .
Shakespearean: So tell them , Publius .

English: And leave us , Publius , in case the people storming us should harm you .
Shakespearean: And leave us , Publius , lest that the people , Rushing on us , should do your age some mischief .

English: Do so .
Shakespearean: Do so .

English: And let no one suffer for this deed except us , the perpetrators .
Shakespearean: And let no man abide this deed But we the doers .

English: Where's Antony ?
Shakespearean: Where is Antony ?

English: He ran to his house , stunned .
Shakespearean: Fled to his house amazed .

English: Men , wives , and children stare , cry out , and run in the streets as though it were doomsday .
Shakespearean: Men , wives , and children stare , cry out , and run As it were doomsday .

English: Why , the man who shortens his life by twenty years cuts off twenty years of worrying about death .
Shakespearean: Why , he that cuts off twenty years of life Cuts off so many years of fearing death .

English: Kneel , Romans , kneel , and let's wash our hands , up to the elbows , in Caesar's blood and smear it on our swords .
Shakespearean: Stoop , Romans , stoop , And let us bathe our hands in Caesar's blood Up to the elbows , and besmear our swords .

English: Then we'll go out , even to the marketplace , and , waving our bloody swords over our heads , let's cry , "Peace , freedom , and liberty ! " Kneel then , and wash .
Shakespearean: Then walk we forth , even to the marketplace , And waving our red weapons o'er our heads Let's all cry , "Peace , freedom , and liberty ! " Stoop , then , and wash .

English: Who's calling me ?
Shakespearean: Who calls ?

English: Quiet , everyone !
Shakespearean: Bid every noise be still .

English: Quiet !
Shakespearean: Peace yet again .

English: Who in the crowd is calling me ?
Shakespearean: Who is it in the press that calls on me ?

English: I hear a voice more piercing than the music of these trumpets calling "Caesar ! " Speak .
Shakespearean: I hear a tongue , shriller than all the music , Cry "Caesar ! " , Speak .

English: Caesar is listening .
Shakespearean: Caesar is turned to hear .

English: Beware of March 15th .
Shakespearean: Beware the ides of March .

English: Who's that ?
Shakespearean: What man is that ?

English: A soothsayer tells you to beware of March 15th .
Shakespearean: A soothsayer bids you beware the ides of March .

English: Bring him in front of me .
Shakespearean: Set him before me .

English: Let me see his face .
Shakespearean: Let me see his face .

English: You , fellow , step out of the crowd .
Shakespearean: Fellow , come from the throng .

English: This is Caesar you're looking at .
Shakespearean: Look upon Caesar .

English: What do you have to say to me now ?
Shakespearean: What sayst thou to me now ?

English: Speak once again .
Shakespearean: Speak once again .

English: Beware of March 15th .
Shakespearean: Beware the ides of March .

English: He's insane .
Shakespearean: He is a dreamer .

English: Let's leave him .
Shakespearean: Let us leave him .

English: Let's move .
Shakespearean: Pass !

English: Are you going to watch the race ?
Shakespearean: Will you go see the order of the course ?

English: How many times will Caesar bleed again in show , though he now lies at the base of Pompey's statue , as worthless as dust !
Shakespearean: How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport , That now on Pompey's basis lies along No worthier than the dust !

English: Yes , every man forward .
Shakespearean: Ay , every man away .

English: Brutus will lead , and we'll follow him with the boldest and best hearts of Rome .
Shakespearean: Brutus shall lead , and we will grace his heels With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome .

English: Wait a minute .
Shakespearean: Soft !

English: Who's that coming ?
Shakespearean: Who comes here ?

English: It's a friend of Antony's .
Shakespearean: A friend of Antony's .

English: Your master is a wise and honorable Roman .
Shakespearean: Thy master is a wise and valiant Roman .

English: I never thought any less of him .
Shakespearean: I never thought him worse .

English: Tell him , if he comes here , I'll explain everything to him and , on my word , he'll leave unharmed .
Shakespearean: Tell him , so please him come unto this place , He shall be satisfied and , by my honor , Depart untouched .

English: I know that he'll be on our side .
Shakespearean: I know that we shall have him well to friend .

English: But here comes Antony. , Welcome , Mark Antony .
Shakespearean: But here comes Antony. , Welcome , Mark Antony .

English: Oh , mighty Caesar !
Shakespearean: O mighty Caesar !

English: Do you lie so low ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou lie so low ?

English: Have all your conquests , glories , triumphs , achievements , come to so little ?
Shakespearean: Are all thy conquests , glories , triumphs , spoils , Shrunk to this little measure ?

English: Farewell .
Shakespearean: Fare thee well .

English: Gentlemen , I don't know what you intend to do , who else you intend to kill , who else you consider corrupt .
Shakespearean: I know not , gentlemen , what you intend , Who else must be let blood , who else is rank .

English: If it's me , there's no time as good as this hour of Caesar's death , and no weapon better than your swords , covered with the noblest blood in the world .
Shakespearean: If I myself , there is no hour so fit As Caesar's death's hour , nor no instrument Of half that worth as those your swords , made rich With the most noble blood of all this world .

English: I ask you , if you have a grudge against me , to kill me now , while your stained hands still reek of blood .
Shakespearean: I do beseech ye , if you bear me hard , Now , whilst your purpled hands do reek and smoke , Fulfill your pleasure .

English: I could live a thousand years and I wouldn't be as ready to die as I am now .
Shakespearean: Live a thousand years , I shall not find myself so apt to die .

English: There's no place I'd rather die than here by Caesar , and no manner of death would please me more than being stabbed by you , the masters of this new era .
Shakespearean: No place will please me so , no mean of death , As here by Caesar , and by you cut off , The choice and master spirits of this age .

English: Oh , Antony , don't beg us to kill you .
Shakespearean: O Antony , beg not your death of us .

English: They are full of pity for Caesar .
Shakespearean: They are pitiful .

English: But a stronger pity , for the wrongs committed against Rome , drove out our pity for Caesar , as fire drives out fire , and so we killed him .
Shakespearean: And pity to the general wrong of Rome , As fire drives out fire , so pity pity , Hath done this deed on Caesar .

English: For you , our swords have blunt edges , too dull to harm you , Mark Antony .
Shakespearean: For your part , To you our swords have leaden points , Mark Antony .

English: Our arms , which can be strong and cruel , and our hearts , filled with brotherly love , embrace you with kind love , good thoughts , and reverence .
Shakespearean: Our arms in strength of malice and our hearts Of brothers ' temper do receive you in With all kind love , good thoughts , and reverence .

English: Your vote will be as strong as anyone's in the reordering of the government .
Shakespearean: Your voice shall be as strong as any man's In the disposing of new dignities .

English: But just be patient until we've calmed the masses , who are beside themselves with fear .
Shakespearean: Only be patient till we have appeased The multitude , beside themselves with fear , And then we will deliver you the cause , Why I , that did love Caesar when I struck him , Have thus proceeded .

English: I don't doubt your wisdom .
Shakespearean: I doubt not of your wisdom .

English: Each of you , give me your bloody hand .
Shakespearean: Let each man render me his bloody hand .

English: Mark Antony , Pardon me , Caius Cassius .
Shakespearean: Mark Antony , Pardon me , Caius Cassius .

English: I took your hands in friendship , but , indeed , I was distracted when I looked down at Caesar .
Shakespearean: Therefore I took your hands , but was indeed Swayed from the point by looking down on Caesar .

English: I am friends with you all and love you all , on one condition , that you prove to me that Caesar was dangerous .
Shakespearean: Friends am I with you all and love you all Upon this hope : that you shall give me reasons Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous .

English: Our reasons are so well considered that even if you , Antony , were Caesar's son , you would be satisfied with them .
Shakespearean: Our reasons are so full of good regard That were you , Antony , the son of Caesar , You should be satisfied .

English: You may , Mark Antony .
Shakespearean: You shall , Mark Antony .

English: Brutus , may I have a word with you ?
Shakespearean: Brutus , a word with you .

English: It'll help us more than hurt us .
Shakespearean: It shall advantage more than do us wrong .

English: Mark Antony , take Caesar's body .
Shakespearean: Mark Antony , here , take you Caesar's body .

English: You will not blame us in your funeral speech , but will say all the good you want to about Caesar and that you do it by our permission .
Shakespearean: You shall not in your funeral speech blame us , But speak all good you can devise of Caesar , And say you do 't by our permission .

English: And you'll speak on the same platform as I do , after I'm done .
Shakespearean: And you shall speak In the same pulpit whereto I am going , After my speech is ended .

English: So be it .
Shakespearean: Be it so .

English: I don't want anything more .
Shakespearean: I do desire no more .

English: Prepare the body , then , and follow us .
Shakespearean: Prepare the body then , and follow us .

English: You are what's left of the noblest man that ever lived .
Shakespearean: Thou art the ruins of the noblest man That ever lived in the tide of times .

English: Pity the hand that shed this valuable blood .
Shakespearean: Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood !

English: Over your wounds , which , like speechless mouths , open their red lips , as though to beg me to speak , I predict that a curse will fall upon the bodies of men .
Shakespearean: Over thy wounds now do I prophesy , Which , like dumb mouths , do ope their ruby lips To beg the voice and utterance of my tongue , A curse shall light upon the limbs of men .

English: Fierce civil war will paralyze all of Italy .
Shakespearean: Domestic fury and fierce civil strife Shall cumber all the parts of Italy .

English: I do , Mark Antony .
Shakespearean: I do , Mark Antony .

English: Caesar wrote for him to come to Rome .
Shakespearean: Caesar did write for him to come to Rome .

English: He received Caesar's letters , and he is coming .
Shakespearean: He did receive his letters and is coming .

English: Grief seems to be contagious , for my eyes , seeing the tears in yours , began to fill .
Shakespearean: Passion , I see , is catching , for mine eyes , Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine , Began to water .

English: Is your master coming ?
Shakespearean: Is thy master coming ?

English: He rests tonight within twenty-one miles of Rome .
Shakespearean: He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome .

English: Report back to him fast and tell him what has happened .
Shakespearean: Post back with speed , and tell him what hath chanced .

English: Don't go back until I've carried the corpse into the marketplace .
Shakespearean: Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corse Into the marketplace .

English: Help me here .
Shakespearean: Lend me your hand .

English: We want answers .
Shakespearean: We will be satisfied !

English: Give us answers .
Shakespearean: Let us be satisfied !

English: Then follow me and listen to my speech , friends .
Shakespearean: Then follow me and give me audience , friends .

English: Cassius , go to the next street and divide the crowd .
Shakespearean: Cassius , go you into the other street And part the numbers .

English: Let those who will hear me speak stay .
Shakespearean: Those that will hear me speak , let 'em stay here .

English: Lead those away who will follow you , and we'll explain publicly the reasons for Caesar's death .
Shakespearean: Those that will follow Cassius , go with him , And public reasons shall be rendered Of Caesar's death .

English: I'll listen to Brutus .
Shakespearean: I will hear Brutus speak .

English: I'll listen to Cassius , and we will compare their reasons .
Shakespearean: I will hear Cassius and compare their reasons When severally we hear them rendered .

English: Noble Brutus has mounted the platform .
Shakespearean: The noble Brutus is ascended .

English: Be patient until I finish .
Shakespearean: Be patient till the last .

English: Romans , countrymen , and friends !
Shakespearean: Romans , countrymen , and lovers !

English: Listen to my reasons and be silent so you can hear .
Shakespearean: Hear me for my cause , and be silent that you may hear .

English: Believe me on my honor and keep my honor in mind , so you may believe me .
Shakespearean: Believe me for mine honor , and have respect to mine honor that you may believe .

English: Be wise when you criticize me and keep your minds alert so you can judge me fairly .
Shakespearean: Censure me in your wisdom , and awake your senses that you may the better judge .

English: If there's anyone in this assembly , any dear friend of Caesar's , I say to him that my love for Caesar was no less than his .
Shakespearean: If there be any in this assembly , any dear friend of Caesar's , to him I say that Brutus ' love to Caesar was no less than his .

English: If , then , that friend demands to know why I rose up against Caesar , this is my answer : it's not that I loved Caesar less , but that I loved Rome more .
Shakespearean: If then that friend demand why Brutus rose against Caesar , this is my answer : not that I loved Caesar less , but that I loved Rome more .

English: Would you rather that Caesar were living and we would all go to our graves as slaves , or that Caesar were dead and we all lived as free men ?
Shakespearean: Had you rather Caesar were living and die all slaves , than that Caesar were dead , to live all free men ?

English: I weep for Caesar in that he was good to me .
Shakespearean: As Caesar loved me , I weep for him .

English: I rejoice in his good fortune .
Shakespearean: As he was fortunate , I rejoice at it .

English: I honor him for being brave .
Shakespearean: As he was valiant , I honor him .

English: But his ambition , for that , I killed him .
Shakespearean: But , as he was ambitious , I slew him .

English: There are tears for his love , joy for his fortune , honor for his bravery , and death for his ambition .
Shakespearean: There is tears for his love , joy for his fortune , honor for his valor , and death for his ambition .

English: Who here is so low that he wants to be a slave ?
Shakespearean: Who is here so base that would be a bondman ?

English: If there are any , speak , for it is he whom I've offended .
Shakespearean: If any , speak , for him have I offended .

English: Who here is so barbarous that he doesn't want to be a Roman ?
Shakespearean: Who is here so rude that would not be a Roman ?

English: If there are any , speak , for it is he whom I've offended .
Shakespearean: If any , speak , for him have I offended .

English: Who here is so vile that he doesn't love his country ?
Shakespearean: Who is here so vile that will not love his country ?

English: If there are any , speak , for it is he whom I have offended .
Shakespearean: If any , speak , for him have I offended .

English: I will pause for a reply .
Shakespearean: I pause for a reply .

English: No one , Brutus , no one .
Shakespearean: None , Brutus , none .

English: Then I have offended no one .
Shakespearean: Then none have I offended .

English: I've done no more to Caesar than you will do to me .
Shakespearean: I have done no more to Caesar than you shall do to Brutus .

English: The reasons for his death are recorded in the Capitol .
Shakespearean: The question of his death is enrolled in the Capitol .

English: His glory has not been diminished where he earned it , nor have those offenses for which he was killed been exaggerated .
Shakespearean: His glory not extenuated wherein he was worthy , nor his offenses enforced for which he suffered death .

English: Here comes his body , mourned by Mark Antony , who , though he had no part in the killing , will benefit from his death , receiving a share in the commonwealth , as you all will .
Shakespearean: Here comes his body , mourned by Mark Antony , who , though he had no hand in his death , shall receive the benefit of his dying , a place in the commonwealth , as which of you shall not ?

English: Live , Brutus !
Shakespearean: Live , Brutus !

English: Live , live !
Shakespearean: Live , live !

English: Let's carry him in triumph to his house !
Shakespearean: Bring him with triumph home unto his house !

English: I don't like sports .
Shakespearean: I am not gamesome .

English: I'm not competitive like Antony .
Shakespearean: I do lack some part Of that quick spirit that is in Antony .

English: But don't let me keep you from going , Cassius .
Shakespearean: Let me not hinder , Cassius , your desires .

English: I'll go my own way .
Shakespearean: I'll leave you .

English: Cassius , don't take it badly .
Shakespearean: Cassius , Be not deceived .

English: Tell me , good Brutus , can you see your face ?
Shakespearean: Tell me , good Brutus , can you see your face ?

English: Let him become Caesar !
Shakespearean: Let him be Caesar !

English: Caesar's better qualities exist in Brutus , and we will crown him .
Shakespearean: Caesar's better parts Shall be crowned in Brutus !

English: We'll bring him to his house with shouts and celebration !
Shakespearean: We'll bring him to his house with shouts and clamors .

English: My countrymen , Silence !
Shakespearean: My countrymen , Peace , silence !

English: Brutus speaks .
Shakespearean: Brutus speaks .

English: Quiet there !
Shakespearean: Peace , ho !

English: Good countrymen , let me leave alone .
Shakespearean: Good countrymen , let me depart alone .

English: I ask that none of you leave , except myself , until Antony has finished .
Shakespearean: I do entreat you , not a man depart , Save I alone , till Antony have spoke .

English: Let him mount the pulpit .
Shakespearean: Let him go up into the public chair .

English: We'll listen to him .
Shakespearean: We'll hear him. , Noble Antony , go up .

English: For Brutus's sake , I am indebted to you .
Shakespearean: For Brutus ' sake , I am beholding to you .

English: What does he say about Brutus ?
Shakespearean: What does he say of Brutus ?

English: He says that for Brutus's sake he finds himself indebted to us all .
Shakespearean: He says for Brutus ' sake He finds himself beholding to us all .

English: He'd better not speak badly of Brutus here .
Shakespearean: Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here .

English: Caesar was a tyrant .
Shakespearean: This Caesar was a tyrant .

English: That's for sure .
Shakespearean: Nay , that's certain .

English: We're lucky that Rome is rid of him .
Shakespearean: We are blest that Rome is rid of him .

English: Quiet !
Shakespearean: Peace !

English: Let's hear what Antony has to say .
Shakespearean: Let us hear what Antony can say .

English: You gentle Romans , Quiet there !
Shakespearean: You gentle Romans , Peace , ho !

English: Let us hear him .
Shakespearean: Let us hear him .

English: Friends , Romans , countrymen , give me your attention .
Shakespearean: Friends , Romans , countrymen , lend me your ears .

English: I have come here to bury Caesar , not to praise him .
Shakespearean: I come to bury Caesar , not to praise him .

English: The evil that men do is remembered after their deaths , but the good is often buried with them .
Shakespearean: The evil that men do lives after them ; The good is oft interred with their bones .

English: It might as well be the same with Caesar .
Shakespearean: So let it be with Caesar .

English: The noble Brutus told you that Caesar was ambitious .
Shakespearean: The noble Brutus Hath told you Caesar was ambitious .

English: If that's true , it's a serious fault , and Caesar has paid seriously for it .
Shakespearean: If it were so , it was a grievous fault , And grievously hath Caesar answered it .

English: With the permission of Brutus and the others , for Brutus is an honorable man ; they are all honorable men , I have come here to speak at Caesar's funeral .
Shakespearean: Here , under leave of Brutus and the rest , For Brutus is an honorable man ; So are they all , all honorable men , Come I to speak in Caesar's funeral .

English: He was my friend , he was faithful and just to me .
Shakespearean: He was my friend , faithful and just to me .

English: But Brutus says he was ambitious , and Brutus is an honorable man .
Shakespearean: But Brutus says he was ambitious , And Brutus is an honorable man .

English: He brought many captives home to Rome whose ransoms brought wealth to the city .
Shakespearean: He hath brought many captives home to Rome Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill .

English: Is this the work of an ambitious man ?
Shakespearean: Did this in Caesar seem ambitious ?

English: When the poor cried , Caesar cried too .
Shakespearean: When that the poor have cried , Caesar hath wept .

English: Ambition shouldn't be so soft .
Shakespearean: Ambition should be made of sterner stuff .

English: Yet Brutus says he was ambitious , and Brutus is an honorable man .
Shakespearean: Yet Brutus says he was ambitious , And Brutus is an honorable man .

English: You all saw that on the Lupercal feast day I offered him a king's crown three times , and he refused it three times .
Shakespearean: You all did see that on the Lupercal I thrice presented him a kingly crown , Which he did thrice refuse .

English: Was this ambition ?
Shakespearean: Was this ambition ?

English: I am not here to disprove what Brutus has said , but to say what I think there's a lot of sense in what he says .
Shakespearean: I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke , But here I am to speak what I do know .

English: If you think about it correctly , Caesar has suffered a great wrong .
Shakespearean: If thou consider rightly of the matter , Caesar has had great wrong .

English: Has he , sirs ?
Shakespearean: Has he , masters ?

English: Caesar wouldn't take the crown .
Shakespearean: He would not take the crown .

English: Therefore it's certain that he wasn't ambitious .
Shakespearean: Therefore 'tis certain he was not ambitious .

English: If it turns out he wasn't , certain people are going to get it .
Shakespearean: If it be found so , some will dear abide it .

English: Poor man !
Shakespearean: Poor soul !

English: Antony's eyes are fiery red from crying .
Shakespearean: His eyes are red as fire with weeping .

English: There isn't a nobler man than Antony in all of Rome .
Shakespearean: There's not a nobler man in Rome than Antony .

English: Only yesterday the word of Caesar might have stood against the world .
Shakespearean: But yesterday the word of Caesar might Have stood against the world .

English: Now he lies there worth nothing , and no one is so humble as to show him respect .
Shakespearean: Now lies he there , And none so poor to do him reverence .

English: Oh , sirs , if I stirred your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage , I would offend Brutus and Cassius , who , you all know , are honorable men .
Shakespearean: O masters , if I were disposed to stir Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage , I should do Brutus wrong , and Cassius wrong , Who , you all know , are honorable men .

English: I will not do them wrong .
Shakespearean: I will not do them wrong .

English: I would rather wrong the dead , and wrong myself and you , than wrong such honorable men .
Shakespearean: I rather choose To wrong the dead , to wrong myself and you , Than I will wrong such honorable men .

English: But here's a paper with Caesar's seal on it .
Shakespearean: But here's a parchment with the seal of Caesar .

English: If you could only hear this testament , which , excuse me , I don't intend to read aloud , you would kiss dead Caesar's wounds and dip your handkerchiefs in his sacred blood , and beg for a lock of hair to remember him by .
Shakespearean: Let but the commons hear this testament , Which , pardon me , I do not mean to read , And they would go and kiss dead Caesar's wounds And dip their napkins in his sacred blood , Yea , beg a hair of him for memory , And , dying , mention it within their wills , Bequeathing it as a rich legacy Unto their issue .

English: We want to hear the will .
Shakespearean: We'll hear the will .

English: Read it , Mark Antony .
Shakespearean: Read it , Mark Antony !

English: The will , the will !
Shakespearean: The will , the will !

English: We want to hear Caesar's will .
Shakespearean: We will hear Caesar's will .

English: It isn't proper for you to know how much Caesar loved you .
Shakespearean: It is not meet you know how Caesar loved you .

English: You aren't wood , you aren't stones , you're men .
Shakespearean: You are not wood , you are not stones , but men .

English: And , being men , the contents of Caesar's will would enrage you .
Shakespearean: And , being men , bearing the will of Caesar , It will inflame you , it will make you mad .

English: Read the will .
Shakespearean: Read the will .

English: We want to hear it , Antony .
Shakespearean: We'll hear it , Antony .

English: You have to read us the will , Caesar's will .
Shakespearean: You shall read us the will , Caesar's will .

English: Will you be patient ?
Shakespearean: Will you be patient ?

English: Will you wait awhile ?
Shakespearean: Will you stay awhile ?

English: I've said too much in telling you of it .
Shakespearean: I have o'ershot myself to tell you of it .

English: I'm afraid that I wrong the honorable men whose daggers have stabbed Caesar .
Shakespearean: I fear I wrong the honorable men Whose daggers have stabbed Caesar .

English: They were traitors .
Shakespearean: They were traitors !

English: The testament !
Shakespearean: The testament !

English: They were villains , murderers .
Shakespearean: They were villains , murderers .

English: The will !
Shakespearean: The will !

English: Read the will !
Shakespearean: Read the will !

English: You force me to read the will , then ?
Shakespearean: You will compel me , then , to read the will ?

English: Then make a circle around Caesar's corpse , and let me show you the man who made this will .
Shakespearean: Then make a ring about the corpse of Caesar , And let me show you him that made the will .

English: Shall I come down ?
Shakespearean: Shall I descend ?

English: Will you let me ?
Shakespearean: And will you give me leave ?

English: Come down .
Shakespearean: Come down .

English: Descend .
Shakespearean: Descend .

English: We'll let you .
Shakespearean: You shall have leave .

English: Stand away from the hearse .
Shakespearean: Stand from the hearse .

English: Stand away from the body .
Shakespearean: Stand from the body .

English: Make room for Antony , most noble Antony !
Shakespearean: Room for Antony , most noble Antony !

English: No , don't press up against me .
Shakespearean: Nay , press not so upon me .

English: Stand further away .
Shakespearean: Stand far off .

English: Stand back .
Shakespearean: Stand back .

English: Give him room .
Shakespearean: Room !

English: If you have tears , prepare to shed them now .
Shakespearean: If you have tears , prepare to shed them now .

English: You all know this cloak .
Shakespearean: You all do know this mantle .

English: I remember the first time Caesar ever put it on .
Shakespearean: I remember The first time ever Caesar put it on .

English: It was the day he overcame the Nervii warriors .
Shakespearean: Twas on a summer's evening in his tent , That day he overcame the Nervii .

English: Look , here's where Cassius's dagger pierced it .
Shakespearean: Look , in this place ran Cassius ' dagger through .

English: See the wound that Casca made .
Shakespearean: See what a rent the envious Casca made .

English: For Brutus , as you know , was Caesar's angel .
Shakespearean: For Brutus , as you know , was Caesar's angel .

English: The gods know how dearly Caesar loved him !
Shakespearean: Judge , O you gods , how dearly Caesar loved him !

English: This was the most unkind cut of all .
Shakespearean: This was the most unkindest cut of all .

English: And at the base of Pompey's statue , with his cloak covering his face , which was dripping with blood the whole time , great Caesar fell .
Shakespearean: Then burst his mighty heart , And , in his mantle muffling up his face , Even at the base of Pompey's statue , Which all the while ran blood , great Caesar fell .

English: Oh , what a fall it was , my countrymen !
Shakespearean: O , what a fall was there , my countrymen !

English: Then you and I and all of us fell down , while bloody treason triumphed .
Shakespearean: Then I , and you , and all of us fell down , Whilst bloody treason flourished over us .

English: Oh , now you weep , and I sense that you feel pity .
Shakespearean: Oh , now you weep , and , I perceive , you feel The dint of pity .

English: These are gracious tears .
Shakespearean: These are gracious drops .

English: But if it overwhelms you to look at Caesar's wounded cloak , how will you feel , kind men , now ?
Shakespearean: Kind souls , what , weep you when you but behold Our Caesar's vesture wounded ?

English: Look at this , here is the man , scarred , as you can see , by traitors .
Shakespearean: Look you here , Here is himself , marred , as you see , with traitors .

English: Oh , what a sad sight !
Shakespearean: O piteous spectacle !

English: Oh , noble Caesar !
Shakespearean: O noble Caesar !

English: Oh , sad day !
Shakespearean: O woeful day !

English: Oh , traitors , villains !
Shakespearean: O traitors , villains !

English: Oh , most bloody sight !
Shakespearean: O most bloody sight !

English: Revenge !
Shakespearean: About !

English: Seek !
Shakespearean: Seek !

English: Burn !
Shakespearean: Burn !

English: Set fire !
Shakespearean: Fire !

English: Kill !
Shakespearean: Kill !

English: Slay !
Shakespearean: Slay !

English: Wait , countrymen .
Shakespearean: Stay , countrymen .

English: Quiet there !
Shakespearean: Peace there !

English: Listen to the noble Antony .
Shakespearean: Hear the noble Antony .

English: Those who have done this deed are honorable .
Shakespearean: They that have done this deed are honorable .

English: I don't know what private grudges they had that made them do it .
Shakespearean: What private griefs they have , alas , I know not , That made them do it .

English: They're wise and honorable , and will no doubt give you reasons for it .
Shakespearean: They are wise and honorable , And will , no doubt , with reasons answer you .

English: I haven't come to steal your loyalty , friends .
Shakespearean: I come not , friends , to steal away your hearts .

English: I have neither cleverness nor rhetorical skill nor the authority nor gesture nor eloquence nor the power of speech to stir men up .
Shakespearean: For I have neither wit nor words nor worth , Action nor utterance nor the power of speech , To stir men's blood .

English: I just speak directly .
Shakespearean: I only speak right on .

English: But if I were Brutus and Brutus were me , then I'd stir you up , and install in each of Caesar's wounds the kind of voice that could convince even stones to rise up and mutiny .
Shakespearean: But were I Brutus , And Brutus Antony , there were an Antony Would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue In every wound of Caesar that should move The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny .

English: We'll mutiny .
Shakespearean: We'll mutiny .

English: We'll burn Brutus's house .
Shakespearean: We'll burn the house of Brutus .

English: Let's go , then !
Shakespearean: Away , then !

English: Come , find the conspirators !
Shakespearean: Come , seek the conspirators .

English: Wait , and listen to me , countrymen .
Shakespearean: Yet hear me , countrymen .

English: Quiet !
Shakespearean: Yet hear me speak .

English: Wait !
Shakespearean: Peace , ho !

English: Listen to Antony .
Shakespearean: Hear Antony .

English: Most noble Antony !
Shakespearean: Most noble Antony !

English: Why , friends , you don't even know what you're doing yet .
Shakespearean: Why , friends , you go to do you know not what .

English: What has Caesar done to deserve your love ?
Shakespearean: Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves ?

English: Alas , you don't know .
Shakespearean: Alas , you know not .

English: I must tell you then .
Shakespearean: I must tell you then .

English: You've forgotten the will I told you about .
Shakespearean: You have forgot the will I told you of .

English: Yes !
Shakespearean: Most true .

English: The will !
Shakespearean: The will !

English: Let's stay and hear the will !
Shakespearean: Let's stay and hear the will .

English: Most noble Caesar !
Shakespearean: Most noble Caesar !

English: We'll revenge his death .
Shakespearean: We'll revenge his death .

English: Oh , royal Caesar !
Shakespearean: O royal Caesar !

English: Listen to me patiently .
Shakespearean: Hear me with patience .

English: Quiet , there !
Shakespearean: Peace , ho !

English: Also , he's left you all his walkways , in his private gardens and newly planted orchards , on this side of the Tiber River .
Shakespearean: Moreover , he hath left you all his walks , His private arbors and new-planted orchards , On this side Tiber .

English: He's left them to you and to your heirs forever , public pleasures in which you will be able to stroll and relax .
Shakespearean: He hath left them you And to your heirs forever , common pleasures , To walk abroad and recreate yourselves .

English: Here was a Caesar !
Shakespearean: Here was a Caesar !

English: When will there be another like him ?
Shakespearean: When comes such another ?

English: We'll burn his body in the holy place and use the brands to set the traitors ' houses on fire .
Shakespearean: We'll burn his body in the holy place , And with the brands fire the traitors ' houses .

English: Take up the body .
Shakespearean: Take up the body .

English: We'll start a fire .
Shakespearean: Go fetch fire .

English: Now , let it work .
Shakespearean: Now let it work .

English: What's up , my man ?
Shakespearean: How now , fellow ?

English: Sir , Octavius has already arrived in Rome .
Shakespearean: Sir , Octavius is already come to Rome .

English: Where is he ?
Shakespearean: Where is he ?

English: He and Lepidus are at Caesar's house .
Shakespearean: He and Lepidus are at Caesar's house .

English: I will go straight to visit him .
Shakespearean: And thither will I straight to visit him .

English: I ask for him , and he comes .
Shakespearean: He comes upon a wish .

English: Fortune is happy today and , in this mood , will give us anything we want .
Shakespearean: Fortune is merry , And in this mood will give us anything .

English: I heard Octavius say that Brutus and Cassius have ridden like madmen through the gates of Rome .
Shakespearean: I heard him say , Brutus and Cassius Are rid like madmen through the gates of Rome .

English: They probably received warning about how much I stirred up the people .
Shakespearean: Belike they had some notice of the people How I had moved them .

English: Take me to Octavius .
Shakespearean: Bring me to Octavius .

English: That's true .
Shakespearean: Tis just .

English: And it's too bad , Brutus , that you don't have any mirrors that could display your hidden excellence to yourself .
Shakespearean: And it is very much lamented , Brutus , That you have no such mirrors as will turn Your hidden worthiness into your eye That you might see your shadow .

English: I've heard many of the noblest Romans , next to immortal Caesar , speaking of you , complaining of the tyranny of today's government , and wishing that your eyes were working better .
Shakespearean: I have heard Where many of the best respect in Rome , Except immortal Caesar , speaking of Brutus And groaning underneath this age's yoke , Have wished that noble Brutus had his eyes .

English: What dangers are you trying to lead me into , Cassius , that you want me to look inside myself for something that's not there ?
Shakespearean: Into what dangers would you lead me , Cassius , That you would have me seek into myself For that which is not in me ?

English: I'll tell you , good Brutus .
Shakespearean: Therefore , good Brutus , be prepared to hear .

English: And since you know you can see yourself best by reflection , I'll be your mirror and show you , without exaggeration , things inside you that you can't see .
Shakespearean: And since you know you can not see yourself So well as by reflection , I , your glass , Will modestly discover to yourself That of yourself which you yet know not of .

English: And don't be suspicious of me , noble Brutus .
Shakespearean: And be not jealous on me , gentle Brutus .

English: If I were your average fool , or if I made my feelings for you worthless by making the same promises of friendship to everybody , or if you'd seen me first flattering men , hugging them tightly , and later slandering them behind their backs , or if you hear that I drunkenly declare friendship at banquets with all the rabble , only then , of course , go ahead and assume I'm dangerous .
Shakespearean: Were I a common laugher , or did use To stale with ordinary oaths my love To every new protester , if you know That I do fawn on men and hug them hard And , after , scandal them , or if you know That I profess myself in banqueting To all the rout , then hold me dangerous .

English: Why are they shouting ?
Shakespearean: What means this shouting ?

English: I'm afraid the people have made Caesar their king .
Shakespearean: I do fear , the people Choose Caesar for their king .

English: Really , are you afraid of that ?
Shakespearean: Ay , do you fear it ?

English: Then I have to assume you don't want him to be king .
Shakespearean: Then must I think you would not have it so .

English: I dreamed last night that I feasted with Caesar , and unlucky signs overwhelmed my imagination .
Shakespearean: I dreamt tonight that I did feast with Caesar , And things unlucky charge my fantasy .

English: I have no desire to go outside , yet something leads me there .
Shakespearean: I have no will to wander forth of doors , Yet something leads me forth .

English: What's your name ?
Shakespearean: What is your name ?

English: Where are you going ?
Shakespearean: Whither are you going ?

English: Where do you live ?
Shakespearean: Where do you dwell ?

English: Are you a married man or a bachelor ?
Shakespearean: Are you a married man or a bachelor ?

English: Answer all of us , now .
Shakespearean: Answer every man directly .

English: Yes , and be brief .
Shakespearean: Ay , and briefly .

English: Yes , and be wise .
Shakespearean: Ay , and wisely .

English: What's my name ?
Shakespearean: What is my name ?

English: Where am I going ?
Shakespearean: Whither am I going ?

English: Where do I live ?
Shakespearean: Where do I dwell ?

English: Am I a married man or a bachelor ?
Shakespearean: Am I a married man or a bachelor ?

English: Then , to answer every man briefly , wisely , and truthfully , wisely I say , I am a bachelor .
Shakespearean: Then , to answer every man directly and briefly , wisely and truly , wisely I say , I am a bachelor .

English: You imply that married men are fools .
Shakespearean: That's as much as to say they are fools that marry .

English: You'll get a blow from me for that , I think .
Shakespearean: You'll bear me a bang for that , I fear .

English: Right this instant , I'm going to Caesar's funeral .
Shakespearean: Directly , I am going to Caesar's funeral .

English: As a friend or an enemy ?
Shakespearean: As a friend or an enemy ?

English: As a friend .
Shakespearean: As a friend .

English: Getting right to the point , I live near the Capitol .
Shakespearean: Briefly , I dwell by the Capitol .

English: Tell us your name , sir , truthfully .
Shakespearean: Your name , sir , truly .

English: Truthfully , my name is Cinna .
Shakespearean: Truly , my name is Cinna .

English: Tear him to pieces .
Shakespearean: Tear him to pieces .

English: He's a conspirator .
Shakespearean: He's a conspirator .

English: I'm not Cinna the conspirator .
Shakespearean: I am not Cinna the conspirator .

English: It doesn't matter .
Shakespearean: It is no matter .

English: His name's Cinna .
Shakespearean: His name's Cinna .

English: Pull only his name out of his heart and let him go .
Shakespearean: Pluck but his name out of his heart and turn him going .

English: Tear him apart , tear him up !
Shakespearean: Tear him , tear him !

English: Come , firebrands , over here !
Shakespearean: Come , brands , ho , firebrands .

English: To Brutus's , to Cassius's , let's burn them all .
Shakespearean: To Brutus ' , to Cassius ' , burn all .

English: Some of you go to Decius's house and some to Casca's .
Shakespearean: Some to Decius ' house and some to Casca's .

English: Some to Ligarius's .
Shakespearean: Some to Ligarius ' .

English: Go !
Shakespearean: Away , go !

English: These ones , then , will be assassinated .
Shakespearean: These many , then , shall die .

English: Their names are marked .
Shakespearean: Their names are pricked .

English: I agree , Put a mark next to his name too , Antony .
Shakespearean: I do consent , Prick him down , Antony .

English: On the condition that your sister's son , Publius , also must die , Mark Antony .
Shakespearean: Upon condition Publius shall not live , Who is your sister's son , Mark Antony .

English: He will die .
Shakespearean: He shall not live .

English: See , I've sealed his fate with this mark next to his name .
Shakespearean: Look , with a spot I damn him .

English: But , Lepidus , go to Caesar's house .
Shakespearean: But , Lepidus , go you to Caesar's house .

English: Bring his will here , and we'll figure out a way to reduce his bequests to the people .
Shakespearean: Fetch the will hither , and we shall determine How to cut off some charge in legacies .

English: Will you be here when I return ?
Shakespearean: What , shall I find you here ?

English: Either here or at the Capitol .
Shakespearean: Or here , or at the Capitol .

English: He's an unremarkable man , fit only to be sent on errands .
Shakespearean: This is a slight , unmeritable man , Meet to be sent on errands .

English: Does it really make sense , once we divide the world into three parts , that he should be one of the three rulers ?
Shakespearean: Is it fit , The threefold world divided , he should stand One of the three to share it ?

English: Octavius , I'm older than you are .
Shakespearean: Octavius , I have seen more days than you .

English: And although we're giving these honors to this man so that he shares some of the blame for what we're doing , he'll carry these honors like a jackass carries gold , groaning and sweating under the load , either led or pushed , as we direct him .
Shakespearean: And though we lay these honors on this man To ease ourselves of divers slanderous loads , He shall but bear them as the ass bears gold , To groan and sweat under the business , Either led or driven , as we point the way .

English: Once he's carried our treasure where we want it , we'll free him of the load and turn him loose like a jackass , to shake his ears and graze in the public pastures .
Shakespearean: And having brought our treasure where we will , Then take we down his load and turn him off , Like to the empty ass , to shake his ears And graze in commons .

English: You can do what you want , but he's an experienced and honorable soldier .
Shakespearean: You may do your will , But he's a tried and valiant soldier .

English: So is my horse , Octavius , and for that reason I give him all the hay he wants .
Shakespearean: So is my horse , Octavius , and for that I do appoint him store of provender .

English: Stop .
Shakespearean: Stand , ho !

English: Pass on the command to halt !
Shakespearean: Give the word , ho , and stand .

English: What's happening now , Lucillius ?
Shakespearean: What now , Lucillius ?

English: Is Cassius nearby ?
Shakespearean: Is Cassius near ?

English: He's nearby , and Pindarus has come to salute you on behalf of his master .
Shakespearean: He is at hand , and Pindarus is come To do you salutation from his master .

English: If he's nearby , I want an explanation .
Shakespearean: But if he be at hand I shall be satisfied .

English: Can I have a word with you , Lucillius ?
Shakespearean: He is not doubted. , A word , Lucillius .

English: He received me with courtesy and sufficient respect , but not with affection , nor with as much open and friendly conversation as he once greeted me .
Shakespearean: But not with such familiar instances Nor with such free and friendly conference As he hath used of old .

English: You've described a warm friend who's cooling off .
Shakespearean: Thou hast described A hot friend cooling .

English: Plain and simple loyalty doesn't make anyone act phony .
Shakespearean: There are no tricks in plain and simple faith .

English: But insincere men , like horses who are too lively at the start of a race , make a big show of their spirit .
Shakespearean: But hollow men , like horses hot at hand , Make gallant show and promise of their mettle .

English: But when push comes to shove , they droop like those horses that are all show and slow to a crawl .
Shakespearean: But when they should endure the bloody spur , They fall their crests and , like deceitful jades , Sink in the trial .

English: Is his army approaching ?
Shakespearean: Comes his army on ?

English: They plan to spend the night in Sardis .
Shakespearean: They mean this night in Sardis to be quartered .

English: The larger part , the main body of cavalry , are coming with Cassius .
Shakespearean: The greater part , the horse in general , Are come with Cassius .

English: Look !
Shakespearean: Hark !

English: He's arrived .
Shakespearean: He is arrived .

English: March to meet him at a dignified pace .
Shakespearean: March gently on to meet him .

English: Halt .
Shakespearean: Stand , ho !

English: Halt !
Shakespearean: Stand , ho !

English: Pass the order along .
Shakespearean: Speak the word along .

English: Halt !
Shakespearean: Stand !

English: Halt !
Shakespearean: Stand !

English: Halt !
Shakespearean: Stand !

English: Most noble brother , you have done me wrong .
Shakespearean: Most noble brother , you have done me wrong .

English: Let the gods judge me !
Shakespearean: Judge me , you gods !

English: Do I mistreat even my enemies ?
Shakespearean: Wrong I mine enemies ?

English: And when you do , Cassius , calm down .
Shakespearean: And when you do them , Cassius , be content .

English: Let's not argue here in front of both our armies , which ought to see nothing but love between us .
Shakespearean: Before the eyes of both our armies here , Which should perceive nothing but love from us , Let us not wrangle .

English: Order them to move back .
Shakespearean: Bid them move away .

English: Then , in my tent , you can elaborate on your complaints , and I'll listen .
Shakespearean: Then in my tent , Cassius , enlarge your griefs , And I will give you audience .

English: Pindarus , order our commanders to lead their charges a little ways away from this ground .
Shakespearean: Pindarus , Bid our commanders lead their charges off A little from this ground .

English: Have Lucius and Titinius guard the door .
Shakespearean: Let Lucius and Titinius guard our door .

English: My evidence that you have wronged me is that you condemned and disgraced Lucius Pella for taking bribes here from the Sardinians , and you ignored my letters , where I argued that he was innocent ; I know the man .
Shakespearean: That you have wronged me doth appear in this : You have condemned and noted Lucius Pella For taking bribes here of the Sardians , Wherein my letters , praying on his side Because I knew the man , were slighted off .

English: You wronged yourself to write on behalf of such a man .
Shakespearean: You wronged yourself to write in such a case .

English: In a time like this , it doesn't make sense to criticize every offense .
Shakespearean: In such a time as this it is not meet That every nice offense should bear his comment .

English: I'll tell you , Cassius , you yourself have been called greedy and been accused of giving your positions to undeserving men in exchange for gold .
Shakespearean: Let me tell you , Cassius , you yourself Are much condemned to have an itching palm , To sell and mart your offices for gold To undeservers .

English: Me , "greedy" !
Shakespearean: I "an itching palm" !

English: You know , if you were anyone other than Brutus , that speech would be your last .
Shakespearean: You know that you are Brutus that speak this , Or , by the gods , this speech were else your last .

English: The name of Cassius gives credit to these corrupt actions , and so they go unpunished .
Shakespearean: The name of Cassius honors this corruption , And chastisement doth therefore hide his head .

English: Unpunished !
Shakespearean: Chastisement !

English: Remember March , March 15th .
Shakespearean: Remember March , the ides of March remember .

English: Didn't great Caesar bleed for the sake of justice ?
Shakespearean: Did not great Julius bleed for justice ' sake ?

English: Who among us stabbed him for any cause but justice ?
Shakespearean: What villain touched his body , that did stab , And not for justice ?

English: Should we now dirty our fingers with lowly bribes and sell the mighty offices that we hold for whatever money we can get our hands on ?
Shakespearean: What , shall one of us That struck the foremost man of all this world But for supporting robbers , shall we now Contaminate our fingers with base bribes , And sell the mighty space of our large honors For so much trash as may be grasped thus ?

English: I'd rather be a dog and howl at the moon than be that kind of Roman .
Shakespearean: I had rather be a dog and bay the moon Than such a Roman .

English: Brutus , do not provoke me .
Shakespearean: Brutus , bait not me .

English: I will not take it .
Shakespearean: I'll not endure it .

English: You're forgetting yourself when you back me into a corner .
Shakespearean: You forget yourself To hedge me in .

English: I'm a soldier , more experienced than you , and better able to give orders .
Shakespearean: I am a soldier , I , Older in practice , abler than yourself To make conditions .

English: Get lost !
Shakespearean: Go to .

English: You are not , Cassius .
Shakespearean: You are not , Cassius .

English: I am .
Shakespearean: I am .

English: I say you're not .
Shakespearean: I say you are not .

English: Don't provoke me any further or I'll forget to restrain myself .
Shakespearean: Urge me no more , I shall forget myself .

English: If you care about your health , you won't push me any further .
Shakespearean: Have mind upon your health , tempt me no further .

English: Leave , you little man .
Shakespearean: Away , slight man !

English: Is this possible ?
Shakespearean: Is 't possible ?

English: Listen to me , for I have something to tell you .
Shakespearean: Hear me , for I will speak .

English: Does a madman scare me when he stares at me ?
Shakespearean: Shall I be frighted when a madman stares ?

English: But why do you keep me here so long ?
Shakespearean: But wherefore do you hold me here so long ?

English: What do you want to tell me ?
Shakespearean: What is it that you would impart to me ?

English: I know this quality in you , Brutus , it's as familiar to me as your face .
Shakespearean: I know that virtue to be in you , Brutus , As well as I do know your outward favor .

English: Indeed , honor is what I want to talk to you about .
Shakespearean: Well , honor is the subject of my story .

English: I don't know what you and other men think of this life , but as for me , I'd rather not live at all than live to worship a man as ordinary as myself .
Shakespearean: I can not tell what you and other men Think of this life , but , for my single self , I had as lief not be as live to be In awe of such a thing as I myself .

English: I was born as free as Caesar .
Shakespearean: I was born free as Caesar .

English: So were you .
Shakespearean: So were you .

English: We both have eaten as well , and we can both endure the cold winter as well as he .
Shakespearean: We both have fed as well , and we can both Endure the winter's cold as well as he .

English: Once , on a cold and windy day , when the river Tiber was crashing against its banks , Caesar said to me , "Cassius , I dare you to jump into this rough water with me and swim to that point there." As soon as he spoke , though I was fully dressed , I plunged in and called for him to follow .
Shakespearean: For once upon a raw and gusty day , The troubled Tiber chafing with her shores , Caesar said to me , "Darest thou , Cassius , now Leap in with me into this angry flood And swim to yonder point ? " Upon the word , Accoutred as I was , I plunged in And bade him follow .

English: And he did .
Shakespearean: So indeed he did .

English: But before we reached the end point , Caesar cried , "Help me , Cassius , or I will sink ! " And just as Aeneas , the hero who founded Rome , emerged from the fires of Troy with his elderly father Anchises on his shoulder , so I emerged from the Tiber carrying the tired Caesar .
Shakespearean: But ere we could arrive the point proposed , Caesar cried , "Help me , Cassius , or I sink ! " I , as Aeneas , our great ancestor , Did from the flames of Troy upon his shoulder The old Anchises bear , so from the waves of Tiber Did I the tired Caesar .

English: All this" ?
Shakespearean: All this" ?

English: Yes , and more .
Shakespearean: Ay , more .

English: Go ahead , rage till your proud heart breaks .
Shakespearean: Fret till your proud heart break .

English: Show your slaves how mad you are , and make your servants tremble .
Shakespearean: Go show your slaves how choleric you are And make your bondmen tremble .

English: Has it come to this ?
Shakespearean: Is it come to this ?

English: You say you're a better soldier .
Shakespearean: You say you are a better soldier .

English: Show it !
Shakespearean: Let it appear so .

English: Make your boasts come true , and I'll be thrilled .
Shakespearean: Make your vaunting true , And it shall please me well .

English: I'm always happy to hear about brave men .
Shakespearean: For mine own part , I shall be glad to learn of noble men .

English: You wrong me in every way .
Shakespearean: You wrong me every way .

English: You wrong me , Brutus .
Shakespearean: You wrong me , Brutus .

English: When Caesar was alive , even he wouldn't dare anger me like this .
Shakespearean: When Caesar lived , he durst not thus have moved me .

English: Oh , be quiet .
Shakespearean: Peace , peace !

English: You wouldn't have dared to tempt him so .
Shakespearean: You durst not so have tempted him .

English: I wouldn't have dared !
Shakespearean: I durst not !

English: No .
Shakespearean: No .

English: You wouldn't have dared , out of fear for your life .
Shakespearean: For your life you durst not .

English: Don't take my love for granted .
Shakespearean: Do not presume too much upon my love .

English: I might do something I'll be sorry for .
Shakespearean: I may do that I shall be sorry for .

English: You've already done something you should be sorry for .
Shakespearean: You have done that you should be sorry for .

English: Your threats don't scare me , Cassius , because I'm so secure in my honesty and integrity that they pass me by like a weak breeze .
Shakespearean: There is no terror , Cassius , in your threats , For I am armed so strong in honesty That they pass by me as the idle wind , Which I respect not .

English: I asked you for gold to pay my soldiers , and you wouldn't give it to me .
Shakespearean: I did send To you for gold to pay my legions , Which you denied me .

English: Was that the Caius Cassius that I knew ?
Shakespearean: Was that done like Cassius ?

English: And would I have ever done that to you ?
Shakespearean: Should I have answered Caius Cassius so ?

English: I didn't refuse you .
Shakespearean: I denied you not .

English: You did .
Shakespearean: You did .

English: I didn't .
Shakespearean: I did not .

English: The man who brought my answer to you was a fool .
Shakespearean: He was but a fool that brought My answer back .

English: You have broken my heart .
Shakespearean: Brutus hath rived my heart .

English: A friend should put up with his friend's weaknesses , but you exaggerate mine .
Shakespearean: A friend should bear his friend's infirmities , But Brutus makes mine greater than they are .

English: I don't until you practice them on me .
Shakespearean: I do not , till you practice them on me .

English: You don't love me .
Shakespearean: You love me not .

English: I don't like your faults .
Shakespearean: I do not like your faults .

English: A friend would never see those faults .
Shakespearean: A friendly eye could never see such faults .

English: No , a flatterer wouldn't , even if the faults were as huge as Mount Olympus .
Shakespearean: A flatterer's would not , though they do appear As huge as high Olympus .

English: Oh , I could weep my soul right out of myself !
Shakespearean: Oh , I could weep My spirit from mine eyes .

English: There's my dagger Put away your dagger .
Shakespearean: Sheathe your dagger .

English: Be angry whenever you like , it's all right with me .
Shakespearean: Be angry when you will , it shall have scope .

English: Do whatever you want , and I'll say your insults are just a bad mood .
Shakespearean: Do what you will , dishonor shall be humor .

English: When I said that , I was angry too .
Shakespearean: When I spoke that , I was ill-tempered too .

English: You admit it , then ?
Shakespearean: Do you confess so much ?

English: Give me your hand .
Shakespearean: Give me your hand .

English: And my heart too .
Shakespearean: And my heart too .

English: Oh , Brutus !
Shakespearean: O Brutus !

English: What's the matter ?
Shakespearean: What's the matter ?

English: Do you have enough love for me to be patient when my bad temper , which I inherited from my mother , makes me forget how I should behave ?
Shakespearean: Have not you love enough to bear with me , When that rash humor which my mother gave me Makes me forgetful ?

English: Yes , Cassius .
Shakespearean: Yes , Cassius .

English: And from now on , when you get hot with me , I'll assume it's your mother speaking and leave it at that .
Shakespearean: And from henceforth When you are over-earnest with your Brutus , He'll think your mother chides and leave you so .

English: What's this !
Shakespearean: How now ?

English: What's the matter ?
Shakespearean: What's the matter ?

English: You should be ashamed , generals !
Shakespearean: For shame , you generals !

English: What do you think you're doing ?
Shakespearean: What do you mean ?

English: Love each other and be friends , like two such men should be .
Shakespearean: Love , and be friends as two such men should be .

English: Listen to me , because I'm older than you , surely .
Shakespearean: For I have seen more years , I'm sure , than ye .

English: Be patient with him , Brutus .
Shakespearean: Bear with him , Brutus .

English: That's just how he is .
Shakespearean: Tis his fashion .

English: I'll humor him when he learns how to behave .
Shakespearean: I'll know his humor when he knows his time .

English: What should we do with all these rhyming fools that follow us from post to post ?
Shakespearean: What should the wars do with these jigging fools ?

English: Get out of here , my friend .
Shakespearean: Companion , hence !

English: Away , away , be gone .
Shakespearean: Away , away , be gone .

English: Lucillius and Titinius , order the commanders to have the men camp for the night .
Shakespearean: Lucillius and Titinius , bid the commanders Prepare to lodge their companies tonight .

English: And return to us immediately , bringing Messala with you .
Shakespearean: And come yourselves , and bring Messala with you , Immediately to us .

English: I didn't think you could even be so angry .
Shakespearean: I did not think you could have been so angry .

English: Oh Cassius , I'm tired out by many sorrows .
Shakespearean: O Cassius , I am sick of many griefs .

English: Portia is dead .
Shakespearean: Portia is dead .

English: Portia !
Shakespearean: Ha , Portia ?

English: She is dead .
Shakespearean: She is dead .

English: What an irreplaceable and grievous loss !
Shakespearean: O insupportable and touching loss !

English: What sickness did she die of ?
Shakespearean: Upon what sickness ?

English: She was worried about my absence , and about the fact that young Octavius and Mark Antony have grown so strong , which I found out at the same time as the news of her death .
Shakespearean: Impatient of my absence , And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony Have made themselves so strong , for with her death That tidings came , with this she fell distract And , her attendants absent , swallowed fire .

English: And that's how she died ?
Shakespearean: And died so ?

English: Yes , like that .
Shakespearean: Even so .

English: Oh , immortal gods !
Shakespearean: O ye immortal gods !

English: My heart is thirsty for that noble promise .
Shakespearean: My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge .

English: Fill my cup , Lucius , until the wine overflows it .
Shakespearean: Fill , Lucius , till the wine o'erswell the cup .

English: I can not drink too much of Brutus's love .
Shakespearean: I can not drink too much of Brutus ' love .

English: Now let's sit closely around this candle and discuss our needs .
Shakespearean: Now sit we close about this taper here And call in question our necessities .

English: Portia , are you really gone ?
Shakespearean: Portia , art thou gone ?

English: No more about that , please .
Shakespearean: No more , I pray you .

English: Messala , I have received these letters explaining that young Octavius and Mark Antony are rushing toward Philippi and bearing down upon us with a mighty power .
Shakespearean: Messala , I have here received letters That young Octavius and Mark Antony Come down upon us with a mighty power , Bending their expedition toward Philippi .

English: I have received letters that say the same .
Shakespearean: Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor .

English: And anything else ?
Shakespearean: With what addition ?

English: That with a series of legal writs , Octavius , Antony , and Lepidus have put a hundred senators to death .
Shakespearean: That by proscription and bills of outlawry , Octavius , Antony , and Lepidus Have put to death an hundred senators .

English: On that point , our letters don't agree .
