Shakespearean: Therein our letters do not well agree .

English: My letters say only seventy senators were killed , one being Cicero .
Shakespearean: Mine speak of seventy senators that died By their proscriptions , Cicero being one .

English: Cicero too ?
Shakespearean: Cicero one ?

English: Cicero is dead , by their decree .
Shakespearean: Cicero is dead , And by that order of proscription .

English: No , Messala .
Shakespearean: No , Messala .

English: And you haven't heard any news about her in your letters ?
Shakespearean: Nor nothing in your letters writ of her ?

English: Nothing , Messala .
Shakespearean: Nothing , Messala .

English: I think that's strange .
Shakespearean: That methinks is strange .

English: Why do you ask ?
Shakespearean: Why ask you ?

English: Have you heard something of her in your letters ?
Shakespearean: Hear you aught of her in yours ?

English: No , my lord .
Shakespearean: No , my lord .

English: Now , as you're a Roman , tell me the truth .
Shakespearean: Now , as you are a Roman , tell me true .

English: Then you must take the truth I have to tell like a Roman .
Shakespearean: Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell .

English: It's certain that she is dead , and she died in a strange way .
Shakespearean: For certain she is dead , and by strange manner .

English: Well , good-bye , Portia .
Shakespearean: Why , farewell , Portia .

English: We all must die , Messala .
Shakespearean: We must die , Messala .

English: Having already thought about the fact that she would have to die sometime , I can endure her death now .
Shakespearean: With meditating that she must die once , I have the patience to endure it now .

English: That's the way great men ought to endure great losses .
Shakespearean: Even so great men great losses should endure .

English: I've practiced Stoicism with as much devotion as you , but I still couldn't bear this news like you do .
Shakespearean: I have as much of this in art as you , But yet my nature could not bear it so .

English: Well , let's move on to our work with the living .
Shakespearean: Well , to our work alive .

English: What do you think of marching to Philippi immediately ?
Shakespearean: What do you think Of marching to Philippi presently ?

English: I don't think it's a good idea .
Shakespearean: I do not think it good .

English: Why not ?
Shakespearean: Your reason ?

English: Here's why : it'd be better for the enemy to come after us .
Shakespearean: This it is : 'T is better that the enemy seek us .

English: That way , he'll waste his provisions and tire out his soldiers , weakening his own capacities , while we , lying still , are rested , energetic , and nimble .
Shakespearean: So shall he waste his means , weary his soldiers , Doing himself offense , whilst we , lying still , Are full of rest , defense , and nimbleness .

English: If we meet him at Philippi , these people will be at our backs .
Shakespearean: The enemy , marching along by them , By them shall make a fuller number up , Come on refreshed , new-added , and encouraged , From which advantage shall we cut him off If at Philippi we do face him there , These people at our back .

English: Listen to me , good brother .
Shakespearean: Hear me , good brother , Under your pardon .

English: Our regiments are full to the brim ; our cause is ready .
Shakespearean: You must note beside , That we have tried the utmost of our friends , Our legions are brim-full , our cause is ripe .

English: The enemy gets larger each day .
Shakespearean: The enemy increaseth every day .

English: We , now at our largest , can only decrease .
Shakespearean: We , at the height , are ready to decline .

English: It's on such a high tide that we're now floating , and we must take the current when it is offered , or lose our campaign .
Shakespearean: On such a full sea are we now afloat , And we must take the current when it serves Or lose our ventures .

English: If that's what you want , all right .
Shakespearean: Then , with your will , go on .

English: We'll go forward with you and meet them at Philippi .
Shakespearean: We'll along ourselves , and meet them at Philippi .

English: It's now late at night , and actions must accommodate bodily needs , which we'll satisfy with only a short rest .
Shakespearean: The deep of night is crept upon our talk , And nature must obey necessity , Which we will niggard with a little rest .

English: That's all there is to say .
Shakespearean: There is no more to say ?

English: There's nothing else .
Shakespearean: No more .

English: Good night .
Shakespearean: Good night .

English: We'll rise and leave early tomorrow .
Shakespearean: Early tomorrow will we rise and hence .

English: Lucius !
Shakespearean: Lucius !

English: Let's pray that we never come into conflict like that again .
Shakespearean: Never come such division 'tween our souls .

English: Let's not , Brutus .
Shakespearean: Let it not , Brutus .

English: And this is the man who has now become a god , and I'm a wretched creature who must bow down if Caesar so much as carelessly nods my way .
Shakespearean: Is now become a god , and Cassius is A wretched creature and must bend his body If Caesar carelessly but nod on him .

English: In Spain , Caesar had a fever , and it made him shake .
Shakespearean: He had a fever when he was in Spain , And when the fit was on him , I did mark How he did shake .

English: It's true , this so-called "god" , he shook .
Shakespearean: Tis true , this god did shake !

English: His cowardly lips turned white , and the same eye whose gaze terrifies the world lost its gleam .
Shakespearean: His coward lips did from their color fly , And that same eye whose bend doth awe the world Did lose his luster .

English: I heard him groan , yes , I did , and the same tongue that ordered the Romans to obey him and transcribe his speeches in their books cried , "Give me some water , Titinius , " like a sick girl .
Shakespearean: I did hear him groan , Ay , and that tongue of his that bade the Romans Mark him and write his speeches in their books , "Alas , " it cried , "give me some drink , Titinius , " As a sick girl .

English: It astounds me that such a weak man could beat the whole world and carry the trophy of victory alone .
Shakespearean: Ye gods , it doth amaze me A man of such a feeble temper should So get the start of the majestic world And bear the palm alone .

English: More shouting !
Shakespearean: Another general shout !

English: I think this applause is for some new honors awarded to Caesar .
Shakespearean: I do believe that these applauses are For some new honors that are heaped on Caesar .

English: Why , Caesar straddles the narrow world like a giant , and we petty men walk under his huge legs and look forward only to dying dishonorably , as slaves .
Shakespearean: Why , man , he doth bestride the narrow world Like a Colossus , and we petty men Walk under his huge legs and peep about To find ourselves dishonorable graves .

English: Men can be masters of their fate .
Shakespearean: Men at some time are masters of their fates .

English: It is not destiny's fault , but our own faults , that we're slaves .
Shakespearean: The fault , dear Brutus , is not in our stars But in ourselves , that we are underlings .

English: Brutus" and "Caesar." What's so special about "Caesar" ?
Shakespearean: Brutus and Caesar , what should be in that "Caesar" ?

English: Why should that name be proclaimed more than yours ?
Shakespearean: Why should that name be sounded more than yours ?

English: Write them together , yours is just as good a name .
Shakespearean: Write them together , yours is as fair a name .

English: Pronounce them , it is just as nice to say .
Shakespearean: Sound them , it doth become the mouth as well .

English: Everything's fine .
Shakespearean: Everything is well .

English: Good night , my lord .
Shakespearean: Good night , my lord .

English: Good night , good brother .
Shakespearean: Good night , good brother .

English: Good night , Lord Brutus .
Shakespearean: Good night , Lord Brutus .

English: Farewell , everyone .
Shakespearean: Farewell , everyone .

English: Give me the gown .
Shakespearean: Give me the gown .

English: Where's your lute ?
Shakespearean: Where is thy instrument ?

English: Here in the tent .
Shakespearean: Here in the tent .

English: What , are you sleepy ?
Shakespearean: What , thou speak'st drowsily ?

English: Call Claudio and some of my other men .
Shakespearean: Call Claudio and some other of my men .

English: I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent .
Shakespearean: I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent .

English: Varrus and Claudio !
Shakespearean: Varrus and Claudio !

English: Did you call , my lord ?
Shakespearean: Calls my lord ?

English: Sirs , I ask you to sleep in my tent .
Shakespearean: I pray you , sirs , lie in my tent and sleep .

English: I might wake you up in a while to send you on an errand to my brother Cassius .
Shakespearean: It may be I shall raise you by and by On business to my brother Cassius .

English: If you like , we'll stand by and wait to do whatever you need .
Shakespearean: So please you , we will stand and watch your pleasure .

English: Look , Lucius , here's the book I was searching for .
Shakespearean: Look , Lucius , here's the book I sought for so .

English: I put it in the pocket of my nightgown .
Shakespearean: I put it in the pocket of my gown .

English: I was sure that you hadn't given it to me .
Shakespearean: I was sure your lordship did not give it me .

English: Can you stay awake a bit longer and play a few tunes on your lute ?
Shakespearean: Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile , And touch thy instrument a strain or two ?

English: Yes , my lord , if you would like .
Shakespearean: Ay , my lord , an 't please you .

English: I would , my boy .
Shakespearean: It does , my boy .

English: I ask too much of you , but you're always willing .
Shakespearean: I trouble thee too much , but thou art willing .

English: It's my duty , sir .
Shakespearean: It is my duty , sir .

English: I shouldn't make you do more than you're able .
Shakespearean: I should not urge thy duty past thy might .

English: I know that young men look forward to their rest .
Shakespearean: I know young bloods look for a time of rest .

English: I've already slept , my lord .
Shakespearean: I have slept , my lord , already .

English: That was good planning , and you'll sleep some more .
Shakespearean: It was well done , and thou shalt sleep again .

English: I won't keep you very long .
Shakespearean: I will not hold thee long .

English: If I live through this , I'll be good to you .
Shakespearean: If I do live , I will be good to thee .

English: This is a sleepy tune .
Shakespearean: This is a sleepy tune .

English: Gentle boy , good night .
Shakespearean: O murderous slumber , Layst thou thy leaden mace upon my boy That plays thee music ? , Gentle knave , good night .

English: I won't trouble you so much as to wake you .
Shakespearean: I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee .

English: Good night , good boy .
Shakespearean: And , good boy , good night .

English: Let me see , let me see .
Shakespearean: Let me see , let me see .

English: Didn't I turn down the page where I left off reading ?
Shakespearean: Is not the leaf turned down Where I left reading ?

English: Here it is , I think .
Shakespearean: Here it is , I think .

English: I think it's my bad eyesight that's making me see this horrible vision .
Shakespearean: I think it is the weakness of mine eyes That shapes this monstrous apparition .

English: It's coming toward me .
Shakespearean: It comes upon me. , Art thou any thing ?

English: Are you a god , an angel , or a devil , that you make my blood turn cold and my hair stand up ?
Shakespearean: Art thou some god , some angel , or some devil That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare ?

English: Tell me what you are .
Shakespearean: Speak to me what thou art .

English: I'm your evil spirit , Brutus .
Shakespearean: Thy evil spirit , Brutus .

English: Why do you come here ?
Shakespearean: Why comest thou ?

English: To tell you that you'll see me at Philippi .
Shakespearean: To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi .

English: Then I'll see you again ?
Shakespearean: Well , then I shall see thee again ?

English: Yes , at Philippi .
Shakespearean: Ay , at Philippi .

English: Alright , then I'll see you at Philippi .
Shakespearean: Why , I will see thee at Philippi , then .

English: Evil spirit , I want to talk some more .
Shakespearean: Ill spirit , I would hold more talk with thee .

English: Claudio !
Shakespearean: Claudio !

English: Claudio !
Shakespearean: The strings , my lord , are false .

English: He thinks he's still playing his instrument .
Shakespearean: He thinks he still is at his instrument .

English: Lucius , wake up !
Shakespearean: Lucius , awake .

English: My lord ?
Shakespearean: My lord ?

English: Were you dreaming , Lucius ?
Shakespearean: Didst thou dream , Lucius , that thou so criedst out ?

English: My lord , I don't think I cried out .
Shakespearean: My lord , I do not know that I did cry .

English: Yes , you did .
Shakespearean: Yes , that thou didst .

English: Did you see anything ?
Shakespearean: Didst thou see any thing ?

English: Nothing , my lord .
Shakespearean: Nothing , my lord .

English: My lord ?
Shakespearean: My lord ?

English: My lord ?
Shakespearean: My lord ?

English: Why did you cry out in your sleep ?
Shakespearean: Why did you so cry out , sirs , in your sleep ?

English: Did we , my lord ?
Shakespearean: Did we , my lord ?

English: Yes .
Shakespearean: Ay .

English: Did you see anything ?
Shakespearean: Saw you anything ?

English: No , my lord , I didn't see anything .
Shakespearean: No , my lord , I saw nothing .

English: Me neither , my lord .
Shakespearean: Nor I , my lord .

English: Go to my brother Cassius .
Shakespearean: Go and commend me to my brother Cassius .

English: Order him to advance his forces first thing , and we'll follow .
Shakespearean: Bid him set on his powers betimes before , And we will follow .

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: It shall be done , my lord .

English: Now , Antony , our prayers have been answered .
Shakespearean: Now , Antony , our hopes are answered .

English: You said the enemy wouldn't come down but keep to the hills and upper regions .
Shakespearean: You said the enemy would not come down But keep the hills and upper regions .

English: It seems not .
Shakespearean: It proves not so .

English: Their forces are nearby .
Shakespearean: Their battles are at hand .

English: They intend to challenge us here at Philippi , responding to our challenge before we've even challenged him .
Shakespearean: They mean to warn us at Philippi here , Answering before we do demand of them .

English: I know how they think , and I understand why they're doing this .
Shakespearean: Tut , I am in their bosoms , and I know Wherefore they do it .

English: They really wish they were somewhere else , but they want to descend on us , looking fierce so we'll think they're brave .
Shakespearean: They could be content To visit other places , and come down With fearful bravery , thinking by this face To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage .

English: But they aren't .
Shakespearean: But 'tis not so .

English: Prepare yourselves , generals .
Shakespearean: Prepare you , generals .

English: The enemy approaches with great display .
Shakespearean: The enemy comes on in gallant show .

English: They show their bloody heralds of battle , and something must be done immediately .
Shakespearean: Their bloody sign of battle is hung out , And something to be done immediately .

English: Octavius , lead your forces slowly out to the left side of the level field .
Shakespearean: Octavius , lead your battle softly on , Upon the left hand of the even field .

English: I'll go to the right side .
Shakespearean: Upon the right hand I .

English: You stay on the left .
Shakespearean: Keep thou the left .

English: Why are you defying me in this urgent matter ?
Shakespearean: Why do you cross me in this exigent ?

English: They want to talk .
Shakespearean: They stand and would have parley .

English: Stay here , Titinius .
Shakespearean: Stand fast , Titinius .

English: We have to go out and talk to them .
Shakespearean: We must out and talk .

English: Mark Antony , should we give the signal to attack ?
Shakespearean: Mark Antony , shall we give sign of battle ?

English: No , Octavius Caesar , we'll respond to their charge .
Shakespearean: No , Caesar , we will answer on their charge .

English: Go forward .
Shakespearean: Make forth .

English: The generals want to speak with us .
Shakespearean: The generals would have some words .

English: Words before fighting .
Shakespearean: Words before blows .

English: Is that how it is , countrymen ?
Shakespearean: Is it so , countrymen ?

English: Not that we love words more than fighting , like you do .
Shakespearean: Not that we love words better , as you do .

English: Good words are better than bad strokes , Octavius .
Shakespearean: Good words are better than bad strokes , Octavius .

English: Brutus , you give a nice speech along with your evil strokes .
Shakespearean: In your bad strokes , Brutus , you give good words .

English: But your words are as sweet as honey , you've stolen from the bees and left them with nothing .
Shakespearean: But for your words , they rob the Hybla bees And leave them honeyless .

English: I took their stings too , wouldn't you say ?
Shakespearean: Not stingless too ?

English: Villains , you didn't do even that much when your vile daggers struck each other as they hacked up Caesar's sides .
Shakespearean: Villains , you did not so when your vile daggers Hacked one another in the sides of Caesar .

English: Now , Brutus , you have only yourself to thank .
Shakespearean: Flatterers ? , Now , Brutus , thank yourself .

English: Come , come , let's remember why we're here .
Shakespearean: When think you that the sword goes up again ?

English: If arguing makes us sweat , the real trial will turn that water to blood .
Shakespearean: Never , till Caesar's three and thirty wounds Be well avenged , or till another Caesar Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors .

English: Caesar , you're not going to be killed by a traitor , unless you kill yourself..
Shakespearean: Caesar , thou canst not die by traitors ' hands Unless thou bring'st them with thee .

English: I hope you're right .
Shakespearean: So I hope .

English: I wasn't born to die on your sword .
Shakespearean: I was not born to die on Brutus ' sword .

English: If you were the noblest of your family , young man , you couldn't die more honorably .
Shakespearean: O , if thou wert the noblest of thy strain , Young man , thou couldst not die more honorable .

English: An annoying schoolboy , unworthy of such an honor , joined by a masquerader and a partier !
Shakespearean: A peevish schoolboy , worthless of such honor , Joined with a masker and a reveler !

English: Still the same old Cassius !
Shakespearean: Old Cassius still .

English: If you dare to fight today , come to the field .
Shakespearean: If you dare fight today , come to the field .

English: If not , come when you have the courage .
Shakespearean: If not , when you have stomachs .

English: Now let the wind blow , waves swell , and ships sink !
Shakespearean: Why , now , blow wind , swell billow , and swim bark !

English: The storm has begun and everything is at stake .
Shakespearean: The storm is up and all is on the hazard .

English: Messala !
Shakespearean: Messala !

English: Messala , today is my birthday , I was born on this very day .
Shakespearean: Messala , This is my birthday , as this very day Was Cassius born .

English: Give me your hand , Messala .
Shakespearean: Give me thy hand , Messala .

English: You'll be my witness that I've been forced , as Pompey was , to wager all of our freedoms on one battle .
Shakespearean: Be thou my witness that against my will , As Pompey was , am I compelled to set Upon one battle all our liberties .

English: You know that I used to believe in Epicurus and his disregard for omens .
Shakespearean: You know that I held Epicurus strong And his opinion .

English: I've changed my mind now and partly believe in omens .
Shakespearean: Now I change my mind , And partly credit things that do presage .

English: Traveling from Sardis , two mighty eagles fell on our front flag and perched there , eating from the hands of the soldiers who'd accompanied us to Philippi .
Shakespearean: Coming from Sardis , on our former ensign Two mighty eagles fell , and there they perched , Gorging and feeding from our soldiers ' hands , Who to Philippi here consorted us .

English: This morning , they've flown away and in their place are ravens , crows , and kites , flying over our heads and looking down on us , as though we were sickly prey .
Shakespearean: This morning are they fled away and gone , And in their steads do ravens , crows , and kites Fly o'er our heads and downward look on us As we were sickly prey .

English: Their shadows are like a deadly canopy , under which our army lies , ready to die .
Shakespearean: Their shadows seem A canopy most fatal , under which Our army lies , ready to give up the ghost .

English: Don't believe in this .
Shakespearean: Believe not so .

English: I only partly believe it , for I'm enthusiastic and resolved to meet all dangers without wavering .
Shakespearean: I but believe it partly , For I am fresh of spirit and resolved To meet all perils very constantly .

English: Now , most noble Brutus , the gods are friendly with us today so that we , who want peace , can live on to old age !
Shakespearean: Now , most noble Brutus , The gods today stand friendly that we may , Lovers in peace , lead on our days to age .

English: But since the affairs of men are always uncertain , let's think about the worst that may happen .
Shakespearean: But since the affairs of men rest still incertain , Let's reason with the worst that may befall .

English: If we lose this battle , this is the last time we'll speak to each other .
Shakespearean: If we do lose this battle , then is this The very last time we shall speak together .

English: If we lose , what do you plan to do ?
Shakespearean: What are you then determined to do ?

English: Cast spells with them , and "Brutus" will call up a ghost as well as "Caesar." Now , in the name of all the gods , I ask you what food does Caesar eat that has made him grow so great ?
Shakespearean: Brutus" will start a spirit as soon as "Caesar." Now in the names of all the gods at once , Upon what meat doth this our Caesar feed That he is grown so great ?

English: Our era should be ashamed !
Shakespearean: Age , thou art shamed !

English: Rome has lost the ability to raise noble men !
Shakespearean: Rome , thou hast lost the breed of noble bloods !

English: When was there ever an age , since the beginning of time , that didn't feature more than one famous man ?
Shakespearean: When went there by an age , since the great flood , But it was famed with more than with one man ?

English: Until now , no one could say that only one man mattered in all of vast Rome .
Shakespearean: When could they say till now , that talked of Rome , That her wide walks encompassed but one man ?

English: Now , though , in all of Rome , there's room for only one man .
Shakespearean: Now is it Rome indeed , and room enough , When there is in it but one only man .

English: You and I have heard our fathers talk of another Brutus , your ancestor , who would've let the devil himself reign in his Roman Republic before he let a king rule .
Shakespearean: Oh , you and I have heard our fathers say , There was a Brutus once that would have brooked Th ' eternal devil to keep his state in Rome As easily as a king .

English: I have no doubt that you love me .
Shakespearean: That you do love me , I am nothing jealous .

English: I'm beginning to understand what you want me to do .
Shakespearean: What you would work me to , I have some aim .

English: What I think about this , and about what's happening here in Rome , I'll tell you later .
Shakespearean: How I have thought of this and of these times I shall recount hereafter .

English: For now , don't try to persuade me anymore , I ask you as a friend .
Shakespearean: For this present , I would not , so with love I might entreat you , Be any further moved .

English: I'll think over what you've said , I'll listen patiently to whatever else you have to say , and I'll find a good time for us to discuss further such weighty matters .
Shakespearean: What you have said I will consider , what you have to say I will with patience hear , and find a time Both meet to hear and answer such high things .

English: Until then , my noble friend , think about this : I'd rather be a poor villager than call myself a citizen of Rome under the hard conditions that this time is likely to put us through .
Shakespearean: Till then , my noble friend , chew upon this : Brutus had rather be a villager Than to repute himself a son of Rome Under these hard conditions as this time Is like to lay upon us .

English: I'm glad that my weak words have provoked even this small show of protest from you .
Shakespearean: I am glad that my weak words Have struck but thus much show of fire from Brutus .

English: Then if we lose this battle , you'll be willing to be led in chains through the streets of Rome ?
Shakespearean: Then if we lose this battle You are contented to be led in triumph Thorough the streets of Rome ?

English: No , Cassius , no .
Shakespearean: No , Cassius , no .

English: Don't imagine that I'll ever allow myself to return to Rome in chains .
Shakespearean: Think not , thou noble Roman , That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome .

English: My mind is too great for that .
Shakespearean: He bears too great a mind .

English: Therefore , accept my everlasting farewell .
Shakespearean: Therefore our everlasting farewell take .

English: Forever and forever , farewell , Cassius !
Shakespearean: Forever and forever farewell , Cassius .

English: If we meet again , then we'll smile .
Shakespearean: If we do meet again , why , we shall smile .

English: If not , then this parting was well done .
Shakespearean: If not , why then this parting was well made .

English: Forever and forever , farewell , Brutus !
Shakespearean: Forever and forever farewell , Brutus .

English: If we meet again , then we'll smile indeed .
Shakespearean: If we do meet again , we'll smile indeed .

English: If not , it's true , this parting was well done .
Shakespearean: If not , 'tis true this parting was well made .

English: Well , lead on .
Shakespearean: Why then , lead on .

English: Oh , I wish I could know what will happen today before it happens !
Shakespearean: Oh , that a man might know The end of this day's business ere it come !

English: But it's enough to know that the day will end , and then the end will be known .
Shakespearean: But it sufficeth that the day will end , And then the end is known. , Come , ho !

English: Let's go !
Shakespearean: Away !

English: Ride , ride , Messala , ride , and give these dispatches to our forces on the other side .
Shakespearean: Ride , ride , Messala , ride , and give these bills Unto the legions on the other side .

English: They should advance immediately , because I sense Octavius's side is a bit fainthearted right now , and a sudden push would overthrow him .
Shakespearean: Let them set on at once , for I perceive But cold demeanor in Octavius ' wing , And sudden push gives them the overthrow .

English: Ride , ride , Messala .
Shakespearean: Ride , ride , Messala .

English: I've become an enemy to my own soldiers !
Shakespearean: Myself have to mine own turned enemy .

English: Oh , Cassius , Brutus gave the orders too soon .
Shakespearean: O Cassius , Brutus gave the word too early , Who , having some advantage on Octavius , Took it too eagerly .

English: Retreat further , my lord , retreat further .
Shakespearean: Fly further off , my lord , fly further off .

English: Mark Antony is in your tents , my lord .
Shakespearean: Mark Antony is in your tents , my lord .

English: Therefore you must run , noble Cassius .
Shakespearean: Fly , therefore , noble Cassius , fly far off .

English: Are those my tents on fire ?
Shakespearean: Are those my tents where I perceive the fire ?

English: They are , my lord .
Shakespearean: They are , my lord .

English: Titinius , if you love me , get on your horse and spur him on until he's brought you to those troops and back again , so that I can find out whether those troops are friends or enemies .
Shakespearean: Titinius , if thou lovest me , Mount thou my horse , and hide thy spurs in him Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops And here again , that I may rest assured Whether yond troops are friend or enemy .

English: I'll be back quicker than you can think a thought .
Shakespearean: I will be here again , even with a thought .

English: Go , Pindarus , climb a little higher on this hill .
Shakespearean: Go , Pindarus , get higher on that hill .

English: My eyesight has always been bad .
Shakespearean: My sight was ever thick .

English: Watch Titinius and tell me what you see in the field .
Shakespearean: Regard Titinius , And tell me what thou notest about the field .

English: Today was the day I breathed my first breath .
Shakespearean: This day I breathed first .

English: Time has come round , and I'll end where I began .
Shakespearean: Time is come round , And where I did begin , there shall I end .

English: My life has run its circle .
Shakespearean: My life is run his compass .

English: What news ?
Shakespearean: What news ?

English: And listen !
Shakespearean: And , hark !

English: They shout for joy .
Shakespearean: They shout for joy .

English: Come down , look no more .
Shakespearean: Come down , behold no more .

English: Oh , I'm such a coward for living long enough to see my best friend taken before my eyes !
Shakespearean: Oh , coward that I am , to live so long To see my best friend ta'en before my face !

English: Come here , boy .
Shakespearean: Come hither , sirrah .

English: Come now , keep your oath .
Shakespearean: Come now , keep thine oath .

English: Caesar , you are revenged with the very same sword that killed you .
Shakespearean: Caesar , thou art revenged , Even with the sword that killed thee .

English: So I'm free .
Shakespearean: So I am free .

English: But I didn't want to be free like this .
Shakespearean: Yet would not so have been , Durst I have done my will .

English: Oh , Cassius , I'll run far from this country to where no Romans can find me .
Shakespearean: O Cassius , Far from this country Pindarus shall run , Where never Roman shall take note of him .

English: The armies have merely changed places , Titinius , because Octavius has been overthrown by noble Brutus's forces at the very moment that Antony overthrew Cassius's legions .
Shakespearean: It is but change , Titinius , for Octavius Is overthrown by noble Brutus ' power , As Cassius ' legions are by Antony .

English: This news will comfort Cassius .
Shakespearean: These tidings will well comfort Cassius .

English: Where did you leave him ?
Shakespearean: Where did you leave him ?

English: On this hill and in despair , with his slave Pindarus .
Shakespearean: All disconsolate , With Pindarus his bondman on this hill .

English: Isn't that him on the ground ?
Shakespearean: Is not that he that lies upon the ground ?

English: He doesn't seem to be alive .
Shakespearean: He lies not like the living .

English: Oh , my heart !
Shakespearean: O my heart !

English: Isn't that him ?
Shakespearean: Is not that he ?

English: Pindarus !
Shakespearean: What , Pindarus !

English: Where are you , Pindarus ?
Shakespearean: Where art thou , Pindarus ?

English: Look for him , Titinius , while I go to meet the noble Brutus and force him to hear this news .
Shakespearean: Seek him , Titinius , whilst I go to meet The noble Brutus , thrusting this report Into his ears .

English: I say "force" because Brutus would rather I stuck sharp blades and poisoned arrows in his ears than fill them with this .
Shakespearean: I may say "thrusting" it , For piercing steel and darts envenomed Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus As tidings of this sight .

English: Hurry , Messala , and I'll look for Pindarus in the meantime .
Shakespearean: Hie you , Messala , And I will seek for Pindarus the while .

English: Why did you send me out , brave Cassius ?
Shakespearean: Why didst thou send me forth , brave Cassius ?

English: Didn't I meet up with your allies ?
Shakespearean: Did I not meet thy friends ?

English: And didn't they place the wreath of victory on my brow and order me to give it to you ?
Shakespearean: And did not they Put on my brows this wreath of victory And bid me give it thee ?

English: Didn't you hear their shouts ?
Shakespearean: Didst thou not hear their shouts ?

English: Alas , you misunderstood everything !
Shakespearean: Alas , thou hast misconstrued everything !

English: But let me place this wreath on your head .
Shakespearean: But , hold thee , take this garland on thy brow .

English: Your Brutus ordered me to give it to you , and I'll do what he says .
Shakespearean: Thy Brutus bid me give it thee , and I Will do his bidding .

English: Where is his body , Messala ?
Shakespearean: Where , where , Messala , doth his body lie ?

English: Over there , where Titinius mourns it .
Shakespearean: Lo , yonder , and Titinius mourning it .

English: Titinius is lying face-up .
Shakespearean: Titinius ' face is upward .

English: He's been killed .
Shakespearean: He is slain .

English: Oh , Julius Caesar , you are still powerful .
Shakespearean: O Julius Caesar , thou art mighty yet !

English: Your ghost walks the earth and turns our swords toward our own stomachs .
Shakespearean: Thy spirit walks abroad and turns our swords In our own proper entrails .

English: Could you have found two Romans as good as these two ?
Shakespearean: Are yet two Romans living such as these ?

English: Good-bye to you , the last of all the Romans .
Shakespearean: The last of all the Romans , fare thee well !

English: I will find the time to cry for you , Cassius , I'll find the time .
Shakespearean: I shall find time , Cassius , I shall find time .

English: Come , then , and send his body to Thasos .
Shakespearean: Come , therefore , and to Thasos send his body .

English: Let's proceed to the field .
Shakespearean: Let us to the field .

English: Labio and Flavio , push our armies onward .
Shakespearean: Labio and Flavio , set our battles on .

English: It is three o'clock , and , Romans , before night , we will try our luck in a second battle .
Shakespearean: Tis three o'clock , and , Romans , yet ere night We shall try fortune in a second fight .

English: Who is so low that he wouldn't ?
Shakespearean: What bastard doth not ?

English: Who will advance with me ?
Shakespearean: Who will go with me ?

English: I will proclaim my name around the field .
Shakespearean: I will proclaim my name about the field .

English: I am the son of Marcus Cato !
Shakespearean: I am the son of Marcus Cato , ho !

English: An enemy to tyrants and a friend to my country .
Shakespearean: A foe to tyrants , and my country's friend .

English: I am the son of Marcus Cato !
Shakespearean: I am the son of Marcus Cato , ho !

English: And I am Brutus , Marcus Brutus .
Shakespearean: And I am Brutus , Marcus Brutus , I !

English: Brutus , my country's friend .
Shakespearean: Brutus , my country's friend .

English: Know that I am Brutus !
Shakespearean: Know me for Brutus !

English: Oh , young and noble Cato , have you been slain ?
Shakespearean: O young and noble Cato , art thou down ?

English: I'd rather die .
Shakespearean: Only I yield to die .

English: Here is some money for you to kill me immediately .
Shakespearean: There is so much that thou wilt kill me straight .

English: Kill Brutus and be honored by the killing .
Shakespearean: Kill Brutus , and be honored in his death .

English: We must not .
Shakespearean: We must not .

English: He is a noble prisoner !
Shakespearean: A noble prisoner !

English: Make room !
Shakespearean: Room , ho !

English: Tell Antony that Brutus has been taken .
Shakespearean: Tell Antony Brutus is ta'en .

English: I'll tell him the news .
Shakespearean: I'll tell the news .

English: Where is he ?
Shakespearean: Where is he ?

English: He's safe , Antony .
Shakespearean: Safe , Antony .

English: I can assure you that no enemy will ever take the noble Brutus alive .
Shakespearean: I dare assure thee that no enemy Shall ever take alive the noble Brutus .

English: The gods protect him from so great a shame !
Shakespearean: The gods defend him from so great a shame !

English: The games are done and Caesar is returning .
Shakespearean: The games are done and Caesar is returning .

English: As they pass by , grab Casca by the sleeve , and he'll tell you if anything important happened today , in his usual sour way .
Shakespearean: As they pass by , pluck Casca by the sleeve , And he will , after his sour fashion , tell you What hath proceeded worthy note today .

English: I'll do so .
Shakespearean: I will do so .

English: But look , Cassius , Caesar looks angry and everyone else looks as if they've been scolded .
Shakespearean: But , look you , Cassius , The angry spot doth glow on Caesar's brow , And all the rest look like a chidden train .

English: Calphurnia's face is pale , and Cicero's eyes are as red and fiery as they get when senators are arguing with him at the Capitol .
Shakespearean: Calphurnia's cheek is pale , and Cicero Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes As we have seen him in the Capitol Being crossed in conference by some senators .

English: Casca will tell us what's the matter .
Shakespearean: Casca will tell us what the matter is .

English: Antonio !
Shakespearean: Antonio .

English: Caesar ?
Shakespearean: Caesar .

English: Come , last of my friends , rest on this rock .
Shakespearean: Come , poor remains of friends , rest on this rock .

English: Statilius waved the torchlight at us , but he hasn't come back .
Shakespearean: Statilius showed the torchlight but , my lord , He came not back .

English: He's been captured or killed .
Shakespearean: He is or ta'en or slain .

English: Sit down , Clitus .
Shakespearean: Sit thee down , Clitus .

English: Listen , Clitus .
Shakespearean: Hark thee , Clitus .

English: Who , me , my lord ?
Shakespearean: What , I , my lord ?

English: No , not for all the world .
Shakespearean: No , not for all the world .

English: Silence , then !
Shakespearean: Peace then !

English: Don't give it away .
Shakespearean: No words .

English: I'd rather kill myself .
Shakespearean: I'll rather kill myself .

English: Listen , Dardanius .
Shakespearean: Hark thee , Dardanius .

English: Would I dare do something like that ?
Shakespearean: Shall I do such a deed ?

English: Oh Dardanius !
Shakespearean: O Dardanius !

English: Oh Clitus !
Shakespearean: O Clitus !

English: Come here , good Volumnius .
Shakespearean: Come hither , good Volumnius .

English: Listen a minute .
Shakespearean: List a word .

English: What is it , my lord ?
Shakespearean: What says my lord ?

English: Once at Sardis and once last night , here in Philippi fields .
Shakespearean: At Sardis once , And this last night here in Philippi fields .

English: I know that my hour has come .
Shakespearean: I know my hour is come .

English: No , it hasn't , my lord .
Shakespearean: Not so , my lord .

English: No , I'm sure it has , Volumnius .
Shakespearean: Nay , I am sure it is , Volumnius .

English: You see how the world goes , Volumnius .
Shakespearean: Thou seest the world , Volumnius , how it goes .

English: Our enemies have driven us to the edge of the grave .
Shakespearean: Our enemies have beat us to the pit .

English: It's nobler to leap in ourselves than dawdle until they push us .
Shakespearean: It is more worthy to leap in ourselves Than tarry till they push us .

English: Good Volumnius , you know that we went to school together .
Shakespearean: Good Volumnius , Thou know'st that we two went to school together .

English: For the sake of our old friendship , I ask you , hold my sword handle while I run on it .
Shakespearean: Even for that our love of old , I prithee , Hold thou my sword hilts , whilst I run on it .

English: That's not a job for a friend , my lord .
Shakespearean: That's not an office for a friend , my lord .

English: Run , run , my lord .
Shakespearean: Fly , fly , my lord .

English: We can't wait here .
Shakespearean: There is no tarrying here .

English: Farewell to you , and you , and you , Volumnius .
Shakespearean: Farewell to you. , And you. , And you , Volumnius .

English: Strato , you've slept this whole time .
Shakespearean: Strato , thou hast been all this while asleep .

English: I'll have glory in this losing day , more than Octavius and Mark Antony will gain by their foul conquest .
Shakespearean: I shall have glory by this losing day More than Octavius and Mark Antony By this vile conquest shall attain unto .

English: So farewell , all , for my tongue has almost finished with its life .
Shakespearean: So fare you well at once , for Brutus ' tongue Hath almost ended his life's history .

English: I can't see ahead of me .
Shakespearean: Night hangs upon mine eyes .

English: My bones want to rest after helping me up to this hour .
Shakespearean: My bones would rest , That have but labored to attain this hour .

English: Run , my lord , run .
Shakespearean: Fly , my lord , fly .

English: Go on !
Shakespearean: Hence .

English: I'll follow .
Shakespearean: I will follow .

English: I beg you , Strato , stay by me .
Shakespearean: I prithee , Strato , stay thou by thy lord .

English: You're a man with a good reputation .
Shakespearean: Thou art a fellow of a good respect .

English: Your life has had honor in it .
Shakespearean: Thy life hath had some smatch of honor in it .

English: Then , hold my sword and turn your face away while I run on it .
Shakespearean: Hold then my sword and turn away thy face While I do run upon it .

English: Will you , Strato ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou , Strato ?

English: Give me your hand , first .
Shakespearean: Give me your hand first .

English: Farewell , good Strato .
Shakespearean: Farewell , good Strato .

English: What man is that ?
Shakespearean: What man is that ?

English: Free from the bondage you are in , Messala .
Shakespearean: Free from the bondage you are in , Messala .

English: I'll take all who served Brutus into my service .
Shakespearean: All that served Brutus , I will entertain them .

English: You , will you join with me ?
Shakespearean: Fellow , wilt thou bestow thy time with me ?

English: Yes , if Messala recommends me to you .
Shakespearean: Ay , if Messala will prefer me to you .

English: Do so , good Messala .
Shakespearean: Do so , good Messala .

English: How did my master die , Strato ?
Shakespearean: How died my master , Strato ?

English: I held the sword and he ran on it .
Shakespearean: I held the sword and he did run on it .

English: Then take this man into your service , Octavius , for he did the final service to my master .
Shakespearean: Octavius , then take him to follow thee , That did the latest service to my master .

English: This was the noblest Roman of them all .
Shakespearean: This was the noblest Roman of them all .

English: All the rest of the conspirators acted out of jealousy of great Caesar .
Shakespearean: All the conspirators save only he Did that they did in envy of great Caesar .

English: Only he acted from honesty and for the general good .
Shakespearean: He only in a general honest thought And common good to all , made one of them .

English: His life was gentle , and the elements mixed so well in him that Nature might stand up and say to all the world , "This was a man." Let's treat him according to his virtue , with all the respect and rituals of burial .
Shakespearean: His life was gentle , and the elements So mixed in him that Nature might stand up And say to all the world , "This was a man." According to his virtue let us use him , With all respect and rites of burial .

English: His body will lie in my tent tonight , with the honorable observance that suits a soldier .
Shakespearean: Within my tent his bones tonight shall lie Most like a soldier , ordered honorably .

English: So order the armies to rest , and let's go home to share the glories of this happy day .
Shakespearean: So call the field to rest , and let's away To part the glories of this happy day .

English: Yes , Casca .
Shakespearean: Ay , Casca .

English: Tell us what happened today that put Caesar in such a serious mood .
Shakespearean: Tell us what hath chanced today That Caesar looks so sad .

English: But you were with him , weren't you ?
Shakespearean: Why , you were with him , were you not ?

English: If I were , I wouldn't need to ask you what happened .
Shakespearean: I should not then ask Casca what had chanced .

English: A crown was offered to him , and he pushed it away with the back of his hand , like this , and then the people started shouting .
Shakespearean: Why , there was a crown offered him ; and , being offered him , he put it by with the back of his hand , thus ; and then the people fell a-shouting .

English: What was the second noise for ?
Shakespearean: What was the second noise for ?

English: The same thing .
Shakespearean: Why , for that too .

English: They shouted three times .
Shakespearean: They shouted thrice .

English: What was the last cry for ?
Shakespearean: What was the last cry for ?

English: For the same thing .
Shakespearean: Why , for that too .

English: The crown was offered to him three times ?
Shakespearean: Was the crown offered him thrice ?

English: Yes , indeed , it was , and he pushed it away three times , each time more gently than the last ; and at each refusal my countrymen shouted .
Shakespearean: Ay , marry , was 't , and he put it by thrice , every time gentler than other , and at every putting-by mine honest neighbors shouted .

English: Who offered him the crown ?
Shakespearean: Who offered him the crown ?

English: Antony .
Shakespearean: Why , Antony .

English: Tell us how it happened , noble Casca .
Shakespearean: Tell us the manner of it , gentle Casca .

English: I can't explain it .
Shakespearean: I can as well be hanged as tell the manner of it .

English: I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown , though it wasn't a real crown , just a small circlet , and , as I told you , he refused it once , though in my opinion he would've liked to have it .
Shakespearean: I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown ( yet 'twas not a crown neither , 'twas one of these coronets ) and , as I told you , he put it by once , but , for all that , to my thinking , he would fain have had it .

English: Then Antony offered it to him again , and he refused it again ( though , in my opinion , he was reluctant to take his hand off it ) .
Shakespearean: Then he offered it to him again , then he put it by again , but , to my thinking , he was very loath to lay his fingers off it .

English: Then Antony offered it the third time .
Shakespearean: And then he offered it the third time .

English: As for myself , I didn't dare laugh , for fear of opening my lips and inhaling the stinking air .
Shakespearean: And for mine own part , I durst not laugh for fear of opening my lips and receiving the bad air .

English: But wait a minute , please .
Shakespearean: But soft , I pray you .

English: Did you say Caesar fainted ?
Shakespearean: What , did Caesar swoon ?

English: He fell down in the marketplace and foamed at the mouth and was speechless .
Shakespearean: He fell down in the marketplace , and foamed at mouth , and was speechless .

English: That's very likely .
Shakespearean: Tis very like .

English: He has epilepsy , a disease where you fall down .
Shakespearean: He hath the falling sickness .

English: No , Caesar doesn't have epilepsy .
Shakespearean: No , Caesar hath it not .

English: You and I , and honest Casca , we have epilepsy , we've fallen .
Shakespearean: But you and I And honest Casca , we have the falling sickness .

English: I don't know what you mean by that , but I'm sure Caesar fell down .
Shakespearean: I know not what you mean by that , but I am sure Caesar fell down .

English: What did he say when he regained consciousness ?
Shakespearean: What said he when he came unto himself ?

English: Indeed , before he fell down , when he realized the commoners were glad he refused the crown , he pulled open his robe and offered them his throat to cut .
Shakespearean: Marry , before he fell down , when he perceived the common herd was glad he refused the crown , he plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his throat to cut .

English: If I'd been a common laborer and hadn't taken him up on his offer , to hell with me .
Shakespearean: An I had been a man of any occupation , if I would not have taken him at a word , I would I might go to hell among the rogues .

English: And so he fainted .
Shakespearean: And so he fell .

English: When he regained consciousness again , he said that if he'd done or said anything wrong , he wanted them to know that it was all because of his sickness .
Shakespearean: When he came to himself again , he said , if he had done or said anything amiss , he desired their worships to think it was his infirmity .

English: Three or four women near me cried , "Alas , good soul ! " and forgave him with all their hearts .
Shakespearean: Three or four wenches where I stood cried , "Alas , good soul ! " and forgave him with all their hearts .

English: But never mind them , if Caesar had stabbed their mothers , they would've forgiven him .
Shakespearean: If Caesar had stabbed their mothers they would have done no less .

English: And after that he came back here looking so serious ?
Shakespearean: And after that he came thus sad away ?

English: Yes .
Shakespearean: Ay .

English: Get out of here !
Shakespearean: Hence !

English: Go home , you lazy men .
Shakespearean: Home , you idle creatures get you home !

English: What , is today a holiday ?
Shakespearean: Is this a holiday ?

English: I'm a carpenter , sir .
Shakespearean: Why , sir , a carpenter .

English: Where are your leather apron and your ruler ?
Shakespearean: Where is thy leather apron and thy rule ?

English: What are you doing , wearing your best clothes ?
Shakespearean: What dost thou with thy best apparel on ?

English: And you , sir , what's Well , compared to a fine workman , you might call me a mere cobbler .
Shakespearean: Truly , sir , in respect of a fine workman , I am but , as you would say , a cobbler .

English: But what's your trade ?
Shakespearean: But what trade art thou ?

English: Answer me straightforwardly .
Shakespearean: Answer me directly .

English: It is a trade , sir , that I practice with a clear conscience .
Shakespearean: A trade , sir , that I hope I may use with a safe conscience , which is , indeed , sir , a mender of bad soles .

English: What trade , boy ?
Shakespearean: What trade , thou knave ?

English: You insolent rascal , what trade ?
Shakespearean: Thou naughty knave , what trade ?

English: Sir , please , don't be angry .
Shakespearean: Nay , I beseech you , sir , be not out with me .

English: But if your soles are worn out , I can mend you .
Shakespearean: Yet , if you be out , sir , I can mend you .

English: What do you mean by that ?
Shakespearean: What mean'st thou by that ?

English: Mend" me , you impertinent fellow ?
Shakespearean: Mend" me , thou saucy fellow ?

English: Did Cicero say anything ?
Shakespearean: Did Cicero say anything ?

English: Yes , he said something in Greek .
Shakespearean: Ay , he spoke Greek .

English: What did he say ?
Shakespearean: To what effect ?

English: If I told you I understood Greek , I'd be lying .
Shakespearean: Nay , an I tell you that , I'll ne'er look you i ' th ' face again .

English: But those who understood him smiled at one another and shook their heads .
Shakespearean: But those that understood him smiled at one another and shook their heads .

English: As for myself , it was Greek to me .
Shakespearean: But , for mine own part , it was Greek to me .

English: I have more news too .
Shakespearean: I could tell you more news too .

English: Murellus and Flavius have been punished for pulling scarves off statues of Caesar .
Shakespearean: Murellus and Flavius , for pulling scarfs off Caesar's images , are put to silence .

English: There you go .
Shakespearean: Fare you well .

English: There was even more foolishness , if I could only remember it .
Shakespearean: There was more foolery yet , if I could remember it .

English: Will you have dinner with me tonight , Casca ?
Shakespearean: Will you sup with me tonight , Casca ?

English: No , I have a commitment .
Shakespearean: No , I am promised forth .

English: Will you dine with me tomorrow ?
Shakespearean: Will you dine with me tomorrow ?

English: Yes , if I'm still alive , and you're still sane , and your dinner is worth eating .
Shakespearean: Ay , if I be alive and your mind hold and your dinner worth the eating .

English: Good .
Shakespearean: Good .

English: I'll expect you .
Shakespearean: I will expect you .

English: Do so .
Shakespearean: Do so .

English: Farewell to you both .
Shakespearean: Farewell both .

English: What a stupid man he's become !
Shakespearean: What a blunt fellow is this grown to be !

English: He was so sharp when he was in school .
Shakespearean: He was quick mettle when he went to school .

English: He's still sharp when it comes to carrying out a bold or noble enterprise , though he puts on this show of stupidity .
Shakespearean: So is he now in execution Of any bold or noble enterprise , However he puts on this tardy form .

English: He speaks roughly , but what he says is smart , and his roughness makes other people enjoy listening to him .
Shakespearean: This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit , Which gives men stomach to digest his words With better appetite .

English: You're right , that's how it is .
Shakespearean: And so it is .

English: I'll leave you for now .
Shakespearean: For this time I will leave you .

English: If you'd like to talk tomorrow , I'll come to your home .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow , if you please to speak with me , I will come home to you .

English: Or , if you don't mind , come to my home , and I'll wait for you .
Shakespearean: Or , if you will , Come home to me , and I will wait for you .

English: I'll do so .
Shakespearean: I will do so .

English: Until then , think about the well-being of Rome .
Shakespearean: Till then , think of the world .

English: Well , Brutus , you're noble .
Shakespearean: Well , Brutus , thou art noble .

English: Caesar resents me , but he loves Brutus .
Shakespearean: Caesar doth bear me hard , but he loves Brutus .

English: If I were Brutus now and Brutus were me , I wouldn't have let him influence me .
Shakespearean: If I were Brutus now and he were Cassius , He should not humor me .

English: Tonight I'll throw through his window a few letters in different handwriting , as if they came from several citizens , all testifying to the great respect Romans have for Brutus , and all alluding to Caesar's unseemly ambition .
Shakespearean: I will this night , In several hands , in at his windows throw , As if they came from several citizens , Writings all tending to the great opinion That Rome holds of his name , wherein obscurely Caesar's ambition shall be glanced at .

English: Did you accompany Caesar home ?
Shakespearean: Brought you Caesar home ?

English: Cicero , I've seen storms in which the angry winds split old oak trees , and I've seen the ocean swell , rage , and foam , as if it wanted to reach the storm clouds , but never before tonight , never until now , have I experienced a storm that drops fire .
Shakespearean: O Cicero , I have seen tempests when the scolding winds Have rived the knotty oaks , and I have seen Th ' ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam To be exalted with the threatening clouds , But never till tonight , never till now , Did I go through a tempest dropping fire .

English: Either there are wars in heaven , or else the world , too insolent toward the gods , provokes them to send destruction .
Shakespearean: Either there is a civil strife in heaven , Or else the world , too saucy with the gods , Incenses them to send destruction .

English: Also , I've kept my sword unsheathed since I saw this , in front of the Capitol I met a lion who looked at me and strutted by without bothering to attack me .
Shakespearean: Besides , I ha ' not since put up my sword , Against the Capitol I met a lion , Who glared upon me and went surly by , Without annoying me .

English: And there were a hundred spooked women huddled together in fear who swore they saw men on fire walk up and down the streets .
Shakespearean: And there were drawn Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women , Transformed with their fear , who swore they saw Men all in fire walk up and down the streets .

English: And yesterday the night owl sat hooting and shrieking in the marketplace at noon .
Shakespearean: And yesterday the bird of night did sit Even at noon-day upon the marketplace , Hooting and shrieking .

English: When all these extraordinary things happen at once , we shouldn't say , "These happenings can be explained rationally .
Shakespearean: When these prodigies Do so conjointly meet , let not men say , "These are their reasons .

English: They're natural enough." I think these things are omens of things to come in our country .
Shakespearean: They are natural." For I believe they are portentous things Unto the climate that they point upon .

English: Indeed , it's a strange time .
Shakespearean: Indeed , it is a strange-disposed time .

English: But men tend to interpret things however suits them and totally miss the actual meaning of the things themselves .
Shakespearean: But men may construe things after their fashion , Clean from the purpose of the things themselves .

English: Is Caesar visiting the Capitol tomorrow ?
Shakespearean: Comes Caesar to the Capitol tomorrow ?

English: He is , because he told Antonius to tell you he'd be there tomorrow .
Shakespearean: He doth , for he did bid Antonius Send word to you he would be there tomorrow .

English: Good night then , Casca .
Shakespearean: Good night then , Casca .

English: This bad weather isn't good to walk around in .
Shakespearean: This disturbed sky Is not to walk in .

English: A Roman .
Shakespearean: A Roman .

English: It's Casca , I know your voice .
Shakespearean: Casca , by your voice .

English: Your ear is good .
Shakespearean: Your ear is good .

English: Cassius , what a night this is !
Shakespearean: Cassius , what night is this !

English: It's a very pleasing night to honest men .
Shakespearean: A very pleasing night to honest men .

English: Who ever saw the heavens threaten like this ?
Shakespearean: Who ever knew the heavens menace so ?

English: Those who have known how bad things are here on earth .
Shakespearean: Those that have known the earth so full of faults .

English: I have walked around the streets , exposing myself to the perilous night , unbuttoned like this , as you see , Casca , baring my chest to the thunderbolt .
Shakespearean: For my part , I have walked about the streets , Submitting me unto the perilous night , And , thus unbraced , Casca , as you see , Have bared my bosom to the thunder-stone .

English: When the forked blue lightning seemed to break open the sky , I put myself right where I thought it would hit .
Shakespearean: And when the cross blue lightning seemed to open The breast of heaven , I did present myself Even in the aim and very flash of it .

English: But why did you tempt the heavens like that ?
Shakespearean: But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens ?

English: Mankind's role is to fear and tremble when the almighty gods send warning signals .
Shakespearean: It is the part of men to fear and tremble When the most mighty gods by tokens send Such dreadful heralds to astonish us .

English: You're acting stupid , Casca , and you lack the quick wits that a Roman should have , or else you don't use them .
Shakespearean: You are dull , Casca , and those sparks of life That should be in a Roman you do want , Or else you use not .

English: You go pale , you stare , and you act in awe of the strange disturbance in the heavens .
Shakespearean: You look pale , and gaze , And put on fear , and cast yourself in wonder To see the strange impatience of the heavens .

English: A man no mightier than you or I in ability , yet grown as huge and frightening as tonight's strange happenings .
Shakespearean: A man no mightier than thyself or me In personal action , yet prodigious grown , And fearful as these strange eruptions are .

English: Let it be who it is .
Shakespearean: Let it be who it is .

English: Our tolerance for slavery and oppression shows us to be weak , like women .
Shakespearean: Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish .

English: Indeed , they say that the senators plan to establish Caesar as a king tomorrow , and he'll wear his crown at sea and on land everywhere except here in Italy .
Shakespearean: Indeed , they say the senators tomorrow Mean to establish Caesar as a king , And he shall wear his crown by sea and land In every place save here in Italy .

English: I know where I'll wear this dagger , then .
Shakespearean: I know where I will wear this dagger then .

English: I'll kill myself to save myself from slavery .
Shakespearean: Cassius from bondage will deliver Cassius .

English: In suicide , gods make the weak strong .
Shakespearean: Therein , ye gods , you make the weak most strong .

English: In suicide , gods allow tyrants to be defeated .
Shakespearean: Therein , ye gods , you tyrants do defeat .

English: No stony tower , no brass walls , no airless dungeon , no iron chains can contain a strong mind .
Shakespearean: Nor stony tower , nor walls of beaten brass , Nor airless dungeon , nor strong links of iron Can be retentive to the strength of spirit .

English: But if a man becomes weary of these obstacles , he can always kill himself .
Shakespearean: But life , being weary of these worldly bars , Never lacks power to dismiss itself .

English: Let everyone beware : I can shake off the tyranny that now oppresses me whenever I choose .
Shakespearean: If I know this , know all the world besides , That part of tyranny that I do bear I can shake off at pleasure .

English: So can I .
Shakespearean: So can I .

English: In fact , every imprisoned man holds in his own hand the tool to free himself .
Shakespearean: So every bondman in his own hand bears The power to cancel his captivity .

English: How can Caesar be a tyrant then ?
Shakespearean: And why should Caesar be a tyrant then ?

English: Poor man !
Shakespearean: Poor man !

English: I know he wouldn't be a wolf if the Romans didn't act like sheep .
Shakespearean: I know he would not be a wolf But that he sees the Romans are but sheep .

English: He couldn't be a lion if the Romans weren't such easy prey .
Shakespearean: He were no lion were not Romans hinds .

English: People who want to start a big fire quickly start with little twigs .
Shakespearean: Those that with haste will make a mighty fire Begin it with weak straws .

English: But , oh no !
Shakespearean: But , O grief , Where hast thou led me ?

English: What have I said in my grief ?
Shakespearean: Then I know My answer must be made .

English: Say no more .
Shakespearean: You speak to Casca , and to such a man That is no fleering telltale .

English: Shake my hand .
Shakespearean: Hold , my hand .

English: If you're joining together to right these wrongs , I'll go as far as any one of you .
Shakespearean: Be factious for redress of all these griefs , And I will set this foot of mine as far As who goes farthest .

English: That's a deal .
Shakespearean: There's a bargain made .

English: Now let me tell you , Casca , I have already convinced some of the noblest Romans to join me in an honorable but dangerous mission .
Shakespearean: Now know you , Casca , I have moved already Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans To undergo with me an enterprise Of honorable-dangerous consequence .

English: And I know that by now they're waiting for me on the porch outside Pompey's theater .
Shakespearean: And I do know by this they stay for me In Pompey's porch .

English: It's Cinna .
Shakespearean: Tis Cinna .

English: I recognize his walk .
Shakespearean: I do know him by his gait .

English: To find you .
Shakespearean: To find out you .

English: Who's that ?
Shakespearean: Who's that ?

English: Metellus Cimber ?
Shakespearean: Metellus Cimber ?

English: No , it's Casca , someone who's going to work with us .
Shakespearean: No , it is Casca , one incorporate To our attempts .

English: Aren't the others waiting for me , Cinna ?
Shakespearean: Am I not stayed for , Cinna ?

English: I'm glad Casca is with us .
Shakespearean: I am glad on 't .

English: What a fearful night this is !
Shakespearean: What a fearful night is this !

English: Two or three of us have seen strange things .
Shakespearean: There's two or three of us have seen strange sights .

English: Are the others waiting ?
Shakespearean: Am I not stayed for ?

English: Tell me .
Shakespearean: Tell me .

English: Yes , they are .
Shakespearean: Yes , you are .

English: Oh , Cassius , if you could only convince Brutus to join us , Don't worry .
Shakespearean: O Cassius , if you could But win the noble Brutus to our party , Be you content .

English: Good Cinna , take this paper and be sure to lay it in the judge's chair where Brutus sits , so he'll find it .
Shakespearean: Good Cinna , take this paper , And look you lay it in the praetor's chair Where Brutus may but find it .

English: When you've finished all this , return to the porch of Pompey's theater , where you'll find us .
Shakespearean: All this done , Repair to Pompey's porch , where you shall find us .

English: Are Decius Brutus and Trebonius there ?
Shakespearean: Is Decius Brutus and Trebonius there ?

English: Everyone's there except Metellus Cimber , and he's gone to look for you at your house .
Shakespearean: All but Metellus Cimber , and he's gone To seek you at your house .

English: Well , I'll hurry and put these papers where you told me .
Shakespearean: Well , I will hie , And so bestow these papers as you bade me .

English: When you've finished , go back to Pompey's theater .
Shakespearean: That done , repair to Pompey's theatre .

English: Come on , Casca , you and I will go see Brutus at his house before sunrise .
Shakespearean: Come , Casca , you and I will yet ere day See Brutus at his house .

English: Yes , you're absolutely right about how worthy Brutus is and how much we need him .
Shakespearean: Him and his worth and our great need of him You have right well conceited .

English: Let's go , because it's already after midnight , and we want him on our side before daylight .
Shakespearean: Let us go , For it is after midnight , and ere day We will awake him and be sure of him .

English: Wake up , I say !
Shakespearean: Awake , I say !

English: Lucius !
Shakespearean: What , Lucius !

English: Did you call me , my lord ?
Shakespearean: Called you , my lord ?

English: Put a candle in my study , Lucius .
Shakespearean: Get me a taper in my study , Lucius .

English: Call me when it's lit .
Shakespearean: When it is lighted , come and call me here .

English: I will , my lord .
Shakespearean: I will , my lord .

English: I have no personal reason to strike at him , only the best interest of the people .
Shakespearean: It must be by his death , and for my part I know no personal cause to spurn at him But for the general .

English: He wants to be crowned .
Shakespearean: He would be crowned .

English: The question is , how would being king change him ?
Shakespearean: How that might change his nature , there's the question .

English: Evil can come from good , just as poisonous snakes tend to come out into the open on bright sunny days , which means we have to walk carefully .
Shakespearean: It is the bright day that brings forth the adder And that craves wary walking .

English: If we crown him , I have to admit we'd be giving him the power to do damage .
Shakespearean: Crown him that , And then I grant we put a sting in him That at his will he may do danger with .

English: Cobble you , sir .
Shakespearean: Why , sir , cobble you .

English: You're a cobbler , are you ?
Shakespearean: Thou art a cobbler , art thou ?

English: Sir , I make my living using an awl .
Shakespearean: Truly , sir , all that I live by is with the awl .

English: I'm a surgeon to old shoes .
Shakespearean: I meddle with no tradesman's matters nor women's matters , but withal I am indeed , sir , a surgeon to old shoes .

English: When they're endangered , I save them .
Shakespearean: When they are in great danger , I recover them .

English: The noblest men who ever walked on leather have walked on my handiwork .
Shakespearean: As proper men as ever trod upon neat's leather have gone upon my handiwork .

English: But why aren't you in your shop today ?
Shakespearean: But wherefore art not in thy shop today ?

English: Why are you leading these men through the streets ?
Shakespearean: Why dost thou lead these men about the streets ?

English: Well , to wear out their shoes and get myself more work .
Shakespearean: Truly , sir , to wear out their shoes to get myself into more work .

English: Why would you celebrate it ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore rejoice ?

English: What victory does he bring home ?
Shakespearean: What conquest brings he home ?

English: What foreign lands has he conquered and captive foreigners chained to his chariot wheels ?
Shakespearean: What tributaries follow him to Rome To grace in captive bonds his chariot wheels ?

English: Rulers abuse their power when they separate it from compassion .
Shakespearean: Th ' abuse of greatness is when it disjoins Remorse from power .

English: Caesar might act like that .
Shakespearean: So Caesar may .

English: Therefore , in case he does , we must hold him back .
Shakespearean: Then , lest he may , prevent .

English: And since our quarrel is with his future behavior , not what he does now , I must frame the argument like this : if his position is furthered , his character will fulfill these predictions .
Shakespearean: And since the quarrel Will bear no color for the thing he is , Fashion it thus : that what he is , augmented , Would run to these and these extremities .

English: The candle is burning in your study , sir .
Shakespearean: The taper burneth in your closet , sir .

English: While I was looking for a flint to light it , I found this paper on the window , sealed up like this , and I'm sure it wasn't there when I went to bed .
Shakespearean: Searching the window for a flint , I found This paper , thus sealed up , and I am sure It did not lie there when I went to bed .

English: Go back to bed .
Shakespearean: Get you to bed again .

English: It isn't daybreak yet .
Shakespearean: It is not day .

English: Is tomorrow the 15th of March , boy ?
Shakespearean: Is not tomorrow , boy , the ides of March ?

English: I don't know , sir .
Shakespearean: I know not , sir .

English: Check the calendar and come tell me .
Shakespearean: Look in the calendar and bring me word .

English: I will , sir .
Shakespearean: I will , sir .

English: Sir , fifteen days of March have gone by .
Shakespearean: Sir , March is wasted fifteen days .

English: Good .
Shakespearean: Tis good .

English: Go to the gate .
Shakespearean: Go to the gate .

English: Somebody's knocking .
Shakespearean: Somebody knocks .

English: I haven't slept since Cassius first began to turn me against Caesar .
Shakespearean: Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar , I have not slept .

English: Is he alone ?
Shakespearean: Is he alone ?

English: Do you know them ?
Shakespearean: Do you know them ?

English: Let them in .
Shakespearean: Let 'em enter .

English: Oh , conspiracy , are you ashamed to show your face even at night , when evil things are most free ?
Shakespearean: O conspiracy , Shamest thou to show thy dangerous brow by night When evils are most free ?

English: If so , when it's day , where are you going to find a cave dark enough to hide your monstrous face ?
Shakespearean: O , then by day Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough To mask thy monstrous visage ?

English: Instead , hide your true face behind smiles and friendliness .
Shakespearean: Hide it in smiles and affability .

English: I'm afraid we're intruding too boldly on your sleep time .
Shakespearean: I think we are too bold upon your rest .

English: Good morning , Brutus .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , Brutus .

English: Are we bothering you ?
Shakespearean: Do we trouble you ?

English: I've been up all night .
Shakespearean: I have been up this hour , awake all night .

English: Do I know these men who are with you ?
Shakespearean: Know I these men that come along with you ?

English: This is Trebonius .
Shakespearean: This is Trebonius .

English: He's welcome here .
Shakespearean: He is welcome hither .

English: This is Decius Brutus .
Shakespearean: This , Decius Brutus .

English: He's welcome too .
Shakespearean: He is welcome too .

English: This is Casca .
Shakespearean: This , Casca .

English: This is Cinna .
Shakespearean: This , Cinna .

English: And this is Metellus Cimber .
Shakespearean: And this , Metellus Cimber .

English: They're all welcome .
Shakespearean: They are all welcome .

English: What worries have kept you awake tonight ?
Shakespearean: What watchful cares do interpose themselves Betwixt your eyes and night ?

English: Can I have a word with you ?
Shakespearean: Shall I entreat a word ?

English: Here's the east .
Shakespearean: Here lies the east .

English: Won't the dawn come from here ?
Shakespearean: Doth not the day break here ?

English: No .
Shakespearean: No .

English: You're both wrong .
Shakespearean: You shall confess that you are both deceived .

English: And let us swear to our resolution .
Shakespearean: And let us swear our resolution .

English: No , let's not swear an oath .
Shakespearean: No , not an oath .

English: Then we can let this ambitious tyrant continue unchallenged until each of us is killed at his whim .
Shakespearean: So let high-sighted tyranny range on Till each man drop by lottery .

English: But if we have reasons that are strong enough to ignite cowards into action and to make weak women brave , and I think we do , then , countrymen , what else could we possibly need to spur us to action ?
Shakespearean: But if these , As I am sure they do , bear fire enough To kindle cowards and to steel with valor The melting spirits of women , then , countrymen , What need we any spur but our own cause To prick us to redress ?

English: What bond do we need other than that of discreet Romans who have said what they're going to do and won't back down ?
Shakespearean: What other bond Than secret Romans that have spoke the word And will not palter ?

English: And what oath do we need other than that we honest men have told each other that this will happen or we will die trying ?
Shakespearean: And what other oath Than honesty to honesty engaged , That this shall be , or we will fall for it ?

English: Swearing is for priests , cowards , overly cautious men , feeble old people , and those long-suffering weaklings who welcome abuse .
Shakespearean: Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous , Old feeble carrions and such suffering souls That welcome wrongs .

English: Only men whom you wouldn't trust anyway would swear oaths , and for the worst reasons .
Shakespearean: Unto bad causes swear Such creatures as men doubt .

English: Don't spoil the justness and virtue of our endeavor nor weaken our own irrepressible spirits by thinking that we need a binding oath , when the blood that every noble Roman contains within him would be proven bastard's blood if he broke the smallest part of any promise he had made .
Shakespearean: But do not stain The even virtue of our enterprise , Nor th ' insuppressive mettle of our spirits , To think that or our cause or our performance Did need an oath , when every drop of blood That every Roman bears , and nobly bears , Is guilty of a several bastardy If he do break the smallest particle Of any promise that hath passed from him .

English: But what about Cicero ?
Shakespearean: But what of Cicero ?

English: Should we see what he thinks ?
Shakespearean: Shall we sound him ?

English: I think he will stand strong with us .
Shakespearean: I think he will stand very strong with us .

English: Let's not leave him out .
Shakespearean: Let us not leave him out .

English: No , by no means .
Shakespearean: No , by no means .

English: Yes , we should get his support , for his mature presence will make others think well of us and speak out in support of our actions .
Shakespearean: O , let us have him , for his silver hairs Will purchase us a good opinion And buy men's voices to commend our deeds .

English: They'll assume that Cicero , with his sound judgment , ordered the actions .
Shakespearean: It shall be said his judgment ruled our hands .

English: No , don't even mention him .
Shakespearean: O , name him not .

English: He'll never follow anything that other men have started .
Shakespearean: Let us not break with him , For he will never follow anything That other men begin .

English: Then leave him out .
Shakespearean: Then leave him out .

English: Indeed , he's not right for this .
Shakespearean: Indeed he is not fit .

English: Good point , Decius .
Shakespearean: Decius , well urged .

English: I don't think it would be wise to let Mark Antony , whom Caesar is so fond of , outlive Caesar .
Shakespearean: I think it is not meet Mark Antony , so well beloved of Caesar , Should outlive Caesar .

English: We'd find that he was a dangerous plotter .
Shakespearean: We shall find of him A shrewd contriver .

English: And as you know , his connections , if he put them to good use , might be enough to hurt us all .
Shakespearean: And , you know , his means , If he improve them , may well stretch so far As to annoy us all ; which to prevent , Let Antony and Caesar fall together .

English: Our action will seem too bloody if we cut off Caesar's head and then hack at his arms and legs too , Caius Cassius , because Mark Antony is merely one of Caesar's arms .
Shakespearean: Our course will seem too bloody , Caius Cassius , To cut the head off and then hack the limbs , Like wrath in death and envy afterwards , For Antony is but a limb of Caesar .

English: Let's be sacrificers but not butchers , Caius .
Shakespearean: Let us be sacrificers but not butchers , Caius .

English: We're all against what Caesar stands for , and there's no blood in that .
Shakespearean: We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar , And in the spirit of men there is no blood .
