English: Oh , how I wish we could oppose Caesar's spirit , his overblown ambition , and not hack up Caesar himself !
Shakespearean: Oh , that we then could come by Caesar's spirit And not dismember Caesar !

English: But , unfortunately , Caesar has to bleed if we're going to stop him .
Shakespearean: But , alas , Caesar must bleed for it .

English: Noble friends , let's kill him boldly but not with anger .
Shakespearean: And , gentle friends , Let's kill him boldly but not wrathfully .

English: Let's carve him up like a dish fit for the gods , not chop him up like a carcass fit for dogs .
Shakespearean: Let's carve him as a dish fit for the gods , Not hew him as a carcass fit for hounds .

English: Let's be angry only long enough to do the deed , and then let's act like we're disgusted by what we had to do .
Shakespearean: And let our hearts , as subtle masters do , Stir up their servants to an act of rage And after seem to chide 'em .

English: This will make our actions seem practical and not vengeful .
Shakespearean: This shall make Our purpose necessary and not envious , Which so appearing to the common eyes , We shall be called purgers , not murderers .

English: If he loves Caesar , then he can only hurt himself , by grieving and dying for Caesar .
Shakespearean: If he love Caesar , all that he can do Is to himself : take thought and die for Caesar .

English: And I'd be surprised if he even did that , for he prefers sports , fun , and friends .
Shakespearean: And that were much he should , for he is given To sports , to wildness and much company .

English: There's nothing to fear in him .
Shakespearean: There is no fear in him .

English: Quiet !
Shakespearean: Peace !

English: Count how many times the clock chimes .
Shakespearean: Count the clock .

English: The clock struck three .
Shakespearean: The clock hath stricken three .

English: It's time to leave .
Shakespearean: Tis time to part .

English: It might happen that these strange signs , the unusual terror of this night , and the urgings of his fortune-tellers will keep him away from the Capitol today .
Shakespearean: It may be , these apparent prodigies , The unaccustomed terror of this night , And the persuasion of his augurers May hold him from the Capitol today .

English: Don't worry about that .
Shakespearean: Never fear that .

English: If he's reluctant , I can convince him .
Shakespearean: If he be so resolved , I can o'ersway him .

English: He loves to hear me tell him how men can be snared by flatterers , just like unicorns can be captured in trees , elephants in holes , and lions with nets .
Shakespearean: For he loves to hear That unicorns may be betrayed with trees , And bears with glasses , elephants with holes , Lions with toils , and men with flatterers .

English: When I tell him he hates flatterers , he agrees , just at the moment when I'm flattering him the most .
Shakespearean: But when I tell him he hates flatterers , He says he does , being then most flattered .

English: Let me work on him .
Shakespearean: Let me work .

English: I can put him in the right mood , and I'll bring him to the Capitol .
Shakespearean: For I can give his humor the true bent , And I will bring him to the Capitol .

English: No , we'll all go there to bring him .
Shakespearean: Nay , we will all of us be there to fetch him .

English: By eight o'clock .
Shakespearean: By the eighth hour .

English: Is that the latest we can do it ?
Shakespearean: Is that the uttermost ?

English: Caius Ligarius doesn't like Caesar , who berated him for speaking well of Pompey .
Shakespearean: Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard , Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey .

English: I wonder that none of you thought about getting his support .
Shakespearean: I wonder none of you have thought of him .

English: Good Metellus , go to him now .
Shakespearean: Now , good Metellus , go along by him .

English: He likes me , and I've given him good reason to .
Shakespearean: He loves me well , and I have given him reasons .

English: Just send him here , and I'll persuade him .
Shakespearean: Send him but hither and I'll fashion him .

English: The morning is approaching .
Shakespearean: The morning comes upon 's .

English: We'll leave , Brutus .
Shakespearean: We'll leave you , Brutus .

English: Friends , go your separate ways .
Shakespearean: And , friends , disperse yourselves .

English: But all of you , remember what you've said and prove yourselves true Romans .
Shakespearean: But all remember What you have said , and show yourselves true Romans .

English: Good gentlemen , look like you're rested and happy .
Shakespearean: Good gentlemen , look fresh and merrily .

English: And so , good morning to all of you .
Shakespearean: And so good morrow to you every one .

English: Boy !
Shakespearean: Boy !

English: Lucius !
Shakespearean: Lucius ! , Fast asleep ?

English: Fast asleep ?
Shakespearean: It is no matter .

English: Well , enjoy the sweetness of deep sleep .
Shakespearean: Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber .

English: That's why you sleep so soundly .
Shakespearean: Therefore thou sleep'st so sound .

English: Brutus , my lord .
Shakespearean: Brutus , my lord .

English: Portia , what are you doing awake ?
Shakespearean: Portia , what mean you ?

English: It isn't good for your health to expose your weak body to the raw , cold morning .
Shakespearean: It is not for your health thus to commit Your weak condition to the raw , cold morning .

English: It's not good for your health , either .
Shakespearean: Nor for yours neither .

English: You rudely snuck out of bed .
Shakespearean: Y ' have ungently , Brutus , Stole from my bed .

English: And last night at dinner , you got up abruptly and paced back and forth with your arms crossed , brooding and sighing , and when I asked you what was the matter , you gave me a dirty look .
Shakespearean: And yesternight , at supper , You suddenly arose and walked about , Musing and sighing , with your arms across , And when I asked you what the matter was , You stared upon me with ungentle looks .

English: I asked you again , and you scratched your head and stamped your foot impatiently .
Shakespearean: I urged you further , then you scratched your head And too impatiently stamped with your foot .

English: I still insisted on knowing what the matter was , but you wouldn't answer me , instead giving me an angry wave of your hand and telling me to leave you alone .
Shakespearean: Yet I insisted ; yet you answered not , But with an angry wafture of your hand Gave sign for me to leave you .

English: My dear lord , tell me what's bothering you .
Shakespearean: Dear my lord , Make me acquainted with your cause of grief .

English: And now you toss flowers in the path of Caesar , who comes in triumph over Pompey's defeated sons ?
Shakespearean: And do you now strew flowers in his way That comes in triumph over Pompey's blood ?

English: Go home !
Shakespearean: Be gone !

English: Run to your houses , fall on your knees , and pray to the gods to spare you the pain that you deserve for such ingratitude .
Shakespearean: Run to your houses , fall upon your knees , Pray to the gods to intermit the plague That needs must light on this ingratitude .

English: Go , go , good countrymen , and to make up for having done wrong , gather up all the poor men like yourselves , lead them to the Tiber , and weep into the river until it overflows its banks .
Shakespearean: Go , go , good countrymen , and for this fault , Assemble all the poor men of your sort , Draw them to Tiber banks , and weep your tears Into the channel till the lowest stream Do kiss the most exalted shores of all .

English: You go down toward the Capitol , and I'll go this way .
Shakespearean: Go you down that way towards the Capitol .

English: Undress the statues if they're decorated in honor of Caesar .
Shakespearean: This way will I. Disrobe the images If you do find them decked with ceremonies .

English: Can we do that ?
Shakespearean: May we do so ?

English: I'll walk around and force the commoners off the streets .
Shakespearean: I'll about And drive away the vulgar from the streets .

English: You do the same , wherever the crowds are thick .
Shakespearean: So do you too , where you perceive them thick .

English: If we take away Caesar's support , he'll have to come back down to earth ; otherwise , he'll fly too high and keep the rest of us in a state of fear and obedience .
Shakespearean: These growing feathers plucked from Caesar's wing Will make him fly an ordinary pitch , Who else would soar above the view of men And keep us all in servile fearfulness .

English: I'm not feeling well , that's all .
Shakespearean: I am not well in health , and that is all .

English: You're smart , though , and if you were sick , you'd take what you needed to get better .
Shakespearean: Brutus is wise , and were he not in health , He would embrace the means to come by it .

English: I'm doing so .
Shakespearean: Why , so I do .

English: Good Portia , go to bed .
Shakespearean: Good Portia , go to bed .

English: Are you sick ?
Shakespearean: Is Brutus sick ?

English: And is it healthy to walk uncovered and breathe in the dampness of the morning ?
Shakespearean: And is it physical To walk unbraced and suck up the humors Of the dank morning ?

English: You're sick , yet you sneak out of your warm bed and let the humid and disease-infested air make you sicker ?
Shakespearean: What , is Brutus sick , And will he steal out of his wholesome bed , To dare the vile contagion of the night And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air To add unto his sickness ?

English: Don't kneel , noble Portia .
Shakespearean: Kneel not , gentle Portia .

English: You're my true and honorable wife , as dear to me as the blood that runs through my sad heart .
Shakespearean: You are my true and honorable wife , As dear to me as are the ruddy drops That visit my sad heart .

English: If that were true , then I'd know your secret .
Shakespearean: If this were true , then should I know this secret .

English: I admit I'm only a woman , but nevertheless I'm the woman Lord Brutus took for his wife .
Shakespearean: I grant I am a woman , but withal A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife .

English: I admit I'm only a woman , but I'm still a woman from a noble family , I'm Cato's daughter .
Shakespearean: I grant I am a woman , but withal A woman well-reputed , Cato's daughter .

English: Do you really think I'm no stronger than the rest of my sex , with such a father and such a husband ?
Shakespearean: Think you I am no stronger than my sex , Being so fathered and so husbanded ?

English: Tell me your secrets .
Shakespearean: Tell me your counsels .

English: I won't betray them .
Shakespearean: I will not disclose 'em .

English: I've proved my trustworthiness by giving myself a voluntary wound here in my thigh .
Shakespearean: I have made strong proof of my constancy , Giving myself a voluntary wound Here in the thigh .

English: If I can bear that pain , then I can bear my husband's secrets .
Shakespearean: Can I bear that with patience , And not my husband's secrets ?

English: Oh , gods , make me worthy of this noble wife !
Shakespearean: O ye gods , Render me worthy of this noble wife !

English: Listen !
Shakespearean: Hark , hark !

English: Someone knocks .
Shakespearean: One knocks .

English: Leave me quickly .
Shakespearean: Leave me with haste .

English: Lucius , who's that knocking ?
Shakespearean: Lucius , who's that knocking ?

English: Here's a sick man who wants to speak with you .
Shakespearean: He is a sick man that would speak with you .

English: How I wish you felt better !
Shakespearean: Would you were not sick !

English: I'm not sick if you've prepared some honorable exploit for me .
Shakespearean: I am not sick if Brutus have in hand Any exploit worthy the name of honor .

English: Indeed , I would have such an exploit for you , Ligarius , if you were healthy enough to hear it .
Shakespearean: Such an exploit have I in hand , Ligarius , Had you a healthful ear to hear of it .

English: A deed that will make sick men healthy .
Shakespearean: A piece of work that will make sick men whole .

English: But aren't there some healthy men whom we have to make sick ?
Shakespearean: But are not some whole that we must make sick ?

English: That too .
Shakespearean: That must we also .

English: My dear Caius , I'll explain the task at hand to you as we walk toward the man we must do it to .
Shakespearean: What it is , my Caius , I shall unfold to thee as we are going To whom it must be done .

English: Follow me , then .
Shakespearean: Follow me , then .

English: Neither the sky nor the earth have been quiet tonight .
Shakespearean: Nor heaven nor earth have been at peace tonight .

English: Calphurnia cried out three times in her sleep , "Help , someone !
Shakespearean: Thrice hath Calphurnia in her sleep cried out , "Help , ho !

English: They're murdering Caesar ! " Who's there ?
Shakespearean: They murder Caesar ! " , Who's within ?

English: My lord ?
Shakespearean: My lord .

English: Go tell the priests to perform a sacrifice immediately , and bring me their interpretation of the results .
Shakespearean: Go bid the priests do present sacrifice And bring me their opinions of success .

English: I will , my lord .
Shakespearean: I will , my lord .

English: What are you doing , Caesar ?
Shakespearean: What mean you , Caesar ?

English: Are you planning to go out ?
Shakespearean: Think you to walk forth ?

English: You're not leaving the house today .
Shakespearean: You shall not stir out of your house today .

English: I will go out .
Shakespearean: Caesar shall forth .

English: The things that threaten me have only seen my back .
Shakespearean: The things that threatened me Ne'er looked but on my back .

English: When they see the face of Caesar , they will vanish .
Shakespearean: When they shall see The face of Caesar , they are vanished .

English: Caesar , I never believed in omens , but now they frighten me .
Shakespearean: Caesar , I never stood on ceremonies , Yet now they fright me .

English: A servant told me the night-watchmen saw horrid sights too , but different ones from what we heard and saw .
Shakespearean: There is one within , Besides the things that we have heard and seen , Recounts most horrid sights seen by the watch .

English: A lioness gave birth in the streets , and graves cracked open and thrust out their dead .
Shakespearean: A lioness hath whelped in the streets , And graves have yawned and yielded up their dead .

English: Fierce , fiery warriors fought in the clouds in the usual formations of war , ranks and squadrons , until the clouds drizzled blood onto the Capitol .
Shakespearean: Fierce fiery warriors fought upon the clouds In ranks and squadrons and right form of war , Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol .

English: Oh , Caesar !
Shakespearean: O Caesar !

English: These things are beyond anything we've seen before , and I'm afraid .
Shakespearean: These things are beyond all use , And I do fear them .

English: How can we avoid what the gods want to happen ?
Shakespearean: What can be avoided Whose end is purposed by the mighty gods ?

English: But I will go out , for these bad omens apply to the world in general as much as they do to me .
Shakespearean: Yet Caesar shall go forth , for these predictions Are to the world in general as to Caesar .

English: When beggars die there are no comets in the sky .
Shakespearean: When beggars die there are no comets seen .

English: The heavens only announce the deaths of princes .
Shakespearean: The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes .

English: Cowards die many times before their deaths .
Shakespearean: Cowards die many times before their deaths .

English: The brave experience death only once .
Shakespearean: The valiant never taste of death but once .

English: Of all the strange things I've ever heard , it seems most strange to me that men fear death , given that death , which can't be avoided , will come whenever it wants .
Shakespearean: Of all the wonders that I yet have heard , It seems to me most strange that men should fear , Seeing that death , a necessary end , Will come when it will come .

English: What do the priests say ?
Shakespearean: What say the augurers ?

English: They don't want you to go out today .
Shakespearean: They would not have you to stir forth today .

English: They pulled out the guts of the sacrificed animal and couldn't find its heart .
Shakespearean: Plucking the entrails of an offering forth , They could not find a heart within the beast .

English: The gods do this to test my bravery .
Shakespearean: The gods do this in shame of cowardice .

English: They're saying I'd be an animal without a heart if I stayed home today out of fear .
Shakespearean: Caesar should be a beast without a heart If he should stay at home today for fear .

English: So , I won't .
Shakespearean: No , Caesar shall not .

English: We're two lions born on the same day in the same litter , and I'm the older and more terrible .
Shakespearean: We are two lions littered in one day , And I the elder and more terrible .

English: I will go out .
Shakespearean: And Caesar shall go forth .

English: Alas , my lord , your confidence is getting the better of your wisdom .
Shakespearean: Alas , my lord , Your wisdom is consumed in confidence .

English: Don't go out today .
Shakespearean: Do not go forth today .

English: Say that it's my fear that keeps you inside and not your own .
Shakespearean: Call it my fear That keeps you in the house , and not your own .

English: We'll send Mark Antony to the senate house , and he'll say that you're sick today .
Shakespearean: We'll send Mark Antony to the senate house , And he shall say you are not well today .

English: Mark Antony will say I'm not well , and to please you I'll stay at home .
Shakespearean: Mark Antony shall say I am not well , And for thy humor I will stay at home .

English: Here's Decius Brutus .
Shakespearean: Here's Decius Brutus .

English: He'll tell them so .
Shakespearean: He shall tell them so .

English: Hail , Caesar !
Shakespearean: Caesar , all hail !

English: Good morning , worthy Caesar .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , worthy Caesar .

English: I've come to take you to the senate house .
Shakespearean: I come to fetch you to the senate house .

English: And you've come at a good time , so you can convey my greetings to the senators and tell them I won't come today .
Shakespearean: And you are come in very happy time To bear my greeting to the senators And tell them that I will not come today .

English: Would I send a lie ?
Shakespearean: Shall Caesar send a lie ?

English: Have I accomplished so much in battle , but now I'm afraid to tell some old men the truth ?
Shakespearean: Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far To be afraid to tell graybeards the truth ?

English: Decius , go tell them that Caesar won't come .
Shakespearean: Decius , go tell them Caesar will not come .

English: Most mighty Caesar , give me some reason , so I won't be laughed at when I tell them so .
Shakespearean: Most mighty Caesar , let me know some cause , Lest I be laughed at when I tell them so .

English: The reason is that it's what I want .
Shakespearean: The cause is in my will .

English: I'm not coming .
Shakespearean: I will not come .

English: That's enough for the senate .
Shakespearean: That is enough to satisfy the senate .

English: But for your private satisfaction , because I love you , I'll tell you .
Shakespearean: But for your private satisfaction , Because I love you , I will let you know .

English: Calphurnia , my wife , is keeping me at home .
Shakespearean: Calphurnia here , my wife , stays me at home .

English: She takes these signs for warnings and predictions of terrible evils to come , and , on her knee , she begged me to stay home today .
Shakespearean: And these does she apply for warnings and portents And evils imminent , and on her knee Hath begged that I will stay at home today .

English: This dream has been interpreted all wrong .
Shakespearean: This dream is all amiss interpreted .

English: It was a good and lucky vision .
Shakespearean: It was a vision fair and fortunate .

English: Your statue spouting blood through many holes , in which many smiling Romans bathed , means that you'll provide great Rome with sustaining blood , and that great men will strive to get some token of approval from your holy blood .
Shakespearean: Your statue spouting blood in many pipes , In which so many smiling Romans bathed , Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck Reviving blood , and that great men shall press For tinctures , stains , relics , and cognizance .

English: This is what Calphurnia's dream means .
Shakespearean: This by Calphurnia's dream is signified .

English: You've offered an excellent interpretation .
Shakespearean: And this way have you well expounded it .

English: I will have when you hear the rest of what I have to say .
Shakespearean: I have , when you have heard what I can say .

English: The senate has decided to give mighty Caesar a crown today .
Shakespearean: And know it now : the senate have concluded To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar .

English: If you send them word that you won't come , they might change their minds .
Shakespearean: If you shall send them word you will not come , Their minds may change .

English: How foolish your fears seem now , Calphurnia !
Shakespearean: How foolish do your fears seem now , Calphurnia !

English: I'm ashamed that I yielded to them .
Shakespearean: I am ashamed I did yield to them .

English: Give me my robe , because I'm going .
Shakespearean: Give me my robe , for I will go .

English: And look , here's Publius , come to fetch me .
Shakespearean: And look , where Publius is come to fetch me .

English: Good morning , Caesar .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , Caesar .

English: Welcome , Publius .
Shakespearean: Welcome , Publius .

English: Caius Ligarius , I was never your enemy so much as the sickness that's made you so thin .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , Casca. , Caius Ligarius , Caesar was ne'er so much your enemy As that same ague which hath made you lean .

English: What time is it ?
Shakespearean: What is 't o'clock ?

English: Caesar , the clock has struck eight .
Shakespearean: Caesar , 'tis strucken eight .

English: I thank you all for your trouble and courtesy .
Shakespearean: I thank you for your pains and courtesy .

English: And to you , most noble Caesar .
Shakespearean: So to most noble Caesar .

English: I'm to blame for making you wait for me .
Shakespearean: I am to blame to be thus waited for .

English: Trebonius !
Shakespearean: Now , Cinna. , Now , Metellus. , What , Trebonius , I have an hour's talk in store for you .

English: Remember to see me today .
Shakespearean: Remember that you call on me today .

English: Stay near me so I'll remember .
Shakespearean: Be near me , that I may remember you .

English: Caesar , I will .
Shakespearean: Caesar , I will .

English: Good friends , go in and have some wine with me .
Shakespearean: Good friends , go in and taste some wine with me .

English: And we'll leave together , like friends .
Shakespearean: And we , like friends , will straightway go together .

English: Calphurnia !
Shakespearean: Calphurnia !

English: Quiet !
Shakespearean: Peace , ho !

English: Caesar's talking .
Shakespearean: Caesar speaks .

English: Calphurnia !
Shakespearean: Calphurnia !

English: I'm here , my lord .
Shakespearean: Here , my lord .

English: Yes , Caesar ?
Shakespearean: Caesar , my lord .

English: I'll remember .
Shakespearean: I shall remember .

English: When Caesar says "do this , " it is done .
Shakespearean: When Caesar says , "do this , " it is performed .

English: Continue , then , and don't forget to perform all of the rituals .
Shakespearean: Set on , and leave no ceremony out .

English: Caesar !
Shakespearean: Caesar !

English: Caesar , beware of Brutus .
Shakespearean: Caesar , beware of Brutus .

English: Watch Cassius .
Shakespearean: Take heed of Cassius .

English: Don't go near Casca .
Shakespearean: Come not near Casca .

English: Keep an eye on Cinna .
Shakespearean: Have an eye to Cinna .

English: Don't trust Trebonius .
Shakespearean: Trust not Trebonius .

English: Pay attention to Metellus Cimber .
Shakespearean: Mark well Metellus Cimber .

English: Decius Brutus doesn't love you .
Shakespearean: Decius Brutus loves thee not .

English: You've wronged Caius Ligarius .
Shakespearean: Thou hast wronged Caius Ligarius .

English: These men all have one intention , and it's directed against Caesar .
Shakespearean: There is but one mind in all these men , and it is bent against Caesar .

English: If you aren't immortal , watch those around you .
Shakespearean: If thou beest not immortal , look about you .

English: A sense of security opens the door to conspiracy .
Shakespearean: Security gives way to conspiracy .

English: I pray that the mighty gods defend you !
Shakespearean: The mighty gods defend thee !

English: Your friend , Artemidorus." I'll stand here until Caesar passes by , and I'll give him this as though it's a petition .
Shakespearean: Thy lover , Artemidorus" Here will I stand till Caesar pass along , And as a suitor will I give him this .

English: If you read this , Caesar , you might live .
Shakespearean: If thou read this , O Caesar , thou mayst live .

English: If not , the Fates are on the side of the traitors .
Shakespearean: If not , the Fates with traitors do contrive .

English: Boy , I beg you to run to the senate house .
Shakespearean: I prithee , boy , run to the senate house .

English: Don't stay to answer me , get going .
Shakespearean: Stay not to answer me , but get thee gone .

English: I want you there and back again before I can even tell you what you should do there .
Shakespearean: I would have had thee there and here again Ere I can tell thee what thou shouldst do there .

English: Madam , what should I do ?
Shakespearean: Madam , what should I do ?

English: Run to the Capitol and nothing else ?
Shakespearean: Run to the Capitol , and nothing else ?

English: And then return to you and nothing else ?
Shakespearean: And so return to you , and nothing else ?

English: Yes , return and tell me if your master looks well , because he was sick when he left .
Shakespearean: Yes , bring me word , boy , if thy lord look well , For he went sickly forth .

English: And pay attention to what Caesar does and which men are close to him .
Shakespearean: And take good note What Caesar doth , what suitors press to him .

English: Listen , boy !
Shakespearean: Hark , boy !

English: What's that noise ?
Shakespearean: What noise is that ?

English: I don't hear anything , madam .
Shakespearean: I hear none , madam .

English: I beg you , listen well .
Shakespearean: Prithee , listen well .

English: Truly , madam , I don't hear anything .
Shakespearean: Sooth , madam , I hear nothing .

English: Come here , you .
Shakespearean: Come hither , fellow .

English: Where are you coming from ?
Shakespearean: Which way hast thou been ?

English: My own house , good lady .
Shakespearean: At mine own house , good lady .

English: What time is it ?
Shakespearean: What is 't o'clock ?

English: Around nine o'clock , madam .
Shakespearean: About the ninth hour , lady .

English: Has Caesar gone to the Capital yet ?
Shakespearean: Is Caesar yet gone to the Capitol ?

English: Madam , not yet .
Shakespearean: Madam , not yet .

English: I'm going to stand so I can see him pass on the way to the Capitol .
Shakespearean: I go to take my stand To see him pass on to the Capitol .

English: You have some plea for Caesar , don't you ?
Shakespearean: Thou hast some suit to Caesar , hast thou not ?

English: Yes , I do , lady .
Shakespearean: That I have , lady .

English: If it pleases Caesar to be so good to himself as to hear me , I'll try to get him to do what's good for him .
Shakespearean: If it will please Caesar To be so good to Caesar as to hear me , I shall beseech him to befriend himself .

English: Why , do you know of any harm intended toward him ?
Shakespearean: Why , know'st thou any harm's intended towards him ?

English: Nothing that I know for sure , but a lot that I'm afraid might happen .
Shakespearean: None that I know will be ; much that I fear may chance .

English: Good morning to you .
Shakespearean: Good morrow to you .

English: The street is narrow here .
Shakespearean: Here the street is narrow .

English: The crowd that follows Caesar at his heels , senators , justices , common petitioners , will suffocate a feeble man almost to death .
Shakespearean: The throng that follows Caesar at the heels , Of senators , of praetors , common suitors , Will crowd a feeble man almost to death .

English: I'll move to a more open place and there speak to great Caesar as he walks past .
Shakespearean: I'll get me to a place more void , and there Speak to great Caesar as he comes along .

English: I must go in .
Shakespearean: I must go in .

English: Yes , Caesar , but it's not gone yet .
Shakespearean: Ay , Caesar , but not gone .

English: Oh , Caesar , read mine first , for my petition affects you more directly .
Shakespearean: O Caesar , read mine first , for mine's a suit That touches Caesar nearer .

English: Read it , great Caesar .
Shakespearean: Read it , great Caesar .

English: Whatever pertains to myself I will deal with last .
Shakespearean: What touches us ourself shall be last served .

English: Don't delay , Caesar .
Shakespearean: Delay not , Caesar .

English: Read it instantly .
Shakespearean: Read it instantly .

English: What , is the man insane ?
Shakespearean: What , is the fellow mad ?

English: You have weapons ?
Shakespearean: Weapons , arms ?

English: What's going on here ?
Shakespearean: What's the matter here ?

English: Stop it , I order you .
Shakespearean: Keep peace , upon your lives .

English: The next person to strike again dies .
Shakespearean: He dies that strikes again .

English: What's going on here ?
Shakespearean: What is the matter ?

English: These are the messengers from my sister and the king .
Shakespearean: The messengers from our sister and the king .

English: What are you fighting about ?
Shakespearean: What is your difference ?

English: Tell me .
Shakespearean: Speak .

English: I'm out of breath , sir .
Shakespearean: I am scarce in breath , my lord .

English: A tailor made you .
Shakespearean: A tailor made thee .

English: That's an odd thing to say .
Shakespearean: Thou art a strange fellow .

English: How can a tailor make a person ?
Shakespearean: A tailor make a man ?

English: Definitely a tailor , sir .
Shakespearean: Ay , a tailor , sir .

English: A sculptor or a painter couldn't have screwed him up as bad as that , even as an apprentice .
Shakespearean: A stone-cutter or painter could not have made him so ill though they had been but two years o ' th ' trade .

English: But tell me what you're fighting about .
Shakespearean: Speak yet .

English: Calm down .
Shakespearean: Peace , sirrah !

English: Don't you have any manners , you savage ?
Shakespearean: You beastly knave , know you no reverence ?

English: Yes , sir , but not when I'm enraged .
Shakespearean: Yes , sir , but anger hath a privilege .

English: Why are you enraged ?
Shakespearean: Why art thou angry ?

English: Are you laughing at what I say , as if I were a fool ?
Shakespearean: Smile you my speeches as I were a fool ?

English: Are you insane , old man ?
Shakespearean: Why , art thou mad , old fellow ?

English: Why are you calling him a jerk ?
Shakespearean: Why dost thou call him "knave" ?

English: What did he do to you ?
Shakespearean: What's his offense ?

English: I don't like his face .
Shakespearean: His countenance likes me not .

English: But maybe you don't like mine , or his , or hers either .
Shakespearean: No more perchance does mine , nor his , nor hers .

English: This is a guy who's been praised for his honest bluntness , and who now insolently pretends to be plainspoken and twists the natural meanings of words .
Shakespearean: This is some fellow , Who , having been praised for bluntness , doth affect A saucy roughness and constrains the garb Quite from his nature .

English: No flattery for him , no sir !
Shakespearean: He can not flatter , he .

English: He's honest , he's got to speak the truth .
Shakespearean: An honest mind and plain , he must speak truth .

English: If people take what he says , fine .
Shakespearean: An they will take it , so .

English: If not , he's got truth on his side !
Shakespearean: If not , he's plain .

English: Dearest , kindest , most honorable sir , may I say , with your esteemed approval , which is lit up by the illuminating radiance of the sun-god Phoebus , that , What do you mean by that ?
Shakespearean: Sir , in good faith , or in sincere verity , Under th ' allowance of your great aspect , Whose influence , like the wreath of radiant fire On flickering Phoebus ' front , What mean'st by this ?

English: I tried to stop speaking plainly , since you dislike plain speech so much .
Shakespearean: To go out of my dialect , which you discommend so much .

English: Sir , I know I'm not a flatterer .
Shakespearean: I know , sir , I am no flatterer .

English: I never offended him at all .
Shakespearean: I never gave him any .

English: These cowards manage to make fools of brave men .
Shakespearean: None of these rogues and cowards But Ajax is their fool .

English: Don't put me in the stocks .
Shakespearean: Call not your stocks for me .

English: I serve the king , who sent me here .
Shakespearean: I serve the king , On whose employment I was sent to you .

English: If you put me in the stocks you'll insult him both as a king and as a man .
Shakespearean: You shall do small respect , show too bold malice Against the grace and person of my master , Stocking his messenger .

English: Bring out the stocks !
Shakespearean: Fetch forth the stocks !

English: I swear on my life and honor , he'll sit here in the stocks until noon .
Shakespearean: As I have life and honor , there shall he sit till noon .

English: Only until noon , my lord ?
Shakespearean: Till noon ?

English: No , the whole day , and all night too .
Shakespearean: Till night , my lord , and all night too .

English: Ma'am , you wouldn't treat me like this if I were your father's dog .
Shakespearean: Why , madam , if I were your father's dog , You should not use me so .

English: But since you're his scoundrel servant , I will .
Shakespearean: Sir , being his knave , I will .

English: This guy is exactly the kind of person your sister warned us about. , Come on , bring in the stocks , now !
Shakespearean: This is a fellow of the selfsame color Our sister speaks of. , Come , bring away the stocks !

English: I beg you not to do this , my lord .
Shakespearean: Let me beseech your grace not to do so .

English: He's done wrong , and his master the king will punish him for it .
Shakespearean: His fault is much , and the good king his master Will check him for 't .

English: The king will be offended to find out that his messenger is so badly treated .
Shakespearean: The king his master needs must take it ill , That he , so slightly valued in his messenger , Should have him thus restrained .

English: I'll take responsibility for that .
Shakespearean: I'll answer that .

English: My sister would be much more offended to have her trusted messenger abused and assaulted just for carrying out her orders. , Put his legs in the stocks .
Shakespearean: My sister may receive it much more worse To have her gentleman abused , assaulted For following her affairs. , Put in his legs .

English: I'm sorry , my friend .
Shakespearean: I am sorry for thee , friend .

English: I'll try talking to him again .
Shakespearean: I'll entreat for thee .

English: Please don't , sir .
Shakespearean: Pray you do not , sir .

English: Even good men have bad luck .
Shakespearean: A good man's fortune may grow out at heels .

English: Have a good morning .
Shakespearean: Give you good morrow .

English: It's wrong for the duke to do this .
Shakespearean: The duke's to blame in this .

English: The king will be angry with him .
Shakespearean: Twill be ill taken .

English: honor you .
Shakespearean: Obey you , love you , and most honor you .

English: Hopefully when I get married , I'll give my husband half my love and half my sense of duty .
Shakespearean: Haply when I shall wed That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry Half my love with him , half my care and duty .

English: I'm sure I'll never get married in the way my sisters say they're married , loving their father only .
Shakespearean: Sure , I shall never marry like my sisters , To love my father all .

English: But do you mean what you're saying ?
Shakespearean: But goes thy heart with this ?

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , good my lord .

English: So young and so cruel ?
Shakespearean: So young and so untender ?

English: So young , my lord , and honest .
Shakespearean: So young , my lord , and true .

English: Then that's the way it'll be .
Shakespearean: Let it be so .

English: The truth will be all the inheritance you get .
Shakespearean: Thy truth then be thy dower .

English: Foreign savages who eat their own children for dinner will be as close to my heart as you , ex-daughter of mine .
Shakespearean: The barbarous Scythian , Or he that makes his generation messes To gorge his appetite , shall to my bosom Be as well neighbored , pitied , and relieved As thou my sometime daughter .

English: But sir , Be quiet , Kent .
Shakespearean: Good my liege , Peace , Kent .

English: I heard myself declared an outlaw and escaped capture by hiding in the trunk of a hollow tree .
Shakespearean: I heard myself proclaimed , And by the happy hollow of a tree Escaped the hunt .

English: Every town and port is crawling with henchmen on the lookout , waiting to capture me .
Shakespearean: No port is free , no place That guard and most unusual vigilance Does not attend my taking .

English: I'll smear my face with filth , put on a loincloth , make my hair matted and tangled , and face the bad weather wearing almost nothing .
Shakespearean: My face I'll grime with filth , Blanket my loins , elf all my hair in knots , And with presented nakedness outface The winds and persecutions of the sky .

English: Well , at least that's something .
Shakespearean: Poor Turlygod ! " "Poor Tom ! " , That's something yet .

English: As Edgar , I'm nothing at all .
Shakespearean: Edgar I nothing am .

English: It's strange that Regan and her husband left their house without sending back my messenger .
Shakespearean: Tis strange that they should so depart from home , And not send back my messenger .

English: According to what I heard , they had no travel plans as of last night .
Shakespearean: As I learned , The night before there was no purpose in them Of this remove .

English: What's this ?
Shakespearean: Ha !

English: Are you sitting around in this humiliation to amuse yourself ?
Shakespearean: Makest thou this shame thy pastime ?

English: No , my lord .
Shakespearean: No , my lord .

English: Ha , ha !
Shakespearean: Ha , ha !

English: That's a nasty garter belt .
Shakespearean: Look , he wears cruel garters .

English: You tie up horses by their heads , dogs and bears by their necks , monkeys by their waists , and humans by their legs .
Shakespearean: Horses are tied by the heads , dogs and bears by the neck , monkeys by the loins , and men by the legs .

English: Your daughter and son-in-law .
Shakespearean: It is both he and she : Your son and daughter .

English: No .
Shakespearean: No .

English: Yes .
Shakespearean: Yes .

English: No , no , they wouldn't .
Shakespearean: No , no , they would not .

English: Yes , they have .
Shakespearean: Yes , they have .

English: By the god Jupiter above , I swear "No." By Jupiter's wife Juno , I swear "Yes." They wouldn't dare .
Shakespearean: By Jupiter , I swear "No." By Juno , I swear "Ay." They durst not do 't .

English: They couldn't , they wouldn't .
Shakespearean: They could not , would not do 't .

English: It's worse than murder to humiliate a king's messenger like this .
Shakespearean: Tis worse than murder To do upon respect such violent outrage .

English: My lord , when I arrived at their home I gave them your letter .
Shakespearean: My lord , when at their home I did commend your highness ' letters to them .

English: He woke up the whole house with his loud and cowardly screams .
Shakespearean: He raised the house with loud and coward cries .

English: That's why your daughter and son-in-law are punishing me shamefully .
Shakespearean: Your son and daughter found this trespass worth The shame which here it suffers .

English: Fathers who wear rags Make their children neglect them .
Shakespearean: Fathers that wear rags Do make their children blind .

English: But fathers who are rich Make their children kind .
Shakespearean: But fathers that bear bags Shall see their children kind .

English: Lady Luck is a fickle whore And never gives the poor a break .
Shakespearean: Fortune , that arrant whore , Ne'er turns the key to th ' poor .

English: But despite all this , your daughters will give you a lot of money , or do I mean pain ? , in the coming year .
Shakespearean: But for all this thou shalt have as many dolors for thy daughters as thou canst tell in a year .

English: I feel my stomach squeezing up against my heart .
Shakespearean: O , how this mother swells up toward my heart !

English: Inside , sir , with the earl .
Shakespearean: With the earl , sir , here within .

English: Don't follow me .
Shakespearean: Follow me not .

English: Stay here .
Shakespearean: Stay here .

English: You didn't do anything else to earn this punishment ?
Shakespearean: Made you no more offense but what you speak of ?

English: Nothing .
Shakespearean: None .

English: Tell me , why did the king arrive with such a small entourage ?
Shakespearean: How chance the king comes with so small a train ?

English: If they'd put you in the stocks for asking that question , you would've deserved it .
Shakespearean: An thou hadst been set i ' th ' stocks for that question , thou'dst well deserved it .

English: Why , Fool ?
Shakespearean: Why , Fool ?

English: You need to learn what ants know well about winter , there's no point in slaving away if there's no hope for profit .
Shakespearean: We'll set thee to school to an ant to teach thee there's no laboring i ' th ' winter .

English: Everyone can see that , and even blind men can smell the stench of his misery now .
Shakespearean: All that follow their noses are led by their eyes but blind men , and there's not a nose among twenty but can smell him that's stinking .

English: When you see a huge wheel rolling down a hill , you shouldn't try to hold on to it or it'll break your neck .
Shakespearean: Let go thy hold when a great wheel runs down a hill , lest it break thy neck with following it .

English: But if you see a wheel going uphill , latch on for the ride .
Shakespearean: But the great one that goes up the hill , let him draw thee after .

English: And when a wise man gives you better advice than I just did , give me my advice back again .
Shakespearean: When a wise man gives thee better counsel , give me mine again .

English: I only want idiots following my advice , the advice of a fool .
Shakespearean: I would have none but knaves follow it since a fool gives it .

English: The gentleman who serves you only for profit And is only superficially loyal to you Will take off when it starts to rain And leave you alone in the storm .
Shakespearean: That sir which serves and seeks for gain , And follows but for form , Will pack when it begins to rain And leave thee in the storm .

English: But I'll linger .
Shakespearean: But I will tarry .

English: The fool will stay .
Shakespearean: The fool will stay .

English: And let the wise man run away .
Shakespearean: And let the wise man fly .

English: Where did you learn that song , Fool ?
Shakespearean: Where learned you this , Fool ?

English: Not in the stocks , fool .
Shakespearean: Not i ' th ' stocks , fool .

English: How can they refuse to speak with me ?
Shakespearean: Deny to speak with me ?

English: They're playing with me .
Shakespearean: They are sick ?

English: These are tricks .
Shakespearean: They are weary ?

English: This is rebellion .
Shakespearean: The images of revolt and flying off .

English: My dear lord , you know how passionately stubborn the duke is .
Shakespearean: My dear lord , You know the fiery quality of the duke , How unremoveable and fixed he is In his own course .

English: Damn it all to hell !
Shakespearean: Vengeance , plague , death , confusion !

English: Passionately" ?
Shakespearean: Fiery" ?

English: What "passion" ?
Shakespearean: What "quality" ?

English: Gloucester , Gloucester , I want to speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife .
Shakespearean: Why , Gloucester , Gloucester , I'd speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife .

English: My lord , I informed them as much .
Shakespearean: Well , my good lord , I have informed them so .

English: Informed them" ?
Shakespearean: Informed them" ?

English: Do you understand what I'm saying , man ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou understand me , man ?

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my good lord .

English: The king wants to speak with Cornwall .
Shakespearean: The king would speak with Cornwall .

English: Did you inform them of that ?
Shakespearean: Are they "informed" of this ?

English: This is unbelievable !
Shakespearean: My breath and blood !

English: Passionate" ?
Shakespearean: Fiery" ?

English: The "passionate" duke ?
Shakespearean: The "fiery" duke ?

English: Tell the hot-headed duke that I, But no , not yet .
Shakespearean: Tell the hot duke that Lear , No , but not yet .

English: Maybe he's not feeling well .
Shakespearean: Maybe he is not well .

English: I just want everything to be all right between you .
Shakespearean: I would have all well betwixt you .

English: Oh , my heart , my heart is rising into my throat !
Shakespearean: O me , my heart , my rising heart !

English: Stay down , heart .
Shakespearean: But down .

English: That's right , uncle , talk to your heart , like the Good morning to you both .
Shakespearean: Good morrow to you both .

English: Hail to your majesty .
Shakespearean: Hail to your grace .

English: I'm glad to see your highness .
Shakespearean: I am glad to see your highness .

English: I believe you are , Regan .
Shakespearean: Regan , I think you are .

English: You know why I think so ?
Shakespearean: I know what reason I have to think so : if thou shouldst not be glad , I would divorce me from thy mother's tomb , Sepulchring an adultress .

English: My dear Regan , your sister's not worth anything .
Shakespearean: Beloved Regan , Thy sister's naught .

English: Oh , Regan , she's torn me apart with unkindness , like a vulture , right here .
Shakespearean: O Regan , she hath tied Sharp-toothed unkindness , like a vulture , here .

English: Calm down , sir , please .
Shakespearean: I pray you , sir , take patience .

English: How do you mean ?
Shakespearean: Say , how is that ?

English: I can't believe my sister would neglect her obligations in any way .
Shakespearean: I can not think my sister in the least Would fail her obligation .

English: If she restrained your rowdy knights , she had such a good reason that you can't blame her for it .
Shakespearean: If , sir , perchance She have restrained the riots of your followers , 'T is on such ground and to such wholesome end As clears her from all blame .

English: I curse her .
Shakespearean: My curses on her !

English: Sir , you're old .
Shakespearean: O sir , you are old .

English: Your life is stretched to its limit .
Shakespearean: Nature in you stands on the very verge Of his confine .

English: You should let others take care of you and submit to people who know better than you do what's good for you .
Shakespearean: You should be ruled and led By some discretion that discerns your state Better than you yourself .

English: Please go back to Goneril's house .
Shakespearean: Therefore I pray you That to our sister you do make return .

English: Admit you were wrong .
Shakespearean: Say you have wronged her , sir .

English: Apologize ?
Shakespearean: Ask her forgiveness ?

English: No more , please .
Shakespearean: On my knees I beg That you'll vouchsafe me raiment , bed , and food." Good sir , no more .

English: These are ugly antics .
Shakespearean: These are unsightly tricks .

English: Go back to my sister's .
Shakespearean: Return you to my sister .

English: Shush , sir , please !
Shakespearean: Fie , sir , fie !

English: I hope lightning strikes her in the eyes !
Shakespearean: You nimble lightnings , dart your blinding flames Into her scornful eyes !

English: I hope poisonous swampy fog covers her face and ruins her complexion !
Shakespearean: Infect her beauty , You fen-sucked fogs drawn by the powerful sun , To fall and blister !

English: Oh , dear gods !
Shakespearean: O the blessed gods !

English: That's how you'll talk about me when you're in this mood .
Shakespearean: So will you wish on me when the rash mood is on .

English: Her eyes are vicious , but yours are comforting .
Shakespearean: Her eyes are fierce , but thine Do comfort and not burn .

English: You haven't forgotten the half of a kingdom I gave you .
Shakespearean: Thy half o ' th ' kingdom hast thou not forgot , Wherein I thee endowed .

English: Sir , let's get to the point .
Shakespearean: Good sir , to the purpose .

English: Get out of my sight ! , I guess if she doesn't love her father , then I'll only have peace when I'm dead. , Call the King of France .
Shakespearean: Hence , and avoid my sight ! , So be my grave my peace as here I give Her father's heart from her. , Call France .

English: Call the Duke of Burgundy .
Shakespearean: Call Burgundy. , Cornwall and Albany , With my two daughters ' dowers digest this third .

English: If she wants to be proud , or "honest , " as she calls it , she can just marry her own pride .
Shakespearean: Let pride , which she calls plainness , marry her .

English: King Lear , I've always honored you as king , loved you as my father , obeyed you as my master , and thanked you in my prayers , I'm furious and ready to snap .
Shakespearean: Royal Lear , Whom I have ever honored as my king , Loved as my father , as my master followed , As my great patron thought on in my prayers , The bow is bent and drawn .

English: Let your anger fall on me then , even if its sharpness pierces my heart .
Shakespearean: Let it fall rather , though the fork invade The region of my heart .

English: Kent can speak rudely when Lear goes mad .
Shakespearean: Be Kent unmannerly When Lear is mad .

English: What are you doing , old man ?
Shakespearean: What wouldst thou do , old man ?

English: When powerful kings cave in to flatterers , do you think loyal men will be afraid to speak out against it ?
Shakespearean: Think'st thou that duty shall have dread to speak When power to flattery bows ?

English: When a majestic king starts acting silly , then it's my duty to be blunt .
Shakespearean: To plainness honor's bound When majesty falls to folly .

English: What's that trumpet ?
Shakespearean: What trumpet's that ?

English: I know it .
Shakespearean: I know 't , my sister's .

English: She'll be here soon , just like her letter said .
Shakespearean: This approves her letter That she would soon be here .

English: This is a lowlife who basks in the reflection of the fading glory of the woman he works for. , Get out of my sight , scoundrel !
Shakespearean: This is a slave whose easy borrowed pride Dwells in the fickle grace of her he follows. , Out , varlet , from my sight !

English: What do you mean , your highness ?
Shakespearean: What means your grace ?

English: Who put my servant in the stocks ?
Shakespearean: Who stocked my servant ?

English: Regan , I hope you didn't know anything about that. , Ah , who's this ?
Shakespearean: Regan , I have good hope Thou didst not know on 't. , Who comes here ?

English: Why shouldn't she take my hand , father ?
Shakespearean: O Regan , wilt thou take her by the hand ?

English: How exactly have I offended you ?
Shakespearean: How have I offended ?

English: I sent him there , sir , but his crimes deserved a worse punishment .
Shakespearean: I set him there , sir , but his own disorders Deserved much less advancement .

English: You !
Shakespearean: You !

English: You did it ?
Shakespearean: Did you ?

English: Please , father , since you're weak , act like it .
Shakespearean: I pray you , father , being weak , seem so .

English: Get rid of half your knights and go back to spend the rest of your month with my sister .
Shakespearean: If till the expiration of your month , You will return and sojourn with my sister , Dismissing half your train , come then to me .

English: Right now I'm away from home and I can't provide you with proper care .
Shakespearean: I am now from home , and out of that provision Which shall be needful for your entertainment .

English: Go back with her ?
Shakespearean: Return to her , and fifty men dismissed ?

English: Go back with her ?
Shakespearean: Return with her ?

English: I might as well go before the King of France , who took my youngest daughter without a dowry , kneel before his throne , and beg him to give me a tiny pension to stay alive .
Shakespearean: Why , the hot-blooded France that dowerless took Our youngest born , I could as well be brought To knee his throne , and , squirelike , pension beg To keep base life afoot .

English: Go back with her ?
Shakespearean: Return with her ?

English: I'd rather be a slave or a packhorse for this hateful stablehand here .
Shakespearean: Persuade me rather to be slave and sumpter To this detested groom .

English: As you wish , sir .
Shakespearean: At your choice , sir .

English: I beg you , daughter , don't make me crazy .
Shakespearean: Now , I prithee , daughter , do not make me mad .

English: I won't bother you .
Shakespearean: I will not trouble thee , my child .

English: We'll never see each other again .
Shakespearean: We'll no more meet , no more see one another .

English: But you're still my child , my flesh and blood , or rather you're a disease in my flesh , a disease I still have to call my own .
Shakespearean: But yet thou art my flesh , my blood , my daughter , Or rather a disease that's in my flesh , Which I must needs call mine .

English: You're a pustule , a sore , a tumor digesting my bloodline .
Shakespearean: Thou art a boil , A plague-sore or embossed carbuncle In my corrupted blood .

English: But I'll stop rebuking you .
Shakespearean: But I'll not chide thee .

English: I won't beg the gods to punish you , or caution you to fear their judgment .
Shakespearean: I do not bid the thunder-bearer shoot , Nor tell tales of thee to high-judging Jove .

English: Become a better
Shakespearean: Mend when thou canst .

English: person when you're ready , if you're inclined .
Shakespearean: Be better at thy leisure .

English: I'll wait patiently .
Shakespearean: I can be patient .

English: Meanwhile I'll stay with Regan with my hundred knights .
Shakespearean: I can stay with Regan , I and my hundred knights .

English: It's not quite that simple .
Shakespearean: Not altogether so , sir .

English: I wasn't expecting you , and I'm not ready to receive you .
Shakespearean: I looked not for you yet , nor am provided For your fit welcome .

English: Please hear what Goneril is saying .
Shakespearean: Give ear , sir , to my sister .

English: We're trying to be reasonable while you're so upset , and we understand that you're old , and, But Goneril knows what she's doing .
Shakespearean: For those that mingle reason with your passion Must be content to think you old , and so , But she knows what she does .

English: Yes , I do .
Shakespearean: I dare avouch it , sir .

English: How could so many people , under two masters , get along under one roof ?
Shakespearean: How , in one house , Should many people under two commands Hold amity ?

English: It would be hard , almost impossible .
Shakespearean: Tis hard ; almost impossible .

English: Why couldn't you be attended by my servants , or by Regan's ?
Shakespearean: Why might not you , my lord , receive attendance From those that she calls servants , or from mine ?

English: Yes , why not , my lord ?
Shakespearean: Why not , my lord ?

English: Then if they're negligent , we could control them .
Shakespearean: If then they chanced to slack you , We could control them .

English: Now that I think about the danger of these knights , if you come to stay with me , please bring no more than twenty-five of them with you .
Shakespearean: If you will come to me , For now I spy a danger , I entreat you To bring but five and twenty .

English: I won't lodge any more than that under my roof .
Shakespearean: To no more Will I give place or notice .

English: I gave you everything , And it was about time too .
Shakespearean: I gave you all , And in good time you gave it .

English: I made you de facto rulers of my kingdom on condition that I could keep a hundred knights of my own .
Shakespearean: Made you my guardians , my depositaries , But kept a reservation to be followed With such a number .

English: Why should I now have to make do with only twenty-five ?
Shakespearean: What , must I come to you With five and twenty , Regan ?

English: Regan , is that what you said ?
Shakespearean: Said you so ?

English: Yes , I'll say it again , my lord .
Shakespearean: And speak 't again , my lord .

English: No more than twenty-five .
Shakespearean: No more with me .

English: Not being the worst daughter deserves some praise , I guess .
Shakespearean: Not being the worst Stands in some rank of praise .

English: Hear me out , my lord .
Shakespearean: Hear me , my lord .

English: Why do you need twenty-five knights , or ten , or even five , when you're staying in a house with a staff of double that at your service ?
Shakespearean: What need you five and twenty , ten , or five To follow in a house where twice so many Have a command to tend you ?

English: Why do you need even one ?
Shakespearean: What need one ?

English: Oh , don't ask me why I "need" them !
Shakespearean: O , reason not the need !

English: You're a well-dressed lady .
Shakespearean: Thou art a lady .

English: If you dressed only to stay warm , you wouldn't need these gorgeous clothes you're wearing , which don't keep you warm at all .
Shakespearean: If only to go warm were gorgeous , Why , nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear'st , Which scarcely keeps thee warm .

English: Oh , gods , give me patience !
Shakespearean: But , for true need , You heavens , give me that patience , patience I need .

English: You see me here , gods , a grieving old man , as wretched in his grief as he is in his old age .
Shakespearean: You see me here , you gods , a poor old man , As full of grief as age , wretched in both .

English: If you're the ones setting my daughters against me , don't let me be foolish enough to take it lying down .
Shakespearean: If it be you that stir these daughters ' hearts Against their father , fool me not so much To bear it tamely .

English: man's cheeks .
Shakespearean: No , you unnatural hags ,

English: No , you monstrous hags , I'll get revenge on you both that will make the whole world, I will do such things , I don't know what I'll do exactly , but it'll be devastating .
Shakespearean: I will have such revenges on you both That all the world shall , I will do such things , What they are yet I know not , but they shall be The terrors of the earth .

English: You expect me to cry ?
Shakespearean: You think I'll weep ?

English: Well , I won't .
Shakespearean: No , I'll not weep .

English: I have a good reason to cry , but my heart will splinter into a hundred thousand pieces before I let myself cry. , Oh , Fool , I'll go mad !
Shakespearean: I have full cause of weeping , but this heart Shall break into a hundred thousand flaws , Or ere I'll weep. , O Fool , I shall go mad !

English: Let's go inside .
Shakespearean: Let us withdraw .

English: There's going to be a storm .
Shakespearean: Twill be a storm .

English: This is a small house .
Shakespearean: This house is little .

English: There's no room for the old man and his followers .
Shakespearean: The old man and his people Can not be well bestowed .

English: It's his fault that he's all worked up like this .
Shakespearean: Tis his own blame .

English: He has to pay the price for his foolish actions .
Shakespearean: Hath put himself from rest , And must needs taste his folly .

English: That's what I intend to do too .
Shakespearean: So am I purposed .

English: Where is Gloucester ?
Shakespearean: Where is my lord of Gloucester ?

English: He followed the old man .
Shakespearean: Followed the old man forth .

English: Here he comes back .
Shakespearean: He is returned .

English: Where's he going ?
Shakespearean: Whither is he going ?

English: He has called for his horse , but I don't know where he's headed .
Shakespearean: He calls to horse , but will I know not whither .

English: It's best just to let him go .
Shakespearean: Tis best to give him way .

English: He won't listen to anyone's advice .
Shakespearean: He leads himself .

English: There's hardly a bush for miles around .
Shakespearean: For many miles about There's scarce a bush .

English: Oh , sir , impetuous people learn their lessons from the consequences of their foolish actions .
Shakespearean: O sir , to wilful men , The injuries that they themselves procure Must be their schoolmasters .

English: Lock the doors .
Shakespearean: Shut up your doors .

English: His attendants are desperate , violent men .
Shakespearean: He is attended with a desperate train .

English: I'm afraid of what they might encourage him to do , considering the state he's in .
Shakespearean: And what they may incense him to , being apt To have his ear abused , wisdom bids fear .

English: Lock the doors , my lord .
Shakespearean: Shut up your doors , my lord .

English: It's a wild night .
Shakespearean: Tis a wild night .

English: Regan gives good advice .
Shakespearean: My Regan counsels well .

English: Come in out of the storm .
Shakespearean: Come out o ' th ' storm .

English: Who's there , aside from this foul weather ?
Shakespearean: Who's there , besides foul weather ?

English: Someone whose mood is as foul as the weather , very troubled .
Shakespearean: One minded like the weather , most unquietly .

English: I know you .
Shakespearean: I know you .

English: Where's the king ?
Shakespearean: Where's the king ?

English: Struggling with the wind and rain .
Shakespearean: Contending with the fretful elements .

English: He's shouting at the wind to blow the earth into the sea , or make the sea flood the earth , he wants to see the world return to primal chaos .
Shakespearean: Bids the winds blow the earth into the sea Or swell the curled water 'bove the main , That things might change or cease .

English: He keeps tearing out his white hair , which the blindly raging winds catch up and blow away into nothingness .
Shakespearean: Tears his white hair , Which the impetuous blasts , with eyeless rage , Catch in their fury and make nothing of .

English: Small but brave in his surroundings , he's trying to stand up against the wind and rain blowing back and forth .
Shakespearean: Strives in his little world of man to outscorn The to-and-fro-conflicting wind and rain .

English: He's running bareheaded , calling for the end of the world , out there on a night like this , when even savage animals ravenous with hunger crawl under cover and hide .
Shakespearean: This night , wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch , The lion and the belly-pinched wolf Keep their fur dry , unbonneted he runs , And bids what will take all .

English: But who's with him ?
Shakespearean: But who is with him ?

English: Nobody but the fool , who's trying to soothe the wounds in the king's heart with jokes .
Shakespearean: None but the fool , who labors to outjest His heart-struck injuries .

English: Sir , I know you , and I trust you enough to share something very important with you .
Shakespearean: Sir , I do know you , And dare upon the warrant of my note Commend a dear thing to you .

English: Some French agents are already at work in our main ports and are on the verge of declaring open war .
Shakespearean: From France there comes a power Into this scattered kingdom , who already , Wise in our negligence , have secret feet In some of our best ports and are at point To show their open banner .

English: Now this is where you come in .
Shakespearean: Now to you .

English: I'm a nobleman , and I know what I'm doing in assigning this job to you .
Shakespearean: I am a gentleman of blood and breeding , And from some knowledge and assurance offer This office to you .

English: Let's discuss it some more .
Shakespearean: I will talk further with you .

English: Let me shake your hand .
Shakespearean: Give me your hand .

English: Do you have anything else to tell me ?
Shakespearean: Have you no more to say ?

English: Rage on , blow !
Shakespearean: Rage , blow !

English: Let tornadoes spew water until the steeples of our churches and the weathervanes are all drowned .
Shakespearean: You cataracts and hurricanoes , spout Till you have drenched our steeples , drowned the cocks !

English: Let quick sulfurous lightning , strong enough to split enormous trees , singe the white hair on my head .
Shakespearean: You sulfurous and thought-executing fires , Vaunt-couriers of oak-cleaving thunderbolts , Singe my white head !

English: Let thunder flatten the spherical world , crack open all the molds from which nature forms human beings , and spill all the seeds from which ungrateful humans grow !
Shakespearean: And thou , all-shaking thunder , Smite flat the thick rotundity o ' th ' world , Crack nature's molds , all germens spill at once That make ingrateful man !

English: Oh , uncle , it's better to smile and flatter indoors where it's dry than get soaked out here .
Shakespearean: O nuncle , court holy water in a dry house is better than this rainwater out o ' door .

English: Please , uncle , let's go in and ask your daughters to forgive you .
Shakespearean: Good nuncle , in , and ask thy daughters blessing .

English: This storm has no pity for either wise men or fools .
Shakespearean: Here's a night pities neither wise man nor fool .

English: Let thunder rumble !
Shakespearean: Rumble thy bellyful !

English: Let lightning spit fire !
Shakespearean: Spit , fire !

English: Let the rain spray !
Shakespearean: Spout , rain !

English: The rain , the wind , the thunder and lightning are not my daughters .
Shakespearean: Nor rain , wind , thunder , fire are my daughters .

English: Nature , I don't accuse your weather of unkindness .
Shakespearean: I tax not you , you elements , with unkindness .

English: So go ahead and have your terrifying fun .
Shakespearean: Why then , let fall Your horrible pleasure .

English: Here I am , your slave , a poor , sick , weak , hated old man .
Shakespearean: Here I stand , your slave , A poor , infirm , weak , and despised old man .

English: Anyone who has a house to cover his head has a good head on his shoulders .
Shakespearean: He that has a house to put 's head in has a good headpiece .

English: On my life I swear to you that your youngest daughter doesn't love you least .
Shakespearean: Answer my life my judgment , Thy youngest daughter does not love thee least , Nor are those empty-hearted whose low sound Reverbs no hollowness .

English: Kent , if you want to stay alive , stop talking .
Shakespearean: Kent , on thy life , no more .

English: Get out of my sight !
Shakespearean: Out of my sight !

English: Learn to see better , Lear , and let me stay here where you can look to me for good advice .
Shakespearean: See better , Lear , and let me still remain The true blank of thine eye .

English: Now , I swear by Apollo, By Apollo , King , you're taking the names of the gods in vain .
Shakespearean: Now , by Apollo , Now , by Apollo , King , Thou swear'st thy gods in vain .

English: Oh , you lowlife !
Shakespearean: O vassal !

English: Scum !
Shakespearean: Miscreant !

English: Please stop , sir .
Shakespearean: Dear sir , forbear !

English: Listen to me , you traitor .
Shakespearean: Hear me , recreant !

English: For there never was a pretty woman who didn't like to preen in the mirror .
Shakespearean: For there was never yet fair woman but she made mouths in a glass .

English: No , I'll be patient .
Shakespearean: No , I will be the pattern of all patience .

English: I won't say a word .
Shakespearean: I will say nothing .

English: Who's there ?
Shakespearean: Who's there ?

English: A wise man and a fool .
Shakespearean: Marry , here's grace and a codpiece , that's a wise man and a fool .

English: Let the gods who stirred up this dreadful storm bring their enemies to light .
Shakespearean: Let the great gods That keep this dreadful pudder o'er our heads Find out their enemies now .

English: It will give you some protection from this storm .
Shakespearean: Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest .

English: They are harder than the stones the house is made of .
Shakespearean: Repose you there , while I to this hard house , More harder than the stones whereof 'tis raised , Which even but now , demanding after you , Denied me to come in , return , and force Their scanted courtesy .

English: I'm starting to lose my mind .
Shakespearean: My wits begin to turn. , Come on , my boy .

English: That's true , my good boy. , Come on , take us to that hut .
Shakespearean: True , my good boy. , Come , bring us to this hovel .

English: I'll recite a prophecy before I go .
Shakespearean: I'll speak a prophecy ere I go .

English: And whoever lives to see that day Will walk with his feet .
Shakespearean: Then comes the time , who lives to see 't , That going shall be used with feet .

English: This is the prophecy that the wizard
Shakespearean: This prophecy Merlin shall make , for I live before his time .

English: Oh , oh , Edmund , I don't like this monstrous business .
Shakespearean: Alack , alack , Edmund , I like not this unnatural dealing .

English: When asked the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall if I could take pity on the king and shelter him from the storm , they took my house away from me and ordered me never to talk about him , lobby for him , or support him in any way .
Shakespearean: When I desire their leave that I might pity him , they took from me the use of mine own house , charged me on pain of their perpetual displeasure neither to speak of him , entreat for him , nor any way sustain him .

English: That's uncivilized and unnatural !
Shakespearean: Most savage and unnatural !

English: Oh , be quiet .
Shakespearean: Go to , say you nothing .

English: There's a feud between the two dukes .
Shakespearean: There's a division betwixt the dukes .

English: It's dangerous to talk about it .
Shakespearean: Tis dangerous to be spoken .

English: I've locked it up in my room .
Shakespearean: I have locked the letter in my closet .

English: The humiliation that the king is suffering now will be revenged thoroughly .
Shakespearean: These injuries the king now bears will be revenged home .

English: Armed forces have already landed .
Shakespearean: There's part of a power already footed .

English: We have to take the king's side .
Shakespearean: We must incline to the king .

English: I'll look for him and secretly help him .
Shakespearean: I will look him and privily relieve him .

English: You go and talk to the duke so he won't notice I'm helping the king .
Shakespearean: Go you and maintain talk with the duke , that my charity be not of him perceived .

English: If he asks to see me , tell him I'm sick and went to bed .
Shakespearean: If he ask for me , I am ill and gone to bed .

English: Even if I have to die , as they threaten , I have to help the king .
Shakespearean: Though I die for it , as no less is threatened me , the king my old master must be relieved .

English: Strange things are about to happen , Edmund .
Shakespearean: There is some strange thing toward , Edmund .

English: Please be careful .
Shakespearean: Pray you , be careful .

English: And I'll tell him about the letter too .
Shakespearean: This courtesy , forbid thee , shall the duke Instantly know , and of that letter too .

English: The young generation rises while the old one falls .
Shakespearean: The younger rises when the old doth fall .

English: Here's the hut , my lord .
Shakespearean: Here is the place , my lord .

English: Please go inside .
Shakespearean: Good my lord , enter .

English: The night's too rough for humans to bear .
Shakespearean: The tyranny of the open night's too rough For nature to endure .

English: Leave me for a bit .
Shakespearean: Let me alone .

English: My lord , here is the entrance .
Shakespearean: Good my lord , enter here .

English: Will you break my heart ?
Shakespearean: Wilt break my heart ?

English: I'd rather break my own heart .
Shakespearean: I had rather break mine own .

English: Now please go in .
Shakespearean: Good my lord , enter .

English: You think it's a big deal that this fierce storm is soaking me to the skin .
Shakespearean: Thou think'st 'tis much that this contentious storm Invades us to the skin .

English: It's a big deal to you .
Shakespearean: So 'tis to thee .

English: But whenever you feel a larger pain , the smaller one disappears .
Shakespearean: But where the greater malady is fixed The lesser is scarce felt .

English: You would run away from a bear , but if the only way to run was into the stormy ocean , you'd turn around and confront the bear .
Shakespearean: Thou'dst shun a bear , But if thy flight lay toward the raging sea Thou'dst meet the bear i ' th ' mouth .

English: When your mind is at peace , your body is sensitive to the elements .
Shakespearean: When the mind's free , The body's delicate .

English: But this storm in my mind keeps me from feeling anything except what's tormenting me , how ungrateful my children are !
Shakespearean: The tempest in my mind Doth from my senses take all feeling else Save what beats there , filial ingratitude .

English: Isn't their ingratitude like the mouth biting the hand that feeds it ?
Shakespearean: Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand For lifting food to 't ?

English: But I'll punish them thoroughly .
Shakespearean: But I will punish home .

English: No , I won't cry any more .
Shakespearean: No , I will weep no more .

English: Imagine them locking me out on a night like this !
Shakespearean: In such a night To shut me out !

English: But let it rain ; I'll survive .
Shakespearean: Pour on , I will endure .

English: On a night like this !
Shakespearean: In such a night as this !

English: Oh , Regan , Goneril , your kind old father whose generous heart gave you everything , Oh , if I think about that I'll go mad .
Shakespearean: O Regan , Goneril , Your old kind father , whose frank heart gave all , Oh , that way madness lies .

English: I want to avoid that .
Shakespearean: Let me shun that .

English: No more of these thoughts .
Shakespearean: No more of that .

English: My lord , please go inside here .
Shakespearean: Good my lord , enter here .

English: Go inside yourself .
Shakespearean: Prithee , go in thyself .

English: Make yourself comfortable .
Shakespearean: Seek thine own ease .

English: This storm protects me from thoughts that would hurt me more .
Shakespearean: This tempest will not give me leave to ponder On things would hurt me more .

English: But I'll go in .
Shakespearean: But I'll go in .

English: Go out and feel what the impoverished feel .
Shakespearean: Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel , That thou mayst shake the superflux to them And show the heavens more just .

English: Don't come in here , uncle !
Shakespearean: Come not in here , nuncle .

English: There's a spirit in here !
Shakespearean: Here's a spirit .

English: Help me , help me !
Shakespearean: Help me , help me !

English: Give me your hand .
Shakespearean: Give me thy hand .

English: Who's there ?
Shakespearean: Who's there ?

English: A ghost , a ghost !
Shakespearean: A spirit , a spirit .

English: He says his name's Poor Tom .
Shakespearean: He says his name's Poor Tom .

English: Who are you , moaning in the hut like that ?
Shakespearean: What art thou that dost grumble there i ' th ' straw ?

English: Come out .
Shakespearean: Come forth .

English: Go away !
Shakespearean: Away !

English: The devil's after me !
Shakespearean: The foul fiend follows me !

English: The cold wind blows through the hawthorn trees .
Shakespearean: Through the sharp hawthorn blows the cold wind .

English: Ha !
Shakespearean: Hum !

English: Get into your cold beds and warm yourselves up .
Shakespearean: Go to thy cold bed and warm thee .

English: Did you give everything to your two daughters and end up like this ?
Shakespearean: Didst thou give all to thy two daughters , and art thou come to this ?

English: Bless your five senses !
Shakespearean: Bless thy five wits .

English: Tom's chilly .
Shakespearean: Tom's a-cold .

English: Oh do-de , do-de , do-de .
Shakespearean: Oh , do-de , do-de , do-de .

English: God protect you from tornadoes , evil stars , and diseases !
Shakespearean: Bless thee from whirlwinds , star-blasting , and taking !

English: Take pity on Poor Tom , who is persecuted by the devil .
Shakespearean: Do Poor Tom some charity , whom the foul fiend vexes .

English: There ! , And over there ! , And over there !
Shakespearean: There could I have him now , and there , and there again , and there .

English: Have his daughters made him crazy like this ? , Couldn't you have kept something for yourself ?
Shakespearean: What , has his daughters brought him to this pass ? , Couldst thou save nothing ?

English: Did you have to give them everything ?
Shakespearean: Wouldst thou give 'em all ?

English: If he hadn't , we'd all be embarrassed to look at him .
Shakespearean: Nay , he reserved a blanket , else we had been all shamed .

English: Then may your daughters be cursed with all the horrible fates that await sinners !
Shakespearean: Now all the plagues that in the pendulous air Hang fated o'er men's faults light on thy daughters !

English: He doesn't have any daughters , sir .
Shakespearean: He hath no daughters , sir .

English: Like hell !
Shakespearean: Death , traitor !

English: Nothing but cruel daughters could have degraded him like this .
Shakespearean: Nothing could have subdued nature To such a lowness but his unkind daughters .

English: Is it fashionable now for neglected fathers to get so little pity ?
Shakespearean: Is it the fashion that discarded fathers Should have thus little mercy on their flesh ?

English: I'm the one who fathered those bloodsucking daughters .
Shakespearean: Twas this flesh begot Those pelican daughters .

English: This stormy night will turn us all into fools and madmen .
Shakespearean: This cold night will turn us all to fools and madmen .
