English: Beware of the devil .
Shakespearean: Take heed o ' th ' foul fiend .

English: Obey your parents , keep your word , don't swear , don't sleep with another man's wife , and don't covet flashy clothes .
Shakespearean: Obey thy parents , keep thy word's justice , swear not , commit not with man's sworn spouse , set not thy sweet heart on proud array .

English: Tom's chilly .
Shakespearean: Tom's a- cold .

English: What were you before this ?
Shakespearean: What hast thou been ?

English: I loved wine and gambling , and had more women than a Turkish sultan keeps in his harem .
Shakespearean: Wine loved I deeply , dice dearly , and in woman outparamoured the Turk .

English: The cold wind's still blowing through the hawthorn tree .
Shakespearean: Still through the hawthorn blows the cold wind , says , "Suum , mun , nonny." Dauphin my boy , my boy , cessez .

English: Look at him .
Shakespearean: Thou art the thing itself .

English: The human being unburdened by the trappings of civilization is no more than a poor , naked , two-legged animal like you .
Shakespearean: Unaccommodated man is no more but such a poor , bare , forked animal as thou art. , Off , off , you lendings !

English: Let me unbutton this .
Shakespearean: Unbutton here .

English: Please calm down , uncle .
Shakespearean: Prithee , nuncle , be contented .

English: This is a nasty night to go swimming .
Shakespearean: Tis a naughty night to swim in .

English: On a night like this a campfire in an empty field would be like the heart of a dirty old man , a tiny spark in a cold body .
Shakespearean: Now a little fire in a wild field were like an old lecher's heart , a small spark , all the rest on 's body cold .

English: Look , here comes a walking fire .
Shakespearean: Look , here comes a walking fire .

English: This is the devil Flibbertigibbet .
Shakespearean: This is the foul fiend Flibbertigibbet .

English: He gets up at nightfall and wanders around till dawn .
Shakespearean: He begins at curfew and walks till the first cock .

English: And go away , witch , go away .
Shakespearean: And aroint thee , witch , aroint thee !

English: How are you , your highness ?
Shakespearean: How fares your grace ?

English: Who are you ?
Shakespearean: Who's there ?

English: What do you want ?
Shakespearean: What is 't you seek ?

English: Who are you ?
Shakespearean: What are you there ?

English: What are your names ?
Shakespearean: Your names ?

English: Calm down , Smulkin , you fiend !
Shakespearean: Peace , Smulkin .

English: He's called Modo and Mahu .
Shakespearean: Modo he's called , and Mahu .

English: Poor Tom's chilly .
Shakespearean: Poor Tom's a-cold .

English: Come back to my house with me .
Shakespearean: Go in with me .

English: I couldn't bear to obey all of your daughters ' harsh orders .
Shakespearean: My duty can not suffer To obey in all your daughters ' hard commands .

English: They commanded me to lock my doors and leave you out in this merciless storm , but I've come out here to find you and take you where there's warmth and food .
Shakespearean: Though their injunction be to bar my doors And let this tyrannous night take hold upon you , Yet have I ventured to come seek you out And bring you where both fire and food is ready .

English: First let me talk with this philosopher here. ,
Shakespearean: First let me talk with this philosopher. ,

English: Now get out of here !
Shakespearean: Away !

English: I swear by Jupiter I'll never revoke this punishment .
Shakespearean: By Jupiter , This shall not be revoked .

English: Farewell , King .
Shakespearean: Why , fare thee well , King .

English: Here are the rulers of France and Burgundy , my lord .
Shakespearean: Here's France and Burgundy , my noble lord .

English: My lord the ruler of Burgundy , I'll speak to you first .
Shakespearean: My lord of Burgundy .

English: You've been competing with this king for my daughter .
Shakespearean: We first address towards you , who with this king Hath rivaled for our daughter .

English: Let me ask you something in private .
Shakespearean: Let me ask you one word in private .

English: Can you blame him ?
Shakespearean: Canst thou blame him ?

English: His daughters want to kill him .
Shakespearean: His daughters seek his death .

English: Ah , good old Kent said this would happen , that poor , banished man .
Shakespearean: Ah , that good Kent , He said it would be thus , poor banished man .

English: You say the king is losing his mind .
Shakespearean: Thou say'st the king grows mad .

English: Let me tell you , my friend , I'm almost insane myself .
Shakespearean: I'll tell thee , friend , I am almost mad myself .

English: I had a son , whom I've legally disowned .
Shakespearean: I had a son , Now outlawed from my blood .

English: He tried to kill me recently , very recently .
Shakespearean: He sought my life , But lately , very late .

English: I loved him , as much as any father ever loved his son .
Shakespearean: I loved him , friend , No father his son dearer .

English: What a storm !
Shakespearean: What a night's this !

English: Excuse me , sir. , Tom's chilly .
Shakespearean: O , cry your mercy , sir. , Tom's a-cold .

English: Stay warm .
Shakespearean: Keep thee warm .

English: Come on , let's all go inside .
Shakespearean: Come let's in all .

English: This way , my lord .
Shakespearean: This way , my lord .

English: Come on , my dear Greek philosopher .
Shakespearean: Come , good Athenian .

English: I'll get my revenge before I leave this house .
Shakespearean: I will have my revenge ere I depart his house .

English: I'm afraid to think how I'll be criticized for letting my natural affection for my father give way to my loyalty to you .
Shakespearean: How , my lord , I may be censured , that nature thus gives way to loyalty , something fears me to think of .

English: Now I realize your brother tried to kill your father not just because your brother is an evil man , but because your father deserved it by being wicked himself .
Shakespearean: I now perceive it was not altogether your brother's evil disposition made him seek his death , but a provoking merit set awork by a reprovable badness in himself .

English: How unlucky am I , having to apologize for doing the right thing !
Shakespearean: How malicious is my fortune , that I must repent to be just !

English: Come with me to see the duchess .
Shakespearean: Go with me to the duchess .

English: If this letter's right , you've got a lot to deal with .
Shakespearean: If the matter of this paper be certain , you have mighty business in hand .

English: Right or not , it's made you the Earl of Gloucester .
Shakespearean: True or false , it hath made thee Earl of Gloucester .

English: I put my trust in you .
Shakespearean: I will lay trust upon thee , and thou shalt find a dearer father in my love .

English: It's better here than outside .
Shakespearean: Here is better than the open air .

English: Be happy about it .
Shakespearean: Take it thankfully .

English: I'll do what I can to make you even more comfortable .
Shakespearean: I will piece out the comfort with what addition I can .

English: I won't be gone long .
Shakespearean: I will not be long from you .

English: He can't bear his grief and so he's losing his mind .
Shakespearean: All the power of his wits have given way to his impatience .

English: May God reward you for your kindness !
Shakespearean: The gods reward your kindness !

English: He's a king , a king !
Shakespearean: A king , a king !

English: No , he's an ordinary guy who 's got a gentleman for a son , since someone would have to be crazy to let his son become a gentleman before he's achieved that distinction himself .
Shakespearean: No , he's a yeoman that has a gentleman to his son , for he's a mad yeoman that sees his son a gentleman before him .

English: I see Regan and Goneril in hell , A thousand hissing devils with sizzling red pitchforks come up to them !
Shakespearean: To have a thousand with red burning spits Come hissing in upon 'em !

English: The nasty devil's biting my butt .
Shakespearean: The foul fiend bites my back .

English: I'll do it .
Shakespearean: It shall be done .

English: The devil sings like a nightingale to haunt Poor Tom .
Shakespearean: The foul fiend haunts Poor Tom in the voice of a nightingale .

English: The demon Hoppedance is in Tom's belly , crying for some fish to eat .
Shakespearean: Hoppedance cries in Tom's belly for two white herring .

English: Stop whining , devil .
Shakespearean: Croak not , black angel .

English: I've got no food to give you .
Shakespearean: I have no food for thee .

English: Let's have the evidence .
Shakespearean: Sit you too .

English: Let's give a fair verdict .
Shakespearean: Let us deal justly .

English: There she is .
Shakespearean: I here take my oath before this honorable assembly , she kicked the poor king her father .

English: Come here , ma'am .
Shakespearean: Come hither , mistress .

English: Is your name Goneril ?
Shakespearean: Is your name Goneril ?

English: She can't deny it .
Shakespearean: She can not deny it .

English: And here's Regan , whose grotesque face betrays her twisted heart .
Shakespearean: And here's another , whose warped looks proclaim What store her heart is made on .

English: Stop her !
Shakespearean: Stop her there !

English: Fire !
Shakespearean: Arms , arms , sword , fire , corruption in the place !

English: You corrupt judge , why did you let her escape ?
Shakespearean: False justicer , why hast thou let her 'scape ?

English: Bless your heart .
Shakespearean: They'll mar my counterfeiting .

English: Look at the three little dogs , Tray , Blanch , and Sweetheart , all barking at me .
Shakespearean: The little dogs and all , Tray , Blanch , and Sweetheart , see , they bark at me .

English: Tom will chase them off. , Go away , you mongrels !
Shakespearean: Tom will throw his head at them. , Avaunt , you curs !

English: Whether you bite to kill , Mastiff , greyhound , or ugly mutt ,
Shakespearean: Tooth that poisons if it bite , Mastiff , greyhound , mongrel grim ,

English: Hound or spaniel , bitch or dog , Whether your tail is short or curly , Tom will make you cry and wail .
Shakespearean: Hound or spaniel , brach or him , Bobtail tyke or trundle-tail , Tom will make them weep and wail .

English: With one little toss of his head , He can scare you off for good .
Shakespearean: For with throwing thus my head , Dogs leap the hatch , and all are fled .

English: Whether your mouth is black or white , Do-dee , dee-dee da .
Shakespearean: Be thy mouth or black or white , Do-de , de-de .

English: Stop !
Shakespearean: Cessez !

English: Run off , go visit fairs and festivals !
Shakespearean: Come , march to wakes and fairs and market towns .

English: Poor Tom , your cup is empty .
Shakespearean: Poor Tom , thy horn is dry .

English: Is there any natural cause for hardening of the heart ?
Shakespearean: Is there any cause in nature that makes these hard hearts ?

English: Please lie down and rest a while , my lord .
Shakespearean: Now , good my lord , lie here and rest awhile .

English: Be quiet , be quiet .
Shakespearean: Make no noise , make no noise .

English: Draw the curtains , just like that .
Shakespearean: Draw the curtains , so , so , so .

English: We'll have supper in the morning .
Shakespearean: We'll go to supper i ' th ' morning .

English: That's right .
Shakespearean: So , so , so .

English: And I'll go to bed at noon .
Shakespearean: And I'll go to bed at noon .

English: He's here , sir , but please don't bother him .
Shakespearean: Here , sir , but trouble him not .

English: He's out of his right mind .
Shakespearean: His wits are gone .

English: Please get him , my friend , I beg you .
Shakespearean: Good friend , I prithee , take him in thy arms .

English: Put
Shakespearean: There is a litter ready .

English: Carry your master out .
Shakespearean: Come , help to bear thy master .

English: Come on , come on .
Shakespearean: Come , come , away .

English: When we see that our betters have the same problems we do , we can almost forget our own misery .
Shakespearean: When we our betters see bearing our woes , We scarcely think our miseries our foes .

English: The person who suffers alone suffers the most .
Shakespearean: Who alone suffers , suffers most i ' th ' mind , Leaving free things and happy shows behind .

English: Companions in sorrow alleviate our grief .
Shakespearean: But then the mind much sufferance doth o'erskip When grief hath mates and bearing fellowship .

English: Let's go , Tom .
Shakespearean: Tom , away !

English: Whatever else happens tonight , I hope the king escapes safely !
Shakespearean: What will hap more tonight , safe 'scape the king !

English: Lurk out of sight .
Shakespearean: Lurk , lurk .

English: Hang him immediately .
Shakespearean: Hang him instantly .

English: Gouge out his eyes !
Shakespearean: Pluck out his eyes .

English: Leave him to my wrath. , Edmund , go with my sister-in-law .
Shakespearean: Leave him to my displeasure. , Edmund , keep you our sister company .

English: You shouldn't have to see the punishment we inflict on your father .
Shakespearean: The revenges we are bound to take upon your traitorous father are not fit for your beholding .

English: Tell the Duke of Albany to prepare for war immediately .
Shakespearean: Advise the duke where you are going , to a most festinate preparation .

English: We will do the same .
Shakespearean: We are bound to the like .

English: We'll keep the lines of communication open between us .
Shakespearean: Our posts shall be swift and intelligent betwixt us. , Farewell , dear sister .

English: Hello .
Shakespearean: How now ?

English: Where's the king ?
Shakespearean: Where's the king ?

English: Lord Gloucester has helped him leave .
Shakespearean: My lord of Gloucester hath conveyed him hence .

English: Thirty-five or thirty-six of his knights met him at the gate , and together with some others they've set off for Dover , where they claim to have powerful friends .
Shakespearean: Some five or six and thirty of his knights , Hot questrists after him , met him at gate , Who with some other of the lord's dependants Are gone with him towards Dover , where they boast To have well-armed friends .

English: Prepare the horses for your lady .
Shakespearean: Get horses for your mistress .

English: Goodbye , my sweet lord. , Goodbye , my sister .
Shakespearean: Farewell , sweet lord , and sister .

English: Goodbye , Edmund .
Shakespearean: Edmund , farewell .

English: Go find the traitor Gloucester .
Shakespearean: Go seek the traitor Gloucester .

English: Tie him up like a thief and bring him here to me .
Shakespearean: Pinion him like a thief , bring him before us .

English: That's him .
Shakespearean: Ingrateful fox , 'tis he .

English: Tie up his withered old arms .
Shakespearean: Bind fast his corky arms .

English: What are you doing ?
Shakespearean: What mean your graces ?

English: My friends , remember that you're my guests here .
Shakespearean: Good my friends , consider You are my guests .

English: Don't play any nasty tricks on me .
Shakespearean: Do me no foul play , friends .

English: Tie him up , I tell you .
Shakespearean: Bind him , I say .

English: Your highness , I want nothing more than what you've already offered .
Shakespearean: Most royal majesty , I crave no more than hath your highness offered .

English: I know you'll offer nothing less than that .
Shakespearean: Nor will you tender less .

English: There she is , over there .
Shakespearean: Sir , there she stands .

English: I don't know what to say .
Shakespearean: I know no answer .

English: So do you take her or leave her ?
Shakespearean: Sir , will you , with those infirmities she owes , Unfriended , new adopted to our hate , Dowered with our curse and strangered with our oath , Take her or leave her ?

English: Then leave her , sir .
Shakespearean: Then leave her , sir , for by the power that made me , I tell you all her wealth .

English: Tie him up harder. , You filthy traitor !
Shakespearean: Hard , hard. , O filthy traitor !

English: I'm not a traitor , unfair lady .
Shakespearean: Unmerciful lady as you are , I'm none .

English: Tie him to this chair. , You'll see , criminal , By the gods , it's disgraceful for you to pull my beard .
Shakespearean: To this chair bind him. , Villain , thou shalt find , By the kind gods , 'tis most ignobly done To pluck me by the beard .

English: As old and white-haired as you are , and you're such a traitor ?
Shakespearean: So white , and such a traitor ?

English: Wicked woman , these white hairs you're pulling off my chin will come to life and accuse you of wrong-doing .
Shakespearean: Naughty lady , These hairs which thou dost ravish from my chin Will quicken and accuse thee .

English: You are my guests .
Shakespearean: I am your host .

English: This is no way to treat a host who has welcomed you into his house .
Shakespearean: With robbers ' hands my hospitable favors You should not ruffle thus .

English: What do you think you're doing ?
Shakespearean: What will you do ?

English: Tell us about the letters that you got from France .
Shakespearean: Come , sir , what letters had you late from France ?

English: Get to the point , since we already know the truth .
Shakespearean: Be simple-answered , for we know the truth .

English: And what's your connection with the traitors who landed in our kingdom recently ?
Shakespearean: And what confederacy have you with the traitors Late footed in the kingdom ?

English: The ones you've sent our lunatic king to .
Shakespearean: To whose hands You have sent the lunatic king .

English: Tell us .
Shakespearean: Speak .

English: It came from a neutral party , not from someone opposed to you .
Shakespearean: I have a letter guessingly set down , Which came from one that's of a neutral heart , And not from one opposed .

English: How clever of you .
Shakespearean: Cunning .

English: Clever lies .
Shakespearean: And false .

English: Where have you sent the king ?
Shakespearean: Where hast thou sent the king ?

English: To Dover .
Shakespearean: To Dover .

English: Why Dover ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore to Dover ?

English: Weren't you ordered , on penalty of , Why Dover ? , Let him answer that question first .
Shakespearean: Wast thou not charged at peril , Wherefore to Dover ? , Let him first answer that .

English: I'm backed into a corner with nowhere to run .
Shakespearean: I am tied to th ' stake , and I must stand the course .

English: Why Dover ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore to Dover , sir ?

English: Because I didn't want to watch while you gouged out his poor old eyes with your cruel fingernails , or while your vicious sister sank her fangs into his sacred flesh .
Shakespearean: Because I would not see thy cruel nails Pluck out his poor old eyes , nor thy fierce sister In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs .

English: You left him out in the storm in the black night , bareheaded , a storm so terrible that if it had happened at sea , the waters would have risen up and extinguished the fire burning in the stars .
Shakespearean: The sea , with such a storm as his bare head In hell-black night endured , would have buoyed up , And quenched the stelled fires .

English: And the poor old man just wept , mixing his tears with the rain .
Shakespearean: Yet poor old heart , he holp the heavens to rain .

English: If wolves had been howling outside your gate at the heart of that storm , you would've told your doorman to let them in , despite all the cruelties you inflict on the world .
Shakespearean: If wolves had at thy gate howled that stern time , Thou shouldst have said , "Good porter , turn the key , " All cruels else subscribed .

English: But soon I'll see the gods punish you for your lack of respect to your father .
Shakespearean: But I shall see The winged vengeance overtake such children .

English: You won't be seeing anything. , Hold his chair still , men. , I'm going to put my foot on his eyes .
Shakespearean: See" 't shalt thou never. , Fellows , hold the chair. , Upon these eyes of thine I'll set my foot .

English: Oh , help me , anyone who wants to live long !
Shakespearean: He that will think to live till he be old , Give me some help !

English: Oh , so cruel !
Shakespearean: O cruel !

English: Oh dear gods !
Shakespearean: O you gods !

English: Now he's a little crooked .
Shakespearean: One side will mock another , th ' other too .

English: I've served you since childhood , but I've never done you a better service than telling you to stop .
Shakespearean: But better service have I never done you Than now to bid you hold .

English: What's this , you dog ?
Shakespearean: How now , you dog ?

English: I am willing to fight you if I must .
Shakespearean: If you did wear a beard upon your chin , I'd shake it on this quarrel .

English: What do you mean by all this ?
Shakespearean: What do you mean ?

English: Come on then .
Shakespearean: Nay then , come on , and take the chance of anger .

English: I am dying ! , My lord , you still have one eye left to see Cornwall punished .
Shakespearean: Oh , I am slain ! , My lord , you have one eye left To see some mischief on him .

English: Oh !
Shakespearean: Oh !

English: Where's your sparkle now ?
Shakespearean: Where is thy luster now ?

English: Where's my son Edmund ?
Shakespearean: Where's my son Edmund ?

English: Wrong , evil traitor .
Shakespearean: Out , treacherous villain !

English: You're appealing to a son who hates you .
Shakespearean: Thou call'st on him that hates thee .

English: He's too good to have any compassion for you .
Shakespearean: It was he That made the overture of thy treasons to us , Who is too good to pity thee .

English: What a fool I've been !
Shakespearean: O my follies !

English: This means I've mistreated Edgar .
Shakespearean: Then Edgar was abused .

English: He can sniff his way to Dover .
Shakespearean: Go thrust him out at gates , and let him smell His way to Dover .

English: I'm wounded .
Shakespearean: I have received a hurt .

English: Follow me , madam. , Throw the blind traitor outside .
Shakespearean: Follow me , lady. , Turn out that eyeless villain .

English: And throw this dead peasant into the manure pit. , Regan , I'm bleeding .
Shakespearean: Throw this slave Upon the dunghill. , Regan , I bleed apace .

English: It's a bad time for such an injury .
Shakespearean: Untimely comes this hurt .

English: Give me your arm .
Shakespearean: Give me your arm .

English: If our criminal master gets off free , I won't care what happens to me anymore .
Shakespearean: I'll never care what wickedness I do , If this man come to good .

English: If she lives a long and happy life , then all women may as well turn into monsters .
Shakespearean: If she live long , And in the end meet the old course of death , Women will all turn monsters .

English: Let's follow the old earl , and get that crazy Tom to take him wherever he wants to go .
Shakespearean: Let's follow the old earl , and get the Bedlam To lead him where he would .

English: As a wandering lunatic , he can do whatever he wants .
Shakespearean: His roguish madness Allows itself to any thing .

English: Go ahead .
Shakespearean: Go thou .

English: I'll get some cloth and egg whites to bandage his bleeding face .
Shakespearean: I'll fetch some flax and whites of eggs To apply to his bleeding face .

English: Heaven help him !
Shakespearean: Now heaven help him !

English: At the bottom , any change is for the better .
Shakespearean: The lamentable change is from the best ; The worst returns to laughter .

English: So I welcome this wind freely .
Shakespearean: Welcome , then , Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace !

English: But who is this ?
Shakespearean: But who comes here ?

English: My father , led by a poor peasant ?
Shakespearean: My father , poorly led ?

English: Oh , life is full of surprises !
Shakespearean: World , world , O world !

English: We age and die because they wear us out .
Shakespearean: But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee , Life would not yield to age .

English: I've rented land from you and your father for eighty years .
Shakespearean: I have been your tenant and your father's tenant these fourscore years .

English: Away , get out of here .
Shakespearean: Away , get thee away .

English: Leave me , my friend .
Shakespearean: Good friend , be gone .

English: But you can't see where you're going , sir .
Shakespearean: Alack , sir , you can not see your way .

English: I don't have anywhere to go , so I don't need to see .
Shakespearean: I have no way , and therefore want no eyes .

English: When I could see , I didn't always see clearly .
Shakespearean: I stumbled when I saw .

English: It's often the case that having something makes us spoiled , while not having it turns out to be advantageous .
Shakespearean: Full oft 'tis seen , Our means secure us and our mere defects Prove our commodities .

English: If I live long enough to touch you again , that would be as good as having my eyesight back .
Shakespearean: O dear son Edgar , The food of thy abused father's wrath , Might I but live to see thee in my touch , I'd say I had eyes again !

English: Who's that ?
Shakespearean: How now ?

English: Who's there ?
Shakespearean: Who's there ?

English: Is it a beggar ?
Shakespearean: Madman and beggar too .

English: I was reminded of my son , even though I despised my son at that time .
Shakespearean: My son Came then into my mind , and yet my mind Was then scarce friends with him .

English: Now I know better .
Shakespearean: I have heard more since .

English: Is that the naked guy ?
Shakespearean: Is that the naked fellow ?

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my lord .

English: But sir , he's crazy .
Shakespearean: Alack , sir , he is mad .

English: It's the tragedy of our times that lunatics must lead the blind .
Shakespearean: Tis the time's plague when madmen lead the blind .

English: Do as I asked you .
Shakespearean: Do as I bid thee .

English: Or rather , do what you feel like doing .
Shakespearean: Or rather , do thy pleasure .

English: Hey , naked guy , Poor Tom's chilly .
Shakespearean: Sirrah , naked fellow , Poor Tom's a-cold .

English: Come here , man .
Shakespearean: Come hither , fellow .

English: Do you know the way to Dover ?
Shakespearean: Know'st thou the way to Dover ?

English: Poor Tom has been scared out of his mind .
Shakespearean: Poor Tom hath been scared out of his good wits .

English: Bless you , master .
Shakespearean: So bless thee , master .

English: Yes , sir .
Shakespearean: Ay , master .

English: There's a cliff there that leans precariously over the deep sea .
Shakespearean: There is a cliff , whose high and bending head Looks fearfully in the confined deep .

English: Take me to the edge of it , and I'll reward all your troubles with something valuable .
Shakespearean: Bring me but to the very brim of it , And I'll repair the misery thou dost bear With something rich about me .

English: Once I'm there , I won't need a guide anymore .
Shakespearean: From that place I shall no leading need .

English: Give me your arm .
Shakespearean: Give me thy arm .

English: Poor Tom will take you there .
Shakespearean: Poor Tom shall lead thee .

English: Welcome , my lord .
Shakespearean: Welcome , my lord .

English: I'm surprised my bland husband didn't meet me on the way here .
Shakespearean: I marvel our mild husband Not met us on the way .

English: Where's your master ?
Shakespearean: Now , where's your master ?

English: But it'd take a miracle to make me believe she could do anything that horrible .
Shakespearean: Sure , her offense Must be of such unnatural degree That monsters it ( or your fore-vouched affection Fall into taint ) , which to believe of her Must be a faith that reason without miracle Could never plant in me .

English: Enough .
Shakespearean: Go to , go to .

English: It would've been better for you not to have been born at all than to displease me as you did .
Shakespearean: Better thou Hadst not been born than not t ' have pleased me better .

English: You mean this is the whole problem , that she is shy and hasn't said everything she means to say and do ? , My lord of Burgundy , what do you have to say to this lady ?
Shakespearean: Is it no more but this , a tardiness in nature Which often leaves the history unspoke That it intends to do ? , My lord of Burgundy , What say you to the lady ?

English: Love's not love when it gets mixed up with irrelevant outside matters .
Shakespearean: Love's not love When it is mingled with regards that stands Aloof from th ' entire point .

English: Will you marry her ?
Shakespearean: Will you have her ?

English: She herself is as valuable as any dowry could ever be .
Shakespearean: She is herself a dowry .

English: I'm at your service until death .
Shakespearean: Yours in the ranks of death .

English: My dear Gloucester !
Shakespearean: My most dear Gloucester !

English: What a man ! , especially compared to my husband .
Shakespearean: Oh , the difference of man and man !

English: Edmund , you deserve me to be your woman .
Shakespearean: To thee a woman's services are due .

English: There's a fool sharing my bed now .
Shakespearean: My fool usurps my body .

English: Ma'am , my master's coming .
Shakespearean: Madam , here comes my lord .

English: So you finally find me worthy of your attentions .
Shakespearean: I have been worth the whistle .

English: Goneril , you aren't worth the dust the wind blows in your face .
Shakespearean: O Goneril , You are not worth the dust which the rude wind Blows in your face .

English: I don't trust you .
Shakespearean: I fear your disposition .

English: You can't trust anyone who abuses her own father , her flesh and blood .
Shakespearean: That nature , which contemns its origin Can not be bordered certain in itself .

English: She will wither and come to a bad end .
Shakespearean: She that herself will sliver and disbranch From her material sap perforce must wither And come to deadly use .

English: Oh , shut up .
Shakespearean: No more .

English: Your words are idiotic .
Shakespearean: The text is foolish .

English: Bad people can't appreciate wisdom or goodness .
Shakespearean: Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile .

English: They only like things as bad as themselves .
Shakespearean: Filths savor but themselves .

English: What have you two sisters done ?
Shakespearean: What have you done ?

Shakespearean: Come , my fair Cordelia .

English: Sister , I have a lot to say about things that concern us both .
Shakespearean: Sister , it is not a little I have to say of what most nearly appertains to us both .

English: I think that our father will leave here tonight .
Shakespearean: I think our father will hence tonight .

English: Yes , I'm sure he will , to stay with you .
Shakespearean: That's most certain , and with you .

Shakespearean: Next month with us .

Shakespearean: You see how full of changes his age is .

English: He has always loved Cordelia best , and his bad judgment in disowning her now is obvious .
Shakespearean: He always loved our sister most , and with what poor judgment he hath now cast her off appears too grossly .

Shakespearean: Though that the queen on special cause is here , Her army is moved on .

Shakespearean: I thank you , sir .

Shakespearean: Let not my worser spirit tempt me again To die before you please .

Shakespearean: Now , good sir , what are you ?

Shakespearean: A most poor man made tame to fortune's blows , Who by the art of known and feeling sorrows Am pregnant to good pity .

English: May heaven bless you .

Shakespearean: That eyeless head of thine was first framed flesh To raise my fortunes .

Shakespearean: Thou old unhappy traitor , Briefly thyself remember .

Shakespearean: Now let thy friendly hand Put strength enough to 't .

Shakespearean: Wherefore , bold peasant , Darest thou support a published traitor ?

Shakespearean: Hence , Lest that th ' infection of his fortune take Like hold on thee .

Shakespearean: Let go his arm .

Shakespearean: Chill not let go , zir , without vurther 'casion .

Shakespearean: Let go , slave , or thou diest !

English: I'll knock your teeth out , sir .
Shakespearean: Chill pick your teeth , zir .

Shakespearean: Come , no matter vor your foins .

Shakespearean: If ever thou wilt thrive , bury my body .

Shakespearean: I am only sorry He had no other death's-man .

Shakespearean: Let our reciprocal vows be remembered .

Shakespearean: Come , father , I'll bestow you with a friend .

English: Please take them off .

Shakespearean: My boon I make it that you know me not Till time and I think meet .

Shakespearean: Then be 't so , my good lord. , How does the king ?

Shakespearean: Madam , sleeps still .

Shakespearean: Is he arrayed ?

Shakespearean: I doubt not of his temperance .

Shakespearean: Very well .

English: Please come closer. , Make the music louder , please !
Shakespearean: Please you , draw near. , Louder the music there !

English: Kind and dear princess !
Shakespearean: Kind and dear princess !

Shakespearean: Had you not been their father , these white flakes Did challenge pity of them .

Shakespearean: And wast thou fain , poor father , To hovel thee with swine and rogues forlorn In short and musty straw ?

Shakespearean: Alack , alack !

English: It's a wonder you didn't lose your life and your mind all at once. , He's waking up .
Shakespearean: Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once Had not concluded all. , He wakes .

Shakespearean: You do me wrong to take me out o ' th ' grave .

Shakespearean: Thou art a soul in bliss , but I am bound Upon a wheel of fire , that mine own tears Do scald like molten lead .

Shakespearean: I should ev'n die with pity To see another thus .

Shakespearean: Methinks I should know you , and know this man .

English: Now that he's old , we can expect to have to deal not only with his old character flaws , which have turned into deep-rooted habits , but also with the uncontrollable crabbiness that comes with old age .
Shakespearean: Then must we look from his age to receive not alone the imperfections of long-engrafted condition , but therewithal the unruly waywardness that infirm and choleric years bring with them .

English: We'll probably witness many more outbursts from him , like banishing Kent .
Shakespearean: Such unconstant starts are we like to have from him as this of Kent's banishment .

Shakespearean: There is further compliment of leave-taking between France and him .

Shakespearean: And we'll wear out In a walled prison packs and sects of great ones That ebb and flow by the moon .

Shakespearean: Take them away .

Shakespearean: With him I sent the queen , My reason all the same , and they are ready Tomorrow or at further space t ' appear Where you shall hold your session .

Shakespearean: The question of Cordelia and her father Requires a fitter place .

English: Again !

English: Again !

Shakespearean: Well then , Legitimate Edgar , I must have your land .

Shakespearean: All this done Upon the gad ? , Edmund , how now ?

Shakespearean: What news ?

Shakespearean: O , know , my name is lost .

Shakespearean: Yet am I noble as the adversary I come to cope withal .

Shakespearean: What's he that speaks for Edmund , Earl of Gloucester ?

English: still fight you and embed your lies back in your hellish heart. , Trumpets , blow !

Shakespearean: By th ' law of arms thou wast not bound to answer An unknown opposite .

English: Listen to my little story , and when it's done , oh , my heart will break !
Shakespearean: List a brief tale , And when 'tis told , oh , that my heart would burst !

English: To escape the decree condemning me
Shakespearean: The bloody proclamation to escape , That followed me so near , O our lives ' sweetness ,

English: I became his guide , I led him and begged for him , and kept him from suicide .

Shakespearean: Never , O fault ! , revealed myself unto him Until some half-hour past , when I was armed .

Shakespearean: But his flawed heart , Alack , too weak the conflict to support , 'Twixt two extremes of passion , joy and grief , Burst smilingly .

English: Your words have moved me , and maybe it'll do some good .

English: I'm almost ready to break down hearing this much .

English: This may have seemed like the pinnacle of sadness , but if I went on I could outdo it .
Shakespearean: This would have seemed a period To such as love not sorrow , but another To amplify too much would make much more And top extremity .

English: Then I heard the trumpets blow twice , and left him there in a trance .
Shakespearean: Twice then the trumpets sounded , And there I left him tranced .

English: But who was that man ?
Shakespearean: But who was this ?

English: It was Kent , sir , the exiled Kent , who , after the king treated him like an enemy of the state , put on a disguise and followed his king , carrying out tasks unworthy of even a slave .
Shakespearean: Kent , sir , the banished Kent , who in disguise Followed his enemy king and did him service Improper for a slave .

English: Help , help , oh , help !
Shakespearean: Help , help , O , help !

English: What kind of help do you need ?
Shakespearean: What kind of help ?

English: Say something , man !
Shakespearean: Speak , man .

English: What is that bloody knife ?
Shakespearean: What means that bloody knife ?

English: It's still warm from the cut .
Shakespearean: Tis hot , it smokes .

English: It was just removed from from the heart of , oh , she's dead !
Shakespearean: It came even from the heart of , oh , she's dead !

English: Who's dead ?
Shakespearean: Who dead ?

English: Speak , man .
Shakespearean: Speak , man .

English: Your wife , sir , your wife .
Shakespearean: Your lady , sir , your lady .

English: And her sister's dead too , poisoned by your wife .
Shakespearean: And her sister By her is poisoned .

English: She confessed .
Shakespearean: She confesses it .

English: I was engaged to both of them .
Shakespearean: I was contracted to them both .

English: All three of us will marry now in death .
Shakespearean: All three Now marry in an instant .

English: Here comes Kent .
Shakespearean: Here comes Kent .

English: I thought the king preferred the Duke of Albany to the Duke of Cornwall .
Shakespearean: I thought the king had more affected the Duke of Albany than Cornwall .

English: We used to think so too .
Shakespearean: It did always seem so to us .

English: But the way he's divided the kingdom recently , nobody can tell which of the dukes he favors more .
Shakespearean: But now in the division of the kingdom , it appears not which of the dukes he values most , for equalities are so weighed that curiosity in neither can make choice of either's moiety .

English: Yes , I've been responsible for his upbringing .
Shakespearean: His breeding , sir , hath been at my charge .

English: I've had to acknowledge that he's my son so many times that now I can do it without embarrassment .
Shakespearean: I have so often blushed to acknowledge him that now I am brazed to it .

English: Do you smell something naughty ?
Shakespearean: Do you smell a fault ?

English: Well , I wouldn't want to undo the naughtiness , since the boy turned out so well .
Shakespearean: I can not wish the fault undone , the issue of it being so proper .

English: But I have a legitimate son a few years older than this one , and I don't love him any more than I love my bastard .
Shakespearean: But I have , sir , a son by order of law , some year older than this , who yet is no dearer in my account .

English: Oh , is that Kent ?
Shakespearean: Oh , is this he ?

English: I've come to say farewell to my king and master .
Shakespearean: I am come To bid my king and master aye good night .

English: Isn't he here ?
Shakespearean: Is he not here ?

English: What an enormous thing for us to forget ! , Edmund , tell us , where's the king ?
Shakespearean: Great thing of us forgot ! , Speak , Edmund , where's the king ?

English: And where's Cordelia ? , Do you see this , Kent ?
Shakespearean: And where's Cordelia ? , Seest thou this object , Kent ?

English: Oh , why is this so ?
Shakespearean: Alack , why thus ?

English: Still , Edmund was beloved .
Shakespearean: Yet Edmund was beloved .

English: One of the sisters poisoned the other out of love for me , and then killed herself .
Shakespearean: The one the other poisoned for my sake , And after slew herself .

English: Apparently so. , Cover their faces .
Shakespearean: Even so. , Cover their faces .

English: I wish I could live longer .
Shakespearean: I pant for life .

English: I want to do a little good despite my evil nature .
Shakespearean: Some good I mean to do Despite of mine own nature .

English: Go quickly , hurry , to the castle , for I've given orders to have Lear and Cordelia killed .
Shakespearean: Quickly send , Be brief in it , to th ' castle , for my writ Is on the life of Lear and on Cordelia .

English: Hurry , send someone immediately !
Shakespearean: Nay , send in time !

English: Run , run , oh , run !
Shakespearean: Run , run , O , run !

English: Whom should we look for in the castle ? , Whose job is it ?
Shakespearean: To who , my lord ? , Who hath the office ?

English: Send something along to prove you're withdrawing the orders .
Shakespearean: Send Thy token of reprieve .

English: Good idea .
Shakespearean: Well thought on .

English: Take my sword .
Shakespearean: Take my sword .

English: The captain , give it to the captain .
Shakespearean: The captain , Give it the captain .

English: Run as if your life depended on it .
Shakespearean: Haste thee for thy life .

English: My wife and I ordered him to hang Cordelia in prison and then to make it look as if she committed suicide in despair .
Shakespearean: He hath commission from thy wife and me To hang Cordelia in the prison and To lay the blame upon her own despair , That she fordid herself .

English: Heaven help her ! , Get him out of here for now .
Shakespearean: The gods defend her ! , hear him hence awhile .

English: Howl , howl , howl , howl !
Shakespearean: Howl , howl , howl , howl !

English: Oh , you men are made of stone !
Shakespearean: Oh , you are men of stones .

English: If I were you with eyes and a tongue to speak with , I'd crack heaven wide open with my laments !
Shakespearean: Had I your tongues and eyes , I'd use them so That heaven's vault should crack .

English: She's gone forever .
Shakespearean: She's gone forever .

English: I know how to tell when someone is alive or dead .
Shakespearean: I know when one is dead and when one lives .

English: She's as dead as the cold ground .
Shakespearean: She's dead as earth .

English: Let me borrow a mirror .
Shakespearean: Lend me a looking-glass .

English: If her breath steams up the glass , then she's alive .
Shakespearean: If that her breath will mist or stain the stone , Why then , she lives .

English: Or just a foretaste of it ?
Shakespearean: Or image of that horror ?

English: Let the world collapse around us .
Shakespearean: Fall and cease .

English: This feather moved because of her breath .
Shakespearean: This feather stirs .

English: She's alive .
Shakespearean: She lives .

English: If that's true , it makes up for all the sorrows I've ever known .
Shakespearean: If it be so , It is a chance which does redeem all sorrows That ever I have felt .

English: Oh , my good master !
Shakespearean: O my good master !

English: Please , go away .
Shakespearean: Prithee , away .

English: It's noble Kent , your friend .
Shakespearean: Tis noble Kent , your friend .

English: Curse you all , you're all murderers and traitors !
Shakespearean: A plague upon you , murderers , traitors all !

English: I could have saved her .
Shakespearean: I might have saved her .

English: Now she's gone forever. , Cordelia , Cordelia , stay a while .
Shakespearean: Now she's gone for ever. , Cordelia , Cordelia , stay a little .

English: Ha ?
Shakespearean: Ha ?

English: It's true , my lords , he did .
Shakespearean: Tis true , my lords , he did .

English: Didn't I ?
Shakespearean: Did I not , fellow ?

English: But I'm old now , and suffering has weakened me .
Shakespearean: I am old now , And these same crosses spoil me .

English: My vision is dull .
Shakespearean: This a dull sight .

English: Aren't you Kent ?
Shakespearean: Are you not Kent ?

English: That's me .
Shakespearean: The same .

English: Your servant Kent .
Shakespearean: Your servant Kent .

English: Where's your servant
Shakespearean: Where is your servant Caius ?

English: He's a good fellow , I can tell you that much .
Shakespearean: He's a good fellow , I can tell you that .

English: He's dead and rotting in the dirt now .
Shakespearean: He's dead and rotten .

English: No , my lord , that was me .
Shakespearean: No , my good lord .

English: I'm the one who , I'll get right on that .
Shakespearean: I am the very man , I'll see that straight .

English: followed you on your sad wanderings , ever since your bad luck began .
Shakespearean: That from your first of difference and decay Have followed your sad steps .

English: Nice to see you .
Shakespearean: You're welcome hither .

English: It was me , no one else .
Shakespearean: Nor no man else .

English: Everything is gloomy , dark , and dreadful .
Shakespearean: All's cheerless , dark , and deadly .

English: Your eldest daughters destroyed themselves and died in despair .
Shakespearean: Your eldest daughters have fordone themselves , And desperately are dead .

English: Yes , I think that's true .
Shakespearean: Ay , so I think .

English: He doesn't know what he's saying .
Shakespearean: He knows not what he says , and vain it is That we present us to him .

English: Edmund is dead , my lord .
Shakespearean: Edmund is dead , my lord .

English: As for me , I'm surrendering all my power over to him , giving him absolute authority for the rest of his life .
Shakespearean: For us , we will resign During the life of this old majesty To him our absolute power .

English: And my poor He's fainted. , My lord , my lord !
Shakespearean: He faints ! , My lord , my lord !

English: Don't disturb his soul .
Shakespearean: Vex not his ghost .

English: Let it go up to heaven .
Shakespearean: O , let him pass .

English: Oh , he's really gone .
Shakespearean: Oh , he is gone indeed .

English: What's amazing is how long he lasted .
Shakespearean: The wonder is he hath endured so long .

English: Carry them away .
Shakespearean: Bear them from hence .

English: Our business now is mourning and grief .
Shakespearean: Our present business Is to general woe .

English: Why are you hiding that letter ?
Shakespearean: Why so earnestly seek you to put up that letter ?

English: I don't have any news to report , my lord .
Shakespearean: I know no news , my lord .

English: What's that paper you were reading ?
Shakespearean: What paper were you reading ?

English: It's nothing , my lord .
Shakespearean: Nothing , my lord .

English: No ?
Shakespearean: No ?

English: Then why did you have to stick it in your pocket in such a hurry ?
Shakespearean: What needed , then , that terrible dispatch of it into your pocket ?

English: If it were nothing , you wouldn't need to hide it .
Shakespearean: The quality of nothing hath not such need to hide itself .

English: Please , sir , I beg you .
Shakespearean: I beseech you , sir , pardon me .

English: It's a letter from my brother that I haven't finished reading yet .
Shakespearean: It is a letter from my brother that I have not all o'er-read .

English: Give me that letter , sir .
Shakespearean: Give me the letter , sir .

English: Now I'll offend you whether I give it to you or not .
Shakespearean: I shall offend , either to detain or give it .

English: The problem is in what the letter says , as far as I can tell .
Shakespearean: The contents , as in part I understand them , are to blame .

English: I hope for my brother's sake that he just wrote it to test my honor .
Shakespearean: I hope , for my brother's justification , he wrote this but as an essay or taste of my virtue .

English: I will have to go on a journey to death soon , sir .
Shakespearean: I have a journey , sir , shortly to go .

English: My master's calling me .
Shakespearean: My master calls me .

English: I can't say no .
Shakespearean: I must not say no .

English: We must remember the gravity of this sad day .
Shakespearean: The weight of this sad time we must obey .

English: We should speak what we feel , not what we ought to say .
Shakespearean: Speak what we feel , not what we ought to say .

English: Come talk to me about this .
Shakespearean: Come to me , that of this I may speak more .

English: If our father were dead you'd receive half of his revenue forever , and you'd have my undying love , Edgar." Hmm , what's this , a conspiracy ?
Shakespearean: If our father would sleep till I waked him , you should enjoy half his revenue forever , and live the beloved of your brother , Edgar." Hum , conspiracy ?

English: How could he have even entertained these thoughts in his heart ?
Shakespearean: Had he a hand to write this , a heart and brain to breed it in ?

English: How did you get this letter ?
Shakespearean: When came this to you ?

English: Who delivered it ?
Shakespearean: Who brought it ?

English: Nobody delivered it , my lord .
Shakespearean: It was not brought me , my lord .

English: That's what's clever about it .
Shakespearean: There's the cunning of it .

English: It was tossed into the window of my room .
Shakespearean: I found it thrown in at the casement of my closet .

English: You're sure the handwriting is your brother's ?
Shakespearean: You know the character to be your brother's ?

English: If he'd written nice things , I'd swear yes right away .
Shakespearean: If the matter were good , my lord , I durst swear it were his .

English: But as it stands , I wish I could believe it wasn't .
Shakespearean: But in respect of that , I would fain think it were not .

English: But it is his handwriting ?
Shakespearean: It is his .

English: It's his handwriting , my lord , but I hope he didn't mean what he wrote .
Shakespearean: It is his hand , my lord , but I hope his heart is not in the contents .

English: Has he ever tested out these ideas on you before ?
Shakespearean: Has he never before sounded you in this business ?

English: Never , my lord .
Shakespearean: Never , my lord .

English: But I've often heard him argue that when sons are at their prime and their fathers are declining , the sons should be their fathers ' guardians and manage their fathers ' money .
Shakespearean: But I have heard him oft maintain it to be fit that , sons at perfect age and fathers declined , the father should be as ward to the son , and the son manage his revenue .

English: Oh , what a villain !
Shakespearean: O villain , villain !

English: That's just what he said in the letter .
Shakespearean: His very opinion in the letter !

English: Evil villain !
Shakespearean: Abhorred villain !

English: Go look for him .
Shakespearean: Go , sirrah , seek him .

English: I'll arrest him .
Shakespearean: I'll apprehend him .

English: Horrid villain !
Shakespearean: Abominable villain !

English: Where is he ?
Shakespearean: Where is he ?

English: I'm not sure , my lord .
Shakespearean: I do not well know , my lord .

English: I'll bet my life that he only wrote this letter to gauge my love for you , and for no other reason .
Shakespearean: I dare pawn down my life for him that he hath wrote this to feel my affection to your honor and to no other pretense of danger .

English: Do you think so ?
Shakespearean: Think you so ?

English: He can't possibly be such a monster , And I'm sure he isn't .
Shakespearean: He can not be such a monster , Nor is not , sure .

English: toward his own father who loves him so completely .
Shakespearean: To his father , that so tenderly and entirely loves him .

English: Oh , God !
Shakespearean: Heaven and earth !

English: Edmund , go find him .
Shakespearean: Edmund , seek him out , wind me into him , I pray you .

English: I'll find him right away , sir , and carry out the business as well as I can .
Shakespearean: I will seek him , sir , presently , convey the business as I shall find means , and acquaint you withal .

English: These recent eclipses of the sun and moon don't bode well for us .
Shakespearean: These late eclipses in the sun and moon portend no good to us .

English: Though science can explain them away , disasters still come after eclipses .
Shakespearean: Though the wisdom of nature can reason it thus and thus , yet nature finds itself scourged by the sequent effects .

English: Love cools off , friendships break up , and brothers become enemies .
Shakespearean: Love cools , friendship falls off , brothers divide , in cities

English: break out , civil war erupts , kings are betrayed , and the bond between father and son snaps .
Shakespearean: mutinies , in countries discord , in palaces treason , and the bond cracked 'twixt son and father .

English: This wicked son of mine confirms the prediction , son against father .
Shakespearean: This villain of mine comes under the prediction , there's son against father .

English: The king acts unnaturally , father against child .
Shakespearean: The king falls from bias of nature , there's father against child .

English: We've seen the best our age has to offer .
Shakespearean: We have seen the best of our time .

English: Conspiracies , fakery , betrayal , and disorder are all that's left until we die .
Shakespearean: Machinations , hollowness , treachery , and all ruinous disorders follow us disquietly to our graves .

English: Find out what this villainous Edgar is thinking , Edmund .
Shakespearean: Find out this villain , Edmund .

English: You won't lose any respect .
Shakespearean: It shall lose thee nothing .

English: Just do it carefully. , And to think that the noble and loyal Kent has been banished , for the crime of telling the truth !
Shakespearean: Do it carefully. , And the noble and true-hearted Kent banished , his offense honesty !

English: It's strange , strange .
Shakespearean: Tis strange , strange .

English: This is a classic example of the idiocy of the world : when we're down and out , often because of our own excesses , we put all the blame on the sun , the moon , and the stars , as if they forced us to be bad , or the heavens compelled us to be villainous or stupid .
Shakespearean: This is the excellent foppery of the world that when we are sick in fortune , often the surfeit of our own behavior , we make guilty of our disasters the sun , the moon , and the stars , as if we were villains by necessity , fools by heavenly compulsion , knaves , thieves , and treachers by spherical predominance , drunkards , liars , and adulterers by an enforced obedience of planetary influence , and all that we are evil in by a divine thrusting-on .

English: My father and mother coupled when the demonic moon was descending , and I was born under the Big Dipper , so it's inevitable that I'm rude and oversexed .
Shakespearean: My father compounded with my mother under the dragon's tail and my nativity was under Ursa Major , so that it follows I am rough and lecherous .

English: I would have been what I am even if the most virginal star in the heavens had twinkled at my conception .
Shakespearean: Fut , I should have been that I am , had the maidenliest star in the firmament twinkled on my bastardizing .

English: Fa , sol , la , mi .
Shakespearean: Fa , sol , la , mi .

English: Hello , brother Edmund .
Shakespearean: How now , brother Edmund ?

English: What are you thinking about so seriously ?
Shakespearean: What serious contemplation are you in ?

English: How long have you believed in astrology ?
Shakespearean: How long have you been a sectary astronomical ?

English: Come on .
Shakespearean: Come , come .

English: When was the last time you saw my father ?
Shakespearean: When saw you my father last ?

English: Why , last night .
Shakespearean: Why , the night gone by .

English: Did you speak to him ?
Shakespearean: Spake you with him ?

English: Yes , we talked for a couple of hours .
Shakespearean: Ay , two hours together .

English: Did you leave on good terms ?
Shakespearean: Parted you in good terms ?

English: Did he express any dissatisfaction with you , either in his words or his face ?
Shakespearean: Found you no displeasure in him by word or countenance ?

English: No , none at all .
Shakespearean: None at all .

English: Some villain has told lies about me .
Shakespearean: Some villain hath done me wrong .

English: That's what I'm afraid of .
Shakespearean: That's my fear .

English: I suggest you lay low until his rage cools a little .
Shakespearean: I pray you , have a continent forbearance till the speed of his rage goes slower .

English: In the meantime , come home with me , and when the time is right I'll take you to talk to him .
Shakespearean: And as I say , retire with me to my lodging , from whence I will fitly bring you to hear my lord speak .

English: Please go .
Shakespearean: Pray ye , go .

English: Here's my key .
Shakespearean: There's my key .

English: If you go outside , arm yourself .
Shakespearean: If you do stir abroad , go armed .

English: Arm myself ?
Shakespearean: Armed , brother ?

English: Brother , I'm giving you good advice .
Shakespearean: Brother , I advise you to the best .

English: Arm yourself .
Shakespearean: Go armed .

English: Now please go .
Shakespearean: Pray you , away .

English: Will I hear from you soon ?
Shakespearean: Shall I hear from you anon ?

English: I'll help you through this business .
Shakespearean: I do serve you in this business .

English: A gullible father and a brother who's so innocent that he can't suspect anyone else of wanting to hurt him , these are the two fools I need for my plan to work .
Shakespearean: A credulous father , and a brother noble , Whose nature is so far from doing harms That he suspects none , on whose foolish honesty My practices ride easy .

English: I know exactly how to proceed .
Shakespearean: I see the business .

English: If I can't have an estate by birthright , then I'll get it by being clever .
Shakespearean: Let me , if not by birth , have lands by wit .

English: Any trick that works is good for me .
Shakespearean: All with me's meet that I can fashion fit .

English: Did my father hit one of my attendants for scolding his fool ?
Shakespearean: Did my father strike my gentleman For chiding of his fool ?

English: Yes , ma'am .
Shakespearean: Ay , madam .

English: He constantly offends me .
Shakespearean: By day and night he wrongs me .

English: Every hour he comes out with some horrible new offense that puts us all on edge .
Shakespearean: Every hour He flashes into one gross crime or other That sets us all at odds .

English: I won't stand for it .
Shakespearean: I'll not endure it .

English: His knights are getting out of control , and he himself reprimands us about every little detail .
Shakespearean: His knights grow riotous , and himself upbraids us On every trifle .

English: When he comes back from hunting , I'm not going to speak to him .
Shakespearean: When he returns from hunting , I will not speak with him .

English: Tell him I'm sick .
Shakespearean: Say I am sick .

English: And if you're not as attentive in serving him as you used to be , that'll be good .
Shakespearean: If you come slack of former services , You shall do well .

English: I'll take responsibility for it .
Shakespearean: The fault of it I'll answer .

English: He's coming , ma'am .
Shakespearean: He's coming , madam .

English: I hear him .
Shakespearean: I hear him .

English: Be as lazy and neglectful as you like around him , you and the other servants .
Shakespearean: Put on what weary negligence you please , You and your fellow servants .

English: If he doesn't like it , he can go live with my sister .
Shakespearean: If he distaste it , let him to our sister , Whose mind and mine I know in that are one , Not to be overruled .

English: That useless old man still thinks he can wield all the powers he's given away .
Shakespearean: Idle old man That still would manage those authorities That he hath given away !

English: I swear , old fools become like babies again .
Shakespearean: Now by my life , Old fools are babes again and must be used With checks as flatteries , when they are seen abused .

English: Remember what I've told you .
Shakespearean: Remember what I have said .

English: Very well , ma'am .
Shakespearean: Very well , madam .

English: And make sure the servants are less friendly to his knights .
Shakespearean: And let his knights have colder looks among you .

English: Don't worry about the consequences .
Shakespearean: What grows of it , no matter .

English: Tell your men as much .
Shakespearean: Advise your fellows so .

English: I want this to provoke confrontations , so I can give him a piece of my mind .
Shakespearean: I would breed from hence occasions , and I shall , That I may speak .

English: I'll write to my sister and tell her my plans .
Shakespearean: I'll write straight to my sister To hold my very course .

English: Now go , set up for dinner .
Shakespearean: Go , prepare for dinner .

English: If I can disguise my voice as well as my appearance , then I'll be able to carry out my plan perfectly .
Shakespearean: If but as well I other accents borrow , That can my speech diffuse , my good intent May carry through itself to that full issue For which I razed my likeness .

English: I love my master , and he'll find me very hard-working .
Shakespearean: Now , banished Kent , If thou canst serve where thou dost stand condemned , So may it come thy master , whom thou lovest , Shall find thee full of labors .

English: Don't make me wait for dinner even a moment .
Shakespearean: Let me not stay a jot for dinner .

English: Get it ready immediately .
Shakespearean: Go get it ready .

English: A man , sir .
Shakespearean: A man , sir .

English: What's your profession ?
Shakespearean: What dost thou profess ?

English: What do you want from me ?
Shakespearean: What wouldst thou with us ?

English: But who are you ?
Shakespearean: What art thou ?

English: An honest guy who's as poor as the king .
Shakespearean: A very honest-hearted fellow , and as poor as the king .

English: If you're as poor a subject as he is a king , you definitely are poor .
Shakespearean: If thou beest as poor for a subject as he's for a king , thou'rt poor enough .

English: What do you want ?
Shakespearean: What wouldst thou ?

English: To work as a servant .
Shakespearean: Service .

English: Who do you want to work for ?
Shakespearean: Who wouldst thou serve ?

English: You .
Shakespearean: You .

English: Do you know me ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou know me , fellow ?

English: Authority .
Shakespearean: Authority .

English: What work can you do ?
Shakespearean: What services canst thou do ?

English: I can be discreet in honorable matters , ride a horse , run , tell a good story badly , and deliver a plain message bluntly .
Shakespearean: I can keep honest counsel , ride , run , mar a curious tale in telling it , and deliver a plain message bluntly .

English: I'm good at everything that ordinary men can do .
Shakespearean: That which ordinary men are fit for , I am qualified in .

English: The best thing about me is that I'm hardworking .
Shakespearean: And the best of me is diligence .

English: How old are you ?
Shakespearean: How old art thou ?

English: Not young enough to fall in love with a woman because she sings well , but not old enough to dote on a woman for any reason .
Shakespearean: Not so young , sir , to love a woman for singing , nor so old to dote on her for anything .

English: I'm forty-eight .
Shakespearean: I have years on my back forty- eight .

English: Follow me .
Shakespearean: Follow me .

English: You'll work for me .
Shakespearean: Thou shalt serve me .

English: Where's my fool ? , Go call my fool and have him come here .
Shakespearean: Where's my knave , my fool ? , Go you , and call my fool hither .

English: No , I don't , my lord .
Shakespearean: No , my lord .

English: Very pleased to meet you , my lord .
Shakespearean: My services to your lordship .

English: I look forward to getting to know you better .
Shakespearean: I must love you and sue to know you better .

English: I'll try to make myself worth your knowledge .
Shakespearean: Sir , I shall study deserving .

English: He's been gone for nine years and he's leaving again soon .
Shakespearean: He hath been out nine years , and away he shall again .

English: The king is coming .
Shakespearean: The king is coming .

English: Go escort the lords of France and Burgundy , Gloucester .
Shakespearean: Attend the lords of France and Burgundy , Gloucester .

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: I shall , my lord .

English: You , sir , where's my daughter ?
Shakespearean: You , you , sirrah , where's my daughter ?

English: I beg your pardon , sir , What did that guy say ?
Shakespearean: So please you , What says the fellow there ?

English: Call the numbskull back in here .
Shakespearean: Call the clotpoll back .

English: Where's my fool ?
Shakespearean: Where's my fool , ho ?

English: You'd think everyone was asleep .
Shakespearean: I think the world's asleep .

English: So what's going on ?
Shakespearean: How now ?

English: Where's that dog ?
Shakespearean: Where's that mongrel ?

English: He says your daughter's not feeling well , my lord .
Shakespearean: He says , my lord , your daughter is not well .

English: My lord , I don't know what's going on , but it seems to me that your highness isn't being treated as politely as before .
Shakespearean: My lord , I know not what the matter is , but to my judgment your highness is not entertained with that ceremonious affection as you were wont .

English: The servants , the duke , and your daughter all seem to be treating you less kindly .
Shakespearean: There's a great abatement of kindness appears as well in the general dependants as in the duke himself also , and your daughter .

English: No , you're just reminding me of something I've also noticed .
Shakespearean: Thou but rememberest me of mine own conception .

Shakespearean: I have perceived a most faint neglect of late , which I have rather blamed as mine own jealous curiosity than as a very pretense and purpose of unkindness .

Shakespearean: I will look further into 't .

Shakespearean: If thou follow him , thou must needs wear my coxcomb. , How now , nuncle ?

Shakespearean: Why , after I have cut the egg i ' th ' middle and eat up the meat , the two crowns of the egg .

Shakespearean: For when thou gavest them the rod , and put'st down thine own breeches , Prithee , nuncle , keep a schoolmaster that can teach thy fool to lie .

Shakespearean: I had rather be any kind o ' thing than a fool .

Shakespearean: Which else were shame , that then necessity Will call discreet proceeding .

English: He exposed Edgar's murderous plot , and was wounded , as you see there , when trying to apprehend him .
Shakespearean: He did bewray his practice , and received This hurt you see striving to apprehend him .

English: Are your men searching for him ?
Shakespearean: Is he pursued ?

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my good lord .

English: If he's caught , he'll never make trouble for anyone again .
Shakespearean: If he be taken , he shall never more Be feared of doing harm .

English: I need people as trustworthy as you .
Shakespearean: Natures of such deep trust we shall much need .

English: I'll always be loyal to you , sir .
Shakespearean: I shall serve you , sir , Truly , however else .

English: You don't know why we came to visit you , Yes , and so unexpectedly , at night .
Shakespearean: You know not why we came to visit you , Thus out of season , threading dark-eyed night .

English: Their messengers are ready , waiting to deliver our response in these matters .
Shakespearean: The several messengers From hence attend dispatch .

English: So please , old friend , give us some good advice .
Shakespearean: Our good old friend , Lay comforts to your bosom , and bestow Your needful counsel to our business , Which craves the instant use .

English: I'm at your service , madam .
Shakespearean: I serve you , madam .

English: Both of you are very welcome here .
Shakespearean: Your graces are right welcome .

English: Good morning to you , friend .
Shakespearean: Good dawning to thee , friend .

English: Do you work in this house ?
Shakespearean: Art of this house ?

English: Yes , I do .
Shakespearean: Ay .

English: Where should we stable our horses ?
Shakespearean: Where may we set our horses ?

English: In the mud .
Shakespearean: I ' th ' mire .

English: Please , sir , be kind to me and tell me .
Shakespearean: Prithee , if thou lovest me , tell me .

English: I won't be kind to you .
Shakespearean: I love thee not .

English: In that case , I don't much care for you either .
Shakespearean: Why , then , I care not for thee .

English: If I could get my hands on you , I'd make you care .
Shakespearean: If I had thee in Lipsbury pinfold , I would make thee care for me .

English: Why are you talking to me like this ?
Shakespearean: Why dost thou use me thus ?

English: I don't even know you .
Shakespearean: I know thee not .

English: Ah , but I know you .
Shakespearean: Fellow , I know thee .

English: Who am I then ?
Shakespearean: What dost thou know me for ?

English: What an ogre you are to slander someone you don't know , and who doesn't know you !
Shakespearean: Why , what a monstrous fellow art thou , thus to rail on one that is neither known of thee nor knows thee !

English: What a shameless jerk you are to pretend you don't know me !
Shakespearean: What a brazen-faced varlet art thou to deny thou knowest me !

English: It was just two days ago that I tripped you and beat you up in front of the king .
Shakespearean: Is it two days ago since I tripped up thy heels and beat thee before the king ?

English: Draw your sword , scoundrel .
Shakespearean: Draw , you rogue , for though it be night yet the moon shines .

English: I'll make ground beef out of you .
Shakespearean: I'll make a sop o ' th ' moonshine of you .

English: Get away from me !
Shakespearean: Away !

English: I've got nothing to do with you .
Shakespearean: I have nothing to do with thee .

English: Draw your sword , you jerk !
Shakespearean: Draw , you rascal .

English: You come here with letters against the king , and you take his conceited daughter's side against his royal highness .
Shakespearean: You come with letters against the king and take Vanity the puppet's part against the royalty of her father .

English: Draw your sword , scoundrel , or I'll slice your thighs like flank steak .
Shakespearean: Draw , you rogue , or I'll so carbonado your shanks .

English: Draw your sword !
Shakespearean: Draw , you rascal !

English: Come on !
Shakespearean: Come your ways .

English: Help !
Shakespearean: Help , ho !

English: Murderer !
Shakespearean: Murder !

English: Help !
Shakespearean: Help !

English: Stand and fight , you overdressed servant , fight !
Shakespearean: Stand , you neat slave , strike !

English: Help !
Shakespearean: Help , ho !

English: Murder , murder !
Shakespearean: Murder , murder !

English: Macbeth .
Shakespearean: Macbeth .

English: Then stay with us .
Shakespearean: Then stand with us .

English: There's still a bit of daylight in the sky .
Shakespearean: The west yet glimmers with some streaks of day .

English: Now all the late travellers are hurrying to reach their inns .
Shakespearean: Now spurs the lated traveler apace To gain the timely inn , and near approaches The subject of our watch .

English: The rest of the king's guests are already inside .
Shakespearean: Then 'tis he : the rest That are within the note of expectation Already are i ' th ' court .

English: That's him .
Shakespearean: Tis he .

English: Prepare yourselves .
Shakespearean: Stand to 't .

English: It will rain tonight .
Shakespearean: It will be rain tonight .

English: Then let the rain come down .
Shakespearean: Let it come down .

English: Oh , this is treachery !
Shakespearean: O treachery !

English: Get out of here , good Fleance , run , run , run !
Shakespearean: Fly , good Fleance , fly , fly , fly !

English: Someday you can get revenge. , Oh , you bastard !
Shakespearean: Thou may 'st revenge , O slave !

English: Who put out the light ?
Shakespearean: Who did strike out the light ?

English: Wasn't that the best thing to do ?
Shakespearean: Was 't not the way ?

English: There's only one body here .
Shakespearean: There's but one down .

English: The son ran away .
Shakespearean: The son is fled .

English: We failed in half of our mission .
Shakespearean: We have lost best half of our affair .

English: Well , let's get out of here and tell Macbeth what we did accomplish .
Shakespearean: Well , let's away and say how much is done .

English: From the highest to the lowest of you , I bid you a hearty welcome .
Shakespearean: At first And last , the hearty welcome .

English: Thanks to your majesty .
Shakespearean: Thanks to your majesty .

English: I will walk around and mingle with all of you , playing the humble host .
Shakespearean: Ourself will mingle with society And play the humble host .

English: Say welcome to all of our friends for me , sir , for in my heart they are all welcome .
Shakespearean: Pronounce it for me , sir , to all our friends , For my heart speaks they are welcome .

English: And they respond to you with their hearts as well .
Shakespearean: See , they encounter thee with their hearts ' thanks .

English: The table is full on both sides .
Shakespearean: Both sides are even .

English: I will sit here in the middle .
Shakespearean: Here I'll sit i ' th ' midst .

English: Be free and happy .
Shakespearean: Be large in mirth .

English: Soon we will toast around the table .
Shakespearean: Anon we'll drink a measure The table round .

English: Then it must be Banquo's .
Shakespearean: Tis Banquo's then .

English: My lord , his throat is cut .
Shakespearean: My lord , his throat is cut .

English: I did that to him .
Shakespearean: That I did for him .

English: You are the best of the cutthroats .
Shakespearean: Thou art the best o ' th ' cutthroats : Yet he's good that did the like for Fleance .

English: If you cut both their throats , then you are the absolute best .
Shakespearean: If thou didst it , thou art the nonpareil .

English: Most royal sir , Fleance has escaped .
Shakespearean: Most royal sir , Fleance is 'scaped .

English: Now I'm scared again .
Shakespearean: Then comes my fit again .

English: Otherwise I would have been perfect , as solid as a piece of marble , as firm as a rock , as free as the air itself .
Shakespearean: I had else been perfect , Whole as the marble , founded as the rock , As broad and general as the casing air .

English: Yes , my good lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my good lord .

English: He's lying dead in a ditch , with twenty deep gashes in his head , any one of which would have been enough to kill him .
Shakespearean: Safe in a ditch he bides , With twenty trenched gashes on his head , The least a death to nature .

English: Thanks for that .
Shakespearean: Thanks for that .

English: The adult snake lies in the ditch .
Shakespearean: There the grown serpent lies .

English: The young snake that escaped will in time become poisonous and threatening , but for now he has no fangs .
Shakespearean: The worm that's fled Hath nature that in time will venom breed ; No teeth for th ' present .

English: Get out of here .
Shakespearean: Get thee gone .

English: I'll talk to you again tomorrow .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow We'll hear ourselves again .

English: My royal lord , you're not entertaining the guests .
Shakespearean: My royal lord , You do not give the cheer .

English: When you just want to eat , it's better to do that at home .
Shakespearean: To feed were best at home ; From thence , the sauce to meat is ceremony ; Meeting were bare without it .

English: Where have you been , sister ?
Shakespearean: Where hast thou been , sister ?

English: Killing pigs .
Shakespearean: Killing swine .

English: And you , sister ?
Shakespearean: Sister , where thou ?

English: A sailor's wife had chestnuts in her lap and munched away at them .
Shakespearean: A sailor's wife had chestnuts in her lap , And munched , and munched , and munched .

English: Give me one , " I said .
Shakespearean: Give me , " quoth I .

English: Get away from me , witch ! " the fat woman cried .
Shakespearean: Aroint thee , witch ! " the rump-fed runnion cries .

English: How nice of you !
Shakespearean: Thou 'rt kind .

English: And I will give you some more .
Shakespearean: And I another .

English: I'll drain the life out of him .
Shakespearean: I'll drain him dry as hay .

English: He won't catch a wink of sleep , either at night or during the day .
Shakespearean: Sleep shall neither night nor day Hang upon his penthouse lid .

English: He will live as a cursed man .
Shakespearean: He shall live a man forbid .

English: For eighty-one weeks he will waste away in agony .
Shakespearean: Weary sev'nnights nine times nine Shall he dwindle , peak and pine .

English: It's nice of you to remind me .
Shakespearean: Sweet remembrancer !

English: Why don't you have a seat , your highness ?
Shakespearean: May 't please your highness sit .

English: His absence means he's broken his promise , sir .
Shakespearean: His absence , sir , Lays blame upon his promise .

English: If it pleases you , your highness , why don't you sit with us and grace us with your royal company ?
Shakespearean: Please 't your highness To grace us with your royal company ?

English: The table's full .
Shakespearean: The table's full .

English: Here's an empty seat , sir .
Shakespearean: Here is a place reserved , sir .

English: Where ?
Shakespearean: Where ?

English: What , my good lord ?
Shakespearean: What , my good lord ?

English: Gentlemen , stand up .
Shakespearean: Gentlemen , rise .

English: His highness is not well .
Shakespearean: His highness is not well .

English: Sit down , worthy friends .
Shakespearean: Sit , worthy friends .

English: My husband is often like this , and he has been since he was a child .
Shakespearean: My lord is often thus And hath been from his youth .

English: Please stay seated .
Shakespearean: Pray you , keep seat .

English: If you pay too much attention to him you'll make him angry , and that will make his convulsions go on longer .
Shakespearean: If much you note him , You shall offend him and extend his passion .

English: Eat your dinner and pay no attention to him .
Shakespearean: Feed and regard him not .

English: Yes , and a brave one , who dares to look at something that would frighten the devil .
Shakespearean: Ay , and a bold one , that dare look on that Which might appall the devil .

English: Oh , that's nonsense !
Shakespearean: O proper stuff !

English: This is just another one of the hallucinations you always get when you're afraid .
Shakespearean: This is the very painting of your fear .

English: These outbursts of yours don't even look like real fear .
Shakespearean: This is the air-drawn dagger which you said Led you to Duncan .
