English: I heard the owl scream and the crickets cry .
Shakespearean: I heard the owl scream and the crickets cry .

English: Didn't you say something ?
Shakespearean: Did not you speak ?

English: When ?
Shakespearean: When ?

English: Just now .
Shakespearean: Now .

English: As I came down ?
Shakespearean: As I descended ?

English: Yes .
Shakespearean: Ay .

English: Listen !
Shakespearean: Hark !

English: Who's sleeping in the second chamber ?
Shakespearean: Who lies i ' th ' second chamber ?

English: Donalbain .
Shakespearean: Donalbain .

English: That's a stupid thing to say .
Shakespearean: A foolish thought , to say a sorry sight .

English: One servant cried , "God bless us ! " and the other replied , "Amen , " as if they had seen my bloody hands .
Shakespearean: One cried , "God bless us ! " and "Amen" the other , As they had seen me with these hangman's hands .

English: Listening to their frightened voices , I couldn't reply "Amen" when they said "God bless us ! " Don't think about it so much .
Shakespearean: List'ning their fear I could not say "Amen , " When they did say "God bless us ! " Consider it not so deeply .

English: But why couldn't I say "Amen" ?
Shakespearean: But wherefore could not I pronounce "Amen" ?

English: I desperately needed God's blessing , but the word "Amen" stuck in my throat .
Shakespearean: I had most need of blessing , and "Amen" Stuck in my throat .

English: We can't think that way about what we did .
Shakespearean: These deeds must not be thought After these ways .

English: If we do , it'll drive us crazy .
Shakespearean: So , it will make us mad .

English: I thought I heard a voice cry , "Sleep no more !
Shakespearean: Methought I heard a voice cry , "Sleep no more !

English: What are you talking about ?
Shakespearean: What do you mean ?

English: The voice kept crying , "Sleep no more ! " to everyone in the house .
Shakespearean: Still it cried , "Sleep no more ! " to all the house .

English: Go get some water and wash this bloody evidence from your hands .
Shakespearean: Go get some water , And wash this filthy witness from your hand .

English: Why did you carry these daggers out of the room ?
Shakespearean: Why did you bring these daggers from the place ?

English: They have to stay there .
Shakespearean: They must lie there .

English: Go take them back and smear the sleeping guards with the blood .
Shakespearean: Go carry them and smear The sleepy grooms with blood .

English: Coward !
Shakespearean: Infirm of purpose !

English: Give me the daggers .
Shakespearean: Give me the daggers .

English: Only children are afraid of scary pictures .
Shakespearean: The sleeping and the dead Are but as pictures .

English: If Duncan bleeds I'll paint the servants ' faces with his blood .
Shakespearean: If he do bleed , I'll gild the faces of the grooms withal , For it must seem their guilt .

English: Where is that knocking coming from ?
Shakespearean: Whence is that knocking ?

English: What's happening to me , that I'm frightened of every noise ?
Shakespearean: How is 't with me when every noise appals me ?

English: I hear someone knocking at the south entry .
Shakespearean: I hear a knocking At the south entry .

English: Let's go back to our bedroom .
Shakespearean: Retire we to our chamber .

English: A little water will wash away the evidence of our guilt .
Shakespearean: A little water clears us of this deed .

English: It's so simple !
Shakespearean: How easy is it , then !

English: You've lost your resolve .
Shakespearean: Your constancy Hath left you unattended .

English: Listen !
Shakespearean: Hark !

English: There's more knocking .
Shakespearean: More knocking .

English: Put on your nightgown , in case someone comes and sees that we're awake .
Shakespearean: Get on your nightgown , lest occasion call us And show us to be watchers .

English: Snap out of your daze .
Shakespearean: Be not lost So poorly in your thoughts .

English: Wake Duncan with your knocking .
Shakespearean: Wake Duncan with thy knocking .

English: I wish you could !
Shakespearean: I would thou couldst .

English: Knock , knock , knock !
Shakespearean: Knock , knock , knock !

English: Knock , knock !
Shakespearean: Knock , knock !

English: Who's there , in the other devil's name ?
Shakespearean: Who's there , in th ' other devil's name ?

English: Come on in , con man .
Shakespearean: O , come in , equivocator .

English: Knock , knock , knock !
Shakespearean: Knock , knock , knock !

English: Who's there ?
Shakespearean: Who's there ?

English: Maybe it's an English tailor who liked to skimp on the fabric for people's clothes .
Shakespearean: Faith , here's an English tailor come hither for stealing out of a French hose .

English: Come on in , tailor .
Shakespearean: Come in , tailor .

English: You can heat your iron up in here .
Shakespearean: Here you may roast your goose .

English: Knock , knock !
Shakespearean: Knock , knock !

English: Never a moment of peace !
Shakespearean: Never at quiet .

English: Who are you ?
Shakespearean: What are you ?

English: Ah , this place is too cold to be hell .
Shakespearean: But this place is too cold for hell .

English: I won't pretend to be the devil's porter anymore .
Shakespearean: I'll devil-porter it no further .

English: I'm coming , I'm coming !
Shakespearean: Anon , anon !

English: Please , don't forget to leave me a tip .
Shakespearean: I pray you , remember the porter .

English: Did you go to bed so late , my friend , that you're having a hard time getting up now ?
Shakespearean: Was it so late , friend , ere you went to bed , That you do lie so late ?

English: What three things does drink make a man do ?
Shakespearean: What three things does drink especially provoke ?

English: It sets you up for a fall .
Shakespearean: Lechery , sir , it provokes and unprovokes .

English: It persuades you and discourages you .
Shakespearean: It provokes the desire , but it takes away the performance .

English: I believe drink did all of this to you last night .
Shakespearean: I believe drink gave thee the lie last night .

English: Is your master awake ?
Shakespearean: Is thy master stirring ?

English: Our knocking woke him up .
Shakespearean: Our knocking has awaked him .

English: Here he comes .
Shakespearean: Here he comes .

English: Good morning , noble sir .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , noble sir .

English: Good morning to both of you .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , both .

English: Is the king awake , worthy thane ?
Shakespearean: Is the king stirring , worthy thane ?

English: Not yet .
Shakespearean: Not yet .

English: He commanded me to wake him up early .
Shakespearean: He did command me to call timely on him .

English: I've almost missed the time he requested .
Shakespearean: I have almost slipped the hour .

English: I'll bring you to him .
Shakespearean: I'll bring you to him .

English: I know the burden of hosting him is both an honor and a trouble , but that doesn't mean it's not a trouble just the same .
Shakespearean: I know this is a joyful trouble to you , But yet 'tis one .

English: The work we enjoy is not really work .
Shakespearean: The labor we delight in physics pain .

English: This is the door .
Shakespearean: This is the door .

English: I'll wake him , because that's my job .
Shakespearean: I'll make so bold to call , For 'tis my limited service .

English: Is the king leaving here today ?
Shakespearean: Goes the king hence today ?

English: He is .
Shakespearean: He does .

English: He told us to arrange it .
Shakespearean: He did appoint so .

English: The night has been chaotic .
Shakespearean: The night has been unruly .

English: The wind blew down through the chimneys where we were sleeping .
Shakespearean: Where we lay , Our chimneys were blown down and , as they say , Lamentings heard i ' th ' air , strange screams of death , And prophesying with accents terrible Of dire combustion and confused events New hatched to the woeful time .

English: The owl made noise all night .
Shakespearean: The obscure bird Clamored the livelong night .

English: Some people say that the earth shook as if it had a fever .
Shakespearean: Some say the Earth Was feverous and did shake .

English: It was a rough night .
Shakespearean: Twas a rough night .

English: I'm too young to remember anything like it .
Shakespearean: My young remembrance can not parallel A fellow to it .

English: Oh , horror , horror , horror !
Shakespearean: O horror , horror , horror !

English: This is beyond words and beyond belief !
Shakespearean: Tongue nor heart can not conceive nor name thee !

English: What's the matter ?
Shakespearean: What's the matter ?

English: The worst thing imaginable has happened .
Shakespearean: Confusion now hath made his masterpiece .

English: The life" ?
Shakespearean: The life" ?

English: Do you mean the king ?
Shakespearean: Mean you his majesty ?

English: Listen to this , King : as soon as we sent those Irish soldiers running for cover , the Norwegian king saw his chance to attack us with fresh troops and shiny weapons .
Shakespearean: Mark , King of Scotland , mark : No sooner justice had , with valor armed , Compelled these skipping kerns to trust their heels , But the Norweyan lord , surveying vantage , With furbished arms and new supplies of men , Began a fresh assault .

English: Didn't this frighten our captains , Macbeth and Banquo ?
Shakespearean: Dismayed not this our captains , Macbeth and Banquo ?

English: The new challenge scared them about as much as sparrows frighten eagles , or rabbits frighten a lion .
Shakespearean: Yes , as sparrows eagles , or the hare the lion .

English: To tell you the truth , they fought the new enemy with twice as much force as before ; they were like cannons loaded with double ammunition .
Shakespearean: If I say sooth , I must report they were As cannons overcharged with double cracks , So they doubly redoubled strokes upon the foe .

English: Your words , like your wounds , bring you honor .
Shakespearean: So well thy words become thee as thy wounds ; They smack of honor both .

English: Take him to the surgeons .
Shakespearean: Go get him surgeons .

English: Who is this ?
Shakespearean: Who comes here ?

English: He looks like someone with a strange tale to tell .
Shakespearean: So should he look That seems to speak things strange .

English: Go into the bedroom and see for yourself .
Shakespearean: Approach the chamber , and destroy your sight With a new Gorgon .

English: Don't ask me to talk about it .
Shakespearean: Do not bid me speak .

English: Go look and then do the talking yourselves .
Shakespearean: See , and then speak yourselves .

English: Wake up , wake up !
Shakespearean: Awake , awake !

English: Ring the alarm bell .
Shakespearean: Ring the alarum bell .

English: Murder and treason !
Shakespearean: Murder and treason !

English: Banquo and Donalbain , Malcolm !
Shakespearean: Banquo and Donalbain !

English: Wake up !
Shakespearean: Awake !

English: Shake off sleep , which looks like death , and look at death itself !
Shakespearean: Shake off this downy sleep , death's counterfeit , And look on death itself !

English: Get up , get up , and look at this image of doomsday !
Shakespearean: Up , up , and see The great doom's image !

English: Malcolm !
Shakespearean: Malcolm !

English: Banquo !
Shakespearean: Banquo !

English: Get up from your beds as if you were rising out of your own graves , and walk like ghosts to come witness this horror .
Shakespearean: As from your graves rise up , and walk like sprites , To countenance this horror !

English: Speak up and tell me !
Shakespearean: Speak , speak !

English: If I repeated it to you , it would kill you as soon as you heard it .
Shakespearean: O gentle lady , 'T is not for you to hear what I can speak : The repetition , in a woman's ear , Would murder as it fell .

English: Oh Banquo , Banquo , the king has been murdered !
Shakespearean: O Banquo , Banquo , Our royal master's murdered !

English: How horrible !
Shakespearean: Woe , alas !

English: What , in our own house ?
Shakespearean: What , in our house ?

English: Dear Macduff , I beg you , tell us you were lying and say it isn't so .
Shakespearean: Dear Duff , I prithee , contradict thyself , And say it is not so .

English: If I had only died an hour before this event I could say I had lived a blessed life .
Shakespearean: Had I but died an hour before this chance , I had lived a blessed time , for from this instant There's nothing serious in mortality .

English: Everything is a sick joke .
Shakespearean: All is but toys .

English: The graceful and renowned king is dead .
Shakespearean: Renown and grace is dead .

English: The wine of life has been poured out , and only the dregs remain .
Shakespearean: The wine of life is drawn , and the mere lees Is left this vault to brag of .

English: What's wrong ?
Shakespearean: What is amiss ?

English: You are , but you don't know it yet .
Shakespearean: You are , and do not know 't .

English: The source from which your royal blood comes has been stopped .
Shakespearean: The spring , the head , the fountain of your blood Is stopped ; the very source of it is stopped .

English: Your royal father is murdered .
Shakespearean: Your royal father's murdered .

English: Who did it ?
Shakespearean: Oh , by whom ?

English: It seems that the guards who were supposed to be protecting his chamber did it .
Shakespearean: Those of his chamber , as it seemed , had done 't .

English: Their hands and faces were all covered with blood .
Shakespearean: Their hands and faces were all badged with blood .

English: So were their daggers , which we found on their pillows , unwiped .
Shakespearean: So were their daggers , which unwiped we found Upon their pillows .

English: They stared at us in confusion .
Shakespearean: They stared , and were distracted .

English: No one's life should have been entrusted to them .
Shakespearean: No man's life was to be trusted with them .

English: And yet I still regret the anger that drove me to kill them .
Shakespearean: Oh , yet I do repent me of my fury , That I did kill them .

English: What did you do that for ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore did you so ?

English: Is it possible to be wise , bewildered , calm , furious , loyal , and neutral all at once ?
Shakespearean: Who can be wise , amazed , temp'rate , and furious , Loyal and neutral , in a moment ?

English: Then right next to him I saw the murderers , dripping with blood , their daggers rudely covered in gore .
Shakespearean: Here lay Duncan , His silver skin laced with his golden blood , And his gashed stabs looked like a breach in nature For ruin's wasteful entrance ; there , the murderers , Steeped in the colors of their trade , their daggers Unmannerly breeched with gore .

English: Who could have restrained himself , who loved Duncan and had the courage to act on it ?
Shakespearean: Who could refrain , That had a heart to love , and in that heart Courage to make 's love known ?

English: Help me out of here , quickly !
Shakespearean: Help me hence , ho !

English: Take care of the lady .
Shakespearean: Look to the lady .

English: Right now we're shaken up by fears and doubts .
Shakespearean: Fears and scruples shake us .

English: I'm putting myself in God's hands , and with his help I plan to fight against the secret plot that caused this treasonous murder .
Shakespearean: In the great hand of God I stand , and thence Against the undivulged pretense I fight Of treasonous malice .

English: So will I .
Shakespearean: And so do I .

English: So will we all .
Shakespearean: So all .

English: Let's get dressed quickly and then meet in the hall .
Shakespearean: Let's briefly put on manly readiness , And meet i ' th ' hall together .

English: Agreed .
Shakespearean: Well contented .

English: What are you going to do ?
Shakespearean: What will you do ?

English: Let's not stay here with them .
Shakespearean: Let's not consort with them .

English: It's easy for a liar to pretend to feel sorrow when he actually feels none .
Shakespearean: To show an unfelt sorrow is an office Which the false man does easy .

English: I'm going to England .
Shakespearean: I'll to England .

English: I'll go to Ireland .
Shakespearean: To Ireland , I .

English: We'll both be safer if we go separate ways .
Shakespearean: Our separated fortune Shall keep us both the safer .

English: Wherever we go , men will smile at us while hiding daggers .
Shakespearean: Where we are , There's daggers in men's smiles .

English: Our closest relatives are the ones most likely to murder us .
Shakespearean: The near in blood , The nearer bloody .

English: We haven't yet encountered that danger , and the best thing to do is avoid it entirely .
Shakespearean: This murderous shaft that's shot Hath not yet lighted , and our safest way Is to avoid the aim .

English: There's good reason to escape when there's no mercy to be found anymore .
Shakespearean: There's warrant in that theft Which steals itself when there's no mercy left .

English: I can remember the past seventy years pretty well , and in all that time I have seen dreadful hours and strange things .
Shakespearean: Threescore and ten I can remember well , Within the volume of which time I have seen Hours dreadful and things strange , but this sore night Hath trifled former knowings .

English: The clock says it's daytime , but dark night is strangling the sun .
Shakespearean: By th ' clock 'tis day , And yet dark night strangles the travelling lamp .

English: They say the horses ate each other .
Shakespearean: Tis said they eat each other .

English: I saw it with my own eyes .
Shakespearean: They did so , to th ' amazement of mine eyes That looked upon 't .

English: Here comes the good Macduff .
Shakespearean: Here comes the good Macduff .

English: How are things going now ?
Shakespearean: How goes the world , sir , now ?

English: Can't you see for yourself ?
Shakespearean: Why , see you not ?

English: The servants Macbeth killed .
Shakespearean: Those that Macbeth hath slain .

English: They were paid to betray their master .
Shakespearean: They were suborned .

English: Malcolm and Donalbain , the king's two sons , have run away and fled , which makes them the prime suspects .
Shakespearean: Malcolm and Donalbain , the king's two sons , Are stol'n away and fled , which puts upon them Suspicion of the deed .

English: Everything about this is unnatural !
Shakespearean: Thriftless ambition , that will raven up Thine own lives ' means !

English: Then it looks like Macbeth will become king .
Shakespearean: Then 'tis most like The sovereignty will fall upon Macbeth .

English: He has already been named king and has left for Scone to be crowned .
Shakespearean: He is already named and gone to Scone To be invested .

English: Where is Duncan's body ?
Shakespearean: Where is Duncan's body ?

English: It was carried to Colmekill to be placed in the tomb of his ancestors , where their bones are kept safe .
Shakespearean: Carried to Colmekill , The sacred storehouse of his predecessors , And guardian of their bones .

English: Are you going to Scone ?
Shakespearean: Will you to Scone ?

English: No , cousin , I'm going to Fife .
Shakespearean: No , cousin , I'll to Fife .

English: Well , I'll go to Scone .
Shakespearean: Well , I will thither .

English: I hope things go well there .
Shakespearean: Well , may you see things well done there .

English: Good-bye !
Shakespearean: Adieu , Lest our old robes sit easier than our new !

English: Farewell , old man .
Shakespearean: Farewell , father .

English: May God's blessing go with you and with all who turn bad into good , and enemies into friends !
Shakespearean: God's benison go with you and with those That would make good of bad and friends of foes .

English: But it was also prophesied that the crown would not go to your descendants , and that my sons and grandsons would be kings instead .
Shakespearean: Yet it was said It should not stand in thy posterity , But that myself should be the root and father Of many kings .

English: If the witches tell the truth , which they did about you , maybe what they said about me will come true too .
Shakespearean: If there come truth from them , As upon thee , Macbeth , their speeches shine , Why , by the verities on thee made good , May they not be my oracles as well , And set me up in hope ?

English: But shhh !
Shakespearean: But hush , no more .

English: I'll shut up now .
Shakespearean: Here's our chief guest .

English: Whatever your highness commands me to do , it is always my duty to do it .
Shakespearean: Let your highness Command upon me , to the which my duties Are with a most indissoluble tie Forever knit .

English: Are you going riding this afternoon ?
Shakespearean: Ride you this afternoon ?

English: Yes , my good lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my good lord .

English: We would have liked to have heard your good advice , which has always been serious and helpful , at the council today , but we'll wait until tomorrow .
Shakespearean: We should have else desired your good advice , Which still hath been both grave and prosperous , In this day's council , but we'll take tomorrow .

English: Are you riding far ?
Shakespearean: Is 't far you ride ?

English: I'm going far enough that I'll be riding from now until dinner .
Shakespearean: As far , my lord , as will fill up the time 'Twixt this and supper .

English: Unless my horse goes faster than expected , I will be back an hour or two after sunset .
Shakespearean: Go not my horse the better , I must become a borrower of the night For a dark hour or twain .

English: Don't miss our feast .
Shakespearean: Fail not our feast .

English: My lord , I won't miss it .
Shakespearean: My lord , I will not .

English: But we can talk more about that tomorrow , when we'll discuss matters of state that concern us both .
Shakespearean: But of that tomorrow , When therewithal we shall have cause of state Craving us jointly .

English: Hurry up and get to your horse .
Shakespearean: Hie you to horse .

English: Good-bye , until you return tonight .
Shakespearean: Adieu , Till your return at night .

English: Is Fleance going with you ?
Shakespearean: Goes Fleance with you ?

English: Yes , my good lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my good lord .

English: It's time we hit the road .
Shakespearean: Our time does call upon 's .

English: Farewell .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: Everybody may do as they please until seven o'clock tonight .
Shakespearean: Let every man be master of his time Till seven at night .

English: In order to make your company even more enjoyable , I'm going to keep to myself until suppertime .
Shakespearean: To make society The sweeter welcome , we will keep ourself Till suppertime alone .

English: Until then , God be with you !
Shakespearean: While then , God be with you !

English: Bring them to me .
Shakespearean: Bring them before us .

English: I'm very afraid of Banquo .
Shakespearean: Our fears in Banquo Stick deep , and in his royalty of nature Reigns that which would be feared .

English: He has the wisdom to act bravely but also safely .
Shakespearean: Tis much he dares , And to that dauntless temper of his mind He hath a wisdom that doth guide his valor To act in safety .

English: I'm not afraid of anyone but him .
Shakespearean: There is none but he Whose being I do fear , and under him My genius is rebuked , as it is said Mark Antony's was by Caesar .

English: Then , like prophets , they named him the father to a line of kings .
Shakespearean: Then , prophetlike , They hailed him father to a line of kings .

English: Who's there !
Shakespearean: Who's there ?

English: God save the king !
Shakespearean: God save the king .

English: Great happiness !
Shakespearean: Great happiness !

English: So now Sweno , the Norwegian king , wants a treaty .
Shakespearean: That now Sweno , the Norways ' king , craves composition .

English: We told him we wouldn't even let him bury his men until he retreated to Saint Colme's Inch and paid us ten thousand dollars .
Shakespearean: Nor would we deign him burial of his men Till he disbursed at Saint Colme's Inch Ten thousand dollars to our general use .

English: Go announce that he will be executed , and tell Macbeth that Cawdor's titles will be given to him .
Shakespearean: No more that thane of Cawdor shall deceive Our bosom interest : go pronounce his present death , And with his former title greet Macbeth .

English: I'll get it done right away .
Shakespearean: I'll see it done .

English: The thane of Cawdor has lost what the noble Macbeth has won .
Shakespearean: What he hath lost , noble Macbeth hath won .

English: Now go to the door and stay there until I call for you .
Shakespearean: Now go to the door and stay there till we call .

English: Wasn't it just yesterday that we spoke to each other ?
Shakespearean: Was it not yesterday we spoke together ?

English: It was yesterday , your highness .
Shakespearean: It was , so please your highness .

English: Well , did you think about what I said ?
Shakespearean: Well then , now Have you considered of my speeches ?

English: I explained how you were deceived , how you were thwarted , the things that were used against you , who was working against you , and a lot of other things that would convince even a half-wit or a crazy person to say , "Banquo did it ! " You explained it all .
Shakespearean: This I made good to you In our last conference , passed in probation with you , How you were borne in hand , how crossed , the instruments , Who wrought with them , and all things else that might To half a soul and to a notion crazed Say , "Thus did Banquo." You made it known to us .

English: I did that and more , which brings me to the point of this second meeting .
Shakespearean: I did so , and went further , which is now Our point of second meeting .

English: Are you so patient and forgiving that you're going to let him off the hook ?
Shakespearean: Do you find Your patience so predominant in your nature That you can let this go ?

English: Are you so pious that you would pray for this man and his children , a man who has pushed you toward an early grave and put your family in poverty forever ?
Shakespearean: Are you so gospeled To pray for this good man and for his issue , Whose heavy hand hath bowed you to the grave And beggared yours forever ?

English: We are men , my lord .
Shakespearean: We are men , my liege .

English: Just as hounds and greyhounds , mongrels , spaniels , mutts , shaggy lapdogs , swimming dogs , and wolf-dog crossbreeds are all dogs .
Shakespearean: Ay , in the catalogue ye go for men , As hounds and greyhounds , mongrels , spaniels , curs , Shoughs , water-rugs , and demi-wolves are clept All by the name of dogs .

English: It's the same with men .
Shakespearean: And so of men .

English: Now , if you occupy some place in the list of men that isn't down at the very bottom , tell me .
Shakespearean: I am one , my liege , Whom the vile blows and buffets of the world Have so incensed that I am reckless what I do to spite the world .

English: Because if that's the case , I will tell you a plan that will get rid of your enemy and bring you closer to me .
Shakespearean: And I another So weary with disasters , tugged with fortune , That I would set my life on any chance , To mend it or be rid on 't .

English: You both know Banquo was your enemy .
Shakespearean: Both of you Know Banquo was your enemy .

English: It's true , my lord .
Shakespearean: True , my lord .

English: We'll do what you want us to , my lord .
Shakespearean: We shall , my lord , Perform what you command us .

English: Though our lives , We have decided , my lord .
Shakespearean: Though our lives , Your spirits shine through you .

English: We're in .
Shakespearean: We are resolved , my lord .

English: I'll call for you soon .
Shakespearean: I'll call upon you straight .

English: Stay inside .
Shakespearean: Abide within .

English: The deal is closed .
Shakespearean: It is concluded .

English: Banquo , if your soul is going to make it to heaven , tonight's the night .
Shakespearean: Banquo , thy soul's flight , If it find heaven , must find it out tonight .

English: Has Banquo left the court ?
Shakespearean: Is Banquo gone from court ?

English: Yes , madam , but he'll be back tonight .
Shakespearean: Ay , madam , but returns again tonight .

English: Go tell the king I want to talk to him for a few minutes .
Shakespearean: Say to the king I would attend his leisure For a few words .

English: No problem , madam .
Shakespearean: Madam , I will .

English: If you get what you want and you're still not happy , you've spent everything and gained nothing .
Shakespearean: Naught's had , all's spent , Where our desire is got without content .

English: It's better to be the person who gets murdered than to be the killer and be tormented with anxiety .
Shakespearean: Tis safer to be that which we destroy Than by destruction dwell in doubtful joy .

English: What's going on , my lord ?
Shakespearean: How now , my lord !

English: What's done is done .
Shakespearean: What's done is done .

English: We have slashed the snake but not killed it .
Shakespearean: We have scorched the snake , not killed it .

English: It will heal and be as good as new , and we'll be threatened by its fangs once again .
Shakespearean: She'll close and be herself whilst our poor malice Remains in danger of her former tooth .

English: We killed those men and sent them to rest in peace so that we could gain our own peace .
Shakespearean: Better be with the dead , Whom we , to gain our peace , have sent to peace , Than on the torture of the mind to lie In restless ecstasy .

English: After that , nothing can hurt him further , not weapons , poison , rebellion , invasion , or anything else .
Shakespearean: Treason has done his worst ; nor steel nor poison , Malice domestic , foreign levy , nothing Can touch him further .

English: Come on , relax , dear .
Shakespearean: Come on , gentle my lord , Sleek o'er your rugged looks .

English: That's exactly what I'll do , my love , and I hope you'll do the same .
Shakespearean: So shall I , love , And so , I pray , be you .

English: You have to stop talking like this .
Shakespearean: You must leave this .

English: You know that Banquo and his son Fleance are still alive .
Shakespearean: Thou know'st that Banquo , and his Fleance , lives .

English: That's comforting .
Shakespearean: There's comfort yet ; they are assailable .

English: So be cheerful .
Shakespearean: Then be thou jocund .

English: Before the bat flies through the castle , and before the dung beetle makes his little humming noise to tell us it's nighttime , a dreadful deed will be done .
Shakespearean: Ere the bat hath flown His cloistered flight , ere to black Hecate's summons The shard-borne beetle with his drowsy hums Hath rung night's yawning peal , there shall be done A deed of dreadful note .

English: What are you going to do ?
Shakespearean: What's to be done ?

English: He who chooses me will get what many men want." What many men want , that "many" could mean that most people are fools and choose by whatever is flashy .
Shakespearean: What many men desire" , that "many" may be meant By the fool multitude that choose by show , Not learning more than the fond eye doth teach ; Which pries not to th ' interior , but like the martlet Builds in the weather on the outward wall , Even in the force and road of casualty .

English: So I won't choose what many men desire , because I won't jump on the bandwagon and include myself with the whole crude population .
Shakespearean: I will not choose what many men desire Because I will not jump with common spirits And rank me with the barbarous multitudes .

English: So I guess it's you , you silver treasure house .
Shakespearean: Why then , to thee , thou silver treasure house .

English: Tell me once more what you say .
Shakespearean: Tell me once more what title thou dost bear .

English: He who chooses me will get what he deserves." That's nicely put , because who's going to cheat luck and get more than he deserves ?
Shakespearean: Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves." And well said too , for who shall go about To cozen fortune and be honorable Without the stamp of merit ?

English: No one should have an honor he doesn't deserve .
Shakespearean: Let none presume To wear an undeserved dignity .

English: Oh , wouldn't it be great if property , rank , official positions , and other honors were earned only by merit , not by corruption ?
Shakespearean: Oh , that estates , degrees and offices Were not derived corruptly , and that clear honor Were purchased by the merit of the wearer !

English: How many people who are humble now would be great then ?
Shakespearean: How many then should cover that stand bare !

English: How many noblemen would be weeded out and would become peasants ?
Shakespearean: How much low peasantry would then be gleaned From the true seed of honor !

English: Well , let me get back to my choice .
Shakespearean: Well , but to my choice .

English: He who chooses me will get what he deserves." I'll assume I deserve the very best. , Give me a key for this one .
Shakespearean: Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves." I will assume desert. , Give me a key for this , And instantly unlock my fortunes here .

English: You thought about it too long , considering what you found there .
Shakespearean: Too long a pause for that which you find there .

English: What's this ?
Shakespearean: What's here ?

English: I'll read it. , It looks so unlike Portia !
Shakespearean: I will read it. , How much unlike art thou to Portia !

English: The one who chooses me will get what he deserves" !
Shakespearean: Who chooseth me shall have as much as he deserves" !

English: Didn't I deserve anything more than a fool's head ?
Shakespearean: Did I deserve no more than a fool's head ?

English: Is this my prize ?
Shakespearean: Is that my prize ?

English: Don't I deserve more than this ?
Shakespearean: Are my deserts no better ?

English: What does this say ?
Shakespearean: What is here ?

English: This box was tested in the fire seven times .
Shakespearean: The fire seven times tried this , Seven times tried that judgment is , That did never choose amiss .

English: Some people kiss shadows .
Shakespearean: Some there be that shadows kiss .

English: They only feel the shadow of joy .
Shakespearean: Such have but a shadow's bliss .

English: This choice was as foolish as they are .
Shakespearean: There be fools alive , iwis , Silvered o'er , and so was this .

English: Take whatever wife you want to bed with you , You'll have a fool's head forever .
Shakespearean: Take what wife you will to bed , I will ever be your head .

English: So go away .
Shakespearean: So be gone .

English: I came here with a fool's head on my shoulders and now I'm leaving with two. , Goodbye , sweet lady .
Shakespearean: With one fool's head I came to woo , But I go away with two. , Sweet , adieu .

English: I'll keep my oath and patiently suffer through my anger .
Shakespearean: I'll keep my oath Patiently to bear my wroth."

English: This is how the candle burned the moth .
Shakespearean: Thus hath the candle singed the moth .

English: Oh , these fools !
Shakespearean: O these deliberate fools !

English: When they choose , they only know how to lose .
Shakespearean: When they do choose , They have the wisdom by their wit to lose .

English: You know what they say .
Shakespearean: The ancient saying is no heresy .

English: Destiny chooses when you'll die and who you'll marry .
Shakespearean: Hanging and wiving goes by destiny .

English: Come on , close the curtain , Nerissa .
Shakespearean: Come , draw the curtain , Nerissa .

English: Where's lady Portia ?
Shakespearean: Where is my lady ?

English: Here .
Shakespearean: Here .

English: How can I help you , sir ?
Shakespearean: What would my lord ?

English: I haven't seen such a promising candidate for your love .
Shakespearean: Yet I have not seen So likely an ambassador of love .

English: Please don't tell me any more .
Shakespearean: No more , I pray thee .

English: Come on , Nerissa , I want to go see this man who's come so courteously .
Shakespearean: I am half afeard Thou wilt say anon he is some kin to thee , Thou spend'st such high-day wit in praising him. , Come , come , Nerissa , for I long to see Quick Cupid's post that comes so mannerly .

English: So , what's the news on the Rialto ?
Shakespearean: Now , what news on the Rialto ?

English: But it's true , I don't want to get all mushy and go on and on , but the good Antonio , the honest Antonio , oh , if I only had a title good enough to match his ! , Come on , get to the point .
Shakespearean: But it is true , without any slips of prolixity or crossing the plain highway of talk , that the good Antonio , the honest Antonio , oh , that I had a title good enough to keep his name company ! , Come , the full stop .

English: What are you saying ?
Shakespearean: Ha , what sayest thou ?

English: Well , the point is , he's lost a ship .
Shakespearean: Why , the end is he hath lost a ship .

English: I hope that's all he loses .
Shakespearean: I would it might prove the end of his losses .

English: Let me say "amen" quickly , before the devil comes in and stops my prayer , because here comes the devil , disguised as a Jew .
Shakespearean: Let me say "Amen" betimes , lest the devil cross my prayer , for here he comes in the likeness of a Jew .

English: How's it going , Shylock ?
Shakespearean: How now , Shylock ?

English: What's the news among the merchants ?
Shakespearean: What news among the merchants ?

English: You knew , no one knew , no one knew as well as you did , about my daughter's plans to run away .
Shakespearean: You knew , none so well , none so well as you , of my daughter's flight .

English: That's true .
Shakespearean: That's certain .

English: I even knew the tailor who made the disguise she wore when she ran off .
Shakespearean: I , for my part , knew the tailor that made the wings she flew withal .

English: She'll be damned for it .
Shakespearean: She is damned for it .

English: That's true , if the devil's judging her .
Shakespearean: That's certain , if the devil may be her judge .

English: My own flesh and blood turned against me !
Shakespearean: My own flesh and blood to rebel !

English: A rebel !
Shakespearean: Out upon it , old carrion !

English: No !
Shakespearean: Rebels it at these years ?

English: Your I mean my daughter is my flesh and blood .
Shakespearean: I say my daughter is my flesh and blood .

English: But tell us , did you hear anything about Antonio's loss at sea ?
Shakespearean: But tell us , do you hear whether Antonio have had any loss at sea or no ?

English: All right , we'll see you at dinnertime .
Shakespearean: Well , we will leave you then till dinnertime .

English: I must be one of these silent so-called wise men Gratiano's talking about , because he never lets me get a word in .
Shakespearean: I must be one of these same dumb wise men , For Gratiano never lets me speak .

English: If you hang around me for two more years , you'll forget the sound of your own voice .
Shakespearean: Well , keep me company but two years more , Thou shalt not know the sound of thine own tongue .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: Thank you .
Shakespearean: I'll grow a talker for this gear .

English: Is he right ?
Shakespearean: Is that any thing now ?

English: Gratiano talks more nonsense than any other man in Venice .
Shakespearean: Gratiano speaks an infinite deal of nothing , more than any man in all Venice .

English: You promised to tell me .
Shakespearean: Well , tell me now what lady is the same To whom you swore a secret pilgrimage , That you today promised to tell me of ?

English: That's another bad deal I've made ! , a bankrupt , a spendthrift , who now has to hide his head on the Rialto , a beggar who used to look so smug in front of the other merchants .
Shakespearean: There I have another bad match ! , a bankrupt , a prodigal who dare scarce show his head on the Rialto , a beggar that was used to come so smug upon the mart .

English: Let him think about his own debt .
Shakespearean: Let him look to his bond .

English: He liked to call me a loan shark ; let him think about his debt to me .
Shakespearean: He was wont to call me usurer ; let him look to his bond .

English: He used to lend money as a favor between Christians ; but now , let him think about his own debt .
Shakespearean: He was wont to lend money for a Christian courtesy ; let him look to his bond .

English: But you won't take his flesh if he can't pay .
Shakespearean: Why , I am sure , if he forfeit thou wilt not take his flesh .

English: What's that good for ?
Shakespearean: What's that good for ?

English: I'll use it for fish bait .
Shakespearean: To bait fish withal .

English: He's laughed at my losses , made fun of my earnings , humiliated my race , thwarted my deals , turned my friends against me , riled up my enemies , and why ?
Shakespearean: He hath disgraced me and hindered me half a million , laughed at my losses , mocked at my gains , scorned my nation , thwarted my bargains , cooled my friends , heated mine enemies , and what's his reason ?

English: Because I'm a Jew .
Shakespearean: I am a Jew .

English: Doesn't a Jew have eyes ?
Shakespearean: Hath not a Jew eyes ?

English: Doesn't a Jew have hands , bodily organs , a human shape , five senses , feelings , and passions ?
Shakespearean: Hath not a Jew hands , organs , dimensions , senses , affections , passions ?

English: Doesn't a Jew eat the same food , get hurt with the same weapons , get sick with the same diseases , get healed by the same medicine , and warm up in summer and cool off in winter just like a Christian ?
Shakespearean: Fed with the same food , hurt with the same weapons , subject to the same diseases , healed by the same means , warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer as a Christian is ?

English: If you prick us with a pin , don't we bleed ?
Shakespearean: If you prick us , do we not bleed ?

English: If you tickle us , don't we laugh ?
Shakespearean: If you tickle us , do we not laugh ?

English: If you poison us , don't we die ?
Shakespearean: If you poison us , do we not die ?

English: And if you treat us badly , won't we try to get revenge ?
Shakespearean: And if you wrong us , shall we not revenge ?

English: If we're like you in everything else , we'll resemble you in that respect .
Shakespearean: If we are like you in the rest , we will resemble you in that .

English: If a Jew offends a Christian , what's the Christian's kind and gentle reaction ?
Shakespearean: If a Jew wrong a Christian , what is his humility ?

English: Revenge .
Shakespearean: Revenge .

English: We've been looking for him everywhere .
Shakespearean: We have been up and down to seek him .

English: Here comes another Jew .
Shakespearean: Here comes another of the tribe .

English: You couldn't find a third like these two unless the devil himself turned into a Jew .
Shakespearean: A third can not be matched unless the devil himself turn Jew .

English: Hello , Tubal .
Shakespearean: How now , Tubal ?

English: Any news from Genoa ?
Shakespearean: What news from Genoa ?

English: Did you find my daughter ?
Shakespearean: Hast thou found my daughter ?

English: I went to many places where I heard news about her , but I couldn't find her .
Shakespearean: I often came where I did hear of her , but can not find her .

English: Oh , oh , oh !
Shakespearean: Why , there , there , there , there !

English: I never felt it until now , two thousand ducats in that diamond , and other precious , precious jewels !
Shakespearean: I never felt it till now , Two thousand ducats in that , and other precious , precious jewels .

English: I wish my daughter were dead at my feet wearing those jewels !
Shakespearean: I would my daughter were dead at my foot and the jewels in her ear !

English: I wish she were in her coffin here , with the ducats in her coffin !
Shakespearean: Would she were hearsed at my foot and the ducats in her coffin !

English: You couldn't find out anything about them ?
Shakespearean: No news of them ?

English: Why ?
Shakespearean: Why , so .

English: I don't even know how much I'm spending to find them .
Shakespearean: And I know not what's spent in the search .

English: Loss upon loss !
Shakespearean: Why thou , loss upon loss !

English: Well , other men have bad luck too .
Shakespearean: Yes , other men have ill luck too .

English: Antonio , as I heard in Genoa , What , what , what ?
Shakespearean: Antonio , as I heard in Genoa , What , what , what ?

English: Bad luck , bad luck ?
Shakespearean: Ill luck , ill luck ?

English: He's had a ship wrecked coming from Tripolis .
Shakespearean: Hath an argosy cast away coming from Tripolis .

English: Thank God , thank God !
Shakespearean: I thank God , I thank God !

English: Is it true , is it true ?
Shakespearean: Is 't true , is 't true ?

English: I spoke with some of the sailors who survived the wreck .
Shakespearean: I spoke with some of the sailors that escaped the wrack .

English: Thank you , Tubal .
Shakespearean: I thank thee , good Tubal .

English: Good news , good news !
Shakespearean: Good news , good news !

English: Ha , ha , heard in Genoa .
Shakespearean: Ha , ha , heard in Genoa .

English: I also heard that your daughter spent eighty ducats in Genoa one night .
Shakespearean: Your daughter spent in Genoa , as I heard , in one night fourscore ducats .

English: Oh , you're sticking a dagger in me !
Shakespearean: Thou stickest a dagger in me .

English: I'll never see my gold again .
Shakespearean: I shall never see my gold again .

English: Eighty ducats in one shot !
Shakespearean: Fourscore ducats at a sitting !

English: Eighty ducats !
Shakespearean: Fourscore ducats !

English: I came to Venice with a number of Antonio's creditors who say he won't be able to avoid going bankrupt .
Shakespearean: There came divers of Antonio's creditors in my company to Venice that swear he can not choose but break .

English: I'm very glad about that .
Shakespearean: I am very glad of it .

English: I'll hound him .
Shakespearean: I'll plague him .

English: I'll torture him .
Shakespearean: I'll torture him .

English: I'm very glad .
Shakespearean: I am glad of it .

English: One creditor showed me a ring he got from your daughter in exchange for a monkey .
Shakespearean: One of them showed me a ring that he had of your daughter for a monkey .

English: Damn her !
Shakespearean: Out upon her !

English: You're torturing me , Tubal .
Shakespearean: Thou torturest me , Tubal .

English: That was my turquoise ring !
Shakespearean: It was my turquoise .

English: Leah gave it to me before we were married .
Shakespearean: I had it of Leah when I was a bachelor .

English: I wouldn't have given it away for a whole jungle of monkeys .
Shakespearean: I would not have given it for a wilderness of monkeys .

English: But Antonio's certainly ruined .
Shakespearean: But Antonio is certainly undone .

English: That's true , that's very true .
Shakespearean: Nay , that's true , that's very true .

English: With him out of Venice , I can make whatever bargains I want when I lend money. , Go , Tubal .
Shakespearean: Bespeak him a fortnight before. , I will have the heart of him if he forfeit , for were he out of Venice I can make what merchandise I will. , Go , go , Tubal , and meet me at our synagogue .

English: Meet me at the synagogue .
Shakespearean: Go , good Tubal .

English: Let me choose now .
Shakespearean: At our synagogue , Tubal .

English: I feel tortured by all this talking .
Shakespearean: Before you hazard , for in choosing wrong I lose your company .

English: Tortured ,
Shakespearean: Therefore forbear awhile .

English: They're as opposite as hot and cold .
Shakespearean: There may as well be amity and life 'Tween snow and fire , as treason and my love .

English: Promise me you'll let me live , and I'll confess the truth .
Shakespearean: Promise me life , and I'll confess the truth .

English: All right then , confess and live .
Shakespearean: Well then , confess and live .

English: Confess and love" is more like it .
Shakespearean: Confess and love" Had been the very sum of my confession .

English: But let me try my luck on the boxes .
Shakespearean: But let me to my fortune and the caskets .

English: Go ahead , then .
Shakespearean: Away , then .

English: I'm locked in one of them .
Shakespearean: I am locked in one of them .

English: If you really love me , you'll find me. , Nerissa and the rest of you , get away from him .
Shakespearean: If you do love me you will find me out. , Nerissa and the rest , stand all aloof .

English: Play some music while he chooses .
Shakespearean: Let music sound while he doth make his choice .

English: Then if he loses , it'll be his swan song , music before the end .
Shakespearean: Then if he lose he makes a swanlike end , Fading in music .

English: What music should we play then ?
Shakespearean: He may win , And what is music then ?

English: We've all come out to see what will happen. , Go , Hercules !
Shakespearean: The rest aloof are the Dardanian wives , With bleared visages come forth to view The issue of th ' exploit. , Go , Hercules !

English: If you survive , I'll live .
Shakespearean: Live thou , I live .

English: I'm more anxious watching you fight than you are in the fight itself .
Shakespearean: With much , much more dismay I view the fight than thou that makest the fray .

English: Ding , dong , bell .
Shakespearean: Ding , dong , bell .

English: How many people are cowards at heart but wear beards like Hercules or Mars , the god of war ?
Shakespearean: How many cowards whose hearts are all as false As stairs of sand wear yet upon their chins The beards of Hercules and frowning Mars , Who , inward searched , have livers white as milk , And these assume but valor's excrement To render them redoubted .

English: Curly golden hair moves so nicely in the wind and makes a woman beautiful .
Shakespearean: So are those crisped snaky golden locks Which maketh such wanton gambols with the wind , Upon supposed fairness , often known To be the dowry of a second head , The skull that bred them in the sepulcher .

English: A lovely , cunning shore can distract a man from the perils of a stormy sea , just as a pretty scarf can hide a dangerous dark-skinned beauty .
Shakespearean: Thus ornament is but the guiled shore To a most dangerous sea , the beauteous scarf Veiling an Indian beauty , in a word , The seeming truth which cunning times put on To entrap the wisest .

English: So I'll have nothing to do with that gaudy gold box , it's like the gold that Midas couldn't eat .
Shakespearean: Therefore then , thou gaudy gold , Hard food for Midas , I will none of thee .

English: Since this prize is yours , Be happy with it , and don't look for a new one .
Shakespearean: Since this fortune falls to you , Be content and seek no new .

English: If you're happy with what you've won And accept this prize as your blissful destiny , Then turn to where your lady is , And claim her with a loving kiss."
Shakespearean: If you be well pleased with this And hold your fortune for your bliss , Turn you where your lady is And claim her with a loving kiss."

English: A nice message .
Shakespearean: A gentle scroll .

English: My lady , with your permission , this note authorizes me to give myself to you with a kiss .
Shakespearean: Fair lady , by your leave , I come by note to give and to receive .

English: And so , beautiful lady , I'm standing here just like that , wondering whether all this can be true until you tell me it is .
Shakespearean: Like one of two contending in a prize That thinks he hath done well in people's eyes , Hearing applause and universal shout , Giddy in spirit , still gazing in a doubt Whether these pearls of praise be his or no , So , thrice fair lady , stand I even so , As doubtful whether what I see be true Until confirmed , signed , ratified by you .

English: You see me standing here , Lord Bassanio .
Shakespearean: You see me , Lord Bassanio , where I stand Such as I am .

English: Though I wouldn't wish to be better for my own sake , for your sake I wish I were twenty times more than myself , a thousand times more beautiful and ten thousand times richer , just so you might value me more , so my good qualities , beauty , possessions , and friends would be more than you could calculate .
Shakespearean: Though for myself alone I would not be ambitious in my wish To wish myself much better , yet for you I would be trebled twenty times myself , A thousand times more fair , ten thousand times more rich , That only to stand high in your account I might in virtue , beauties , livings , friends Exceed account .

English: I'm even happier that I'm not stupid , and I can learn .
Shakespearean: Happier than this , She is not bred so dull but she can learn .

English: I'm happiest of all that I'm yours now , my lord , my king , and you can guide me as you wish .
Shakespearean: Happiest of all is that her gentle spirit Commits itself to yours to be directed As from her lord , her governor , her king .

English: Everything I am and everything I have now belongs to you .
Shakespearean: Myself and what is mine to you and yours Is now converted .

English: Just a minute ago I was the owner of this beautiful mansion , master of these servants , and queen over myself .
Shakespearean: But now I was the lord Of this fair mansion , master of my servants , Queen o'er myself .

English: But as of right this second all these things are yours .
Shakespearean: And even now , but now , This house , these servants , and this same myself Are yours , my lord's .

English: With this ring I give them all to you .
Shakespearean: I give them with this ring , Which when you part from , lose , or give away , Let it presage the ruin of your love

English: Please let me know your plan , Bassanio .
Shakespearean: I pray you , good Bassanio , let me know it .

English: As long as it's honorable , you can be sure that I'll let you use all my money and do everything I can to help you .
Shakespearean: And if it stand , as you yourself still do , Within the eye of honor , be assured My purse , my person , my extremest means Lie all unlocked to your occasions .

English: Back when I was a schoolboy , if I lost an arrow I would try to find it by shooting another arrow in the same direction , watching the second arrow more carefully than I had the first .
Shakespearean: In my school days , when I had lost one shaft , I shot his fellow of the selfsame flight The selfsame way with more advised watch To find the other forth , and by adventuring both , I oft found both .

English: By risking the second arrow , I'd often get both of them back .
Shakespearean: I urge this childhood proof Because what follows is pure innocence .

English: I'm telling you this story for a reason .
Shakespearean: I owe you much , and , like a willful youth , That which I owe is lost .

English: I owe you a lot , and like a spoiled kid I've lost what I owe you .
Shakespearean: You know me well , and herein spend but time To wind about my love with circumstance .

English: But if you'd be willing to shoot another arrow the same way you shot the first , I'll watch your arrow more carefully this time .
Shakespearean: And out of doubt you do me now more wrong In making question of my uttermost Than if you had made waste of all I have .

English: Just tell me what to do , and I'll do it .
Shakespearean: Then do but say to me what I should do That in your knowledge may by me be done , And I am pressed unto it .

English: Tell me .
Shakespearean: Therefore speak .

English: If you see me without it , you can be confident I'm dead .
Shakespearean: O , then be bold to say Bassanio's dead !

English: Now we can shout , "Congratulations , congratulations , my lord and lady ! " My Lord Bassanio , and my dear lady , I wish you all the joy I can wish for .
Shakespearean: My lord and lady , it is now our time , That have stood by and seen our wishes prosper , To cry , "Good joy , good joy , my lord and lady ! " My Lord Bassanio and my gentle lady , I wish you all the joy that you can wish , For I am sure you can wish none from me .

English: And when you get married , I hope I can be married at the same time .
Shakespearean: And when your honors mean to solemnize The bargain of your faith , I do beseech you Even at that time I may be married too .

English: Absolutely , if you can find a wife by then .
Shakespearean: With all my heart , so thou canst get a wife .

English: I think I've found one already , thanks to you , my lord .
Shakespearean: I thank your lordship , you have got me one .

English: And do you mean what you're saying , Gratiano ?
Shakespearean: What , and stake down ?

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: What , and my old Venetian friend Salerio ?

English: Hey , if I lay down my " Welcome , Lorenzo and Salerio .
Shakespearean: Lorenzo and Salerio , welcome hither , If that the youth of my new interest here Have power to bid you welcome .

English: I do too , my lord .
Shakespearean: So do I , my lord .

English: They're entirely welcome .
Shakespearean: They are entirely welcome .

English: That's true , and with good reason .
Shakespearean: And I have reason for it .

English: This letter is for you from Signor Antonio .
Shakespearean: Signor Antonio Commends him to you .

English: Before I open this letter , please tell me how my good friend is doing .
Shakespearean: Ere I ope his letter , I pray you tell me how my good friend doth .

English: He's not sick , my lord , but he's very upset , and his problems are serious .
Shakespearean: Not sick , my lord , unless it be in mind , Nor well , unless in mind .

English: His letter will tell you how he's doing .
Shakespearean: His letter there Will show you his estate .

English: I wish you'd won the Something bad in that letter is making Bassanio turn pale .
Shakespearean: There are some shrewd contents in yond same paper That steals the color from Bassanio's cheek .

English: Some good friend of his must have died , because nothing else in the world could change a man so much .
Shakespearean: Some dear friend dead , else nothing in the world Could turn so much the constitution Of any constant man .

English: What , does the news only get worse ? , Please , Bassanio , I'm half of you , so let me bear half the burden this letter brings you .
Shakespearean: What , worse and worse ? , With leave , Bassanio , I am half yourself , And I must freely have the half of anything That this same paper brings you .

English: Oh Portia , these are some of the worst words that ever stained a piece of paper .
Shakespearean: O sweet Portia , Here are a few of the unpleasant'st words That ever blotted paper .

English: My darling , when I gave my love to you , I told you that all the wealth I had ran within my veins , that I have noble blood , but no money .
Shakespearean: Gentle lady , When I did first impart my love to you , I freely told you , all the wealth I had Ran in my veins .

English: When I said that , I told you the truth .
Shakespearean: I was a gentleman , And then I told you true .

English: But my dear , when I said I was worth nothing , I was actually bragging , I should've said that I was worse than nothing .
Shakespearean: When I told you My state was nothing , I should then have told you That I was worse than nothing , for indeed I have engaged myself to a dear friend , Engaged my friend to his mere enemy To feed my means .

English: Have all his business ventures failed ?
Shakespearean: Have all his ventures failed ?

English: Not even one success ?
Shakespearean: What , not one hit ?

English: Not one , my lord .
Shakespearean: Not one , my lord .

English: Anyway , even if he had the money now , the Jew probably wouldn't take it .
Shakespearean: Besides , it should appear that if he had The present money to discharge the Jew , He would not take it .

English: I've never seen a creature with a human shape who was so eager to destroy a man .
Shakespearean: Never did I know A creature that did bear the shape of man So keen and greedy to confound a man .

English: He's at the duke's morning and night , accusing the state of harming free trade if they deny him justice .
Shakespearean: He plies the duke at morning and at night , And doth impeach the freedom of the state If they deny him justice .

English: When I was still living with him I heard him swear to Tubal and Cush , his countrymen , that he'd rather have Antonio's flesh than twenty times the sum Antonio owed .
Shakespearean: When I was with him I have heard him swear To Tubal and to Chus , his countrymen , That he would rather have Antonio's flesh Than twenty times the value of the sum That he did owe him .

English: And I know that unless the law intervenes , it'll be bad news for poor Antonio .
Shakespearean: And I know , my lord , If law , authority , and power deny not , It will go hard with poor Antonio .

English: Is this your good friend who's in so much trouble ?
Shakespearean: Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble ?

English: How much does he owe the Jew ?
Shakespearean: What sum owes he the Jew ?

English: Three thousand ducats .
Shakespearean: For me , three thousand ducats .

English: What , that's all ?
Shakespearean: What , no more ?

English: Pay him six thousand and cancel the debt .
Shakespearean: Pay him six thousand and deface the bond !

English: I'll give you enough gold to pay back your debt twenty times over .
Shakespearean: You shall have gold To pay the petty debt twenty times over .

English: When it's paid , bring your friend back .
Shakespearean: When it is paid , bring your true friend along .

English: Until you get back , Nerissa and I will live like virgins and widows .
Shakespearean: My maid Nerissa and myself meantime Will live as maids and widows .

English: Put on a happy face , and welcome your friends .
Shakespearean: Bid your friends welcome , show a merry cheer .

English: But let me hear the letter from your friend .
Shakespearean: But let me hear the letter of your friend .

English: Dear Bassanio , my ships have all been wrecked .
Shakespearean: Sweet Bassanio , my ships have all miscarried .

English: My creditors are getting mean .
Shakespearean: My creditors grow cruel .

English: My money's almost run out .
Shakespearean: My estate is very low .

English: I couldn't pay my debt to the Jew on the due date .
Shakespearean: My bond to the Jew is forfeit .

English: In any case , do what you want .
Shakespearean: Notwithstanding , use your pleasure .

English: If your affection for me doesn't convince you to come , don't let my letter do so." Oh , my darling , make your arrangements and go !
Shakespearean: If your love do not persuade you to come , let not my letter." O love , dispatch all business and be gone !

English: Since you're letting me leave , I'll hurry .
Shakespearean: Since I have your good leave to go away , I will make haste .

English: But I won't sleep till I get back .
Shakespearean: But till I come again , No bed shall e'er be guilty of my stay , No rest be interposer 'twixt us twain .

English: Jailer , watch out for this one .
Shakespearean: Jailer , look to him .

English: This is the fool who lent out money without charging interest .
Shakespearean: This is the fool that lent out money gratis .

English: Jailer , keep an eye on him .
Shakespearean: Jailer , look to him .

English: Listen to me , good Shylock .
Shakespearean: Hear me yet , good Shylock .

English: I'm going to get my Please , listen to me .
Shakespearean: I pray thee , hear me speak .

English: I want my bond .
Shakespearean: I'll have my bond .

English: I won't listen to you .
Shakespearean: I will not hear thee speak .

English: I want my bond , so stop talking .
Shakespearean: I'll have my bond , and therefore speak no more .

English: I won't be taken for a fool who sighs and gives in to Christian meddlers .
Shakespearean: I'll not be made a soft and dull-eyed fool To shake the head , relent and sigh , and yield To Christian intercessors .

English: Don't follow me .
Shakespearean: Follow not .

English: I'm not talking with you .
Shakespearean: I'll have no speaking .

English: I want my bond .
Shakespearean: I will have my bond .

English: He's the most stubborn dog that ever lived among humans .
Shakespearean: It is the most impenetrable cur That ever kept with men .

English: Leave him alone .
Shakespearean: Let him alone .

English: I won't follow him around with useless pleas anymore .
Shakespearean: I'll follow him no more with bootless prayers .

English: He wants me dead .
Shakespearean: He seeks my life .

English: I know the real reason .
Shakespearean: His reason well I know .

English: I've often given money to people who were unable to pay back their loans to him .
Shakespearean: I oft delivered from his forfeitures Many that have at times made moan to me .

English: That's why he hates me .
Shakespearean: Therefore he hates me .

English: I'm sure the duke will never allow this contract to be enforced .
Shakespearean: I am sure the duke Will never grant this forfeiture to hold .

English: So go .
Shakespearean: Therefore go .

English: I've lost so much weight worrying about my losses have that I'll hardly have a pound of flesh to spare for my bloody creditor tomorrow. , Well , jailer , let's go. , I hope to God that Bassanio comes to see me pay his debt .
Shakespearean: These griefs and losses have so bated me , That I shall hardly spare a pound of flesh Tomorrow to my bloody creditor. , Well , jailer , on. , Pray God Bassanio come To see me pay his debt , and then I care not .

English: Lorenzo , please take charge of the management of my house until my husband comes back .
Shakespearean: Lorenzo , I commit into your hands The husbandry and manage of my house Until my lord's return .

English: Madam , with all my heart .
Shakespearean: Madam , with all my heart .

English: I'll do anything you ask .
Shakespearean: I shall obey you in all fair commands .

English: They'll consider you and Jessica masters of this house in place of Lord Bassanio and myself .
Shakespearean: My people do already know my mind And will acknowledge you and Jessica In place of Lord Bassanio and myself .

English: So goodbye until we meet again .
Shakespearean: So fare you well till we shall meet again .

English: Goodbye , Jessica .
Shakespearean: Fare you well , Jessica .

English: Now , Balthazar , you've always been honest and faithful to me , and I trust you still are .
Shakespearean: Now , Balthazar , As I have ever found thee honest true , So let me find thee still .

English: Sometimes the expression on her face tells me she likes me .
Shakespearean: Sometimes from her eyes I did receive fair speechless messages .

English: Her name is Portia .
Shakespearean: Her name is Portia , nothing undervalued To Cato's daughter , Brutus ' Portia .

English: I'll meet you at the ferry .
Shakespearean: I shall be there before thee .

English: I'll go as fast as I can , madam .
Shakespearean: Madam , I go with all convenient speed .

English: Come on , Nerissa , I have many things to do that you don't even know about yet .
Shakespearean: Come on , Nerissa , I have work in hand That you yet know not of .

English: We'll see our husbands before they even have a chance to miss us .
Shakespearean: We'll see our husbands Before they think of us .

English: Will they see us ?
Shakespearean: Shall they see us ?

English: They will , Nerissa , but we'll be disguised as men .
Shakespearean: They shall , Nerissa , but in such a habit That they shall think we are accomplished With that we lack .

English: I'll tell twenty lies like that , so men will think I graduated from school at least a year ago .
Shakespearean: And twenty of these puny lies I'll tell , That men shall swear I have discontinued school Above a twelvemonth .

English: I know a thousand immature tricks like that , and I'll use them all .
Shakespearean: I have within my mind A thousand raw tricks of these bragging jacks Which I will practice .

English: Why , are we turning to men ?
Shakespearean: Why , shall we turn to men ?

English: What kind of question is that !
Shakespearean: Fie , what a question's that If thou wert near a lewd interpreter !

English: Here , I'll tell you my whole plan in my carriage , which is waiting for us at the gate .
Shakespearean: But come , I'll tell thee all my whole device When I am in my coach , which stays for us At the park gate .

English: So hurry up , because we have twenty miles to cover today .
Shakespearean: And therefore haste away , For we must measure twenty miles today .

English: Yes , look , it's true that children are punished for the sins of their fathers .
Shakespearean: Yes , truly , for look you , the sins of the father are to be laid upon the children .

English: That's why I'm worried about you .
Shakespearean: Therefore I promise ye I fear you .

English: I've always been straightforward with you , so now I'm telling you what I think .
Shakespearean: I was always plain with you , and so now I speak my agitation of the matter .

English: Cheer up , because I think you're going to hell .
Shakespearean: Therefore be o ' good cheer , for truly I think you are damned .

English: There's only one hope for you , and even that's a kind of illegitimate hope .
Shakespearean: There is but one hope in it that can do you any good , and that is but a kind of bastard hope neither .

English: What hope is that , may I ask ?
Shakespearean: And what hope is that , I pray thee ?

English: You can hope your father isn't your real father .
Shakespearean: Marry , you may partly hope that your father got you not , that you are not the Jew's daughter .

English: That really is an illegitimate hope .
Shakespearean: That were a kind of bastard hope indeed .

English: Then I'd be punished for the sins of my mother .
Shakespearean: So the sins of my mother should be visited upon me .

English: In that case I'm afraid you're damned by both your father and your mother .
Shakespearean: Truly then I fear you are damned both by father and mother .

English: When you avoid one trap , you fall into another .
Shakespearean: Thus when I shun Scylla your father , I fall into Charybdis your mother .

English: You're in trouble either way .
Shakespearean: Well , you are gone both ways .

English: My husband will save me .
Shakespearean: I shall be saved by my husband .

English: He's made me a Christian .
Shakespearean: He hath made me a Christian .

English: He was wrong to do that .
Shakespearean: Truly , the more to blame he .

English: There were enough Christians before , as many of them as could stand to live near each other .
Shakespearean: We were Christians eno ' before , e'en as many as could well live one by another .

English: All these new Christians will make the price of hogs go up .
Shakespearean: This making Christians will raise the price of hogs .

English: If we're all pork-eaters , we won't be able to get our hands on a slice of bacon , even if we've got the money for it .
Shakespearean: If we grow all to be pork-eaters , we shall not shortly have a rasher on the coals for money .

English: I'll tell my husband what you've said , Launcelot .
Shakespearean: I'll tell my husband , Launcelot , what you say .

English: Here he comes .
Shakespearean: Here he comes .

English: You're going to make me jealous , Launcelot , if you keep taking my wife into dark corners like this !
Shakespearean: I shall grow jealous of you shortly , Launcelot , if you thus get my wife into corners .

English: No , you don't need to worry about us , Lorenzo .
Shakespearean: Nay , you need not fear us , Lorenzo .

English: Launcelot and I can't agree on anything .
Shakespearean: Launcelot and I are out .

English: He says I won't get into heaven because I'm a Jew's daughter , and he says you're irresponsible because by converting Jews to Christianity you're raising the price of pork .
Shakespearean: He tells me flatly there is no mercy for me in heaven because I am a Jew's daughter , and he says you are no good member of the commonwealth , for in converting Jews to Christians you raise the price of pork .

English: I can justify that better than you can justify sleeping with Portia's African servant .
Shakespearean: I shall answer that better to the commonwealth than you can the getting up of the Negro's belly .

English: The It's too bad there's more of the Moor than there ought to be .
Shakespearean: It is much that the Moor should be more than reason .

English: I think the best sign of intelligence will soon be silence , and talking will only be a good thing for parrots to do .
Shakespearean: I think the best grace of wit will shortly turn into silence , and discourse grow commendable in none only but parrots .

English: That's already been done , sir .
Shakespearean: That is done , sir .

English: They're all ready to eat dinner .
Shakespearean: They have all stomachs .

English: Good Lord , what a clown you are !
Shakespearean: Goodly Lord , what a wit-snapper are you !

English: Are you planning on showing me all your wit at once ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou show the whole wealth of thy wit in an instant ?

English: About the table , sir , dinner will be served on it .
Shakespearean: For the table , sir , it shall be served in .

English: As for the food , it will be served in covered dishes .
Shakespearean: For the meat , sir , it shall be covered .

English: As for your coming in to dinner , just do what you feel is right .
Shakespearean: For your coming in to dinner , sir , why , let it be as humours and conceits shall govern .

English: Oh , he's good at bending words around !
Shakespearean: O dear discretion , how his words are suited !

English: Anyway , how are you , Jessica ?
Shakespearean: How cheerest thou , Jessica ?

English: And how do you like Lord Bassanio's wife ?
Shakespearean: How dost thou like the Lord Bassanio's wife ?

English: I like her more than I can say .
Shakespearean: Past all expressing .

English: And if he doesn't deserve this joy on earth , he'll never deserve it in heaven .
Shakespearean: And if on earth he do not merit it , In reason he should never come to heaven .

English: The poor rude world doesn't have her equal .
Shakespearean: Why , if two gods should play some heavenly match And on the wager lay two earthly women , And Portia one , there must be something else Pawned with the other , for the poor rude world Hath not her fellow .

English: As good a wife as she is , that's how good a husband I am to you .
Shakespearean: Even such a husband Hast thou of me as she is for a wife .

English: First let's go to dinner .
Shakespearean: First let us go to dinner .

English: No , let me say some good things about you while I'm in the mood .
Shakespearean: Nay , let me praise you while I have a stomach .

English: No , please , save it for dinner conversation .
Shakespearean: No , pray thee , let it serve for table talk .

English: Is Antonio here ?
Shakespearean: What , is Antonio here ?

English: Yes , sir , I'm here .
Shakespearean: Ready , so please your grace .

English: I feel sorry for you .
Shakespearean: I am sorry for thee .

English: You've come to face a ruthless enemy , an inhuman wretch incapable of pity , without any feelings of mercy .
Shakespearean: Thou art come to answer A stony adversary , an inhuman wretch Uncapable of pity , void and empty From any dram of mercy .

English: They tell me you've done everything you can to talk him out of what he's doing .
Shakespearean: I have heard Your grace hath ta'en great pains to qualify His rigorous course .

English: I'm ready to suffer peacefully whatever he does to me in his cruelty and anger .
Shakespearean: But since he stands obdurate And that no lawful means can carry me Out of his envy's reach , I do oppose My patience to his fury , and am armed To suffer with a quietness of spirit The very tyranny and rage of his .

English: One of you go call the Jew into court here .
Shakespearean: Go , one , and call the Jew into the court .

English: He's standing ready outside the door .
Shakespearean: He is ready at the door .

English: Here he comes , my lord .
Shakespearean: He comes , my lord .

English: We all expect a nice answer from you , Jew .
Shakespearean: We all expect a gentle answer , Jew .

English: I've told you what I intend to do , and I've sworn by the holy Sabbath to seek the penalty that is due according to our contract .
Shakespearean: I have possessed your grace of what I purpose , And by our holy Sabbath have I sworn To have the due and forfeit of my bond .

English: If you refuse to allow me to do so , your city's charter and its freedom are endangered .
Shakespearean: If you deny it , let the danger light Upon your charter and your city's freedom .

English: You're going to ask me why I'd rather have a pound of decaying flesh than three thousand ducats .
Shakespearean: You'll ask me why I rather choose to have A weight of carrion flesh than to receive Three thousand ducats .

English: I won't answer that .
Shakespearean: I'll not answer that But say it is my humour .

English: Is that enough of an answer ?
Shakespearean: Is it answered ?

English: What if I had a rat in my house , and I felt like paying ten thousand ducats to have it exterminated ?
Shakespearean: What if my house be troubled with a rat And I be pleased to give ten thousand ducats To have it baned ?

English: Do you have your answer yet ?
Shakespearean: What , are you answered yet ?

English: Some men don't like roast pig , others go crazy if they see a cat , and others can't help urinating when they hear bagpipes .
Shakespearean: Some men there are love not a gaping pig , Some that are mad if they behold a cat , And others , when the bagpipe sings i ' th ' nose , Can not contain their urine .

English: So , to answer your question .
Shakespearean: Are you answered ?

English: It doesn't excuse your cruel behavior .
Shakespearean: This is no answer , thou unfeeling man , To excuse the current of thy cruelty .

English: I don't have to give you answers that you like .
Shakespearean: I am not bound to please thee with my answers .

English: Does everyone kill what they don't love ?
Shakespearean: Do all men kill the things they do not love ?

English: What , would you let a snake bite you twice ?
Shakespearean: What , wouldst thou have a serpent sting thee twice ?

English: You might as well do the impossible rather than try to soften his Jewish heart .
Shakespearean: You may as well do anything most hard , As seek to soften that , than which what's harder ? , His Jewish heart .

English: I would choose to take my penalty .
Shakespearean: I would have my bond .

English: How can you ever hope for mercy for yourself , when you don't give any now ?
Shakespearean: How shalt thou hope for mercy , rendering none ?

English: Why should I be afraid of your judgment when I haven't done anything wrong ?
Shakespearean: What judgment shall I dread , doing no wrong ?

English: Many of you own slaves , which , like your donkeys and dogs and mules , you use to perform awful jobs just because you bought them .
