Shakespearean: You have among you many a purchased slave , Which , like your asses and your dogs and mules , You use in abject and in slavish parts Because you bought them .

English: Should I say to you , "Set them free !
Shakespearean: Shall I say to you , "Let them be free !

English: Let them marry your children !
Shakespearean: Marry them to your heirs !

English: Why are you making them work so hard ?
Shakespearean: Why sweat they under burdens ?

English: Let their beds be as soft as yours , and let them eat the same food as you" ?
Shakespearean: Let their beds Be made as soft as yours and let their palates Be seasoned with such viands" ?

English: No , you'd answer , "The slaves are ours." And that's just how I'm answering you .
Shakespearean: You will answer , "The slaves are ours." So do I answer you .

English: The pound of flesh that I want from him was very expensive .
Shakespearean: The pound of flesh which I demand of him Is dearly bought .

English: It's mine and I'm going to get it .
Shakespearean: Tis mine and I will have it .

English: If you refuse me , the laws of Venice have no validity .
Shakespearean: If you deny me , fie upon your law , There is no force in the decrees of Venice .

English: I await justice .
Shakespearean: I stand for judgment .

English: Oh Nerissa , my poor little body is tired of this great big world .
Shakespearean: By my troth , Nerissa , my little body is aweary of this great world .

English: But as far as I can tell , people with too much suffer as much as people with nothing .
Shakespearean: And yet for aught I see , they are as sick that surfeit with too much as they that starve with nothing .

English: The best way to be happy is to be in between .
Shakespearean: It is no mean happiness , therefore , to be seated in the mean .

English: Good point , and well said .
Shakespearean: Good sentences , and well pronounced .

English: It would be better if you actually applied it to your life .
Shakespearean: They would be better if well followed .

English: It takes a good priest to practice what he preaches .
Shakespearean: It is a good divine that follows his own instructions .

English: But thinking like this won't help me choose a husband .
Shakespearean: But this reasoning is not in the fashion to choose me a husband .

English: Isn't it a pain that I can't choose or refuse anyone , Nerissa ?
Shakespearean: Is it not hard , Nerissa , that I can not choose one nor refuse none ?

English: I have the authority to dismiss this court , unless Bellario comes today .
Shakespearean: Upon my power I may dismiss this court , Unless Bellario , a learned doctor , Whom I have sent for to determine this , Come here today .

English: Bring us the letters .
Shakespearean: Bring us the letter .

English: Call the messenger in .
Shakespearean: Call the messenger .

English: Cheer up , Antonio !
Shakespearean: Good cheer , Antonio !

English: Keep up your courage , man !
Shakespearean: What , man , courage yet !

English: I'll give the Jew my flesh , blood , bones , and everything before you lose one drop of blood for me .
Shakespearean: The Jew shall have my flesh , blood , bones and all , Ere thou shalt lose for me one drop of blood .

English: I'm like the one sick sheep in the flock , the one who deserves to die .
Shakespearean: I am a tainted wether of the flock , Meetest for death .

English: The weakest fruit drops to the ground first , so let me drop .
Shakespearean: The weakest kind of fruit Drops earliest to the ground , and so let me .

English: Bassanio , the best thing you can do is to keep living and write an epitaph for my gravestone .
Shakespearean: You can not better be employed , Bassanio , Than to live still and write mine epitaph .

English: Have you come from Bellario's office in Padua ?
Shakespearean: Came you from Padua , from Bellario ?

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: From both , my lord .

English: Bellario sends his greetings .
Shakespearean: Bellario greets your grace .

English: To cut my penalty from that bankrupt man over there .
Shakespearean: To cut the forfeiture from that bankrupt there .

English: You're sharpening that knife not on your sole but on your soul , you cruel Jew .
Shakespearean: Not on thy sole , but on thy soul , harsh Jew , Thou makest thy knife keen .

English: No metal , not even the executioner's axe , could ever be half as sharp as your hatred .
Shakespearean: But no metal can , No , not the hangman's axe , bear half the keenness Of thy sharp envy .

English: Can't any prayers reach your heart ?
Shakespearean: Can no prayers pierce thee ?

English: No , none that you're smart enough to make .
Shakespearean: No , none that thou hast wit enough to make .

English: You make me want to agree with the philosopher Pythagoras that animal souls are reincarnated in human bodies .
Shakespearean: Thou almost makest me waver in my faith To hold opinion with Pythagoras That souls of animals infuse themselves Into the trunks of men .

English: That's why your desires are wolfish , bloody , and ravenous .
Shakespearean: Thy currish spirit Governed a wolf who , hanged for human slaughter , Even from the gallows did his fell soul fleet , And whilst thou layest in thy unhallowed dam Infused itself in thee , for thy desires Are wolvish , bloody , starved , and ravenous .

English: Unless your taunts can undo the signature on my contract , you're just wearing out your lungs by speaking so loud .
Shakespearean: Till thou canst rail the seal from off my bond , Thou but offend'st thy lungs to speak so loud .

English: Be quiet , boy , or you'll lose your mind .
Shakespearean: Repair thy wit , good youth , or it will fall To cureless ruin .

English: I stand here with the law on my side .
Shakespearean: I stand here for law .

English: This letter from Bellario introduces us to a young and well-educated legal expert .
Shakespearean: This letter from Bellario doth commend A young and learned doctor to our court .

English: Where is he ?
Shakespearean: Where is he ?

English: He's waiting nearby to find out if you'll invite him in .
Shakespearean: He attendeth here hard by To know your answer whether you'll admit him .

English: With all my heart. , Three or four of you go welcome him. , In the meantime , I'll read Bellario's letter out loud .
Shakespearean: With all my heart. , Some three or four of you Go give him courteous conduct to this place. , Meantime the court shall hear Bellario's letter .

English: His name is Balthazar .
Shakespearean: His name is Balthazar .

English: I leave him to you .
Shakespearean: I leave him to your gracious acceptance , whose trial shall better publish his commendation." You hear the learned Bellario , what he writes .

English: Did old Bellario send you here ?
Shakespearean: Come you from old Bellario ?

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: I did , my lord .

English: Welcome .
Shakespearean: You are welcome .

English: Please have a seat .
Shakespearean: Take your place .

English: Are you familiar with the case currently before the court ?
Shakespearean: Are you acquainted with the difference That holds this present question in the court ?

English: Yes , thoroughly .
Shakespearean: I am informed thoroughly of the cause .

English: Antonio and Shylock , both of you come forward .
Shakespearean: Antonio and old Shylock , both stand forth .

English: Is your name Shylock ?
Shakespearean: Is your name Shylock ?

English: Shylock is my name .
Shakespearean: Shylock is my name .

English: Your case is most unusual , though the Venetian law can't stop you from proceeding. , Yes , so he says .
Shakespearean: Of a strange nature is the suit you follow , Yet in such rule that the Venetian law Can not impugn you as you do proceed. , Ay , so he says .

English: Do you acknowledge the contract ?
Shakespearean: Do you confess the bond ?

English: Yes , I do .
Shakespearean: I do .

English: Then the Jew must show you mercy .
Shakespearean: Then must the Jew be merciful .

English: Why do I have to do that ?
Shakespearean: On what compulsion must I ?

English: Tell me .
Shakespearean: Tell me that .

English: No one shows mercy because he has to .
Shakespearean: The quality of mercy is not strained .

English: It just happens , the way gentle rain drops on the ground .
Shakespearean: It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven Upon the place beneath .

English: It blesses the one who gives it and the one who receives it .
Shakespearean: It is twice blessed : It blesseth him that gives and him that takes .

English: It's strongest in the strongest people .
Shakespearean: Tis mightiest in the mightiest .

English: It looks better in a king than his own crown looks on him .
Shakespearean: It becomes The throned monarch better than his crown .

English: Kingly power seems most like God's power when the king mixes mercy with justice .
Shakespearean: And earthly power doth then show likest God's When mercy seasons justice .

English: If you pursue it , this strict court of Venice will need to carry out the sentence against the merchant there .
Shakespearean: I have spoke thus much To mitigate the justice of thy plea , Which if thou follow , this strict court of Venice Must needs give sentence 'gainst the merchant there .

English: I take all responsibility for my decisions .
Shakespearean: My deeds upon my head .

English: I want the law , the penalty , and the fulfillment of my contract .
Shakespearean: I crave the law , The penalty , and forfeit of my bond .

English: Can't he pay back the money ?
Shakespearean: Is he not able to discharge the money ?

English: If that's not enough , I'll sign a contract to pay ten times that much , and I'll give you my hands , my head , and my heart as security .
Shakespearean: If that will not suffice , I will be bound to pay it ten times o'er , On forfeit of my hands , my head , my heart .

English: There's no power in Venice that can change an established decree .
Shakespearean: There is no power in Venice Can alter a decree established .

English: The change will be recorded as a precedent , and many bad legal decisions will result .
Shakespearean: Twill be recorded for a precedent , And many an error by the same example Will rush into the state .

English: That can't happen .
Shakespearean: It can not be .

English: Please , let me review the contract .
Shakespearean: I pray you , let me look upon the bond .

English: Shylock , they're offering you three times the money you lent .
Shakespearean: Shylock , there's thrice thy money offered thee .

English: But I made an oath , an oath , an oath in heaven .
Shakespearean: An oath , an oath , I have an oath in heaven .

English: Should I perjure my soul by disobeying it ?
Shakespearean: Shall I lay perjury upon my soul ?

English: No , not for all of Venice .
Shakespearean: No , not for Venice .

English: And so the Jew may lawfully claim a pound of flesh nearest the merchant's heart , to be cut off by him. , But please have mercy .
Shakespearean: And lawfully by this the Jew may claim A pound of flesh to be by him cut off Nearest the merchant's heart. , Be merciful .

English: Take three times your money .
Shakespearean: Take thrice thy money .

English: Tell me to tear up this contract .
Shakespearean: Bid me tear the bond .

English: I'll tear it up when it's paid .
Shakespearean: When it is paid according to the tenor .

English: You seem like a good judge .
Shakespearean: It doth appear you are a worthy judge .

English: You know the law .
Shakespearean: You know the law .

English: I urge you to deliver your verdict .
Shakespearean: I charge you by the law , Whereof you are a well-deserving pillar , Proceed to judgment .

English: I swear that nothing anyone can say will change my mind .
Shakespearean: By my soul I swear There is no power in the tongue of man To alter me .

English: I'm sticking to the contract .
Shakespearean: I stay here on my bond .

English: I beg the court to deliver the verdict .
Shakespearean: Most heartily I do beseech the court To give the judgment .

English: Well , then , here it is : you must prepare yourself for his knife .
Shakespearean: Why then , thus it is : You must prepare your bosom for his knife .

English: Oh , good judge !
Shakespearean: O noble judge !

English: Oh , you excellent young man !
Shakespearean: O excellent young man !

English: The law fully authorizes the penalty , which you have to pay according to the contract .
Shakespearean: For the intent and purpose of the law Hath full relation to the penalty , Which here appeareth due upon the bond .

English: Very true .
Shakespearean: Tis very true .

English: Oh wise judge !
Shakespearean: O wise and upright judge !

English: You're so much older than you look !
Shakespearean: How much more elder art thou than thy looks !

English: Yes , his chest !
Shakespearean: Ay , his breast .

English: Nearest his heart." , Those are the very words .
Shakespearean: Nearest his heart" , those are the very words .

English: Yes .
Shakespearean: It is so .

English: Is there a scale here to weigh the flesh ?
Shakespearean: Are there balance here to weigh The flesh ?

English: I have it ready .
Shakespearean: I have them ready .

English: Pay a surgeon to stand by and bind his wounds , Shylock , so he doesn't bleed to death .
Shakespearean: Have by some surgeon , Shylock , on your charge , To stop his wounds lest he do bleed to death .

English: Is that called for in the contract ?
Shakespearean: Is it so nominated in the bond ?

English: Not explicitly , but so what ?
Shakespearean: It is not so expressed , but what of that ?

English: It wouldn't hurt you to be charitable .
Shakespearean: Twere good you do so much for charity .

English: I can't find it .
Shakespearean: I can not find it .

English: It's not in the contract .
Shakespearean: Tis not in the bond .

English: Not much .
Shakespearean: But little .

English: I'm ready and waiting. , Give me your hand , Bassanio .
Shakespearean: I am armed and well prepared. , Give me your hand , Bassanio .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Fare you well .

English: Don't be sad that this happened because of you , because Lady Luck's been nicer to me than usual .
Shakespearean: Grieve not that I am fall'n to this for you , For herein Fortune shows herself more kind Than is her custom .

English: Be sad only at the fact that you'll lose your friend , your friend doesn't regret that he paid your debt .
Shakespearean: Repent but you that you shall lose your friend , And he repents not that he pays your debt .

English: If the Jew cuts deep enough , I'll pay it instantly with all my heart .
Shakespearean: For if the Jew do cut but deep enough , I'll pay it presently with all my heart .

English: Antonio , I married a woman as dear to me as life itself .
Shakespearean: Antonio , I am married to a wife Which is as dear to me as life itself .

English: But life itself , my wife , and the whole world aren't more valuable to me than your life is .
Shakespearean: But life itself , my wife , and all the world Are not with me esteemed above thy life .

English: I'd give it all up , yes , I'd sacrifice them all to this devil here , to save you .
Shakespearean: I would lose all , ay , sacrifice them all Here to this devil , to deliver you .

English: Your wife wouldn't like it if she were here to hear you make that offer .
Shakespearean: Your wife would give you little thanks for that If she were by to hear you make the offer .

English: I have a wife I love .
Shakespearean: I have a wife , whom I protest I love .

English: I wish she were in heaven so she could appeal to some power to make this dog Jew change his mind .
Shakespearean: I would she were in heaven , so she could Entreat some power to change this currish Jew .

English: It's nice you're offering to sacrifice her behind her back .
Shakespearean: Tis well you offer it behind her back .

English: That's what you get for marrying Christian husbands .
Shakespearean: These be the Christian husbands .

English: I have a daughter .
Shakespearean: I have a daughter .

English: The court awards it and the law authorizes it .
Shakespearean: The court awards it , and the law doth give it .

English: What a righteous judge !
Shakespearean: Most rightful judge !

English: And you have to cut this flesh from his chest .
Shakespearean: And you must cut this flesh from off his breast .

English: The law allows it , and the court awards it .
Shakespearean: The law allows it , and the court awards it .

English: What a wise judge !
Shakespearean: Most learned judge , a sentence !

English: Come on , get ready .
Shakespearean: Come , prepare .

English: But wait a moment .
Shakespearean: Tarry a little .

English: There's something else .
Shakespearean: There is something else .

English: This contract doesn't give you any blood at all .
Shakespearean: This bond doth give thee here no jot of blood .

English: The words expressly specify "a pound of flesh." So take your penalty of a pound of flesh , but if you shed one drop of Christian blood when you cut it , the state of Venice will confiscate your land and property under Venetian law .
Shakespearean: The words expressly are "a pound of flesh." Take then thy bond , take thou thy pound of flesh , But in the cutting it if thou dost shed One drop of Christian blood , thy lands and goods Are by the laws of Venice confiscate Unto the state of Venice .

English: Is that the law ?
Shakespearean: Is that the law ?

English: You can see for yourself .
Shakespearean: Thyself shalt see the act .

English: You asked for justice , so rest assured you'll get more justice than you bargained for .
Shakespearean: For as thou urgest justice , be assured Thou shalt have justice more than thou desirest .

English: Pay me three times the amount of the loan and let the Christian go .
Shakespearean: I take this offer then : pay the bond thrice And let the Christian go .

English: Here is the money .
Shakespearean: Here is the money .

English: Wait !
Shakespearean: Soft !

English: The Jew will have justice .
Shakespearean: The Jew shall have all justice .

English: Wait , don't rush !
Shakespearean: Soft , no haste .

English: He's not getting anything except the penalty .
Shakespearean: He shall have nothing but the penalty .

English: So get ready to cut off the flesh .
Shakespearean: Therefore prepare thee to cut off the flesh .

English: Don't shed any blood , or cut less or more than exactly a pound of flesh .
Shakespearean: Shed thou no blood , nor cut thou less nor more But just a pound of flesh .

English: If you take more or less than exactly a pound , even if it's just the tiniest fraction of an ounce , if the scale changes by even so much as a hair , you die , and all your property will be confiscated .
Shakespearean: If thou takest more Or less than a just pound , be it but so much As makes it light or heavy in the substance Or the division of the twentieth part Of one poor scruple , nay , if the scale do turn But in the estimation of a hair , Thou diest and all thy goods are confiscate .

English: A second Daniel ! , A Daniel , Jew !
Shakespearean: A second Daniel ! , A Daniel , Jew !

English: I've got you now , pagan .
Shakespearean: Now , infidel , I have you on the hip .

English: Why is the Jew waiting ?
Shakespearean: Why doth the Jew pause ?

English: Take your penalty .
Shakespearean: Take thy forfeiture .

English: Give me my money and let me go .
Shakespearean: Give me my principal , and let me go .

English: I have it ready for you .
Shakespearean: I have it ready for thee .

English: Here it is .
Shakespearean: Here it is .

English: Your father was an extremely moral man , and religious people get odd ideas on their deathbeds .
Shakespearean: Your father was ever virtuous , and holy men at their death have good inspirations .

English: But tell me .
Shakespearean: I pray thee , overname them .

English: Well , first there was the prince from Naples .
Shakespearean: First , there is the Neapolitan prince .

English: I'm afraid his mother may have had an affair with a blacksmith .
Shakespearean: I am much afeard my lady his mother played false with a smith .

English: Then there's the Count Palatine .
Shakespearean: Then there is the County Palatine .

English: He does nothing but frown , as if he wants to say , "If you don't want me , I don't care." He doesn't even smile when he hears funny stories .
Shakespearean: He doth nothing but frown , as who should say , "An you will not have me , choose." He hears merry tales and smiles not .

English: If he's so sad and solemn when he's young , I can only imagine how much he'll cry as an old man .
Shakespearean: I fear he will prove the weeping philosopher when he grows old , being so full of unmannerly sadness in his youth .

English: No , I'd rather be married to a skull with a bone in its mouth than to either of those men .
Shakespearean: I had rather be married to a death's-head with a bone in his mouth than to either of these .

English: God protect me from these two !
Shakespearean: God defend me from these two !

English: What did you think about that French lord , Monsieur le Bon ?
Shakespearean: How say you by the French lord , Monsieur le Bon ?

English: No , he refused it publicly , in open court .
Shakespearean: He hath refused it in the open court .

English: He will have only justice and his penalty .
Shakespearean: He shall have merely justice and his bond .

English: You can't have anything but the penalty , to be taken at your peril , Jew .
Shakespearean: Thou shalt have nothing but the forfeiture To be so taken at thy peril , Jew .

English: Well , then , I hope he chokes on it !
Shakespearean: Why then , the devil give him good of it !

English: I'm not staying here to argue anymore .
Shakespearean: I'll stay no longer question .

English: Wait a minute , Jew .
Shakespearean: Tarry , Jew .

English: The law has another hold on you .
Shakespearean: The law hath yet another hold on you .

English: The laws of Venice state that if a foreign resident directly or indirectly attempts to kill any citizen , the person he tried to kill will receive one half of the foreigner's goods .
Shakespearean: It is enacted in the laws of Venice , If it be proved against an alien That by direct or indirect attempts He seek the life of any citizen , The party 'gainst the which he doth contrive Shall seize one half his goods .

English: The other half goes to the state .
Shakespearean: The other half Comes to the privy coffer of the state , And the offender's life lies in the mercy Of the Duke only 'gainst all other voice .

English: So get down on your knees and beg mercy from the duke .
Shakespearean: Down , therefore , and beg mercy of the Duke .

English: So you'll be hanged at the state's expense .
Shakespearean: Therefore thou must be hanged at the state's charge .

English: I want you to see the difference between us , so I pardon you even before you ask for a pardon .
Shakespearean: That thou shalt see the difference of our spirit , I pardon thee thy life before thou ask it .

English: Half of your wealth goes to Antonio .
Shakespearean: For half thy wealth , it is Antonio's .

English: The other half goes to the state .
Shakespearean: The other half comes to the general state , Which humbleness may drive unto a fine .

English: Yes , the state's half can be reduced , but not Antonio's .
Shakespearean: Ay , for the state , not for Antonio .

English: No , go ahead and take my life .
Shakespearean: Nay , take my life and all .

English: Don't pardon that .
Shakespearean: Pardon not that .

English: You take my house away when you take the money I need for upkeep .
Shakespearean: You take my house when you do take the prop That doth sustain my house .

English: You take my life when you take away my means of making a living .
Shakespearean: You take my life When you do take the means whereby I live .

English: What mercy can you show him , Antonio ?
Shakespearean: What mercy can you render him , Antonio ?

English: Nothing else , for God's sake !
Shakespearean: A halter gratis , nothing else , for God's sake .

English: If the duke and his court agree to set aside the fine for one half of his property , I'm happy , as long as he lets me have the other half in trust , to give it to the gentleman who recently stole his daughter .
Shakespearean: So please my lord the duke and all the court , To quit the fine for one half of his goods I am content , so he will let me have The other half in use to render it Upon his death unto the gentleman That lately stole his daughter .

English: Second , he must make a will here in this court that leaves all his property to his son-in-law Lorenzo and his daughter when he dies .
Shakespearean: Two things provided more : that for this favor He presently become a Christian ; The other , that he do record a gift Here in the court , of all he dies possessed , Unto his son Lorenzo and his daughter .

English: He must do this , or I'll recant the pardon I just delivered .
Shakespearean: He shall do this , or else I do recant The pardon that I late pronounced here .

English: Are you satisfied , Jew ?
Shakespearean: Art thou contented , Jew ?

English: What do you say ?
Shakespearean: What dost thou say ?

English: I'm satisfied .
Shakespearean: I am content .

English: Please let me go .
Shakespearean: I pray you , give me leave to go from hence .

English: I'm not well .
Shakespearean: I am not well .

English: Send the deed after me and I'll sign it .
Shakespearean: Send the deed after me , And I will sign it .

English: Go , but sign the deed .
Shakespearean: Get thee gone , but do it .

English: I should really leave right away .
Shakespearean: I must away this night toward Padua , And it is meet I presently set forth .

English: I'm sorry you don't have time. , Antonio , give this gentleman a reward .
Shakespearean: I am sorry that your leisure serves you not. , Antonio , gratify this gentleman , For in my mind you are much bound to him .

English: We owe you love and service forever .
Shakespearean: And stand indebted , over and above , In love and service to you evermore .

English: Being satisfied with a job well done is payment enough .
Shakespearean: He is well paid that is well satisfied .

English: In saving you I consider myself well paid .
Shakespearean: And I , delivering you , am satisfied , And therein do account myself well paid .

English: My thoughts were never on money .
Shakespearean: My mind was never yet more mercenary .

English: I hope you'll recognize me when we meet again .
Shakespearean: I pray you , know me when we meet again .

English: I wish you well .
Shakespearean: I wish you well , and so I take my leave .

English: Take some memento from us as a token of our gratitude , not as a fee .
Shakespearean: Take some remembrance of us as a tribute , Not as a fee .

English: This ring , sir , oh no , it's nothing .
Shakespearean: This ring , good sir , alas , it is a trifle .

English: I'd be ashamed to give you this .
Shakespearean: I will not shame myself to give you this .

English: I don't want anything but that .
Shakespearean: I will have nothing else but only this .

English: Now that I think about it , I really want it .
Shakespearean: And now methinks I have a mind to it .

English: There's more to this ring than its cash value .
Shakespearean: There's more depends on this than on the value .

English: I'll give you the most expensive ring in Venice , and I'll make a public announcement to help me find it .
Shakespearean: The dearest ring in Venice will I give you , And find it out by proclamation .

English: But as for this ring , please excuse me .
Shakespearean: Only for this , I pray you , pardon me .

English: I see you like to make big offers , sir .
Shakespearean: I see , sir , you are liberal in offers .

English: First you taught me how to beg , and now I think you're teaching me how a beggar should be answered .
Shakespearean: You taught me first to beg , and now methinks You teach me how a beggar should be answered .

English: Good sir , this ring was given to me by my wife .
Shakespearean: Good sir , this ring was given me by my wife .

English: When she put it on my finger , she made me swear never to sell it , give it away , or lose it .
Shakespearean: And when she put it on , she made me vow That I should neither sell nor give nor lose it .

English: Many men use that excuse to avoid giving gifts .
Shakespearean: That 'scuse serves many men to save their gifts .

English: If your wife's not a madwoman , and you tell her how much I deserve this ring , she won't stay angry at you forever if you give it to me .
Shakespearean: An if your wife be not a madwoman , And know how well I have deserved the ring , She would not hold out enemy forever For giving it to me .

English: Well , anyway , goodbye .
Shakespearean: Well , peace be with you .

English: Bassanio , let him have the ring .
Shakespearean: My Lord Bassanio , let him have the ring .

English: Come on , you and I will go soon .
Shakespearean: Come , you and I will thither presently .

English: Early in the morning we'll both rush to Belmont .
Shakespearean: And in the morning early will we both Fly toward Belmont .

English: Come on , Antonio .
Shakespearean: Come , Antonio .

English: Find out where the Jew's house is .
Shakespearean: Inquire the Jew's house out .

English: Give him this deed and have him sign it .
Shakespearean: Give him this deed , And let him sign it .

English: We'll leave tonight and be home a day before our husbands get back .
Shakespearean: We'll away tonight , And be a day before our husbands home .

English: Lorenzo will be happy with what we've done .
Shakespearean: This deed will be well welcome to Lorenzo .

English: And could you please take my servant to old Shylock's house ?
Shakespearean: Furthermore , I pray you show my youth old Shylock's house .

English: I'll do that .
Shakespearean: That will I do .

English: Go , hurry .
Shakespearean: Away , make haste .

English: You know where I'll be waiting .
Shakespearean: Thou know'st where I will tarry .

English: The moon's bright tonight .
Shakespearean: The moon shines bright .

English: I think that on a night like this , when the wind blew the trees so gently that they didn't make a sound , On a night like this , On a night like this , On a night like this ,
Shakespearean: In such a night as this , When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees And they did make no noise , in such a night Troilus methinks mounted the Trojan walls And sighed his soul toward the Grecian tents Where Cressid lay that night .

English: On a night like this , young Lorenzo swore he loved her very much , stealing her heart with vows of love , but not one vow was true .
Shakespearean: In such a night Did young Lorenzo swear he loved her well , Stealing her soul with many vows of faith , And ne'er a true one .

English: On a night like this , pretty Jessica , in a bad mood , said outrageously wrong things about her lover , and he forgave her .
Shakespearean: In such a night Did pretty Jessica , like a little shrew , Slander her love , and he forgave it her .

English: I hear his footsteps .
Shakespearean: But , hark , I hear the footing of a man .

English: Who are you , coming so fast in this quiet night ?
Shakespearean: Who comes so fast in silence of the night ?

English: A friend .
Shakespearean: A friend .

English: A friend ?
Shakespearean: A friend ?

English: What friend ?
Shakespearean: What friend ?

English: What's your name , please , friend ?
Shakespearean: Your name , I pray you , friend ?

English: My name's Stephano , and I've come to tell you my mistress will arrive here at Belmont before sunrise .
Shakespearean: Stephano is my name , and I bring word My mistress will before the break of day Be here at Belmont .

English: She's still at the monastery , kneeling and praying for a happy marriage .
Shakespearean: She doth stray about By holy crosses , where she kneels and prays For happy wedlock hours .

English: Who's coming with her ?
Shakespearean: Who comes with her ?

English: No one except her maid and a holy hermit .
Shakespearean: None but a holy hermit and her maid .

English: Has my master returned yet ?
Shakespearean: I pray you , is my master yet returned ?

English: Hey , hey !
Shakespearean: Sola , sola !

English: Hey !
Shakespearean: Wo , ha , ho !

English: Yoo-hoo !
Shakespearean: Sola , sola !

English: Who's shouting ?
Shakespearean: Who calls ?

English: Hey !
Shakespearean: Sola !

English: Have you seen Master Lorenzo !
Shakespearean: Did you see Master Lorenzo ?

English: Stop hollering , man !
Shakespearean: Leave holloaing , man .

English: I'm here .
Shakespearean: Here .

English: Hey !
Shakespearean: Sola !

English: Where , where ?
Shakespearean: Where , where ?

English: Here .
Shakespearean: Here .

English: Tell him a messenger has arrived from my master with good news .
Shakespearean: Tell him there's a post come from my master with his horn full of good news .

English: My master will be here in the morning .
Shakespearean: My master will be here ere morning .

English: My dear , let's go inside and wait for them to arrive .
Shakespearean: Sweet soul , let's in , and there expect their coming .

English: But I guess it doesn't matter .
Shakespearean: And yet no matter .

English: We might as well call him a man , since God created him .
Shakespearean: God made him and therefore let him pass for a man .

English: His horse is better than the Neapolitan's and he frowns more than the Count Palatine .
Shakespearean: In truth , I know it is a sin to be a mocker , but he ! , why , he hath a horse better than the Neapolitan's , a better bad habit of frowning than the Count Palatine .

English: What about Falconbridge , that young English baron ?
Shakespearean: What say you then to Falconbridge , the young baron of England ?

English: I have no opinion about him .
Shakespearean: You know I say nothing to him , for he understands not me , nor I him .

English: He doesn't speak Latin , French , or Italian , and you know how little English I speak .
Shakespearean: He hath neither Latin , French , nor Italian , and you will come into the court and swear that I have a poor pennyworth in the English .

English: He's great-looking , but how can you talk to someone who doesn't speak your language ?
Shakespearean: He is a proper man's picture , but alas , who can converse with a dumb show ?

English: He was dressed so oddly too !
Shakespearean: How oddly he is suited !

English: I think he got his jacket in Italy , his tights in France , his hat in Germany , and his behavior everywhere .
Shakespearean: I think he bought his doublet in Italy , his round hose in France , his bonnet in Germany , and his behavior everywhere .

English: What do you think of his neighbor , the Scottish lord ?
Shakespearean: What think you of the Scottish lord , his neighbor ?

English: How beautiful the moonlight's shining on this bank !
Shakespearean: How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank !

English: Let's sit here and let the music fill our ears .
Shakespearean: Here will we sit and let the sounds of music Creep in our ears .

English: Stillness and nighttime are perfect for beautiful music .
Shakespearean: Soft stillness and the night Become the touches of sweet harmony .

English: Sit down , Jessica .
Shakespearean: Sit , Jessica .

English: Look at the stars , see how the floor of heaven is inlaid with small disks of bright gold .
Shakespearean: Look how the floor of heaven Is thick inlaid with patens of bright gold .

English: Wake up the moon goddess with a hymn !
Shakespearean: Come ho , and wake Diana with a hymn !

English: Get her attention and draw her home with music .
Shakespearean: With sweetest touches pierce your mistress ' ear , And draw her home with music .

English: I'm never in the mood to laugh when I hear sweet music .
Shakespearean: I am never merry when I hear sweet music .

English: His soul is as dull as night and dark as the underworld .
Shakespearean: The motions of his spirit are dull as night , And his affections dark as Erebus .

English: Nobody like that should be trusted .
Shakespearean: Let no such man be trusted .

English: Pay attention to the music .
Shakespearean: Mark the music .

English: That light we see is coming from my hall .
Shakespearean: That light we see is burning in my hall .

English: Look how far that little candle sends its light !
Shakespearean: How far that little candle throws his beams !

English: That's the way a good deed shines in a naughty world .
Shakespearean: So shines a good deed in a naughty world .

English: While the moon was shining we didn't even notice the candle .
Shakespearean: When the moon shone we did not see the candle .

English: Well , brighter lights always dim the smaller ones .
Shakespearean: So doth the greater glory dim the less .

English: A governor shines as brightly as a king until a king is near by , and the governor suddenly looks like a nobody .
Shakespearean: A substitute shines brightly as a king Until a king be by , and then his state Empties itself , as doth an inland brook Into the main of waters .

English: Music , listen !
Shakespearean: Music , hark .

English: It's your music , madam , from your house .
Shakespearean: It is your music , madam , of the house .

English: Now I see that you can't call anything good except in right context .
Shakespearean: Nothing is good , I see , without respect .

English: How many things in life seem good to us because of when they happen !
Shakespearean: How many things by season seasoned are To their right praise and true perfection !

English: Quiet now !
Shakespearean: Peace !

English: Look how the moon seems to be sleeping with its lover and can't be awoken !
Shakespearean: How the moon sleeps with Endymion And would not be awaked .

English: If I'm not mistaken , that's Portia's voice .
Shakespearean: That is the voice , Or I am much deceived , of Portia .

English: He recognizes me like a blind man recognizes a cuckoo , by its bad voice .
Shakespearean: He knows me as the blind man knows the cuckoo , By the bad voice .

English: Dear lady , welcome home .
Shakespearean: Dear lady , welcome home .

English: We've been praying for our husbands ' welfare .
Shakespearean: We have been praying for our husbands ' welfare , Which speed , we hope , the better for our words .

English: Have they come back ?
Shakespearean: Are they returned ?

English: Go inside , Nerissa .
Shakespearean: Go in , Nerissa .

English: Tell my servants not to mention that we were gone .
Shakespearean: Give order to my servants that they take No note at all of our being absent hence. , Nor you , Lorenzo. , Jessica , nor you .

English: I hear his trumpet .
Shakespearean: I hear his trumpet .

English: I think this night is just like sick daylight .
Shakespearean: This night methinks is but the daylight sick .

English: It only looks a little paler .
Shakespearean: It looks a little paler .

English: It looks like a day when the sun is hidden .
Shakespearean: Tis a day Such as the day is when the sun is hid .

English: I'll give Thank you , darling .
Shakespearean: I thank you , madam .

English: I'd like to introduce you to my friend .
Shakespearean: Give welcome to my friend .

English: This is Antonio , my dearest friend .
Shakespearean: This is the man , this is Antonio , To whom I am so infinitely bound .

English: Sir , welcome to our house .
Shakespearean: Sir , you are very welcome to our house .

English: But action speaks louder than words , so I'll cut short these polite words .
Shakespearean: It must appear in other ways than words , Therefore I scant this breathing courtesy .

English: What , an argument already ?
Shakespearean: A quarrel , ho , already ?

English: What's the matter ?
Shakespearean: What's the matter ?

English: It said , "Love me and don't leave me." How can you talk about the quality of the poem or the value of the ring ?
Shakespearean: About a hoop of gold , a paltry ring That she did give me , whose posy was For all the world like cutler's poetry Upon a knife , "Love me and leave me not." What talk you of the posy or the value ?

English: You swore to me when I gave it to you that you would wear it till you died , and that it would be buried with you .
Shakespearean: You swore to me when I did give it you That you would wear it till your hour of death , And that it should lie with you in your grave .

English: And now you claim you gave it to a judge's clerk !
Shakespearean: Gave it a judge's clerk !

English: He will if he lives long enough to become a man .
Shakespearean: He will , an if he live to be a man .

English: Yes , if a woman grows up to be a man .
Shakespearean: Ay , if a woman live to be a man .

English: I didn't have the heart to say no to him .
Shakespearean: I could not for my heart deny it him .

English: You were wrong to give away your wife's first gift so thoughtlessly , a thing you swore to keep on your finger and bound faithfully to your body .
Shakespearean: You were to blame , I must be plain with you , To part so slightly with your wife's first gift , A thing stuck on with oaths upon your finger And so riveted with faith unto your flesh .

English: I gave my lover a ring and made him swear never to lose it or give it away .
Shakespearean: I gave my love a ring and made him swear Never to part with it .

English: And here he is .
Shakespearean: And here he stands .

English: I'd swear he wouldn't leave it behind , or even take it off his finger , for all the money in the world .
Shakespearean: I dare be sworn for him he would not leave it Nor pluck it from his finger for the wealth That the world masters .

English: To tell the truth , Gratiano , you're giving your wife a valid reason to get upset .
Shakespearean: Now in faith , Gratiano , You give your wife too unkind a cause of grief .

English: If it were me , I'd be very upset too .
Shakespearean: An 'twere to me , I should be mad at it .

English: Bassanio gave his ring to the judge who asked for it , and deserved it too .
Shakespearean: My Lord Bassanio gave his ring away Unto the judge that begged it and indeed Deserved it too .

English: And then his clerk , who went to a lot of trouble with the writing , begged for mine .
Shakespearean: And then the boy , his clerk , That took some pains in writing , he begged mine .

English: Neither of them would take anything but the two rings .
Shakespearean: And neither man nor master would take aught But the two rings .

English: Which ring did you give away , my lord ?
Shakespearean: What ring gave you my lord ?

English: Not the one I gave you , I hope .
Shakespearean: Not that , I hope , which you received of me .

English: If I could make things better by lying , I'd deny it .
Shakespearean: If I could add a lie unto a fault I would deny it .

English: But you see my finger doesn't have the ring on it .
Shakespearean: but you see my finger Hath not the ring upon it .

English: It's gone .
Shakespearean: It is gone .

English: My dear Portia , if you knew who I gave the ring to , for whose sake I gave the ring to him , why I gave it to him , and how unwilling I was to leave it when he wouldn't accept anything but the ring , you wouldn't be so angry .
Shakespearean: Sweet Portia , If you did know to whom I gave the ring , If you did know for whom I gave the ring , And would conceive for what I gave the ring , And how unwillingly I left the ring When naught would be accepted but the ring , You would abate the strength of your displeasure .

English: If you'd known how much that ring meant , how much the woman who gave it to you is worth , or how much your honor depended on your keeping the ring , you wouldn't have let it go .
Shakespearean: If you had known the virtue of the ring , Or half her worthiness that gave the ring , Or your own honor to contain the ring , You would not then have parted with the ring .

English: Nerissa's got the right idea .
Shakespearean: Nerissa teaches me what to believe .

English: I'll bet my life you gave some woman the ring !
Shakespearean: I'll die for 't but some woman had the ring .

English: What could I say , my dear ?
Shakespearean: What should I say , sweet lady ?

English: I had to send it to him .
Shakespearean: I was enforced to send it after him .

English: Don't let that lawyer ever come near my house !
Shakespearean: Let not that doctor e'er come near my house !

English: Since he has the jewel I loved , which you swore you'd keep forever , I'll be as generous as you were to him .
Shakespearean: Since he hath got the jewel that I loved , And that which you did swear to keep for me , I will become as liberal as you .

English: I won't deny him anything of mine , including my own body and my husband's bed .
Shakespearean: I'll not deny him anything I have , No , not my body , nor my husband's bed .

English: I'll recognize him all right , I'm sure of it .
Shakespearean: Know him I shall , I am well sure of it .

English: So don't spend one night away from this house .
Shakespearean: Lie not a night from home .

English: Watch me like a hawk .
Shakespearean: Watch me like Argus .

English: If you don't , if I'm left alone , I swear I'll have that legal expert as my bedfellow .
Shakespearean: If you do not , if I be left alone , Now , by mine honor , which is yet mine own , I'll have that doctor for my bedfellow .

English: All these quarrels are about me .
Shakespearean: I am th ' unhappy subject of these quarrels .

English: Don't be upset .
Shakespearean: Sir , grieve not you .

English: All these friends are my witnesses , so I swear to you , I swear by your beautiful eyes , in which I see myself reflected , Did you hear that !
Shakespearean: Portia , forgive me this enforced wrong , And in the hearing of these many friends I swear to thee , even by thine own fair eyes Wherein I see myself , Mark you but that !

English: He sees himself in my two eyes , so there's two of him .
Shakespearean: In both my eyes he doubly sees himself , In each eye , one .

English: He should swear by his two-faced self , and that's an oath I'll believe !
Shakespearean: Swear by your double self , And there's an oath of credit !

English: No , just listen to me .
Shakespearean: Nay , but hear me .

English: If you forgive my mistake , I swear I'll never break an oath with you again .
Shakespearean: Pardon this fault , and by my soul I swear I never more will break an oath with thee .

English: I lent my body once to make him rich .
Shakespearean: I once did lend my body for his wealth , Which but for him that had your husband's ring Had quite miscarried .

English: My God , it's the same one I gave the judge !
Shakespearean: By heaven , it is the same I gave the doctor !

English: I got it from him .
Shakespearean: I had it of him .

English: What , did you cheat on us before we deserved it ?
Shakespearean: What , are we cuckolds ere we have deserved it ?

English: Don't be crass. , You all look confused .
Shakespearean: Speak not so grossly. , You are all amazed .

English: I'm speechless .
Shakespearean: I am dumb .

English: Yes , but the clerk will never do it , unless he grows up to be a man .
Shakespearean: Ay , but the clerk that never means to do it Unless he live until he be a man .

English: Madam , you've given me life and given me a living too .
Shakespearean: Sweet lady , you have given me life and living .

English: How did you like the young German , the duke of Saxony's nephew ?
Shakespearean: How like you the young German , the Duke of Saxony's nephew ?

English: He's pretty awful in the morning when he's sobering up , and even worse in the afternoon when he's drunk .
Shakespearean: Very vilely in the morning , when he is sober , and most vilely in the afternoon , when he is drunk .

English: At his best he's a little less than a man , and at his worst he's little more than an animal .
Shakespearean: When he is best he is a little worse than a man , and when he is worst he is little better than a beast .

English: I'll do anything rather than marry a drunk , Nerissa .
Shakespearean: I will do any thing , Nerissa , ere I'll be married to a sponge .

English: You don't have to worry about any of these lords , my lady .
Shakespearean: You need not fear , lady , the having any of these lords .

English: I wish them all safe trips home .
Shakespearean: And I pray God grant them a fair departure .

English: Do you remember a Venetian scholar and soldier who accompanied the marquess of Montferrat here once when your father was still alive ?
Shakespearean: Do you not remember , lady , in your father's time a Venetian , a scholar and a soldier , that came hither in company of the Marquess of Montferrat ?

English: How are you , Lorenzo ?
Shakespearean: How now , Lorenzo ?

English: My clerk has some comforting news for you , too .
Shakespearean: My clerk hath some good comforts too for you .

English: Yes , and I'll give it to him for free .
Shakespearean: Ay , and I'll give them him without a fee .

English: Ladies , you're dropping bread from the heavens to starving people .
Shakespearean: Fair ladies , you drop manna in the way Of starved people .

English: It's almost morning , but I'm sure you're not fully satisfied about what happened .
Shakespearean: It is almost morning , And yet I am sure you are not satisfied Of these events at full .

English: Let's go inside and we'll answer all your questions truthfully .
Shakespearean: Let us go in , And charge us there upon interr'gatories , And we will answer all things faithfully .

English: All right , then .
Shakespearean: Let it be so .

English: My first question for Nerissa is whether she'd rather wait till tomorrow night or go to bed now , since there are only two more hours till morning .
Shakespearean: The first interr'gatory That my Nerissa shall be sworn on is Whether till the next night she had rather stay , Or go to bed now , being two hours to day .

English: When the day comes , I'll wish it were nighttime , so I could sleep with the legal expert's clerk .
Shakespearean: But were the day come , I should wish it dark , That I were couching with the doctor's clerk .

English: Yes , madam , that's the one .
Shakespearean: True , madam .

English: He deserves a beautiful wife more than all the other men I've ever seen .
Shakespearean: He , of all the men that ever my foolish eyes looked upon , was the best deserving a fair lady .

English: I remember him well , and my memory tells me that he deserves your praise .
Shakespearean: I remember him well , and I remember him worthy of thy praise .

English: Hello , do you have any news ?
Shakespearean: How now , what news ?

English: The four suitors are looking for you so they can say goodbye , madam .
Shakespearean: The four strangers seek for you , madam , to take their leave .

English: And there's a messenger representing a fifth one , the prince of Morocco , who says the prince will be here tonight .
Shakespearean: And there is a forerunner come from a fifth , the Prince of Morocco , who brings word the prince his master will be here tonight .

English: If I could say hello to the fifth one as happily as I'll say goodbye to the first four , I'd be very happy he's coming .
Shakespearean: If I could bid the fifth welcome with so good a heart as I can bid the other four farewell , I should be glad of his approach .

English: If he's as good as a saint but is black like a devil , I'd rather he hear my confession than marry me .
Shakespearean: If he have the condition of a saint and the complexion of a devil , I had rather he should shrive me than wive me .

English: Let's go , Nerissa. ,
Shakespearean: Come , Nerissa. ,

English: Three thousand ducats , hmmm .
Shakespearean: Three thousand ducats , well .

English: Yes , for three months .
Shakespearean: Ay , sir , for three months .

English: For three months , hmmm .
Shakespearean: For three months , well .

English: As I said before , Antonio will guarantee the loan .
Shakespearean: For the which , as I told you , Antonio shall be bound .

English: If I default , he'll pay you .
Shakespearean: Antonio shall become bound , well .

English: Antonio will guarantee it , hmmm .
Shakespearean: May you stead me ?

English: Can you help me ?
Shakespearean: Will you pleasure me ?

English: What's your answer ?
Shakespearean: Shall I know your answer ?

English: Three thousand ducats for three months , and Antonio will guarantee it .
Shakespearean: Three thousand ducats for three months , and Antonio bound .

English: Your answer ?
Shakespearean: Your answer to that ?

English: Antonio's a good man .
Shakespearean: Antonio is a good man .

English: Have you heard anything to the contrary ?
Shakespearean: Have you heard any imputation to the contrary ?

English: But his investments are uncertain right now .
Shakespearean: Yet his means are in supposition .

English: He has one ship bound for Tripoli , another heading for the Indies .
Shakespearean: He hath an argosy bound to Tripolis , another to the Indies .

English: What's more , people at the
Shakespearean: I understand moreover , upon the Rialto , he hath a third at Mexico , a fourth for England , and other ventures he hath squandered abroad .

English: But ships are just fragile boards , and sailors are just men .
Shakespearean: But ships are but boards , sailors but men .

English: There are rats and thieves and pirates , not to mention storms , winds , and rocks .
Shakespearean: There be land rats and water rats , water thieves and land thieves , I mean pirates , and then there is the peril of waters , winds , and rocks .

English: But in spite of all this , the man is still wealthy enough .
Shakespearean: The man is notwithstanding sufficient .

English: I assure you he can .
Shakespearean: Be assured you may .

English: Oh yes , to smell This is Signor Antonio .
Shakespearean: This is Signor Antonio .

English: To be honest , I don't know why I'm so sad .
Shakespearean: In sooth , I know not why I am so sad .

English: I'm tired of it , and you say you're tired of it too .
Shakespearean: It wearies me ; you say it wearies you .

English: I'd be peering over maps to figure out the best ports , piers , and waterways .
Shakespearean: Believe me , sir , had I such venture forth , The better part of my affections would Be with my hopes abroad .

English: Everything that made me worry about my ships would make me sad .
Shakespearean: And every object that might make me fear Misfortune to my ventures out of doubt Would make me sad .

English: Shylock , are you listening ?
Shakespearean: Shylock , do you hear ?

English: If I remember correctly , I can't raise the entire three thousand ducats immediately .
Shakespearean: I am debating of my present store , And by the near guess of my memory I can not instantly raise up the gross Of full three thousand ducats .

English: But so what ?
Shakespearean: What of that ?

English: Tubal , a wealthy Jew I know , will supply me with the cash .
Shakespearean: Tubal , a wealthy Hebrew of my tribe , Will furnish me .

English: But wait a minute !
Shakespearean: But soft !

English: How many months do you want ?
Shakespearean: How many months Do you desire ?

English: Shylock , although I never lend or borrow with interest , I'm willing to break that habit to help a friend in need .
Shakespearean: Shylock , albeit I neither lend nor borrow By taking nor by giving of excess , Yet to supply the ripe wants of my friend , I'll break a custom .

English: Oh yes , three thousand ducats .
Shakespearean: Ay , ay , three thousand ducats .

English: For three months .
Shakespearean: And for three months .

English: Yes , I forgot , three months .
Shakespearean: I had forgot , three months .

English: That's right .
Shakespearean: You told me so .

English: That's not how I do business .
Shakespearean: I do never use it .

English: When Jacob took care of his uncle Laban's sheep , Jacob was the heir to his grandfather Abraham's birthright , because his mother cleverly arranged for her husband Isaac to make Jacob his heir , What's your point ?
Shakespearean: When Jacob grazed his uncle Laban's sheep , This Jacob from our holy Abram was , As his wise mother wrought in his behalf , The third possessor , ay , he was the third , And what of him ?

English: Did he charge interest ?
Shakespearean: Did he take interest ?

English: Jacob didn't have any control over what happened .
Shakespearean: This was a venture , sir , that Jacob served for , A thing not in his power to bring to pass But swayed and fashioned by the hand of heaven .

English: That your interest payments are like Jacob's sheep ?
Shakespearean: Or is your gold and silver ewes and rams ?

English: But listen to me , signor ,
Shakespearean: But note me , signor ,

English: An evil soul using a holy story is like a criminal who smiles at you .
Shakespearean: An evil soul producing holy witness Is like a villain with a smiling cheek , A goodly apple rotten at the heart .

English: Oh , liars can look so honest !
Shakespearean: Oh , what a goodly outside falsehood hath !

English: Three months from twelve months of the year .
Shakespearean: Three months from twelve , then .

English: Let me see .
Shakespearean: Let me see .

English: The interest rate will be , Well , Shylock ?
Shakespearean: The rate , Well , Shylock , shall we be beholding to you ?

English: Signor Antonio , you've often insulted my money and my business practices in the Rialto .
Shakespearean: Signor Antonio , many a time and oft In the Rialto you have rated me About my moneys and my usances .

English: And all because I use my own money to make a profit .
Shakespearean: You call me misbeliever , cutthroat dog , And spet upon my Jewish gaberdine , And all for use of that which is mine own .

English: And now it looks like you need my help .
Shakespearean: Well then , it now appears you need my help .

English: All right then .
Shakespearean: Go to , then !

English: You come to me saying , "Shylock , we need money." You say that ! , even though you spat on my beard and kicked me like you'd kick a stray mutt out your front door .
Shakespearean: You come to me and you say , "Shylock , we would have moneys." You say so ! , You , that did void your rheum upon my beard And foot me as you spurn a stranger cur Over your threshold !

English: And now you're asking for money .
Shakespearean: Moneys is your suit .

English: What can I tell you ?
Shakespearean: What should I say to you ?

English: Shouldn't I say , "Does a dog have money ?
Shakespearean: Should I not say , "Hath a dog money ?

English: Is it possible for a mutt to lend three thousand ducats ? " Or should I bend down low , and in a humble and submissive voice say :
Shakespearean: Is it possible A cur can lend three thousand ducats ? " Or Shall I bend low and in a bondman's key With bated breath and whispering humbleness Say this :

English: If you're going to lend us this money , don't lend it to us as if we were your friends .
Shakespearean: If thou wilt lend this money , lend it not As to thy friends , for when did friendship take A breed for barren metal of his friend ?

English: Instead , lend it to me as your enemy .
Shakespearean: But lend it rather to thine enemy , Who , if he break , thou mayst with better face Exact the penalty .

English: Look at you getting all riled up !
Shakespearean: Why , look you how you storm !

English: I want to be friends with you , and forget all the times you've embarrassed and humiliated me .
Shakespearean: I would be friends with you and have your love , Forget the shames that you have stained me with , Supply your present wants and take no doit Of usance for my moneys , and you'll not hear me !

English: I'm making a kind offer , zero percent financing .
Shakespearean: This is kind I offer .

English: That really would be kind .
Shakespearean: This were kindness .

English: I'll show you how kind I am .
Shakespearean: This kindness will I show .

English: If you don't repay me on the day we agree on , in the place we name , for the sum of money fixed in our contract , your penalty will be a pound of your pretty flesh , to be cut off and taken out of whatever part of your body I like .
Shakespearean: Go with me to a notary , seal me there Your single bond , and , in a merry sport , If you repay me not on such a day , In such a place , such sum or sums as are Expressed in the condition , let the forfeit Be nominated for an equal pound Of your fair flesh , to be cut off and taken In what part of your body pleaseth me .

English: It's a deal .
Shakespearean: Content , in faith .

English: I'll agree to those terms and even say that Jews are nice .
Shakespearean: I'll seal to such a bond , And say there is much kindness in the Jew .

English: No , you can't sign a contract like that for me !
Shakespearean: You shall not seal to such a bond for me !

English: I'd rather go without the money .
Shakespearean: I'll rather dwell in my necessity .

English: In two months , a month before this loan is due , I expect to earn more than three times that much from my investments .
Shakespearean: Within these two months , that's a month before This bond expires , I do expect return Of thrice three times the value of this bond .

English: A pound of human flesh taken isn't even as valuable as a pound of mutton or beef .
Shakespearean: A pound of man's flesh taken from a man Is not so estimable , profitable neither , As flesh of muttons , beefs , or goats .

English: If he agrees , great .
Shakespearean: If he will take it , so .

English: If not , goodbye .
Shakespearean: If not , adieu .

English: And I hope you won't think badly of me .
Shakespearean: And for my love I pray you wrong me not .

English: Yes , Shylock , I'll sign the contract and agree to its terms .
Shakespearean: Yes , Shylock , I will seal unto this bond .

English: Then meet me right away at the notary's .
Shakespearean: Then meet me forthwith at the notary's .

English: Give him the instructions for our amusing little contract , and I'll go get the money for you right away .
Shakespearean: Give him direction for this merry bond , And I will go and purse the ducats straight , See to my house left in the fearful guard Of an unthrifty knave , and presently I will be with you .

English: Hurry up , my Jewish friend .
Shakespearean: Hie thee , gentle Jew .

English: My ships will come home a month before the money is due .
Shakespearean: My ships come home a month before the day .

English: I wouldn't change it except to make you think of me , my darling queen .
Shakespearean: I would not change this hue Except to steal your thoughts , my gentle queen .

English: Thank you for saying that .
Shakespearean: Even for that I thank you .

English: Show me the caskets and let me try my luck .
Shakespearean: Therefore I pray you lead me to the caskets To try my fortune .

English: I swear by my sword , which killed the Shah of Persia and a Persian prince and defeated the Sultan Suleiman three times , that I would face the meanest-looking warriors on earth .
Shakespearean: By this scimitar That slew the Sophy and a Persian prince That won three fields of Sultan Solyman , I would o'erstare the sternest eyes that look , Outbrave the heart most daring on the earth , Pluck the young sucking cubs from the she-bear , Yea , mock the lion when he roars for prey , To win the lady .

English: But this is bad !
Shakespearean: But , alas the while !

English: Think about it carefully .
Shakespearean: Nor will not .

English: Let me take my chances .
Shakespearean: Come , bring me unto my chance .

English: Let's go to the temple first .
Shakespearean: First , forward to the temple .

English: You can take your chances after dinner .
Shakespearean: After dinner Your hazard shall be made .

English: I'm sure I'll feel guilty if I run away from this Jew , my master .
Shakespearean: Certainly my conscience will serve me to run from this Jew , my master .

English: Be tough , " says the devil , "and run ! " But then my conscience , hanging around my heart , says very wisely to me , "My good friend Launcelot , you're a good boy , the son of an honest man , " really , that should be the son of an honest woman , since my father cheated on my mother .
Shakespearean: For the heavens , rouse up a brave mind , " says the fiend , "and run." Well , my conscience , hanging about the neck of my heart , says very wisely to me , "My honest friend Launcelot , being an honest man's son" , or rather an honest woman's son , for indeed my father did something smack , something grow to .

English: Anyway , my conscience says , "Stay put." "Go , " the devil says .
Shakespearean: He had a kind of taste. , Well , my conscience says , "Launcelot , budge not." "Budge ! " says the fiend .

English: Don't go , " says my conscience .
Shakespearean: Budge not , " says my conscience .

English: Conscience , " I say , "you give good advice." "Devil , " I say , "you give good advice." If I listened to my conscience , I'd stay with the Jew my master , who's a devil .
Shakespearean: Conscience , " say I , "you counsel well." "Fiend , " say I , "you counsel well." To be ruled by my conscience I should stay with the Jew my master , who , God bless the mark , is a kind of devil .

English: But if I ran away from the Jew , I'd be following the advice of the devil , who's the very devil himself .
Shakespearean: And to run away from the Jew I should be ruled by the fiend , who , saving your reverence , is the devil himself .

English: The devil's advice is nicer .
Shakespearean: The fiend gives the more friendly counsel .

English: I'll run , devil .
Shakespearean: I will run , fiend .

English: Tell me to run , and I'll run .
Shakespearean: I will run .

English: Excuse me , young man , how do I get to the Jew's residence ?
Shakespearean: Master young man , you , I pray you , which is the way to Master Jew's ?

English: Young man , excuse me , how do I get to the Jew's ?
Shakespearean: Master young gentleman , I pray you , which is the way to Master Jew's ?

English: Turn right at the next turn , but at the following turn , turn left .
Shakespearean: Turn up on your right hand at the next turning , but at the next turning of all on your left .

English: Oh , and then at the very next turn , don't turn left or right , but turn down and around to the Jew's house .
Shakespearean: Marry , at the very next turning turn of no hand , but turn down indirectly to the Jew's house .

English: Good heavens , those are difficult directions .
Shakespearean: By God's sonties , 'twill be a hard way to hit .

English: Can you tell me if a man named Launcelot , who lives with him , is still there ?
Shakespearean: Can you tell me whether one Launcelot that dwells with him , dwell with him or no ?

English: Are you talking about young Master Launcelot ?
Shakespearean: Talk you of young Master Launcelot ?

English: He's not a "master , " sir , he's just a poor man's son .
Shakespearean: No "master , " sir , but a poor man's son .

English: His father , if I do say so myself , is an honest but very poor man , and , thank God , likely to live a long time .
Shakespearean: His father , though I say 't , is an honest exceeding poor man and , God be thanked , well to live .

English: He's just Launcelot .
Shakespearean: Your worship's friend and Launcelot , sir .

English: Who wouldn't get sad thinking about things like that ?
Shakespearean: Shall I have the thought To think on this , and shall I lack the thought That such a thing bechanced would make me sad ?

English: It's obvious .
Shakespearean: But tell not me .

English: No , that's not it , trust me .
Shakespearean: Believe me , no .

English: So it's not my business that's making me sad .
Shakespearean: Therefore my merchandise makes me not sad .

English: Well then , you must be in love .
Shakespearean: Why then , you are in love .

English: You're not in love either ?
Shakespearean: Not in love neither ?

English: But excuse me , Yes , I'm talking about Launcelot , sir .
Shakespearean: But I pray you , ergo , old man , ergo , I beseech you , talk you of young Master Launcelot ?

English: Oh , no .
Shakespearean: Ergo , Master Launcelot .

English: God forbid !
Shakespearean: Marry , God forbid !

English: The boy was going to support me in my old age !
Shakespearean: The boy was the very staff of my age , my very prop .

English: What am I , a cane ?
Shakespearean: Do I look like a cudgel or a hovel-post , a staff or a prop ?

English: Don't you recognize me , father ?
Shakespearean: Do you know me , Father ?

English: Heaven help me , I don't know you , sir .
Shakespearean: Alack the day , I know you not , young gentleman .

English: But please tell me , is my boy , God rest his soul , alive or dead ?
Shakespearean: But I pray you , tell me , is my boy , God rest his soul , alive or dead ?

English: You really don't recognize me , father ?
Shakespearean: Do you not know me , Father ?

English: Sir , I'm half-blind .
Shakespearean: Alack , sir , I am sand-blind .

English: I don't know you .
Shakespearean: I know you not .

English: Even if you had your eyes , you still might not recognize me .
Shakespearean: Nay , indeed if you had your eyes , you might fail of the knowing me .

English: It takes a wise father to know his own child .
Shakespearean: It is a wise father that knows his own child .

English: Well , old man , I'll tell you news of your son .
Shakespearean: Well , old man , I will tell you news of your son .

English: Give me your blessing .
Shakespearean: Give me your blessing .

English: Please stand up !
Shakespearean: Pray you , sir , stand up .

English: I'm sure you aren't Launcelot , my boy .
Shakespearean: I am sure you are not Launcelot , my boy .

English: Give me your blessing .
Shakespearean: Pray you , let's have no more fooling about it , but give me your blessing .

English: I'm Launcelot , who was your boy , is your son , and will be your child .
Shakespearean: I am Launcelot , your boy that was , your son that is , your child that shall be .

English: I can't believe you're my son .
Shakespearean: I can not think you are my son .

English: Yes , you're right , her name is Margery .
Shakespearean: Her name is Margery , indeed .

English: If you're Launcelot , then you're my own flesh and blood .
Shakespearean: I'll be sworn , if thou be Launcelot , thou art mine own flesh and blood .

English: Then Dobbin's tail must be growing backward .
Shakespearean: It should seem then that Dobbin's tail grows backward .

English: I'm sure he had more hair on his tail than I have on my face when I last saw him .
Shakespearean: I am sure he had more hair of his tail than I have of my face when I last saw him .

English: Lord , how you've changed !
Shakespearean: Lord , how art thou changed !

English: How are you and your master getting along ?
Shakespearean: How dost thou and thy master agree ?

English: I've brought him a present .
Shakespearean: I have brought him a present .

English: How are you ?
Shakespearean: How 'gree you now ?

English: My master's a total Jew .
Shakespearean: My master's a very Jew .

English: You're giving him a present ?
Shakespearean: Give him a present .

English: Give him a noose to hang himself .
Shakespearean: Give him a halter .

English: He's starving me to death .
Shakespearean: I am famished in his service .

English: You can see my ribs so well you can count them .
Shakespearean: You may tell every finger I have with my ribs .

English: I'm glad you've come , father .
Shakespearean: Father , I am glad you are come .

English: Give me your present to give to Master Bassanio .
Shakespearean: Give me your present to one Master Bassanio , who indeed gives rare new liveries .

English: Thank you .
Shakespearean: Gramercy !

English: What do you want with me ?
Shakespearean: Wouldst thou aught with me ?

English: What do you want ?
Shakespearean: What would you ?

English: To work for you , sir .
Shakespearean: Serve you , sir .

English: That's what we're trying to say , sir .
Shakespearean: That is the very defect of the matter , sir .

English: I know who you are .
Shakespearean: I know thee well .

English: You can have what you want .
Shakespearean: Thou hast obtained thy suit .

English: Father , go ahead .
Shakespearean: Father , in .

English: BASSANIO Please , Leonardo , think about this I'll do my best .
Shakespearean: My best endeavours shall be done herein .

English: He's walking over there , sir .
Shakespearean: Yonder , sir , he walks .

English: Signor Bassanio !
Shakespearean: Signor Bassanio !

English: Gratiano !
Shakespearean: Gratiano !

English: I have a favor to ask .
Shakespearean: I have a suit to you .

English: Anything .
Shakespearean: You have obtained it .

English: Don't say no .
Shakespearean: You must not deny me .

English: Let me go with you to Belmont .
Shakespearean: I must go with you to Belmont .

English: Well , if you have to go , you have to go .
Shakespearean: Why , then you must .

English: But listen to me , Gratiano .
Shakespearean: But hear thee , Gratiano .

English: Sometimes you get a bit too wild , and you let your voice get a bit loud and rude .
Shakespearean: Thou art too wild , too rude and bold of voice , Parts that become thee happily enough And in such eyes as ours appear not faults .

English: Please , try to act a little more serious , or the people in Belmont will get the wrong impression about me , and your wildness will make me blow my chance with Portia .
Shakespearean: Pray thee , take pain To allay with some cold drops of modesty Thy skipping spirit , lest through thy wild behavior I be misconst'red in the place I go to , And lose my hopes .

English: Listen , Signor Bassanio , there's nothing to worry about .
Shakespearean: Signor Bassanio , hear me .

English: I'll carry prayer books in my pocket and look sweet , even more .
Shakespearean: If I do not put on a sober habit , Talk with respect and swear but now and then , Wear prayer books in my pocket , look demurely , Nay more .

English: If I don't do all this , never trust me again .
Shakespearean: While grace is saying , hood mine eyes Thus with my hat , and sigh and say , "Amen" , Use all the observance of civility Like one well studied in a sad ostent To please his grandam , never trust me more .

English: Well , we'll see how you act .
Shakespearean: Well , we shall see your bearing .

English: Okay , but tonight doesn't count .
Shakespearean: Nay , but I bar tonight .

English: You can't judge me based on what I do tonight .
Shakespearean: You shall not gauge me By what we do tonight .

English: I'd rather see you having fun , because we have friends coming who want to have fun .
Shakespearean: I would entreat you rather to put on Your boldest suit of mirth , for we have friends That purpose merriment .

English: Anyway , I have to say goodbye to you now .
Shakespearean: But fare you well .

English: I've got some business to take care of .
Shakespearean: I have some business .

English: I'm sorry you're leaving my father like this .
Shakespearean: I am sorry thou wilt leave my father so .

English: It's hell in our house , and you helped cheer it up , like a funny devil .
Shakespearean: Our house is hell , and thou , a merry devil , Didst rob it of some taste of tediousness .

English: You'll soon be meeting Lorenzo at supper ; he'll be a guest of your new master .
Shakespearean: And Launcelot , soon at supper shalt thou see Lorenzo , who is thy new master's guest .

English: Give him this letter .
Shakespearean: Give him this letter .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Adieu !

English: I'm sure some Christian will resort to trickery to get you .
Shakespearean: If a Christian do not play the knave and get thee , I am much deceived .

English: But goodbye .
Shakespearean: But adieu .

English: It's not manly to cry .
Shakespearean: These foolish drops do something drown my manly spirit .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Adieu .

English: Goodbye , Launcelot .
Shakespearean: Farewell , good Launcelot .

English: Oh God , what a heinous sinner I am , being ashamed to be my father's child !
Shakespearean: Alack , what heinous sin is it in me To be ashamed to be my father's child !

English: But I need to remember I'm related to him by blood , not behavior .
Shakespearean: But though I am a daughter to his blood , I am not to his manners .

English: Oh Lorenzo , if you keep your promise to me , I'll end this agony by becoming a Christian and marrying you .
Shakespearean: O Lorenzo , If thou keep promise , I shall end this strife , Become a Christian and thy loving wife .

English: No , we'll sneak away at supper time , disguise ourselves with masks at my house , and come back in an hour .
Shakespearean: Nay , we will slink away in supper time , Disguise us at my lodging , and return , All in an hour .

English: But we haven't made any preparations .
Shakespearean: We have not made good preparation .

English: We haven't even talked about who'll be our torchbearers .
Shakespearean: We have not spoke us yet of torchbearers .

English: I think it's better to call it off .
Shakespearean: Tis vile , unless it may be quaintly ordered , And better in my mind not undertook .

English: It's only four o'clock now .
Shakespearean: Tis now but four o'clock .

English: We have two hours to get ready .
Shakespearean: We have two hours To furnish us .

English: Launcelot , what's going on ?
Shakespearean: Friend Launcelot , what's the news ?

English: I recognize the handwriting .
Shakespearean: I know the hand .

English: I bet it's a love letter !
Shakespearean: Love news , in faith ?

English: Where are you going ?
Shakespearean: Whither goest thou ?

English: To invite my former boss , the Jew , to dine tonight with my new master , the Christian .
Shakespearean: Marry , sir , to bid my old master the Jew to sup tonight with my new master the Christian .

English: Me too .
Shakespearean: And so will I .

English: Meet me and Gratiano at his house in about an hour .
Shakespearean: Meet me and Gratiano At Gratiano's lodging some hour hence .

English: It's good we're doing this .
Shakespearean: Tis good we do so .

English: Wasn't that letter from Jessica ?
Shakespearean: Was not that letter from fair Jessica ?

English: Some people will laugh at anything , and others are so grouchy they won't even crack a smile when they hear something hysterically funny .
Shakespearean: Some that will evermore peep through their eyes And laugh like parrots at a bagpiper , And other of such vinegar aspect That they'll not show their teeth in way of smile Though Nestor swear the jest be laughable .

English: Goodbye , then .
Shakespearean: Fare ye well .

English: You're both very precious to me .
Shakespearean: Your worth is very dear in my regard .

English: You need to leave to take care of your own business .
Shakespearean: I take it your own business calls on you And you embrace th ' occasion to depart .

English: We're available .
Shakespearean: Good signors both , when shall we laugh ?

English: Bassanio , we'll say goodbye for now , since you've found Antonio .
Shakespearean: My Lord Bassanio , since you have found Antonio , We two will leave you .

English: Don't worry , I'll be there .
Shakespearean: I will not fail you .

English: I have to tell you everything .
Shakespearean: I must needs tell thee all .

English: Who asked you to call her ?
Shakespearean: Who bids thee call ?

English: I'm not asking you to call her .
Shakespearean: I do not bid thee call .
