Shakespearean: Pray you , if it be , give it me , for I am slow of study .

English: Let me play the lion too .
Shakespearean: Let me play the lion too .

English: And that would get us all executed .
Shakespearean: And that were enough to hang us all .

English: Yeah , that would get every single one of us executed .
Shakespearean: That would hang us , every mother's son .

English: Well , my friends , you've got to admit that if you scare the living daylights out of the ladies , they'd have no choice but to execute us .
Shakespearean: I grant you , friends , if you should fright the ladies out of their wits , they would have no more discretion but to hang us .

English: Because Pyramus is a good-looking man , the most handsome man that you could find on a summer's day , a lovely gentlemanly man .
Shakespearean: For Pyramus is a sweet-faced man , a proper man as one shall see in a summer's day , a most lovely , gentlemanlike man .

English: So you're the only one who could play Pyramus .
Shakespearean: Therefore you must needs play Pyramus .

English: Well then , I'll do it .
Shakespearean: Well , I will undertake it .

English: What kind of beard should I wear for the part ?
Shakespearean: What beard were I best to play it in ?

English: Whatever kind you want , I guess .
Shakespearean: Why , what you will .

English: No , you'll see , four days will quickly turn into four nights .
Shakespearean: Four days will quickly steep themselves in night .

English: And since we dream at night , time passes quickly then .
Shakespearean: Four nights will quickly dream away the time .

English: Finally the new moon , curved like a silver bow in the sky , will look down on our wedding celebration .
Shakespearean: And then the moon , like to a silver bow New bent in heaven , shall behold the night Of our solemnities .

English: Sadness is only appropriate for funerals .
Shakespearean: Turn melancholy forth to funerals .

English: We don't want it at our festivities .
Shakespearean: The pale companion is not for our pomp .

English: But I'll marry you under different circumstances , with extravagant festivals , public festivities , and celebration .
Shakespearean: But I will wed thee in another key , With pomp , with triumph , and with reveling .

English: Long live Theseus , our famous and respected duke !
Shakespearean: Happy be Theseus , our renowned duke .

English: I'll play the part wearing either a straw-colored beard , or a sandy beard , or a red beard , or one of those bright yellow beards that's the color of a French coin .
Shakespearean: I will discharge it in either your straw-color beard , your orange-tawny beard , your purple-in-grain beard , or your French crown-color beard , your perfect yellow .

English: It's best to rehearse there , because if we do it here in the city , we'll be bothered by crowds of people and everyone will know the plot of our play .
Shakespearean: There will we rehearse , for if we meet in the city we shall be dogged with company , and our devices known .

English: Meanwhile , I'll make a list of props that we'll need for the play .
Shakespearean: In the meantime I will draw a bill of properties such as our play wants .

English: Don't leave me in the lurch .
Shakespearean: I pray you , fail me not .

English: We'll be there , and there we'll rehearse courageously and wonderfully , truly obscenely .
Shakespearean: We will meet , and there we may rehearse most obscenely and courageously .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Adieu .

English: We'll meet at the giant oak tree in the duke's forest .
Shakespearean: At the duke's oak we meet .

English: Got it ?
Shakespearean: Enough .

English: Be there , or don't show your face again .
Shakespearean: Hold , or cut bowstrings .

English: Hello , spirit !
Shakespearean: How now , spirit ?

English: Where are you going ?
Shakespearean: Whither wander you ?

English: I go over hills and valleys , through bushes and thorns , over parks and fenced-in spaces , through water and fire .
Shakespearean: Over hill , over dale , Thorough bush , thorough brier , Over park , over pale , Thorough flood , thorough fire .

English: I wander everywhere faster than the moon revolves around the Earth .
Shakespearean: I do wander everywhere Swifter than the moon's sphere .

English: I work for Titania , the Fairy Queen , and organize fairy dances for her in the grass .
Shakespearean: And I serve the fairy queen To dew her orbs upon the green .

English: The cowslip flowers are her bodyguards .
Shakespearean: The cowslips tall her pensioners be .

English: Their sweet smells come from those little freckles .
Shakespearean: In those freckles live their savors .

English: Now I have to go find some dewdrops and hang a pearl earring on every cowslip flower .
Shakespearean: I must go seek some dewdrops here And hang a pearl in every cowslip's ear .

English: Goodbye , you dumb old spirit .
Shakespearean: Farewell , thou lob of spirits .

English: I've got to go .
Shakespearean: I'll be gone .

English: The queen and her elves will be here soon .
Shakespearean: Our queen and all our elves come here anon .

English: He's furious because she stole an adorable boy from an Indian king .
Shakespearean: For Oberon is passing fell and wrath Because that she , as her attendant hath A lovely boy stolen from an Indian king .

English: He wants the child for himself , to accompany him on his wanderings through the wild forests .
Shakespearean: And jealous Oberon would have the child Knight of his train , to trace the forests wild .

English: Instead , she puts flowers in the boy's hair and makes a fuss over him .
Shakespearean: But she perforce withholds the loved boy , Crowns him with flowers , and makes him all her joy .

English: You do their work for them and give them good luck .
Shakespearean: Those that "Hobgoblin" call you , and "sweet Puck , " You do their work , and they shall have good luck .

English: That's you , right ?
Shakespearean: Are not you he ?

English: What you say is true .
Shakespearean: Thou speak'st aright .

English: That's me you're talking about , the playful wanderer of the night .
Shakespearean: I am that merry wanderer of the night .

English: When she takes a sip , I bob up against her lips and make her spill the drink all over her withered old neck .
Shakespearean: And sometime lurk I in a gossip's bowl In very likeness of a roasted crab , And when she drinks , against her lips I bob And on her withered dewlap pour the ale .

English: But I slip from underneath her and she falls down , crying , "Ow , my butt ! " and starts coughing , and then everyone laughs and has fun .
Shakespearean: Then slip I from her bum , down topples she , And "Tailor ! " cries , and falls into a cough , And then the whole quire hold their hips and laugh , And waxen in their mirth , and neeze , and swear A merrier hour was never wasted there .

English: But step aside , fairy !
Shakespearean: But , room , fairy !

English: Here comes Oberon .
Shakespearean: Here comes Oberon .

English: And here's my mistress , Titania .
Shakespearean: And here my mistress .

English: I wish he'd go away !
Shakespearean: Would that he were gone !

English: How What , are you jealous , Oberon ? , Fairies , let's get out of here .
Shakespearean: What , jealous Oberon ? , Fairies , skip hence .

English: I've sworn I'll never sleep with him or talk to him again .
Shakespearean: I have forsworn his bed and company .

English: Wait just a minute , you brazen hussy .
Shakespearean: Tarry , rash wanton .

English: The only reason you left India was to come here and see that butch Amazon Hippolyta .
Shakespearean: Why art thou here , Come from the farthest step of India ?

English: She was your boot-wearing mistress and your warrior lover , and now that she's getting married to Theseus , you've come to celebrate their marriage .
Shakespearean: But that , forsooth , the bouncing Amazon , Your buskined mistress and your warrior love , To Theseus must be wedded , and you come To give their bed joy and prosperity .

English: How can you stand there shamelessly talking about me and Hippolyta , when you know that I know about your love for Theseus ?
Shakespearean: How canst thou thus for shame , Titania , Knowing I know thy love to Theseus ?

English: Weren't you the one who made him desert Perigouna in the middle of the night , right after he'd raped her ?
Shakespearean: Glance at my credit with Hippolyta , Didst thou not lead him through the glimmering night From Perigouna , whom he ravished ?

English: And weren't you the one who made him cheat on all of his other girlfriends , like Aegles , Ariadne , and Antiopa ?
Shakespearean: And make him with fair aegles break his faith , With Ariadne and Antiopa ?

English: These are nothing but jealous lies .
Shakespearean: These are the forgeries of jealousy .

English: We haven't been able to meet on a hill or in a valley , in the forest or a meadow , by a pebbly fountain or a rushing stream , or on the beach by the ocean without you disturbing us .
Shakespearean: And never , since the middle summer's spring , Met we on hill , in dale , forest , or mead , By paved fountain , or by rushy brook , Or in the beached margent of the sea , To dance our ringlets to the whistling wind , But with thy brawls thou hast disturbed our sport .

English: And because you interrupt us so that we can't dance for them , the winds have made fogs rise up out of the sea and fall down on the rivers so that the rivers flood , just to get revenge on you .
Shakespearean: Therefore the winds , piping to us in vain , As in revenge , have sucked up from the sea Contagious fogs , which falling in the land Have every pelting river made so proud That they have overborne their continents .

English: So all the work that oxen and farmers have done in plowing the fields has been for nothing , because the unripe grain has rotted before it was ripe .
Shakespearean: The ox hath therefore stretched his yoke in vain , The ploughman lost his sweat , and the green corn Hath rotted ere his youth attained a beard .

English: Sheep pens are empty in the middle of the flooded fields , and the crows get fat from eating the dead bodies of infected sheep .
Shakespearean: The fold stands empty in the drowned field , And crows are fatted with the murrain flock .

English: So the pale , angry moon , who controls the tides , fills the air with diseases .
Shakespearean: Therefore the moon , the governess of floods , Pale in her anger , washes all the air , That rheumatic diseases do abound .

English: Spring , summer , fertile autumn and angry winter have all changed places , and now the confused world doesn't know which is which .
Shakespearean: The spring , the summer , The childing autumn , angry winter change Their wonted liveries , and the mazed world , By their increase , now knows not which is which .

English: And this is all because of our argument .
Shakespearean: And this same progeny of evils comes From our debate , from our dissension .

English: We are responsible for this .
Shakespearean: We are their parents and original .

English: Do something about it , then .
Shakespearean: Do you amend it then .

English: You have the power to fix it .
Shakespearean: It lies in you .

English: Why would Titania want to argue with her Oberon ?
Shakespearean: Why should Titania cross her Oberon ?

English: All I'm asking for is to have that little human boy as part of my crew .
Shakespearean: I do but beg a little changeling boy , To be my henchman .

English: Get over it .
Shakespearean: Set your heart at rest .

English: I won't give up this child for all of Fairyland .
Shakespearean: The Fairyland buys not the child of me .

English: How long do you plan to stay here in this forest ?
Shakespearean: How long within this wood intend you stay ?

English: Maybe until after Theseus's wedding day .
Shakespearean: Perchance till after Theseus ' wedding day .

English: If you behave yourself and join us in our circle dance and moonlight celebrations , then you can come with us .
Shakespearean: If you will patiently dance in our round And see our moonlight revels , go with us .

English: If not , leave me alone , and I'll stay away from your turf .
Shakespearean: If not , shun me , and I will spare your haunts .

English: Give me that boy and I'll come with you .
Shakespearean: Give me that boy and I will go with thee .

English: Not for your entire fairy kingdom. , Come , fairies , let's go .
Shakespearean: Not for thy fairy kingdom. , Fairies , away !

English: We're going to have an out-and-out brawl if I stay any longer .
Shakespearean: We shall chide downright , if I longer stay .

English: Well , go on your way , then .
Shakespearean: Well , go thy way .

English: You won't leave this grove until I've paid you back for this insult .
Shakespearean: Thou shalt not from this grove Till I torment thee for this injury. , My gentle Puck , come hither .

English: Yes , I remember .
Shakespearean: I remember .

English: You couldn't see him , but I could .
Shakespearean: That very time I saw ( but thou couldst not ) Flying between the cold moon and the Earth , Cupid all armed .

English: He took aim at a beautiful young virgin who was sitting on a throne in the western part of the world , and he shot his arrow of love well enough to have pierced a hundred thousand hearts .
Shakespearean: A certain aim he took At a fair vestal throned by the west , And loosed his love shaft smartly from his bow As it should pierce a hundred thousand hearts .

English: But I could see that Cupid's fiery arrow was put out by watery , virginal moonbeams , so the royal virgin continued her virginal thoughts without being interrupted by thoughts of love .
Shakespearean: But I might see young Cupid's fiery shaft Quenched in the chaste beams of the watery moon , And the imperial votaress passed on , In maiden meditation , fancy-free .

English: But I paid attention to where Cupid's arrow fell .
Shakespearean: Yet marked I where the bolt of Cupid fell .

English: It fell on a little western flower , which used to be white as milk but now has turned purple from being wounded by the arrow of love .
Shakespearean: It fell upon a little western flower , Before milk-white , now purple with love's wound .

English: Young girls call it "love-in-idleness." Bring me that flower .
Shakespearean: And maidens call it "love-in-idleness." Fetch me that flower .

English: I showed it to you once .
Shakespearean: The herb I showed thee once .

English: If its juice is put on someone's eyelids while they're asleep , that person will fall in love with the next living creature he or she sees .
Shakespearean: The juice of it on sleeping eyelids laid Will make or man or woman madly dote Upon the next live creature that it sees .

English: Bring me this plant , and get back here before the sea monster has time to swim three miles .
Shakespearean: Fetch me this herb , and be thou here again Ere the leviathan can swim a league .

English: I could go around the world in forty minutes .
Shakespearean: I'll put a girdle round about the Earth In forty minutes .

English: When I have the juice of that flower , I'll trickle some drops of it on Titania's eyes while she's sleeping .
Shakespearean: Having once this juice , I'll watch Titania when she is asleep And drop the liquor of it in her eyes .

English: She'll fall madly in love with the first thing she sees when she wakes up , even if it's a lion , a bear , a wolf , a bull , a monkey , or an ape .
Shakespearean: The next thing then she waking looks upon , Be it on lion , bear , or wolf , or bull , On meddling monkey or on busy ape , She shall pursue it with the soul of love .

English: And before I make her normal again , I can cure her by treating her with another plant , I'll make her give me that little boy as my page .
Shakespearean: And ere I take this charm from of her sight , As I can take it with another herb , I'll make her render up her page to me .

English: But who's that coming this way ?
Shakespearean: But who comes here ?

English: Look , I don't love you , so stop following me around .
Shakespearean: I love thee not , therefore pursue me not .

English: Where are Lysander and beautiful Hermia ?
Shakespearean: Where is Lysander and fair Hermia ?

English: Lysander I want to stop , but Hermia stops my heart from beating .
Shakespearean: The one I'll stay , the other stayeth me .

English: You told me they escaped into this forest .
Shakespearean: Thou told'st me they were stol'n unto this wood .

English: And here I am , going crazy in the middle of the woods because I can't find my Hermia .
Shakespearean: And here am I , and wood within this wood , Because I can not meet my Hermia .

English: Go away , get out of here , and stop following me .
Shakespearean: Hence , get thee gone , and follow me no more .

English: You attract me to you , you cruel magnet !
Shakespearean: You draw me , you hard-hearted adamant .

English: But you must not attract iron , because my heart is as true as steel .
Shakespearean: But yet you draw not iron , for my heart Is true as steel .

English: If you let go of your power to attract me , I won't have any power to follow you .
Shakespearean: Leave you your power to draw , And I shall have no power to follow you .

English: Do I ask you to follow me ?
Shakespearean: Do I entice you ?

English: Do I speak to you kindly ?
Shakespearean: Do I speak you fair ?

English: Don't I tell you in the clearest terms that I do not and can not love you ?
Shakespearean: Or rather , do I not in plainest truth Tell you I do not , nor I can not , love you ?

English: Yes , but that makes me love you even more .
Shakespearean: And even for that do I love you the more .

English: I'm your little dog , Demetrius .
Shakespearean: I am your spaniel .

English: The more you beat me , the more I'll love you .
Shakespearean: And , Demetrius , The more you beat me , I will fawn on you .

English: Treat me like you would treat a dog , kick me , hit me , neglect me , try to lose me .
Shakespearean: Use me but as your spaniel , spurn me , strike me , Neglect me , lose me .

English: Just let me follow behind you , even though I'm not good enough for you .
Shakespearean: Only give me leave , Unworthy as I am , to follow you .

English: Just looking at you makes me sick .
Shakespearean: For I am sick when I do look on thee .

English: And I get sick when I can't look at you .
Shakespearean: And I am sick when I look not on you .

English: I rely on your virtue to protect me .
Shakespearean: Your virtue is my privilege .

English: This forest doesn't seem deserted when you're here , because you are all the world to me .
Shakespearean: Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company , For you in my respect are all the world .

English: So how can anyone say I'm alone , when the whole world is here to look at me ?
Shakespearean: Then how can it be said I am alone When all the world is here to look on me ?

English: I'll run away from you and hide in the bushes , and leave you to the mercy of wild animals .
Shakespearean: I'll run from thee and hide me in the brakes , And leave thee to the mercy of wild beasts .

English: The wildest animal isn't as cruel as you are .
Shakespearean: The wildest hath not such a heart as you .

English: Leave me alone .
Shakespearean: Let me go .

English: Or if you follow me , you'd better understand that I'll do something bad to you in the forest .
Shakespearean: Or if thou follow me , do not believe But I shall do thee mischief in the wood .

English: Yes , you already hurt me in the church , in the town , and in the fields .
Shakespearean: Ay , in the temple , in the town , the field You do me mischief .

English: Shame on you , Demetrius !
Shakespearean: Fie , Demetrius !

English: Your behavior is an insult to all women .
Shakespearean: Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex .

English: We can not fight for love as men can .
Shakespearean: We can not fight for love as men may do .

English: I'll follow you and turn this hell I'm in into a kind of heaven .
Shakespearean: I'll follow thee and make a heaven of hell , To die upon the hand I love so well .

English: Goodbye , nymph .
Shakespearean: Fare thee well , nymph .

English: Before he leaves this part of the forest , you'll change places : you'll be the one running away , and he'll be in love with you .
Shakespearean: Ere he do leave this grove , Thou shalt fly him and he shall seek thy love .

English: Do you have the flower ?
Shakespearean: Hast thou the flower there ?

English: Welcome , traveler .
Shakespearean: Welcome , wanderer .

English: Yes , here it is .
Shakespearean: Ay , there it is .

English: Please , give it to me .
Shakespearean: I pray thee , give it me .

English: Thanks , good Egeus .
Shakespearean: Thanks , good Egeus .

English: What's new with you ?
Shakespearean: What's the news with thee ?

English: I'm here , full of anger , to complain about my daughter Hermia. , Step forward , Demetrius. , My lord , this man , Demetrius , has my permission to marry her. , Step forward , Lysander. , But this other man , Lysander , has cast a magic spell over my child's heart. , You , you , Lysander , you've given her poems , and exchanged tokens of love with my daughter .
Shakespearean: Full of vexation come I with complaint Against my child , my daughter Hermia. , Stand forth , Demetrius. , My noble lord , This man hath my consent to marry her. , Stand forth , Lysander. , And my gracious duke , This man hath bewitched the bosom of my child. , Thou , thou , Lysander , thou hast given her rhymes , And interchanged love tokens with my child .

English: You've pretended to be in love with her , singing fake love songs softly at her window by moonlight , and you've captured her imagination by giving her locks of your hair , rings , toys , trinkets , knickknacks , little presents , flowers , and candies , things that can really influence an impressionable young person .
Shakespearean: Thou hast by moonlight at her window sung With feigning voice verses of feigning love , And stol'n the impression of her fantasy With bracelets of thy hair , rings , gauds , conceits , Knacks , trifles , nosegays , sweetmeats , messengers Of strong prevailment in unhardened youth .

English: You've connived to steal my daughter's heart , making her stubborn and harsh instead of obedient ( like she should be ) . , And , my gracious duke , if she won't agree to marry Demetrius right now , I ask you to let me exercise the right that all fathers have in Athens .
Shakespearean: With cunning hast thou filched my daughter's heart , Turned her obedience ( which is due to me ) To stubborn harshness. , And , my gracious duke , Be it so she will not here before your grace Consent to marry with Demetrius , I beg the ancient privilege of Athens .

English: Since she belongs to me , I can do what I want with her , as the law says : I can either make her marry Demetrius , or have her killed .
Shakespearean: As she is mine , I may dispose of her , Which shall be either to this gentleman Or to her death , according to our law Immediately provided in that case .

English: What do you have to say for yourself , Hermia ?
Shakespearean: What say you , Hermia ?

English: Demetrius is an admirable man .
Shakespearean: Demetrius is a worthy gentleman .

English: Titania sleeps there sometimes at night , lulled to sleep among the flowers by dances and other delights .
Shakespearean: There sleeps Titania sometime of the night , Lulled in these flowers with dances and delight .

English: Snakes shed their skin there , and the shed skin is wide enough to wrap a fairy in .
Shakespearean: And there the snake throws her enameled skin , Weed wide enough to wrap a fairy in .

English: I'll put the juice of this flower on Titania's eyes , and fill her with horrible delusions and desires .
Shakespearean: And with the juice of this I'll streak her eyes And make her full of hateful fantasies .

English: Don't worry , sir .
Shakespearean: Fear not , my lord .

English: I'm at your service .
Shakespearean: Your servant shall do so .

English: Okay , let's go !
Shakespearean: Hence , away !

English: Everything's fine now .
Shakespearean: Now all is well .

English: One of us will stay and stand guard .
Shakespearean: One aloof stand sentinel .

English: Whatever you see first when you wake up , think of it as your true love .
Shakespearean: What thou seest when thou dost wake , Do it for thy true love take .

English: Wake up when something nasty is nearby .
Shakespearean: Wake when some vile thing is near .

English: Let's do that , Lysander .
Shakespearean: Be it so , Lysander .

English: I'm going to rest my head on this little slope .
Shakespearean: Find you out a bed , For I upon this bank will rest my head .

English: We'll have one heart , one bed , two bodies , and one faithful vow .
Shakespearean: One heart , one bed , two bosoms , and one troth .

English: No , Lysander .
Shakespearean: Nay , good Lysander .

English: Don't sleep so close to me .
Shakespearean: Do not lie so near .

English: I just meant that our hearts are joined , so we can almost think of them as one heart .
Shakespearean: I mean that my heart unto yours is knit So that but one heart we can make of it .

English: So let me sleep next to you .
Shakespearean: Then by your side no bed room me deny .

English: Stay away for now , and good night , my sweet friend .
Shakespearean: And , good night , sweet friend .

English: I hope your love for me remains this strong for your entire life !
Shakespearean: Thy love ne'er alter till thy sweet life end !

English: Amen to that .
Shakespearean: Amen , amen to that fair prayer , say I .

English: I'll sleep over here .
Shakespearean: Here is my bed .

English: Stop , Demetrius !
Shakespearean: Pretty soul !

English: Stop , even if only to kill me .
Shakespearean: Stay , though thou kill me , sweet Demetrius .

English: I'm telling you , get out of here , and don't follow me around like this .
Shakespearean: I charge thee , hence , and do not haunt me thus .

English: Oh , will you leave me alone in the dark ?
Shakespearean: O , wilt thou darkling leave me ?

English: Don't .
Shakespearean: Do not so .

English: Stay here at your own risk .
Shakespearean: Stay , on thy peril .

English: I'm going on alone .
Shakespearean: I alone will go .

English: Oh , I'm out of breath from this foolish chase .
Shakespearean: Oh , I am out of breath in this fond chase .

English: The more I pray , the less I get out of it .
Shakespearean: The more my prayer , the lesser is my grace .

English: Hermia is lucky , wherever she is , because she has beautiful eyes .
Shakespearean: Happy is Hermia , wheresoe'er she lies , For she hath blessed and attractive eyes .

English: How did her eyes get so bright ?
Shakespearean: How came her eyes so bright ?

English: Not from crying .
Shakespearean: Not with salt tears .

English: If that's the case , tears wash my eyes more than hers .
Shakespearean: If so , my eyes are oftener washed than hers .

English: No , no , I'm as ugly as a bear , since animals that see me run away in terror .
Shakespearean: No , no , I am as ugly as a bear , For beasts that meet me run away for fear .

English: So it's no surprise that Demetrius runs away from me as if I were a monster .
Shakespearean: Therefore no marvel though Demetrius Do , as a monster , fly my presence thus .

English: What evil and deceitful mirror made me think I could rival Hermia's starry eyes ?
Shakespearean: What wicked and dissembling glass of mine Made me compare with Hermia's sphery eyne ?

English: Don't say that , Lysander .
Shakespearean: Do not say so , Lysander .

English: Don't say that .
Shakespearean: Say not so .

English: Why do you care that he loves Hermia ?
Shakespearean: What though he love your Hermia ?

English: What does it matter ?
Shakespearean: Lord , what though ?

English: Happy with Hermia ?
Shakespearean: Content with Hermia ?

English: No .
Shakespearean: No .

English: I regret all the boring time I wasted with her .
Shakespearean: I do repent The tedious minutes I with her have spent .

English: I don't love Hermia ; I love Helena .
Shakespearean: Not Hermia but Helena I love .

English: Fruits and vegetables don't ripen until the right season of the year .
Shakespearean: Things growing are not ripe until their season .

English: Likewise , I'm young , and my sense of reason has just ripened .
Shakespearean: So I , being young , till now ripe not to reason .

English: Is it not enough , is it not enough , young man , that I'll never be pretty enough to get a kind look from Demetrius ?
Shakespearean: Is 't not enough , is 't not enough , young man , That I did never , no , nor never can , Deserve a sweet look from Demetrius ' eye , But you must flout my insufficiency ?

English: Do you have to harp on my inadequacy ?
Shakespearean: Good troth , you do me wrong , good sooth , you do , In such disdainful manner me to woo .

English: But goodbye .
Shakespearean: But fare you well .

English: I have to tell you , I thought you were a much kinder person than this .
Shakespearean: Perforce I must confess I thought you lord of more true gentleness .

English: Oh , how awful that a lady who's been rejected by one man should therefore be treated horribly by another one !
Shakespearean: Oh , that a lady of one man refused Should of another therefore be abused !

English: Are we all here ?
Shakespearean: Are we all met ?

English: Right on time .
Shakespearean: Pat , pat .

English: This is the perfect place to rehearse .
Shakespearean: And here's a marvelous convenient place for our rehearsal .

English: This clearing will be the stage , and this hawthorn bush will be our dressing room .
Shakespearean: This green plot shall be our stage , this hawthorn-brake our tiring-house , and we will do it in action as we will do it before the duke .

English: Peter Quince , What is it , jolly Bottom ?
Shakespearean: Peter Quince , What sayest thou , bully Bottom ?

English: There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and Thisbe that will never work .
Shakespearean: There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and Thisbe that will never please .

English: First of all , Pyramus has to take out a sword to kill himself , which the ladies in the audience won't be able to stand .
Shakespearean: First , Pyramus must draw a sword to kill himself , which the ladies can not abide .

English: What should we do about that ?
Shakespearean: How answer you that ?

English: I think we'll have to leave out all the killing , come to think of it .
Shakespearean: I believe we must leave the killing out , when all is done .

English: Not at all !
Shakespearean: Not a whit .

English: I've got a plan that will fix everything .
Shakespearean: I have a device to make all well .

English: I'll tell them that we won't hurt anyone with our swords , and that Pyramus isn't really dead .
Shakespearean: Write me a prologue , and let the prologue seem to say we will do no harm with our swords , and that Pyramus is not killed indeed .

English: And to make it even clearer , we can tell them that I'm playing Pyramus but I'm not really Pyramus , really , I'm Bottom the weaver .
Shakespearean: And for the more better assurance , tell them that I , Pyramus , am not Pyramus , but Bottom the weaver .

English: That'll keep them from being afraid .
Shakespearean: This will put them out of fear .

English: All right , we'll have a prologue then .
Shakespearean: Well .

English: We'll write it in alternating eight- and six-syllable lines , just like in a ballad .
Shakespearean: We will have such a prologue , and it shall be written in eight and six .

English: No , add a couple more syllables .
Shakespearean: No , make it two more .

English: Make it eight and eight .
Shakespearean: Let it be written in eight and eight .

English: Won't the ladies be scared of the lion ?
Shakespearean: Will not the ladies be afeard of the lion ?

English: I'm really worried about that .
Shakespearean: I fear it , I promise you .

English: There's no scarier wild bird than the living lion , and we should remember that .
Shakespearean: For there is not a more fearful wildfowl than your lion living .

English: So we need another prologue to tell everyone he's not a real lion .
Shakespearean: Therefore another prologue must tell he is not a lion .

English: No , we can just announce the actor's name , and let his face show through the lion costume , and have him say something himself .
Shakespearean: Nay , you must name his name , and half his face must be seen through the lion's neck .

English: Because , you know , Pyramus and Thisbe meet by moonlight .
Shakespearean: For , you know , Pyramus and Thisbe meet by moonlight .

English: So is Lysander .
Shakespearean: So is Lysander .

English: You're right , Lysander's admirable too .
Shakespearean: In himself he is .

English: But since your father doesn't want him to marry you , you have to consider Demetrius to be the better man .
Shakespearean: But in this kind , wanting your father's voice , The other must be held the worthier .

English: I wish my father could see them with my eyes .
Shakespearean: I would my father looked but with my eyes .

English: No , you must see them as your father sees them .
Shakespearean: Rather your eyes must with his judgment look .

English: Your grace , please forgive me .
Shakespearean: I do entreat your grace to pardon me .

English: But please , tell me the worst thing that could happen to me if I refuse to marry Demetrius .
Shakespearean: I know not by what power I am made bold Nor how it may concern my modesty In such a presence here to plead my thoughts , But I beseech your grace that I may know The worst that may befall me in this case , If I refuse to wed Demetrius .

English: So think carefully about what you want , beautiful Hermia .
Shakespearean: Therefore , fair Hermia , question your desires .

English: Consider how young you are , and question your feelings .
Shakespearean: Know of your youth .

English: Will the moon be shining on the night we're performing our play ?
Shakespearean: Doth the moon shine that night we play our play ?

English: We need a calendar !
Shakespearean: A calendar , a calendar !

English: Look in the almanac .
Shakespearean: Look in the almanac .

English: Look up moonshine , look up moonshine !
Shakespearean: Find out moonshine , find out moonshine !

English: What do you think , Bottom ?
Shakespearean: What say you , Bottom ?

English: He can hold his fingers in a V-shape like this , and Pyramus and Thisbe can whisper to each other through that little crack .
Shakespearean: And let him hold his fingers thus , and through that cranny shall Pyramus and Thisbe whisper .

English: If we can do that , everything will be all right .
Shakespearean: If that may be then all is well .

English: Now sit down , everybody , and rehearse your parts , Pyramus , you start .
Shakespearean: Come , sit down , every mother's son , and rehearse your parts. , Pyramus , you begin .

English: When you have said your lines , go hide in that bush. , Everyone else , go there too when you're not onstage .
Shakespearean: When you have spoken your speech , enter into that brake. , And so everyone according to his cue .

English: Speak , Pyramus. , Thisbe , come forward .
Shakespearean: Speak , Pyramus. , Thisbe , stand forth .

English: Yes , you are .
Shakespearean: Ay , marry , must you .

English: You're supposed to show that you understand that Pyramus just went to check on a noise he heard and is coming right back .
Shakespearean: For you must understand he goes but to see a noise that he heard , and is to come again .

English: That's "Ninus's grave , " man .
Shakespearean: Ninus ' tomb , " man .

English: And don't say all of that yet .
Shakespearean: Why , you must not speak that yet .

English: You just said all your lines at once , cues and all. , Pyramus , enter .
Shakespearean: You speak all your part at once , cues and all. , Pyramus , enter .

English: It's "never get tired." Oh !
Shakespearean: It is "never tire." Oh .

English: Help !
Shakespearean: Oh , monstrous !

English: It's a monster !
Shakespearean: Oh , strange !

English: We're being haunted .
Shakespearean: We are haunted .

English: Run , everyone , run !
Shakespearean: Fly , masters !

English: I'll follow you .
Shakespearean: I'll follow you .

English: Sometimes I'll turn into fire !
Shakespearean: Sometime a horse I'll be , sometime a hound , A hog , a headless bear , sometime a fire .

English: And I'll neigh like a horse and bark like a hound and grunt like a pig and roar like a bear and burn like a fire at every turn .
Shakespearean: And neigh , and bark , and grunt , and roar , and burn , Like horse , hound , hog , bear , fire , at every turn .

English: Why are they running away ?
Shakespearean: Why do they run away ?

English: Oh , Bottom , you've changed !
Shakespearean: O Bottom , thou art changed !

English: What have you got on your head ?
Shakespearean: What do I see on thee ?

English: What do you think I've got on my head ?
Shakespearean: What do you see ?

English: You're acting like an ass , don't you think ?
Shakespearean: You see an ass head of your own , do you ?

English: God bless you , Bottom , God bless you .
Shakespearean: Bless thee , Bottom , bless thee .

English: Reborn .
Shakespearean: Thou art translated .

English: But I won't leave this spot , no matter what they do .
Shakespearean: But I will not stir from this place , do what they can .

English: I'll walk up and down and sing a song , so they'll know I'm not afraid .
Shakespearean: I will walk up and down here and I will sing , that they shall hear I am not afraid .

English: Who'd waste his time talking to such a stupid bird ?
Shakespearean: For indeed , who would set his wit to so foolish a bird ?

English: I don't think you've got much of a reason to love me .
Shakespearean: Methinks , mistress , you should have little reason for that .

English: But to tell you the truth , reason and love have very little to do with each other these days .
Shakespearean: And yet , to say the truth , reason and love keep little company together nowadays .

English: It's too bad some mutual friend of theirs doesn't introduce them .
Shakespearean: The more the pity that some honest neighbors will not make them friends .

English: You're as wise as you are beautiful .
Shakespearean: Thou art as wise as thou art beautiful .

English: No , that's not true .
Shakespearean: Not so , neither .

English: But if I were smart enough to get out of this forest , I'd be wise enough to satisfy myself .
Shakespearean: But if I had wit enough to get out of this wood , I have enough to serve mine own turn .

English: I'm no ordinary fairy .
Shakespearean: I am a spirit of no common rate .

English: So come with me .
Shakespearean: Therefore go with me .

English: And I'll turn you into a spirit like us , so you won't die as humans do. , Come here , Peaseblossom , Cobweb , Moth , and Mustardseed !
Shakespearean: And I will purge thy mortal grossness so That thou shalt like an airy spirit go. , Peaseblossom , Cobweb , Moth , and Mustardseed !

English: Ready .
Shakespearean: Ready .

English: Me too .
Shakespearean: And I .

English: Me too .
Shakespearean: And I .

English: And me too .
Shakespearean: And I .

English: Where should we go ?
Shakespearean: Where shall we go ?

English: Be kind and polite to this gentleman .
Shakespearean: Be kind and courteous to this gentleman .

English: Leap and dance for him .
Shakespearean: Hop in his walks and gambol in his eyes .

English: Feed him apricots and blackberries , with purple grapes , green figs , and mulberries .
Shakespearean: Feed him with apricoks and dewberries , With purple grapes , green figs , and mulberries .

English: Pluck off colorful butterfly wings , and use them to fan moonbeams away from his eyes as he sleeps .
Shakespearean: And pluck the wings from painted butterflies To fan the moonbeams from his sleeping eyes .

English: Bow to him , fairies , and curtsy to him .
Shakespearean: Nod to him , elves , and do him courtesies .

English: Hello , mortal !
Shakespearean: Hail , mortal .

English: Hello !
Shakespearean: Hail .

English: Hello !
Shakespearean: Hail .

English: Hello !
Shakespearean: Hail .

English: I beg your pardon , sirs. , Please tell me your name , sir ?
Shakespearean: I cry your worships ' mercy , heartily. , I beseech your worship's name .

English: Cobweb .
Shakespearean: Cobweb .

English: I'd like to get to know you better , Mr. Cobweb .
Shakespearean: I shall desire you of more acquaintance , good Master Cobweb .

English: If I cut my finger , I'll use you as a bandage to stop the bleeding. , And your name , sir ?
Shakespearean: If I cut my finger , I shall make bold with you. , Your name , honest gentleman ?

English: Peaseblossom .
Shakespearean: Peaseblossom .

English: Please , give my regards to your mother , Mrs. Peapod , and your father , Mr. Peapod .
Shakespearean: I pray you , commend me to Mistress Squash , your mother , and to Master Peascod , your father .

English: Good Mr. Peaseblossom , I'd like to get to know you better too. , And you , may I ask what your name is , sir ?
Shakespearean: Good Master Peaseblossom , I shall desire you of more acquaintance too. , Your name , I beseech you , sir ?

English: Mustardseed .
Shakespearean: Mustardseed .

English: Good Mr. Mustardseed , I know you very well .
Shakespearean: Good Master Mustardseed , I know your patience well .

English: Those cowardly , gigantic sides of beef have been responsible for many of your family members getting eaten as a condiment on beef .
Shakespearean: That same cowardly , giantlike ox-beef hath devoured many a gentleman of your house .

English: I swear to you , many members of your mustard family have made my eyes water before .
Shakespearean: I promise you your kindred hath made my eyes water ere now .

English: I look forward to getting to know you better , Mr. Mustardseed .
Shakespearean: I desire you of more acquaintance , good Master Mustardseed .

English: Take good care of him .
Shakespearean: Come , wait upon him .

English: Take him to my sleeping area .
Shakespearean: Lead him to my bower .

English: The moon looks sad to me .
Shakespearean: The moon methinks looks with a watery eye .

English: When she cries , all the little flowers cry too .
Shakespearean: And when she weeps , weeps every little flower , Lamenting some enforced chastity .

English: Keep my lover quiet .
Shakespearean: Tie up my love's tongue .

English: Bring him to me in silence .
Shakespearean: Bring him silently .

English: Ah , here comes my messenger. , What's going on , you crazy spirit ?
Shakespearean: Here comes my messenger. , How now , mad spirit ?

English: What havoc have you wreaked in this part of the forest ?
Shakespearean: What night-rule now about this haunted grove ?

English: My mistress Titania is in love with a monster .
Shakespearean: My mistress with a monster is in love .

English: I led them on in this frightened , distracted state , and left sweet
Shakespearean: I led them on in this distracted fear And left sweet Pyramus translated there .

English: At that exact moment , Titania woke up and immediately fell in love with him , an ass .
Shakespearean: When in that moment so it came to pass , Titania waked and straightway loved an ass .

English: This is going even better than I planned .
Shakespearean: This falls out better than I could devise .

English: But have you put the love juice from the flower on the eyes of that Athenian , as I asked you to do ?
Shakespearean: But hast thou yet latched the Athenian's eyes With the love juice , as I did bid thee do ?

English: Yes , I found him when he was asleep , so that's taken care of too , and the Athenian woman was sleeping near him .
Shakespearean: I took him sleeping , that is finished too , And the Athenian woman by his side , That , when he waked , of force she must be eyed .

English: Why are you so rude to someone who loves you so much ?
Shakespearean: Oh , why rebuke you him that loves you so ?

English: Save that kind of harsh language for your worst enemy .
Shakespearean: Lay breath so bitter on your bitter foe .

English: If you killed Lysander while he was sleeping , then you're already up to your ankles in blood .
Shakespearean: If thou hast slain Lysander in his sleep , Being o'er shoes in blood , plunge in the deep , And kill me too .

English: He was more faithful to me than the sun is to the daytime .
Shakespearean: The sun was not so true unto the day As he to me .

English: Would he have snuck away from me while I was asleep ?
Shakespearean: Would he have stolen away From sleeping Hermia ?

English: The only possibility is that you've murdered him .
Shakespearean: It can not be but thou hast murdered him .

English: A murderer should look like you do , so pale and grim .
Shakespearean: So should a murderer look , so dead , so grim .

English: That's how someone who's been murdered should look , and that's how I look .
Shakespearean: So should the murdered look , and so should I , Pierced through the heart with your stern cruelty .

English: You've pierced me through the heart with your cruelty , and yet you , the murderer , look as bright and clear as a star in the sky .
Shakespearean: Yet you , the murderer , look as bright , as clear , As yonder Venus in her glimmering sphere .

English: What does that have to do with my Lysander ?
Shakespearean: What's this to my Lysander ?

English: Where is he ?
Shakespearean: Where is he ?

English: Oh , good Demetrius , will you find him for me ?
Shakespearean: Ah , good Demetrius , wilt thou give him me ?

English: Did you kill him , then ?
Shakespearean: Hast thou slain him then ?

English: Oh , how brave of you !
Shakespearean: O brave touch !

English: A snake could do that as easily as you could .
Shakespearean: Could not a worm , an adder , do so much ?

English: A snake did do it , because no snake ever had a more forked , lying tongue than you have .
Shakespearean: An adder did it , for with doubler tongue Than thine , thou serpent , never adder stung .

English: I didn't kill Lysander .
Shakespearean: I am not guilty of Lysander's blood .

English: As far as I know , he's not even dead .
Shakespearean: Nor is he dead , for aught that I can tell .

English: Then please tell me he's all right .
Shakespearean: I pray thee , tell me then that he is well .

English: If I told you that , what would I get out of it ?
Shakespearean: An if I could , what should I get therefore ?

English: Please give in , sweet Hermia. , And Lysander , stop acting like she's yours .
Shakespearean: Relent , sweet Hermia , And , Lysander , yield Thy crazed title to my certain right .

English: Her father loves you , Demetrius .
Shakespearean: You have her father's love , Demetrius .

English: She's mine , and I'm giving her to Demetrius .
Shakespearean: And she is mine , and all my right of her I do estate unto Demetrius .

English: The privilege of never seeing me again .
Shakespearean: A privilege never to see me more .

English: And now I'm going to leave your despised company .
Shakespearean: And from thy hated presence part I so .

English: You'll never see me again , whether or not he's dead .
Shakespearean: See me no more , whether he be dead or no .

English: So I'll stay here for a while .
Shakespearean: Here therefore for a while I will remain .

English: That's the way of the world .
Shakespearean: And laid the love juice on some true love's sight .

English: Go around the forest , moving faster than the wind , and make sure you find Helena of Athens. , She's lovesick , and her face is pale from all the sighing she's been doing , because sighing is bad for the blood .
Shakespearean: About the wood go swifter than the wind , And Helena of Athens look thou find , All fancy-sick she is and pale of cheer , With sighs of love , that costs the fresh blood dear .

English: You purple flower , hit by Cupid's arrow , sink into the pupils of this man's eyes .
Shakespearean: Flower of this purple dye , Hit with Cupid's archery , Sink in apple of his eye .

English: Young man , when you wake up , if she's nearby , beg her to cure your lovesickness .
Shakespearean: When thou wakest , if she be by , Beg of her for remedy .

English: Should we watch this ridiculous scene ?
Shakespearean: Shall we their fond pageant see ?

English: Lord , what fools these mortals are !
Shakespearean: Lord , what fools these mortals be !

English: Step aside .
Shakespearean: Stand aside .

English: The noise they're making will wake up Demetrius .
Shakespearean: The noise they make Will cause Demetrius to awake .

English: Then the two of them will both pursue one girl .
Shakespearean: Then will two at once woo one .

English: Why do you think I'm making fun of you when I tell you I love you ?
Shakespearean: Why should you think that I should woo in scorn ?

English: People don't cry when they're mocking someone .
Shakespearean: Look , when I vow , I weep .

English: How can it seem like I'm making fun of you , when my tears prove that I'm sincere ?
Shakespearean: How can these things in me seem scorn to you , Bearing the badge of faith to prove them true ?

English: You get trickier and trickier .
Shakespearean: You do advance your cunning more and more .

English: Will you abandon her ?
Shakespearean: Will you give her o'er ?

English: Demetrius loves her , and he doesn't love you .
Shakespearean: Demetrius loves her , and he loves not you .

English: Damn it !
Shakespearean: Crystal is muddy .

English: I see you're all determined to gang up on me for a few laughs .
Shakespearean: I see you all are bent To set against me for your merriment .

English: You're competing for
Shakespearean: You are unkind , Demetrius .

English: Don't be cruel , Demetrius .
Shakespearean: Be not so .

English: In exchange , give up your claim to love Helena , since I love her and will love her until I die .
Shakespearean: And yours of Helena to me bequeath , Whom I do love and will do till my death .

English: Lysander , keep your Hermia .
Shakespearean: Lysander , keep thy Hermia .

English: I don't want her .
Shakespearean: I will none .

English: Helena , it's not true .
Shakespearean: Helen , it is not so .

English: Look , here comes the woman you love .
Shakespearean: Look , where thy love comes .

English: It's hard to see clearly in the dark of night , but it's easier to hear well .
Shakespearean: Dark night , that from the eye his function takes , The ear more quick of apprehension makes .

English: I couldn't see you , Lysander , but I heard your voice , and that's how I found you .
Shakespearean: Thou art not by mine eye , Lysander , found .

English: Why did you leave me alone so unkindly ?
Shakespearean: Mine ear , I thank it , brought me to thy sound But why unkindly didst thou leave me so ?

English: Why stay when love tells you to go ?
Shakespearean: Why should he stay , whom love doth press to go ?

English: But what love could make my Lysander leave me ?
Shakespearean: What love could press Lysander from my side ?

English: I had to hurry to my love , beautiful Helena , who lights up the night better than all those fiery stars .
Shakespearean: Lysander's love , that would not let him bide , Fair Helena , who more engilds the night Than all yon fiery oes and eyes of light .

English: Why are you looking for me ?
Shakespearean: Why seek'st thou me ?

English: Didn't you figure out that I left you because I hate you ?
Shakespearean: Could not this make thee know The hate I bear thee made me leave thee so ?

English: You can't mean what you're saying .
Shakespearean: You speak not as you think .

English: It's impossible .
Shakespearean: It can not be .

English: So , she's in on this too !
Shakespearean: Lo , she is one of this confederacy !

English: Now I see that all three of them have gotten together to play this cruel trick on me .
Shakespearean: Now I perceive they have conjoined all three To fashion this false sport , in spite of me. , Injurious Hermia !

English: Have you forgotten all the talks we've had together , the vows we made to be like sisters to one another , all the hours we spent together , wishing that we never had to say goodbye , have you forgotten ?
Shakespearean: Is all the counsel that we two have shared , The sisters ' vows , the hours that we have spent When we have chid the hasty-footed time For parting us , oh , is it all forgot ?

English: Our friendship in our schooldays , our childhood innocence ?
Shakespearean: All schooldays ' friendship , childhood innocence ?

English: We used to sit together and sew one flower with our two needles , sewing it on one piece of cloth , sitting on the same cushion , singing one song in the same key , as if our hands , our sides , our voices and our minds were stuck together .
Shakespearean: We , Hermia , like two artificial gods , Have with our needles created both one flower , Both on one sampler , sitting on one cushion , Both warbling of one song , both in one key , As if our hands , our sides , voices , and minds , Had been incorporate .

English: We grew together like twin cherries , which seemed to be separate but were also together , two lovely cherries on one stem .
Shakespearean: So we grew together , Like to a double cherry , seeming parted But yet an union in partition , Two lovely berries molded on one stem ;

English: There is scorn and disdain in her eyes , and those sparkling eyes despise everything they look upon .
Shakespearean: Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes , Misprizing what they look on , and her wit Values itself so highly that to her All matter else seems weak .

English: She can't even imagine what "love" is .
Shakespearean: She can not love Nor take no shape nor project of affection She is so self-endeared .

English: It would be bad if she knew about Benedick's love and teased him about it .
Shakespearean: Sure , I think so , And therefore certainly it were not good She knew his love , lest she make sport at it .

English: It's true .
Shakespearean: Why , you speak truth .

English: And so she turns men inside out and never acknowledges the integrity and merit that a man has .
Shakespearean: So turns she every man the wrong side out And never gives to truth and virtue that Which simpleness and merit purchaseth .

English: But who would dare tell her ?
Shakespearean: But who dare tell her so ?

English: If I said something , she'd mock me so mercilessly that I'd probably disintegrate into air .
Shakespearean: If I should speak , She would mock me into air .

English: She'd laugh me right out of my body and kill me with her wit .
Shakespearean: O , she would laugh me Out of myself , press me to death with wit .

English: Like a fire that gets covered up , Benedick should smother his love and waste away .
Shakespearean: Therefore let Benedick , like covered fire , Consume away in sighs , waste inwardly .

English: It would be better to die that way than to die from being mocked , which is as bad as being killed by tickling .
Shakespearean: It were a better death than die with mocks , Which is as bad as die with tickling .

English: No , instead I'll go to Benedick and advise him to fight his emotions .
Shakespearean: No , rather I will go to Benedick And counsel him to fight against his passion ; And truly I'll devise some honest slanders To stain my cousin with .

English: You don't know how quickly affection can be killed with a single nasty word .
Shakespearean: One doth not know How much an ill word may empoison liking .

English: Oh , don't injure your cousin like that !
Shakespearean: O , do not do your cousin such a wrong !

English: With the quick , intelligent wit she's rumored to have , she can't really be such a bad judge of character that she'd refuse a man as exceptional as Signior Benedick .
Shakespearean: She can not be so much without true judgment , Having so swift and excellent a wit As she is prized to have , as to refuse So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick .

English: He's the only worthy man in Italy , aside from my dear Claudio .
Shakespearean: He is the only man of Italy , Always excepted my dear Claudio .

English: True , he has an excellent reputation .
Shakespearean: Indeed , he hath an excellent good name .

English: And he deserves it , having been excellent before he had a reputation for it .
Shakespearean: His excellence did earn it , ere he had it .

English: When are you getting married , madam ?
Shakespearean: When are you married , madam ?

English: Tomorrow , and then every day after that .
Shakespearean: Why , every day , tomorrow .

English: Come on , let's go inside .
Shakespearean: Come , go in .

English: I'll stay in Messina until you're married , and then I'll go to Aragon .
Shakespearean: I do but stay till your marriage be consummate , and then go I toward Aragon .

English: I'll go with you , my lord , if you'll allow me .
Shakespearean: I'll bring you thither , my lord , if you'll vouchsafe me .

English: No , taking you away from your new marriage would be like showing a child a new coat and then not letting him wear it .
Shakespearean: Nay , that would be as great a soil in the new gloss of your marriage as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to wear it .

English: I'll ask only Benedick to come with me , for from the top of his head to the soles of his feet he's a joker .
Shakespearean: I will only be bold with Benedick for his company , for from the crown of his head to the sole of his foot he is all mirth .

English: He's evaded love once or twice , and since then Cupid doesn't dare to shoot at him .
Shakespearean: He hath twice or thrice cut Cupid's bow-string , and the little hangman dare not shoot at him .

English: Benedick's heart is like a bell , with his tongue as the clapper : everything his heart thinks , his tongue speaks .
Shakespearean: He hath a heart as sound as a bell , and his tongue is the clapper , for what his heart thinks , his tongue speaks .

English: Gentleman , I am not the same man I was before .
Shakespearean: Gallants , I am not as I have been .

English: I agree .
Shakespearean: So say I. Methinks you are sadder .

English: I hope he's in love .
Shakespearean: I hope he be in love .

English: There isn't a single drop of sincerity in him that could be touched with love .
Shakespearean: There's no true drop of blood in him to be truly touched with love .

English: If he looks serious , he must need money .
Shakespearean: If he be sad , he wants money .

English: What , are you moaning on about your toothache ?
Shakespearean: What , sigh for the toothache ?

English: I repeat , he's in love .
Shakespearean: Yet say I , he is in love .

English: Unless you're talking about his love for this kind of foolishness , which , judging from his appearance , he has , he is no fool for love , as you pretend .
Shakespearean: Unless he have a fancy to this foolery , as it appears he hath , he is no fool for fancy , as you would have it appear he is .

English: If he's not in love with a woman , then you can't trust the usual symptoms .
Shakespearean: If he be not in love with some woman , there is no believing old signs .

English: He brushes his hat in the mornings .
Shakespearean: He brushes his hat o ' mornings .

English: What do you think that means ?
Shakespearean: What should that bode ?

English: Has any man seen him at the barber's ?
Shakespearean: Hath any man seen him at the barber's ?

English: No , but the barber's assistant has been seen with him .
Shakespearean: No , but the barber's man hath been seen with him , and the old ornament of his cheek hath already stuffed tennis balls .

English: And he's rubbed himself with perfume .
Shakespearean: Nay , he rubs himself with civet .

English: Can you smell out his secret now ?
Shakespearean: Can you smell him out by that ?

English: But when You take up your duties too cheerfully .
Shakespearean: You embrace your charge too willingly .

English: That's what her mother always tells me .
Shakespearean: Her mother hath many times told me so .

English: Ah , he got you back , Benedick !
Shakespearean: You have it full , Benedick .

English: Congratulations , lady : you resemble a most honorable man .
Shakespearean: Truly , the lady fathers herself. , Be happy , lady , for you are like an honorable father .

English: Well , even if he is her father , I'm sure she wouldn't want to have the head of the old man on her shoulders !
Shakespearean: If Signor Leonato be her father , she would not have his head on her shoulders for all Messina , as like him as she is .

English: I'm amazed you're still talking , Signior Benedick .
Shakespearean: I wonder that you will still be talking , Signor Benedick .

English: No one's listening to you .
Shakespearean: Nobody marks you .

English: Look , it's my dear Lady Disdain !
Shakespearean: What , my dear Lady Disdain !

English: Aren't you dead yet ?
Shakespearean: Are you yet living ?

English: That's as good as proof that the sweet young man's in love .
Shakespearean: That's as much as to say , the sweet youth's in love .

English: The biggest clue is his seriousness .
Shakespearean: The greatest note of it is his melancholy .

English: And when has he ever been known to wash his face ?
Shakespearean: And when was he wont to wash his face ?

English: Yes , or to wear cosmetics ?
Shakespearean: Yea , or to paint himself ?

English: I hear what they say about him for doing that .
Shakespearean: For the which I hear what they say of him .

English: Indeed , his mocking spirit has now crawled into a Truly , it all adds up to a serious story for Benedick .
Shakespearean: Nay , but his jesting spirit , which is now crept into a lute string and now governed by stops , Indeed , that tells a heavy tale for him .

English: A conclusion , a conclusion : he is in love .
Shakespearean: Conclude , conclude , he is in love .

English: Oh , and I know who loves him .
Shakespearean: Nay , but I know who loves him .

English: She'll be buried with her face upwards , then .
Shakespearean: She shall be buried with her face upwards .

English: This chatter is no cure for my toothache .
Shakespearean: Yet is this no charm for the toothache. , Old Signior , walk aside with me .

English: It must be .
Shakespearean: Tis even so .

English: My lord and brother , God save you .
Shakespearean: My lord and brother , God save you .

English: Good evening , brother .
Shakespearean: Good e'en , brother .

English: If you don't mind , I'd like to speak with you .
Shakespearean: If your leisure served , I would speak with you .

English: In private ?
Shakespearean: In private ?

English: If you wish .
Shakespearean: If it please you .

English: But Count Claudio can stay , for what I'm about to say concerns him .
Shakespearean: Yet Count Claudio may hear , for what I would speak of concerns him .

English: What's the matter ?
Shakespearean: What's the matter ?

English: You know that he does .
Shakespearean: You know he does .

English: I don't know that , once he knows what I know .
Shakespearean: I know not that , when he knows what I know .

English: If there's any reason we shouldn't get married , I urge you to tell me .
Shakespearean: If there be any impediment , I pray you discover it .

English: You may think that I don't love you .
Shakespearean: You may think I love you not .

English: I hope that , after I tell you my news , you will think better of me .
Shakespearean: Let that appear hereafter , and aim better at me by that I now will manifest .

English: My brother thinks highly of you , and because of his affection , has helped arrange your marriage , but that was definitely a waste of his time and energy .
Shakespearean: For my brother , I think he holds you well , and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect your ensuing marriage , surely suit ill spent and labor ill bestowed .

English: Why , what's the matter ?
Shakespearean: Why , what's the matter ?

English: I came here to tell you , I'll make this short , since she's already been talked about for too long , the lady is unfaithful .
Shakespearean: I came hither to tell you ; and , circumstances shortened , for she has been too long a-talking of , the lady is disloyal .

English: Who , Hero ?
Shakespearean: Who , Hero ?

English: That's the one : Leonato's Hero , your Hero , every man's Hero .
Shakespearean: Even she : Leonato's Hero , your Hero , every man's Hero .

English: Unfaithful ?
Shakespearean: Disloyal ?

English: The word is too good to represent her wickedness .
Shakespearean: The word is too good to paint out her wickedness .

English: She is worse than wicked .
Shakespearean: I could say she were worse .

English: If you can think of a more awful title , I'll call her that .
Shakespearean: Think you of a worse title , and I will fit her to it .

English: But don't keep wondering without more proof .
Shakespearean: Wonder not till further warrant .

English: Come with me tonight , and you'll see a man enter her bedroom chamber , even tonight , the night before her wedding .
Shakespearean: Go but with me tonight , you shall see her chamber window entered , even the night before her wedding day .

English: If you still love her after that , then marry her tomorrow .
Shakespearean: If you love her then , tomorrow wed her .

English: But you would be more honorable if you changed your mind .
Shakespearean: But it would better fit your honor to change your mind .

English: I won't consider it .
Shakespearean: I will not think it .

English: If I see anything tonight that convinces me not to marry her , I'll shame her tomorrow in the very congregation where I would have married her .
Shakespearean: If I see anything tonight why I should not marry her , tomorrow in the congregation , where I should wed , there will I shame her .

English: And since I wooed her in your name , I'll join you in disgracing her .
Shakespearean: And as I wooed for thee to obtain her , I will join with thee to disgrace her .

English: Remain calm until midnight , and then you'll see what the trouble is .
Shakespearean: Bear it coldly but till midnight and let the issue show itself .

English: Oh , this day has turned into a disaster !
Shakespearean: O day untowardly turned !

English: Oh , mischief has ruined our plans !
Shakespearean: O mischief strangely thwarting !

English: Oh , a plague has been prevented , thank God !
Shakespearean: O plague right well prevented !

English: That's what you'll say once you've seen part two .
Shakespearean: So will you say when you have seen the sequel .

English: Are you all good and honest men ?
Shakespearean: Are you good men and true ?

English: Come here , Sir Seacole .
Shakespearean: Come hither , neighbor Seacole .

English: God has blessed you with a good name .
Shakespearean: God hath blessed you with a good name .

English: To be good-looking is a matter of luck , but to read and write is a natural gift .
Shakespearean: To be a well-favored man is the gift of fortune , but to write and read comes by nature .

English: Both of which , master constable , You have .
Shakespearean: Both which , Master Constable , You have .

English: I knew that would be your answer .
Shakespearean: I knew it would be your answer .

English: Well , for your good looks , sir , thank God and don't boast about it .
Shakespearean: Well , for your favor , sir , why , give God thanks , and make no boast of it , and for your writing and reading , let that appear when there is no need of such vanity .

English: You're thought to be the most
Shakespearean: You are thought here to be the most senseless and fit man for the constable of the watch ; therefore bear you the lantern .

English: you will And what if he won't stop ?
Shakespearean: How if he will not stand ?

English: Then immediately call the rest of the watch together and thank God that you've gotten rid of such a criminal .
Shakespearean: Why , then , take no note of him , but let him go and presently call the rest of the watch together and thank God you are rid of a knave .

English: If he won't stop when he's told to , then he isn't one of the Prince's subjects .
Shakespearean: If he will not stand when he is bidden , he is none of the Prince's subjects .

English: We know what's appropriate for a watch .
Shakespearean: We know what belongs to a watch .

English: Why , you speak like an experienced and quiet watchman .
Shakespearean: Why , you speak like an ancient and most quiet watchman , for I can not see how sleeping should offend .

English: Also , you're supposed to visit all the bars and tell anyone who's drunk to go home and go to bed .
Shakespearean: Well , you are to call at all the alehouses and bid those that are drunk get them to bed .

English: And what if they won't go ?
Shakespearean: How if they will not ?

English: Well then , leave them alone until they're sober .
Shakespearean: Why , then , let them alone till they are sober .

English: If even then they don't answer to your satisfaction , you can say that they're not the men you thought they were .
Shakespearean: If they make you not then the better answer , you may say they are not the men you took them for .

English: Very good , sir .
Shakespearean: Well , sir .

English: So if we know that a man is a thief , should we try to arrest him ?
Shakespearean: If we know him to be a thief , shall we not lay hands on him ?

English: You , constable , are representing the Prince himself .
Shakespearean: You , constable , are to present the Prince's own person .

English: If you meet the Prince in the night , you can order him to stop .
Shakespearean: If you meet the Prince in the night , you may stay him .

English: No , by our Lady , I don't think he can .
Shakespearean: Nay , by 'r Lady , that I think he can not .

English: I'll bet any man who knows the law five shillings to one on it .
Shakespearean: Five shillings to one on 't , with any man that knows the statutes , he may stay him , marry , not without the Prince be willing , for indeed the watch ought to offend no man , and it is an offense to stay a man against his will .

English: By our Lady , I think that's true .
Shakespearean: By 'r lady , I think it be so .

English: And if anything important happens , find me and let me know .
Shakespearean: An there be any matter of weight chances , call up me .

English: Well gentlemen , we've heard our assignment .
Shakespearean: Well , masters , we hear our charge .

English: Let's sit here on the church bench until two and then go off to bed .
Shakespearean: Let us go sit here upon the church bench till two , and then all to bed .

English: One more thing , good gentlemen .
Shakespearean: One word more , honest neighbors .

English: Watch over Signior Leonato's house ; with the wedding being held there tomorrow , there's a great to-do there tonight .
Shakespearean: I pray you watch about Signior Leonato's door , for the wedding being there tomorrow , there is a great coil tonight .

English: Adieu .
Shakespearean: Adieu , be vigitant , I beseech you .

English: Be Conrade !
Shakespearean: What Conrade !

English: Conrade , I say !
Shakespearean: Conrade , I say !

English: Come to think of it , I thought I felt a scab there .
Shakespearean: Mass , and my elbow itched , I thought there would a scab follow .

English: I'll get you for that .
Shakespearean: I will owe thee an answer for that .

English: Now get on with your story .
Shakespearean: And now forward with thy tale .

English: Since it's drizzling , stand under this overhang with me and , like a true drunk , I'll tell you everything .
Shakespearean: Stand thee close , then , under this penthouse , for it drizzles rain , and I will , like a true drunkard , utter all to thee .

English: You should know I've earned a thousand gold pieces from Don John .
Shakespearean: Therefore know I have earned of Don John a thousand ducats .

English: Is it possible that any crime could be so valuable ?
Shakespearean: Is it possible that any villainy should be so dear ?

English: You should ask instead if it's possible that any criminal could be so rich .
Shakespearean: Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any villainy should be so rich .

English: Because when rich villains need poor villains ' services , those poor ones can name the price .
Shakespearean: For when rich villains have need of poor ones , poor ones may make what price they will .

English: I can't believe it .
Shakespearean: I wonder at it .

English: That only proves how inexperienced you are .
Shakespearean: That shows thou art unconfirmed .

English: You know that the style of a man's jacket or hat or coat means nothing .
Shakespearean: Thou knowest that the fashion of a doublet , or a hat , or a cloak , is nothing to a man .

English: Yes , it's just clothing .
Shakespearean: Yes , it is apparel .

English: Yes , fashion is fashion .
Shakespearean: Yes , the fashion is the fashion .

English: C'mon , I might as well say the fool's the fool !
Shakespearean: Tush , I may as well say the fool's the fool .

English: But don't you see what a Did you hear someone ?
Shakespearean: Didst thou not hear somebody ?

English: Just the weathervane moving .
Shakespearean: No , 'twas the vane on the house .

English: But you're all wound up about fashion , too .
Shakespearean: But art not thou thyself giddy with the fashion too , that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion ?

English: No , I'm not wound up .
Shakespearean: Not so , neither .

English: But I will tell you that I seduced Margaret , the Lady Hero's waiting woman , tonight .
Shakespearean: But know that I have tonight wooed Margaret , the Lady Hero's gentlewoman , by the name of Hero .

English: I should backtrack and begin with how my master , Don John , arranged for the Prince , Claudio , and himself to witness this friendly encounter from the orchard .
Shakespearean: I should first tell thee how the Prince , Claudio and my master , planted and placed and possessed by my master Don John , saw afar off in the orchard this amiable encounter .

English: That makes Lady Courtesy a traitor .
Shakespearean: Then is courtesy a turncoat .

English: All ladies love me , except you .
Shakespearean: But it is certain I am loved of all ladies , only you excepted .

English: It's too bad I'm so hard-hearted , because I really don't love anyone .
Shakespearean: And I would I could find in my heart that I had not a hard heart , for truly I love none .

English: Women are lucky , then .
Shakespearean: A dear happiness to women .

English: You would make a nasty suitor .
Shakespearean: They would else have been troubled with a pernicious suitor .

English: I would rather listen to my dog bark at a crow than hear a man swear that he loves me .
Shakespearean: I had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man swear he loves me .

English: Well , I hope you stay in that frame of mind or some poor man will end up with his face all scratched up .
Shakespearean: God keep your Ladyship still in that mind , so some gentle- man or other shall 'scape a predestinate scratched face .

English: If he has a face like yours , a good scratching couldn't make him look any worse .
Shakespearean: Scratching could not make it worse an 'twere such a face as yours were .

English: Listen to you , instructing me like a parrot would .
Shakespearean: Well , you are a rare parrot-teacher .

English: I'd rather be a squawking bird than an animal like you .
Shakespearean: A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours .

English: I wish my horse moved as fast as your mouth and was as tireless .
Shakespearean: I would my horse had the speed of your tongue and so good a continuer .

English: That's it , I'm done .
Shakespearean: I have done .

English: You always slip out of the argument like this .
Shakespearean: You always end with a jade's trick .

English: I know you from before .
Shakespearean: I know you of old .

English: And that's everything , Leonato. , Claudio , Benedick , my dear friend Leonato has invited you all to stay here at Messina .
Shakespearean: That is the sum of all , Leonato. , Signior Claudio and Signior Benedick , my dear friend Leonato hath invited you all .

English: I told him we'll stay for at least a month , and he says that he hopes we'll stay longer .
Shakespearean: I tell him we shall stay here at the least a month , and he heartily prays some occasion may detain us longer .

English: I think he's actually serious , and not just being polite .
Shakespearean: I dare swear he is no hypocrite but prays from his heart .

English: And they thought Margaret was Hero ?
Shakespearean: And thought they Margaret was Hero ?

English: We charge you , in the Prince's name , to stop !
Shakespearean: We charge you , in the Prince's name , stand !

English: Call up the Master Constable Dogberry .
Shakespearean: Call up the right Master Constable .

English: We have And one of them is the criminal Deformed .
Shakespearean: We have here recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that ever was known in the commonwealth .

English: I know him ; he wears a lock of hair .
Shakespearean: And one Deformed is one of them .

English: Gentlemen , gentlemen , Gentlemen , don't speak .
Shakespearean: I know him ; he wears a lock .

English: We
Shakespearean: Masters , masters , warrant you .

English: We're probably a very valuable catch for these guys .
Shakespearean: Masters , never speak , we charge you , let us obey you go with us .

English: Let's go , we'll obey you .
Shakespearean: A commodity in question , I warrant you. , Come , we'll obey you .

English: Good Ursula , go wake my cousin and ask her to get up .
Shakespearean: Good Ursula , wake my cousin Beatrice and desire her to rise .

English: I will , lady .
Shakespearean: I will , lady .

English: And request that she come here .
Shakespearean: And bid her come hither .

English: Very well .
Shakespearean: Well .

English: Really , I think your other ruff is better .
Shakespearean: Troth , I think your other rebato were better .

English: No , please good Meg , I'll wear this one .
Shakespearean: No , pray thee , good Meg , I'll wear this .

English: Honestly , it's not as good as the other one , and I'm sure your cousin will agree with me .
Shakespearean: By my troth , 's not so good , and I warrant your cousin will say so .

English: My cousin's a fool , and you are too .
Shakespearean: My cousin's a fool , and thou art another .

English: I'll wear this one and none other .
Shakespearean: I'll wear none but this .

English: I like your new wig and headdress , though I'd like it more if the hair were a shade browner .
Shakespearean: I like the new tire within excellently , if the hair were a thought browner ; and your gown's a most rare fashion , i ' faith .

English: You know , I saw the Duchess of Milan's gown , the one that everyone praises so highly .
Shakespearean: I saw the Duchess of Milan's gown that they praise so .

English: Oh , they say that dress surpasses all others .
Shakespearean: Oh , that exceeds , they say .

English: But for a fine , elegant , graceful , and excellent dress , yours is worth ten of those .
Shakespearean: But for a fine , quaint , graceful , and excellent fashion , yours is worth ten on 't .

English: I hope I enjoy wearing it , for my heart is very heavy .
Shakespearean: God give me joy to wear it , for my heart is exceeding heavy .
