English: It will be made even heavier soon , by the weight of a man .
Shakespearean: Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man .

English: Shame of what , lady ?
Shakespearean: Of what , lady ?

English: Sex and marriage are honorable things , even for a beggar , right ?
Shakespearean: Is not marriage honorable in a beggar ?

English: And isn't your husband an honorable man ?
Shakespearean: Is not your lord honorable without marriage ?

English: Good morning , sweet Hero .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , sweet Hero .

English: Why do you sound so odd ?
Shakespearean: Why , how now ?

English: Are you ill ?
Shakespearean: Do you speak in the sick tune ?

English: You sound out of tune .
Shakespearean: I am out of all other tune , methinks .

English: You sing , and I'll dance .
Shakespearean: Do you sing it , and I'll dance it .

English: Never !
Shakespearean: O illegitimate construction !

English: The Count sent me an excellent pair of perfumed gloves .
Shakespearean: These gloves the Count sent me , they are an excellent perfume .

English: Sorry , I'm all stuffed .
Shakespearean: I am stuffed , cousin .

English: Ever since you lost yours .
Shakespearean: Even since you left it .

English: Doesn't my wit suit me well ?
Shakespearean: Doth not my wit become me rarely ?

English: It doesn't get seen enough ; you should wear it in your cap , the way fools wear coxcombs .
Shakespearean: It is not seen enough ; you should wear it in your cap .

English: God , I'm really sick .
Shakespearean: By my troth , I am sick .

English: I just meant that you should use some holy thistle .
Shakespearean: I meant plain holy thistle .

English: Maybe you think that I think you're in love .
Shakespearean: You may think perchance that I think you are in love .

English: No , by Our Lady , I'm not such a fool to think what I please , and I don't please to think what I can , and in fact I can not think , even if I could think my heart right past thinking , that you are in love or that you will be in love or even that you can be in love .
Shakespearean: Nay , by 'r Lady , I am not such a fool to think what I list , nor I list not to think what I can , nor indeed I can not think , if I would think my heart out of thinking , that you are in love or that you will be in love or that you can be in love .

English: But Benedick was once an enemy of love as well , and now he's become a real man .
Shakespearean: Yet Benedick was such another , and now is he become a man .

English: He swore that he'd never get married , but now , despite his earlier protestations , he loves ungrudgingly .
Shakespearean: He swore he would never marry , and yet now , in despite of his heart , he eats his meat without grudging .

English: And yet I think you look with your eyes just like every other woman does .
Shakespearean: And how you may be converted I know not , but methinks you look with your eyes as other women do .

English: It's not a false gallop , anyway .
Shakespearean: Not a false gallop .

English: Madam , we have to go : the Prince , the Count , Signior Benedick , Don John , and all the gentlemen of the town have come to bring you to church .
Shakespearean: Madam , withdraw : the Prince , the Count , Signor Benedick , Don John , and all the gallants of the town are come to fetch you to church .

English: Good cousin , good Meg , good Ursula , come help me get dressed .
Shakespearean: Help to dress me , good coz , good Meg , good Ursula .

English: What do you want from me , my good man ?
Shakespearean: What would you with me , honest neighbor ?

English: Indeed , sir , it is .
Shakespearean: Marry , this it is , sir .

English: Yes , it truly is .
Shakespearean: Yes , in truth it is , sir .

English: What's the news , my good friends ?
Shakespearean: What is it , my good friends ?

English: Sorry , sir , Goodman Verges tends to ramble .
Shakespearean: Goodman Verges , sir , speaks a little off the matter .

English: Thank you for saying that , your Worship , but we're just the poor duke's officers .
Shakespearean: It pleases your Worship to say so , but we are the poor duke's officers .

English: But truly , if I were as
Shakespearean: But truly , for mine own part , if I were as tedious as a king , I could find it in my heart to bestow it all of your worship .

English: Oh , so you'd give me all your tediousness ?
Shakespearean: All thy tediousness on me , ah ?

English: Yes , even if I had a thousand more pounds than that , for I hear that you are Me , too .
Shakespearean: Yea , an 'twere a thousand pound more than 'tis , for I hear as good exclamation on your Worship as of any man in the city , and though I be but a poor man , I am glad to hear it .

English: God gives those gifts , I had nothing to do with it .
Shakespearean: Gifts that God gives .

English: Now I must return to the wedding .
Shakespearean: I must leave you .

English: One more thing , sir .
Shakespearean: One word , sir .

English: Examine them yourselves , then bring me your findings .
Shakespearean: Take their examination yourself and bring it me .

English: Now I'm in a great hurry , as I'm sure you can see .
Shakespearean: I am now in great haste , as it may appear unto you .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Fare you well .

English: My lord , they're waiting for you to give your daughter away to Claudio .
Shakespearean: My lord , they stay for you to give your daughter to her husband .

English: I'm coming .
Shakespearean: I am ready .

English: Go to Francis Seacole , the constable of the watch .
Shakespearean: Go , good partner , go , get you to Francis Seacole .

English: Tell him to bring his pen and his inkwell to the jail .
Shakespearean: Bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the jail .

English: We won't hold back any of our wisdom .
Shakespearean: We will spare for no wit , I warrant you .

English: We'll drive them to a
Shakespearean: Here's that shall drive some of them to a noncome .

English: I am being serious , my lord .
Shakespearean: If you swear , my lord , you shall not be forsworn .

English: Thank you .
Shakespearean: I thank you .

English: I'm not a man who talks a lot , but I thank you .
Shakespearean: I am not of many words , but I thank you .

English: If it pleases you , your highness , will you lead us all inside ?
Shakespearean: Please it your Grace lead on ?

English: Give me your hand , Leonato .
Shakespearean: Your hand , Leonato .

English: We will go in together .
Shakespearean: We will go together .

English: Benedick , did you notice Signior Leonato's daughter ?
Shakespearean: Benedick , didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato ?

English: I saw her , but I didn't notice her .
Shakespearean: I noted her not , but I looked on her .

English: Isn't she a well-mannered young lady ?
Shakespearean: Is she not a modest young lady ?

English: Do you want my true opinion ?
Shakespearean: Do you question me as an honest man should do , for my simple true judgment ?

English: Or do you want me to criticize her like I do all women ?
Shakespearean: Or would you have me speak after my custom , as being a professed tyrant to their sex ?

English: No , please , speak seriously .
Shakespearean: No , I pray thee speak in sober judgment .

English: Well , it seems to me that she is too short to be praised highly , too dark to be praised fairly , and too small to be praised greatly .
Shakespearean: Why , i ' faith , methinks she's too low for a high praise , too brown for a fair praise , and too little for a great praise .

English: I can only say this about her : if she looked different than she does , she would be ugly , and since she can't be anything but herself , I don't like her .
Shakespearean: Only this commendation I can afford her , that were she other than she is , she were unhandsome , and being no other but as she is , I do not like her .

English: You think I'm kidding .
Shakespearean: Thou thinkest I am in sport .

English: Please tell me seriously what you think of her .
Shakespearean: I pray thee tell me truly how thou lik'st her .

English: All right , Friar Francis , let's keep this short .
Shakespearean: Come , Friar Francis , be brief , only to the plain form of marriage , and you shall recount their particular duties afterwards .

English: No .
Shakespearean: No .

English: No , he comes to be married Lady , do you come here to be married to this count ?
Shakespearean: Lady , you come hither to be married to this count ?

English: I do .
Shakespearean: I do .

English: If either of you knows any secret reason why you two should not be joined in marriage , I order you on your souls to say so .
Shakespearean: If either of you know any inward impediment why you should not be conjoined , charge you on your souls to utter it .

English: Do you know any , Hero ?
Shakespearean: Know you any , Hero ?

English: None , my lord .
Shakespearean: None , my lord .

English: Do you know any , count ?
Shakespearean: Know you any , count ?

English: I'm sure I can answer for him , he doesn't know any , either .
Shakespearean: I dare make his answer , none .

English: Oh , the things men dare to do !
Shakespearean: O , what men dare do !

English: The things men are allowed to do !
Shakespearean: What men may do !

English: The things men do daily , not knowing what they're doing !
Shakespearean: What men daily do , not knowing what they do !

English: What , are we playing with interjections ?
Shakespearean: How now , interjections ?

English: Well then , add some interjections that indicate laughter , like Hold on , Friar .
Shakespearean: Why , then , some be of laughing , as , ah , ha , he !

English: As freely , son , as God gave her to me .
Shakespearean: As freely , son , as God did give her me .

English: And what should I give you that would be equal in value to this rare and precious gift ?
Shakespearean: And what have I to give you back whose worth May counterpoise this rich and precious gift ?

English: Nothing , sir , except grandchildren .
Shakespearean: Nothing , unless you render her again .

English: There , Leonato , take your daughter back .
Shakespearean: Sweet Prince , you learn me noble thankfulness. , There , Leonato , take her back again .

English: She only appears honorable from the outside .
Shakespearean: She's but the sign and semblance of her honor .

English: Look , how she blushes like a virgin !
Shakespearean: Behold how like a maid she blushes here !

English: Oh , sin can disguise itself so artfully !
Shakespearean: Oh , what authority and show of truth Can cunning sin cover itself withal !

English: Doesn't that rising blush suggest that she is virtuous and innocent ?
Shakespearean: Comes not that blood as modest evidence To witness simple virtue ?

English: All of you who are looking at her , wouldn't you swear that she's a virgin , judging by these outward shows ?
Shakespearean: Would you not swear , All you that see her , that she were a maid By these exterior shows ?

English: But she is no virgin .
Shakespearean: But she is none .

English: She has been in a man's bed .
Shakespearean: She knows the heat of a luxurious bed .

English: She blushes from guilt , not modesty .
Shakespearean: Her blush is guiltiness , not modesty .

English: What do you mean , my lord ?
Shakespearean: What do you mean , my lord ?

English: My dear lord , if it was you who conquered her and took her virginity , I know what you're about to say .
Shakespearean: Dear my lord , if you in your own proof Have vanquished the resistance of her youth And made defeat of her virginity , I know what you would say : if I have known her , You will say she did embrace me as a husband , And so extenuate the forehand sin .

English: And have I ever seemed less than modest or appropriate to you ?
Shakespearean: And seemed I ever otherwise to you ?

English: Curse you for your false appearances !
Shakespearean: Out on thee , seeming !

English: Is that why you're talking so wildly ?
Shakespearean: Is my lord well , that he doth speak so wide ?

English: Good Prince , say something !
Shakespearean: Sweet Prince , why speak not you ?

English: What should I say ?
Shakespearean: What should I speak ?

English: I've been dishonored : I arranged for a friend of mine to marry a common whore .
Shakespearean: I stand dishonored , that have gone about To link my dear friend to a common stale .

English: Are you really saying these things , or am I dreaming ?
Shakespearean: Are these things spoken , or do I but dream ?

English: They're really being spoken , sir , and they're true .
Shakespearean: Sir , they are spoken , and these things are true .

English: This doesn't look like a wedding .
Shakespearean: This looks not like a nuptial .

English: It's true !
Shakespearean: True !

English: Oh God !
Shakespearean: O God !

English: Leonato , am I standing here ?
Shakespearean: Leonato , stand I here ?

English: Is this the Prince ?
Shakespearean: Is this the Prince ?

English: Is this the Prince's brother ?
Shakespearean: Is this the Prince's brother ?

English: Is this face Hero's ?
Shakespearean: Is this face Hero's ?

English: Are these our eyes ?
Shakespearean: Are our eyes our own ?

English: Yes , that's all true , but what do you mean by it , my lord ?
Shakespearean: All this is so , but what of this , my lord ?

English: Let me just ask her one question , and by your authority as her father , order her to answer truthfully .
Shakespearean: Let me but move one question to your daughter , And by that fatherly and kindly power That you have in her , bid her answer truly .

English: As my child , I order you to do so .
Shakespearean: I charge thee do so , as thou art my child .

English: Oh , God help me !
Shakespearean: Oh , God defend me !

English: What kind of game is this ?
Shakespearean: how am I beset ! , What kind of catechizing call you this ?

English: We just want you to answer to your real name .
Shakespearean: To make you answer truly to your name .

English: Isn't my name Hero ?
Shakespearean: Is it not Hero ?

English: Who can stain that name with a just accusation ?
Shakespearean: Who can blot that name With any just reproach ?

English: Indeed , Hero herself can !
Shakespearean: Marry , that can Hero !

English: You've stained your virtue with your own actions .
Shakespearean: Hero itself can blot out Hero's virtue .

English: What man were you talking to at your window last night , between the hours of midnight and one ?
Shakespearean: What man was he talked with you yesternight Out at your window betwixt twelve and one ?

English: If you're a virgin , you'll answer this question .
Shakespearean: Now , if you are a maid , answer to this .

English: I wasn't talking to any man at that time , my lord .
Shakespearean: I talked with no man at that hour , my lord .

English: I swear on my honor that we saw and heard Hero talking to a brute at her window last night .
Shakespearean: Upon mine honor , Myself , my brother , and this grieved count Did see her , hear her , at that hour last night Talk with a ruffian at her chamber window Who hath indeed , most like a liberal villain , Confessed the vile encounters they have had A thousand times in secret .

English: Pretty lady , I'm much ashamed of your shocking behavior .
Shakespearean: There is not chastity enough in language , Without offense , to utter them. , Thus , pretty lady , I am sorry for thy much misgovernment .

English: What's wrong , cousin ?
Shakespearean: Why , how now , cousin !

English: Why have you collapsed ?
Shakespearean: wherefore sink you down ?

English: Come , let's go .
Shakespearean: Come , let us go .

English: These revelations have overwhelmed her .
Shakespearean: These things , come thus to light , Smother her spirits up .

English: How is she ?
Shakespearean: How doth the lady ?

English: She's dead , I think. , Help , uncle ! , Hero , why Hero !
Shakespearean: Dead , I think. , Help , uncle ! , Hero , why , Hero !

English: Uncle !
Shakespearean: Uncle !

English: Signior Benedick !
Shakespearean: Signor Benedick !

English: Friar !
Shakespearean: Friar !

English: Death is the best way to cover over her shame .
Shakespearean: Death is the fairest cover for her shame That may be wished for .

English: How are you , Hero ?
Shakespearean: How now , cousin Hero !

English: Yes , why shouldn't she ?
Shakespearean: Yea , wherefore should she not ?

English: Why not !
Shakespearean: Wherefore !

English: Isn't every living thing condemning her ?
Shakespearean: Why , doth not every earthly thing Cry shame upon her ?

English: Am I sorry that I only had one child ?
Shakespearean: Grieved I I had but one ?

English: Do I blame Nature for being so thrifty ?
Shakespearean: Chid I for that at frugal Nature's frame ?

English: Oh , one child is one too many !
Shakespearean: O , one too much by thee !

English: Why did I ever have one ?
Shakespearean: Why had I one ?

English: Why did you once seem lovely to me ?
Shakespearean: Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes ?

English: Why didn't I just adopt a beggar's child left at my doorstep , whose shame and dishonor I could have denied , not being its true father ?
Shakespearean: Why had I not with charitable hand Took up a beggar's issue at my gates , Who , smirched thus , and mired with infamy , I might have said , "No part of it is mine ; This shame derives itself from unknown loins" ?

English: Sir , sir , calm down .
Shakespearean: Sir , sir , be patient .

English: I'm so amazed by this , I don't know what to say .
Shakespearean: For my part , I am so attired in wonder I know not what to say .

English: Oh , on my soul , my cousin has been slandered falsely !
Shakespearean: Oh , on my soul , my cousin is belied !

English: Lady , did you sleep in her room last night ?
Shakespearean: Lady , were you her bedfellow last night ?

English: No , I didn't , but I did every night for the past year .
Shakespearean: No , truly not , although until last night I have this twelvemonth been her bedfellow .

English: Then it's confirmed !
Shakespearean: Confirmed , confirmed !

English: And in her eyes I see a fire that would seem to burn away the lies the princes have told about her chastity .
Shakespearean: I have marked A thousand blushing apparitions To start into her face , a thousand innocent shames In angel whiteness beat away those blushes , And in her eye there hath appeared a fire To burn the errors that these princes hold Against her maiden truth .

English: But she must be , Friar .
Shakespearean: Friar , it can not be .

English: You see that any morals she has left are preventing her from denying the charges : she doesn't want to add perjury to her list of sins .
Shakespearean: Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left Is that she will not add to her damnation A sin of perjury .

English: The princes are under some strange misunderstanding .
Shakespearean: There is some strange misprision in the princes .

English: Two of them are completely honorable , and if they have been tricked in this , we must blame John the Bastard , who lives to create conflict .
Shakespearean: Two of them have the very bent of honor , And if their wisdoms be misled in this , The practice of it lives in John the Bastard , Whose spirits toil in frame of villainies .

English: I don't know .
Shakespearean: I know not .

English: If they have spoken the truth about Hero , I will tear her apart with my bare hands .
Shakespearean: If they speak but truth of her , These hands shall tear her ; if they wrong her honor , The proudest of them shall well hear of it .

English: Age hasn't dried up my body or eroded my intelligence so much , and luck hasn't robbed me of so much of my fortune , and my bad ways haven't deprived me of so many friends , that they won't find me ready to seek revenge both physically and mentally , with money and friends at my disposal .
Shakespearean: Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine Nor age so eat up my invention Nor fortune made such havoc of my means Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends But they shall find , awaked in such a kind , Both strength of limb and policy of mind , Ability in means and choice of friends , To quit me of them throughly .

English: Hold on a moment , and listen to my advice .
Shakespearean: Pause awhile , And let my counsel sway you in this case .

English: The princes left your daughter here for dead .
Shakespearean: Your daughter here the princes left for dead .

English: Hide her for a while in your house , and tell everyone that she has , in fact , died .
Shakespearean: Let her awhile be secretly kept in And publish it that she is dead indeed .

English: Make a bug show of mourning for her , hang sad epitaphs up at your family's tomb , and perform all the appropriate burial ceremonies .
Shakespearean: Maintain a mourning ostentation , And on your family's old monument Hang mournful epitaphs and do all rites That appertain unto a burial .

English: Why should we do this ?
Shakespearean: What shall become of this ?

English: What will this do ?
Shakespearean: What will this do ?

English: That will be a good thing .
Shakespearean: That is some good .

English: We'll maintain that she died the instant she was accused , and everyone who hears this will grieve for her , pity her , and excuse her actions .
Shakespearean: She , dying , as it must so be maintained , Upon the instant that she was accused , Shall be lamented , pitied and excused Of every hearer .

English: That's how Claudio will respond .
Shakespearean: So will it fare with Claudio .

English: And even if they don't , at least Hero's supposed death will stop the rumors of her infidelity .
Shakespearean: But if all aim but this be leveled false , The supposition of the lady's death Will quench the wonder of her infamy .

English: And if it doesn't go well , then you can keep her hidden in a nunnery , the best place for someone with her kind of dirtied reputation , away from the public's eyes , tongues , mind , and insults .
Shakespearean: And if it sort not well , you may conceal her , As best befits her wounded reputation , In some reclusive and religious life , Out of all eyes , tongues , minds , and injuries .

English: Signior Leonato , listen to the friar's plan .
Shakespearean: Signior Leonato , let the friar advise you .

English: And even though you know I'm very close to the Prince and Claudio , I swear I'll keep your counsel and deal with this secretly and justly .
Shakespearean: And though you know my inwardness and love Is very much unto the Prince and Claudio , Yet , by mine honor , I will deal in this As secretly and justly as your soul Should with your body .

English: Are you thinking of buying her ?
Shakespearean: Would you buy her , that you enquire after her ?

English: But tell me , are you speaking seriously ?
Shakespearean: But speak you this with a sad brow ?

English: Or are you just teasing ?
Shakespearean: Or do you play the flouting jack , to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder and Vulcan a rare carpenter ?

English: If I'm going to sing along with you , I need to know what key you're singing in .
Shakespearean: Come , in what key shall a man take you to go in the song ?

English: I think she's the most wonderful woman I've ever laid eyes on .
Shakespearean: In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I looked on .

English: I'm still young enough to see without glasses , and I don't see what you're talking about .
Shakespearean: I can see yet without spectacles , and I see no such matter .

English: But , hey , this doesn't mean you're looking to get married , does it ?
Shakespearean: But I hope you have no intent to turn husband , have you ?

English: Even if I had sworn never to marry , I wouldn't trust myself to keep that promise if Hero would marry me .
Shakespearean: I would scarce trust myself , though I had sworn the contrary , if Hero would be my wife .

English: What's going on these days ?
Shakespearean: Is 't come to this ?

English: Isn't there one man left in the world who knows not to take a wife ?
Shakespearean: In faith , hath not the world one man but he will wear his cap with suspicion ?

English: Look , Don Pedro has come back for you .
Shakespearean: Look , Don Pedro is returned to seek you .

English: This is a good agreement .
Shakespearean: Tis well consented .

English: Come , lady ; you must die in order to live .
Shakespearean: Presently away , For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure. , Come , lady , die to live .

English: Hopefully , your wedding day is only postponed .
Shakespearean: This wedding day Perhaps is but prolonged .

English: Have patience and endure .
Shakespearean: Have patience and endure .

English: Lady Beatrice , have you been crying this entire time ?
Shakespearean: Lady Beatrice , have you wept all this while ?

English: Yes , and I'll keep crying a while longer .
Shakespearean: Yea , and I will weep a while longer .

English: I don't wish that on you .
Shakespearean: I will not desire that .

English: I really believe your cousin was falsely accused .
Shakespearean: Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged .

English: Oh , the man who avenged her could ask anything of me !
Shakespearean: Ah , how much might the man deserve of me that would right her !

English: Is there any way I could show such friendship to you ?
Shakespearean: Is there any way to show such friendship ?

English: A very clear way , but there is no friend who will undertake it .
Shakespearean: A very even way , but no such friend .

English: Can a man do it ?
Shakespearean: May a man do it ?

English: It's a job meant for a man , but not you .
Shakespearean: It is a man's office , but not yours .

English: There is nothing in the world that I love as much as you .
Shakespearean: I do love nothing in the world so well as you .

English: Isn't that strange ?
Shakespearean: Is not that strange ?

English: It's as strange as this other thing which I don't understand .
Shakespearean: As strange as the thing I know not .

English: I feel awful for my cousin .
Shakespearean: I am sorry for my cousin .

English: By my sword , Beatrice , you love me .
Shakespearean: By my sword , Beatrice , thou lovest me .

English: Not with any sauce they could provide for them .
Shakespearean: With no sauce that can be devised to it .

English: I swear , I love you .
Shakespearean: I protest I love thee .

English: Well then , God forgive me !
Shakespearean: Why then , God forgive me .

English: Why , what have you done , sweet Beatrice ?
Shakespearean: What offense , sweet Beatrice ?

English: You got to me first .
Shakespearean: You have stayed me in a happy hour .

English: I was about to swear that I loved you .
Shakespearean: I was about to protest I loved you .

English: Then do so , with all your heart .
Shakespearean: And do it with all thy heart .

English: I love you with so much of my heart that none of it is left to protest with .
Shakespearean: I love you with so much of my heart that none is left to protest .

English: Come , ask me to do anything for you .
Shakespearean: Come , bid me do anything for thee .

English: Kill Claudio .
Shakespearean: Kill Claudio .

English: Ha !
Shakespearean: Ha !

English: I wouldn't do that for the whole wide world .
Shakespearean: Not for the wide world .

English: Then , rejecting my request , you kill
Shakespearean: You kill me to deny it .

English: Wait , sweet Beatrice .
Shakespearean: Tarry , sweet Beatrice .

English: My body waits here , but the rest of me is gone .
Shakespearean: I am gone , though I am here .

English: You don't really love me .
Shakespearean: There is no love in you .

English: I beg you to let me go .
Shakespearean: Nay , I pray you let me go .

English: Beatrice , I swear , I'm going .
Shakespearean: Beatrice , In faith , I will go .

English: Not until we part as friends .
Shakespearean: We'll be friends first .

English: How dare you try to be my friend when you refuse to fight my enemy .
Shakespearean: You dare easier be friends with me than fight with mine enemy .

English: Is Claudio your enemy ?
Shakespearean: Is Claudio thine enemy ?

English: Hasn't he proven himself to be a great villain , slandering , scorning , and dishonoring my cousin ?
Shakespearean: Is he not approved in the height a villain , that hath slandered , scorned , dishonored my kinswoman ?

English: Oh , I wish I were a man !
Shakespearean: Oh , that I were a man !

English: He pretended that everything was fine until the moment they were exchanging vows , and then , with public accusation , blatant slander , pure hatred , Oh God , if only I were a man !
Shakespearean: What , bear her in hand until they come to take hands and then , with public accusation , uncovered slander , unmitigated rancor , O God , that I were a man !

English: I would rip his heart out in public and eat it .
Shakespearean: I would eat his heart in the marketplace .

English: Listen to me , Beatrice , Talking with a man outside her bedroom window !
Shakespearean: Hear me , Beatrice , Talk with a man out at a window !

English: A likely story !
Shakespearean: A proper saying !

English: No , but Beatrice , Sweet Hero , she's been wronged , she's been slandered , she's been ruined .
Shakespearean: Nay , but Beatrice , Sweet Hero , she is wronged , she is slandered , she is undone .

English: Beat ,
Shakespearean: Beat ,

English: Princes and counts !
Shakespearean: Princes and counties !

English: He's a proper count , that Count Sugarplum , a sweet gentleman , for sure !
Shakespearean: Surely , a princely testimony , a goodly count , Count Comfect , a sweet gallant , surely !

English: Oh , if only I were a man !
Shakespearean: Oh , that I were a man for his sake !

English: Or had a friend who would be a man for me !
Shakespearean: Or that I had any friend would be a man for my sake !

English: All this conversing has turned men into tongues , and fancy ones , at that .
Shakespearean: But manhood is melted into curtsies , valor into compliment , and men are only turned into tongue , and trim ones too .

English: The man who tells a lie and swears by it is now considered as brave as Hercules .
Shakespearean: He is now as valiant as Hercules that only tells a lie and swears it .

English: I can't make myself a man by wishing I were , so as a woman I'll die , from grieving .
Shakespearean: I can not be a man with wishing , therefore I will die a woman with grieving .

English: Wait , good Beatrice .
Shakespearean: Tarry , good Beatrice .

English: I swear by this hand that I love you .
Shakespearean: By this hand , I love thee .

English: Don't just swear by it ; put your hand to some use that will prove you love me .
Shakespearean: Use it for my love some other way than swearing by it .

English: That's enough for me , then .
Shakespearean: Enough , I am engaged .

English: I'll challenge him .
Shakespearean: I will challenge him .

English: I'll kiss your hand , and with that I leave you .
Shakespearean: I will kiss your hand , and so I leave you .

English: I swear that Claudio will pay dearly for this .
Shakespearean: By this hand , Claudio shall render me a dear account .

English: Keep me in your thoughts and go comfort your cousin .
Shakespearean: Go comfort your cousin .

English: Which ones are the malefactors ?
Shakespearean: Which be the malefactors ?

English: Sir , that would be me and my partner .
Shakespearean: Marry , that am I and my partner .

English: Have them come in front of the master constable .
Shakespearean: Let them come before Master Constable .

English: Yes , indeed , bring them before me .
Shakespearean: Yea , marry , let them come before me .

English: What's your name , friend ?
Shakespearean: What's your name , friend ?

English: Borachio .
Shakespearean: Borachio .

English: Please , write down "Borachio." , And yours ?
Shakespearean: Pray , write down , "Borachio." , Yours , sirrah ?

English: I'm a gentleman , sir , and my name is Conrade .
Shakespearean: I am a gentleman , sir , and my name is Conrade .

English: Write down "Master Gentleman Conrade." , Gentlemen , are you good Christians , and do you serve God ?
Shakespearean: Write down "Master Gentleman Conrade." , Masters , do you serve God ?

English: Yes , sir , we hope so .
Shakespearean: Yea , sir , we hope .

English: How do you both plead ?
Shakespearean: How answer you for yourselves ?

English: Honestly , sir , we say that we are not criminals .
Shakespearean: Marry , sir , we say we are none .

English: He's a marvelously witty fellow , no doubt , but I'll outmaneuver him. , Come over here ; I'll whisper a word in your ear .
Shakespearean: A marvelous witty fellow , I assure you , but I will go about with him. , Come you hither , sirrah , a word in your ear .

English: Sir , I tell you we believe you're both lying criminals .
Shakespearean: Sir , I say to you it is thought you are false knaves .

English: Sir , I tell you that we are not .
Shakespearean: Sir , I say to you we are none .

English: Well , okay. , I swear to God , both their stories match .
Shakespearean: Well , stand aside. , 'Fore God , they are both in a ale .

English: Have you written that down , that they aren't criminals ?
Shakespearean: Have you writ down that they are none ?

English: Master Constable , you're going about this all wrong .
Shakespearean: Master Constable , you go not the way to examine .

English: First , you have to speak to the watchmen who accused them .
Shakespearean: You must call forth the watch that are their accusers .

English: Yes , good idea ; that's the
Shakespearean: Yea , marry , that's the eftest way. , Let the watch come forth .

English: This man said , sir , that Don John , the Prince's brother , was a villain .
Shakespearean: This man said , sir , that Don John , the Prince's brother , was a villain .

English: Write down that Prince John is a villain .
Shakespearean: Write down Prince John a villain .

English: I swear , I don't like the look of you .
Shakespearean: I do not like thy look , I promise thee .

English: That Don John had given him a thousand pieces of gold for wrongfully accusing the Lady Hero .
Shakespearean: Marry , that he had received a thousand ducats of Don John for accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully .

English: That's burglary , that is .
Shakespearean: Flat burglary as ever was committed .

English: Yes , by God , that it is .
Shakespearean: Yea , by Mass , that it is .

English: What else did you hear ?
Shakespearean: What else , fellow ?

English: What else ?
Shakespearean: What else ?

English: That's all .
Shakespearean: This is all .

English: I'll get there first and tell him what we found out .
Shakespearean: Prince John is this morning secretly stolen away .

English: Honest to God , where's the sexton ?
Shakespearean: God's my life , where's the Sexton ?

English: Come on , tie them up .
Shakespearean: Let him write down the Prince's officer "coxcomb." Come , bind them. , Thou naughty varlet !

English: Get away from me , you ass !
Shakespearean: Away !

English: You ass !
Shakespearean: You are an ass , you are an ass !

English: Don't you suspect my office ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou not suspect my place ?

English: Don't you
Shakespearean: Dost thou not suspect my years ?

English: If you keep on the way you've been going , you'll kill yourself .
Shakespearean: If you go on thus , you will kill yourself , And 'tis not wisdom thus to second grief Against yourself .

English: Stop advising me ; your words pass through my ears like water through a sieve .
Shakespearean: I pray thee , cease thy counsel , Which falls into mine ears as profitless As water in a sieve .

English: Find a father who loved his child as overwhelmingly as I loved Hero and ask
Shakespearean: Bring me a father that so loved his child , Whose joy of her is overwhelmed like mine , And bid him speak of patience .

English: So don't advise me .
Shakespearean: Therefore give me no counsel .

English: Please , leave me alone .
Shakespearean: I pray thee , peace .

English: I intend to be flesh and blood , not airy philosophy , for there has never yet been a philosopher who could endure a toothache patiently , even though they all write as if they had risen above human suffering and misfortune .
Shakespearean: I will be flesh and blood , For there was never yet philosopher That could endure the toothache patiently , However they have writ the style of gods And made a push at chance and sufferance .

English: But don't take all that pain on yourself .
Shakespearean: Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself .

English: Make sure the ones who have wronged you suffer too .
Shakespearean: Make those that do offend you suffer too .

English: Now you're talking .
Shakespearean: There thou speak'st reason .

English: I definitely will .
Shakespearean: Nay , I will do so .

English: In my soul , I believe Hero has been falsely accused .
Shakespearean: My soul doth tell me Hero is belied , And that shall Claudio know ; so shall the Prince And all of them that thus dishonor her .

English: The Prince and Claudio are hurrying this way .
Shakespearean: Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily .

English: Good evening , good evening .
Shakespearean: Good e'en , good e'en .

English: Good day to both of you .
Shakespearean: Good day to both of you .

English: Listen , my lords , We're in a bit of a hurry , Leonato .
Shakespearean: Hear you , my lords , We have some haste , Leonato .

English: Your highness will have to force me to tell .
Shakespearean: I would your grace would constrain me to tell .

English: It's good if you love Hero , because she's worthy of your love .
Shakespearean: Amen , if you love her , for the lady is very well worthy .

English: You're trying to trick me , my lord .
Shakespearean: You speak this to fetch me in , my lord .

English: I swear , I'm telling you what I honestly think .
Shakespearean: By my troth , I speak my thought .

English: A bit of a hurry , my lord !
Shakespearean: Some haste , my lord !

English: Well then , good bye , my lord .
Shakespearean: Well , fare you well , my lord .

English: You're in a hurry , are you ?
Shakespearean: Are you so hasty now ?

English: Well then , don't bother .
Shakespearean: Well , all is one .

English: Come on , don't quarrel with us , good old man .
Shakespearean: Nay , do not quarrel with us , good old man .

English: If it's fighting he is after , some of us here should run and hide .
Shakespearean: If he could right himself with quarreling , Some of us would lie low .

English: Who has wronged him ?
Shakespearean: Who wrongs him ?

English: Indeed , you have wronged me , you liar .
Shakespearean: Marry , thou dost wrong me , thou dissembler , thou .

English: Don't bother trying to intimidate me by putting your hand on your sword .
Shakespearean: Nay , never lay thy hand upon thy sword .

English: I'm not scared of you .
Shakespearean: I fear thee not .

English: Curse my hand if it ever threatened an old man like you .
Shakespearean: Marry , beshrew my hand If it should give your age such cause of fear .

English: Really , I had no intention of going for my sword .
Shakespearean: In faith , my hand meant nothing to my sword .

English: Damn you , don't mock and sneer at me .
Shakespearean: Tush , tush , man , never fleer and jest at me .

English: I'm not a doddering old fool who brags about the things he did when he was young , and what he would do now if he weren't so old .
Shakespearean: I speak not like a dotard nor a fool , As under privilege of age to brag What I have done being young , or what would do Were I not old .

English: Claudio , I'm telling you right to your face that you have wronged me and my innocent child .
Shakespearean: Know , Claudio , to thy head , Thou hast so wronged mine innocent child and me That I am forced to lay my reverence by , And with gray hairs and bruise of many days Do challenge thee to trial of a man .

English: You have ruined my innocent child .
Shakespearean: I say thou hast belied mine innocent child .

English: Your slander has broken her heart , and now she lies buried with her ancestors in a tomb , ancestors who had never been tainted by scandal until you caused one with your wickedness .
Shakespearean: Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart , And she lies buried with her ancestors , Oh , in a tomb where never scandal slept Save this of hers , framed by thy villainy .

English: My wickedness ?
Shakespearean: My villainy ?

English: Yours , Claudio , yours , I say .
Shakespearean: Thine , Claudio , thine , I say .

English: You've got it wrong , old man .
Shakespearean: You say not right , old man .

English: I'll beat him despite his fancy fencing techniques and all the practicing he does , despite his youth and manliness .
Shakespearean: My lord , my lord , I'll prove it on his body if he dare , Despite his nice fence and his active practice , His May of youth and bloom of lustihood .

English: Not a chance !
Shakespearean: Away !

English: I'll have nothing to do with you .
Shakespearean: I will not have to do with you .

English: You think you can get rid of me that easily ?
Shakespearean: Canst thou so daff me ?

English: You killed my child .
Shakespearean: Thou hast killed my child .

English: Take on someone your own size : if you kill me , boy , you'll have killed a man .
Shakespearean: If thou kill'st me , boy , thou shalt kill a man .

English: He'll have to kill both of us , and indeed we're both men .
Shakespearean: He shall kill two of us , and men indeed , But that's no matter .

English: But let him start off easy by killing one of us .
Shakespearean: Let him kill one first .

English: Come on , kill me and brag about it !
Shakespearean: Win me and wear me !

English: Let me at him .
Shakespearean: Let him answer me. , Come , follow me , boy .

English: I will , as surely as I am a gentleman .
Shakespearean: Sir boy , I'll whip you from your foining fence , Nay , as I am a gentleman , I will .

English: Brother , Quiet .
Shakespearean: Brother , Content yourself .

English: God knows I loved my niece , and now she's dead , slandered to death by cowards who would just as likely fight a real man as I would grab a poisonous snake by the tongue .
Shakespearean: God knows I loved my niece , And she is dead , slandered to death by villains That dare as well answer a man indeed As I dare take a serpent by the tongue. , Boys , apes , braggarts , jacks , milksops !

English: Brother Anthony ,
Shakespearean: Brother Anthony ,

English: Hold your peace .
Shakespearean: Hold you content .

English: But brother Anthony , Don't , it's no big deal .
Shakespearean: But brother Anthony , Come , 'tis no matter .

English: Don't bother with it .
Shakespearean: Do not you meddle .

English: Let me deal with this .
Shakespearean: Let me deal in this .

English: Gentlemen , we won't stay here and anger you further .
Shakespearean: Gentlemen both , we will not wake your patience .

English: I'm sorry about your daughter's death , but I swear our accusations were true , and backed up with proof .
Shakespearean: My heart is sorry for your daughter's death , But , on my honor , she was charged with nothing But what was true and very full of proof .

English: My lord , my lord , I don't want to hear any more about it .
Shakespearean: My lord , my lord , I will not hear you .

English: No ?
Shakespearean: No ?

English: Come on , brother !
Shakespearean: Come , brother ; away !

English: I'm determined to be heard by someone .
Shakespearean: I will be heard .

English: And you will be , or some people here will suffer for it .
Shakespearean: And shall , or some of us will smart for it .

English: Look , here comes just the man we were looking for .
Shakespearean: See , see , here comes the man we went to seek .

English: What's up , mister ?
Shakespearean: Now , Signior , what news ?

English: Welcome , sir .
Shakespearean: Welcome , Signior .

English: You just missed a fight that was barely avoided .
Shakespearean: You are almost come to part almost a fray .

English: We were about to have our noses snapped off by two old men with no teeth .
Shakespearean: We had like to have had our two noses snapped off with two old men without teeth .

English: Leonato and his brother .
Shakespearean: Leonato and his brother .

English: What do you think ?
Shakespearean: What think'st thou ?

English: I think if we had fought , we would have proven too young and strong for them after all .
Shakespearean: Had we fought , I doubt we should have been too young for them .

English: There's no bravery in an unfair fight .
Shakespearean: In a false quarrel there is no true valor .

English: Look : Benedick is so pale , are you sick , or angry ?
Shakespearean: As I am an honest man , he looks pale. , Art thou sick , or angry ?

English: Lighten up .
Shakespearean: killed a cat ?

English: Sir , don't even try to beat me in a battle of wits .
Shakespearean: Thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care .

English: I'll meet all your attacks , even if you come charging at me with a lance at full gallop .
Shakespearean: Sir , I shall meet your wit in the career , an you charge it against me .

English: Choose another tack .
Shakespearean: I pray you , choose another subject .

English: I think he really is angry .
Shakespearean: I think he be angry indeed .

English: If he is , that's his problem .
Shakespearean: If he be , he knows how to turn his girdle .

English: Can I have a word with you privately ?
Shakespearean: Shall I speak a word in your ear ?

English: God forbid he wants to challenge me !
Shakespearean: God bless me from a challenge !

English: lain .
Shakespearean: Do me right , or I will protest your cowardice .

English: You've killed an innocent woman , and you're going to pay dearly for her death .
Shakespearean: You have killed a sweet lady , and her death shall fall heavy on you .

English: What do you say ?
Shakespearean: Let me hear from you .

English: What , are we having a feast ?
Shakespearean: What , a feast , a feast ?

English: Yes , we are .
Shakespearean: I ' faith , I thank him .

English: Benedick , Beatrice praised your wit the other day .
Shakespearean: I'll tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit he other day .

English: I said you had a fine wit .
Shakespearean: I said thou hadst a fine wit .

English: True , " she said , "a fine little one." "No , " I said , "a huge wit." "Right , " she said , "a hugely awful one." "No , " I said , "he has a good wit." "Exactly , " she said , "it's good and mild ; it doesn't hurt anyone." "No , " I said , "Benedick is wise." "He is certainly , " she said , She cried a lot at that , and said she didn't care .
Shakespearean: True , " said she , "a fine little one." "No , " said I , "a great wit." "Right , " says she , "a great gross one." "Nay , " said I , "a good wit." "Just , " said she , "it hurts nobody." "Nay , " said I , "the gentleman is wise." "Certain , " said she , "a wise gentleman." "Nay , " said I , "he hath the tongues." "That I believe , " said she , "for he swore a thing to me on Monday night , which he forswore on Tuesday morning ; there's a double tongue , there's two tongues." Thus did she an hour together transshape thy particular virtues .

English: That she did .
Shakespearean: Yea , that she did .

English: And yet for all that , if she didn't hate him to death , she'd love him to death .
Shakespearean: But yet for all that , an if she did not hate him deadly , she would love him dearly .

English: Leonato's daughter had told us everything .
Shakespearean: The old man's daughter told us all .

English: Absolutely everything .
Shakespearean: All , all .

English: And , moreover , God saw Benedick when he was hid in the garden .
Shakespearean: And , moreover , God saw him when he was hid in the garden .

English: But when exactly will we see Benedick married ?
Shakespearean: But when shall we set the savage bull's horns on the sensible Benedick's head ?

English: Yes , with the sign underneath him that says : "Here lives Benedick the married man" ?
Shakespearean: Yea , and text underneath : "Here dwells Benedick the married man" ?

English: Goodbye , boy .
Shakespearean: Fare you well , boy .

English: You know what I intend .
Shakespearean: You know my mind .

English: I'll leave you now to chatter and gossip like an old woman .
Shakespearean: I will leave you now to your gossip-like humor .

English: The wit you flaunt is like a blunt sword , it can't hurt anyone , thank God. , My lord , I thank you for your many kindnesses .
Shakespearean: You break jests as braggarts do their blades , which , God be thanked , hurt not. , My lord , for your many courtesies I thank you .

English: I'm leaving your court now .
Shakespearean: I must discontinue your company .

English: Your brother Don John the Bastard has run away from Messina .
Shakespearean: Your brother the Bastard is fled from Messina .

English: The three of you have killed a sweet , innocent woman .
Shakespearean: You have among you killed a sweet and innocent lady .

English: Lord Babyface over there will meet me in a duel , and good luck to him then .
Shakespearean: For my Lord Lackbeard there , he and I shall meet , and till then peace be with him .

English: He's serious .
Shakespearean: He is in earnest .

English: Very serious , and I'm sure it's because of Beatrice .
Shakespearean: In most profound earnest , and , I'll warrant you , for the love of Beatrice .

English: And he challenged you to a duel ?
Shakespearean: And hath challenged thee ?

English: He did , very sincerely .
Shakespearean: Most sincerely .

English: What a strange sight , a man who has put on all his fancy clothes but forgotten his brain at home !
Shakespearean: What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his doublet and hose and leaves off his wit !

English: A guy like that is bigger than an ape , but the ape could be his doctor , it's so much smarter .
Shakespearean: He is then a giant to an ape ; but then is an ape a doctor to such a man .

English: But wait a minute .
Shakespearean: But soft you , let me be .

English: Let me gather my wits and get serious here .
Shakespearean: Pluck up , my heart , and be sad .

English: Didn't he say my brother has run away ?
Shakespearean: Did he not say my brother was fled ?

English: Come on , you .
Shakespearean: Come you , sir .

English: If they let you off , then we'll have to assume that Lady Justice has lost all her power .
Shakespearean: If justice can not tame you , she shall ne'er weigh more reasons in her balance .

English: Since you are a lying hypocrite , we must look after you .
Shakespearean: Nay , an you be a cursing hypocrite once , you must be looked to .

English: What's this ?
Shakespearean: How now ?

English: Two of my brother's men , all tied up !
Shakespearean: Two of my brother's men bound !

English: Officers , what crime have these men committed ?
Shakespearean: Officers , what offense have these men done ?

English: Well sir , they've lied ; moreover , they have said things that were not true ; secondarily , they are slanderers ; sixth and lastly , they have falsely accused a lady ; thirdly , they have confirmed things that did not in fact happen ; and , in conclusion , they are lying scoundrels .
Shakespearean: Marry , sir , they have committed false report ; moreover , they have spoken untruths ; secondarily , they are slanders ; sixth and lastly , they have belied a lady ; thirdly , they have verified unjust things ; and , to conclude , they are lying knaves .

English: First , I ask you what they've done ; thirdly , I ask you what offense they're charged with ; sixth and lastly , I ask you why they've been committed here ; and , in conclusion , I ask what they're accused of .
Shakespearean: First , I ask thee what they have done ; thirdly , I ask thee what's their offense ; sixth and lastly , why they are committed ; and , to conclude , what you lay to their charge .

English: I tricked your own eyes .
Shakespearean: I have deceived even your very eyes .

English: They've recorded my crimes , and I would rather die than have to retell this shameful story .
Shakespearean: My villainy they have upon record , which I had rather seal with my death than repeat over to my shame .

English: The lady has died because of the false accusations of me and my master .
Shakespearean: The lady is dead upon mine and my master's false accusation .

English: His words are like poison to me .
Shakespearean: I have drunk poison whiles he uttered it .

English: Yes , and paid me well for doing it .
Shakespearean: Yea , and paid me richly for the practice of it .

English: He is made of treachery , and has run away to avoid his crimes .
Shakespearean: He is composed and framed of treachery , And fled he is upon this villainy .

English: Sweet Hero ; when I imagine you now , you seem as beautiful as you did when I first loved you .
Shakespearean: Sweet Hero , now thy image doth appear In the rare semblance that I loved it first .

English: Come , take away the Here comes Master Signior Leonato with the sexton .
Shakespearean: Here , here comes Master Signior Leonato , and the Sexton too .

English: Which one of them did it ?
Shakespearean: Which is the villain ?

English: Let me see what he looks like , so when I see another man who resembles him , I'll know to avoid him .
Shakespearean: Let me see his eyes , That , when I note another man like him , I may avoid him .

English: Which one is it ?
Shakespearean: Which of these is he ?

English: If you want to see your deceiver , then look at me .
Shakespearean: If you would know your wronger , look on me .

English: Are you the slave who , with your slanderous words , killed my innocent child ?
Shakespearean: Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast killed Mine innocent child ?

English: Yes , I am the one .
Shakespearean: Yea , even I alone .

English: No , villain , but you didn't work alone .
Shakespearean: No , not so , villain , thou beliest thyself .

English: I don't know how to ask you for forgiveness , but I have to say something .
Shakespearean: I know not how to pray your patience , Yet I must speak .

English: Choose your revenge .
Shakespearean: Choose your revenge yourself .

English: I can't ask you to make my daughter live , that's impossible , but I beg you both to tell the people of Messina that she was innocent when she died .
Shakespearean: I can not bid you bid my daughter live , That were impossible , but , I pray you both , Possess the people in Messina here How innocent she died .

English: And if your love can produce something from its sadness , write a poem for her ; hang it on her grave and sing it to her bones .
Shakespearean: And if your love Can labor ought in sad invention , Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb And sing it to her bones .

English: Sing it tonight .
Shakespearean: Sing it tonight .

English: Then come to my house tomorrow morning , and since you couldn't be my son-in-law , be my nephew instead .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow morning come you to my house , And since you could not be my son-in-law , Be yet my nephew .

English: My brother has a daughter who looks exactly like Hero ; this girl is heir to both our estates .
Shakespearean: My brother hath a daughter , Almost the copy of my child that's dead , And she alone is heir to both of us .

English: Marry her as you should have married her cousin , and I will let my revenge die .
Shakespearean: Give her the right you should have given her cousin , And so dies my revenge .

English: And I feel that I love her .
Shakespearean: That I love her , I feel .

English: I know that she is worthy of that love .
Shakespearean: That she is worthy , I know .

English: Or in the power of reason .
Shakespearean: And never could maintain his part but in the force of his will .

English: I was conceived by a woman , and I thank her very much for all her effort .
Shakespearean: That a woman conceived me , I thank her .

English: And then she brought me up , and I thank her for that , too .
Shakespearean: That she brought me up , I likewise give her most humble thanks .

English: I swear , before I die I'm going to see you sick with love .
Shakespearean: I shall see thee , ere I die , look pale with love .

English: With anger , with fever , or with hunger , sure , my friend , but never sick with love .
Shakespearean: With anger , with sickness , or with hunger , my lord , not with love .

English: If you can prove that I'll ever be so in love that I can't be brought to my senses with a good round of beers , you can pluck out my eyes with a love-poet's pen and hang me on a brothel's door where the picture of blind Cupid usually goes .
Shakespearean: Prove that ever I lose more blood with love than I will get again with drinking , pick out mine eyes with a ballad-maker's pen and hang me up at the door of a brothel house for the sign of blind Cupid .

English: Oh , noble sir !
Shakespearean: O noble sir !

English: Your overwhelming kindness makes me weep .
Shakespearean: Your overkindness doth wring tears from me .

English: I willingly accept your offer and put my future in your hands .
Shakespearean: I do embrace your offer ; and dispose For henceforth of poor Claudio .

English: I will see you tomorrow , then .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow then I will expect your coming .

English: Now I have to leave .
Shakespearean: Tonight I take my leave .

English: This wicked man will be brought face to face with Margaret , who I believe was hired by Don John to take part in this plot .
Shakespearean: This naughty man Shall face to face be brought to Margaret , Who I believe was packed in all this wrong , Hired to it by your brother .

English: Thank you for all your efforts .
Shakespearean: I thank thee for thy care and honest pains .

English: You speak like a very thankful and respectful boy , and may God bless you .
Shakespearean: Your worship speaks like a most thankful and reverent youth , and I praise God for you .

English: God save the charitable organization !
Shakespearean: God save the foundation !

English: I leave a slimy bastard with you , your Worship , for you to punish and make an example of .
Shakespearean: I leave an arrant knave with your Worship , which I beseech your Worship to correct yourself , for the example of others .

English: God bless your Worship !
Shakespearean: God keep your Worship !

English: I wish you well .
Shakespearean: I wish your Worship well .

English: I hope that God restores you to health .
Shakespearean: God restore you to health !

English: Goodbye , gentlemen .
Shakespearean: Farewell , my lords .

English: We'll see you tomorrow .
Shakespearean: We look for you tomorrow .

English: We'll be there .
Shakespearean: We will not fail .

English: I will mourn Hero tonight .
Shakespearean: Tonight I'll mourn with Hero .

English: Please Margaret , help me write this poem for Beatrice .
Shakespearean: Pray thee , sweet Mistress Margaret , deserve well at my hands by helping me to the speech of Beatrice .

English: You certainly deserve it .
Shakespearean: To have no man come over me !

English: It's just that my wit is very gentlemanly , Margaret , and refuses to hurt a woman .
Shakespearean: A most manly wit , Margaret , it will not hurt a woman .

English: Now please , tell Beatrice to come out .
Shakespearean: And so , I pray thee , call Beatrice .

English: I'll go get Beatrice for you , who can walk here by herself , she has legs .
Shakespearean: Well , I will call Beatrice to you , who I think hath legs .

English: So that means she'll come .
Shakespearean: And therefore will come .

English: I'm really a pitiful singer .
Shakespearean: I mean in singing .

English: Take Beatrice , have you come because I called for you ?
Shakespearean: Sweet Beatrice , wouldst thou come when I called thee ?

English: Yes , sir , and I'll leave when you ask me to .
Shakespearean: Yea , Signior , and depart when you bid me .

English: Oh , well , stay till then !
Shakespearean: Oh , stay but till then !

English: I spoke angry , foul words to him , and with that I will kiss you .
Shakespearean: Only foul words , and thereupon I will kiss thee .

English: If you had foul words in your mouth , then your breath must be foul , and foul breath is nauseating .
Shakespearean: Foul words is but foul wind , and foul wind is but foul breath , and foul breath is noisome .

English: Thus , I'll leave without being kissed .
Shakespearean: Therefore I will depart unkissed .

English: Your wit is so forceful , it frightens the very meaning out of your words .
Shakespearean: Thou hast frighted the word out of his right sense , so forcible is thy wit .

English: But I will tell you this very plainly : I have challenged Claudio , and either he'll accept the challenge or admit he's a coward .
Shakespearean: But I must tell thee plainly , Claudio undergoes my challenge , and either I must shortly hear from him , or I will subscribe him a coward .

English: Now , tell me , which of my bad qualities did you fall in love with first ?
Shakespearean: And I pray thee now tell me , for which of my bad parts didst thou first fall in love with me ?

English: With all of them at once : they work together to create such an entirely evil person that no good ever manages to enter the mix .
Shakespearean: For them all together , which maintained so politic a state of evil that they will not admit any good part to intermingle with them .

English: But tell me , which of my good qualities first made you suffer love for me ?
Shakespearean: But for which of my good parts did you first suffer love for me ?

English: Suffer love !
Shakespearean: Suffer love !

English: That's a good way of putting it .
Shakespearean: A good epithet !

English: I do suffer love , because I love you against my will .
Shakespearean: I do suffer love indeed , for I love thee against my will .

English: You love me in spite of your heart , I think .
Shakespearean: In spite of your heart , I think .

English: In this day and age , if a man doesn't erect his own monument before he dies , he won't be remembered past the funeral bell's ringing and his widow's crying .
Shakespearean: If a man do not erect in this age his own tomb ere he dies , he shall live no longer in monument than the bell rings and the widow weeps .

English: Exactly how long is that , do you think ?
Shakespearean: And how long is that , think you ?

English: About an hour for the ringing and fifteen minutes for the crying .
Shakespearean: Question : why , an hour in clamor and a quarter in rheum .

English: That's why it's better for wise men to trumpet their own virtues , like I do .
Shakespearean: Therefore is it most expedient for the wise , if Don Worm , his conscience , find no impediment to the contrary , to be the trumpet of his own virtues , as I am to myself .

English: That's why I praise myself , who , if I do say so myself , is quite praiseworthy .
Shakespearean: So much for praising myself , who , I myself will bear witness , is praiseworthy .

English: But tell me , how is your cousin ?
Shakespearean: An now tell me , how doth your cousin ?

English: I'm very sick , too .
Shakespearean: Very ill , too .

English: Have faith , love me , and you will get better .
Shakespearean: Serve God , love me , and mend .

English: Madam , you have to go to your uncle's .
Shakespearean: Madam , you must come to your uncle .

English: It's been proven that Lady Hero is innocent , that the Prince and Claudio have been utterly deceived , and that Don John , who has run away , is the source of all the trouble .
Shakespearean: It is proved my Lady Hero hath been falsely accused , the Prince and Claudio mightily abused , and Don John is the author of all , who is fled and gone .

English: Will you come immediately ?
Shakespearean: Will you come presently ?

English: Will you come with me to hear this news , sir ?
Shakespearean: Will you go hear this news , Signior ?

English: I will live in your heart , die in your lap , and be buried in your eyes , and , what's more , I will go with you to your uncle's .
Shakespearean: I will live in thy heart , die in thy lap , and be buried in thy eyes , and moreover , I will go with thee to thy uncle's .

English: Is this the family tomb of Leonato ?
Shakespearean: Is this the monument of Leonato ?

English: It is , my lord .
Shakespearean: It is , my lord .

English: Here lies Hero , The heroic maiden killed by slanderous words .
Shakespearean: Done to death by slanderous tongues Was the Hero that here lies .

English: To repay her for her troubles , Death Gives her undying fame .
Shakespearean: Death , in guerdon of her wrongs , Gives her fame which never dies .

English: So the life that died with shame Lives on with fame .
Shakespearean: So the life that died with shame Lives in death with glorious fame .

English: This epitaph will hang here forever , Continuing to praise Hero after I die .
Shakespearean: Hang thou there upon the tomb , Praising her when I am dumb .

English: Now start the music , and sing the solemn hymn .
Shakespearean: Now , music , sound , and sing your solemn hymn .

English: Now I say good night to your bones , Hero .
Shakespearean: Now , unto thy bones good night !

English: I will perform this ceremony every year .
Shakespearean: Yearly will I do this rite .

English: Good morning , gentlemen .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , masters .

English: Put out your torches .
Shakespearean: Put your torches out .

English: The wolves have finished preying for the night , and look , the gentle dawn is rising , dappling the sleepy eastern sky with spots of light .
Shakespearean: The wolves have preyed , and look , the gentle day , Before the wheels of Phoebus , round about Dapples the drowsy east with spots of grey .

English: Good morning , gentlemen .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , masters .

English: Didn't I tell you she was innocent ?
Shakespearean: Did I not tell you she was innocent ?

English: And the Prince and Claudio , who accused her , are innocent as well , because they were deceived by Don John .
Shakespearean: So are the Prince and Claudio , who accused her Upon the error that you heard debated .

English: Well , I'm glad that everything has been sorted out .
Shakespearean: Well , I am glad that all things sort so well .

English: Me too , otherwise I would have had to duel with Claudio .
Shakespearean: And so am I , being else by faith enforced To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it .

English: When I send for you , come out wearing masks .
Shakespearean: Well , daughter , and you gentlewomen all , Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves , And when I send for you , come hither masked .

English: The Prince and Claudio are supposed to be here by now. , You know your job , brother .
Shakespearean: The Prince and Claudio promised by this hour To visit me. , You know your office , brother .

English: You have to pretend to be your niece's father , and give her away to Claudio .
Shakespearean: You must be father to your brother's daughter , And give her to young Claudio .

English: What do you need me to do ?
Shakespearean: To do what , Signior ?

English: She sees you with the eyes my daughter lent her , it's true .
Shakespearean: That eye my daughter lent her ; 'tis most true .

English: And I see her also through the eyes of love .
Shakespearean: And I do with an eye of love requite her .

English: And those eyes were endowed with sight by Claudio , the Prince , and me .
Shakespearean: The sight whereof I think you had from me , From Claudio and the Prince .

English: But what did you want ?
Shakespearean: But what's your will ?

English: Sir , I'm puzzled by what you just said .
Shakespearean: Your answer , sir , is enigmatical .

English: And I'll help you .
Shakespearean: And my help .

English: Here comes the Prince and Claudio .
Shakespearean: Here comes the Prince and Claudio .

English: Good morning to all these lovely people .
Shakespearean: Good morrow to this fair assembly .

English: Good morning , Prince ; good morning , Claudio .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , Prince ; good morrow , Claudio .

English: We're waiting here for you .
Shakespearean: We here attend you .

English: Are you still set on marrying my brother's daughter ?
Shakespearean: Are you yet determined Today to marry with my brother's daughter ?

English: I wouldn't change my mind even if she were
Shakespearean: I'll hold my mind were she an Ethiope .

English: Well , time will tell .
Shakespearean: Well , as time shall try .

English: Just you wait .
Shakespearean: Well , you temporize with the hours .

English: Give him my respects , and tell him I'll definitely be there for dinner , since I know he has gone to great lengths for this meal .
Shakespearean: Commend me to him and tell him I will not fail him at supper , for indeed he hath made great preparation .

English: Bring her out , brother .
Shakespearean: Call her forth , brother .

English: The friar's ready .
Shakespearean: Here's the friar ready .

English: Good morning , Benedick .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , Benedick .

English: I think he's nervous , he's about to become the savage bull who got domesticated .
Shakespearean: I think he thinks upon the savage bull .

English: Oh , don't worry about it , we'll dip your I'll get you for that one .
Shakespearean: Tush , fear not , man .

English: But here are other matters to be dealt with .
Shakespearean: Here comes other reck'nings .

English: Which is the lady I'm supposed to marry ?
Shakespearean: Which is the lady I must seize upon ?

English: This one , and I will give her to you .
Shakespearean: This same is she , and I do give you her .

English: No , you can't do that until you take her hand and , in front of this friar , swear to marry her .
Shakespearean: No , that you shall not till you take her hand Before this friar and swear to marry her .

English: It's another Hero !
Shakespearean: Another Hero !

English: Exactly right .
Shakespearean: Nothing certainer .

English: And as surely as I am alive , I am a virgin .
Shakespearean: One Hero died defiled , but I do live , And surely as I live , I am a maid .

English: It's the former Hero !
Shakespearean: The former Hero !

English: The Hero that died !
Shakespearean: Hero that is dead !

English: She was only dead , my lord , as long as her slander lived .
Shakespearean: She died , my lord , but whiles her slander lived .

English: I can confirm that all these shocking things are true .
Shakespearean: All this amazement can I qualify When after that the holy rites are ended I'll tell you largely of fair Hero's death .

English: Which one of you is Beatrice ?
Shakespearean: Soft and fair , Friar. , Which is Beatrice ?

English: Do you love me ?
Shakespearean: Do not you love me ?

English: No , no more than is reasonable .
Shakespearean: Why no , no more than reason .

English: Well then , your uncle and the Prince and Claudio have been deceived .
Shakespearean: Why then , your uncle and the Prince and Claudio Have been deceived .

English: They swore you did .
Shakespearean: They swore you did .

English: Do you love me ?
Shakespearean: Do not you love me ?

English: Truly , no , no more than is reasonable .
Shakespearean: Troth , no , no more than reason .

English: Well then , Margaret , Ursula , and my cousin have been very much deceived , for they swore you did .
Shakespearean: Why then , my cousin , Margaret , and Ursula Are much deceived , for they did swear you did .

English: They swore that you were sick with love for me .
Shakespearean: They swore that you were almost sick for me .

English: They swore that you were nearly dead with love for me .
Shakespearean: They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me .

English: Oh , well .
Shakespearean: Tis no such matter .

English: So you don't love me ?
Shakespearean: Then you do not love me ?

English: No , I don't , except as a friend .
Shakespearean: No , truly , but in friendly recompense .

English: Come on , niece , I'm sure you love him .
Shakespearean: Come , cousin , I am sure you love the gentleman .

English: And here's another poem , which I stole from my cousin's pocket , in her handwriting and all about her adoration for Benedick .
Shakespearean: And here's another , Writ in my cousin's hand , stol'n from her pocket , Containing her affection unto Benedick .

English: What a miracle !
Shakespearean: A miracle !

English: Our handwriting gives away our hearts .
Shakespearean: Here's our own hands against our hearts .

English: Come on , I'll take you , but honestly I'm only doing it out of pity .
Shakespearean: Come , I will have thee , but , by this light , I take thee for pity .

English: I won't say no to you , but let it be known that I'm only doing this after a lot of persuasion and to save your life , I hear you were quickly wasting away without me .
Shakespearean: I would not deny you , but , by this good day , I yield upon great persuasion , and partly to save your life , for I was told you were in a consumption .

English: Oh , shut up !
Shakespearean: Peace !

English: I'll stop your mouth with a kiss .
Shakespearean: I will stop your mouth .

English: How does it feel to be Benedick the Married Man ?
Shakespearean: How dost thou , Benedick , the married man ?

English: I'll tell you what , Prince : a whole university full of wisecrackers couldn't change my mood today .
Shakespearean: I'll tell thee what , Prince : a college of wit-crackers can not flout me out of my humor .

English: You think I care what I'm called ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou think I care for a satire or an epigram ?

English: Well , I don't .
Shakespearean: No .

English: No , before !
Shakespearean: First , of my word !

English: Musicians , play us a song. , Prince , you look sad .
Shakespearean: Therefore play , music. , Prince , thou art sad .

English: You should get a wife !
Shakespearean: Get thee a wife , get thee a wife .

English: Into God's hands .
Shakespearean: To the tuition of God .

English: From my house , if I had a house , " "The sixth of July .
Shakespearean: From my house , if I had it , The sixth of July .

English: Before you make My lord , you could really help me out now .
Shakespearean: My liege , your highness now may do me good .

English: I am at your service .
Shakespearean: My love is thine to teach .

English: Just tell me what you want me to do , and however hard it is , you'll see that I'm eager to do it .
Shakespearean: Teach it but how , And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn Any hard lesson that may do thee good .

English: Does Leonato have a son , my lord ?
Shakespearean: Hath Leonato any son , my lord ?

English: Hero is his only child , and his only heir .
Shakespearean: No child but Hero ; she's his only heir .

English: Do you like her , Claudio ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou affect her , Claudio ?

English: Look , if you really love the beautiful Hero , enjoy it .
Shakespearean: If thou dost love fair Hero , cherish it , And I will break with her and with her father , And thou shalt have her .

English: Isn't that the reason you told me all this ?
Shakespearean: Was 't not to this end That thou began'st to twist so fine a story ?

English: But I didn't want you to think that I'm hasty in my emotions .
Shakespearean: But lest my liking might too sudden seem , I would have salved it with a longer treatise .

English: That's like building a bridge wider than the river it crosses .
Shakespearean: What need the bridge much broader than the flood ?

English: I'll disguise myself as you and pour out "my" feelings to Hero , taking her prisoner with the force of my love story .
Shakespearean: I will assume thy part in some disguise And tell fair Hero I am Claudio , And in her bosom I'll unclasp my heart And take her hearing prisoner with the force And strong encounter of my amorous tale .

English: Let's get started right away .
Shakespearean: In practice let us put it presently .

English: Has he taken care of the music ?
Shakespearean: Hath he provided this music ?

English: He is taking care of it as we speak .
Shakespearean: He is very busy about it .

English: But brother , I have some strange news for you .
Shakespearean: But , brother , I can tell you strange news that you yet dreamt not of .

English: Is it good news ?
Shakespearean: Are they good ?

English: Is this servant of yours a smart man ?
Shakespearean: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this ?

English: He's very bright .
Shakespearean: A good sharp fellow .

English: I'll get him to come here , and you can ask him yourself .
Shakespearean: I will send for him , and question him yourself .

English: He must be very near by now .
Shakespearean: He is very near by this .

English: When I left him , he was less than nine miles from here .
Shakespearean: He was not three leagues off when I left him .

English: How many noblemen were killed in the battle you just fought ?
Shakespearean: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action ?

English: Not many , and no one important .
Shakespearean: But few of any sort , and none of name .

English: A victory in battle is twice as victorious when all the soldiers return home safely .
Shakespearean: A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings home full numbers .

English: Claudio deserves to be honored , and Don Pedro has rewarded him accordingly .
Shakespearean: I find here that Don Pedro hath bestowed much honor on a young Florentine called Claudio .

English: He has an uncle here in Messina who will be glad to hear this news .
Shakespearean: He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much glad of it .

English: No , no , until it comes true we'll pretend it was just a dream we had .
Shakespearean: No , no , we will hold it as a dream till it appear itself .

English: But my daughter should know about this , so she can be prepared with an answer just in case .
Shakespearean: But I will acquaint my daughter withal , that she may be the better prepared for an answer if peradventure this be true .

English: Go to her and tell her for me .
Shakespearean: Go you and tell her of it .

English: Cousins , you all have work to do. , Oh , I beg your pardon .
Shakespearean: Cousins , you know what you have to do. , O , I cry you mercy , friend .

English: Come with me now , and help me out .
Shakespearean: Go you with me and I will use your skill. , Good cousin , have a care this busy time .

English: Really , my lord , why are you so excessively sad ?
Shakespearean: What the goodyear , my lord , why are you thus out of measure sad ?

English: Therefore my sadness is without limit .
Shakespearean: Therefore the sadness is without limit .

English: You should listen to reason .
Shakespearean: You should hear reason .

English: I can't hide what I am .
Shakespearean: I can not hide what I am .

English: Sure , but don't do it at full volume until there's no danger in it .
Shakespearean: Yea , but you must not make the full show of this till you may do it without controlment .

English: Not long ago you challenged and opposed your brother , and it is only very recently that he has forgiven you .
Shakespearean: You have of late stood out against your brother , and he hath ta'en you newly into his grace , where it is impossible you should take true root but by the fair weather that you make yourself .

English: You have to wait for the appropriate time to let loose .
Shakespearean: It is needful that you frame the season for your own harvest .

English: I'd rather be a weed in a hedge than a rose in my brother's garden .
