Shakespearean: I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in his grace , and it better fits my blood to be disdained of all than to fashion a carriage to rob love from any .

English: Though I am not a flattering , righteous man , at least you can say that I am honest about being a villain .
Shakespearean: In this , though I can not be said to be a flattering honest man , it must not be denied but I am a plain-dealing villain .

English: Until that happens , let me be who I am and don't try to change me .
Shakespearean: In the meantime , let me be that I am , and seek not to alter me .

English: Can't you somehow use your dissatisfaction to your own advantage ?
Shakespearean: Can you make no use of your discontent ?

English: I use it all the time , since it's all that I have .
Shakespearean: I make all use of it , for I use it only .

English: Who's that ?
Shakespearean: Who comes here ?

English: What's going on , Borachio ?
Shakespearean: What news , Borachio ?

English: Who is this fool who wants all the fuss of marriage ?
Shakespearean: What is he for a fool that betroths himself to unquietness ?

English: Your brother's right-hand man .
Shakespearean: Marry , it is your brother's right hand .

English: Who ?
Shakespearean: Who ?

English: That pretty boy , Claudio ?
Shakespearean: The most exquisite Claudio ?

English: That's the one .
Shakespearean: Even he .

English: Hero , the daughter and heir of Leonato .
Shakespearean: Marry , on Hero , the daughter and heir of Leonato .

English: A lively young one !
Shakespearean: A very forward March-chick !

English: How did you learn about this ?
Shakespearean: How came you to this ?

English: As I was working on one musty room , the Prince and Claudio entered .
Shakespearean: Being entertained for a perfumer , as I was smoking a musty room , comes me the Prince and Claudio , hand in hand , in sad conference .

English: Come , let's go to the dance .
Shakespearean: Come , come , let us thither .

English: This just may cheer me up .
Shakespearean: This may prove food to my displeasure .

English: If there's any way I can spoil his life , I'll be overjoyed .
Shakespearean: If I can cross him any way , I bless myself every way .

English: You'll both help me , right ?
Shakespearean: You are both sure , and will assist me ?

English: Until the day we die , my lord .
Shakespearean: To the death , my lord .

English: Let's go to this great feast .
Shakespearean: Let us to the great supper .

English: Lead the way , sir .
Shakespearean: We'll wait upon your lordship .

English: Wasn't Don John at dinner tonight ?
Shakespearean: Was not Count John here at supper ?

English: I didn't see him .
Shakespearean: I saw him not .

English: That man always looks so sour !
Shakespearean: How tartly that gentleman looks !

English: Just looking at him gives me heartburn .
Shakespearean: I never can see him but I am heartburned an hour after .

English: He has a very gloomy attitude .
Shakespearean: He is of a very melancholy disposition .

English: It would be excellent if they could make a man halfway between Don John and Benedick .
Shakespearean: He were an excellent man that were made just in the midway between him and Benedick .

English: One of them is too much like a painting of a man , he never speaks , and the other is too much like a spoiled little boy , always chattering .
Shakespearean: The one is too like an image and says nothing , and the other too like my lady's eldest son , evermore tattling .

English: So , the man would talk half as much as Benedick and be half as serious as Don John , And if he were handsome , agile , and rich , too , he could have any woman in the world , all he'd need was her good will .
Shakespearean: Then half Signor Benedick's tongue in Count John's mouth , and half Count John's melancholy in Signor Benedick's face , With a good leg and a good foot , uncle , and money enough in his purse , such a man would win any woman in the world , if he could get her goodwill .

English: Really , niece , you'll never get a husband if you keep saying such harsh things about people .
Shakespearean: By my troth , niece , thou wilt never get thee a husband if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue .

English: Honestly , she is too ill-tempered .
Shakespearean: In faith , she's too curst .

English: Maybe you will find a husband without a beard .
Shakespearean: You may light on a husband that hath no beard .

English: And then what would I do with him ?
Shakespearean: What should I do with him ?

English: So you'll go to hell ?
Shakespearean: Well then , go you into hell ?

English: No , just to the gates of hell , where the devil will meet me , with the horns on his head like a cuckold , and say , "Go up to heaven , Beatrice .
Shakespearean: No , but to the gate , and there will the devil meet me like an old cuckold with horns on his head , and say , "Get you to heaven , Beatrice , get you to heaven ; here's no place for you maids." So deliver I up my apes and away to Saint Peter .

English: He will show me the part of heaven where the bachelors sit , and I'll have fun there forever .
Shakespearean: For the heavens , he shows me where the bachelors sit , and there live we as merry as the day is long .

English: No , I won't take a husband until they make men out of something other than dirt .
Shakespearean: Not till God make men of some other metal than earth .

English: What woman wouldn't be distressed , being lorded over by a handful of dust ?
Shakespearean: Would it not grieve a woman to be overmastered with a piece of valiant dust ?

English: Can you imagine being hitched to a lump of clay ?
Shakespearean: To make an account of her life to a clod of wayward marl ?

English: No , uncle , I won't be married .
Shakespearean: No , uncle , I'll none .

English: If he is too insistent , tell him that romance is like a dance : it has its own rhythm and timing .
Shakespearean: If the Prince be too important , tell him there is measure in everything , and so dance out the answer .

English: The wooing is like a Scottish jig : hot and fast and full of whimsy and illusion .
Shakespearean: For hear me , Hero , wooing , wedding , and repenting is as a Scotch jig , a measure , and a cinquepace .

English: Niece , you are exceptionally perceptive .
Shakespearean: Cousin , you apprehend passing shrewdly .

English: I have a good eye , uncle .
Shakespearean: I have a good eye , uncle .

English: I can see what's in broad daylight .
Shakespearean: I can see a church by daylight .

English: The partygoers have arrived .
Shakespearean: The revelers are entering , brother .

English: Let's give them room .
Shakespearean: Make good room .

English: My lady , will you have a dance with me ?
Shakespearean: Lady , will you walk a bout with your friend ?

English: As long as you move gracefully , look handsome , and say nothing , I'm yours for the dance .
Shakespearean: So you walk softly , and look sweetly , and say nothing , I am yours for the walk , and especially when I walk away .

English: And when will that be ?
Shakespearean: And when please you to say so ?

English: When I like the way you look , for God forbid your face be as ugly as your mask !
Shakespearean: When I like your favor , for God defend the lute should be like the case !

English: My mask is like the roof of the poor
Shakespearean: My visor is Philemon's roof ; within the house is Jove .

English: If you wish to speak of love , speak more softly .
Shakespearean: Speak low if you speak love .

English: Well , I wish you liked me .
Shakespearean: Well , I would you did like me .

English: Tell me one .
Shakespearean: Which is one ?

English: I say my prayers out loud .
Shakespearean: I say my prayers aloud .

English: That makes me love you even more .
Shakespearean: I love you the better ; the hearers may cry "Amen." God match me with a good dancer !

English: Amen .
Shakespearean: Amen .

English: Go ahead , say "Amen." No more talking .
Shakespearean: No more words .

English: I've got my answer .
Shakespearean: The clerk is answered .

English: No , really , I'm not .
Shakespearean: At a word , I am not .

English: I can tell by the way you waggle your head .
Shakespearean: I know you by the waggling of your head .

English: Really , I'm only pretending to be him .
Shakespearean: To tell you true , I counterfeit him .

English: You could only imitate his imperfections so well if you were the man himself .
Shakespearean: You could never do him so ill-well unless you were the very man .

English: Look , you've got his wrinkled hands .
Shakespearean: Here's his dry hand up and down .

English: You are Antonio , you are he .
Shakespearean: You are he , you are he .

English: In short , I'm not .
Shakespearean: At a word , I am not .

English: Come on , do you think I can't recognize you by your excellent wit ?
Shakespearean: Come , come , do you think I do not know you by your excellent wit ?

English: Can a good thing hide itself ?
Shakespearean: Can virtue hide itself ?

English: Be quiet , you are Antonio .
Shakespearean: Go to , mum , you are he .

English: A man's virtues will always show themselves , and that's the end of that .
Shakespearean: Graces will appear , and there's an end .

English: Won't you tell me who told you that ?
Shakespearean: Will you not tell me who told you so ?

English: No , you'll have to excuse me .
Shakespearean: No , you shall pardon me .

English: And you won't tell me who you are ?
Shakespearean: Nor will you not tell me who you are ?

English: Not now .
Shakespearean: Not now .

English: Who said that I was disdainful , and that I got all my best lines out of a bad joke book ? !
Shakespearean: That I was disdainful and that I had my good wit out of The Hundred Merry Tales !

English: Well , it must have been Signior Benedick .
Shakespearean: Well this was Signor Benedick that said so .

English: Who's that ?
Shakespearean: What's he ?

English: I'm sure you know him .
Shakespearean: I am sure you know him well enough .

English: No I don't , believe me .
Shakespearean: Not I , believe me .

English: What , he never made you laugh ?
Shakespearean: Did he never make you laugh ?

English: Yes , heavily .
Shakespearean: In great measure .

English: There's no face more sincere than one washed in tears .
Shakespearean: There are no faces truer than those that are so washed .

English: And it's definitely better to cry because you're happy than laugh because you're sad !
Shakespearean: How much better is it to weep at joy than to joy at weeping !

English: There was no Signior Montanto in our army .
Shakespearean: There was none such in the army of any sort .

English: Who are you talking about , niece ?
Shakespearean: What is he that you ask for , niece ?

English: My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua .
Shakespearean: My cousin means Signor Benedick of Padua .

English: Oh , yes , Benedick has returned and is as cheerful as ever .
Shakespearean: Oh , he's returned , and as pleasant as ever he was .

English: Please tell me , who is this man ?
Shakespearean: I pray you , what is he ?

English: Why , he's the Prince's fool , and a very dull fool at that .
Shakespearean: Why , he is the Prince's jester , a very dull fool , only his gift is in devising impossible slanders .

English: I'm sure he's out there dancing .
Shakespearean: I am sure he is in the fleet .

English: I could have sworn he trampled on me .
Shakespearean: I would he had boarded me .

English: When I meet this gentleman , I'll tell him what you've said .
Shakespearean: When I know the gentleman , I'll tell him what you say .

English: Oh , please do .
Shakespearean: Do , do .

English: And that will save a partridge wing from being eaten , because he'll be too miserable for dinner .
Shakespearean: He'll but break a comparison or two on me , which , peradventure not marked or not laughed at , strikes him into melancholy , and then there's a partridge wing saved , for the fool will eat no supper that night .

English: Come on , we have to follow the leaders of the dance .
Shakespearean: We must follow the leaders .

English: In every good thing they do .
Shakespearean: In every good thing .

English: No , if they try to lead us to harm , I will leave the dance floor at the next song .
Shakespearean: Nay , if they lead to any ill , I will leave them at the next turning .

English: That's Claudio .
Shakespearean: And that is Claudio .

English: You know me too well .
Shakespearean: You know me well .

English: I am Benedick .
Shakespearean: I am he .

English: Sir , my brother is very fond of you .
Shakespearean: Signor , you are very near my brother in his love .

English: He is in love with Hero .
Shakespearean: He is enamored on Hero .

English: Please make him change his mind .
Shakespearean: I pray you , dissuade him from her .

English: How do you know he loves her ?
Shakespearean: How know you he loves her ?

English: I heard him swear he did .
Shakespearean: I heard him swear his affection .

English: I did too , and he also swore he would marry her tonight .
Shakespearean: So did I too , and he swore he would marry her tonight .

English: Come on , let's get to the banquet .
Shakespearean: Come , let us to the banquet .

English: Though I said my name was Benedick , I heard this news with Claudio's ears .
Shakespearean: Thus answer I in the name of Benedick , But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio .

English: Of course the Prince wants Hero for himself .
Shakespearean: Tis certain so , the Prince woos for himself .

English: Friendship is enduring except when love is involved .
Shakespearean: Friendship is constant in all other things Save in the office and affairs of love .

English: Therefore , all lovers should speak for themselves .
Shakespearean: Therefore all hearts in love use their own tongues .

English: Beauty is a witch whose spells can turn loyalty into passion .
Shakespearean: Let every eye nogetiate for itself And trust no agent , for beauty is a witch Against whose charms faith melteth into blood .

English: Goodbye then , Hero .
Shakespearean: Farewell , therefore , Hero .

English: Claudio ?
Shakespearean: Count Claudio ?

English: Yes , that's me .
Shakespearean: Yea , the same .

English: Will you come with me ?
Shakespearean: Come , will you go with me ?

English: Where ?
Shakespearean: Whither ?

English: Right over to that I hope he enjoys her .
Shakespearean: I wish him joy of her .

English: You sound like a cattle dealer : that's the way they sell bulls .
Shakespearean: Why , that's spoken like an honest drover ; so they sell bullocks .

English: But do you really think the Prince would treat you that way ?
Shakespearean: But did you think the Prince would have served you thus ?

English: Please , leave me alone .
Shakespearean: I pray you , leave me .

English: Look at you , thrashing about like a blind man .
Shakespearean: Ho , now you strike like the blind man .

English: A boy robbed you , but you'll beat up the post instead .
Shakespearean: Twas the boy that stole your meat , and you'll beat the post .

English: If you won't leave , then
Shakespearean: If it will not be , I'll leave you .

English: Oh , the poor bird .
Shakespearean: Alas , poor hurt fowl , now will he creep into sedges .

English: But how strange that Beatrice should seem to know who I was and yet not know at the same time .
Shakespearean: But that my Lady Beatrice should know me , and not know me !

English: The Prince's fool" !
Shakespearean: The Prince's fool !

English: Maybe they call me that because I am cheerful .
Shakespearean: Ha , it may be I go under that title because I am merry .

English: Yes , but I am insulting myself by thinking this way .
Shakespearean: Yea , but so I am apt to do myself wrong .

English: I don't have that kind of reputation !
Shakespearean: I am not so reputed !

English: Well , I'll get my revenge .
Shakespearean: Well , I'll be revenged as I may .

English: Now , sir , where is Claudio ?
Shakespearean: Now , Signior , where's the Count ?

English: Did you see him ?
Shakespearean: Did you see him ?

English: Yes , my lord , I played the part of a gossip and brought him the news .
Shakespearean: Troth , my lord , I have played the part of Lady Fame .

English: I found him here , Beating ?
Shakespearean: I found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a warren .

English: Why , what did he do ?
Shakespearean: What's his fault ?

English: He was like a schoolboy who finds a bird's nest and happily shows it to his friend , who then steals it from him .
Shakespearean: The flat transgression of a schoolboy who , being overjoyed with finding a birds ' nest , shows it his companion , and he steals it .

English: What , is trusting a friend such a crime ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou make a trust a transgression ?

English: The criminal is the one who stole the nest .
Shakespearean: The transgression is in the stealer .

English: Lady Beatrice is angry with you .
Shakespearean: The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you .

English: The gentleman she danced with told her you insulted her .
Shakespearean: The gentleman that danced with her told her she is much wronged by you .

English: She speaks daggers , and every word stabs .
Shakespearean: She speaks poniards , and every word stabs .

English: If her breath were as terrible as her words , she would kill every living thing from here to the furthest star .
Shakespearean: If her breath were as terrible as her terminations , there were no living near her ; she would infect to the north star .

English: I wouldn't marry her , even if she were as blessed as paradise .
Shakespearean: I would not marry her , though she were endowed with all that Adam had left him before he transgressed .

English: Please , don't mention her .
Shakespearean: Come , talk not of her .

English: Look , here she comes .
Shakespearean: Look , here she comes .

English: Your highness , could you send me on a mission to the ends of the earth ?
Shakespearean: Will your grace command me any service to the world's end ?

English: I'll go to the Antipodes for any little errand you can think of .
Shakespearean: I will go on the slightest errand now to the Antipodes that you can devise to send me on .

English: Really , he won it from me once before in a dishonest game of dice .
Shakespearean: Marry , once before he won it of me with false dice .

English: So I suppose your grace can truly say that I have lost it .
Shakespearean: Therefore your Grace may well say I have lost it .

English: You've humiliated him , lady : you've put him down .
Shakespearean: You have put him down , lady , you have put him down .

English: Why are you so sad ?
Shakespearean: Why , how now , Count , wherefore are you sad ?

English: I'm not sad , my lord .
Shakespearean: Not sad , my lord .

English: What then , sick ?
Shakespearean: How then , sick ?

English: I'm neither , my lord .
Shakespearean: Neither , my lord .

English: The count is neither sad nor sick nor cheerful nor well , he's just civil , as Seville as an orange , with the same jealous-yellow complexion .
Shakespearean: The Count is neither sad , nor sick , nor merry , nor well , but civil count , civil as an orange , and something of that jealous complexion .

English: I've told her father , and he's given his permission .
Shakespearean: I have broke with her father and his goodwill obtained .

English: Tell us when you wish to get married , and may God give you joy .
Shakespearean: Name the day of marriage , and God give thee joy .

English: Claudio , take my daughter , and , with her , take my fortunes .
Shakespearean: Count , take of me my daughter , and with her my fortunes .

English: The Prince has made the match , and may God bless it .
Shakespearean: His grace hath made the match , and all grace say "Amen" to it .

English: Speak , Claudio , that's your cue .
Shakespearean: Speak , Count , 'tis your cue .

English: For you , I give myself away and I'm ecstatic about the exchange .
Shakespearean: I give away myself for you and dote upon the exchange .

English: Truly , lady , you have a merry heart .
Shakespearean: In faith , lady , you have a merry heart .

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Yea , my lord .

English: I thank my heart , the poor fool , for it keeps away from seriousness .
Shakespearean: I thank it , poor fool , it keeps on the windy side of care .

English: Look , my cousin is whispering to Claudio that she loves him .
Shakespearean: My cousin tells him in his ear that he is in her heart .

English: Why , you're absolutely right , cousin .
Shakespearean: And so she doth , cousin .

English: Thank the lord for alliances !
Shakespearean: Good Lord for alliance !

English: So everyone goes off into the world except me , who stays in because I'm sunburned .
Shakespearean: Thus goes everyone to the world but I , and I am sunburnt .

English: I should sit in the corner and sing that song , "Heigh-Ho for a Husband ! " Lady Beatrice , I'll get you a husband .
Shakespearean: I may sit in a corner and cry , "Heigh-ho for a husband ! " Lady Beatrice , I will get you one .

English: I'd rather get a husband from your father .
Shakespearean: I would rather have one of your father's getting .

English: Don't you have any brothers like you ?
Shakespearean: Hath your grace ne'er a brother like you ?

English: Your father's sons would make excellent husbands , if only a girl could catch one for herself .
Shakespearean: Your father got excellent husbands , if a maid could come by them .

English: Will you take me , my lady ?
Shakespearean: Will you have me , lady ?

English: No , my lord , unless I could have another husband for the work week .
Shakespearean: No , my lord , unless I might have another for working days .

English: You are too expensive to wear every day .
Shakespearean: Your Grace is too costly to wear every day .

English: But please , forgive me , your highness .
Shakespearean: But I beseech your Grace pardon me .

English: I was born to speak cleverly , not seriously .
Shakespearean: I was born to speak all mirth and no matter .

English: Niece , will you take care of those things I mentioned ?
Shakespearean: Niece , will you look to those things I told you of ?

English: Oh , yes , I'm sorry , uncle. , If you'll excuse me , your grace .
Shakespearean: I cry you mercy , uncle. , By your Grace's pardon .

English: I swear , she's a very good-natured lady .
Shakespearean: By my troth , a pleasant-spirited lady .

English: There's very little about her that's gloomy , my lord .
Shakespearean: There's little of the melancholy element in her , my lord .

English: She's only sad when she sleeps , and not even then .
Shakespearean: She is never sad but when she sleeps , and not ever sad then , for I have heard my daughter say she hath often dreamed of unhappiness and waked herself with laughing .

English: She can't stand to hear about getting a husband .
Shakespearean: She can not endure to hear tell of a husband .

English: No , not at all .
Shakespearean: Oh , by no means .

English: She mocks all her suitors so severely that they drop the suit .
Shakespearean: She mocks all her wooers out of suit .

English: She would make a good wife for Benedick .
Shakespearean: She were an excellent wife for Benedict .

English: Oh , Lord , if they were married , they'd drive themselves crazy within a week .
Shakespearean: O Lord , my lord , if they were but a week married , they would talk themselves mad .

English: Count Claudio , when do you plan to go to church and be married ?
Shakespearean: County Claudio , when mean you to go to church ?

English: Tomorrow , my lord .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow , my lord .

English: My lord , I will help you , even if it means I have to stay awake for ten nights straight .
Shakespearean: My lord , I am for you , though it cost me ten nights ' watchings .

English: Me too , my lord .
Shakespearean: And I , my lord .

English: And you , sweet Hero ?
Shakespearean: And you too , gentle Hero ?

English: I'll do any decent thing , my lord , to help my cousin get a good husband .
Shakespearean: I will do any modest office , my lord , to help my cousin to a good husband .

English: And Benedick is not the worst husband I can think of .
Shakespearean: And Benedick is not the unhopefulest husband that I know .

English: This much I can say about him : he is well-born , has proven his bravery in battle , and has established his good character .
Shakespearean: Thus far can I praise him : he is of a noble strain , of approved valor , and confirmed honesty .

English: Come inside with me , and I will tell you my plan .
Shakespearean: Go in with me , and I will tell you my drift .

English: But I'm sure he'll get even with you .
Shakespearean: Faith , niece , you tax Signor Benedick too much , but he'll be meet with you , I doubt it not .

English: Signior Benedick served well in the war , my lady .
Shakespearean: He hath done good service , lady , in these wars .

English: You had rotten food , and he helped you eat it .
Shakespearean: You had musty victual , and he hath holp to eat it .

English: He's a good soldier too , lady .
Shakespearean: And a good soldier too , lady .

English: He's a lord to a lord and a man to a man .
Shakespearean: A lord to a lord , a man to a man , stuffed with all honorable virtues .

English: He is positively stuffed with honorable virtues .
Shakespearean: He is no less than a stuffed man .

English: Absolutely , he is stuffed , like a dummy .
Shakespearean: But for the stuffing , well , we are all mortal .

English: Please don't take my niece the wrong way , sir .
Shakespearean: You must not , sir , mistake my niece .

English: Benedick and Beatrice have been waging a war of wits between themselves .
Shakespearean: There is a kind of merry war betwixt Signor Benedick and her .

English: Whenever they meet , there's a little battle .
Shakespearean: They never meet but there's a skirmish of wit between them .

English: Every month he has a new best friend .
Shakespearean: He hath every month a new sworn brother .

English: Is that possible ?
Shakespearean: Is 't possible ?

English: It's arranged .
Shakespearean: It is so .

English: The Count Claudio will marry Leonato's daughter .
Shakespearean: The Count Claudio shall marry the daughter of Leonato .

English: Yes , my lord , but I can spoil it .
Shakespearean: Yea , my lord , but I can cross it .

English: Any obstacle or barrier to Claudio's happiness will be like medicine to me .
Shakespearean: Any bar , any cross , any impediment will be med'cinable to me .

English: I hate him so much it makes me sick , and whoever can ruin his happiness will make me happy .
Shakespearean: I am sick in displeasure to him , and whatsoever comes athwart his affection ranges evenly with mine .

English: How will you wreck this marriage ?
Shakespearean: How canst thou cross this marriage ?

English: I can only do it by lying , my lord , but I can do it so secretly that no one will suspect me .
Shakespearean: Not honestly , my lord , but so covertly that no dishonesty shall appear in me .

English: Quickly , tell me how .
Shakespearean: Show me briefly how .

English: I think it was a year ago that I told you how much Margaret , Hero's servant woman , likes me .
Shakespearean: I think I told your lordship a year since how much I am in the favor of Margaret , the waiting gentlewoman to Hero .

English: I remember .
Shakespearean: I remember .

English: I can arrange it so that at some indecent hour of the night , she looks out Hero's bedroom window .
Shakespearean: I can , at any unseasonable instant of the night , appoint her to look out at her lady's chamber window .

English: How will that kill this marriage ?
Shakespearean: What life is in that to be the death of this marriage ?

English: That part is up to you .
Shakespearean: The poison of that lies in you to temper .

English: What will be my evidence ?
Shakespearean: What proof shall I make of that ?

English: Evidence enough to deceive the Prince , anger Claudio , ruin Hero , and kill Leonato .
Shakespearean: Proof enough to misuse the Prince , to vex Claudio , to undo Hero , and kill Leonato .

English: Is there anything else you wish ?
Shakespearean: Look you for any other issue ?

English: That's all I want , and I'll do anything to accomplish it .
Shakespearean: Only to despite them , I will endeavor anything .

English: Find a time to speak with Don Pedro and Claudio alone .
Shakespearean: Go then , find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and the Count Claudio alone .

English: Tell them you know that Hero loves me .
Shakespearean: Tell them that you know that Hero loves me .

English: Pretend to be very concerned about both the Prince , who has compromised his honor by making the match , and Claudio , whose reputation will be ruined by this woman who's pretending to be a virgin .
Shakespearean: Intend a kind of zeal both to the Prince and Claudio , as in love of your brother's honor , who hath made this match , and his friend's reputation , who is thus like to be cozened with the semblance of a maid , that you have discovered thus .

English: Of course , they won't believe you without proof .
Shakespearean: They will scarcely believe this without trial .

English: If you make the accusation convincingly , then my cunning won't fail me .
Shakespearean: Be you constant in the accusation , and my cunning shall not shame me .

English: I'll go now to find out the date of the wedding .
Shakespearean: I will presently go learn their day of marriage .

English: Boy !
Shakespearean: Boy !

English: Yes Signior ?
Shakespearean: Signior ?

English: In my bedroom window there is a book .
Shakespearean: In my chamber window lies a book .

English: Go get it and bring it to me here in the orchard .
Shakespearean: Bring it hither to me in the orchard .

English: I'm already here , sir .
Shakespearean: I am here already , sir .

English: I see that you are here , but I'd like you to go there and then come back again .
Shakespearean: I know that , but I would have thee hence and here again .

English: I knew him when he listened to nothing but the military drum and fife ; now he would rather hear the sweet and refined music of the tabor and pipe .
Shakespearean: I have known when there was no music with him but the drum and the fife , and now had he rather hear the tabor and the pipe .

English: I knew him when he would've walked ten miles to see a well-crafted suit of armor ; now he spends ten nights awake in his room designing himself a fancy new jacket .
Shakespearean: I have known when he would have walked ten mile afoot to see a good armor , and now will he lie ten nights awake carving the fashion of a new doublet .

English: I'm not sure , but I don't think so .
Shakespearean: I can not tell ; I think not .

English: I can't promise that love won't transform me , but I can promise you this : until I truly fall in love , a woman will never make me act like such a fool .
Shakespearean: I will not be sworn but love may transform me to an oyster , but I'll take my oath on it , till he have made an oyster of me , he shall never make me such a fool .

English: Ha !
Shakespearean: Ha !

English: Look , it's the Prince and Mr. Love .
Shakespearean: The Prince and Monsieur Love !

English: I'll hide in the arbor .
Shakespearean: I will hide me in the arbor .

English: Well , should we hear some music ?
Shakespearean: Come , shall we hear this music ?

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Yea , my good lord .

English: Come on , Balthasar , let's hear that song again .
Shakespearean: Come , Balthasar , we'll hear that song again .

English: Oh , my good lord , don't make me insult music again with my awful singing .
Shakespearean: O , good my lord , tax not so bad a voice To slander music anymore than once .

English: Come on , please sing .
Shakespearean: I pray thee , sing , and let me woo no more .

English: Just know this before I begin : I can't play a single note that's worthy of note .
Shakespearean: Note this before my notes : There's not a note of mine that's worth the noting .

English: Listen to him speaking in quarter notes !
Shakespearean: strange that sheeps ' guts should hale souls out of men's bodies ?

English: That's a good song .
Shakespearean: By my troth , a good song .

English: And a bad singer , my lord .
Shakespearean: And an ill singer , my lord .

English: Yes , do you hear me , Balthasar ?
Shakespearean: Yea , marry , dost thou hear , Balthasar ?

English: Please , get some excellent music , because tomorrow we want to serenade Lady Hero at her bedroom window .
Shakespearean: I pray thee , get us some excellent music , for tomorrow night we would have it at the Lady Hero's chamber window

English: I'll do the best I can , my lord .
Shakespearean: The best I can , my lord .

English: Please do .
Shakespearean: Do so .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: Come here , Leonato .
Shakespearean: Come hither , Leonato .

English: What was it that you told me today , that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signior Benedick ?
Shakespearean: What was it you told me of today , that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signor Benedick ?

English: Oh yes .
Shakespearean: Oh , ay .

English: I didn't , either .
Shakespearean: sits. , I did never think that lady would have loved any man .

English: But how wonderful that she should be so fond of Signior Benedick , whom she has always appeared to hate .
Shakespearean: No , nor I neither , but most wonderful that she should so dote on Signor Benedick , whom she hath in all outward behaviors seemed ever to abhor .

English: Really , my lord , I don't know what to make of it , but she loves him with such a passion that it's past all understanding .
Shakespearean: By my troth , my lord , I can not tell what to think of it , but that she loves him with an enraged affection , it is past the infinite of thought .

English: Maybe she's just pretending .
Shakespearean: May be she doth but counterfeit .

English: Yes , that's quite likely .
Shakespearean: Faith , like enough .

English: Oh God !
Shakespearean: O God !

English: Pretending ?
Shakespearean: Counterfeit ?

English: No one has ever faked passion as skillfully as this , then .
Shakespearean: There was never counterfeit of passion came so near the life of passion as she discovers it .

English: Why , what symptoms of love does she exhibit ?
Shakespearean: Why , what effects of passion shows she ?

English: What symptoms , my lord ?
Shakespearean: What effects , my lord ?

English: She will have a seat , you heard my daughter tell you how .
Shakespearean: She will sit you , you heard my daughter tell you how .

English: Yes , she did tell us .
Shakespearean: She did indeed .

English: Please , please tell me !
Shakespearean: How , how I pray you ?

English: This is amazing .
Shakespearean: You amaze me .

English: I would have thought she was invincible against any assault of love .
Shakespearean: I would have thought her spirit had been invincible against all assaults of affection .

English: I would have sworn that , too , my lord , especially against Benedick .
Shakespearean: I would have sworn it had , my lord , especially against Benedick .

English: Has she told Benedick how she feels ?
Shakespearean: Hath she made her affection known to Benedick ?

English: No , and she swears she never will .
Shakespearean: No , and swears she never will .

English: That's what's driving her crazy .
Shakespearean: That's her torment .

English: It's true , Hero says so .
Shakespearean: Tis true indeed , so your daughter says .

English: My daughter told me everything .
Shakespearean: My daughter tells us all .

English: Now that you speak of paper , I remember a funny story of Hero's .
Shakespearean: Now you talk of a sheet of paper , I remember a pretty jest your daughter told .

English: Oh , you mean when Beatrice writes a letter and Hero sees that it has "Benedick" and "Beatrice" written all over it ?
Shakespearean: Oh , when she had writ it and was reading it over , she found "Benedick" and "Beatrice" between the sheet ?

English: Yes , that's the one .
Shakespearean: That .

English: Oh , she tears that letter into a thousand small pieces and berates herself for being so forward as to write a letter to a man she knows would mock her .
Shakespearean: O , she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence , railed at herself that she should be so immodest to write to one that she knew would flout her .

English: It's true .
Shakespearean: It is very true .

English: If she won't tell Benedick , someone else should .
Shakespearean: It were good that Benedick knew of it by some other , if she will not discover it .

English: And what would that accomplish ?
Shakespearean: To what end ?

English: He'll just turn it into a joke and torment the poor woman even more .
Shakespearean: He would make but a sport of it and torment the poor lady worse .

English: If he did that , it would be a charitable deed to hang him .
Shakespearean: An he should , it were an alms to hang him .

English: She's an excellent , sweet woman , and there's no doubt that she is virtuous .
Shakespearean: She's an excellent sweet lady , and , out of all suspicion , she is virtuous .

English: And she is very smart .
Shakespearean: And she is exceeding wise .

English: Oh , my lord , when wisdom and passion are in one body , it's ten to one that the passion will win .
Shakespearean: Oh , my lord , wisdom and blood combating in so tender a body , we have ten proofs to one that blood hath the victory .

English: I am sorry for her , as I should be , since I am both her uncle and her guardian .
Shakespearean: I am sorry for her , as I have just cause , being her uncle and her guardian .

English: I wish she were in love with me instead .
Shakespearean: I would she had bestowed this dotage on me .

English: I would have thrown away all other considerations and made her my wife .
Shakespearean: I would have daffed all other respects and made her half myself .

English: Please , tell Benedick about her feelings and see what he has to say .
Shakespearean: I pray you tell Benedick of it and hear what he will say .

English: Is that a good idea , do you think ?
Shakespearean: Were it good , think you ?

English: Hero thinks Beatrice will surely die , for she says she'll die if he doesn't love her , and that she'll die before she tells him , and she'll die if he woos her and she's made to hold back even one of her usual insults .
Shakespearean: Hero thinks surely she will die , for she says she will die if he love her not , and she will die ere she make her love known , and she will die if he woo her rather than she will bate one breath of her accustomed crossness .

English: She's probably right .
Shakespearean: She doth well .

English: If she offers him her love , it's very possible that he'll scorn it , since , as we all know , he tends to be contemptuous .
Shakespearean: If she should make tender of her love , 'tis very possible he'll scorn it , for the man , as you know all , hath a contemptible spirit .

English: He's a very proper man .
Shakespearean: He is a very proper man .

English: And I swear to God he's very smart .
Shakespearean: Before God , and in my mind , very wise .

English: He does indeed show sparks of something like wit .
Shakespearean: He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit .

English: It's entirely possible .
Shakespearean: Very easily possible .

English: I can see you don't like this gentleman .
Shakespearean: I see , lady , the gentleman is not in your books .

English: No , absolutely not .
Shakespearean: No .

English: But please tell me , who's his best friend ?
Shakespearean: But I pray you , who is his companion ?

English: He spends most of his time with the good , noble Claudio .
Shakespearean: He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio .

English: Oh God , Benedick will plague him like a disease !
Shakespearean: O Lord , he will hang upon him like a disease !

English: God help Claudio !
Shakespearean: God help the noble Claudio !

English: If he's caught the Benedick , he'll lose all his money before he's cured .
Shakespearean: If he have caught the Benedick , it will cost him a thousand pound ere a be cured .

English: I'm going to make sure I stay on your good side , lady .
Shakespearean: I will hold friends with you , lady .

English: Do that , my friend .
Shakespearean: Do , good friend .

English: You will never fall victim to Benedick's charms , my niece .
Shakespearean: You will never run mad , niece .

English: No , not until we see a hot January .
Shakespearean: No , not till a hot January .

English: Don Pedro is here .
Shakespearean: Don Pedro is approached .

English: If he fears God , he must necessarily keep the peace .
Shakespearean: If he do fear God , he must necessarily keep peace .

English: If he breaks the peace , he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear and trembling .
Shakespearean: If he break the peace , he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear and trembling .

English: Well , I'm sorry for your niece .
Shakespearean: Well , I am sorry for your niece .

English: Should we go find Benedick and tell him about Beatrice's love ?
Shakespearean: Shall we go seek Benedick and tell him of her love ?

English: Against my will , I've been told to bring you in to dinner .
Shakespearean: Against my will , I am sent to bid you come in to dinner .

English: Lovely Beatrice , I thank you for taking the pains to tell me that .
Shakespearean: Fair Beatrice , I thank you for your pains .

English: I didn't take any more pains bringing this message than you took pains in thanking me .
Shakespearean: I took no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to thank me .

English: If the job had been painful , I would not have come .
Shakespearean: If it had been painful , I would not have come .

English: So you took pleasure in bringing me this message ?
Shakespearean: You take pleasure then in the message ?

English: Yes , as much pleasure as one might take in choking a bird at knifepoint .
Shakespearean: Yea , just so much as you may take upon a knife's point and choke a daw withal .

English: You don't want to eat , sir ?
Shakespearean: You have no stomach , Signior .

English: Goodbye , then .
Shakespearean: Fare you well .

English: Ha !
Shakespearean: Ha !

English: Against my will , I've been told to bring you in to dinner." There's a double meaning in that .
Shakespearean: Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner." There's a double meaning in that .

English: I didn't take any more pains bringing this message than you took pains in thanking me." That's like saying , "Any thing I do for you is as easy as saying 'thank you.'" If this doesn't move me to take pity on her , I'm a horrible person .
Shakespearean: I took no more pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me." That's as much as to say , "Any pains that I take for you is as easy as thanks." If I do not take pity of her , I am a villain .

English: If I don't love her , I'm completely
Shakespearean: If I do not love her , I am a Jew .

English: Margaret , run into the sitting room .
Shakespearean: Good Margaret , run thee to the parlor .

English: You'll find Beatrice there , talking to Claudio and the Prince .
Shakespearean: There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice Proposing with the Prince and Claudio .

English: Whisper to her that Ursula and I are walking in the orchard and that we're talking all about her .
Shakespearean: Whisper her ear and tell her I and Ursula Walk in the orchard , and our whole discourse Is all of her .

English: Tell her you heard us , and that she should sneak into the arbor where the crisscrossing branches overhead keep the honeysuckles out of the sun .
Shakespearean: Say that thou overheardst us , And bid her steal into the pleached bower Where honeysuckles ripened by the sun Forbid the sun to enter , like favorites Made proud by princes , that advance their pride Against that power that bred it .

English: She can hide there and eavesdrop on our conversation .
Shakespearean: There will she hide her To listen our propose .

English: This is your job .
Shakespearean: This is thy office .

English: Do it well , and then leave us .
Shakespearean: Bear thee well in it and leave us alone .

English: I'll make her come right away , I promise you .
Shakespearean: I'll make her come , I warrant you , presently .

English: All right Ursula , as Beatrice arrives , we'll be walking up and down this alley and speaking about nothing but Benedick .
Shakespearean: Now , Ursula , when Beatrice doth come , As we do trace this alley up and down , Our talk must only be of Benedick .

English: Whenever I mention him , praise him more than any man deserves .
Shakespearean: When I do name him , let it be thy part To praise him more than ever man did merit .

English: It'll be my job to talk about how Benedick is sick with love for Beatrice .
Shakespearean: My talk to thee must be how Benedick Is sick in love with Beatrice .

English: Let's start .
Shakespearean: Fear you not my part of the dialogue .

English: But are you sure that Benedick loves Beatrice that much ?
Shakespearean: But are you sure That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely ?

English: That's what the Prince and my fiance say .
Shakespearean: So says the Prince and my new-trothed lord .

English: And did they ask you to tell Beatrice about this , madam ?
Shakespearean: And did they bid you tell her of it , madam ?

English: They did want me to tell her , but I persuaded them that , if they truly loved Benedick , they would try to get him to battle his emotions and keep Beatrice in the dark .
Shakespearean: They did entreat me to acquaint her of it , But I persuaded them , if they loved Benedick , To wish him wrestle with affection And never to let Beatrice know of it .

English: Why did you do that ?
Shakespearean: Why did you so ?

English: Doesn't Benedick deserve as much luck with a mate as he would have with Beatrice ?
Shakespearean: Doth not the gentleman Deserve as full as fortunate a bed As ever Beatrice shall couch upon ?

English: What's the matter , lieutenant ?
Shakespearean: What's the matter , lieutenant ?

English: I'll beat him until the welts look like basket-weave !
Shakespearean: I'll beat the knave into a twiggen bottle .

English: You'll beat me ?
Shakespearean: Beat me ?

English: Are you talking , you villain ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou prate , rogue ?

English: No , don't hit him , lieutenant !
Shakespearean: Nay , good lieutenant !

English: Please , sir , restrain yourself .
Shakespearean: I pray you , sir , hold your hand .

English: Let me go , or I'll knock you on the head .
Shakespearean: Let me go , sir , or I'll knock you o'er the mazzard .

English: Come on , you're drunk .
Shakespearean: Come , come , you're drunk .

English: Drunk ?
Shakespearean: Drunk ?

English: No , lieutenant , God , gentlemen , Help , Lieutenant , sir , Montano , Help , men ! , The night guard is coming !
Shakespearean: Alas , gentlemen , Help , ho ! , Lieutenant , sir , Montano , Help , masters ! , Here's a goodly watch indeed !

English: Who's sounding that alarm ?
Shakespearean: Who's that which rings the bell ? , Diablo , ho !

English: The whole town will riot !
Shakespearean: The town will rise .

English: You'll be ashamed of this forever !
Shakespearean: Fie , Fie , lieutenant , You'll be ashamed for ever .

English: What is the matter here ?
Shakespearean: What is the matter here ?

English: I'll kill him !
Shakespearean: He dies !

English: Stop right now !
Shakespearean: Hold , for your lives !

English: Stop !
Shakespearean: Hold , ho !

English: Stop !
Shakespearean: Hold !

English: The general is talking to you !
Shakespearean: The general speaks to you .

English: Stop , for God's sake !
Shakespearean: Hold , for shame !

English: For heaven's sake , stop this savage brawl !
Shakespearean: For Christian shame , put by this barbarous brawl .

English: The next man who swings his sword must not care about his life , because the instant he strikes , he dies .
Shakespearean: He that stirs next to carve for his own rage Holds his soul light , he dies upon his motion .

English: Stop that alarm from ringing , it's scaring the islanders .
Shakespearean: Silence that dreadful bell , it frights the isle From her propriety .

English: What's the matter here , gentlemen ? , Honest Iago , you look upset .
Shakespearean: What is the matter , masters ? , Honest Iago , that looks dead with grieving , Speak , who began this ?

English: Answer me .
Shakespearean: On thy love , I charge thee .

English: I don't know .
Shakespearean: I do not know .

English: I don't
Shakespearean: Swords out , and tilting one at other's breasts In opposition bloody .

English: I'd rather have lost my legs in battle than be a part of this !
Shakespearean: I can not speak Any beginning to this peevish odds , And would in action glorious I had lost Those legs that brought me to a part of it .

English: You're famous for it .
Shakespearean: Worthy Montano , you were wont be civil .

English: What in the world made you risk your reputation like this and become a street brawler ?
Shakespearean: What's the matter That you unlace your reputation thus And spend your rich opinion for the name Of a night-brawler ?

English: Tell me .
Shakespearean: Give me answer to it .

English: Othello , I've been seriously hurt .
Shakespearean: Worthy Othello , I am hurt to danger .

English: I didn't do anything wrong that I know of , unless it was a sin to defend myself when someone attacked me .
Shakespearean: Nor know I aught By me that's said or done amiss this night , Unless self-charity be sometimes a vice , And to defend ourselves it be a sin When violence assails us .

English: All right , now I'm starting to lose my cool .
Shakespearean: Now , by heaven , My blood begins my safer guides to rule , And passion , having my best judgment collied , Assays to lead the way .

English: That's unbelievably bad .
Shakespearean: Tis monstrous .

English: Iago , who started it ?
Shakespearean: Iago , who began 't ?

English: You're hitting close to home there .
Shakespearean: Touch me not so near .

English: I'd rather cut my tongue out of my mouth than say anything bad about Michael Cassio .
Shakespearean: I had rather have this tongue cut from my mouth Than it should do offence to Michael Cassio .

English: But I don't think it'll hurt him to tell the truth .
Shakespearean: Yet I persuade myself to speak the truth Shall nothing wrong him .

English: They were nearly killing each other , as you saw when you pulled them apart .
Shakespearean: When I came back , For this was brief , I found them close together At blow and thrust , even as again they were When you yourself did part them .

English: I can't tell you anything else .
Shakespearean: More of this matter can not I report .

English: Cassio was wrong to hurt Montano , who was only trying to help him , but I'm sure the guy who ran away must have offended Cassio in some terrible way , and Cassio couldn't let it pass .
Shakespearean: Though Cassio did some little wrong to him , As men in rage strike those that wish them best , Yet surely Cassio , I believe , received From him that fled some strange indignity Which patience could not pass .

English: I'll make you an example for the others to learn from .
Shakespearean: I'll make thee an example .

English: What's the matter , dear ?
Shakespearean: What's the matter , dear ?

English: Everything's fine , now , sweetheart .
Shakespearean: All's well , sweeting , Come away to bed. , Myself will be your surgeon .

English: Are you hurt , lieutenant ?
Shakespearean: What , are you hurt , lieutenant ?

English: Yes , but no doctor can help me .
Shakespearean: Ay , past all surgery .

English: Oh I hope that's not true !
Shakespearean: Marry , heaven forbid !

English: You know I'm powerful enough to make you pay for this .
Shakespearean: But thou must needs be sure My spirits and my place have in their power To make this bitter to thee .

English: Please wait , sir .
Shakespearean: Patience , good sir .

English: Why are you talking about robbery ?
Shakespearean: What tell'st thou me of robbing ?

English: We come here to help you and you treat us like thugs , but you let an African horse climb all over your daughter .
Shakespearean: Because we come to do you service and you think we are ruffians , you'll have your daughter covered with a Barbary horse .

English: Your grandsons will neigh to you like horses .
Shakespearean: You'll have your nephews neigh to you .

English: Your whole family will be ruined .
Shakespearean: You'll have coursers for cousins and gennets for germans .

English: What kind of crude jerk are you ?
Shakespearean: What profane wretch art thou ?

English: The kind that tells you that the Moor is having sex with your daughter right now .
Shakespearean: I am one , sir , that comes to tell you your daughter and the Moor are now making the beast with two backs .

English: You're a villain !
Shakespearean: Thou art a villain !

English: You're a senator !
Shakespearean: You are a senator !

English: You're going to pay for this , Roderigo .
Shakespearean: This thou shalt answer .

English: I know who you are .
Shakespearean: I know thee , Roderigo .

English: I'll answer for everything .
Shakespearean: Sir , I will answer any thing .

English: My reputation , my reputation !
Shakespearean: Reputation , reputation , reputation !

English: Oh , my reputation , Iago , my reputation !
Shakespearean: My reputation , Iago , my reputation !

English: I swear I thought you meant you'd been hurt physically .
Shakespearean: As I am an honest man , I thought you had received some bodily wound .

English: Your physical health matters more than your reputation .
Shakespearean: There is more sense in that than in reputation .

English: You haven't lost it unless you think you have .
Shakespearean: You have lost no reputation at all unless you repute yourself such a loser .

English: There are lots of ways to get on the general's good side again .
Shakespearean: What , man , there are ways to recover the general again .

English: Go to him , petition him .
Shakespearean: Sue to him again and he's yours .

English: Drunk ?
Shakespearean: Drunk ?

English: Babbling senselessly ?
Shakespearean: And speak parrot ?

English: Squabbling ?
Shakespearean: And squabble ?

English: Swaggering ?
Shakespearean: Swagger ?

English: Ranting and raving to my own shadow !
Shakespearean: And discourse fustian with one's own shadow ?

English: Oh , wine is the devil !
Shakespearean: O thou invisible spirit of wine , if thou hast no name to be known by , let us call thee devil !

English: Who were you chasing with your sword ?
Shakespearean: What was he that you followed with your sword ?

English: What did he do to you ?
Shakespearean: What had he done to you ?

English: I don't know .
Shakespearean: I know not .

English: Is that possible ?
Shakespearean: Is 't possible ?

English: I remember a jumble of impressions , but nothing distinctly .
Shakespearean: I remember a mass of things , but nothing distinctly .

English: I remember a fight , but not why we were fighting .
Shakespearean: A quarrel , but nothing wherefore .

English: Why do we party until we're like animals ?
Shakespearean: That we should , with joy , pleasance revel and applause , transform ourselves into beasts !

English: You seem all right now .
Shakespearean: Why , but you are now well enough .

English: How did you get better ?
Shakespearean: How came you thus recovered ?

English: One weakness led to another , to make me hate myself .
Shakespearean: One unperfectness shows me another , to make me frankly despise myself .

English: Come on , you're being too hard on yourself .
Shakespearean: Come , you are too severe a moraler .

English: I wish none of this had happened , given the situation here , and your rank .
Shakespearean: As the time , the place , and the condition of this country stands , I could heartily wish this had not befallen .

English: But since this has happened , you should fix it for your own good .
Shakespearean: But since it is as it is , mend it for your own good .

English: I'll ask him for my position back again , and he'll tell me I'm a drunk .
Shakespearean: I will ask him for my place again , he shall tell me I am a drunkard .

English: Even if I had a whole bunch of mouths , I wouldn't be able to answer that .
Shakespearean: Had I as many mouths as Hydra , such an answer would stop them all .

English: I was a reasonable man , then I became a fool , and finally a beast !
Shakespearean: To be now a sensible man , by and by a fool , and presently a beast !

English: Oh , how strange !
Shakespearean: Oh , strange !

English: Every glass of liquor is damned , and the devil's the main ingredient !
Shakespearean: Every inordinate cup is unblessed and the ingredient is a devil .

English: Come on now , wine is good for you , if you know how to use it .
Shakespearean: Come , come , good wine is a good familiar creature , if it be well used .

English: Don't say anything bad about wine anymore .
Shakespearean: Exclaim no more against it .

English: Lieutenant , I think you know I'm your friend .
Shakespearean: And , good lieutenant , I think you think I love you .

English: I know that , sir .
Shakespearean: I have well approved it , sir .

English: Imagine , me , a drunk !
Shakespearean: I drunk !

English: Any man can get drunk sometime .
Shakespearean: You or any man living may be drunk at a time , man .

English: I'll tell you what to do .
Shakespearean: I tell you what you shall do .

English: Othello's wife has a lot of influence now .
Shakespearean: Our general's wife is now the general .

English: Ask her to help you get back your position .
Shakespearean: Confess yourself freely to her , importune her help to put you in your place again .

English: She is so generous , kind , and ready to help that she thinks it's wrong not to do everything she can , even more than she is asked to do .
Shakespearean: She is of so free , so kind , so apt , so blessed a disposition , she holds it a vice in her goodness not to do more than she is requested .

English: Ask her to help you heal the rift between her husband and you .
Shakespearean: This broken joint between you and her husband entreat her to splinter , and , my fortunes against any lay worth naming , this crack of your love shall grow stronger than it was before .

English: That's good advice .
Shakespearean: You advise me well .

English: I believe it completely .
Shakespearean: I protest , in the sincerity of love and honest kindness .

English: Early in the morning I'll go visit Desdemona and plead my case .
Shakespearean: I think it freely , and betimes in the morning I will beseech the virtuous Desdemona to undertake for me .

English: My situation is desperate .
Shakespearean: I am desperate of my fortunes if they check me .

English: You're doing the right thing .
Shakespearean: You are in the right .

English: Good night , lieutenant .
Shakespearean: Good night , lieutenant , I must to the watch .

English: Good night , honest Iago .
Shakespearean: Good night , honest Iago .

English: Who can say I'm evil when my advice is so good ?
Shakespearean: And what's he then that says I play the villain ?

English: That's really the best way to win the Moor back again .
Shakespearean: When this advice is free I give and honest , Probal to thinking and indeed the course To win the Moor again ?

English: It's easy to get Desdemona on your side .
Shakespearean: For 'tis most easy Th ' inclining Desdemona to subdue In any honest suit .

English: She's full of good intentions .
Shakespearean: She's framed as fruitful As the free elements .

English: How am I evil to advise Cassio to do exactly what'll do him good ?
Shakespearean: How am I then a villain To counsel Cassio to this parallel course , Directly to his good ?

English: When devils are about to commit their biggest sins they put on their most heavenly faces , just like I'm doing now .
Shakespearean: When devils will the blackest sins put on They do suggest at first with heavenly shows As I do now .

English: The more she
Shakespearean: And by how much she strives to do him good She shall undo her credit with the Moor .

English: And that's how I'll turn her good intentions into a big trap to snag them all .
Shakespearean: So will I turn her virtue into pitch And out of her own goodness make the net That shall enmesh them all .

English: Hello , Roderigo !
Shakespearean: How now , Roderigo !

English: I've spent most of my money , and tonight I got beaten up .
Shakespearean: My money is almost spent , I have been tonight exceedingly well cudgeled , and I think the issue will be I shall have so much experience for my pains .

English: So with no money , but a little more wisdom , I'm going back to Venice .
Shakespearean: And so , with no money at all and a little more wit , return again to Venice .

English: You're a poor man if you're this impatient !
Shakespearean: How poor are they that have not patience !

English: No , it heals gradually .
Shakespearean: What wound did ever heal but by degrees ?

English: We achieve things with our intelligence , not by magic , and intelligent planning takes time .
Shakespearean: Thou know'st we work by wit and not by witchcraft , And wit depends on dilatory time .

English: Aren't things going well ?
Shakespearean: Does't not go well ?

English: My God , it's morning .
Shakespearean: In troth , 'tis morning .

English: All this excitement has made the time fly by .
Shakespearean: Pleasure and action make the hours seem short .

English: Go back to where you're staying and go to sleep .
Shakespearean: Retire thee , go where thou art billeted .

English: Go .
Shakespearean: Nay , get thee gone .

English: Now two things still need to be done .
Shakespearean: Two things are to be done : My wife must move for Cassio to her mistress .

English: I'll put her on that .
Shakespearean: I'll set her on .

English: Yes , that's the way I'll do it .
Shakespearean: Ay , that's the way .

English: I'll pay you for your trouble .
Shakespearean: Masters , play here , I will content your pains .

English: Are these wind instruments ?
Shakespearean: Are these , I pray you , wind instruments ?

English: Yes , they are .
Shakespearean: Ay , marry , are they , sir .

English: Oh , there's the problem .
Shakespearean: Oh , thereby hangs a tail .

English: What's the problem ?
Shakespearean: Whereby hangs a tale , sir ?

English: Well , we'll stop , then .
Shakespearean: Well , sir , we will not .

English: If you've got any music that can't be heard , then play that .
Shakespearean: If you have any music that may not be heard , to 't again .

English: But as I said , the general isn't really in the mood to hear music now .
Shakespearean: But , as they say , to hear music the general does not greatly care .

English: We don't have any music that can't be heard .
Shakespearean: We have none such , sir .

English: Then pack up your instruments and go away .
Shakespearean: Then put up your pipes in your bag , for I'll away .

English: Go !
Shakespearean: Go , vanish into air , away !

English: Do you hear , my friend ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou hear , my honest friend ?

English: Please don't play games .
Shakespearean: Prithee , keep up thy quillets .

English: CASSIO She's awake , sir .
Shakespearean: She is stirring , sir .

English: If she feels like coming over here , I'll give her your message .
Shakespearean: If she will stir hither , I shall seem to notify unto her .

English: Good to see you , Iago .
Shakespearean: In happy time , Iago .

English: You didn't go to sleep , then ?
Shakespearean: You have not been abed , then ?

English: No .
Shakespearean: Why , no .

English: I'm going to ask her to let me talk to Desdemona .
Shakespearean: My suit to her Is that she will to virtuous Desdemona Procure me some access .

English: I humbly thank you .
Shakespearean: I humbly thank you for't .

English: Even for a Good morning , lieutenant .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , good Lieutenant .

English: I'm sorry about what happened , but I'm sure everything will turn out all right .
Shakespearean: I am sorry For your displeasure , but all will sure be well .

English: The general and his wife are talking about it now , and she's defending you strongly .
Shakespearean: The general and his wife are talking of it , And she speaks for you stoutly .

English: The Moor says the man you hurt is very important in Cyprus , and that under the circumstances he has no choice but to refuse to reinstate you .
Shakespearean: The Moor replies That he you hurt is of great fame in Cyprus And great affinity , and that in wholesome wisdom He might not but refuse you .

English: But he says he still loves and respects you , and based on his own feelings alone he's looking for an opportunity to safely take you back .
Shakespearean: But he protests he loves you And needs no other suitor but his likings To take the safest occasion by the front To bring you in again .

English: Please find a way to give me some time alone with Desdemona , if you think that's all right .
Shakespearean: Yet I beseech you , If you think fit , or that it may be done , Give me advantage of some brief discourse With Desdemona alone .

English: Please come in .
Shakespearean: Pray you come in .

English: I'll take you to a place where you can speak freely .
Shakespearean: I will bestow you where you shall have time To speak your bosom freely .

English: Thank you very much .
Shakespearean: I am much bound to you .

English: Iago , give these letters to the ship's captain who brought me here , and ask him to pay my respects to the Senate of Venice .
Shakespearean: These letters give , Iago , to the pilot , And by him do my duties to the senate .

English: Now that's done , I'm going to walk on the fortification walls .
Shakespearean: That done , I will be walking on the works , Repair there to me .

English: I will , my lord .
Shakespearean: Well , my good lord , I'll do 't .

English: Shall we go see this fortification , men ?
Shakespearean: This fortification , gentlemen , shall we see 't ?

English: We're at your service , my lord .
Shakespearean: We'll wait upon your lordship .

English: I'll do everything I can for you , Cassio .
Shakespearean: Be thou assured , good Cassio , I will do All my abilities in thy behalf .

English: Please do , madam .
Shakespearean: Good madam , do .

English: I'm sure you and my husband will be as friendly as you were before .
Shakespearean: Do not doubt , Cassio , But I will have my lord and you again As friendly as you were .

English: Yes , my lady .
Shakespearean: You do love my lord .

English: But those political considerations might last such a long time that the general will forget my love and service , especially if I'm gone and someone else has my job .
Shakespearean: Ay , but , lady , That policy may either last so long , Or feed upon such nice and waterish diet , Or breed itself so out of circumstances , That , I being absent and my place supplied , My general will forget my love and service .

English: My husband will never get a moment's rest , I'll keep him up at night talking about you until he runs out
Shakespearean: My lord shall never rest , I'll watch him tame and talk him out of patience .

English: But if you didn't know about it , then you were wrong to get mad at us .
Shakespearean: But if you know not this my manners tell me We have your wrong rebuke .

English: I'd never play pranks on you .
Shakespearean: Do not believe That , from the sense of all civility , I thus would play and trifle with your reverence .

English: If she is , you can sue me for lying to you .
Shakespearean: If she be in her chamber or your house , Let loose on me the justice of the state For thus deluding you .

English: Light the candles !
Shakespearean: Strike on the tinder , ho !

English: Wake up my whole household !
Shakespearean: Give me a taper , call up all my people !

English: I dreamt about this .
Shakespearean: This accident is not unlike my dream , Belief of it oppresses me already .

English: Give me some light !
Shakespearean: Light , I say , light !

English: It's time for me to say goodbye to you .
Shakespearean: Farewell , for I must leave you .

English: It would be inappropriate , dangerous , even , for me to be seen working against the Moor , as I would if I stayed .
Shakespearean: It seems not meet , nor wholesome to my place , To be producted ( as , if I stay , I shall ) Against the Moor .

English: of patience .
Shakespearean: In which regard ,

English: I'm your advocate , and I'd rather die than give up on you .
Shakespearean: Therefore be merry , Cassio , For thy solicitor shall rather die Than give thy cause away .

English: Madam , here comes your husband .
Shakespearean: Madam , here comes my lord .

English: Madam , I'd better leave now .
Shakespearean: Madam , I'll take my leave .

English: Why not stay and hear me talk to him ?
Shakespearean: Why , stay and hear me speak .

English: No , madam .
Shakespearean: Madam , not now .

English: I'm very uncomfortable , and that won't help my case .
Shakespearean: I am very ill at ease , Unfit for mine own purposes .

English: Well , do whatever you think best .
Shakespearean: Well , do your discretion .

English: Hey !
Shakespearean: Ha !

English: I don't like that .
Shakespearean: I like not that .

English: What did you say ?
Shakespearean: What dost thou say ?

English: Nothing , my lord , or if I did , I don't know what .
Shakespearean: Nothing , my lord , or if , I know not what .

English: Wasn't that Cassio leaving my wife ?
Shakespearean: Was not that Cassio parted from my wife ?

English: Cassio , my lord ?
Shakespearean: Cassio , my lord ?

English: I really think it was him .
Shakespearean: I do believe 'twas he .

English: What's this , my lord ?
Shakespearean: How now , my lord ?

English: I was talking to a petitioner here just now , someone who's suffering from your anger .
Shakespearean: I have been talking with a suitor here , A man that languishes in your displeasure .

English: Who do you mean ?
Shakespearean: Who is 't you mean ?

English: Your lieutenant , Cassio .
Shakespearean: Why , your lieutenant , Cassio .

English: Oh , if I've got any influence over you at all , please patch things up with him .
Shakespearean: Good my lord , If I have any grace or power to move you His present reconciliation take .

English: Please call him and tell him to come back here .
Shakespearean: I prithee , call him back .

English: Was that him just now ?
Shakespearean: Went he hence now ?

English: Yes .
Shakespearean: Ay , sooth , so humbled That he hath left part of his grief with me To suffer with him .

English: My love , call him back in here .
Shakespearean: Good love , call him back .

English: Not now , my sweet Desdemona .
Shakespearean: Not now , sweet Desdemona .

English: Some other time .
Shakespearean: Some other time .

English: But will it be soon ?
Shakespearean: But shall 't be shortly ?

English: Very soon , because you want it .
Shakespearean: The sooner , sweet , for you .

English: Will it be tonight at supper ?
Shakespearean: Shall 't be tonight at supper ?

English: No , not tonight .
Shakespearean: No , not tonight .

English: Then tomorrow at dinner ?
Shakespearean: Tomorrow dinner , then ?

English: Well then , tomorrow night , or Tuesday morning .
Shakespearean: Why , then , tomorrow night , or Tuesday morn .

English: Or Tuesday noon or at night , or Wednesday morning .
Shakespearean: On Tuesday noon , or night , or Wednesday morn .

English: Please just name a time , but don't wait more than three days .
Shakespearean: I prithee name the time , but let it not Exceed three days .

English: His mistake was hardly worth punishing him for in the first place , though in wartime it is sometimes necessary to make examples out of even the best soldiers .
