Shakespearean: Within these three days let me hear thee say That Cassio's not alive .

English: But let her live .
Shakespearean: But let her live .

English: Oh , damn her , damn her !
Shakespearean: Oh , damn her , damn her !

English: Come away with me .
Shakespearean: Come , go with me apart .

English: I'm going inside to think up some way to kill that beautiful devil .
Shakespearean: I will withdraw To furnish me with some swift means of death For the fair devil .

English: You're my lieutenant now .
Shakespearean: Now art thou my lieutenant .

English: I'm yours forever .
Shakespearean: I am your own for ever .

English: Lead the way .
Shakespearean: Pray you lead on .

English: I'll stop at every house .
Shakespearean: At every house I'll call .

English: I'll reward you for your troubles .
Shakespearean: I will deserve your pains .

English: Why do you say that ?
Shakespearean: Why , man ?

English: Oh , come on .
Shakespearean: Go to .

English: Where does he sleep ?
Shakespearean: Where lodges he ?

English: Telling you where he's sleeping is like telling you where I'm lying .
Shakespearean: To tell you where he lodges is to tell you where I lie .

English: What on earth does that mean ?
Shakespearean: Can anything be made of this ?

English: I don't know where he's staying , so if I told you he's sleeping here or there , I'd be lying .
Shakespearean: I know not where he lodges , and for me to devise a lodging and say he lies here , or he lies there , were to lie in mine own throat .

English: Can you ask around and find out ?
Shakespearean: Can you inquire him out and be edified by report ?

English: Find him and tell him to come here .
Shakespearean: Seek him , bid him come hither .

English: Tell him I've spoken to my husband on his behalf , and I think everything will be all right .
Shakespearean: Tell him I have moved my lord on his behalf , and hope all will be well .

English: I think I can do that .
Shakespearean: To do this is within the compass of man's wit , and therefore I will attempt the doing it .

English: Where could I have lost that handkerchief , Emilia ?
Shakespearean: Where should I lose that handkerchief , Emilia ?

English: I don't know , madam .
Shakespearean: I know not , madam .

English: Believe me , I'd rather have lost a purse full of gold coins .
Shakespearean: Believe me , I had rather have lost my purse Full of crusadoes .

English: This would be enough to make my husband suspect me , if he wasn't so free of jealousy .
Shakespearean: And but my noble Moor Is true of mind and made of no such baseness As jealous creatures are , it were enough To put him to ill thinking .

English: He's not jealous ?
Shakespearean: Is he not jealous ?

English: Who , him ?
Shakespearean: Who , he ?

English: I think all tendencies to jealousy were burned out of him by the sun of his native land .
Shakespearean: I think the sun where he was born Drew all such humors from him .

English: Look , here he comes .
Shakespearean: Look where he comes .

English: I won't leave him alone until he gives Cassio his job back. , How are you , my lord ?
Shakespearean: I will not leave him now till Cassio Be called to him. , How is 't with you , my lord ?

English: Hot , hot and moist .
Shakespearean: Hot , hot , and moist .

English: With a hand like this you need to
Shakespearean: This hand of yours requires A sequester from liberty , fasting , and prayer ,

English: fast and pray to stave off temptations .
Shakespearean: Much castigation , exercise devout , For here's a young and sweating devil here , That commonly rebels .

English: It's a nice hand , an open one .
Shakespearean: Tis a good hand , A frank one .

English: But these days , people give each other their hands without their hearts .
Shakespearean: The hearts of old gave hands , But our new heraldry is hands , not hearts .

English: I don't know about that .
Shakespearean: I can not speak of this .

English: Now , don't forget , you promised me something .
Shakespearean: Come now , your promise .

English: What did I promise , my dear ?
Shakespearean: What promise , chuck ?

English: I sent for Cassio to come talk with you .
Shakespearean: I have sent to bid Cassio come speak with you .

English: I have a bad cold that's bothering me .
Shakespearean: I have a salt and sorry rheum offends me .

English: Lend me your handkerchief .
Shakespearean: Lend me thy handkerchief .

English: Here , my lord .
Shakespearean: Here , my lord .

English: No , the one I gave you .
Shakespearean: That which I gave you .

English: I don't have it with me .
Shakespearean: I have it not about me .

English: You don't ?
Shakespearean: Not ?

English: No , my lord .
Shakespearean: No , indeed , my lord .

English: That's not good .
Shakespearean: That's a fault .

English: almost read people's thoughts .
Shakespearean: The thoughts of people .

English: She told my mother that as long as she kept it with her , my father would love and desire her .
Shakespearean: She told her , while she kept it 'Twould make her amiable and subdue my father Entirely to her love , but if she lost it Or made gift of it , my father's eye Should hold her loathed and his spirits should hunt After new fancies .

English: When she was dying she gave it to me and told me to give it to my wife when I got married .
Shakespearean: She , dying , gave it me And bid me , when my fate would have me wived , To give it her .

English: I did .
Shakespearean: I did so , and take heed on 't , Make it a darling like your precious eye .

English: Is that possible ?
Shakespearean: Is 't possible ?

English: Yes , it's true .
Shakespearean: Tis true .

English: There's magic in its fabric .
Shakespearean: There's magic in the web of it .

English: A two-hundred-year-old witch sewed it while she was in a fevered trance .
Shakespearean: A sibyl , that had numbered in the world The sun to course two hundred compasses , In her prophetic fury sewed the work .

English: The silk came from sacred silkworms , and it was dyed with fluid made from embalmed virgins ' hearts .
Shakespearean: The worms were hallowed that did breed the silk , And it was dyed in mummy which the skillful Conserved of maidens ' hearts .

English: Really ?
Shakespearean: Indeed ?

English: Is that true ?
Shakespearean: Is 't true ?

English: It's absolutely true , so take good care of it .
Shakespearean: Most veritable , therefore look to 't well .

English: I wish I had never seen it !
Shakespearean: Then would to Heaven that I had never seen 't !

English: Ha !
Shakespearean: Ha !

English: Why ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore ?

English: Why are you yelling at me so angrily ?
Shakespearean: Why do you speak so startingly and rash ?

English: Is it lost ?
Shakespearean: Is 't lost ?

English: Is it gone ?
Shakespearean: Is 't gone ?

English: Tell me , is it missing ?
Shakespearean: Speak , is 't out o ' th ' way ?

English: God help me !
Shakespearean: Bless us !

English: What do you have to say for yourself ?
Shakespearean: Say you ?

English: It's not lost , but what if it were ?
Shakespearean: It is not lost , but what and if it were ?

English: What do you mean ?
Shakespearean: How !

English: I'm telling you , it's not lost .
Shakespearean: I say , it is not lost .

English: Please hire Cassio again .
Shakespearean: Pray you , let Cassio be received again .

English: Bring me the handkerchief , My mind is full of doubt .
Shakespearean: Fetch me the handkerchief , my mind misgives .

English: Come on .
Shakespearean: Come , come , You'll never meet a more sufficient man .

English: The handkerchief !
Shakespearean: The handkerchief !

English: Damn it !
Shakespearean: Away !

English: And you say he's not jealous ?
Shakespearean: Is not this man jealous ?

English: I never saw him like this before .
Shakespearean: I ne'er saw this before .

English: They're like stomachs and we're just the food .
Shakespearean: They are all but stomachs , and we all but food .

English: They eat us up hungrily , and when they're full , they vomit us up .
Shakespearean: To eat us hungerly , and when they are full , They belch us .

English: Look , here comes Cassio and my husband .
Shakespearean: Look you , Cassio and my husband !

English: There's no other way .
Shakespearean: There is no other way .

English: She's the one who's got to do it .
Shakespearean: Tis she must do 't , And , lo , the happiness !

English: Go ahead and ask her .
Shakespearean: Go and importune her .

English: Then I could stop wondering , and find some other career .
Shakespearean: So shall I clothe me in a forced content , And shut myself up in some other course , To fortune's alms .

English: If his face changed as much as his personality has , I wouldn't recognize him .
Shakespearean: My lord is not my lord , nor should I know him Were he in favor as in humor altered .

English: God knows I have done my best to argue for you , and made him angry at me for being so aggressive .
Shakespearean: So help me every spirit sanctified As I have spoken for you all my best And stood within the blank of his displeasure For my free speech .

English: You'll just have to be patient for a little while .
Shakespearean: You must awhile be patient .

English: I'll do what I can , more than I'd do for myself .
Shakespearean: What I can do I will , and more I will Than for myself I dare .

English: Let that be enough for you .
Shakespearean: Let that suffice you .

English: Is Othello angry ?
Shakespearean: Is my lord angry ?

English: Can he even get angry ?
Shakespearean: Can he be angry ?

English: If he's angry , there must be something seriously wrong .
Shakespearean: There's matter in 't indeed , if he be angry .

English: Please , do so .
Shakespearean: I prithee , do so .

English: There must be some political news from Venice , or some dangerous plot here in Cyprus has ruined his good mood .
Shakespearean: Something , sure , of state , Either from Venice , or some unhatched practice Made demonstrable here in Cyprus to him , Hath puddled his clear spirit , and in such cases Men's natures wrangle with inferior things , Though great ones are their object .

English: That's the way it goes .
Shakespearean: Tis even so , For let our finger ache and it endues Our other healthful members even to that sense Of pain .

English: We shouldn't expect men to be perfect , or for them to be as polite as on the weddingday .
Shakespearean: Nay , we must think men are not gods , Nor of them look for such observances As fit the bridal .

English: I hope to God it's something political , like you think , and not jealousy involving you .
Shakespearean: Pray heaven it be State matters , as you think , and no conception Nor no jealous toy concerning you .

English: Oh no !
Shakespearean: Alas the day !

English: I never gave him reason to be jealous .
Shakespearean: I never gave him cause .

English: But jealous people don't think like that .
Shakespearean: But jealous souls will not be answered so .

English: They're never jealous for a reason ; they're just jealous .
Shakespearean: They are not ever jealous for the cause , But jealous for they're jealous .

English: It's like a monster that just grows and grows , out of nothing .
Shakespearean: It is a monster Begot upon itself , born on itself .

English: I hope God keeps that monster from growing in Othello's mind !
Shakespearean: Heaven keep the monster from Othello's mind !

English: Amen to that , lady .
Shakespearean: Lady , amen .

English: I'll go look for him , Cassio , stay around here .
Shakespearean: I will go seek him. , Cassio , walk hereabout .

English: If he's in a good mood I'll mention you again , and do everything I can .
Shakespearean: If I do find him fit , I'll move your suit And seek to effect it to my uttermost .

English: I thank you , lady .
Shakespearean: I humbly thank your ladyship .

English: Hello , Cassio !
Shakespearean: Save you , friend Cassio !

English: Why are you so far from home ?
Shakespearean: What make you from home ?

English: How are you , my pretty Bianca ?
Shakespearean: How is 't with you , my most fair Bianca ?

English: To tell you the truth , I was just going to your house .
Shakespearean: Indeed , sweet love , I was coming to your house .

English: And I was just going to yours .
Shakespearean: And I was going to your lodging , Cassio .

English: You've kept away from me for a week ?
Shakespearean: What , keep a week away ?

English: Seven days and seven nights ?
Shakespearean: Seven days and nights ?

English: A hundred and sixty-eight hours ?
Shakespearean: Eight score eight hours ?

English: And lovers ' hours are a hundred and sixty times longer than normal ones !
Shakespearean: And lovers ' absent hours More tedious than the dial eightscore times !

English: What a tedious wait !
Shakespearean: Oh weary reckoning !

English: Oh , Cassio , where did you get this ?
Shakespearean: O Cassio , whence came this ?

English: Has it come to this ?
Shakespearean: Is 't come to this ?

English: Well , well .
Shakespearean: Well , well .

English: Oh , come on , woman .
Shakespearean: Go to , woman , Throw your vile guesses in the devil's teeth From whence you have them .

English: Well , whose is it ?
Shakespearean: Why , whose is it ?

English: It's pretty .
Shakespearean: I like the work well .

English: So I'd like it copied .
Shakespearean: Ere it be demanded , As like enough it will , I would have it copied .

English: Take it and do that for me , and leave me alone for a while .
Shakespearean: Take it and do 't , and leave me for this time .

English: Leave you alone !
Shakespearean: Leave you !

English: Why ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore ?

English: I'm waiting here for the general , and I don't want him to see me with a woman .
Shakespearean: I do attend here on the general And think it no addition , nor my wish , To have him see me womaned .

English: And why's that ?
Shakespearean: Why , I pray you ?

English: It's not because I don't love you .
Shakespearean: Not that I love you not .

English: But you don't love me .
Shakespearean: But that you do not love me .

English: Please , just walk with me a little ways , and tell me if I'll see you later tonight .
Shakespearean: I pray you bring me on the way a little And say if I shall see you soon at night .

English: I can only walk a little way with you , since I'm waiting here .
Shakespearean: Tis but a little way that I can bring you , For I attend here .

English: But I'll see you soon .
Shakespearean: But I'll see you soon .

English: All right , have it your way .
Shakespearean: Tis very good .

English: I have to make do .
Shakespearean: I must be circumstanced .

English: Nine or ten times I wanted to stab him under the ribs .
Shakespearean: Nine or ten times I had thought t ' have yerked him here under the ribs .

English: It's better that you didn't kill him .
Shakespearean: Tis better as it is .

English: But he kept chattering so foolishly , talking about you in such insulting and despicable terms , that it was hard for me to restrain myself .
Shakespearean: Nay , but he prated And spoke such scurvy and provoking terms Against your honor That , with the little godliness I have , I did full hard forbear him .

English: But please tell me , sir , is your marriage Let him do his worst .
Shakespearean: Let him do his spite .

English: The services I have done for the Venetian government will count for more than his complaints will .
Shakespearean: My services which I have done the signiory Shall out-tongue his complaints .

English: Do you really think so ?
Shakespearean: Will you think so ?

English: What do you mean , do I think so ?
Shakespearean: Think so , Iago ?

English: What , just because they kissed in private ?
Shakespearean: What , To kiss in private ?

English: An illicit kiss !
Shakespearean: An unauthorized kiss !

English: Maybe she was just naked in bed with him for an hour or so , but they didn't do anything .
Shakespearean: Or to be naked with her friend in bed An hour or more , not meaning any harm ?

English: Naked in bed together , but without doing anything ?
Shakespearean: Naked in bed , Iago , and not mean harm !

English: Come on , Iago .
Shakespearean: It is hypocrisy against the devil .

English: As long as they didn't do anything , it would only be a minor sin .
Shakespearean: So they do nothing , 'tis a venial slip .

English: But if I gave my wife a handkerchief , Then what ?
Shakespearean: But if I give my wife a handkerchief , What then ?

English: Her reputation is also her own .
Shakespearean: She is protectress of her honor too .

English: Can she give that away too ?
Shakespearean: May she give that ?

English: But a handkerchief , God , I wish I could forget about the handkerchief !
Shakespearean: But for the handkerchief , By heaven , I would most gladly have forgot it .

English: What you told me it haunts me like a nightmare , he's got my handkerchief !
Shakespearean: Thou saidst , Oh , it comes o'er my memory , As doth the raven o'er the infectious house , Boding to all , he had my handkerchief .

English: Yes , what about it ?
Shakespearean: Ay , what of that ?

English: That's not good .
Shakespearean: That's not so good now .

English: What if I'd said I saw him do something to hurt you ?
Shakespearean: What if I had said I had seen him do you wrong ?

English: Yes , but he'd deny it all .
Shakespearean: He hath , my lord , but be you well assured No more than he'll unswear .

English: What did he say ?
Shakespearean: What hath he said ?

English: He said he did , I don't know .
Shakespearean: Why , that he did , I know not what he did .

English: He was in bed with , With her ?
Shakespearean: Lie , With her ?

English: With her , on top of her , however you want to say it .
Shakespearean: With her , on her , what you will .

English: In bed with her ?
Shakespearean: Lie with her ?

English: On top of her ?
Shakespearean: lie on her ?

English: My God , it's nauseating !
Shakespearean: Lie with her , that's fulsome .

English: Handkerchief , confessions , handkerchief !
Shakespearean: Handkerchief , confessions , handkerchief !

English: Noses , ears , lips .
Shakespearean: Noses , ears , and lips .

English: Is it possible ?
Shakespearean: Is 't possible ?

English: This is the way to trick gullible fools .
Shakespearean: Confess ! , Handkerchief ! , Oh , devil ! , Work on , My medicine , work !

English: Hey , Cassio !
Shakespearean: How now , Cassio !

English: What's the matter ?
Shakespearean: What's the matter ?

English: This is his second fit like this .
Shakespearean: This is his second fit .

English: He had one yesterday .
Shakespearean: He had one yesterday .

English: Rub his temples .
Shakespearean: Rub him about the temples .

English: No , don't .
Shakespearean: No , forbear .

English: If you interrupt it , he'll foam at the mouth and go crazy .
Shakespearean: If not , he foams at mouth and by and by Breaks out to savage madness .

English: Look , he's moving .
Shakespearean: Look , he stirs .

English: Why don't you go away for a bit ?
Shakespearean: Do you withdraw yourself a little while ,

English: When he leaves , it's very important that I talk to you .
Shakespearean: When he is gone I would on great occasion speak with you .

English: What happened , general ?
Shakespearean: How is it , general ?

English: Did you hit your head ?
Shakespearean: Have you not hurt your head ?

English: Are you making fun of me ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou mock me ?

English: I wish you could face your bad news like a man !
Shakespearean: Would you would bear your fortune like a man !

English: He's subhuman , like an animal .
Shakespearean: A horned man's a monster and a beast .

English: Did he confess ?
Shakespearean: Did he confess it ?

English: Sir , be a man .
Shakespearean: Good sir , be a man , Think every bearded fellow that's but yoked May draw with you .

English: Your case is better than that .
Shakespearean: Your case is better .

English: Then I'll know exactly what she is , just as I know what I am .
Shakespearean: No , let me know , And knowing what I am , I know what she shall be .

English: You're wise !
Shakespearean: Oh , thou art wise !

English: That's for sure .
Shakespearean: Tis certain .

English: While you were dazed by grief , which isn't appropriate for a man like you , Cassio showed up here .
Shakespearean: Whilst you were here o'erwhelmed with your grief , A passion most resulting such a man , Cassio came hither .

English: I got him to leave , and made up an excuse for your trance .
Shakespearean: I shifted him away And laid good 'scuses upon your ecstasy ,

English: I told him to come back and talk to me in a bit , and he promised he would .
Shakespearean: Bade him anon return and here speak with me , The which he promised .

English: I'll make him tell me the whole story again , where , how often , how long ago , and when he plans to sleep with your wife in the future .
Shakespearean: For I will make him tell the tale anew Where , how , how oft , how long ago , and when He hath , and is again to cope your wife .

English: I'm telling you , just watch his face .
Shakespearean: I say , but mark his gesture .

English: But stay calm , and don't get carried away by rage , or I'll think you're not a man .
Shakespearean: Marry , patience , Or I shall say you are all in all in spleen , And nothing of a man .

English: Do you hear what I'm saying , Iago ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou hear , Iago ?

English: Will you go hide ?
Shakespearean: Will you withdraw ?

English: Now I'll ask Cassio about Bianca , a prostitute who sells her body for food and clothes .
Shakespearean: Now will I question Cassio of Bianca , A huswife that by selling her desires Buys herself bread and clothes .

English: That's the whore's curse , to seduce many men , but to be seduced by one .
Shakespearean: It is a creature That dotes on Cassio , as 'tis the strumpet's plague To beguile many and be beguiled by one .

English: Whenever he talks about her he can't stop laughing .
Shakespearean: He , when he hears of her , can not refrain From the excess of laughter .

English: And when he laughs , Othello will go crazy .
Shakespearean: As he shall smile , Othello shall go mad .

English: In his ignorant jealousy , he'll totally misunderstand Cassio's smiles , gestures , and jokes. , How are you , lieutenant ?
Shakespearean: And his unbookish jealousy must construe Poor Cassio's smiles , gestures , and light behavior Quite in the wrong. , How do you now , lieutenant ?

English: The poor thing !
Shakespearean: Alas , poor caitiff !

English: He's laughing already !
Shakespearean: Look how he laughs already !

English: I never knew a woman who loved a man so much .
Shakespearean: I never knew woman love man so .

English: The poor thing , I really think she loves me .
Shakespearean: Alas , poor rogue , I think indeed she loves me .

English: Now he denies it a bit , and tries to laugh it off .
Shakespearean: Now he denies it faintly , and laughs it out .

English: Have you heard this , Cassio ?
Shakespearean: Do you hear , Cassio ?

English: He's asking him to tell the story again .
Shakespearean: Now he importunes him To tell it o'er .

English: Go on , tell it .
Shakespearean: Go to , well said , well said .

English: She says you're going to marry her .
Shakespearean: She gives it out that you shall marry her .

English: Are you ?
Shakespearean: Do you intend it ?

English: Ha , ha , ha !
Shakespearean: Ha , ha , ha !

English: Do you think you've won ?
Shakespearean: Do you triumph ?

English: Me , marry her ?
Shakespearean: I marry her !

English: That whore ?
Shakespearean: What ?

English: Please give me a little credit !
Shakespearean: Prithee bear some charity to my wit .

English: I'm not that stupid .
Shakespearean: Do not think it so unwholesome .

English: Ha , ha , ha !
Shakespearean: Ha , ha , ha !

English: So , so , so , so !
Shakespearean: So , so , so , so !

English: You're kidding !
Shakespearean: Prithee say true !

English: All right , then .
Shakespearean: Well .

English: She thinks I'll marry her because she loves me .
Shakespearean: She is persuaded I will marry her , out of her own love and flattery , not out of my promise .

English: Iago is gesturing for me to come closer .
Shakespearean: Iago beckons me .

English: Now he's telling the story .
Shakespearean: Now he begins the story .

English: She was here just now .
Shakespearean: She was here even now .

English: She hangs around me all the time .
Shakespearean: She haunts me in every place .

English: I was talking to some Venetians down by the shore , and the fool showed up .
Shakespearean: I was the other day talking on the sea-bank with certain Venetians , and thither comes the bauble and , by this hand , she falls me thus about my neck , Crying "O dear Cassio ! " as it were .

English: Ha , ha , ha !
Shakespearean: Ha , ha , ha !

English: Now he's saying how she took him into our bedroom .
Shakespearean: Now he tells how she plucked him to my chamber .

English: Look out , here she comes .
Shakespearean: Look , where she comes .

English: Damn you !
Shakespearean: Tis such another fitchew .

English: What did you mean by giving me this handkerchief ?
Shakespearean: What did you mean by that same handkerchief you gave me even now ?

English: I was an idiot to take it !
Shakespearean: I was a fine fool to take it .

English: You want me to copy the embroidery pattern ?
Shakespearean: I must take out the work ?

English: That was a likely story , that you found it in your room and didn't know who it belonged to .
Shakespearean: A likely piece of work , that you should find it in your chamber , and not know who left it there !

English: This is a love token from some other slut , and you want me to copy its pattern for you ?
Shakespearean: This is some minx's token , and I must take out the work ?

English: What is it , my dear Bianca ?
Shakespearean: How now , my sweet Bianca !

English: What's wrong ?
Shakespearean: How now , how now ?

English: My God , that's my handkerchief !
Shakespearean: By heaven , that should be my handkerchief !

English: If you want to come have dinner with me , you can .
Shakespearean: If you'll come to supper tonight , you may .

English: If you don't want to , then good riddance .
Shakespearean: If you will not , come when you are next prepared for .

English: Go after her , go .
Shakespearean: After her , after her .

English: Actually , I should .
Shakespearean: I must , she'll rail in the street else .

English: Will you be having dinner with her tonight ?
Shakespearean: Will you sup there ?

English: Yes , I will .
Shakespearean: Yes , I intend so .

English: Did you see how he laughed about sleeping with her ?
Shakespearean: Did you perceive how he laughed at his vice ?

English: Oh Iago !
Shakespearean: O Iago !

English: And did you see the handkerchief ?
Shakespearean: And did you see the handkerchief ?

English: Was it mine ?
Shakespearean: Was that mine ?

English: It was yours , I swear .
Shakespearean: Yours by this hand .

English: And do you see how much your foolish wife means to him ?
Shakespearean: And to see how he prizes the foolish woman your wife !

English: She gave it to him , and he gave it to his whore .
Shakespearean: She gave it him , and he hath given it his whore .

English: I wish I could keep killing him for nine years straight .
Shakespearean: I would have him nine years a-killing .

English: Oh , she's a fine woman !
Shakespearean: A fine woman !

English: A fair woman !
Shakespearean: A fair woman !

English: A sweet woman !
Shakespearean: A sweet woman !

English: No , you have to forget all that now .
Shakespearean: Nay , you must forget that .

English: Yes , let her die and rot and go to hell tonight .
Shakespearean: Ay , let her rot and perish and be damned tonight , for she shall not live .

English: Oh , the world never saw a sweeter creature .
Shakespearean: Oh , the world hath not a sweeter creature , she might lie by an emperor's side and command him tasks .

English: But that's not how you're going to be .
Shakespearean: Nay , that's not your way .

English: She's so good at sewing , and a wonderful musician .
Shakespearean: So delicate with her needle , an admirable musician .

Shakespearean: Oh , she will sing the savageness out of a bear !

Shakespearean: Oh , a thousand thousand times , and then of so gentle a condition !

Shakespearean: If you are so fond over her iniquity , give her patent to offend , for if it touch not you it comes near nobody .

Shakespearean: I will chop her into messes !

Shakespearean: When being not at your lodging to be found The Senate hath sent about three several guests To search you out .

Shakespearean: Maybe the letter moved him , For , as I think , they do command him home , Deputing Cassio in his government .

Shakespearean: My lord , this would not be believed in Venice , Though I should swear I saw 't .

Shakespearean: Who , I , my lord ?

Shakespearean: Sir , she can turn , and turn , and yet go on , And turn again .

English: And she can cry , sir , oh , how she can cry !
Shakespearean: And she can weep , sir , weep .

English: Very obedient , keep crying. , Concerning this , oh , what fake emotion ! , I am being ordered home , Get away from me , I'll send for you later. , Sir , I'll obey the order and return to Venice .
Shakespearean: And she's obedient , as you say , obedient , Very obedient. , Proceed you in your tears. , Concerning this , sir , Oh , well-painted passion ! , I am commanded home. , Get you away , I'll send for you anon. , Sir , I obey the mandate And will return to Venice. , Hence , avaunt !

English: Cassio can have my job .
Shakespearean: Cassio shall have my place .

Shakespearean: And , sir , tonight I do entreat that we may sup together .

Shakespearean: Or did the letters work upon his blood And new-create his fault ?

English: be like the fountain that my children and all my descendants flow from , has rejected me !

English: Worse than that , she's polluted herself , so that the fountain is a place where disgusting toads copulate and reproduce !
Shakespearean: Or keep it as a cistern for foul toads To knot and gender in !

Shakespearean: Turn thy complexion there , Patience , thou young and rose-lipped cherubin , , Ay , there , look grim as hell !

English: I don't know .

Shakespearean: He might have chid me so , for , in good faith , I am a child to chiding .

Shakespearean: Alas , Iago , my lord hath so bewhored her , Thrown such despite and heavy terms upon her , That true hearts can not bear it .

Shakespearean: Am I that name , Iago ?

Shakespearean: Hath she forsook so many noble matches , Her father and her country , and her friends , To be called "whore" ?

English: Doesn't that make you want to cry ?
Shakespearean: Would it not make one weep ?

Shakespearean: I will be hanged else !

English: Nobody's that bad .

Shakespearean: The Moor's abused by some most villainous knave , Some base notorious knave , some scurvy fellow .

English: Keep your voice down .

English: Oh , to hell with those people !

Shakespearean: Alas Iago , What shall I do to win my lord again ?

Shakespearean: Here I kneel : If e'er my will did trespass 'gainst his love , Either in discourse of thought or actual deed , Or that mine eyes , mine ears , or any sense , Delighted them , or any other form , Or that I do not yet , and ever did ,

English: then I hope I have a life of misery !
Shakespearean: And ever will , though he do shake me off To beggarly divorcement , love him dearly , Comfort forswear me !

English: Unkindness is powerful , and his unkindness may kill me , but it'll never destroy my love .
Shakespearean: Unkindness may do much , And his unkindness may defeat my life , But never taint my love .

English: I can't say "whore." It makes me sick to say the word even now .
Shakespearean: I can not say "whore , " It does abhor me now I speak the word .

Shakespearean: The business of the state does him offence , And he does chide with you .

English: If only that were all it is , It is , I promise .

English: That's not fair .

English: It's the truth .

Shakespearean: You have told me she hath received them and returned me expectations and comforts of sudden respect and acquaintance , but I find none .

English: You've said what you have to say now .

English: Yes , and I'll do everything I just said .

English: From this moment on I have a higher opinion of you than before .
Shakespearean: Why , now I see there's mettle in thee , and even from this instant to build on thee a better opinion than ever before .

English: Give me your hand , Roderigo .

Shakespearean: I grant indeed it hath not appeared , and your suspicion is not without wit and judgment .

Shakespearean: But , Roderigo , if thou hast that in thee indeed , which I have greater reason to believe now than ever , I mean purpose , courage and valor , this night show it .

English: If you're not having sex with Desdemona tomorrow night , then I suggest you find some way to stab me in the back and kill me .
Shakespearean: If thou the next night following enjoy not Desdemona , take me from this world with treachery and devise engines for my life .

English: Well , what's your plan ?

Shakespearean: Why , then Othello and Desdemona return again to Venice .

Shakespearean: How do you mean , removing of him ?

Shakespearean: Why , by making him uncapable of Othello's place : knocking out his brains .

Shakespearean: And that you would have me to do !

English: I'll be nearby to help you , and between the two of us we can handle him .
Shakespearean: I will be near to second your attempt , and he shall fall between us .

Shakespearean: I will show you such a necessity in his death that you shall think yourself bound to put it on him .

Shakespearean: But for the whole world ?

English: Why , a bad action is just a wrong in this world , but when you've won the whole world , it's a wrong in your own world , so you can make it right then .
Shakespearean: Why the wrong is but a wrong i ' th ' world , and having the world for your labor , 'tis a wrong in your own world , and you might quickly make it right .

Shakespearean: I do not think there is any such woman .

English: Yes , a dozen of them , as many as there are women in the world , in fact .

Shakespearean: But I do think it is their husbands ' faults If wives do fall .

Shakespearean: Say that they slack their duties

Shakespearean: Let husbands know Their wives have sense like them .

Shakespearean: They see and smell And have their palates both for sweet and sour , As husbands have .

English: Is it out of lust ?

Shakespearean: Then let them use us well , else let them know , The ills we do , their ills instruct us so .

Shakespearean: Good night , good night .

Shakespearean: Heaven me such uses send , Not to pick bad from bad , but by bad mend !

Shakespearean: Emilia , run you to the citadel And tell my lord and lady what hath happed. , Will you go on afore ?

Shakespearean: This is the night That either makes me or fordoes me quite .

English: I took the hint and spoke to her .
Shakespearean: Upon this hint I spake .

English: She said she loved me for the dangers I'd survived , and I loved her for feeling such strong emotions about me .
Shakespearean: She loved me for the dangers I had passed , And I loved her that she did pity them .

English: That's the only witchcraft I ever used .
Shakespearean: This only is the witchcraft I have used .

English: Here comes my wife now .
Shakespearean: Here comes the lady .

English: She'll confirm everything .
Shakespearean: Let her witness it .

English: I think a story like that would win my own daughter over .
Shakespearean: I think this tale would win my daughter too .

English: Please let her speak .
Shakespearean: I pray you , hear her speak .

English: If she admits she wanted this , then I won't blame Othello. , Come here , my child .
Shakespearean: If she confess that she was half the wooer , Destruction on my head if my bad blame Light on the man. , Come hither , gentle mistress .

English: Who do you obey here ?
Shakespearean: Do you perceive in all this noble company Where most you owe obedience ?

English: Father , this isn't easy for me .
Shakespearean: My noble father , I do perceive here a divided duty .

English: I'm torn .
Shakespearean: To you I am bound for life and education .

English: You're the one I have to obey .
Shakespearean: You are the lord of duty .

English: I'm your daughter .
Shakespearean: I am hitherto your daughter .

English: I'm finished , then .
Shakespearean: I have done .

English: Duke , please go ahead with your state business .
Shakespearean: Please it your grace , on to the state affairs .

English: I'd rather adopt a child than have one of my own. , Come here , Moor .
Shakespearean: I had rather to adopt a child than get it. , Come hither , Moor .

English: With all my heart , I give you that thing which , if you didn't already have it , I'd try with all my heart to keep from you .
Shakespearean: I here do give thee that with all my heart Which , but thou hast already , with all my heart I would keep from thee .

English: You would have made me treat them like a tyrant. , I'm done , my lord .
Shakespearean: For thy escape would teach me tyranny , To hang clogs on them. , I have done , my lord .

English: Let me refer to a proverb that may help you forgive these lovers : if you can't change something , don't cry about it .
Shakespearean: Let me speak like yourself and lay a sentence Which , as a grise or step , may help these lovers .

English: Please , I'm asking you , go ahead and get back to your state affairs .
Shakespearean: I humbly beseech you , proceed to th ' affairs of state .

English: The Turks are heading for Cyprus with a powerful fleet .
Shakespearean: The Turk with a most mighty preparation makes for Cyprus .

English: She can stay at her father's house .
Shakespearean: Why , at her father's .

English: I won't allow it .
Shakespearean: I'll not have it so .

English: Neither will I .
Shakespearean: Nor I .

English: Dear Duke , please listen to what I have to say .
Shakespearean: Most gracious Duke , To my unfolding lend your prosperous ear And let me find a charter in your voice , T ' assist my simpleness .

English: What do you want to do , Desdemona ?
Shakespearean: What would you , Desdemona ?

English: When I fell in love with Othello I made up my mind that I wanted to live with him .
Shakespearean: That I did love the Moor to live with him , My downright violence and storm of fortunes May trumpet to the world .

English: I saw Othello's true face when I saw his mind .
Shakespearean: I saw Othello's visage in his mind , And to his honors and his valiant parts Did I my soul and fortunes consecrate .

English: Let me go with him .
Shakespearean: Let me go with him .

English: Please allow her to do this .
Shakespearean: Let her have your voice .

English: You can decide that privately .
Shakespearean: Be it as you shall privately determine , Either for her stay or going .

English: What's important is the urgency of this mission .
Shakespearean: Th ' affair cries haste And speed must answer it .

English: You'll have to leave tonight .
Shakespearean: You must away tonight .

English: With all my heart , I'll go right away .
Shakespearean: With all my heart .

English: We'll meet again at nine in the morning .
Shakespearean: At nine i ' th ' morning here we'll meet again .

English: Othello , have one of your officers stay behind to bring you your commission and whatever else is important to you .
Shakespearean: Othello , leave some officer behind And he shall our commission bring to you , And such things else of quality and respect As doth import you .

English: He'll accompany my wife , and bring whatever else you think I might need .
Shakespearean: To his conveyance I assign my wife , With what else needful your good grace shall think To be sent after me .

English: which any peace-lover can do .
Shakespearean: Wherein the toged consuls can propose As masterly as he .

English: His military understanding is all theory , no practice .
Shakespearean: Mere prattle without practice Is all his soldiership .

English: And there's nothing I can do about it .
Shakespearean: Why , there's no remedy .

English: That's the curse of military service .
Shakespearean: Tis the curse of service .

English: Now , you tell me : should I feel loyal to the Moor ?
Shakespearean: Now sir , be judge yourself , Whether I in any just term am affined To love the Moor .

English: If you don't like him you should quit .
Shakespearean: I would not follow him then .

English: No , calm down .
Shakespearean: O sir , content you .

English: I'm serving under him to take advantage of him .
Shakespearean: I follow him to serve my turn upon him .

English: We can't all be masters , and not all masters should be followed .
Shakespearean: We can not all be masters , nor all masters Can not be truly followed .

English: Look at all the devoted servants who work for their masters their whole lives for nothing but their food , and then when they get old they're terminated .
Shakespearean: You shall mark Many a duteous and knee-crooking knave That ( doting on his own obsequious bondage ) Wears out his time much like his master's ass For naught but provender , and when he's old , cashiered .

English: They ought to be whipped for being so stupid .
Shakespearean: Whip me such honest knaves .

English: Let me tell
Shakespearean: These fellows have some soul ,

English: All right , then .
Shakespearean: Let it be so .

English: Treat Desdemona well .
Shakespearean: Use Desdemona well .

English: Keep an eye on her , Moor .
Shakespearean: Look to her , Moor , if thou hast eyes to see .

English: She lied to me , and she may lie to you .
Shakespearean: She has deceived her father , and may thee .

English: Iago , I'm leaving my dear Desdemona with you .
Shakespearean: My life upon her faith ! , Honest Iago , My Desdemona must I leave to thee .

English: Have your wife attend to her , and bring them along as soon as you can .
Shakespearean: I prithee , let thy wife attend on her , And bring them after in the best advantage .

English: Come on , Desdemona , I've only got an hour of love to spend with you , to tell you what you need to do .
Shakespearean: Come , Desdemona , I have but an hour Of love , of worldly matter and direction , To spend with thee .

English: We're on a tight schedule .
Shakespearean: We must obey the time .

English: Iago .
Shakespearean: Iago .

English: What do you have to say , noble friend ?
Shakespearean: What say'st thou , noble heart ?

English: What do you think I should do ?
Shakespearean: What will I do , think'st thou ?

English: Go to bed , and sleep .
Shakespearean: Why , go to bed , and sleep .

English: I'm going to go drown myself .
Shakespearean: I will incontinently drown myself .

English: If you do that , I'll never respect you again .
Shakespearean: If thou dost I shall never love thee after .

English: Why , you silly man !
Shakespearean: Why , thou silly gentleman !

English: Oh , how stupid !
Shakespearean: Oh , villainous !

English: I've been alive for twenty-eight years , and I've never met a man who knew what was good for him .
Shakespearean: I have looked upon the world for four times seven years , and since I could distinguish betwixt a benefit and an injury I never found man that knew how to love himself .

English: I'd rather be a baboon than kill myself out of love for some woman I can't have .
Shakespearean: Ere I would say I would drown myself for the love of a guinea hen , I would change my humanity with a baboon .

English: What should I do ?
Shakespearean: What should I do ?

English: I know it's foolish to be so much in love , but I can't help it .
Shakespearean: I confess it is my shame to be so fond , but it is not in my virtue to amend it .

English: Can't help it ?
Shakespearean: Virtue ?

English: Nonsense !
Shakespearean: A fig !

English: What we are is up to us .
Shakespearean: Tis in ourselves that we are thus or thus .

English: Our bodies are like gardens and our willpower is like the gardener .
Shakespearean: Our bodies are our gardens , to the which our wills are gardeners .

English: Depending on what we plant , weeds or lettuce , or one kind of herb rather than a variety , the garden will either be barren and useless , or rich and productive .
Shakespearean: So that if we will plant nettles or sow lettuce , set hyssop and weed up thyme , supply it with one gender of herbs or distract it with many , either to have it sterile with idleness , or manured with industry , why , the power and corrigible authority of this lies in our wills .

English: If we didn't have rational minds to counterbalance our emotions and desires , our bodily urges would take over .
Shakespearean: If the balance of our lives had not one scale of reason to poise another of sensuality , the blood and baseness of our natures would conduct us to most prepost'rous conclusions .

English: Thankfully , we have reason to cool our raging lusts .
Shakespearean: But we have reason to cool our raging motions , our carnal stings , our unbitted lusts .

English: I don't believe it .
Shakespearean: It can not be .

English: You feel love because you feel lust and you have no willpower .
Shakespearean: It is merely a lust of the blood and a permission of the will .

English: Come on , be a man .
Shakespearean: Come , be a man .

English: Drown yourself ?
Shakespearean: Drown thyself ?

English: Drowning is for cats or blind puppies , don't drown yourself !
Shakespearean: Drown cats and blind puppies !

English: I've told you I'm your friend , and I'll stick by you .
Shakespearean: I have professed me thy friend , and I confess me knit to thy deserving with cables of perdurable toughness .

English: I've never been more useful to you than I will be now .
Shakespearean: I could never better stead thee than now .

English: Here's what you'll do .
Shakespearean: Put money in thy purse .

English: Moors are moody people. , So sell your lands and raise a lot of cash .
Shakespearean: These Moors are changeable in their wills , fill thy purse with money .

English: What seems sweet to him now will soon turn bitter .
Shakespearean: The food that to him now is as luscious as locusts shall be to him shortly as bitter as coloquintida .

English: She'll have to have it .
Shakespearean: She must change for youth .

English: So have your money ready .
Shakespearean: Therefore , put money in thy purse .

English: If you want to go to hell , there are better ways to do it than killing yourself .
Shakespearean: If thou wilt needs damn thyself , do it a more delicate way than drowning .

English: Raise all the money you can .
Shakespearean: Make all the money thou canst .

English: I can get the better of religion and a few flimsy vows between a misguided barbarian and a depraved Venetian girl .
Shakespearean: If sanctimony and a frail vow betwixt an erring barbarian and supersubtle Venetian be not too hard for my wits and all the tribe of hell , thou shalt enjoy her .

English: And to hell with drowning yourself !
Shakespearean: A pox of drowning thyself !

English: That's completely beside the point .
Shakespearean: Tis clean out of the way .

English: You can trust me .
Shakespearean: Thou art sure of me .

English: Go now and get cash .
Shakespearean: Go , make money .

English: I told you before , and I'll tell you again and again : I hate the Moor .
Shakespearean: I have told thee often , and I re-tell thee again and again , I hate the Moor .

English: So let's join forces and get revenge .
Shakespearean: Let us be conjunctive in our revenge against him .

English: Go get money .
Shakespearean: Traverse , go , provide thy money .

English: We'll speak again tomorrow .
Shakespearean: We will have more of this tomorrow .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Adieu .

English: Where will we meet in the morning ?
Shakespearean: Where shall we meet i ' th ' morning ?

English: At my house .
Shakespearean: At my lodging .

English: I'll be there early .
Shakespearean: I'll be with thee betimes .

English: No more talk about killing yourself , okay ?
Shakespearean: No more of drowning , do you hear ?

English: I've changed my mind about that .
Shakespearean: I am changed .

English: Go then , goodbye .
Shakespearean: Go to , farewell .

English: Put a lot of cash together .
Shakespearean: Put money enough in your purse .

English: I'm going to sell all my land .
Shakespearean: I'll sell all my land .

English: That's how I always do it , getting money from fools .
Shakespearean: Thus do I ever make my fool my purse .

English: I'd be wasting my skills dealing with an idiot like that if I couldn't get something useful out of him .
Shakespearean: For I mine own gained knowledge should profane If I would time expend with such a snipe But for my sport and profit .

English: I hate the Moor , and there's a widespread rumor that he's slept with my wife .
Shakespearean: I hate the Moor , And it is thought abroad that 'twixt my sheets He's done my office .

English: I'm not sure it's true , but just the suspicion is enough for me .
Shakespearean: I know not if 't be true , But I , for mere suspicion in that kind , Will do as if for surety .

English: He thinks highly of me .
Shakespearean: He holds me well .

English: Cassio's a handsome man .
Shakespearean: Cassio's a proper man .

English: Let's see , how can I
Shakespearean: Let me see now ,

English: get his position and use him to hurt Othello at the same time ?
Shakespearean: To get his place and to plume up my will In double knavery .

English: How ?
Shakespearean: How ?

English: How ?
Shakespearean: How ?

English: Let's see .
Shakespearean: Let's see .

English: I've worked it out .
Shakespearean: I have 't .

English: What can you see out on the ocean ?
Shakespearean: What from the cape can you discern at sea ?

English: Nothing .
Shakespearean: Nothing at all .

English: It was windy on shore too .
Shakespearean: It is a high-wrought flood .

English: A big blast of wind shook our fortifications .
Shakespearean: Methinks the wind hath spoke aloud at land , A fuller blast ne'er shook our battlements .

English: What do you think will be the result of this storm ?
Shakespearean: What shall we hear of this ?

English: The Turkish navy will be broken up .
Shakespearean: A segregation of the Turkish fleet .

English: The wind's whipping up the waves so high you expect them to reach the clouds and splash against the stars in the sky .
Shakespearean: For do but stand upon the foaming shore , The chidden billow seems to pelt the clouds , The wind-shaked surge , with high and monstrous mane , Seems to cast water on the burning bear , And quench the guards of th ' ever-fixed pole .

English: I've never seen the waters so disturbed .
Shakespearean: I never did like molestation view On the enchafed flood .

English: If the Turkish fleet isn't protected in some harbor , their men must all be drowned .
Shakespearean: If that the Turkish fleet Be not ensheltered and embayed , they are drowned .

English: No ship could survive this storm .
Shakespearean: It is impossible they bear it out .

English: I've got news , boys , the war's over !
Shakespearean: News , lads , Our wars are done !

English: This terrible storm has smashed the Turks so badly that their plans are ruined .
Shakespearean: The desperate tempest hath so banged the Turks , That their designment halts .

English: One of our ships has reported that it saw most of their fleet shipwrecked .
Shakespearean: A noble ship of Venice Hath seen a grievous wreck and sufferance On most part of their fleet .

English: What ?
Shakespearean: How ?

English: Is this true ?
Shakespearean: Is this true ?

English: Michael Cassio , lieutenant of the Moor Othello , has arrived on shore .
Shakespearean: Michael Cassio , Lieutenant to the warlike Moor Othello , Is come on shore .

English: The Moor himself is still at sea .
Shakespearean: The Moor himself at sea And is in full commission here for Cyprus .

English: I'm happy about that .
Shakespearean: I am glad on 't .

English: He'll be a good governor .
Shakespearean: Tis a worthy governor .

English: The two of them were separated during the storm .
Shakespearean: For they were parted With foul and violent tempest .

English: I hope to God Othello's all right .
Shakespearean: Pray heavens he be , For I have served him , and the man commands Like a full soldier .

English: Let's do that .
Shakespearean: Come , let's do so .

English: Every minute we expect more ships to arrive .
Shakespearean: For every minute is expectancy Of more arrivance .

English: Thanks , you brave men who defend this island and respect Othello .
Shakespearean: Thanks , you the valiant of this warlike isle That so approve the Moor .

English: I hope heaven protects him from the weather , because I lost sight of him on the stormy sea .
Shakespearean: Oh , let the heavens Give him defense against the elements , For I have lost him on a dangerous sea .

English: Is his ship sturdy ?
Shakespearean: Is he well shipped ?

English: Yes , it's well built , and the ship's pilot is very expert and experienced .
Shakespearean: His bark is stoutly timbered and his pilot Of very expert and approved allowance Therefore my hopes , not surfeited to death , Stand in bold cure .

English: What's all that shouting about ?
Shakespearean: What noise ?

English: Please go find out for certain who has arrived .
Shakespearean: I pray you sir , go forth And give us truth who 'tis that is arrived .

English: I'll do that .
Shakespearean: I shall .

English: Good lieutenant , is your general married ?
Shakespearean: But good lieutenant , is your general wived ?

English: A man named Iago , the general's ensign .
Shakespearean: Tis one Iago , ancient to the general .

English: Who's that ?
Shakespearean: What is she ?

English: Look , the precious Desdemona has arrived on shore .
Shakespearean: Oh , behold , The riches of the ship is come on shore !

English: We should all kneel before her , men of Cyprus !
Shakespearean: You men of Cyprus , let her have your knees .

English: Greetings , my lady , and may God always be with you .
Shakespearean: Hail to thee , lady , and the grace of heaven , Before , behind thee , and on every hand , Enwheel thee round !

English: Thank you , brave Cassio .
Shakespearean: I thank you , valiant Cassio .

English: Is there any news about my husband ?
Shakespearean: What tidings can you tell me of my lord ?

English: He hasn't arrived yet .
Shakespearean: He is not yet arrived .

English: As far as I know , he's okay and will arrive here soon .
Shakespearean: Nor know I aught But that he's well and will be shortly here .

English: Oh , but I'm worried .
Shakespearean: Oh , but I fear .

English: How did you two get separated ?
Shakespearean: How lost you company ?

English: The storm separated us .
Shakespearean: The great contention of the sea and skies Parted our fellowship , But , hark !

English: Go find out the news .
Shakespearean: See for the news .

English: you , as sure as your name's Roderigo , if I were the Moor I wouldn't want to be Iago .
Shakespearean: For , sir , It is as sure as you are Roderigo , Were I the Moor , I would not be Iago .

English: I'm not who I appear to be .
Shakespearean: I am not what I am .

English: Do it , and shout like the city's on fire .
Shakespearean: Do , with like timorous accent and dire yell As when , by night and negligence , the fire Is spied in populous cities .

English: Hey , Brabantio !
Shakespearean: What , ho , Brabantio !

English: Signor Brabantio , hey !
Shakespearean: Signior Brabantio , ho !

English: Thieves !
Shakespearean: Thieves !

English: Thieves !
Shakespearean: Thieves !

English: Check on your daughter , your house , your money !
Shakespearean: Look to your house , your daughter , and your bags !

English: Thieves !
Shakespearean: Thieves !

English: Thieves !
Shakespearean: thieves !

English: If she gave you as much lip as she gives me , you'd be sick of her by now .
Shakespearean: Sir , would she give you so much of her lips As of her tongue she oft bestows on me , You'll have enough .

English: She's always talking when I want to sleep .
Shakespearean: I find it still , when I have leave to sleep .

English: I admit that in front of you , my lady , she keeps a bit quiet .
Shakespearean: Marry , before your ladyship , I grant , She puts her tongue a little in her heart And chides with thinking .

English: You have no reason to say that .
Shakespearean: You have little cause to say so .

English: Come on , come on .
Shakespearean: Come on , come on .

English: In your own kitchens you act like wildcats .
Shakespearean: You are pictures out of door , bells in your parlors , wild-cats in your kitchens , saints in your injuries , devils being offended , players in your housewifery , and housewives in your beds .

English: Shame on you , you slanderer !
Shakespearean: Oh , fie upon thee , slanderer !

English: No , it's true , or if it's not , I'm a villain .
Shakespearean: Nay , it is true , or else I am a Turk .

English: You wake up to have fun , and you start work when you go to bed .
Shakespearean: You rise to play and go to bed to work .

English: No , I don't .
Shakespearean: No , let me not .

English: But if you had to say something nice about me , what would you say ?
Shakespearean: What wouldst thou write of me , if thou should'st praise me ?

English: Don't make me do it , my lady .
Shakespearean: O gentle lady , do not put me to 't , For I am nothing , if not critical .

English: I'm critical by nature .
Shakespearean: Come on , assay .

English: Yes , madam .
Shakespearean: Ay , madam .

English: I'm not as happy as I seem .
Shakespearean: I am not merry , but I do beguile The thing I am by seeming otherwise .

English: Come on , what would you say about me ?
Shakespearean: Come , how wouldst thou praise me ?

English: Very clever !
Shakespearean: Well praised !

English: Even if she's ugly , she'll be smart enough to find a guy to sleep with her .
Shakespearean: If she be black , and thereto have a wit , She'll find a white that shall her blackness fit .

English: This is getting worse and worse !
Shakespearean: Worse and worse !

English: What if she's pretty but stupid ?
Shakespearean: How if fair and foolish ?

English: You don't know a thing !
Shakespearean: Oh , heavy ignorance !

English: You give your best praise to the worst women .
Shakespearean: Thou praisest the worst best .

English: But how would you praise a truly good woman , someone who had no reason to worry about what anyone said about her ?
Shakespearean: But what praise couldst thou bestow on a deserving woman indeed , one that in the authority of her merit did justly put on the vouch of very malice itself ?

English: A woman who was beautiful but never proud , who could speak well but knew when to be quiet , who dressed well but was never overdressed , who had self-restraint even when she could get what she wanted , a woman who never took revenge , who overlooked it when people hurt her , who was too wise to do anything stupid , who could think without revealing her thoughts , and who could refrain from flirting with men in love with her , that kind of woman , if she ever existed , would , Would do what ?
Shakespearean: She that was ever fair and never proud , Had tongue at will and yet was never loud , Never lacked gold and yet went never gay , Fled from her wish and yet said "Now I may , " She that being angered , her revenge being nigh , Bade her wrong stay and her displeasure fly , She that in wisdom never was so frail To change the cod's head for the salmon's tail , She that could think and ne'er disclose her mind , See suitors following and not look behind , She was a wight , if ever such wights were , To do what ?

English: Would raise babies and clip coupons .
Shakespearean: To suckle fools and chronicle small beer .

English: Oh , that's pathetic !
Shakespearean: Oh , most lame and impotent conclusion !

English: Don't listen to him , Emilia , even though he's your husband .
Shakespearean: Do not learn of him , Emilia , though he be thy husband .

English: What do you think about him , Cassio ?
Shakespearean: How say you , Cassio ?

English: Isn't he a horrible man ?
Shakespearean: Is he not a most profane and liberal counselor ?

English: He speaks bluntly , madam .
Shakespearean: He speaks home , madam .

English: He's more of a soldier than a wise man .
Shakespearean: You may relish him more in the soldier than in the scholar .

English: I recognize his trumpet .
Shakespearean: I know his trumpet .

English: Yes , it is .
Shakespearean: Tis truly so .

English: Let's go greet him when he lands .
Shakespearean: Let's meet him and receive him .

English: Look , here he comes .
Shakespearean: Lo , where he comes !

English: My beautiful warrior !
Shakespearean: Oh my fair warrior !

English: My darling Othello !
Shakespearean: My dear Othello !

English: I'm amazed you got here before me .
Shakespearean: It gives me wonder great as my content To see you here before me .

English: But I'm overjoyed !
Shakespearean: Oh , my soul's joy !

English: If I died right now I'd be completely happy , since I'll probably never be as happy as this again in my life .
Shakespearean: If it were now to die , 'Twere now to be most happy , for I fear My soul hath her content so absolute That not another comfort like to this Succeeds in unknown fate .

English: God willing , our love and our happiness will only increase as we get older .
Shakespearean: The heavens forbid But that our loves and comforts should increase , Even as our days do grow .

English: Amen to that !
Shakespearean: Amen to that , sweet powers !

English: I can't talk about my happiness anymore .
Shakespearean: I can not speak enough of this content .

English: It's too much .
Shakespearean: It stops me here , it is too much of joy .

English: Let's go up to the castle .
Shakespearean: Come , let us to the castle .

English: Good news , friends .
Shakespearean: News , friends !

English: The war's over and the Turks are drowned .
Shakespearean: Our wars are done , the Turks are drowned .

English: How are my old friends from this island doing ? , Honey , they'll love you here in Cyprus .
Shakespearean: How does my old acquaintance of this isle ? , Honey , you shall be well desired in Cyprus , I have found great love amongst them .

English: And bring the ship's captain to the castle .
Shakespearean: Bring thou the master to the citadel .

English: He's a good man. , Let's go , Desdemona .
Shakespearean: He is a good one , and his worthiness Does challenge much respect. , Come , Desdemona , Once more , well met at Cyprus .

English: Meet me down at the harbor. , Come here .
Shakespearean: Do thou meet me presently at the harbor. , Come hither .

English: Lieutenant Cassio will be on guard duty tonight .
Shakespearean: The lieutenant tonight watches on the court of guard .

English: But first , I have to tell you that Desdemona's completely in love with him .
Shakespearean: First , I must tell thee this : Desdemona is directly in love with him .

English: With Cassio ?
Shakespearean: With him ?

English: That's impossible .
Shakespearean: Why , 'tis not possible .

English: Be quiet and listen to me .
Shakespearean: Lay thy finger thus , and let thy soul be instructed .

English: Othello isn't any of those things .
Shakespearean: All which the Moor is defective in .

English: Now , if that's true , and it's obviously true , who's in a better position than Cassio ?
Shakespearean: Now sir , this granted , as it is a most pregnant and unforced position , who stands so eminent in the degree of this fortune as Cassio does ?

English: Besides , he's young and handsome , and he's got all the qualities that naive and silly girls go for .
Shakespearean: Besides , the knave is handsome , young , and hath all those requisites in him that folly and green minds look after .

English: I can't believe that .
Shakespearean: I can not believe that in her .

English: She's very moral .
Shakespearean: She's full of most blessed condition .

English: Like hell she is !
Shakespearean: The wine she drinks is made of grapes .

English: If she were so moral , she would never have fallen in love with the Moor in the first place .
Shakespearean: If she had been blessed , she would never have loved the Moor .

English: Good lord !
Shakespearean: Blessed pudding !

English: Did you see that ?
Shakespearean: Didst not mark that ?

English: They were lusting after each other .
Shakespearean: They met so near with their lips that their breaths embraced together .

English: Disgusting !
Shakespearean: Pish !

English: But listen to me ; let me guide you .
Shakespearean: But , sir , be you ruled by me .

English: I brought you here from Venice .
Shakespearean: I have brought you from Venice .

English: Be on guard duty tonight .
Shakespearean: Watch you tonight for the command , I'll lay 't upon you .

English: Cassio doesn't know you .
Shakespearean: Cassio knows you not .

English: I'll be nearby .
Shakespearean: I'll not be far from you .

English: Make Cassio angry somehow , either by speaking too loud , or insulting his military skills , or however else you want .
Shakespearean: Do you find some occasion to anger Cassio , either by speaking too loud , or tainting his discipline , or from what other course you please , which the time shall more favorably minister .

English: All right .
Shakespearean: Well .

English: He's hot-tempered , and he might try to hit you with his staff .
Shakespearean: Sir , he's rash and very sudden in choler , and haply may strike at you .

English: Try to get him to do that .
Shakespearean: Provoke him that he may .

English: To get what you want , you need to get Cassio out of the way .
Shakespearean: For even out of that will I cause these of Cyprus to mutiny , whose qualification shall come into no true taste again but by the displanting of Cassio .

English: I'll do it , if you help me out .
Shakespearean: I will do this , if you can bring it to any opportunity .

English: I promise I will .
Shakespearean: I warrant thee .

English: Meet me in a little while at the citadel .
Shakespearean: Meet me by and by at the citadel .

English: I need to get Othello's things from the ship .
Shakespearean: I must fetch his necessaries ashore .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Adieu .

English: I won't be satisfied until I get even with him , wife for wife .
Shakespearean: The thought whereof Doth , like a poisonous mineral , gnaw my inwards , And nothing can or shall content my soul Till I am evened with him , wife for wife .

English: If I can't do that , I can at least make the Moor so jealous that he can't think straight .
Shakespearean: Or , failing so , yet that I put the Moor At least into a jealousy so strong That judgment can not cure .

English: For besides the good news , we are also celebrating his marriage .
Shakespearean: For besides these beneficial news , it is the celebration of his nuptial .

English: That's the end of the announcement .
Shakespearean: So much was his pleasure should be proclaimed .

English: There will be a feast from five o'clock until eleven .
Shakespearean: All offices are open , and there is full liberty of feasting from this present hour of five till the bell have told eleven .

English: God bless the island of Cyprus and our noble general Othello !
Shakespearean: Bless the isle of Cyprus and our noble general Othello !

English: Iago's a good man .
Shakespearean: Iago is most honest .

English: Goodnight , Michael .
Shakespearean: Michael , good night .

English: Come talk to me tomorrow as early as you can. , Come with me , my dear love .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow with your earliest Let me have speech with you. , Come , my dear love , The purchase made , the fruits are to ensue : That profit's yet to come 'tween me and you .

English: Good night , everyone .
Shakespearean: Good night .

English: Hello , Iago .
Shakespearean: Welcome , Iago .

English: It's time for us to stand guard .
Shakespearean: We must to the watch .

English: The general got rid of us early tonight so he could be with Desdemona. , I can't blame him .
Shakespearean: Our general cast us thus early for the love of his Desdemona , who let us not therefore blame .

English: What's the reason for this horrible shouting ?
Shakespearean: What is the reason of this terrible summons ?

English: What's the matter ?
Shakespearean: What is the matter there ?

English: Sir , is everyone in your family at home ?
Shakespearean: Signior , is all your family within ?

English: Are your doors locked ?
Shakespearean: Are your doors locked ?

English: Why are you asking me that ?
Shakespearean: Why , wherefore ask you this ?

English: For God's sake , sir , you've been robbed .
Shakespearean: Zounds , sir , you're robbed !

English: Your heart's going to break .
Shakespearean: For shame , put on your gown .

English: It's like half your soul's been ripped out .
Shakespearean: Your heart is burst , you have lost half your soul .

English: At this very minute an old black ram is having sex with your little white lamb .
Shakespearean: Even now , now , very now , an old black ram Is tupping your white ewe .

English: Wake up , wake up , ring a bell and wake up all the snoring citizens .
Shakespearean: Arise , arise , Awake the snorting citizens with the bell Or else the devil will make a grandsire of you .

English: Get up , I tell you !
Shakespearean: Arise , I say !

English: Are you crazy ?
Shakespearean: What , have you lost your wits ?

English: Do you recognize my voice , noble lord ?
Shakespearean: Most reverend signior , do you know my voice ?

English: Not me .
Shakespearean: Not I .

English: Who are you ?
Shakespearean: What are you ?

English: My name's Roderigo .
Shakespearean: My name is Roderigo .

English: I told you not to hang around my house .
Shakespearean: I have charged thee not to haunt about my doors .

English: I've already told you quite plainly that my daughter will never marry you .
Shakespearean: In honest plainness thou hast heard me say My daughter is not for thee .

English: Sir , sir , sir ,
Shakespearean: Sir , sir , sir ,

English: Yes , she's young and tender .
Shakespearean: Indeed she's a most fresh and delicate creature .

English: Like an invitation .
Shakespearean: What an eye she has !

English: But she's modest and ladylike too .
Shakespearean: An inviting eye , and yet methinks right modest .

English: And when she speaks , doesn't her voice stir up passion ?
Shakespearean: And when she speaks , is it not an alarum to love ?

English: She's a perfect woman , it's true .
Shakespearean: She is indeed perfection .

English: Well , good luck to them tonight in bed !
Shakespearean: Well , happiness to their sheets !

English: Not tonight , Iago .
Shakespearean: Not tonight , good Iago .

English: I'm not much of a drinker .
Shakespearean: I have very poor and unhappy brains for drinking .

English: I wish there was less social pressure to drink .
Shakespearean: I could well wish courtesy would invent some other custom of entertainment .

English: Oh , but these are our friends .
Shakespearean: Oh , they are our friends .

English: Just one glass .
Shakespearean: But one cup .

English: I'll do most of the drinking for you .
Shakespearean: I'll drink for you .

English: I've already had a glass of wine tonight , watered down , but look how drunk I am .
Shakespearean: I have drunk but one cup tonight , and that was craftily qualified too , and behold what innovation it makes here .

English: What are you talking about , man ?
Shakespearean: What , man , 'tis a night of revels !

English: Tonight is for celebrating !
Shakespearean: The gallants desire it .

English: Where are they ?
Shakespearean: Where are they ?

English: By the door .
Shakespearean: Here at the door .

English: Please invite them in .
Shakespearean: I pray you call them in .

English: I'll do it , but I don't like it .
Shakespearean: I'll do 't , but it dislikes me .

English: If I can just get him to drink one more glass after what he's drunk already , he'll be as argumentative and eager to fight as a little dog .
Shakespearean: If I can fasten but one cup upon him , With that which he hath drunk tonight already , He'll be as full of quarrel and offense As my young mistress ' dog .

English: Now I'll get Cassio to do something in front of all these drunkards that will offend everyone on the island .
Shakespearean: Now 'mongst this flock of drunkards Am I to put our Cassio in some action That may offend the isle .

English: Here they come .
Shakespearean: But here they come .

English: If the future turns out as I hope it will , I'm all set for success .
Shakespearean: If consequence do but approve my dream My boat sails freely , both with wind and stream .

English: My God , they've given me a lot to drink .
Shakespearean: Fore heaven , they have given me a rouse already .

English: No , it was a little one , not more than a pint .
Shakespearean: Good faith , a little one , not past a pint , As I am a soldier .

English: Bring in more wine !
Shakespearean: Some wine , ho !

English: My God , what a great song !
Shakespearean: Fore heaven , an excellent song .

English: I learned it in England , where they have a talent for drinking .
Shakespearean: I learned it in England where indeed they are most potent in potting .

English: The Danes , the Germans , and the Dutch , come on , drink , drink ! , are nothing compared to the English .
Shakespearean: Your Dane , your German , and your swag-bellied Hollander , Drink , ho ! , are nothing to your English .

English: Are Englishmen really such heavy drinkers ?
Shakespearean: Is your Englishman so expert in his drinking ?

English: They drink Danes under the table , and it takes them no effort at all to out-drink Germans .
Shakespearean: Why , he drinks you with facility your Dane dead drunk ; he sweats not to overthrow your Almain .

English: Let's drink to our general !
Shakespearean: To the health of our general !

English: I'll drink as much as you do !
Shakespearean: I am for it , lieutenant , and I'll do you justice .

English: Oh , sweet England !
Shakespearean: Oh , sweet England !

English: God , that song's even better than the other one .
Shakespearean: Why , this is a more exquisite song than the other .

English: Do you want to hear it again ?
Shakespearean: Will you hear 't again ?

English: No , because we shouldn't be doing that , stuff .
Shakespearean: No , for I hold him to be unworthy of his place that does those things .

English: Oh well , God's in charge , and some people have to go to heaven , while other people have to go to hell .
Shakespearean: Well , heaven's above all , and there be souls must be saved , and there be souls must not be saved .

English: That's true , lieutenant .
Shakespearean: It's true , good lieutenant .

English: Speaking for myself , and no offense to the general or anyone else , I hope I'm going to heaven .
Shakespearean: For mine own part , no offence to the general nor any man of quality , I hope to be saved .

English: Me too , lieutenant .
Shakespearean: And so do I too , lieutenant .

English: Okay , but please not before me .
Shakespearean: Ay , but ( by your leave ) not before me .

English: The lieutenant has to get to heaven before the ensign .
Shakespearean: The lieutenant is to be saved before the ancient .

English: But let's stop this drinking and get down to business. , God forgive our sins ! , Gentlemen , let's get down to business .
Shakespearean: Let's have no more of this , let's to our affairs. , Forgive us our sins ! , Gentlemen , let's look to our business .

English: By the way , I don't want anyone thinking I'm drunk .
Shakespearean: Do not think , gentlemen , I am drunk .

English: I'm not drunk .
Shakespearean: I am not drunk now .

English: I can stand well enough , and I can speak just fine .
Shakespearean: I can stand well enough , and I speak well enough .

English: Yes , you're speaking very well .
Shakespearean: Excellent well !

English: Yes , very well .
Shakespearean: Why , very well then .

English: So don't think that I'm drunk .
Shakespearean: You must not think then that I am drunk .

English: It's too bad .
Shakespearean: Tis pity of him .

English: But is he often like this ?
Shakespearean: But is he often thus ?

English: He drinks like this every night before he goes to sleep .
Shakespearean: Tis evermore the prologue to his sleep .

English: He'd stay up all night and all day if he didn't drink himself to sleep .
Shakespearean: He'll watch the horologe a double set If drink rock not his cradle .

English: The general should be informed about this .
Shakespearean: It were well The general were put in mind of it .

English: Don't you think so ?
Shakespearean: Is not this true ?

English: And it's too bad that the Moor chose a man with such a deep-rooted drinking problem as his second-in-command .
Shakespearean: And 'tis great pity that the noble Moor Should hazard such a place as his own second With one of an ingraft infirmity .

English: We should definitely say something to the Moor .
Shakespearean: It were an honest action to say So to the Moor .

English: Well .
Shakespearean: Why , so .

English: Now I've done a good day's work .
Shakespearean: Now have I done a good day's work .

English: You must all keep up this united front .
Shakespearean: You peers , continue this united league .

English: Don't simply hide your hatred .
Shakespearean: Dissemble not your hatred .

English: Swear your love for each other .
Shakespearean: Swear your love .

English: On my honor , I swear I love Rivers with all my heart .
Shakespearean: And with my hand I seal my true heart's love .

English: And I love Hastings with all my heart .
Shakespearean: And I as I love Hastings with my heart .

English: Take my hand , Hastings .
Shakespearean: You have been factious one against the other. , Wife , love Lord Hastings .

English: Dorset , embrace Hastings. , Hastings , express your affection for the marquess of Dorset .
Shakespearean: Dorset , embrace him. , Hastings , love Lord Marquess .

English: I swear I will never break this promise of love .
Shakespearean: This interchange of love , I here protest , Upon my part shall be inviolable .

English: And so do I , my lord .
Shakespearean: And so swear I .

English: Now , noble Buckingham , seal this alliance by embracing my wife's friends , and make me happy in your unity .
Shakespearean: Now , princely Buckingham , seal thou this league With thy embracements to my wife's allies And make me happy in your unity .

English: Noble Buckingham , your promise is like medicine to my ailing heart .
Shakespearean: A pleasing cordial , princely Buckingham , Is this thy vow unto my sickly heart .

English: And just in time , here he comes with Sir Richard Ratcliffe .
Shakespearean: And in good time , Here comes Sir Richard Ratcliffe and the duke .

English: Good morning to my sovereign king and queen .
Shakespearean: Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen , And , princely peers , a happy time of day .

English: Happy indeed , the way we have spent the day .
Shakespearean: Happy indeed , as we have spent the day .

English: What blessed work , my king .
Shakespearean: A blessed labor , my most sovereign lord .
