English: I hate it and want all good men's love .
Shakespearean: Tis death to me to be at enmity ; I hate it , and desire all good men's love .

English: Today shall always be remembered as a holy day .
Shakespearean: A holy day shall this be kept hereafter .

English: If only all struggles ended this well .
Shakespearean: I would to God all strifes were well compounded .

English: Please pardon our brother Clarence .
Shakespearean: My sovereign lord , I do beseech your Highness To take our brother Clarence to your grace .

English: Why , madam , have I offered you my love only to be flouted in front of the king ?
Shakespearean: Why , madam , have I offered love for this , To be so flouted in this royal presence ?

English: Who doesn't know that the good duke is dead ?
Shakespearean: Who knows not that the gentle duke is dead ?

English: Who doesn't know he's dead ?
Shakespearean: Who knows not he is dead !

English: Who says he is ?
Shakespearean: Who knows he is ?

English: Oh my God , what a terrible world this is !
Shakespearean: All-seeing heaven , what a world is this !

English: Do I look as pale as everyone else does , Lord Dorset ?
Shakespearean: Look I so pale , Lord Dorset , as the rest ?

English: Is Clarence dead ?
Shakespearean: Is Clarence dead ?

English: But I reversed the death sentence .
Shakespearean: The order was reversed .

English: Well , the poor man died by your first order , which was carried by a winged messenger .
Shakespearean: But he , poor man , by your first order died , And that a winged Mercury did bear .

English: Some tardy cripple must have taken the counter-order , who came after Clarence was already buried .
Shakespearean: Some tardy cripple bear the countermand , That came too lag to see him buried .

English: It's clear that someone less noble , less loyal , more bloody-minded than Clarence but not a blood relation , deserves as bad an end as my brother , but he goes free .
Shakespearean: God grant that some , less noble and less loyal , Nearer in bloody thoughts , and not in blood , Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did , And yet go current from suspicion .

English: Please be quiet .
Shakespearean: I prithee , peace .

English: My soul is full of sorrow .
Shakespearean: My soul is full of sorrow .

English: I will not rise until your Highness hears me .
Shakespearean: I will not rise unless your Highness hear me .

English: Then hurry up and tell me what you want .
Shakespearean: Then say at once what is it thou requests .

English: That you lift the death sentence on my servant , who killed a rowdy and belligerent former servant of the duke of Norfolk .
Shakespearean: The forfeit , sovereign , of my servant's life , Who slew today a riotous gentleman Lately attendant on the duke of Norfolk .

English: We know you have a job to do , Brakenbury , and we'll do what you say .
Shakespearean: We know thy charge , Brakenbury , and will obey .

English: Farewell , brother .
Shakespearean: We are the queen's abjects and must obey. , Brother , farewell .

English: It doesn't make either of us happy , I know .
Shakespearean: I know it pleaseth neither of us well .

English: Well , your imprisonment won't last long .
Shakespearean: Well , your imprisonment shall not be long .

English: I will either get you out , lying if I have to , or stay in prison in your place .
Shakespearean: I will deliver you or else lie for you .

English: In the meantime , be patient .
Shakespearean: Meantime , have patience .

English: I have no choice .
Shakespearean: I must perforce .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: Go walk the path that you will never return from .
Shakespearean: Go tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return .

English: I love you so much that I'll send your soul to heaven very soon , if heaven will accept anything from me , that is .
Shakespearean: Simple , plain Clarence , I do love thee so That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven , If heaven will take the present at our hands .

English: But who's coming ?
Shakespearean: But who comes here ?

English: Good afternoon , my dear lord !
Shakespearean: Good time of day unto my gracious lord .

English: The same to you , my lord !
Shakespearean: As much unto my good Lord Chamberlain .

English: Welcome to the open air again .
Shakespearean: Well are you welcome to the open air .

English: How did you tolerate prison ?
Shakespearean: How hath your lordship brooked imprisonment ?

English: But his punishment was bitter death .
Shakespearean: My brother killed no man ; his fault was thought , And yet his punishment was bitter death .

English: Who pleaded with me to pardon
Shakespearean: Who sued to me for him ?

English: This is what happens when you act rashly .
Shakespearean: This is the fruits of rashness .

English: Did you notice how the queen's guilty relatives turned pale when they heard about Clarence's death ?
Shakespearean: Marked you not How that the guilty kindred of the queen Looked pale when they did hear of Clarence ' death ?

English: Oh , they continually urged the king to do it .
Shakespearean: O , they did urge it still unto the king .

English: God will revenge it .
Shakespearean: God will revenge it .

English: But come , lords , will you come with me to Edward's room to comfort him ?
Shakespearean: Come , lords , will you go To comfort Edward with our company ?

English: We'll come with you , your Grace .
Shakespearean: We wait upon your Grace .

English: Tell me , good grandmother , is our father dead ?
Shakespearean: Good grandam , tell us , is our father dead ?

English: No , boy .
Shakespearean: No , boy .

English: My pretty children , both of you misunderstand me .
Shakespearean: My pretty cousins , you mistake me both .

English: So you're admitting Clarence , my father , is dead .
Shakespearean: Then , you conclude , my grandam , he is dead .

English: My uncle the king is to blame for this .
Shakespearean: The king mine uncle is to blame for it .

English: God will take revenge .
Shakespearean: God will revenge it , whom I will importune With earnest prayers , all to that effect .

English: And so will I .
Shakespearean: And so will I .

English: Quiet , children , quiet .
Shakespearean: Peace , children , peace .

English: The king loves you very much .
Shakespearean: The king doth love you well .

English: Innocent sweethearts , you have no idea who's responsible for your father's death .
Shakespearean: Incapable and shallow innocents , You can not guess who caused your father's death .

English: You think my uncle was lying , grandmother ?
Shakespearean: Think you my uncle did dissemble , grandam ?

English: Yes , boy .
Shakespearean: Ay , boy .

English: I can't believe that .
Shakespearean: I can not think it .

English: What's that noise ?
Shakespearean: Hark , what noise is this ?

English: I plan to fall into the blackest despair .
Shakespearean: I'll join with black despair against my soul And to myself become an enemy .

English: Why are the branches still living when the root is gone ?
Shakespearean: Why grow the branches when the root is gone ?

English: Why aren't the leaves withering now that the sap is all dried up ?
Shakespearean: Why wither not the leaves that want their sap ?

English: If you do intend to live , then mourn .
Shakespearean: If you will live , lament .

English: If you're going to die , be quick about it so you can catch the king's departing soul or follow him , like obedient subjects , to his new kingdom of endless night .
Shakespearean: If die , be brief , That our swift-winged souls may catch the king's , Or , like obedient subjects , follow him To his new kingdom of ne'er-changing night .

English: Since your woes are only a portion of mine , I have every reason to surpass your lamentations and drown out your cries with my own .
Shakespearean: O , what cause have I , Thine being but a moiety of my moan , To overgo thy woes and drown thy cries !

English: I could drown the world .
Shakespearean: All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes , That I , being governed by the watery moon , May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world .

English: My poor husband , my dear Edward !
Shakespearean: Ah , for my husband , for my dear lord Edward !

English: Our poor father , Clarence !
Shakespearean: Ah , for our father , for our dear lord Clarence !

English: My sons Edward and Clarence !
Shakespearean: Alas for both , both mine , Edward and Clarence !

English: What support did I have other than Edward ?
Shakespearean: What stay had I but Edward ?

English: And now he's gone .
Shakespearean: And he's gone .

English: What support did we have besides our father ?
Shakespearean: What stay had we but Clarence ?

English: And now he's gone .
Shakespearean: And he's gone .

English: And now they're both gone .
Shakespearean: And they are gone .

English: There has never been a widow who suffered such loss as me .
Shakespearean: Was never widow had so dear a loss .

English: There have never been orphans who've suffered what we have .
Shakespearean: Were never orphans had so dear a loss .

English: There was never a mother who suffered so much loss .
Shakespearean: Was never mother had so dear a loss .

English: Alas , I am the mother of all these others ' griefs .
Shakespearean: Alas , I am the mother of these griefs .

English: She weeps for Edward and so do I , while she does not weep for Clarence , though I do .
Shakespearean: She for an Edward weeps , and so do I ; I for a Clarence weep ; so doth not she .

English: These young children cry for Clarence and so do I , though they don't cry for Edward , as I do .
Shakespearean: These babes for Clarence weep and so do I ; I for an Edward weep ; so do not they .

English: Be a careful mother , madam , and think about your son , the young prince .
Shakespearean: Madam , bethink you , like a careful mother , Of the young prince your son .

English: Your peace of mind depends on him .
Shakespearean: In him your comfort lives .

English: Sister , calm down .
Shakespearean: Sister , have comfort .

English: All of us have reason to mourn the dimming of our shining star the king .
Shakespearean: All of us have cause To wail the dimming of our shining star , But none can help our harms by wailing them. , Madam , my mother , I do cry you mercy ; I did not see your Grace .

English: On my knee , I humbly ask your blessing .
Shakespearean: Humbly on my knee I crave your blessing .

English: God bless you and make you obedient , loving , and kind .
Shakespearean: God bless thee , and put meekness in thy breast , Love , charity , obedience , and true duty .

English: You mournful princes and grieving gentlemen who have been sharing this burden of grief , now it's time to cheer each other up with love .
Shakespearean: You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers That bear this heavy mutual load of moan , Now cheer each other in each other's love .

English: Though we have lost a generous king , we are about to enjoy the benefits of a new king .
Shakespearean: Though we have spent our harvest of this king , We are to reap the harvest of his son .

English: We must preserve our goodwill toward each other and not break into factions again .
Shakespearean: The broken rancor of your high-swoll'n hates , But lately splintered , knit , and joined together , Must gently be preserved , cherished , and kept .

English: I think a few members of the court should fetch the young prince from Wales and bring him to London to be crowned our king .
Shakespearean: Meseemeth good that with some little train Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fet Hither to London , to be crowned our king .

English: Why only a few courtiers , my lord of Buckingham ?
Shakespearean: Why "with some little train , " my Lord of Buckingham ?

English: The king made peace among all of us .
Shakespearean: I hope the king made peace with all of us ; And the compact is firm and true in me .

English: And so do I. I think we all do .
Shakespearean: And so in me , and so , I think , in all .

English: So , I agree with noble Buckingham , only a few should go to meet the prince .
Shakespearean: Therefore I say with noble Buckingham That it is meet so few should fetch the prince .

English: I think so too .
Shakespearean: And so say I .

English: For God's sake , my lord , let's be sure to be part of the group that meets the prince .
Shakespearean: My lord , whoever journeys to the prince , For God's sake let not us two at home .

English: Along the way , I'll find an opportunity to separate him from the queen's proud relatives , as step one in the plan we've discussed .
Shakespearean: For by the way I'll sort occasion , As index to the story we late talked of , To part the queen's proud kindred from the prince .

English: You are my other self , my oracle , my prophet , my dear brother !
Shakespearean: My other self , my council's consistory , My oracle , my prophet , my dear cousin , I , as a child , will go by thy direction Toward Ludlow then , for we'll not stay behind .

English: Good morrow , neighbor , whither away so fast ?
Shakespearean: Good morrow , neighbor , whither away so fast ?

English: I'm telling you , I hardly know myself .
Shakespearean: I promise you I scarcely know myself .

English: Did you hear the news that's going around ?
Shakespearean: Hear you the news abroad ?

English: Yes , that the king is dead .
Shakespearean: Yes , that the king is dead .

English: Neighbors , hello .
Shakespearean: Neighbors , God speed .

English: Good day to you , sir .
Shakespearean: Give you good morrow , sir .

English: Is it true that good King Edward has died ?
Shakespearean: Doth this news hold of good King Edward's death ?

English: Yes , sir , it's all too true , God help us .
Shakespearean: Ay , sir , it is too true , God help the while .

English: Then , gentlemen , we can count on trouble .
Shakespearean: Then , masters , look to see a troublous world .

English: No , no , with God's help , his son will be king .
Shakespearean: No , no , by God's good grace , his son shall reign .

English: It's bad news when a country is ruled by a child .
Shakespearean: Woe to the land that's governed by a child .

English: His counselors will govern as long as he's a minor , and then he'll take over .
Shakespearean: In him there is a hope of government , Which , in his nonage , council under him , And , in his full and ripened years , himself , No doubt shall then , and till then , govern well .

English: With patience , noble lord , as prisoners must .
Shakespearean: With patience , noble lord , as prisoners must .

English: It's a shame that we eagles are caged up while the vultures are free to do whatever they please .
Shakespearean: More pity that the eagle should be mewed While kites and buzzards prey at liberty .

English: What's the news abroad ?
Shakespearean: What news abroad ?

English: Very sad .
Shakespearean: Tis very grievous to be thought upon .

English: Where is he , in his bed ?
Shakespearean: Where is he , in his bed ?

English: He is .
Shakespearean: He is .

English: You go ahead , and I will follow you .
Shakespearean: Go you before , and I will follow you .

English: That's how it was with Henry the Sixth , who was crowned in Paris when he was only nine months old .
Shakespearean: So stood the state when Henry the Sixth Was crowned in Paris but at nine months old .

English: Really ?
Shakespearean: Stood the state so ?

English: It would be better if they were all on his father's side , or that there were none at all on his father's side .
Shakespearean: Better it were they all came by his father , Or by the father there were none at all , For emulation who shall now be nearest Will touch us all too near if God prevent not .

English: Richard , the duke of Gloucester , is very dangerous , and the queen's sons and brothers are haughty and proud , it would be better for this ailing country if they were subjects , not rulers .
Shakespearean: O , full of danger is the duke of Gloucester , And the queen's sons and brothers haught and proud , And were they to be ruled , and not to rule , This sickly land might solace as before .

English: Come , come , we're worrying about the worst-case scenario .
Shakespearean: Come , come , we fear the worst .

English: I'm sure everything will be fine .
Shakespearean: All will be well .

English: When storms arrive early , you can expect the harvest will be damaged .
Shakespearean: Untimely storms make men expect a dearth .

English: So , if all turns out fine , as you say , it's more than we deserve or I expect .
Shakespearean: All may be well ; but if God sort it so , 'T is more than we deserve or I expect .

English: It's always like this in times of change .
Shakespearean: Before the days of change , still is it so .

English: But leave it all to God .
Shakespearean: But leave it all to God .

English: Where are you all off to ?
Shakespearean: Whither away ?

English: The court has sent for us .
Shakespearean: Marry , we were sent for to the justices .

English: They'll be here tomorrow or the next day .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow or next day they will be here .

English: I'm dying to see the prince .
Shakespearean: I long with all my heart to see the prince .

English: I hope he's grown a lot since I last saw him .
Shakespearean: I hope he is much grown since last I saw him .

English: Yes , mother , but I wish I hadn't .
Shakespearean: Ay , mother , but I would not have it so .

English: Why , dear child ?
Shakespearean: Why , my young cousin ?

English: It's good to grow .
Shakespearean: It is good to grow .

English: Yes , " said my uncle Gloucester , "Small plants are graceful , while ugly weeds grow fast." And since then , I've wished I wouldn't grow so fast , because sweet flowers are slow while the weeds grow in a hurry .
Shakespearean: Grandam , one night as we did sit at supper , My uncle Rivers talked how I did grow More than my brother : "Ay , " quoth my uncle Gloucester , "Small herbs have grace ; great weeds do grow apace." And since , methinks I would not grow so fast Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste .

English: Well , it certainly wasn't true for Richard !
Shakespearean: Good faith , good faith , the saying did not hold In him that did object the same to thee !

English: As a child , he took such a long time to grow up that , according to his rule , he should have grown up into a gracious adult .
Shakespearean: He was the wretched'st thing when he was young , So long a-growing and so leisurely , That if this rule were true , he should be gracious .

English: And no doubt he is , gracious madam .
Shakespearean: And so no doubt he is , my gracious madam .

English: I hope he is , but mothers get to have their doubts .
Shakespearean: I hope he is , but yet let mothers doubt .

English: Hey , if I'd remembered something about him , I could have had a good comeback for my uncle , touching on his growth worse than he touched on mine .
Shakespearean: Now , by my troth , if I had been remembered , I could have given my uncle's grace a flout To touch his growth nearer than he touched mine .

English: What would you have said , my young York ?
Shakespearean: How , my pretty York ?

English: Do tell .
Shakespearean: I prithee let me hear it .

English: Indeed , they say my uncle grew so fast that he could gnaw on a crust of bread when he was two hours old .
Shakespearean: Marry , they say my uncle grew so fast That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old .

English: It took me two years before I had a single tooth .
Shakespearean: Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth .

English: Grandmother , this would have been a biting joke .
Shakespearean: Grandam , this would have been a biting jest .

English: Pretty York , who told you about his teeth ?
Shakespearean: I prithee , pretty York , who told thee this ?

English: His nurse , grandmother .
Shakespearean: Grandam , his nurse .

English: His nurse ?
Shakespearean: His nurse ?

English: Why , she was dead before you were even born .
Shakespearean: Why , she was dead ere thou wast born .

English: Well , if it wasn't her , I don't know .
Shakespearean: If 'twere not she , I can not tell who told me .

English: A mischievous child .
Shakespearean: A parlous boy !

English: Come , come , you are too clever for your own good .
Shakespearean: Go to , you are too shrewd .

English: Good lady , don't be angry with the child .
Shakespearean: Good madam , be not angry with the child .

English: Little pitchers have big ears .
Shakespearean: Pitchers have ears .

English: Here comes a messenger .
Shakespearean: Here comes a messenger .

English: What's the news ?
Shakespearean: What news ?

English: My lord , it's news I wish I didn't have to report .
Shakespearean: Such news , my lord , as grieves me to report .

English: How's the prince ?
Shakespearean: How doth the prince ?

English: He's fine and healthy , madam .
Shakespearean: Well , madam , and in health .

English: What is your news ?
Shakespearean: What is thy news then ?

English: The powerful dukes Gloucester and Buckingham .
Shakespearean: The mighty dukes , Gloucester and Buckingham .

English: What did they do wrong ?
Shakespearean: For what offence ?

English: I've told you everything I know .
Shakespearean: The sum of all I can , I have disclosed .

English: Why the nobles were imprisoned , and on what charges , I don't know , my gracious lord .
Shakespearean: Why , or for what , the nobles were committed Is all unknown to me , my gracious lord .

English: Oh no !
Shakespearean: Ay me !

English: I see the downfall of my family .
Shakespearean: I see the ruin of my house .

English: Welcome , destruction , blood , and massacre !
Shakespearean: Welcome , destruction , blood , and massacre .

English: My husband lost his life to get the crown , and my sons ' fortunes have been tossed up and down , leaving me to rejoice over their victories and weep over their losses .
Shakespearean: My husband lost his life to get the crown , And often up and down my sons were tossed For me to joy , and weep , their gain and loss .

English: Let it end , or let me die so I won't have to watch any more of it .
Shakespearean: O , preposterous And frantic outrage , end thy damned spleen , Or let me die , to look on death no more .

English: The tiring journey seems to have made you gloomy .
Shakespearean: The weary way hath made you melancholy .

English: It wasn't the journey itself , uncle , but the troubles we encountered that made it wearisome and dull .
Shakespearean: No , uncle , but our crosses on the way Have made it tedious , wearisome , and heavy .

English: I want more uncles here to welcome me .
Shakespearean: I want more uncles here to welcome me .

English: Those uncles that you wish were here were dangerous .
Shakespearean: Those uncles which you want were dangerous .

English: Your Grace heard their saccharine words , but didn't take note of their poisonous intentions .
Shakespearean: Your Grace attended to their sugared words But looked not on the poison of their hearts .

English: God protect you from them and from other false friends !
Shakespearean: God keep you from them , and from such false friends .

English: God should keep me from false friends , but they weren't false .
Shakespearean: God keep me from false friends , but they were none .

English: My lord , the mayor of London is here to greet you .
Shakespearean: My lord , the mayor of London comes to greet you .

English: God bless your Grace with health and happy days .
Shakespearean: God bless your Grace with health and happy days .

English: And what a slug Hastings is that he hasn't even arrived to tell us whether they're coming !
Shakespearean: Fie , what a slug is Hastings that he comes not To tell us whether they will come or no !

English: And , just in time , here comes the sweaty lord .
Shakespearean: And in good time here comes the sweating lord .

English: Welcome , my lord .
Shakespearean: Welcome , my lord .

English: What , isn't my mother coming ?
Shakespearean: What , will our mother come ?

English: God knows why , but your mother and your brother have taken sanctuary in Westminster Abbey .
Shakespearean: On what occasion God He knows , not I , The queen your mother and your brother York Have taken sanctuary .

English: Your sweet brother wanted to come meet you , but his mother wouldn't let him .
Shakespearean: The tender prince Would fain have come with me to meet your Grace , But by his mother was perforce withheld .

English: I wouldn't commit so serious a crime for anything .
Shakespearean: Not for all this land Would I be guilty of so deep a sin .

English: In these less dainty times , you're not breaking the laws of sanctuary to seize him .
Shakespearean: Weigh it but with the grossness of this age , You break not sanctuary in seizing him .

English: The prince has done neither ; therefore , in my opinion , he isn't really protected by sanctuary .
Shakespearean: This prince hath neither claimed it nor deserved it And therefore , in mine opinion , can not have it .

English: Often I have heard of "sanctuary men , " but until now I've never heard of "sanctuary children." My lord , you've won me over this time .
Shakespearean: Oft have I heard of sanctuary men , But sanctuary children , ne'er till now .

English: Lord Hastings , will you go with me ?
Shakespearean: My lord , you shall o'errule my mind for once. , Come on , Lord Hastings , will you go with me ?

English: I'm coming , my lord .
Shakespearean: I go , my lord .

English: Go as fast as you can .
Shakespearean: Good lords , make all the speedy haste you may .

English: Say , uncle Richard , if my brother comes , where will I stay till my coronation ?
Shakespearean: Say , uncle Gloucester , if our brother come , Where shall we sojourn till our coronation ?

English: Whatever seems best to you .
Shakespearean: Where it seems best unto your royal self .

English: Of all places , I don't like the
Shakespearean: I do not like the Tower , of any place. , Did Julius Caesar build that place , my lord ?

English: He started it , my noble lord , and succeeding generations rebuilt it .
Shakespearean: He did , my gracious lord , begin that place , Which , since , succeeding ages have re-edified .

English: Is it on record that he built it , or is it just word of mouth ?
Shakespearean: Is it upon record , or else reported Successively from age to age , he built it ?

English: On record , my gracious lord .
Shakespearean: Upon record , my gracious lord .

English: Well , I think that even if it weren't on record , the truth would be remembered from one generation to the next , all the way to Doomsday .
Shakespearean: But say , my lord , it were not registered , Methinks the truth should live from age to age , As 'twere retailed to all posterity , Even to the general all-ending day .

English: What did you say , uncle ?
Shakespearean: What say you , uncle ?

English: Death didn't conquer
Shakespearean: Death makes no conquest of this conqueror , For now he lives in fame , though not in life .

English: The king won't live , I hope .
Shakespearean: He can not live , I hope , and must not die Till George be packed with post-horse up to heaven .

English: I'll marry the earl of Warwick's youngest daughter , Lady Anne .
Shakespearean: For then I'll marry Warwick's youngest daughter .

English: So what if I killed her husband and her father ?
Shakespearean: What though I killed her husband and her father ?

English: So that's what I'll do , not because I love her but because I'll get something out of it .
Shakespearean: The readiest way to make the wench amends Is to become her husband and her father ; The which will I , not all so much for love As for another secret close intent By marrying her which I must reach unto .

English: But I'm running ahead of myself .
Shakespearean: But yet I run before my horse to market .

English: Clarence is still alive ; Edward is not only alive , he's king .
Shakespearean: Clarence still breathes ; Edward still lives and reigns .

English: Only when they're dead can I start to count my gains .
Shakespearean: When they are gone , then must I count my gains .

English: What , my dear lord ?
Shakespearean: What , my gracious lord ?

English: Richard of York , how are you doing , my loving brother ?
Shakespearean: Richard of York , how fares our loving brother ?

English: Very well , my supreme lord , that's what I have to call you now .
Shakespearean: Well , my dread lord , so must I call you now .

English: How's my nephew doing , noble lord of York ?
Shakespearean: How fares our cousin , noble Lord of York ?

English: Thank you for asking , uncle .
Shakespearean: I thank you , gentle uncle .

English: Oh , my lord , you once said that lazy weeds grow fast .
Shakespearean: O , my lord , You said that idle weeds are fast in growth .

English: The prince has far outgrown me .
Shakespearean: The prince my brother hath outgrown me far .

English: He has , my lord .
Shakespearean: He hath , my lord .

English: Does that mean he's lazy ?
Shakespearean: And therefore is he idle ?

English: Oh , my handsome nephew , I must not say that .
Shakespearean: O , my fair cousin , I must not say so .

English: In that case , he's more obliged to you than I am .
Shakespearean: Then is he more beholding to you than I .

English: He may command me as my king , but you still have power over me as a relative .
Shakespearean: He may command me as my sovereign , But you have power in me as in a kinsman .

English: Uncle , please give me your dagger .
Shakespearean: I pray you , uncle , give me this dagger .

English: My dagger , little nephew ?
Shakespearean: My dagger , little cousin ?

English: With all my heart .
Shakespearean: With all my heart .

English: Are you begging , brother ?
Shakespearean: A beggar , brother ?

English: From my kind uncle , who I know will give it to me , especially as it's not worth much .
Shakespearean: Of my kind uncle , that I know will give , And being but a toy , which is no grief to give .

English: I'll give you a greater gift than that , nephew .
Shakespearean: A greater gift than that I'll give my cousin .

English: A greater gift ?
Shakespearean: A greater gift ?

English: That must mean a sword .
Shakespearean: O , that's the sword to it .

English: Yes , gentle cousin , if it were light enough for you .
Shakespearean: Ay , gentle cousin , were it light enough .

English: Oh , I see , you will only part with lightweight presents .
Shakespearean: O , then I see you will part but with light gifts .

English: For more important things , you'll say no .
Shakespearean: In weightier things you'll say a beggar nay .

English: A sword's too heavy for you to wear .
Shakespearean: It is too heavy for your Grace to wear .

English: I wouldn't think much of it even if it were heavier .
Shakespearean: I weigh it lightly , were it heavier .

English: What's that ?
Shakespearean: How ?

English: But , uncle , you know how to bear with him .
Shakespearean: Uncle , your Grace knows how to bear with him .

English: You mean , to bear me , not to bear My protector , Richard , insists on it .
Shakespearean: You mean , to bear me , not to bear with me. , Uncle , my brother mocks both you and me .

English: I can't sleep quietly in the Tower .
Shakespearean: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower .

English: Why , what are you afraid of ?
Shakespearean: Why , what should you fear ?

English: My uncle Clarence's angry ghost .
Shakespearean: Marry , my uncle Clarence ' angry ghost .

English: My grandmother told me he was murdered there .
Shakespearean: My grandam told me he was murdered there .

English: I'm not afraid of dead uncles .
Shakespearean: I fear no uncles dead .

English: Nor living ones , I hope .
Shakespearean: Nor none that live , I hope .

English: Well , I hope not .
Shakespearean: An if they live , I hope I need not fear .

English: No doubt , no doubt .
Shakespearean: No doubt , no doubt .

English: Oh , he's a dangerously clever boy , bold , quick-witted , capable .
Shakespearean: O , 'tis a parlous boy , Bold , quick , ingenious , forward , capable .

English: He's his mother's child from head to toe .
Shakespearean: He is all the mother's , from the top to toe .

English: Well , enough about them. , Come here , Catesby .
Shakespearean: Well , let them rest. , Come hither , Catesby .

English: Hastings loved the prince's father so much that we won't be able to persuade him to do anything against the prince .
Shakespearean: He , for his father's sake , so loves the prince That he will not be won to aught against him .

English: What about Stanley ?
Shakespearean: What think'st thou then of Stanley ?

English: Won't he join us ?
Shakespearean: Will not he ?

English: He'll do whatever Hastings does .
Shakespearean: He will do all in all as Hastings doth .

English: Okay , just do this , noble Catesby : sound out Lord Hastings , but make it seem as if you're just mulling over the idea , that it hasn't been firmed up yet .
Shakespearean: Well then , no more but this : go , gentle Catesby , And , as it were far off , sound thou Lord Hastings How he doth stand affected to our purpose And summon him tomorrow to the Tower To sit about the coronation .

English: If he seems game to our plan , encourage him to join us and explain all our reasons .
Shakespearean: If thou dost find him tractable to us , Encourage him and show him all our reasons .

English: But if he's resistant and chilly , then be like that too and break off the conversation .
Shakespearean: If he be leaden , icy , cold , unwilling , Be thou so too , and so break off the talk , And give us notice of his inclination ; For we tomorrow hold divided councils , Wherein thyself shalt highly be employed .

English: Give my regards to Hastings , Catesby .
Shakespearean: Commend me to Lord William .

English: My good lords , I plan to .
Shakespearean: My good lords both , with all the heed I can .

English: Will we hear from you before bedtime , Catesby ?
Shakespearean: Shall we hear from you , Catesby , ere we sleep ?

English: You will , my lord .
Shakespearean: You shall , my lord .

English: You'll find us both at Crosby Place .
Shakespearean: At Crosby Place , there shall you find us both .

English: Now , my lord , what are we going to do if we find that Lord Hastings won't go along with our plans ?
Shakespearean: Now , my lord , what shall we do , if we perceive Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots ?

English: Chop off his head .
Shakespearean: Chop off his head .

English: Whatever we decide to do .
Shakespearean: Something we will determine .

English: And when I'm king , remember to ask me for the earldom of Hereford and all the possessions that go with it , which my brother the king used to own .
Shakespearean: And look when I am king , claim thou of me The earldom of Hereford , and all the moveables Whereof the king my brother was possessed .

English: I look forward to that present .
Shakespearean: I'll claim that promise at your Grace's hands .

English: You'll find I'll give it to you very willingly .
Shakespearean: And look to have it yielded with all kindness .

English: Come , let's have an early dinner so that we have time to work out our plans .
Shakespearean: Come , let us sup betimes , that afterwards We may digest our complots in some form .

English: A messenger from Lord Stanley .
Shakespearean: One from the Lord Stanley .

English: Four o'clock in the morning .
Shakespearean: Upon the stroke of four .

English: Can't Lord Stanley sleep ?
Shakespearean: Can not my Lord Stanley sleep these tedious nights ?

English: I guess not , for good reason , as you'll soon hear .
Shakespearean: So it appears by that I have to say .

English: First , he sends his regards .
Shakespearean: First , he commends him to your noble self .

English: And then ?
Shakespearean: What then ?

English: Besides that , he says that two meetings are going to be held tomorrow , and something may be decided at one of them that may make you and him , who are at the other , sorry .
Shakespearean: Then certifies your Lordship that this night He dreamt the boar had razed his helm Besides , he says there are two councils kept , And that may be determined at the one Which may make you and him to rue at th ' other .

English: While he and I are at one , my loyal servant Catesby will be at the other , so nothing will happen that we won't find out about .
Shakespearean: His Honor and myself are at the one , And at the other is my good friend Catesby , Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us Whereof I shall not have intelligence .

English: Tell your master there is no sound basis for his worries .
Shakespearean: Tell him his fears are shallow , without instance .

English: And as for his dreams , I'm surprised he's so foolish as to trust the fantasies of a restless night .
Shakespearean: And for his dreams , I wonder he's so simple To trust the mock'ry of unquiet slumbers .

English: If we flee from the boar before the boar even pursues us , we'll only make the boar angry and suspicious , causing him to chase us when he never intended to .
Shakespearean: To fly the boar before the boar pursues Were to incense the boar to follow us And make pursuit where he did mean no chase .

English: Good morning , my noble lord .
Shakespearean: Many good morrows to my noble lord .

English: Good day , Catesby .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , Catesby .

English: You're up early .
Shakespearean: You are early stirring .

English: What news can you tell me in this fast-moving , unsteady state of ours ?
Shakespearean: What news , what news in this our tott'ring state ?

English: I believe it won't stop moving and stand upright till Richard wears the wreath of the realm .
Shakespearean: It is a reeling world indeed , my lord , And I believe will never stand upright Till Richard wear the garland of the realm .

English: What do you mean , "wears the wreath" ?
Shakespearean: How "wear the garland" ?

English: Are you talking about the crown ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou mean the crown ?

English: Yes , my good lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , my good lord .

English: I'll have my head cut from my shoulders before I'll see the crown so misplaced .
Shakespearean: I'll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders Before I'll see the crown so foul misplaced .

English: But do you think that's what he's aiming for ?
Shakespearean: But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it ?

English: For that reason he sends you this good news , that this very day your enemies , the queen's relatives , will die at Pomfret .
Shakespearean: Ay , on my life , and hopes to find you forward Upon his party for the gain thereof ; And thereupon he sends you this good news , That this same very day your enemies , The kindred of the queen , must die at Pomfret .

English: Well , I'm not sorry to hear that , because they have always been my enemies .
Shakespearean: Indeed , I am no mourner for that news , Because they have been still my adversaries .

English: Well , let's hope you stay in that noble frame of mind .
Shakespearean: God keep your Lordship in that gracious mind .

English: But as for now , before two weeks have gone by , I'm going to send some people packing .
Shakespearean: Well , Catesby , ere a fortnight make me older I'll send some packing that yet think not on 't .

English: It's a horrible thing to die when you're not prepared for it , my gracious lord .
Shakespearean: Tis a vile thing to die , my gracious lord , When men are unprepared and look not for it .

English: Yes , monstrous , monstrous !
Shakespearean: O monstrous , monstrous !

English: That's how it will be for some other men , too , who think they're as safe as you and I , who are well-loved by noble Richard and Buckingham .
Shakespearean: And so falls it out With Rivers , Vaughan , Grey ; and so 'twill do With some men else that think themselves as safe As thou and I , who , as thou know'st , are dear To princely Richard and to Buckingham .

English: I know they do , and I certainly deserve it .
Shakespearean: The princes both make high account of you , I know they do , and I have well deserved it .

English: You're afraid of the boar but you go around without your spear ?
Shakespearean: Fear you the boar , and go so unprovided ?

English: My lord , good morning .
Shakespearean: My lord , good morrow .

English: Good morning , Catesby .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , Catesby. , You may jest on , but , by the Holy Rood , I do not like these several councils , I .

English: My lord , my life is as important to me as yours is to you , and it was never as precious to me as it is now .
Shakespearean: My lord , I hold my life as dear as you do yours , And never in my days , I do protest , Was it so precious to me as 'tis now .

English: Do you think I would be feeling as triumphant as I am if I didn't know that our situation was secure ?
Shakespearean: Think you but that I know our state secure , I would be so triumphant as I am ?

English: I hope to God I'm proven wrong !
Shakespearean: Pray God , I say , I prove a needless coward !

English: Well , should we head to the Tower ?
Shakespearean: What , shall we toward the Tower ?

English: The day is well on its way .
Shakespearean: The day is spent .

English: Set down your honorable load , men , if there is ever any honor in being dead .
Shakespearean: Set down , set down your honorable load , If honor may be shrouded in a hearse , Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament Th ' untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster .

English: You know what , my lord ?
Shakespearean: Wot you what , my lord ?

English: Those men you just mentioned will be beheaded today .
Shakespearean: Today the lords you talked of are beheaded .

English: They deserved to keep their heads more than some people who have managed to keep their positions .
Shakespearean: They , for their truth , might better wear their heads Than some that have accused them wear their hats .

English: But come , my lord , let's go .
Shakespearean: But come , my lord , let's away .

English: Go on ahead .
Shakespearean: Go on before .

English: I'll talk with this good man .
Shakespearean: I'll talk with this good fellow .

English: What's up , man ?
Shakespearean: How now , sirrah !

English: How's it going ?
Shakespearean: How goes the world with thee ?

English: Better , since your lordship was nice enough to ask .
Shakespearean: The better that your Lordship please to ask .

English: I tell you , man , it's better for me , too , than the last time we met here .
Shakespearean: I tell thee , man , 'tis better with me now Than when thou met'st me last where now we meet .

English: But now , I tell you , keep it to yourself , though , those enemies of mine are being put to death today , and I'm better than I've ever been .
Shakespearean: But now , I tell thee , keep it to thyself , This day those enemies are put to death , And I in better state than e'er I was .

English: Well , let's hope your good fortune continues !
Shakespearean: God hold it , to your Honor's good content !

English: Here , drink to me .
Shakespearean: There , drink that for me .

English: God be good to you !
Shakespearean: I thank your Honor .

English: A nice coincidence , my lord .
Shakespearean: Well met , my lord .

English: I'm glad to see you .
Shakespearean: I am glad to see your Honor .

English: I thank you , Sir John , with all my heart .
Shakespearean: I thank thee , good Sir John , with all my heart .

English: I am indebted to you for your last sermon .
Shakespearean: I am in your debt for your last exercise .

English: By next week , I'll be able to pay you .
Shakespearean: Come the next sabbath , and I will content you .

English: Your friends at Pomfret , they're the ones who need a priest .
Shakespearean: Your friends at Pomfret , they do need the priest ; Your Honor hath no shriving work in hand .

English: When I ran into this holy man , those men you mentioned did come to mind , in fact .
Shakespearean: Good faith , and when I met this holy man , The men you talk of came into my mind .

English: Are you headed to the Tower ?
Shakespearean: What , go you toward the Tower ?

English: I'll be off before you are .
Shakespearean: I shall return before your Lordship thence .

English: Yes , probably , because I'm staying for lunch .
Shakespearean: Nay , like enough , for I stay dinner there .

English: I'll follow you , my lord .
Shakespearean: I'll wait upon your Lordship .

English: Hurry up .
Shakespearean: Dispatch .

English: Your lives are over .
Shakespearean: The limit of your lives is out .

English: Oh , Pomfret , Pomfret !
Shakespearean: O Pomfret , Pomfret !

English: Oh , you bloody prison , fatal and threatening to noble lords !
Shakespearean: O thou bloody prison , Fatal and ominous to noble peers !

English: Now Margaret's curse has fallen on our heads , for standing by and doing nothing when Richard stabbed her son .
Shakespearean: Now Margaret's curse is fall'n upon our heads , When she exclaimed on Hastings , you , and I , For standing by when Richard stabbed her son .

English: She cursed Hastings then .
Shakespearean: Then cursed she Hastings .

English: Oh God , remember to hear her prayer for them , just as for us !
Shakespearean: O , remember , God , To hear her prayer for them , as now for us !

English: But don't kill my sister and her royal sons , be satisfied , dear God , with our blood , which is being spilled unjustly , as you know .
Shakespearean: And for my sister and her princely sons , Be satisfied , dear God , with our true blood , Which , as thou know'st , unjustly must be spilt .

English: Hurry up .
Shakespearean: Make haste .

English: The hour of death is approaching .
Shakespearean: The hour of death is expiate .

English: Come , Grey .
Shakespearean: Come , Grey .

English: Come , Vaughan .
Shakespearean: Come , Vaughan .

English: Let's embrace
Shakespearean: Let us all embrace .

English: In God's name , speak .
Shakespearean: In God's name , speak .

English: When should the royal day be ?
Shakespearean: When is the royal day ?

English: Is everything ready for that event ?
Shakespearean: Is all things ready for the royal time ?

English: It is .
Shakespearean: It is , and wants but nomination .

English: Tomorrow's a good day .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow , then , I judge a happy day .

English: Who knows what the Lord Protector thinks ?
Shakespearean: Who knows the Lord Protector's mind herein ?

English: Who's closest to him ?
Shakespearean: Who is most inward with the noble duke ?

English: You , I think , would best know what he's thinking .
Shakespearean: Your Grace , we think , should soonest know his mind .

English: We know each other's faces , but as for our thoughts , he doesn't know any more about my thinking than I do about yours or his , or you do about mine .
Shakespearean: We know each other's faces ; for our hearts , He knows no more of mine than I of yours , Or I of his , my lord , than you of mine. , Lord Hastings , you and he are near in love .

English: Lord Hastings , you and he are close .
Shakespearean: I thank his Grace .

English: Thank you .
Shakespearean: I know he loves me well .

English: I know he holds me dear , but I haven't asked him about the coronation , and he hasn't told me .
Shakespearean: But for his purpose in the coronation , I have not sounded him , nor he delivered His gracious pleasure any way therein .

English: But you , my noble lords , may name a time , and I'll second it on the duke's behalf , which I don't think he'll mind .
Shakespearean: But you , my honorable lords , may name the time , And in the duke's behalf I'll give my voice , Which I presume he'll take in gentle part .

English: Right on cue , here's the duke himself .
Shakespearean: In happy time here comes the duke himself .

English: My noble lords and relatives , good morning .
Shakespearean: My noble lords and cousins all , good morrow .

English: If you hadn't shown up on cue , my lord , Lord Hastings was going to take your part , I mean , he was going to speak for you , in the crowning of the king .
Shakespearean: Had you not come upon your cue , my lord , William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part , I mean your voice for crowning of the king .

English: No one may be bolder than my Lord Hastings .
Shakespearean: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder .

English: Buckingham , I need to have a word with you .
Shakespearean: Cousin of Buckingham , a word with you .

English: I'll come soon .
Shakespearean: I'll go with you .

English: We have not yet set the coronation day .
Shakespearean: We have not yet set down this day of triumph .

English: Where is my lord , the duke of Gloucester ?
Shakespearean: Where is my lord the duke of Gloucester ?

English: I have sent for the strawberries .
Shakespearean: I have sent for these strawberries .

English: Richard is looking cheerful today .
Shakespearean: His grace looks cheerfully and smooth this morning .

English: You always know he's got some plan that pleases him when he says good morning with such gusto .
Shakespearean: There's some conceit or other likes him well When that he bids good morrow with such spirit .

English: I don't think there's a man under the sun who's worse at hiding his love or hate than Richard .
Shakespearean: I think there's never a man in Christendom Can lesser hide his love or hate than he , For by his face straight shall you know his heart .

English: I pray to God he isn't .
Shakespearean: I pray God he be not , I say .

English: Then see the evidence of their evil with your own eyes .
Shakespearean: Then be your eyes the witness of their evil .

English: If they have done this thing , my noble lord , If ?
Shakespearean: If they have done this deed , my noble lord , If ?

English: You lover of that damned whore , you're talking to me of "ifs" ?
Shakespearean: Thou protector of this damned strumpet , Talk'st thou to me of "ifs" ?

English: You're a traitor. , Off with his head .
Shakespearean: Thou art a traitor , Off with his head .

English: I pity England , but not myself .
Shakespearean: Woe , woe for England !

English: Stanley dreamed the boar beheaded him , and I laughed and refused to flee with him .
Shakespearean: Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm , And I did scorn it and disdain to fly .

English: Three times today my horse stumbled and started when he looked in the direction of the Tower , as if he hated to carry me to this slaughterhouse .
Shakespearean: Three times today my foot-cloth horse did stumble , And started when he looked upon the Tower , As loath to bear me to the slaughterhouse .

English: Oh , now I really need that priest who spoke to me today !
Shakespearean: O , now I need the priest that spake to me !

English: And I regret having bragged to the messenger about how my enemies were being butchered at Pomfret while I , as I said , was in good standing with Richard .
Shakespearean: I now repent I told the pursuivant , As too triumphing , how mine enemies Today at Pomfret bloodily were butchered , And I myself secure in grace and favor .

English: Oh Margaret , Margaret , your heavy curse has now landed on poor Hastings's miserable head !
Shakespearean: O Margaret , Margaret , now thy heavy curse Is lighted on poor Hastings ' wretched head .

English: Make your confession short .
Shakespearean: Make a short shrift .

English: He's eager to see your head .
Shakespearean: He longs to see your head .

English: We spend more time seeking out the fleeting glories of this temporary world than looking to the permanent grace of God !
Shakespearean: O momentary grace of mortal men , Which we more hunt for than the grace of God !

English: Anyone who builds his hopes on air lives like a drunken sailor hanging on a mast , ready with every dizzy nod of his head to tumble to the bottom of the sea .
Shakespearean: Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast , Ready with every nod to tumble down Into the fatal bowels of the deep .

English: Come , come , hurry up .
Shakespearean: Come , come , dispatch .

English: It's pointless to talk now .
Shakespearean: Tis bootless to exclaim .

English: Oh bloody Richard !
Shakespearean: O bloody Richard !

English: Miserable England , I foresee for you the most frightening time you have ever experienced. , Come , lead me to the block .
Shakespearean: Miserable England , I prophesy the fearfull'st time to thee That ever wretched age hath looked upon. , Come , lead me to the block .

English: Bring him my head .
Shakespearean: Bear him my head .

English: Those who smile at it will soon be dead themselves .
Shakespearean: They smile at me that shortly shall be dead .

English: Frightening looks are also at my service , as are fake smiles .
Shakespearean: Ghastly looks Are at my service , like enforced smiles , And both are ready in their offices , At any time to grace my stratagems .

English: But has Catesby gone ?
Shakespearean: But what , is Catesby gone ?

English: A drum !
Shakespearean: Catesby , o'erlook the walls .

English: And if he ever has a wife , let her be more miserable when he dies than I am now .
Shakespearean: If ever he have wife , let her be made More miserable by the death of him Than I am made by my poor lord and thee. , Come now towards Chertsey with your holy load , Taken from Paul's to be interred there .

English: What wicked magician has conjured up this devil to interrupt this sacred burial rite ?
Shakespearean: What black magician conjures up this fiend To stop devoted charitable deeds ?

English: Lord Mayor , the reason we have sent , Look behind you !
Shakespearean: Lord Mayor , the reason we have sent , Look back !

English: Defend yourself !
Shakespearean: Defend thee !

English: There are enemies here .
Shakespearean: Here are enemies .

English: God defend and guard us innocents against them !
Shakespearean: God and our innocence defend and guard us !

English: Stay calm .
Shakespearean: Be patient .

English: They're friends , Ratcliffe and Lovell .
Shakespearean: They are friends , Ratcliffe and Lovell .

English: Here's the head of that notorious traitor , the dangerous and unsuspected Hastings .
Shakespearean: Here is the head of that ignoble traitor , The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings .

English: I loved this man so much it makes me weep .
Shakespearean: So dear I loved the man that I must weep .

English: He was so slick in covering over his plans that if it hadn't been for his love affair with Shore's wife , I would never have suspected him .
Shakespearean: So smooth he daubed his vice with show of virtue That , his apparent open guilt omitted , I mean his conversation with Shore's wife , He lived from all attainder of suspects .

English: He would have ?
Shakespearean: Had he done so ?

English: What , do you think we're Turks or savages , instead of Christians ?
Shakespearean: What , think you we are Turks or infidels ?

English: I didn't expect any better from him once he got involved with Mistress Shore .
Shakespearean: I never looked for better at his hands After he once fell in with Mistress Shore .

English: But , my good lord , the words of you and Lord Buckingham are as trustworthy to me as if I had seen and heard him speak myself .
Shakespearean: But , my good lord , your Graces ' words shall serve As well as I had seen and heard him speak ; And do not doubt , right noble princes both , But I'll acquaint our duteous citizens With all your just proceedings in this case .

English: That is exactly why we wanted you here , your lordship , to avoid the public carping and complaints .
Shakespearean: And to that end we wished your Lordship here T ' avoid the censures of the carping world .

English: There was no limit to what his lustful eye and savage heart would prey on .
Shakespearean: Moreover , urge his hateful luxury And bestial appetite in change of lust , Which stretched to their servants , daughters , wives , Even where his raging eye or savage heart , Without control , lusted to make his prey .

English: And , if you need to , approach the subject of me : tell them that when my mother became pregnant with the insatiable Edward , my noble father was fighting in France .
Shakespearean: Nay , for a need , thus far come near my person : Tell them when that my mother went with child Of that insatiate Edward , noble York My princely father then had wars in France , And , by true computation of the time , Found that the issue was not his begot , Which well appeared in his lineaments , Being nothing like the noble duke my father .

English: But only hint at this vaguely , because , as you know , my mother's still alive .
Shakespearean: Yet touch this sparingly , as 'twere far off , Because , my lord , you know my mother lives .

English: Goodbye , my lord .
Shakespearean: And so , my lord , adieu .

English: If things go well , bring the crowd to I'm off .
Shakespearean: If you thrive well , bring them to Baynard's Castle , Where you shall find me well accompanied With reverend fathers and well-learned bishops .

English: Around three or four o'clock , look for news from the meeting hall .
Shakespearean: I go ; and towards three or four o'clock Look for the news that the Guildhall affords .

English: Lovell , go as fast as you can to Doctor Shaw .
Shakespearean: Go , Lovell , with all speed to Doctor Shaw .

English: Now I'll go inside and write out a secret order to keep Clarence's brats out of sight and to forbid anyone whatsoever from seeing King Edward's sons .
Shakespearean: Now will I go to take some privy order To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight , And to give order that no manner of person Have any time recourse unto the princes .

English: What a backward world we live in !
Shakespearean: Here's a good world the while .

English: Why , who's so stupid that he can't see through this fraud ?
Shakespearean: Who is so gross That can not see this palpable device ?

English: The world is a bad place , where you can't speak what you know .
Shakespearean: Bad is the world , and all will come to naught When such ill dealing must be seen in thought .

English: It's incredible , they didn't say a word .
Shakespearean: Now , by the holy mother of our Lord , The citizens are mum , say not a word .

English: Did you mention that Edward's children are bastards ?
Shakespearean: Touched you the bastardy of Edward's children ?

English: I did .
Shakespearean: No .

English: He said that the people weren't used to being spoken to except by the What blocks of wood !
Shakespearean: His answer was , the people were not used To be spoke to but by the recorder .

English: They wouldn't say anything ?
Shakespearean: Would not they speak ?

English: Aren't the mayor and his fellow citizens coming ?
Shakespearean: Will not the mayor then and his brethren come ?

English: The mayor is here at hand .
Shakespearean: The mayor is here at hand .

English: And make sure to carry a prayer book in your hand and to stand between two priests , okay ?
Shakespearean: And look you get a prayer book in your hand And stand between two churchmen , good my lord , For on that ground I'll make a holy descant .

English: But don't be easily won over .
Shakespearean: And be not easily won to our requests .

English: I'm going now .
Shakespearean: I go .

English: If you're as good at pleading to them as I am at saying no to you , this will definitely come to a happy end .
Shakespearean: An if you plead as well for them As I can say "nay" to thee for myself , No doubt we bring it to a happy issue .

English: Hurry , go up to the roof .
Shakespearean: Go , go , up to the leads .

English: The Lord Mayor is knocking .
Shakespearean: The Lord Mayor knocks .

English: Welcome , my lord .
Shakespearean: Welcome , my lord .

English: I don't think he wants to be disturbed .
Shakespearean: I think the duke will not be spoke withal .

English: Now , Catesby , what does your lord say to my request ?
Shakespearean: Now , Catesby , what says your lord to my request ?

English: My lord , he asks that you please visit him tomorrow or the next day .
Shakespearean: He doth entreat your Grace , my noble lord , To visit him tomorrow or next day .

English: Return to the gracious duke , good Catesby .
Shakespearean: Return , good Catesby , to the gracious duke .

English: Tell him that the mayor , some citizens , and I have come to confer with his grace in matters of great importance concerning the general good .
Shakespearean: Tell him myself , the mayor , and aldermen , No less importing than our general good , In deep designs , and matters of great moment Are come to have some conference with his grace .

English: I'll tell him right away , my lord .
Shakespearean: I'll signify so much unto him straight .

English: Ah , my lord , this prince is nothing like Edward !
Shakespearean: Ah , ha , my lord , this prince is not an Edward !

English: He's not sleeping to fatten up his lazy body , but praying , to nourish his attentive soul .
Shakespearean: He is not lolling on a lewd love bed , But on his knees at meditation ; Not dallying with a brace of courtesans , But meditating with two deep divines ; Not sleeping , to engross his idle body , But praying , to enrich his watchful soul .

English: England would be lucky to have this virtuous prince as king .
Shakespearean: Happy were England would this virtuous prince Take on his grave the sovereignty thereof .

English: But I'm afraid we'll never get him to agree to be king .
Shakespearean: But sure I fear we shall not win him to it .

English: But God forbid he says no to us !
Shakespearean: Marry , God defend his grace should say us nay !

English: I'm afraid he will .
Shakespearean: I fear he will .

English: Here comes Catesby again .
Shakespearean: Here Catesby comes again .

English: What's up , Catesby , what does your master say ?
Shakespearean: Now , Catesby , what says his grace ?

English: My lord , he wonders why you have assembled such troops of citizens to speak with him , since he had no idea they were coming .
Shakespearean: He wonders to what end you have assembled Such troops of citizens to come to him , His grace not being warned thereof before .

English: My lord , he's afraid you mean him harm .
Shakespearean: He fears , my lord , you mean no good to him .

English: I'm sorry my noble brother is suspicious of me .
Shakespearean: Sorry I am my noble cousin should Suspect me that I mean no good to him .

English: When devoutly religious men are praying , it's hard to draw them out of it , because they get lost in the wonder of their contemplation .
Shakespearean: When holy and devout religious men Are at their beads , 'tis much to draw them thence , So sweet is zealous contemplation .

English: See how he stands between two clergymen !
Shakespearean: See where his Grace stands , 'tween two clergymen .

English: My lord , you don't need to apologize .
Shakespearean: My lord , there needs no such apology .

English: I beg you to pardon me .
Shakespearean: I do beseech your Grace pardon me , Who , earnest in the service of my God , Deferred the visitation of my friends .

English: I suspect that I have committed some offence to the city and you have come to reprimand me for not knowing better .
Shakespearean: I do suspect I have done some offense That seems disgracious in the city's eye , And that you come to reprehend my ignorance .

English: You have , my lord .
Shakespearean: You have , my lord .

English: Sweet saint , for goodness's sake , don't be so angry .
Shakespearean: Sweet saint , for charity , be not so curst .

English: If you enjoy looking at your awful deeds , take a look at this noteworthy example of your butcheries .
Shakespearean: If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds , Behold this pattern of thy butcheries .

English: It's your presence that draws out this blood from his empty veins .
Shakespearean: O , gentlemen , see , see dead Henry's wounds Open their congealed mouths and bleed afresh ! , Blush , blush , thou lump of foul deformity , For 'tis thy presence that exhales this blood From cold and empty veins where no blood dwells .

English: Oh earth , which soaks up this blood , revenge his death !
Shakespearean: O earth , which this blood drink'st revenge his death !

English: Either let heaven send lightning to strike the murderer dead or let the earth open wide and devour him , as it does this good king's blood .
Shakespearean: Either heaven with lightning strike the murderer dead , Or earth gape open wide and eat him quick , As thou dost swallow up this good king's blood , Which his hell-governed arm hath butchered !

English: If I don't answer , perhaps you'll think I'm accepting the heavy responsibility you foolishly want to impose on me .
Shakespearean: If not to answer , you might haply think Tongue-tied ambition , not replying , yielded To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty , Which fondly you would here impose on me .

English: First of all , even if all the obstacles were eliminated and my path led straight to the crown , if it were truly my birthright , I would rather hide from my greatness than hide inside the greatness of the position itself and be smothered by it .
Shakespearean: First , if all obstacles were cut away And that my path were even to the crown As the ripe revenue and due of birth , Yet so much is my poverty of spirit , So mighty and so many my defects , That I would rather hide me from my greatness , Being a bark to brook no mighty sea , Than in my greatness covet to be hid And in the vapor of my glory smothered .

English: So , thank God , there is no real need for me , as I wouldn't be able to help you much .
Shakespearean: But , God be thanked , there is no need of me , And much I need to help you , were there need .

English: The royal tree has left us other fruit , which , with time , will do just fine on the throne and make us all happy as king , I'm sure .
Shakespearean: The royal tree hath left us royal fruit , Which , mellowed by the stealing hours of time , Will well become the seat of majesty , And make , no doubt , us happy by his reign .

English: God forbid that I snatch the crown from him .
Shakespearean: On him I lay what you would lay on me , The right and fortune of his happy stars , Which God defend that I should wring from him .

English: King Edward was going to marry Lady Lucy , your mother can vouch for that , and then he was betrothed to Bona , the King of France's sister-in-law .
Shakespearean: For first was he contract to Lady Lucy , Your mother lives a witness to that vow , And afterward by substitute betrothed To Bona , sister to the king of France .

English: But both of these were put off by Elizabeth Grey , a careworn mother of many children who had once been a beauty but was now a stressed-out widow long past her prime .
Shakespearean: These both put off , a poor petitioner , A care-crazed mother to a many sons , A beauty-waning and distressed widow , Even in the afternoon of her best days , Made prize and purchase of his wanton eye , Seduced the pitch and height of his degree To base declension and loathed bigamy .

English: Don't refuse the love we offer you .
Shakespearean: Refuse not , mighty lord , this proffered love .

English: Oh , make them joyful !
Shakespearean: O , make them joyful .

English: Grant their law-abiding request !
Shakespearean: Grant their lawful suit .

English: Alas , why would you heap all these responsibilities on me ?
Shakespearean: Alas , why would you heap this care on me ?

English: I am unfit to rule and to be king .
Shakespearean: I am unfit for state and majesty .

English: Please , don't take it badly , but I can not and will not give in to you .
Shakespearean: I do beseech you , take it not amiss ; I can not , nor I will not , yield to you .

English: But listen , if
Shakespearean: Zounds , I'll entreat no more .

English: Oh , please don't swear , my lord of Buckingham .
Shakespearean: O , do not swear , my lord of Buckingham !

English: If you refuse it , the whole country will regret it .
Shakespearean: If you deny them , all the land will rue it .

English: Would you tie me to a whole world of worries ?
Shakespearean: Will you enforce me to a world of cares ?

English: Well , call them back again .
Shakespearean: Call them again .

English: I am not made of stone ; I am affected by all these kind pleas , though it goes against my conscience and my soul .
Shakespearean: I am not made of stones , But penetrable to your kind entreaties , Albeit against my conscience and my soul .

English: God bless your Grace !
Shakespearean: God bless your Grace !

English: We understand you're just doing it for us , and we'll be sure to say so .
Shakespearean: We see it and will say it .

English: If you say that , you'll only be telling the truth .
Shakespearean: In saying so , you shall but say the truth .

English: Then I salute you with this royal title : long live Richard , England's worthy king !
Shakespearean: Then I salute you with this royal title : Long live Richard , England's worthy king !

English: Amen .
Shakespearean: Amen .

English: Will you be crowned tomorrow ?
Shakespearean: Tomorrow will it please you to be crowned ?

English: Whenever you want , since you're the one who wants it .
Shakespearean: Even when you please , since you will have it so .

English: Who's this ?
Shakespearean: Who meets us here ?

English: My granddaughter , with her kind aunt , the duchess of Gloucester , leading her by the hand ?
Shakespearean: My niece Plantagenet Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester ?

English: Now , on my life , the young child must be headed to the Tower to greet the young princes , whom she adores .
Shakespearean: Now , for my life , she's wandering to the Tower , On pure heart's love , to greet the tender prince. , Daughter , well met .

English: Where are you going ?
Shakespearean: Whither away ?

English: Just to the Tower , I'm guessing , for the same reason you are : to salute the noble princes who are staying there .
Shakespearean: No farther than the Tower , and , as I guess , Upon the like devotion as yourselves , To gratulate the gentle princes there .

English: Yes , kind sister .
Shakespearean: Kind sister , thanks .

English: We can all go together .
Shakespearean: We'll enter all together .

English: And here comes the warden , just in time .
Shakespearean: And in good time here the lieutenant comes. , Master Lieutenant , pray you , by your leave , How doth the prince and my young son of York ?

English: They're just fine , my dear madam .
Shakespearean: Right well , dear madam .

English: But I'm sorry , I'm not allowed to let you visit them .
Shakespearean: By your patience , I may not suffer you to visit them .

English: The king has strictly forbidden it .
Shakespearean: The king hath strictly charged the contrary .

English: The king ?
Shakespearean: The king ?

English: Who's that ?
Shakespearean: Who's that ?

English: I meant to say the Lord Protector .
Shakespearean: I mean , the Lord Protector .

English: The Lord keep him from the title of king !
Shakespearean: The Lord protect him from that kingly title !

English: Richard has set boundaries between my love and theirs ?
Shakespearean: Hath he set bounds between their love and me ?

English: I am their mother .
Shakespearean: I am their mother .

English: Who's going to keep me from them ?
Shakespearean: Who shall bar me from them ?

English: I am their father's mother .
Shakespearean: I am their father's mother .

English: I will see them .
Shakespearean: I will see them .

English: I am their aunt , and I love them like a mother .
Shakespearean: Their aunt I am in law , in love their mother .

English: So take me to see them .
Shakespearean: Then bring me to their sights .

English: Officer , I'll take the responsibility from you , and the blame too .
Shakespearean: I'll bear thy blame And take thy office from thee , on my peril .

English: No , madam , no .
Shakespearean: No , madam , no .

English: I can't do this .
Shakespearean: I may not leave it so .

English: I am bound by oath , so please forgive me .
Shakespearean: I am bound by oath , and therefore pardon me .

English: In just an hour from now , Duchess of York , I'll be saluting you as the mother of two beautiful queens .
Shakespearean: Let me but meet you ladies one hour hence , And I'll salute your Grace of York as mother And reverend looker-on , of two fair queens .

English: Oh , cut my bodice-staps so that my pent-up heart can have some room to breathe , or I'll faint from this deadly news !
Shakespearean: Ah , cut my lace asunder , That my pent heart may have some scope to beat , Or else I swoon with this dead-killing news !

English: Cruel , cruel news !
Shakespearean: O , unpleasing news !

English: Your mother's name has become a threat to her own children .
Shakespearean: Thy mother's name is ominous to children .

English: I'll write to my stepson Richmond on your behalf , so that he'll meet you on the way .
Shakespearean: You shall have letters from me to my son In your behalf , to meet you on the way .

English: But don't delay .
Shakespearean: Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay .

English: O , this evil wind that spreads nothing but misery .
Shakespearean: O ill-dispersing wind of misery !

English: It has hatched a I go unwillingly .
Shakespearean: And I in all unwillingness will go .

English: I wish to God that the golden crown that I'll have to wear were red-hot steel and burned me straight through to the brain !
Shakespearean: O , would to God that the inclusive verge Of golden metal that must round my brow Were red-hot steel to sear me to the brains !

English: If you want to make me happy , don't wish yourself harm .
Shakespearean: To feed my humor , wish thyself no harm .

English: No ?
Shakespearean: No ?

English: Why ?
Shakespearean: Why ?

English: Every night I'm awakened by his Poor dear , goodbye .
Shakespearean: Poor heart , adieu .

English: I pity your situation .
Shakespearean: I pity thy complaining .

English: No more than I do yours .
Shakespearean: No more than from my soul I mourn for yours .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Farewell , thou woeful welcomer of glory .

English: You are a rude , ragged nurse and an old , sullen playmate for such tender princes .
Shakespearean: Rude ragged nurse , old sullen playfellow For tender princes , use my babies well .

English: Please treat my babies well .
Shakespearean: So foolish sorrows bids your stones farewell .

English: Dear woman , you don't know the rules of charity .
Shakespearean: Lady , you know no rules of charity , Which renders good for bad , blessings for curses .

English: Villain , you don't know the laws of God or of man .
Shakespearean: Villain , thou know'st not law of God nor man .

English: Even the fiercest wild animal has some touch of pity .
Shakespearean: No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity .

English: If I know nothing about pity , that must mean I'm not an animal .
Shakespearean: But I know none , and therefore am no beast .

English: It's even stranger when an angel is so angry .
Shakespearean: More wonderful , when angels are so angry .

English: Divine , perfect woman , give me a chance to prove in detail that I'm innocent of the evils you accuse me of .
Shakespearean: Vouchsafe , divine perfection of a woman , Of these supposed crimes to give me leave By circumstance but to acquit myself .

English: Contagious infection of humanity , give me a chance to condemn you for the evils I know you've committed .
Shakespearean: Vouchsafe , defused infection of a man , Of these known evils but to give me leave By circumstance to curse thy cursed self .

English: You who are beautiful beyond words , calm down and let me explain myself .
Shakespearean: Fairer than tongue can name thee , let me have Some patient leisure to excuse myself .

English: You who are wicked beyond belief , the only "explanation" I'll accept from you is for you to hang yourself .
Shakespearean: Fouler than heart can think thee , thou canst make No excuse current but to hang thyself .

English: Such an expression of despair would only prove that I was guilty .
Shakespearean: By such despair I should accuse myself .

English: My gracious king .
Shakespearean: My gracious sovereign .

English: Give me your hand .
Shakespearean: Give me thy hand .

English: Because of your advice and your help , I have a high position now .
Shakespearean: Thus high , by thy advice And thy assistance is King Richard seated .

English: But will I wear these honors for only a day or will I enjoy them for a long time ?
Shakespearean: But shall we wear these glories for a day , Or shall they last and we rejoice in them ?

English: Let them last forever .
Shakespearean: Still live they , and forever let them last .

English: Oh Buckingham , now I'm going to test to see if you're truly made of gold .
Shakespearean: Ah , Buckingham , now do I play the touch , To try if thou be current gold indeed .

English: Young Prince Edward is still alive , what do you think I'm going to say next ?
Shakespearean: Young Edward lives ; think now what I would speak .

English: Go on , my loving lord .
Shakespearean: Say on , my loving lord .

English: Ha !
Shakespearean: Ha !

English: But Edward is still alive .
Shakespearean: Tis so , but Edward lives .

English: True , noble prince .
Shakespearean: True , noble prince .

English: Oh , how bitter it is that Edward , the real "true , noble prince" , should still be alive !
Shakespearean: O bitter consequence That Edward still should live "true noble prince" !

English: Cousin , you didn't used to be so thickheaded .
Shakespearean: Cousin , thou wast not wont to be so dull .

English: Shall I put it plainly ?
Shakespearean: Shall I be plain ?

English: What do you say ?
Shakespearean: What sayest thou now ?

English: Your Grace can do whatever he wants .
Shakespearean: Your Grace may do your pleasure .

English: Tut , tut , you've become rather icy .
Shakespearean: Tut , tut , thou art all ice ; thy kindness freezes .

English: Tell me , do I have your consent to kill them ?
Shakespearean: Say , have I thy consent that they shall die ?

English: Give me a little breathing space , my lord , a little pause to think .
Shakespearean: Give me some little breath , some pause , dear lord , Before I positively speak in this .

English: I'll let you know my answer shortly .
Shakespearean: I will resolve you herein presently .

English: My lord ?
Shakespearean: And unrespective boys .

English: Do you know anyone who would kill someone for money ?
Shakespearean: Know'st thou not any whom corrupting gold Will tempt unto a close exploit of death ?

English: What's his name ?
Shakespearean: What is his name ?

English: His name is Tyrrel , my lord .
Shakespearean: His name , my lord , is Tyrrel .

English: I know the man a bit .
Shakespearean: I partly know the man .

English: Go , bring him here , boy .
Shakespearean: Go , call him hither , boy No more shall be the neighbor to my counsels Hath he so long held out with me , untired , And stops he now for breath ?

English: Look who's here !
Shakespearean: Well , be it so .

English: What's the news with you ?
Shakespearean: How now , Lord Stanley , what's the news ?

English: You should know , my loving lord , I've heard that the marquess Dorset has fled to Brittany , to the earl of Richmond .
Shakespearean: Know , my long lord , The marquess Dorset , as I hear , is fled To Richmond , in the parts where he abides .

English: Come here , Catesby .
