Shakespearean: Come hither , Catesby .

English: Spread the rumor abroad that Anne , my wife , is very sick .
Shakespearean: Rumor it abroad That Anne my wife is very grievous sick .

English: And find a poverty stricken gentleman who I can marry straightaway to Clarence's daughter .
Shakespearean: Inquire me out some mean poor gentleman , Whom I will marry straight to Clarence ' daughter .

English: Look at you , standing there in a stupor !
Shakespearean: Look how thou dream'st !

English: I repeat , spread the rumor that Anne , my wife , is sick and likely to die .
Shakespearean: I say again , give out That Anne my queen is sick and like to die .

English: Are you Tyrrel ?
Shakespearean: Is thy name Tyrrel ?

English: James Tyrrel , and your most obedient subject .
Shakespearean: James Tyrrel , and your most obedient subject .

English: Are you indeed ?
Shakespearean: Art thou indeed ?

English: Do you dare kill a friend of mine ?
Shakespearean: Dar'st thou resolve to kill a friend of mine ?

English: Well , that's what you get to do .
Shakespearean: Why then , thou hast it .

English: Two great enemies , in fact , enemies to my peace of mind .
Shakespearean: Two deep enemies , Foes to my rest , and my sweet sleep's disturbers , Are they that I would have thee deal upon .

English: Tyrrel , I mean those bastards in the Tower .
Shakespearean: Tyrrel , I mean those bastards in the Tower .

English: Give me access to them , and soon you won't have to worry about them anymore .
Shakespearean: Let me have open means to come to them , And soon I'll rid you from the fear of them .

English: That's music to my ears .
Shakespearean: Thou sing'st sweet music .

English: Come here , Tyrrel .
Shakespearean: Hark , come hither , Tyrrel .

English: By this token , you'll be admitted to their cell .
Shakespearean: Go , by this token .

English: Get up and listen to me .
Shakespearean: Rise , and lend thine ear .

English: That's all there is to it .
Shakespearean: There is no more but so .

English: As soon as the deed is done , you will be in my favor and I will promote you .
Shakespearean: Say it is done , And I will love thee and prefer thee for it .

English: I'll do it right away .
Shakespearean: I will dispatch it straight .

English: My lord , I have thought over the request you just made of me .
Shakespearean: My lord , I have considered in my mind The late request that you did sound me in .

English: Well , it doesn't matter anymore .
Shakespearean: Well , let that rest .

English: Dorset has fled to the earl of Richmond .
Shakespearean: Dorset is fled to Richmond .

English: I heard the news , my lord .
Shakespearean: I hear the news , my lord .

English: Stanley , Richmond is your wife's son .
Shakespearean: Stanley , he is your wife's son .

English: Get information from her .
Shakespearean: Well , look unto it .

English: My lord , I'd want to have the gift you promised me on your honor : the earldom of Hereford and all the possessions that go with it .
Shakespearean: My lord , I claim the gift , my due by promise , For which your honor and your faith is pawned , Th ' earldom of Hereford and the movables Which you promised I shall possess .

English: Stanley , pay attention to your wife's doings .
Shakespearean: Stanley , look to your wife .

English: If she sends any letters to Richmond , you will be accountable to me for it .
Shakespearean: If she convey Letters to Richmond , you shall answer it .

English: What do you say , your Highness , about my just request ?
Shakespearean: What says your Highness to my just request ?

English: As I remember , Henry the Sixth prophesied that Richmond would be king when Richmond was only a foolish little boy .
Shakespearean: I do remember me , Henry the Sixth Did prophesy that Richmond should be king , When Richmond was a little peevish boy .

English: A king , perhaps , My lord , How is it that the prophet didn't tell me at the time that I would kill him ?
Shakespearean: A king , perhaps , My lord , How chance the prophet could not at that time Have told me , I being by , that I should kill him ?

English: My lord , your promise of the earldom , Richmond !
Shakespearean: My lord , your promise for the earldom , Richmond !

English: The last time I was in Exeter , the mayor kindly showed me the castle there and called it " My lord !
Shakespearean: When last I was at Exeter , The mayor in courtesy showed me the castle And called it Rougemont , at which name I started , Because a bard of Ireland told me once I should not live long after I saw Richmond .

English: Yes , what time is it ?
Shakespearean: My Lord , Ay , what's o'clock ?

English: I'm reminding your grace what you promised me .
Shakespearean: I am thus bold to put your Grace in mind Of what you promised me .

English: Well , but what time is it ?
Shakespearean: Well , but what's o'clock ?

English: It's almost ten o'clock .
Shakespearean: Upon the stroke of ten .

English: Well , let it strike ten then .
Shakespearean: Well , let it strike .

English: Why "let it strike" ?
Shakespearean: Why let it strike ?

English: Because you're like the lowborn fellow who strikes the bell , you keep interrupting my thoughts .
Shakespearean: Because that , like a jack , thou keep'st the stroke Betwixt thy begging and my meditation .

English: I am not in the giving mood today .
Shakespearean: I am not in the giving vein today .

English: You're bothering me .
Shakespearean: Why then , resolve me whether you will or no .

English: I'm not in the mood .
Shakespearean: Thou troublest me ; I am not in the vein .

English: Is this really happening ?
Shakespearean: And is it thus ?

English: Does he reward my dedicated service with such deep contempt ?
Shakespearean: Repays he my deep service With such deep contempt ?

English: Did I work to make him king for this ?
Shakespearean: Made I him king for this ?

English: Oh , let me remember what happened to Hastings and hurry to
Shakespearean: O , let me think on Hastings and be gone To Brecknock , while my fearful head is on !

English: It was the most ruthless massacre this country has ever been guilty of .
Shakespearean: The tyrannous and bloody act is done , The most arch deed of piteous massacre That ever yet this land was guilty of .

English: Dighton and Forrest , whom I hired to perform the butchery , are used to killing people , the bloody dogs .
Shakespearean: Dighton and Forrest , whom I did suborn To do this piece of ruthless butchery , Albeit they were fleshed villains , bloody dogs , Melted with tenderness and mild compassion , Wept like two children in their deaths ' sad story .

English: Their lips , like four red roses on a stalk , touched .
Shakespearean: Their lips were four red roses on a stalk , And in their summer beauty kissed each other .

English: Kind Tyrrel , will your news make me happy ?
Shakespearean: Kind Tyrrel , am I happy in thy news ?

English: If my doing what you told me to makes you happy , then be happy , because I did it .
Shakespearean: If to have done the thing you gave in charge Beget your happiness , be happy then , For it is done .

English: But did you see them dead ?
Shakespearean: But did'st thou see them dead ?

English: I did , my lord .
Shakespearean: I did , my lord .

English: And buried , noble Tyrrel ?
Shakespearean: And buried , gentle Tyrrel ?

English: The Tower's chaplain has buried them , but to tell you the truth , I don't know where .
Shakespearean: The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them , But where , to say the truth , I do not know .

English: Tyrrel , come back shortly after dinner and tell me the details of their deaths .
Shakespearean: Come to me , Tyrrel , soon at after-supper , When thou shalt tell the process of their death .

English: In the meantime , think about how I can do you good and give you what you want .
Shakespearean: Meantime , but think how I may do thee good , And be inheritor of thy desire .

English: See you soon .
Shakespearean: Farewell till then .

English: I humbly say goodbye .
Shakespearean: I humbly take my leave .

English: Edward's sons have been carried off by the angels and Anne , my wife , has bid good night to the world .
Shakespearean: The son of Clarence have I pent up close , His daughter meanly have I matched in marriage , The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham's bosom , And Anne my wife hath bid this world goodnight .

English: Now I go , a jolly , thriving wooer , to marry my brother Edward's young daughter , Elizabeth , because I know Richmond has his eye on her .
Shakespearean: Now , for I know the Breton Richmond aims At young Elizabeth , my brother's daughter , And by that knot looks proudly on the crown , To her go I , a jolly thriving wooer .

English: My lord !
Shakespearean: My lord !

English: Is the news good or bad that you enter without knocking ?
Shakespearean: Good or bad news , that thou com'st in so bluntly ?

English: Bad news , my lord .
Shakespearean: Bad news , my lord .

English: The Bishop of Ely has fled to Richmond , and Buckingham , backed by a hardy Welsh army , is on the march .
Shakespearean: Morton is fled to Richmond , And Buckingham , backed with the hardy Welshmen , Is in the field , and still his power increaseth .

English: Ely joining Richmond troubles me more than Buckingham and his quickly assembled army .
Shakespearean: Ely with Richmond troubles me more near Than Buckingham and his rash-levied strength .

English: Let's say I didn't kill them .
Shakespearean: Say that I slew them not .

English: Then you might as well say they're not dead .
Shakespearean: Then say they were not slain .

English: But they are dead , and you killed them , you slave of the devil .
Shakespearean: But dead they are , and devilish slave , by thee .

English: I did not kill your husband .
Shakespearean: I did not kill your husband .

English: Well , then he must be alive .
Shakespearean: Why then , he is alive .

English: You're lying .
Shakespearean: In thy foul throat thou liest .

English: Queen Margaret saw your sword steaming with his blood .
Shakespearean: Queen Margaret saw Thy murd'rous falchion smoking in his blood , The which thou once didst bend against her breast , But that thy brothers beat aside the point .

English: She provoked me with her lying mouth , accusing me of crimes I didn't commit .
Shakespearean: I was provoked by her sland'rous tongue , That laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders .

English: No , what provoked you was your own bloody mind , which never thinks about anything but butchering .
Shakespearean: Thou wast provoked by thy bloody mind , That never dream'st on aught but butcheries .

English: You killed this king , didn't you ?
Shakespearean: Didst thou not kill this king ?

English: Yes , I'll grant you that .
Shakespearean: I grant you .

English: You'll grant me , you hedgehog ?
Shakespearean: Dost grant me , hedgehog ?

English: Then let God grant me that you'll be damned for that wicked deed .
Shakespearean: Then , God grant me too Thou mayst be damned for that wicked deed .

English: Oh , he was gentle , mild , and virtuous .
Shakespearean: O , he was gentle , mild , and virtuous .

English: That will please God , who has him now .
Shakespearean: The better for the King of heaven that hath him .

English: He is in heaven , where you will never go .
Shakespearean: He is in heaven , where thou shalt never come .

English: Let him thank me , who helped him get there .
Shakespearean: Let him thank me , that holp to send him thither , For he was fitter for that place than earth .

English: I've lurked in the shadows here to watch the downfall of my enemies .
Shakespearean: Here in these confines slyly have I lurked To watch the waning of mine enemies .

English: I'll head to France soon .
Shakespearean: A dire induction am I witness to , And will to France , hoping the consequence Will prove as bitter , black , and tragical .

English: It's time to hide , wretched Margaret .
Shakespearean: Withdraw thee , wretched Margaret .

English: Who's coming ?
Shakespearean: Who comes here ?

English: Ah , my poor princes !
Shakespearean: Ah , my poor princes !

English: If your gentle souls are still flying in the air and have not yet landed where they will remain forever , hover around me with your airy wings and hear your mother's lament .
Shakespearean: Ah , my tender babes , My unblown flowers , new-appearing sweets , If yet your gentle souls fly in the air And be not fixed in doom perpetual , Hover about me with your airy wings And hear your mother's lamentation .

English: Hover about her and tell her she got what she deserved , with her children dead before their time .
Shakespearean: Hover about her ; say that right for right Hath dimmed your infant morn to aged night .

English: I've been crazed with so many miseries that my tongue has tired of lamenting and gone mute .
Shakespearean: So many miseries have crazed my voice That my woe-wearied tongue is still and mute .

English: Edward Plantagenet , why are you dead ?
Shakespearean: Edward Plantagenet , why art thou dead ?

English: Will you abandon such gentle lambs , God , and throw them to the wolves ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou , O God , fly from such gentle lambs And throw them in the entrails of the wolf ?

English: Have you ever slept before while such a terrible deed was done ?
Shakespearean: When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done ?

English: Let my sorrow have the upper hand .
Shakespearean: Give mine the benefit of seigniory , And let my griefs frown on the upper hand .

English: You had a Clarence , too , and Richard killed him .
Shakespearean: I had a Richard too , and thou did'st kill him ; I had a Rutland too ; thou holp'st to kill him .

English: Oh righteous God , how can I thank you enough that this meat-eating mutt preys on his mother's children and forces her to join others in their grief !
Shakespearean: O upright , just , and true-disposing God , How do I thank thee that this carnal cur Preys on the issue of his mother's body And makes her pew-fellow with others ' moan !

English: O Harry's wife , do not triumph in my sorrow !
Shakespearean: O Harry's wife , triumph not in my woes !

English: With God as my witness , I swear I have wept for yours .
Shakespearean: God witness with me , I have wept for thine .

English: Your son Edward , who stabbed my son Edward , is dead .
Shakespearean: Thy Edward he is dead , that killed my Edward , Thy other Edward dead , to quit my Edward ; Young York , he is but boot , because both they Matched not the high perfection of my loss .

English: Your Clarence , who stabbed my Edward , is also dead .
Shakespearean: Thy Clarence he is dead that stabbed my Edward , And the beholders of this frantic play , Th ' adulterate Hastings , Rivers , Vaughan , Grey , Untimely smothered in their dusky graves .

English: Richard , a fiendish spy for hell itself , still lives , but only long enough to buy souls to send below .
Shakespearean: Richard yet lives , hell's black intelligencer , Only reserved their factor to buy souls And send them thither .

English: I pray that God ends his life before I die , so I can say , "The dog is dead ! "
Shakespearean: Cancel his bond of life , dear God I pray , That I may live to say , "The dog is dead."

English: Oh , you prophesied that the time would come when I would want your help in cursing that humpbacked spider , that hideous toad !
Shakespearean: O , thou didst prophesy the time would come That I should wish for thee to help me curse That bottled spider , that foul bunch-backed toad !

English: Back then , I called you "a poor , imitation queen , " a badly reproduced copy of what I was , a pretty prologue for the tragedy that was about to follow , a woman who was lifted high only to be hurled down to hell , a mother only teased with two beautiful children , who would soon die .
Shakespearean: I called thee then "vain flourish of my fortune." I called thee then poor shadow , "painted queen , " The presentation of but what I was , The flattering index of a direful pageant , One heaved a-high , to be hurled down below , A mother only mocked with two fair babes , A dream of what thou wast , a garish flag To be the aim of every dangerous shot , A sign of dignity , a breath , a bubble , A queen in jest , only to fill the scene .

English: And I was right , because where's your husband now ?
Shakespearean: Where is thy husband now ?

English: Your brothers ?
Shakespearean: Where be thy brothers ?

English: Your two sons ?
Shakespearean: Where are thy two sons ?

English: Now you have only the memory of what you were , which tortures you when you consider what you've become .
Shakespearean: Thus hath the course of justice whirled about And left thee but a very prey to time , Having no more but thought of what thou wast To torture thee the more , being what thou art .

English: You once stole my position ; now you get to have the grief that goes with it .
Shakespearean: Thou didst usurp my place , and dost thou not Usurp the just proportion of my sorrow ?

English: Your English sorrows will make me smile in France .
Shakespearean: These English woes will make me smile in France .

English: You who are so skilled in cursing , stay awhile and teach me how to curse my enemies .
Shakespearean: O , thou well-skilled in curses , stay awhile , And teach me how to curse mine enemies .

English: Remember your children as being sweeter than they actually were , and think of the man who killed them as worse than he is .
Shakespearean: Forbear to sleep the nights , and fast the days ; Compare dead happiness with living woe ; Think that thy babes were sweeter than they were , And he that slew them fouler than he is .

English: Making your loss greater makes the person who caused it worse .
Shakespearean: Bettering thy loss makes the bad causer worse .

English: Think like this all day , and you'll learn how to curse .
Shakespearean: Revolving this will teach thee how to curse .

English: My words are dull .
Shakespearean: My words are dull .

English: Enliven them with yours !
Shakespearean: O , quicken them with thine !

English: Your misery will make them sharp and piercing like mine .
Shakespearean: Thy woes will make them sharp and pierce like mine .

English: But give words a chance .
Shakespearean: Why should calamity be full of words ?

English: If that's true , then don't be tongue-tied .
Shakespearean: If so , then be not tongue-tied .

English: Come with me , and let's smother my fiendish son , who smothered your two sweet sons , in bitter words .
Shakespearean: Go with me , And in the breath of bitter words let's smother My damned son that thy two sweet sons smothered .

English: Who's blocking the way ?
Shakespearean: Who intercepts my expedition ?

English: The woman who might have blocked you from all the murders you've committed by strangling you in her cursed womb .
Shakespearean: O , she that might have intercepted thee , By strangling thee in her accursed womb , From all the slaughters , wretch , that thou hast done .

English: Are you hiding your forehead with a golden crown , when , if there was any justice in this world , it should be branded with the murders you committed , your slaughter of the prince who held that crown , and of my sons and my brothers ?
Shakespearean: Hid'st thou that forehead with a golden crown Where should be branded , if that right were right , The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown And the dire death of my poor sons and brothers ?

English: Tell me , you villainous lowlife , where are my children ?
Shakespearean: Tell me , thou villain-slave , where are my children ?

English: Where are the noble Hastings , Rivers , Vaughan , Grey ?
Shakespearean: Where is gentle Rivers , Vaughan , Grey ?

English: Where is kind Hastings ?
Shakespearean: Where is kind Hastings ?

English: Play , trumpets !
Shakespearean: Strike alarum , drums !

English: Don't let the heavens hear these chattery women abuse the Lord's anointed king .
Shakespearean: Let not the heavens hear these telltale women Rail on the Lord's anointed .

English: Play , I say !
Shakespearean: Strike , I say !

English: Either be calm and polite or I'll drown you out with the music of war .
Shakespearean: Either be patient and entreat me fair , Or with the clamorous report of war Thus will I drown your exclamations .

English: Are you my son ?
Shakespearean: Art thou my son ?

English: Yes , I thank God , my father , and yourself .
Shakespearean: Ay , I thank God , my father , and yourself .

English: Then patiently listen to my impatience .
Shakespearean: Then patiently hear my impatience .

English: Madam , I'm a bit like you in that I can't tolerate a tone of disapproval .
Shakespearean: Madam , I have a touch of your condition , Which can not brook the accent of reproof .

English: Oh , let me speak !
Shakespearean: O , let me speak !

English: Go ahead , but I won't listen .
Shakespearean: Do then , but I'll not hear .

English: I'll be gentle and mild .
Shakespearean: I will be mild and gentle in my words .

English: And brief , good mother , I'm in a hurry .
Shakespearean: And brief , good mother , for I am in haste .

English: Are you that impatient ?
Shakespearean: Art thou so hasty ?

English: God knows I waited for you in anguish , pain , and agony when I gave birth to you .
Shakespearean: I have stayed for thee , God knows , in torment and in agony .

English: And didn't I finally arrive to comfort you ?
Shakespearean: And came I not at last to comfort you ?

English: So , what hour of comfort have I ever had in your company ?
Shakespearean: What comfortable hour canst thou name , That ever graced me in thy company ?

English: Name one .
Shakespearean: Faith , none but Humfrey Hower , that called your Grace To breakfast once , forth of my company .

English: You're too bitter .
Shakespearean: I prithee , hear me speak .

English: Just listen this once .
Shakespearean: You speak too bitterly .

English: I'll never speak to you again .
Shakespearean: Hear me a word , For I shall never speak to thee again .

English: So be it .
Shakespearean: So .

English: Though I have far more reason , I don't have as much energy to curse you .
Shakespearean: Though far more cause , yet much less spirit to curse Abides in me .

English: But I say amen to everything she said .
Shakespearean: I say amen to her .

English: Wait , madam .
Shakespearean: Stay , madam .

English: I need to speak a word with you .
Shakespearean: I must talk a word with you .

English: I have no more royal sons for you to murder .
Shakespearean: I have no more sons of the royal blood For thee to slaughter .

English: You have a daughter named Elizabeth , who is virtuous and beautiful , aristocratic and full of grace .
Shakespearean: You have a daughter called Elizabeth , Virtuous and fair , royal and gracious .

English: And does she have to die for this ?
Shakespearean: And must she die for this ?

English: Oh , let her live , and I'll ruin her manners and her beauty .
Shakespearean: O , let her live , And I'll corrupt her manners , stain her beauty , Slander myself as false to Edward's bed , Throw over her the veil of infamy .

English: So that she may live , I'll say I cheated on Edward and that she is not really his child .
Shakespearean: So she may live unscarred of bleeding slaughter , I will confess she was not Edward's daughter .

English: Don't wrong her birth .
Shakespearean: Wrong not her birth .

English: She has royal blood .
Shakespearean: She is a royal princess .

English: To save her life , I'll say she doesn't .
Shakespearean: To save her life , I'll say she is not so .

English: Yes , as safe as her brothers ' lives were .
Shakespearean: And only in that safety died her brothers .

English: Bad friends were .
Shakespearean: No , to their lives ill friends were contrary .

English: My children would have enjoyed a better death if God had blessed you with a purer life .
Shakespearean: My babes were destined to a fairer death If grace had blessed thee with a fairer life .

English: Whichever hand literally stabbed their tender hearts , you're the one who gave the order .
Shakespearean: Whose hand soever launched their tender hearts , Thy head , all indirectly , gave direction .

English: No doubt the murderous knife was blunt till it was sharpened on your stony heart , you reveled in my lambs ' bloody guts .
Shakespearean: No doubt the murd'rous knife was dull and blunt Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart , To revel in the entrails of my lambs .

English: But constant expression of wild grief will only make it tame , so I'm not going to say any more about my boys until I've gouged your eyes out with my bare hands .
Shakespearean: But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame , My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys Till that my nails were anchored in thine eyes , And I , in such a desp'rate bay of death , Like a poor bark of sails and tackling reft , Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom .

English: Madam , if I do as well as I think I'm going to do in these dangerous , violent wars , you and your relatives will have more good at my hands than you've ever had bad !
Shakespearean: Madam , so thrive I in my enterprise And dangerous success of bloody wars As I intend more good to you and yours Than ever you or yours were by me harmed !

English: What good does heaven have in store that can do me any good now ?
Shakespearean: What good is covered with the face of heaven , To be discovered , that can do me good ?

English: The advancement of your children , noble lady .
Shakespearean: The advancement of your children , gentle lady .

English: Advancement to some scaffold , to lose their heads .
Shakespearean: Up to some scaffold , there to lose their heads .

English: No , advancement to the dignity and height of honor , to a high , imperial kind of glory .
Shakespearean: Unto the dignity and height of fortune , The high imperial type of this earth's glory .

English: And you're not suited for any place except hell .
Shakespearean: And thou unfit for any place but hell .

English: Yes , and one other place , if you'll only let me name it .
Shakespearean: Yes , one place else , if you will hear me name it .

English: Some dungeon .
Shakespearean: Some dungeon .

English: Your bedroom .
Shakespearean: Your bedchamber .

English: There is no rest to be had in any bedroom where you are !
Shakespearean: Ill rest betide the chamber where thou liest !

English: Exactly , madam , until I sleep with you .
Shakespearean: So will it , madam till I lie with you .

English: Well , explain , but do it fast so that your puny store of kindness isn't used up by talking about it .
Shakespearean: Be brief , lest that the process of thy kindness Last longer telling than thy kindness ' date .

English: Then know that from my soul I love your daughter .
Shakespearean: Then know that from my soul I love thy daughter .

English: I believe it .
Shakespearean: My daughter's mother thinks it with her soul .

English: What do you believe ?
Shakespearean: What do you think ?

English: That you love my daughter to spite your soul .
Shakespearean: That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul .

English: Don't be so quick to twist my meaning .
Shakespearean: Be not so hasty to confound my meaning .

English: The one who makes her queen , of course .
Shakespearean: Even he that makes her queen .

English: Who else should it be ?
Shakespearean: Who else should be ?

English: What , you ?
Shakespearean: What , thou ?

English: What do you think , madam ?
Shakespearean: How think you of it ?

English: How would you woo her ?
Shakespearean: How canst thou woo her ?

English: And Madam , with all my heart .
Shakespearean: Madam , with all my heart .

English: Come , come , you're making fun of me .
Shakespearean: You mock me , madam .

English: This is not the way to win your daughter .
Shakespearean: This is not the way To win your daughter .

English: There isn't any other way , unless you took on another form and became someone else .
Shakespearean: There is no other way , Unless thou couldst put on some other shape And not be Richard , that hath done all this .

English: But suppose I did all the things you named out of love for her .
Shakespearean: Say that I did all this for love of her .

English: Then she has no choice but to hate you , as you purchased her love with murder .
Shakespearean: Nay , then indeed she can not choose but hate thee , Having bought love with such a bloody spoil .

English: Whatever has already been done can't be undone now .
Shakespearean: Look what is done can not be now amended .

English: Men act imprudently sometimes , then realize their mistakes when they have time to think about them .
Shakespearean: Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes , Which after-hours give leisure to repent .

English: If I took the kingdom from your sons , I'll give it to your daughter to make up for it .
Shakespearean: If I did take the kingdom from your sons , To make amends I'll give it to your daughter .

English: If I have killed your children , I will have children with your daughter .
Shakespearean: If I have killed the issue of your womb , To quicken your increase I will beget Mine issue of your blood upon your daughter .

English: A grandmother is loved hardly less than a mother is .
Shakespearean: A grandam's name is little less in love Than is the doting title of a mother .

English: Your children caused you trouble in your youth , but mine will bring you comfort in your old age .
Shakespearean: Your children were vexation to your youth , But mine shall be a comfort to your age .

English: I can't make up for everything that I'd like to , so accept such kindness as I can offer .
Shakespearean: I can not make you what amends I would ; Therefore accept such kindness as I can .

English: Indeed , we have many good days to look forward to !
Shakespearean: What , we have many goodly days to see !

English: Go , then , mother , to your daughter .
Shakespearean: Go then , my mother ; to thy daughter go .

English: What should I say to her ?
Shakespearean: What were I best to say ?

English: That her father's brother wants to be her husband ?
Shakespearean: Her father's brother Would be her lord ?

English: Or should I say it's her uncle ?
Shakespearean: Or shall I say her uncle ?

English: Or should I describe you as the one who killed her brothers and her uncles ?
Shakespearean: Or he that slew her brothers and her uncles ?

English: How can I describe you that will make you appeal to the young woman and will also agree with God , the law , my honor , and her feelings ?
Shakespearean: Under what title shall I woo for thee , That God , the law , my honor and her love Can make seem pleasing to her tender years ?

English: Claim fair England's peace depends on this alliance .
Shakespearean: Infer fair England's peace by this alliance .

English: She will purchase that peace with an everlasting war .
Shakespearean: Which she shall purchase with still-lasting war .

English: Tell her that the king , who has the power to command people , asks her .
Shakespearean: Tell her the king , that may command , entreats , That , at her hands , which the king's King forbids .

English: He asks her to do what God Say she will be a high and mighty queen .
Shakespearean: Say she shall be a high and mighty queen .

English: Only to watch that title become worthless , as her mother has .
Shakespearean: To vail the title , as her mother doth .

English: Say I will love her everlastingly .
Shakespearean: Say I will love her everlastingly .

English: But how long will "ever" last ?
Shakespearean: But how long shall that title "ever" last ?

English: Until her beautiful life's end .
Shakespearean: Sweetly in force unto her fair life's end .

English: But how long will her beautiful life last ?
Shakespearean: But how long fairly shall her sweet life last ?

English: As long as heaven and nature extend it .
Shakespearean: As long as heaven and nature lengthens it .

English: As long as hell and Richard want it .
Shakespearean: As long as hell and Richard likes of it .

English: Tell her that I , her king , am her lowly subject .
Shakespearean: Say I , her sovereign , am her subject low .

English: But she , your subject , hates such a king .
Shakespearean: But she , your subject , loathes such sovereignty .

English: Be eloquent on my behalf .
Shakespearean: Be eloquent in my behalf to her .

English: An honest tale succeeds best when it is told simply .
Shakespearean: An honest tale speeds best being plainly told .

English: Then tell her my loving story in simple terms .
Shakespearean: Then plainly to her tell my loving tale .

English: You can't tell a story simply when it's a lie .
Shakespearean: Plain and not honest is too harsh a style .

English: Your answers are too shallow and too hasty .
Shakespearean: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick .

English: Oh no , my reasons are deep and as permanent as death .
Shakespearean: O no , my reasons are too deep and dead , Too deep and dead , poor infants , in their graves .

English: Don't harp on that point , madam , it's past .
Shakespearean: Harp not on that string , madam ; that is past .

English: I will harp on it till my heartstrings break .
Shakespearean: Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break .

English: Now , by St. George , my knighthood , and my crown , The first you profaned , the second you dishonored , and the third you stole .
Shakespearean: Now by my George , my Garter , and my crown , Profaned , dishonored , and the third usurped .

English: I swear , By nothing , because this is no oath .
Shakespearean: I swear , By nothing , for this is no oath .

English: St. George loses his holiness once Then , by myself , You've misused yourself .
Shakespearean: Then , by myself , Thyself is self-misused .

English: Now , by the world , It's full of your ugly wrongdoings .
Shakespearean: Now , by the world , 'T is full of thy foul wrongs .

English: By my father's death , Your life has dishonored his death .
Shakespearean: My father's death , Thy life hath it dishonored .

English: If you had been afraid to break an oath with him , the crown you are currently wearing would have graced the head of my child , and both princes would still be alive , not preyed on by worms .
Shakespearean: If thou hadst feared to break an oath by Him , Th ' imperial metal circling now thy head Had graced the tender temples of my child , And both the princes had been breathing here , Which now , two tender bedfellows for dust , Thy broken faith hath made the prey for worms .

English: What can you swear by now ?
Shakespearean: What canst thou swear by now ?

English: By the future .
Shakespearean: The time to come .

English: There are parents living whose children you have butchered ; they are now old withered plants who will moan over their losses as they grow old .
Shakespearean: The children live whose fathers thou hast slaughtered , Ungoverned youth , to wail it in their age ; The parents live whose children thou hast butchered , Old barren plants , to wail it with their age .

English: Don't swear by the future , because you've ruined it before it has even arrived .
Shakespearean: Swear not by time to come , for that thou hast Misused ere used , by times ill-used o'erpast .

English: May I only do well in these dangerous battles if my intention to repent and prosper is sincere !
Shakespearean: As I intend to prosper and repent , So thrive I in my dangerous affairs Of hostile arms !

English: Let me destroy myself , let heaven and destiny deprive me of happy hours , let day remain dark and night sleepless , and let me have nothing but terrible luck if I do not love with a pure heart , clean devotion , and holy thoughts your beautiful royal daughter .
Shakespearean: Myself myself confound , Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours , Day , yield me not thy light , nor night thy rest , Be opposite all planets of good luck To my proceedings if , with dear heart's love , Immaculate devotion , holy thoughts , I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter .

English: My happiness and yours lie in her .
Shakespearean: In her consists my happiness and thine .

English: It
Shakespearean: Urge the necessity and state of times , And be not peevish found in great designs .

English: Shall I be tempted by the devil ?
Shakespearean: Shall I be tempted of the devil thus ?

English: Yes , if the devil tempts you to do good .
Shakespearean: Ay , if the devil tempt you to do good .

English: Yes , if your memories do you no good .
Shakespearean: Ay , if your self's remembrance wrong yourself .

English: Yet you killed my children .
Shakespearean: Yet thou didst kill my children .

English: But in your daughter's womb I will bury them .
Shakespearean: But in your daughter's womb I bury them , Where , in that nest of spicery , they will breed Selves of themselves , to your recomforture .

English: Should I go convince my daughter to marry you ?
Shakespearean: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will ?

English: And be a happy mother by doing so .
Shakespearean: And be a happy mother by the deed .

English: I'm going .
Shakespearean: I go .

English: Write to me very soon and I'll let you know what she thinks .
Shakespearean: Write to me very shortly , And you shall understand from me her mind .

English: Many former friends of ours have gathered to meet the fleet and aren't willing to beat it back .
Shakespearean: To our shores Throng many doubtful hollow-hearted friends , Unarmed and unresolved to beat them back .

English: Word is that Richmond is the navy's admiral .
Shakespearean: Tis thought that Richmond is their admiral ; And there they hull , expecting but the aid Of Buckingham to welcome them ashore .

English: Someone who can ride fast , go to the duke of Here , my good lord .
Shakespearean: Some light-foot friend post to the duke of Norfolk , Ratcliffe , thyself , or Catesby .

English: Catesby , fly to the duke .
Shakespearean: Catesby , fly to the duke .

English: I will my lord , as fast as I can .
Shakespearean: I will , my lord , with all convenient haste .

English: Ratcliffe , come here .
Shakespearean: Ratcliffe , come hither .

English: Ride to Salisbury .
Shakespearean: Post to Salisbury .

English: Oh , right , good Catesby .
Shakespearean: O true , good Catesby .

English: Tell him to gather together the greatest army he can muster in a hurry and meet me right away at Salisbury .
Shakespearean: Bid him levy straight The greatest strength and power that he can make And meet me suddenly at Salisbury .

English: I'm off .
Shakespearean: I go .

English: What would you like me to do at Salisbury ?
Shakespearean: What , may it please you , shall I do at Salisbury ?

English: Why , what is there to do before I get there ?
Shakespearean: Why , what wouldst thou do there before I go ?

English: Your Highness just told me that I should ride there before you .
Shakespearean: Your Highness told me I should post before .

English: I changed my mind .
Shakespearean: My mind is changed .

English: Stanley , what news do you have ?
Shakespearean: Stanley , what news with you ?

English: Nothing that you want to hear , my lord , but nothing so bad that I can't mention it .
Shakespearean: None good , my liege , to please you with the hearing , Nor none so bad but well may be reported .

English: Well , how nice , a riddle !
Shakespearean: Hoyday , a riddle !

English: Neither good nor bad .
Shakespearean: Neither good nor bad .

English: Why do you go around in circles when you could get to the point ?
Shakespearean: What need'st thou run so many mile about When thou mayst tell thy tale the nearest way ?

English: Once again , what's the news ?
Shakespearean: Once more , what news ?

English: Richmond is sailing on the sea .
Shakespearean: Richmond is on the seas .

English: Let him sink there so the sea will cover him !
Shakespearean: There let him sink , and be the seas on him !

English: Lily-livered coward , what's he doing there ?
Shakespearean: White-livered runagate , what doth he there ?

English: Well , what do you guess ?
Shakespearean: Well , as you guess ?

English: That , stirred up by Dorset , Buckingham , and Morton , he's coming to England to claim the crown .
Shakespearean: Stirred up by Dorset , Buckingham , and Morton , He makes for England , here to claim the crown .

English: They are my daylight , my life .
Shakespearean: It is my day , my life .

English: Then I hope night shadows your day , and death takes your life !
Shakespearean: Black night o'ershade thy day , and death thy life .

English: Don't damn yourself .
Shakespearean: Curse not thyself , fair creature ; thou art both .

English: I wish I were , so I could deprive you of both day and life .
Shakespearean: I would I were , to be revenged on thee .

English: There is no better one on earth .
Shakespearean: His better doth not breathe upon the earth .

English: Is the throne empty ?
Shakespearean: Is the chair empty ?

English: Is the army without a leader ?
Shakespearean: Is the sword unswayed ?

English: Is the king dead , the empire dispossessed ?
Shakespearean: Is the king dead , the empire unpossessed ?

English: What heir of the York family is there alive other than myself ?
Shakespearean: What heir of York is there alive but we ?

English: And who is England's king but an heir of the great York ?
Shakespearean: And who is England's king but great York's heir ?

English: Therefore , tell me , what is he doing at sea ?
Shakespearean: Then tell me , what makes he upon the seas ?

English: Where is your army , then , to beat him back ?
Shakespearean: Where is thy power , then , to beat him back ?

English: Where are your tenants and your followers ?
Shakespearean: Where be thy tenants and thy followers ?

English: Aren't they at this very moment on the western shore helping the rebels land safely from their ships ?
Shakespearean: Are they not now upon the western shore , Safe-conducting the rebels from their ships ?

English: Then they're cold friends to me .
Shakespearean: Cold friends to me .

English: What are they doing in the north when they should be in the west serving their king ?
Shakespearean: What do they in the north When they should serve their sovereign in the west ?

English: They haven't been commanded to go to the west , mighty king .
Shakespearean: They have not been commanded , mighty king .

English: If your Majesty would like , I'll muster up my friends and meet you wherever and whenever you like .
Shakespearean: Pleaseth your Majesty to give me leave , I'll muster up my friends and meet your Grace Where and what time your Majesty shall please .

English: Most mighty sovereign , you have no reason to doubt my friendship .
Shakespearean: Most mighty sovereign , You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful .

English: I was never disloyal , and I never will be .
Shakespearean: I never was nor never will be false .

English: Then go gather your men , but leave behind your son , George Stanley .
Shakespearean: Go then and muster men , but leave behind Your son George Stanley .

English: My noble king , my friends have informed me that Sir Edward Courtney and his brother , the haughty Bishop of Exeter , are now in My king , the Guildfords in My lord , the duke of Buckingham's army , Enough , you
Shakespearean: My gracious sovereign , now in Devonshire , As I by friends am well advertised , Sir Edward Courtney and the haughty prelate , Bishop of Exeter , his elder brother , With many more confederates are in arms .

English: The news I have to tell your majesty is that Buckingham's army has dispersed from sudden floods and heavy rainfall .
Shakespearean: In Kent , my liege , the Guilfords are in arms , And every hour more competitors Flock to the rebels , and their power grows strong .

English: Buckingham himself has wandered away alone to who knows where .
Shakespearean: My lord , the army of great Buckingham , Out on you , owls !

English: I beg your pardon .
Shakespearean: Nothing but songs of death .

English: Yes , your Highness .
Shakespearean: But this good comfort bring I to your Highness : The Breton navy is dispersed by tempest .

English: Even if we don't fight foreign enemies , we'll beat down these rebels at home .
Shakespearean: March on , march on , since we are up in arms , If not to fight with foreign enemies , Yet to beat down these rebels here at home .

English: While we're talking here , a royal battle could be won and lost .
Shakespearean: While we reason here , A royal battle might be won and lost .

English: Someone deliver the order that Buckingham be brought to Salisbury .
Shakespearean: Someone take order Buckingham be brought To Salisbury .

English: Everyone else , march on with me .
Shakespearean: The rest march on with me .

English: But , tell me , where is the noble Richmond now ?
Shakespearean: But , tell me , where is princely Richmond now ?

English: At Pembroke , or at Harfordwest in Wales .
Shakespearean: At Pembroke , or at Ha'rfordwest in Wales .

English: Sir Walter Herbert , a renowned soldier ; Sir Gilbert Talbot ; Sir William Stanley ; Oxford ; the highly feared Pembroke ; Sir James Blunt ; Rice ap Thomas , with a valiant crew ; and many other famous and powerful noblemen .
Shakespearean: Sir Walter Herbert , a renowned soldier ; Sir Gilbert Talbot , Sir William Stanley , Oxford , redoubted Pembroke , Sir James Blunt , And Rice ap Thomas , with a valiant crew , And many other of great name and worth ; And towards London they do bend their power , If by the way they be not fought withal .

English: Now we wear the wreaths of victory on our heads .
Shakespearean: Now is the winter of our discontent Made glorious summer by this son of York , And all the clouds that loured upon our house In the deep bosom of the ocean buried .

English: I'm left with nothing to do in this weak , idle peacetime , unless I want to look at my lumpy shadow in the sun and sing about
Shakespearean: Grim-visaged war hath smoothed his wrinkled front ; And now , instead of mounting barbed steeds To fright the souls of fearful adversaries , He capers nimbly in a lady's chamber To the lascivious pleasing of a lute .

English: Won't King Richard let me speak with him ?
Shakespearean: Will not King Richard let me speak with him ?

English: No , my good lord .
Shakespearean: No , my good lord .

English: So be calm .
Shakespearean: Therefore be patient .

English: Hastings and Edward's children , Rivers and Grey , holy King Henry and your fine son Edward , Vaughan , and all who have died from underhanded , corrupt , fiendish injustice , if your angry souls are witnessing this moment through the clouds , enjoy the revenge , laugh at my ruin !
Shakespearean: Hastings and Edward's children , Grey and Rivers , Holy King Henry and thy fair son Edward , Vaughan , and all that have miscarried By underhand , corrupted , foul injustice , If that your moody , discontented souls Do through the clouds behold this present hour , Even for revenge mock my destruction. , This is All Souls ' Day , fellow , is it not ?

English: This is It is , my lord .
Shakespearean: It is .

English: Why , then , it's my body's doomsday .
Shakespearean: Why , then All Souls ' Day is my body's doomsday .

English: Today I'm going to get what I said I wished would happen to me if I was ever false to King Edward's children or his wife's allies .
Shakespearean: This is the day which , in King Edward's time , I wished might fall on me when I was found False to his children and his wife's allies .

English: This is the day I'm going to get what I wished for when I wished that the person I most trusted would betray me .
Shakespearean: This is the day wherein I wished to fall By the false faith of him who most I trusted .

English: This , this All-Souls ' day , is my just desserts .
Shakespearean: This , this All Souls ' Day to my fearful soul Is the determined respite of my wrongs .

English: I tried to play games with God , and he turned my fake prayer on my head , giving me for real what I'd asked for as a joke .
Shakespearean: That high All-seer which I dallied with Hath turned my feigned prayer on my head And given in earnest what I begged in jest .

English: This is how God forces wicked men to turn their swords against themselves .
Shakespearean: Thus doth he force the swords of wicked men To turn their own points in their masters ' bosoms .

English: I have done wrong , so I will suffer wrong .
Shakespearean: Wrong hath but wrong , and blame the due of blame .

English: I suspect his friends will join us .
Shakespearean: I doubt not but his friends will turn to us .

English: He has no friends except those who are too afraid to defy him .
Shakespearean: He hath no friends but who are friends for fear .

English: In his greatest need , even they will desert him .
Shakespearean: Which in his dearest need will fly from him .

English: All to our advantage .
Shakespearean: All for our vantage .

English: So , in God's name , let's march .
Shakespearean: Then , in God's name , march .

English: Hope with good cause is swift ; it flies as fast as a swallow .
Shakespearean: True hope is swift , and flies with swallow's wings .

English: It turns kings into gods and men of lower rank into kings .
Shakespearean: Kings it makes gods , and meaner creatures kings .

English: My heart is ten times lighter than my looks .
Shakespearean: My heart is ten times lighter than my looks .

English: My Lord of Norfolk , Here , most gracious king .
Shakespearean: My Lord of Norfolk , Here , most gracious liege .

English: Norfolk , we're going to have a few blows , right ?
Shakespearean: Norfolk , we must have knocks , ha , must we not ?

English: We've got to give them and take them , my lord .
Shakespearean: We must both give and take , my loving lord .

English: I'll lie here tonight .
Shakespearean: Up with my tent ! , Here will I lie tonight .

English: But where will I lie tomorrow ?
Shakespearean: But where tomorrow ?

English: Well , it doesn't matter .
Shakespearean: Well , all's one for that .

English: Six or seven thousand , at most .
Shakespearean: Six or seven thousand is their utmost power .

English: Why , our troops amount to three times that .
Shakespearean: Why , our battalia trebles that account .

English: Besides , the king's name is a tower of strength ; the opposition doesn't have that advantage .
Shakespearean: Besides , the king's name is a tower of strength Which they upon the adverse party want .

English: Let's be disciplined and not delay , because tomorrow is a busy day .
Shakespearean: Let's lack no discipline , make no delay , For , lords , tomorrow is a busy day .

English: My Lord of Oxford , you , Sir William Brandon , and you , Sir Walter Herbert , are going to stay with me .
Shakespearean: My Lord of Oxford , you , Sir William Brandon , And you , Sir Walter Herbert , stay with me .

English: Good Captain Blunt , tell the earl goodnight from me , and tell him that by two in the morning I would like him to visit my tent .
Shakespearean: The earl of Pembroke keeps his regiment , Good Captain Blunt , bear my goodnight to him , And by the second hour in the morning Desire the earl to see me in my tent .

English: Unless I've mistaken his battle flags , which I'm sure I haven't , his regiment lies at least half a mile south of the king's mighty army .
Shakespearean: Unless I have mista'en his colors much , Which well I am assured I have not done , His regiment lies half a mile , at least , South from the mighty power of the king .

English: If it's possible to do this without putting yourself in danger , dear Captain Blunt , say goodnight to him from me and give him this important note .
Shakespearean: If without peril it be possible , Sweet Blunt , make some good means to speak with him , And give him from me this most needful note .

English: Upon my life , my lord , I'll do it .
Shakespearean: Upon my life , my lord , I'll undertake it .

English: There is a man who loves you better than your husband could .
Shakespearean: He lives that loves thee better than he could .

English: Name him .
Shakespearean: Name him .

English: Plantagenet .
Shakespearean: Plantagenet .

English: Yes , that's my husband's name .
Shakespearean: Why , that was he .

English: Someone else has the same name , but he's a better man .
Shakespearean: The selfsame name , but one of better nature .

English: Where is this man ?
Shakespearean: Where is he ?

English: Here .
Shakespearean: Here .

English: Why do you spit at me ?
Shakespearean: Why dost thou spit at me ?

English: If only I could spit poison .
Shakespearean: Would it were mortal poison for thy sake .

English: Poison never came from such a sweet place .
Shakespearean: Never came poison from so sweet a place .

English: Poison never landed on such an ugly toad .
Shakespearean: Never hung poison on a fouler toad .

English: Get out of my sight !
Shakespearean: Out of my sight !

English: You're poisoning my eyes .
Shakespearean: Thou dost infect mine eyes .

English: Your beautiful eyes , sweet lady , have infected mine with love .
Shakespearean: Thine eyes , sweet lady , have infected mine .

English: I wish my eyes were
Shakespearean: Would they were basilisks to strike thee dead .

English: Good night , dear Captain Blunt .
Shakespearean: Good night , good Captain Blunt .

English: Come , gentlemen , let's discuss tomorrow's action in my tent .
Shakespearean: Come , gentlemen , Let us consult upon tomorrow's business Into my tent .

English: The night air is too raw and cold for us to stay outdoors .
Shakespearean: The dew is raw and cold .

English: What time is it ?
Shakespearean: What is "t o"clock ?

English: It's dinnertime , my lord .
Shakespearean: It's suppertime , my lord .

English: It's nine o'clock .
Shakespearean: It's nine o'clock .

English: I'm not going to eat dinner tonight .
Shakespearean: I will not sup tonight .

English: Give me some ink and paper .
Shakespearean: Give me some ink and paper .

English: Is the visor of my helmet working better now ?
Shakespearean: What , is my beaver easier than it was ?

English: And has my armor been put in my tent ?
Shakespearean: And all my armor laid into my tent ?

English: My good man Norfolk , hurry to your post .
Shakespearean: Good Norfolk , hie thee to thy charge .

English: I'm off , my lord .
Shakespearean: I go , my lord .

English: Get up early tomorrow , at the sound of the lark , noble Norfolk .
Shakespearean: Stir with the lark tomorrow , gentle Norfolk .

English: I will , my lord .
Shakespearean: I warrant you , my lord .

English: Catesby .
Shakespearean: Catesby .

English: Yes , my lord ?
Shakespearean: My lord .

English: Yes , my lord ?
Shakespearean: My lord .

English: Did you see the gloomy Lord Northumberland ?
Shakespearean: Sawst thou the melancholy Lord Northumberland ?

English: Thomas , the earl of Surrey , and he were moving from troop to troop around twilight cheering up the soldiers .
Shakespearean: Thomas the earl of Surrey and himself , Much about cockshut time , from troop to troop Went through the army cheering up the soldiers .

English: Good , I'm satisfied .
Shakespearean: So , I am satisfied .

English: Set it down .
Shakespearean: Set it down .

English: Is my ink and paper ready ?
Shakespearean: Is ink and paper ready ?

English: It is , my lord .
Shakespearean: It is , my lord .

English: Ratcliffe , around midnight come to my tent and help me put on my armor .
Shakespearean: Ratcliffe , about the mid of night come to my tent And help to arm me .

English: Now leave me alone , as I said .
Shakespearean: Leave me , I say .

English: Let fortune and victory be yours !
Shakespearean: Fortune and victory sit on thy helm !

English: I wish you all the comfort that such a dark night as this can offer , noble father-in-law .
Shakespearean: All comfort that the dark night can afford Be to thy person , noble father-in-law .

English: Tell me , how is my mother ?
Shakespearean: Tell me , how fares our loving mother ?

English: Your mother sends her blessings .
Shakespearean: I , by attorney , bless thee from thy mother , Who prays continually for Richmond's good .

English: To be brief , as the occasion requires , prepare to fight early in the morning , when your future will be decided .
Shakespearean: In brief , for so the season bids us be , Prepare thy battle early in the morning , And put thy fortune to the arbitrament Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war .

English: I can't do everything I want to , but I'll help you as well as I can .
Shakespearean: I , as I may , that which I would I can not , , With best advantage will deceive the time , And aid thee in this doubtful shock of arms .

English: But I can't be too obvious about being on your side without risking the life of your stepbrother , young George .
Shakespearean: But on thy side I may not be too forward , Lest , being seen , thy brother , tender George , Be executed in his father's sight .

English: Farewell .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: The lack of time and the risk I'm under will have to keep us from bonding and catching up on each other's news the way we usually would after not seeing each other for so long .
Shakespearean: The leisure and the fearful time Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love And ample interchange of sweet discourse , Which so-long-sundered friends should dwell upon .

English: I hope we have the time some day !
Shakespearean: God give us leisure for these rites of love !

English: Again , goodbye .
Shakespearean: Once more , adieu .

English: Be brave and do well !
Shakespearean: Be valiant , and speed well .

English: Again , good night , kind lords and gentlemen .
Shakespearean: Once more , good night , kind lords and gentlemen .

English: Oh God , whose side I think I'm fighting on , look kindly on my forces .
Shakespearean: O Thou , whose captain I account myself , Look on my forces with a gracious eye .

English: Make us your agents of revenge , so we can praise you when we're victorious !
Shakespearean: Make us thy ministers of chastisement , That we may praise thee in the victory !

English: Before I fall asleep , I entrust my soul to you .
Shakespearean: To thee I do commend my watchful soul , Ere I let fall the windows of mine eyes .

English: Defend me , God , both when I'm asleep and when I'm awake .
Shakespearean: Sleeping and waking , O , defend me still !

English: I'm sweating and trembling with fear .
Shakespearean: Think upon Vaughan , and with guilty fear Let fall thy lance .

English: Myself ?
Shakespearean: Despair , and die !

English: Yes , I am .
Shakespearean: Edward's unhappy sons do bid thee flourish .

English: Then run away .
Shakespearean: Think on Lord Hastings .

English: What , from myself ?
Shakespearean: Despair and die !

English: Why ?
Shakespearean: Thy adversary's wife doth pray for thee .

English: Did I do anything good to myself ?
Shakespearean: The last was I that felt thy tyranny .

English: Oh , no .
Shakespearean: O , in the battle think on Buckingham , And die in terror of thy guiltiness .

English: I am a villain .
Shakespearean: Dream on , dream on , of bloody deeds and death .

English: Fool , do not flatter yourself .
Shakespearean: But cheer thy heart , and be thou not dismayed .

English: Give me another horse !
Shakespearean: Give me another horse !

English: Bandage my wounds !
Shakespearean: Bind up my wounds !

English: Have mercy , Jesus ! , Wait , I was only dreaming .
Shakespearean: Have mercy , Jesu ! , Soft , I did but dream .

English: Oh cowardly conscience , how you're torturing me !
Shakespearean: O coward conscience , how dost thou afflict me !

English: But what am I afraid of ?
Shakespearean: What do I fear ?

English: Myself ?
Shakespearean: Myself ?

English: There's no one else here .
Shakespearean: There's none else by .

English: Richard loves Richard , that is , there's just me and myself here .
Shakespearean: Richard loves Richard ; that is , I and I .

English: Is there a murderer here ?
Shakespearean: Is there a murderer here ?

English: No .
Shakespearean: No .

English: Yes , I am .
Shakespearean: Yes , I am .

English: Then run away .
Shakespearean: Then fly !

English: What , from myself ?
Shakespearean: What , from myself ?

English: Unfortunately , I love myself .
Shakespearean: Alack , I love myself .

English: Why ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore ?

English: Did I do anything good to myself ?
Shakespearean: For any good That I myself have done unto myself ?

English: Oh , no .
Shakespearean: O , no !

English: Alas , I hate myself instead , because of the hateful deeds I've committed .
Shakespearean: Alas , I rather hate myself For hateful deeds committed by myself .

English: I am a villain .
Shakespearean: I am a villain .

English: Fool , speak well of yourself .
Shakespearean: Fool , of thyself speak well .

English: Fool , do not flatter yourself .
Shakespearean: Fool , do not flatter .

English: My lord .
Shakespearean: My lord .

English: Damn it , who's there ?
Shakespearean: Zounds , who is there ?

English: Ratcliffe , my lord , it's me .
Shakespearean: Ratcliffe , my lord , 'tis I .

English: The rooster has already crowed twice .
Shakespearean: The early village cock Hath twice done salutation to the morn .

English: Your friends are up and buckling on their armor .
Shakespearean: Your friends are up and buckle on their armor .

English: Oh Ratcliffe , I had a terrifying dream !
Shakespearean: O Ratcliffe , I have dreamed a fearful dream !

English: What do you think , will my friends prove loyal ?
Shakespearean: What think'st thou , will our friends prove all true ?

English: No doubt , my lord .
Shakespearean: No doubt , my lord .

English: By St. Paul , ghosts have struck more terror in my soul tonight than ten thousand of worthless Richmond's soldiers could , dressed up in their most sword-proof armor .
Shakespearean: By the apostle Paul , shadows tonight Have struck more terror to the soul of Richard Than can the substance of ten thousand soldiers Armed in proof and led by shallow Richmond .

English: It's not yet daylight .
Shakespearean: Tis not yet near day .

English: Come with me ; I'll spy under the tents to see if any of my own people plan to desert me .
Shakespearean: Come , go with me ; Under our tents I'll play the eavesdropper To see if any mean to shrink from me .

English: Good morning , Richmond .
Shakespearean: Good morrow , Richmond .

English: Pardon me , lords and gentlemen who stayed awake .
Shakespearean: Cry mercy , lords and watchful gentlemen , That you have ta'en a tardy sluggard here .

English: How did you sleep , my lord ?
Shakespearean: How have you slept , my lord ?

English: Since you left , I've been enjoying the sweetest sleep and most promising dreams I've ever had , my lords .
Shakespearean: The sweetest sleep and fairest-boding dreams That ever entered in a drowsy head Have I since your departure had , my lords .

English: I dreamed the souls of the people Richard murdered came to my tent and promised me victory .
Shakespearean: Methought their souls whose bodies Richard murdered Came to my tent and cried on victory .

English: I tell you , I feel very jolly remembering such a beautiful dream .
Shakespearean: I promise you , my soul is very jocund In the remembrance of so fair a dream .

English: How late is it , lords ?
Shakespearean: How far into the morning is it , lords ?

English: It's almost four .
Shakespearean: Upon the stroke of four .

English: Why , then , it's time to put on my armor and instruct the troops .
Shakespearean: Why , then 'tis time to arm and give direction .

English: We have God and a good cause on our side .
Shakespearean: God and our good cause fight upon our side .

English: The prayers of saints and those that Richard wronged support us like high-walled fortresses .
Shakespearean: The prayers of holy saints and wronged souls , Like high-reared bulwarks , stand before our faces .

English: Other than Richard , even those whom we fight against would rather we won .
Shakespearean: Richard except , those whom we fight against Had rather have us win than him they follow .

English: Because who is this man they follow ?
Shakespearean: For what is he they follow ?

English: If you struggle to bring down a tyrant , you will sleep peacefully when the tyrant is killed .
Shakespearean: If you do sweat to put a tyrant down , You sleep in peace , the tyrant being slain .

English: When you fight against your country's enemies , you will be paid for your efforts with your country's wealth .
Shakespearean: If you do fight against your country's foes , Your country's fat shall pay your pains the hire .

English: If you fight to protect your wives , your wives will welcome you home as conquerors .
Shakespearean: If you do fight in safeguard of your wives , Your wives shall welcome home the conquerors .

English: When you free your children from the sword , your grandchildren will repay you in your old age .
Shakespearean: If you do free your children from the sword , Your children's children quits it in your age .

English: So , in the name of God and all the good that will come of this
Shakespearean: Then , in the name of God and all these rights , Advance your standards .

English: I wish they were , so that I could die right now , because , at this point , I live a living death .
Shakespearean: I would they were , that I might die at once , For now they kill me with a living death .

English: I never tried to win over a friend or enemy with sweet words .
Shakespearean: I never sued to friend , nor enemy ; My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word .

English: If your vengeful heart can't forgive me , here , take my sword and bury it in my heart so that my soul , which adores you , can be free .
Shakespearean: If thy revengeful heart can not forgive , Lo , here I lend thee this sharp-pointed sword , Which if thou please to hide in this true breast And let the soul forth that adoreth thee , I lay it naked to the deadly stroke And humbly beg the death upon my knee .

English: No , don't pause , because I
Shakespearean: Nay , do not pause ; for I did kill King Henry , But 'twas thy beauty that provoked me .

English: What did Northumberland say about Richmond ?
Shakespearean: What said Northumberland as touching Richmond ?

English: That he was never trained as a soldier .
Shakespearean: That he was never trained up in arms .

English: That's true .
Shakespearean: He said the truth .

English: And what did Surrey say to that ?
Shakespearean: And what said Surrey then ?

English: He smiled and said , "The better for us." He's right , and that's how it is .
Shakespearean: He smiled and said "The better for our purpose." He was in the right , and so indeed it is .

English: Read the time there .
Shakespearean: Tell the clock there .

English: Give me an almanac .
Shakespearean: Give me a calendar .

English: I didn't , my lord .
Shakespearean: Not I , my lord .

English: Ratcliffe !
Shakespearean: Ratcliffe !

English: My lord ?
Shakespearean: My lord .

English: The sun will not appear today .
Shakespearean: The sun will not be seen today .

English: The sky frowns and scowls on our army .
Shakespearean: The sky doth frown and lour upon our army .

English: I wish there wasn't so much dew on the ground .
Shakespearean: I would these dewy tears were from the ground .

English: So , the sun won't shine today !
Shakespearean: Not shine today ?

English: Get ready , my lord .
Shakespearean: Arm , arm , my lord .

English: The enemy is making its appearance on the battlefield .
Shakespearean: The foe vaunts in the field .

English: Hurry , hurry , prepare my horse .
Shakespearean: Come , bustle , bustle .

English: John Duke of Norfolk and Thomas Earl of Surrey will lead the horsemen and foot soldiers .
Shakespearean: John Duke of Norfolk , Thomas Earl of Surrey , Shall have the leading of this foot and horse .

English: I'll follow in the center of the troop formation , which I'll defend with my best horse , and with Saint George on my side , as well !
Shakespearean: They thus directed , we will follow In the main battle , whose puissance on either side Shall be well winged with our chiefest horse .

English: What do you think , Norfolk ?
Shakespearean: This , and Saint George to boot , What think'st thou , Norfolk ?

English: A good plan , warrior king .
Shakespearean: A good direction , warlike sovereign .

English: I found this pinned to my tent this morning .
Shakespearean: This found I on my tent this morning .

English: Listen !
Shakespearean: Hark !

English: I hear their drums .
Shakespearean: I hear their drum .

English: Startle even the sky with the sound of your lances cracking .
Shakespearean: Amaze the welkin with your broken staves ,

English: What does Lord Stanley say ?
Shakespearean: What says Lord Stanley ?

English: Will he bring his army ?
Shakespearean: Will he bring his power ?

English: My lord , he refuses to come .
Shakespearean: My lord , he doth deny to come .

English: Off with his son George's head !
Shakespearean: Off with his son George's head !

English: My lord , the enemy has already passed the marsh .
Shakespearean: My lord , the enemy is past the marsh .

English: Let George Stanley die after the battle .
Shakespearean: After the battle let George Stanley die .

English: Let's go !
Shakespearean: Upon them !

English: Victory is with us .
Shakespearean: Victory sits on our helms .

English: Help , my lord of Norfolk , help , help !
Shakespearean: Rescue , my lord of Norfolk , rescue , rescue !

English: The king performs more wonders than seem humanly possible , challenging every enemy he sees .
Shakespearean: The king enacts more wonders than a man , Daring an opposite to every danger .

English: His horse is killed , so he's fighting on foot , risking his life to search out Richmond .
Shakespearean: His horse is slain , and all on foot he fights , Seeking for Richmond in the throat of death .

English: Help , dear lord , or the battle will be lost !
Shakespearean: Rescue , fair lord , or else the day is lost !

English: A horse , a horse , I'd give my kingdom for a horse !
Shakespearean: A horse , a horse , my kingdom for a horse !

English: Get off the field , my lord .
Shakespearean: Withdraw , my lord .

English: I'll find you another horse .
Shakespearean: I'll help you to a horse .

English: God and your work be praised , victorious friends .
Shakespearean: God and your arms be praised , victorious friends !

English: Great God of heaven , say amen to all this !
Shakespearean: Great God of heaven , say amen to all !

English: But , tell me , is young George Stanley alive ?
Shakespearean: But tell me , is young George Stanley living ?

English: He is , my lord , and safe in Leicester , where , if you'd like , we can retreat to .
Shakespearean: He is , my lord , and safe in Leicester town , Whither , if it please you , we may now withdraw us .

English: John Duke of Norfolk , Walter Lord Ferrers , Sir Robert Brakenbury , and Sir William Brandon .
Shakespearean: John Duke of Norfolk , Walter , Lord Ferrers , Sir Robert Brakenbury , and Sir William Brandon .

English: As I vowed , I will unite the York and Lancaster families .
Shakespearean: And then , as we have ta'en the sacrament , We will unite the white rose and the red .

English: Smile , then , on this beautiful union .
Shakespearean: Smile heaven upon this fair conjunction , That long have frowned upon their enmity .

English: What traitor hears me and doesn't say amen ?
Shakespearean: What traitor hears me and says not "Amen ? " England hath long been mad and scarred herself .

English: Now let Richmond and Elizabeth , the true heirs of each royal house , be joined together !
Shakespearean: O , now let Richmond and Elizabeth , The true succeeders of each royal house , By God's fair ordinance conjoin together , And let their heirs , God , if thy will be so .

English: Gracious Lord , blunt the swords of those traitors who mean to tear poor England apart again !
Shakespearean: Abate the edge of traitors , gracious Lord , That would reduce these bloody days again , And make poor England weep in streams of blood !

English: Let those who would mar this fair land's peace with treason die before they can enjoy its wealth .
Shakespearean: Let them not live to taste this land's increase , That would with treason wound this fair land's peace .

English: Civil wounds now can heal , and peace can live again .
Shakespearean: Now civil wounds are stopped , peace lives again .

English: So that England may live a long life like this , let God say amen !
Shakespearean: That she may long live here , God say amen .

English: Take up the sword again , or take me up .
Shakespearean: Take up the sword again , or take up me .

English: Get up , liar .
Shakespearean: Arise , dissembler .

English: Though I wish you were dead , I'm not going to be the one to kill you .
Shakespearean: Though I wish thy death , I will not be the executioner .

English: I have already .
Shakespearean: I have already .

English: You said it when you were furious .
Shakespearean: That was in thy rage .

English: Say it again , just one word , and my hand , which killed your lover out of love , will kill your far truer lover .
Shakespearean: Speak it again and , even with the word , This hand , which for thy love did kill thy love , Shall for thy love kill a far truer love .

English: You will be an accessory to both crimes .
Shakespearean: To both their deaths shalt thou be accessory .

English: I wish I knew what was in your heart .
Shakespearean: I would I knew thy heart .

English: I've told you .
Shakespearean: Tis figured in my tongue .

English: I fear that your words and your heart are both false .
Shakespearean: I fear me both are false .

English: Then no man has ever been honest .
Shakespearean: Then never man was man true .

English: Well , then , put your sword away .
Shakespearean: Well , well , put up your sword .

English: Tell me that you'll accept my love .
Shakespearean: Say then my peace is made .

English: You'll know about that later .
Shakespearean: That shall you know hereafter .

English: But can I have some hope ?
Shakespearean: But shall I live in hope ?

English: I'd like to think all men have some hope .
Shakespearean: All men I hope live so .

English: Please wear this ring .
Shakespearean: Vouchsafe to wear this ring .

English: Wear both the ring and my heart , because both are yours .
Shakespearean: Wear both of them , for both of them are thine .

English: And if I , your poor devoted servant , may ask you for one small favor , you will guarantee my happiness forever .
Shakespearean: And if thy poor devoted servant may But beg one favor at thy gracious hand , Thou dost confirm his happiness forever .

English: What's that ?
Shakespearean: What is it ?

English: Please leave it to me to take care of the burial , as I have more reason to mourn than you do .
Shakespearean: That it would please you leave these sad designs To him that hath more cause to be a mourner , And presently repair to Crosby House , Where , after I have solemnly interred At Chertsey monast'ry this noble king And wet his grave with my repentant tears , I will with all expedient duty see you .

English: For various reasons that must remain secret , please do this for me .
Shakespearean: For divers unknown reasons , I beseech you , Grant me this boon .

English: I'll do it with all my heart .
Shakespearean: With all my heart , and much it joys me too To see you are become so penitent. , Tressel and Berkeley , go along with me .

English: Say goodbye to me .
Shakespearean: Bid me farewell .

English: Sirs , take up the corpse .
Shakespearean: Sirs , take up the corse .

English: Toward Chertsey , noble lord ?
Shakespearean: Towards Chertsey , noble lord ?

English: No , to the Whitefriars monastery .
Shakespearean: No , to Whitefriars .

English: Wait for me there .
Shakespearean: There attend my coming .

English: Has anyone ever courted a woman in this state of mind ?
Shakespearean: Was ever woman in this humor wooed ?

English: And has anyone ever won her , as I've done ?
Shakespearean: Was ever woman in this humor won ?

English: I'll get her , but I won't keep her long .
Shakespearean: I'll have her , but I will not keep her long .

English: And yet , against all odds , I win her over !
Shakespearean: And yet to win her , all the world to nothing !

English: Ha !
Shakespearean: Ha !

English: Has she already forgotten her brave husband , Prince Edward , whom I stabbed on the battlefield three months ago in my anger ?
Shakespearean: Hath she forgot already that brave prince , Edward , her lord , whom I some three months since Stabbed in my angry mood at Tewkesbury ?

English: He was graced with lots of natural gifts , he was young , valiant , wise , and no doubt meant to be king .
Shakespearean: A sweeter and a Lovellier gentleman , Framed in the prodigality of nature , Young , valiant , wise , and , no doubt , right royal , The spacious world can not again afford .

English: And yet she cheapens herself by turning her gaze on me , who cut her sweet prince's life short and made her a widow ?
Shakespearean: And will she yet abase her eyes on me , That cropped the golden prime of this sweet prince And made her widow to a woeful bed ?

English: On me , though I am barely half the man that Edward was ?
Shakespearean: On me , whose all not equals Edward's moiety ?

English: On me , though I am limping and deformed ?
Shakespearean: On me , that halts and am misshapen thus ?

English: I bet I've been wrong about myself all this time .
Shakespearean: My dukedom to a beggarly denier , I do mistake my person all this while !

English: Even though I don't see it , this lady thinks I'm a marvelously good-looking man .
Shakespearean: Upon my life , she finds , although I can not , Myself to be a marv'lous proper man .

English: Time to buy myself a mirror and employ a few dozen tailors to dress me up in the current fashions .
Shakespearean: I'll be at charges for a looking glass And entertain a score or two of tailors To study fashions to adorn my body .

English: Since I'm suddenly all the rage , it will be worth the cost .
Shakespearean: Since I am crept in favor with myself , I will maintain it with some little cost .

English: But first , I'll dump this fellow in his grave , then return to my love weeping with grief .
Shakespearean: But first I'll turn yon fellow in his grave And then return lamenting to my love .

English: Come out , beautiful sun , until I've bought a mirror to admire my reflection in , I'll watch my shadow as I stroll along .
Shakespearean: Shine out , fair sun , till I have bought a glass , That I may see my shadow as I pass .

English: Be patient , madam .
Shakespearean: Have patience , madam .

English: I'm sure his majesty will recover his health soon .
Shakespearean: There's no doubt his majesty Will soon recover his accustomed health .

English: Then you'll be able to cheer If he were dead , what would happen to me ?
Shakespearean: If he were dead , what would betide on me ?

English: But he's young , and as long as he's too young to become king , Richard , the duke of Gloucester , has power over him .
Shakespearean: Ah , he is young , and his minority Is put unto the trust of Richard Gloucester , A man that loves not me nor none of you .

English: Richard loves neither me nor any of you .
Shakespearean: Is it concluded that he shall be Protector ?
