English: Has it been decided that Richard will be It's been decided , though not yet officially announced .
Shakespearean: It is determined , not concluded yet ; But so it must be if the king miscarry .

English: I hope God makes you happy again , like you once were .
Shakespearean: God make your Majesty joyful , as you have been .

English: Did you see the king today , Lord Derby ?
Shakespearean: Saw you the king today , my lord of Derby ?

English: Yes , the duke of Buckingham and I have just returned from visiting him .
Shakespearean: But now the duke of Buckingham and I Are come from visiting his majesty .

English: What are the chances of his getting better , lords ?
Shakespearean: What likelihood of his amendment , lords ?

English: Madam , keep up hope .
Shakespearean: Madam , good hope .

English: He seems cheerful .
Shakespearean: His grace speaks cheerfully .

English: God give him health .
Shakespearean: God grant him health .

English: Did you talk with him ?
Shakespearean: Did you confer with him ?

English: Yes , madam .
Shakespearean: Ay , madam .

English: I wish I could believe you that all was well !
Shakespearean: Would all were well , but that will never be .

English: They're out to get me , and I won't stand for it !
Shakespearean: They do me wrong , and I will not endure it !

English: Which of you has been complaining to the king that I don't like them ?
Shakespearean: Who is it that complains unto the king That I , forsooth , am stern and love them not ?

English: Can't a plain man live and do no harm to anyone without being taken advantage of by a bunch of slick , sneaky lowlifes ?
Shakespearean: Can not a plain man live and think no harm , But thus his simple truth must be abused With silken , sly , insinuating jacks ?

English: Which of us are you referring to ?
Shakespearean: To whom in all this presence speaks your Grace ?

English: You , who are neither honest nor good .
Shakespearean: To thee , that hast nor honesty nor grace .

English: When did I ever do you any harm ?
Shakespearean: When have I injured thee ?

English: Or any of you ?
Shakespearean: Or any of your faction ?

English: Damn you all !
Shakespearean: A plague upon you all !

English: The king , whom I hope God will protect better than you would like , can't get a minute's rest without you bothering him with your outrageous complaints .
Shakespearean: His royal grace , Whom God preserve better than you would wish , Can not be quiet scarce a breathing while But you must trouble him with lewd complaints .

English: Brother , you've made a mistake .
Shakespearean: Brother of Gloucester , you mistake the matter .

English: He I can't tell what's going on .
Shakespearean: I can not tell .

English: The world has become so bad that now little wrens have settled where eagles used to roost .
Shakespearean: The world is grown so bad That wrens make prey where eagles dare not perch .

English: Come , come , I know what you're referring to , Richard .
Shakespearean: Come , come , we know your meaning , brother Gloucester .

English: You resent my friends ' rise in society , and my own .
Shakespearean: You envy my advancement , and my friends ' .

English: Let's hope we never need your help for anything .
Shakespearean: God grant we never may have need of you .

English: Meanwhile , we're the ones who need you .
Shakespearean: Meantime God grants that we have need of you .

English: My brother is imprisoned because of you , I am disgraced , and the nobility are held in contempt while those who two days ago weren't worth a dime have suddenly been promoted .
Shakespearean: Our brother is imprisoned by your means , Myself disgraced , and the nobility Held in contempt , while great promotions Are daily given to ennoble those That scarce some two days since were worth a noble .

English: By the Lord who raised me to this weighty post from the happy and carefree life I used to enjoy , I promise you I never did anything to get the king to turn against the duke of Clarence .
Shakespearean: By Him that raised me to this careful height From that contented hap which I enjoyed , I never did incense his majesty Against the duke of Clarence , but have been An earnest advocate to plead for him .

English: Since I can't amuse myself by being a lover , I've decided to become a villain .
Shakespearean: And therefore , since I can not prove a lover To entertain these fair well-spoken days , I am determined to prove a villain And hate the idle pleasures of these days .

English: I've set dangerous plans in motion , using lies , drunken prophecies , and stories about dreams to set my brother Clarence and the king against each other .
Shakespearean: Plots have I laid , inductions dangerous , By drunken prophecies , libels and dreams , To set my brother Clarence and the king In deadly hate , the one against the other ; And if King Edward be as true and just As I am subtle , false , and treacherous , This day should Clarence closely be mewed up About a prophecy which says that "G" Of Edward's heirs the murderer shall be .

English: His majesty is so concerned about my personal safety that he has ordered them to conduct me to the You're being arrested ?
Shakespearean: His majesty , Tend'ring my person's safety , hath appointed This conduct to convey me to the Tower .

English: Why ?
Shakespearean: Upon what cause ?

English: Because my name is George .
Shakespearean: Because my name is George .

English: That's not your fault !
Shakespearean: Alack , my lord , that fault is none of yours .

English: He should imprison the person who named you , instead .
Shakespearean: He should , for that , commit your godfathers .

English: Maybe the king is sending you to the Tower to have you renamed .
Shakespearean: O , belike his majesty hath some intent That you shall be new christened in the Tower .

English: But , really , what's going on , Clarence ?
Shakespearean: But what's the matter , Clarence ?

English: Can you tell me ?
Shakespearean: May I know ?

English: She could even what ?
Shakespearean: What may she not ?

English: Certainly , your grandmother had a worse match .
Shakespearean: I wis , your grandam had a worser match .

English: My lord of Gloucester , I have suffered your blunt upbraidings and your bitterness toward me for too long .
Shakespearean: My Lord of Gloucester , I have too long borne Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs .

English: By God , I will tell the king about these taunts .
Shakespearean: By heaven , I will acquaint his majesty With those gross taunts that oft I have endured .

English: I would rather be a country serving maid than a great queen if it meant I could escape your scorn and constant harassment .
Shakespearean: I had rather be a country servant-maid Than a great queen with this condition , To be so baited , scorned , and stormed at .

English: I've had very little joy as England's queen .
Shakespearean: Small joy have I in being England's queen .

English: If you were king , we would do the same .
Shakespearean: So should we you , if you should be our king .

English: If I were king ?
Shakespearean: If I should be ?

English: I'd rather be a peddler .
Shakespearean: I had rather be a peddler .

English: Hear me , you wrangling pirates .
Shakespearean: Hear me , you wrangling pirates , that fall out In sharing that which you have pilled from me !

English: Which of you does not tremble when you see me ?
Shakespearean: Which of you trembles not that looks on me ?

English: Ugly , wrinkled witch , what are you doing here ?
Shakespearean: Foul , wrinkled witch , what mak'st thou in my sight ?

English: Only describing what you have ruined .
Shakespearean: But repetition of what thou hast marred .

English: Or at least that's what I plan to do before I let you go .
Shakespearean: That will I make before I let thee go .

English: Weren't you banished on pain of death ?
Shakespearean: Wert thou not banished on pain of death ?

English: I was .
Shakespearean: I was , but I do find more pain in banishment Than death can yield me here by my abode .

English: The sorrow that I feel actually belongs to you , and the high life you enjoy actually belongs to me .
Shakespearean: The sorrow that I have by right is yours , And all the pleasures you usurp are mine .

English: Oh , killing that child was the dirtiest , most merciless deed there ever was !
Shakespearean: O , 'twas the foulest deed to slay that babe , And the most merciless that e'er was heard of !

English: Tyrants themselves wept when they heard about it .
Shakespearean: Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported .

English: Even What , were you all snarling before I arrived , ready to catch each other by the throat like dogs , but now that I'm here , you turn your hatred toward me ?
Shakespearean: What , were you snarling all before I came , Ready to catch each other by the throat , And turn you all your hatred now on me ?

English: All because of what happened to that brat Rutland ?
Shakespearean: Thyself a queen , for me that was a queen , Outlive thy glory , like my wretched self .

English: Enough of your magic spells , you hateful , withered hag .
Shakespearean: Have done thy charm , thou hateful , withered hag .

English: And leave you out ?
Shakespearean: And leave out thee ?

English: Don't move , dog .
Shakespearean: Stay , dog , for thou shalt hear me .

English: It's your turn now .
Shakespearean: The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul .

English: Richard .
Shakespearean: Richard !

English: Yes ?
Shakespearean: Ha ?

English: I didn't call you .
Shakespearean: I call thee not .

English: I beg your pardon , I thought it was me whom you were calling all those terrible names .
Shakespearean: I cry thee mercy , then , for I did think That thou hadst called me all these bitter names .

English: Yes , I was , but I don't want an answer from you .
Shakespearean: Why , so I did , but looked for no reply .

English: Let me finish my curse .
Shakespearean: O , let me make the period to my curse !

English: I've finished it for you , and it ends in "Margaret." He's turned your curse against you , Margaret .
Shakespearean: Tis done by me , and ends in "Margaret." Thus have you breathed your curse against yourself .

English: Poor imitation queen , why do you align yourself with this humpbacked spider when he's got you trapped in his deadly web ?
Shakespearean: Poor painted queen , vain flourish of my fortune , Why strew'st thou sugar on that bottled spider , Whose deadly web ensnareth thee about ?

English: The day will come when you'll wish I could help you cast spells against this poisonous , hunchbacked toad .
Shakespearean: The day will come that thou shalt wish for me To help thee curse that poisonous bunch-backed toad .

English: Woman , stop your frantic curses and false prophesies before we run out of patience and do something bad to you .
Shakespearean: False-boding woman , end thy frantic curse , Lest to thy harm thou move our patience .

English: Shame on you ; I've already run out of patience with you all .
Shakespearean: Foul shame upon you , you have all moved mine .

English: If you got what you deserved , you would learn some respect .
Shakespearean: Were you well served , you would be taught your duty .

English: What I deserve is that you treat me like a queen , and what you deserve is to act like my subjects .
Shakespearean: To serve me well , you all should do me duty : Teach me to be your queen , and you my subjects .

English: Give me what I deserve , and do your duty !
Shakespearean: O , serve me well , and teach yourselves that duty !

English: People in high positions are shaken by many blasts of wind , and when they fall , they shatter into pieces .
Shakespearean: They that stand high have many blasts to shake them , And if they fall , they dash themselves to pieces .

English: Good advice , indeed .
Shakespearean: Good counsel , marry .

English: Take it to heart , Dorset .
Shakespearean: Learn it , learn it , marquess .

English: It applies to you as much as to me , my lord .
Shakespearean: It touches you , my lord , as much as me .

English: But you turn that sun into a shadow .
Shakespearean: And turns the sun to shade .

English: You are building your nest in
Shakespearean: Urge neither charity nor shame to me .

English: Stop , if you can't be kind , at least have some shame .
Shakespearean: Uncharitably with me have you dealt , And shamefully my hopes by you are butchered .

English: How dare you talk about kindness or shame .
Shakespearean: My charity is outrage , life my shame , And in that shame still live my sorrows ' rage .

English: Enough , enough .
Shakespearean: Have done , have done .

English: Your clothes aren't spattered with my family's blood , and you aren't affected by my curse .
Shakespearean: Thy garments are not spotted with our blood , Nor thou within the compass of my curse .

English: No one here is affected by your curse , because curses are just words with no power .
Shakespearean: Nor no one here , for curses never pass The lips of those that breathe them in the air .

English: What is she saying , my lord ?
Shakespearean: What doth she say , my lord of Buckingham ?

English: Nothing that interests me , my good lord .
Shakespearean: Nothing that I respect , my gracious lord .

English: What , you ignore my kind advice and try to please the devil I'm warning you about ?
Shakespearean: What , dost thou scorn me for my gentle counsel , And soothe the devil that I warn thee from ?

English: Her curses have made my hair stand on end .
Shakespearean: My hair doth stand an end to hear her curses .

English: Mine , too .
Shakespearean: And so doth mine .

English: I don't understand why she's not locked up .
Shakespearean: I muse why she's at liberty .

English: I can't blame her .
Shakespearean: I can not blame her .

English: I never caused her any harm , as far as I know .
Shakespearean: I never did her any , to my knowledge .

English: But you have all the advantages from the harm done .
Shakespearean: Yet you have all the vantage of her wrong .

English: And look how he's repaid poor Clarence for his loyalty , penned him up like a pig being fattened for slaughter .
Shakespearean: Marry , as for Clarence , he is well repaid ; He is franked up to fatting for his pains .

English: God pardon those who are responsible for Clarence's troubles .
Shakespearean: God pardon them that are the cause thereof .

English: I always pray for them
Shakespearean: So do I ever For had I cursed now , I had cursed myself .

English: I'll tell you as soon as I know , Richard , because at this point I have no idea .
Shakespearean: Yea , Richard , when I know , for I protest As yet I do not .

English: He picked out the letter "G" from the alphabet and said a wizard told him that "G" will take the throne away from his children .
Shakespearean: But , as I can learn , He hearkens after prophecies and dreams , And from the crossrow plucks the letter And says a wizard told him that by "G" His issue disinherited should be .

English: He thinks "G" is me .
Shakespearean: And for my name of George begins with It follows in his thought that I am he .

English: Well , this is what happens when men let themselves be ruled by women .
Shakespearean: Why , this it is when men are ruled by women .

English: The king isn't the one sending you to the Tower , Clarence .
Shakespearean: Tis not the king that sends you to the Tower .

English: It's his wife , Lady Grey , who got him to do this .
Shakespearean: My Lady Grey his wife , Clarence , 'tis she That tempers him to this extremity .

English: Madam , his majesty asks for you , and for you , Duke of Gloucester , and for you , my noble lords .
Shakespearean: Madam , his majesty doth call for you , , And for your Grace , , and yours , my gracious lords .

English: We will wait on you , your majesty .
Shakespearean: We wait upon your Grace .

English: I do the wrong and am the first to start quarrels .
Shakespearean: I do the wrong , and first begin to brawl .

English: Dressing my out-and-out wickedness in scraps of Scripture , I look like a saint exactly when I'm most like the devil .
Shakespearean: Now they believe it and withal whet me To be revenged on Rivers , Dorset , Grey ; But then I sigh and , with a piece of scripture , Tell them that God bids us do good for evil ; And thus I clothe my naked villainy With odd old ends stolen out of Holy Writ , And seem a saint when most I play the devil .

English: But quiet .
Shakespearean: But , soft !

English: Are you going to take care of this thing now ?
Shakespearean: Are you now going to dispatch this thing ?

English: We are , my lord .
Shakespearean: We are , my lord , and come to have the warrant That we may be admitted where he is .

English: Good thinking .
Shakespearean: Well thought upon .

English: I have it on me here .
Shakespearean: I have it here about me .

English: Tut , tut , my lord , we're not going to stand around chit-chatting .
Shakespearean: Tut , tut , my lord , we will not stand to prate .

English: Talkers aren't good doers .
Shakespearean: Talkers are no good doers .

English: Rest assured that we're going there to use our hands , not our tongues .
Shakespearean: Be assured We go to use our hands and not our tongues .

English: When fools cry , you remain stony .
Shakespearean: Your eyes drop millstones , when fools ' eyes drop tears .

English: I like you guys .
Shakespearean: I like you lads .

English: Hurry now , get the job done .
Shakespearean: Go , go , dispatch .

English: We will , my noble lord .
Shakespearean: We will , my noble lord .

English: Why do you look so depressed today , your Grace ?
Shakespearean: Why looks your grace so heavily today ?

English: What was your dream ?
Shakespearean: What was your dream , my lord ?

English: Tell me .
Shakespearean: I pray you tell me .

English: I thought I had escaped from the Tower and was on a ship to France with my brother Richard , who persuaded me to leave my cabin and walk on deck with him .
Shakespearean: Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower And was embarked to cross to Burgundy , And in my company my brother Gloucester , Who from my cabin tempted me to walk Upon the hatches .

English: Looking toward England , we reminisced about the countless frightening experiences we'd had in the wars between the Yorks and the Lancasters .
Shakespearean: Thence we looked toward England And cited up a thousand fearful times , During the wars of York and Lancaster That had befall'n us .

English: Lord , how painful it was to drown .
Shakespearean: O Lord , methought what pain it was to drown , What dreadful noise of waters in my ears , What sights of ugly death within my eyes .

English: I saw a thousand shipwrecks , a thousand men whom fish had gnawed to the bone , huge anchors , chunks of gold , heaps of pearls , and precious jewels , all scattered on the bottom of the sea .
Shakespearean: Methoughts I saw a thousand fearful wracks , A thousand men that fishes gnawed upon , Wedges of gold , great anchors , heaps of pearl , Inestimable stones , unvalued jewels , All scattered in the bottom of the sea .

English: So you had time as you were dying to look around ?
Shakespearean: Had you such leisure in the time of death To gaze upon the secrets of the deep ?

English: It wouldn't let my soul find its way to air but smothered it inside my gasping body .
Shakespearean: Methought I had , and often did I strive To yield the ghost , but still the envious flood Stopped in my soul and would not let it forth To find the empty , vast , and wand'ring air , But smothered it within my panting bulk , Who almost burst to belch it in the sea .

English: In fact , the real nightmare had only just begun .
Shakespearean: I passed , methought , the melancholy flood , With that sour ferryman which poets write of , Unto the kingdom of perpetual night .

English: With the help of the grim The first to greet me there was my great
Shakespearean: The first that there did greet my stranger-soul Was my great father-in-law , renowned Warwick , Who spake aloud , "What scourge for perjury Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence ? " And so he vanished .

English: Clarence has arrived , lying , cowardly I'm not surprised it scared you , my lord .
Shakespearean: No marvel , lord , though it affrighted you .

English: It scares me just to hear you talk about it .
Shakespearean: I am afraid , methinks , to hear you tell it .

English: I did them for Edward's sake , and look how he rewards me. , Oh God , if my prayers don't satisfy you , and you have to avenge the wrongs I've done , at least punish me alone !
Shakespearean: Ah keeper , keeper , I have done those things , That now give evidence against my soul , For Edward's sake , and see how he requites me. , O God , if my deep prayers can not appease thee , But thou wilt be avenged on my misdeeds , Yet execute thy wrath in me alone !

English: Please spare my innocent wife and children ! , Kind warden , please stay with me for a while .
Shakespearean: O , spare my guiltless wife and my poor children ! , Keeper , I prithee sit by me awhile .

English: I'm feeling very low , and I need to sleep .
Shakespearean: My soul is heavy , and I fain would sleep .

English: I'll stay , my lord .
Shakespearean: I will , my lord .

English: May God bring you sleep !
Shakespearean: God give your Grace good rest .

English: Sorrow interrupts all hours and seasons .
Shakespearean: Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours , Makes the night morning , and the noontide night .

English: The only glory princes have are their titles .
Shakespearean: Princes have but their titles for their glories , An outward honor for an inward toil ,

English: What do you want , fellow ?
Shakespearean: What wouldst thou , fellow ?

English: And how did you get in here ?
Shakespearean: And how cam'st thou hither ?

English: I want to speak with Clarence , and I came here on my legs .
Shakespearean: I would speak with Clarence , and I came hither on my legs .

English: That's it ?
Shakespearean: What , so brief ?

English: Well , sir , it's better to say little than to be tedious .
Shakespearean: Tis better , sir , to be brief than tedious. , Let him see our commission , and talk no more .

English: It orders me to hand the noble duke of Clarence over to you .
Shakespearean: I am in this commanded to deliver The noble duke of Clarence to your hands .

English: Here are the keys , and there is the duke , sleeping .
Shakespearean: There lies the duke asleep , and there the keys .

English: You may , sir .
Shakespearean: You may , sir .

English: That's a wise idea .
Shakespearean: Tis a point of wisdom .

English: Goodbye .
Shakespearean: Fare you well .

English: What , should I stab him while he sleeps ?
Shakespearean: What , shall I stab him as he sleeps ?

English: No .
Shakespearean: No .

English: When he wakes up !
Shakespearean: He'll say 'twas done cowardly , when he wakes .

English: Why , he won't wake up till Judgment Day .
Shakespearean: Why , he shall never wake until the great Judgment Day .

English: Okay , so that's when he'll say we stabbed him in his sleep .
Shakespearean: Why , then he'll say we stabbed him sleeping .

English: That word "judgment" makes me feel a bit guilty .
Shakespearean: The urging of that word "judgment" hath bred a kind of remorse in me .

English: What , are you afraid ?
Shakespearean: What , art thou afraid ?

English: Not of killing him , because I have a warrant for it , but of being damned for killing him , which no warrant can protect me from .
Shakespearean: Not to kill him , having a warrant , but to be damned for killing him , from the which no warrant can defend me .

English: I thought you were resolved to do this .
Shakespearean: I thought thou hadst been resolute .

English: I am resolved , to let him live .
Shakespearean: So I am , to let him live .

English: I'll go back to the duke of Gloucester and tell him so .
Shakespearean: I'll back to the duke of Gloucester and tell him so .

English: Please , just wait a minute .
Shakespearean: Nay , I prithee stay a little .

English: I'm hoping my holy mood will pass .
Shakespearean: I hope this passionate humor of mine will change .

English: It usually only lasts about twenty seconds .
Shakespearean: It was wont to hold me but while one tells twenty .

English: How are you feeling now ?
Shakespearean: How dost thou feel thyself now ?

English: Actually , I'm still feeling some pangs of conscience .
Shakespearean: Faith , some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me .

English: Remember the reward we're getting when the deed's done .
Shakespearean: Remember our reward when the deed's done .

English: Jesus , let's kill him !
Shakespearean: Zounds , he dies !

English: I forgot about the reward .
Shakespearean: I had forgot the reward .

English: Where's your conscience now ?
Shakespearean: Where's thy conscience now ?

English: Oh , in the duke of Gloucester's wallet .
Shakespearean: O , in the duke of Gloucester's purse .

English: When he opens his wallet to give us our pay , your conscience will fly out ?
Shakespearean: So when he opens his purse to give us our reward , thy conscience flies out .

English: It won't matter .
Shakespearean: Tis no matter .

English: Let it fly out .
Shakespearean: Let it go .

English: No one will listen to it .
Shakespearean: There's few or none will entertain it .

English: And what will you do if it returns to you ?
Shakespearean: What if it come to thee again ?

English: I won't bother with it .
Shakespearean: I'll not meddle with it .

English: It blushes , is easily embarrassed , and stages regular uprisings in a man's heart .
Shakespearean: Tis a blushing , shamefaced spirit that mutinies in a man's bosom .

English: I'm strong-willed .
Shakespearean: I am strong-framed .

English: He won't get the better of me .
Shakespearean: He can not prevail with me .

English: Spoken like a brave man who respects his reputation .
Shakespearean: Spoke like a tall man that respects thy reputation .

English: Shall we get to work ?
Shakespearean: Come , shall we fall to work ?

English: We'll hit him on the head with the handles of our swords , then throw him in the wine barrel in the next room .
Shakespearean: Take him on the costard with the hilts of thy sword , and then throw him into the malmsey butt in the next room .

English: What an excellent idea , he'll soak up the wine !
Shakespearean: O excellent device , and make a sop of him .

English: Strike !
Shakespearean: Strike !

English: No , first let's talk to him .
Shakespearean: No , we'll reason with him .

English: Where are you , keeper ?
Shakespearean: Where art thou , keeper ?

English: Give me a cup of wine .
Shakespearean: Give me a cup of wine .

English: You'll have wine enough , my lord , soon .
Shakespearean: You shall have wine enough , my lord , anon .

English: In God's name , who are you ?
Shakespearean: In God's name , what art thou ?

English: A man , like you .
Shakespearean: A man , as you are .

English: But not a member of the royal family , like me .
Shakespearean: But not , as I am , royal .

English: And you're not loyal , like us .
Shakespearean: Nor you , as we are , loyal .

English: Your voice is loud and commanding , but you look like a working man .
Shakespearean: Thy voice is thunder , but thy looks are humble .

English: I'm speaking for the king , but I look like myself .
Shakespearean: My voice is now the king's , my looks mine own .

English: Your eyes look threatening .
Shakespearean: Your eyes do menace me .

English: And why are you so pale ?
Shakespearean: Why look you pale ?

English: Who sent you here ?
Shakespearean: Who sent you hither ?

English: Why are you here ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore do you come ?

English: To , to , to , To murder me ?
Shakespearean: To , to , to , To murder me ?

English: Yes .
Shakespearean: Ay , ay .

English: You barely have the heart to tell me , so you can't possibly have the nerve to do it .
Shakespearean: You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so , And therefore can not have the hearts to do it .

English: Besides , how have I offended you , my friends ?
Shakespearean: Wherein , my friends , have I offended you ?

English: You didn't offend us , you offended the king .
Shakespearean: Offended us you have not , but the king .

English: He and I will make up .
Shakespearean: I shall be reconciled to him again .

English: Never , my lord .
Shakespearean: Never , my lord .

English: So prepare to die .
Shakespearean: Therefore prepare to die .

English: It's your job in life to kill the innocent ?
Shakespearean: Are you drawn forth among a world of men To slay the innocent ?

English: What did I do wrong ?
Shakespearean: What is my offense ?

English: Where's the evidence against me ?
Shakespearean: Where is the evidence that doth accuse me ?

English: Where's the jury , the judge , the lawful proceedings , the verdict ?
Shakespearean: What lawful quest have given their verdict up Unto the frowning judge ?

English: Who pronounced this death sentence before a court of law could even convict me ?
Shakespearean: Or who pronounced The bitter sentence of poor Clarence ' death Before I be convict by course of law ?

English: For you to threaten to kill me is most unlawful .
Shakespearean: To threaten me with death is most unlawful .

English: If you hope to have your sins forgiven by Christ's dear blood , which He shed for our terrible sins , you must leave and keep your hands off me .
Shakespearean: I charge you , as you hope to have redemption , By Christ's dear blood shed for our grievous sins , That you depart , and lay no hands on me .

English: What we do we have been commanded to do .
Shakespearean: What we will do , we do upon command .

English: All right .
Shakespearean: Even so .

English: If you like , Brakenbury , you can listen to anything we say .
Shakespearean: An please your Worship , Brakenbury , You may partake of anything we say .

English: We're not saying anything treasonous , man .
Shakespearean: We speak no treason , man .

English: We say the king is wise and good , and his noble queen is getting old , pretty , and not jealous .
Shakespearean: We say the king Is wise and virtuous , and his noble queen Well struck in years , fair , and not jealous .

English: What do you think ?
Shakespearean: How say you , sir ?

English: Is there anything inaccurate in that ?
Shakespearean: Can you deny all this ?

English: I have nothing to do with what you're talking about , my lord .
Shakespearean: With this , my lord , myself have naught to do .

English: Her husband , you rascal .
Shakespearean: Her husband , knave .

English: Are you going to get me in trouble ?
Shakespearean: Wouldst thou betray me ?

English: I beg your
Shakespearean: I do beseech your Grace to pardon me , and withal Forbear your conference with the noble duke .

English: And the one who commands us is our king .
Shakespearean: And he that hath commanded is our king .

English: He does , and now he's taking revenge on you , for breaking promises and for murder , too .
Shakespearean: And that same vengeance doth He hurl on thee For false forswearing and for murder too .

English: Whom you swore you would protect and defend .
Shakespearean: Whom thou wert sworn to cherish and defend .

English: How dare you tell us about God's laws when you have broken them so savagely yourself ?
Shakespearean: How canst thou urge God's dreadful law to us When thou hast broke it in such dear degree ?

English: But for whose sake did I do that sick deed ?
Shakespearean: For whose sake did I that ill deed ?

English: For my brother Edward's sake .
Shakespearean: For Edward , for my brother , for his sake .

English: If God will be revenged for this deed , he will do it publicly .
Shakespearean: If God will be avenged for this deed , O , know you yet He doth it publicly !

English: God doesn't need to use indirect or illegal means to kill those who have offended him .
Shakespearean: Take not the quarrel from His powerful arm ; He needs no indirect or lawless course To cut off those that have offended Him .

English: My brother's love , the devil , and my own anger made me do it .
Shakespearean: My brother's love , the devil , and my rage .

English: I am his brother , and I love him very much .
Shakespearean: I am his brother , and I love him well .

English: You're mistaken .
Shakespearean: You are deceived .

English: Richard , the duke of Gloucester , hates you .
Shakespearean: Your brother Gloucester hates you .

English: No , he loves and cherishes me .
Shakespearean: O , no , he loves me , and he holds me dear .

English: Go to him from me .
Shakespearean: Go you to him from me .

English: We will .
Shakespearean: Ay , so we will .

English: Tell him that when our noble father , the duke of York , gave his three sons his blessing , he never imagined that our friendship would come to this .
Shakespearean: Tell him , when that our princely father York Blessed his three sons with his victorious arm , He little thought of this divided friendship .

English: Remind Richard of this , and he will weep .
Shakespearean: Bid Gloucester think of this , and he will weep .

English: Yes , he'll weep stones , as he taught us to do .
Shakespearean: Ay , millstones , as he lessoned us to weep .

English: Yes , as kind as snow to a harvest .
Shakespearean: Right , as snow in harvest .

English: Come on , you're fooling yourself .
Shakespearean: Come , you deceive yourself .

English: It's Richard who sent us here to slaughter you .
Shakespearean: Tis he that sends us to destroy you here .

English: Well , that's what he's doing , making you free to enjoy heaven .
Shakespearean: Why , so he doth , when he delivers you From this earth's thralldom to the joys of heaven .

English: Make peace with God , for you must die , my lord .
Shakespearean: Make peace with God , for you must die , my lord .

English: You have enough holy feeling to advise me to "make peace with God , " but you're willing to go to war with God by murdering me ?
Shakespearean: Have you that holy feeling in your souls To counsel me to make my peace with God , And art you yet to your own souls so blind That thou will war with God by murd'ring me ?

English: Oh sirs , consider this : those who sent you to do this deed will hate you for doing it .
Shakespearean: O sirs , consider : they that set you on To do this deed will hate you for the deed .

English: Relent , and save your souls .
Shakespearean: Relent , and save your souls .

English: If either of you were a prince's son , and you were imprisoned as I am now , and two murderers like yourselves came to you , wouldn't you beg for your life ?
Shakespearean: Which of you , if you were a prince's son Being pent from liberty , as I am now , If two such murderers as yourselves came to you , Would not entreat for life ?

English: Yes , you would beg , if you were in my position .
Shakespearean: Ay , you would beg , Were you in my distress .

English: Relent ?
Shakespearean: Relent ?

English: No .
Shakespearean: No .

English: That's cowardly and womanish .
Shakespearean: Tis cowardly and womanish .

English: Look behind you , my lord .
Shakespearean: Look behind you , my lord .

English: Take that , and that .
Shakespearean: Take that , and that .

English: A What's going on ?
Shakespearean: How now ?

English: What did you mean by not helping me ?
Shakespearean: What mean'st thou , that thou help'st me not ?

English: By God , I'm going to tell the duke how slack you've been .
Shakespearean: By heavens , the duke shall know how slack you have been .

English: I wish you could tell him I saved his brother .
Shakespearean: I would he knew that I had saved his brother .

English: I'm not .
Shakespearean: So do not I .

English: Go , coward that you are .
Shakespearean: Go , coward as thou art .

English: Well , I'll go hide the body in some hole until the duke gives orders for his burial .
Shakespearean: Well , I'll go hide the body in some hole Till that the duke give order for his burial .

English: And when I get my reward , I'll get out of here .
Shakespearean: And when I have my meed , I will away , For this will out , and then I must not stay .

English: Here comes your father .
Shakespearean: Here comes your father .

English: Don't even think about refusing .
Shakespearean: Never make denial .

English: I must and will have Katherine for my wife .
Shakespearean: I must and will have Katherine to my wife .

English: Now , Signior Petruchio , how are you getting on with my daughter ?
Shakespearean: Now , Signior Petruchio , how speed you with my daughter ?

English: Beautifully , sir , beautifully !
Shakespearean: How but well , sir ?

English: Now , daughter Katherine ?
Shakespearean: Why , how now , daughter Katherine ?

English: Are you down in the dumps ?
Shakespearean: In your dumps ?

English: You have the nerve to call me daughter ?
Shakespearean: Call you me daughter ?

English: Sir , this is the truth : you and the rest , all the people who have ever talked about her , have all been wrong .
Shakespearean: Father , 'tis thus : yourself and all the world That talked of her have talked amiss of her .

English: She has the patience of a I'll see you hanged on Sunday first !
Shakespearean: I'll see thee hanged on Sunday first .

English: Listen to that Petruchio : she says she'll see you hanged first .
Shakespearean: Hark , Petruchio : she says she'll see thee hanged first .

English: Is this your idea of success ?
Shakespearean: Is this your speeding ?

English: So much for our plan .
Shakespearean: Nay , then , good night our part .

English: Relax , gentlemen .
Shakespearean: Be patient , gentlemen .

English: I've made my choice .
Shakespearean: I choose her for myself .

English: If she and I are happy , what's it to you ?
Shakespearean: If she and I be pleased , what's that to you ?

English: When we were alone , we agreed that in public she would go on being unpleasant .
Shakespearean: Tis bargained 'twixt us twain , being alone , That she shall still be curst in company .

English: I tell you , though , it's incredible how much she loves me .
Shakespearean: I tell you , 'tis incredible to believe How much she loves me .

English: Darling Kate !
Shakespearean: O , the kindest Kate !

English: You men are rank beginners !
Shakespearean: O , you are novices !

English: Give me your hand , Kate .
Shakespearean: Tis a world to see , How tame , when men and women are alone , A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew. , Give me thy hand , Kate .

English: I'm off to Venice to buy outfits for the wedding .
Shakespearean: I will unto Venice To buy apparel 'gainst the wedding day .

English: God give you joy , Petruchio .
Shakespearean: God send you joy , Petruchio .

English: Call it a match !
Shakespearean: Tis a match .

English: Amen to that !
Shakespearean: Amen , say we .

English: We'll be your witnesses .
Shakespearean: We will be witnesses .

English: Father , wife , friends , farewell !
Shakespearean: Father , and wife , and gentlemen , adieu .

English: I'm off to Venice .
Shakespearean: I will to Venice .

English: Sunday is just around the corner .
Shakespearean: Sunday comes apace .

English: We're to be married on Sunday .
Shakespearean: We will be married o ' Sunday .

English: Was there ever a match put together so quickly ?
Shakespearean: Was ever match clapped up so suddenly ?

English: I've made a risky investment .
Shakespearean: Twill bring you gain or perish on the seas .

English: The only profit I seek is a peaceful match .
Shakespearean: The gain I seek is quiet in the match .

English: There's no doubt that Petruchio's got quite a catch .
Shakespearean: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch .

English: Now , Baptista , let's turn to your younger daughter .
Shakespearean: But now , Baptista , to your younger daughter .

English: We've been waiting a long time for this day .
Shakespearean: Now is the day we long have looked for .

English: I'm your neighbor and came courting first .
Shakespearean: I am your neighbor , and was suitor first .

English: Callow youth , you don't yet know how to love !
Shakespearean: Youngling , thou canst not love so dear as I. Graybeard , thy love doth freeze .

English: And you're all sizzle .
Shakespearean: But thine doth fry .

English: Stand back , boy .
Shakespearean: Skipper , stand back .

English: Age is the thing that nourishes .
Shakespearean: Tis age that nourisheth .

English: Enough , gentlemen .
Shakespearean: Content you , gentlemen .

English: I will settle this matter .
Shakespearean: I will compound this strife .

English: First of all , my house in the city , as you know , is filled with expensive furniture and household articles , china and gold , basins and pitchers for her to wash her dainty hands in .
Shakespearean: First , as you know , my house within the city Is richly furnished with plate and gold , Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands ; My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry , In ivory coffers I have stuffed my crowns , In cypress chests my arras counterpoints , Costly apparel , tents , and canopies , Fine linen , Turkey cushions bossed with pearl , Valance of Venice gold in needlework , Pewter and brass , and all things that belong To house or housekeeping .

English: Then , at my farm I have a hundred milk cows , a hundred and twenty fat oxen in my stables , and all the equipment necessary to maintain them .
Shakespearean: Then , at my farm I have a hundred milch-kine to the pail , Six score fat oxen standing in my stalls , And all things answerable to this portion .

English: Two thousand ducats a year from his land !
Shakespearean: Two thousand ducats by the year of land !

English: I can't offer her more than all I have .
Shakespearean: Nay , I have offered all , I have no more , And she can have no more than all I have .

English: I must admit your offer is the best .
Shakespearean: I must confess your offer is the best , And , let your father make her the assurance , She is your own ; else , you must pardon me .

English: Otherwise , forgive me , but if you should die before him , what becomes of her dowry ?
Shakespearean: If you should die before him , where's her dower ?

English: Oh , and young men never die ?
Shakespearean: And may not young men die as well as old ?

English: As you know , next Sunday my daughter Katherina is to be married .
Shakespearean: Well , gentlemen , I am thus resolved : On Sunday next , you know My daughter Katherina is to be married .

English: I believe your Honor is thinking of a character called Soto .
Shakespearean: I think 'twas Soto that your Honor means .

English: Yes , that was it .
Shakespearean: Tis very true .

English: You gave an excellent performance .
Shakespearean: Thou didst it excellent .

English: There is a particular lord who will watch you perform tonight .
Shakespearean: There is a lord will hear you play tonight ; But I am doubtful of your modesties , Lest over-eyeing of his odd behavior , For yet his Honor never heard a play , You break into some merry passion And so offend him .

English: Go , lad , and take them to the pantry .
Shakespearean: Go , sirrah , take them to the buttery And give them friendly welcome every one .

English: Farewell , good neighbor .
Shakespearean: Adieu , good neighbor .

English: Your father would be a fool to give you all his wealth and spend his declining years as a guest in your house .
Shakespearean: Sirrah young gamester , your father were a fool To give thee all and in his waning age Set foot under thy table .

English: It's absurd .
Shakespearean: Tut , a toy !

English: An old Italian fox is never that generous , my boy .
Shakespearean: An old Italian fox is not so kind , my boy .

English: Sneaky , dried-up old coot !
Shakespearean: A vengeance on your crafty withered hide !

English: Usually fathers produce children , not the other way around .
Shakespearean: Fathers commonly Do get their children .

English: But in this case of wooing , a child shall father his own father , if my wits don't fail me .
Shakespearean: But in this case of wooing , A child shall get a sire , if I fail not of my cunning .

English: I'll have my lessons in the order and manner
Shakespearean: His lecture will be done ere you have tuned .

English: Where did we leave off ?
Shakespearean: Where left we last ?

English: Here , madam : Translate .
Shakespearean: Here , madam : Conster them .

English: Now let me see if I can translate it .
Shakespearean: Now let me see if I can conster it .

English: There's no need to be , really , for , You're my teacher , so I must believe you .
Shakespearean: I must believe my master ; else , I promise you , I should be arguing still upon that doubt .

English: But let it go. , Now , Litio , it's your turn .
Shakespearean: But let it rest. , Now , Litio , to you .

English: I hope , sir , that you're not angry that I've been equally attentive to you both !
Shakespearean: Good master , take it not unkindly , pray , That I have been thus pleasant with you both .

English: You call this a scale ?
Shakespearean: Call you this "gamut" ?

English: I don't like it .
Shakespearean: Tut , I like it not .

English: I like doing things the old-fashioned way .
Shakespearean: Old fashions please me best .

English: Mistress , your father requests that you leave your books and come help decorate your sister's room .
Shakespearean: Mistress , your father prays you leave your books And help to dress your sister's chamber up .

English: You know tomorrow is her wedding day .
Shakespearean: You know tomorrow is the wedding day .

English: Farewell to both of you , dear teachers .
Shakespearean: Farewell , sweet masters both .

English: I have to go .
Shakespearean: I must be gone .

English: But there's reason for me to look more closely at this schoolmaster .
Shakespearean: But I have cause to pry into this pedant .

English: He acts like a man in love .
Shakespearean: Methinks he looks as though he were in love .

English: The humiliation is all mine .
Shakespearean: No shame but mine .

English: So now everyone will point at me and say , "Look , there goes the wife of that comedian Petruchio , if he could be bothered to marry the pathetic thing ! "
Shakespearean: Now must the world point at poor Katherine And say , "Lo , there is mad Petruchio's wife , If it would please him come and marry her ! " Upon my life , Petruchio means but well , Whatever fortune stays him from his word : Though he be blunt , I know him passing wise ; Though he be merry , yet withal he's honest .

English: Maybe , but I wish I'd never laid eyes on him .
Shakespearean: Would Katherine had never seen him , though !

English: Go , daughter .
Shakespearean: Go , girl .

English: I can not blame you now for weeping .
Shakespearean: I can not blame thee now to weep , For such an injury would vex a very saint , Much more a shrew of thy impatient humor .

English: Master , master !
Shakespearean: Master , master !

English: I have news , old news such as you never heard before !
Shakespearean: News , old news , and such news as you never heard of !

English: You say you have news that's old ?
Shakespearean: Is it new and old too ?

English: How can that be ?
Shakespearean: How may that be ?

English: Well , is it not news that Petruchio's coming ?
Shakespearean: Why , is it not news to hear of Petruchio's coming ?

English: Is he here ?
Shakespearean: Is he come ?

English: Why , no , sir .
Shakespearean: Why , no , sir .

English: What then ?
Shakespearean: What then ?

English: He is coming .
Shakespearean: He is coming .

English: When will he be here ?
Shakespearean: When will he be here ?

English: When he stands where I am and sees you there .
Shakespearean: When he stands where I am and sees you there .

English: Who comes with him ?
Shakespearean: Who comes with him ?

English: He's dressed like a freak , a total freak , and not at all like a proper footman or a gentleman's valet .
Shakespearean: A monster , a very monster in apparel , and not like a Christian footboy or a gentleman's lackey .

English: I am glad he's coming , however he's dressed .
Shakespearean: I am glad he's come , howsoe'er he comes .

English: Why , sir , he's not coming .
Shakespearean: Why , sir , he comes not .

English: Didn't you just say he was ?
Shakespearean: Didst thou not say he comes ?

English: Who ?
Shakespearean: Who ?

English: Petruchio ?
Shakespearean: That Petruchio came ?

English: Yes , Petruchio .
Shakespearean: Ay , that Petruchio came .

English: No , I said his horse is coming , with him on its back .
Shakespearean: No , sir , I say his horse comes , with him on his back .

English: Well , that's the same thing .
Shakespearean: Why , that's all one .

English: No , by Saint Jamy , I'll bet you a penny !
Shakespearean: Nay , by Saint Jamy , I hold you a penny , A horse and a man Is more than one And yet not many .

English: You are welcome , sir .
Shakespearean: You are welcome , sir .

English: I'll give you more instructions later .
Shakespearean: See this dispatched with all the haste thou canst : Anon I'll give thee more instructions .

English: I know the boy will be a convincing gentlewoman , taking up her exact walk and talk and gentle gestures .
Shakespearean: I know the boy will well usurp the grace , Voice , gait , and action of a gentlewoman .

English: I can't wait to hear him call the drunkard "husband , " and to watch my men smother their laughter as they pay their respects to this simple peasant .
Shakespearean: I long to hear him call the drunkard "husband , " And how my men will stay themselves from laughter When they do homage to this simple peasant .

English: I'll go and coach them .
Shakespearean: I'll in to counsel them .

English: Where is my lovely bride ?
Shakespearean: Where is my love ?

English: Why , sir , you know this is your wedding day .
Shakespearean: Why , sir , you know this is your wedding day .

English: It's a long story , and tough to listen to .
Shakespearean: Tedious it were to tell and harsh to hear .

English: But where is Kate ?
Shakespearean: But where is Kate ?

English: We're wasting time here .
Shakespearean: I stay too long from her .

English: Don't greet your bride in these disgraceful clothes .
Shakespearean: See not your bride in these unreverent robes .

English: Go to my room and put on something of mine .
Shakespearean: Go to my chamber , put on clothes of mine .

English: Not me .
Shakespearean: Not I , believe me .

English: I'll see her like this .
Shakespearean: Thus I'll visit her .

English: But surely you're not planning to
Shakespearean: But thus , I trust , you will not marry her .

English: Yes , just like this .
Shakespearean: Good sooth , even thus .

English: Though I expect she'll wear me out more quickly than I'll wear out what I'm wearing , which will be good for her and even better for me !
Shakespearean: Could I repair what she will wear in me As I can change these poor accoutrements , 'Twere well for Kate and better for myself .

English: But what a fool I am to stand here chatting when I should bid good morning to my bride and seal the bargain with a loving kiss .
Shakespearean: But what a fool am I to chat with you , When I should bid good morrow to my bride And seal the title with a lovely kiss !

English: He must be wearing this crazy outfit for some reason .
Shakespearean: He hath some meaning in his mad attire .

English: I'll try to persuade him to put on something more appropriate before going to the church , if it's at all possible .
Shakespearean: We will persuade him , be it possible , To put on better ere he go to church .

English: I'll go too and make sure that happens .
Shakespearean: I'll after him , and see the event of this .

English: And
Shakespearean: So shall you quietly enjoy your hope And marry sweet Bianca with consent .

English: We'll outwit them all , that old geezer , Gremio ; the suspicious father , Minola ; the prim musician lover , Litio , all for the sake of my master , Lucentio .
Shakespearean: We'll overreach the graybeard , Gremio , The narrow-prying father , Minola , The quaint musician , amorous Litio , All for my master's sake , Lucentio .

English: Signior Gremio , are you coming from the church ?
Shakespearean: Signior Gremio , came you from the church ?

English: As eagerly as I ever came from school .
Shakespearean: As willingly as e'er I came from school .

English: Bridegroom ?
Shakespearean: A bridegroom , say you ?

English: No , he's a devil , a devil , I tell you !
Shakespearean: Why , he's a devil , a devil , a very fiend .

English: Why , she's a lamb , a dove , a child compared to him !
Shakespearean: Tut , she's a lamb , a dove , a fool to him !

English: She trembled and shook because he stamped and swore and carried on as though the vicar were trying to put something over on him .
Shakespearean: Now take them up , " quoth he , "if any list." Trembled and shook , for why he stamped and swore As if the vicar meant to cozen him .

English: Finally , the ceremony done , he called for wine .
Shakespearean: But after many ceremonies done , He calls for wine .

English: Next he slung his arm around the bride's neck and kissed her with such a smack that when they parted the sound of their lips made the whole church echo .
Shakespearean: This done , he took the bride about the neck And kissed her lips with such a clamorous smack That at the parting all the church did echo .

English: That was the limit for me .
Shakespearean: Such a mad marriage never was before .

English: It's disgraceful !
Shakespearean: Hark , hark !

English: There go the minstrels .
Shakespearean: I hear the minstrels play .

English: You're not thinking of leaving tonight , surely ?
Shakespearean: Is 't possible you will away tonight ?

English: Not tonight , today .
Shakespearean: Make it no wonder .

English: If you knew the reason , you'd understand and would urge me to go rather than stay .
Shakespearean: If you knew my business , You would entreat me rather go than stay .

English: Good friends , I thank you all for coming to see me wed this patient , sweet , virtuous wife .
Shakespearean: And , honest company , I thank you all , That have beheld me give away myself To this most patient , sweet and virtuous wife .

English: Goodbye to you all .
Shakespearean: Let me entreat you .

English: Can't do it .
Shakespearean: It can not be .

English: As a favor to Nope .
Shakespearean: Let me entreat you .

English: As a favor to I'm delighted .
Shakespearean: I am content .

English: Delighted to stay ?
Shakespearean: Are you content to stay ?

English: Delighted to hear you ask so nicely , but I won't stay in any case .
Shakespearean: I am content you shall entreat me stay , But yet not stay , entreat me how you can .

English: Look , if you love me , stay .
Shakespearean: Now , if you love me , stay .

English: Grumio , get me my horse .
Shakespearean: Grumio , my horse .

English: Yes , sir , they're ready .
Shakespearean: Ay , sir , they be ready .

English: They've eaten themselves sick .
Shakespearean: The oats have eaten the horses .

English: The door is open , sir .
Shakespearean: The door is open , sir .

English: Go on , wear your boots out !
Shakespearean: There lies your way .

English: As for me , I'll leave when I like .
Shakespearean: For me , I'll not be gone till I please myself .

English: Calm down , Kate .
Shakespearean: O Kate , content thee .

English: Please don't be angry .
Shakespearean: Prithee , be not angry .

English: I will be angry .
Shakespearean: I will be angry .

English: What business is it of yours ? , Father , be quiet .
Shakespearean: What hast thou to do ? , Father , be quiet .

English: He'll stay as long as I say .
Shakespearean: He shall stay my leisure .

English: Okay , now it starts !
Shakespearean: Ay , marry , sir , now it begins to work .

English: Gentlemen , on to the bridal dinner .
Shakespearean: Gentlemen , forward to the bridal dinner .

English: I see a woman may be made a fool of if she doesn't have nerve enough to stand up for herself .
Shakespearean: I see a woman may be made a fool If she had not a spirit to resist .

English: They
Shakespearean: I'll buckler thee against a million .

English: No , let them go .
Shakespearean: Nay , let them go , a couple of quiet ones .

English: They're certainly a peaceful couple !
Shakespearean: Went they not quickly , I should die with laughing .

English: That since she's mad herself , she's married a madman .
Shakespearean: That , being mad herself , she's madly mated .

English: Neighbors and friends , though we don't have anyone for the bride and bridegroom's places at the table , you know there's nothing missing in the feast itself .
Shakespearean: Neighbors and friends , though bride and bridegroom wants For to supply the places at the table , You know there wants no junkets at the feast .

English: She shall , Lucentio .
Shakespearean: She shall , Lucentio .

English: Come , gentlemen , let's go in .
Shakespearean: Come , gentlemen , let's go .

English: To hell with all worn-out horses , all crazy masters , and all bad roads .
Shakespearean: Fie , fie on all tired jades , on all mad masters , and all foul ways !

English: Was a man ever beaten as much as me ?
Shakespearean: Was ever man so beaten ?

English: Was a man ever as dirty as me ?
Shakespearean: Was ever man so 'rayed ?

English: Was a man ever so tired ?
Shakespearean: Was ever man so weary ?

English: I have been sent on ahead to light a fire , and they are coming after to warm themselves .
Shakespearean: I am sent before to make a fire , and they are coming after to warm them .

English: It's a good thing I'm like a little pot and warm up quickly , or else my lips themselves would freeze and stick to my teeth , my tongue to the roof of my mouth , and my heart would freeze in my belly , before I managed to get thawed out .
Shakespearean: Now , were not I a little pot and soon hot , my very lips might freeze to my teeth , my tongue to the roof of my mouth , my heart in my belly , ere I should come by a fire to thaw me .

English: I'll warm myself by blowing on the fire .
Shakespearean: But I with blowing the fire shall warm myself .

English: Who calls so coldly ?
Shakespearean: Who is that calls so coldly ?

English: A piece of ice .
Shakespearean: A piece of ice .

English: Trust me , you could slide all the way from my shoulder to my heel taking no more of a running start than the distance between my head and my neck .
Shakespearean: If thou doubt it , thou mayst slide from my shoulder to my heel with no greater a run but my head and my neck .

English: Start the fire , good Curtis .
Shakespearean: A fire , good Curtis .

English: Are my master and his wife coming , Grumio ?
Shakespearean: Is my master and his wife coming , Grumio ?

English: Yes , yes , Curtis , so hurry up and start the fire .
Shakespearean: Oh , ay , Curtis , ay , and therefore fire , fire .

English: Leave out the water .
Shakespearean: Cast on no water .

English: Is she as fiery a shrew as they say ?
Shakespearean: Is she so hot a shrew as she's reported ?

English: Well she was , good Curtis , before this frost .
Shakespearean: She was , good Curtis , before this frost .

English: Your horn is a foot long , and I'm at least that size .
Shakespearean: Why , thy horn is a foot , and so long am I , at the least .

English: So tell me , Grumio , how goes the world ?
Shakespearean: I prithee , good Grumio , tell me , how goes the world ?

English: Therefore , do your duty and take your reward , because my master and mistress are nearly frozen to death .
Shakespearean: Do thy duty , and have thy duty , for my master and mistress are almost frozen to death .

English: The fire is ready .
Shakespearean: There's fire ready .

English: So go on , tell me the news .
Shakespearean: And therefore , good Grumio , the news .

English: I think I'm getting delirious .
Shakespearean: Why , therefore fire , for I have caught extreme cold .

English: Where's the cook ?
Shakespearean: Where's the cook ?

English: Is supper ready ?
Shakespearean: Is supper ready , the house trimmed , rushes strewed , cobwebs swept , the servingmen in their new fustian , their white stockings , and every officer his wedding garment on ?

English: Are all the cups and glasses in their places , the tablecloths laid out , everything in order ?
Shakespearean: Be the Jacks fair within , the Jills fair without , the carpets laid , and everything in order ?

English: For God's sake , would someone bring me a mug of beer !
Shakespearean: For God's sake , a pot of small ale .

English: Would your Honor like to try this dried fruit ?
Shakespearean: Will 't please your Honor taste of these conserves ?

English: What garment would your Honor like to wear today ?
Shakespearean: What raiment will your Honor wear today ?

English: I'm Christopher Sly .
Shakespearean: I am Christophero Sly .

English: Everything's ready .
Shakespearean: All ready .

English: So tell me what's been going on .
Shakespearean: And therefore , I pray thee , news .

English: Well , first of all , my horse is tired and my master and mistress have had a falling out .
Shakespearean: First , know my horse is tired , my master and mistress fallen out .

English: How ?
Shakespearean: How ?

English: From their saddles into the dirt , but that's another story .
Shakespearean: Out of their saddles into the dirt , and thereby hangs a tale .

English: Well , let's have it , Grumio .
Shakespearean: Let's ha ' 't , good Grumio .

English: Lean forward .
Shakespearean: Lend thine ear .

English: Here .
Shakespearean: Here .

English: There !
Shakespearean: There !

English: This is to feel the news , not hear it .
Shakespearean: This 'tis to feel a tale , not to hear a tale .

English: That's what makes it "sensitive" news .
Shakespearean: And therefore 'tis called a sensible tale .

English: I was just knocking to see if anyone was home .
Shakespearean: And this cuff was but to knock at your ear and beseech list'ning .

English: Now , I'll begin : first , we came down a steep hill , my master riding behind my mistress , Both on one horse ?
Shakespearean: Now I begin : Imprimis , we came down a foul hill , my master riding behind my mistress , Both of one horse ?

English: What's the difference ?
Shakespearean: What's that to thee ?

English: Well , the difference of a horse !
Shakespearean: Why , a horse .

English: It's too bad .
Shakespearean: Tell thou the tale !

English: Yes , as you and the rest will find out as soon as he's home .
Shakespearean: Ay , and that thou and the proudest of you all shall find when he comes home .

English: But why am I telling you this ?
Shakespearean: But what talk I of this ?

English: Get them in here , Nathaniel , Joseph , Nicholas , Philip , Walter , Sugarsop , and the rest .
Shakespearean: Call forth Nathaniel , Joseph , Nicholas , Philip , Walter , Sugarsop , and the rest .

English: Tell them to slick down their hair , brush their blue coats , and make sure their socks match .
Shakespearean: Let their heads be slickly combed , their blue coats brushed , and their garters of an indifferent knit .

English: Have them click their heels together and don't dare touch a hair of the master's horse's tail till they kiss their hands .
Shakespearean: Let them curtsy with their left legs , and not presume to touch a hair of my master's horse-tail till they kiss their hands .

English: Are they all ready ?
Shakespearean: Are they all ready ?

English: They are .
Shakespearean: They are .

English: Get them in here .
Shakespearean: Call them forth .

English: She already has a face .
Shakespearean: Why , she hath a face of her own .

English: Yeah , so ?
Shakespearean: Who knows not that ?

English: You just said they had to face her .
Shakespearean: Thou , it seems , that calls for company to countenance her .

English: I meant they had to give her credit .
Shakespearean: I call them forth to credit her .

English: She's not going to borrow money from them .
Shakespearean: Why , she comes to borrow nothing of them .

English: Welcome home , Grumio .
Shakespearean: Welcome home , Grumio .

English: What's up , Grumio ?
Shakespearean: How now , Grumio ?

English: Hey , Grumio !
Shakespearean: What , Grumio !

English: My man Grumio !
Shakespearean: Fellow Grumio !

English: So what's the story , old boy ?
Shakespearean: How now , old lad ?

English: Any minute .
Shakespearean: E'en at hand , alighted by this .

English: Where are those bastards ?
Shakespearean: Where be these knaves ?

English: Here , here , sir !
Shakespearean: Here , here , sir !

English: Here , sir !
Shakespearean: Here , sir !

English: Here , sir !
Shakespearean: Here , sir !

English: Here , sir !
Shakespearean: Here , sir !

English: Here , sir !
Shakespearean: Here , sir !

English: Here , sir ! " You stupid , unpolished dolts !
Shakespearean: Here , sir ! " You loggerheaded and unpolished grooms !

English: Where is the fool I sent on ahead ?
Shakespearean: Where is the foolish knave I sent before ?

English: Here , sir , as foolish as ever .
Shakespearean: Here , sir , as foolish as I was before .

English: You unwashed farmworker !
Shakespearean: You peasant swain !

English: You bastard workhorse drudge !
Shakespearean: You whoreson malt-horse drudge !

English: Didn't I tell you to meet me outside and bring these morons with you ?
Shakespearean: Did I not bid thee meet me in the park And bring along these rascal knaves with thee ?

English: Nathaniel's coat was being fixed , sir .
Shakespearean: Nathaniel's coat , sir , was not fully made , And Gabriel's pumps were all unpinked i ' th ' heel .

English: And Walter couldn't get his dagger out of its sheath .
Shakespearean: There was no link to color Peter's hat , And Walter's dagger was not come from sheathing .

English: Only Adam , Rafe , and Gregory were ready .
Shakespearean: There were none fine but Adam , Rafe , and Gregory .

English: Go , blockheads , go , and bring my supper to me .
Shakespearean: Go , rascals , go , and fetch my supper in .

English: Where are my slippers ?
Shakespearean: One , Kate , that you must kiss and be acquainted with. , Where are my slippers ?

English: Can we have some water please here ? , Come and wash , Kate , make yourself at home .
Shakespearean: Shall I have some water ? , Come , Kate , and wash , and welcome heartily. , You whoreson villain !

English: Take it easy !
Shakespearean: Will you let it fall ?

English: Please !
Shakespearean: Patience , I pray you !

English: It was just an accident !
Shakespearean: Twas a fault unwilling .

English: Will you say grace , sweet Kate , or shall I ? , What is this ?
Shakespearean: Will you give thanks , sweet Kate , or else shall I ? , What's this ?

English: Mutton ?
Shakespearean: Mutton ?

English: Yes .
Shakespearean: Ay .

English: Who brought it out here ?
Shakespearean: Who brought it ?

English: I did .
Shakespearean: I .

English: You bastards !
Shakespearean: What dogs are these !

English: Where is that moron of a cook ?
Shakespearean: Where is the rascal cook ?

English: How dare you serve it to me this way !
Shakespearean: How durst you , villains , bring it from the dresser And serve it thus to me that love it not ?

English: There , take it all back , plates , cups , the whole thing .
Shakespearean: There , take it to you , trenchers , cups , and all !

English: Please , dear , calm down .
Shakespearean: I pray you , husband , be not so disquiet .

English: The meat was fine if you wanted to eat it .
Shakespearean: The meat was well , if you were so contented .

English: And I'm telling you it was burnt and dried out .
Shakespearean: I tell thee , Kate , 'twas burnt and dried away .

English: Come , I'll show you your bridal chamber .
Shakespearean: Come , I will bring thee to thy bridal chamber .

English: Peter , did you ever see anything like it ?
Shakespearean: Peter , didst ever see the like ?

English: He's giving her a taste of her own medicine .
Shakespearean: He kills her in her own humor .

English: Where is he ?
Shakespearean: Where is he ?

English: Look out , he's coming !
Shakespearean: Away , away , for he is coming hither !

English: Well , I've begun my reign with a carefully thought-out plan , and I have every hope of succeeding .
Shakespearean: Thus have I politicly begun my reign , And 'tis my hope to end successfully .

English: My falcon is now hungry and unfed and must not be given enough to eat until she comes to me , for if her hunger is satisfied , she'll pay no attention to the bait .
Shakespearean: My falcon now is sharp and passing empty , And , till she stoop , she must not be full-gorged , For then she never looks upon her lure .

English: I have another plan to make my bird come to me and recognize her owner's call is to keep her from sleeping ,
Shakespearean: Another way I have to man my haggard , To make her come and know her keeper's call .

English: the way trainers do with young hawks that flutter and flap and will not obey .
Shakespearean: That is , to watch her , as we watch these kites That bate and beat and will not be obedient .

English: She had no food today and will have none .
Shakespearean: She ate no meat today , nor none shall eat .

English: Last night she got no sleep , and she won't get any tonight .
Shakespearean: Last night she slept not , nor tonight she shall not .

English: Just as I did with the meat , I'll make up some problem with the way the bed is made , and throw the pillow one way and the cushion the other , and the blanket over here and the sheets over there .
Shakespearean: As with the meat , some undeserved fault I'll find about the making of the bed , And here I'll fling the pillow , there the bolster , This way the coverlet , another way the sheets .

English: And if she starts to drop off , I'll rant and yell until I wake her up .
Shakespearean: And , in conclusion , she shall watch all night , And if she chance to nod I'll rail and brawl , And with the clamor keep her still awake .

English: If anyone here knows a better way to tame a shrew , speak up , please .
Shakespearean: He that knows better how to tame a shrew , Now let him speak ; 'tis charity to show .

English: It would be much appreciated .
Shakespearean: Is 't possible , friend Litio , that mistress Bianca Doth fancy any other but Lucentio ?

English: What are you reading , teacher ?
Shakespearean: What , master , read you ?

English: Answer me that first .
Shakespearean: First resolve me that .

English: I hope you're an expert in your field .
Shakespearean: And may you prove , sir , master of your art .

English: Let me come clean .
Shakespearean: I tell thee , Litio , this is wonderful !

English: I'm not really Litio .
Shakespearean: Mistake no more .

English: My name is Hortensio , sir .
Shakespearean: Know , sir , that I am called Hortensio .

English: Look how they kiss and carry on !
Shakespearean: See how they kiss and court !

English: The hell with her !
Shakespearean: Fie on her !

English: Look how she carries on with him !
Shakespearean: See how beastly she doth court him !

English: It's revolting !
Shakespearean: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn !

English: Well , to be on the safe side , so I don't go back on my promise , I plan to get myself married to a wealthy widow within the next three days .
Shakespearean: For me , that I may surely keep mine oath , I will be married to a wealthy widow , Ere three days pass , which hath as long loved me As I have loved this proud disdainful haggard .

English: Farewell , then , Signior Lucentio .
Shakespearean: And so farewell , Signior Lucentio .

English: From now on , goodness in women , not superficial beauty , will win my heart .
Shakespearean: Kindness in women , not their beauteous looks , Shall win my love , and so I take my leave , In resolution as I swore before .

English: What , are you trying to make me crazy ?
Shakespearean: What , would you make me mad ?

English: I'm Christopher Sly , son of old Sly of Barton-on-Heath , a peddler by birth , a Oh , this is why your poor wife is mourning !
Shakespearean: Am not I Christopher Sly , old Sly's son of Burton Heath , by birth a peddler , by education a cardmaker , by transmutation a bearherd , and now by present profession a tinker ?

English: And this is why your servants hang their heads in sorrow !
Shakespearean: Oh , this is it that makes your servants droop !

English: Oh noble lord , consider your lineage .
Shakespearean: O noble lord , bethink thee of thy birth , Call home thy ancient thoughts from banishment , And banish hence these abject lowly dreams .

English: Look how your servants wait on you , each one ready to do whatever you command .
Shakespearean: Look how thy servants do attend on thee , Each in his office ready at thy beck .

English: Would you care to hear some music ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou have music ?

English: Listen !
Shakespearean: Hark !

English: Do you want to sleep ?
Shakespearean: Apollo plays , And twenty caged nightingales do sing : Or wilt thou sleep ?

English: We'll have a couch made up that's softer and more fragrant even than the bed of lustful
Shakespearean: We'll have thee to a couch Softer and sweeter than the lustful bed On purpose trimmed up for Semiramis .

English: You're busted .
Shakespearean: Or wilt thou hunt ?

English: Hortensio and I have given you up .
Shakespearean: Nay , I have ta'en you napping , gentle love , And have forsworn you with Hortensio .

English: You can't mean it , Tranio !
Shakespearean: Tranio , you jest .

English: Have you both really given me up ?
Shakespearean: But have you both forsworn me ?

English: Yes , ma'am , we have .
Shakespearean: Mistress , we have .

English: So Litio's out of the picture .
Shakespearean: Then we are rid of Litio .

English: He's going after a young widow .
Shakespearean: I ' faith , he'll have a lusty widow now That shall be wooed and wedded in a day .

English: Well , good for him !
Shakespearean: God give him joy !

English: Yeah , and he's going to tame her .
Shakespearean: Ay , and he'll tame her .

English: Is that what he says ?
Shakespearean: He says so , Tranio ?

English: The taming school ?
Shakespearean: The taming school ?

English: Is there such a place ?
Shakespearean: What , is there such a place ?

English: Master , master , I've been on the lookout so long , I'm ready to fall down dead , but I've got one , finally !
Shakespearean: Ay , mistress , and Petruchio is the master , That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue .

English: What does he look like , Biondello ?
Shakespearean: What is he , Biondello ?

English: And what about him , Tranio ?
Shakespearean: And what of him , Tranio ?

English: Go , take your sweetheart and leave him to me .
Shakespearean: Take in your love , and then let me alone .

English: May God keep you well , sir .
Shakespearean: God save you , sir .

English: This is it , for now .
Shakespearean: You are welcome .

English: Mantua .
Shakespearean: Of Mantua .

English: Killed ?
Shakespearean: My life , sir !

English: Why ?
Shakespearean: how , I pray ?

English: That would be a little extreme !
Shakespearean: For that goes hard .

English: It's a capital offense for anyone from Mantua to come to Padua .
Shakespearean: Tis death for anyone in Mantua To come to Padua .

English: Didn't you know ?
Shakespearean: Know you not the cause ?

English: It's strange that you haven't heard .
Shakespearean: Tis marvel , but that you are but newly come , You might have heard it else proclaimed about .

English: I have promissory notes from Florence that I have to deliver .
Shakespearean: Alas , sir , it is worse for me than so , For I have bills for money by exchange From Florence , and must here deliver them .

English: Oh yes , sir , I have often been to Pisa , Pisa , City of Wise Men .
Shakespearean: Ay , sir , in Pisa have I often been , Pisa renowned for grave citizens .

English: Oh sir , I accept .
Shakespearean: O sir , I do , and will repute you ever The patron of my life and liberty .

English: And I'll be eternally grateful to you .
Shakespearean: In all these circumstances I'll instruct you .

English: No , no , I can't , really .
Shakespearean: No , no , forsooth , I dare not for my life .

English: The more I suffer , the more spiteful he becomes .
Shakespearean: The more my wrong , the more his spite appears .

English: Did he marry me just to starve me ?
Shakespearean: What , did he marry me to famish me ?

English: And if they don't find charity there , they find it someplace else .
Shakespearean: If not , elsewhere they meet with charity .

English: But I , who have never known how to beg and never had to beg , am starved for food , dizzy with lack of sleep , kept awake with curses and fed with brawling .
Shakespearean: But I , who never knew how to entreat , Nor never needed that I should entreat , Am starved for meat , giddy for lack of sleep , With oaths kept waking and with brawling fed .

English: And what irks me more than all these things put together is that he does it under the pretense of love , as though for me to eat or sleep would bring on fatal illness or sudden death .
Shakespearean: And that which spites me more than all these wants , He does it under name of perfect love , As who should say , if I should sleep or eat , 'Twere deadly sickness or else present death .

English: What do you say to a calf's foot ?
Shakespearean: What say you to a neat's foot ?

English: Oh , lovely .
Shakespearean: Tis passing good .

English: Can I have some ?
Shakespearean: I prithee let me have it .

English: I'm afraid it will I'd love it .
Shakespearean: I fear it is too choleric a meat .

English: Nice Grumio , bring me some .
Shakespearean: Good Grumio , fetch it me .

English: I don't know .
Shakespearean: I can not tell .

English: I'm afraid it will make you too hot , too .
Shakespearean: I fear 'tis choleric .

English: What do you say to a piece of beef with mustard ?
Shakespearean: What say you to a piece of beef and mustard ?

English: Yes , but the mustard is probably too hot .
Shakespearean: Ay , but the mustard is too hot a little .

English: Well then , the beef without the mustard .
Shakespearean: Why then , the beef , and let the mustard rest .

English: Absolutely not .
Shakespearean: Nay then , I will not .

English: You'll take the mustard or you'll get no beef from Grumio .
Shakespearean: You shall have the mustard Or else you get no beef of Grumio .

English: Then both , or one , or anything you like .
Shakespearean: Then both , or one , or anything thou wilt .

English: How about the mustard without the beef .
Shakespearean: Why then , the mustard without the beef .

English: Get out of here , you measly , lying wretch .
Shakespearean: Go , get thee gone , I say .

English: Cheer up .
Shakespearean: Mistress , what cheer ?

English: Give us a smile .
Shakespearean: Pluck up thy spirits .

English: Look , love , see how devoted I am ?
Shakespearean: Here love , thou seest how diligent I am , To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee .

English: I am sure , sweet Kate , this kindness deserves thanks .
Shakespearean: I am sure , sweet Kate , this kindness merits thanks .

English: What , not a word ?
Shakespearean: What , not a word ?

English: I guess you don't want it .
Shakespearean: Nay , then thou lov'st it not And all my pains is sorted to no proof .

English: Here , take away the dish .
