Shakespearean: Here , take away this dish .

English: Please , leave it here .
Shakespearean: I pray you , let it stand .

English: Thank you , sir .
Shakespearean: I thank you , sir .

English: Come , mistress Kate , I'll join you .
Shakespearean: Come , mistress Kate , I'll bear you company .

English: Now , tailor , let's see what you've got .
Shakespearean: Come , tailor , let us see these ornaments .

English: Lay out the gown .
Shakespearean: Lay forth the gown .

English: What can I do for you , sir ?
Shakespearean: What news with you , sir ?

English: Here is the cap your Worship ordered .
Shakespearean: Here is the cap your Worship did bespeak .

English: Why , this was modeled on a porridge bowl !
Shakespearean: Why , this was molded on a porringer !

English: No , definitely not !
Shakespearean: A velvet dish !

English: It's cheap and nasty !
Shakespearean: Fie , fie , 'tis lewd and filthy !

English: It's like a cockleshell or a walnut shell , a joke , a prank , a doll's cap .
Shakespearean: Why , 'tis a cockle or a walnut shell , A knack , a toy , a trick , a baby's cap .

English: Take it away .
Shakespearean: Away with it !

English: Bring me a bigger one .
Shakespearean: Come , let me have a bigger .

English: I won't have one any bigger .
Shakespearean: I'll have no bigger .

English: When you are gentle , you shall have one , too , and not till then .
Shakespearean: When you are gentle , you shall have one too , And not till then .

English: Sir , I think I have the right to speak , and speak I certainly will .
Shakespearean: Why , sir , I trust I may have leave to speak , And speak I will .

English: I am not a child or an infant .
Shakespearean: I am no child , no babe .

English: Better men than you have heard me speak my mind , and if you can't take it , then you'd better plug your ears .
Shakespearean: Your betters have endured me say my mind , And if you can not , best you stop your ears .

English: You know , you're right .
Shakespearean: Why , thou say'st true .

English: It's a measly little cap , a dessert crust , a plaything , a silk pie .
Shakespearean: It is a paltry cap , A custard-coffin , a bauble , a silken pie .

English: I love you all the more for not liking it .
Shakespearean: I love thee well in that thou lik'st it not .

English: I don't care if you love me or not , I like the cap and I'll have it or I won't have any .
Shakespearean: Love me or love me not , I like the cap , And it I will have , or I will have none .

English: Now , your gown ?
Shakespearean: Thy gown ?

English: Yes , yes .
Shakespearean: Why , ay .

English: Come , tailor , show it to us .
Shakespearean: Come , tailor , let us see 't .

English: Merciful God !
Shakespearean: O mercy , God !

English: What do you call this ?
Shakespearean: What's this ?

English: A sleeve ?
Shakespearean: A sleeve ?

English: It's like a cannon .
Shakespearean: Tis like a demi-cannon .

English: Carved it up and down like an apple tart ?
Shakespearean: What , up and down , carved like an apple tart ?

English: Snip and snip and cut and slash , it's got more holes than a sieve !
Shakespearean: Here's snip and nip and cut and slish and slash , Like to a censer in a barber's shop .

English: What in the world do you call this , tailor !
Shakespearean: Why , what i ' devil's name , tailor , call'st thou this ?

English: You told me to make it well and properly and in keeping with the current style .
Shakespearean: You bid me make it orderly and well , According to the fashion and the time .

English: Certainly , I did .
Shakespearean: Marry , and did .

English: But if you remember , I didn't tell you to parody the style .
Shakespearean: But if you be remembered , I did not bid you mar it to the time .

English: I won't take it .
Shakespearean: I'll none of it .

English: Do whatever you want with it .
Shakespearean: Hence , make your best of it .

English: I never saw a better-designed gown , more elegant and pleasing and well made .
Shakespearean: I never saw a better-fashioned gown , More quaint , more pleasing , nor more commendable .

English: Yes , that's it !
Shakespearean: Why , true , he means to make a puppet of thee .

English: It's a lie , you thread , you thimble , you measurement !
Shakespearean: Thou liest , thou thread , thou thimble , Thou yard , three-quarters , half-yard , quarter , nail !

English: You flea , you louse , you winter cricket !
Shakespearean: Thou flea , thou nit , thou winter cricket thou !

English: Disrespected in my own house by a spool of thread !
Shakespearean: Braved in mine own house with a skein of thread ?

English: I tell you , you've ruined her gown .
Shakespearean: I tell thee , I , that thou hast marred her gown .

English: It's not true .
Shakespearean: Your Worship is deceived .

English: The gown was made just as my master was directed .
Shakespearean: The gown is made Just as my master had direction .

English: Grumio gave the order for how it should be done .
Shakespearean: Grumio gave order how it should be done .

English: I gave him no order .
Shakespearean: I gave him no order .

English: I gave him the material .
Shakespearean: I gave him the stuff .

English: But how did you want it made ?
Shakespearean: But how did you desire it should be made ?

English: With a needle and thread .
Shakespearean: Marry , sir , with needle and thread .

English: But didn't you expect us to cut the cloth ?
Shakespearean: But did you not request to have it cut ?

English: Well , don't face off with me .
Shakespearean: Face not me .

English: You have bested many things , well don't try and best me .
Shakespearean: Thou hast braved many men ; brave not me .

English: I will not be faced or bested .
Shakespearean: I will neither be faced nor braved .

English: I tell you I requested that your master cut out the gown , but I didn't ask him to cut it all to pieces .
Shakespearean: I say unto thee , I bid thy master cutout the gown , but I did not bid him cut it to pieces .

English: Why , here is the order to prove it .
Shakespearean: Why , here is the note of the fashion to testify .

English: Read it .
Shakespearean: Read it .

English: The note is a big fat liar if it says I said so .
Shakespearean: The note lies in 's throat , if he say I said so .

English: Do you like pictures ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou love pictures ?

English: You have a noble wife who is much more beautiful than any other woman in this declining age .
Shakespearean: Thou hast a lady far more beautiful Than any woman in this waning age .

English: Before she began shedding tears all over her lovely face , she was the fairest creature in the world , and even now she has no equal .
Shakespearean: And till the tears that she hath shed for thee Like envious floods o'errun her lovely face , She was the fairest creature in the world , And yet she is inferior to none .

English: I admit the cape .
Shakespearean: I confess the cape .

English: I admit two sleeves .
Shakespearean: I confess two sleeves .

English: Ah , there's the problem .
Shakespearean: Ay , there's the villany .

English: Error in the bill , sir , error in the bill !
Shakespearean: Error i ' the bill , sir , error i ' the bill !

English: I ordered that the sleeves be cut out and sewed up again , and I'll prove it in combat even if your little finger is armed with your thimble .
Shakespearean: I commanded the sleeves should be cut out and sewed up again , and that I'll prove upon thee , though thy little finger be armed in a thimble .

English: I am ready for you .
Shakespearean: I am for thee straight .

English: You take the bill and I'll take your yardstick .
Shakespearean: Take thou the bill , give me thy mete- yard , and spare not me .

English: God have mercy , Grumio !
Shakespearean: God-a-mercy , Grumio !

English: He won't have a chance .
Shakespearean: Then he shall have no odds .

English: Well , sir , the gown is not for me .
Shakespearean: Well , sir , in brief , the gown is not for me .

English: You are right , it's for my mistress .
Shakespearean: You are i ' the right , sir , 'tis for my mistress .

English: Go , take it away and let your master make whatever use of it he can .
Shakespearean: Go , take it up unto thy master's use .

English: Certainly not !
Shakespearean: Villain , not for thy life !

English: Take off my mistress ' gown for your master's use !
Shakespearean: Take up my mistress ' gown for thy master's use !

English: Why , what's the problem ?
Shakespearean: Why , sir , what's your conceit in that ?

English: Oh , sir , the problem goes far deeper than you realize .
Shakespearean: O , sir , the conceit is deeper than you think for .

English: Take up my mistress ' gown for his master's use !
Shakespearean: Take up my mistress ' gown to his master's use !

English: Oh , that's disgusting !
Shakespearean: O , fie , fie , fie !

English: Ah well , my Kate .
Shakespearean: Well , come , my Kate .

English: I mean , is the jay more precious than the lark because his feather is more beautiful ?
Shakespearean: What , is the jay more precious than the lark Because his feathers are more beautiful ?

English: Is the snake better than the eel because the pattern on his back pleases the eye ?
Shakespearean: Or is the adder better than the eel Because his painted skin contents the eye ?

English: Hardly , Kate .
Shakespearean: Oh , no , good Kate .

English: If you regard it as shameful , put the shame on me .
Shakespearean: If thou account'st it shame , lay it on me , And therefore frolic !

English: We're off to eat and whoop it up at your father's house .
Shakespearean: We will hence forthwith To feast and sport us at thy father's house .

English: I hate to say it , but it's almost two and we won't get there before suppertime .
Shakespearean: I dare assure you , sir , 'tis almost two , And 'twill be supper time ere you come there .

English: It shall be seven o'clock before I get on my horse .
Shakespearean: It shall be seven ere I go to horse .

English: Whatever I say , or think , or do , you're continually contradicting it .
Shakespearean: Look what I speak , or do , or think to do , You are still crossing it .

English: Sirs , never mind .
Shakespearean: Sirs , let 't alone .

English: We won't go today , or any day until it's clear that it shall be whatever time I say it is .
Shakespearean: I will not go today , and ere I do It shall be what o'clock I say it is .

English: Yes , certainly .
Shakespearean: Ay , what else ?

English: Unless I am mistaken , Signior Baptista may remember me from the Pegasus in Genoa , where we both stayed twenty years ago .
Shakespearean: and but I be deceived , Signior Baptista may remember me , Near twenty years ago , in Genoa , Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus .

English: Of course I will .
Shakespearean: I warrant you .

English: But , sir , here comes your servant .
Shakespearean: But , sir , here comes your boy .

English: Don't worry about me .
Shakespearean: Tut , fear not me .

English: I told him that your father was in Venice , and that you expected him to arrive in Padua today .
Shakespearean: I told him that your father was at Venice , And that you looked for him this day in Padua .

English: He gives BIONDELLO Here comes Baptista .
Shakespearean: Here comes Baptista .

English: Places , everyone !
Shakespearean: Set your countenance , sir .

English: Signior Baptista , I'm glad to see you. , Sir , this is the gentleman I told you of .
Shakespearean: Signior Baptista , you are happily met. , Sir , this is the gentleman I told you of .

English: I hope you'll be a good father to me now .
Shakespearean: I pray you stand good father to me now .

English: Give me Bianca for my inheritance .
Shakespearean: Give me Bianca for my patrimony .

English: Sir , pardon me for what I am about to say .
Shakespearean: Sir , pardon me in what I have to say .

English: I appreciate your frankness and your brevity .
Shakespearean: Your plainness and your shortness please me well .

English: It's true that your son Lucentio here loves my daughter , and she loves him , or else they're putting on quite an act .
Shakespearean: Right true it is your son Lucentio here Doth love my daughter and she loveth him , Or both dissemble deeply their affections .

English: Your son will have my consent to marry my daughter .
Shakespearean: Your son shall have my daughter with consent .

English: Not in my house , Lucentio .
Shakespearean: Not in my house , Lucentio , for you know Pitchers have ears , and I have many servants .

English: My servants might overhear , and old Gremio is still hanging around , so we might be interrupted .
Shakespearean: Besides , old Gremio is heark'ning still , And happily we might be interrupted .

English: I hope with all my heart she will !
Shakespearean: I pray the gods she may , with all my heart !

English: Cambio .
Shakespearean: Cambio .

English: What is it , Biondello ?
Shakespearean: What sayest thou , Biondello ?

English: You saw my master wink and laugh at you ?
Shakespearean: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you ?

English: What about it ?
Shakespearean: Biondello , what of that ?

English: Please , educate me .
Shakespearean: I pray thee , moralize them .

English: He's talking with the bogus father about the bogus son .
Shakespearean: Then thus : Baptista is safe , talking with the deceiving father of a deceitful son .

English: And so , ?
Shakespearean: And what of him ?

English: You are to bring his daughter to the supper .
Shakespearean: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper .

English: And then ?
Shakespearean: And then ?

English: The old priest at Saint Luke's Church is at your command at all hours .
Shakespearean: The old priest at Saint Luke's Church is at your command at all hours .

English: And what of all this ?
Shakespearean: And what of all this ?

English: I don't know , except they are busy with some phony guarantee .
Shakespearean: I can not tell , except they are busied about a counterfeit assurance .

English: So go and put your stamp on the girl .
Shakespearean: Take you assurance of her cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum .

English: Go to the church : take the priest , the clerk , and some reasonably honest witnesses .
Shakespearean: To th ' church take the priest , clerk , and some sufficient honest witnesses .

English: If this isn't what you've been hoping for , I have no more to say except that you ought to say goodbye to Bianca forever .
Shakespearean: If this be not that you look for , I have no more to say , But bid Bianca farewell forever and a day .

English: I knew a girl who was married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit .
Shakespearean: I knew a wench married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit , and so may you , sir .

English: Farewell , sir .
Shakespearean: And so adieu , sir .

English: My master has instructed me to go to Saint Luke's to tell the priest to be ready in case you should show up with your better half .
Shakespearean: My master hath appointed me to go to Saint Luke's to bid the priest be ready to come against you come with your appendix .

English: She will be pleased .
Shakespearean: She will be pleased .

English: Then why am I worried ?
Shakespearean: Then wherefore should I doubt ?

English: It will be hard if "Cambio" loses her .
Shakespearean: It shall go hard if "Cambio" go without her .

English: Come , let's continue on toward your father's house .
Shakespearean: Come on , i ' God's name , once more toward our father's .

English: Good Lord , how bright and splendid is the moon tonight !
Shakespearean: Good Lord , how bright and goodly shines the moon !

English: The moon ?
Shakespearean: The moon ?

English: You mean the sun !
Shakespearean: The sun !

English: It is not nighttime now .
Shakespearean: It is not moonlight now .

English: I say it's the moon that shines so bright .
Shakespearean: I say it is the moon that shines so bright .

English: I know it's the sun that shines so bright .
Shakespearean: I know it is the sun that shines so bright .

English: Now , by my mother's son , and that's me , it will be moon or star or whatever I want before I'll travel to your father's house .
Shakespearean: Now , by my mother's son , and that's myself , It shall be moon , or star , or what I list , Or e'er I journey to your father's house .

English: I say it's the moon .
Shakespearean: I say it is the moon .

English: I know it's the moon .
Shakespearean: I know it is the moon .

English: Well , you're a liar , then .
Shakespearean: Nay , then you lie .

English: It's the blessed sun .
Shakespearean: It is the blessed sun .

English: Then God be praised , it Petruchio , do whatever you like .
Shakespearean: Then God be blessed , it is the blessed sun .

English: You've won .
Shakespearean: Petruchio , go thy ways ; the field is won .

English: Well , onward , then .
Shakespearean: Well , forward , forward !

English: That's how things should be , straight and smooth .
Shakespearean: Thus the bowl should run , And not unluckily against the bias .

English: But , hang on !
Shakespearean: But , soft !

English: I hear someone coming .
Shakespearean: Company is coming here .

English: Young budding virgin , fair and pure and sweet , where are you off to ?
Shakespearean: Young budding virgin , fair and fresh and sweet , Whither away , or where is thy abode ?

English: Your parents are lucky to have such a lovely child .
Shakespearean: Happy the parents of so fair a child .

English: Is Would your Mightiness care to wash his hands ?
Shakespearean: Will 't please your Mightiness to wash your hands ?

English: We're overjoyed to see you sane again .
Shakespearean: O , how we joy to see your wit restored !

English: If only you had a clearer memory of who you are !
Shakespearean: O , that once more you knew but what you are !

English: These past fifteen years you have been living in a dream , and even when you were awake , it was as though you slept .
Shakespearean: These fifteen years you have been in a dream Or , when you waked , so waked as if you slept .

English: Fifteen years !
Shakespearean: These fifteen years !

English: That's some nap .
Shakespearean: By my fay , a goodly nap .

English: But I never spoke the whole time ?
Shakespearean: But did I never speak of all that time ?

English: Oh yes , you spoke , my lord , but total nonsense .
Shakespearean: O , yes , my lord , but very idle words .

English: But sir , there is no such house , no such maid , and no such men as you have dreamed up , like a certain Stephen Sly and one old John Naps of Greece , a Peter Turph , one "Henry Pimpernell , " and twenty more men of this sort , who never actually existed .
Shakespearean: Why , sir , you know no house nor no such maid , Nor no such men as you have reckoned up , As Stephen Sly and old John Naps of Greece , And Peter Turph and Henry Pimpernell , And twenty more such names and men as these , Which never were , nor no man ever saw .

English: Why , dear me , Kate !
Shakespearean: Why , how now , Kate !

English: I hope you haven't lost your mind .
Shakespearean: I hope thou art not mad .

English: This is not a maiden , as you say , but an old man , wrinkled , faded , and withered .
Shakespearean: This is a man , old , wrinkled , faded , withered , And not a maiden , as thou say'st he is .

English: Well , sir , and you , witty lady , who gave me quite a turn with your strange talk , my name is Vincentio , my hometown Pisa , and I am traveling to Padua to visit a son of mine whom I haven't seen in a long while .
Shakespearean: Fair sir , and you , my merry mistress , That with your strange encounter much amazed me , My name is called Vincentio , my dwelling Pisa , And bound I am to Padua , there to visit A son of mine which long I have not seen .

English: What is his name ?
Shakespearean: What is his name ?

English: Lucentio , sir .
Shakespearean: Lucentio , gentle sir .

English: A fortunate coincidence , more fortunate for your son .
Shakespearean: Happily met , the happier for thy son .

English: The sister of my wife , this lady here , is married to your son .
Shakespearean: The sister to my wife , this gentlewoman , Thy son by this hath married .

English: And there's no need for wonder or worry .
Shakespearean: Wonder not Nor be grieved .

English: Let me embrace the father of Lucentio , and then we'll journey on to see your son , who will rejoice at your arrival .
Shakespearean: Let me embrace with old Vincentio , And wander we to see thy honest son , Who will of thy arrival be full joyous .

English: I assure you , sir , it's true .
Shakespearean: I do assure thee , father , so it is .

English: Well , Petruchio , all this is very encouraging .
Shakespearean: Well , Petruchio , this has put me in heart .

English: The priest is already there .
Shakespearean: Softly and swiftly , sir , for the priest is ready .

English: We're off , Biondello .
Shakespearean: I fly , Biondello .

English: I'll see them safely married first and then hurry back to my master's .
Shakespearean: Nay , faith , I'll see the church a ' your back , and then come back to my master's as soon as I can .

English: I wonder why Cambio hasn't shown up in all this time .
Shakespearean: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while .

English: Here is the door , sir .
Shakespearean: Sir , here's the door .

English: This is Lucentio's house .
Shakespearean: This is Lucentio's house .

English: My father-in-law lives closer to the marketplace .
Shakespearean: My father's bears more toward the marketplace .

English: That's where I'm going now , so I'll leave you here .
Shakespearean: Thither must I , and here I leave you , sir .

English: You must not go without having a drink first .
Shakespearean: You shall not choose but drink before you go .

English: They're pretty busy in there .
Shakespearean: They're busy within .

English: You'd better knock louder .
Shakespearean: You were best knock louder .

English: Is Signior Lucentio at home , sir ?
Shakespearean: Is Signior Lucentio within , sir ?

English: What if a fellow were bringing him a couple of hundred pounds to toss around ?
Shakespearean: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two to make merry withal ?

English: I believe I have some choice in the matter , sir .
Shakespearean: Hope I may choose , sir .

English: Come here , you wretch !
Shakespearean: Come hither , you rogue !

English: What , have you forgotten me ?
Shakespearean: What , have you forgot me ?

English: Forgotten you !
Shakespearean: Forgot you !

English: No , sir .
Shakespearean: No , sir .

English: I could not forget you , since I never saw you before in my life .
Shakespearean: I could not forget you , for I never saw you before in all my life .

English: My honorable , reverend master ?
Shakespearean: What , my old worshipful old master ?

English: Yes , of course .
Shakespearean: Yes , marry , sir .

English: There he is at the window .
Shakespearean: See where he looks out of the window .

English: Is that so ?
Shakespearean: Is 't so , indeed .

English: Help , help , help !
Shakespearean: Help , help , help !

English: This madman will murder me .
Shakespearean: Here's a madman will murder me .

English: How dare I ?
Shakespearean: Oh , I am undone , I am undone !

English: How dare What , is the man crazy ?
Shakespearean: What , is the man lunatic ?

English: Your father !
Shakespearean: Thy father !

English: Why , you scoundrel !
Shakespearean: O villain !

English: Your father is a sailmaker in Bergamo .
Shakespearean: He is a sailmaker in Bergamo .

English: You're wrong , sir , very wrong .
Shakespearean: You mistake , sir , you mistake , sir .

English: Why , what do you imagine his name to be ?
Shakespearean: Pray , what do you think is his name ?

English: His name !
Shakespearean: His name !

English: Lucentio !
Shakespearean: Lucentio !

English: Oh God , he's murdered his master !
Shakespearean: Oh , he hath murdered his master !

English: Oh , my son , my son !
Shakespearean: O my son , my son !

English: Tell me , you monster , where is my son Lucentio ?
Shakespearean: Tell me , thou villain , where is my son Lucentio ?

English: Take this mad wretch to jail. , Father-in-law Baptista , will you see that he's available to appear in court ?
Shakespearean: Carry this mad knave to the jail. , Father Baptista , I charge you see that he be forthcoming .

English: Take me off to jail ?
Shakespearean: Carry me to the jail ?

English: He mustn't go to prison .
Shakespearean: He shall not go to prison .

English: Be quiet , Signior Gremio .
Shakespearean: Talk not , Signior Gremio .

English: I say he shall go to prison .
Shakespearean: I say he shall go to prison .

English: Be careful , Signior Baptista , lest you be made the dupe in this business .
Shakespearean: Take heed , Signior Baptista , lest you be cony-catched in this business .

English: I could swear this is the real Vincentio .
Shakespearean: I dare swear this is the right Vincentio .

English: Well , no , not literally .
Shakespearean: Nay , I dare not swear it .

English: No , I know that you're Signior Lucentio .
Shakespearean: Yes , I know thee to be Signior Lucentio .

English: Away with the doddering fool !
Shakespearean: Away with the dotard !

English: Take him off to jail !
Shakespearean: To the jail with him !

English: We're ruined !
Shakespearean: O !

English: There he is !
Shakespearean: We are spoiled and yonder he is !

English: Pardon , dear father .
Shakespearean: Pardon , sweet father .

English: Dear son , you're alive !
Shakespearean: Lives my sweet son ?

English: Pardon us , dear father .
Shakespearean: Pardon , dear father .

English: What have you done ?
Shakespearean: How hast thou offended ?

English: Where is Lucentio ?
Shakespearean: Where is Lucentio ?

English: I have made your daughter mine by marriage while false impressions blinded your eyes .
Shakespearean: Here's Lucentio , right son to the right Vincentio , That have by marriage made thy daughter mine While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne .

English: We've all been duped .
Shakespearean: Here's packing , with a witness , to deceive us all !

English: Where is that damned wretch , Tranio , who defied me in such a disgraceful manner ?
Shakespearean: Where is that damned villain , Tranio , That faced and braved me in this matter so ?

English: Say , isn't this the Latin master Cambio ?
Shakespearean: Why , tell me , is not this my Cambio ?

English: Cambio is transformed into Lucentio .
Shakespearean: Cambio is changed into Lucentio .

English: It was love that performed these miracles .
Shakespearean: Love wrought these miracles .

English: Bianca's love made me trade places with Tranio while he masqueraded as me around town .
Shakespearean: Bianca's love Made me exchange my state with Tranio , While he did bear my countenance in the town , And happily I have arrived at the last Unto the wished haven of my bliss .

English: What Tranio did , he did at my command .
Shakespearean: What Tranio did , myself enforced him to .

English: So pardon him , dear father , for my sake .
Shakespearean: Then pardon him , sweet father , for my sake .

English: No , I'll slit the nose of the villain who would have sent me to jail .
Shakespearean: I'll slit the villain's nose that would have sent me to the jail .

English: But sir , have you married my daughter without my consent ?
Shakespearean: But do you hear , sir , have you married my daughter without asking my goodwill ?

English: Don't worry , Baptista , you'll be perfectly satisfied .
Shakespearean: Fear not , Baptista , we will content you .

English: You'll see .
Shakespearean: Go to .

English: All I can hope for now is a share of the feast .
Shakespearean: My cake is dough , but I'll in among the rest , Out of hope of all but my share of the feast .

English: Let's follow them to see how this turns out .
Shakespearean: Husband , let's follow to see the end of this ado .

English: First kiss me , Kate , and then we will .
Shakespearean: First kiss me , Kate , and we will .

English: What , here in the middle of the street ?
Shakespearean: What , in the midst of the street ?

English: Are you ashamed of me ?
Shakespearean: What , art thou ashamed of me ?

English: But I'm ashamed to kiss , sir .
Shakespearean: No , sir , God forbid , but ashamed to kiss .

English: All right then , back home we go .
Shakespearean: Why , then let's home again .

English: No , wait .
Shakespearean: Nay , I will give thee a kiss .

English: I Isn't this good ?
Shakespearean: Is not this well ?

English: Come , my sweet Kate .
Shakespearean: Come , my sweet Kate .

English: Better late than never , and it's never too late to change .
Shakespearean: Better once than never , for never too late .

English: Well , thank God I'm cured !
Shakespearean: Now Lord be thanked for my good amends !

English: Amen .
Shakespearean: Amen .

English: I thank you all .
Shakespearean: I thank thee .

English: You won't regret this .
Shakespearean: Thou shalt not lose by it .

English: How is my noble lord ?
Shakespearean: How fares my noble lord ?

English: This is all quite pleasant .
Shakespearean: Marry , I fare well , For here is cheer enough .

English: Where is my wife ?
Shakespearean: Where is my wife ?

English: Here , noble lord .
Shakespearean: Here , noble lord .

English: What is your wish with regard to her ?
Shakespearean: What is thy will with her ?

English: You call yourself my wife , yet you don't call me "husband" ?
Shakespearean: Are you my wife and will not call me "husband" ?

English: It's my men who should call me "lord." I'm your man , your fellow .
Shakespearean: My men should call me "lord." I am your goodman .

English: My fair Bianca , bid my father welcome , while I with equal affection welcome yours .
Shakespearean: My fair Bianca , bid my father welcome , While I with selfsame kindness welcome thine .

English: This last course here is for closing up the stomach after great feasting .
Shakespearean: My banquet is to close our stomachs up , After our great good cheer .

English: Now everyone be seated , as this is the part where we sit and chat as well as eat .
Shakespearean: Pray you , sit down , For now we sit to chat as well as eat .

English: All we do is sit and sit and eat and eat .
Shakespearean: Nothing but sit and sit , and eat and eat !

English: I wish that were true for both our sakes !
Shakespearean: For both our sakes , I would that word were true .

English: Hortensio
Shakespearean: Now , for my life , Hortensio fears his widow .

English: That's very sensible , but you missed my sense : I meant Hortensio is afraid of you .
Shakespearean: You are very sensible , and yet you miss my sense : I mean , Hortensio is afeard of you .

English: He who is dizzy thinks the world is spinning .
Shakespearean: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round .

English: A very candid reply .
Shakespearean: Roundly replied .

English: What's that supposed to mean ?
Shakespearean: Mistress , how mean you that ?

English: That's what I conceive of him .
Shakespearean: Thus I conceive by him .

English: Nice save !
Shakespearean: Very well mended .

English: Kiss him for that , good widow .
Shakespearean: Kiss him for that , good widow .

English: He who is dizzy thinks the world is spinning" , please , tell me what you meant by that .
Shakespearean: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round" , I pray you , tell me what you meant by that .

English: Your husband , being saddled with a shrew , projects his own suffering onto my husband .
Shakespearean: Your husband being troubled with a shrew Measures my husband's sorrow by his woe .

English: And now you know my meaning .
Shakespearean: And now you know my meaning .

English: A very nasty meaning .
Shakespearean: A very mean meaning .

English: My meaning And I
Shakespearean: Right , I mean you .

English: You tell her , widow !
Shakespearean: To her , widow !

English: I'll bet you a hundred marks , my Kate puts her flat on her back .
Shakespearean: A hundred marks , my Kate does put her down .

English: Well , that's really my job .
Shakespearean: That's my office .

English: Well said !
Shakespearean: Spoke like an officer !

English: Here's to you !
Shakespearean: Ha ' to thee , lad !

English: What do you think of these quick-witted folks , Gremio ?
Shakespearean: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks ?

English: They certainly do like to butt heads !
Shakespearean: Believe me , sir , they butt together well .

English: Yes , but not out of fear .
Shakespearean: Ay , but not frighted me .

English: I'll go back to sleep now .
Shakespearean: Therefore I'll sleep again .

English: No , you shall not .
Shakespearean: Nay , that you shall not .

English: I'll
Shakespearean: Am I your bird ?

English: Well , she got away .
Shakespearean: She hath prevented me .

English: Signior Tranio , you also took aim at that bird , though you didn't hit her. , So here's a health to all who've shot and missed .
Shakespearean: Here , Signior Tranio , This bird you aimed at , though you hit her not. , Therefore a health to all that shot and missed .

English: A witty if a cynical reply .
Shakespearean: A good swift simile , but something currish .

English: It's good you hunted for yourself , sir .
Shakespearean: Tis well , sir , that you hunted for yourself .

English: Tranio got you that time .
Shakespearean: Tranio hits you now .

English: I thank you for that quip , good Tranio .
Shakespearean: I thank thee for that gird , good Tranio .

English: He's made me a little sore , I'll admit .
Shakespearean: He has a little galled me , I confess .

English: But since the gibe glanced off me , ten to one it hit you both straight on .
Shakespearean: And , as the jest did glance away from me , 'T is ten to one it maimed you two outright .

English: Seriously , though , son Petruchio , I think you have the most thoroughgoing shrew of us all .
Shakespearean: Now , in good sadness , son Petruchio , I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all .

English: Well , I disagree .
Shakespearean: Well , I say no .

English: Agreed .
Shakespearean: Content .

English: What's the bet ?
Shakespearean: What's the wager ?

English: Twenty crowns .
Shakespearean: Twenty crowns .

English: Twenty crowns ?
Shakespearean: Twenty crowns ?

English: I'd wager twenty times as much on my wife .
Shakespearean: I'll venture so much of my hawk or hound , But twenty times so much upon my wife .

English: A hundred then .
Shakespearean: A hundred then .

English: Agreed .
Shakespearean: Content .

English: Good !
Shakespearean: A match !

English: It's a bet .
Shakespearean: Tis done .

English: Who should begin ?
Shakespearean: Who shall begin ?

English: I will .
Shakespearean: That will I .

English: Biondello , go and tell your mistress to come to me .
Shakespearean: Go , Biondello , bid your mistress come to me .

English: Here I go .
Shakespearean: I go .

English: Son , I'll stake you half that Bianca comes .
Shakespearean: Son , I'll be your half Bianca comes .

English: I'll have no halves .
Shakespearean: I'll have no halves .

English: What !
Shakespearean: How !

English: She's busy and can not come ! " Is that an answer ?
Shakespearean: She's busy , and she can not come ! " Is that an answer ?

English: Yes , and a nice one at that .
Shakespearean: Ay , and a kind one too .

English: Pray God your wife doesn't send you a worse one .
Shakespearean: Pray God , sir , your wife send you not a worse .

English: I'm hoping for better .
Shakespearean: I hope better .

English: So , where's my wife ?
Shakespearean: Now , where's my wife ?

English: She says she thinks this is a prank .
Shakespearean: She says you have some goodly jest in hand .

English: She will not come .
Shakespearean: She will not come .

English: She says that you should come to her .
Shakespearean: She bids you come to her .

English: Worse and worse !
Shakespearean: Worse and worse .

English: She I can guess her answer .
Shakespearean: I know her answer .

English: What ?
Shakespearean: What ?

English: She will not .
Shakespearean: She will not .

English: By all that's holy , here comes Katherina !
Shakespearean: Now , by my holidam , here comes Katherina !

English: You sent for me , sir ?
Shakespearean: What is your will , sir , that you send for me ?

English: Where are your sister and Hortensio's wife ?
Shakespearean: Where is your sister , and Hortensio's wife ?

English: They sit chatting by the parlor fire .
Shakespearean: They sit conferring by the parlor fire .

English: Go bring them here .
Shakespearean: Go fetch them hither .

English: If they refuse to come , get physical , use a whip if you have to , but get them out here to their husbands .
Shakespearean: If they deny to come , Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands .

English: This is a miracle , if you talk of miracles .
Shakespearean: Here is a wonder , if you talk of a wonder .

English: It is .
Shakespearean: And so it is .

English: I wonder what it means .
Shakespearean: I wonder what it bodes .

English: It means peace and love and a quiet life , supremacy based on reverence and profound respect , and , not to go on and on about it , everything that's sweet and happy .
Shakespearean: Marry , peace it bodes , and love , and quiet life , And awful rule , and right supremacy , And , to be short , what not that's sweet and happy ?

English: May good fortune come to you , good Petruchio !
Shakespearean: Now , fair befall thee , good Petruchio !

English: You've won the wager , and I will add twenty thousand crowns to what they owe you .
Shakespearean: The wager thou hast won , and I will add Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns , Another dowry to another daughter , For she is changed as she had never been .

English: Look , here she comes , with your ungovernable wives in tow , like prisoners of her womanly persuasion. , Katherine , that cap of yours doesn't look good on you .
Shakespearean: See where she comes and brings your froward wives As prisoners to her womanly persuasion. , Katherine , that cap of yours becomes you not .

English: Take it off and throw it on the ground .
Shakespearean: Off with that bauble , throw it underfoot .

English: Lord , may I never see a day of trouble until the day I let someone treat me like that .
Shakespearean: Lord , let me never have a cause to sigh , Till I be brought to such a silly pass !

English: For shame !
Shakespearean: Fie !

English: What kind of loyalty is this ?
Shakespearean: What a foolish duty call you this ?

English: I wish your loyalty were as foolish .
Shakespearean: I would your duty were as foolish too .

English: The wisdom of your loyalty , fair Bianca , has cost me a hundred crowns since dinner .
Shakespearean: The wisdom of your duty , fair Bianca , Hath cost me an hundred crowns since suppertime .

English: The more fool you for betting on my loyalty .
Shakespearean: The more fool you for laying on my duty .

English: There will be no lecture .
Shakespearean: We will have no telling .

English: She shall not .
Shakespearean: She shall not .

English: I say she shall. , And first begin with her .
Shakespearean: I say she shall. , And first begin with her .

English: Girls , girls !
Shakespearean: Fie , fie !

English: This disrespectful stance toward the man who is your lord , your king , your governor tarnishes your beauty the way the frosts of winter blights the land .
Shakespearean: Unknit that threat'ning unkind brow And dart not scornful glances from those eyes To wound thy lord , thy king , thy governor .

English: A woman owes her husband the same loyalty a subject owes his king .
Shakespearean: Such duty as the subject owes the prince , Even such a woman oweth to her husband .

English: And when she is peevish and perverse , sullen , sour , and disobedient to his honest wishes , what is she but a loathsome , warlike rebel and an ungrateful traitor to her loving lord ?
Shakespearean: And when she is froward , peevish , sullen , sour , And not obedient to his honest will , What is she but a foul contending rebel And graceless traitor to her loving lord ?

English: I am ashamed that women are so foolish as to declare war when they should plead on their knees for peace , that they seek authority , supremacy , and power when they are under an obligation to serve , love , and obey .
Shakespearean: I am ashamed that women are so simple To offer war where they should kneel for peace ; Or seek for rule , supremacy and sway When they are bound to serve , love , and obey .

English: Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth , unfit for toil and trouble in the world , if not so that our soft qualities and our hearts should agree with our external parts ?
Shakespearean: Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth , Unapt to toil and trouble in the world , But that our soft conditions and our hearts Should well agree with our external parts ?

English: Come , come , you weak , ungovernable worms !
Shakespearean: Come , come , you froward and unable worms !

English: My spirit has been as proud as each of yours , my courage as great , and my reason perhaps even better suited to bandy words back and forth and exchange frown for frown .
Shakespearean: My mind hath been as big as one of yours , My heart as great , my reason haply more , To bandy word for word and frown for frown .

English: But now I see our weapons are like straws , our strength like a straw's weakness , and our weakness past comparison , so that we seem to be the thing we most are not .
Shakespearean: But now I see our lances are but straws , Our strength as weak , our weakness past compare , That seeming to be most which we indeed least are .

English: Come on and kiss me , Kate .
Shakespearean: Come on and kiss me , Kate .

English: It's nice to see children playing well together .
Shakespearean: Tis a good hearing when children are toward .

English: But not so nice when women misbehave .
Shakespearean: But a harsh hearing when women are froward .

English: Come , Kate , let's go to bed .
Shakespearean: Come , Kate , we'll to bed .

English: We three are married , but you two are defeated .
Shakespearean: We three are married , but you two are sped .

English: It's amazing , if I may say so , that she let herself be tamed .
Shakespearean: Tis a wonder , by your leave , she will be tamed so .

English: Madam wife , they say I've been dreaming or asleep for more than fifteen years .
Shakespearean: Madam wife , they say that I have dreamed And slept above some fifteen year or more .

English: Yes , and it seemed twice as long to me , having been kept from your bed that whole time .
Shakespearean: Ay , and the time seems thirty unto me , Being all this time abandoned from your bed .

English: That's too long. , Servants , leave her and me alone .
Shakespearean: Tis much. , Servants , leave me and her alone .

English: Now , madam , undress and come to bed .
Shakespearean: Madam , undress you and come now to bed .

English: Thrice noble lord , I beg you to excuse me for another night or two , or at least until nightfall .
Shakespearean: Thrice noble lord , let me entreat of you To pardon me yet for a night or two , Or if not so , until the sun be set .

English: Your doctors have expressly forbidden me to sleep with you , as there's a risk that you might have a relapse .
Shakespearean: For your physicians have expressly charged , In peril to incur your former malady , That I should yet absent me from your bed .

English: I hope this explanation will stand as my excuse .
Shakespearean: I hope this reason stands for my excuse .

English: I'm not sure I can wait that long .
Shakespearean: Ay , it stands so that I may hardly tarry so long .

English: Still , I'd hate to see my former dreams return .
Shakespearean: But I would be loath to fall into my dreams again .

English: So I Your Honor's actors , hearing of your recovery , have come to perform a pleasing comedy for you , and your doctors approve wholeheartedly .
Shakespearean: Your Honor's players , hearing your amendment , Are come to play a pleasant comedy , For so your doctors hold it very meet , Seeing too much sadness hath congealed your blood , And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy .

English: So they think it's a good idea for you to watch a play and direct your thoughts toward laughter and merriment , two strong preventive medicines that foster long life .
Shakespearean: Therefore they thought it good you hear a play And frame your mind to mirth and merriment , Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life .

English: Okay , bring on the play .
Shakespearean: Let them play it .

English: What , like stuff from a house ?
Shakespearean: What , household stuff ?

English: No , it's a story .
Shakespearean: It is a kind of history .

English: Well , let's watch it .
Shakespearean: Well , we'll see 't .

English: We're not getting any younger .
Shakespearean: We shall ne'er be younger .

English: I was born in Pisa , famous for its serious citizens , like my father before me ; my father , Vincentio , a successful , world-traveled merchant , was one of the
Shakespearean: Pisa , renowned for grave citizens , Gave me my being and my father first , A merchant of great traffic through the world , Vincentio , come of the Bentivolii .

English: I'll fix you , I swear .
Shakespearean: I'll pheeze you , in faith .

English: You thug !
Shakespearean: A pair of stocks , you rogue !

English: Read your history !
Shakespearean: Y'are a baggage , the Slys are no rogues .

English: We You won't pay for the glasses you smashed ?
Shakespearean: Therefore You will not pay for the glasses you have burst ?

English: No , not a penny .
Shakespearean: No , not a denier .

English: Get out of my face .
Shakespearean: Go by , Saint Jeronimy .

English: Go play with yourself .
Shakespearean: Go to thy cold bed and warm thee .

English: I know my rights .
Shakespearean: I know my remedy .

English: I'm not moving an inch , pal .
Shakespearean: I'll not budge an inch , boy .

English: Let them come , I don't care .
Shakespearean: Let him come , and kindly .

English: That's good advice .
Shakespearean: Gramercies , Tranio , well dost thou advise .

English: Wait !
Shakespearean: But stay awhile .

English: Who are all these people ?
Shakespearean: What company is this ?

English: Maybe it's a parade to welcome us to town , master .
Shakespearean: Master , some show to welcome us to town .

English: Don't worry , I couldn't care less .
Shakespearean: I ' faith , sir , you shall never need to fear .

English: The only possible interest I could take in you would be to hit you on the head with a stool , paint your face with blood , and make a fool out of you .
Shakespearean: But if it were , doubt not her care should be To comb your noddle with a three-legged stool And paint your face and use you like a fool .

English: May the good Lord keep me safe from all women like her !
Shakespearean: From all such devils , good Lord , deliver us !

English: Me too , Lord !
Shakespearean: And me too , good Lord !

English: What a spoiled little brat .
Shakespearean: Maid's mild behavior and sobriety .

English: Sister , be happy in my unhappiness. , Sir , I will humbly obey you .
Shakespearean: Sister , content you in my discontent. , Sir , to your pleasure humbly I subscribe .

English: I'll take comfort in my books and music , reading and practicing my instruments .
Shakespearean: My books and instruments shall be my company , On them to look and practice by myself .

English: Listen Tranio !
Shakespearean: Hark , Tranio !

English: That's Signior Baptista , will you really be this cruel ?
Shakespearean: Signior Baptista , will you be so strange ?

English: Why are you locking her away because of this fiend from hell , Signor Baptista ?
Shakespearean: Why will you mew her up , Signior Baptista , for this fiend of hell And make her bear the penance of her tongue ?

English: And because I know how fond she is of music , playing her instruments , and poetry , I plan to hire live-in tutors for her .
Shakespearean: And for I know she taketh most delight In music , instruments , and poetry , Schoolmasters will I keep within my house , Fit to instruct her youth .

English: Katherina , you may stay .
Shakespearean: And so farewell. , Katherina , you may stay , For I have more to commune with Bianca .

English: I don't think so !
Shakespearean: Why , and I trust I may go too , may I not ?

English: Am I to be dictated to , like a child ?
Shakespearean: What , shall I be appointed hours as though , belike , I knew not what to take and what to leave , ha ?

English: You can go straight to hell !
Shakespearean: You may go to the devil's dam !

English: So long .
Shakespearean: Farewell .

English: That is , if we ever want to return to being rivals for Bianca's love .
Shakespearean: Though the nature of our quarrel yet never brooked parle , know now upon advice , it toucheth us both , that we may yet again have access to our fair mistress and be happy rivals in Bianca's love , to labor and effect one thing specially .

English: And that would be , ?
Shakespearean: What's that , I pray ?

English: To find a husband for her sister .
Shakespearean: Marry , sir , to get a husband for her sister .

English: A husband ?
Shakespearean: A husband ?

English: You mean a devil !
Shakespearean: A devil !

English: I mean a husband .
Shakespearean: I say a husband .

English: I say a devil .
Shakespearean: I say a devil .

English: Do you really think there's a man fool enough to marry into hell , however rich the father is ?
Shakespearean: Think'st thou , Hortensio , though her father be very rich , any man is so very a fool to be married to hell ?

English: Oh , I don't know .
Shakespearean: Tush , Gremio .

English: Guys who'd take her with all her faults , provided there were enough money involved .
Shakespearean: Though it pass your patience and mine to endure her loud alarums , why , man , there be good fellows in the world , an a man could light on them , would take her with all faults , and money enough .

English: I don't know .
Shakespearean: I can not tell .

English: What do you say , Signior Gremio ?
Shakespearean: How say you , Signior Gremio ?

English: This imaginary suitor for Katherina , I'd buy him the best horse in Padua if he'd get here quickly , woo her , marry her , take her to bed , and rid the house of her .
Shakespearean: I am agreed , and would I had given him the best horse inv Padua to begin his wooing that would thoroughly woo her , wed her , and bed her , and rid the house of her !

English: Let's go .
Shakespearean: Come on .

English: Sir , is it possible that a person could fall in love so suddenly ?
Shakespearean: I pray , sir , tell me , is it possible That love should of a sudden take such hold ?

English: Oh , Tranio , until it happened to me , I never would have thought it possible .
Shakespearean: O Tranio , till I found it to be true , I never thought it possible or likely .

English: The heart won't be reasoned with .
Shakespearean: Affection is not rated from the heart .

English: If love has touched you , love has touched you , end of story .
Shakespearean: If love have touched you , naught remains but so : Gramercies , lad , go forward .

English: Yes , you're right .
Shakespearean: This contents .

English: Please go on .
Shakespearean: The rest will comfort , for thy counsel's sound .

English: I feel better already , and I know there's more good advice where that came from .
Shakespearean: Master , you looked so longly on the maid , Perhaps you marked not what's the pith of all .

English: Master , you were so focused on the girl herself , I wonder if you missed the main point here .
Shakespearean: Oh yes , I saw sweet beauty in her face Such as the daughter of Agenor had , That made great Jove to humble him to her hand When with his knees he kissed the Cretan strand .

English: Oh no !
Shakespearean: Saw you no more ?

English: Tranio , I saw her coral-pink lips move and perfume the air with her breath .
Shakespearean: Tranio , I saw her coral lips to move And with her breath she did perfume the air .

English: Oh , Tranio , what a cruel father he is .
Shakespearean: Ah , Tranio , what a cruel father's he !

English: Still , did you notice how ready he was to hire good tutors for her ?
Shakespearean: But art thou not advised , he took some care To get her cunning schoolmasters to instruct her ?

English: I did , and now I've got it !
Shakespearean: Ay , marry , am I , sir ; and now 'tis plotted !

English: Tranio , I think I've got it !
Shakespearean: I have it , Tranio !

English: I'll bet we're both thinking the same thing , master .
Shakespearean: Master , for my hand , Both our inventions meet and jump in one .

English: Tell me your idea first .
Shakespearean: Tell me thine first .

English: You will pretend to be a schoolmaster and offer to teach the girl .
Shakespearean: You will be schoolmaster And undertake the teaching of the maid : That's your device .

English: It is .
Shakespearean: It is .

English: Do you think it would work ?
Shakespearean: May it be done ?

English: No , not a chance .
Shakespearean: Not possible .

English: Enough !
Shakespearean: Tis hatched , and shall be so .

English: It's obvious : Here comes Biondello .
Shakespearean: When Biondello comes , he waits on thee , But I will charm him first to keep his tongue .

English: Where have you been , boy ?
Shakespearean: Where have I been ?

English: Where have Come here , boy .
Shakespearean: Nay , how now , where are you ?

English: It's no time for jokes : sober up .
Shakespearean: Sirrah , come hither : 'tis no time to jest , And therefore frame your manners to the time .

English: Understand ?
Shakespearean: You understand me ?

English: Of course , sir .
Shakespearean: Aye , sir .

English: And you're not to utter a syllable of Tranio's name .
Shakespearean: And not a jot of "Tranio" in your mouth .

English: Wish I could say the same .
Shakespearean: Would I were so too .

English: I'd second your wish if it automatically meant that Lucentio could have Baptista's youngest daughter .
Shakespearean: So could I , faith , boy , to have the next wish after , That Lucentio indeed had Baptista's youngest daughter .

English: This is for your master's sake , not mine .
Shakespearean: But , sirrah , not for my sake , but your master's , I advise You use your manners discreetly in all kind of companies .

English: When we're by ourselves you can call me "Tranio." Everywhere else , address me as your master Lucentio .
Shakespearean: When I am alone , why then I am Tranio ; But in all places else , your master Lucentio .

English: Tranio , let's go .
Shakespearean: Tranio , let's go .

English: One last thing , and this is up to you .
Shakespearean: One thing more rests , that thyself execute , to make one among these wooers .

English: You'll have to woo Bianca like the rest .
Shakespearean: If thou ask me why , sufficeth my reasons are both good and weighty .

English: Don't ask why .
Shakespearean: My lord , you nod .

English: No , no .
Shakespearean: You do not mind the play .

English: Very impressive .
Shakespearean: A good matter , surely .

English: Is there any more , or is that it ?
Shakespearean: Comes there any more of it ?

English: And what an excellent piece of work it is , too , madam lady !
Shakespearean: Tis a very excellent piece of work , madam lady .

English: I wish it were over .
Shakespearean: Would 'twere done .

English: Huntsman , look after my hounds .
Shakespearean: Huntsman , I charge thee , tender well my hounds .

English: Let Merriman catch his breath , the poor dog's foaming at the mouth .
Shakespearean: Breathe Merriman , the poor cur is embossed , And couple Clowder with the deep-mouthed brach .

English: I think Belman is just as good , my lord .
Shakespearean: Why , Belman is as good as he , my lord .

English: I swear he's the better dog .
Shakespearean: Trust me , I take him for the better dog .

English: You're a fool .
Shakespearean: Thou art a fool .

English: If Echo were as fast , he would be worth a dozen like Belman .
Shakespearean: If Echo were as fleet , I would esteem him worth a dozen such .

English: But give them all a good dinner and look after them well .
Shakespearean: But sup them well and look unto them all .

English: I'll go hunting again tomorrow , I think .
Shakespearean: Tomorrow I intend to hunt again .

English: I will , my lord .
Shakespearean: I will , my lord .

English: What's this ?
Shakespearean: What's here ?

English: A drunkard or a corpse ?
Shakespearean: One dead , or drunk ?

English: Check and see if he's breathing .
Shakespearean: See , doth he breathe ?

English: He is , my lord .
Shakespearean: He breathes , my lord .

English: But this would be too cold a place to sleep if he hadn't warmed himself with ale .
Shakespearean: Were he not warmed with ale , This were a bed but cold to sleep so soundly .

English: Alas , grim death , how vile and ugly your near-twin , sleep , is !
Shakespearean: Grim death , how foul and loathsome is thine image !

English: What do you think ?
Shakespearean: Sirs , I will practice on this drunken man .

English: I'm off to visit my friends in Padua , particularly my best friend Hortensio .
Shakespearean: Verona , for a while I take my leave , To see my friends in Padua , but of all My best beloved and approved friend , Hortensio .

English: And I think this is his house .
Shakespearean: And I trow this is his house .

English: Here , you there , Grumio .
Shakespearean: Here , sirrah Grumio .

English: Knock .
Shakespearean: Knock , I say .

English: Knock , sir ?
Shakespearean: Knock , sir ?

English: Whom should I knock ?
Shakespearean: Whom should I knock ?

English: Has anyone offended your Worship ?
Shakespearean: Is there any man has rebused your Worship ?

English: Moron !
Shakespearean: Knock you here , sir ?

English: I'm telling you to make a fist and pound .
Shakespearean: Villain , I say , knock me at this gate And rap me well , or I'll knock your knave's pate .

English: My master is being difficult .
Shakespearean: My master is grown quarrelsome .

English: Say , what's the trouble ?
Shakespearean: How now , what's the matter ?

English: If it isn't my old friend Grumio , and my dear friend Petruchio !
Shakespearean: My old friend Grumio and my good friend Petruchio ?

English: How's everyone in Verona ?
Shakespearean: How do you all at Verona ?

English: Hortensio , have you come to break up the fight ?
Shakespearean: Signior Hortensio , come you to part the fray ?

English: I don't care what he told you in Latin .
Shakespearean: Nay , 'tis no matter , sir , what he 'leges in Latin .

English: I told him to knock at your gate and for the life of me could not get him to do it .
Shakespearean: I bade the rascal knock upon your gate And could not get him for my heart to do it .

English: Knock at the gate ?
Shakespearean: Knock at the gate ?

English: Oh , for Pete's sake !
Shakespearean: O heavens !

English: Didn't you clearly say "Knock , " "pound , " and "put your fists to work" ?
Shakespearean: Spake you not these words plain : "Sirrah , knock me here , rap me here , knock me well , and knock me soundly" ?

English: Now you say it was "Knock at the gate" ?
Shakespearean: And come you now with "knocking at the gate" ?

English: I'm warning you .
Shakespearean: Petruchio , patience .

English: Easy , Petruchio .
Shakespearean: I am Grumio's pledge .

English: I'll vouch for Grumio .
Shakespearean: Why , this ' a heavy chance 'twixt him and you , Your ancient , trusty , pleasant servant Grumio .

English: Now , my dear friend , what lucky wind blows you in from Verona ?
Shakespearean: And tell me now , sweet friend , what happy gale Blows you to Padua here from old Verona ?

English: The wind that scatters young men throughout the world , encouraging them to seek their fortunes some place other than home , where there's little to be found in the way of experience .
Shakespearean: Such wind as scatters young men through the world To seek their fortunes farther than at home , Where small experience grows .

English: I have money in my purse and property at home , so I'm off to see the world .
Shakespearean: Crowns in my purse I have and goods at home , And so am come abroad to see the world .

English: I doubt you'd thank me in the end , but she's rich , all right , very rich .
Shakespearean: Thou'dst thank me but a little for my counsel ; And yet I'll promise thee she shall be rich , And very rich .

English: But you're too good a friend for me to wish her on you .
Shakespearean: But thou'rt too much my friend , And I'll not wish thee to her .

English: Hortensio , good friends like us can get by on a few words .
Shakespearean: Signior Hortensio , 'twixt such friends as we Few words suffice .

English: I can help you find a wife who's rich , young , beautiful , and reared in a manner fit for a gentlewoman .
Shakespearean: I can , Petruchio , help thee to a wife With wealth enough , and young and beauteous , Brought up as best becomes a gentlewoman .

English: Her only flaw , and it's a big one , is that she's unbearable , a total witch , so much so that I wouldn't think of marrying her myself , not even if I were in a worse fix than I am , not for a whole goldmine .
Shakespearean: Her only fault , and that is faults enough , Is that she is intolerable curst , And shrewd and froward , so beyond all measure That , were my state far worser than it is , I would not wed her for a mine of gold .

English: Hush , Hortensio .
Shakespearean: Hortensio , peace .

English: You don't know what money can buy .
Shakespearean: Thou know'st not gold's effect .

English: Her father is Baptista Minola , a pleasant and courteous gentleman .
Shakespearean: Her father is Baptista Minola , An affable and courteous gentleman .

English: Her name is Katherina Minola , famous throughout Padua for her scolding tongue .
Shakespearean: Her name is Katherina Minola , Renowned in Padua for her scolding tongue .

English: I don't know her , but I know her father and he knew mine well .
Shakespearean: I know her father , though I know not her , And he knew my deceased father well .

English: I won't sleep until I see her , Hortensio .
Shakespearean: I will not sleep , Hortensio , till I see her , And therefore let me be thus bold with you To give you over at this first encounter , Unless you will accompany me thither .

English: Wait , Petruchio , I should go with you .
Shakespearean: Tarry , Petruchio , I must go with thee , For in Baptista's keep my treasure is .

English: His youngest daughter , the beautiful Bianca , is the jewel of my life , and he keeps her hidden away from me and other rivals for her hand .
Shakespearean: He hath the jewel of my life in hold , His youngest daughter , beautiful Bianca , And her withholds from me and other more , Suitors to her and rivals in my love , Supposing it a thing impossible , For those defects I have before rehearsed , That ever Katherina will be wooed .

English: Katherine the shrew ! " That's the worst thing you can call a young woman .
Shakespearean: Katherine the curst ! " A title for a maid of all titles the worst .

English: Now my friend Petruchio will help me out , presenting me to old Baptista as a schoolmaster for Bianca well-versed in music .
Shakespearean: Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace , And offer me disguised in sober robes To old Baptista as a schoolmaster Well seen in music , to instruct Bianca , That so I may , by this device at least , Have leave and leisure to make love to her And , unsuspected , court her by herself .

English: I'll disguise myself in somber robes .
Shakespearean: Here's no knavery !

English: Oh , Master , master , look !
Shakespearean: Master , master , look about you .

English: Who are these people ?
Shakespearean: Who goes there , ha ?

English: Hush , Grumio .
Shakespearean: Peace , Grumio .

English: It is my rival for Bianca .
Shakespearean: It is the rival of my love .

English: Petruchio , let's stand over here awhile .
Shakespearean: Petruchio , stand by a while .

English: Oh , what an excellent thing this learning is !
Shakespearean: O this learning , what a thing it is !

English: Good to see you , Signior Hortensio .
Shakespearean: And you are well met , Signior Hortensio .

English: Do you know where I'm going ?
Shakespearean: Trow you whither I am going ?

English: To Baptista Minola's house .
Shakespearean: To Baptista Minola .

English: That's great .
Shakespearean: Tis well .

English: And I have met a gentleman who promises to help me find a good music tutor to instruct our lady love .
Shakespearean: And I have met a gentleman Hath promised me to help me to another , A fine musician to instruct our mistress .

English: Gremio , this is no time to compete over how deeply we love Bianca .
Shakespearean: Gremio , 'tis now no time to vent our love .

English: That's good , if he'll really do it .
Shakespearean: So said , so done , is well .

English: Have you told him all her faults , Hortensio ?
Shakespearean: Hortensio , have you told him all her faults ?

English: I know she is a hateful , brawling scold .
Shakespearean: I know she is an irksome brawling scold .

English: If that's all , gentlemen , I see no problem .
Shakespearean: If that be all , masters , I hear no harm .

English: No ?
Shakespearean: No ?

English: Tell me , friend .
Shakespearean: Say'st me so , friend ?

English: Where are you from ?
Shakespearean: What countryman ?

English: My father's dead , and his fortune is mine now .
Shakespearean: My father dead , my fortune lives for me .

English: I hope to see good days , and many of them .
Shakespearean: And I do hope good days and long to see .

English: Sir , such a life with such a wife is unlikely !
Shakespearean: O sir , such a life with such a wife were strange !

English: But if you have the stomach for it , you'll have all the help from me you need .
Shakespearean: But if you have a stomach , to 't , i ' God's name : You shall have me assisting you in all .

English: Do you really mean to go after this wildcat ?
Shakespearean: But will you woo this wildcat ?

English: Why did I come here if not for that ?
Shakespearean: Why came I hither but to that intent ?

English: I , who have survived storms at sea where the winds raged like wild animals ?
Shakespearean: Have I not heard the sea , puffed up with winds , Rage like an angry boar chafed with sweat ?

English: I , who have heard the rumble of guns in battle , and thunder in the sky ( heaven's version of artillery ) .
Shakespearean: Have I not heard great ordnance in the field , And heaven's artillery thunder in the skies ?

English: Listen , Hortensio .
Shakespearean: Hortensio , hark .

English: Absolutely , so long as he gets the girl .
Shakespearean: And so we will , provided that he win her .

English: I wish I could be as certain of a good dinner .
Shakespearean: I would I were as sure of a good dinner .

English: Is that the man you want ?
Shakespearean: He that has the two fair daughters , is 't he you mean ?

English: But not the woman who scolds , anyway , I hope .
Shakespearean: Not her that chides , sir , at any hand , I pray .

English: Sir , a word before you go .
Shakespearean: Sir , a word ere you go .

English: Are you a suitor to the girl we speak of , yes or no ?
Shakespearean: Are you a suitor to the maid you talk of , yea or no ?

English: What if I am ?
Shakespearean: An if I be , sir , is it any offense ?

English: Not if you go away , there isn't .
Shakespearean: No , if without more words you will get you hence .

English: Because , if you must know , she's been chosen by Signior Gremio .
Shakespearean: For this reason , if you'll know : That she's the choice love of Signior Gremio .

English: Because she's been chosen by Signior Hortensio .
Shakespearean: That she's the chosen of Signior Hortensio .

English: Wait a minute , gentlemen .
Shakespearean: Softly , my masters .

English: Be good enough to hear me out .
Shakespearean: If you be gentlemen , Do me this right : hear me with patience .

English: Baptista is a noble gentleman , one to whom my father is not completely unknown , and lovely as his daughter is , she is entitled to any number of suitors , myself among them .
Shakespearean: Baptista is a noble gentleman , To whom my father is not all unknown , And were his daughter fairer than she is , She may more suitors have , and me for one .

English: I don't think he'd have any choice , my lord .
Shakespearean: Believe me , lord , I think he can not choose .

English: When he woke , he wouldn't know where he was .
Shakespearean: It would seem strange unto him when he waked .

English: It would be just like a nice daydream or fantasy .
Shakespearean: Even as a flatt'ring dream or worthless fancy .

English: Well , take him on up and we'll try to pull it off .
Shakespearean: Then take him up and manage well the jest .

English: Carry him to my best room , gently , so he doesn't wake , and hang all my erotic paintings around him .
Shakespearean: Carry him gently to my fairest chamber And hang it round with all my wanton pictures .

English: Bathe his filthy head with warm , scented water .
Shakespearean: Balm his foul head in warm distilled waters And burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet .

English: Convince him that he has been out of his mind , and when he says he's out of his mind My lord , I promise we will play our parts so skillfully that he will believe everything we tell him .
Shakespearean: My lord , I warrant you we will play our part As he shall think by our true diligence He is no less than what we say he is .

English: The beautiful Helen of Troy had a thousand suitors .
Shakespearean: Fair Leda's daughter had a thousand wooers ; Then well one more may fair Bianca have .

English: This fellow will out-talk us all .
Shakespearean: This gentleman will out-talk us all .

English: Hortensio , what's all this about ?
Shakespearean: Hortensio , to what end are all these words ?

English: Yes , leave that labor to great Hercules , it's worse than the previous twelve put together .
Shakespearean: Yea , leave that labor to great Hercules , And let it be more than Alcides ' twelve .

English: Sir , that's well said and well thought out .
Shakespearean: Sir , you say well , and well you do conceive .

English: An excellent motion .
Shakespearean: O excellent motion !

English: Let's go .
Shakespearean: Fellows , let's be gone .

English: I second that
Shakespearean: The motion's good indeed and be it so. , Petruchio , I shall be your

English: Dear sister , it's unfair to me , and unfair to yourself , to turn me into a slave .
Shakespearean: Good sister , wrong me not nor wrong yourself , To make a bondmaid and a slave of me .

English: That I won't stand for .
Shakespearean: That I disdain .

English: And don't lie .
Shakespearean: See thou dissemble not .

English: You lying brat .
Shakespearean: Minion , thou liest .

English: It's Hortensio , isn't it ?
Shakespearean: Is 't not Hortensio ?

English: Oh , I see .
Shakespearean: Oh , then belike you fancy riches more .

English: You'll live in luxury with Gremio .
Shakespearean: You will have Gremio to keep you fair .

Shakespearean: Is it for him you do envy me so ?

Shakespearean: And you , good sir .

Shakespearean: Pray , have you not a daughter Called Katherina , fair and virtuous ?

English: I have a daughter named Katherina , sir .
Shakespearean: I have a daughter , sir , called Katherina .

English: Please , Signior Gremio .
Shakespearean: You wrong me , Signior Gremio .

English: Allow me to continue. , I am a gentleman of Verona , sir , who , hearing of your daughter's beauty and wit , her friendly disposition and bashful modesty , her uncommon virtues and her mild behavior , have taken the liberty of presenting myself as a guest at your house in the hope of seeing for myself if what I've heard is true .
Shakespearean: Give me leave. , I am a gentleman of Verona , sir , That hearing of her beauty and her wit , Her affability and bashful modesty , Her wondrous qualities and mild behavior , Am bold to show myself a forward guest Within your house , to make mine eye the witness Of that report which I so oft have heard .

English: You and he are both welcome , sir .
Shakespearean: You're welcome , sir , and he for your good sake .

English: As for my daughter Katherine , this much I know : she's not for you , more's the pity .
Shakespearean: But for my daughter Katherine , this I know , She is not for your turn , the more my grief .

Shakespearean: I see you do not mean to part with her , Or else you like not of my company .

Shakespearean: I speak but as I find .

Shakespearean: Petruchio is my name , Antonio's son , A man well known throughout all Italy .

Shakespearean: To express the like kindness , myself , that have been more kindly beholding to you than any , freely give unto you this young scholar

English: I know him well by reputation .

Shakespearean: We will go walk a little in the orchard , And then to dinner .

Shakespearean: You knew my father well , and in him me , Left solely heir to all his lands and goods , Which I have bettered rather than decreased .

Shakespearean: Then tell me , if I get your daughter's love , What dowry shall I have with her to wife ?

Shakespearean: After my death , the one half of my lands , And , in possession , twenty thousand crowns .

Shakespearean: Say that she rail ; why then I'll tell her plain She sings as sweetly as a nightingale .

Shakespearean: Say that she frown ; I'll say she looks as clear As morning roses newly washed with dew .

Shakespearean: Say she be mute and will not speak a word ; Then I'll commend her volubility , And say she uttereth piercing eloquence .

English: If she orders me to go , I'll thank her warmly as if she'd just offered to put me up for a week .
Shakespearean: If she do bid me pack , I'll give her thanks , As though she bid me stay by her a week .

English: If she refuses my proposal , I'll tell her how much I'm looking forward to the announcement and the wedding .
Shakespearean: If she deny to wed , I'll crave the day When I shall ask the banns and when be married .

Shakespearean: Sirrah , go see what trumpet 'tis that sounds .

Shakespearean: An't please your Honor , players That offer service to your Lordship .

Shakespearean: I have forgot your name , but sure that part Was aptly fitted and naturally performed .

Shakespearean: His backward voice is to utter foul speeches and to detract .

Shakespearean: O Stephano , two Neapolitans 'scaped !

Shakespearean: Here , kiss the book .

Shakespearean: The whole butt , man .

Shakespearean: Hast thou not dropped from heaven ?

English: No , from the moon , I'm telling you .
Shakespearean: Out o ' th ' moon , I do assure thee .

Shakespearean: I was the man i ' the moon when time was .

Shakespearean: My mistress showed me thee and thy dog and thy bush .

English: I can't believe I was scared of him !
Shakespearean: I afeard of him !

English: A pretty pathetic monster .
Shakespearean: A very weak monster .

English: The man in the moon !
Shakespearean: The man i ' th ' moon !

English: What a poor , gullible monster. , That was a nice big gulp , monster !
Shakespearean: A most poor credulous monster. , Well drawn , monster , in good sooth !

English: What a lying , drunken monster .
Shakespearean: By this light , a most perfidious and drunken monster .

English: When his god falls asleep , the monster will snatch his wine bottle .
Shakespearean: When 's god's asleep , he'll rob his bottle .

English: Come on , then .
Shakespearean: Come on then .

English: Get down and swear it .
Shakespearean: Down , and swear .

Shakespearean: I shall laugh myself to death at this puppy-headed monster .

Shakespearean: I could find in my heart to beat him , But that the poor monster's in drink .

English: An awful monster !
Shakespearean: An abominable monster !

English: I'll show you where to get fresh water .
Shakespearean: I'll show thee the best springs .

Shakespearean: I'll pluck thee berries .

Shakespearean: I'll fish for thee and get thee wood enough .

English: The tyrant I'm serving now can go to hell !
Shakespearean: A plague upon the tyrant that I serve !

English: What a silly monster , to think a poor drunk is wonderful .
Shakespearean: A most ridiculous monster , to make a wonder of a poor drunkard .

English: Show us the way without further delay. , Trinculo , since the king and all our comrades are drowned , we're the heirs of this place. , Here , carry my wine bottle. , Trinculo , my buddy , we'll get that bottle refilled soon enough .
Shakespearean: I prithee now , lead the way without any more talking. , Trinculo , the king and all our company else being drowned , we will inherit here. , Here , bear my bottle. , Fellow Trinculo , we'll fill him by and by again .

English: A loud-mouthed , drunken monster .
Shakespearean: A howling monster , a drunken monster .

English: Good monster !
Shakespearean: O brave monster !

Shakespearean: Lead the way .

English: Right now I'd give a thousand
Shakespearean: Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acre of barren ground : long heath , brown furze , anything .

English: Some kinds of lowly activities are done for noble reasons .
Shakespearean: Some kinds of baseness Are nobly undergone .

English: And you can do poor things that lead to rich results .
Shakespearean: And most poor matters Point to rich ends .

English: This hard work would be boring and nasty to me , but I'm working for a mistress who makes me enjoy my labor .
Shakespearean: This my mean task Would be as heavy to me as odious , but The mistress which I serve quickens what's dead And makes my labors pleasures .

English: Oh , she's ten times nicer than her father is mean , and he's the height of crabbiness .
Shakespearean: Oh , she is Ten times more gentle than her father's crabbed , And he's composed of harshness .

English: I have thousands of logs to take away and pile up , on strict orders from him .
Shakespearean: I must remove Some thousands of these logs and pile them up , Upon a sore injunction .

English: My sweet darling cries when she sees me work and tells me that such a wonderful man never performed such lowly tasks before .
Shakespearean: My sweet mistress Weeps when she sees me work , and says such baseness Had never like executor .

English: These sweet thoughts relieve me and refresh me , especially when I'm slaving away busily .
Shakespearean: I forget , But these sweet thoughts do even refresh my labors , Most busiest when I do it .

English: Now , please , I beg you , don't work so hard .
Shakespearean: Alas now , pray you , Work not so hard .

English: I wish the lightning had burned up all those logs that you've been ordered to stack !
Shakespearean: I would the lightning had Burnt up those logs that you are enjoined to pile !
