Shakespearean: Pray , set it down and rest you .

English: When this wood burns , it'll weep for making you tired .
Shakespearean: When this burns , 'Twill weep for having wearied you .

English: My father's studying hard , so he won't see you .
Shakespearean: My father Is hard at study .

English: So please rest .
Shakespearean: Pray now , rest yourself .

English: We're safe from my father for at least three hours .
Shakespearean: He's safe for these three hours .

English: Oh , my dear mistress , I won't be able to finish this work until sunset at the earliest .
Shakespearean: O most dear mistress , The sun will set before I shall discharge What I must strive to do .

English: If you sit down , I'll carry your logs a while .
Shakespearean: If you'll sit down , I'll bear your logs the while .

English: Please give me that .
Shakespearean: Pray , give me that .

English: I'll take it over to the pile .
Shakespearean: I'll carry it to the pile .

Shakespearean: It would become me As well as it does you , and I should do it With much more ease , for my good will is to it And yours it is against .

English: You look tired .
Shakespearean: You look wearily .

English: I beg you to tell me your name so I can use it in my prayers .
Shakespearean: I do beseech you , Chiefly that I might set it in my prayers , What is your name ?

English: Miranda. , Oh father , I've disobeyed you by telling him that !
Shakespearean: Miranda. , O my father , I have broke your hest to say so !

Shakespearean: Full many a lady I have eyed with best regard and many a time

Shakespearean: Nor have I seen More that I may call men than you , good friend , And my dear father .

Shakespearean: I am in my condition A prince , Miranda , I do think , a king ; I would , not so ! , and would no more endure This wooden slavery than to suffer The flesh-fly blow my mouth .

Shakespearean: Hear my soul speak .

English: The second I saw you , my heart rushed to serve you and be your slave , so here I am now , a patient log-man .
Shakespearean: The very instant that I saw you did My heart fly to your service , there resides To make me slave to it , and for your sake Am I this patient log-man .

English: Do you love me ?
Shakespearean: Do you love me ?

Shakespearean: O heaven , O earth , bear witness to this sound And crown what I profess with kind event

English: More than anything else in the world , I love you , value you , and honor you .
Shakespearean: I Beyond all limit of what else i ' th ' world Do love , prize , honor you .

Shakespearean: I am a fool To weep at what I am glad of .

Shakespearean: At mine unworthiness , that dare not offer What I desire to give , and much less take What I shall die to want .

Shakespearean: My mistress , dearest , and I thus humble ever .

English: Will you be my husband , then ?
Shakespearean: My husband , then ?

English: A million goodbyes to you .
Shakespearean: A thousand thousand !

English: Now it's time to get back to my studying , since I have a lot of serious business to take care of before dinner .
Shakespearean: I'll to my book , For yet ere supper-time must I perform Much business appertaining .

English: Don't tell me that .
Shakespearean: Tell not me .

English: When the barrel's empty , we'll drink water .
Shakespearean: When the butt is out , we will drink water .

English: Not one drop sooner .
Shakespearean: Not a drop before .

English: Therefore , drink up. , Servant-monster , drink a toast to me .
Shakespearean: Therefore bear up and board 'em. , Servant- monster , drink to me .

English: Servant monster" ?
Shakespearean: Servant-monster" ?

English: What a crazy island this is .
Shakespearean: The folly of this island .

English: They say there are only five people on it .
Shakespearean: They say there's but five upon this isle .

English: We're three of them .
Shakespearean: We are three of them .

English: If the other two are as loopy as we are , our country's in bad shape .
Shakespearean: If th ' other two be brained like us , the state totters .

English: Drink when I order you , servant-monster .
Shakespearean: Drink , servant-monster , when I bid thee .

English: Your eyes look like they've sunk into your head .
Shakespearean: Thy eyes are almost set in thy head .

English: Where else should his eyes be , if not in his head ?
Shakespearean: Where should they be set else ?

English: He'd be quite a monster if his eyes were in his tail .
Shakespearean: He were a brave monster indeed , if they were set in his tail .

English: My man , monster is so drunk he can't talk .
Shakespearean: For my part , the sea can not drown me .

English: He's not standing straight enough to hold a flag .
Shakespearean: He's no standard .

English: We're not going to run in our army , Monsieur Monster .
Shakespearean: We'll not run , Monsieur Monster .

English: Or walk either .
Shakespearean: Nor go neither .

English: You'll just lie there like sleeping dogs and say nothing .
Shakespearean: But you'll lie like dogs , and yet say nothing neither .

English: Monster sweetie , be a good monster and just speak once .
Shakespearean: Mooncalf , speak once in thy life , if thou beest a good mooncalf .

English: How is your Highness ?
Shakespearean: How does thy honor ?

English: Let me lick your shoe .
Shakespearean: Let me lick thy shoe .

English: Lord , " he calls you ?
Shakespearean: Lord , " quoth he ?

English: What an idiot that monster is !
Shakespearean: That a monster should be such a natural !

English: Trinculo , speak politely .
Shakespearean: Trinculo , keep a good tongue in your head .

English: If you mutiny against me , I'll hang you from the next tree .
Shakespearean: If you prove a mutineer , the next tree .

English: Thank you , my noble lord .
Shakespearean: I thank my noble lord .

English: Now would you please listen once again to the request I made to you earlier ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou be pleased to hearken once again to the suit I made to thee ?

English: I'll stand , and so will Trinculo .
Shakespearean: I will stand , and so shall Trinculo .

English: You lie .
Shakespearean: Thou liest .

English: Trinculo , if you interrupt him any more , I swear I'll knock some teeth out of your head .
Shakespearean: Trinculo , if you trouble him any more in 's tale , by this hand , I will supplant some of your teeth .

English: I didn't say anything .
Shakespearean: Why , I said nothing .

English: Okay , just stay quiet .
Shakespearean: Mum , then , and no more .

English: Go on .
Shakespearean: Proceed .

English: I was telling you he used witchcraft to take this island .
Shakespearean: I say , by sorcery he got this isle .

English: He stole it from me .
Shakespearean: From me he got it .

English: If your highness is willing , take revenge on him for that , because I know you're brave enough , I don't dare to , That's for sure .
Shakespearean: If thy greatness will Revenge it on him , for I know thou darest , But this thing dare not , That's most certain .

English: You'll be lord of the island then , and I'll be your servant .
Shakespearean: Thou shalt be lord of it and I'll serve thee .

English: And how would we go about doing that ?
Shakespearean: How now shall this be compassed ?

English: Can you bring me to him ?
Shakespearean: Canst thou bring me to th ' party ?

English: Yes , yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Yea , yea , my lord .

English: I'll take you to where he sleeps , and you can pound a nail into his head .
Shakespearean: I'll yield him thee asleep , Where thou mayst knock a nail into his head .

English: You lie .
Shakespearean: Thou liest .

English: You can't do that .
Shakespearean: Thou canst not .

English: What an idiot this guy is ! , You're a rotten piece of work ! , I beg your highness , beat him up and take his wine bottle from him .
Shakespearean: What a pied ninny's this ! , Thou scurvy patch ! , I do beseech thy greatness , give him blows And take his bottle from him .

English: When he loses that , he'll be drinking salt water , since I'll never tell him where the freshwater springs are .
Shakespearean: When that's gone , He shall drink naught but brine , for I'll not show him Where the quick freshes are .

English: Trinculo , watch out .
Shakespearean: Trinculo , run into no further danger .

English: If you interrupt this monster with one more word , I'll beat you like a piece of salted fish .
Shakespearean: Interrupt the monster one word further , and , by this hand , I'll turn my mercy out o ' doors and make a stockfish of thee .

English: What did I do ?
Shakespearean: Why , what did I ?

English: I didn't do anything .
Shakespearean: I did nothing .

English: I need to get away from you .
Shakespearean: I'll go farther off .

English: Didn't you call him a liar ?
Shakespearean: Didst thou not say he lied ?

English: You lie .
Shakespearean: Thou liest .

English: I didn't accuse you of lying .
Shakespearean: I did not give the lie .

English: Are you out of your mind and deaf too ?
Shakespearean: Out o ' your wits and hearing too ?

English: Damn your wine !
Shakespearean: A pox o ' your bottle !

English: Ha , ha , ha !
Shakespearean: Ha , ha , ha !

English: Now go ahead and tell me the rest of your story. , Please go stand farther away .
Shakespearean: Now , forward with your tale. , Prithee , stand farther off .

English: Beat him up .
Shakespearean: Beat him enough .

English: After a little while , I'll beat him too .
Shakespearean: After a little time , I'll beat him too .

English: Just as I told you , he usually sleeps in the afternoon .
Shakespearean: Why , as I told thee , 'tis a custom with him , I ' th ' afternoon to sleep .

English: At that time you can smash in his skull after seizing his books ; or you can bash his skull with a log ; or you can stab him in the belly ; or cut his windpipe .
Shakespearean: There thou mayst brain him , Having first seized his books ; or with a log Batter his skull ; or paunch him with a stake ; Or cut his weasand with thy knife .

English: Just remember to grab his books first , since without them he's just a poor fool like me , and can't command a single spirit .
Shakespearean: Remember First to possess his books , for without them He's but a sot , as I am , nor hath not One spirit to command .

English: All the spirits hate him as much as I do .
Shakespearean: They all do hate him As rootedly as I .

English: Be sure to burn his magic books .
Shakespearean: Burn but his books .

English: He has some wonderful home furnishings , that's what he calls them , that he'll use to decorate his house when he gets one .
Shakespearean: He has brave utensils , for so he calls them , Which when he has a house , he'll deck withal .

English: The most important thing for you to think about is how beautiful his daughter is .
Shakespearean: And that most deeply to consider is The beauty of his daughter .

English: He says she has no equal .
Shakespearean: He himself Calls her a nonpareil .

English: I never saw a woman except her and Sycorax , my mother .
Shakespearean: I never saw a woman , But only Sycorax my dam and she .

English: But Miranda is so much more beautiful , you can't even compare the two .
Shakespearean: But she as far surpasseth Sycorax As great'st does least .

English: Is she really that wonderful ?
Shakespearean: Is it so brave a lass ?

English: Yes , my lord .
Shakespearean: Ay , lord .

English: Monster , I'll kill this man .
Shakespearean: Monster , I will kill this man .

English: His daughter and I will be king and queen , God protect us ! , and you and Trinculo will be our governors. , Do you like that idea , Trinculo ?
Shakespearean: His daughter and I will be king and queen , save our graces ! , and Trinculo and thyself shall be viceroys. , Dost thou like the plot , Trinculo ?

English: Excellent .
Shakespearean: Excellent .

English: Give me your hand .
Shakespearean: Give me thy hand .

English: I'm sorry I hit you .
Shakespearean: I am sorry I beat thee .

English: But try to control your speech .
Shakespearean: But while thou livest , keep a good tongue in thy head .

English: In a half an hour he'll be asleep .
Shakespearean: Within this half hour will he be asleep .

English: Will you kill him then ?
Shakespearean: Wilt thou destroy him then ?

English: Dear father , if you caused this terrible storm with your magic powers , please put an end to it .
Shakespearean: If by your art , my dearest father , you have Put the wild waters in this roar , allay them .

English: The sky's so dark it looks like it would rain down boiling hot tar if the sea weren't swelling up to the sky to put its fire out .
Shakespearean: The sky , it seems , would pour down stinking pitch , But that the sea , mounting to th ' welkin's cheek , Dashes the fire out .

English: Oh , I suffered along with all the men I watched suffer !
Shakespearean: Oh , I have suffered With those that I saw suffer .

English: A fine ship , with some good people in it , I'm sure , smashed to pieces .
Shakespearean: A brave vessel Who had , no doubt , some noble creature in her Dashed all to pieces .

English: Their dying shouts broke my heart !
Shakespearean: Oh , the cry did knock Against my very heart !

English: The poor people died .
Shakespearean: Poor souls , they perished .

English: If I'd been a god I would've let the sea sink inside the earth before it had a chance to swallow up that ship and all the people it was carrying .
Shakespearean: Had I been any god of power , I would Have sunk the sea within the earth or ere It should the good ship so have swallowed and The fraughting souls within her .

English: Calm down .
Shakespearean: Be collected .

English: There's nothing to get upset about .
Shakespearean: No more amazement .

English: No harm was done .
Shakespearean: Tell your piteous heart There's no harm done .

English: Oh , what a horrible day !
Shakespearean: Oh , woe the day !

English: There was no harm , I'm telling you .
Shakespearean: No harm .

English: It never occurred to me to imagine there was anything more to know .
Shakespearean: More to know Did never meddle with my thoughts .

English: Yes , I swear .
Shakespearean: Ay , on mine honor .

English: You make me so happy .
Shakespearean: Thou makest me merry .

English: I'm full of joy .
Shakespearean: I am full of pleasure .

English: Let's be light-hearted .
Shakespearean: Let us be jocund .

English: I'll do anything you ask , monster , anything reasonable. , Come on , Trinculo , let's sing .
Shakespearean: At thy request , monster , I will do reason , any reason. , Come on , Trinculo , let us sing .

English: That's not the tune I had in mind .
Shakespearean: That's not the tune .

English: What's this song ?
Shakespearean: What is this same ?

English: Oh , forgive all my sins !
Shakespearean: O , forgive me my sins !

English: Are you scared ?
Shakespearean: Art thou afeard ?

English: No , monster , not me .
Shakespearean: No , monster , not I .

English: Don't be scared .
Shakespearean: Be not afeard .

English: This'll be a wonderful kingdom to live in , where they play music for free .
Shakespearean: This will prove a brave kingdom to me , where I shall have my music for nothing .

English: As soon as you kill Prospero .
Shakespearean: When Prospero is destroyed .

English: That'll happen soon enough .
Shakespearean: That shall be by and by .

English: I remember the plan .
Shakespearean: I remember the story .

English: The sound is going away .
Shakespearean: The sound is going away .

English: But let's follow it , and then do our dirty work afterward .
Shakespearean: Let's follow it , and after do our work .

English: Lead us , monster ; we'll follow .
Shakespearean: Lead , monster ; we'll follow .

English: I wish I could see this invisible drummer .
Shakespearean: I would I could see this taborer .

English: He really plays well .
Shakespearean: He lays it on .

English: Are you coming monster ?
Shakespearean: Wilt come ?

English: My old bones are tired .
Shakespearean: My old bones ache .

English: We're wandering in a maze .
Shakespearean: Here's a maze trod indeed Through forthrights and meanders .

English: If you don't mind , I need to rest a bit .
Shakespearean: By your patience , I needs must rest me .

English: I can't blame you , old lord .
Shakespearean: Old lord , I can not blame thee , Who am myself attached with weariness To th ' dulling of my spirits .

English: Sit down and rest .
Shakespearean: Sit down and rest .

English: We're searching on land , but he's lost in the sea .
Shakespearean: He is drowned Whom thus we stray to find , and the sea mocks Our frustrate search on land .

English: We have to give up and let him go .
Shakespearean: Well , let him go .

English: What's that music ?
Shakespearean: What harmony is this ?

English: My friends , listen .
Shakespearean: My good friends , hark !

English: What marvelous music !
Shakespearean: Marvelous sweet music !

English: Heaven help us !
Shakespearean: Give us kind keepers , heavens !

English: What were those things ?
Shakespearean: What were these ?

English: Now I'll believe that unicorns exist , and that there's a tree in Arabia where the phoenix lives .
Shakespearean: Now I will believe That there are unicorns , that in Arabia There is one tree , the phoenix ' throne , one phoenix At this hour reigning there .

English: Travelers have never told lies , no matter what the fools at home accuse them of .
Shakespearean: Travelers ne'er did lie , Though fools at home condemn 'em .

English: If I told them about this back in Naples , would they believe me ?
Shakespearean: If in Naples I should report this now , would they believe me ?

English: I'd tell them that I saw natives like these , since they must be natives , who are graceful and well-mannered even if they're monstrous to look at , kinder than most human beings you might find , kinder than almost any human .
Shakespearean: If I should say , I saw such islanders , For , certes , these are people of the island , Who , though they are of monstrous shape , yet note , Their manners are more gentle-kind than of Our human generation you shall find Many , nay , almost any .

English: They vanished strangely .
Shakespearean: They vanished strangely .

English: It's all right , since they left their food behind , and we're hungry .
Shakespearean: No matter , since They have left their viands behind , for we have stomachs .

English: Would you like to taste the banquet ?
Shakespearean: Will 't please you taste of what is here ?

English: Not me .
Shakespearean: Not I .

English: I assure you , sir , there's nothing to be afraid of .
Shakespearean: Faith , sir , you need not fear .

English: Brother , Duke , please have some food .
Shakespearean: Brother , my lord the duke , Stand to and do as we .

English: Oh , it's horrible , horrible .
Shakespearean: Oh , it is monstrous , monstrous .

English: I thought the clouds were talking to me , the winds were singing to me , and the thunder , like an awful organ pipe , roared Prospero's name .
Shakespearean: Methought the billows spoke and told me of it , The winds did sing it to me , and the thunder , That deep and dreadful organ pipe , pronounced The name of Prosper .

English: It sang about my crimes .
Shakespearean: It did bass my trespass .

English: I'll go join him there , going down deeper than any anchor ever sank , and lie with him dead in the mud .
Shakespearean: Therefore my son i ' th ' ooze is bedded , and I'll seek him deeper than e'er plummet sounded And with him there lie mudded .

English: I'll fight every one of these devils if I have to , one at a time .
Shakespearean: But one fiend at a time , I'll fight their legions o'er .

English: I'll back you up .
Shakespearean: I'll be thy second .

English: All three of them are crazy with despair .
Shakespearean: All three of them are desperate .

English: Their guilt is finally starting to gnaw at them , like a slow-acting poison .
Shakespearean: Their great guilt , Like poison given to work a great time after , Now 'gins to bite the spirits .

English: Those of you who are young and active , I beg you to follow them and keep them from doing the crazy things their guilt might push them to do .
Shakespearean: I do beseech you That are of suppler joints , follow them swiftly And hinder them from what this ecstasy May now provoke them to .

English: Follow them , please .
Shakespearean: Follow , I pray you .

English: But if you have sex with her before the marriage ceremony takes place , the heavens will not bless your relationship , but will overwhelm you with hate , contempt , and discord , and will poison your marriage bed so that you both grow to loathe it .
Shakespearean: But If thou dost break her virgin knot before All sanctimonious ceremonies may With full and holy rite be ministered , No sweet aspersion shall the heavens let fall To make this contract grow , but barren hate , Sour-eyed disdain , and discord shall bestrew The union of your bed with weeds so loathly That you shall hate it both .

English: You've said it well .
Shakespearean: Fairly spoke .

English: So have a seat and talk to her .
Shakespearean: Sit then and talk with her .

English: She's yours. , Come , Ariel !
Shakespearean: She is thine own. , What , Ariel !

English: My trusty servant , Ariel !
Shakespearean: My industrious servant , Ariel !

English: What does my powerful master wish for ?
Shakespearean: What would my potent master ?

English: I'm here .
Shakespearean: Here I am .

English: You and your fellow spirits did your last assignment well , and now I need your help again .
Shakespearean: Thou and thy meaner fellows your last service Did worthily perform , and I must use you In such another trick .

English: Go bring them all here ; I give you power over them .
Shakespearean: Go bring the rabble , O'er whom I give thee power , here to this place .

English: I've promised them I would , and they're expecting it .
Shakespearean: It is my promise , And they expect it from me .

English: Right now ?
Shakespearean: Presently ?

English: Yes , right away .
Shakespearean: Ay , with a twink .

English: Before you can say "Come" and "Go , " And breathe twice , and shout "So , so ! " Each one of your servants will rush here ,
Shakespearean: Before you can say "Come" and "Go , " And breathe twice and cry "So , so ! " Each one , tripping on his toe ,

English: It's time for you to know the whole story .
Shakespearean: Tis time I should inform thee farther .

English: Give me a hand and help me off with this magic cloak .
Shakespearean: Lend thy hand And pluck my magic garment from me .

English: Not yet." Well , the time has come .
Shakespearean: Not yet." The hour's now come .

English: Can you remember the time before you came to live in this shack ?
Shakespearean: Canst thou remember A time before we came unto this cell ?

English: I doubt it , since you weren't even three at the time .
Shakespearean: I do not think thou canst , for then thou wast not Out three years old .

English: Sure I can , father .
Shakespearean: Certainly , sir , I can .

English: What do you remember ?
Shakespearean: By what ?

English: A house , a person ?
Shakespearean: By any other house or person ?

English: Tell me anything you remember .
Shakespearean: Of anything the image tell me that Hath kept with thy remembrance .

English: I love you dearly , Ariel .
Shakespearean: Dearly my delicate Ariel .

English: Don't come near till you hear me call you .
Shakespearean: Do not approach Till thou dost hear me call .

English: All right , I understand .
Shakespearean: Well , I conceive .

English: I assure you , sir , the tender love I feel in my heart is stronger than the sexual passions stirring down below .
Shakespearean: I warrant you , sir , The white cold virgin snow upon my heart Abates the ardor of my liver .

English: Good. , Now come , Ariel !
Shakespearean: Well. , Now come , my Ariel !

English: Better to have an extra servant on hand than be understaffed .
Shakespearean: Bring a corollary , Rather than want a spirit .

English: Appear before me now quickly , No talking .
Shakespearean: Appear and pertly ! , No tongue .

English: Just watch !
Shakespearean: All eyes !

English: Be quiet .
Shakespearean: Be silent .

English: I have come to announce that Juno has asked you , Ceres , goddess of the fields and the earth , to leave your rich farms of wheat , rye , barley , oats , and peas , the hills where the
Shakespearean: Ceres , most bounteous lady , thy rich leas Of wheat , rye , barley , vetches , oats , and peas ; Thy turfy mountains , where live nibbling sheep , And flat meads thatched with stover , them to keep ; Thy banks with pioned and twilled brims ,

English: Why has your queen , Juno , called me here to this grassy spot ?
Shakespearean: Why hath thy queen Summoned me hither to this short-grassed green ?

English: To celebrate a marriage of true love , and give a gift to the lovers .
Shakespearean: A contract of true love to celebrate , And some donation freely to estate On the blessed lovers .

English: Tell me , rainbow , do you know if either Venus , the goddess of love , or her son , Cupid , is accompanying Queen Juno ?
Shakespearean: Tell me , heavenly bow , If Venus or her son , as thou dost know , Do now attend the queen ?

English: Ever since Venus and her blind son plotted a way for the god of the underworld to steal my daughter away for half the year , I swore I'd never speak to them again .
Shakespearean: Since they did plot The means that dusky Dis my daughter got , Her and her blind boy's scandaled company I have forsworn .

English: Don't be afraid of her company .
Shakespearean: Of her society Be not afraid .

English: I met Venus as she was with her son on her way to her home on Paphos , in a carriage pulled by doves .
Shakespearean: I met her deity Cutting the clouds towards Paphos , and her son Dove-drawn with her .

English: They were planning to pull a mischievous trick on Ferdinand and Miranda , who have sworn not to sleep together till their wedding day .
Shakespearean: Here thought they to have done Some wanton charm upon this man and maid , Whose vows are that no bed-right shall be paid Till Hymen's torch be lighted , but in vain .

English: But their trick failed .
Shakespearean: Mars's hot minion is returned again .

English: Venus went home again , and her little son broke all his arrows , swearing he'll never shoot them again , but play with birds like other little boys .
Shakespearean: Her waspish-headed son has broke his arrows , Swears he will shoot no more , but play with sparrows And be a boy right out .

English: Great Queen Juno is coming .
Shakespearean: Highest queen of state , Great Juno , comes .

English: I know her by her walk .
Shakespearean: I know her by her gait .

English: How is my generous sister ?
Shakespearean: How does my bounteous sister ?

English: Come help me bless this couple , so they will be prosperous and have many children .
Shakespearean: Go with me To bless this twain that they may prosperous be , And honored in their issue .

English: This is a majestic and harmonious vision .
Shakespearean: This is a most majestic vision , and Harmonious charmingly .

English: Are these spirits we see before us ?
Shakespearean: May I be bold To think these spirits ?

English: Yes , they're spirits that I've called out of their prisons to perform my whims .
Shakespearean: Spirits , which by mine art I have from their confines called to enact My present fancies .

English: Let me live here forever .
Shakespearean: Let me live here ever .

English: Such a wonderful father-in-law and wife make this place a paradise .
Shakespearean: So rare a wondered father and a wife Makes this place paradise .

English: Now be quiet .
Shakespearean: Sweet now , silence .

English: Juno and Ceres are whispering about something serious .
Shakespearean: Juno and Ceres whisper seriously .

English: There's something else to be done .
Shakespearean: There's something else to do .

English: Be silent , or else my magic spell will be broken .
Shakespearean: Hush and be mute , Or else our spell is marred .

English: Come , sweet nymphs , and help us celebrate the wedding of two true lovers .
Shakespearean: Come , temperate nymphs , and help to celebrate A contract of true love .

English: Don't be late .
Shakespearean: Be not too late .

English: Now , you tanned fieldworkers who are so tired of August's labors , get out of the dirt and come rejoice with us here .
Shakespearean: You sunburnt sicklemen of August weary , Come hither from the furrow and be merry .

English: Put your straw hats on , have some fun , and dance with these young nymphs .
Shakespearean: Your rye-straw hats put on , And these fresh nymphs encounter every one In country footing .

English: The moment they planned to act is almost here .
Shakespearean: The minute of their plot Is almost come. , Well done .

English: I've never seen him like this .
Shakespearean: Never till this day Saw I him touched with anger so distempered .

English: We are all made of dreams , and our life stretches from sleep before birth to sleep after death .
Shakespearean: We are such stuff As dreams are made on , and our little life Is rounded with a sleep .

English: Sir , I'm upset .
Shakespearean: Sir , I am vexed .

English: Please put up with my weakness .
Shakespearean: Bear with my weakness .

English: My old brain is troubled .
Shakespearean: My old brain is troubled .

English: Don't be disturbed by my illness .
Shakespearean: Be not disturbed with my infirmity .

English: If you like , you can rest a while in my room .
Shakespearean: If you be pleased , retire into my cell And there repose .

English: I'll go for a short walk to calm down my feverish mind .
Shakespearean: A turn or two I'll walk To still my beating mind .

English: We hope you feel better and find some peace .
Shakespearean: We wish your peace .

English: Come , Ariel , I summon you with a thought .
Shakespearean: Come with a thought .

English: Thank you , Ariel .
Shakespearean: I thank thee , Ariel .

English: Come .
Shakespearean: Come .

English: I obey all your thoughts .
Shakespearean: Thy thoughts I cleave to .

English: What do you wish ?
Shakespearean: What's thy pleasure ?

English: Spirit , we have to get ready to meet with Caliban .
Shakespearean: Spirit , We must prepare to meet with Caliban .

English: Yes , my master .
Shakespearean: Ay , my commander .

English: When I was putting on the Ceres show , I thought of reminding you about Caliban , but I was afraid of upsetting you .
Shakespearean: When I presented Ceres , I thought to have told thee of it , but I feared Lest I might anger thee .

English: Tell me again , where did you leave those lowlifes ?
Shakespearean: Say again , where didst thou leave these varlets ?

English: I told you , sir , they were totally drunk , so puffed up with courage that they were getting angry at the air for blowing in their faces , and beating the ground for touching their feet , yet even when drunk , they kept their plan firmly in mind .
Shakespearean: I told you , sir , they were red-hot with drinking , So full of valor that they smote the air For breathing in their faces , beat the ground For kissing of their feet , yet always bending Towards their project .

English: Then I beat my drum , at which point they pricked up their ears and opened their eyes , looking around for the source of my music .
Shakespearean: Then I beat my tabor , At which , like unbacked colts , they pricked their ears , Advanced their eyelids , lifted up their noses As they smelt music .

English: I enchanted them so thoroughly that they followed me through thorn bushes and prickly shrubs that tore up their shins .
Shakespearean: So I charmed their ears That , calflike , they my lowing followed through Toothed briers , sharp furzes , pricking gorse , and thorns , Which entered their frail shins .

English: In the end I left them standing in the smelly pond behind your room , with the stinking water covering them up to their chins .
Shakespearean: At last I left them I ' th ' filthy-mantled pool beyond your cell , There dancing up to th ' chins , that the foul lake O'erstunk their feet .

English: Good job , my little one .
Shakespearean: This was well done , my bird .

English: Stay invisible .
Shakespearean: Thy shape invisible retain thou still .

English: Bring the fancy clothes out of my house , to use as bait to catch these thieves .
Shakespearean: The trumpery in my house , go bring it hither For stale to catch these thieves .

English: I'm going , I'm going .
Shakespearean: I go , I go .

English: He's a devil , a born devil , who can never be trained .
Shakespearean: A devil , a born devil on whose nature Nurture can never stick , on whom my pains , Humanely taken , all , all lost , quite lost .

English: As his body grows uglier with age , his mind rots away as well .
Shakespearean: And as with age his body uglier grows , So his mind cankers .

English: I'll torment them all till they roar with pain .
Shakespearean: I will plague them all , Even to roaring .

English: Here , hang them on this clothesline .
Shakespearean: Come , hang them on this line .

English: Please walk softly , so not even a mole hears us approach .
Shakespearean: Pray you , tread softly , that the blind mole may not hear a foot fall .

English: We're near his room now .
Shakespearean: We now are near his cell .

English: Hey monster , the spirit you've been talking about , the one you call harmless , has been playing tricks on us .
Shakespearean: Monster , your fairy , which you say is a harmless fairy , has done little better than played the jack with us .

English: Monster , I smell like horse piss , which is making my nose pretty upset .
Shakespearean: Monster , I do smell all horse piss , at which my nose is in great indignation .

English: Mine too. , Are you listening , monster ?
Shakespearean: So is mine. , Do you hear , monster ?

English: If I decide to get angry at you , just watch out , You'd be done for then , monster .
Shakespearean: If I should take a displeasure against you , look you , Thou wert but a lost monster .

English: My good lord , I still need you to like me .
Shakespearean: Good my lord , give me thy favor still .

English: Be patient , because the prize I'm leading you to will make you forget how smelly you are now .
Shakespearean: Be patient , for the prize I'll bring thee to Shall hoodwink this mischance .

English: So be quiet .
Shakespearean: Therefore speak softly .

English: It's as silent as a graveyard here .
Shakespearean: All's hushed as midnight yet .

English: That upsets me much more than getting wet .
Shakespearean: That's more to me than my wetting .

English: And you called the fairy creature harmless , monster .
Shakespearean: Yet this is your harmless fairy , monster .

English: Please , my king , be quiet .
Shakespearean: Prithee , my king , be quiet .

English: Look here , this is the entrance to his room .
Shakespearean: Seest thou here , This is the mouth o ' th ' cell .

English: Be silent and go in .
Shakespearean: No noise , and enter .

English: Do the deed that will make this island yours forever , and will make me , Caliban , your worshipful foot-licker .
Shakespearean: Do that good mischief which may make this island Thine own for ever , and I , thy Caliban , For aye thy foot-licker .

English: Give me your hand .
Shakespearean: Give me thy hand .

English: I'm starting to feel murderous urges .
Shakespearean: I do begin to have bloody thoughts .

English: Leave it alone , you fool .
Shakespearean: Let it alone , thou fool .

English: It's worthless .
Shakespearean: It is but trash .

English: Oh , monster , we know secondhand clothes when we see them. , Take off that gown , Trinculo .
Shakespearean: Oh , ho , monster , we know what belongs to a frippery. , Put off that gown , Trinculo .

English: I swear that gown's for me .
Shakespearean: By this hand , I'll have that gown .

English: You can have it then , your highness .
Shakespearean: Thy grace shall have it .

English: To hell with this idiot !
Shakespearean: The dropsy drown this fool !

English: Why are you going crazy over these trashy clothes ?
Shakespearean: What do you mean To dote thus on such luggage ?

English: Leave them alone , and do the murder first .
Shakespearean: Let's alone , And do the murder first .

English: If he wakes up before we kill him , he'll never stop punishing us .
Shakespearean: If he awake , From toe to crown he'll fill our skins with pinches , Make us strange stuff .

English: Thank you kindly .
Shakespearean: Do , do .

English: Thank you for that joke .
Shakespearean: I thank thee for that jest .

English: As king of this country I like to reward wit when I hear it .
Shakespearean: Wit shall not go unrewarded while I am king of this country .

English: Here's another jacket to say thanks .
Shakespearean: There's another garment for 't .

English: Come here , monster , put some glue on your fingers , and carry away the rest of these clothes for us .
Shakespearean: Monster , come , put some lime upon your fingers , and away with the rest .

English: I won't have any of this .
Shakespearean: I will have none on 't .

English: Monster , use your fingers .
Shakespearean: Monster , lay to your fingers .

English: Help us carry these clothes to where my barrel of wine is hidden , or I'll kick you out of my kingdom .
Shakespearean: Help to bear this away where my hogshead of wine is , or I'll turn you out of my kingdom .

English: Go on , take them .
Shakespearean: Go to , carry this .

English: Take these too .
Shakespearean: And this .

English: Yes , and these .
Shakespearean: Ay , and this .

English: Hey , Mountain , hey !
Shakespearean: Hey , Mountain , hey !

English: Silver .
Shakespearean: Silver .

English: There they go , Silver !
Shakespearean: There it goes , Silver !

English: My memory is hazy , more like a dream than a recollection .
Shakespearean: Tis far off , And rather like a dream than an assurance That my remembrance warrants .

English: Didn't I use to have four or five women taking care of me ?
Shakespearean: Had I not Four or five women once that tended me ?

English: Indeed you did , and more besides , Miranda .
Shakespearean: Thou hadst , and more , Miranda .

English: But how is it possible that you still remember this , through all the darkness of the past ?
Shakespearean: But how is it That this lives in thy mind ?

English: If you remember your life before you came here , you may also remember how you got here .
Shakespearean: If thou rememberest aught ere thou camest here , How thou camest here thou mayst .

English: No , that I don't remember .
Shakespearean: But that I do not .

English: Twelve years ago , Miranda , twelve years ago your father was the Duke of Milan , a powerful prince .
Shakespearean: Twelve year since , Miranda , twelve year since , Thy father was the Duke of Milan and A prince of power .

English: Aren't you my father ?
Shakespearean: Sir , are not you my father ?

English: Your mother was extremely virtuous , and she said you were my daughter .
Shakespearean: Thy mother was a piece of virtue and She said thou wast my daughter .

English: And your father was Duke of Milan , and you were his heir , a princess .
Shakespearean: And thy father Was Duke of Milan , and thou his only heir And princess no worse issued .

English: Good lord !
Shakespearean: Oh , the heavens !

English: What evil things were done to us that we were driven here ?
Shakespearean: What foul play had we that we came from thence ?

English: Or was it a blessing that we came here ?
Shakespearean: Or blesse was 't we did ?

English: Both , both , my girl .
Shakespearean: Both , both , my girl .

English: We were pushed out of power by evil deeds , as you call them .
Shakespearean: By foul play , as thou sayst , were we heaved thence , But blessedly holp hither .

English: Fury , Fury ! , Get over there , Tyrant , there .
Shakespearean: Fury , Fury ! , There , Tyrant , there .

English: Listen , listen !
Shakespearean: Hark , hark !

English: Ariel , go order my goblin servants to make these fellows ' bones ache , give them muscle cramps all over , and give them more bruises than leopards have spots .
Shakespearean: Go charge my goblins that they grind their joints With dry convulsions , shorten up their sinews With aged cramps , and more pinch-spotted make them Than pard or cat o ' mountain .

English: Listen they're howling .
Shakespearean: Hark , they roar .

English: Hunt them down .
Shakespearean: Let them be hunted soundly .

English: Now all my enemies are at my mercy .
Shakespearean: At this hour Lie at my mercy all mine enemies .

English: Soon all my work will be done , and you'll be free .
Shakespearean: Shortly shall all my labors end , and thou Shalt have the air at freedom .

English: Just obey me a little bit longer .
Shakespearean: For a little Follow , and do me service .

English: My plans are almost at their climax .
Shakespearean: Now does my project gather to a head .

English: My spells are working well , my spirits are obeying me , and everything is right on schedule .
Shakespearean: My charms crack not , my spirits obey , and time Goes upright with his carriage .

English: What time is it ?
Shakespearean: How's the day ?

English: It's after six o'clock , my lord , when you said our work would be finished .
Shakespearean: On the sixth hour , at which time , my lord , You said our work should cease .

English: That's what I said when I first conjured the tempest .
Shakespearean: I did say so When first I raised the tempest .

English: Tell me , spirit , how's the king and his entourage ?
Shakespearean: Say , my spirit , How fares the king and 's followers ?

English: All cooped up together , just as you ordered , all imprisoned in the grove of linden trees that protects your room from bad weather .
Shakespearean: Confined together In the same fashion as you gave in charge , Just as you left them , all prisoners , sir , In the line grove which weather-fends your cell .

English: They can't move till you release them .
Shakespearean: They can not budge till your release .

English: The king , his brother , and your brother are all waiting there in a crazed state of mind , and the rest are grieving over them , sad and astonished .
Shakespearean: The king , His brother , and yours , abide all three distracted , And the remainder mourning over them , Brimful of sorrow and dismay .

English: Good old lord Gonzalo , " as you call him , is saddest of all , with tears running down his beard .
Shakespearean: But chiefly Him that you termed , sir , "the good old Lord Gonzalo , " His tears run down his beard like winter's drops From eaves of reeds .

English: Your magic spell has such an effect on them that if you saw them now , you'd feel sorry for them .
Shakespearean: Your charm so strongly works 'em That if you now beheld them , your affections Would become tender .

English: Do you think so , spirit ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou think so , spirit ?

English: I'd feel sorry for them , if I were human .
Shakespearean: Mine would , sir , were I human .

English: I will too .
Shakespearean: And mine shall .

English: It's better to act virtuously rather than vengefully .
Shakespearean: The rarer action is In virtue than in vengeance .

English: Go release them , Ariel .
Shakespearean: Go release them , Ariel .

English: I'll break my spells and bring them back to their senses , and they'll feel like themselves again .
Shakespearean: My charms I'll break , their senses I'll restore , And they shall be themselves .

English: I'll go get them , sir .
Shakespearean: I'll fetch them , sir .

English: With his own lightning bolts ; I've shaken up the sturdy cliffs and uprooted pines and cedars ; I've opened up graves and awakened the corpses sleeping in them , letting them out with my powerful magic .
Shakespearean: With his own bolt ; the strong-based promontory Have I made shake , and by the spurs plucked up The pine and cedar ; graves at my command Have waked their sleepers , oped , and let 'em forth By my so potent art .

English: But I surrender all this magic now , when I've summoned some heavenly music to cast a spell , as I'm doing now , I'll break my staff and bury it far underground , and throw my book of magic spells deeper into the sea than any anchor ever sank .
Shakespearean: But this rough magic I here abjure , and when I have required Some heavenly music , which even now I do , To work mine end upon their senses that This airy charm is for , I'll break my staff , Bury it certain fathoms in the earth , And deeper than did ever plummet sound I'll drown my book .

English: Let this solemn melody comfort your fevered minds , which are now useless , seething inside your skulls. , All of you stand there in my spell. ,
Shakespearean: A solemn air and the best comforter To an unsettled fancy cure thy brains , Now useless , boiled within thy skull. , There stand , For you are spell-stopped. , Mine eyes , ev'n sociable to the show of thine , Fall fellowly drops .

English: Why , that's my dainty Ariel singing now .
Shakespearean: Why , that's my dainty Ariel .

English: I'll miss you , Ariel , but you'll be free. , Yes , you will , yes. , Go to the king's ship in your invisible state .
Shakespearean: I shall miss thee , But yet thou shalt have freedom. , So , so , so. , To the king's ship , invisible as thou art .

English: This place is full of trouble , torments , and amazements .
Shakespearean: All torment , trouble , wonder , and amazement Inhabits here .

English: There must be a strange explanation for this , if it's true .
Shakespearean: This must crave , An if this be at all , a most strange story .

English: I surrender your dukedom and beg you to forgive me all my crimes .
Shakespearean: Thy dukedom I resign and do entreat Thou pardon me my wrongs .

English: But how is it possible that Prospero's alive and well and living on this island ?
Shakespearean: But how should Prospero Be living and be here ?

English: I won't bet on whether or not any of this is real .
Shakespearean: Whether this be Or be not , I'll not swear .

English: Welcome , my friends .
Shakespearean: Welcome , my friends all .

English: It's the devil speaking through him .
Shakespearean: The devil speaks in him .

English: You suffered a loss like mine ?
Shakespearean: You the like loss ?

English: Yes , just as great and just as recent .
Shakespearean: As great to me as late .

English: And I have much less to comfort me than you do , since I've lost my daughter .
Shakespearean: And supportable To make the dear loss have I means much weaker Than you may call to comfort you , for I Have lost my daughter .

English: A daughter ?
Shakespearean: A daughter ?

English: Oh God , I wish the two of them were alive and living in Naples , as king and queen !
Shakespearean: O heavens , that they were living both in Naples , The king and queen there !

English: I'd give up my life and take my son's place in the mud on the ocean floor if I could see them alive in Naples. , When did you lose your daughter ?
Shakespearean: That they were , I wish Myself were mudded in that oozy bed Where my son lies. , When did you lose your daughter ?

English: In this recent storm .
Shakespearean: In this last tempest .

English: These lords seem so astonished that they've lost their use of reason and can hardly believe what they see with their own eyes. , But whatever the reason for your losing your senses , you can know for sure that I'm Prospero , that same duke who was kicked out of Milan and landed on this same island where you landed , and became the lord of it .
Shakespearean: I perceive these lords At this encounter do so much admire That they devour their reason and scarce think Their eyes do offices of truth , their words Are natural breath. , But howsoev'r you have Been justled from your senses , know for certain That I am Prospero and that very duke Which was thrust forth of Milan , who most strangely Upon this shore where you were wracked , was landed , To be the lord on 't .

English: No , my dearest love , I wouldn't cheat you for the whole world .
Shakespearean: No , my dearest love , I would not for the world .

English: If this dream vision is typical of what this island conjures up , then I'll lose my son twice .
Shakespearean: If this prove A vision of the Island , one dear son Shall I twice lose .

English: A wonderful miracle !
Shakespearean: A most high miracle !

English: Receive all the blessings of a happy father .
Shakespearean: Now all the blessings Of a glad father , compass thee about .

English: Get up and tell me how you came here .
Shakespearean: Arise , and say how thou camest here .

English: How amazing !
Shakespearean: Oh , wonder !

English: How many wonderful creatures there are here !
Shakespearean: How many goodly creatures are there here !

English: Mankind is so beautiful !
Shakespearean: How beauteous mankind is !

English: Oh , what a wonderful new world , that has such people in it !
Shakespearean: O brave new world , That has such people in 't !

English: It's new to you .
Shakespearean: Tis new to thee .

English: No , sir , she's human .
Shakespearean: Sir , she is mortal .

English: But by the grace of God , she's mine .
Shakespearean: But by immortal providence , she's mine .

English: I chose her for my wife when I thought I had no father to ask advice of .
Shakespearean: I chose her when I could not ask my father For his advice , nor thought I had one .

English: She's the daughter of this famous Duke of Milan I heard so much about but never saw before .
Shakespearean: She Is daughter to this famous Duke of Milan , Of whom so often I have heard renown But never saw before , of whom I have Received a second life .

English: He's given me a second life , and marrying her makes him a second father to me .
Shakespearean: And second father This lady makes him to me .

English: And I'm her father as well .
Shakespearean: I am hers .

English: But oh , how odd it is to have to ask for my child's forgiveness !
Shakespearean: But oh , how oddly will it sound that I Must ask my child forgiveness !

English: Stop right there , sir .
Shakespearean: There , sir , stop .

English: Let's not get gloomy in our reminiscing , since there's no reason for sadness anymore .
Shakespearean: Let us not burden our remembrances with A heaviness that's gone .

English: Oh , it breaks my heart to think how painful it must be for you to recall all this , things that I can't remember .
Shakespearean: Oh , my heart bleeds To think o ' th ' teen that I have turned you to , Which is from my remembrance !

English: But please tell me more .
Shakespearean: Please you , farther .

English: My brother , your uncle Antonio , just listen to this ( I still can't believe a brother could be so disloyal !
Shakespearean: My brother and thy uncle , called Antonio , I pray thee , mark me ( that a brother should Be so perfidious !

English: My brother whom , aside from you , I loved more than anyone else in the world , I trusted to run my state , which at that time was the strongest in the land , and Prospero the number one duke , famous for my dignity and my education .
Shakespearean: he whom next thyself Of all the world I loved and to him put The manage of my state , as at that time Through all the signories it was the first , And Prospero the prime duke , being so reputed In dignity , and for the liberal arts Without a parallel .

English: Since I was so drawn to studying things like logic , grammar , geometry , and astronomy , I let my control of the government slide a bit , being too wrapped up in my occult books .
Shakespearean: Those being all my study , The government I cast upon my brother And to my state grew stranger , being transported And rapt in secret studies .

English: Your disloyal uncle , are you paying attention ?
Shakespearean: Thy false uncle , Dost thou attend me ?

English: I'm hanging on every word .
Shakespearean: Sir , most heedfully .

English: Oh , yes I am , father .
Shakespearean: O , good sir , I do .

English: Dear gods , bless this couple , since you're the ones who have shown us the path that led us here .
Shakespearean: Look down , you gods , And on this couple drop a blessed crown , For it is you that have chalked forth the way Which brought us hither .

English: Amen to that , Gonzalo .
Shakespearean: I say amen , Gonzalo .

English: Was the Duke of Milan kicked out of Milan so his children could become kings of Naples ?
Shakespearean: Was Milan thrust from Milan , that his issue Should become kings of Naples ?

English: Oh , this is cause for an extraordinary joy that should be engraved in gold on pillars to last forever .
Shakespearean: O , rejoice Beyond a common joy , and set it down With gold on lasting pillars .

English: On one and the same trip Claribel found a husband in Tunis , and Ferdinand , her brother , found a wife where he was shipwrecked ; Prospero found his dukedom on a poor island ; and all of us found ourselves when we lost control of ourselves .
Shakespearean: In one voyage Did Claribel her husband find at Tunis ; And Ferdinand , her brother , found a wife Where he himself was lost ; Prospero , his dukedom In a poor isle ; and all of us , ourselves When no man was his own .

English: So be it .
Shakespearean: Be it so .

English: Amen .
Shakespearean: Amen .

English: Oh , look , sir , look , sir !
Shakespearean: Oh , look , sir , look , sir !

English: More of us are here .
Shakespearean: Here is more of us .

English: The best news of all is that we've located our king and our men .
Shakespearean: The best news is that we have safely found Our king and company .

English: The next bit of good news is that our ship , which we gave up for ruined only three hours ago , is as well-outfitted and seaworthy as it was when we first set sail .
Shakespearean: The next , our ship , Which , but three glasses since , we gave out split , Is tight and yare and bravely rigged as when We first put out to sea .

English: These are unnatural events .
Shakespearean: These are not natural events .

English: In an instant we were separated from them , as if in a dream , and brought here in a daze .
Shakespearean: On a trice , so please you , Even in a dream were we divided from them And were brought moping hither .

English: This is a stranger business than men have ever set foot in before , and it's not natural either .
Shakespearean: This is as strange a maze as e'er men trod , And there is in this business more than nature Was ever conduct of .

English: We need some oracle to tell us what's going on .
Shakespearean: Some oracle Must rectify our knowledge .

English: Sir , my king , don't waste your time mulling over how strange this business is .
Shakespearean: Sir , my liege , Do not infest your mind with beating on The strangeness of this business .

English: How is my lord ?
Shakespearean: How fares my gracious sir ?

English: If I can believe my eyes , this is a fine sight to see .
Shakespearean: Coraggio , bully-monster , If these be true spies which I wear in my head , here's a goodly sight .

English: Oh Setebos , these are handsome spirits !
Shakespearean: O Setebos , these be brave spirits indeed !

English: How wonderful my master is !
Shakespearean: How fine my master is !

English: I'm afraid he'll punish me .
Shakespearean: I am afraid He will chastise me .

English: Ha , ha !
Shakespearean: Ha , ha !

English: What are these things we're looking at , my lord Antonio ?
Shakespearean: What things are these , my lord Antonio ?

English: Can you buy them with money ?
Shakespearean: Will money buy 'em ?

English: He'll kill me with tortures .
Shakespearean: I shall be pinched to death .

English: Isn't this Stephano , my drunken butler ?
Shakespearean: Is not this Stephano , my drunken butler ?

English: He's definitely drunk now .
Shakespearean: He is drunk now .

English: Where did he get wine ?
Shakespearean: Where had he wine ?

English: And Trinculo's drunk .
Shakespearean: And Trinculo is reeling ripe .

English: How are you doing , Stephano ?
Shakespearean: Why , how now , Stephano ?

English: Oh , don't touch me .
Shakespearean: O , touch me not .

English: I'm not Stephano , I'm a walking cramp .
Shakespearean: I am not Stephano , but a cramp .

English: You wanted to be king of the island , sir ?
Shakespearean: You'd be king o ' th ' isle , sirrah ?

English: I would've been a sore king then .
Shakespearean: I should have been a sore one then .

English: He's as ugly in his manners as he is in appearance. , I will indeed .
Shakespearean: He is as disproportioned in his manners As in his shape. , Take with you your companions .

English: And after this I'll be good and hope you forgive me .
Shakespearean: And I'll be wise hereafter And seek for grace .

English: What an idiot I was to think this drunkard was a god and to worship such a stupid fool !
Shakespearean: What a thrice-double ass Was I , to take this drunkard for a god And worship this dull fool !

English: Go away , now .
Shakespearean: Go to , away .

English: Or stole it , rather .
Shakespearean: Or stole it , rather .

English: And in the morning I'll take you to your ship and we'll sail to Naples , where I hope to see this loving couple married .
Shakespearean: And in the morn I'll bring you to your ship and so to Naples , Where I have hope to see the nuptial Of these our dear-beloved solemnized , And thence retire me to my Milan , where Every third thought shall be my grave .

English: I'm dying to hear your life story , which must be a strange tale .
Shakespearean: I long To hear the story of your life , which must Take the ear strangely .

English: Now my spells are all broken , And the only power I have is my own , Which is very weak .
Shakespearean: Now my charms are all o'erthrown , And what strength I have's mine own , Which is most faint .

English: Release me So I can return to my dukedom With your help .
Shakespearean: Let me not , Since I have my dukedom got And pardoned the deceiver , dwell In this bare island by your spell , But release me from my bands With the help of your good hands .

English: Just as you'd like to have your sins forgiven , Indulge me , forgive me , and set me free .
Shakespearean: As you from crimes would pardoned be , Let your indulgence set me free .

English: Please listen to me carefully .
Shakespearean: I pray thee , mark me .

English: As I neglected practical matters , being totally dedicated to solitude and to improving my mind with subjects more valuable than most people imagine , I was so shut away from the world that I unwittingly stirred up evil wishes in my disloyal brother .
Shakespearean: I , thus neglecting worldly ends , all dedicated To closeness and the bettering of my mind With that which , but by being so retired , O'erprized all popular rate , in my false brother Awaked an evil nature .

English: My deep trust in him made him deeply untrustworthy , arousing in him a treachery as big as my trust was , my trust which had no limit , an infinite confidence .
Shakespearean: And my trust , Like a good parent , did beget of him A falsehood in its contrary as great As my trust was , which had indeed no limit , A confidence sans bound .

English: With his ambition growing like this , do you hear what I'm saying ?
Shakespearean: Hence his ambition growing , Dost thou hear ?

English: Of course I hear it .
Shakespearean: Your tale , sir , would cure deafness .

English: My library was a large enough dukedom for me .
Shakespearean: Me , poor man , my library Was dukedom large enough .

English: Good heavens !
Shakespearean: Oh , the heavens !

English: Think about that , and about what followed afterward .
Shakespearean: Mark his condition and the event .

English: Then tell me if Antonio can be called a brother .
Shakespearean: Then tell me If this might be a brother .

English: It would be wrong for me to think poorly of my grandmother .
Shakespearean: I should sin To think but nobly of my grandmother .

English: The king of Naples , my arch-enemy , listens to my brother's request , which was that the king , in exchange for the respect and money paid to him , would get rid of me and make my brother Duke of Milan instead .
Shakespearean: The King of Naples , being an enemy To me inveterate , hearkens my brother's suit , Which was that he , in lieu o ' th ' premises Of homage and I know not how much tribute , Should presently extirpate me and mine Out of the dukedom , and confer fair Milan With all the honors on my brother .

English: How awful !
Shakespearean: Alack , for pity !

English: I can't remember how I cried then , but I'll cry all over again .
Shakespearean: I , not remembering how I cried out then , Will cry it o'er again .

English: This story breaks my heart .
Shakespearean: It is a hint That wrings mine eyes to 't .

English: Just listen a little more , and I'll bring you up to date about the present situation , which is the whole reason I'm telling you this story in the first place .
Shakespearean: Hear a little further And then I'll bring thee to the present business Which now 's upon 's , without the which this story Were most impertinent .

English: Why didn't they just kill us that night ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore did they not That hour destroy us ?

English: Good question , my girl .
Shakespearean: Well demanded , wench .

English: My story does raise that question .
Shakespearean: My tale provokes that question .

English: The answer , my dear , is that they didn't dare , because the people of Milan loved me too much .
Shakespearean: Dear , they durst not , So dear the love my people bore me , nor set A mark so bloody on the business , but With colors fairer painted their foul ends .

English: God , what a burden on you I must have been !
Shakespearean: Alack , what trouble Was I then to you !

English: No , my dear , you were a little angel who kept me going .
Shakespearean: Oh , a cherubim Thou wast that did preserve me .

English: You smiled with a strength you must have gotten from heaven , while I cried salty tears into the salty sea , and groaned at our situation .
Shakespearean: Thou didst smile Infused with a fortitude from heaven , When I have decked the sea with drops full salt , Under my burthen groaned ; which raised in me An undergoing stomach to bear up Against what should ensue .

English: How did we manage to get ashore ?
Shakespearean: How came we ashore ?

English: With God's help .
Shakespearean: By providence divine .

English: We had a little food and fresh water that a nobleman from Naples , Gonzalo , had given us out of the kindness of his heart .
Shakespearean: Some food we had and some fresh water that A noble Neapolitan , Gonzalo , Out of his charity , who being then appointed Master of this design , did give us , with Rich garments , linens , stuffs , and necessaries , Which since have steaded much .

English: Knowing how much I loved my books , he gave me some books from my library that I value more than my dukedom .
Shakespearean: So , of his gentleness , Knowing I loved my books , he furnished me From mine own library with volumes that I prize above my dukedom .

English: I wish I could see that man someday !
Shakespearean: Would I might But ever see that man !

English: Now I'll stand up .
Shakespearean: Now I arise .

English: May God thank you for it .
Shakespearean: Heavens thank you for 't !

English: But please , father , the question is still nagging at me , why did you conjure up this storm ?
Shakespearean: And now , I pray you , sir , For still 'tis beating in my mind , your reason For raising this sea storm ?

English: You should know this : much luck is on my side , and my enemies have happened to wreck their ship on this island .
Shakespearean: Know thus far forth : By accident most strange , bountiful Fortune ( Now my dear lady ) hath mine enemies Brought to this shore .

English: Now , no more questions .
Shakespearean: Here cease more questions .

English: It's a nice hazy feeling , so give in to it .
Shakespearean: Tis a good dullness , And give it way .

English: I know you have no choice .
Shakespearean: I know thou canst not choose .

English: Come on , servant , come .
Shakespearean: Come away , servant , come .

English: I'm ready now .
Shakespearean: I am ready now .

English: Come here , Ariel .
Shakespearean: Approach , my Ariel , come .

English: Humble greetings , great master !
Shakespearean: All hail , great master !

English: Worthy sir , greetings !
Shakespearean: Grave sir , hail !

English: Spirit , did you carry out the storm just as I ordered ?
Shakespearean: Hast thou , spirit , Performed to point the tempest that I bade thee ?

English: Sometimes I appeared in many places at once .
Shakespearean: Sometime I'd divide , And burn in many places .

English: I flashed about faster than lightning .
Shakespearean: Jove's lightning , the precursors O ' th ' dreadful thunderclaps , more momentary And sight-outrunning were not .

English: Good spirit !
Shakespearean: My brave spirit !

English: Boatswain !
Shakespearean: Boatswain !

English: I'm here , sir .
Shakespearean: Here , master .

English: Hurry , hurry !
Shakespearean: What cheer ?

English: Come on , men !
Shakespearean: Good , speak to th ' mariners .

English: That's the way to do it !
Shakespearean: Fall to 't yarely , or we run ourselves aground .

English: Where's the Master ?
Shakespearean: Where's the Master ?

English: Make these men work .
Shakespearean: Play the men .

English: Please stay below deck , sir .
Shakespearean: I pray now , keep below .

English: Where's the Master , Boatswain ?
Shakespearean: Where is the Master , Boatswain ?

English: Everyone there got a little crazy and pulled some desperate stunts .
Shakespearean: Not a soul But felt a fever of the mad and played Some tricks of desperation .

English: Everyone except the sailors dove into the sea , leaving behind the ship that I had set on fire .
Shakespearean: All but mariners Plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel , Then all afire with me .

English: The king's son , Ferdinand , with his hair standing straight up , it looked like reeds , not hair , was the first person to jump , shouting , "Hell is empty , and all the devils are here ! " Good job !
Shakespearean: The king's son , Ferdinand , With hair up-staring , then , like reeds , not hair , Was the first man that leaped , cried , "Hell is empty And all the devils are here." Why , that's my spirit !

English: But was this near the shore ?
Shakespearean: But was not this nigh shore ?

English: Very near , my master .
Shakespearean: Close by , my master .

English: But are they all safe , Ariel ?
Shakespearean: But are they , Ariel , safe ?

English: Nobody was hurt in the slightest .
Shakespearean: Not a hair perished .

English: Even their clothes are unstained , and look fresher than before the storm .
Shakespearean: On their sustaining garments not a blemish , But fresher than before .

English: I've separated them into groups around the island , just as you ordered .
Shakespearean: And , as thou badest me , In troops I have dispersed them 'bout the isle .

English: I sent the king's son off by himself to a faraway nook on the island , where he's sitting now sighing , with his arms crossed like this .
Shakespearean: The king's son have I landed by himself , Whom I left cooling of the air with sighs In an odd angle of the isle , and sitting , His arms in this sad knot .

English: Tell me what you did with the king's ship , the sailors , and the other ships .
Shakespearean: Of the king's ship , The mariners , say how thou hast disposed , And all the rest o ' th ' fleet .

English: The sailors are all below deck , sleeping both from their labor and from a magic spell I cast over them .
Shakespearean: The mariners all under hatches stowed , Who , with a charm joined to their suffered labor , I have left asleep .

English: As for the rest of the ships , I scattered them , and they've gathered again in the Mediterranean , sailing sadly home to Naples , believing that they witnessed the shipwreck and death of their great king .
Shakespearean: And for the rest o ' th ' fleet , Which I dispersed , they all have met again And are upon the Mediterranean float , Bound sadly home for Naples , Supposing that they saw the king's ship wracked And his great person perish .

English: Ariel , you've done your work exactly as I ordered .
Shakespearean: Ariel , thy charge Exactly is performed .

English: But there's more work to be done .
Shakespearean: But there's more work .

English: What time is it ?
Shakespearean: What is the time o ' th ' day ?

English: Past noon .
Shakespearean: Past the mid season .

English: At least two hours past .
Shakespearean: At least two glasses .

English: We can't waste time between now and six o'clock .
Shakespearean: The time 'twixt six and now Must by us both be spent most preciously .

English: Is there more work to do ?
Shakespearean: Is there more toil ?

English: Since you're giving me new assignments , let me remind you what you promised me but haven't come through with yet .
Shakespearean: Since thou dost give me pains , Let me remember thee what thou hast promised , Which is not yet performed me .

English: What ?
Shakespearean: How now ?

English: You're in a bad mood ?
Shakespearean: Moody ?

English: What could you possibly ask for ?
Shakespearean: What is 't thou canst demand ?

English: My freedom .
Shakespearean: My liberty .

English: Before your sentence has been completed ?
Shakespearean: Before the time be out ?

English: Don't say anything else .
Shakespearean: No more !

English: I beg you , remember the good work I've done for you , and how I've never lied to you , never made mistakes , and never grumbled in my work .
Shakespearean: I prithee , Remember I have done thee worthy service , Told thee no lies , made thee no mistakings , served Without or grudge or grumblings .

English: You promised to take a full year off my sentence .
Shakespearean: Thou didst promise To bate me a full year .

English: Have you forgotten the torture I freed you from ?
Shakespearean: Dost thou forget From what a torment I did free thee ?

English: No .
Shakespearean: No .

English: You have forgotten , and you think it's a burden when I ask you to walk through the ocean , or run on the north wind , or do business for me underground when the earth's frozen solid .
Shakespearean: Thou dost , and think'st it much to tread the ooze Of the salt deep , To run upon the sharp wind of the north , To do me business in the veins o ' th ' earth When it is baked with frost .

English: No , I don't , sir .
Shakespearean: I do not , sir .

English: You lie , you nasty , ungrateful thing !
Shakespearean: Thou liest , malignant thing !

English: Have you forgotten the horrid witch Sycorax , stooped over with old age and ill will ?
Shakespearean: Hast thou forgot The foul witch Sycorax , who with age and envy Was grown into a hoop ?

English: Have you forgotten her ?
Shakespearean: Hast thou forgot her ?

English: No , sir .
Shakespearean: No , sir .

English: You have .
Shakespearean: Thou hast .

English: Where was she born ?
Shakespearean: Where was she born ?

English: Speak .
Shakespearean: Speak .

English: Tell me .
Shakespearean: Tell me .

English: In Algiers , sir .
Shakespearean: Sir , in Argier .

English: Oh , was she now ?
Shakespearean: Oh , was she so ?

English: I'll have to tell the story again every month , since you seem to forget it .
Shakespearean: I must Once in a month recount what thou hast been , Which thou forget'st .

English: This damned witch Sycorax was kicked out of Algiers for various witching crimes too terrible for humans to hear about .
Shakespearean: This damned witch Sycorax , For mischiefs manifold and sorceries terrible To enter human hearing , from Argier , Thou know'st , was banished .

English: But for one reason they refused to execute her .
Shakespearean: For one thing she did They would not take her life .

English: Isn't that true ?
Shakespearean: Is not this true ?

English: Yes , sir .
Shakespearean: Ay , sir .

English: This sunken-eyed hag was brought here pregnant and left by the sailors .
Shakespearean: This blue-eyed hag was hither brought with child And here was left by th ' sailors .

English: You , my slave , were her servant at the time , as you admit yourself .
Shakespearean: Thou , my slave , As thou report'st thyself , wast then her servant .

English: In a fit of rage she locked you up in a hollow pine tree , with the help of her powerful assistants , and left you there for twelve years .
Shakespearean: And , for thou wast a spirit too delicate To act her earthy and abhorred commands , Refusing her grand hests , she did confine thee , By help of her more potent ministers And in her most unmitigable rage , Into a cloven pine , within which rift Imprisoned thou didst painfully remain A dozen years ; within which space she died And left thee there , where thou didst vent thy groans As fast as mill wheels strike .

English: That's right , you stupid thing .
Shakespearean: Dull thing , I say so .

English: Caliban , who now serves me .
Shakespearean: He , that Caliban Whom now I keep in service .

English: It was my magic that saved you when I arrived on the island and heard you , making the pine tree open and let you out .
Shakespearean: It was mine art , When I arrived and heard thee , that made gape The pine and let thee out .

English: Thank you , master .
Shakespearean: I thank thee , master .

English: If you complain any more , I'll split an oak tree and lock you up in it till you've howled for twelve years .
Shakespearean: If thou more murmur'st , I will rend an oak And peg thee in his knotty entrails till Thou hast howled away twelve winters .

English: Please forgive me , master .
Shakespearean: Pardon , master .

English: I'll be obedient and do all my tasks without complaining .
Shakespearean: I will be correspondent to command And do my spiriting gently .

English: Do that , and I'll set you free in two days .
Shakespearean: Do so , and after two days I will discharge thee .

English: That's noble of you , master .
Shakespearean: That's my noble master !

English: What shall I do for you ?
Shakespearean: What shall I do ?

English: Just tell me .
Shakespearean: Say , what ?

English: What shall I do ?
Shakespearean: What shall I do ?

English: Go disguise yourself as a sea nymph .
Shakespearean: Go make thyself like a nymph o ' th ' sea .

English: Be invisible to everyone except yourself and me .
Shakespearean: Be subject To no sight but thine and mine , invisible To every eyeball else .

English: Take this garment , put it on , and then come back here .
Shakespearean: Go take this shape And hither come in 't .

English: Hurry , go !
Shakespearean: Go hence with diligence .

English: Shake off your sleepiness .
Shakespearean: Shake it off .

English: Come on .
Shakespearean: Come on .

English: We'll go visit Caliban , my slave who always talks to us so nastily .
Shakespearean: We'll visit Caliban , my slave who never Yields us kind answer .

English: But even so , we can't do without him .
Shakespearean: But as 'tis , We can not miss him .

English: He builds our fires , gets our firewood , and does all kinds of useful things for us. , Hey !
Shakespearean: He does make our fire , Fetch in our wood , and serves in offices That profit us. , What , ho !

English: Caliban !
Shakespearean: Slave !

English: Pile of dirt !
Shakespearean: Caliban !

English: Say something .
Shakespearean: Speak .

English: Come out , I order you .
Shakespearean: Come forth , I say !

English: There's other work for you to do .
Shakespearean: There's other business for thee .

English: Come on , you turtle !
Shakespearean: Come , thou tortoise !

English: What a fine sight !
Shakespearean: Fine apparition !

English: My dear clever Ariel , listen carefully .
Shakespearean: My quaint Ariel , Hark in thine ear .

English: My lord , I'll do it right away .
Shakespearean: My lord it shall be done .

English: I hope you both get drenched with a dew as evil as what my mother used to collect with a crow's feather from the poison swamps .
Shakespearean: As wicked dew as e'er my mother brushed With raven's feather from unwholesome fen Drop on you both !

English: May a hot southwest wind blow on you and cover you with blisters all over .
Shakespearean: A southwest blow on ye And blister you all o'er !

English: I'll give you cramps for saying that , horrible pains in your sides that will keep you from breathing .
Shakespearean: For this , be sure , tonight thou shalt have cramps , Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up .

English: I'll send goblins out at night to work their nasty deeds on you .
Shakespearean: Urchins Shall , forth at vast of night that they may work , All exercise on thee .

English: You'll be pricked all over , and it'll sting like bees .
Shakespearean: Thou shalt be pinched As thick as honeycomb , each pinch more stinging Than bees that made 'em .

English: I have to eat my dinner now .
Shakespearean: I must eat my dinner .

English: This island belongs to me because Sycorax , my mother , left it to me .
Shakespearean: This island's mine , by Sycorax my mother , Which thou takest from me .

English: I curse myself for doing that !
Shakespearean: Cursed be I that did so !

English: You liar , you respond better to the whip than to kindness !
Shakespearean: Thou most lying slave , Whom stripes may move , not kindness !

English: I took good care of you , piece of filth that you are , and let you stay in my own hut until you tried to rape my daughter .
Shakespearean: I have used thee , Filth as thou art , with human care , and lodged thee In mine own cell till thou didst seek to violate The honor of my child .

English: Oh ho , oh ho !
Shakespearean: Oh ho , oh ho !

English: I wish I had !
Shakespearean: Would 't had been done !

English: You stopped me .
Shakespearean: Thou didst prevent me .

English: You horrid slave , you can't be trained to be good , and you're capable of anything evil !
Shakespearean: Abhorred slave , Which any print of goodness wilt not take , Being capable of all ill !

English: I pitied you , worked hard to teach you to speak , and taught you some new thing practically every hour .
Shakespearean: I pitied thee , Took pains to make thee speak , taught thee each hour One thing or other .

English: But you had bad blood in you , no matter how much you learned , and good people couldn't stand to be near you .
Shakespearean: But thy vile race , Though thou didst learn , had that in 't which good natures Could not abide to be with .

English: So you got what you deserved , and were locked up in this cave , which is more fitting for the likes of you than a prison would be .
Shakespearean: Therefore wast thou Deservedly confined into this rock , Who hadst deserved more than a prison .

English: You taught me language , and all I can do with it is curse .
Shakespearean: You taught me language , and my profit on 't Is I know how to curse .

English: Damn you for teaching me your language !
Shakespearean: The red plague rid you For learning me your language !

English: No , please .
Shakespearean: No , pray thee .

English: Go then , slave .
Shakespearean: So , slave , hence !

English: The watchdogs bark .
Shakespearean: The watchdogs bark .

English: Listen , listen !
Shakespearean: Hark , hark !

English: Where's that music coming from ?
