Shakespearean: I hear The strain of strutting chanticleer Cry "Cock-a-diddle-dow." Where should this music be ?

English: From the earth , or the air ?
Shakespearean: I ' th ' air or th ' earth ?

English: It's stopped now , it must be played for some local god of the island .
Shakespearean: It sounds no more , and sure , it waits upon Some god o ' th ' island .

English: As I sat on the shore crying over my father's shipwreck , I heard the music creep over the wild waves , calming their fury and soothing my own grief with its sweet melodies .
Shakespearean: Sitting on a bank , Weeping again the king my father's wrack , This music crept by me upon the waters , Allaying both their fury and my passion With its sweet air .

English: I followed it here , or I should say it dragged me here .
Shakespearean: Thence I have followed it , Or it hath drawn me rather .

English: But now it's stopped .
Shakespearean: But 'tis gone .

English: No , there it is again .
Shakespearean: No , it begins again .

English: Listen , I hear them .
Shakespearean: Hark , now I hear them .

English: This song's about my dead father .
Shakespearean: The ditty does remember my drowned father .

English: I hear it now overhead .
Shakespearean: I hear it now above me .

English: What is it ?
Shakespearean: What is 't ?

English: A spirit ?
Shakespearean: A spirit ?

English: Lord , it's glancing every which way !
Shakespearean: Lord , how it looks about !

English: How handsome it is .
Shakespearean: Believe me , sir , It carries a brave form .

English: It must be a spirit .
Shakespearean: But 'tis a spirit .

English: No , girl !
Shakespearean: No , wench !

English: It eats and sleeps and has the same five senses we do .
Shakespearean: It eats and sleeps and hath such senses As we have , such .

English: He's lost his comrades and is wandering around looking for them .
Shakespearean: He hath lost his fellows And strays about to find 'em .

English: He's busy , can't you hear him giving orders ?
Shakespearean: Do you not hear him ?

English: You're getting in the way of our work .
Shakespearean: You mar our labor .

English: Stay in your cabins .
Shakespearean: Keep your cabins .

English: You're helping the storm , not us .
Shakespearean: You do assist the storm .

English: Don't get wound up , my good man .
Shakespearean: Nay , good , be patient .

English: Now get out of here !
Shakespearean: Hence !

English: Go to your cabins and be quiet !
Shakespearean: To cabin , silence !

English: Don't bother us up here .
Shakespearean: Trouble us not .

English: Just remember who you've got on board with you , good man .
Shakespearean: Good , yet remember whom thou hast aboard .

English: Nobody I care about more than myself .
Shakespearean: None that I more love than myself .

English: You're a king's advisor .
Shakespearean: You are a councilor .

English: Go ahead , use your authority .
Shakespearean: Use your authority .

English: If you can't do it , be grateful you've lived this long and go wait to die in your cabin , if it comes to that. , Harder , men ! , Now get out of our way , I'm telling you .
Shakespearean: If you can not , give thanks you have lived so long and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour , if it so hap. , Cheerly , good hearts ! , Out of our way , I say .

English: I feel a lot better after talking to this guy .
Shakespearean: I have great comfort from this fellow .

English: I could imagine he's divine , since I never saw anything so noble-looking on earth before .
Shakespearean: I might call him A thing divine , for nothing natural I ever saw so noble .

English: I'm not marvelous , sir , but I'm certainly a maiden .
Shakespearean: No wonder , sir , But certainly a maid .

English: She speaks my language !
Shakespearean: My language !

English: My God , I'm the highest-ranking person who speaks this language , if only we were back where it's spoken .
Shakespearean: Heavens , I am the best of them that speak this speech , Were I but where 'tis spoken .

English: What's that ?
Shakespearean: How ?

English: The highest-ranking ?
Shakespearean: The best ?

English: What would the King of Naples do if he heard you say that ?
Shakespearean: What wert thou if the King of Naples heard thee ?

English: He would just see me for what I am , a person amazed to hear you talking about Naples .
Shakespearean: A single thing , as I am now , that wonders To hear thee speak of Naples .

English: He does hear me , and that makes me cry .
Shakespearean: He does hear me , And that he does I weep .

English: I myself am the King of Naples , since I saw with my own eyes , these eyes that haven't been dry since , my father killed in a shipwreck .
Shakespearean: Myself am Naples , Who with mine eyes , never since at ebb , beheld The king my father wracked .

English: Ah , how pitiful !
Shakespearean: Alack , for mercy !

English: Yes , indeed , and all the King's men , the Duke of Milan and his fine son too .
Shakespearean: Yes , faith , and all his lords , the Duke of Milan And his brave son being twain .

English: Hang on , sir !
Shakespearean: Soft , sir !

English: Just a moment .
Shakespearean: One word more .

English: If the devil had such a beautiful house as his body , then good things would fight to live in it .
Shakespearean: If the ill spirit have so fair a house , Good things will strive to dwell with 't .

English: What's that ?
Shakespearean: What , I say ?

English: Get out of that position , because I can disarm you with my magic wand and make your sword drop .
Shakespearean: Come from thy ward , For I can here disarm thee with this stick And make thy weapon drop .

English: Please , father , I beg you .
Shakespearean: Beseech you , father .

English: Let go of me !
Shakespearean: Hence !

English: Don't tug on my clothes .
Shakespearean: Hang not on my garments .

English: Father , take pity on him .
Shakespearean: Sir , have pity , I'll be his surety .

English: Quiet !
Shakespearean: Silence !

English: If you say one more word , I'll punish you , maybe even hate you .
Shakespearean: One word more Shall make me chide thee , if not hate thee .

English: You're defending an impostor ?
Shakespearean: What , An advocate for an imposter ?

English: You think he's special , since you've only ever seen him and Caliban .
Shakespearean: Hush , Thou think'st there is no more such shapes as he , Having seen but him and Caliban .

English: Foolish girl , in the eyes of most people this man's a Caliban , and compared to him , they're angels .
Shakespearean: Foolish wench , To th ' most of men this is a Caliban And they to him are angels .

English: Then my love is humble .
Shakespearean: My affections Are then most humble .

English: I don't feel any urge to see a more handsome man than this one .
Shakespearean: I have no ambition To see a goodlier man .

English: That's true , they are .
Shakespearean: So they are .

English: My strength is all gone , as if in a dream .
Shakespearean: My spirits , as in a dream , are all bound up .

English: The death of my father , my physical weakness , the loss of all my friends , the threats of this man who's taken me prisoner , all that would be easy for me to take , if only I could look through my prison windows once a day and see this girl .
Shakespearean: My father's loss , the weakness which I feel , The wrack of all my friends , nor this man's threats , To whom I am subdued , are but light to me , Might I but through my prison once a day Behold this maid .

English: A prison like that would give me enough liberty .
Shakespearean: Space enough Have I in such a prison .

English: Please say no more .
Shakespearean: Prithee , peace .

English: What a pain .
Shakespearean: A dollar .

English: Pain , yes indeed .
Shakespearean: Dolor comes to him , indeed .

English: You thought you were being funny , but you said the truth .
Shakespearean: You have spoken truer than you purposed .

English: You're taking it more seriously than I meant it .
Shakespearean: You have taken it wiselier than I meant you should .

English: Well , I'm nearly finished .
Shakespearean: Well , I have done .

English: Which one will start yammering first , Gonzalo or Adrian ?
Shakespearean: But yet , Which , of he or Adrian , for a good wager , first begins to crow ?

English: The old guy .
Shakespearean: The old cock .

English: I pick the younger one .
Shakespearean: The cockerel .

English: You're on .
Shakespearean: Done .

English: What's the prize ?
Shakespearean: The wager ?

English: A good laugh .
Shakespearean: A laughter .

English: It's a deal !
Shakespearean: A match !

English: Though this island may appear desolate ,
Shakespearean: Though this island seem to be desert ,

English: The island must be mild , and have a temperate climate .
Shakespearean: It must needs be of subtle , tender , and delicate temperance .

English: I knew Temperance , she was a fine girl .
Shakespearean: Temperance was a delicate wench .

English: Yes , and she was mild too .
Shakespearean: Ay , and a subtle , as he most learnedly delivered .

English: There's always a breath of fresh air here .
Shakespearean: The air breathes upon us here most sweetly .

English: Stinking like a swamp .
Shakespearean: Or as 'twere perfumed by a fen .

English: This island contains everything beneficial to life .
Shakespearean: Here is everything advantageous to life .

English: True .
Shakespearean: True .

English: Everything except something to live on .
Shakespearean: Save means to live .

English: There's little or nothing of that .
Shakespearean: Of that there's none , or little .

English: Look how lush and healthy the grass is !
Shakespearean: How lush and lusty the grass looks !

English: How green !
Shakespearean: How green !

English: The ground is brown .
Shakespearean: The ground indeed is tawny .

English: With a touch of green in it .
Shakespearean: With an eye of green in 't .

English: He doesn't miss a thing .
Shakespearean: He misses not much .

English: No , he just gets reality completely wrong .
Shakespearean: No , he doth but mistake the truth totally .

English: But the really unbelievable thing is , and this is incredible , As most unbelievable things are .
Shakespearean: But the rarity of it is , which is indeed almost beyond credit , As many vouched rarities are .

English: That our clothes were drenched with sea water , but they came out looking brand-new .
Shakespearean: That our garments , being , as they were , drenched in the sea , hold notwithstanding their freshness and glosses , being rather new-dyed than stained with salt water .

English: Or stuff what he says into their pockets .
Shakespearean: Ay , or very falsely pocket up his report .

English: Seriously , I think our clothes are as fresh now as they were the day we put them on in Africa , when we attended the marriage of the king's daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis .
Shakespearean: Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Afric , at the marriage of the king's fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis .

English: It was a lovely wedding , and we're doing really well on our trip home .
Shakespearean: Twas a sweet marriage , and we prosper well in our return .

English: Tunis has never had such a beautiful queen .
Shakespearean: Tunis was never graced before with such a paragon to their queen .

English: Next thing you know , he'll be saying "widower Aeneas." "Widow Dido , " did you say ?
Shakespearean: Widow Dido" said you ?

English: I'm not sure about that .
Shakespearean: You make me study of that .

English: Dido was from Carthage , not Tunis .
Shakespearean: She was of Carthage , not of Tunis .

English: Carthage ?
Shakespearean: Carthage ?

English: I'm telling you , it was Carthage .
Shakespearean: I assure you , Carthage .

English: Gonzalo is a miracle-worker .
Shakespearean: His word is more than the miraculous harp .

English: What miracle will he work next ?
Shakespearean: What impossible matter will he make easy next ?

English: I think he'll carry this island home in his pocket and give it to his son like an apple .
Shakespearean: I think he will carry this island home in his pocket and give it his son for an apple .

English: And then throw the seeds in the sea , to make more islands grow .
Shakespearean: And sowing the kernels of it in the sea , bring forth more islands .

English: Yes indeed .
Shakespearean: Ay .

English: Absolutely , yes indeed .
Shakespearean: Why , in good time .

English: Bring down that top sail !
Shakespearean: Down with the topmast !

English: Fast !
Shakespearean: Yare , lower , lower !

English: Let the ship sail close to the wind .
Shakespearean: Bring her to try wi ' th ' main course .

English: Damn those men shouting down there !
Shakespearean: A plague upon this howling !

English: They're louder than the storm or us sailors .
Shakespearean: They are louder than the weather or our office .

English: Oh , not you again .
Shakespearean: Yet again ?

English: What do you want ?
Shakespearean: What do you here ?

English: Should we all give up and drown ?
Shakespearean: Shall we give o'er and drown ?

English: Do you want to sink ?
Shakespearean: Have you a mind to sink ?

English: Yes , I guarantee he won't drown , even if this ship were as fragile as an eggshell and as leaky as a menstruating woman .
Shakespearean: I'll warrant him for drowning though the ship were no stronger than a nutshell and as leaky as an unstanched wench .

English: Turn the ship to the wind !
Shakespearean: Lay her a-hold , a-hold !

English: It's no use !
Shakespearean: All lost !

English: We're done for !
Shakespearean: To prayers , to prayers , all lost !

English: The most beautiful queen they ever had .
Shakespearean: And the rarest that e'er came there .

English: I beg your pardon , except for the widow Dido .
Shakespearean: Bate , I beseech you , widow Dido .

English: Oh , except for the widow Dido ?
Shakespearean: Oh , widow Dido ?

English: That's right , except for the widow Dido .
Shakespearean: Ay , widow Dido .

English: Isn't my vest just as clean and fresh as the day I put it on ?
Shakespearean: Is not , sir , my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it ?

English: In a way , I mean .
Shakespearean: I mean , in a sort .

English: In a way" is the right way to go .
Shakespearean: That "sort" was well fished for .

English: I mean when I wore it at your daughter's wedding .
Shakespearean: When I wore it at your daughter's marriage ?

English: You keep cramming words into my ears that I don't want to hear .
Shakespearean: You cram these words into mine ears against The stomach of my sense .

English: Sir , he may still be alive .
Shakespearean: Sir , he may live .

English: I have no doubt he got ashore alive .
Shakespearean: I not doubt He came alive to land .

English: No , no , he's dead .
Shakespearean: No , no , he's gone .

English: Please be quiet .
Shakespearean: Prithee , peace .

English: We all begged you not to go ahead with those marriage plans , and your lovely daughter struggled between disgust at marrying an African and the desire to obey you .
Shakespearean: You were kneeled to and importuned otherwise By all of us , and the fair soul herself Weighed between loathness and obedience , at Which end o ' th ' beam should bow .

English: Now I'm afraid we've lost your son forever .
Shakespearean: We have lost your son , I fear , forever .

English: Our shipwreck has made more women widows in Milan and Naples than there are survivors to comfort them .
Shakespearean: Milan and Naples have More widows in them of this business ' making Than we bring men to comfort them .

English: And it's all your fault .
Shakespearean: The fault's your own .

English: And the greatest sorrow is mine too .
Shakespearean: So is the dearest o ' th ' loss .

English: My lord Sebastian , even though what you say is true , your way of saying it is tactless and comes at the wrong time .
Shakespearean: My lord Sebastian , The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness And time to speak it in .

English: You're rubbing salt in his wounds when you should be applying bandages .
Shakespearean: You rub the sore When you should bring the plaster .

English: All right , I'll stop .
Shakespearean: Very well .

English: Like a good doctor .
Shakespearean: And most chirurgeonly .

English: Bad times ?
Shakespearean: Foul weather ?

English: Yes , very bad .
Shakespearean: Very foul .

English: If I could colonize this island , my lord , He'd cultivate weeds on it .
Shakespearean: Had I plantation of this isle , my lord , He'd sow 't with nettle seed .

English: Or thorn-bushes .
Shakespearean: Or docks , or mallows .

English: And if I were king of it , you know what I'd do ?
Shakespearean: And were the king on 't , what would I do ?

English: He wouldn't get drunk much , since there's no wine here .
Shakespearean: Scape being drunk for want of wine .

English: I wouldn't allow any commerce .
Shakespearean: For no kind of traffic Would I admit .

English: There'd be no work .
Shakespearean: No occupation .

English: There'd be no kingship , He wants to be king in a place with no kingship .
Shakespearean: No sovereignty , Yet he would be king on 't .

English: Everything would be produced without labor , and would be shared by all .
Shakespearean: All things in common nature should produce Without sweat or endeavor .

English: Nature would produce its harvests in abundance , to feed my innocent people .
Shakespearean: But nature should bring forth Of its own kind all foison , all abundance , To feed my innocent people .

English: There'd be no marriage ?
Shakespearean: No marrying 'mong his subjects ?

English: No .
Shakespearean: None , man .

English: Oh , please be quiet .
Shakespearean: Prithee , no more .

English: You're absolutely right , your highness .
Shakespearean: Thou dost talk nothing to me .

English: It's you we were laughing at .
Shakespearean: Twas you we laughed at .

English: Ouch , what a comeback !
Shakespearean: What a blow was there given !

English: Too bad it fell flat .
Shakespearean: An it had not fallen flat-long .

English: You're brave gentlemen .
Shakespearean: You are gentlemen of brave mettle .

English: You'd give the moon a shove if it got stuck five weeks in its orbit .
Shakespearean: You would lift the moon out of her sphere if she would continue in it five weeks without changing .

English: That's right , and then after we fixed the moon , we'd go bird-hunting .
Shakespearean: We would so , and then go a-batfowling .

English: I'm not .
Shakespearean: No , I warrant you .

English: Go to sleep , and listen to us laughing .
Shakespearean: Go sleep , and hear us .

English: What , everybody falls asleep so fast ?
Shakespearean: What , all so soon asleep ?

English: I wish I could sleep too , it would stop me from thinking .
Shakespearean: I wish mine eyes Would with themselves shut up my thoughts .

English: Come to think of it , I am feeling sleepy .
Shakespearean: Please you , sir , Do not omit the heavy offer of it .

English: In that case you should sleep .
Shakespearean: It seldom visits sorrow .

English: The two of us will guard you while you sleep , my lord , and keep you safe .
Shakespearean: We two , my lord , Will guard your person while you take your rest And watch your safety .

English: Thank you .
Shakespearean: Thank you .

English: I'm terribly sleepy .
Shakespearean: Wondrous heavy .

English: How strange that they all got so sleepy !
Shakespearean: What a strange drowsiness possesses them !

English: There must be something in the air here .
Shakespearean: It is the quality o ' th ' climate .

English: So why aren't our eyelids heavy ?
Shakespearean: Why Doth it not then our eyelids sink ?

English: I'm not sleepy at all .
Shakespearean: I find not Myself disposed to sleep .

English: Me neither .
Shakespearean: Nor I .

English: I'm wide awake .
Shakespearean: My spirits are nimble .

English: They all fell asleep together , as if they'd planned it .
Shakespearean: They fell together all , as by consent .

English: Opportunity's knocking for you , and in my imagination I see a crown dropping onto your head .
Shakespearean: Th ' occasion speaks thee , and My strong imagination sees a crown Dropping upon thy head .

English: Are you dreaming or awake ?
Shakespearean: What , art thou waking ?

English: Don't you hear me speaking ?
Shakespearean: Do you not hear me speak ?

English: I do , and it sounds like you're talking in your sleep .
Shakespearean: I do , and surely It is a sleepy language , and thou speak'st Out of thy sleep .

English: What did you say ?
Shakespearean: What is it thou didst say ?

English: You're snoring , but it sounds like you're talking .
Shakespearean: Thou dost snore distinctly .

English: There's meaning in your snoring .
Shakespearean: There's meaning in thy snores .

English: I'll show you how .
Shakespearean: I'll teach you how to flow .

English: You need to .
Shakespearean: Do so .

English: Oh , if you only knew how close to success you are , even while you make fun of what I'm telling you !
Shakespearean: Oh , If you but knew how you the purpose cherish Whiles thus you mock it !

English: The more you joke about it , the more clearly I feel how serious it is !
Shakespearean: How , in stripping it , You more invest it !

English: Lazy people end up at the bottom , and you deserve to be at the top .
Shakespearean: Ebbing men indeed Most often do so near the bottom run By their own fear or sloth .

English: Please , tell me more .
Shakespearean: Prithee , say on .

English: Yes , I'm sure he's dead .
Shakespearean: I have no hope That he's undrowned .

English: I've got no hope that he survived .
Shakespearean: Oh , out of that "no hope" What great hope have you !

English: But in that "no hope" there are great hopes for you !
Shakespearean: No hope that way is Another way so high a hope that even Ambition can not pierce a wink beyond , But doubt discovery there .

English: Do you agree that Ferdinand must have drowned ?
Shakespearean: Will you grant with me That Ferdinand is drowned ?

English: He's dead .
Shakespearean: He's gone .

English: So , in that case , tell me who's next in line to inherit the kingdom of Naples ?
Shakespearean: Then , tell me , Who's the next heir of Naples ?

English: Claribel , his daughter .
Shakespearean: Claribel .

English: It's true that my brother's daughter is Queen of Tunis , and heir of Naples .
Shakespearean: Tis true , my brother's daughter's Queen of Tunis , So is she heir of Naples , 'twixt which regions There is some space .

English: I could do it myself .
Shakespearean: I myself could make A chough of as deep chat .

English: Do you even get what I'm saying ?
Shakespearean: Oh , that you bore The mind that I do , what a sleep were this For your advancement !

English: I think I do .
Shakespearean: Methinks I do .

English: And does this prospect of good fortune make you happy ?
Shakespearean: And how does your content Tender your own good fortune ?

English: I remember you took the throne from your brother Prospero .
Shakespearean: I remember You did supplant your brother Prospero .

English: My brother's servants used to be my equals .
Shakespearean: My brother's servants Were then my fellows .

English: Now they work for me .
Shakespearean: Now they are my men .

English: But what about your guilty conscience ?
Shakespearean: But , for your conscience ?

English: Yes .
Shakespearean: Ay , sir .

English: I don't feel anything .
Shakespearean: But I feel not This deity in my bosom .

English: As
Shakespearean: Should not upbraid our course .

English: for the other men , we can make them believe anything we choose .
Shakespearean: For all the rest , They'll take suggestion as a cat laps milk .

English: They'll set their watches to whatever time we say .
Shakespearean: They'll tell the clock to any business that We say befits the hour .

English: You'll be my role model .
Shakespearean: Thy case , dear friend , Shall be my precedent .

English: Just as you got Milan , I'll get Naples .
Shakespearean: As thou got'st Milan , I'll come by Naples .

English: Take out your sword .
Shakespearean: Draw thy sword .

English: With one cut you can be through paying money to Naples .
Shakespearean: One stroke Shall free thee from the tribute which thou payest .

English: And as king I'll love you forever .
Shakespearean: And I the king shall love thee .

English: You take out your sword too .
Shakespearean: Draw together .

English: When I raise my hand , you do the same , and bring it down on Gonzalo's head .
Shakespearean: And when I rear my hand , do you the like , To fall it on Gonzalo .

English: Oh , but there's one more thing to tell you .
Shakespearean: O , but one word .

English: What , we're going to die ?
Shakespearean: What , must our mouths be cold ?

English: The king and the prince are praying .
Shakespearean: The king and prince at prayers .

English: I'm out of patience .
Shakespearean: I'm out of patience .

English: This bigmouth jerk here , ( He'll still die by hanging , not drowning , even if every drop of water in the sea tries to swallow him .
Shakespearean: He'll be hanged yet , though every drop of water swear against it and gape at widest to glut him .

English: Let's all sink with the king .
Shakespearean: Let's all sink wi ' th ' king .

English: Let's say goodbye to him .
Shakespearean: Let's take leave of him .

English: Let's act quickly .
Shakespearean: Then let us both be sudden .

English: Why are your swords out ?
Shakespearean: Why are you drawn ?

English: Why do you look like that ?
Shakespearean: Wherefore this ghastly looking ?

English: What's this all about ?
Shakespearean: What's the matter ?

English: While we were here guarding you as you slept , we heard a loud roar that sounded like bulls , or lions .
Shakespearean: Whiles we stood here securing your repose , Even now , we heard a hollow burst of bellowing Like bulls , or rather lions .

English: Didn't you hear it ?
Shakespearean: Did 't not wake you ?

English: We heard it very clearly .
Shakespearean: It struck mine ear most terribly .

English: I didn't hear anything .
Shakespearean: I heard nothing .

English: Oh , it was a monstrous roar , to make the earth tremble !
Shakespearean: Oh , 'twas a din to fright a monster's ear , To make an earthquake !

English: I'm sure there was a herd of lions nearby .
Shakespearean: Sure , it was the roar Of a whole herd of lions .

English: Did you hear this , Gonzalo ?
Shakespearean: Heard you this , Gonzalo ?

English: It's true I heard a humming sound , a strange one , which woke me up .
Shakespearean: Upon mine honor , sir , I heard a humming , And that a strange one too , which did awake me .

English: I shook you and shouted at you , sir .
Shakespearean: I shaked you , sir , and cried .

English: When I opened my eyes , I saw their swords out .
Shakespearean: As mine eyes opened , I saw their weapons drawn .

English: There was a noise , that's certainly true .
Shakespearean: There was a noise , That's verily .

English: Let's draw our own swords too .
Shakespearean: Let's draw our weapons .

English: I hope those lions stay far away from him .
Shakespearean: Heavens keep him from these beasts !

English: I'm sure he's somewhere on the island .
Shakespearean: For he is , sure , i ' th ' island .

English: Get us out of here .
Shakespearean: Lead away .

English: His spirits are listening to me , but I can't help cursing him anyway .
Shakespearean: His spirits hear me And yet I needs must curse .

English: They won't pinch me , frighten me , push me in the mud , or mislead me unless he tells them to .
Shakespearean: But they'll nor pinch , Fright me with urchin-shows , pitch me i ' th ' mire , Nor lead me like a firebrand in the dark Out of my way , unless he bid 'em .

English: Sometimes snakes wrap around me , hissing at me with their forked tongues till I go crazy .
Shakespearean: Sometime am I All wound with adders who with cloven tongues Do hiss me into madness .

English: Hey , look over there !
Shakespearean: Lo , now , lo !

English: Maybe he won't see me .
Shakespearean: Perchance he will not mind me .

English: There are no bushes or shrubs to protect me from the weather here .
Shakespearean: Here's neither bush nor shrub to bear off any weather at all .

English: And there's another storm brewing , I can hear it in the way the wind whistles .
Shakespearean: And another storm brewing , I hear it sing i ' th ' wind .

English: That huge black cloud over there looks like a filthy liquor jug that's about to pour out its contents .
Shakespearean: Yond same black cloud , yond huge one , looks like a foul bombard that would shed his liquor .

English: A strange fish .
Shakespearean: A strange fish !

English: If I were in England now , like I was once , and I had even a painted picture of this fish , every fool there would give me a piece of silver to look at it .
Shakespearean: Were I in England now , as once I was , and had but this fish painted , not a holiday fool there but would give a piece of silver .

English: In England this strange monster would be just like a man .
Shakespearean: There would this monster make a man .

English: Any strange beast there can be considered a man .
Shakespearean: Any strange beast there makes a man .

English: The men there won't give a penny to a lame beggar , but they'll pay ten cents to look at a freak show exhibit .
Shakespearean: When they will not give a doit to relieve a lame beggar , they will lay out ten to see a dead Indian .

English: This guy has legs like a man but fins for arms !
Shakespearean: Legged like a man and his fins like arms !

English: And he's still warm , by God .
Shakespearean: Warm , o ' my troth .

English: I guess this is not a fish , but a native who got struck by lightning just now .
Shakespearean: I do now let loose my opinion , hold it no longer : this is no fish , but an islander that hath lately suffered by a thunderbolt .

English: Oh , here comes the storm again .
Shakespearean: Alas , the storm is come again !

English: The best thing to do is crawl under his cloak .
Shakespearean: My best way is to creep under his gaberdine .

English: There's no other shelter around here .
Shakespearean: There is no other shelter hereabouts .

English: In emergencies you meet the strangest folks .
Shakespearean: Misery acquaints a man with strange bedfellows .

English: I'll just stay here till the storm passes .
Shakespearean: I will here shroud till the dregs of the storm be past .

English: This is a rotten song to sing at a man's funeral .
Shakespearean: This is a very scurvy tune to sing at a man's funeral .

English: At least I've got some booze to comfort me .
Shakespearean: Well , here's my comfort .

English: Don't hurt me .
Shakespearean: Do not torment me .

English: Oh !
Shakespearean: Oh !

English: What's going on ?
Shakespearean: What's the matter ?

English: Do we have devils on the island ?
Shakespearean: Have we devils here ?

English: Are you playing tricks on me by showing me savages and uncivilized men from the Indies , ha ?
Shakespearean: Do you put tricks upon 's with savages and men of Ind , ha ?

English: I didn't survive a shipwreck so I could be scared of your four legs now .
Shakespearean: I have not 'scaped drowning to be afeard now of your four legs .

English: The spirit is torturing me .
Shakespearean: The spirit torments me .

English: Oh !
Shakespearean: Oh !

English: This is some monster of the island , with four legs , who seems to me to have some kind of ache .
Shakespearean: This is some monster of the isle with four legs who hath got , as I take it , an ague .

English: How the hell does he know our language ?
Shakespearean: Where the devil should he learn our language ?

English: I'll help out , if only because he speaks the same language as me .
Shakespearean: I will give him some relief if it be but for that .

English: If I can cure him from his fever and tame him , and get him back to Naples , he'd make a great present for any emperor .
Shakespearean: If I can recover him and keep him tame and get to Naples with him , he's a present for any emperor that ever trod on neat's leather .

English: Don't hurt me , please .
Shakespearean: Do not torment me , prithee .

English: I promise I'll carry the wood faster .
Shakespearean: I'll bring my wood home faster .

English: He's having a fit and talking nonsense .
Shakespearean: He's in his fit now and does not talk after the wisest .

English: I'll give him some liquor .
Shakespearean: He shall taste of my bottle .

English: If he's never drunk it before , it'll help soothe his fever .
Shakespearean: If he have never drunk wine afore , it will go near to remove his fit .

English: If I can tame him , I'll charge as much as I can get for him .
Shakespearean: If I can recover him and keep him tame , I will not take too much for him .

English: He'll bring a lot of money to the person who owns him , that's for sure .
Shakespearean: He shall pay for him that hath him , and that soundly .
